title: A prospective, controlled study of a pharmacy-controlled warning system to increase thrombosis prophylaxis rates in inpatients.
abstract: Although venous thromboembolism is an important cause of in-hospital morbidity and mortality, a significant proportion of inpatients at risk do not receive interventions known to reduce the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. The aim of the present study was to determine whether a pharmacy-controlled alarm system would be associated with a higher rate of adequate measures for venous thromboembolism prevention in inpatients at risk in a general internal medicine service compared to usual care. The study was a prospective, controlled study conducted at a university teaching hospital. The participants were adults who were admitted to the general inpatient internal medicine service from June 19 to September 21, 2006 (Monday to Friday). Her treatment included a pharmacist assessment of venous thromboembolism risk and pharmacist-driven notification to the treating physician. The proportion of risk patients who received adequate thrombosis prophylaxis within 36 hours of admission was recorded. A total of 140 patients had a sufficient risk of venous thromboembolism to be included. In the normal care group, prophylactic measures were ordered in 49 (61%) of the 80 patients with intermediate to high risk. In the pharmacist warning group, 44 (73%) of the 60 patients with an intermediate to high risk of venous thromboembolism received adequate thromboprophylaxis (p = 0.15). Although we did not observe a statistically significant difference between groups, our results are consistent with previous reports suggesting that alert systems can increase the proportion of hospitalized patients receiving adequate venous thromboembolism prevention measures.

title: Effect of a clinical pharmacy service on lipid control in patients with peripheral arterial disease.
abstract: Aim Our group and others have previously found that patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) are significantly undertreated despite national guidelines to the contrary regarding overall management of cardiovascular risk factors. To maximize risk factor control in our patients with PAD, we established a pharmacist-managed, physician-supervised algorithmic approach to outpatient lipid management in patients with PAD. The purpose of this study was to determine the effect of this service on lipid screening and control in patients with PAD. Methods We analyzed the records of patients treated in a large non-profit regional group model managed care system serving approximately 405,000 members. An electronic patient file provided complete examination, laboratory and pharmacy data for all patients. Pharmacy data were analyzed to determine the prescription of lipid-lowering drugs. Lipid control was assessed using fasting lipid data. Patients with validated PAD and no clinical coronary artery disease (CAD) were offered the service between May 2003 and September 2004 and followed up for at least 6 months. Results We administratively identified 5159 active patients with a diagnosis of PAD. Of these, 1075 could be validated with a non-invasive arterial study. The exclusion of 384 patients with CAD diagnosis resulted in a cohort of 691 patients. Of these, 90 patients were enrolled in the lipid service (study group) and 601 received standard care. The mean follow-up time was 17.1 months. Screening fasting lipid profiles were found in 95.6% (86/90) of patients in the study group and only 66.9% (402/601) of standard of care patients (p<0.0001). Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) control was improved in the pharmacist-guided group, with 79.1% (68/86) achieving LDL-C less than 100 mg/dL compared to the standard of care group (54 .8% [219/400]";" P<0.0001). LDL-C greater than 130 mg/dL was found in 1.2% and 14.0% (56/400) in the treatment and control groups, respectively (P<0.001). Statins were used in 51.9% (312/601) of patients in the control group and 84.4% (76/90) of the pharmacist-led group (P<0.001). Conclusions Despite national consensus on PAD as a CAD equivalent, patients are currently undertreated with regard to modification of atherosclerotic risk factors. The introduction of a pharmacist-led, physician-supervised lipid service improves compliance with national guidelines

title: Using peer feedback to improve handwashing and glove use among Thai healthcare workers.
abstract: Background: Without protective practices such as universal precautions, healthcare workers are at significant risk of blood-borne infection, particularly in areas such as Thailand with a high prevalence of HIV infection. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a peer feedback program (PFP) on hand washing and glove wearing (HW/GW) among Thai healthcare workers. METHODS: Subjects (N = 91) were randomly assigned to PFP versus no treatment. Using a checklist, peer observers assessed their staff's HW/GW compliance during patient care. For 1 month, the investigator published a report on the compliance behavior of each 3 observation days. HW/GW was also assessed by the investigator through direct observation 1 month before the intervention, during the intervention period, and 1 month after the intervention. Results: The baseline HW/GW rates for the PFP and control groups were 49.2% and 61.5%, respectively. The PFP group had a significantly higher adjusted compliance rate than the control group during the intervention period (p=0.0001). However, there was no significant difference in the compliance scores obtained 1 month after the intervention. Conclusions: The PFP was effective throughout the intervention period, but there was no retention of effect. Therefore, complementary methods should be sought to promote maintenance of the effect. (AJIC Am J Infect Control 2000";"28:365-9)

title: "Doctoring" doctors and their families
abstract: Being selected to provide medical care to other physicians or their family members is not only a gratifying professional recognition of competence from one's peers, but also a challenge. Many personal and psychological factors can influence the medical care provided by physicians. Sick physicians may have difficulties with role reversal and "VIP syndrome," while treating physicians may have to contend with their own anxieties and issues such as confidentiality, privacy, empathy, and intrusion by a physician's relative into the care of medical family members. Based on experiences with more than 200 doctor patients and many adult relatives of doctors, suggestions for the care of these patient groups are made.

title: "Ethics and clinical research" revisited. A tribute to Henry K. Beecher
abstract: The doctrine of informed consent, borrowed from tort law, cannot easily be transferred to therapeutic situations. The broader, as-yet-unrealized idea of informed consent, which suggests that parties must make decisions together, should guide interactions between physicians and patients or researchers and subjects.

title: "Do no harm": Legal guidelines for health programs for youth aged 10 to 17 who sell sex or inject drugs
abstract: INTRODUCTION: There is a strong evidence base that the stigma, discrimination and criminalization affecting key youth populations (KPs) aged 10-17 years is amplified due to national and international legal constructs that rely on law enforcement-based interventions ranging from arrest, Previous convictions Pre-trial detention, imprisonment and forced "rehabilitation" in institutional accommodation. Although there are evidence-based and rights-based technical guidelines for interventions in older cohorts, these guidelines have not yet been adopted by international public health stakeholders due to concerns that international law may have different standards for adolescents aged 10-17 who engage in behavior such as selling sex or injecting drugs. DISCUSSION: For reasons of international human rights, health, juvenile justice and child protection law, interventions among juvenile CPs aged 10-17 years must not involve arrest, prosecution or detention of any kind. It is imperative that interventions do not rely on law enforcement but rather on low-threshold, voluntary services, shelter and support, using as much peer outreach as possible. These services must be mobile, accessible, and allow for alternatives to parental consent for the delivery of life-saving support, including HIV testing, treatment and care, needle and syringe programs, opioid substitution therapy, safe abortions, antiretroviral therapy, and gender-affirming care and hormone treatment for transgender people -Teens. To ensure registration for services, international guidelines indicate that informed consent and confidentiality must be guaranteed, including the waiver of parental consent requirements. To discourage healthcare practitioners and researchers from dealing with juvenile KPs aged 10 to 17, government agencies and ethical review bodies are encouraged to grant exceptions or exemptions from reporting requirements. If authorities attempt to involuntarily institutionalize juvenile CPs in violation of international law and guidelines, they are entitled to a judicial process. Legal guidelines also provide that these juveniles have control over their placement, access to legal counsel to challenge the conditions of their detention and regular visits from peers, friends and family members, and that all facilities are subject to frequent and regular independent audits. including community-based groups led by KPs. CONCLUSIONS: The scrutiny of international law states that protective interventions for KPs aged 10-17 must not only include low-threshold, voluntary services, but also “protect” juvenile KPs from the harms associated with law enforcement-based interventions. Going forward, health workers must respect the right to health by adapting programs according to the principles of minimum intervention, due process and proportionality, and duly limiting the involvement of juvenile justice and child protection as a last resort, where they exist.

title: "How much do you get paid if I volunteer?" Proposed Institutional Policies on Reward, Consent, and Research
abstract: Pharmaceutical companies often ask practicing physicians to conduct phase IV or post-marketing research on new drugs. Companies pay doctors to enroll their patients and report information on dosages and side effects. Postmarketing research involves a multibillion-dollar effort to fund and educate, but informed consent from subjects does not typically include medical rewards. Improving the investigators' financial situation while increasing the medical risks for phase IV subjects is ethically unacceptable, especially when the investigators are unaware of the investigators' rewards. We propose a model policy and guidelines that reaffirm subjects' need for education, investigators' need for recognition and support, and institutions' need to protect patients from undisclosed risks and relationships.

title: "If it ain't broke, don't fix it
"Let me get you a nicotine patch": Nurses' perceptions of implementation of smoking cessation guidelines for hospital veterans
abstract: Many residential smokers do not receive tobacco treatment recommended by the guidelines, but little is known about residential caregivers' perceptions of tobacco treatment. We used a mixed-methods sequential explanatory design to explain the results of an academic intervention study in the inpatient medical units of four Veterans Affairs (VA) hospitals. We interviewed 164 nurses and conducted semi-structured interviews with a targeted sample of 33 nurses with different attitudes towards exit counseling. Content analysis was used to inductively characterize the questions raised by the participants. Emerging issues were categorized using the knowledge-attitude-behaviour framework of compliance. Knowledge and attitudinal barriers included the perceived lack of skills in cessation counseling and skepticism about the effectiveness of cessation policies among hospital veterans. Nurses also reported several behavioral and organizational barriers to guideline compliance: patient resistance, insufficient time and resources, the presence of smoking areas on VA premises, and a lack of coordination with primary care. VA hospitals should train inpatient staff to negotiate behavior changes, integrate cessation counseling into the caregiver workflow, develop alternative referral mechanisms for cessation counseling after discharge, and adopt hospital policies to promote inpatient abstinence.

title: "Rules" of evidence in assessing the efficacy and effectiveness of treatments
abstract: A brief review of the "rules" of evidence in evaluating the efficacy and effectiveness of treatments leads to a discussion of what the future might hold in developing the rules for randomized clinical trials (RCTs) to amplify the impact of such trials . Discussions and interactions between researchers, clinicians, policy makers and patient advocates on the one hand and between basic scientists and clinical researchers on the other seem to be the most important prerequisite for increasing the impact of trials.

title: (S)Partners for Heart Health: a school-based program to improve physical activity and nutrition to promote cardiovascular health in 5th grade students
abstract: BACKGROUND: The American Heart Association Position Statement on Promoting Cardiovascular Health in Public Schools promotes school-based interventions for the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease (CVD) through risk factor prevention or reduction in children, with an emphasis on creating an environment that promotes healthy eating and physical activity (PA). To address issues associated with cardiovascular risk factors, including childhood obesity in Michigan, a multidisciplinary team of Michigan State University (MSU) health care faculty, clinicians and students was formed to “(S)partner” with undergraduate medicine are joining Education (PE) Teachers and MSU Extension Staff to develop and implement a cost-effective, sustainable program aimed at prevention and management of CVD risk factors for 5th grade students. This (S)partnership aims to expand and improve the existing 5th grade physical education, health and nutrition curriculum by achieving the following objectives: 1) Improving students' knowledge, attitudes and confidence in relation to nutrition, physical education and heart health; 2) increasing the number of students who meet national recommendations for physical activity and diet;” and 3) increasing the number of students with a desirable CVD risk factor status based on national pediatric guidelines. Secondary goals include school staff advancement and parental heart health support to help children achieve their goals and to provide experiential learning and services to MSU health care students for academic credit. METHODS/DESIGN: This pilot efficacy study was approved by the MSU IRB. At the beginning and end of the school year, students undergo a CVD risk factor assessment conducted by MSU medical and graduate students. Key intervention components include eight lesson plans (delivered every two months) designed to promote heart-healthy eating and exercise behaviors, delivered by physical education teachers with support from MSU students in dietetics and kinesiology (Spartners). During the last 10 minutes of each lesson, MSU Spartners conduct small breakout/discussion groups with the 5th grade students. Additionally, each Spartner case manages/supervises two to three 5th grade students using a web-based goal setting and tracking protocol throughout the school year. DISCUSSION: This paper describes the rationale, development and methods of the Spartners for Heart Health program. This is a multi-step intervention aimed at promoting heart-healthy behaviors and preventing or managing cardiovascular risk factors in children. By including college students as an integral part of measurement and intervention teams, we believe this will be a viable sustainable intervention that can be disseminated and adopted by other institutions at minimal cost.

title: â€œValue for moneyâ€ : Use with caution
abstract: In this issue, Owens and colleagues (1) argue that the goal of policy should be “to maintain the delivery of interventions that offer good value”. "Unintended reductions in effective and efficient care." Cutler and colleagues (2) have argued that an intervention that produces more benefits than costs is socially beneficial regardless of whether it increases expenditure. The Clinical Guidelines Committee of the American College of Physicians makes an important contribution to this policy debate by offering definitions and concepts to guide the search for quality healthcare, but the Value for Money goal raises many questions that warrant further discussion.

title: 100 apples divided by 15 red herrings: A cautionary tale from the mid-19th century comparing hospital mortality rates
abstract: In 1863, Florence Nightingale argued that London hospitals were dangerous, especially when compared to provincial institutions. She backed up this claim with statistics published in William Fair's Registrar-General report, claiming that 24 London hospitals had mortality rates in excess of 90%, while rural hospitals had an average mortality rate of 13%. Farr had calculated mortality rates by dividing the total number of patients who died over the year by the number of patients hospitalized on a single day. Calculated as the annual number of deaths divided by the total number of inpatients during the year, the mortality rate in London hospitals was 10%. A heated debate broke out in the London medical press about how best to calculate mortality rates in hospitals. Critics claimed Farr failed to adjust for differences in the severity of the disease between urban and rural hospitals and that his numbers mislead the public. Farr and Nightingale, in turn, criticized the poor quality of the hospital data. This story reinforces the need to understand the methodological derivation of statistics used to compare vendor quality.

title: 1931 German guidelines on human experimentation
2013 ACC/AHA Cholesterol Management Guideline: A paradigm shift in managing the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease
abstract: The 2013 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guideline on managing blood cholesterol to reduce atherosclerotic cardiovascular risk in adults represents a significant change from previous guidelines on cholesterol management. The new guidelines include data from individual randomized trials as well as the most comprehensive Meta-analyses and introduce several important paradigm shifts, including: targeting ASCVD risk reduction as opposed to targeting LDL-C levels, advocating the use of evidence-based doses of statins as first-line therapy, and using a new risk calculator and risk cut-off to to guide the initiation of statin therapy. These major changes have caused controversy and confusion in the medical community, with some clinicians reluctant to embrace the change. We review the evidence that underpins these major changes, compares it to other important lipid guidelines, and recommends an integrated approach to treating dyslipidemia to reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

title: 2015 AAHA/AAFP Pain Management Guidelines for Dogs and Cats
abstract: Rationale: The significant advances in the management of pain in companion animals underpin the decision by the American Animal Hospital Association (AAHA) and the American Association of Feline Practitioners (AAFP) to expand the information provided in the 2007 AAHA/AAFP Pain Management Guidelines. The 2015 guidelines summarize much of this new knowledge and provide a differentiated overview. RELEVANCE: Pain management is central to the veterinary practice as it reduces pain, improves patient outcomes and improves both the quality of life and the vet-patient relationship. These guidelines support veterinarians to integrate pain management into practice and improve patient care. APPROACHES: Management of pain requires continuous care that includes anticipation, early intervention, and assessment of response on an individual patient basis. A team-oriented approach that involves the owner is essential to maximize the detection, prevention and treatment of pain in animals. Evidence base: The guidelines include both pharmacological and non-pharmacological modalities for pain management, they are evidence-based as far as possible and otherwise represent a consensus of expert opinion. Behavioral changes are currently the main indicator of pain and its course or progression and the basis for recently validated pain Scores. Postoperative pain is highly predictable, but there is strong evidence supporting strategies to mitigate both adaptive and maladaptive forms. Chronic pain is dominated by degenerative joint disease (DJD), one of the most significant and underdiagnosed diseases in felines and dogs. DJD is ubiquitous, occurs in pets of all ages and inevitably progresses over time." Evidence-based management strategies are established in dogs and emerging in cats.

title: 5As a team intervention in obesity in primary care: development and evaluation of shared decision-making tools for weight management
abstract: Despite multiple clinical practice guidelines, a significant gap in the prevention and management of obesity in primary care remains. To address the need to change provider behavior, a convergent mixed-method evaluation randomized controlled trial, the 5As Team (5AsT) trial, was conducted. The 5AsT toolkit was developed as part of the 5AsT intervention. This paper describes the development process and the evaluation of these tools. The tools were co-developed by the multidisciplinary research team and the 5AsT, which included registered nurses (n=15), psychiatrists (n=7), and registered dietitians (n=7) who were previously randomized to the 5AsT intervention group in a primary care network in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. The development of the 5AsT tool occurred through a hands-on/implementation-based, needs-based, iterative process during collaborative learning sessions of the 5AsT intervention. Feedback during tool development was obtained through field notes and final vendor evaluation was conducted through anonymous questionnaires. Twelve tools were developed together with 5AsT. All tools were rated by the 5AsT as either 'most useful' or 'moderately useful' in primary care practice. Four key learnings during the development of the 5AsT tool were the need for: tools that were adaptable, tools to facilitate interdisciplinary practice, tools to help patients understand realistic weight loss expectations, and tools for shared decision making for goal setting and relapse prevention. The 5AsT tools are primary care tools that extend the usefulness of the 5As of the obesity management framework in clinical practice.

title: 6-PACK Program to Reduce Fall Injuries in Acute Hospitals: Cluster-randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effect of the 6-PACK program on falls and fall injuries in acute care units. DESIGN cluster randomized controlled trial. SETTING Six Australian hospitals. PARTICIPANTS All patients admitted to 24 acute care units during the trial period. INTERVENTIONS Participating units were randomly assigned to either the nurse-led 6-PACK program or usual care over 12 months. The 6-PACK program included a fall risk tool and individual application of one or more of six interventions: “fall alert” sign, monitoring patients in the bathroom, ensuring patients' walkers are within reach, a toilet schedule, use of a Low-low bed and using a bed/chair alarm. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The co-primary endpoints were falls and fall injuries per 1000 occupied bed days. RESULTS During the study, 46,245 admissions were made to 16 medical and eight surgical wards. Since many people were admitted more than once, these were 31,411 individual patients. Patient characteristics and length of stay were similar on the intervention and control wards. Utilization of the 6-PACK program components was higher in intervention wards than in control wards (incidence rate ratio 3.05, 95% confidence interval 2.14 to 4.34"; P<0.001). A total of 1831 falls and 613 fall injuries occurred, and the rates of falls (incidence rate ratio 1.04, 0.78 to 1.37; P=0.796) and fall injuries (0.96, 0.72 to 1.27; P=0.766) were similar at intervention and control wards.CONCLUSIONSPositive changes in fall prevention practice occurred after implementation of the 6-PACK program. However, no difference in falls or fall injuries was observed between groups. High-quality evidence supporting the effectiveness of fall prevention interventions in acute care units remains lacking. New solutions to the problem of falls in hospital are urgently needed TRIAL REGISTRATION Australia-New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry ACTRN12611000332921.

title: before-and-after study of OncoDoc, a guideline-based breast cancer management decision support system: Implications for physician prescribing behavior
abstract: Guideline-based decision support systems have been developed to influence physician prescribing behavior, but have not yet been shown to increase physician compliance with routine best practices. OncoDoc is a non-automated system that allows flexibility in interpreting guidelines to provide the best patient-specific recommendations at the point of care. OncoDoc is used to treat breast cancer. We tested the system at Institut Gustave Roussy with a before-and-after study measuring treatment decisions for breast cancer patients before and after using the system to assess its impact on physician prescribing behavior. After 4 months, 127 decisions were recorded. Physician compliance with OncoDoc was significantly improved (p < 10(-4) ) and reached 85.03% after using the system. Comparing the initial and final decisions showed that the doctors changed their prescription in 31% of the cases. The response rate for clinical trials increased by 50%, although not statistically significant as estimated at small numbers.

title: behavioral economics view of poverty
abstract: Standard theories about poverty fall into two camps. Social scientists view the behavior of the economically disadvantaged either as a calculated adaptation to prevailing circumstances or as the result of a unique "culture of poverty" shaped by dissenting values. The first camp assumes that people are highly rational, that they have coherent and justified beliefs, and that they pursue their goals effectively, without error and without help. The second camp ascribes to the poor a variety of psychological and attitudinal deficiencies that often mislead their views and their decisions so that they need paternalistic leadership. We propose a third view. We argue that the behavioral patterns of the poor are neither perfectly calculating nor particularly deviant. Rather, the poor may exhibit the same fundamental weaknesses and prejudices as people in other walks of life, except that in poverty, with its low error rates, the same behaviors can often be more pronounced and lead to poorer outcomes. Below we illustrate the types of insights that might be gained from a behaviorally more realistic analysis of the economic conditions of the poor and propose these alternative measures

title: behavioral model for the training of general practitioners by a rheumatology team
abstract: This project evaluated a model for in-service arthritis education based in part on principles of applied behavior analysis. Thirty-seven public health nurses (PHN) from 10 rural Midwestern counties received instruction on screening and management of patients with arthritis";" a random half of the counties also received public and physician information measures aimed at increasing arthritis referrals to community physicians in certain circumstances. In clinical interviews with PHN patients, there were modest but significant increases in 14 of 16 target behaviors attributable to education. Because the measured arthritis effects were small in this older adult population, physician referral rates were not affected by any of the interventions. This model illustrates generalizable behavior modification guidelines that are useful adjuncts to traditional methods for developing professional arthritis education.

title: case of osteomalacia, osteoporosis and hypercalcemia
A case of sarcoid with cryptococcal meningitis demonstrated at the Royal Postgraduate Medical School
abstract: A fatal case is described in a 30-year-old army officer who had served abroad.

title: A case report on the evaluation of a large-scale health system improvement project in an uncontrolled setting: a quality improvement initiative in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa
abstract: Objective New approaches are needed to assess quality improvement (QI) in large-scale public health efforts. This case report describes the challenges of a large-scale QI evaluation and proposes solutions based on an adaptive study design. Study Design We used two sequential assessment methods to examine a QI effort to improve HIV prevention care in public health facilities in three districts in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa over a 3-year period. We initially used a cluster randomized controlled trial design (RCT). Main findings During the RCT study period, tensions arose between the intervention implementation and the evaluation design due to the loss of integrity of the randomization unit over time, the pressure to implement changes across the boundaries of the randomization unit, and the use of administrative rather than functional structures for randomization. In response to this loss of design integrity, we switched to a more flexible intervention design and a mixed-methods quasi-experimental assessment that relied on both qualitative analysis and quantitative analysis with punctuated time series. Conclusions Cluster RCT designs may not be optimal for evaluating complex interventions to improve implementation in uncontrolled “real world” environments. More flexible, context-sensitive evaluation designs provide a better balance between the need to adjust the intervention during evaluation to address implementation challenges, while providing the data needed to evaluate effectiveness. Our case study was about HIV care in a resource-constrained setting, but these issues are likely to apply to complex improvement efforts in other settings.

title: centralized cardiovascular risk service to improve compliance in private GP practices
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many large healthcare systems now employ clinical pharmacists in team-based care to assist patients and physicians in managing cardiovascular disease (CV). However, small private offices often lack the resources to hire a clinical pharmacist for their office. The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether a centralized, web-based CV Risk Service (CVRS) managed by clinical pharmacists will improve adherence to guidelines in primary care physician offices in rural and small communities. METHODS: This study is a cluster-randomized prospective study in 12 primary care practices. Physician offices were randomized to either CVRS intervention or usual care. The intervention lasts 12 months and all subjects have research visits at baseline and 12 months. Primary outcomes include adherence to treatment guidelines and control of key cardiovascular risk factors. Data will also be collected from the medical record at 30 months to determine if the intervention effect persists after discontinuation. CONCLUSIONS: This study will enroll subjects through 2015 and results will be available in 2018. This study will shed light on whether a remote, centralized CV risk service can improve adherence to guidelines in physician offices that lack the resources to employ clinical pharmacists.

title: clinical decision support system for the prevention of venous thromboembolism: Implications for physician behavior
abstract: CONTEXT: Computer-based clinical decision support systems (CDSSs) have been promoted for their potential to improve the quality of healthcare. However, given the limited range of clinical settings in which they have been tested, such systems must be rigorously evaluated prior to widespread introduction into clinical practice. AIM: To determine whether the provision of guidelines for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis using a CDSS increases the proportion of appropriate decisions in clinical practice. DESIGN: Time series study conducted between December 1997 and July 1999. INSTITUTION: Department of Orthopedic Surgery of a teaching hospital in Paris, France. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 1971 patients who underwent orthopedic surgery. INTERVENTION: A CDSS for the immediate provision of information on the prevention of venous thromboembolism in surgical patients was integrated into daily medical practice during three 10-week intervention periods alternating with four 10-week control periods, with a 4-week washout between each period. KEY OUTCOME MEASUREMENT: Proportion of appropriate anticoagulation prescriptions according to pre-established clinical guidelines during intervention vs. control periods. RESULTS: Physicians complied with the guidelines in 82.8% (95% confidence interval [CI], 77.6% - 87.1%) of the cases during the control periods and in 94.9% (95% CI, 92.5% - 96.6%) of cases during intervention periods. Prescribing appropriateness increased significantly (P<0.001) during each intervention period. Each time the CDSS was removed, physician practice reverted to that observed before the intervention began. The relative risk of inappropriate treatment decisions during control vs. intervention periods was 3.8 (95% CI, 2.7-5.4). CONCLUSIONS: In our study, implementation of clinical guidelines for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis through a CDSS routinely used in an orthopedic surgery department and integrated into the hospital information system changed physician behavior and improved adherence to the guidelines. JAMA. 2000";"283:2816-2821

title: clinical study of a knowledge-based medical record
abstract: To meet the needs of general practitioners caring for patients with HIV infection, we have developed a knowledge-based medical record to allow the online medical record to play an active role in the care process. These programs integrate online patient record, rules-based decision support, and full-text information retrieval into a clinical workstation for the practicing clinician. To determine whether the use of a knowledge-based medical record was associated with faster and more complete adherence to practice guidelines and improved quality of care, we conducted a controlled clinical study of physicians and nurses caring for 349 patients infected with the human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV)";" 191 patients were treated by 65 doctors and nurses in the intervention group and 158 patients by 61 doctors and nurses in the control group. During the 18-month study period, the computer generated 303 alerts in the intervention group and 388 in the control group. The median physician response time to these warnings was 11 days in the intervention group and 52 days in the control group (PJJ0.0001, log-rank test). During the study, the computer generated 432 primary care reminders for the intervention group and 360 reminders for the control group. The physicians' median response time to these warnings was 114 days in the intervention group and more than 500 days in the control group (PJJ0.0001, log-rank test). Of the 191 patients in the intervention group, 67 (35%) had one or more hospitalizations compared to 70 (44%) of the 158 patients in the control group (PJ=J0.04, Wilcoxon test, stratified for initial CD4 count). There was no difference in survival between the intervention and control groups (P=0.18, log-rank test). We conclude that our clinical workplace has significantly changed the behavior of physicians in their response to intervention alerts in primary care and that these interventions have resulted in fewer HIV-infected patients being hospitalized.

title: clinically integrated postgraduate training program in evidence-based medicine versus no intervention for improving disability assessment: a clustered randomized clinical trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although several studies have shown that teaching EBM helps improve knowledge, there is currently no convincing evidence that teaching EBM also changes professional behavior in practice. Therefore, the primary aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a clinically integrated postgraduate training program in EBM in the evidence-based assessment of disabilities. METHODS AND RESULTS: In a cluster-randomized controlled study, 54 case-based study groups consisting of 132 physicians and 1680 patients were randomly assigned to intervention or control groups. The intervention group was offered a clinically integrated, postgraduate, 5-day Evidence-Based Medicine training program consisting of (home)work, peer teaching, interactive training in database searches, lectures, and brainstorming sessions. The control group received no training. The primary outcome was the evidence-based assessment of disability, as indicated by the frequency of use of evidence of sufficient quality in disability assessment reports. No general EBM behavioral outcome measures are available. Therefore, we followed general guidelines for the creation of performance indicators and defined a priori a threshold for determining sufficient quality as recommended for the evaluation of EB training. Physicians trained in EBM performed more evidence-based disability assessments compared to physicians in the control group (difference in absolute proportion 9.7%, 95% CI 3.5 to 15.9). The primary outcome differences between groups remained significant after both the cluster-adjusted analysis and additional sensitivity analyzes that accounted for subjects lost to follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: An EBM program successfully improved the use of evidence in a medical specialty outside the hospital setting. Our results support the general recommendations to use multiple educational methods to change physician behavior. In addition, it appeared important that the professional context of the intervention was very supportive, in the sense that database searching, use and application of guidelines and other forms of evidence are considered common practice and encouraged by colleagues and management.

title: clinic-based mammography intervention for inner-city women.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim was to evaluate the effect of a clinically-based intervention program on the use of mammography by inner-city women. DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial was conducted using a fixed system methodology. SETTING: The study setting was a general internal medicine clinic at a university-affiliated county hospital serving the Seattle metropolitan area. PARTICIPANTS: Women aged 50 to 74 years with at least one routine hospital visit (when a mammogram was due) during the study period were enrolled (n=314). INTERVENTIONS: The intervention program emphasized nurse involvement and included physician training, provider prompts, use of audiovisual and printed patient education materials, transportation assistance in the form of bus tickets, telephone or postcard reminders before appointments, and assistance with rescheduling appointments. Women in the control group received usual care. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Mammography completion within 8 weeks of clinic visits was significantly higher in intervention (49%) than control (22%) fixed women (p<0.001). These effects persisted after adjustment for possible confounders of age, race, health insurance coverage, and prior hospital experience with mammography (odds ratio 3.5: 95% confidence interval 1.9, 6.5). The intervention effect was modified by the type of insurance coverage and the history of mammography. The process evaluation found that bus passes and rebooking efforts did not contribute to the observed increases in screening attendance. CONCLUSIONS: A clinic-based program that includes physician education, physician prompts, patient education materials, and appointment reminders that emphasizes nursing involvement may facilitate compliance with breast cancer screening guidelines among inner-city women.

title: cluster-randomized controlled trial of the clinical and cost-effectiveness of a "whole system" model of self-management support for the management of long-term illness in primary care: study protocol
abstract: Background Patients with long-term conditions are increasingly the focus of health care quality improvement efforts to reduce the impact of these conditions on quality of life and to reduce the burden of seeking care. There is significant interest in the potential of self-management support to improve health and reduce utilization in these patient populations, but there is little consensus on the optimal model that would best provide such support. We describe the implementation and evaluation of self-management support through an evidence-based "whole system" model that includes patient support, primary care team training, and service reorganization, all integrated into routine delivery within primary care. Methods The evaluation included a large-scale, multi-site study of the implementation, effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of this model of self-management support using a cluster-randomized controlled trial in patients with three long-term chronic obstructive diabetic pulmonary diseases (COPD) and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Outcome measures include health care utilization and quality of life. We describe the methods of the cluster-randomized study. Discussion If the “whole systems” model proves effective and cost-effective, it will provide decision-makers with a model for delivering self-management support to populations with long-term illnesses that can be widely implemented to maximize “reach” to the broader patient population.

title: cluster-randomized clinical trial to improve prescribing patterns in outpatient pediatrics.
abstract: Aims Having previously demonstrated that an electronic prescribing and decision support system improved pediatric prescribing behavior for otitis media in an academic clinical setting, we assessed whether providing evidence at the point of care demonstrates similar effects for a variety of other common pediatric conditions could . Design cluster randomized controlled trial. Surroundings A teaching hospital/clinical practice site and pediatric primary care hospital serving a rural and semi-urban mix of patients. Participants A total of 36 service providers in the teaching clinic/practice and eight service providers in the private children's primary clinic. Intervention An evidence-based messaging system that presents real-time evidence to physicians based on prescribing practices for acute otitis media, allergic rhinitis, sinusitis, constipation, pharyngitis, croup, urticaria, and bronchiolitis. Outcome measures The proportion of prescriptions that are filled according to the evidence. Results The proportion of prescriptions issued in accordance with the evidence improved by four percentage points from 38% at baseline to 42% after the intervention. The control group improved by one percentage point from 39% at baseline to 40% at the end of the study. The adjusted difference between the intervention and control groups was 8% (95% confidence interval 1%, 15%). The effectiveness of the intervention did not decrease over time. Conclusion For common pediatric outpatient conditions, an evidence-based point-of-care prescription and decision support system has been associated with significant improvements in prescribing practice.

title: cluster-randomized controlled trial aimed at implementing local quality improvement collaborations to improve primary care physician prescribing and trial ordering performance: study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: The use of guidelines in general practice is suboptimal. Although evidence-based methods for improving guideline adherence are available, the variability in physician compliance with general treatment guidelines remains relatively high. The aim of this study is to translate into practice a quality improvement strategy based on audits, feedback, training materials and peer group discussions moderated by local opinion leaders. The research questions are: Will the multi-layered strategy be implemented on a large scale as planned? and what are the costs of implementing the strategy? Methods: To evaluate the effects, costs, and feasibility of this new strategy, we plan a multicenter randomized controlled cluster study (RCT) with a balanced incomplete block design. Local GP groups in the south of the Netherlands, which already participate in pharmacotherapeutic audit session groups, are being recruited by regional health officers. Approximately 50 groups of GPs will be randomly assigned to two arms. These GPs are offered two different balanced clinical themes. Each GP within a group receives comparative feedback on test ordering and prescribing performance. The feedback is discussed in the group and working agreements are made after discussing the guidelines and barriers to change. The data for the feedback will be collected both at the beginning and after one year from existing and newly formed databases. DISCUSSION: We are not aware of any published studies on the successes and failures of attempts to scale up a multi-faceted strategy targeting GP ordering and prescribing behavior to stakeholders in this area. This pragmatic study will focus on compatibility with existing infrastructure while allowing a degree of customization to local needs and routines.

title: cluster-randomized study of improving standard quality versus patient-centered interventions to improve depression management for African Americans in primary care: study protocol NCT00243425
abstract: BACKGROUND: Several studies document differences in access to and quality of care for African Americans for depression. Research suggests that patient attitudes and physician communication may contribute to these differences. Evidence links patient-centered care to improvements in mental health outcomes";" Therefore, quality improvement interventions that improve this dimension of care are promising strategies for improving depression treatment and outcomes in African Americans. This paper describes the design of the BRIDGE study (Blacks Receiving Interventions for Depression and Gaining Empowerment). The aim of the study is to compare the effectiveness of two interventions for African American patients with depression - a standard quality improvement program and a patient-centered quality improvement program. The main hypothesis is that patients in the patient-centered group have greater reductions in their depression symptoms, higher depression remission rates, and greater mental health improvements than patients in the standard group at six, twelve, and eighteen months. The study also examines patient ratings of care and receipt of guideline-compliant treatment for depression. METHODS/DESIGN: A total of 36 general practitioners and 132 of their African-American patients with major depression were recruited into a cluster-randomized study. The study uses intent-to-treat analyzes to compare the effectiveness of standard quality improvement interventions (academic details of depression guidelines for clinicians and disease-focused care management for their patients) and patient-centered quality improvement interventions (training communication skills to improve participation) in decision-making for Clinicians and care managers with a focus on explanatory models, sociocultural barriers, and treatment preferences for their patients) to improve outcomes over a 12-month period. DISCUSSION: The BRIDGE study includes physicians and African American patients in community practices with under-resources who have not been well represented in clinical trials designed to improve the treatment of depression. The patient-centered and culture-aligned approach to treating depression is relatively new and has not been tested in most previous studies. The study will provide evidence on whether patient-centered adjustments improve quality of care and outcomes to a greater extent than standard quality improvement strategies for African Americans with depression. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00243425.

title: combined paging alert and web-based tool changes clinical behavior and shortens hospital stays in acute pancreatitis
abstract: OBJECTIVES: There are many published clinical guidelines for acute pancreatitis (AP). The implementation of these recommendations varies. We hypothesized that a clinical decision support tool (CDS) would change clinical behavior and reduce length of stay in hospital (LOS). METHODS: DESIGN/SETTING: Observational study entitled The AP Early Response (TAPER) Project. Emergency Department (ED) and Tertiary Center Hospital. PARTICIPANTS: Two consecutive samples of patients with the ICD-9 code (577.0) for AP were generated from emergency department (ED) or hospital admissions. The diagnosis of AP was based on conventional Atlanta criteria. The pre-TAPER CDS tool group (05/30/06-06/22/07) had 110 patients who presented with AP per 976 ICD-9 (577.0) codes and the post-TAPER CDS tool group in presented to the emergency department (05/30/06 - 06/22/07) had 113 per 907 ICD-9 codes (07/14/10 - 05/05/11). INTERVENTION: The TAPER-CDS tool, developed 12/2008 to 14/07/2010, is a combined early, automated paging alert system that notifies ED clinicians of a patient with AP via SMS, and an intuitive web-based point-of- Care instrument consisting of seven recommendations for early management. RESULTS: The pre- vs. post-TAPER CDS tool groups had similar baseline characteristics. The post-TAPER CDS tool group achieved two management goals more frequently than the pre-TAPER CDS tool group: risk stratification (P6L/1.0-24 h (P=0.0003). Mean (SD) hospital LOS was significantly shorter in the post-TAPER CDS tool group (4.6 (3.1) vs. 6.7 (7.0) days, P=0.0126) Multivariate analysis identified four independent variables for length of hospital stay: the TAPER-CDS tool associated with shorter LOS (P=0.0049) and three variables associated with longer LOS: Japanese severity (P=0.0361), persistent organ failure (P=0.0088) and local pancreatic complications (<0.0001) CONCLUSIONS: The TAPER-CDS tool is associated with altered clinical behavior and reduced hospital length of stay, which has significant financial implications.

title: An Approach to Improving Community Capacity for Early Detection of Breast and Cervical Cancer in Older Women of Color
abstract: As part of the Screening Older Minority Women project, the authors applied a community capacity-enhancing approach to promote breast and cervical cancer screening among older black women. Members of informal support networks were recruited for this health promotion effort to empower Hispanic and African American women to engage in positive health behaviors. The authors describe the phases of the intervention and the experiences from the community. Guidelines are identified to assist researchers and practitioners in planning and implementing community health promotion interventions with women of color.

title: A community-based approach to promoting breastfeeding in Mexico
abstract: comprehensive education strategy is presented that combines training, community education, research and mass media efforts to improve breastfeeding practices. Breastfeeding promotion models, an administration system and experiences from the project are described. It has been shown that the keys to effective breastfeeding promotion are accurate information, adequate education, training and follow-up, and a supportive management system.; PIP: An operational research project aimed to determine which intervention model was most successful in promoting breastfeeding among 585 urban women in Mexico. Interventions have included trained promoters teaching and counseling breastfeeding mothers in Irapuato, program leaders teaching groups of mothers in Chihuahua, and both trained promoters and program leaders training individuals or groups in Cuauhtemoc. Jalapa served as a checkpoint. The pre-intervention rate of breastfeeding in the 4 communities varied between 64.5% and 81.3% with a mean in the target group of 74.9%. The mean for this group increased to 88.8% after the intervention. In addition, the breastfeeding prevalence rate for Jalapa fell from 65.9% to 56%. Furthermore, 70% of the women in the experimental group exclusively breastfed their infants at 1 month, while only 63.3% in the control group did so. The prevalence rates of breastfeeding in the following months decreased by 13.7% and 14.7% (5 months) and 9.4% and 3.3% (6 months) in the experimental and control groups, respectively. As a result of the educational and counseling activities, informal self-help groups of breastfeeding mothers unexpectedly formed. The data showed that the promoter intervention model was the most successful strategy. They also provided guidelines for researchers and other health professionals interested in promoting community-based breastfeeding programs. For example, supervisors should not discourage promoters from attending to other community needs, as discouragement may jeopardize their commitment to promoting breastfeeding. In addition, program planners should gather geographic and socio-demographic data of the area and population prior to planning and intervention.

title: comparison of the effects of computer and manual reminders on adherence to a mental health clinical practice guideline.
abstract: Aim: To evaluate the relative effectiveness of computer and manual reminder systems in implementing a clinical practice guideline. DESIGN: Seventy-eight outpatients in a psychiatric hospital were randomly assigned to one of the two memory systems within the clinician. The computer system, called CaseWalker, reminded clinicians when guideline-recommended screening for mood disorders was due and ensured that the diagnosis of major depressive disorder met the criteria of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition (DSM -IV), corresponds. and creates a progress bar. The manual system was a checklist that was inserted into the paper medical record. Measures: Screening rates for mood disorders and the completeness of documentation of which DSM-IV criteria were met by patients diagnosed with a major depressive disorder were compared. Results: The CaseWalker resulted in a higher rate of screening for mood disorders (86.5 vs. 61 percent, P=0.008) and a higher rate of complete documentation of DSM-IV criteria (100 vs. 5, 6 percent, P<0.001). Conclusions: In a psychiatric outpatient clinic, computer reminders were shown to be superior to manual reminders in improving adherence to a clinical practice guideline for depression.

title: computer-assisted intervention to improve the adequacy of monitoring antiepileptic drug levels
abstract: We designed and implemented 2 automated, computerized screens for use at the time of entering the antiepileptic drug testing (AED) order to improve appropriateness by reminding physicians when a potentially redundant test has been ordered and general indications for monitoring and provide pharmacokinetics of the specific AED. All computerized prescriptions for stationary AED serum levels during two 3-month periods were included in the study. During the 3-month period after implementation of the automated intervention, 13% of all AED tests ordered were canceled following computerized reminders. For orders that appear superfluous, the cancellation rate was 27%. For non-redundant orders, 4% were canceled when information on specific AED monitoring and pharmacokinetics was provided. The cancellation rate was maintained after 4 years. Since the implementation of this measure, the overall volume of AED testing has decreased by 19.5%, although the overall volume of chemistry testing has increased by 19.3%. Inappropriateness due to repeated testing before reaching pharmacological steady state decreased from 54% of all AED prescriptions to 14.6%. A simple, automated, activity-based intervention targeting specific test ordering behavior effectively reduced inappropriate lab testing. The sustained benefit supports the notion that computer-assisted interventions can permanently influence physician behavior. The computerized delivery of such evidence-based borderline guidelines can help narrow the gap between evidence and practice.

title: handheld computerized decision support system to improve the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism: a randomized study.
abstract: Background: The examination for pulmonary embolism often deviates from the recommendations of evidence-based guidelines. Aim: To evaluate the effectiveness of a portable clinical decision support system to improve the diagnostic workup of suspected pulmonary embolism in patients in the emergency department. Design: Cluster randomized study. The allocation was made using a random number table, the providers were not blinded and the evaluation of the results was automated. (ClinicalTrials.gov registration number: NCT00188032) Environment: 20 emergency departments in France. Patients: 1103 and 1768 consecutive outpatients with suspected pulmonary embolism. Intervention: After a pre-intervention phase involving 20 centers and 1103 patients, during which providers became accustomed to entering clinical data into wearable devices and investigators assessed baseline tests, emergency departments were randomized with activation of a decision support system commissioned on the devices (10 centers, 753 patients) or posters and pocket cards showing validated diagnostic strategies (10 centers, 1015 patients). Measurements: Adequacy of diagnostic work-up, defined as any set of tests that result in a post-test probability of less than 5% or greater than 85% (primary outcome) or strict adherence to guideline recommendations (secondary outcome)"; number of tests per patient (secondary endpoint). Results: The proportion of patients who received an adequate diagnosis was greater in both groups during the study than in the preintervention period, but the increase was larger in the group with computer-guided guidelines (adjusted mean difference in increase, 19.3 percentage points in favor of computer-guided guidelines [95% CI, 2.9 to 35.6 percentage points]; p=0.023) Among patients with adequate work-up, those in the computer-guided guide group received slightly fewer tests than did patients in the paper guideline group (mean tests per patient, 1.76 [SD, 0.98] vs. 2.25 [SD, 1.04]; "PÂ < 0.001). Limitation: The study was not designed to show a difference in patients' clinical outcomes during follow-up. Conclusion: A wearable decision support system improved diagnostic decision making for patients with suspected pulmonary embolism in the emergency department.

title: computer-assisted intervention to reduce calcium channel blocker use in hypertension.
abstract: Aim To determine whether computerized reminder would change prescribing habits for the treatment of hypertension in accordance with current clinical guidelines in a general internal medicine clinic. Design A randomized study. Establishment of the Veterans Affairs Puget Sound Health System General Internal Medicine Clinic, Seattle Division. Patients/participants Clinic providers were randomly assigned to a control group (n=35) or intervention group (n=36). We targeted providers of patients treated for hypertension with calcium channel blockers, a class of drugs not recommended for first line therapy. Intervention An automated computer query identified eligible patients and their providers. A policy reminder has been included in the medical records of intervention providers";" the medical records of the control providers received no reminder. Measurements and Main Results During the 5-month study period, 346 patients were treated by the 36 primary care physicians (staffed physicians, nurses, residents and fellows) in the intervention group and 373 patients by the 35 providers in the control group. Intervention providers switched to other medications in 39 patients (11.3%) during the study period compared to 1 patient (<1.0%) in control providers (p<0.0001). In patients with unchanged therapy, physicians found angina pectoris in 23.1%, indications other than hypertension in 9.5%, intolerable side effects in first-line therapy in 13.9%, and inadequate control in first-line therapy in 13.9% . Of the patients with no physician-reported contraindications, 23.6% were switched from calcium channel blockers to first-line drugs during the intervention period. Conclusions The use of a computer-assisted, clinically-based intervention increased adherence to guidelines in the management of primary hypertension in general and decreased the use of calcium channel blockers to treat hypertension in particular.

title: computerized reminder for prophylaxis of deep vein thrombosis in surgical patients
abstract: AIM: To measure the effect of a computerized reminder system on the rate of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prophylaxis in surgical patients. DESIGN: A prospective study to measure change in compliance compared to historical controls. MEASUREMENTS: LDS hospital surgeons developed a local consensus on which procedures should have DVT prophylaxis. The historical rate of prophylaxis for the procedures was measured by a database search of patient records. A computerized reminder system was then implemented, utilizing an expert knowledge base and a time drive mechanism to flag surgical cases for DVT prophylaxis. A DVT reminder appeared in the surgical plan for eligible patients";" The surgical staff used this as a guide for the use of prophylaxis. During the 3-month study, the rate of DVT prophylaxis was re-measured and compared to the pre-intervention rate. RESULTS: The preintervention rate of DVT prophylaxis over 3 months was 85.2% (785 of 921 eligible cases). In the 3 months following the introduction of computer-assisted reminders, adherence to DVT prophylaxis increased to 99.3% (1084 of 1092 eligible cases). The difference between historical controls and study participants was highly significant (p<0.001). CONCLUSION: A computer-assisted reminder is an effective method to increase DVT prophylaxis rates in surgical patients.

title: computerized reminder system to increase the use of preventive care for hospitalized patients
abstract: BACKGROUND Although effective in outpatient settings, computerized reminders have not been shown to improve preventive care in inpatient settings. METHODS We conducted a randomized, controlled trial to determine the impact of computerized reminders on the rates at which four preventive therapies were ordered for inpatients. During an 18-month study period, a computerized system processed online information for all 6,371 patients admitted to a general medical service (for a total of 10,065 hospitalizations) and generated preventive reminders where appropriate. Physicians who were in the intervention group viewed these memories when using a computerized system to enter instructions for inpatients. RESULTS The reminder system identified 3416 patients (53.6 percent) as eligible for preventive care not ordered by the admitting physician. In patients with at least one indication, computer-assisted reminders resulted in higher adjusted order rates for pneumococcal vaccine (35.8 percent of patients in the intervention group vs. 0.8 percent of patients in the control group, P<0.001), influenza vaccine (51, 4 percent vs. 1.0 percent, P<0.001), prophylactic heparin (32.2 percent vs. 18.9 percent, P<0.001), and prophylactic aspirin at discharge (36.4 percent vs. 27.6 percent, P<0.001). CONCLUSIONS A majority of the hospitalized patients in this study were eligible for preventive interventions, and computerized reminders significantly increased the delivery rate of such therapies.

title: concept for the implementation and evaluation of the guideline “Early Breast Cancer Detection in Germany”
abstract: Systematically developed, evidence- and consensus-based guidelines are important tools for improving healthcare. The effectiveness of a guideline relates not only to its methodological quality, but also to the implementation strategy used. The following article describes the systematic development of a strategy for the implementation and evaluation of the guideline “Early Breast Cancer Detection in Germany” as part of a national project. A multi-faceted systematic implementation strategy was developed that addresses existing barriers and builds on projects recently launched in Germany to improve breast cancer screening and treatment. The aim is to bring about behavioral changes in women as service recipients and doctors as service providers, both of whom are involved in the medical decision-making process within the framework of the guideline. In addition, it supports organizational changes to ensure compliance with the guideline through quality assurance and quality management. In order to ensure the evaluation of the implementation process, a number of quality indicators were identified for the baseline evaluation of structures, provider performance and results. Both the effectiveness of the implementation process and the effectiveness of the guideline itself are measured using the same indicators for reassessment within a predefined time interval of 18 months. The quasi-experimental design of this uncontrolled before-after implementation study outlined in the present work enables the assessment of clinically relevant changes using quality indicators that measure the effectiveness of the guideline at the national level.

title: controlled study to incorporate symptom data into computer-aided treatment proposals for the management of patients with chronic heart failure
abstract: Background Heart failure is common and associated with significant morbidity and expense, yet physician adherence to treatment guidelines is suboptimal. We conducted a randomized controlled trial to determine whether adding symptom information to evidence-based, computer-generated treatment proposals would affect treatment decisions of primary care physicians treating outpatients with heart failure at two Veterans Affairs medical centers. Methods Physicians were randomly assigned treatment proposals generated with electronic medical record data and symptom data from questionnaires mailed to patients within 2 weeks of scheduled outpatient visits (intervention group) or proposals generated with electronic medical record data only were (control group). Patients were required to have a diagnosis of heart failure and objective evidence of left ventricular systolic dysfunction. We assessed physician adherence to heart failure guidelines, as well as New York Heart Association (NYHA) patient class, quality of life, satisfaction with care, hospitalizations, and outpatient visits at 6 and 12 months post-enrollment. Results The patients in the intervention (n = 355) and control groups (n = 365) were similar at baseline. At 12 months, there were no significant differences in adherence to treatment recommendations between physicians in the intervention and control groups (33% vs. 30%, P=0.4). There were also no significant changes in NYHA class (P = 0.1) and quality of life measures (P > 0.1), and no differences in the number of outpatient visits between intervention and control patients (6.7 vs 7.1 visits, P=0.48). Intervention patients were more satisfied with their physicians (P = 0.02) and primary care visit (P = 0.02), but had more hospitalizations for all reasons at 6 months (1.5 vs. 0.7 hospitalizations, P = 0.0002) and 12 months (2.3 vs 1.7 hospital admissions, P=0.05). Conclusion Adding symptom information to computer-generated treatment proposals for heart failure patients did not impact physician treatment decisions or improve patient outcomes.

title: controlled study of web-based diabetes disease management.
abstract: OBJECTIVE – To test the impact of a web-based decision support tool, the Diabetes Disease Management Application (DMA), designed to improve evidence-based management of type 2 diabetes. RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS—We conducted a randomized controlled group study involving 12 intervention and 14 control staff providers and 307 intervention and 291 control patients with type 2 diabetes in an internal medicine clinic. Providers were randomly assigned to have access to the DMA (intervention) or not (control) from May 1998 to April 1999. The DMA displays interactive patient-specific clinical data, treatment advice, and links to other web-based care resources. We compared patients in the intervention and control groups for changes in processes and treatment outcomes from the pre-study year to the study year by intention-to-treat analysis. RESULTS - The DMA was used for 42% of scheduled patient visits. The number of HbA1c tests performed per year increased significantly in the intervention group (+0.3 tests/year) compared to the control group (-0.04 tests/year, P=0.008), as did the number of LDL cholesterol tests ( intervention, +0.2 tests/year"; control, +0.01 tests/year; P = 0.02) and the proportions of patients undergoing at least one foot examination per year (intervention, +9.8%; control, -0.7%; P=0.003) of HbA1c decreased by 0.2 in the intervention group and increased by 0.1 in the control group (p=0.09);" The proportion of patients with LDL-C < 130 mg/dl increased by 20.3% in the intervention group and by 10.5% in the control group (p=0.5) CONCLUSIONS—Web-based, patient-specific decision support has the potential to improve evidence-based parameters of diabetes care.

title: cross-sectional study of the number and frequency of terms used in a body of health literature to refer to knowledge translation in 2006: a Tower of Babel?
abstract: The study of putting research results into practice is growing rapidly and has acquired many competing names (e.g. dissemination, uptake, exploitation, translation) and contributing disciplines. The interdisciplinary use of several terms impedes communication and progress in the application of research results. In a collection of health literature published in 2006, we attempted to create an inventory of terms that describe this area and how often authors use them. Methods We refer to this area as knowledge translation (KT). Terms describing aspects of KT and their definitions have been collected from literature, the internet, reports, textbooks and contact with experts. We compiled a database of KT and other articles by reading 12 health journals representing multiple disciplines. All articles published in these journals in 2006 were categorized as KT or not. The KT articles (all KT) were further categorized, where possible, according to whether they described KT projects or implementations (KT application articles) or presented the theoretical foundations, models, tools, methods or techniques of KT (KT theory articles ). Accuracy was checked by double reading. Custom software determined how often KT terms were used in the titles and abstracts of articles categorized as KT. Results A total of 2,603 articles were evaluated and 581 identified as KT articles. Of these, 201 described KT applications and 153 contained KT theory. Of the 100 KT terms collected, 46 were used by the authors in the titles or abstracts of articles categorized as KT. Across all 581 KT articles, eight terms or term variations used by the authors were highly discriminatory for the separation of KT and non-KT articles (p<0.001): implementation, adoption, quality improvement, dissemination, complex intervention (with multiple endings) , implementation ( within three words) research and complex intervention. More KT terms were associated with KT application articles (n=13) and KT theory articles (n=18). Conclusions We have collected 100 terms that describe KT research. Authors used 46 of these in titles and abstracts of KT articles. Of these, about half differentiated between KT and non-KT articles. Therefore, the need for consolidation and consistent use of fewer terms related to KT research is evident.

title: formative study of colorectal cancer surveillance: implications for survival-centered interventions
abstract: Colon cancer is one of the most commonly diagnosed cancers in the United States, and increasing numbers of survivors have emphasized the need for improved quality of colon cancer surveillance. Post-treatment monitoring includes follow-up visits and testing, as well as psychosocial support and lifestyle counseling. This formative study examined the factors at the individual, interpersonal, and organizational levels associated with adherence to surveillance guidelines to identify modifiable factors for potential educational intervention strategies. A sample of 22 survivors (12 females and 10 males) from two cancer centers were recruited to participate in focus groups or telephone interviews with key informants to explore their experiences of post-treatment care and to complete a short survey. Content analysis was used to identify topics. The results confirmed that the survivors went through a complex surveillance plan and described a strong trust in their healthcare providers that guided their follow-up experiences. The terms “survivorship” and “follow-up” were defined in different ways by the participants. On an individual level, issues critical to the survivor's experience included having a positive attitude, relying on one's beliefs, and managing fear. Interpersonal-level issues focused on interactions and communication with family and healthcare providers in aftercare. While organizational-level factors were rarely highlighted, participants rated office reminder systems and communication between their various providers as valuable. Educational interventions that leverage survivors' connections to their physicians and focus on preparing survivors for what to expect in the next phase of their cancer experience could be beneficial at the end of treatment to prepare survivors for the post-mortem transition to activate the treatment.

title: framework for good practice in inter-agency interventions in cases of self-neglect
abstract: Self-neglect is probably more common than commonly thought and creates a number of difficult conceptual, identification and intervention problems for health and social care workers. These patient management problems are compounded by the lack of any real-world evidence base for nurses to rely on when faced with the management of people who are self-neglecting. Nurses who work with self-neglect work in an interdisciplinary context that includes professional groups such as environmental health officers not typically found in health and social care teams. In the absence of such an evidence base, a pragmatic solution in the form of a framework for multi-agency practice has been proposed. The background to this framework, including a research study of housing in self-neglect and multi-agency responses, is briefly outlined in this paper.

title: framework to support healthcare professionals in recommending quality apps to support self-management of chronic diseases: Illustrative evaluation of type 2 diabetes apps
abstract: BACKGROUND: This paper presents an approach to assist healthcare professionals in recommending quality apps to support chronic disease self-management. Most app reviews focus on popularity, aesthetics, functionality, usability, and information quality. There is no doubt that these factors are important to select trustworthy apps that are attractive to users, but behavioral theory can also be useful in tailoring the apps to users' needs. OBJECTIVE: The developed framework aims to be methodologically sound, to be able to select popular apps containing content covered by evidence-based programs, consistent with behavioral theory, as well as a patient-centric approach to app customization to the individual needs of the patients. METHODS: A single disease - type 2 diabetes - was chosen to illustrate how the framework could be applied as it was believed to represent the types of strategies used in many chronic diseases. A systematic approach, based on behavioral theory and recommendations from best practice guidelines, was developed to adapt apps to patients' needs. In March 2014, a range of search strategies were used to identify the top-rated iPhone and Android health apps, representing 29 topics across five categories of type 2 diabetes self-management strategies. Topics were selected from published international guidelines for the management of diabetes. The senior author (KH) evaluated the most popular apps found that addressed these topics using the Behavioral Theory Content Survey (BTS), which is based on traditional behavioral theory. A tool to support decision-making when using apps has been developed and tested with healthcare professionals to make it easier to use and understand. RESULTS: A total of 14 apps representing all five self-management topics were evaluated. Total theoretical (BTS) scores were below 50 on a 100-point scale for all apps. Each app scored less than 50% of the total possible BTS score for all four behavioral theories and most of the 20 behavioral strategies";" However, apps scored more than 50% of the total possible BTS score for specific strategies related to their main focus. Our results suggest that the apps studied would be more effective in conjunction with therapy than as standalone apps. Apps were categorized by topic and key intervention strategies. Based on app categorization and the principles of patient-centric care, a framework was developed to match apps with identified patient needs. The approach was well accepted and understood by a sample of health practitioners. CONCLUSIONS: The presented framework can be used by healthcare practitioners to better tailor apps to clients' needs. Some apps incorporate highly interactive behavioral theory strategies and, when used as an adjunct, can increase patient involvement and the effectiveness of therapy.

title: French adaptation of the Overt Behavior Scale (OBS) measuring challenging behavior after acquired brain injury: The Echelle des coportements observables (ECO)
abstract: PURPOSE: To develop a French version of the Overt Behavior Scale (OBS) and study some of its psychometric properties. METHODS: The scale was adjusted and validated according to standard guidelines for cross-cultural adjustment of questionnaires (Echelle des comportements observables";" ECO). The reliability and construct validity of the ECO was examined in 29 inpatients and outpatients with acquired brain damage. The tools were administered by 12 doctors at eight rehabilitation centers and the local Brain Injury Association. RESULTS: The ECO provided descriptive behavioral profiles similar to the original scale. It showed excellent reliability and good convergent and divergent validity, reflected in significant associations with other measures that contained similar behavioral elements and by the lack of correlations of meaning with broader constructs such as physical and cognitive abilities.
