CONCLUSION: This study provides evidence that the ECO behaves similarly to the original OBS, shows promising initial results in terms of reliability and validity, and represents a valuable research and clinical tool to assess the severity and typology of challenging behaviors after a To assess acquired brain injury and monitor behavioral development after interventions in French and bilingual communities.

title: portable computer smoking intervention tool and its implications for physician smoking cessation counseling
abstract: AIM: The aim of this study was to evaluate a portable computer-based smoking cessation intervention tool designed to assist physicians in smoking cessation counseling with patients. METHODS: This study used a pre/post survey design with a 4-month trial period for the software. Study participants included 22 faculty and resident physicians from the University of Virginia. Paired-sample t-tests were used to assess mean differences on the 4 major subscales (Physician Behaviour, Attitudes, Comfort with Counseling Patients to Quit Smoking, and Knowledge). RESULTS: No statistically significant mean differences were found for physician behavior (mean increase = 0.44, p = 0.55) or physician attitude (mean increase = 0.44, p = 0.16). A statistically significant mean increase of 2.29 was observed for the physician comfort subscale (t=3.87, df=16, p=0.001). Physicians reported improved comfort in advising patients on smoking cessation (p=0.007) and improved comfort in using public health clinical practice guidelines (p=0.012). CONCLUSION: Physicians' convenience in advising patients on smoking cessation can be enhanced by handheld computer software. When used in conjunction with other practice modifications, this tool has the potential to improve physicians' smoking cessation intervention practices.

title: randomized hybrid efficacy-implementation cluster study of group CBT for anxiety in urban schools: rationale, design, and methods
abstract: Background Schools offer a context with great potential for the implementation of psychosocial evidence-based practices. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is an evidence-based practice that has been shown to be very effective in treating anxiety in a variety of settings, including schools. Friends for Life (FRIENDS) is a powerful CBT group protocol for anxiety. Unfortunately, evidence-based practices for anxiety are rarely employed in underfunded urban schools because many treatment protocols do not fit well with the urban school context or population, existing behavioral health staff do not receive adequate training or support to enable them to faithfully implement treatment, or school districts do not have the Resources to contract with external consultants. In our previous work, we adapted FRIENDS to create a more culturally sensitive, focused, and actionable CBT for Anxiety Treatment in Schools (CATS) protocol. Methods/Design The aim of this 5-year study is to evaluate both the effectiveness of CATS for urban public schools compared to the original FRIENDS and the implementation strategies (Train-the-Trainer vs. Train-the-Trainer?+ ) to be compared (ongoing consultation) by conducting a three-arm, parallel group, Type 2 Hybrid Effectiveness Implementation Study in 18 urban K-8 public schools. We will also evaluate the economics and the intermediaries and facilitators of fidelity. 90 therapists, 18 supervisors and 360 children will participate. The Framework for Interactive Systems for Dissemination and Implementation guides the training and support processes for therapists and supervisors. Discussion This study has the potential to show that agency therapists and supervisors who have had little to no experience with evidence-based practices (EBPs) can reliably implement EBPs with an anxiety disorder. Comparisons of implementation strategies would provide data for large urban mental health systems to make decisions about the implementation of EBPs.

title: low-fat vegan diet results in larger macronutrient changes, but is comparable to a more conventional diabetic diet in individuals with type 2 diabetes in terms of compliance and acceptability
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although therapeutic diets are critical to diabetes management, their acceptance by patients remains largely unexplored. OBJECTIVE: To quantify adherence and acceptability for two types of diets for diabetes. DESIGN: Controlled study conducted between 2004 and 2006. SUBJECTS/SETTINGS: Individuals with type 2 diabetes (n=99) in a community-based research facility. Participants were randomly assigned to a diet following 2003 American Diabetes Association guidelines or a low-fat vegan diet for 74 weeks. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: Attrition, adherence, eating behaviors, diet acceptance, and cravings. STATISTICAL ANALYZES: In nutrient intake and questionnaire results, t-tests determined differences between groups. For measures of diet acceptance, the Wilcoxon sum-rank test for related samples assessed changes within the group; the Mann-Whitney U test for independent samples compared the diet groups. Changes in reported symptoms between groups were compared to Chi(2) for independent samples. RESULTS: All participants completed the first 22 weeks, 90% (45/50) in the American Diabetes Association diet group (45/50) and 86% (42 /49) of participants in the vegan diet group completed 74 weeks Carbohydrate and fiber intake increased more in the vegan group. At 22 weeks, 44% (22/50) of members in the American Diabetes Association diet group and 67% (33/49 ) the vegan the group-specific dietary compliance criteria-group participants (p=0.019); the American Diabetes Association nutrition group reported a greater increase in dietary restraint;" this difference was not significant at week 74. Both groups reported reduced hunger and reduced disinhibition. Responses to the questionnaire rated both diets as satisfactory, with no significant Differences between groups, except for ease of preparation, for which the 22-week ratings marginally favored the American Diabetes Association guideline group Fatty food cravings decreased more in the vegan group at 22 weeks, with no significant difference at 74 weeks CONCLUSIONS: Despite its greater impact on macronutrient absorption, a low-fat vegan diet has an acceptance rate similar to that of a more conventional diabetic diet Acceptance does not appear to be a barrier to its use in medical nutrition therapy.

title: meta-analysis of the association between adherence to drug therapy and mortality
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the relationship between adherence to medical therapy, including placebo, and mortality. DESIGN Meta-analysis of observational studies. DATA SOURCES Electronic databases, contact with investigators and textbooks and overviews on adherence. Screening Methods Predefined criteria were used to select studies reporting mortality in participants with good and poor adherence. Data were extracted for disease, drug therapy groups, methods of measuring adherence rate, definition of good adherence, and mortality. RESULTS Data were available from 21 studies (46,847 participants), including eight studies with placebo arms (19,633 participants). Compared with poor adherence, good adherence was associated with lower mortality (odds ratio 0.56, 95% confidence interval 0.50 to 0.63). Good adherence to placebo was associated with lower mortality (0.56, 0.43 to 0.74), as was good adherence to beneficial drug therapy (0.55, 0.49 to 0.62). Good adherence to harmful drugs was associated with increased mortality (2.90, 1.04 to 8.11). CONCLUSION Good adherence to drug therapy is associated with positive health outcomes. Furthermore, the observed association between good adherence to placebo and mortality supports the existence of the "healthy adherence" effect, whereby adherence to drug therapy may be a surrogate marker for overall healthy behavior.

title: midwife-led in-hospital birth center within an academic medical center: achievements and challenges
abstract: The University of California San Diego's Community Women's Health Program (CWHP) has emerged as a successful and sustainable coexistence model for women's health care. The cornerstone of this midwifery practice is California's only hospital birthing center. This unique and separate birthing center is located within the medical center and has been the site of more than 4000 births. With 10% cesarean and 98% breastfeeding rates, it is an exceptional example of minimally invasive care. The integration of this formerly detached birth center into an academic center has led to attempts at mistrust and ineffective communication. Education, consistent leadership, and the development of multidisciplinary policies helped address these challenges. This collaborative model provides a structure in which residents learn to be respectful advisors and to appreciate differences in medical practice. The CWHP and its Birth Center demonstrate that through persistence and flexibility, a collaborative model of maternity services can thrive and positively impact not only new families but future generations of providers.

title: migraine management training program for primary care physicians: an overview of the results of a survey and pilot study, lessons learned, and considerations for further research
abstract: BACKGROUND: There are five to nine million primary care physician visits for migraines each year in the United States. However, migraine care in primary care is often suboptimal. A previous study showed that primary care physicians (PCPs) desire direct contact with headache specialists to improve the migraine care they provide. OBJECTIVE: We sought to further investigate GP knowledge of migraine management and assess the feasibility of a multimodal migraine education program for GPs. METHODS: We conducted a survey to assess primary care physicians' knowledge of migraine. We then held three live training sessions and developed an email consultation service for GPs to ask questions they had about migraines. We report both quantitative and qualitative results. RESULTS: Twenty-one general practitioners completed the survey. They were generally consistent with the epidemiology of migraine (mean prevalence of reported migraine 12.6% +/- 10.1) and psychiatric comorbidities (mean prevalence of comorbid depression 24.5% +/- 16.7, mean prevalence of comorbid anxiety 24.6% +) familiar /- 18.3) and evidence-based behavioral therapies. 56% named cognitive behavioral therapy, 78% biofeedback and 61% relaxation therapy as evidence-based treatments. Although most were aware of the prevalence of psychiatric comorbidities, they did not routinely assess for them (43% did not routinely assess for anxiety, 29% did not routinely assess for depression). GPs reported that they frequently refer patients for non-evidence-based, Level A treatments: special diets (60%), acupuncture (50%), physical therapy (30%), and psychoanalysis (20%). Relaxation therapy was recommended by 40% of general practitioners. Only 10% reported turning to cognitive behavioral therapy or biofeedback. Nineteen percent made minimal or no use of preventive migraine medications. 72% had little or no knowledge of the American Academy of Neurology's migraine guidelines. Attendance at the training sessions varied (N=22 at 1st session, 6 at 2nd session, 15 at 3rd session). Very few PCPs used the email counseling service (N=4). CONCLUSIONS: Although primary care physicians are familiar with many aspects of migraine care, there is a need and opportunity for improvement. The three live sessions were poorly attended and the email counseling service was rarely used. We provide an in-depth discussion of targeted areas for educational interventions, challenges in developing a migraine education program for PCPs, and areas for future study.

title: model for collaboration in quality improvement projects: implementation of a weight-based heparin dosing nomogram in an integrated health care system
abstract: BACKGROUND: Aurora Health Care, an integrated delivery system based in Milwaukee, established a system-level clinical quality improvement division in 1995 to facilitate collaboration on clinical quality improvement (QI) initiatives. THE COLLABORATION MODEL: A model was developed to leverage expertise within the system and avoid unnecessary duplication while maintaining acceptance of the project's interventions at the point of service delivery. It was believed that a single team could design the improvement effort or policy and then work at a more local level with another group of people to implement the processes. APPLICATION OF THE MODEL TO THE HEPARIN-QI PROJECT: Anticoagulation with heparin is recognized as a mainstay in the treatment of pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis. However, a large gap was identified between current anticoagulation practices and published best practices in achieving a key process action. To reduce the overall time to achieve effective anticoagulation, a system-level team created an intervention consisting primarily of a preprinted order sheet, including the nomogram of weight-based heparin dosing, and an educational curriculum for physicians and other health professionals. Significant improvement was observed at all pilot sites, with the overall rate of adequate anticoagulation improving from 73% to 95% within the first 24 hours. DISCUSSION: The system was able to standardize care in four of its five major hospitals and provide better patient outcomes to a larger portion of the population, and then replicate the heparin project at four additional sites over a six-month period. This model has been successfully applied to other quality improvement projects.

title: policy analysis modeling tool to support the design of efficient and effective policy responses to complex public health problems
abstract: Background In public health policy-making, a broader understanding of risk factors for disease throughout the life-course and an increasing awareness of the social determinants of health have led to the development of broader, intersectoral strategies to tackle complex problems. However, comprehensive strategies may not represent the most efficient or effective approach to reducing the burden of disease at the population level. Rather, they can act to spread limited resources less intensively across a larger number of programs and initiatives, thereby diluting the potential impact of the investment. Although analytical tools are available that use research to identify and prioritize disease risk factors for public health interventions, they are insufficient to support more targeted and effective policy responses to complex public health problems. Discussion This paper discusses the limitations of analytical tools commonly used to support evidence-based policy decisions on complex problems. It proposes an alternative policy analysis tool that can integrate different sources of evidence and provide a platform for virtually testing policy alternatives to design solutions that are efficient, effective and equitable. The case of suicide prevention in Australia is presented to demonstrate the limitations of current prevention policy information tools and to discuss the usefulness of the new policy analysis tool. Summary Contrary to popular belief, a systems approach goes a step further than broad thinking and seeks to identify where public health interventions and resources can best be deployed to achieve optimal impact. It is primarily concerned with what can reasonably be left out of prevention strategies and can be used to study where disinvestment can occur without compromising the health (or equity) of populations. Simulation models used for policy analysis promise to better operationalize research results to support decision-making on complex problems, improve public health policy direction, and provide a basis for strengthening relationships between policymakers, stakeholders, and researchers .

title: national cross-sectional study of socio-behavioural factors influencing physicians' decision to start antimicrobial therapy
abstract: PURPOSE: Current efforts to prevent antimicrobial resistance include limiting antimicrobial use, providing education on appropriate use, and developing better point-of-care testing, but what do physicians actually think of rational prescribing and possible interventions? We sought to understand what factors may influence a physician's decision to start antimicrobial therapy in a patient and his or her opinion on measures to promote rational prescribing. Methods: We conducted a nationwide cross-sectional survey of 10,600 physicians from the medical associations of all known statutory health insurance physicians in Germany. RESULTS: Of respondents (n=3,492; 33%; including detailed nonresponse bias analysis), 90% said they elect to start antimicrobial therapy in a patient at least weekly, and 66% said they that they would decide every day. We identified correlates to the decision to start antimicrobial therapy in a patient. Predictors were status as hospital physician (odds ratio (OR) 1.29 (95% confidence interval (CI) 1.00-1.68)), physician (OR 1.81 (95% CI 1.42-2.31) ), age 50-59 (OR 1.56 (95% CI 1.10-2.21)) and practiced in the new federal states (OR 1.60 (95% CI 1.15-2.21 )). Each specialist decided to start antimicrobial therapy significantly less frequently than ENT specialists and urologists. Other predictors agreed to prescribing to be on the safe side (OR 1.34 (95% CI 1.03-1.76)) as they believed that the quality of prescribing practice is improving after being continuously used by pharmaceutical companies trained (OR 1.43 (95% CI 1.11-1.84). )) and experience with unsuccessful therapy for resistant pathogens (OR 2.42 (95% CI 1.83-3.19)). CONCLUSIONS: Physicians in our sample choose to initiate antimicrobial therapy in a patient and value interventions to support prudent use, e.g. B. Continuing Education, Practice Guidelines and Implementation of Monitoring Measures. Social behavior factors, regional differences, gender and age merit further research to promote rational antimicrobial prescribing and to examine related influencers.

title: new tool to assess the risk of walking in hospitalized patients
abstract: This article describes the development and implementation of a migratory screening and intervention program based on the identification of hospitalized patients with cognitive and mobility impairments. A migratory screening tool developed by a multidisciplinary team was linked to appropriate levels of intervention available in the electronic health record. Advanced Practice Nurses (APNs) confirmed the accuracy of screening and bedside nurse interventions for all patients who screened positive. Of 1,528 patients hospitalized during a 3-week period, 48 (3.1%) screened positive for wandering. Patients at risk were elderly (age >/= 65) (66.7%), patients admitted to surgical departments (41.7%), Caucasian (89.6%), and male (58.3%). Thirteen (27.1%) had dementia and 45 (93.8%) had impaired cognition. Of the patients who screened positive for hiking, the APNs agreed with the nurses' assessment in 79.2% of the cases (38/48) regarding risk for hiking and 89.5% (34/38 true positives) of the interventions match. A migratory screening tool and two-element intervention were feasible for use by nurses at the bedside. Further studies are needed to determine if this tool is effective in preventing wandering.

title: Pan-Canadian Practice Guideline: Prevention, Screening, Evaluation, and Management of Sleep Disorders in Adults With Cancer
abstract: PURPOSE: This study aims to provide recommendations on the optimal strategies and interventions for the prevention, screening, assessment, and management of cancer-related sleep disorders (insomnia and insomnia syndrome) in adult cancer populations. METHODS: A systematic search of the published health literature was performed to identify randomized controlled trials, clinical practice guidelines, systematic reviews, and other guides. The Sleep Disorders Expert Panel [consisting of nurses, psychologists, primary care physicians, oncologists, sleep disorder physicians, researchers, and guideline methodologists] reviewed, discussed, and approved the final version of the guideline. Healthcare professionals across Canada were asked to provide feedback as part of an external review process. RESULTS: Three clinical practice guidelines and 12 randomized controlled trials were identified as the evidence base. Overall, despite the lack of evidence, the evidence and expert consensus suggest that it is important to routinely screen and assess adult cancer patients for sleep disorders using standardized screening tools. While prevention of sleep disorders is the intended goal, cognitive behavioral therapies are effective in improving sleep outcomes. In the external review of 16 healthcare providers, 81% agreed with the written recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: Sleep disorders are a widespread problem in cancer populations that need more recognition from healthcare professionals. Prevention, screening, assessment and treatment strategies, based on the best available evidence, are crucial. Recommendations and care path algorithms for practice are offered.

title: patient-initiated system for health care.
abstract: Objective To test the effectiveness of a patient-initiated touch-sensitive computer system (TSCS) in improving screening rates for cancers of the breast, cervix, colon and rectum, and oral cavity. Design One-year, randomized, controlled study with primary care practice as the unit of analysis. Set up sixty primary care practices randomly recruited from 329 non-teaching practices in a southeastern state. Subjects Random sample of medical records of 50 pre-intervention male and female adult patients and 50 post-intervention adult patients at each office and a random sample of 507 TSCS users. Interventions Touch-sensitive computer system and a registered nurse who served as the liaison to the study offices. The TSCS provided patient-specific recommendations for preventive services and facilitated workflow to expedite delivery of these interventions. Main Outcome Measures Mean change, adjusted for Health Maintenance Examination (HME) and use of TSCS, in the proportion of eligible patients undergoing screening mammography, clinical breast exam, digital rectal exam, fecal occult blood test, flexible sigmoidoscopy, papanicolaou - Swab and examination of the oral cavity. Results We observed a significant increase in the performance of screening mammograms (6.6%; P<=0.05) and clinical breast examinations (6.1%; P<=0.01) in women aged 50 and over older, particularly among those who had an HME during the academic year. Conclusions Patients with HME are more likely to receive cancer screening, however, a computerized system for preventive services can help improve screening. Among patients who did not have HME, TSCS users had a higher rate of breast cancer screening than non-users.

title: peer-reviewed feedback method to promote adherence to prevention guidelines in an ambulatory care clinic
abstract: BACKGROUND: Simply distributing clinical practice guidelines to physicians does not change practice behavior. At the Marshall University School of Medicine outpatient clinic (Huntington, West Virginia), a low-cost, continuous peer-reviewed feedback method was used to promote adherence by resident physicians to nine preventive care guidelines. METHODS: Prevention guidelines were distributed and a peer-reviewed feedback program was implemented in the general practice of the general practitioner. The frequency of use of nine preventive care options in private practices was collected and compared over three periods: pre-guideline (September 1, 1993 to March 1, 1994; 148 patients), guideline (September 1, 1994 to March 1, 1995; 148 patients) and one-year Follow-up (September 1, 1995 to March 1, 1996; 150 patients).Patients in the three periods were similar in terms of age, sex, and risk of influenza and pneumococcal infections.RESULTS:During the guideline period, resident physicians offered patients four prophylactic Treatments for - tetanus toxoid immunization, clinical breast examination, papanicolaou smear test, and hemoccult test - were offered significantly more frequently than during the pre-guideline period All services were offered significantly more frequently than in the pre-guideline and as frequently as in the guideline in the one-year follow-up period : An affordable, continuous peer-reviewed feedback pro gramm significantly and permanently improves the compliance of resident physicians with the guidelines of clinical practice on preventive care services. However, the effectiveness of the feedback method for poor reviews may not generalize to private practices or other settings. Research into other methods of promoting adherence to clinical practice guidelines and influencing physician behavior in general should continue.

title: pilot study of an electronic interprofessional evidence-based care planning tool for clients with mental health problems and addictions
abstract: BACKGROUND: The health system needs to develop effective solutions to the growing challenges it faces in relation to people with mental health disorders and addictions. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the applicability and potential impact on outcomes of a knowledge translation system aimed at improving client-centered, evidence-based care for hospitalized patients with schizophrenia. METHODOLOGY: A pre-posttest design was used. The e-Volution TREAT system was implemented in two inpatient units of a large psychiatric facility. 37 nurses, allied health workers and doctors from two units attended. Data collection included questionnaires, semi-structured interviews, and observations. Outcome data from 38 consenting clients was collected from the organization's records. RESULTS: Overall, the participating employees were very satisfied with the functions of the e-Volution TREAT system. Barriers to using the system were identified by participants in relation to the work environment, staff shortages, equipment issues, uneasiness with using technology, and a focus on short-term rather than long-term goals. Guidelines on social issues were used moderately, and guidelines on family support and addictions were poorly used. There were significant improvements over time in four client outcomes, specifically aggressive behavior, depression, withdrawal, and psychosis. CONCLUSIONS: In summary, users were overall satisfied with the e-Volution TREAT system, but expressed workload challenges that impacted the time to use the system. Without a randomized controlled trial with outcomes compared to a control group, it would be premature to conclude that the change in patient outcomes is related to the e-Volition TREAT system. Future research must incorporate strategies for changing context and involve clinicians capable of modeling change.

title: population-based cross-sectional study of colorectal cancer screening practices of first-degree relatives of colorectal cancer patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: The aim of this study was to determine the proportions and predictors of first-degree relatives (FDRs) of colorectal cancer (CRC) patients (i) ever receiving a CRC test and (ii) CRC screening according to the Get CRC Screening Guidelines. METHODS: Colorectal cancer patients and their FDRs were recruited via the population-based Victorian Cancer Registry, Victoria, Australia. Seven hundred and seven FDRs conducted telephone interviews. Of these, 405 FDRs were classified as asymptomatic and suitable for analysis. RESULTS: 69% of FDRs had ever received a CRC test. Older first-degree relatives, those with private health insurance, siblings, and FDRs who had ever been interviewed by a physician about their family history of CRC were significantly more likely than their peers to have ever received a CRC test. Twenty-five percent of FDRs “at risk or slightly above average” adhered to the CRC screening guidelines. For this group, adherence to the guideline-recommended screening was significantly more likely in male FDRs and those with a higher level of education. For those at “moderate risk” and “potentially high risk,” 47% and 49%, respectively, adhered to the CRC screening guidelines. For this group, the guidelines-recommended screening was significantly more likely for FDRs who lived in metropolitan areas, siblings, married or partner, and those who were ever asked about a family history of CRC. CONCLUSIONS: FDRs demonstrated a significant level of non-compliance with screening guidelines. Improved CRC screening according to guidelines and effective systematic interventions to increase screening rates in populations affected by inequality are needed. STUDY REGISTRATION: Australian and New Zealand Clinical Trial Registry: ACTRN12609000628246.

title: primary care nurse-delivered rescue intervention in older adults: PACE (Pedometer Accelerometer Consultation Evaluation)-Lift-Cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Brisk walking in the elderly may increase step count and moderate-to-vigorous intensity physical activity (MVPA) in >/= 10-minute bouts, as recommended by World Health Organization guidelines. Previous interventions have reported an increase in step count but no change in objectively measured MVPA in older people. We examined whether a complex intervention performed by a primary care nurse increased objectively measured step counts and MVPA. METHODS AND RESULTS: A total of 988 60- to 75-year-olds able to increase walking randomly selected from three UK GP practices were invited to participate in a parallel, two-armed, randomized cluster study; randomization was by household. Two hundred - 98 people from 250 households were randomized between 2011 and 2012;" 150 people in the intervention group, 148 in the control group for usual care. Intervention participants received four physical activity (PA) consultations over a 3-month period from caregivers in of primary care, which included behavior modification techniques, pedometer pedometer and accelerometer PA intensity feedback, and an individual PA diary and plan. Assessors were not blinded to group status, but statistical analyzes were performed blindly. The primary endpoint was the change from baseline to month 3 in average daily step count measured by accelerometry, with the change at month 12 being a secondary endpoint.Other secondary endpoints were the change in MVPA over time from baseline in >/= 10-minute seizures, Akzel erometer counts and counts/minute at 3 months and 12 months. Other outcomes included adverse events, anthropometric measurements, mood, and pain. Qualitative evaluations by intervention participants and practice nurses assessed acceptance of the intervention. At 3 months, eight participants had withdrawn or were lost for follow-up, 280 (94%) subjects provided primary outcome data. At 3 months, changes in both mean daily step count and weekly MVPA in >/= 10-minute bouts were significantly greater in the intervention group than in the control group: by 1,037 (95% CI 513-1,560) steps/day and 63 ( 95% CI 40-87) minutes/week. At 12 months, the corresponding differences were 609 (95% CI 104-1115) steps/day and 40 (95% CI 17-63) minutes/week. Counts and counts/minute showed similar effects as steps and MVPA. Adverse events, anthropometry, mood, and pain were similar in both groups. Participants and practice nurses found the intervention acceptable and comfortable. CONCLUSIONS: The PACE-Lift study increased both step count and objectively measured MVPA in >/= 10-minute seizures in 60-75 year olds aged 3 and 12 months, with no impact on adverse events. To our knowledge, this is the first study in this age group to show objective increases in MVPA and underscores the value of individualized support incorporating objective PA assessment in a primary care setting. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Controlled-Trials.com ISRCTN42122561.

title: process to develop a community consensus related to the diagnosis and treatment of Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder
abstract: Major discrepancies remain between pediatrician practice patterns and the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) guidelines for the evaluation and treatment of children with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Several studies raise additional concerns about access to ADHD treatment for girls, blacks, and poorer individuals. Barriers can occur at multiple levels, including identification and referral by school staff, parental help-seeking behavior, diagnosis by the healthcare provider, treatment decisions, and treatment acceptance. These results confirm the importance of establishing appropriate mechanisms to ensure that children of both genders and all socioeconomic, racial and ethnic groups receive appropriate evaluation and treatment. The release of the AAP ADHD Toolkit provides resources to assist in implementing ADHD guidelines into clinical practice. These resources address a number of barriers to implementation in practice, including ignorance of the criteria of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, difficulties in identifying comorbidities, and insufficient knowledge of effective coding practices. Also critical to the success of improved processes in clinical practice is community collaboration in care, particularly collaboration with the educational system. Such collaboration removes other barriers to good care, such as B. pressure from parents and schools to prescribe stimulants, cultural biases that may prevent schools from screening children for ADHD or families from seeking medical care, and discrepancies in recognition and referral between schools in the same system. Collaboration can also create efficiencies in data collection and school-physician communication, thereby reducing physicians' non-personal (and thus non-reimbursable) elements of care. This article describes a process used in Guilford County, North Carolina to reach consensus among health care providers, educators, and child advocates regarding the assessment and treatment of children with ADHD symptoms. The result, a community protocol followed by school staff and community physicians for >10 years, ensures communication and collaboration between educators and physicians in the assessment and management of children with ADHD symptoms. This protocol has the potential to increase practice efficiencies, improve practice standards for children with ADHD, and improve child identification in schools. Perhaps most importantly, the community process through which the protocol was developed and implemented has an educational component that increases school staff's knowledge of ADHD and its treatment, increases the likelihood that referrals will be appropriate, and increases the likelihood that Children from the coordination benefit from interventions between school staff, doctors and parents. The protocol reflects a consensus among school staff and community health providers regarding: (1) "ideal ADHD assessment and treatment principles"; (2) a common entry point (one team) at schools for children assessed for inattention and classrooms behavioral issues, whether the issues first arise with a medical provider, the behavioral health system, or the school; (3) a protocol followed by the school system that recognizes schools' resource limitations but meets the needs of community health providers for instructional observations , psychoeducational testing, parental and teacher behavioral rating scales, and functional assessment; (4) an information pack on each child identified as requiring a medical evaluation; (5) a liaison or team at each doctor's office to to receive the package men from the school and referral to the appropriate clinician; (6) an assessment process that examines comorbidities and applies appropriate diagnostic criteria; (7) evidence-based interventions; (8) procedures for follow-up monitoring of children after a treatment plan has been established; (9) roles for key participants (school staff, physicians, school nurses, and mental health professionals) in the assessment, management, and follow-up of children with attention deficit disorders; (10) Forms for collecting and sharing information at each step; (11) Processes and key contacts for communication flow at each step; and (12) a plan to educate school and health professionals about the new processes. A recreation of the community process initiated in Forsyth County, North Carolina in 2001 provides insight into the role of the AAP ADHD guidelines in facilitating the development of a community consensus protocol. This replication also draws attention to school-level identification and referral barriers. The following recommendations, drawn from the 2 community processes, describe a role for physicians in the collaborative community care of children with ADHD symptoms. (1) Reach consensus with the school system regarding the role of school staff in collecting data for children with learning and behavioral difficulties; Components to consider include (a) vision and hearing screening, (b) educational/school history, (c) classroom observation by a counselor, (d) rating scales for parental and teacher behavior (e.g., Vanderbilt, Conner, or Achenbach scales), (e) accounting for speech/language assessment, (f) screening intelligence tests, (g) screening achievement tests, (h) full intelligence and achievement tests when discrepancies are evident in abbreviated tests, and (i) Attempt classroom interventions (2) Visit the pediatrician's office to identify children with academic or behavioral problems and symptoms of inattention (medical history or questionnaire) (3) Refer identified children to the contact person at each child's school and request information in accordance with Community consensus (4) Designate a contact person who will receive school practice materials. (5) Review the school's package and integrate the school's data into the clinical assessment. (6) Affirm with parents and the school the need for a multimodal intervention, including academic and learning strategies for the classroom and home, in-depth psychological testing of children whose cognitive level/performance discrepancies suggest learning or language disabilities, and the Need for an individualized education plan (special education), consideration of the designation “other impaired” as an alternative route to an individualized education plan or 504 plan (classroom accommodations), behavior modification techniques for targeted behavior problems, and drug testing as indicated. (7) Refer the patient to a psychologist if evaluation indicates co-existing conditions. (8) Use communication forms to share diagnostic and medication information, recommended interventions, and follow-up plans with the school and family. (9) Receive requested follow-up reports from teachers and parents and make adjustments in therapy as indicated by the child's functioning in target areas. (10) Maintaining communication with the school and parents, especially in times of transition (e.g. beginning and end of the school year, changing schools, times of family stress, times of a change in management, adolescence and entry into university or the workforce).

title: prospective, multicenter study of a pneumonia practice guideline
abstract: AIM: To investigate the impact of a practice guideline on length of stay on patient outcomes. DESIGN: A prospective, non-randomized, interventional study. SETTING: Six geographically dispersed hospitals. PATIENTS: Two hundred forty-two consecutively hospitalized "low-risk" patients with pneumonia. MEASUREMENTS AND RESULTS: One hundred fifty-two patients (63%) completed the mailed post-discharge survey and were included in the analysis. The data were collected prospectively for 85 patients from the baseline observation period (B) and 67 patients from the intervention period (I). During I, case managers provided physicians with patient risk information based on guideline recommendations. There was no significant change in guideline compliance (B vs. I: 76.5% vs. 83.6%; p=0.32) or length of stay (B vs. I: 3.5 days [95% CI, 3, 2 to 3.8] vs. 3.6 days [95% confidence interval, 3.3 to 4.0]). Additionally, there were no statistically significant effects of the intervention on patient outcomes, post-hospital care, and patient satisfaction scores. CONCLUSION: Patients in this study often had a shorter length of stay than recommended by the practice guideline. This suggests that the external environment may have had a greater impact on physician behavior and length of stay than the practice guideline itself. In addition, it demonstrates the importance of ongoing assessment of physician practices immediately before, during, and after the application of the clinical practice guideline.

title: protocol for the pharmacological treatment of major depressive disorder. A field test of a potential prototype
abstract: BACKGROUND: Much attention is given to the development of clinical practice guidelines for the management of mental health disorders. The aim of this study was to field test a prototype protocol for the pharmacological treatment of major depressive disorder. METHOD: The protocol consisted of four, six-week treatment phases with critical therapy decisions defined by scores on the MADRS (Montgomery Asberg Depression Rating Scale). Observational data collected on the protocol's behavior in terms of relevance, acceptance, ease of use and effectiveness. RESULTS: The effectiveness of the protocol was good for the patients who adhered to it, with three quarters of them achieving remission. However, more than half of all patients discontinued treatment, with no-shows and adverse events being the most common reasons. CONCLUSION: The protocol for the treatment of major depressive disorder appeared relevant, easy to use and potentially effective. LIMITATION: Physician and patient non-compliance issues presented significant challenges to the design of the protocol. Such difficulties demonstrate the need to field test any proposed design, since prejudices about a protocol's performance can be misplaced. CLINICAL RELEVANCE: The tested protocol represents an advance towards the goal of developing optimal strategies for the use of pharmacotherapeutic agents in the treatment of depression.

title: qualitative assessment of the barriers and intermediaries in implementing the WHO surgical safety checklist in hospitals in England: lessons learned from the surgical checklist implementation project
abstract: Objectives: To assess how the World Health Organization (WHO) surgical safety checklist has been implemented in hospitals in England; identifying barriers and facilitators to implementation;' and generally draw lessons for the implementation of surgical/healthcare improvement initiatives. Background: The WHO checklist has been associated with improved surgical outcomes and teamwork, but we know little about the factors that influence their successful implementation Methods: A longitudinal interview study of OR staff in a representative sample of 10 hospitals in England was conducted between March 2010 and March 2011. The interviews were recorded over the telephone and respondents were ranked according to their experience with the introduction of the checklist and the factors that hindered or supported this process.The transcripts were subjected to a thematic analysis.Results: A total of 119 interviews were conducted.The implementation of the checklist varied greatly between and within hospitals and ranged from pre-planned/step-by-step approaches to checklists that simply “appeared” in operating rooms or staff felt forced to do. Most implementation barriers were specific to the checklist itself (e.g. perceived design issues) but also involved problematic integration into pre-existing processes. The most common barrier was resistance from experienced clinicians. The facilitators highlighted some positive steps that can be taken to prevent/address these barriers, e.g. B. modifying the checklist, providing education/training, providing feedback on local data, fostering strong leadership (particularly at participant level) and introducing accountability. Conclusions: We identified common themes that supported or hindered the adoption of the WHO checklist in England and translated these into recommendations to guide the implementation of improvement initiatives in surgery and the wider health system.

title: qualitative study to understand the non-guideline use of imaging for staging of prostate cancer
abstract: BACKGROUND: About half of veterans with low-risk prostate cancer receive non-guideline imaging. Our aim was to identify and describe (1) physicians' knowledge, attitudes and practices related to the use of imaging for staging of prostate cancer, (2) patient attitudes and behaviors regarding the use of imaging and (3) to compare the responses of three VA Medical Centers (VAMCs). METHODS: A qualitative approach was used to examine patient and provider knowledge and behavior regarding the use of imaging. We conducted a total of 39 semi-structured interviews—including 22 interviews with newly diagnosed prostate cancer patients and 17 interviews with treating physicians—in three VAMCs between September 2014 and July 2015, representing a spectrum of inappropriate imaging rates. After the core theoretical concepts were identified, the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF) was chosen to explore connections between topics within the data set and existing domains within the framework. The interviews were audio-taped, transcribed verbatim, and then encoded and analyzed using Nvivo software. RESULTS: Subjects from patient interviews were categorized into four TDF domains. Patients reported little interest in staging compared to disease treatment (goals), and many could not recall having had imaging at all (knowledge). Patients were more likely to trust their doctor to make decisions about appropriate testing (Beliefs about Capabilities). Some patients expressed minor concerns about exposure to radiation, but fear of the consequences of the cancer outweighed these fears (emotions). Physician interview topics were categorized into five TDF domains. Most physicians reported knowing and trusting imaging guidelines (knowledge), but some likely followed their own intuition, whether based on clinical suspicion or years of experience (belief in ability). In addition, physicians reported that medicolegal concerns, fear of missing associated diagnoses (consequence beliefs), the influence of peers who frequently take pictures (social influences), and the facility in which they practice practice affect imaging rates (environmental context ). CONCLUSIONS: Interviews with patients and physicians suggest that physicians are the primary (and in some cases only) decision makers regarding imaging staging of prostate cancer. This finding suggests that targeted physician intervention may be the most effective strategy for improving guideline-compliant prostate cancer imaging.

title: quality improvement intervention to address vendor behavior related to the application of the CA-MRSA guidelines
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the impact of a provider-focused quality improvement training intervention on appropriate prescribing for community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infections. BACKGROUND: Patient, provider, and healthcare system factors contribute to appropriate antibiotic prescribing. Achieving adequate prescribing is critical to reducing the burden of antibiotic resistance. Knowing about appropriate prescribing for community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection is the first step in shifting prescriber behavior towards evidence-based recommendations. DESIGN: Quality improvement project. METHOD: After a review of best practice guidelines and the application of the Stetler Research Utilization model, a brief pedagogical intervention using voice-over PowerPoint was conducted. Items of the educational intervention included indications for screening, particularly the role of monitoring and waiting after culturing for simple abscesses. The intervention was delivered in a for-profit, non-academic emergency care setting and assessed the knowledge and practice of the prescribing providers. RESULTS: Of 48 physicians, physician assistants, and nurses, 18 (37.5%) participated";" 12 of the 18 (67%) participants showed an increase in knowledge. 43% of the prescribing tables showed improved practice through the use of the guidelines. Of 18 prescribing physicians, 44% sent a total of 21 cultures for abscesses. There was no difference in practical behavior between the occupational groups. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the increase in knowledge values, this improvement in knowledge did not result in dramatic changes in practice, although trends in a positive direction were noted. RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: This quality improvement project underscores the complexity of changing prescriber behavior and the need for ongoing interventions.

title: quantitative method for evaluating prescription patterns using electronic health records
abstract: BACKGROUND: Most available quality indicators for hospitals are represented by simple ratios or proportions and are limited to specific events. A generalized method that can be applied to different clinical events has not been developed. The aim of this study was to develop a simple method to assess physician prescribing patterns for different events and their awareness of clinical guidelines. METHODS AND RESULTS: We developed a quantitative method called Prescription Pattern Around Clinical Event (PACE) that is applicable to Electronic Medical Records (EHRs). Three discrete prescription patterns (intervention, maintenance, and discontinuation) were determined based on the prescription change index (PCI), which was calculated from the increase or decrease in prescription rate after a clinical event. Hyperkalemia and Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) were used as example cases. We calculated the PCIs of 10 drugs associated with hyperkalemia, categorized them into prescription patterns, and then compared the resulting prescription patterns to known standards for hyperkalemia treatment. The physicians' knowledge of hyperkalemia was assessed using a questionnaire and compared with the prescription model. Prescriptions for CDAD were also identified and compared to clinical knowledge. Clinical data from 1698, 348 and 1288 patients were collected from EHR data. The physicians who prescribed behaviors for hyperkalemia and CDAD were standard knowledge. Prescribing patterns correlated well with individual physicians' knowledge of hyperkalemia (kappa = 0.714). Prescribing behavior according to event severity or clinical condition was presented as a simple summary chart. CONCLUSION: The algorithm successfully evaluated the prescribing patterns from the EHR data. Prescribing patterns correlated well with physician knowledge. We anticipate that this algorithm will enable prescribers' adherence to clinical guidelines to be quantified and serve to facilitate improved prescribing practices.

title: randomized clinical trial of a tailored lifestyle intervention for obese, sedentary patients in primary care
abstract: PURPOSE: The aim of the study was to test a tailored lifestyle intervention to help obese primary care patients achieve weight loss and increase physical activity. METHODS: We conducted a 24-month randomized clinical trial in Rhode Island. Primary care physicians identified obese, sedentary patients who were motivated to lose weight and increase their moderate-to-vigorous physical activity. These patients were randomized into 1 of 2 experimental groups: enhanced intervention (EI) or standard intervention (SI). Both groups received 3 face-to-face weight loss meetings. The expanded intervention group also received telephone counseling calls, individually tailored printed materials, and DVDs focusing on nutrition and physical activity. Active intervention occurred at year 1 with an ending maintenance phase at year 2. RESULTS: 211 obese, sedentary patients were recruited from 24 primary care practices. The participants were 79% women and 16% minorities. They had an average age of 48.6 years, a mean body mass index (BMI) of 37.8 kg/m2 and 21.2 minutes/week of moderate to vigorous physical activity. Significantly more EI participants lost 5% of their baseline weight than SI participants (post-visit group, P<0.001). The difference was significant during active treatment at 6 months (37.2% EI vs. 12.9% SI) and 12 months (47.8% vs. 11.6%), but was greater during the maintenance phase at 18 months ( 31.4% vs. 26.7%) no longer significant. or 24 months (33.3% vs. 24.6%). The EI group reported significantly more minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity over time than the SI group (post-visit group, P=0.04). The differences in minutes per week at 6 months were 95.7 minutes for the EI group vs. 68.3 minutes for the SI group; at 12 months, they were 126.1 vs. 73.7; at 18 months, 103.7 vs. 63.7; and at 24 months, 101.3 vs. 75.4. Similar trends were found for absolute weight loss and percentage meeting national physical activity guidelines. CONCLUSION: A home-based tailored lifestyle intervention in obese, sedentary primary care patients was effective in promoting weight loss and increasing moderate-to-vigorous physical activity, with effects peaking at 12 months but tapering off at 24 months.

title: randomized controlled trial of a drug use review intervention for sedating hypnotic medications
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Drug use screening is used by both the public and private sectors to influence patient prescribing behavior and drug use. Previous interventions mailed to prescribers have had mixed results. The aim was to evaluate the effect of a one-time mailed intervention on subsequent use of sedating hypnotic drugs. Methods: An experimental design was used. The intervention included guidelines for the use of sedating hypnotics, a prescriber profile describing the prescribing of sedating hypnotics, and a patient profile. Grouping of patients and their common prescribers was performed to avoid contamination bias and statistical problems related to lack of independence of observations. The subjects were 189 Washington State Medicaid recipients who had received at least one pill of a sedating hypnotic drug per day for 1 year and their prescribing physicians or (when information about the physician was missing) the dispensing pharmacy. RESULTS: A significant reduction in the use of targeted sedative hypnotics was measured in the intervention group (-27.6%) compared to the control group (-8.5%). In the intervention group, 9.4% of patients started a new prescription of a benzodiazepine not targeted by drug use review, while none of the control patients started a new use of non-target benzodiazepines. CONCLUSIONS: The intervention produced a statistically significant reduction in targeted drug use, and the magnitude of the reduction may have reduced the risk of fractures associated with benzodiazepine use. This study adds to the recent evidence that post-mail drug use screening interventions can have a desirable impact on patients' drug use.

title: randomized controlled trial of a comprehensive lifestyle management intervention (ELMI) after cardiac rehabilitation: study design and baseline data
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cardiac rehabilitation programs (CRP) represent comprehensive interventions, typically limited to four months. After completion of CRP, risk factors and lifestyle behaviors appear to worsen. The Extensive Lifestyle Management Intervention (ELMI) Following Cardiac Rehabilitation Study will examine the benefits of a randomized intervention to prevent these adverse changes. METHODS: Patients with ischemic heart disease (IHD) were randomized to ELMI or usual care after standard CRP. The ELMI program is a case-driven intervention aimed at individualizing risk factor and lifestyle management based on current treatment guidelines. The program consists of cardiac rehabilitation sessions, telephone follow-up, and risk factor and lifestyle counseling sessions. Health professionals work with participants through behavioral counseling and communication with participants' GPs. Participants on usual care return for care from their GP and only come to the study clinic for the annual outcome assessment. The primary outcome is the change in global IHD risk at four years. Secondary endpoints include composite cardiovascular events, health care utilization, lifestyle compliance, quality of life, and risk factors. RESULTS: Over 28 months, 302 men and women were randomized. This represented 29% of the total population screened. The mean age of the study participants is 64 years, 18% are women, 53% had a previous myocardial infarction, 73% had a previous revascularization and 20% have diabetes mellitus. Risk factors for ischemic heart disease for the entire cohort improved significantly after subjects went through previous CRPs. Baseline risk factors, lifestyle behaviors, and medications were similar between groups. CONCLUSIONS: This study population is representative of patients completing standard CRP. The results of the ELMI study will provide valuable information for the future design of CRPs.

title: randomized controlled trial of IVR-based brief alcohol intervention to promote patient-provider communication in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Brief interventions for unhealthy alcohol use in primary care are effective but underutilized. Efforts to improve short-term intervention rates through provider training and office systems redesign have had limited effect. Our novel brief intervention uses Interactive Voice Response (IVR) to provide direct information and counseling to unhealthy drinkers prior to a doctor's visit, with the goal of stimulating in-office dialogue about drinking and reducing unhealthy drinking. This automated approach is potentially scalable for wide application. OBJECTIVE: Our aim was to investigate the effect of short-term pre-visit alcohol intervention (IVR-BI) on patient-caregiver conversations about alcohol during the visit. DESIGN: This was a randomized, controlled, parallel-group study with two treatment arms: 1) IVR-BI or 2) usual care (no IVR-BI). PARTICIPANTS: A total of 1,567 patients from eight university medical clinics for internal medicine and family medicine were recruited. INTERVENTIONS: IVR-BI is a brief alcohol intervention delivered via automated telephone. It has four components based on the intervention steps outlined in the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism guidelines for clinicians: 1) asking about alcohol use, 2) evaluating for alcohol use disorders, 3) advising the patient to limit alcohol use, or stop doing so, and 4) follow up on subsequent visits. KEY INTERVENTIONS: Outcomes were reported by patient: discussion between patient and provider about alcohol during visit; patient initiation of the conversation;' and the physician's recommendation of the patient's alcohol consumption. MAIN RESULTS: Patients randomized to IVR-BI were more likely to report having discussed alcohol with their doctor (52% vs. 44%, p=0.003) and to have raised the issue themselves (20% vs 12%, p<0.001) and received a referral (20% vs. 14%, p<0.001). Other predictors for the result were consumption, education, age and the diagnosis of an alcohol use disorder. CONCLUSIONS: Providing automated brief interventions to patients prior to a GP visit encourages discussion about unhealthy drinking and increases specific professional counseling to change drinking behavior.

title: randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of a distance learning program for pediatricians in asthma
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate provider acceptance of a distance learning program for pediatric asthma and pilot test its impact on physician knowledge, attitudes, and treatment practices. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: Louisville and the surrounding region in central Kentucky. PARTICIPANTS: Twenty-four pediatricians in clinical practice. interventions. A distance learning program for pediatric asthma consisting of web or CD-ROM based multimedia learning modules and two conference calls. OUTCOME MEASURES: Learner satisfaction and changes in physicians' asthma knowledge, attitudes, and treatment behavior at 1 to 4 months (short-term) and 6 to 8 months (long-term). RESULTS: Pediatricians had completed their medical studies an average of 11.6 years prior to study entry (SD +/-8.9)";" 56% were female. For all aspects of student satisfaction, the average score on a 5-point scale was 4.0 or higher, indicating a positive response from participants. Participants in the training group reported increased familiarity with asthma guidelines for prescribing daily inhaled corticosteroids during short-term follow-up compared to control physicians (p=0.03). Participants also expressed increased confidence in drug selection for patients requiring a low-dose inhaled steroid (p=0.03). However, these differences were not observed in long-term follow-up. Compared to the control group, there was no significant increase in the proportion of patients receiving inhaled steroids for persistent asthma at short- or long-term follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: Pediatricians who participated in an asthma distance learning program reported high levels of learner satisfaction. The program was associated with a transient increase in familiarity and confidence in the implementation of components of the asthma guidelines.

title: randomized controlled trial to improve lymph node assessment in stage II colon cancer
abstract: HYPOTHESIS: Physicians seem to learn best from their peers, but the influence of opinion leaders on physician behavior is unclear. Because colon cancer staging was identified as suboptimal in Ontario, Canada, we sought to assess the influence of colorectal cancer experts and local opinion leaders in optimizing colorectal cancer lymph node assessment. DESIGN, SETTING, PARTICIPANTS: A cluster-randomized study including all Ontario hospitals that included a local opinion leader with an intervention between January 5 and June 17, 2004 identified an expert opinion leader in colorectal cancer. The 21 intervention hospitals also received a scientific description of a local opinion leader by the expert opinion leader and a toolkit. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The mean number of lymph nodes assessed in patients with stage II colon cancer and the proportion of cases assessed with at least 12 lymph nodes before and after a standardized presentation were assessed. RESULTS: Patient demographics and tumor factors were similar in both groups before and after the standardized presentation. Lymph node assessment improved significantly (p<0.001) after standardized presentation at intervention and control sites. No additional benefit of academic detailing and provision of toolkits in the intervention was demonstrated. CONCLUSIONS: Personal provision of information by a colorectal cancer opinion leader may enhance performance in colorectal cancer lymph node assessment. Scientific detailing from a local opinion leader did not further improve lymph node assessment.

title: randomized outpatient trial of an information technology decision support tool.
abstract: Background Information technology for decision support is often used to improve clinical decision making, but it is seldom rigorously evaluated. Congress mandated the evaluation of Problem-Knowledge Couplers (PKC Corp, Burlington, Vt.), a decision support tool proposed for the Department of Defense's new health information network. Methods This was a patient-level, randomized study conducted in 2 military practices. A total of 936 patients were assigned to the intervention group and 966 to standard care. Couplers were applied prior to routine outpatient clinic visits. The primary outcome was quality of care, which was assessed based on the overall percentage of 24 health care quality process measures (ability to provide evidence-based care) that were met. Secondary endpoints included medical resource consumption within 60 days of enrollment and patient and provider satisfaction. Results There were 4639 health care choices (2374 in the coupler group and 2265 in the usual care group) with no difference in the proportion of choices fulfilled (33.9% vs. 30.7%; P=0.12). Although there was a modest improvement in performance on screening/prevention interventions, this was offset by poorer performance on some acute care interventions. Coupler patients consumed more laboratory and pharmacy resources than standard care patients (log mean difference, $71). No difference in patient satisfaction was observed between groups, and provider satisfaction was mixed. Conclusion This study does not provide strong evidence for the usefulness of this decision support tool, but it does demonstrate the value of a rigorous evaluation of information technology for decision support.

title: randomized attempt at "follow-up commands" to avoid omission errors.
abstract: Objective: Omission errors are a common cause of system failures. Doctors often fail to order tests or treatments needed to monitor/improve the effects of other tests or treatments. The authors hypothesized that automated, guideline-based reminders to physicians when writing instructions might reduce these omissions. Design: The study was conducted on the inpatient general medical ward of a public teaching hospital. Faculty and domestic staff at Indiana University School of Medicine who used computer workstations to write instructions were randomly assigned to intervention and control groups. When intervention physicians wrote instructions for 1 of 87 selected tests or treatments, the computer suggested appropriate instructions needed to detect or mitigate adverse reactions to the trigger instructions. Doctors could accept or reject these suggestions. RESULTS: During the 6-month study, reminders for subsequent prescriptions were presented to 48 intervention physicians and withheld from 41 control physicians. Intervention physicians ordered the proposed follow-up orders 46.3% of the time when they received a reminder, compared with 21.9% of control physicians (p<0.0001). Physicians discriminated in accepting proposed prescriptions, willingly accepting some while rejecting others. There were a third fewer pharmacist-initiated interventions with physicians in the intervention than control groups. Conclusion: This study demonstrates that physician workstations, coupled with a comprehensive electronic medical record, can be an effective means of reducing omission errors and improving adherence to practice guidelines.

title: randomized trial of a computer-assisted intervention to reduce the use of redundant laboratory tests
abstract: PURPOSE: To determine the impact of computerized reminders to physicians about seemingly redundant clinical laboratory tests. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: We conducted a prospective, randomized, controlled study including all inpatients at a large teaching hospital over a 15-week period. The intervention consisted of computerized reminders of when a test that seemed redundant was ordered. The main target parameters were the proportion of canceled clinical laboratory orders and the proportion of tests actually performed. RESULTS: During the study period, there were 939 apparently redundant laboratory tests among the 77,609 study tests allocated between the intervention (n=5,700 patients) and control (n=5,886 patients) groups. In the intervention group, 69% (300 out of 437) of the tests were discontinued due to reminders. Out of 137 overrides, 41% appeared justified based on review of the charts. In the control group, 51% of the ordered redundant tests were performed, while only 27% of the ordered redundant tests were performed in the intervention group (p < 0.001). However, the estimated annual savings in lab fees was only $35,000. This happened because only 44% of the redundant tests performed had computer orders, because only half of the computer orders were checked for redundancy, and because nearly a third of the reminders were overridden. CONCLUSIONS: Order reminders for apparently redundant laboratory tests were effective when delivered. However, the overall effect was limited because many tests were run without corresponding computer orders, and many orders were not checked for redundancy.

title: randomized trial of computerized reminders and audit and feedback to improve primary care HIV screening.
abstract: Despite recommendations for voluntary HIV screening, few medical centers have implemented screening programs. The aim of the study was to determine whether a computerized reminder and feedback intervention would increase screening for HIV in a Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) health care system. The study design was a randomized controlled trial in five primary care clinics of the VA Palo Alto Health Care System. All general practitioners were able to take part in the study. The study intervention consisted of computerized reminders to either assess HIV risk behaviors or to offer HIV testing.” Feedback on reminder compliance was provided. The key outcome measure was the difference in HIV testing rates between the intervention and control group providers. The control group Providers tested 1.0% (n=67) and 1.4% (n=106) of patients in the preintervention and intervention phases, respectively;” Intervention providers tested 1.8% (n=98) and 1, respectively, 9% (n=114) (p=0.75). In our random sample of 753 untested patients, 204 (27%) had documented risky behaviors. Providers adhered to testing reminders rather than reminders to perform a risk assessment (11% vs. 5%, P<0.01). Sixty-one percent of vendors felt that lack of time prevented risk assessment. In summary, HIV testing rates in primary care clinics in our area have been low. Providers were unaware of the high rate of risky behaviors in their patient population and saw important barriers to testing. Clinical reminders and low-intensity feedback did not increase screening rates.

title: randomized trial of computerized reminders for blood pressure screening in primary care.
abstract: In a randomized, controlled trial (N = 8,298), the authors compared three ways of getting patients to monitor blood pressure in a large primary care practice. Based on computerized medical records in a family medicine teaching center, the study included patients aged 18 years and older who had not had their blood pressure measured in the previous year. In a normally served control group, 21.1% of those due for a blood pressure measurement received one during the trial year. In one intervention group, a computer-generated message reminded the doctor to check the blood pressure of patients who happened to visit the center for an appointment.” 30.7% of the patients assigned to this group were checked. In the second group, the nurse contacted patients by phone and encouraged 24.1% of patients who were due to get a check. Sending a letter to patients in the third group resulted in a 35.7% compliance rate. Considering the cost of the three interventions, physician reminder was the most costly effective, followed by reminder letters. Although statistically significant, the effect of the reminders was modest. A better approach might be a combination of routine reminders to the physician, followed by letters to noncompliant patients, include.

title: randomized trial of electronic clinical reminders to improve the quality of care in diabetes and coronary artery disease.
abstract: Aim: The aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of an integrated patient-specific electronic clinical reminder system on the management of diabetes and coronary artery disease (CAD) and to assess physician attitudes towards this reminder system. Design: We recruited 194 primary care physicians attending 4549 diabetic patients and 2199 CHD patients in 20 outpatient clinics. Clinics were randomized so that physicians received either evidence-based electronic reminders in their patients' electronic medical records or usual care. There were five reminders for diabetes care and four reminders for CHD care. Measurements: The primary outcome was maintenance of recommended treatment for diabetes and CHD. We created a summary outcome to assess the likelihood of increased compliance with general diabetes care (based on five measures) and general CAD care (based on four measures). We surveyed physicians to assess attitudes toward the memory system. Results: Baseline adherence rates for all quality measures were low. While electronic reminders increased the likelihood of recommended diabetes care (odds ratio [OR] 1.30, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.01-1.67) and CHD (OR 1.25, 95% CI 1.01-1.55 ) increased, the impact of individual reminders was variable. A total of three out of nine reminders effectively increased rates of recommended treatment for diabetes or CAD. The majority of physicians (76%) felt reminders improved the quality of care. Conclusion: An integrated electronic reminder system resulted in a variable improvement in diabetes and CHD care. These improvements have often been limited and gaps in quality persist.

title: randomized trial of the effectiveness of on-demand versus computer-guided drug decision support in primary care.
abstract: Objectives: Prescription alerts generated by Computerized Drug Decision Support (CDDS) can prevent drug-related morbidity. However, the vast majority of warnings are ignored due to clinical irrelevance. The ability to customize commercial alert systems should improve physician acceptance because the physician can select the circumstances and types of drug alerts displayed. We tested the effectiveness of two approaches to tailoring medication alerts to reduce the prevalence of prescription problems: on-demand versus computerized decision support. Physicians in each study condition could preset values that triggered alarms. DESIGN: This was a cluster study of 28 primary care physicians who were randomized to receive either automated or on-demand CDDS in the MOXXI drug management system for 3,449 of their patients to be treated over the next 6 months. Measurements: The CDDS generated alerts for prescribing issues that could be customized by severity. Prescribing issues included dosing errors, drug-drug interactions, age, allergy, and disease. Physicians randomized to on-demand activated drug proving if they deemed it clinically relevant, while physicians randomized to computerized decision support enabled all e-prescription alerts according to their selected severity level for both common and common see problems that arise. Data from administrative applications and MOXXI were used to measure the difference in the prevalence of prescribing problems at the end of follow-up. RESULTS: During follow-up, 50% of physicians receiving computer-controlled alarms modified the alarm threshold (n=7), and 21% of physicians in the alarm-on-demand group modified the alarm level (n=3). In the on-demand group, 4,445 prescription issues were identified, 41 (0.9%) were seen through a requested drug review, and 31 issues (75.6%) had the prescription revised. In comparison, 668 (10.3%) of the 6,505 prescribing problems in the computer-guided group were seen and 81 (12.1%) were revised. The majority of alerts were ignored because the benefit was considered greater than the risk, the interaction was known, or the interaction was considered clinically insignificant (computer driven: 75.8% of 585 alerts ignored; on-demand: 90% of 10 ignored warnings). warnings). At the end of follow-up, there was a significant reduction in therapeutic duplication problems in the computer-guided group (odds ratio, 0.55; p=0.02), but no difference in the overall prevalence of prescribing problems. triggered alert systems are more useful than on-demand review in detecting and resolving prescribing problems, but neither approach has been effective in reducing prescribing problems. New strategies are needed to maximize the use of drug decision support systems and reduce drug-related morbidity to reduce.

title: randomized trial comparing alternative education interventions to improve colorectal cancer screening in a hard-to-reach urban minority with health insurance
abstract: This randomized controlled trial evaluated different educational approaches to increase colorectal cancer screening utilization in a sample of predominantly non-US-born urban minorities over the age of 50 who have health insurance and are non-adherent to screening guidelines. In one group, participants received printed educational materials in the mail (n=180); in a second group, participants' GPs received academic details on how to improve screening referral and follow-up procedures (n=185);" in one third, physicians received detailed academic information and participants received customized telephone training (n = 199). Overall, 21.5% of participants (n=121) received adequate screening within 1 year of randomization. There were no statistically significant pairwise differences between groups in screening rate. However, in the over-60s, the detailing and telephone education group had a higher screening rate than the pressure group (27.3 vs. 7.7%, p=0.02). Different types of interventions will be needed to improve early detection of colorectal cancer in the shrinking segment of the population that is not screened. ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT02392143.

title: randomized trial of real-world step wedge clusters for exercise facilitation to improve cardiovascular care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Facilitation of practice has been associated with significant improvements in disease prevention and quality of patient care. The Improved Delivery of Cardiovascular Care (IDOCC) project aimed to improve the delivery of evidence-based cardiovascular care in primary care practices in a large healthcare region through practice facilitation. Our goal was to assess the impact of IDOCC on compliance with healthcare processes. METHODS: A pragmatic randomized stepwedge cluster study of primary care physician recruitment in private practices in eastern Ontario, Canada (ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT00574808). Participants were randomly assigned to one of three steps by region. Trainers should visit the office every 3-4 (Year 1 Intensive) or 6-12 weeks (Year 2 Sustained) to encourage changes in exercise behavior. The primary endpoint was mean adherence to indicators of evidence-based care, measured at the patient level. Adherence was assessed using a chart overview of a randomly selected cohort of 66 patients per practice at each pre-intervention year, and at year 1 and year 2 post-intervention. RESULTS: 84 practices (182 physicians) participated. On average, moderators had 6.6 (min: 2, max: 11) face-to-face visits to practices in year 1 and 2.5 (min: 0, max: 10) visits in year 2. We collected chart data from 5292 patients. After adjustment for patient and provider characteristics, there was an absolute decrease in mean adherence of 1.9% (95% confidence interval (CI): -2.9 to -0.9%) and 4.2% (95% CI: - 5.7 to -2.6%). Baseline to intensive or sustainability years. CONCLUSIONS: IDOCC did not improve compliance with best practice guidelines.
