Our results showed a small statistically significant decrease in mean adherence of questionable clinical significance. Possible reasons for this result include implementation challenges, competing priorities in practice, a broad focus on multiple chronic disease indicators, and the use of an overall index of compliance. These results contrast with findings from previously reported facilitation trials and highlight the complexities and challenges involved in translating research findings into clinical practice. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00574808.

title: research agenda for quality palliative care
abstract: Palliative care has evolved from a misunderstood term and cautiously viewed by many clinicians to one of the most sought-after services in healthcare systems across the country. This is the greatest possible proof of the field's potential value. However, as demand has rapidly outstripped supply of palliative care professionals (1), the specialty's ability to sustainably provide quality care is paradoxically threatened by its own success. We propose a research agenda organized around 5 key questions on the optimal organization and allocation of limited resources in specialized palliative care to bridge the gap between staff and patient needs. The table provides key considerations and suggested approaches to address each research challenge. Amid a growing body of evidence on the potential value of specialized palliative care (2), we believe that answering these questions is essential to maximize value and inform much-needed guidelines to support such care (3).

title: resolution for doctors: time to focus on the public health threat posed by gun violence
A review of family intervention guidelines for pediatric-acquired brain injury
abstract: pediatric-acquired brain injury (BI) affects not only the child with the injury, but their family as well. Studies suggest that there is an increased incidence of psychological distress from caregivers and siblings after a child in the family has experienced BI. The functioning of the family after BI also affects the child's recovery. Reviewing the literature, we identified seven theoretical clinical guidelines for working with families of children and adolescents with BI. These clinical guidelines are to: (1) select developmentally appropriate interventions, (2) tailor the intervention to the family, (3) provide advocacy, (4) educate injuries, (5) focus on family realignment, (6) appropriately adjust the child's environment; and (7) teach skills to the family and the child. Existing research on family interventions in BI is reviewed in the context of these theoretical guidelines, and empirical support for each guideline is then assessed against specific criteria for empirically supported treatments. Unfortunately, there are very few randomized controlled trials and more research is needed to classify all clinical guidelines as “effective”. In addition, continued research will help educate professionals on specific approaches to use when working with a family of a child with BI. Currently, clinicians and researchers can draw on the existing clinical guidelines to overcome the numerous obstacles that arise from the implementation and investigation of family interventions for pediatric BI.

title: review of quantitative studies of adherence to clinical practice guidelines in the field of mental health
abstract: Guidelines for mental health clinical practice have proliferated, but there is little evidence of the extent to which they are actually implemented in clinical practice. The aim of this study was to find and review all peer-reviewed reports published up to the year 2000 that provide quantitative information on adherence to specific mental health guidelines. A literature search revealed 41 relevant studies. These studies were of three types: 26 were cross-sectional studies conducted after publication of guidelines, six were conducted before and after publication of guidelines without a specific intervention (before/after), and nine included a controlled study of a specific intervention. Only 37% were in the mental health field. Adequate adherence was found in 27% of cross-sectional and pre/post studies but in 67% of controlled studies. Successful interventions tended to be complex and required a system redesign or additional resources. Only six of 13 studies (46%) that also measured patient outcome found that better outcome was associated with better adherence to guidelines. Several studies showed that adherence rates returned to pre-intervention levels after the interventions ended. Thus, the evidence suggests that guideline adherence is not high without specific intervention, but that certain interventions (typically multifaceted and resource-intensive) improve adherence. However, the public health challenge is to design and implement interventions that are sustainable in mainstream clinical practice.

title: review of evidence of suboptimal adherence to standard/universal infection control precautions by healthcare professionals
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The review examines, from international research: the extent to which practitioners adhere to infection control precautions; the relevant issues considered to be influencing compliance; which strategies have been evaluated to induce positive behavior change among practitioners, and the impact of these interventions. BACKGROUND: Standard/Universal Precautions (UP) are internationally recognized as fundamental to the prevention and control of infection and effective in protecting physicians and patients. However, compliance has been problematic and the use of standard/UPs is suboptimal worldwide METHODS: Literature review identifying relevant evidence using multiple electronic databases, from 1994 to 2006, with a number of key terms used. Data was extracted using key headings, making analysis easier. RESULTS: Thirty-seven studies were reviewed. Twenty-four related to measuring practitioner compliance and 13 studies evaluating t The impact of a research intervention on compliance. In addition, other studies were included that examined the specific reasons for suboptimal compliance or discussed infection control precautions in general. CONCLUSIONS: Compliance with infection control precautions is suboptimal internationally. The evidence confirms that compliance with certain aspects of standards/UPs varies and practitioners are selective in applying recommended practice. Compliance improves after a structured intervention; however, the research does not indicate how long the intervention affects physician compliance or whether compliance returns to the norm after a period of time. Several reasons for non-compliance are discussed and recommendations are made for the future Research recommended Relevance to clinical practice Sub-optimal compliance has significant implications for staff safety, patient protection and the care environment Infection control teams and researchers need to understand the reasons for non-compliance Consider compliance and create a supportive environment conducive to routine, long-term application of standard precautions.

title: review of the literature on remote monitoring technology in incentive-based interventions for health-related behavior change.
abstract: The use of technology (eg, internet, cell phones) to remotely implement incentive interventions for health-related behavior change is increasing. To our knowledge, a systematic review of this published literature is still pending. This report provides a systematic review of controlled trials published between 2004 and 2015 that used technology to implement financial incentive interventions targeting substance use and other health behaviors. To be included in the review, studies had to use technology to achieve 1 of the following 2 goals, alone or in combination: (a) monitoring target behavior or (b) providing incentives to achieve the target goal. Studies also had to examine financial incentives (e.g., cash, vouchers) for health-related behavior changes, be published in peer-reviewed journals, and include a research design that evaluated the effectiveness of the incentive intervention compared to another condition (e.g., non conditional incentives, treatment as usual). Of the 39 reports that met the inclusion criteria, 18 were directed substance use, 10 were directed medication adherence or home health monitoring, and 11 were directed diet, exercise, or weight loss. All 39 (100%) studies used technology to facilitate remote monitoring of target behavior and 26 (66.7%) studies also incorporated technology into remote delivery of stimuli. Statistically significant intervention effects were reported in 71% of the studies reviewed. Overall, the results provide substantial support for the effectiveness of remote incentive interventions for health-related behavior change, which have the potential to increase the cost-effectiveness and outreach of this treatment approach. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: An overview of the use of laboratory tests: A catalyst for cost reductions and quality improvements in healthcare
abstract: BACKGROUND: Given the role of laboratory testing as a central part of controlling healthcare expenditure, this study intends to examine the overuse of laboratory testing in Iran to pave the way for future interventions. METHODS: Inappropriate laboratory use was assessed in a cross-sectional survey through the retrospective analysis of 384 medical records from a tertiary center. To pave the way for future interventions, overuse tests were classified into two categories, inappropriate and inefficient, and then analyzed. Frequency analysis was used to analyze patient age, gender, hospital ward, length of stay, and diagnosis, as well as inappropriate and ineffective testing. RESULTS: A total of 143 (1.50%) of the tests were inefficient and ordered because of laboratory errors such as hemolysis, inefficient sampling, or absurd results. 2522 (26.40%) of the tests were inappropriate, resulting from failure to meet medical/clinical appropriateness criteria. CONCLUSION: While inappropriate test ordering was more common than inefficient testing, the initial improvement strategy should focus on physicians' test ordering behavior through appropriate teaching strategies, continuous auditing and pedagogical feedback, implementation of health information technology tools, application of laboratory practice guidelines (LPGs) and testing algorithms . Where testing is inefficient, implementation of a continuous quality improvement cycle for laboratory services and training of personnel involved in blood collection is recommended.

title: simple intervention to improve hospital antibiotic prescribing
abstract: AIM: To evaluate changes in prescribing behavior after distribution of antibiotic guidelines printed on a 9 x 6 cm laminated card suitable for clipping to a hospital ID card. INTERVENTION: Guidelines for appropriate antibiotic prescribing for 20 common and important pediatric infections were printed on a laminated 9 x 6 cm card that can be clipped to a hospital ID card and distributed to all medical staff. DESIGN: We collected medical record data for three marker disorders (tonsillitis, pneumonia, and orbital/periorbital cellulitis) on patient samples from the 6-month periods on either side of the month in which the cards were distributed. The prescribing physicians were unaware of the study and the researchers analyzed the prescriptions without knowledge of the time period in which they were written. Prescriptions were evaluated for appropriate antibiotic choice and dose. Data on antibiotic costs were also collected. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Proportion of cases where antibiotic choice was appropriate; Proportion of cases where antibiotic dose was appropriate;' annualized cost of third-generation cephalosporins. RESULTS: In tonsillitis, prescribing practice changed little after the cards were introduced. In pneumonia, the number of cases with appropriate selection increased from 77% to 92% (p=0.028) and the number of cases with appropriate dose from 48% to 81% (p=0.001). For orbital/periorbital cellulitis, cases with appropriate choice increased from 19% to 78% (p<0.001) and cases with appropriate dose from 30% to 51% (p=0.11). The annualized cost of third-generation cephalosporins was $193,245 for precards and $89,814 for postcards. CONCLUSION: The maps appeared to have a positive effect on prescribing practice for the three marker conditions. This simple procedure is likely to be inexpensive and useful in reducing the inappropriate use of antibiotics.

title: simple way to improve adherence to the DVT protocol
abstract: Aim: To assess the impact on deep vein thrombosis (DVT) protocol violations by introducing a label attached to the patient's drug card that specifically allows the prescription of low-dose subcutaneous heparin or anti-thromboembolic stockings (TEDS). Design: An Audit Study. Setting: General Surgery Department of a District General Hospital in the United Kingdom. Method: All adult general surgery inpatients on a weekday were examined. The staff were not warned about the studies. Patient details and risk factors for DVT were noted. Details of the DVT prophylaxis administered were recorded. A total of four separate studies were conducted, namely: with original protocols (I), with refined protocol 1 and 3 years later (II, III) and finally after introduction of the label (IV). Results: Protocol violations were defined as "acceptable" or "unacceptable". Sensitization between Studies I and II reduced acceptable violations to zero. There was no statistically significant reduction in unacceptable injuries (24 of 80 patients, 1", 17 of 75, II, 13 of 60, III). In study IV, after the label was introduced, there were only 6 violations in 51 patients (p<0, 02) Conclusion: The combination of increased awareness with the attachment of a label to the drug table reduced unacceptable violations by 63%.

title: snapshot of primary care physician attitudes, levels of confidence, and self-reported asthma management in children
abstract: The prevalence of asthma in Australia is high. Previous findings suggest that asthma management, particularly in primary care, remains suboptimal, and recent government initiatives to improve asthma management and encourage the use of written asthma action plans (WAAPs) in general practice have been implemented. Our aim was to assess the attitudes, confidence and self-reported treatment practices of pediatric asthma in a sample of Australian general practitioners (GPs). A baseline questionnaire was administered to general practitioners as part of a randomized controlled trial. General Practitioners (GPs) were recruited from two areas of Greater Sydney, NSW between 2006 and 2008. Invitations were sent out to an estimated 1200 potential GPs. Of 150 (12.5%) participating general practitioners, 122 (10.2%) completed the baseline questionnaire. Although 89% were aware of the Australian National Asthma Guidelines, less than 40% were familiar with the guidelines' recommendations. While 85.2% had a positive attitude toward WAAPs, only 45.1% reported deploying them frequently. 90% agreed to prescribe daily inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) to children with common symptoms, and 83% said they currently prescribe ICS to such patients. These results point to gaps in primary care physician attitudes and behaviors, and highlight opportunities for interventions to improve pediatric asthma management.

title: nationwide controlled study intervention to reduce the use of unproven or ineffective breast cancer treatments
abstract: BACKGROUND: Challenged by public opinion, peers, and the Congressional Budget Office, medical societies have begun to compile "top five" lists of expensive procedures that do not provide significant benefit to at least some categories of patients for whom they are commonly ordered . However, the extent to which these lists influenced the behavior of physicians or patients is unknown. METHODS: We collaborated with a nationwide consortium of health systems to examine the effectiveness of two interventions: (i) "basic" public reporting and (ii) an "enhanced" intervention that augments public reporting with a smartphone-based application , the provider provides just-in-time information, decision support, and personalized patient education materials to help reduce the use of eight breast cancer interventions designated by Choosing Wisely(R) or Oncology Society guidelines. Our objectives are: (1) to examine whether basic public reporting reduces the use of targeted breast cancer practices in a current cohort of patients with new-onset breast cancer in the intervention state compared to usual care in comparator states; (2) to examine the effectiveness of the expanded intervention compared to the baseline intervention;" and (3) to simulate cost savings resulting from the nationwide implementation of both interventions. DISCUSSION: The results will provide rigorous evidence for the effectiveness of a unique public reporting system for provide all payers and all age groups for influencing provider behavior that can be easily exported to other states and potentially large healthcare systems as well.The results will continue to be relevant to the ACO environment, which is expected to create financial disincentives for provides ineffective or unproven care TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov number pending.

title: study of factors related to cost and variation in prescribing among primary care physicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: Inappropriate prescribing can harm both individuals and society. Previous research has identified physician or demographic characteristics that influence prescription variation that could not be changed. OBJECTIVES: To identify modifiable factors associated with primary care physician prescribing variability and costs. METHOD: Qualitative research methods were used in semi-structured taped interviews with 17 GPs in Avon, South West NHS Region, UK. RESULTS: GPs considered themselves cautious and conservative prescribers. Prescribing decisions were often justified by the prescribing physician despite conflicting clinical or cost arguments. A personally developed drug formula was used to reduce dilemmas potentially associated with prescription uncertainty. The willingness to reflect on prescribing habits and to measure them against established professional standards varied greatly. The lack of monitoring mechanisms for prescribing decisions, coupled with underutilization of the community pharmacist, led to uncertain prescribing outcomes. Some GPs found it difficult to keep up to date professionally due to time constraints. Excessive patient demand was thought to affect their prescribing, but GPs indicated they were not unduly influenced by the drug representative. CONCLUSIONS: Prescribing has significant health and budget implications, yet remains a controversial issue. Improved partnerships between patient, doctor and pharmacist need to be established. Better monitoring of the prescribing decision and support through policy development and educational interventions is needed to reduce prescribing uncertainty. Newly formed primary care groups may need to reflect on the difficulties prescribers face, particularly when prescribing within a limited budget, to avoid conflicts between prescribing behavior and local policy development.

title: successful experiment in reducing unnecessary laboratory use at a community hospital
abstract: series of interventions in a 228-bed general hospital provided physicians with periodic feedback on the amount of laboratory services expended in treating their patients. Case-mix-adjusted estimates of laboratory tests allowed each physician to compare laboratory test use to that of colleagues in the same department at the same hospital. Physicians with "excessive" practice patterns ordered hundreds more lab tests than average each year. A multifaceted training program included the following: 1) discussions were held on costs and unnecessary laboratory tests; 2) Physicians received descriptions of their practice patterns compared to their peers in large and small departmental discussions; 3) the feedback was repeat one year later; 4) a consensus conference established guidelines for test ordering;" and 5) a sample of patient charts were reviewed for appropriateness of ordering laboratory tests. A total of 37% of a sample of tests ordered during the baseline period by physicians with "excessive" practice patterns were deemed inappropriate The intervention resulted in a reduction of 1.8 tests per patient (P=0.0005) Eight of the nine tests individually showed a reduction in usage Fee data from the target hospital showed a statistically significant reduction in laboratory fees per patient in the quarter after the start of the program (P=0.02) and no evidence of change in a group of five comparator hospitals There was no evidence of cuts in the ordering of essential tests These results demonstrate a cost-effective approach to reducing unnecessary costs , which can be implemented in hospitals with integrated data systems n.

title: survey of tobacco-related knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors of primary care providers in Mississippi
abstract: Rationale: Compared to other regions in the US, Mississippi has a high prevalence of tobacco use and tobacco-related diseases. This study examined the tobacco-related knowledge, attitudes, and intervention behaviors of primary care physicians, dentists, and nurse practitioners in the state of Mississippi. METHODS: The Provider Attitude Survey, an 85-item measurement of tobacco-related knowledge, attitudes, and intervention behaviors, was mailed to all members of the Mississippi family medicine, dentistry, and nursing professional organizations (N=2043). RESULTS: More than a third (n=802, 39.2%) of eligible providers responded. Only 24.3% had received tobacco cessation training and 33.7% were aware of the Public Health Service's clinical practice guideline. Over 90% said it was their job to prevent tobacco use"; felt rewarded for helping patients quit;" and were concerned and upset about the health effects of tobacco. Doctors cared for more patients than nurses or dentists. Physicians and nurses reported greater self-efficacy, motivation, and willingness to treat tobacco use than dentists. Providers with training performed more interventions and reported greater self-efficacy, willingness, and fewer barriers than providers without training. The training was associated with greater increases in self-efficacy, willingness, and intervention behavior in dentists than in the other groups. CONCLUSIONS: Despite a high prevalence of tobacco use and tobacco-related diseases in Mississippi, primary care physicians in Mississippi provide tobacco cessation interventions at an unacceptably low frequency compared to other regions. Training is likely to increase the frequency of interventional behaviors.

title: sustainable strategy to prevent antibiotic misuse in acute respiratory infections
abstract: Background Over 50% of antibiotic prescriptions are prescribed for ambulatory patients with Acute Respiratory Tract Infections (ARI). Many of them are not needed, thus contributing to both preventable adverse events and pressure to develop bacterial resistance. Could a clinical decision support system (CDSS) interposed at the time of e-prescribing align antibiotic use with consensus treatment guidelines for ARI? Methods This is a retrospective comparison of the pre-intervention (2002) and post-intervention periods (2003-2006) in two comprehensive health systems (intervention and control). The intervention was a CDSS targeting fluoroquinolone and azithromycin; other antibiotics remained unrestricted. 7000 outpatient visits flagged by an ARI case finding algorithm were checked for compliance with guidelines (antibiotic prescribed when warranted or not prescribed when unwarranted). Results 3831 patients met case definitions for one or more ARIs: pneumonia (537), bronchitis (2931), sinusitis (717), and non-specific ARI (145). All patients with pneumonia received antibiotics. The relative risk (RR) of congruent prescribing was 2.57 (95% CI?=?(1.865 to 3.540) in favor of the intervention site for the antibiotics targeted by the CDSS; congruence did not change for other antibiotics (adjusted RR? =?1.18 (95% CI?=?(0.691 to 2.011)) The proportion of unjustified prescriptions for the targeted antibiotics decreased from 22% to 3%, before vs. after the intervention (p<0.0001). eradicated unjustified use of targeted antibiotics for ARI for four years This intervention provides a path to sustainable antibiotic use for outpatients with ARI.

title: systematic qualitative analysis of psychoeducational interventions for depression in cancer patients
abstract: PURPOSE/OBJECTIVES: To determine whether research-based recommendations can be made for clinical management of depression in cancer patients. DATA SOURCES: Reports of scientific studies, qualitative or quantitative systematic reviews of scientific studies, and practice guidelines published from 1980-2000. Data Synthesis: A total of 36 pieces of evidence supported the conclusion that psychoeducational interventions benefit depressive symptoms. Evidence included two well-conducted meta-analyses and nine well-designed, large-sample (N>100) randomized clinical trials. Regarding the content of the intervention, 70% of the behavioral therapy studies and 66% of the counseling studies came to conclusions that supported the hypothesis. Additionally, 58% of the studies that tested behavioral therapy or counseling in combination with cancer education had positive results. CONCLUSIONS: Evidence supports the conclusion that psychoeducational interventions reduce depressive symptoms in cancer patients and that behavioral therapy or counseling alone or in combination with cancer education is beneficial. IMPLICATIONS FOR NURSING PRACTICE: Nurses may choose from a variety of educational, behavioral, and counseling techniques to help prevent or manage depression in their patients.

title: systematic review of clinical decision support systems for antimicrobial management: are we failing to adequately examine these interventions?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Clinical decision support systems (CDSS) for antimicrobial management can assist physicians in optimizing antimicrobial therapy. We reviewed all original literature (qualitatively and quantitatively) to understand the current scope of CDSS for antimicrobial management and to analyze existing methods used to evaluate and report on such systems. METHOD: PRISMA guidelines were followed. The Medline, EMBASE, HMIC Health and Management, and Global Health databases were searched from January 1, 1980 to October 31, 2015. All primary research studies describing CDSS for antimicrobial management in adults in primary or secondary care were included. A thematic synthesis was carried out for qualitative studies. The quality was assessed using the ICROMS criteria (Integrated Quality Criteria for the Review Of Multiple Study Designs). CDSS reporting was assessed against a reporting framework for implementing behavior change interventions. RESULTS: Fifty-eight original articles were included describing 38 independent CDSS. The majority of systems target antimicrobial prescription (29/38; 76%), are platforms integrated with electronic medical records (28/38; 74%), and have rules-based infrastructure that provide decision support (29th /38; 76%). When evaluated against the intervention reporting framework, CDSS studies fail to report accounting for non-competent end-user workflow. They have a narrow focus, such as B. antimicrobial agent selection, and use proxy outcome measures. Clinician commitment to CDSS was low. CONCLUSION: When designing CDSS interventions, greater consideration needs to be given to the factors driving non-expert decision-making. Future work must aim to expand CDSS beyond simply selecting appropriate antimicrobials, with clear and systematic reporting frameworks for CDSS interventions designed to address current gaps identified in evidence reporting.

title: systematic review of computerized patient record systems and quality of care: more randomized clinical trials or a broader approach?
abstract: PURPOSE: To analyze the impact of computerized health record systems (CBPRS) on medical practice, quality of care, and user and patient satisfaction. DATA SOURCES: Manual and electronic searches of Medline, Cochrane and Embase databases. STUDY SELECTION: Selected articles were published from 2000 to March 2003. CBPRS was defined as computer software to be used by clinicians as a direct aid in clinical decision-making. To be included, systems should have recorded patient characteristics and offered online counseling or information or reminders specific to clinicians during the consultation. DATA EXTRACTION: The keywords used for the search were: electronic record, informatics record, electronic medical record, electronic medical record, patient order entry, computerized patient system, clinical decision support systems, and assessment. RESULTS: Twenty-six articles were selected. The use of a CBPRS was perceived positively by physicians, with satisfaction studies being overwhelmingly positive. A positive impact of CBPRS on prevention was observed in all three studies that examined this criterion. The 12 studies examining the impact on medical practice and adherence to guidelines showed that positive experiences were just as common as experiences that showed no benefit. None of the six studies that analyzed the impact of CBPRS on patient outcomes reported benefit. CONCLUSIONS: CBPRS increased user and patient satisfaction, which could lead to significant improvements in medical care. However, studies on the impact of CBPRS on patient outcomes and quality of care have been inconclusive. Alternative approaches considering social, cultural and organizational factors may be required to assess the usefulness of CBPRS.

title: systematic review of HIV/AIDS prevention education among older adults
abstract: Through an extensive literature search, the authors of this systematic review identified 21 articles that focused on the primary prevention of HIV/AIDS for adults 50 years and older. Three major challenges in providing HIV/AIDS education to older adults are age discrimination by health professionals, older adults' reluctance to talk about sex, and their misconceptions about their HIV risk. Clinical guidelines for social workers, nurses and physicians have highlighted the importance of information sharing and risk assessment, taking into account cultural diversity and developing creative implementation strategies. Three models of HIV/AIDS education include group education programs conducted by social workers or other health professionals, peer education models, and one-to-one early intervention models, including HIV/AIDS testing. Additional outreach and research on HIV/AIDS prevention in older adults is needed.

title: systematic review of faculty development initiatives to improve teaching effectiveness in medical education: BEME Guide #8
abstract: BACKGROUND: Preparing healthcare professionals for teaching is considered essential to improving teaching effectiveness. Although many reports describe various faculty development interventions, there is little research to support their effectiveness. AIM: To summarize the existing evidence on the question, "What are the effects of faculty development interventions on the knowledge, attitudes, and skills of medical education teachers and the institutions in which they work?" Period 1980-2002, included three databases (Medline, ERIC and EMBASE) and used the keywords: "personnel development", "in-service training", "medical faculty", "faculty training/development"; advanced medical education. Manual searches were also conducted. Articles focused on faculty development to improve teaching effectiveness, targeting basic and clinical scientists, were reviewed. All study designs that included outcome data beyond participant satisfaction were accepted. From an initial 2777 abstracts, 53 articles met the review criteria. Data were extracted from six coders using the standardized BEME coding sheet, which was adapted for our use. Each study was coded by two reviewers, and coding differences were resolved through discussion. Data were synthesized using Kirkpatrick's four levels of educational outcomes. Outcomes were grouped by type of intervention and described by outcome level. In addition, 8 high-quality studies were analyzed in a "focused image". RESULTS: The majority of the interventions were targeted at practicing clinicians. All reports focused on instructional improvement, and interventions included workshops, seminar series, short courses, longitudinal programs, and 'other interventions'. Study designs included 6 randomized controlled trials and 47 quasi-experimental studies, 31 of which used a pre-test-post-test design. KEY POINTS: Despite methodological limitations, the literature on faculty development tends to support the following findings: Overall satisfaction with faculty development programs was high. Participants consistently found the programs acceptable, useful, and relevant to their goals. Participants reported positive changes in attitudes towards faculty development and teaching. Participants reported improved knowledge of pedagogical principles and gains in teaching skills. Significant gains were seen where formal knowledge tests were used. Changes in teaching behavior were repeatedly reported by the participants and also noted by the students. Changes in organizational practice and student learning have not been widely studied. However, reported changes included greater participation in education and the establishment of higher education networks. Key characteristics of effective faculty development that contribute to effectiveness included the use of experiential learning, the provision of feedback, effective relationships with peers and colleagues, well-designed interventions that follow principles of teaching and learning, and the use of a variety of educational methods within individual interventions. Methodological issues: More rigorous designs and greater use of qualitative and mixed methods are needed to capture the complexity of the interventions. Newer methods of performance-based assessment using different data sources should be investigated and reliable and valid outcome measures should be developed. Sustaining change over time should be considered, as well as process-oriented studies comparing different faculty development strategies. CONCLUSIONS: Teacher development activities seem to be highly valued by participants, who also report changes in learning and behavior. Notwithstanding methodological limitations in the literature, certain program characteristics appear to be consistently associated with effectiveness. Further research is needed to explore these relationships and to document the results at an individual and organizational level.

title: tailored intervention to implement guideline recommendations for older patients with depression in primary care: a pragmatic cluster-randomized study
abstract: Background Elderly patients with depression are underdiagnosed, undertreated and at high risk for chronic disease. General practitioners follow clinical practice guidelines to a limited extent. In the international research project Tailored Implementation for Chronic Diseases, we tested the effectiveness of tailored interventions to improve the care of patients with chronic diseases. In Norway, we investigated this approach to improve adherence to six guideline recommendations for elderly patients with depression, addressed to healthcare professionals, patients, and administrators. Methods We conducted a cluster randomized study in 80 Norwegian municipalities. We identified practice determinants for six recommendations and then tailored interventions to address these determinants. Targeted at healthcare professionals, administrators and patients, the interventions consisted of outreach visits, a website presenting the recommendations and the underlying evidence, tools for treating depression in the elderly, and other web-based resources, including a continuing education course for general practitioner. The primary outcome was mean adherence to recommendations. Secondary outcomes were an improvement in depression symptoms as measured by patients and primary care physicians. We offered outreach visits to all general practitioners and practice staff in the intervention communities. We used electronic software that extracted eligible patients from GP lists. We collected data by interviewing GPs or sending them a questionnaire about their practice for four patients on their list and by sending a questionnaire to the patients. Results 124 of the 900 general practitioners (14%) took part in the data collection, 51 in the intervention group and 73 in the control group. We interviewed 77 general practitioners, 47 general practitioners completed the questionnaire and 134 patients answered the questionnaire. Among the primary care physicians who provided data, adherence to recommendations was 1.6 percentage points higher in the intervention group than in the control group (95% CI -6 to 9). Conclusions The effectiveness of our tailored intervention to implement recommendations for elderly patients with depression in primary care is uncertain due to the low response rate to data collection. However, it is unlikely that the effect was large. It remains uncertain how compliance with evidence-based recommendations, and thus the quality of care, can best be improved for these patients. ClinicalTrials.gov trial registration: NCT01913236.

title: Teachable Moment Communication Process for Smoking Cessation Conversations: Description of a Group-Randomized Clinically-Focused Intervention
abstract: BACKGROUND: Effective physician-patient communication about health behavior change is one of the most important and most overlooked strategies for promoting health and preventing disease. Existing guidelines for specific health behavior counseling have been created and published but have not been successfully adopted in primary care practice. Building on work focused on developing effective clinical strategies to promote health behavior change in primary care, we developed an intervention aimed at improving clinicians' communication skills to create and respond to teachable moments for smoking cessation . In this manuscript, we describe the development and implementation of the Teachable Moment Communication Process (TMCP) intervention and the baseline features of a randomized group study to evaluate its effectiveness. METHODS/DESIGN: This randomized group study included thirty-one community-based general practitioners practicing in northeast Ohio and 840 of their adult patients. Clinicians were randomly assigned to receive either the Teachable Moments Communication Process (TMCP) smoking cessation intervention or the delayed intervention. The TMCP intervention consisted of two 3-hour training sessions, including didactic presentation, demonstration of skills through video examples, exercises with standardized patients, and feedback from peers and the trainers. For each enrolled clinician, 12 patients were recruited for two time points. Before and after the intervention, data were collected from the clinicians, patients, and audio recordings of clinician-patient interactions. At baseline, the two groups of physicians and their patients were similar across all demographics and practice characteristics examined. Both physician and patient recruitment targets were met, and retention was 96% and 94%, respectively. DISCUSSION: The results support the feasibility of training physicians to use the Teachable Moments communication process. The next steps are to assess how well physicians are using these skills in their practices and assess the impact on patient outcomes. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01575886.

title: telephone coaching intervention to improve asthma self-management behaviors
abstract: Recognizing that asthma, one of the most common chronic childhood diseases, is difficult to treat, the National Asthma Education Prevention Program has developed clinical practice guidelines to support healthcare providers, particularly those in primary care. However, asthma maintenance care still does not meet national standards. Therefore, in an attempt to improve and support asthma self-management behaviors in parents of children aged 5 to 12 with persistent asthma, a novel telephone coaching intervention for nurses was tested in a randomized controlled trial. A detailed description of the intervention is provided along with parent satisfaction results, an overview of the training used to prepare caregivers, and a discussion of challenges experienced and lessons learned.

title: theory of international bioethics: the negotiable and the non-negotiable
abstract: The previous article in this issue of the Kennedy Institute of Ethics Journal presents the argument that "moral fundamentalism," the position that international bioethics rests on "fundamental" or "fundamental" moral principles universally accepted across eras and cultures under which a multitude of multicultural and postmodern critiques collapse. This article considers the contractarian tradition of Hobbes and Locke - reinterpreted by David Gauthier, Robert Nozick and John Rawls - for an alternative justification of international bioethics. Drawing on the central themes of this tradition, it is argued that international bioethics can be rationally reconstructed as a negotiated moral order that respects culturally and individually defined areas of non-negotiability. Furthermore, the theory of a negotiated moral order is consistent with traditional human rights ideals, flexible enough to accommodate the genuine insights of multiculturalism and postmodernism, yet strong enough to justify transcultural and transtemporal moral judgments, including condemnation of the Nazi doctors in Nuremberg. This theory is also consistent with the history of the ethics of human experimentation, providing insight into current controversies such as the controversy over changing the consent rule for experiments in emergency medicine and the controversy over the exemption of certain clinical trials of inexpensive treatments to prevent perinatal disease transmission AIDS from the ethical standards of the sponsoring country.

title: theory-based educational intervention targeting nurses' attitudes and knowledge regarding cancer-related pain management: a study protocol with quasi-experimental design
abstract: BACKGROUND: Pain is one of the most common problems in cancer patients. Despite the availability of effective pharmacological treatments, this patient population is often not managed optimally. Research on nurse pain management highlights certain factors such as: B. lack of knowledge and attitudes and inadequate methods for systematic pain assessment, as common obstacles to effective pain management. However, educational interventions targeting caregiver pain management have shown promise. As cancer-related pain is also known to have a negative impact on vital aspects of the patient's life and is often associated with problems such as sleep, fatigue, depression and anxiety, further development of knowledge in this area is warranted. METHODS/DESIGN: In a quasi-experimental study design, it will be investigated whether the implementation of guidelines for systematic daily pain assessment after a theory-based educational intervention leads to an improvement in the knowledge and attitude of nursing staff. Another aim is to investigate whether the intervention targeting nurse behavior improves the pain perception of hospitalized patients. Data on nurses' knowledge and attitudes about pain (primary outcome), patients' pain perception (secondary outcome), along with sociodemographic variables, will be collected at baseline, four weeks, and 12 weeks after the intervention. DISCUSSION: Nursing is now recognized as an increasingly complicated activity and "the complexity of nursing is such that it can be considered the quintessence of complex intervention". In order to be able to change and improve clinical practice, several points of attack are required that are suitable for overcoming complex challenges. Consequently, we expect that the theory-based intervention used in our quasi-experimental study will improve care as well as quality of life in this patient population, and we also envision that evidence-based guidelines targeting pain in this patient population will be more widely implemented. STUDY REGISTRATION NUMBER: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT01313234.

title: tool for assessing a community's capacity for substance abuse treatment
abstract: Evidence-based substance abuse prevention and intervention programs are on the rise. Community needs assessments and health rankings provide descriptions of local behavioral health needs, but do not provide guidance to public health practitioners and policy makers as to the number of programs, health practitioners, or interventions required in the local addiction care system. This article introduces a new framework for measuring and evaluating the substance abuse care system in a community. Assessment can inform resource allocation across the continuum of care to distribute interventions and care more equitably and efficiently. We conducted two literature reviews and combined our findings to create a community assessment methodology and needs calculator, CAST (Calculation for an Appropriate System Tool). We reviewed 212 articles to create an inventory of the community and social correlates of behavioral health, components of a substance abuse care system, and numerical scores for guidelines for estimating community needs. CAST produces community-specific assessments of the capacity of the components of a community-based addiction support system. CAST generates recommendations by applying social and community health determinants as risk coefficients to each component need estimate. CAST can assist public health practitioners in evaluating and improving the capacity of community-based substance abuse treatment systems. By using recommendations for component needs across the care continuum, community leaders can use CAST to prioritize resource allocation more effectively and efficiently.

title: universal preventive education intervention for healthcare workers in Sardjito and PKU Hospital in Indonesia
abstract: non-randomized control study was conducted to design and evaluate a culturally appropriate scientific study detailing the intervention on the general knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors of health care workers in hospitals regarding precautionary measures. The study involved 55 healthcare workers (44 nurses and 11 doctors). They were visited individually to discuss the principles of universal precautions and the impact of the automatic pilot on their work practices. Self-reported knowledge and attitude measures were collected from each participant before and after the intervention. A care observer recorded measurements of participants' adherence to general precautionary guidelines according to a pre-established protocol before and after the procedure. There were significantly different levels of knowledge, attitudes, and adherence to general precautions between the control and intervention hospitals, with p = 0.0007, p = 0.038, and p = 0.03 after the intervention, respectively. It is concluded that an academic detailing approach to education used in this study significantly improved knowledge, attitudes, and compliance scores.

title: cluster-randomized study of decision support strategies to reduce antibiotic use in acute bronchitis
abstract: Background National quality indicators show little change in antibiotic overuse in uncomplicated acute bronchitis. We compared the effect of 2 decision support strategies on antibiotic treatment of uncomplicated acute bronchitis. Methods We conducted a 3-arm randomized cluster study among 33 primary care practices belonging to an integrated health care system in central Pennsylvania. The printed decision support intervention sites (11 practices) received decision support for acute cough disorders through a print-based strategy, the computer-assisted decision support intervention sites (11 practices) received decision support through an electronic medical record-based strategy, and the control sites (11 practices) served as the control arm. Both intervention centers also received clinical training and feedback on prescribing practices, as well as patient information booklets at check-in. In an intent-to-treat analysis, antibiotic prescription rates for uncomplicated acute bronchitis in the winter period (October 1, 2009 to March 31, 2010) after the introduction of the intervention were compared to the previous 3 winter periods. Results Compared to the baseline period, the proportion of adolescents and adults who prescribed antibiotics during the intervention period increased at the printed decision support intervention sites (from 80.0% to 68.3%) and at the computer-based decision support intervention sites (from 74.0 % to 60.7%), but increased slightly at the checkpoints (from 72.5% to 74.3%). After controlling for patient and physician characteristics and clustering observations by physician and practice location, the differences for intervention centers versus control centers were statistically significant (P = 0.003 for control centers vs. intervention centers with printed decision-making aids and P = 0.003). 0.01 for control sites vs. intervention sites for computer-aided decision support), but not among themselves (P=.67 for printed intervention sites for decision-support vs. intervention sites for computer-aided decision support). The changes in overall visits, 30-day repeat visit rates, and proportion diagnosed with uncomplicated acute bronchitis were similar across study sites. Conclusions Implementing a decision support strategy for acute bronchitis can help reduce antibiotic overuse in primary care. The effect of printed vs. computer-based decision support strategies in providing decision support was equivalent.

title: Personality and behavior abnormalities in adults (Section F 6) - results of the ICD-10 field trial
abstract: Personality disorders, the main category of Section F6, were examined in the ICD-10 field trial. The overall kappa values for interrater reliability of section F6 are 0.64, for personality disorders 0.61, and for dyssocial personality 0.73. These results are very close to those of the DSM-III field trials. Subjective assessments of feasibility, suitability, and quality of fit show good acceptance of the diagnostic guidelines by clinicians. A comparison of ICD-9, DSM-III, and ICD-10 diagnoses revealed broad agreement for personality disorder diagnoses with overlapping kappa values of 0.91 and 0.94. A number of improvements and the planned introduction of a multi-axis system have increased the acceptance and reliability of the new classification.

title: Academic detail does not affect asthma medication prescribing in Danish general practice: a 3-year randomized controlled trial with 12-month follow-ups
abstract: BACKGROUND: Educational visits, particularly when combined with social marketing, appear to be a promising approach to modifying health-care worker behavior, particularly prescribing. Results of previous studies have shown a different effect. OBJECTIVE: The aim of the study is to investigate the effect of academic detailing as a method for implementing clinical guidelines in general practice. METHODS: A cluster-randomized, controlled, blinded study was conducted on the effect of an academic detail visit versus postal distribution of a guideline for asthma medication prescription. Half of the practices in a Danish county with 100 practices were visited once. Outcome measurement consisted of routinely collected data from all Danish pharmacies on the sale of asthma medication. Data were collected monthly for 2 years before and 1 year after the intervention. RESULTS: There was no effect on post-visit asthma medication prescribing pattern, either immediate or long-term. CONCLUSION: We found no effect of academic detailing as a single intervention.

title: Access to medical records for medical review purposes
accident prevention
Accuracy of rapid and point-of-care screening tests for hepatitis C
Achieving change in primary care - root causes of the evidence-to-practice gap: systematic reviews of assessments
abstract: Background This study aims to identify, summarize, and synthesize literature on the causes of the evidence-to-practice gap for complex interventions in primary care. Design This study is a systematic review of reviews. The MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, Cochrane Library, and PsychINFO methods were searched from inception through December 2013. Appropriate reviews have addressed the causes of the evidence for the practice gap in primary care in developed countries. Data from included reviews were extracted and synthesized using guidelines for meta-synthesis. Results Seventy reviews met the inclusion criteria and covered a wide range of topics, such as guideline implementation, integration of new roles, technology implementation, public health, and preventive medicine. None of the included papers used the term â€˜causeâ€™ or stated any intention to investigate causes at all. A descriptive approach was often used and the papers included expressed the causes in terms of obstacles and facilitators to implementation. We have developed a four-tiered framework covering the external context, the organization, the professionals and the intervention. External contextual factors included policies, incentive structures, dominant paradigms, stakeholders, infrastructure, and technological advances. Organizational factors included culture, available resources, integration into existing processes, relationships, skill mix, and employee ownership. At the level of the individual professionals, the professional role, underlying philosophy of care and competencies were important. Characteristics of the intervention that impacted implementation included evidence of benefit, ease of use, and adaptability to local circumstances. We posit that the â€˜fitâ€™ between the intervention and the context is critical to the success of implementation. Conclusions This comprehensive review of reviews summarizes current knowledge about the barriers and facilitations to the implementation of various complex interventions in primary care. To maximize the acceptability of complex interventions in primary care, health professionals and commissioning organizations should consider the range of contextual factors and remain aware of the dynamic nature of context. Future studies should focus on describing the context and articulating the relationships between the factors identified here.

title: Achievement of guidelines for treating depression in primary care: is medical education sufficient?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The authors investigate whether continuing medical education has a lasting impact on the treatment of depression. METHODS: Depressed primary care patients initiating antidepressant treatment from primary care clinics of a staff model health maintenance organization were studied. Quasi-experimental and before-and-after comparisons of medical practices, supplemented by patient surveys, served to compare the course of care and depression outcomes. The intervention consisted of comprehensive medical training spanning a period of 12 months. This included individual case advice, didactics, scientific detailing (e.g. clear naming of the educational and behavioral goals for the individual doctors) and role-playing games for optimal treatment. Main Outcome Measures were divided into two groups. Quasi-experimental samples included: (1) choice of antidepressant and (2) appropriateness (dose and duration) of pharmacotherapy. Survey samples included: (3) intensity of follow-up; (4) Physicians delivered educational messages about treating depression; (5) Patient Satisfaction;' and (6) Depression Scores. RESULTS: No sustained educational effect was consistently observed for any of the outcomes measured. CONCLUSIONS: There was no sustained improvement in the management of depression in primary care patients. At the same time, however, guidelines were established for the treatment of depression for intervention patients who participated in a multifaceted cooperative care program during the training period. These results suggest that the continuation of reorganized service delivery programs to support the role of a primary care physician (e.g., on-site mental health staff, close monitoring of patient progress and adherence to therapy) in addition to physician education is critical to success of essential are policy implementation.

title: Smoking cessation campaign for suspected tuberculosis (ASSIST) in Pakistan
abstract: Background: Tobacco use is responsible for a large part of the total burden of disease from tuberculosis. Pakistan is one of the 10 countries with a high burden of tuberculosis and tobacco use. Aim: To evaluate the effectiveness of a behavioral support intervention and bupropion in achieving 6 months of continuous abstinence in adult smokers with suspected pulmonary tuberculosis. Design: Cluster randomized controlled study. (Recent controlled studies: ISRCTN08829879) Setting: Health centers in Jhang and Sargodha districts of Pakistan. Patients: 1955 adult smokers with suspected tuberculosis. Intervention: Health centers were randomly assigned to provide 2 short behavioral support (BSS) sessions, BSS plus 7 weeks of bupropion therapy (BSS+), or usual care. Measurements: The primary endpoint was continued abstinence 6 months after the termination date and was determined by the patients' carbon monoxide levels. Secondary endpoints were point abstinence at 1 and 6 months. Results: Both treatments resulted in statistically significant relative risks (RRs) for abstinence compared to usual treatment (RR for BSS+, 8.2 [95% CI, 3.7 to 18.2]"; RR for BSS, 7.4 [CI, 3.4 to 16.4]).Equivalence between treatments could not be established.In the BSS+ group, 275 of 606 patients (45.4% [CI, 41.4% to 49.4% ]) sustained abstinence compared to 254/620 (41.0% [CI, 37.1% to 45.0%]) in the BSS group and 52/615 (8.5% [CI, 6.4 % to 10.9%]) in the usual care group There was significant heterogeneity in program effects between clusters Limitations: imbalances in urban and rural conditions and smoking habits between treatment groups and inability to maintain bupropion treatment adherence to confirm and validate longer-term abstinence or the effect of smoking cessation on tuberculosis outcomes Reason: Behavioral support alone or in combination with bupropion is effective in promoting smoking cessation in suspected tuberculosis. Primary source of funding: International Development Research Centre.

title: Acute B virus hepatitis becomes fulminant after infection with hepatitis A virus
Acute coronary syndromes without ST segment elevation. From randomized clinical trials to consensus guidelines to clinical practice in Italy, the circle must be closed
abstract: Recent therapeutic advances in the treatment of acute ischemic heart disease have been supported by randomized clinical trials and formal practice guidelines. This rigorous approach has resulted in significant reductions in mortality and morbidity across the spectrum of acute coronary syndromes (ACS). However, contemporary registries of non-ST elevation ACS established by the cardiology community in Italy, as well as in the rest of Europe and in America, have shown limited compliance with the general indication of early treatment of high-risk patients using an invasive approach, protected by the Use of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor blockers. This partial failure in the process of improving patient care can be attributed to several reasons, including suspicions that practice guidelines may be skewed by conflicts of interest, concerns about the applicability of clinical trial results to the real world, unrealistic expectations of treatment implications, and finally logistical ones and economic obstacles, including the availability of cath labs and the high cost of platelet receptor blockers. Although the practice guidelines can provide cultural support for translating clinical research findings into patient care, national and local cardiology associations can help raise awareness of the real benefits of an early aggressive approach in high-risk patients, so health care managers should remove bureaucratic roadblocks and reallocate resources from treatments with unproven benefits to those that have been shown to reduce mortality and risk of reinfarction in ACS patients.

title: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy and diagnosis by computed tomography
abstract: 39-year-old woman was admitted to a maternity ward at 34 weeks pregnant with nausea, vomiting and jaundice. Her condition worsened and she was hospitalized deeply unconscious and hypotensive. The diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy was originally suggested by the typical history of prodromal malaise and vomiting and the rapid onset of hepatic encephalopathy with severe hypoglycemia and only small increases in transaminase activity. Computed tomography was performed: there was no enlargement of the liver or spleen, but the decimation over the liver indicated significant fatty degeneration of the liver, establishing the diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Computed tomography is of value in diagnosing liver disease late in pregnancy, and this technique may become the method of choice for examining acute fatty liver in pregnancy.

title: Adding evidence-based interventions to assertive community treatment: a feasibility study
abstract: AIM: This 24-month study, conducted in the Netherlands, evaluated the feasibility of improving the effectiveness of assertive community treatment (ACT) by adding evidence-based interventions. METHODS: A total of 159 patients were randomly assigned to two ACT teams, one standard ACT (N585) and one ACT-plus team that also performed evidence-based interventions (N574): psychoeducation, family interventions, individual placement and support, as well as cognitive behavioral therapy. The interventions were delivered by psychologists and nurses working independently of the ACT team. RESULTS: Although most patients were rated eligible for each of the four interventions (range 65% to 89%), only 12 of the 74 patients (16%) successfully completed an intervention. The results, such as B. the use of inpatient care, for ACT-Plus and standard ACT patients did not differ significantly. CONCLUSIONS: Guidelines for the treatment of schizophrenia should consider the feasibility of providing evidence-based interventions for hard-to-reach patients.

title: Add exercise or subtract sedentary time for glycemic control: where do we stand?
abstract: While regular structured exercise is a well-established (though arguably underutilized) cornerstone in the prevention and management of type 2 diabetes, population adherence to recommended exercise guidelines remains stubbornly low. In fact, most adults are exposed to environmental conditions (at work, driving, and in the home) that not only limit their physical activity, but also encourage sedentary behavior for prolonged periods. However, recent experimental evidence suggests that reducing and disrupting sedentary time may also be a useful strategy for improving glycemic control. In this issue of Diabetologia, Duvivier and colleagues report results suggesting that reducing sedentary time through standing and low-intensity activities could be a possible alternative to structured exercise for improving glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes. We review and discuss the results of this study, their potential clinical implications, and a number of knowledge gaps and opportunities that could be addressed in the interest of future research. Duvivier and colleagues' findings should encourage healthcare professionals, researchers and patients with type 2 diabetes to consider the full spectrum of physical activity, from sedentary behaviors to structured exercise.

title: Adding motivational interventions to exercise and traditional physical therapy: a review and meta-analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Undeniable epidemiological trends suggest that an escalation of chronic lifestyle-related diseases will dominate mortality and morbidity for the foreseeable future. International guidelines recommend the implementation of evidence-based approaches to changing health behavior. Motivational interventions to increase adherence and physical activity are not part of traditional physical therapy for any condition. AIM: To evaluate the evidence for the effectiveness of adding motivational interventions to traditional physical therapy to increase physical activity and short- and long-term adherence to exercise regimens. DATA SOURCES: A literature search of PubMed, EMBASE, Scopus, CINAHL, PsychINFO, AMED, and the Allied Health Evidence database using keywords and headwords. STUDY SELECTION: Only randomized controlled trials comparing two or more arms were included, with one arm focusing on motivational interventions to influence exercise and a control arm. The search identified 493 titles, of which 14 studies (with 1504 participants) were included. DATA EXTRACTION: The principal investigator extracted data that was independently verified by another author. Methodological quality was assessed independently by two authors using the Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool and the PEDro scale. Outcomes were measured at the impairment, activity limitation, and attendance limitation levels. The standardized mean difference between the control and intervention group at the follow-up times was used as the analysis mode. I2</=50% was used as the threshold for acceptable heterogeneity, above which a random effects model was applied. RESULTS: Training participation was measured in six studies (n=378) and the results show that there was no significant difference in training participation between groups (random effects model, standardized mean difference 0.33, 95% confidence interval - 0.03 to 0.68, I2 62%). Results on perceived self-efficacy were pooled from six studies (n=722) and a significant difference between groups in favor of the interventions was found (fixed effects model, standardized mean difference 0.71, 95% confidence interval 0.55 to 0.87, I2 41%). Activity limitation results were pooled (n=550) and there was a significant difference between groups in favor of the interventions (REM, standardized mean difference -0.37, 95% confidence interval -0.65 to -0.08, I (2) 61%). LIMITATIONS: The majority of included studies were of moderate quality and four studies were of low quality. Data from a variety of different populations and settings were pooled, expanding the range of study characteristics. CONCLUSIONS: Motivational interventions can support exercise adherence, have a positive impact on long-term physical activity behavior, improve self-efficacy, and reduce activity limitations. The optimal choice of theory and the most beneficial duration and type of intervention have not been defined, although all interventions showed benefits. It needs to be determined how practicing physiotherapists are currently optimizing adherence and what their current level of knowledge about motivational interventions is. IMPLICATIONS OF KEY RESULTS: The results indicate that motivational interventions are successful in increasing healthy physical activity behaviors. Physiotherapists are ideally placed to fill this role and motivational interventions need to become part of physiotherapy practice.

title: Treatment of nicotine addiction in women. role of the midwife
abstract: Smoking is the leading preventable cause of cancer, cardiovascular disease, and other premature deaths among women in the United States. Tobacco use accounts for 10% of perinatal mortality and is 100% preventable. Smoking is now more common among adolescent girls than among boys. Women's healthcare providers are in an excellent position to intervene in this growing epidemic. This article looks at the health consequences of smoking, as well as the social, economic, and emotional impacts of cigarette smoking on women and their families. It examines the reasons why women start and continue to smoke despite known risks. The role of the midwife in the lifelong management of nicotine addiction in women is examined. A theoretical model based on the woman's stage of change is presented as an intervention framework. Behavioral and pharmacological treatment recommendations are included. Opportunities for professional activities related to community education and advocacy for a tobacco-free society are presented.

title: Compliance with NICE guidelines on diabetes prevention in the UK: implications for patient knowledge and perceived risk
abstract: BACKGROUND: The NICE guidelines for preventing diabetes include identifying those at risk, followed by cost-effective interventions if needed. Based on a risk assessment using a questionnaire and/or blood test, the intervention may include a brief discussion of risk factors and preventative counseling or referral for an intensive lifestyle intervention. DESIGN AND SETTING: In this cross-sectional study, 59 subjects recruited from local primary care practices were invited by letter to participate in a screening for a diabetes prevention study. METHOD: After a telephone screening in which subjects were asked if they would be informed if they were at high risk for type 2 diabetes, eligible subjects completed a risk perception survey of developing diabetes (RPS-DD), a validated diabetes risk score and subjected to an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) during medical screening. RESULTS: As measured by the Diabetes UK Risk Score, 44.1% were at high risk, 42.4% at intermediate risk and 13.6% at increased risk. 42% of patients were informed by a healthcare professional that they were at high risk. Those who had been informed about their risk had significantly higher perceived risk scores (p<0.001), higher knowledge scores (p<0.001), and lower optimism scores (p=0.004), but were no more aware that diet (p=0 .42) and weight control (p=0.57) may play a role in preventing diabetes. CONCLUSIONS: People at high risk of diabetes are not informed of their risk status as recommended by the NICE guidelines. There is scope for education for health professionals and the public.

title: contraception in adolescents
abstract: PIP: Many teens in the United States remain at risk of unplanned pregnancy, despite advances in contraceptive technology and the increasing availability of birth control methods. Physicians caring for adolescents need to be familiar with the different contraceptive measures and their appropriateness for adolescents. A healthcare professional must also be prepared to participate in sex education and to counsel or refer individual adolescent patients when sexual problems arise. In this discussion of adolescent contraception, attention is drawn to: reasons for not using contraception, postcoital contraception, oral contraception (contraindications, side effects, guidelines for use in adolescents and the minipill (progestogen only), IUDs, diaphragms, vaginal chemical birth control, condoms, withdrawal or rhythm, intervention techniques, and choosing the right method. The average teen is exposed to a year or more of unprotected sex before asking for birth control. Available evidence suggests that teens are now using birth control more than ever before, but a significant number do not employ a method for a variety of reasons Most reasons reflect a lack of knowledge, some reflect unavailability, and intense feelings of guilt induced by the idea of the possibility of the sexual en to be prepared for intercourse. Many young people are reluctant to ask private doctors for contraceptive advice or prescriptions because they fear preaching and rejection of their requests. There is evidence in at least 1 study that locating the family planning clinic within the school is effective in reducing pregnancy rates and ensuring high continuation rates at 36 months of follow-up. Intervention techniques that might be effective include providing a method immediately after an event (abortion, childbirth, rape) when motivation is at its highest, and tailoring the method to individual lifestyle and preferences. If there are no contraindications, the teenager should be given the preferred method based on the frequency of sexual intercourse. A backup method should also be provided if the preferred method is not tolerated or never started. To maximize continuation rates, frequent follow-up is essential.

title: Overweight and obesity in adolescents - how to best deal with it in general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: The prevalence of overweight and obesity among adolescents continues to increase. Community level management is required as specialized services are limited. AIM: This article outlines a general practice treatment plan for overweight adolescents that uses a chronic care approach and follows the National Health and Medical Research Council's clinical practice guidelines for the management of overweight and obesity in children and adolescents. DISCUSSION: Overweight and obesity do not spontaneously resolve during adolescence, and active intervention is required to both improve current health and well-being and reduce the risks of premature morbidity and mortality in adulthood. Modest, cumulative lifestyle changes along with modest weight loss goals to reduce the risk of weight gain are important. Any intervention must take into account the rapid cognitive and behavioral changes of adolescence.

title: Adolescent violence prevention practices among California pediatricians
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To examine the delivery of violence prevention services by pediatricians to their adolescent patients and to identify factors associated with the delivery of these services by pediatricians. DESIGN: A cross-sectional sample of California pediatricians completed a self-report questionnaire. The Precede/Proceed theoretical model guided the questionnaire in identifying factors related to pediatrician screening and intervention practices in the prevention of adolescent violence. RESULTS: Two hundred and twenty pediatricians (54% female, 66% White, 24% Asian, 5% Latino, and 5% other) participated in the study. On average, participants screened their patients for violence-related risk factors 31% of the time when it came to fights, 39% for domestic violence, and 29% for carrying guns. Participants provided their at-risk patients with violence-related interventions less than 50% of the time (on average) by providing the following interventions: written materials, follow-up appointments, disciplinary counseling, or referral to a community organization, child protective services, or a specialized youth clinic. Factors associated with screening practices for violence prevention included the following: positive attitudes and beliefs about screening for violence, familiarity with violence prevention guidelines, use of prompts in medical records, perception of greater ability, and positive reinforcement by patients and peers for delivery of violence prevention services (R(2)=0.44"; P<0.001). Factors associated with violence prevention intervention practices included: positive attitudes and beliefs about screening for violence, availability of resources, and positive reinforcement by patients and peers for delivery from violence prevention services (R(2) = 0.37; "P < 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: California pediatricians do not comprehensively screen their adolescent patients for risk factors associated with adolescent violence, nor do they provide interventions for their adolescent patients who may be at risk of violence. The factors associated with pediatricians' implementation of violence prevention services can aid in the development of effective interventions aimed at improving their delivery of these services to their adolescent patients.

title: Adoption, outreach, implementation and maintenance of behavioral and mental health assessment in primary care
abstract: PURPOSE: Guidelines recommend screening patients for unhealthy behavior and mental health problems. Health risk assessments can systematically identify patient needs and trigger treatment. This study attempts to assess whether primary care practices can routinely implement such assessments into routine care. METHODS: As part of a cluster-randomized pragmatic study, 9 different primary care practices implemented My Own Health Report (MOHR) – an electronic or paper-based health behavior and mental health assessment and feedback system coupled with counseling and goal setting. We observed how practices integrated MOHR into their workflows, how much additional time it took practice staff to do so, and what percentage of patients completed a MOHR assessment (Reach). RESULTS: Most of the practices contacted (60%) agreed to the introduction of MOHR. How they implemented MOHR depended on the practice's resources, informatics capacity, and patient characteristics. Three practices sent patient invitations to fill out MOHRs online, 1 called patients and filled out MOHRs over the phone, 1 had patients fill out MOHRs on paper at the practice, and 4 had staff members help patients fill out MOHRs online at the practice. A total of 3,591 patients were contacted and 1,782 completed MOHR (reach = 49.6%). Reach varied according to implementation strategy, with greater reach when staff completed MOHR than patients (71.2% vs. 30.2%, p<0.001). No practice was able to maintain the full MOHR score without post-study adjustments. Using MOHR increased staff and clinic time by an average of 28 minutes per visit. CONCLUSIONS: Primary care practices can conduct health behavior and mental health assessments, but effective patient counseling requires effort. Practices will need more support to implement and maintain assessments.

title: Adult education program in palliative care for doctors in nursing homes: conception and pilot project
abstract: Nursing homes (NF) are important places of care for dying patients. NF physicians need curricula that could improve end-of-life care. For this purpose, a model curriculum for palliative care from the medical faculty for experienced NF physicians was modified. Adult learning techniques and interactions that could alter physician behavior were highlighted. Opinion leader involvement, auditing with feedback, use of consensus guidelines, and other techniques to change physician behavior were included. Written materials to complement the course were identified. This new program has been pilot tested and improved. An entrance examination of the medical practices and a survey of the NF staff, a half-day adult education session and a follow-up with the medical director of the NF are proposed. This intervention should be tested to determine whether it improves patient care outcomes at the end of life in this setting.

title: respiratory distress syndrome in adults
