Further developing the literature on designing audit and feedback interventions: identifying theory-driven hypotheses
abstract: Background audit and feedback (A&F) is a common strategy to help healthcare providers put evidence into practice. Despite extensive studies, A&F interventions in healthcare remain variable in effectiveness, with overall effect sizes not improving since 2003. Contributing to this stagnation is the fact that most A&F interventions in healthcare have been designed largely without theoretical understanding from the behavioral and social sciences. To determine whether the trend can be improved, the goal of this study was to develop a list of testable, theory-driven hypotheses about how to design more effective H&F interventions. Methods Using targeted sample selection, semi-structured 60-90 minute telephone interviews were conducted with experts in A&F theories from various fields (e.g. cognitive, health and organizational psychology, medical decision-making, economics). Guided by detailed descriptions of A&F interventions from the health literature, respondents described how they would approach the problem of developing improved A&F interventions. Specific, theory-driven hypotheses about the conditions for an effective design and delivery of O&F interventions were raised from the interviews. The resulting hypotheses were assigned to topics and topic categories by three independently working coders in an iterative process. Results We conducted 28 interviews and identified 313 theory-driven hypotheses that were assigned to 30 themes. The 30 themes included hypotheses in the following five categories: A&F recipients (seven themes), content of the A&F (ten themes), delivery process of the A&F (six themes), behavior that was the focus of the A&F (three themes). ) and others (four subjects). Conclusions We have identified a number of testable, theory-driven hypotheses from a wide range of behavioral and social sciences that suggest conditions for more effective A&F interventions. This work demonstrates the breadth of perspectives on H&H from non-health disciplines in a way that provides testable hypotheses for H&H interventions in healthcare. These results will serve as the basis for further work aimed at setting research priorities in the A&F research community.

title: Advancing the science of patient safety
abstract: Despite decades of effort, patient safety has slowly improved, in part due to the limited evidence base for the development and widespread dissemination of successful patient safety practices. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality sponsored an international group of experts in patient safety and assessment methods to develop criteria to improve the design, assessment and reporting of patient safety practice research. This article reports the findings and recommendations of this group, which include greater use of theoretical and logical models, more detailed descriptions of interventions and their implementation, improved explanation of desired and unintended outcomes, and better description and measurement of context and contextual influences interventions. Using these criteria and measurement and reporting contexts will improve the science of patient safety.

title: Benefits and challenges of community-based cognitive-behavioral therapy for elderly depression in rural China: A qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: The delivery of mental health services in rural China is severely constrained due in part to a lack of qualified mental health professionals and other hindering factors. A behavioral therapy intervention by a village doctor can be a way to improve accessibility. The purpose of this study was to examine the benefits and challenges of implementing this intervention, as performed by trained village doctors, for the treatment of depression in the elderly in rural China. Methods: We conducted a focus group discussion with 10 village doctors, 10 individual interviews with each village doctor, and individual interviews with 19 older adults. The theme guides were benefits and challenges of the intervention program from the perspective of village doctors and older adults. The interviews were audio recorded, transcribed, encoded with NVivo 8 and analyzed with thematic analysis. RESULTS: The village doctors stressed the importance of role play and the use of textbooks in training. Proper mentoring was also an important part of the program. The benefits of the intervention for the village doctors and the elders were positive, so that both the doctors and the older adults were willing to implement/adopt this intervention. Cultural and political factors (renqing and perceived political consideration) facilitated elders' access to mental health services. Challenges included the lack of real therapy (as opposed to role play) demonstrated in training and the lack of a step-by-step manual based on different types of problems encountered. Other obstacles to the successful delivery of the intervention were the time constraints of the village doctors and the presence of other people when delivering the intervention. CONCLUSIONS: The present study demonstrated that the intervention program is likely to be an acceptable geriatric depression intervention in rural China if multiple challenges are adequately addressed.

title: Advising patients seeking complementary and alternative medical therapies for cancer
abstract: Many cancer patients use complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) therapies. Physicians need authoritative information about CAM therapies to be able to responsibly advise patients who desire these interventions. This article summarizes current evidence on the efficacy and safety of selected CAM therapies commonly used by cancer patients. The main categories of interventions covered are: diet modification and supplementation, herbal products and other biological agents, acupuncture, massage, exercise, and psychological and mental and physical therapies. Two categories of evidence of efficacy are considered: possible effects on disease progression and survival, and possible palliative effects. When evaluating safety evidence, two types of risks are considered: the risk of direct side effects and the risk of interactions with conventional treatments. For any therapy, the current body of evidence on efficacy and safety indicates whether the therapy is reasonably recommended, accepted (z -dose vitamin A supplementation). This strategy enables the development of an approach for responsible, evidence-based, patient-centered counseling of cancer patients using CAM therapies.

title: Alcohol use and dependence among elderly patients in an urban community
Alcohol: prevention, policy and responses in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Alcohol is Australia's "most socially acceptable legal drug" but alcohol-related harm has increased significantly over time. Promoting safer alcohol consumption should be a national health priority and a focus for health practitioners. AIM: The purpose of this paper is to discuss some of the reasons why alcohol is such a popular and valued commodity in Australia and some of the most common problems caused by alcohol. We outline the most effective guidelines and treatment approaches to reduce alcohol use and its associated harms. DISCUSSION: Research suggests that the most effective policies to reduce alcohol use and its associated harms are those that focus on reducing its availability and accessibility." However, for political and economic reasons, such policies are often not implemented or enforced. Conducting screening and brief interventions are effective ways to address problem alcohol use in primary care and can be further supported by promoting community-organized periods of abstinence.

title: Alcohol-Related and Non-Alcohol Activity Participation and Enjoyment Among College Students: An Analysis of Behavioral Theories of Choice.
abstract: College student alcohol abuse remains a significant public health problem, and there is a need for theory-driven and empirically-based models to guide prevention efforts. Behavioral theories of choice posit that the decision to consume alcohol is influenced by the relative value of alcohol compared to other available activities. In the present study, a sample of college drinkers (N=108; 56% female, 44% male) who had previously completed a mandatory alcohol intervention completed a measure of participation in and enjoyment of alcohol-related and non-alcoholic activities. The aim of the study was to examine the influence of drinking amount and contextual variables on activity enjoyment and to identify enjoyable non-alcoholic activities that take place on evenings when students might otherwise be drinking. Overall, students found alcohol-related activities more enjoyable than non-alcoholic activities, and drinking amount was positively related to enjoyment. However, non-alcoholic activities such as watching films, going to the theater or museum, going to bars or parties, hanging out with friends, eating out in restaurants and being creative were generally just as enjoyable as drinking. Alcohol-free activities with peers or dating were more enjoyable than solitary activities. Men were less likely to participate in alcohol-free activities that their peers participated in and reported less enjoyment of alcohol-free activities than women. Further research is needed to identify methods of increasing participation in alcohol-free activities and whether increased participation in alcohol-free activities leads to reduced alcohol consumption. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Everything you need to read in the other general magazines
abstract: Between 1998 and 2009, a single surgeon in France reconstructed the genitals of 2,938 women who had been mutilated or circumcised as girls. The case series, one of the largest to date, suggests that surgery can help at least some women with a history of female genital mutilation achieve acceptable sex lives without pain. Most of the women were from French-speaking West Africa, although more than 564 had undergone female genital mutilation while growing up in France. Most of them wanted to be operated on to restore their female identity and autonomy. Four-fifths were also seeking a better sex life. All had undergone female genital mutilation, in which the clitoris was removed or damaged, at an average age of 6 years. One of the goals of the operation was to restore a normal clitoris. More than three quarters of the women who presented for surgery (78% (2053/2613)) had never had an orgasm. Only 866 women (29%) returned for follow-up one year after surgery. About half (414/840) reported an improvement in pain. Slightly fewer reported improvements in sexual pleasure (385/834) and 430 were now having orgasms. We don't know how they felt about their bodies after surgery, and future studies should include validated measures of identity, satisfaction with surgery, and global satisfaction with sex, according to a linked comment (doi:10.1016 /S0140-6736(12)60636-9). Lancet2012";"doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(12)60813-7 Citicoline is already approved in some countries as a neuroprotector for adults with acute stroke. Animal models suggest it may protect surviving neurons near the infarct and even enhance repair. However, results from human studies have been mixed, and the latest and largest recently found no difference in recovery between people treated with citicoline and controls who received a placebo (odds ratio for global recovery 1.03, 95 %CI 0.86 to 1.25). Treatment began within â‚¬Â¦

title: Alliance not Compliance: Coaching Strategies to Improve Type 2 Diabetes Outcomes
abstract: PURPOSE: To explore strategies to improve patient outcomes in type 2 diabetes. DATA SOURCES: The literature on type 2 diabetes management, behavior change, communication, diabetes self-management and coaching. CONCLUSIONS: The strategies currently proposed to improve patient outcomes, e.g. B. improving provider adherence to evidence-based treatment guidelines, streamlining practice systems, and encouraging patient lifestyle changes through intensive education have yielded mixed results. Of the many complexities associated with managing type 2 diabetes, motivating patients to change behavior is perhaps the greatest challenge. One suggestion to improve patient self-management in type 2 diabetes is the use of coaching communication as part of behavior change in the context of encounters between nurses (NPs) and their patients in primary care. PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: Given the variable outcomes of current strategies, coaching by NPs may represent a viable alternative for improving patient outcomes in type 2 diabetes. Coaching communication can be carried out during doctor visits as a free intervention. However, to effectively implement this approach, practicing NPs and NP students need more formal training in this expected but underdeveloped NP role competency. NPs are encouraged to contribute the knowledge needed to validate the benefits of coaching for their patients.

title: Alprazolam prescribing in Tasmania: a dual intervention to reduce inappropriate prescriptions and concomitant opiate prescriptions
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The population rate of alprazolam prescriptions in Tasmania was more than double the national rates. Serious side effects have been observed with concomitant administration of opioid medications with alprazolam. A two-pronged intervention consisting of general practitioner education coupled with changes in prescribing regulations was designed with the intent to reduce inappropriate prescribing of alprazolam and thereby reduce adverse outcomes. The aim of this study was to assess the impact of the intervention on prescription rates. METHOD: We measured the number of alprazolam prescriptions for the years before and the year after the intervention. Health Insurance Commission data was used to allow a comparison of subsidized alprazolam prescribing rates in Tasmania and compared to national data. The participants were registered physicians in Tasmania who were potential prescribers of alprazolam. The interventions consisted of three continuing education events for general practitioners, one in each of the major regions of Tasmania, in June 2007 on evidence-based interventions in panic disorder. Changes in regulatory procedures to minimize the co-prescribing of alprazolam with opioids were introduced in September 2007. RESULTS: Post-intervention reduction in alprazolam prescribing occurred in Tasmania. Conclusion: Education can be a powerful strategy to influence physician prescribing behavior. It is likely that this effect can be amplified by adopting more stringent regulatory requirements.

title: Alternative perspectives on the biased foundations of medical technology evaluation
abstract: Medical engineering assessment aims to improve the care of individual patients (the traditional unit of clinical practice) through assessment studies conducted in patient groups (the traditional unit of clinical investigation). This distinction between individuals and groups has practical relevance to the design, analysis, and clinical applicability of technology assessment studies. We define several biased perspectives on technology assessment that arise from the distinction between individuals and groups: a misguided emphasis on efficacy versus effectiveness, statistical significance versus clinical importance, and objective versus subjective outcomes. We contrast each of these alternative perspectives and speculate about their implications for health policy.

title: American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists und American College of Endocrinology Comprehensive Clinical Practice Guidelines for Medical Care of Patients with Obesity
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The development of these guidelines is mandated by the Board of Directors of the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (AACE) and the Board of Trustees of the American College of Endocrinology (ACE) and adheres to published AACE protocols for the standardized preparation of Clinical Practice Guidelines (CPGs). . METHODS: The recommendations are based on a careful review of the clinical evidence with a transparent inclusion of subjective factors. RESULTS: There are 9 comprehensive clinical questions with 123 recommendation numbers containing 160 specific statements (85 [53.1%] strong [Grade A]", 48 [30.0%] moderate [Grade B] and 11 [6.9 %] weak [grade C], with 16 [10.0%] based on expert opinion [grade D]) preparing a comprehensive medical care plan for obesity 133 (83.1%) statements were based on strong (best evidence level [BEL ] 1 = 79 [49.4%]) or intermediate (BEL 2 = 54 [33.7%]) level of scientific support There were 34 (23.6%) evidence-based recommendation grades (Grade AC = 144) based on subjective factors were adjusted.Of the 1,790 reference citations used in this guideline, 524 (29.3%) were based on strong (evidence level [EL] 1), 605 (33.8%) on moderate (EL 2) and 308 (17.2%) based on weak (EL 3) scientific studies, of which 353 (19.7%) based on reviews and opinions (EL 4) CONCLUSION: The final recommendations acknowledge that obesity is a complex obesity-based chronic disease in which management targets both weight-related complications and obesity to improve overall health and quality of life. The detailed evidence-based recommendations enable differentiated clinical decision-making that considers real-world medical care for patients with obesity, including screening, diagnosis, assessment, choice of therapy, treatment goals, and individualization of care. The goal is to facilitate quality care for patients with obesity and to provide a rational, scientific approach to management that optimizes health outcomes and safety. title: American Cancer Society Survivorship Care Guidelines for Colorectal Cancer
abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most common type of cancer and the third leading cause of cancer death in both men and women, and the second leading cause of cancer death when men and women are combined in the United States (US). Almost two-thirds of CRC survivors are alive 5 years after diagnosis. Given recent declines in both incidence and mortality, the prevalence of CRC survivors becomes likely in the coming decades as CRC screening rates increase, further advances in early detection and treatment, and the aging and growing US population increase dramatically. Survivors are at risk for CRC recurrence, new primary CRC, other cancers, and both short-term and long-term side effects of CRC and the modalities used to treat it. CRC survivors may also have psychological, reproductive, genetic, social, and labor concerns after treatment. Communication and coordination of care between the treating oncologist and the primary care physician is critical to the effective and efficient management of long-term care for CRC survivors. The guidelines in this article are intended to assist primary care physicians in providing risk-based healthcare to CRC survivors who have completed active therapy.

title: American College of Physicians Ethics Manual
abstract: Medicine, law and social values are not static. Reviewing the ethical principles of medicine and their application in new circumstances is a necessary exercise. The Sixth Edition of the American College of Physicians (ACP) Handbook of Ethics addresses emerging issues in medical ethics and addresses older issues that are still very relevant. It reflects many of the ethical tensions in medicine and attempts to shed light on how existing principles impact emerging concerns. In addition, by repeating ethical principles that have provided guidance in resolving previous ethical problems, the manual can help physicians avert future problems. The handbook is not a substitute for the experience and integrity of individual physicians, but it can serve as a reminder of the collective responsibilities of the medical profession.

title: Statement from the American Medical Society for Sports Medicine: Concussion in Sport
abstract: WITHOUT IDENTIFICATION: PURPOSE OF STATEMENT: black triangle at right To provide an evidence-based summary of best practice to assist physicians in the evaluation and management of sports concussion. right black triangle To identify the level of evidence, gaps in knowledge, and areas that require additional research. MEANING OF AN AMSSM STATEMENT: black triangle at right Sports medicine physicians are often involved in the care of patients with sports concussion. right black triangle Sports medicine physicians are specially trained to treat the entire sports concussion continuum from the acute injury to return-to-play (RTP) decisions. right black triangle Care for athletes with sports concussion is ideally provided by healthcare professionals with special training and experience in concussion assessment and treatment. Competence should be determined by education and experience, not dictated by specialization. right black triangle Although this statement is intended for sports medicine professionals, it may also be helpful to other physicians and healthcare professionals caring for patients with sports concussion. DEFINITION: black triangle right Concussion is defined as a trauma-induced transient disturbance in brain function and involves a complex pathophysiological process. Concussion is a subtype of mild traumatic brain injury (MTBI) that is generally self-limiting and falls on the less severe end of the brain injury spectrum. PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: black triangle at right Animal and human studies support the concept of postconcussive vulnerability, showing that a second blow before the brain has recovered leads to worsening of metabolic changes within the cell. right black triangle Experimental evidence suggests that the brain with concussion is less responsive to normal neural activation, and when premature cognitive or physical activity occurs before full recovery, the brain may be vulnerable to ongoing dysfunction. FREQUENCY: Right black triangle An estimated 3.8 million concussions occur each year in the United States during competitive sports and recreational activities";" however, up to 50% of concussions go unreported. right black triangle Concussions occur in all sports, with the highest incidence in soccer, hockey, rugby, soccer and basketball. RISK FACTORS FOR SPORT RESULTS: black triangle right A history of concussion is associated with a higher risk of having another concussion. right black triangle Greater number, severity, and duration of symptoms after concussion are predictors of prolonged recovery. right black triangle In sports with similar rules of the game, the reported incidence of concussion is higher in female athletes than in male athletes. right black triangle Certain sports, positions, and individual playstyles have an increased risk of concussion. black triangle at right Youth athletes have longer recovery periods and are more susceptible to a concussion accompanied by a catastrophic injury. black triangle right Pre-injury-related mood disorders, learning disabilities, attention deficit disorder (ADD/ADHD), and migraines complicate concussion diagnosis and treatment. Diagnosis of Concussion: Black Triangle Right Concussion remains a clinical diagnosis, ideally made by a healthcare provider familiar with the athlete and skilled in concussion detection and assessment. black triangle right Tiered Symptom Checklists provide an objective tool for assessing a variety of concussion-related symptoms while tracking the severity of those symptoms via serial assessments. right black triangle Standardized assessment tools provide a useful structure for assessing concussion, although limited validation of these assessment tools is available. MINOR AREA ASSESSMENT AND TREATMENT: Black triangle on the right. Any athlete suspected of having a concussion should be removed from play and evaluated by a licensed health care provider trained in concussion assessment and treatment. right black triangle Detection and initial assessment of concussion should be guided by a symptom checklist, cognitive assessment (including orientation, past and immediate memory, new learning, and concentration), balance testing, and an additional neurological physical examination. right black triangle While standardized sideline tests provide a useful framework for investigation, the sensitivity, specificity, validity, and reliability of these tests across different age groups, cultural groups, and settings are largely undefined. Their practical use with or without an individual baseline test is also largely unknown. black triangle on the right Balance disorder is a specific indicator of concussion, but not very sensitive. Sideline balance testing may differ significantly from baseline testing due to differences in shoe/cleat type or surface, use of ankle strap or braces, or the presence of other lower extremity injuries. black triangle right Imaging is reserved for athletes suspected of having an intracerebral hemorrhage. right black triangle There is no same-day RTP for an athlete diagnosed with concussion. right black triangle Athletes suspected or diagnosed with concussion should be monitored for worsening physical or mental condition. NEUROPSYCHOLOGICAL TESTS: black triangle at right Neuropsychological (NP) tests are an objective measure of brain-behaviour relationships and are more sensitive to subtle cognitive impairments than clinical tests. right black triangle Most concussions can be adequately treated without the use of NP tests. right black triangle Computerized neuropsychological (CNP) tests should be interpreted by healthcare professionals trained and familiar with the type of test and individual test limitations, including an informed assessment of the reliable index of change, baseline variability, and false positives and false negatives Guess . black triangle at right Paper and pencil NP tests can be more comprehensive, testing different areas and checking for other conditions that may masquerade as concussion or make assessment more difficult. Right black triangle NP tests should only be used as part of a comprehensive concussion management strategy and not in isolation. black triangle on the right The ideal time, frequency and type of NP testing have not yet been determined. right black triangle In some cases, a properly performed and interpreted NP test offers added value in assessing cognitive function and recovery in the management of sports concussion. right black triangle It is unknown whether the use of NP testing in the treatment of concussion associated with sports helps prevent recurrent concussion, catastrophic injury, or long-term complications. black triangle right A comprehensive NP evaluation is useful in the post-concussion management of athletes with persistent symptoms or complicated trajectories. BACK TO CLASSROOM: Black triangle at right Students need cognitive rest and possible academic adjustments such as reduced workload and longer time on tests while recovering from concussion. BACK TO PLAY: Black triangle on the right Concussion symptoms should be resolved before you return to training. right black triangle RTP progression involves a gradual, incremental increase in physical demands, sport-specific activities, and contact risk. right black triangle If symptoms occur during activity, progression should be halted and resumed at the previous symptom-free step. Right black triangle RTP after a concussion should only be done with medical clearance from a licensed health care provider trained in concussion assessment and treatment. SHORT-TERM RISKS OF PREMATURE RTP: Black triangle on the right The main problem with early RTP is reduced reaction time, leading to an increased risk of recurrence of concussion or other injury and prolongation of symptoms. LONG-TERM EFFECTS: Black Triangle Right There is increasing concern that exposure to head impact and recurrent concussions contribute to long-term neurological consequences. right black triangle Some studies suggest a link between previous concussions and chronic cognitive dysfunction. Large-scale epidemiological studies are needed to more clearly define risk factors and causes of long-term neurological impairment. DISQUALIFICATION FROM SPORT: black triangle at right There are no evidence-based guidelines for disqualifying/removing an athlete from a sport after concussion. Each case should be carefully considered and an individual approach taken to determine disqualification. EDUCATION: black triangle at right Greater effort is needed to educate stakeholders, including athletes, parents, coaches, officials, school administrators and healthcare providers, to improve concussion detection, treatment and prevention. Right black triangle Physicians should be prepared to offer advice on possible long-term consequences of concussion and recurring concussions. PREVENTION: black triangle on the right Primary prevention of some injuries may be possible through modification and enforcement of the rules and fair play. black triangle right Helmets, both hard (football, lacrosse and hockey) and soft (soccer, rugby) are best suited to absorb impact injuries (fractures, bleeding, lacerations, etc.) concussions. black triangle right There is currently no evidence that face masks can reduce or prevent the severity of concussions. black triangle on the right Secondary prevention may be possible through appropriate RTP management. LEGISLATION: Black triangle at right Legislative efforts are creating a unified standard for school and non-school sports organizations related to concussion safety and management. FUTURE DIRECTIONS: black triangle at right Additional research is needed to validate current assessment tools, describe the role of the NP test, and improve identification of individuals at risk of prolonged post-concussion symptoms or other long-term complications. right black triangle Emerging technologies for diagnosing concussions, such as New techniques, such as newer imaging techniques or biological markers, can provide new insights into the assessment and treatment of concussion in sports.

title: The Americans want to water down the Helsinki Declaration
A detailed scientific intervention to disseminate physician-led smoking cessation counseling: smoking cessation outcomes from the Physicians Counseling Smokers Project
abstract: BACKGROUND: Little is known about the effectiveness of interventions in disseminating smoking cessation interventions among a population of primary care physicians. The aim of this study was to determine the effect of a community-based academic intervention on cessation rates in a population-based sample of smokers. METHODS: This community-based, quasi-experimental study included representative samples of 259 general practitioners and 4295 adult smokers. Over a period of 15 months, physicians in intervention areas were offered a detailed scientific intervention. Analyzes were performed on data from 2346 subjects who reported at least one physician visit over 24 months. Multivariate regression analyzes were performed to determine the impact of the intervention on self-reported smoking cessation rates, as indicated by adjusted odds ratios. RESULTS: Among smokers who reported a physician visit during the study period, there was a borderline significant effect for those living in intervention areas compared to control areas (OR = 1.35 inches; 95% CI.99-1.83; P = 0.057). Among a subset of 819 smokers who reported a visit to an enrolled physician, we observed a significant effect for those residing in intervention areas (OR = 1.80; 95% CI 1.16-2.75; "P = 0.008 CONCLUSION: A scientifically detailed intervention to improve physician smoking cessation counseling is an effective strategy for disseminating smoking cessation interventions in community-based practices.

title: An administrative intervention to improve the use of laboratory tests within a university hospital
abstract: BACKGROUND: Improving the adequacy of testing behavior and reducing the number of laboratory tests have been identified as essential components of quality improvement. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of an administrative and short-term educational intervention aimed at reducing the workload of the clinical-biochemistry laboratory. DESIGN: An analysis comparing the use of laboratory tests performed on hospitalized patients before and after the procedure. SETTING: Computerized database of all laboratory tests performed at Hadassah Ein Kerem Medical Center, Jerusalem, Israel between 1999 and 2003. INTERVENTION: Administrative intervention included limiting available emergency laboratory tests and frequency of repeat orders. Educational activities included: Discussing the abuse of laboratory tests and its consequences with the hospital's medical staff and presenting the new restrictive policy. Feedback on the results of the intervention was sent to the wards and discussed with senior medical staff. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Change in utilization (measured as rates per 100 hospital days) of clinical biochemistry tests by hospital department and by selected laboratory tests. RESULTS: An overall reduction of 19% in laboratory tests (95% CI: 18.8-19.2%) was observed in the year after the intervention. The occupancy rate fell significantly in all medical departments of the hospital and ranged from 14.9 to 43.8%. During the intervention period, the use of hematological tests was reduced by 7.6% (p = 0.009). Statistically significant reductions were found in the order of all 12 selected clinical biochemistry tests. Although total cholesterol orders decreased by 72.2%, the use of "high volume" tests, such as glucose and electrolytes, showed only a modest decrease (7.9% and 6.9%, respectively). CONCLUSIONS: The present study included all hospital medical staff and covered all available clinical biochemical tests. This relatively simple and inexpensive procedure resulted in a significant reduction in orders for clinical biochemistry tests as well as orders for hematological blood tests.

title: An assessment of user acceptance and satisfaction with the automated clinical practice smoking cessation policy
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To describe user acceptance and satisfaction with the automated clinical practice guideline (ACPG) on tobacco cessation (TUC) in the Henry Ford Health System. STUDY DESIGN: A previous review assessed adherence to the 5 As (ask, advise, assess, support and arrange) of the TUC ACPG in 3 study arms. This article describes user satisfaction with the TUC ACPG after implementation. Methods: In all study arms, providers completed a survey before participating in a focus group. RESULTS: All providers in the TUC arm reported that they "almost always" asked their patients about tobacco use. Providers in the TUC arm were generally satisfied with the features of the TUC ACPG, particularly the ease of electronically referring a patient to the smoking intervention program. Obstacles to use included time constraints, staff shortages, and a desire to "decline" the program for patients in certain situations (e.g., patients with terminal illnesses). CONCLUSION: As ACPGs are integrated into electronic health records, it is important to seek vendor input prior to implementation, to provide technology that is user-friendly and fits into the clinic's workflow, and to give physicians autonomy to deviate from the guideline opt out in certain clinical circumstances.

title: An automatic rejection rule for the minimum repeat interval reduces the workload and expense of repeat CRP and influences the physician's request behavior
abstract: Objectives Repeated measurements of serum C-reactive protein (CRP) on the same day or on consecutive days are of limited clinical value. Minimum retest intervals are recommended to avoid unnecessary retesting. As not previously reported, we examined the effect of refusing tests with the minimum repeat interval on laboratory workload and expenses, and on physician demand behavior. Methods In a prospective study, we evaluated the effect of an automated 48-hour minimum repeat test interval CRP rule on CRP workload and costs in both inpatient and outpatient settings. Control data on inpatient and outpatient serum urea and electrolyte loads (UE) were collected during the study. Results Over a 1-year period, there was a decrease of 7.0% and 12.3%, respectively, in CRP requirements and analyzed CRP tests after the implementation of the minimum repeat interval rule compared to the 1-year baseline period. This equated to an estimated annual reduction in cost of sales of £10,500 but cash savings in utility costs of £3,000. There was no significant change in UE requests. Conclusions We report for the first time that automatic rejection rules for minimum repeat testing intervals as a standalone strategy is a cost-effective and sustainable method to reduce unnecessary CRP repeat testing, resulting in modest laboratory cost savings, more efficient use of laboratory resources, and standardization of patient care pathways. The minimum repeat interval rejection rule also changed the physician's test request behavior toward a more reasonable request.

title: An educational program that influences health professionals to recommend exercise to their type 2 diabetic patients - understanding the processes: a case study from Oxfordshire, UK
abstract: BACKGROUND: Increasing physical activity reduces the risk of premature mortality associated with chronic diseases, e.g. B. coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes, stroke. Despite this, most adults in England do not meet physical activity guidelines. It is recommended that GPs provide physical activity advice and guidance to at-risk patients. However, education in sports medicine is sparse, resulting in little practitioner knowledge of the evidence for risk reduction and strategies for implementing effective patient behavior change. The Generation Games intervention aims to increase physical activity among the over 50s in Oxfordshire. It offers a Health Professions Education Program (HPEP) that provides training in sports medicine and the promotion of intergenerational play that health professionals can lead patients to. There is a poor evidence base on how such education leads to a change in patients' physical activity behavior. METHODS: The research aimed to gain a better understanding of how an educational program can influence health professionals to recommend Generation Games and improve physical activity behaviors in type 2 diabetes patients. A case study methodology facilitated examination of the routines and cultures studied - the experience of diabetes caregivers was used as an example of best practice engagement with the HPEP. Observation, interviews and documentation were used to triangulate the data. Data analysis refined and developed themes within important theoretical frameworks. RESULTS: First, there is a lack of knowledge about the benefits of risk reduction from physical activity and the belief that efforts to motivate patients to increase their physical activity are ineffective, creating barriers to the incorporation of HPEP. Second, practicing nurses tasked with providing lifestyle advice to diabetic patients – who themselves suffer from a deficit in motivational interviewing skills – find ingrained behaviors associated with physical activity extremely challenging and value the HPEP for providing helpful tools. Third, when patients learn about intergenerational play from a healthcare professional, they may have conflicting expectations of how their physical activity behaviors may change. CONCLUSIONS: Sports medicine education has the potential to improve patient care and services. Before initiatives like HPEP can be successful, primary care practice requires a more supportive culture of exercise medicine. Adequate resource allocation for patient-centred behavior change counseling, training, encouragement and monitoring services is also required.

title: An educational approach to improving acute kidney injury (AKI) outcomes: report of a quality improvement project
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the impact of a quality improvement project that employed a multifaceted educational intervention to improve the knowledge, confidence, and awareness of the acute kidney injury (AKI) clinician. FACILITIES: 2 major acute care hospitals in England serving a combined population of over 1.5 million people. PARTICIPANTS: All secondary care clinicians working in the clinical areas were addressed, with a particular focus on clinicians working in acute intake areas. INTERVENTIONS: A multifaceted pedagogical intervention consisting of traditional didactic lectures, case-based instruction in small groups and an interactive web-based learning resource. OUTCOME MEASURES: We assessed clinicians' knowledge of AKI and their self-reported clinical behavior using an interactive questionnaire before and after the educational intervention. Secondary outcome measurements included clinical review of patient notes before and after the intervention. RESULTS: Twenty-six percent of clinicians reported knowledge of local AKI guidelines in the preintervention questionnaire compared to 64% in the follow-up questionnaire (chi2" = 60.2, p<0.001). There was an improvement in the Number of clinicians 50% vs 68% (chi2 = 12.1, p<0.001) reported satisfactory practice in diagnosing AKI and 48% vs 64% in evaluating patients with AKI (chi2 "= 9.5, p=0.002). Clinical audit manufacturers showed a trend towards better clinical practice. CONCLUSIONS: This quality improvement project, which utilized a multifaceted educational intervention, improved awareness of AKI, as demonstrated by changes in clinician self-reported treatment of patients with AKI. Elements of the project have been maintained beyond the project period and demonstrate the power of quality improvement projects to initiate change in practice. Our results are limited by confounding factors and underscore the need to conduct formal randomized trials to determine the impact of educational initiatives in clinical settings.

title: An educational intervention reduces the rate of inappropriate echocardiograms in an inpatient medical service
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to prospectively investigate the impact of an Adequate Usage Criteria (AUC)-based transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) placement training intervention in domestic staff on inpatient general internal medicine at an academic medical center. BACKGROUND: AUC for TTE were developed in response to concerns about inappropriate use of TTE. To date, AUC-based educational interventions to reduce inappropriate TTE use have not been prospectively studied. METHODS: A prospective time-series analysis of an educational intervention was performed and then compared to TTE prescription at the same medical facility during a control period. The intervention consisted of: 1) a lecture to housekeeping staff on the 2011 AUC for TTE"; 2) a pocket map applying the AUC to common clinical scenarios;" and 3) bi-weekly email feedback on ordering behavior. TTE order was tracked daily during the intervention period and feedback reports were emailed at two-week intervals. The primary endpoint was the proportion of inappropriate and appropriate TTEs ordered during the intervention period. RESULTS: Of all TTEs ordered in the control and study periods, 99% and 98% were classifiable by 2011 AUC, respectively. During the study period, there was a 26 percent reduction in the number of TTE ordered per day compared to the number ordered during the control period (2.9 vs. 3.9 TTE, p<0.001). During the study period, the proportion of inappropriate TTE was significantly lower (5% vs. 13%, p<0.001) and the proportion of appropriate TTE was significantly higher (93% vs. 84%, p<0.001). CONCLUSIONS: A simple educational intervention resulted in a significant reduction in the rate of inappropriate TTE and increased the rate of appropriate TTE ordered by an inpatient conventional medical service. This study offers a practical approach to using AUC to reduce the number of inappropriate TTEs. Further studies in other practice settings are warranted.

title: An efficacy study of cognitive behavioral therapy in a representative sample of outpatients with psychosis
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapies for psychosis (CBTp) has been demonstrated sufficiently to be included in some national treatment guidelines. However, treatment efficacy does not guarantee efficacy in routine practice, where clinical expertise and patient composition may vary. Therefore, we evaluated the applicability, acceptability, and effectiveness of CBTp when routinely offered in a public mental health service. DESIGN: A prospectively recruited representative sample (N=94) of patients with psychotic disorders from a geographic catchment area in Melbourne, Australia, were randomly assigned to CBTp or treatment-as-usual. METHOD: The CBTp intervention included psychoeducation, positive symptom and comorbid problem components. The therapists negotiated goals with the patients and used treatment components from a manual. Intention-to-treat analyzes used baseline, 9-month, and 18-month data. RESULTS: Working group and customer satisfaction measurements showed excellent acceptance. Both groups improved to a similar extent on the Positive and Negative Syndrome scales, with no benefit for the CBTp group. The most commonly implemented CBTp components were comorbid disorders/personal problems and personalized psychoeducation; working with persistent symptoms was the focus of relatively few sessions. CONCLUSIONS: The lack of benefit for the CBTp group may be due to: the infrequent focus on positive symptoms (the most commonly replicated range of outcomes for CBTp); the unselected nature of the patients (rather than those with distressing symptoms or referred by physicians);" or to inadequate therapist competence.

title: An electronic health record-based intervention to improve tobacco treatment in primary care: a cluster-randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background To improve the documentation and treatment of tobacco use in primary care, we designed and implemented a three-part electronic medical record extension: (1) smoking status icons, (2) tobacco treatment reminders, and (3) a tobacco smart form that facilitated the ordering of medicines and recommendations for advice by fax and e-mail. Methods We conducted a cluster-randomized, controlled study of improvement in improvement in 26 primary care practices between December 19, 2006 and September 30, 2007. The primary outcome was the proportion of documented smokers who had contacted a smoking cessation counselor. Secondary endpoints included coded documentation of smoking status and medication prescription. Results During the 9-month study period, 132,630 patients visited 315,962 study practices. Coded documentation of smoking status increased from 37% of patients to 54% (+17%) in intervention practices and from 35% of patients to 46% (+11%) in control practices (P < 0.001 for difference in differences). Among the 9589 patients who were smokers at the start of the study, more patients were recorded in the intervention practices than non-smokers at the end of the study (5.3% vs. 1.9% in control practices; p<0.001). Among 12,207 documented smokers, more patients in the intervention practices contacted a cessation counselor (3.9% vs. 0.3% in control practices; p<0.001) Smokers in the intervention practices did not receive more smoking cessation drug prescriptions (2% vs. 2% in control practices ;" P = 0.40). Conclusion This electronic health record-based intervention improved documentation of smoking status and increased counseling support for smokers, but not the prescription of cessation drugs.

title: An electronic medical record-based intervention to improve the quality of care in gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and atypical manifestations of GERD.
abstract: Background Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is widespread in primary care but often underdiagnosed and untreated. GERD can also present with atypical symptoms, such as chronic cough and asthma, and physicians may not be aware of this phenomenon. Our goal was to implement and evaluate an intervention to improve the diagnosis and treatment of GERD and atypical GERD in primary care. Method This was a primary care randomized controlled trial using a national network of US practices (the Medical Quality Improvement Consortium - MQIC) that use the same Electronic Medical Record (EMR). Thirteen practices with 53 providers were randomized to the intervention of EMR-based prompts and education, and 14 practices with 66 providers were randomized to the control group with a total of over 67,000 patients and evaluated the outcomes of GERD diagnosis and appropriate treatment. Results In patients who did not have GERD at baseline, new GERD diagnoses increased significantly (p<0.01) in the intervention group (3.1%) compared to the control group (2.3%). This remained significant after controlling for cluster formation with a diagnostic probability of 1.33 (95% CI 1.13-1.56) for the intervention group. For patients with atypical symptoms, patients in the intervention group had both higher odds of being diagnosed with GERD (OR 2.02, 95% CI 1.41-2.88) and being treated for GERD (OR 1.40, 95% CI 1.08-1.83) than in the control group. Conclusions GERD diagnosis and treatment in primary care, particularly in patients with atypical symptoms, can be improved through the use of an EMR-based tool that includes decision support and education. However, there is significant room for improvement when using an appropriate treatment.

title: An assessment of opioid prescribing for chronic non-malignant pain by Australian general practitioners
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Our aim was to assess the quality of opioid analgesic prescribing for chronic nonmalignant pain (CNMP) by general practitioners (general practitioners, primary care physicians). DESIGN: An anonymous, questionnaire-based, cross-sectional survey. SETTING: The setting was five Australian general practice departments (geographically based associations of general practitioners). METHODS: A questionnaire was mailed to all department members. Outcome measures were adherence to individual recommendations of locally derived CNMP practice guidelines. RESULTS: We received 404 responses (response rate 23.3%). In the previous 14 days, general practitioners prescribed long-term continuous opioids for CNMP in a median of 4 and a mean of 7.1 (+/-8.7) patients with CNMP. Guideline concordance (GLC) was poor, as no GP always followed all guideline items and only 31% of GPs typically used most of the items. GLC was highest for avoiding high dosages or fast-acting formulations. It was lowest for strategies to minimize individual and public health harm, such as B. the introduction of opioids on a time-limited trial basis, the use of contracts, and the exclusion or management of deviant behavior. GLC was positively associated with relevant education or qualifications, registration with the Australian Prescription Drug Monitoring Program, prescribers of opioid substitution therapy, and female gender. CONCLUSIONS: In this study, long-term opioids for CNMP were frequently initiated without a quality approach to drug use. Possible consequences are inadequate treatment of pain and escalating opioid-related harm. These data suggest a need for improved resource acquisition and education in the use of opioids for pain and addiction.

title: An evidence-based guide to writing grant proposals for clinical research
abstract: In 1863, Florence Nightingale argued that London hospitals were dangerous, especially when compared to provincial institutions. She backed up this claim with statistics published in William Fair's Registrar-General report, claiming that 24 London hospitals had mortality rates in excess of 90%, while rural hospitals had an average mortality rate of 13%. Farr had calculated mortality rates by dividing the total number of patients who died over the year by the number of patients hospitalized on a single day. Calculated as the annual number of deaths divided by the total number of inpatients during the year, the mortality rate in London hospitals was 10%. A heated debate broke out in the London medical press about how best to calculate mortality rates in hospitals. Critics claimed Farr failed to adjust for differences in the severity of the disease between urban and rural hospitals and that his numbers mislead the public. Farr and Nightingale, in turn, criticized the poor quality of the hospital data. This story reinforces the need to understand the methodological derivation of statistics used to compare vendor quality.

title: An evolving perspective on physical activity counseling by healthcare professionals
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical inactivity is a modifiable risk factor for many chronic diseases and a major cause of premature mortality. An increasing proportion of adults worldwide are not engaging in sufficient physical activity to prevent or mitigate these adverse effects. Healthcare professionals have been identified as a potentially powerful source of influence for those who do not meet minimum physical activity guidelines. Healthcare professionals are respected and expected advisors and reach a large and relevant segment of the population. Despite this potential, health professionals do not routinely encourage physical activity. DISCUSSION: Physicians face several known barriers to physical activity promotion, including lack of time and a lack of perceived effectiveness in changing patients' physical activity behaviors. Additionally, the evidence for effective promotion of physical activity by healthcare professionals is inconclusive. To address these issues, new approaches to physical activity promotion are proposed. These include collaborating with community-based physical activity behavior change interventions, preparing patients for effective brief counseling during a consultation with healthcare professionals, and using interactive behavior change technologies. SUMMARY: It is important that we recognize the latent risk of physical inactivity in patients presenting to clinical settings. Preparing to improve the patient's physical activity behavior should begin prior to the consultation and may include physical activity screening. Healthcare professionals should also identify appropriate community interventions to which to refer physically inactive patients. Outsourcing the bulk of a comprehensive physical activity intervention to community-based interventions reduces the clinical consultation time required to address the issue in each patient. Priorities for future research include investigating ways to encourage successful referrals and then engaging in broader community support programs to increase physical activity in inactive patients. In addition, future clinical trials of physical activity interventions should be evaluated in the context of a broader set of outcomes to provide a systematic view of comprehensive strengths and weaknesses in relation to not only effectiveness but also cost-effectiveness and the likelihood of successful translation of interventions into clinical contexts to allow.

title: An experimental study on determinants of group judgments in clinical guideline development
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical guidelines to improve quality of care are a familiar part of clinical practice. Formal consensus procedures such as the nominal group technique are commonly used in guideline development, but little is known about factors affecting statements produced by nominal groups and their consistency with research evidence. METHODS: Cognitive-behavioral therapy, behavioral therapy, brief psychodynamic interpersonal therapy, and antidepressants for irritable bowel syndrome, chronic fatigue syndrome, and chronic low back pain were selected for the study. 16 nominal groups in a factorial design allowed comparison of pure primary care physicians with mixed groups of primary care physicians and specialists, providing a literature review without providing and ratings related to realistic or ideal health care resources. Participants rated appropriateness independently and again after a moderated meeting. Audio tapes from four group discussions were analyzed. RESULTS: 51% of the 192 scenarios agreed with the research results. Agreement was more likely when the group were primary care physicians only, when a review of the literature was presented, or when the evidence was consistent with the clinicians' beliefs. Assumptions about the amount of available resources had no influence. Clinical and social cues had mixed effects regardless of the research findings. The qualitative analysis showed the modifying effect of clinical experience and beliefs about research results. INTERPRETATION: Policies cannot be based on data alone";" Judgment is inevitable. The nominal group technique is a method to collect and aggregate judgments in a transparent and structured way. It can provide important information on the level of agreement between experts. However, the conclusions may conflict with the published literature. If this is the case, the reasons must be explicit.

title: An experimental study on determinants of group judgments in clinical guideline development
abstract: BackgroundClinical guidelines for improving the quality of care are a familiar part of clinical practice. Formal consensus procedures such as the nominal group technique are often used as part of guideline development, but little is known about factors influencing the statements produced by nominal groups and their consistency with the research evidence.";" BackgroundClinical guidelines for improving the quality of care are a familiar part of clinical practice. Formal consensus procedures such as the nominal group technique are commonly used in guideline development, but little is known about factors affecting statements produced by nominal groups and their consistency with research evidence.

title: An experimental study of determinants of the magnitude of disagreement within clinical guideline development groups
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effect of design features and clinical and social cues on the level of disagreement among participants in a formal consensus development process. METHODS: Factorial design with 16 groups consisting of 135 general practitioners (GPs) and 42 mental health professionals from England. The groups assessed the appropriateness of four mental health interventions for three conditions (chronic low back pain, irritable bowel syndrome, and chronic fatigue syndrome) in the context of various clinical and social cues. The groups differed on three design features: provision of a systematic literature review (vs. not provided), group composition (mixed vs. only general practitioners), and assumptions about available health care resources (realistic vs. idealistic). Deviation was measured as the mean absolute deviation from a group's mean rating for a scenario. RESULTS: None of the design features significantly influenced the level of disagreement within the groups (all p>0.3). Disagreements differed between treatments (closer consensus for cognitive behavioral therapy and behavioral therapy than for brief psychodynamic intervention therapy and antidepressants) and indications (closer consensus for depressed patients and patients willing to try any treatment). CONCLUSION: Concerning the level of disagreement in the groups of this study, formal consensus development was a robust technique because the results were not dependent on the way it was conducted.

title: An implementation research agenda
abstract: In October 2006, the Chief Medical Officer (CMO) of England asked Professor Sir John Tooke "On the State of Public Health" in response to the "Waste not, don't want" chapter in the CMO's 2005 annual report. The high-level group made recommendations to the CMO to discuss possible avenues to improve clinical effectiveness in the UK National Health Service (NHS) and encourage clinical commitment to achieve this. The report included a brief section on the research needs that emerged from the process of writing the report, but in order to more fully identify the relevant research agenda, Professor Sir John Tooke asked Professor Martin Eccles to convene an expert group - the Clinical Efficacy Research Agenda Group (CERAG ) – to set the research agenda. CERAG's brief was to "further develop the research agenda in relation to the pursuit of clinically effective practice within the (British) National Health Service". This editorial contains the executive summary of the CERAG report and recommendations.

title: An integrated safety, quality and risk management framework: an information and incident management system based on a universal patient safety classification
abstract: More needs to be done to improve safety, quality and manage risks in healthcare. Existing processes are fragmented and there is no single comprehensive source of information about what is going wrong. An integrated safety, quality and risk management framework is required, with an information and incident management system based on a universal patient safety classification. The World Alliance for Patient Safety provides a platform for developing a coherent approach";" 43 desirable attributes for such an approach are discussed. An example of an incident management and information system dedicated to patient safety is presented with a brief description of how and where it is currently used. Such a system is worthless unless it improves safety and quality. Quadruple loop learning (personal, local, national and international) is proposed with examples of how an example system has been used successfully at the different levels. Currently, there is an opportunity to “get it right” through international collaboration through the World Health Organization to develop an integrated framework that includes systems that can ingest information from all sources, manage and monitor errors, and enable the global exchange of information and the Dissemination of tools to implement strategies that are proven to work.

title: An integrative review examining decision factors influencing mental health nurses' use of restraint
abstract: UNLABELING: WHAT IS KNOWN ABOUT THE SUBJECT?: There is accumulating evidence highlighting the countertherapeutic effects of the use of restraint and encouraging the minimization of this practice in mental health care. Psychiatric nurses are often the profession that uses restraint, and understanding factors influencing their decision-making becomes crucial. To date, there are no other published works that have undertaken a similarly comprehensive search on this subject. WHAT DOES THIS PAPER ADD TO EXISTING KNOWLEDGE?: Eight emerging issues are identified as factors influencing mental health caregiver decision-making when using coercive measures. The themes are: safety for all, restraint as a necessary intervention, restraint as a last resort, role conflict, maintaining control, staff composition, knowledge and perception of patient behavior, and psychological impact “. "Last resort" seems to be the mantra of acceptable coercion use, although to date there have been no studies specifically addressing what this concept actually is. WHAT ARE THE IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE?: These findings should be considered when evaluating the use of restraint in mental health settings and appropriate strategies to support the transition to minimizing restraint. As the concept of “last resort” is mentioned in many policies and guidelines at the international level without a published understanding of what this means, research should prioritize this as a crucial next step in efforts to minimize restrictions. INTRODUCTION: While mechanical and manual restraint may sometimes seem necessary as an institutional control method in psychiatric settings, there is emerging literature that highlights the potential countertherapeutic implications of this practice for patients and staff. Nurses are the profession most likely to use mechanical and manual restraint methods in mental health settings. Therefore, in-depth insight is needed to understand what factors influence nurses' decision-making regarding the use of restraints. OBJECTIVE: To investigate what influences mental health nurse decision-making when using restraint. METHOD: An integrative review using Cooper's framework was performed. RESULTS: Eight emerging themes were identified: "Safety for all", "Restraint as a necessary intervention", "Restraint as a last resort", "Role conflict", "Maintaining control", "Staff composition", "Knowledge and perception of patient behaviour" and "psychological effects". These themes highlight how ethical and safety responsibilities, as well as interpersonal and staff-related factors, influence the decision-making of mental health caregivers. CONCLUSION: Research is needed to better understand the experience and realization of the 'last resort' in the use of restraint and to provide strategies to prevent the use of restraint in mental health settings.

title: Clinical Behavior Modification Intervention: Conceptual Framework for Multicolored Simplified Recall of Asthma Guidelines (MSAGR)
abstract: Clinical practice guidelines reduce variation in healthcare because they standardize the care provided by healthcare providers. Seventeen years after publication, the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program (NAEPP) guidelines are considered the "gold standard" in asthma management, but despite three revisions, most recently in July 2007, they remain underutilized. Several factors are cited for lack of compliance with the guidelines. This article reviews the Multicolored Simplified Asthma Guideline Reminder (MSAGR), an algorithmic graph intervention designed to help change physician behavior to better comply with NAEPP guidelines, and describes the conceptual framework that Underlies this intervention to predict better outcomes for providers and physicians in children.

title: An investigative journalist deals with medical ethics
abstract: KIE: Campbell criticizes the British medical and research community and the General Medical Council (GMC) for their lack of initiative in investigating the activities of doctors. James Sharp and Jabar Sultan. Sharp and Sultan conducted a series of highly publicized but unethical and potentially harmful experiments on private patients that were eventually made public through Campbell's report and a BBC television program. Campbell asks why senior doctors, journal reviewers, and others failed to speak out against Sharp and Sultan or to alert the GMC, and why the GMC failed to independently investigate the researchers. He warns that as UK medicine becomes more commercialised, legislation is needed to create a national regulator to oversee standards in the private sector.

title: An ongoing struggle: a mixed-methods systematic review of interventions, barriers, and facilitators to achieve optimal self-care among children and adolescents with type 1 diabetes in educational settings
abstract: BACKGROUND: Type 1 diabetes is more common among younger children, often of preschool age, who enter the educational system with evolving diabetes-related support needs over time. It is important that children are supported in optimizing their diet, exercise, blood glucose monitoring and insulin regime at school. Young people manage themselves at college/university. METHOD: Theory-based mixed-method systematic review to determine intervention effectiveness and synthesize child/parent/professional views on barriers and facilitators to achieving optimal diabetes self-care and management for children and adolescents aged 3-25 years in educational settings . RESULTS: Eleven intervention and 55 view studies were included. A meta-analysis was not possible. Focus of study Largely coordinated school diabetes counseling. Intervention studies were limited to specific contexts, mostly with a high risk of bias. Views studies were mostly of moderate quality with shared transferable results. Health plans and support from school nurses (various types) were effective. School telemedicine was effective for individual case management. Most educational interventions to increase children's or school staff's knowledge and confidence have had significant short-term effects, but longer follow-up is needed. Children, parents, and staff reported struggling with many common structural, organizational, educational, and attitudinal school barriers. Aspects of school counseling were not generally implemented (e.g. individual health plans). Children recognized and valued school staff who were trained and confident in supporting diabetes management. Research with college/university students was lacking. Supporting campus-based college/university students greatly improved knowledge, attitudes and diabetes self-care. Self-management was easier for students who juggled diabetes management with student lifestyles, such as B. The adoption of strategies to control alcohol consumption. CONCLUSION: This novel mixed-methods systematic review is the first to integrate the effectiveness of the intervention with the views of children/parents/professionals matched against school diabetes guidelines. Diabetes management in general could be improved by fully implementing and reviewing the impact of the guidelines. Evidence is limited by quality and there are gaps in knowledge about what works. Telemedicine between health care providers and schools, and the support of children by school nurses are effective in certain contexts, but not all education systems employ nurses locally. More innovative and sustainable solutions and robust assessments are required. Comprehensive lifestyle approaches for college/university students need to be further developed and evaluated.

title: An update on the management of the patient with non-ST elevation acute coronary artery syndrome
abstract: Over 780,000 patients in the United States are diagnosed with Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) each year. As physicians, it is our responsibility to promptly screen, diagnose, and treat these patients. After identifying the patient with ACS and confirming that they do not have an ST segment elevation myocardial infarction that requires immediate revascularization, physicians should perform evaluation for non-ST segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS). It is important to understand the latest best practice guidelines for the treatment and management of patients with NSTE-ACS, who have a high in-hospital mortality rate. Physicians must integrate the history and examination, electrocardiogram, and laboratory findings to properly diagnose NSTE-ACS. Even with an early invasive strategy with cardiac catheter and percutaneous coronary intervention, early treatment with guideline-based drug therapy is essential. The focus of this review is to discuss appropriate strategies for evaluating and managing patients with NSTE-ACS based on the most recent ACC/AHA practice guidelines.

title: Anesthesia and other treatments for shell shock: World War I and beyond
abstract: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a major health risk factor for military personnel engaged in modern warfare. During World War I, this condition (then known as shell shock or "neurasthenia") was such a problem that French doctors began "forward psychiatry" in 1915. Some British doctors meanwhile tried general anesthesia (ether and chloroform). others preferred the use of electricity. In 1917, four British "Forward Psychiatric Units" were established. Hospitals for shell-shocked soldiers were also set up in Britain, including (for officers) the Craiglockhart War Hospital in Edinburgh. Patients diagnosed with more serious psychiatric conditions have been transferred to the Royal Edinburgh Asylum. By late 1918, anesthetic and electrical treatments for grenade shock were gradually being supplanted by modified Freudian methods of psychodynamic intervention. The effectiveness of "forward psychiatry" has been disputed. In 1922 the War Office produced a report on shell shock with recommendations for preventing war neuroses. However, when World War II broke out in 1939, this seemed to have been ignored. The term "combat fatigue" was introduced when failure rates became alarming, and then the value of pre-selection was realized. At Maudsley Hospital, London, in 1940, barbiturate abreaction was advocated for rapid relief of severe anxiety and hysteria using iv anesthetics: somnifain, paraldehyde, sodium amytal. "Pentothal anesthesia" and "narcoanalysis" were adopted by British and American military psychiatrists. By 1945, however, medical thought gradually settled on the same approaches that seemed effective in 1918. The term PTSD was introduced in 1980. In the UK, the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) recommends guidelines for management (2005). Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy and consideration of antidepressants.

title: Analgesia and anesthesia for the newborn: study design and ethical issues
abstract: AIM: The purpose of this article is to summarize the clinical, methodological, and ethical considerations for researchers interested in designing future studies in neonatal analgesia and anesthesia, hopefully stimulating further research in this area. METHODS: The MEDLINE, PubMed, EMBASE, and Cochrane registry databases were searched using keywords related to infant, neonatal, neonatal, analgesia, anesthesia, ethics, and study design. Cross-references and personnel files were searched manually. Studies with original data or review articles on these topics were viewed and critically evaluated by experts in the respective subject areas. Data on population demographics, study characteristics, and cognitive and behavioral outcomes were abstracted and synthesized in a systematic manner and refined by the group members. The data synthesis and results were reviewed by a panel of independent experts and presented to a wider audience including clinicians, scientists, supervisors and industry representatives at the Newborn Drug Development Initiative workshop. The recommendations were revised after extensive discussions at the workshop and among committee members. RESULTS: The design of clinical trials investigating new or currently available approaches to analgesia and anesthesia in the newborn requires consideration of study design excellence and ethical issues. Conditions requiring treatment include pain/stress from invasive procedures, surgical procedures, inflammatory conditions, and routine neonatal critical care. Study design considerations must define inclusion and exclusion criteria, a rationale for stratification, the confounding effects of comorbid conditions, and other clinical factors. Key ethical issues include the limitations of neonatal screening, obtaining informed consent, conducting risk-benefit assessments, setting allowances or rewards for participation, safety considerations, use of placebo controls, and differences between the institutional review bodies in the interpretation of federal guidelines on human research. Optimal study design requires investigators to formulate well-defined study questions, select appropriate study designs, assess drug efficacy, calculate sample size, determine study duration, identify pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic parameters, and avoid drug-drug interactions. Specific outcome measures may include assessment on pain rating scales, various biomarkers and their response patterns, process outcomes (eg, length of stay, time to extubation), intermediate or long-term outcomes, and safety parameters. CONCLUSIONS: Much more research is needed in this area to formulate a scientifically sound, evidence-based, and clinically useful framework for the management of anesthesia and analgesia in the neonate. Newer study designs and additional ethical dilemmas can be defined with accumulating data in this area.

title: Analysis of investigational drug safety information submitted by clinical trial sponsors
abstract: During the conduct of clinical trials in medical facilities, investigational drug safety information is submitted by trial sponsors in accordance with good clinical practice guidelines. The present study examined reports of clinical trials conducted at Tokyo University Hospital, with a focus on the safety information provided to the Institutional Review Board (IRB). 202 reports (52 protocols) containing safety information were submitted to the IRB by clinical trial sponsors between April 2000 and March 2001, of which 185 contained a total of 3021 adverse event cases. Of these, 194 clinical investigator/physician reports were assessed as not associated with significant problems and the studies continued. For 157 of these 194 reports, it was considered unnecessary to inform subjects about the content of the report, including adverse events. The decision as to whether subjects should be informed about such content or not depended more on the causal relationship between the adverse events and medication intake and the predictability of the adverse events. For 8 of these 194 reports, the IRB recommended that the investigators/physicians provide information to the subjects and/or provide the IRB with detailed information on the status of those subjects. Based on these results, we propose that establishing a system for unifying and assessing drug safety information is necessary to provide safe and efficient clinical trials.

title: Angina on the Palm: Randomized Controlled Pilot Trial of Palm PDA Software for Cardiac Test Referrals.
abstract: GOAL Personal Digital Assistants (PDAs) are popular with physicians: in 2003, 33% of Canadian physicians reported using them in their practice. However, we do not know if using an epidural changes the behavior of practicing physicians. We evaluated the effectiveness of a PDA software application to help primary care physicians diagnose angina in patients with chest pain. DESIGN Prospective randomized controlled pilot study using a cluster design. RECRUITMENT Primary care practices in the Toronto area. PARTICIPANTS Eighteen primary care physicians affiliated with the North Toronto Primary Care Research Network (Nortren) or recruited from a local hospital. INTERVENTIONS We randomized physicians to receive a Palm PDA (which contained the angina diagnostic software) or to continue conventional care. Physicians prospectively charted the treatment process for patients aged 30 to 75 years presenting with suspected angina pectoris over a 7-month period. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Has the treatment process for patients with suspected angina improved when their physicians had PDAs and software? The primary endpoints we considered were the frequency of orders for cardiac stress testing for suspected angina and the adequacy of referral for cardiac stress testing at presentation and for nuclear cardiac testing after cardiac stress testing. The secondary endpoint was referrals to cardiologists. RESULTS The software resulted in greater use of cardiac stress testing overall (81% vs. 50%). The absolute increase was 31% (p=0.007, 95% confidence interval [CI] 8% to 58%). There was a trend toward more appropriate use of exercise testing (48.6% with PDA vs. 28.6% controls), a 20% increase (P=0.284, 95% CI -11.54% to 51.4% ).
