There was also a trend toward more appropriate use of nuclear cardiology after cardiac exercise testing (63.0% vs. 45.5%), an absolute increase of 17.5% (p=0.400, 95% CI -13.9% to 48 .9%). Referrals to cardiologists did not increase (38.2% with the epidural vs. 40.9%, p=0.869). CONCLUSION A PDA-based software application can lead to improved care of patients with suspected angina in primary care offices";" this finding needs to be confirmed in a larger study.

title: anorexia
Antibiotic prescribing in long-term care settings: a qualitative, multidisciplinary study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To explore the views of healthcare professionals on antibiotic prescribing in Long-Term Care Facilities (LTCFs). Using the results to recommend intervention strategies for antimicrobial stewardship in LTCFs. DESIGN: Qualitative semi-structured interviews were conducted. The data were analyzed by thematic content analysis. After the interviews, the emerging findings were mapped to the Theory Domains Framework (TDF), and the behavior change wheel and behavior change technique (BCT) taxonomy were used to recommend future intervention strategies. PARTICIPANTS: Between December 2012 and March 2013, interviews were conducted with 37 health professionals working in LTCFs (10 general practitioners, 4 specialists, 14 nurses, 9 pharmacists). USE: The interviews were conducted in Greater Cork. RESULTS: The main domains from the TDF that emerged were: 'Knowledge', 'Environmental Context and Resources', 'Social Influences', 'Consequence Beliefs', 'Memory, Attention and Decision Making', with the results identifying a need for "Behaviour Regulation". Many participants felt that antibiotic prescribing at their LTCF was satisfactory despite a lack of surveillance activities. CONCLUSIONS: Using the TDF and BCT taxonomy, this study found that antibiotic prescribing in LTCFs is influenced by many social and contextual factors. The challenges of the setting and the patient population, the belief in the consequences for the patient and the lack of implementation of guidelines and knowledge regarding antibiotic prescribing patterns are significant challenges that need to be addressed. Based on the study results and application of the TDF and BCT taxonomy, we propose some practical intervention features for antimicrobial stewardship in LTCFs.

title: antibiotic resistance
abstract: Resistance to antibiotics is economically and physiologically costly. Controlling antibiotic resistance will require the aggressive implementation of numerous strategies. Ongoing surveillance is required to monitor known types of antibiotics and to be able to detect the development of other potential types. Early intervention is required to combat the rising resistance rate. The consistent application of hygiene measures and the controlled use of antibiotics contain the spread of antibiotic resistance. Healthcare providers must monitor compliance with control measures. Hand and environmental control measures remain a critical part of employee training activities. Active management of infections with non-pharmacological treatments should be encouraged. Motivational campaigns will reinforce positive infection control behaviors. Consistent monitoring of antibiotic use will help meet CDC guidance on combating antimicrobial resistance and maintain population health.

title: Antibiotic treatment for 6 weeks versus 12 weeks in patients with pyogenic vertebral osteomyelitis: an open-label, randomized, controlled, noninferiority study
abstract: Background The duration of treatment for patients with vertebral osteomyelitis is mainly based on expert advice and not on evidence. Our aim was to determine whether 6-week antibiotic treatment is non-inferior to 12-week treatment in patients with pyogenic vertebral osteomyelitis.";" Background The duration of treatment for patients with vertebral osteomyelitis is mainly based on expert advice and not on evidence. Our aim was to determine whether 6-week antibiotic treatment is non-inferior to 12-week treatment in patients with pyogenic vertebral osteomyelitis.

title: Sample of antimalarial drug prescribing in government hospitals and selected semi-government hospitals in Lagos, Nigeria
abstract: BACKGROUND: Malaria is a curable and preventable disease and a major public health problem in Nigeria. Chloroquine was until recently the drug of choice in its treatment in Nigeria, where artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are being promoted. Inappropriate prescribing, that is, failure to prescribe drugs according to guidelines based on scientific evidence to ensure safe, effective, and economical use, is irrational drug use behavior. Greater benefit from chloroquine or slowing the progression of resistance could be achieved through improvements in prescribing practice, drug quality and patient compliance. OBJECTIVE: To determine the antimalarial prescribing pattern and evaluate the rational prescribing of chloroquine by prescribers in state hospitals and parastatal institutions in Lagos State. METHODS: The study was conducted in all ten state general hospitals under the Lagos State Hospitals Management Board (now Lagos State Health Service Commission), one semi-state hospital and one oil company clinic using patient prescriptions. Over a period of one year (January to December 2000), 100 prescriptions each for adults and children were systematically sampled for each month. If there were fewer than 100 prescriptions in a month, all available prescriptions were used for the analysis. RESULTS: The mean number of medications per contact in all hospitals was 4.259 +/- 0.009. The average number of injections per encounter was 1.215 +/- 0.009. About 48.5% of all prescriptions contained at least one injection, while 40.9% of prescriptions contained a dipyrone injection. The average drug cost per encounter was N 147.40 +/- 0.765. The percentage of encounters with chloroquine was 82.5%, followed by sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine 14.2%. The percentage of prescriptions with the correct chloroquine dose was 47.5%. CONCLUSIONS: Polypharmacy exists in all hospitals. The average number of medications per contact was over 4 for most hospitals. Less than half of the prescriptions contained the correct dose of chloroquine. This study can serve as a basis for interventions in irrational prescribing.

title: Antioxidant vitamin supplement to prevent cardiovascular disease
abstract: Oxidative stress, in particular the oxidative modification of LDL cholesterol, appears to be of great importance in the pathogenesis of arteriosclerosis. Various observational epidemiological studies suggest that intake of antioxidant vitamins is associated with reduced cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. Also, experimental animal studies have shown that antioxidant vitamins slow the progression of atherosclerosis. However, prospective controlled clinical trials have failed to demonstrate any benefit of antioxidant vitamin supplementation in the primary or secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease. Therefore, the use of antioxidants and vitamin supplements cannot be recommended as a preventive or therapeutic intervention.

title: Antipruritic therapy in atopic eczema
abstract: In patients with atopic eczema, the quality of life is severely impaired by excruciating itching. Because the pathogenesis of pruritus is not understood, symptomatic measures are the mainstay of treatment, along with avoidance of aggravating factors. These include emollients, topical and systemic agents, and physical therapies (eg, phototherapy) appropriate to the severity of the condition. Behavioral therapy provides additional support. New treatment modalities, some of which are still in the experimental stage, such as immunomodulators, immunosuppressants and opiate antagonists, are reserved for unresponsive patients";" They too will be checked.

title: Antipsychotic polypharmacy in schizophrenia: benefits and risks
abstract: Antipsychotic polypharmacy refers to the concurrent prescription of more than one antipsychotic drug for a single patient. International surveys of psychiatric service prescriptions have identified the relatively frequent and consistent use of combination antipsychotics, usually in people with pre-existing schizophrenia, with a prevalence of up to 50% in some clinical settings. A common reason for prescribing more than one antipsychotic is to achieve a greater or faster therapeutic response than has been achieved with antipsychotic monotherapy. However, the evidence on the risks and benefits of such a strategy is inconclusive and is generally not considered sufficient to justify a recommendation for its use in routine psychiatric clinical practice. Combination antipsychotics contribute significantly to the prescription of high doses, are associated with an increased burden of side effects, and are of limited value in determining the optimal maintenance regimen for a patient. The relatively widespread use of antipsychotic polypharmacy found in cross-sectional surveys reflects not only the addition of a second antipsychotic to enhance therapeutic response, but also the use of antipsychotics as needed (mainly to treat behavioral disorders) and a gradual cross-titration switch from one antipsychotic to another and supplementing clozapine with a second antipsychotic when the disease has not responded adequately to an optimized trial of clozapine. This review reviews clinical trial data and other evidence for each of these pharmacological approaches. Also reviewed are examples of systematic, practice-based interventions to reduce the prevalence of antipsychotic drug polypharmacy, most of which have had only modest success. The guidelines generally agree that when combination antipsychotics are prescribed for the treatment of refractory psychotic disorders, this should be done after other, evidence-based, pharmacological treatments such as clozapine have been exhausted. In addition, their prescription should be based on an individual study for each patient, with monitoring of clinical response and side effects, and appropriate physical health monitoring.

title: Application of a hospital audit to the use of nebulizers: the case of the Hotel-Dieu de France-Lebanon
abstract: PROBLEM: The aim of the study was to reduce unjustified prescriptions of nebulization therapy in order to comply with international guidelines and reduce healthcare costs. METHODS: DESIGN: We conducted a controlled, prospective study to assess the impact of local policies to improve physician behavior on adequacy and cost of implementation. BACKGROUND AND INSTITUTION: All departments of a university hospital: medical and surgical departments, intensive care units, emergency rooms and day wards. KEY CHANGE ACTION: Reducing the number of inappropriate nebulization therapy prescriptions. STRATEGIES FOR CHANGE: Implementation included two educational presentations, posters posted in all departments, emails to all physicians and residents, and a prescription re-evaluation a week later. RESULTS: Before the intervention, the rate of inappropriate prescriptions was 11.9% (42/358 of the patients treated with nebulizers had no indication for this treatment and 3/19 of the patients had an indication for nebulization but were not treated)”; In the postintervention, the rate of inappropriate prescriptions was 14.6% (15.7% patients with no treatment indication, but no patient with treatment indication untreated), reflecting a lack of significant impact of the intervention. CONCLUSIONS: The mere presentation of clinical guidelines led not a change in medical practice Effectively improving this outcome requires a different approach.

title: Use of the MAT-CHDSP to assess guideline adherence and therapeutic goal achievement in secondary prevention of coronary artery disease after percutaneous coronary intervention
abstract: PURPOSE: Numerous studies have documented suboptimal adherence to guideline recommendations in secondary prevention of coronary artery disease (CAD(SP)). Clinical Practice Guidelines (CPGs) are continually evolving to define appropriate patient care and reduce the risk of morbidity and death. The Medication Assessment Tool for CHD(SP) (MAT-CHD(SP)) was developed to assess adherence to guidelines for medication therapy and follow-up of patients with CHD(SP). The aim of this study was to investigate whether the MAT-CHD(SP) can be used retrospectively to assess adherence to guidelines and the achievement of therapy goals in secondary prevention of CHD. METHODS: We collected electronic medical record data from all patients who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention with stenting from January to March 2008 (n = 300) and applied the MAT-CHD (SP). We measured the time for data collection and MAT application, and tested reproducibility by calculating Cohen's kappa value (kappa) for between- and within-observer agreement. RESULTS: A total of 247 MAT applications were analyzed, showing an overall applicability of 66% of the 4,446 MAT-CHD(SP) criteria and high reproducibility of MAT-CHD(SP) application (kappa values 0.93 and 0.95 for intra- and interobserver) showed agreement respectively). The median time for data collection and MAT-CHD(SP) application was 11 min. Compliance with prescribing criteria was high (>75%), but cholesterol and blood pressure therapy goals were low (<50%). Documentation of lifestyle counseling achieved moderate (50-75%) or low adherence, as did therapy adjustments for patients who failed to meet therapy goals at hospital admission. CONCLUSIONS: The MAT-CHD(SP) provides a means to identify both compliance and non-compliance with CHD(SP) guidelines, is applicable in the retrospective assessment of CHD(SP), and identifies potential for improved patient care.

title: Applying theory to improve audit and feedback interventions to increase acceptance of evidence-based transfusion practices: an intervention development protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Audits of blood transfusions show that approximately 20% of transfusions fall outside of national recommendations and guidelines. Audit and feedback are widely used quality improvement interventions, but the implications for clinical practice vary, suggesting room for improvement. Behavior theory, theoretical frameworks of behavior change, and behavior change techniques provide systematic processes for improving intervention. This study is part of a larger program of work to promote the adoption of evidence-based transfusion practice. OBJECTIVES: The objectives of this study are to develop two theoretically improved audit and feedback interventions";" one focused on content and one on delivery, examining feasibility and acceptability. METHODS: Study A (Content): A coding framework based on current evidence on audit and feedback and behavior change theory and framework is developed and applied as part of a structured content analysis to specify the key components of existing feedback documents. Prototype feedback documents with improved content and also a protocol describing principles for improving the feedback content will be developed. Study B (Delivery): Individual semi-structured interviews with healthcare professionals and observations of team meetings at four hospitals are used to specify and ascertain views on current audit and feedback practice. The interviews are based on a topic guide developed using the Theoretical Domains Framework and the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research. Analysis of transcripts based on these frameworks will provide the evidence base for the development of a protocol describing an improved intervention focused on providing feedback. Study C (Feasibility and Acceptability): Improved interventions are being tested in four hospitals. Semi-structured interviews, questionnaires, and observations are used to assess feasibility and acceptability. DISCUSSION: This intervention development work reflects the UK Medical Research Council's guidance on complex intervention development, which emphasizes the importance of a robust theoretical basis for intervention design and recommends a systematic assessment of feasibility and acceptability before evaluating interventions in their full randomized trial. The workup includes an indication of current practice so that in the studies to be conducted later in this program there will be a clear distinction between the control conditions (common practice) and the interventions to be evaluated.

title: Applying decision architecture principles to understanding HIV testing: Lessons learned from Malawi and Zimbabwe
abstract: Improvements driven by the World Health Organization in prenatal HIV counseling in sub-Saharan Africa from 2004 to 2011 have led to a parallel increase in HIV testing. We sought to determine to what extent the application of architectural choice principles (one that introduces an opt-out option by default) influences HIV testing uptake, beyond attitudes and cognitions at the individual level. Demographic and health survey data were analyzed between 2004 and 2011 from Zimbabwe (N=1,330) and Malawi (N=4,043)—countries where more than 10% of adults are infected with HIV. We examined the influence of demographic variables, forms of knowledge about HIV, stigma of people living with HIV, attitudes towards spousal abuse, and whether or not HIV testing was offered during antenatal visits. Results showed that, accounting for secular trends in higher testing rates, support at the structural level was the strongest predictor of HIV testing, over and above individual-level attitudes and cognitions. Read more: https://guilfordjournals.com/doi/abs/10.1521/aeap.2015.27.4.362

title: Approaches based on behavioral economics could help motivate patients and providers to slow down growth in healthcare spending
abstract: Measures that change the environment or context in which decisions are made and 'nudge' people to make certain decisions have been relatively ignored in healthcare. This article examines the role behavioral economics-based approaches could play in 'nudging' healthcare providers and patients in ways that could slow healthcare spending growth. The fundamental insight of behavioral economics is that behavior is guided by the highly fallible human brain and is heavily influenced by the environment or context in which decisions are made. In policy areas such as pensions and personal savings, approaches based on behavioral economics have yielded remarkable results. In healthcare, such approaches have been used successfully, but in limited ways, such as the use of surgical checklists, which have increased patient safety and reduced costs. As healthcare spending grows at an unsustainable pace, we examine the role that behavioral economics-based approaches could play in offering policymakers a range of potential new tools to slow spending growth.

title: Architectural framework: Definition of the structures for the implementation of learning health systems
abstract: Background The vision of transforming health systems into learning health systems (LHSs) that rapidly and continuously convert knowledge into improved health outcomes at lower cost is attracting increasing interest from government agencies, health organizations, and health research communities. While existing initiatives show that different approaches can successfully realize the vision of LHS, they are too different in purpose, focus and scale to be reproduced without undue effort. In fact, the necessary structures to effectively design and implement LHS on a larger scale are lacking. In this paper, we propose the use of architectural frameworks to develop LHSs that follow an accepted vision while being adapted to their specific organizational context. Architectural frameworks are general descriptions of an organization as a system";" They capture the structure of its main components at different levels, the interrelationships between these components, and the principles that guide their development. Because these frameworks support the analysis of LHS and allow the simulation of their results, they act as pre-implementation decision aids that identify potential roadblocks and prerequisites for system development. This increases the chances of a successful LHS application. Discussion We present an architectural framework for LHSs that encompasses five dimensions: scientific, social, technical, and ethical goals, which are common in the LHS literature. The proposed architectural framework consists of six levels of decision-making that model these dimensions. The performance layer models goals, the science layer models the scientific dimension, the organization layer models the social dimension, the data layer and information technology layer models the technical dimension, and the ethics and security layer models the ethical dimension. We describe the types of decisions that need to be made within each level and identify methods to support decision making. Conclusion In this article, we outline a high-level architectural framework based on conceptual and empirical LHS literature. Application of this architectural framework can guide the development and implementation of new LHSs and the evolution of existing ones, as it allows for a clear and critical understanding of the types of decisions underlying LHS operations. Further research is needed to evaluate and refine its generalizability and methods.

title: Are non-specific practice guidelines potentially harmful? A randomized comparison of the effect of non-specific versus specific guidelines on physician decision-making
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To test the ability of two different clinical practice guideline formats to influence physician prescribing of electrodiagnostic testing in low back pain. DATA SOURCES/STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial of the effect of practice guidelines on physicians' self-reported ordering behavior in response to a series of 12 clinical vignettes. The data are from a national random sample of 900 US neurologists, physical medicine physicians, and general internists. INTERVENTION: Two different versions of a practice guideline for the use of electrodiagnostic testing (EDT) were developed by the US Public Health Policy Agency and the Research Low Back Problems Panel. The two guidelines were similar in content but differed in the specificity of their recommendations. DATA COLLECTION: The proportion of clinical vignettes for which EDTs were ordered for appropriate and inappropriate clinical indications in each of the three physician groups was randomly assigned to receive vignettes only, vignettes plus the non-specific version of the guideline, or vignettes plus the specific version of the guideline policy. KEY FINDINGS: The survey response rate was 71 percent. The proportion of eligible vignettes for which EDTs were ordered averaged 77 percent for the no-guideline group, 71 percent for the no-guideline-specific group, and 79 percent for the guideline-specific group (p = .002). The corresponding values for the number of EDTs ordered because of unsuitable vignettes were 32 percent, 32 percent and 26 percent, respectively (p = 0.08). Pairwise comparisons showed that physicians who received the nonspecific guidelines ordered fewer EDTs for appropriate clinical vignettes than physicians who did not receive the guidelines (p=0.02). Additionally, physicians with specific guidelines ordered significantly more EDTs for appropriate vignettes (p=.0007) and significantly fewer EDTs for inappropriate vignettes (p=.04) compared to physicians with non-specific guidelines. CONCLUSIONS: The clarity and clinical applicability of a guideline can be important attributes that contribute to the impact of practice guidelines.

title: Are nurses an answer to new needs in primary care?
Are the clinicians of the psychiatric crisis assessment and treatment team at the forefront of psychotherapy?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: There is limited data on the psychological interventions used by clinicians on the Crisis Assessment and Treatment (CAT) team, although practice guidelines dictate that part of their role is to provide counseling. This study aimed to catalog and categorize the spectrum of psychotherapeutic interventions used by clinicians on a CAT team operating in a metropolitan area. METHODS: Self-report, treatment episode data was collected regarding clinicians' views of the type of psychotherapeutic intervention they used and details of what they discussed with patients, as well as the location and duration of the interventions. RESULTS: Thirty-two nursing episodes were cataloged. On average, clinicians spent 74% of their total contact time with patients involved in psychological interventions. A wide range of strategies based on a broad theoretical basis was used. Aside from general approaches that support engagement, interventions could be grouped into the following categories: metastrategy ('treatment about treatment'), 'critical', 'practical', specifically psychotherapeutic (cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and others), and supportive. CONCLUSIONS: Clinicians saw themselves as spending the majority of patient contact time on psychological interventions that have a broad theoretical basis. Observational studies of what clinicians actually do and empirical research into their effectiveness can have implications for clinician training and supervision.

title: Have national NHS results frameworks passed their expiry date?
Are we adequately preparing the next generation of physicians to prescribe exercise as prevention and treatment? Residents express the desire for more training in the exercise ordinance
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity (PA) is a key intervention for chronic disease, yet few physicians provide a prescription for physical activity (EP). EP is an important component in broader strategies to reduce noncommunicable diseases (NCDs). Our aim was to assess the knowledge, competence and perspectives of general practitioners (FMR) to inform future curriculum development. METHODS: A 49-item cross-sectional survey was conducted at 396 University of British Columbia FMRs. Residents' EP knowledge, competence, attitudes/beliefs, current practices, personal physical activity level, and exercise prospects were assessed primarily using a 7-point Likert scale. RESULTS: The response rate was 80.6% (319/396). After eliminating 25 that did not meet the inclusion criteria, 294 were included in the final analysis. A majority of 95.6% of FMRs identified EP as important in their future practice, despite having low knowledge of Canadian PA guidelines (mean score 1.77/4), low self-reported competence in prescribing exercise for prevention (mean score 13.35/21) and self-rating as “somewhat incompetent” and prescribing exercise to patients with chronic conditions (mean score 11.26/21). FMR believe PA is an essential part of their patients' health (98.0%), physical inactivity is harmful (97.9%), and feel obligated to discuss PA with patients (99.7%). Few FMRs (14.9%) found their training in EP adequate and 91.0% would like more. CONCLUSIONS: FMR report EP is important but they are not adequately prepared to provide EP. In future curriculum development, medical educators should consider the low level of knowledge, low competency, perceived support from the program, and their expressed desire for more training in prescribing exercise.

title: ARIA 2016: Treatment pathways implementing new technologies for predictive medicine in rhinitis and asthma across the life cycle
abstract: The Allergic Rhinitis and its Impact on Asthma (ARIA) initiative was launched in 1999 during a World Health Organization workshop. The initial objectives were (1) to propose a new classification of allergic rhinitis, (2) to promote the concept of multimorbidity in asthma and rhinitis, and (3) to develop guidelines with all stakeholders that could be used worldwide for all countries and populations . ARIA is distributed and implemented in over 70 countries worldwide and is now focused on implementing new technologies for individualized and predictive medicine. MASK [MACVIA (Contre les Maladies Chroniques pour un Vieillissement Actif)-ARIA Sentinel Network] uses mobile technology to develop treatment pathways for the management of rhinitis and asthma by a multidisciplinary group and by the patients themselves. An app (Android and iOS) is available in 20 countries and 15 languages. It uses a visual analog scale to assess symptom control and work productivity, and a clinical decision support system. It is connected to an interoperable tablet for doctors and other healthcare professionals. The scaling-up strategy uses the recommendations of the European Innovation Partnership on Active and Healthy Ageing. The aim of the novel ARIA approach is to enable rhinitis patients, regardless of age, gender or socioeconomic status, to lead active and healthy lives in order to reduce health and social inequalities caused by the disease.

title: Arriba: Effects of an educational intervention on prescribing behavior in the prevention of CVD in general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is insufficient evidence on the effectiveness of prescribing behavioral modification education to prevent cardiovascular disease. We evaluated the impact of a brief educational intervention on the prescribing of hydroxymethylglutaryl-CoA reductase inhibitors (statins), antiplatelet drugs (IPA), and antihypertensive drugs (AH). DESIGN: Cluster randomized controlled trial with groups of general practitioners (GPs) in continuing medical education (CME). METHODS: Prescribing of statins, IPA, and AH was reviewed at baseline (BL), immediately after the index consultation (IC), and at the 6-month follow-up (FU). Prescribing for high-risk patients (>15% risk of a cardiovascular event in 10 years, based on Framingham's equation) and no prescribing for low-risk patients (</= 15%) were considered appropriate. Results: An intervention effect on prescription could only be determined for IPA. In general, changes in prescribing over time all aimed at higher prescribing rates and remained at FU regardless of risk status and group assignment. CONCLUSIONS: Active implementation of a brief evidence-based educational intervention on global risk in cardiovascular disease did not directly result in risk-adjusted changes in prescription. Studies over a longer period would determine whether such decision support would sustainably improve risk-adjusted prescribing.

title: Articles on Diagnostic Tests: A New Series and an Invitation to Authors
Assessing the availability of scientific journals, databases, and health library services in Canadian health departments: a cross-sectional study
abstract: Background Evidence-based health policy logically depends on timely access to research evidence. To our knowledge, despite significant political and societal pressure to improve the use of the best available research in public health policy and program decision-making, there is no study addressing the availability of peer-reviewed research in Canada's Departments of Health. Objectives To assess the availability of (1) a targeted selection of high-quality scientific journals, (2) bibliographic databases, and (3) health library services in Canada's fourteen Departments of Health. Methods From May to October 2011, we conducted a cross-sectional survey of librarians employed by Canada's Departments of Health to collect information on the availability of scholarly journals, bibliographic databases, and health library services. The availability of scholarly journals in each ministry was determined using a sample of 48 journals selected from the 2009 Journal Citation Reports (Sciences and Social Sciences Editions). Selection criteria were: relevance to health policy based on scope note information on subject categories and journal popularity based on impact factors. Results We found that the majority of Canadian Health Departments did not have subscription access to major journals and relied heavily on interlibrary lending. Overall, based on a sample of top-ranked scholarly journals, the availability of journals via interlibrary loan, online, and print-only subscriptions was estimated at 63%, 28%, and 3%, respectively. Health Canada had 2.3 times more journal subscriptions than the provincial department average. Most organizations provided access to numerous subject-specific and multidisciplinary databases. Many organizations provided access to the library resources described through library partnerships or consortia. No professionally maintained health library was found in four out of fourteen Canadian Departments of Health (ie, Manitoba Health, Northwest Territories Department of Health and Human Services, Nunavut Department of Health and Human Services, and Yukon Department of Health and Human Services). Conclusions There is unequal availability of peer-reviewed research across Canada's fourteen Departments of Health. This inequity could pose a problem, as each province and territory is responsible for formulating and implementing evidence-based health policies and services for the benefit of its population.

title: Assessing the impact of national guidelines on the management of children hospitalized for acute bronchiolitis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Acute bronchiolitis is a common condition that accounts for $500 million in hospitalizations annually. Despite the frequency of bronchiolitis, its diagnosis and treatment varies. To counteract this variability, the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) published an evidence-based practice management guideline for bronchiolitis in 2006. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate changes in physician behavior in the management of bronchiolitis before and after the publication of the 2006 AAP bronchiolitis guideline hospitalized with a primary or secondary discharge diagnosis of bronchiolitis. Pre-guideline diagrams from 2004 to 2005 and post-guideline diagrams from 2007 to 2008 were collected. Evaluation and therapeutic interventions before and during hospitalization were analyzed. Data were analyzed using chi-square analysis for categorical variables, Mann-Whitney tests for continuous variables. RESULTS: One thousand two hundred thirty-three patients met the inclusion criteria. Rates of diagnostic laboratory tests did not decrease after publication of the guideline. The number of chest X-rays received decreased from 72.9% to 66.7% after guidelines (p=0.02). Fewer children received a trial with racemic epinephrine (17.8% vs. 12.2%, P=0.006) or albuterol (81.6% vs. 72.6%, P<0.0001) according to the guidelines, and physicians were more likely to discontinue albuterol if documented in the post-guideline period (28.6% vs. 78.9%, P<0.0001). Corticosteroid use in children without RAD or a history of asthma fell according to guidelines (26.5% vs. 17.5%, P<0.0001). CONCLUSIONS: According to the guidelines, a slight change in physician behavior was observed when treating inpatients with bronchiolitis. Additional education and training for healthcare providers is warranted to reduce unnecessary interventions and consumption of healthcare resources.

title: Assessment of treatment-as-usual for control groups in adherence studies: exploring the use of an open-ended questionnaire to identify behavior modification techniques
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Reporting guidelines require detailed descriptions of control group support as well as interventions. However, it remains unclear how to assess the active content (behavior modification techniques (BCTs)) of treatment-as-usual (TAU) administered to control groups in trials. The aim of this study is to pretest a method for assessing TAU in a multicenter cost-effectiveness study of an HIV treatment adherence intervention. DESIGN: HIV caregivers (N=21) completed a semi-structured, open-ended questionnaire asking about TAU compliance counseling. Two coders independently encoded BCTs. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: Completeness and clarity of nurse responses, intercoder reliabilities, and the types of BCTs reported were examined. RESULTS: The clarity and completeness of the nurses' responses were adequate. Twenty-three of the 26 identified BCTs could be reliably encoded (mean kappa = 0.79; mean agreement rate = 96%) and three BCTs scored below kappa = 0.60. The total number of BCTs reported per nurse ranged from 7 to 19 (M=13.86, SD=3.35). CONCLUSIONS: This study suggests that the open-ended TAU questionnaire is a viable and reliable tool to capture the active content of support provided to control participants in a multicenter compliance intervention study. Considerable variability was observed in the number of BCTs administered to control patients, highlighting the importance of reliable detection and accurate reporting of control group support.

title: Assessment and lifestyle management of patients with obesity: clinical recommendations from systematic reviews
abstract: IMPORTANT: Although one-third of US adults are obese, obesity detection and treatment rates remain low. Physician commitment is critical to providing overweight or obese patients with guidance and support to address the underlying cause of many chronic diseases. OBJECTIVES: To describe current best practices for the assessment and management of obesity and how the updated (2013) guidelines for the management of overweight and obesity in adults are based on a systematic review of evidence published by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI) can be applied to a single patient. Evidence review: Systematic evidence review performed for the guidelines (2013) on managing adult overweight and obesity supports treatment recommendations in 5 areas (risk assessment, benefits of weight loss, weight loss diets, comprehensive lifestyle intervention approaches and bariatric surgery)”; For areas outside of this scope, the recommendations are supported by other guidelines (for obesity, 1998 NHLBI-sponsored obesity guidelines and those of the National Center for Health and Clinical Excellence and Canadian and US professional societies such as the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists and the American Society of Bariatric Physicians; for physical activity recommendations, the 2008 Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans); a PubMed search identified recent systematic reviews covering depression and obesity, motivational interviewing for weight management, metabolic adaptation to weight loss, and pharmacotherapy of obesity. Step in Managing Obesity aims to screen all adults for overweight and obesity. A medical history should be taken that examines the multiple determinants of obesity, including diet and exercise patterns, psychosocial factors, drugs used to gain weight, and family characteristics. Emphasizing the complications of obesity to identify patients who will benefit most from treatment is more useful than using body mass index (BMI; calculated as weight in kilograms divided by height in meters squared) alone for treatment decisions . The guidelines (2013) recommend that physicians provide patients who would benefit from weight loss (either BMI >/=30 with or without comorbidities or >/=25 with 1 comorbidity or risk factor) an intensive, multi-component behavioral intervention offer. Some clinicians do this in their GP offices; others refer patients for these services. Weight loss is achieved by creating a negative energy balance through changes in diet and exercise. The guidelines (2013) advocate comprehensive lifestyle management through intensive intervention. Treatment can be provided either in a doctor's office or by referral to a registered dietitian or commercial weight loss program. The usual goal is a 5% to 10% weight loss. It is not required that patients achieve a BMI of less than 25 to. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Screening and assessment of patients for obesity, followed by initiation or referral of treatment, should be integrated into primary care practice when clinicians appropriate patients for weight loss and be able to provide informed advice and support on how to achieve and maintain modest weight loss, they will address the underlying driver of many coma related disorders and can have a major impact on patient health outcomes.

title: Evaluation of a distant collaborative program for the treatment of depression in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Primary care teams play an important role in the management of depression, the effectiveness of which is enhanced when inserted into a collaborative model of disease management. AIM: Report on the results of a clinical study conducted to test the effectiveness of a collaborative program between primary health teams and specialists, supported by an electronic platform. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Physicians from four community hospitals belonging to the Reloncavi Health Service network recruited 81 patients with depression aged 37 to 43 years, 84% of whom were female. Participants were divided into an active group, which participated in the collaborative program, and a control group, which received usual treatment per Department of Health guidelines for depression. The main outcome was the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI-I) score after three months of intervention. RESULTS: Participants had a mean BDI-I score of 29.6 (95% CI: 27.6-31.6) and 38% of them had a high risk of suicide. There were no statistically significant baseline differences between the active and control groups. In the intervention group, the BDI-I score changed from 30.0 (95% CI 27.0 to 32.8) to 15.3 (95% CI 11.8 to 18.8). In the control group, the score changed from 29.2 (95% CI: 26.4-31.9) points to 20.8 (95% CI: 16.8-24.7). The decline was significantly higher in the intervention groups. CONCLUSIONS: A program of this type can be useful in assisting primary care teams in remote areas of the country to improve treatment outcomes for depression.

title: Evaluation of a pay-for-performance program in primary care designed by target groups.
abstract: Background: Over the past decade, evidence for performance-related pay (P4P) has been sought as financial incentives to influence healthcare professional behavior and improve quality of care have increased. The effectiveness of P4P is inconclusive, although some reviews have reported significant effects. Aim: Assess changes in performance after implementation of a participatory P4P program. Design: An observational study with a pre- and post-measurement. Environment and topics: 65 general practitioner practices in the south of the Netherlands. Intervention: A P4P program developed by target users that includes indicators of chronic care, prevention, practice management, and patient experience (functioning of the general practitioner [GP] and organization of care). Quality indicators were calculated for each practice. By comparing the performance of the practice with a benchmark, a maximum bonus of 6890 euros per 1000 patients was determined. Key Outcome Parameters: Quality indicators for clinical care (process and outcome) and patient experience. Results: We included 60 practices. At one year, there was a significant improvement in process indicators for all chronic conditions, ranging from +7.9% improvement in cardiovascular risk management to +11.5% in asthma. Five outcome indicators improved significantly, as did patients' experiences of how GPs work and how care is organized. No significant improvements were seen in influenza vaccination coverage and cervical cancer screening utilization. The clinical process and outcome indicators as well as the patient experience indicators were influenced by baseline measures. Smaller practices showed more improvements. Conclusions: A participatory P4P program could stimulate quality improvement in clinical care and improve patients' experiences of how family doctors work and how care is organized. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Assessing decision support for ordering blood tests in primary care. a randomized study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Various methods of changing blood test ordering behavior in primary care have been shown to be effective. However, randomized studies comparing these methods are lacking. OBJECTIVE: To compare the effect of two versions of BloodLink, a computerized clinical decision support system, on ordering blood tests from general practitioners. DESIGN: Randomized study. SETTING: 44 practices of general practitioners in the Delft region, the Netherlands. PARTICIPANTS: 60 general practitioners in 44 practices who use computerized patient records in their practices. INTERVENTION: After stratification into individual and group practices, practices were randomly assigned to use BloodLink-Restricted, which initially displays a reduced list of tests, or BloodLink-Guideline, which is based on guidelines from the Dutch College of General Practitioners. MEASUREMENTS: Average number of blood tests ordered per order form per practice. RESULTS: GPs using BloodLink-Guideline requested, on average, 20% fewer tests than physicians using BloodLink-Restricted (mean [+/-SD], 5.5 +/- 0.9 tests vs. 6.9+ /- 1.6 tests) ;" P = 0.003, Mann-Whitney test). CONCLUSIONS: Guideline-based decision aids are more effective in changing blood test ordering behavior than decision aids based on the initial display of a limited number of tests Guideline-driven decision support systems can effectively reduce the number of laboratory tests ordered by GPs.

title: Evaluation of radiological referral practice and effect of computerized guidelines on radiological needs in two emergency departments.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate referral practices in emergency medical radiology compared to a set of French guidelines and to measure the efficiency of computerized guidelines for unnecessary medical imaging. MATERIALS AND METHODS: All radiological queries were computerized in the emergency medical departments of two French teaching hospitals. Radiological inquiries were recorded during the control periods, but no action was taken. During the intervention periods, on-screen reminders displayed the appropriate recommendations. Three control and three intervention periods of 1 month each were carried out. The percentage of applications that did not meet the guidelines and the deviations in relation to control and intervention periods were measured. RESULTS: The proportion of requests that did not follow the guidelines was 33 x 2% when the guidelines were inactive and decreased to 26 x 9% when the recommendations were active (p < 0 x 0001). The three imaging tests (chest X-ray, abdominal X-ray and brain CT) accounted for more than 80% of all inquiries; more than 50% of requests for abdominal X-rays did not conform to recommendations, while this percentage was 24 x 9% and 15 x 8% for chest X-rays and computed tomography (CT) of the brain, respectively. Seven situations accounted for 70% of non-compliant radiological referrals out, in these situations the knowledge of the young doctors was insufficient. CONCLUSION: While the computer provided advice tailored to the needs of individual patients, at the same time as the care, the effect of our intervention was weak. However, our study identified the few situations that accounted for the majority of unnecessary radiological inquiries." We expect that this result could help clinicians and radiologists to develop more specific interventions for these situations. Karton, M. et al. (2002) Clinical Radiology (2002) 57, 123-128.

title: Assessing Self-Injury in an Accident and EMS - the development of a form for assessing suicidal intent and mental status in individuals presenting to the emergency department with self-harm
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The UK has one of the highest rates of self-harm in Europe, approximately 400 per 100,000 population (Horrocks et al. 2002). It accounts for 150,000 emergency department visits each year and is one of the top five reasons for acute medical admissions in the UK (NICE 2002). OBJECTIVES: Objectives included to examine the method of self-harm and the demographics of those presenting self-harm to the emergency department. In addition, we wanted to review the emergency department physician's assessment of suicidal risk factors and suicidal intent, and whether a psychiatric evaluation was performed with a full assessment of mental status, with referral to psychiatric services if deemed necessary. We wanted to examine current practice regarding self-harm presentations in the ED, according to NICE guidelines. METHODS: Data were collected retrospectively from February to August 2009. 25 sets of medical notes were randomly compiled for patients who presented to the emergency department with self-harm. The notes were reviewed for evidence of the investigation of the event, psychiatric assessment, risk factors for suicide, and further referrals. RESULTS: 14 of the 25 patients presented had taken an overdose. 9 had inflicted another form of self-harm, namely lacerations on themselves. A mixed presentation was found in 2 cases. A psychiatric history was documented in 16 cases. 11 had a history of depression or anxiety disorders", 1 had a known history of bipolar disorder, 1 had a past diagnosis of borderline personality disorder, and 3 patients had no history. In 9 cases, the history was undocumented. DISCUSSION : As of February through August 2009, twenty-five sets of medical records were reviewed from people presenting to the emergency department with self-harm. Of these, 12 were in the age group over 25. 17 were women and 8 were men. The majority of patients were White British ancestry. 14 had one Took an overdose; 9 had committed some other form of self-harm;" and 2 had a mixed presentation. Suicide risk factors and suicidal intent were poorly documented, with mental status assessment found to be undocumented in all 25 cases studied. 18 were admitted to the emergency department a Declared medically fit and referred for psychiatric evaluation. These unfortunate findings could be due to the time pressures physicians face in the emergency department, namely the four-hour target, and possibly a lack of adequate training in psychosocial risk assessment. As a result of this poor documentation by the emergency department physicians, a form was created that included suicidal risk factors and the assessment of suicidal intent, in addition to a brief version of the mental status assessment. CONCLUSION: The recent Royal College of Psychiatrists report on self-harm has raised concerns that current levels of care for service users fall below the standards set in policies and guidelines, with poor ratings, unskilled staff and inadequate pathways of care (Royal College of Psychiatrists, Report CR 158 , 2010). Indeed, evidence suggests that appropriate training and intervention of emergency department staff can improve the quality of the psychosocial assessment of patients with intentional self-harm (Crawford et al. 1998).

title: Assessing the potential effects of a recall system on reducing diagnostic error: a quasi-experimental study
abstract: Background Computer-aided decision support systems (DSS) have primarily focused on improving clinicians' diagnostic accuracy in unusual and challenging cases. However, since diagnostic omission errors can predominantly result from incomplete workup in clinical routine, providing appropriate patient- and context-specific reminders may have a greater impact on patient safety. In this experimental study, a mix of easy and difficult simulated cases was used to assess the impact of a novel diagnostic reminder system (ISABEL) on the quality of clinical decisions made by different stages of clinicians during acute assessment. Methods Subjects of various grades (consultants, registrars, senior house officers and medical students) evaluated a balanced panel of 24 simulated cases on a test website. Subjects recorded their clinical decisions for the cases (differential diagnosis, test design, and treatment) before and after the system consultation. A panel of two pediatric consultants independently provided gold-standard responses for each case, against which the subjects' decision quality was measured. The primary endpoint was the change in the number of diagnostic omission errors (DEO). A more sensitive assessment of the system's impact was achieved using specific quality scores; in addition, the additional consultation time due to DSS usage was calculated. Results Seventy-six subjects (18 consultants, 24 registrars, 19 senior house officers, and 15 students) completed a total of 751 case episodes. The mean number of DEO fell from 5.5 to 5.0 in all subjects (repeated measures ANOVA, p<0.001); no significant interaction with subject grade was noted. The mean diagnostic quality score increased after system consultation (0.044; 95% confidence interval 0.032, 0.054). ISABEL reminded subjects to consider at least one clinically important diagnosis in 1 out of 8 case episodes and asked them to order an important test in 1 out of 10 case episodes. The median additional time for the DSS consultation was 1 minute (IQR: 30 seconds to 2 minutes). Conclusion The provision of patient- and context-specific reminders has the potential to reduce diagnostic omissions across all subject levels for a range of cases. This study suggests a promising role for the use of future memory-based DSS in reducing diagnostic error.

title: Association between the Academic Medical Center's guidelines on pharmaceutical detailing and the physician's prescription
abstract: Significance To regulate conflicts of interest among physicians, some academic medical centers (AMCs) in the US enacted policies between 2006 and 2012 restricting sales visits by pharmaceutical sales representatives to physicians (so-called detailing). Little is known about the impact of these guidelines on prescribing by physicians. Aim To analyze the relationship between detailed policies enacted in AMCs and physician prescribing of actively detailed and non-detailed drugs. Design, Setting, and Participants The study used multivariable difference-in-differences regression analysis to assess changes in physician prescribing before and after implementation of detailed guidelines at AMCs in 5 states (California, Illinois, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, and New York). to compare. who formed the intervention group with changes in prescription, by a matched control group of similar physicians who are not subject to detailed guideline. Exposures Implementation of Academic Medical Center policies governing visits by pharmaceutical vendors to treating physicians. Key Findings and Measures The monthly market share within drug class of prescriptions written by a single physician for detailed and non-detailed drugs across 8 drug classes (lipid lowering drugs, gastroesophageal reflux disease drugs, diabetes drugs, antihypertensives, licensed hypnotics). treatment of insomnia [sleeping pills], medications for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, antidepressants and antipsychotics), comparing the 10-36 month period before implementation of the detailed guidelines with the 12-36 month period after implementation, subject to data availability . Results The analysis included 16-121-483 prescriptions issued between January 2006 and June 2012 by 2126 treating physicians of the 19 AMCs in the intervention group and by 24-593 physicians in the corresponding control group. The average market share of the sample at the doctor-drug-month level for detailed and non-detailed drugs prior to the enactment of the guidelines were 19.3% and 14.2%, respectively. Exposure to an AMC detailing guideline was associated with a 1.67 percentage point decrease in detailed drug market share (95% CI, ?2.18 to ?1.18 percentage points"; P?<?.001) and an increase in market share associated by non-detailed drugs of 0.84 percentage points (95% CI, 0.54 to 1.14 percentage points; P?<?.001) Associations were statistically significant for 6 of 8 study drug classes for detailed drugs (lipid-lowering drugs, drugs against gastroesophageal reflux disease)., antihypertensive drugs, sleep aids, drugs for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, and antidepressants) and for 9 of the 19 AMCs that implemented policies. Eleven of the 19 AMCs regulated vendor gifts to physicians, restricted vendor access to facilities, and specifically included enforcement mechanisms.In 8 of these 11 AMCs there was a significant change in prescription On the other hand, there was a significant change in only 1 out of 8 AMCs that did not issue policies in all 3 areas. Conclusions and Relevance e Implementation of policies at AMCs that restricted drug detailing between 2006 and 2012 was associated with a modest but significant decrease in the prescribing of detailed drugs in 6 out of 8 major drug classes. However, changes have not been noted in all AMCs that have issued policies.

title: Association between efavirenz as initial therapy for HIV-1 infection and an increased risk of suicidal ideation, attempted or completed suicide
abstract: Background The association between efavirenz use and suicidality is not well defined. Aim To compare the time to suicidal tendencies for efavirenz-containing versus efavirenz-free antiretroviral regimens in the initial treatment of HIV. Design Participant-level data were analyzed from four AIDS Clinical Trials Group (ACTG) antiretroviral-naïve studies conducted between 2001 and 2010. Within each study, participants were randomly assigned to receive an efavirenz-containing (n=3241) or efavirenz-free regimen (n=2091). Recruitment of ACTG positions”; 74% enrolled in the United States. Patients Antiretroviral-naïve participants. Intervention Efavirenz versus efavirenz-free therapies. Measurements Suicidality was defined as suicidal ideation, attempted suicide, or completed suicide. HR) and 95% confidence interval (CI) estimated from a Cox model stratified by study. RESULTS: 73% were males, median age was 37 years." 32% had a documented history of psychiatric disorders within 30 days prior to study entry or were receiving psychoactive medications. The median follow-up time was 96 weeks. The incidence of suicidality per 1000 person-years was 8.08 (47 events) in the efavirenz group and 3.66 (15 events) in the efavirenz-free group, HR: 2.28 (95% CI: 1.27 to 4.10, p=0.006).The incidence of attempted or completed suicide was 2.90 (17 events) and 1.22 (5 events) in the efavirenz and efavirenz-free groups, respectively, HR: 2.58 (95% CI: 0.94 to 7.06, p= 0.065). Eight deaths from suicide were reported in the efavirenz group and one in the efavirenz-free group. Limitations There was no standardized questionnaire on suicidal ideation or attempt. Efavirenz was open-label in three of four studies. Conclusions Initial treatment with an efavirenz-containing An antiretroviral regimen was associated with a two-fold increased risk of suicide compared to a regimen without efavirenz. Key words: efavirenz, suicide, suicidal ideation, suicidal behavior, HIV, adverse event, psychiatry

title: Association of a low-frequency variant of HNF1A with type 2 diabetes in a Latino population
abstract: Significance Latino populations have one of the highest prevalences of type 2 diabetes in the world. Objectives To investigate the association between rare protein-coding genetic variants and the prevalence of type 2 diabetes in a large Latino population and to investigate potential molecular and physiological mechanisms for the observed associations. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Whole exome sequencing was performed on DNA samples from 3,756 Mexican and US Latinos (1,794 with type 2 diabetes and 1,962 without diabetes) recruited from 1993-2013. One variant was further characterized for allelic frequency and association with type 2 diabetes in large multiethnic datasets of 14-276 participants and in experimental assays. Main outcome and measures Prevalence of type 2 diabetes. Secondary endpoints included age at onset, body mass index and effect on protein function. Results A single rare missense variant (c.1522G>A [p.E508K]) was associated with type 2 diabetes prevalence (odds ratio [OR], 5.48", 95% CI, 2.83- 10.61;P?=?4.4?Â ¡Ã ?10?7) in hepatocyte nuclear factor 1-Ã¦Ã (HNF1A), the gene responsible for adult-onset type 3 diabetes (MODY3). This variant was observed in 0.36% of participants without type 2 diabetes 2.1% of participants with it.In multiracial replication datasets, the p.E508K variant was only found in Latino patients (n?=?1443 with type 2 -diabetes and 1673 without diabetes) and was associated with type 2 diabetes (OR, 4.16; 95% CI, 1.75-9.92; "P?=?.0013). In experimental assays, HNF- 1A protein encoding the p.E508K mutant had reduced transactivation activity of its target promoter compared to a wild-type protein.In our data, carriers and non-carriers of the p.E508K mutation with type 2 diabetes showed no significant differences the compared clinic characteristics, including age at onset. The mean (SD) age for carriers was 45.3 years (11.2) versus 47.5 years (11.5) for non-carriers (P?=?.49), and the mean (SD) BMI for carriers was 28, 2 (5.5) versus 29.3 (5.3) for carrier noncarriers (P?=?.19). Conclusions and Relevance Using whole exome sequencing, we identified a single low-frequency variant in the MODY3-causing gene HNF1A that is associated with type 2 diabetes in Latino populations and may impair protein function. This finding may have implications for screening and therapeutic modification in this population, but additional studies are needed.

title: Association of combatant status and sexual violence with health and psychological outcomes in post-conflict Liberia
abstract: Initial situation The wars in Liberia since 1989 have cost the lives of tens of thousands of people and traumatized many people mentally and physically. Objectives To assess the prevalence and impact of war-related psychosocial trauma, including information on participation in Liberia's civil wars, exposure to sexual violence, social functioning and mental health. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS A population-based, multi-level, randomized, cross-sectional cluster survey of 1666 adults 18 years and older using structured interviews and questionnaires, conducted in Liberia in May 2008 over a 3-week period. Main outcome measures Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) and Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) symptoms, social functioning, exposure to sexual violence, and health and mental health needs among Liberian adults who have witnessed or participated in the conflicts in the past 2 decades. Results In the Liberian adult household population, 40% (95% confidence interval [CI], 36%-45%; n=672/1659) met symptom criteria for MDD, 44% (95% CI, 38%-49%; n=718 /1661) met symptom criteria for PTSD and 8% (95% CI, 5%-10%; n=133/1666) met criteria for social dysfunction. 1666) reported having served time in the armed forces, and 33.2% of ex-combatants (182/549) were female. Ex-combatants were more likely to experience sexual violence than non-combatants: among women 42.3% (95% CI, 35.4% -49.1%) vs. 9.2% (95% CI, 6.7% -11.7 %), males 32.6% (95% CI, 27.6% - 37.6%) vs. 7.4% (95% CI, 4.5% - 10.4% ). , 95% CI, 63%-84%) was higher than among those who had not experienced sexual violence (44%; 95% CI, 33%-53%). The prevalence of PTSD symptoms in male ex-combatants who experienced sexual violence was higher (81%; 95% CI, 74%-87%) than in male ex-combatants who did not experience sexual violence (46%; 95 % CI, 39% - 52%). and 30.1% [95% CI, 18.7%-41.6%], respectively) Conclusions Ex-combatants in Liberia were not exclusively male Both female and male ex-combatants who experienced sexual violence had worse mental health problems than non-combatants and other ex-combatants who have experienced sexual violence have not experienced sexual violence.

title: Association of socioeconomic position with health behavior and mortality
abstract: Context Previous studies may have underestimated the contribution of health behaviors to social inequalities in mortality because health behaviors were only assessed at the start of the study. Aim To investigate the role of health behaviors in the association between socioeconomic position and mortality, and to compare whether their contribution, when assessed at only one point in time, differs from that assessed longitudinally over the follow-up period. Design, setting and participants The Whitehall II UK cohort study, launched in 1985, includes 10,308 civil servants aged 35-55 living in London, England. The analyzes are based on 9,590 men and women followed for mortality through April 30, 2009. Socioeconomic position was derived from civil service grade (high, medium, and low) at baseline. Smoking, alcohol consumption, diet and physical activity were assessed 4 times during the follow-up period. Main outcome measures all-cause mortality and cause-specific mortality. Results A total of 654 participants died during the follow-up period. In analyzes adjusted for sex and year of birth, those in the lowest socioeconomic position had a 1.60 times greater risk of dying from all causes than those in the highest socioeconomic position (a rate difference of 1.94/1000 person-years). This association was attenuated by 42% (95% confidence interval [CI], 21%-94%) when health behaviors assessed at baseline were entered into the model, and by 72% (95% CI, 42%-154%) when if this was the case, were entered as time-dependent covariates. The corresponding attenuations were 29% (95% CI, 11% - 54%) and 45% (95% CI, 24% - 79%) for cardiovascular mortality and 61% (95% CI, 16% - 425%) and 94% (95% CI, 35%-595%) for non-cancer and non-cardiovascular mortality. The difference between the baseline assessment alone and the repeated health behavior assessments was mainly due to an increased explanatory power of diet (from 7% to 17% for all-cause mortality), physical activity (from 5% to 21% for all causes of death), and alcohol consumption (from 3rd % to 12% for all-cause mortality). The role of smoking, the strongest mediator in these analyses, did not change when baseline or repeated assessments were used (from 32% to 35% for all-cause mortality). Conclusion In a public sector population in London, England, there was an association between socioeconomic position and mortality that was largely explained by adjustment to health behaviors, particularly when behaviors were repeatedly assessed.

title: Asthma awareness program in Russia: educating patients
abstract: To counter the recent increase in asthma morbidity and mortality in Russia, an intervention study was conducted to improve the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of asthma. The US recommendations for asthma management have been adapted to educate Moscow families with children with asthma. Two hundred and fifty-two children with asthma, aged 4 to 14 years, who were being treated with their parents at eight Moscow public health clinics, were enrolled in the study to see whether US textbooks on asthma management in Russia are acceptable and effective would be. Children in four of the clinics with recent asthma attacks were randomly assigned to either the education or control groups to test whether patient education and guided asthma management would improve patient outcomes. Modern drugs were made available to both groups to see if training in US guidelines was necessary to get physicians to use the drugs. Children with recent asthma attacks in the other four clinics were defined as comparison group 1 to control for the possible effect of drug availability. All of the children in the eight clinics who did not have asthma attacks made up comparison group 2 to see if the outcomes for these children would change over time. One-year follow-up results showed a significant improvement in children's and parents' asthma self-management skills in relation to asthma treatment only in the education group. Significant increases were observed in the subgroup of children in the education group who were taking anti-inflammatory drugs for asthma control. Children in the education group had significantly increased peak flow rates and reduced diurnal peak flow variability compared to control and comparison groups. There was a significantly greater reduction in doctor visits by the educational group of children compared to the control group. Presumably, behavioral changes by parents and children related to asthma treatment and prevention skills, proper management of the disease, and access to medication could be responsible for reducing asthma morbidity in children.

title: Attitudes towards reproduction in Latin America. Lessons from the application of modern reproductive technologies
abstract: The use of modern reproductive technology, such as in vitro fertilization and related procedures, has opened up new areas of legal, religious, and public interest. 30 years ago, the development of effective methods to control reproduction sparked debate about whether couples have the right to enjoy sex without its reproductive effects. Today, assisted reproductive technology (ART) enables couples to have their own children without direct sex intermediation. The Catholic Church has responded against both contraception and ART, and specific directives have been issued to the public, the medical profession, and legislators. In a recent survey, 88.4% of the population in Latin America say they are Catholic";" Thus, bioethical considerations and legal implications regarding reproductive interference are strongly imbued with the moral teachings of Catholicism. In 1996, 83 physicians and scientists participating in the Latin American Assisted Reproduction Network prepared a consensus document on ethical aspects and legal implications of ART. The document contains minimal ethical guidelines that Latin American professionals want to adhere to even without legal regulations. This article examines how the medical profession, legislators, and the public respond to religious influences when confronted with difficult bioethical decisions such as the right to reproduce.

title: Audit and feedback as a strategy for implementing guidelines in clinical practice: a model for nurses in acute care
abstract: BACKGROUND: The transfer of research results into practice and changing provider behavior is a challenge, even if the benefits are strong. Despite the availability of clinical practice guidelines for supportive care (CPG), consistent integration of these principles into practice has not been achieved. The failure of dissemination strategies has been identified as the main obstacle to successful implementation. A potentially effective approach to facilitating the transfer of research results into practice is through audit and feedback. Audit and Feedback is a summary of vendor performance over time, with or without recommendations for improving the practice. Rationale: Cancer pain is an optimal symptom to study when examining the effect of an audit and feedback intervention. It is a common condition with important implications, established guidelines are available, measurable outcomes are defined and there is room for improvement in current practice. Acute Care Nurses Practitioners (NPs) are often responsible for the monitoring and direct management of symptoms such as pain and are well placed to implement CPG and study the impact of guideline adherence on patient pain outcomes. METHODOLOGY: A systematic review of published articles, MEDLINE, the Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature, and the Cochrane Library computerized databases was conducted to assess the state of the art on auditing and feedback as a strategy for changing professional practice. A behavior change model is proposed for its application in advanced nursing practice. PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: Recognized in medicine as a valuable intervention to improve the quality of healthcare, audit and feedback is a strategy that has not been extensively studied in nursing. Although cancer pain cannot always be completely eliminated, the majority of patients can effectively manage their pain with appropriate use of available therapies. This article reviews the literature on audit and feedback as a strategy for changing professional practice and presents a model for operationalizing the intervention.

title: Audit and Feedback: Implications for Professional Practice and Healthcare Outcomes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Audit and feedback continue to be widely used as a strategy to improve professional practice. It seems logical that health professionals would be asked to change their practice if they received feedback that their clinical practice was inconsistent with that of their peers or accepted guidelines. However, audit and feedback have not been consistently effective. OBJECTIVES: To assess the impact of audit and feedback on healthcare professional practice and patient outcomes. SEARCH STRATEGY: We searched the registry and pending files of the Cochrane Effective Practice and Organization of Care Group up to January 2004. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized audit and feedback studies (defined as any summary of clinical performance over a period of time) that reported objectively measured professional practice in a health setting or health outcomes. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently extracted data and assessed study quality. Quantitative (meta-regression), visual and qualitative analyzes were performed. For each comparison, we calculated the risk difference (RD) and risk ratio (RR), adjusted for baseline compliance where possible, for dichotomous outcomes, and the percentage and percent change relative to the mean of the post-intervention control group, adjusted for baseline performance if possible, for continuous results. We examined the following factors as possible explanations for the variation in the effectiveness of interventions across comparisons: the type of intervention (audit and feedback alone, audit and feedback with educational events, or multifaceted interventions that included audit and feedback), the intensity of the audit and feedback, the complexity of the intended behavior, the seriousness of the outcome, compliance with baseline values, and the quality of the study. MAIN RESULTS: Thirty new studies were added to this update and a total of 118 studies were included. The primary analysis included 88 comparisons from 72 studies that compared any intervention that includes audit and feedback to no intervention. For dichotomous endpoints, the adjusted risk difference of compliance with desired practice varied from -0.16 (a 16% absolute decrease in compliance) to 0.70 (a 70% increase in compliance) (median = 0.05, interquartile range = 0.03 to 0.11) and the adjusted risk ratio varied from 0.71 to 18.3 (median = 1.08, interquartile range = 0.99 to 1.30). For continuous endpoints, the adjusted percent change relative to control varied from -0.10 (a 10% absolute decrease in compliance) to 0.68 (a 68% increase in compliance) (median = 0.16, interquartile range = 0.05 to 0.37). Low baseline compliance with recommended practice and higher audit and feedback intensity were associated with larger adjusted risk ratios (greater efficacy) across studies. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: Audit and feedback can help to improve professional practice. When effective, effects are generally minor to moderate. The relative effectiveness of audit and feedback is likely to be greater when adherence to recommended practices is low initially and when feedback is more intense.

title: Audit of a tuberculosis contact tracing clinic
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the effectiveness of tuberculosis contact tracing in South Glamorgan 1987-9. DESIGN Review of contact tracing clinic records and Mycobacterium Reference Unit data. The clinic's practice was compared to the 1983 recommendations of the British Thoracic Society. DISCONTINUATION Health Department Tuberculosis Control Program. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Percentage of contacts reviewed, follow-up attendance rates, number of secondary cases detected, and quality of records. RESULTS 101 index patients and 611 contacts were identified. 596 (97.5%) contacts were screened, of which 139 should not have been screened. Of 356 contacts who required a Heaf test, 237 were tested, seven declined the test, and 112 had a chest X-ray without a Heaf test. 95 contacts were tested unnecessarily. Chest X-rays were taken unnecessarily in 87 contacts, and X-rays should have been taken in seven people but were not. 34 contacts received inappropriate follow-up appointments and seven were missed during follow-up. Tuberculosis was diagnosed in five asymptomatic contacts, all at initial screening and in all close contacts of index patients with lung disease. CONCLUSION Inadequate data, non-adherence to contact tracing guidelines, and lack of definition of the term “highly contagious index case” resulted in many contacts being unnecessarily screened or traced. IMPACT The efficiency of contact tracing would be improved by reporting swab results and index case ethnicity on the reporting form, clearly categorizing contacts as close or causal, and clearly defining the term highly contagious.

title: Australian and New Zealand Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Depression
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists (RANZCP) coordinates the development of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) in psychiatry funded under the National Mental Health Strategy (Australia) and the New Zealand Department of Health. METHOD: The CPG team reviewed the outcomes literature, consulted physicians and patients, and performed meta-analyses of outcome research. TREATMENT RECOMMENDATIONS: Establish an effective therapeutic relationship; provide the patient with information about the condition, the reasons for treatment, the likelihood of a positive reaction and the expected time frame; consider the patient's strengths, life stresses, and supports. The choice of treatment depends on the skill of the physician and the circumstances and preferences of the patient and should be guided by, but not dictate, these guidelines. For moderate depression, all recognized antidepressant drugs, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), and interpersonal psychotherapy (IPT) are equally effective;" Clinicians should consider both the treatment burden and benefits, including side effects and toxicity. For major depression, antidepressant treatment should be preceded by psychotherapy precede it. For depression with psychosis, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) or a tricyclic in combination with an antipsychotic are equally helpful. Treatments for other subtypes are discussed. Caution should be exercised in individuals taking other medications or with medical conditions. If responding to any Adequate study with first-line treatment is poor, another evidence-based treatment should be used Second opinions are useful Depression has a high rate of recurrence and efforts to reduce it are critical interpretation

title: Author Conflict of Interest Disclosures in Vascular Surgery Journals
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Advances in vascular surgery are increasingly technology-driven, and relationships between surgeons and the medical device industry can be complex. This study reviewed conflicts of interest (COI) disclosures in the vascular surgery journals in relation to several selected technology-driven topics including endovascular stent grafts (EV), carotid stenting (CAS) and peripheral arterial interventions (PI) to suggest further directions.
