METHODS: The authors' COI disclosures were reviewed from all clinical articles published in 2008 and 2009 in each of the six vascular surgery journals relating to three selected topics (EV, CAS, and PI). The rate of COI disclosure was assessed as a function of journal, subject, article type (randomized trial, case series, case report, review, or meta-analysis), and authors' region of origin. Second, the consistency of authors' disclosures was assessed by reviewing articles by the same author and topic. RESULTS: Six hundred and thirty-five articles from the six journals were reviewed. A COI was declared for 125 (19.7%) of these papers. This rate differed between journals (range: 3.2%–34.1%; P<0.0001). The disclosure rate did not differ between topics (range: 12.8%-21.2%; P=0.12), article type (range: 14.7%-30%; P=0.28), or region of origin (range: 0% - 33.3%; "P=0.09). There were 116 cases in which the same author wrote articles describing the same general topic. COI disclosure was consistent in most of these cases (72.4% ), but inconsistent in 32 cases (27.6%) The most common (P = 0.006) inconsistencies concerned the same article type in different journals (46.9%) or in the same journal (25%).CONCLUSIONS: Disclosure rates of COI and inconsistencies in disclosures in the vascular surgery literature are at least partly due to differences in journal reporting guidelines, while a smaller proportion of these discrepancies are due to the behavior of individual authors Journals should adopt a consistent requirement for a separate COI statement in which all relevant financial arrangements are disclosed.

title: Authors' response: Handwashing is about respect for patients
Automated auditing of hand hygiene with and without intervention
abstract: BACKGROUND: Daily feedback from continuous automated audits with a peer reminder intervention has been used to improve compliance. Compliance rates from covert and overt automated audit phases with and without intervention were compared to mandatory human audits. METHODS: An automated system was installed to covertly detect hand hygiene events with each press of the alcohol-based hand sanitizer dispenser for 5 months. The open phase included key clinicians who were trained to share daily rates with clinicians, set compliance goals, and encourage each other to comply for 6 months. The intervention was continued for another 6 months without any refresher. Quarterly Human Audits were conducted during the procedure by Hand Hygiene Australia (HHA) in accordance with World Health Organization guidelines. Percentage point (PP) differences between compliance rates were used to determine change. RESULTS: The HHA rates for June 2014 were 85% and 87% on the medical and surgical wards, respectively. These rates were 55 PPs and 38 PPs higher than the June 2014 covert automation rates for the medical and surgical wards of 30% and 49%, respectively. During the intervention phase, mean compliance at the medical ward did not change from its covert rate, while the surgical ward improved by 11 PPs to 60% compared to the covert phase. On average, compliance did not change during the procedure without a refresher on the medical ward, while the mean rate on the surgical ward decreased by 9 PP. CONCLUSIONS: Automation provided a unique opportunity to respond to daily rates, but compliance will return to pre-intervention levels once active intervention ceases or human investigators leave the ward unless clinicians commit to a change.

title: Automated identification of postoperative complications within an electronic medical record using natural language processing
abstract: Context Currently, most automated methods for identifying patient safety incidents rely on administrative data codes";" However, free text searches in electronic patient files could represent an additional monitoring approach. Objective To evaluate a natural language processing search method for identifying postoperative surgical complications in a comprehensive electronic medical record. Design, Setting, and Patients Cross-sectional study of 2,974 patients who underwent inpatient surgical procedures at 6 Veterans Health Administration (VHA) medical centers from 1999 to 2006, sepsis, pneumonia, or myocardial infarction, identified through medical record review under the VA program for improvement in surgical quality were identified. We determined the sensitivity and specificity of the natural language processing approach to identify these complications and compared its performance to patient safety indicators using discharge coding information. Results The proportion of postoperative events per sample was 2% (39 of 1924) for acute renal failure requiring dialysis, 0.7% (18 of 2327) for pulmonary embolism, 1% (29 of 2327) for deep vein thrombosis, 7% (61 of 866) for sepsis, 16% (222 of 1405) for pneumonia and 2% (35 of 1822) for myocardial infarction. Natural language processing correctly identified 82% (95% confidence interval [CI], 67%-91%) of acute renal failure cases compared to 38% (95% CI, 25%-54%) for patient safety indicators. Similar results were obtained for venous thromboembolism (59%, 95% CI, 44%-72% vs. 46%, 95% CI, 32%-60%), pneumonia (64%, 95% CI, 58%-70% vs 5%, 95% CI, 3%-9%), sepsis (89%, 95% CI, 78%-94% vs. 34%, 95% CI, 24%-47%) and postoperative myocardial infarction (91%, 95% CI, 78% - 97%) vs. 89%, 95% CI, 74% - 96%). Both natural language processing and patient safety indicators were highly specific to these diagnoses. Conclusion In patients undergoing inpatient surgical procedures in VA hospitals, processing natural language analysis of electronic medical records to identify postoperative complications had higher sensitivity and lower specificity compared to patient safety indicators based on discharge coding.

title: Availability and prescribing practices of anti-malarial drugs in the private health sector in Yemen
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Although the Yemeni government changed the national malaria treatment policy in November 2005 from chloroquine to artesunate + sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (SP) combinations as first-line treatment and lumefantrine + artemether as second-line treatment for uncomplicated malaria, physicians in public and private health facilities continued to prescribe chloroquine because of little knowledge of the new treatment policy. METHODOLOGY: A non-randomized study to pre- and post-evaluate the training and reporting interventions on prescribing behavior and availability of antimalarial drugs among clinicians and pharmacists in the private sector in three governorates in Yemen was conducted. RESULTS: Adherence to the new national guidelines for antimalarial drugs by private sector clinicians improved from 21% pre-intervention to 38% post-intervention, as artesunate + SP was prescribed as first-line treatment. Prescribing of lumefantrine + artemether as second-line antimalarial treatment also improved from 18% pre-procedure to 22% post-procedure. Unfortunately, the combination of halofantrine + SP continued to be widely prescribed by physicians in the city of Sana'a (18%). Artesunate + SP and quinine significantly increased their commercialization from 8% pre-intervention to 22% post-intervention (P-value 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: The study provides evidence for the usefulness of the educational intervention on national guidelines for malaria treatment. In addition, involving private health care providers in reporting processes will promote prudent prescribing and availability of antimalarial drugs.

title: Available screening tools for adults suffering from bipolar affective disorder in primary care: An integrative literature review
abstract: PURPOSE: To evaluate the effectiveness of six tools used in primary care for screening for bipolar affective disorder (BPAD). BPAD has a history of being underdiagnosed or misdiagnosed, followed by inappropriate treatment, leading to detrimental flare-ups, suicide, and an increased risk of comorbidities. DATA SOURCES: An electronic search was performed to identify articles in the following databases: MEDLINE, CINAHL, Cochrane Library, ERIC, National Guideline Clearinghouse, PsycINFO, Psychology and Behavioral Sciences Collection, and PsycARTICLES. Additional information was also gathered from the NIH, CDC, Healthy People 2020, the Black Dog Institute, and the Center for Quality Assessment and Improvement for Mental Health. CONCLUSION: There is evidence that primary care physicians are often the first and sometimes only providers, underscoring the importance of early detection and screening of BPAD in primary care. By implementing appropriate screening tools and adhering to recommended treatment and intervention guidelines, relapse prevention is increased and comorbidities are diagnosed more frequently, resulting in an overall improved quality of life. PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: Primary care physicians play an important role in adequate screening for BPAD and implementation of recommended treatments to increase relapse prevention and promote a healthier and more socially successful quality of life.

title: Barriers and enablers to implementing guideline recommendations for multiple stroke: a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Putting evidence into practice is an important final step in the evidence-based practice process. Medical record audits can be used to examine how well the practice compares to published evidence and to identify gaps between evidence and practice. After providing audit feedback to professionals, local barriers to practice change can be identified and addressed with targeted behavior change interventions. This study aimed to identify barriers and prerequisites for the implementation of multiple stroke policy recommendations in an Australian stroke unit. METHODS: A qualitative methodology was used. A sample of 28 health, nursing and medical professionals participated in a group or individual interview. These interviews took place after employees received audit feedback and identified areas for practice change. Questions focused on barriers and requirements for implementing the guideline recommendations for managing: upper extremity sensory impairments, mobility including balance while sitting, vision, anxiety and depression, neglect, swallowing, communication, education for stroke survivors and caregivers, Advice on returning to work and driving.Qualitative data were analyzed for subjects using theoretical domains described by Michie and colleagues (2005).RESULTS: Six group and two individual interviews were conducted, spanning six disciplines Barriers varied between disciplines.The six main barriers identified were: (1) Beliefs about the abilities of individual professionals and their discipline, and about the abilities of patients (2) Beliefs about the positive and negative consequences of implementing the recommendations (3) Recalling and observing best practices (4) Knowledge and skills required to implement best practice;" (5) intent and motivation to implement best practices; and (6) resources. Some barriers also paved the way for change. For example, occupational therapists needed new knowledge and skills (a barrier) to better manage sensitivity and neglect impairments, while physical therapists generally knew how to implement best practice mobility rehabilitation (an enabler). CONCLUSIONS: The results complement current knowledge about barriers to change and implementation of several guideline recommendations. The biggest challenges included sex education and depression screening. Limited knowledge and skills were a common obstacle. Knowledge of specific interventions was required before implementation could begin and to maintain treatment accuracy. Providing detailed online intervention protocols and manuals can help physicians overcome the knowledge barrier.

title: Barriers and facilitations associated with nonsurgical management of osteoarthritis patients in orthopedic practice
abstract: INTRODUCTION: International evidence-based guidelines for the management of patients with hip and knee osteoarthritis (OA) recommend starting with (a combination of) non-surgical treatments and resorting to surgery only when a patient is not responding adequately to non-surgical treatment addresses treatment options. Despite these recommendations, there is strong evidence that nonsurgical treatments are not optimally used in orthopedic practice. Improving the uptake of non-surgical treatments requires more insight into the barriers and enablers of these treatments. Therefore, this study investigated the barriers and facilitations associated with the use and prescription of various non-surgical treatments for osteoarthritis of the hip and knee in orthopedic practice among patients and orthopedic surgeons in the Netherlands. MATERIALS AND METHODS: We conducted two internet-based surveys among 172 orthopedic surgeons and 174 OA patients. Univariate association and multivariable regression techniques are used to identify barriers and promoters associated with the use of nonsurgical treatments. RESULTS: Most of the barriers and relief experienced by patients were associated with the use of physical therapy, lifestyle counseling, and nutritional therapy. Among orthopedic surgeons, most were associated with the prescription of acetaminophen, diet therapy, and physical therapy. Examples of barriers and supporters among patients included “People around me have had positive experiences with surgery” (moderator for osteoarthritis education) and “Advice from people around me to keep moving” (moderator for lifestyle and nutrition advice ). Examples of orthopedists were “Lack of guideline knowledge” (barrier to lifestyle advice), “Agreements/consultation with GP” and “Easy communication with a nutritionist” (facilitator for nutritional therapy). Belief in the effectiveness of these treatments was also associated with increased prescribing. CONCLUSIONS: Strategies to improve the use of nonsurgical treatments in orthopedic practice should aim to change orthopedic surgeon beliefs, communicate with other OA care providers, and involve the patient's environment in OA treatment.

title: Obstacles and facilitators to the implementation of VA household basic services on Indian reservations: a multi-case qualitative study
abstract: Background Veterans Health Affairs (VA) home primary care (HBPC) is an evidence-based interdisciplinary approach to non-institutional long-term care developed in urban settings to provide long-term care to vulnerable elderly patients. Under the authority of a memorandum of understanding between the VA and Indian Health Service (IHS) to improve access to healthcare, 14 VA Medical Centers (VAMC) have independently initiated plans to expand HBPC programs to rural Indian reservations, and 12 VAMC have successful programs implemented. The purpose of this study is to describe barriers and facilitators to implementation in rural indigenous communities, with the goal of informing planners and policymakers for future program expansions. Methods A qualitative comparative case study approach was used, with each of the 14 VAMC treated as a case. Using the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research (CFIR) as the basis for an open-ended interview guide, telephone interviews (n = 37) were conducted with HBPC staff and clinicians and local/regional managers who participated in or oversaw the implementation. The interviews were transcribed, coded, and then analyzed using CFIR domains and constructs to describe and compare experiences and to identify facilitators, barriers, and adaptations that were common across VAMC and HBPC programs. Findings Within the VAMC, there were significant differences in local contexts. Nonetheless, implementation was typically facilitated by key individuals who were able to build trust in VA healthcare in Native American communities. The guidelines encouraged clinical collaboration, but collaborations generally occurred on an ad hoc basis between VA and IHS clinicians to optimize patient resources. All programs required some adjustments to remove barriers in rural areas, such as B. distances, caseloads, or delays in hiring additional clinicians. VA funding opportunities facilitated the expansion and maintenance of these programs. Conclusions Since program expansion is the responsibility of the HBPC program director, there is little exchange of experience between the VA institutions. Collaborative learning opportunities would benefit federal health organizations to extend other medical services to additional Native American communities and other rural and underserved communities, as well as coordinate with other health organizations. The CFIR structure was an effective analysis tool to compare programs that address multiple inner and outer settings.

title: Obstacles and requirements for evidence-based practice in perinatal care in the SEA-ORCHID project
abstract: Rationale, Aims, and Objectives: The South-East Asia Optimizing Reproductive and Child Health in Developing Countries (SEA-ORCHID) project aimed to improve maternal and infant health outcomes in nine hospitals in Southeast Asia by supporting evidence-based perinatal health care. In this investigation, we aimed to identify and examine the factors that may have acted as barriers or enablers to evidence-based practice change in each of the hospitals. METHODS: During the final 6 months of the intervention phase of the project, semi-structured face-to-face interviews were conducted with 179 nurses, midwives, and physicians from the maternal and neonatal departments in each of the nine participating Southeast Asian country hospitals. RESULTS: The interviews identified several factors that participants believed had a significant impact on the effectiveness of the SEA-ORCHID intervention. These included knowledge, skills, hierarchy, multidisciplinarity and leadership, beliefs about consequences, resources, and the nature of behavior. The success of the SEA-ORCHID intervention in improving practice may reflect the extent to which tailored strategies have been effective in overcoming these barriers. CONCLUSION: Effective interventions to align practice with evidence rely on identifying and removing barriers to practice change. The barriers identified in this study may be useful to those designing similar clinical practice improvement projects, as well as ongoing practice improvement efforts at the SEA-ORCHID hospitals.

title: Barriers to breast and cervical cancer screening among underserved women in the District of Columbia
abstract: PURPOSE/OBJECTIVES: To identify, from the perspective of medically underserved women in the District of Columbia (DC), barriers to breast and cervical cancer screening services that may influence intent to engage in breast and cervical screening behaviors” to any relationship between determine attitudes and influence of significant others on intended behaviors;' and to identify a relationship between the location where services are provided and underserved women's intentions to engage in screening behaviors. DESIGN: cross section, correlation. SETTING: Breast and cervical cancer screening clinics in DC. SAMPLE: 339 medically underserved adult women. METHODS: Face-to-face investigator-led interviews. KEY RESEARCH VARIABLES: Demographic and contextual variables, as well as attitudes and influence of significant others. Intend to have a monthly mammogram, Pap test, or breast self-examination (BSE). RESULTS: Intention to have a mammogram was positively associated with the influence of important caregivers and negatively associated with indifferent healthcare professionals. The intention to have a Pap test was positively related to one's own attitude towards the test and to the influence of important caregivers. The intention to carry out BSE was positively related to attitudes towards and previous carrying out of BSE and the influence of significant others. No significant relationships were observed between intent to engage in screening behaviors and demographic variables. CONCLUSIONS: Factors influencing women's attitudes toward screening and intent to perform these behaviors include prior screening behaviors, the influence of significant others, and relationships with healthcare professionals. IMPLICATIONS FOR NURSING PRACTICE: Oncology nurses are well placed to develop and test intervention strategies designed to improve access to and adherence to recommended screening guidelines in medically underserved people. Findings from this study could potentially guide the development and evaluation of such strategies sensitive to this particular population.

title: Barriers to the implementation of preconception nursing guidelines as perceived by primary care physicians: a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite strong evidence for the benefit of preconception interventions in improving pregnancy outcomes, the provision and utilization of preconception care and periconceptional folic acid supplementation remain low. Primary care physicians play a pivotal role in providing preconception care. Understanding primary care physicians' perceptions of the barriers and requirements for implementing preconception care allows for more appropriate targeting of quality improvement interventions. Consequently, the aim of this study was to examine the barriers and prerequisites for the provision and uptake of guidelines on preconception care from the perspective of general practitioners, using theoretical areas related to behavior change. METHODS: We conducted a qualitative study using focus groups composed of 22 general practitioners recruited from three regional general practice support organizations. The questions were based on the theoretical domain framework, which describes 12 domains related to behavior change. The GPs' responses were grouped into predefined themes using a deductive process of thematic analysis. RESULTS: Beliefs about abilities, motivations and goals, environmental context and resources, and memory, attention and decision-making were the key domains identified in the barrier analysis. Some of the perceived barriers identified by GPs were time constraints, the lack of women presenting in the preconception phase, the multiple competing preventive priorities within the GP practice, issues related to cost and access to preconception care, and absenteeism of resources to assist in providing care guidelines prior to conception. Perceived enablers identified by GPs included the availability of preconception care checklists and patient brochures, handouts, and waiting room posters that outlined the benefits and availability of preconception care consultations. CONCLUSIONS: Our study has identified some of the barriers and enablers to the provision and adoption of preconception care guidelines as perceived by general practitioners. The relationship of these barriers to a theoretical domain framework provides a clearer understanding of some of the psychological aspects involved in GP behavior in relation to the provision and use of preconception care. Further research to prioritize these barriers and the theoretical areas to which they relate is needed before a methodologically rigorous intervention can be designed, implemented, and evaluated.

title: Barriers to the use of therapies to reduce the risk of breast cancer
abstract: Evidence from randomized clinical trials supports the use of tamoxifen, raloxifene, exemestane, and anastrozole to reduce the risk of invasive breast cancer, mostly estrogen receptor-positive tumors. Revised clinical guidelines now strongly recommend that physicians offer high-risk drugs to women to reduce their risk of breast cancer. Although only a small proportion of eligible women receive risk-reduction drugs, this suggests a higher uptake in women with atypical hyperplasia or lobular carcinoma in situ. Barriers to prescribing risk-reduction drugs include inadequate risk assessment training among physicians, a lack of reimbursement for prevention counseling, and the unavailability of easily accessible and easy-to-use predictive tools for estimating risk-benefit profiles. Strategies to improve acceptance among women have focused on providing breast cancer risk education and information that accurately conveys the risks and benefits of risk-reduction medications. Priority research areas identified to improve the use of risk reduction drugs are (1) the development of risk assessment tools that more accurately identify women most likely to benefit, (2) the identification of circulating or tissue Biomarkers that can predict and monitor treatment responsiveness, and (3) better understanding of patient-related barriers, including patients' subjective beliefs and experiences.

title: Baseline depression severity as a moderator of depression outcomes between cognitive behavioral therapy and pharmacotherapy: An individual patient data meta-analysis
abstract: IMPORTANT: Current guidelines recommend treating major depression with pharmacotherapy. Both randomized clinical trials and traditional meta-analyses have significant limitations when testing for moderators of treatment outcomes. OBJECTIVES: To conduct a systematic literature review, collect primary data from studies, and analyze depression severity as a moderator of treatment outcomes between cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and antidepressant drugs (ADM). DATA SOURCES: A total of 14902 abstracts were examined from a comprehensive literature search of PubMed, PsycINFO, EMBASE and Cochrane Registry of Controlled Trials from 1966 to 1 January 2014. STUDY SELECTION: Randomized clinical trials comparing CBT and ADM in patients with a DSM-defined major depressive disorder were included. DATA EXTRACTION AND SYNTHESIS: Study authors were asked to provide primary data from their study. Primary data from 16 of 24 identified studies (67%) involving 1700 outpatients (794 from the CBT condition and 906 from the ADM condition) were included. Missing data were imputed using several imputation methods. Mixed-effects models adjusted for study-level differences were used to examine baseline depression severity as a moderator of treatment outcomes. MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression at seventeen points (HAM-D) and Beck Depression Inventory (BDI). RESULTS: There was a major effect of ADM versus CBT on HAM-D (beta = -0.88"; P = 0.03) and a non-significant trend on BDI (beta = -1.14; P = 0, 08, statistical trend test).), but no significant differences in response (odds ratio [OR], 1.24; P=0.12) or remission (OR, 1.18; P=0.22). No modest reduction in depressive symptoms between CBT and ADM in outcome (beta = 0.00; P = 0.96).Similar results were observed using the BDI.Severity of depression at baseline also did not moderate the likelihood of response (OR, 0.99 ; P = 0.96).77) or remission (OR, 1.00; "P = 0.93) between CBT and ADM. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Baseline depression severity did not moderate differences between CBT and ADM on the HAM-D or BDI or in response or remission. This finding cannot be extrapolated to other psychotherapies, individual ADMs, or inpatients. However, it offers new and substantive evidence relevant to researchers, physicians and therapists, and patients.

title: Baseline feature of a randomized trial evaluating the impact of disease management programs on prevention of recurrent ischemic stroke
abstract: BACKGROUND: Comprehensive and long-term patient education programs to improve self-management can help patients better manage their condition. Using disease management programs (DMPs) prepared for each of the risk factors according to clinical practice guidelines, we assess their impact on stroke prevention. METHODS: This is a randomized study conducted in patients with ischemic stroke within 1 year of its onset. Subjects in the intervention group received a 6-month DMP, which included training in self-management by a nurse and support in collaboration with the GP. Those in the usual care group received usual outpatient care. The primary endpoints are stroke recurrence and stroke death. Patients were enrolled for 2 years, with plans for a 2-year follow-up after the 6-month training period (total 30 months). RESULTS: A total of 321 eligible subjects (mean age 67.3 years; 96 women [29.9%]), including 21 subjects (6.5%) with transient ischemic attack, were enrolled in this study. Regarding risk factors for stroke, 260 patients (81.0%) had hypertension, 249 patients (77.6%) had dyslipidemia, 102 patients (31.8%) had diabetes mellitus, 47 patients (14.6%) had atrial fibrillation and 98 patients (30.5%) ) had chronic kidney disease. There were no significant differences between the two groups in terms of subject characteristics. CONCLUSIONS: This article describes the rationale, design, and basic characteristics of a randomized controlled trial aimed at evaluating the effect of DMPs for the secondary prevention of stroke. Subject follow-up is ongoing and will end in 2015.

title: Friends' carers of people with dementia: randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effectiveness of a voluntary sector-based friendship program in improving the psychological well-being and quality of life of caregivers of people with dementia. DESIGN Single-blind, randomized, controlled study. SETTING Community settings in East Anglia and London. PARTICIPANTS 236 family caregivers of people with primary progressive dementia. INTERVENTION Contact a friend-facilitator and offer a match with a trained lay volunteer friend versus no friend-facilitator contact";" all participants continued to receive the “usual care”. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Nurse mood (hospital anxiety and depression scale—depression) and health-related quality of life (EuroQoL) 15 months after randomization. RESULTS The intention-to-treat analysis showed no benefit for the access to a facilitator friend intervention on the primary outcome or on any of the secondary outcome measures. CONCLUSIONS As with many care services, not all caregivers take up referral programs, and access to a referral program is not effective in improving well-being. Study Registration Current CONTROLLED STUDIES: ISRCTN08130075.

title: Behavior change without communication for behavior change: nudging handwashing among elementary school students in Bangladesh.
abstract: Communicating behavior change to improve handwashing with soap can be labor and resource intensive, but high-quality results are difficult to achieve. Nudges are environmental stimuli that trigger unconscious decision-making processes to stimulate behavioral change. In this proof-of-concept study, we developed an inexpensive set of nudges to encourage handwashing with soap after using the toilet in two primary schools in rural Bangladesh. We conducted direct observation of behavior at baseline, after deployment of traditional handwashing infrastructure, and at multiple time periods after targeted handwashing nudges (1 day, 2 weeks, and 6 weeks). No additional hand washing training or motivational messages were given. Handwashing with soap among schoolchildren was low at baseline (4%) and increased to 68% the day after the nudges were completed and to 74% at 2 weeks and 6 weeks after the intervention. Findings indicate that nudge-based interventions have the potential to improve handwashing with soap among schoolchildren in Bangladesh, and specific areas for further investigation are discussed.

title: Behavior counseling after primary care alcohol abuse screening: A systematic review and meta-analysis for the United States Prevention Services Task Force
abstract: Background: Alcohol abuse, which spans the spectrum from hazardous drinking to alcohol dependence, is a leading cause of preventable death in the United States. Purpose: To evaluate the benefits and harms of behavioral counseling interventions for adolescents and adults who abuse alcohol. Data Sources: MEDLINE, EMBASE, Cochrane Library, CINAHL, PsycINFO, International Pharmaceutical Abstracts and reference lists of published literature (January 1985 to January 2012, restricted to English language articles). Study selection: Controlled studies of at least 6 months duration enrolling alcohol abusers identified through primary care screening and evaluating behavioral counseling interventions. Data Extraction: One reviewer extracted data and a second verified accuracy. Two independent reviewers assigned quality scores and assessed the strength of the evidence. DATA SYNTHESIS: The 23 included studies generally excluded people with alcohol dependence. The best evidence was for short (10 to 15 minutes) multi-contact interventions. Adults receiving behavioral interventions reduced consumption by 3.6 drinks/week from baseline (weighted mean difference, 3.6 drinks/week [95% CI, 2.4 to 4.8 drinks/week],” 10 studies; 4332 participants), 12% fewer adults reported heavy drinking episodes (risk difference 0.12 [CI 0.07 to 0.16]; 7 studies; 2737 participants), and 11% more adults reported less than recommended limits to drink (risk difference 0.11 [CI 0.08 to 0.13]; 9 studies). ;" 5973 participants) over 12 months compared to controls (moderate weight of evidence). There was insufficient evidence to conclude on accidents, injuries or alcohol-related liver problems. Studies involving young adults or college students showed a reduced use and fewer episodes of heavy drinking (moderate weight of evidence) Little or no evidence of harm was found Limitations: Results may be skewed to zero because control participants' behavior may have been influenced by alcohol abuse ratings the evidence is unlikely to be applicable to individuals with alcohol dependence and selective reporting may have occurred.Conclusion: Behavioral counseling interventions improve behavioral outcomes for adults with risky alcohol usePrimary source of funding: Agency for Research and Quality im healthcare.

title: Behavioral Counseling Interventions to Prevent Sexually Transmitted Infections: Statement of Recommendation from the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force
abstract: DESCRIPTION: New US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendations for behavioral counseling for adolescents and adults to prevent sexually transmitted infections (STIs). METHODS: The USPSTF reviewed the evidence on the benefits and harms of counseling. The review included studies evaluating behavioral counseling interventions delivered in primary care, those deemed feasible in primary care, and those to which patients might be referred from primary care. RECOMMENDATIONS: The USPSTF recommends high-intensity behavioral counseling for all sexually active youth and adults at increased risk for STIs. (B recommendation) The current evidence is insufficient to assess the benefit-harm balance of behavioral counseling to prevent sexually transmitted infections in non-sexually active adolescents and adults without an increased risk of sexually transmitted infections. (I-statement).

title: Behavioral counseling to promote physical activity and a healthy diet to prevent cardiovascular disease in adults: A systematic review for the U.S. Prevention Services Task Force
abstract: Background: Poor diet and lack of exercise can worsen cardiovascular health, yet most Americans do not follow recommendations on diet and physical activity advice to prevent cardiovascular disease. Data sources: MEDLINE, PsycINFO, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (2001 to January 2010), experts and existing systematic reviews used a priori inclusion criteria and critically assessed each study using design-specific quality criteria. Random effects meta-analyses were performed for several intermediate health and behavioral outcomes. however, other direct evidence of a reduction in disease morbidity is lacking. High-intensity nutritional counseling, with or without exercise counseling, resulted in changes in body mass index (obesity) of 0.3 to 0.7 kg/m2, 1.5 mm Hg (95% CI, 0.9 to 2.1 mm Hg) in systolic blood pressure, ?0.7 mm Hg (CI, ?0.6 to ?0.9 mm Hg) in diastolic pressure, ?0.17 mmol/L (CI, ?0.09 to ?0.25 mmol/L) (?6.56 mg/dL [CI, 3.47 to 9.65 mg/dL]) total cholesterol level and 0.13 mmol/L (CI, 0.06 to 0.21 mmol/L) ( 5.02 mg/dL [CI, 2.32 to 8.11 mg/dL ]) in low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels. Moderate- and high-intensity counseling resulted in moderate-to-large changes in self-reported diet and exercise behaviors. Limitations: Meta-analyses for some outcomes showed high statistical heterogeneity or evidence of publication bias. Only 11 studies followed results beyond 12 months. Conclusion: Counseling to improve diet or increase physical activity altered health behaviors and was associated with modest improvements in obesity, blood pressure, and lipid levels. Primary funding source: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality.

title: Behavioral Economics and Physician Compensation—Promises and Challenges.
Behavioral programs for type 2 diabetes mellitus: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
abstract: Background: Behavioral programs can improve outcomes for people with type 2 diabetes mellitus, but there is a wide variety of behavioral interventions and uncertainty about how to optimize the effectiveness of these programs. Purpose: To identify factors that moderate the effectiveness of behavioral programs for adults with type 2 diabetes. Data sources: 6 databases (1993 to January 2015), conference proceedings (2011 to 2014) and reference lists. Study Selection: Duplicate screening and selection of 132 randomized controlled trials evaluating behavioral programs versus usual treatments, active controls, or other behavioral programs. Data Extraction: One reviewer extracted and another verified data. Two reviewers independently assessed the risk of bias. Data Synthesis: Behavioral programs were grouped based on program content and delivery methods. A Bayesian network meta-analysis showed that most lifestyle and diabetes self-management education and support programs (typically offering 11 contact hours) resulted in clinically important improvements in glycemic control (0.4% reduction in hemoglobin A1c [HbA1c] ). ), while most diabetes self-management education programs without additional support, especially those offering 10 or fewer contact hours, have yielded little benefit. Programs with higher effect sizes were more often delivered in person than via technology. Lifestyle programs led to the largest reductions in body mass index. Reductions in HbA1c appeared to be greater in participants with a baseline HbA1c of 7.0% or greater, in adults younger than 65 years of age, and in minority groups (subgroups with 75% nonwhite participants). Limitations: All studies had an intermediate or high risk of bias. Subgroup analyzes were indirect and therefore exploratory. Most outcomes were reported immediately after the interventions. Conclusion: Diabetes self-management training that provided 10 or fewer hours of contact with delivery staff was of little benefit. Behavioral programs appear to benefit those with suboptimal or poor glycemic control more than those with good control. Primary source of funding: Health Research and Quality Agency. (PROSPERO registration number: CRD42014010515)

title: Behavioral Sexual Risk Reduction Counseling in Primary Care for Preventing Sexually Transmitted Infections: A Systematic Review for the U.S. Prevention Services Task Force
abstract: Background: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are common and preventable. Purpose: To update a previous systematic review of the benefits and harms of sexual risk reduction counseling for STD prevention for the US Preventive Services Task Force. Data sources: Selected databases from January 2007 to October 2013, manual searches of reference lists and gray literature, and studies from the previous review. Study selection: English-language studies of fair or good quality conducted on adolescents or adults. Data Extraction: One investigator abstracted data and a second reviewed the abstraction. The quality of the study was checked twice. Data synthesis: 31 studies were included: 16 (n=56,110) were newly published and 15 (n=14,214) were from the previous review. Most studies have targeted people at increased risk for STIs based on sociodemographic characteristics, risky sexual behavior, or history of an STI. High-intensity (>2 hours) interventions reduced STI incidence in adolescents (odds ratio, 0.38 [95% CI, 0.24 to 0.60]) and adults (odds ratio, 0.70 [CI, 0 .56 to 0.87]). Lower-intensity interventions have generally not been effective in adults, but some approaches have shown promise. Although moderate-intensity interventions can be effective in adolescents, data have been very sparse. Reported behavioral outcomes were heterogeneous, most likely demonstrating benefit with high-intensity interventions at 6 months or less. No consistent evidence was found that sexual risk reduction counseling was harmful. Limitations: Low-risk populations and adolescent males were underrepresented. The reliability of the self-reported behavioral outcomes was unknown. Conclusion: Intensive sexual risk reduction counseling can reduce sexually transmitted infections in primary care and allied settings, particularly among sexually active adolescents and adults at increased risk of sexually transmitted infections. Primary source of funding: Health Research and Quality Agency.

title: Behavioral therapy with or without biofeedback and electrical pelvic floor stimulation for persistent postprostatectomy incontinence
abstract: Context Although behavioral therapy has been shown to improve postoperative continence recovery, there have been no controlled studies of behavioral therapy for incontinence after prostatectomy lasting longer than 1 year. Objective To evaluate the effectiveness of behavioral therapy in reducing persistent postprostatectomy incontinence and to determine whether biofeedback and pelvic electrical stimulation technologies improve the effectiveness of behavioral therapy. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS A prospective, randomized, controlled study of 208 community-dwelling men, ages 51 to 84, with persistent incontinence 1 to 17 years after radical prostatectomy was conducted at a university and 2 Veterans Affairs continence clinics (2003-2008). performed and included a 1-year follow-up after active treatment. 24% of the men were African American, 75% white. Interventions After stratification by type and frequency of incontinence, participants were randomized to one of 3 groups: 8 weeks of behavioral therapy (pelvic floor muscle training and bladder control strategies), behavioral therapy plus dual-channel electromyograph biofeedback in the office, and daily electrical pelvic floor stimulation at home at 20 Hz, current up to 100 mA (behaviour plus) or delayed treatment, which served as a control group Reduction in mean number of incontinence episodes after 8 weeks of treatment, documented in 7-day bladder diaries. ) after behavioral therapy and from 26 to 12 (51% reduction; 95% CI, 37%-65%) after behavior plus therapy. Both reductions were significantly greater than the reduction from 25 to 21 (24% reduction; 95% CI, 10%-39%) observed among controls (P=0.001 for both treatment groups). However, there was no significant difference in the reduction in incontinence between the treatment groups (p=0.69). Improvements lasted up to 12 months in the active treatment groups: 50% reduction (95% CI, 39.8%-61.1%; 13.5 episodes per week) in the behavioral group and 59% reduction (95% CI, 45.0% - 73.1%; " 9.1 episodes per week) in the behavior plus group (p = 0.32). Conclusions In patients with postprostatectomy incontinence for at least 1 year, 8 weeks of behavioral therapy resulted reduced episodes of incontinence compared to a delayed treatment control group.The addition of biofeedback and electrical pelvic floor stimulation did not result in greater efficacy.

title: Behavioral therapy of obesity in primary care patients: a systematic review
abstract: IMPORTANT: In 2011, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) approved intensive behavioral weight loss counseling for approximately 14 in-person, 10- to 15-minute sessions over 6 months for obese primary care beneficiaries when delivered by physicians and others CMS-defined general practitioners. AIM: To conduct a systematic review of behavioral counseling for overweight and obese patients recruited from primary care, as provided by primary care physicians, alone or with trained interventionists (e.g., medical assistants, registered dietitians) or by trained interventionists, who work independently, work. REVIEW OF EVIDENCE: We searched PubMed, CINAHL and EMBASE for randomized controlled trials published between January 1980 and June 2014 that recruited overweight and obese patients from primary care and received behavioral counseling (i.e. diet, exercise and behavioral therapy) for at least 3 months, with at least 6 months of follow-up after randomisation; included at least 15 participants per treatment group and objectively measured weights;” and had a comparison test, an intention-to-treat analysis, and a turnover of less than 30% at 1 year or less than 40% at longer follow-up. RESULTS: Review of 3304 abstracts identified 12 studies with 3893 participants that met inclusion/exclusion criteria and specified quality assessments. No studies were found in which general practitioners provided consultations according to the CMS guidelines. Mean 6-month weight changes from baseline in the intervention groups ranged from a loss of 0.3 kg to 6.6 kg. In the control group, the mean change ranged from an increase of 0.9 kg to a decrease of 2.0 kg. Weight loss in both groups generally decreased with longer follow-up (12-24 months). Interventions that prescribed both reduced energy intake (e.g., >/= 500 kcal/day) and increased physical activity (e.g., >/= 150 minutes of walking per week) with traditional behavioral therapy generally resulted in a greater weight loss than interventions without all 3 specific components. In the previous studies, more treatment sessions, delivered in person or over the phone by trained interventionists, were associated with greater mean weight loss and patients were more likely to lose 5% or more of their baseline weight. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Intensive behavioral counseling can induce clinically meaningful weight loss, but there is little research on primary care physicians providing such care. The present results suggest that a range of trained interventionists, counseling in person or by telephone, could be considered for the management of overweight or obesity in patients encountered in primary care.

title: Behavior change strategies to reduce the blood pressure-related burden of disease: Findings from a global implementation research program
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Global Alliance for Chronic Diseases comprises the majority of the world's public research funding organizations. It focuses on implementation research to address the burden of chronic disease in low- and middle-income countries and among vulnerable populations in high-income countries. Its first research call funded 15 projects focused on reducing the burden of disease related to blood pressure. In this study, we describe a reflexive mapping exercise to identify the behavior change strategies implemented in each of these projects. METHODS: Using the behavior change wheel, each team assessed the ability, opportunity, and motivation of the different actors who were integral to each project (e.g., community members, non-physician health workers, and physicians in projects focused on service delivery). The teams then mapped the interventions they implemented and identified the major policy categories in which those interventions were implemented. Provided guidance on using the behavior change wheel to help ensure consistency of responses across teams. Ratings were iteratively discussed and refined in several group sessions. RESULTS: There were marked differences in the perceived skills, opportunities, and motivations of the different actors targeted for behavior change strategies. Despite this variation, there was a high degree of synergy in the intervention functions, with most teams employing complex interventions involving education, training, empowerment, environmental restructuring, and persuasion strategies. Similar policy categories were also targeted across teams, particularly in the areas of policy, communication/marketing and service delivery, with some teams focusing on fiscal measures, regulation and legislation. CONCLUSIONS: The large differences in the willingness to change behavior among the key actors in these projects suggest that the interventions themselves are received differently, despite the similarity of the approaches used. The results underscore the importance of contextual factors in the success and failure of research programs. Future outcome and process assessments of each project will build on this exploratory work and provide a better understanding of factors that might influence the scale-up of intervention strategies.

title: behavioral insights in health care
Beliefs and attitudes about breast cancer and screening practices among Arab women living in Qatar: a cross-sectional study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite rising breast cancer incidence and mortality rates, breast cancer screening (BCS) rates among women in Qatar remain low. Previous studies point to the need for a better understanding of the many complex beliefs, values, and attitudes that influence the health-oriented behaviors of Arab women in order to develop culturally appropriate and effective breast cancer intervention strategies in the Middle East. This study examines beliefs, attitudes, and BCS practices of Arabic-speaking women in Qatar. Methods: From March 2011 to July 2011, a multi-centre, cross-sectional, quantitative survey was conducted in Qatar among 1,063 (87.5% response rate) Arabic-speaking female Qatari citizens and non-Qatar residents aged 35 years or older. Associations between beliefs and BCS practice were estimated using chi-square tests and multivariate logistic regression analysis. Participants who adhered to BCS guidelines (BCS practice = Yes) were compared to those who did not (BCS practice = No). RESULTS: In addition to low awareness and participation rates in BCS, a quarter of the participants said their doctors had discussed breast cancer with them, and less than half of the women surveyed believed breast cancer could be prevented. Women who practiced BCS were more likely to have a doctor talk to them about breast cancer and believe they were in good to excellent health, that cancer could be prevented, or that cancer was hereditary. The majority wanted to know if they had cancer and felt that their medical care needs were met. The main reasons given for not planning BCS were lack of referral, fear and embarrassment. CONCLUSIONS: These results indicate that a variety of channels (healthcare providers, media, breast cancer survivors, community leaders) should be leveraged to create culturally appropriate breast cancer intervention programs and to raise awareness about breast cancer, BCS, and the benefits of early breast cancer detection. Deploying these measures will reduce breast cancer mortality rates among Arabic-speaking women living in the state of Qatar.

title: Beliefs about mammography screening in women presenting to the emergency department for non-urgent care
abstract: INTRODUCTION: One in 8 women in the US will be diagnosed with invasive breast cancer during their lifetime. Despite evidence that mammography is an effective method of early detection, certain at-risk groups, such as For example, those using the ED as a medical facility do not follow mammography screening guidelines and experience differential mortality from breast cancer. The purpose of this study was to examine differences in opinion about mammography screening among women visiting the emergency department for non-urgent care, and ultimately to develop interventions that promote mammography for this at-risk population. METHODS: We examined the relationship between the stage of readiness to introduce mammography behavior and barriers, benefits, and perceived vulnerabilities by issuing risk, benefit, and barrier scales in a sample of 110 women presenting to the emergency department of a public hospital non-urgent complaints or sat in the emergency room waiting room. We also collected socio-demographic information and maturity level. RESULTS: Mammography adherence was approximately 60%. Most of the women who didn't follow current guidelines were thinkers. Those who did not consider getting tested were significantly less likely to consider themselves at risk of developing breast cancer. Women who had greater barriers to mammography felt less benefit from mammography. African-American women felt less benefit from mammography. DISCUSSION: Mammography advertising is appropriately placed in the emergency department waiting room given the suboptimal rate at which this population is being screened. Opinions on mammography differ among women at various stages of mammography introduction and among women from minority groups. Understanding these differences will allow population-specific interventions in this setting. Emergency room nurses are an important, and sometimes the only, point of contact for patients who routinely visit the emergency department. As such, they have a valuable opportunity to deliver promotional messages for cancer prevention. It is critical that caregivers in this setting understand the complexities of providing this information and the need to do so.

title: Beneficial and harmful effects of enhanced feedback on physicians' clinical teaching performance
abstract: PURPOSE: To assess whether clinical teaching skills could be improved by providing teachers with enhanced student feedback. METHOD: A 1994 randomized, controlled study involved 42 treating physicians and 39 resident physicians from the Indiana University School of Medicine, who taught 110 students on a one-month rotation basis. Before the lesson rotation, the teachers of the intervention group received norm-related, graphical summaries of their teaching performance as evaluated by the students. At mid-month, teachers in the intervention group received student assessments, supplemented by individualized instructional effectiveness guidelines based on the Stanford Faculty Development Program framework. Linear models were used to analyze mean student ratings of mid-month and month-end instructional behavior. Independent variables included performance ratings, intervention status, teacher status, classroom experience, and interactions with baseline ratings. RESULTS: Complex interactions with output were observed for most instructional categories at mid-month and end-month. The teachers in the intervention group with high baseline performance scores had higher student ratings than the control group teachers with similar baseline scores; the teachers in the intervention group with low baseline performance scores were rated lower than the teachers in the control group with comparable baseline scores. RESIDENTS with moderate or high baselines were rated higher than treating physicians with comparable baselines.” The performance of RESIDENTS with low baselines was similar to that of treating physicians with comparable baselines. CONCLUSION: Baseline performance is important to target those teachers who are most likely to benefit from expanded student feedback. A potential deterioration in teaching performance warrants a re-examination of the distribution of student ratings among low-achieving teachers.

title: Benefits and harms of pharmacological treatment of urinary incontinence in women
abstract: Background: Urinary incontinence (UI) in women impairs quality of life. PURPOSE: To conduct a systematic literature review on drugs for urgent UI in women. Data sources: MEDLINE, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, SCIRUS and Google Scholar were searched for articles published from 1966 to November 2011. Study selection: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) in English. Data extraction: Outcome rates and risk of bias were extracted using a standardized form to summarize the absolute risk differences and calculate the number of attributable events per 1000 patients treated with 95% CIs. Data synthesis: 94 RCTs were eligible. Pooled analyzes showed that among the medications for urgent UI, per 1000 women treated, continence was restored in 130 with fesoterodine (CI 58 to 202), 85 with tolterodine (CI 40 to 129) and 114 with oxybutynin (CI 64 to 163) , 107 with solifenacin (CI, 58 to 156) and 114 with trospium (CI, 83 to 144). Discontinuation rates due to adverse events were 31 per 1000 subjects treated with fesoterodine (CI, 10 to 56), 63 with oxybutynin (CI, 12 to 127), 18 with trospium (CI, 4 to 33), and 13 with solifenacin (CI, 1 to 26). The studies' conflicting definitions of reduction in UI and quality of life made evidence synthesis difficult. Limitation: Evidence for improvements in quality of life and comparative drug efficacy was limited, and evidence for the effects of race, severity of UI at baseline, and comorbidities on treatment outcome was insufficient. Conclusion: Overall, medications for urgent UI showed a similarly small benefit. Therapeutic decisions should take into account the damage profile. Evidence of long-term adherence and safety of the treatments is lacking. Primary source of funding: Health Research and Quality Agency.

title: Benzodiazepines, opioids, and driving: a review of experimental research
abstract: PROBLEMS: Road traffic accidents are a significant contributor to the overall burden of injuries in Australia, with the risk of injury being linked to the presence of drugs and/or alcohol in the driver's blood. Increasingly, prescription drugs are among the most commonly discovered drugs, with the most notable being benzodiazepines and opioids. However, there is a lack of experimental research on the effects of prescribed psychiatric drugs on driving behavior. APPROACH: This paper reviews experimental studies examining the effects of prescribed doses of benzodiazepines and opioids on driving ability and suggests future research directions. MAIN FINDINGS: There is increasing epidemiological evidence that the therapeutic use of benzodiazepines and opioids is associated with an increased risk of accidents. However, the current experimental literature remains unclear. Limitations in study methods have led to conflicting results. IMPLICATION: There is limited experimental evidence to inform guidelines and guidelines on the fitness to drive of patients taking prescribed benzodiazepines and opioids. CONCLUSION: Further experimental research is needed to elucidate the effects of these drugs on driving under different conditions and in different medical contexts. This will ensure that physicians prescribing benzodiazepines and opioids are well informed and can adequately advise patients on the risks associated with driving while taking these drugs.

title: Grief Interventions for Adults with Intellectual Disabilities: What Works?
abstract: Exploring the theoretical foundations of grief and loss is now beginning for adults with intellectual disabilities (ID). However, as the life expectancy of people with intellectual disabilities increases, these adults experience more and more events of loss and grief. Practitioners, particularly bereavement workers, find it increasingly important that they understand best practice principles for working with bereaved adults with intellectual disabilities in their day-to-day work. Practitioners are also asked to guide families and caregivers regarding grief and death education. This article provides counselors and other professionals with an overview of existing grief intervention research for adults with intellectual disabilities. Best practice recommendations are made at three levels: informal support, formal intervention, and community building.

title: Best practice in the management of primary nocturnal enuresis in children: a systematic review
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Nocturnal wetting is the involuntary nocturnal loss of urine in a child of an age and physical condition when it should be dry. The prevalence of this condition in Australia has been estimated at 18.9% in children aged 5 to 12, with up to 19% of boys and 16% of girls by the age of 5 wetting the bed at least once a month. Up to the age of 13, bedwetting is more common in boys and more common in girls from that age. Nocturnal bed-wetting has a spontaneous cure rate of about 14%, however up to 3% of children remain enuretic as adults. Although this condition is pathologically benign, it can have serious social and psychological effects on the sufferer, including effects on self-esteem, academic success, parental disapproval, and even sexual activity later in life. Despite the amount of information available on the treatment of enuresis, the majority of research has been conducted outside of Australia. Therefore, the purpose of this work was to develop treatment guidelines for children's night-time wetting that are specific to Australian clinical practice. INCLUSION CRITERIA: This review considered systematic reviews or concurrent controlled trials (randomized controlled trials (RCT), pseudo-randomized controlled trials, controlled clinical trials (CCT), interrupted time series (ITS), and controlled before-and-after studies (CBA)) on To study the effectiveness of measures to treat night-time wetting in children up to 16 years of age. SEARCH STRATEGY: A systematic search of the literature was performed to identify all available evidence. Cochrane and other health technology assessment websites were searched for existing systematic reviews. For more recent randomized controlled trials and controlled trials (1990 to 2007), Pubmed, Embase, and CINAHL databases were searched. Reference lists of all articles found were searched for relevant studies. These reviews and guidelines have been summarized and presented to an advisory panel of continence advisors and clinicians to ensure relevance to Australian clinical practice. METHODOLOGICAL QUALITY: The methodological quality of all studies was assessed by two reviewers using the JBI forms for critical evaluation of experimental studies in the JBI-MAStARI software. This tool was used to identify all sources of bias. In the event of differences of opinion between the two experts, a third expert decided. RESULTS: Seven systematic reviews, eight new studies, and two guidelines were used in the development of these guidelines. Brief treatment recommendations include: CONCLUSIONS: Despite the high prevalence of night-time wetting and the negative psychosocial consequences that can result from this condition, treatment is both readily available and effective. PRACTICAL IMPLICATIONS: The practical management of night-wetting in children should begin with treating both daytime-wetting and any signs of constipation. Subsequently, less invasive behavioral therapies should be tried. If these measures fail, the use of alarms with or without a short course of desmopressin can be tried. Other interventions have yet to prove definitively effective and should be viewed with caution. However, it should be emphasized that the vast majority of children will become continent at some point in the future, with or without the benefit of interventions. RESEARCH IMPLICATIONS: While it is clear that some behavioral methods, alerts, and desmopressin can be effective interventions, the evidence for other treatments is less conclusive. However, the observation that even alarms and/or desmopressin do not work in all children suggests that investigations to determine the effectiveness of other interventions (particularly behavioral and complementary treatments) should take the form of large, carefully designed RCTs.

title: Best Strategies for Implementing Clinical Pathways in an Emergency Department: Study Protocol for a Randomized Controlled Cluster Trial
abstract: Background The clinical pathway is a tool that operationalizes the best evidence recommendations and clinical practice guidelines in an accessible format for point-of-care management by multidisciplinary health teams in hospitals. While high-quality, expert-developed clinical pathways have many potential benefits, their impact has been limited by variable implementation strategies and suboptimal research designs. The best strategies for implementing paths in hospital environments are still unknown. The aim of this study is to develop and comprehensively evaluate the best strategies for effective local implementation of externally developed clinical pathways. Design/Methods We will develop a theory-based and knowledge-based intervention strategy to implement two pediatric treatment pathways: asthma and gastroenteritis. Using a balanced incomplete block design, we will randomize 16 community emergency departments to receive the intervention for one clinical pathway and serve as a control for the alternative clinical pathway, and thus conduct two clustered randomized controlled trials to evaluate this implementing intervention. A minimization procedure is used to randomize locations. Intervention centers receive a tailored strategy to support the full implementation of the clinical pathway. We will assess the effectiveness of the implementation strategy by measuring relevant processes and clinical outcomes. The primary outcome of the process is the existence of an appropriately completed clinical pathway on the map for relevant patients. The primary clinical outcomes for each clinical pathway include: Asthma¡Âªthe proportion of asthmatic patients adequately treated with corticosteroids in the ED and at discharge";" and Gastroenteritis¡ª the proportion of relevant patients adequately treated with oral rehydration therapy. Data sources include chart audits, administrative databases, environmental scans and qualitative interviews. We also conduct an overall process assessment to assess implementation strategy and an economic analysis to assess implementation costs and benefits. Discussion This study will contribute to the evidence supporting effective strategies for implementing clinical pathways and ultimately reduce the research gaps in practice by operationalizing the best evidence-based nursing recommendations through the effective use of clinical pathways.

title: Best practice intervention for the care of clients who are self-mutilating
abstract: PURPOSE: To describe the development of a best practice intervention to guide Nurse Practitioners (NPs) who care for individuals who are self-mutilating. DATA SOURCES: The evidence on which the guideline was based includes six descriptive studies and clinical expert opinions. The framework for guideline development is a systematic process to obtain and analyze the best available evidence, develop a theory-guided intervention, and propose a system for ongoing assessment of the intervention's effectiveness. Conclusions: The guide is an information sheet that includes the definition of self-mutilation, background of the problem, target group concerned and intervention. The three components of the intervention are (a) the NP's self-evaluation of values, beliefs, and assumptions about self-mutilators; (b) a targeted, in-depth assessment of the client; and (c) therapeutic strategies to address the emotional, social, and biological dimensions of self-mutilation. PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: This best-practice intervention for the care of self-injurious clients provides NPs with guidance on how to effectively address avoidable, self-injurious behavior. Further studies are needed to examine the effectiveness of using the guideline and the intervention.

title: Better medicine by default
abstract: Background. The American healthcare system is switching to electronic doctor appointments. These computerized systems are unique in that they allow for custom job interfaces. While these systems offer great benefits, there are also potential pitfalls, as behavioral science has shown that the actual format of electronic interfaces can influence decision-making. In particular, current research examines how errors in electronic prescription templates affect treatment decisions and treatment errors by physicians. methods. 45 residents filled out order kits for 3 medical case studies. Participants were randomly assigned to receive order sets with either "opt-in" defaults (options visible but not selected) or "opt-out" defaults (options visible and preselected). The results compare error rates between conditions and examine the type and severity of errors most commonly made with opt-in and opt-out defaults. Results. Compared to opt-in defaults, opt-out defaults led to a larger number of items ordered and in particular to increased commission errors (overordering). While opt-in defaults resulted in fewer orders, they also resulted in more omission errors. Taking into account the severity of the errors, the failure effects appear to be limited to less severe errors. Conclusion. The specifications used in electronic prescription records influence medical treatment decisions when the impact on a patient's health is minor. This pattern suggests that physicians cognitively override wrong standard decisions, but only up to a point, and it implies trade-offs that maximize accuracy and minimize cognitive effort. The results indicate that default values for low-impact items on electronic templates require careful attention, as physicians are unlikely to override them.

title: Better practices in collaborative mental health care: an analysis of the evidence base
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Conduct a systematic review of the experimental literature to identify better practices in collaborative mental health care in primary care. METHODS: A review of the Canadian and international literature using Medline, PsycInfo, Embase, the Cochrane Library and other databases identified over 900 related reports, of which 38 studies met the inclusion criteria. A systematic review and descriptive analysis is presented with the main conclusions and best practices. RESULTS: A successful collaboration requires preparation, time and supportive structures, building on pre-existing clinical relationships. Collaborative practice is likely to be most developed when clinicians are co-located and most effective when the location is familiar and non-stigmatizing to patients. The degree of collaboration does not appear to predict clinical outcome. Improved collaboration coupled with treatment guidelines or protocols offer important advantages over any intervention alone for major depression. Systematic follow-up was a strong predictor of a positive outcome in cooperative treatment for depression. A clear correlation between collaborative efforts to increase drug intake and clinical outcomes was not apparent. Collaboration alone has not been shown to result in skill transfer in PCP knowledge or behaviors in treating depression. A restructuring of services aimed at supporting changes in the practice patterns of primary health care providers is also required. Improved patient education has been part of many studies with good results. Education was generally provided by someone other than the PCP. Collaborative interventions that are part of a research protocol can be difficult to sustain over the long term without ongoing funding. Consumer choice of treatment modality may be important to treatment in collaborative care (e.g., the ability to choose psychotherapy over medication). CONCLUSIONS: There is now a wealth of experimental literature assessing the impact of improved collaboration on patient outcomes, mainly in depressive disorders. Better practices in collaborative mental health care are beginning to emerge.

title: Between collegial discussion and controlled study: sources of information and practical knowledge of neurologists in the treatment of stroke patients
abstract: The application of evidence-based and standardized knowledge is an important basis for coordinated and effective clinical work. A multicenter study conducted in 30 clinical neurology departments and in which 99 junior and senior registrars participated addressed aspects of practical knowledge of stroke treatment through open structured oral interviews that were analyzed for inter-physician and guideline compliance. In addition, the participants were asked to rate the usefulness of various sources of information and to describe the information sources they used according to the aspects of practical knowledge addressed. The respective heads of department were asked about the sources of medical knowledge accessible in their clinic. In almost all hospitals, doctors had access to a library and the Internet. However, the departments differed with regard to their information management (frequency and type of medical training, quality management, participation in research activities). In line with other studies, the most commonly cited sources of knowledge were textbooks, journals, and clinical studies. For most sources, the utility rankings closely matched the user behavior rankings. Both were only weak predictors for inter-physician and guideline compliance. They relate more to the intra-departmental homogeneity of practical knowledge than to cross-departmental and guideline conformity. Homogeneity within the department is enhanced through the use of current, published and evidence-based sources and up-to-date interaction with clinical colleagues. Conformity with the guideline referred to the use of databases and specialist journals. Preference for colleagues from outpatient practices reduced both inter-physician and guideline compliance. It seems that there is still untapped potential for departmental knowledge management, e.g. B. medical education, implementation and use of guidelines and current discussions that can improve the homogeneity and guideline conformance of the practical knowledge that clinicians apply.

title: Between control and therapy: An evolutionary concept analysis of special observation in acute psychiatry
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The special observation is a seriously invasive and resource-intensive procedure. For further investigations and practice, it is necessary to conceptualize this measure scientifically. Methods: Evolutionary concept analysis. RESULTS: The identified histories, features and consequences of a particular observation range between control and therapy as well as patient safety and professional coverage. Antecedents include legitimacy (note, evaluation, regulation), resources (internal policies, architectural structures, information), and contextual factors (security needs, personal attitudes). The attitudes identified are organization (qualification, change of caregiver, duration, location), intervention (relationship, reassessment, transparency) and the tension between control and therapy. The consequences consist of side effects (patients, caregivers, resources) and conflicts (ethical dilemmas, role conflicts). CONCLUSION: Society and discipline have influenced the concept over time, and a distinction between the supervisory and control pattern versus a therapeutic approach is recommended.

title: Between scientific application and therapy: The ethical consideration
abstract: The development of life sciences and biotechnology over the past thirty years has had a tremendous impact on medicine. New techniques have emerged and new types of treatment have been and are being introduced. Theories about the pathogenesis and causes of disease are changing while new therapeutics are constantly being introduced. The way in which new technologies and medicines are introduced increasingly contains an experimental phase in which animals and humans are used to test the results of the research. These experiments are usually carried out according to the Declaration of Helsinki (WMA, Helsinki 1964, Tokyo, 1975). The guidelines of this declaration deal with the ethical aspects of experiments involving human beings. Although the guidelines are said to have global relevance, the fact remains that some of them are being discussed in several regions of the world. They seem to have a cultural background (e.g. respect for the individual) and life scientists sometimes argue that for this reason they must be considered non-scientific constraints. Based on a general philosophical and ethical view, this paper argues that ethical guidelines are at the core of biomedicine and biology itself. It is in the common interest of researchers, clinicians, patients and scientists to consider the ethical implications of research results before it can be determined that valuable knowledge will be gained. The implementation of monoclonal antibodies in clinical practice can be seen as an example for this reasoning.

title: Beyond screening for domestic violence: a systems model approach in a managed care setting
abstract: BACKGROUND: Implementation of domestic violence screening guidelines has been challenging. The multi-faceted “systems model” can provide a powerful tool to improve domestic violence screening, identification and intervention in healthcare settings. METHODS: We developed: (1) a systems model approach using tools for effective referral, assessment, and reporting of domestic violence; (2) materials for distribution to patients; (3) training for social services and mental health clinicians assessing domestic violence; and (4) strong ties to the community INSTITUTION: A nonprofit managed care facility in Richmond, California PARTICIPANTS: Staff and members of the managed care plan by clinicians; (2) increased awareness of the health facility as a resource for domestic violence support;" and (3) increased member satisfaction with the health plan's efforts to address domestic violence. RESULTS: The number of clinician referrals and patient self-referrals to an evaluator by on-site domestic violence increased by more than two-fold A pre- and post-intervention telephone survey of members seen for routine assessment revealed an increase in member recall of domestic violence issues Post-intervention, statistically significant increases in perceptions of the Members observed the health plan's concern about the health effects of domestic violence (p<0.0001), and member satisfaction with the health plan's efforts to address this issue (p<0.0001). approach improved within lb a year providing domestic violence services in a managed care health setting and influencing the behavior of clinicians and the experience of health plan members. This successful implementation makes it possible to answer critical research questions on the impact of a health intervention for victims of domestic violence in a managed health setting.

title: Big pharma and healthcare: unresolvable conflict of interest between private company and public health
abstract: seminal paper on game theory showed that individual profit maximization inevitably compromises the common good, and since the problem has no technical solution, "it requires a fundamental extension of morality" (1). We propose here that public health as a public good is now emerging as a severe example of this problem. Recent events and reports increasingly point to a disconnect between the interests of the pharmaceutical industry and those of public health.
