Johnson & Johnson illegally and effectively promoted Propulsid to children off-label, despite internal company documents raising safety concerns. The drug-trial death was described as a "trade secret." Regarding Vioxx, Topol wrote: "Unfortunately, it is clear that Merck's commercial interest outweighed its concerns about the toxicity of the drug" (2). Scientists and editors of major journals are increasingly raising concerns about the type and quality of published evidence, which often focuses on the effectiveness of new products. Industry, which funds over 80% of trials, is creating a research agenda that is more driven by marketing than clinical considerations. Intelligent statistical and epidemiological tactics help to achieve the desired results. The budget for marketing is far larger than for research. Massive advertising to doctors and the general public is becoming more sophisticated: ghostwriting, professional guidelines, targeting consumer groups, and manipulating media to spread disease. Pervasive lobbying and political affiliations limit the independence of regulators. Duty to shareholders, which outweighs public health considerations, is not unique to the pharmaceutical industry. The chemical, tobacco and food industries use similar tactics: they proclaim doubts about safety issues, buy researchers, infiltrate universities, boards, media and legislatures. In contrast, high-performing and cheap health-promoting activities that have poor industry support because they are too cheap and unpatented are grossly underutilized: behavior modification technologies (e.g., cardiac rehabilitation), palliative care, and the use of old, more effective, and safer medicines - all could benefit from industry's marketing and quality tools. With the sick, the poor and the least educated being hardest hit, the successes of the free market seem to pose insurmountable challenges to social justice in public health.

title: Binge eating disorder in adults: a systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: The best treatment options for binge eating disorder are unclear. PURPOSE: To summarize evidence on the benefits and harms of psychological and pharmacological therapies for adults with binge eating disorder. DATA SOURCES: English language publications in EMBASE, The Cochrane Library, Academic OneFile, CINAHL, and ClinicalTrials.gov up to November 18, 2015 and in MEDLINE up to May 12, 2016. STUDY SELECTION: 9 wait-list-controlled psychological studies and 25 placebo-controlled studies covering pharmacology (n = 19) or combination studies (n = 6) treatment. All were randomized trials with low or moderate risk of bias.DATA EXTRACTION: 2 reviewers independently extracted study data, assessed risk of bias, and rated the strength of evidence.DATA SYNTHESIS: Therapist-led cognitive-behavioral therapy, lisdexamfetamine, and second-generation antidepressants (SGAs) reduced binge -Eating frequency and increased binge eating abstinence (relative risk, 4.95 [95% CI, 3.06 to 8.00], 2.61 [CI, 2.04 to 3.33] and 1, respectively, 67 [CI, 1.24 to 2.26]) . Lisdexamfetamine (mean difference [MD], -6.50 [CI, -8.82 to -4.18]) and SGAs (MD, -3.84 [CI, -6.55 to -1.13]) reduced Binge eating and compulsive eating and SGAs reduced symptoms of depression (MD, -1.97 [CI, -3.67 to -0.28]). Headache, gastrointestinal disturbance, sleep disturbance and sympathetic nervous system excitation were more common with lisdexamfetamine than with placebo (relative risk range 1.63 to 4.28). Other forms of cognitive behavioral therapy and topiramate also increased abstinence and reduced the frequency of binge eating and associated psychopathology. Topiramate reduced weight and increased sympathetic nervous system arousal, and lisdexamfetamine reduced weight and appetite. LIMITATIONS: Most study participants were overweight or obese white women aged 20 to 40 years. Many therapies have only been investigated in individual studies. Outcomes were measured inconsistently across studies and rarely assessed beyond the end of treatment. CONCLUSION: Cognitive behavioral therapy, lisdexamfetamine, SGAs, and topiramate reduced binge eating and associated psychopathology, and lisdexamfetamine and topiramate reduced weight in adults with binge eating disorder.

title: Biomedical and Behavioral Research in Nursing Homes: Guidelines for Ethical Inquiry
abstract: As nursing homes become increasingly important sites for biomedical and behavioral research, researchers must address the ethical issues of increased vulnerability and the high prevalence of mental and physical disorders in nursing home populations. Obtaining valid informed consent is just one of the many difficult issues faced by the nursing home investigator. Efforts should be made to involve nursing home residents, as well as family members and staff, in reviewing the research. The benefits and burdens of research protocols should be shared equitably, and potential conflicts of interest for staff and physicians should be minimized or their potential adverse effects mitigated. Adequate attention to these ethical concerns can facilitate research in nursing homes while protecting vulnerable residents. We offer suggested guidelines for conducting research ethically in nursing homes to stimulate discussion among investigators, nursing home staff and residents, residents' families, and ethicists.

title: Center for Bipolar Disorder for Pennsylvanians: Conducting an Efficacy Study to Improve Treatment for Patients at Risk
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Adolescents, older adults, African Americans, and rural residents are less likely to be diagnosed with bipolar disorder than their middle-aged white urban counterparts, receive appropriate treatment, remain on treatment once identified, and have positive outcomes. The Bipolar Disorder Center for Pennsylvanians (BDCP) study was designed to address these differences. This report highlights the methods used to recruit, screen, and enroll a cohort of hard-to-recruit individuals with bipolar disorder. METHODS: Study centers included three specialty bipolar disorder clinics in a university setting and one rural behavioral clinic. The study process was standardized and the entire study staff was trained in the study processes. Several strategies were used for recruitment. RESULTS: It was possible to implement the identical assessment and screening protocol in institutions regardless of whether they had implemented research protocols in the past. This protocol could also be used across the age range, in urban and rural settings, and in a racially diverse cohort of participants. The four sites enrolled 515 people with bipolar disorder as a result of these methods (69 African American and 446 non-African American). Although clinical characteristics at baseline did not differ appreciably between African Americans and non-African Americans, treatment pathways differed significantly. CONCLUSIONS: Rigorous recruitment and assessment procedures can be successfully implemented in different settings and with different patient cohorts, facilitating access to quality treatment for individuals who often do not receive adequate treatment for bipolar disorder.

title: Books and reading: evidence-based standard of care whose time has come
abstract: Reach Out and Read (ROR) is the only clinical activity to advance child development in primary care that has been systematically evaluated across the United States. The ROR intervention is straightforward: Physicians provide advice on the benefits of reading aloud and provide books directly to at-risk children and parents to take home at each pediatric visit for children aged 6 months to 5 years. ROR builds on a significant body of evidence of the value of reading to young children. The studies evaluating ROR in different sites from people of different racial backgrounds and numerous outcome measures are consistently positive. From its first single site at Boston City Hospital in 1989 to over 4,600 clinical sites in 2010, over 30,000 clinicians distributed over 6.2 million books annually to 3.9 million children across the United States. Future efforts for ROR include the integration of mental health competencies found in the American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines as part of the training of board specialists and physicians in the ROR paradigm, quality improvements to ensure fidelity to the intervention, and an expanded involvement of pediatric clinicians in local early childhood/school readiness collaborative efforts. Finally, the most important goal for the future is to take over the advice on reading aloud and the development-appropriate allocation of books to families at risk as best practice from official bodies.

title: Borderline personality disorder in adolescence
abstract: Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) is a common and serious mental disorder associated with severe functional impairment and a high rate of suicide. BPD is usually associated with other psychiatric and personality disorders, a high burden on families and caregivers, sustained resource use, and high treatment costs. BPD was a controversial diagnosis in adolescents, but it is no longer justified. Recent evidence indicates that adolescent BPD is as reliable and valid as that in adults, and that adolescents with BPD may benefit from early intervention. As a result, adolescent BPD is now recognized in psychiatric classification systems and in national treatment guidelines. This review aims to educate practitioners in the field of adolescent health about the nature of adolescent BPD and the benefits of early detection and intervention. BPD diagnosis and treatment should be considered part of routine adolescent mental health practice to improve the well-being and long-term prognosis of these individuals.

title: Happy new EMR
Breaking new ground: challenging existing asthma guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: While there are international guidelines and various national guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of asthma, asthma remains poorly controlled in many children and adults. In this paper, we address the limitations of current asthma guidelines and describe important issues and remaining issues related to the use of asthma guidelines, particularly in primary care. DISCUSSION: Clinical practice guidelines based on evidence from randomized controlled trials are considered the most rigorous and accurate. However, current evidence-based guidelines are overwhelmingly written from the perspective of the patient with a clear diagnosis of asthma and tend to fail to account for the heterogeneity of asthma or to account for individual patient variations in terms of treatment or their needs, as well as differences in practice settings or local differences in the availability and cost of therapies. The results of randomized controlled trials designed to demonstrate treatment efficacy under ideal conditions may not apply to "real world" clinical practice where patients are not selected, monitoring is less frequent and efficacy - the usefulness of treatment in routine clinical practice – is the most relevant finding. In addition, most guidelines look at asthma in isolation, rather than considering other factors that may affect asthma and response to asthma therapy, particularly age, allergic rhinitis, cigarette smoking, adherence, and genetic factors. When these associations are recognized, guidelines rarely provide practical recommendations for treatment in these scenarios. Finally, there is evidence that general practitioners are not confident in the applicability of asthma guidelines in their practice, particularly when guideline writers work primarily in specialist practices. CONCLUSION: The development of country-specific guidelines, or ideally local guidelines, could provide more practical solutions for asthma care and could take into account regional factors influencing patient choice and treatment adherence. Pragmatic clinical trials and well-designed observational studies, in addition to randomized controlled trials, are needed to assess the effectiveness of therapies in practice, and such evidence must also be considered by guideline authors. Finally, practical tools are needed to diagnose and assess asthma and factors responsible for poor control, such as associated allergic rhinitis, impaired adherence and smoking behavior, to complement the treatment information provided in the clinical practice guidelines for asthma.

title: Breast cancer knowledge, attitudes, and screening behaviors among African-American women: the Black Beautician Health Advancement Program
abstract: BACKGROUND: African American women have a higher death rate from breast cancer than their white counterparts. Studies have shown that this is partly caused by the detection of cancer at a later stage, underscoring the importance of promoting early detection of breast cancer in this population. This study examined whether a cohort of African American women living in San Diego had sufficient basic breast cancer screening knowledge to guide the development of a breast cancer awareness effort, to focus the health promotion efforts of other health educators and clinicians, and to adhere to commonly recommended screening guidelines. METHODS: African American women (N=1,055) from San Diego, California, participated in a beauty salon survey on breast cancer knowledge, attitudes, and screening practices. The ages of the women ranged from 20 to 94 years, with a mean age of 42.20 (SD = 13.53) years. Thirty-four percent reported having completed college and/or graduate school education, and 52% reported having completed college or post-high school education. 75 percent of those surveyed said they work outside of their home. The participating estheticians and their salons were recruited for the study through word of mouth from highly respected African American community leaders. RESULTS: Salon clients reported low adherence to recommended breast cancer screening guidelines. Of the 1,055 participants, 31% said they perform breast self-exams every month. Of participants 40 years and older, 57% reported having had a clinical breast exam and 43% reported having had a mammogram in the past year. Awareness of breast cancer was associated with adherence to screening guidelines. While women recognized the serious health threat that breast cancer poses and that early detection of breast cancer is important, only 30% of women said they felt well informed about the disease. Many participants lacked basic knowledge about breast cancer. The Health Belief Model posits that access to such information is an essential element in developing screening behaviors. CONCLUSION: The data from this study reflect a continuing need for increased breast cancer education for African American women. Given the considerable amount of mainstream information that is available about breast cancer, these data reinforce the need for more breast cancer awareness programs that are clearly aimed at catching the attention of African American women.

title: Bridging the Gap Between Pragmatic Intervention Design and Theory: Using Behavioral Science Tools to Modify an Existing Quality Improvement Program to Implement “Sepsis Six”
abstract: BACKGROUND: Sepsis has a 40% mortality rate that can be halved if the evidence-based "Sepsis Six" package of care is implemented within 1 hour. UK audit shows low implementation rates. Interventions to improve this have had minimal impact. Quality improvement programs could be further developed by using theoretical frameworks (Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF)) to modify existing interventions by identifying influences on clinical behavior and selecting appropriate content. The aim of this study was to illustrate the use of this process to modify an intervention developed using Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycles and partially successful in improving the implementation of Sepsis Six in a hospital was. METHODS: Factors influencing implementation were examined using the TDF to analyze interviews with 34 health professionals. The nursing team that designed and moderated the intervention used the data to select modifications using the Behavior Change Technique (BCT) taxonomy (v1) and the APEASE criteria: affordability, feasibility, efficacy, acceptability, safety, and equity. RESULTS: Five issues affecting implementation and modification of the guided intervention were identified. These were: (1) "knowing what to do and why" (TDF domains Knowledge, Social/Professional Role and Identity)";" (2) “Risks and Benefits” (beliefs about consequences), e.g. B. Fear of harming patients through fluid overload, which acts as a barrier to implementation versus belief in the effectiveness of the bundle, which acts as a lever for implementation";" (3) "Collaboration" (social influences, social/professional role and identity), e.g. e.g. team collaboration as a lever versus physician-nurse conflict as a barrier";" (4) "empowerment and support" (beliefs about abilities, social/professional role and identity, behavior regulation, social influences), e.g. B. Involving staff in intervention development as a lever versus lack of trust to challenge colleagues' decisions not to take action as a barrier";" (5) “Human resources” (environmental context and resources), e.g. B. nightly shortage of doctors, which prevents implementation. The modified intervention included six new BCTs and consisted of two additional components (Sepsis Six Training for the Hospital at Night Coordinator, a partnership agreement that affirms commitment from all clinical staff and allows for collegial challenges) and changes to two existing components (staff training sessions; "Documents and Materials). CONCLUSIONS: This work demonstrates the feasibility of the TDF and BCT taxonomy (v1) for the development of an existing quality improvement measure. The tools are compatible with the pragmatic PDSA cycle approach commonly used in quality improvement work.

title: Bridging the gap between pragmatic intervention design and theory: Using behavioral science tools to modify an existing quality improvement program to implement “Sepsis Six”.
abstract: Background Sepsis has a 40% mortality rate, which can be halved if the evidence-based treatment package “Sepsis Six” is implemented within 1 hour. UK audit shows low implementation rates. Interventions to improve this have had minimal impact. Quality improvement programs could be further developed by using theoretical frameworks (Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF)) to modify existing interventions by identifying influences on clinical behavior and selecting appropriate content. The aim of this study was to illustrate the use of this process to modify an intervention developed using Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycles and partially successful in improving the implementation of Sepsis Six in a hospital was. Methods Factors affecting implementation were examined using the TDF to analyze interviews with 34 health professionals. The nursing team that designed and moderated the intervention used the data to select modifications using the Behavior Change Technique (BCT) taxonomy (v1) and the APEASE criteria: affordability, feasibility, efficacy, acceptability, safety, and equity. Results Five issues affecting the implementation and modification of the guided intervention were identified. These were: (1) "knowing what to do and why" (TDF domain knowledge, social/professional role and identity)"; (2) “risks and benefits” (beliefs about consequences), e.g. B. Fear of harming patients through fluid overload, which acts as a barrier to implementation versus belief in the effectiveness of the bundle, which acts as a lever for implementation; (3) "Collaboration" (social influences, social/professional role and identity), e.g. B. Team collaboration as a lever versus doctor/nurse conflict as a barrier; (4) empowerment and support (beliefs about abilities, social/professional role and identity, behavioral regulation, social influences), e.g. B. Involvement of staff in intervention development who act as a lever versus lack of confidence to challenge decisions by colleagues not to implement decisions that act as a hindrance; (5) human resources (environmental context and resources), e.g. B. Night-time physician shortages preventing implementation included six new BCTs and consisted of two additional components (Sepsis Six Training for the Hospital at Night Coordinator; a partnership agreement that supports commitment from all clinical staff and allows for collegial challenges) and Changes to two existing components (staff training sessions; documents and materials). Conclusions This work demonstrates the feasibility of the TDF and BCT taxonomy (v1) for the development of an existing quality improvement intervention: the tools are compatible with the pragmatic PDSA cycle approach commonly used in quality improvement work.

title: Bridging the science-service gap in schizophrenia care in the Netherlands: the Schizophrenia Quality Improvement Collaborative
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Many patients with schizophrenia are not treated according to evidence-based guidelines. This study examines the large-scale implementation of the National Multidisciplinary Guideline for Schizophrenia in the Netherlands. DESIGN: /st> observational study, prospective study, with repeated measures. SETTING: Thirty psychiatric teams in different regions of the Netherlands. PARTICIPANTS: Three hundred and fifty-nine clinicians from diverse professional backgrounds and 1489 patients with schizophrenia. INTERVENTION(S): Six evidence-based interventions for schizophrenia were delivered as part of a quality improvement collaboration: Assertive Community Treatment (ACT) or its adapted version Functional Assertive Community Treatment (FACT), cognitive behavioral therapy, psychoeducation, family interventions, individual mediation support, and pharmacotherapy. KEY OUTCOME MEASUREMENT(S): Occupational performance, social functioning, and recidivism rates. RESULTS: Improved professional performance according to guidelines. The availability of (F)ACT improved from 23 to 60%. Individual placement support improved from 20% to 53%. Complete treatment plans were established for 38% of patients and routine outcome monitoring was implemented in most teams. Social functioning improved slightly (HoNOS mean: from 6.2 to 5.6). Relapse rates did not improve over the course of the study. CONCLUSIONS: An intensive implementation program can lead to improved delivery of evidence-based care, increased continuity of care, and slightly improved outcomes for persons with schizophrenia. More rigorous research designs need to confirm these results.

title: Brief, physician-initiated smoking cessation strategies for clinical oncology settings: a study coordinated by the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group
abstract: PURPOSE: Although tobacco use increases the risk of recurrence, reduces treatment effectiveness, and worsens quality of life in cancer patients, about one-third of patients who smoked before their diagnosis continue to smoke. Since the patients are in regular contact with oncologists, the effectiveness of medical smoking cessation treatment was evaluated. METHODS: Cancer patients (n=432) were randomly assigned to either usual care or a smoking intervention administered by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) physician. The primary endpoint was 7-day point prevalence abstinence at 6 and 12 months after study entry. RESULTS: At the 6-month follow-up, there was no significant difference in dropout rates between the usual care (11.9%) and intervention groups (14.4%), and there was no significant difference between the groups with the usual care (13.6%) and intervention groups (13.3%) at the 12-month follow-up. Patients were more likely to have quit smoking by 6 months if they had head and neck or lung cancer, started smoking after age 16, reported at baseline that they had received advice on smoking in the past 6 months self-help to quit smoking or used treatment, and more showed a basic desire to quit. Patients were more likely to have quit smoking at 12 months if they smoked 15 or fewer cigarettes per day, had head and neck or lung cancer, tried a group cessation program, and demonstrated a greater baseline desire to quit smoking. Finally, physicians demonstrated greater adherence to the NIH model for physician smoking management among patients in the intervention group compared to the usual treatment group. CONCLUSION: While training physicians in treating cancer patients for smoking cessation may improve physician adherence to clinical practice guidelines, physician interventions for smoking cessation do not result in significant increases in long-term smoking cessation rates in cancer patients.

title: British Association for Psychopharmacology consensus guide on the use of psychotropic drugs before conception in pregnancy and after childbirth 2017
abstract: Decisions about the use of psychiatric drugs in pregnancy are an ongoing challenge for clinicians and women with mental health problems, due to the uncertainties surrounding the risks of the disease itself to the mother and foetus/child, the effectiveness of medications in pregnancy, and risks to the Fetus/infant via in utero exposure or via breast milk. These consensus guidelines aim to provide pragmatic advice on these issues. They are divided into the sections Risks of Untreated Illness in Pregnancy, General Principles of Drug Use in the Perinatal Period, Benefits and Harms Associated with Individual Drugs, and Risks of Untreated Illness in Pregnancy. and recommendations for the treatment of specific diseases.

title: Capacity building for antiretroviral administration in South Africa: a qualitative assessment of the PALSA PLUS training program for nurses
abstract: BACKGROUND: South Africa recently started a national antiretroviral treatment program. This has created an urgent need for training nurses in antiretroviral treatment (ART). The PALSA PLUS program provides guidelines and training for primary health care (PHC) nurses in the management of adult pulmonary disease and HIV/AIDS, including ART. A process evaluation was conducted to document the training, examine perceptions of the value of training, and compare the PALSA PLUS training approach (used at intervention sites) to the provincial training model. The evaluation was conducted in parallel with a randomized controlled trial measuring the effects of PALSA PLUS nursing training (study reference number ISRCTN24820584). METHODS: Qualitative methods were used, including participant observation of training sessions, focus group discussions, and interviews. The data were analyzed thematically. RESULTS: Nurse acceptance of PALSA PLUS training was high, not only in terms of ART-specific components, but also in terms of lung health. The continuous on-site training of all PHC nurses, as opposed to the one-time central training offered for ART nurses only in non-interventional clinics, enhanced the nurses' experience of supporting their work by not only providing continuous experiential learning, supervision and emotional support, but also for the ongoing review of any infrastructure and system level changes required to facilitate healthcare provider behavior change and policy implementation. Training all PHC nurses to use the PALSA PLUS guideline as opposed to ART nurses alone was also seen as better integrating AIDS care into the clinical context. CONCLUSION: The PALSA PLUS training has successfully engaged all PHC nurses in a comprehensive approach to a range of diseases affecting both HIV positive and negative patients. PHC nursing education for integrated systems-based interventions should be prioritized on the ART funding agenda. However, behavior change training for individual providers is just one aspect of the ongoing system-wide interventions needed to bring about lasting improvement in patient care in the context of an overburdened and underfunded PHC system.

title: Building clinical networks: a development assessment framework
abstract: Background Clinical networks were conceived as a cross-organizational mechanism for planning and delivering health services. Given recent concerns about the effectiveness of these structures, it is time to consider an evidence-based approach to their development and assessment. Aim To document an assessment framework for clinical networks by drawing on the network assessment literature and a 5-year study of clinical networks. Method We searched literature in three areas: network assessment, factors supporting or inhibiting network evolution, and robust methods for measuring network properties. This material was used to create a framework needed for effective development assessment. Results The architecture of the framework identifies three phases of clinical network development";" Partner selection, network design and network management. At each stage there are indications of factors that act as facilitators and obstacles to network growth. These factors can be used to measure progress using appropriate methods and tools. The framework can provide network growth and support informed decisions about progress. Conclusions For the first time in one place, a framework containing rigorous methodologies and tools can identify factors known to influence the evolution of clinical networks. The target group of users are internal stakeholders who need to conduct a development assessment in order to make important decisions along the development path of their network.

title: Establish nationwide academic support infrastructure for students with mild traumatic brain injuries
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Focus on building nationwide capacity to support students with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI)/concussion. METHOD: Consensus-building process involving a multidisciplinary group of clinicians, researchers, policy makers, and State Department of Education staff. RESULTS: The white paper represents the group's consensus on the essential components of a nationwide educational infrastructure to support the management of students with mTBI. The nature and recovery process of mTBI is briefly described, with particular reference to its impact on academic learning and performance. State and local policy considerations are then emphasized to encourage the implementation of a consistent process. Five key components to building a nationwide infrastructure for students with mTBI are outlined, including (1) definition and training of the interdisciplinary school team, (2) professional development of the school and medical communities, (3) identification, assessment, and progress monitoring protocols, (4) a flexible set of intervention strategies to meet students' recovery needs; and (5) systematized protocols for active communication among medical, school, and family team members. It is emphasized that research is required to guide effective program implementation. CONCLUSION: This guiding framework aims to support the development of support structures for recovering students with mTBI to optimize academic outcomes. Until more evidence is available on academic housing and other school-based support, education systems should follow current best practice guidance.

title: Building Trust: The History and Ongoing Relationships Between DSD Clinicians, Researchers, and Patient Advocacy Groups
abstract: Individuals born with sex development differences or disorders (DSD) have been marginalized from society and the healthcare system. The standards of care in the mid-20th century were based on fixing the child with DSD through hormonal and surgical intervention; these treatments and diagnoses were almost never disclosed to the child, and sometimes they were not disclosed to the parents. This led to secrecy, shame and stigma. As these children grew up and demanded access to their medical records, realizing the depth of the secrecy led to the formation of activist groups that rocked the medical community. Despite shaky beginnings, advocates, health professionals, and researchers have been able to bring about changes in the standard of care. The 2006 Consensus Statement on Managing Intersex Disorder called for a multidisciplinary treatment approach and challenged the evidence for many of the standard practices, a cover-up model to a patient-centered paradigm, and funding agencies put Resources to determine the future avenues of research on DSD The need to address patient priorities has led to changing international standards for patient involvement in research design. Remaining challenges include: the Institute of Medicine's findings that sexual and gender minorities have poor health outcomes; Building trust between all parties;" developing a common language and creating spaces for individuals to engage in dialogue that addresses personal experiences, research design, clinical practices, and intervention strategies.

title: birth by cesarean section. Summary of an NIH consensus statement
Can a court order participation in the research?
Can a work-related activity program in rural communities make a difference for chronic pain disabled injured workers?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of a clinical-guideline-based multidisciplinary work-related activity program and improve the physical, psychological, and occupational functioning of injured workers disabled by chronic pain. DESIGN: An uncontrolled, repeated-measures pilot study was conducted. SETTING: The intervention was conducted in a community setting in regional New South Wales. PARTICIPANTS: Participants (n=30), mean age 41 years, had a compensable musculoskeletal injury: 60% were male, 63% had back injuries; the average inability to work was 13 months. INTERVENTION: A cognitive-behavioral, interdisciplinary intervention was delivered using a multi-contributor-provider model (a clinical psychologist and a physical therapist from separate practices working in liaison with the participant's occupational rehabilitation provider and the treating physician. ) Groups of six participants participated half a day per week for six weeks. OUTCOME MEASURES: Outcome measures included: physical functioning, pain intensity, and psychological variables assessed before and after the program;” and medical certificate and work attendance, assessed before the program and recorded after six months. RESULTS: Significant advances were made in pain intensity, physical and psychological functioning, and medical certification. The mean effect size of the intervention was medium to large (d = 0.70). At the six-month follow-up, there was no significant change in employment status. CONCLUSIONS: The results of this pilot study suggest that independent rural and community-based practitioners working together using an integrated treatment program can achieve positive outcomes for injured workers with pain disability and outcomes similar to those experienced by metropolitan pain sufferers clinics are reported.

title: Can computer-generated evidence-based treatment proposals improve evidence-based management of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease? A randomized controlled trial.
abstract: objective. The translation of evidence-based guidelines into clinical practice has been inconsistent. We conducted a randomized controlled trial of guideline-based treatment suggestions submitted to physicians as they wrote prescriptions at computer workstations. study setting. Inner-city academic practice for general internal medicine. study design. Randomized controlled trial with 246 physicians (25 percent faculty general practitioners, 75 percent internal medicine residents) and 20 ambulatory pharmacists. We enrolled 706 of their primary care patients with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. When writing prescriptions or filling out prescriptions at computer workstations, half of the physicians and pharmacists selected at random were given supply suggestions for drugs and monitoring. A 2×2 factorial randomization of practice sessions and pharmacists resulted in four patient groups: physician intervention, pharmacist intervention, both interventions, and controls. Data Extraction/Collection Methods. Adherence to guidelines and clinical activity were assessed using patients' electronic medical records. Health-related quality of life, medication adherence, and satisfaction with care were recorded using telephone questionnaires. main results. During their year in the study, patients made an average of five scheduled primary care visits. There were no differences between groups in adherence to care recommendations, overall or condition-specific quality of life, satisfaction with physicians or pharmacists, medication adherence, emergency department visits, or hospital stays. Physicians who received the intervention had significantly higher overall healthcare costs. Physicians' attitudes towards the guidelines were mixed. Conclusions. Treatment recommendations shown to physicians and pharmacists at computer workstations did not impact the delivery or outcomes of treatment for patients with reactive airway disease.

title: Can handheld computers improve compliance? A (Palm) pilot study of primary care physicians in British Columbia
abstract: OBJECTIVE To study whether Palm Prevention, a free software tool for Palm OS Personal Digital Assistants (PDAs) that provides quick access to patient-specific prevention guidelines at the point of care, improves adherence to five preventive interventions in primary care. DESIGN Prospective intervention pilot study. SETTING Vancouver, BC, and Vicinity. PARTICIPANTS Eight general practitioners. INTERVENTIONS Each physician used Palm Prevention for five preventive interventions during routine check-ups in 10 patients (n=80). Charts from consenting patients were reviewed to document the recommended maneuvers. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Adherence rates to five evidence-based guidelines selected by the Canadian and US Prevention Task Forces and incorporated into Palm Prevention. RESULTS Intervention and control physicians were similar in their familiarity with and use of epidurals and recruited similar patients for the study. Intervention and control groups had similar screening rates for hypertension. The intervention improved adherence to the remaining four guidelines: cervical cancer screening increased by 22% (only absolute increases are reported), hyperlipidemia screening increased by 30%, colorectal cancer screening increased by 27%, and acetylsalicylic acid prophylaxis in high-risk patients by 38% % increased Participants were interviewed after the study;" all indicated that they found the software helpful and would continue to use Palm Prevention. Usage statistics showed that study participants used the tool outside of the study: During the two-month intervention, users took between 28 and 68 individual patients enrolled in the program CONCLUSION This pilot study suggests that PDAs are useful in improving prevention and facilitating the transfer of knowledge into practice, particularly with recent guidelines.

title: Can lineage clinicians master the conceptual complexities of dialectical behavior therapy? An evaluation of a State Department of Mental Health training program
abstract: Dialectical-behavioral therapy for borderline personality disorder has quickly gained widespread popularity, with an indication of the development of educational initiatives by the Department of Mental Health in at least two states in the United States. Efficacy data published by the treatment's originator, Marsha Linehan, and her colleagues likely explain, at least in part, this popularity. However, the complexity of DBT raises a fundamental question related to these broader applications: Can clinicians from different backgrounds achieve a common and differentiated understanding of treatment theory? Clinical usefulness of treatment relies heavily on ease of dissemination (APA, Template for developing guidelines: Interventions in mental disorders and psychosocial aspects of physical disorders. Washington, DC: Author, 1995) and in this regard DBT - a complicated, multi-faceted approach - might appear vulnerable. This vulnerability is compounded when institutional adoption involves the collaboration of numerous clinicians who, despite different roles, still need to develop a common understanding of treatment. Through a detailed survey of DBT knowledge, we assessed the conceptual proficiency of 109 clinicians trained through an initiative of the State Department of Mental Health. Exam performance correlated specifically with DBT training. Prior training or background in behavioral therapy accounted for little variation, suggesting that clinicians filling different roles gained adequate intellectual mastery of this complex model.

title: "Can patient practice be increased simply by implementing agreed national guidelines?" An observational study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To increase the autonomous exercise time of patients in the stroke unit of a nursing home. INTERVENTION: Nurses stimulated and exercised patients using four interventions (muscle strengthening, sitting balance and reach, rising from a chair, walking) from the evidence-based guidelines for clinical nursing rehabilitation after stroke. DESIGN: An observational study. The exercise time of elderly stroke patients in this study was compared to the time observed in our previous study in the same setting. SETTING: Rehabilitation units of a nursing home in the Netherlands. PROJECTS: Seventeen frail stroke patients, including 8 males, 9 females, with a mean age of 75.8 (SD +/- 9) and 17 subjects with the same characteristics, who participated in a previous observational study. MAIN MEASURES: The time spent on therapeutic activities was measured using the behavioral mapping method. RESULTS: The time spent in therapeutic activities increased significantly from 103.5 minutes measured in our previous study to 156.5 minutes in this study (Z = 2.86"; P < 0.005;" d' = 1.09). The mean Barthel Index score was 8.8 (SD +/- 4.1). The patients with more options were more active, resulting in a significantly positive Barthel Index-therapy time relationship (r=0.73, P</=0.001). Conclusions: Autonomous exercise time in elderly fragile comorbid stroke patients increased during weekdays. Patients who are stimulated and challenged by caregivers train harder and more within their capabilities. Because this guide is specifically designed for caregivers, caregivers can encourage stroke survivors to be more involved in autonomous practice, thereby contributing to their recovery.

title: Can psychological models bridge the gap between clinical guidelines and clinician behavior? A randomized controlled trial of an intervention to influence dentist intention to adopt evidence-based practice
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The delay between publication of clinical practice evidence and implementation by clinicians can be decades. Research using psychological models shows that changing intention is very important for behavior change. This study evaluated an intervention (trying alternative measures) to change dentists' intent to implement evidence-based practices (EBP) for third molar (TM) management. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial/postal. SETTING: Basic care. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: Dentists were randomly selected from the Scottish Dental Practice Board register, then randomly assigned to intervention or control groups and sent a questionnaire. The intervention group listed management alternatives to TM extraction prior to their TM extraction intention, the control group did not. Based on psychological models for reducing the frequency of a behavior (EBP is weighted against TM extraction), prior listing of alternatives should reduce extraction intent. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Intent to extract TMs. RESULTS: A total of 99 dentists - 70 men, 29 women”; Mean age = 41.42 years (SD = 8.62) participated in the study. The intervention significantly influenced intention to extract TMs as desired. Despite similar backgrounds and knowledge of treatment alternatives, participants in the intervention group had significantly lower extraction intent: control group mean (SD) = 0.39 (1.99); Intervention group mean (SD) = -0.78 (1.89); mean difference (SE) = 1.17 (0.42);" 95% confidence interval for the difference = 0.34 to 1.99. CONCLUSION: The results suggest that this intervention, which was successful, is a proximal predictor of Behavior related to dental EBP may lead to improved EBP in a service-level study Basing implementation interventions and study methodology on psychological models can effectively bridge the gap between clinical guidelines and practice.

title: Can we address depression in visual rehabilitation facilities? Professionals' perspectives on the barriers to the integration of problem-solving treatments
abstract: PURPOSE: Given the high prevalence of untreated depression in adults with visual impairment, low-vision rehabilitation (LVR) is a relevant context for the integration of early, evidence-based psychological interventions. This study aims to identify the perceived barriers and intermediaries to staff-delivered primary care telephone troubleshooting (PST-PC), offered as an integrated component of LVR. METHODS: Qualitative semi-structured interviews, developed using the Theoretical Domain Framework (TDF) and the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research (CFIR), were conducted with 21 LVR experts and one clinical psychologist involved in the delivery of PST-PC. Barriers and intermediaries at the practitioner, client, intervention and organization levels were identified with thematic analysis using a 'theoretical' approach. RESULTS: Prominent barriers were a lack of role recognition for PST-PC practitioners (n=32), unmet customer expectations with PST-PC (n=28), dissatisfaction with phone delivery (n=27), and limited organizational awareness of PST- pc (n=39). Supporting factors included a recognized need for evidence-based psychological services (n=28), clients experiencing benefits in early sessions (n=38), PST-PC promoting practical skills (n=26), and comprehensive PST- PC training (n = 26). = 36). CONCLUSIONS: PST-PC may provide an accessible early intervention for LVR clients with depressive symptoms. Ongoing physician education, clinical support, and treatment eligibility screening of potential LVR clients are likely to improve delivery in this environment. Implications for rehabilitation Depression is common among adults participating in low-vision rehabilitation (LVR) programs, but few receive support. Clinical guidelines recommend offering integrated care models within rehabilitation facilities as early intervention for mild to moderate depressive symptoms. Integrated primary care telephone problem-solving treatment (PST-PC), delivered by trained LVR practitioners, is a practical, competency-based model that has the potential to improve access to early psychological intervention in LVR clients with depressive symptoms . LVR clients are often elderly, have multiple comorbid health conditions, and significant levels of functional disability, requiring flexibility in providing PST-PC and specialist staff training, as well as support in working with older and more complex clients.

title: Can we improve adherence to guidelines for treating lower urinary tract infections? A simple, versatile intervention in emergency services
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To improve antibiotic prescribing behavior of primary care physicians in large-scale on-call services for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections (LUTI) in women aged 20-80 years, considered to be one of the most common bacterial infections in primary care. METHODS: A quasi-experimental design was used in two regional large after-hours services. In one region (the intervention region) a simple, varied intervention was offered over a period of 16 weeks. During the two washout periods, at 5 and 17 months, we observed diagnoses and prescriptions. The main outcome measure was the proportion of appropriate and inappropriate prescriptions. RESULTS: The proportion of patients with LUTI ranged from 1.0% to 2.1%. The relative proportion of appropriate prescriptions in the intervention region rose from 26.9% to 69.4%, but then fell to 40.8%. CONCLUSIONS: A simple, multifaceted intervention to manage LUTI during out-of-hours care can improve the quality of antimicrobial prescribing, although the improvement may not last in the longer term.

title: Canadian Contraceptive Consensus (Part 1 of 4)
abstract: AIM: To provide guidance to healthcare providers on the use of birth control methods to prevent pregnancy and promote healthy sexuality. RESULTS: Guidance for Canadian practitioners on overall efficacy, mechanism of action, indications, contraindications, non-contraceptive benefits, side effects, and risks, and initiation of cited contraceptive methods"; family planning in the context of sexual health and general well-being; contraceptive counseling methods, and access to and availability of cited Contraceptive practices in Canada EVIDENCE: Published literature was retrieved by searching Medline and the Cochrane database from January 1994 to January 2015 using appropriately controlled vocabulary (e.g., contraception, sexuality, sexual health) and keywords (e.g., Contraception, family planning, hormonal contraception, emergency contraception) Results were limited to systematic reviews, randomized controlled trials/controlled clinical trials, and observational studies conducted from January 1994 to Yes published in English in 2015 were regularly updated and incorporated into the guideline by June 2015. G Rey (unpublished) literature was identified by searching the websites of health technology assessment and health technology-related agencies, collections of clinical practice guidelines, clinical trial registries, and national and international medical societies. VALUES: The quality of the evidence in this document was assessed using the criteria described in the Canadian Task Force on Preventive Health Care report (table). Chapter 1: Contraception in Canada Executive Summary 1. Canadian women spend a significant portion of their lives at risk of unwanted pregnancy. (II-2) 2. Effective contraceptive methods are underused in Canada, particularly among vulnerable populations. (II-2) 3. Long-acting reversible contraceptive methods, including contraceptive implants and intrauterine contraception (copper-releasing and levonorgestrel-releasing devices/systems), are the most effective reversible contraceptive methods and have the highest continuation rates. (II-1) 4. Canada does not currently collect reliable data to determine contraceptive use, abortion rates and the prevalence of unwanted pregnancies among women of childbearing potential. (II-2) 5. A universal subsidy for contraceptive methods, as provided by many Canadian peer nations and some Canadian provinces, can lead to cost savings in the healthcare system. (II-2) 6. Health Canada's contraceptive approval processes were less efficient than those of other drug regulatory agencies and Health Canada's processes for other drug classes. (II-2) 7. It is feasible and safe for contraceptive and family planning services to be provided by appropriately trained allied health professionals such as midwives, registered nurses, registered nurses and pharmacists. (II-2) Recommendations 1. Contraceptive counseling should include a discussion of typical failure rates in use and the importance of consistent and correct use of the contraceptive method to avoid pregnancy. (II-2A) 2. Women who desire contraception should be counseled about the wide range of effective contraceptive methods, including long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARCs). LARCs are the most effective methods of reversible contraception, have high continuity rates, and should be considered when offering contraceptive options to women of childbearing potential. (II-2A) 3. Family planning counseling should include counseling on the decline in fertility associated with increasing female age. (III-A) 4. Health policies that support a universal contraceptive subsidy and strategies to encourage the adoption of high-impact methods as cost-saving measures that improve health and health equity should be considered by Canadian health decision-makers. (III-B) 5. Canadian health authorities should consider expanding the scope of other trained professionals, such as nurses, midwives and pharmacists, and promoting shared family planning responsibilities. (II-2B) 6. The Canadian Community Health Survey should include appropriate reproductive health indicators to enable health care providers and policy makers to make appropriate decisions regarding reproductive health policies and services in Canada. (III-B) 7. Health Canada's processes and policies should be reviewed to ensure that a wide range of modern contraceptive methods are available to Canadian women. (III-B) Chapter 2: Contraception and Access Summary Statements 8. Although contraceptive options are plentiful in Canada, only a small variety of contraceptive methods are used by those of childbearing age. (II-3) 9. Condom use decreases with longer relationship durations and when the sexual partner is viewed as the primary partner, probably due to a lower perceived risk of sexually transmitted infection in that relationship. Condom use can also decrease significantly as an unintended consequence of initiating an effective non-barrier method such as hormonal or intrauterine contraception. (II-3) 10. Family planning counseling provides a natural transition to screening for concerns about sexual functioning or intimate partner violence. (III) 11. Well-informed and motivated individuals who have developed skills to practice safer sex behaviors are more likely to use birth control methods and safer sex practices effectively and consistently. (II-2) Recommendations 8. Comprehensive family planning services, including abortion services, should be accessible to all Canadians regardless of geographic location. These services should be confidential, non-judgmental, and respect individual privacy and cultural context. (III-A) 9. A contraceptive visit should include history taking, screening for contraindications, dispensing or prescription of a contraceptive method, and investigation of contraceptive choice and adherence in the broader context of the person's sexual behavior, risk to reproductive health, social circumstances, and relevant belief systems. (III-B) 10. Healthcare providers should provide practical information about the wide range of contraceptive options and their potential non-contraceptive benefits, and help women and their partners determine the most appropriate method of use. (III-B) 11. Health care providers should help women and men to develop the skills necessary to negotiate contraceptive use and the correct and consistent use of a chosen method. (III-B) 12. Preventive measures should include discussion and management of the risk of sexually transmitted infection, including appropriate recommendations for condom use and double protection, STI screening, post-exposure prophylaxis, and vaccination for hepatitis B and human papillomavirus. (III-B) 13. Healthcare providers should emphasize the use of condoms not only for protection against sexually transmitted infections, but also as a backup method when compliance with a hormonal contraceptive might be suboptimal. (IA) 14. Health care providers should be aware of current media controversies in the field of reproductive health and seek relevant evidence-based information that can be shared briefly and directly with their patients. (III-B) 15. Referral resources for intimate partner violence, sexually transmitted infections, sexual dysfunction, abortion, and child protection services should be available to assist physicians in providing preventive care in the broader context of women's health. (III-B) Chapter 3: Emergency Contraception Summary 12. The copper intrauterine device is the most effective method of emergency contraception. (II-2) 13. A copper intrauterine device may be used for emergency contraception up to 7 days after unprotected intercourse, provided pregnancy has been ruled out and there are no other contraindications to its insertion. (II-2) 14. Levonorgestrel emergency contraception is effective up to 5 days (120 hours) after intercourse; its effectiveness decreases with increasing time between unprotected sex and ingestion. (II-2) 15. Ulipristal acetate for emergency contraception is more effective than levonorgestrel emergency contraception up to 5 days after unprotected intercourse This difference in effectiveness is more pronounced with increasing time to unprotected intercourse, especially after 72 hours (I) 16. Hormonal emergency contraception (levonorgestrel emergency contraception and ulipristal acetate for Emergency contraception) is not effective if taken on the day of ovulation or after ovulation (II-2) 17. Levonorgestrel emergency contraception may be less effective in women with a body mass index > 25 kg/m2 and ulipristal acetate for emergency contraception may be less effective in women with a body mass index > 35 kg/m2, however, emergency hormonal contraception may still have some effectiveness regardless of a woman's body weight or body mass index. (II-2) 18. Emergency hormonal contraception is associated with higher failure rates when women continue to have unprotected sex. (II-2) 19. Hormonal contraception may be started on the day or the day after levonorgestrel rescue contraception is used, with supplemental contraception being used for the first 7 days. (III) 20. Hormonal contraception can be started 5 days after use of ulipristal acetate for emergency contraception, using supplemental contraception for the first 14 days. (III) Recommendations 16. All emergency contraception should be started as soon as possible after unprotected intercourse. (II-2A) 17. Women should be informed that the copper intrauterine device (IUD) is the most effective method of emergency contraception and can be used by any woman with no contraindications to the use of the IUD. (II-3A) 18.

title: Canadian guidelines for the evidence-based treatment of tic disorders: behavioral therapy, deep brain stimulation, and transcranial magnetic stimulation
abstract: This clinical guideline provides recommendations for non-pharmacological treatments of tic disorders. We performed a systematic literature search for clinical trials on the treatment of tics. One evidence-based review (including 30 studies) and 3 behavioral intervention studies, 3 deep brain stimulation (DBS) studies, and 3 transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) studies met our inclusion criteria. Based on this evidence, we have made strong recommendations for the use of habit reversal therapy and exposure and response prevention, preferably embedded in a supportive, psychoeducational program and with the option to combine either of these approaches with pharmacotherapy. Although there is evidence for the effectiveness of DBS, the quality of this evidence is poor and the risks and burdens of the procedure are delicately balanced with the perceived benefits. Our recommendation is that this intervention continues to be viewed as an experimental treatment for severe, medically refractory tics that have severely reduced quality of life. We recommend that the procedure should only be performed within the context of research studies and by physicians who are experts in DBS programming and tic management. There is no evidence to support the use of TMS in the treatment of tics. However, the procedure has a low rate of known complications and could continue to be evaluated as part of research protocols. The recommendations we give are based on the current state of knowledge and further study may lead to a revision in the future.

title: Canadian Survey of Clinical Status at Dialysis Initiation 1998-1999: a multicenter prospective survey
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Recent growth in end-stage renal disease populations has prompted increased efforts to understand the impact of dialysis-initiating status on long-term outcomes. Our main goal was to increase the understanding of current Canadian nephrology practice between October 1998 and December 1999. METHODS: Fifteen renal centers in 7 provinces participated in a prospective data collection study. The main outcome of interest was the clinical status at the start of dialysis, determined by: residual renal function, willingness to undergo chronic dialysis as measured by the presence or absence of a permanent peritoneal or hemodialysis line, hemoglobin and serum albumin. Uremic symptoms at dialysis initiation were also recorded, but in some cases these symptom data were collected retrospectively. RESULTS: Data were collected from 251 patients during 1-month periods. Patients started dialysis at mean calculated creatinine clearance values of approximately 10 mL/min with an average of 3 symptoms. 35% of dialysis patients had been known to nephrologists for less than 3 months. These patients are more likely to start without permanent access and with lower hemoglobin and albumin levels. Even of those known to nephrologists, only 66% had permanent access. CONCLUSIONS: Patients starting dialysis in Canada appear to do so in relative agreement with published guidelines regarding when to start. Despite increased awareness of kidney disease, a significant number of patients continue to begin dialysis without prior nephrologist care. Those seen by nephrologists have suboptimal clinical and laboratory parameters according to current guidelines. This survey serves as an important basis for future comparisons after implementation of training strategies for referring physicians and nephrologists.

title: Cancer among adolescents in France between 1988 and 1997
abstract: We report a cancer pathway in adolescents from referral to diagnosis and treatment to follow-up in France. All cancer cases between 15 and 19 years old, diagnosed between 1988 and 1997 and recorded by nine French population cancer registries (10% of the French population) were included. Treatment of adolescent cancer by pediatricians was rare. An adolescent's journey through cancer care can be summarized as follows: initial visit to the primary care physician, referral to an adult oncologist for hematologic malignancies and medical or surgical specialists for solid tumors, treatment in the adult unit, and follow-up by an adult oncologist, an adult medical practitioner or surgeon specialist or general practitioner. Only 9% of 15-19 year olds participate in a clinical trial (6% and 3% in adult and pediatric clinical trials, respectively). Inclusion rate varies by diagnosis, higher in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (39%), non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) (27%), and acute non-lymphoblastic leukemia (20%). Only 4% of adolescent cancers were treated in shared adult and pediatric wards, particularly soft tissue sarcoma (14.9%), malignant bone tumors (13.4%), central nervous system tumors (6.2%) and NHL (4th .4%). Whatever the reasons for non-participation in clinical trials, an ideal model that requires communication and collaboration between all adult and pediatric specialists involved in adolescent cancer care should reduce the large gap in access to collaborative groups.

title: Cancer awareness among primary care physicians in an underserved community
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Urban minority groups, such as those living in north Manhattan, are generally underserved when it comes to cancer prevention and screening. GPs are in a crucial position when it comes to advising their patients on these issues and ordering screening tests for their patients. METHODS: Eighty-four primary care physicians in two intervention communities who received educational visits about cancer screening and prevention were compared with 38 physicians in a nearby community who received no intervention. In pre- and post-test interviews over an 18-month period, physicians were asked about their attitude, knowledge (relative to American Cancer Society guidelines), and likelihood of breast, cervical, colon, and cervical counseling and screening prostate asked cancer. RESULTS: The comparison of the two physician surveys revealed no statistically significant differences in knowledge about cancer prevention or screening. However, at post-test, physicians in the intervention group identified significantly fewer barriers to practice than physicians in the control group (p<0.05). While the educational visits to inner-city GPs did not appear to significantly alter overall cancer prevention practices, a positive dose-response relationship was demonstrated in the subset of participants who received three or more project contacts. CONCLUSIONS: We discovered significant changes in attitudes based on academic detailing among city primary care physicians practicing in north Manhattan. A significant pre-test sensitization effect and low numbers may have obscured overall changes in cancer prevention and physician screening behaviors due to the intervention.

title: Cancer-related and treatment-related fatigue
abstract: Fatigue is a distressing and persistent symptom for patients with gynecologic cancer and survivors. Debilitating cancer-related fatigue (CRF) is caused by both the disease and its treatment. Although awareness and investigation of CKD has increased in recent years, consistent assessment has not been a priority in routine medical practice. The pathophysiological mechanisms that induce CKD remain unclear, and effective pharmacological interventions have yet to be established. Based on the literature and our own research, this review focuses on recent advances in understanding the nature and causes of CKD and on several promising treatment modalities. Given the prevalence and severity of CKD in the gynecologic cancer patient population, the establishment of standardized fatigue measurement and management methods in routine clinical oncology care is of paramount importance. However, whether CKD has an underlying inflammatory cause is still hypothetical, and no mechanism-driven symptom intervention is currently used clinically, although the development of such interventions would offer patients better symptom control. To advance translational and clinical fatigue research, anatomical pathway studies and well-designed clinical investigations are required, focusing on the development of mechanism-driven interventions based on physiological-behavioural fatigue research, the implementation of guidelines for experimental designs, and the discovery of biomarkers for Identifying individuals at high stress risk for CKD. Validated patient-reported outcome measurements are an essential part of such clinical trials. Because there are numerous subscales, one-dimensional measures, and multidimensional measures, clinicians and researchers should consider individual circumstances, good clinical practice, and research goals as a guide to selecting the most appropriate fatigue measurement instrument. In addition, education about CKD should be made available to all patients and their caregivers, as accurate and age-appropriate information about conditions such as CKD can alleviate much of the stress and anxiety that arises from poor communication about this debilitating condition.

title: Interactions with cardiac drugs and psychotropic drugs: importance and recommendations
abstract: Understanding the cardiac drug interactions associated with the concomitant prescription of psychotropic drugs is critical for the practicing cardiologist and general practitioner, as well as for the psychiatrist. In both psychiatry and cardiology, there has been an explosion in the use of new drugs without widespread knowledge of their potential interactions. The increasing trend towards polypharmacy, the use of psychotropic drugs by cardiologists and general practitioners caring for cardiac patients, and the increasing aging of the population pose major challenges for practitioners. Finally, there is a need for models/paradigms to predict possible drug interactions - e.g. B. the cytochrome p450 scheme. This paper describes a method for identifying, understanding, and codifying the interactions between psychotropic drugs and cardiac drugs, a systematic approach to updating this key database, and specific interactions between cardiac psychotropic drugs. In particular, this document 1) describes the interactions, 2) addresses the level of their clinical significance, 3) describes the potential mechanisms of the interactions, and 4) provides recommendations for the clinician. Because the majority of original clinical trials, whether for cardiac drugs or psychotropic drugs, do not include studies comparing these two drug domains simultaneously, their interactions are often not known until their combined use in the clinical setting, using the patient as a "guinea pig" , " and through subsequent reporting.

title: Cardiac rehabilitation and risk factor management after myocardial infarction. Clinical and economic evaluation
abstract: The increasing scarcity of available and limited health care resources and the increased demands on health care have made considering the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of health services, such as B. the secondary prevention of heart disease, a necessity. There is considerable evidence that changing cigarette smoking habits, hyperlipidemia, hypertension and physical inactivity, either individually or in combination, are effective in reducing the number of clinical events in secondary prevention of heart disease. Economic evaluation is the comparative analysis of alternative courses of action with regard to costs and consequences. Data generated during economic assessments of health services, such as B. the modification of risk factors in the secondary prevention of heart disease, are useful in the development of clinical practice guidelines and public health policies. Smoking cessation is the most cost-effective intervention for patients with established cardiac disease, while treatment for hyperlipidemia and referral for cardiac rehabilitation are very cost-effective per quality-adjusted life-year and relatively cost-effective per life-year saved. Management of risk factors, performed by a team of cardiovascular specialists and other physicians together with appropriately trained healthcare professionals, is the cornerstone of optimal care in both the primary and secondary prevention of heart disease.

title: Cardiac Rehabilitation: Unraveling the Complexities of Referrals and Current Delivery Models
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence-based guidelines recommend strategies to reduce risk factors for secondary prevention of acute coronary syndromes, but referral to and completion of programs to provide this advice are inadequate. PURPOSE: In this article, we describe the complexity of the factors affecting the referral and delivery of evidence-based cardiac rehabilitation (CR) programs in an Australian context and provide guidance for solutions for clinicians and policy makers to consider. The ecological approach is used as a framework for synthesizing evidence. The approach includes 5 categories whose characteristics can act as barriers and enablers to the promotion and adoption of health behaviors, and includes (a) interpersonal factors, (b) interpersonal factors, (c) institutional factors, (d) community networks, and (e ) public order. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the context of strong evidence for efficacy, this review highlights systematic shortcomings in the implementation of CR, an important intervention that has been shown to improve patient outcomes and prevent cardiac events. Recommendations from this review include standardizing program delivery, improving data collection, leveraging technological innovation and social networking to facilitate the delivery of information and support, and establishing a coherent, consistent message through cross-organizational collaboration in CR. CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS: These pathways indicate potential solutions to improve CR uptake and secondary prevention.

title: Care in Specialized Medical and Mental Health Units Compared with Standard Care for Elderly People with Cognitive Impairment Admitted to a General Hospital: Randomized Controlled Trial (NIHR TEAM Trial)
abstract: GOAL Development and evaluation of a best-practice model for general medical acute care of older people with cognitive impairment. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial adjusted to account for the limitations imposed by a busy medical admissions system. RECRUITMENT Large general acute hospital in the UK. PARTICIPANTS 600 patients over the age of 65 admitted for acute medical care who were identified as “confused” on admission. INTERVENTIONS Participants were randomized to a specialist medical and mental health unit designed to provide best practice care for people with delirium or dementia, or to standard care (acute geriatric or general medicine units). Characteristics of the department included a "joint staffing of medical and mental health workers", improved staff training in delirium, dementia and person-centered dementia care, provision of organized, goal-oriented activities, changing the environment to meet the needs of people with cognitive impairments , delirium prevention, and a proactive and inclusive approach to caregivers.RESULTS There was no significant difference in days spent at home between the specialty and standard care groups (median 51 vs. 45 days, 95% confidence interval for the difference -12 to 24; P=0.3).The median index hospital stay was 11 versus 11 days, mortality 22% versus 25% (-9% to 4%), readmission 32% versus 35% (-10% to 5%) and new admissions to the nursing home 20% compared to 28% (-16% to 0) for the specialist department or the state ard care group. Patients who returned home spent a median of 70.5 versus 71.0 days at home (-6.0 to 6.5). Patients in the specialty department spent significantly more time with positive mood or engagement (79% vs. 68%, 2% to 20%; P=0.03) and experienced more interactions with staff that met emotional and psychological needs (median 4 vs. 1 per observation; P<0.001). More caregivers were satisfied with care (overall 91% vs. 83%, 2% to 15%; P=0.004) and strong dissatisfaction was lower (5% vs. 10%, -10% to 0%; P= 0.05). CONCLUSIONS: Specialist care for people with delirium and dementia improved patient experience and caregiver satisfaction, but there were no convincing benefits related to health status or service utilization. Patient experience and caregiver satisfaction may be more appropriate measures of success for frail elderly people approaching the end of life STUDY REGISTRATION Clinical Studies NCT01136148.

title: Caring for Adults with Developmental Disabilities: Effects of a Continuing Education Course for Primary Caregivers
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Evaluation of the effects of interdisciplinary, guideline-based further education on measures for the care of adults with developmental disabilities (DD). DESIGN: Before-after study with a control group. SETTING: Ontario. PARTICIPANTS: Forty-seven primary care providers (physicians, registered nurses and registered nurses). INTERVENTION: Participants either received only reference material on primary care for people with DD (control group) or participated in a continuing education course on primary care for people with DD (intervention group) in addition to the reference material. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: Participants reported 5 key measures related to the care of adults with DD: frequency of use of guidelines, frequency of completion of regular health assessments, frequency of assessment of patients presenting with behavior changes, level of comfort in caring for adults with DD, and primary care knowledge of adults with DD. RESULTS: Over time, the intervention group showed significant increases in 4 of the 5 key measures of care compared to the control group: frequency of guideline application (P<0.001), frequency of rating patients' behavior change (P=0.001). 03), level of comfort in caring for people with DD (P=0.01), and knowledge of primary care in relation to adults with DD (P=0.01). CONCLUSION: A continuing education course in primary care for adults with DD is a useful interdisciplinary model for training health professionals who provide primary care services to these patients.

title: Caring for the menopausal patient: a nurse's perspective
abstract: PURPOSE: To evaluate the benefits and risks of hormone therapy (HT) and other treatment options for early postmenopausal women. DATA SOURCES: Published clinical studies, selected peer-reviewed literature, and current clinical practice guidelines. CONCLUSIONS: The results of the Women's Health Initiative (WHI) studies on HT may not be directly applicable to healthy, early postmenopausal women who experience hot flashes. HT is the most effective treatment for menopausal symptoms. The benefits of HT in relieving menopausal symptoms likely outweigh the risks in this population. PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: GHI results underscore the importance of individualized care based on a woman's medical history, medical needs, and desired outcomes. Nurses can help their patients put recent results into perspective. If HT is used, caregivers should consider using lower doses and reassess the need for therapy annually.

title: Monitoring of CD4 cell count and viral load in patients undergoing antiretroviral therapy in Uganda: cost-effectiveness study
abstract: AIM To investigate the cost and cost-effectiveness of quarterly monitoring of CD4 cell count and viral load in patients receiving antiretroviral therapy (ART). DESIGN profitability study. SETTING A randomized trial in a home ART program in Tororo, Uganda. PARTICIPANTS People living with HIV who were members of the AIDS Support Organization and had a CD4 cell count < 250 × 10(6) cells/L or World Health Organization stage 3 or 4 disease. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Outcomes calculated for the study period and projected 15 years into the future included costs, disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs), and incremental cost-effectiveness ratios (ICERs); $ per DALY averted). Cost inputs were based on the study and other sources Clinical inputs from the study In the base case, we assumed that point estimates reflect true differences even if they are not significant We performed univariate and multivariate sensitivity analyzes INTERVENTIONS Three surveillance strategies: clinical surveillance with quarterly CD4 cell counts and measurement of viral load (clinical/CD4/viral load); clinical surveillance and quarterly CD4 counts (clinical/CD4);" and clinical surveillance alone. RESULTS Using intention to treat (ITT) results per 100 people starting ART, we found that clinical/CD4 surveillance and 117.3 DALYs prevented (ICER = $174 per DALY) compared to clinical monitoring alone. Monitoring adds $142,458 and eliminates 27.5 DALYs ($5,181 per DALY) The superior ICER for clinical/CD4 monitoring is robust to input value uncertainty, and this strategy compares favorably to clinical/CD4/viral load monitoring dominant (less expensive and more effective) in a quarter of the simulations If the clinical inputs are based on the as-treated analysis from 90 days (after the start of laboratory monitoring), then the clinical/CD4/viral load exercise Surveillance dominated by other strategies.
