CONCLUSIONS Based on this study, routine CD4 cell count monitoring is significantly less expensive than adding routine viral load testing to the monitoring strategy and less expensive than ART compared to clinical surveillance alone.

title: Cervical cancer screening in adolescents: an evidence-based internet educational program to improve practice among advanced nurses
abstract: BACKGROUND: The literature reports large differences in the level of knowledge and application of recent changes in guidelines for cervical cancer screening in clinical practice. Evidence-based screening guidelines for cervical cancer prevention and screening offer healthcare providers an opportunity to improve practice patterns among adolescent girls by reducing psychological distress, healthcare costs, and morbidity associated with over-screening. PURPOSE: The purpose of this pilot interventional study was to determine the impact of a web-based continuing education program (CEU) on the knowledge of advanced nurse practitioners (APNs) of current evidence-based recommendations for cervical cancer screening and their application in practice. This paper presents a process improvement project as an example of a way to disseminate updated evidence-based practice guidelines among busy healthcare providers. METHODS: This web-based CEU program was designed, tested and evaluated specifically for APNs. The program addressed their level of knowledge about cervical cancer and its relationship to the high-risk human papillomavirus. It also looked at the new guidelines for the early detection of cervical cancer and the application of these guidelines in clinical practice. RESULTS: The results of the study indicate that there are gaps in knowledge about early detection of cervical cancer in adolescents in APNs. However, when provided with CEU education, APNs' level of knowledge increased and their self-reported behavior in clinical practice changed, in line with the new guidelines for cervical cancer screening. LINKING EVIDENCE TO PRACTICE: The provision of convenient and easily accessible up-to-date electronic content that CEU provides promotes the adoption of clinical practice guidelines, thereby reducing the potential of morbidities associated with over-screening for cervical cancer in adolescents and young women are connected.

title: Challenges and opportunities associated with the deployment of next-generation durable insecticide nets for malaria control: a case study from Burkina Faso
abstract: Background The decline in malaria incidence in Africa can be largely attributed to the increase in malaria vector control activities, primarily the use of long-lived insecticide nets (LLINs). conventional LLINs, there is an increasing urgency to implement alternative tools that control these resistant populations. The aim of this study was to identify potential challenges and opportunities for faster access to next-generation LLINs in Burkina Faso, a country with areas of high concentrations of, to identify insecticide resistance Methods An analytical framework was used to guide interviewee selection, data collection and analysis Semi-structured interviews were conducted with key informants in April 2014 in Burkina Faso Interviews were conducted in French and English, audio recorded and transcribed and entered into NVivo 10 for data management and analysis. They are coded according to the framework themes and then analyzed to provide a description of key points and to explain patterns in the data. Findings Respondents reported that the political architecture in Burkina Faso is characterized by a strong framework of actors contributing to policy-making and strong national research capacities contributing indirectly to national policy changes through collaboration with internationally-led research. Funding has a significant impact on the potential adoption, availability and affordability of next-generation LLINs. This gives significant power to international donors who fund vector control. National decisions about sourcing LLINs have been limited to quantity and delivery dates.” The potential to control insecticide resistance was not part of the decision-making process. In addition, there was no World Health Organization (WHO) at the time of the study. Guidance on where and when next-generation LLINs might have a positive impact on malaria transmission, severely limiting their acceptability, availability, and affordability Conclusions This study shows that access to next-generation LLINs has been severely hampered by the lack of global guidance Burkina Faso, where WHO recommendations are being adopted relatively quickly, clear WHO recommendation and adequate funding will be key to accelerate access to next-generation LLINs.

title: Mutability, Trust, Common Sense, and Affirmation: Comprehensive Assessment of Suicide Risk
abstract: AIM: The authors, in collaboration with NSW Health, recently developed a comprehensive framework for assessing suicide risk. This paper describes key concepts in the assessment of suicide risk by mental health professionals. METHODS: A framework for conducting a comprehensive suicide risk assessment was derived from the literature, analysis of incidents, and clinical experience. The framework has been subject to a consultation process involving clinicians from the mental health services in the NSW area. The aim was to provide physicians with a standardized conceptual map for assessing suicide risk. A MEDLINE search was conducted for publications dealing with "suicide" and "suicide risk assessment" from 1980 to 2002. The recommendations of sentinel event reviews conducted in a NSW area psychiatric service in 1999-2002 were reviewed. Findings from a visit to a coroner's family support group for people betrayed by suicide also influenced the development of the guidelines. RESULTS: A framework for assessing suicide risk is proposed. The framework promotes a reflective style of practice and encourages clinicians to evaluate their judgment and limitations. The risk assessment is always performed as part of a full clinical assessment and an assessment of the person's current predicament and psychosociocultural context. The concepts of changeability, confidence in assessment, common sense, and the importance of affirmation are built into the framework. CONCLUSIONS: Mental health clinicians can use a framework for assessing and documenting suicide risk. Assessing suicide risk can result in a suicide risk rating, for which minimum standards of care can be mandated.

title: Changes and challenges: Coping with ADHD in a fast-paced world
abstract: BACKGROUND: Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) disrupts the lives of children and adults. Left undiagnosed and untreated, ADHD can have serious lifelong consequences. Research has identified diagnostic cues, neurotransmitter pathways, and psychiatric comorbidities associated with ADHD, as well as effective pharmacological, behavioral, and psychosocial interventions. Stimulants have been the basis of ADHD therapy for more than 50 years. The availability of new sustained-release (XR or ER) and longer-acting (LA) formulations and novel active ingredients allow for broader and more individualized treatment options. Stimulant side effects are generally mild, short-lived, and responsive to adjustments in dosage or timing. ADHD treatment outcomes can be improved through the use of clear treatment guidelines and tools that help clinicians implement them efficiently and effectively. The Texas Children's Medication Algorithm Project (CMAP) provides a system of algorithm-driven treatment decisions that is evidence-based and easy to implement. AIM: (1) To review the psychological components of attention, the neurotransmitter pathways associated with ADHD, and the range of therapeutic options for ADHD, with emphasis on recent introductions to the therapeutic armamentarium”; (2) discussion of the rare psychiatric and cardiovascular side effects associated with stimulants; (3) review abuse liability, comorbidities, and proposed approaches to these issues;" and (4) review the development and use of CMAP and offer resources for its implementation in clinical practice. CONCLUSION: The pathophysiology of ADHD is associated with dysfunction of the fronto -subcortical networks and a dysregulation of dopaminergic, noradrenergic and nicotinic neurotransmitter systems. An additive effect of several genes as well as environmental influences contributes to the clinical picture. Treatment with stimulants and non-stimulants has been shown to be effective in different subgroups, with the effectiveness of specific agents most likely being related to the primary neurotransmitters involved The availability of formulations containing XR, ER, LA, and transdermal stimulants, as well as alternative non-stimulant agents, offers new options for the pharmacotherapy of ADHD Issues associated with stimulant abuse liability have been eliminated by the availability of ER formulations that have reduced potentiating effects associated with short-acting preparations. Medication outcomes in ADHD can be improved by using evidence-based algorithms such as CMAP. Keys to success are appropriate initial assessment and diagnosis, use of sustained-release products, adequate dose titration, and use of clinical rating scales with feedback from caregivers and teachers. Optimal treatment results can be achieved through appropriate pharmacotherapy in combination with psychosocial interventions.

title: Changes in the attitudes, self-efficacy, intention, knowledge and skills of insurance physicians regarding the guidelines for depression following an implementation strategy
abstract: INTRODUCTION: To improve guideline adherence by panellists (IPs), an implementation strategy was developed and evaluated in a randomized controlled trial. This implementation strategy included a multifaceted training program for a group of IPs in the use of the depression guidelines. In this study, we report the impact of implementation strategy on physician attitudes, intent, self-efficacy, and knowledge and skills as behavioral determinants of guideline adherence. Any associations between these self-reported behavioral determinants and levels of compliance were also determined. Methods: Immediately before and 3 months after the implementation of the multifaceted training, the intervention (n = 21) and a questionnaire measuring behavioral determinants based on the ASE model (attitude, social norm, self-efficacy) were completed by the control group (n = 19 ). Questionnaire items were grouped to form scales of ASE determinants. The internal consistency of the scales was calculated using Cronbach's alphas. Differences between groups in changes in ASE determinants and the association of these changes with improvements in compliance were analyzed using an analysis of covariance. RESULTS: The internal consistency of the scales of the ASE determinants proved to be sufficiently reliable with Cronbach's alphas of at least 0.70. At the 3-month follow-up, the IPs with the implementation strategy showed significant improvement over the IPs in the control group for all ASE determinants examined. Changes in knowledge and skills were only weakly associated with improvements in guideline adherence. Conclusions: The implementation strategy developed for insurance physicians can increase their attitude, intention, self-efficacy, and knowledge and skills in applying the guidelines for depression. These changes in the behavioral determinants may indicate positive changes in the IPs' behavior towards the use of the depression guidelines. However, only changes in the knowledge and skills associated with applying the policies were associated with improvements in the IPs' actual performance in applying the policies.

title: Lifestyle changes after nurse counseling: 1-year results of the Groningen Overweight and Lifestyle Study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The Groningen Overweight and Lifestyle (GOAL) Study primarily aims to prevent weight gain by caregivers (NP) guided by a standardized computerized software program. Because favorable changes in physical activity (PA) and diet can improve health regardless of weight (loss), insight into the impact on lifestyle habits is essential. We examined the 1-year effects of lifestyle counseling by NP on PA and diet compared to usual GP care (GP-UC). DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial. SETTING: Eleven general practice locations in the Netherlands. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 341 GOAL participants with overweight or obesity and either hypertension or dyslipidemia or both who completed an FFQ and a brief Health Enhancing Physical Activity (SQUASH) Assessment Questionnaire at baseline and at 1 year. RESULTS: At 1 year, the NP group spent 33 min/week more walking compared to the GP-UC group, which spent -5 min/week walking (P=0.05). No significant differences were found between the NP and GP-UC groups in the percentage of subjects adhering to the PA guidelines. In both groups, nutrient intake changed in a favorable direction and participants adhered to dietary guidelines more often, but with no overall difference between the NP and GP-UC groups. CONCLUSIONS: With the exception of an increase in walking (based on self-reported data) in the NP group, there were no intervention effects on PA and diet. Positive changes in nutrient intake were observed in both groups.

title: Changes in caregiver knowledge and behavior after brief training on Healthy Eating and Activity Sharing (HEAT) guidelines.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Primary care providers, particularly pediatric nurses, are a key force in combating the adolescent obesity epidemic. However, the majority of nurses report poor knowledge of their ability to adequately prevent and manage pediatric obesity. In response, the National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP) developed the evidence-based Healthy Eating and Activity Together (HEAT) Clinical Practice Guideline (CPG) to improve provider behavior and effectiveness. METHOD: 35 practicing nurse practitioners attending the NAPNAP annual conference underwent an intensive 4-hour HEAT-CPG training session. Before and after the training, data was collected on providers' knowledge, practices and barriers to preventing obesity in adolescents. RESULTS: Results after exercise indicated significant improvements in (a) physician's knowledge (assessment of patient's growth, family history, psychosocial functioning, diet, and physical activity)"; (b) physician's intent to improve behavior ( d Use behavior modification and counseling aimed at changing the behavior of patients and families);" and (c) practitioners' report of increased confidence in ability to address barriers. DISCUSSION: The study results show preliminary support for the HEAT CPG as an effective tool aimed at helping providers improve their ability to maintain healthy weight in patients. Future research is needed to verify the impact of HEAT CPG on long-term improvements in care.

title: Changes in nursing home residents during innovation based on the theory of gerotranscendence
abstract: AIMS AND OBJECTIVES: The aim of the present study was to investigate how residents were affected when an intervention based on the theory of gerotranscendence and guidelines derived from it were introduced in a nursing home. BACKGROUND: The notion that communication is essential in staff-resident interactions is widely accepted in both theory and practice, as is the notion that communicative behavior influences patient outcomes. To date, no studies have focused on whether residents are influenced by staff's use of guidelines derived from gerotranscendence theory. DESIGN: The study was exploratory in nature and used a qualitative approach. Methods: Data was collected through resident interviews and participatory observations; a qualitative content analysis was carried out. SAMPLE SIZE: six residents. RESULTS: The study shows that many residents reviewed and reflected on their lives and that this aspect changed over the study period. The descriptions of the situation of some residents showed that certain changes in the social life on the ward had occurred as a result of the intervention PRACTICAL RELATION: A challenge for gerontology nurses to know and provide the best care and individualized treatment for each resident;" it involves a holistic approach that helps residents in their aging process. Using guidelines derived from the Derived from gerotranscendence theory, caregivers could help promote positive aging and provide a way to treat residents more individually.

title: Changing acute pain management to improve patient outcomes: an educational approach
abstract: The United States Agency for Health Care Policy and Research (AHCPR) guidelines for the management of acute pain were written to provide a scientific basis for practice. Educational programs to promote the use of the guidelines can transform practice in community hospitals. This article describes the development and implementation of a training program for nurses, doctors and pharmacists in six community hospitals. Program content is described that addresses the use of continuous quality improvement (CQI) teams, detailed pain histories, application of algorithms, and dose calculation.";" direct and indirect outcome measures are reviewed. Six months after the program, all three trial sites reported on the use of the AHCPR guidelines in practice. Nurses reported that assessing and documenting the duration of patients' pain was seen as the most important behaviors nurses benefit patients: Among all the activities respondents reported on regularly performed activities, the activity performed by the largest proportion was assessment and documentation of pain using a 0-10 rating scale.

title: Changing clinical behavior by specifying guidelines
abstract: The problems of getting people to act on evidence-based guidelines are widely recognized.1 A review of 41 systematic reviews found that the most promising approach was to use a variety of interventions, including audit and feedback, reminders and education. 1 The effective interventions have often involved complicated procedures and have always been complementary to the provision of guidelines. None of the studies used the simplest intervention—that is, changing the wording of the guidelines. We examine the importance of precise behavioral recommendations and suggest how some current policies could be improved.

title: Changing physician behavior: a training program to disseminate a new clinical pathway for hospital management of hip fractures in elderly patients in Lazio, Italy
abstract: Rationale and Objectives: Concerns about patient safety have increased interest in approaches to improve physician performance, but dissemination of clinical guidelines and conventional medical education have often failed. This study examined the impact of a training program based on experience reflection on the quality of care for hip fracture patients in Lazio, Italy. Methods: Five hospitals participated. The study consisted of the development of a clinical pathway, a preparatory phase and the pedagogical intervention itself, which included a course followed by monthly audits with reflection on practice, guided by the analysis of patient files. Data on the quality of care of patients with hip fractures were collected from the routine information system for the time before and after the intervention. RESULTS: There was a significant increase in the proportion of patients who underwent surgery within 48 hours of admission (from 7% in 2006 to 26.4% in 2007) and a significant reduction in the mean length of hospital stay (from 18.8 to 16.4 days). . Some process indicators of treatment quality were high post-procedure, although non-recommended practices were still routinely used (e.g., urinary catheterization in 72.2% of patients). When comparing the hospitals, there were differences in the changes. CONCLUSION: An educational intervention that combined dissemination of a clinical pathway with external auditing focused on reflection on practice was effective in promoting behavioral change in physicians. The persistence of non-recommended practices and the differences between hospitals indicate that multiple factors affect performance and affect the effectiveness of interventions.

title: Modifying human behavior to prevent disease: the importance of targeting automatic processes.
abstract: Much of the global burden of disease is associated with behaviors—overeating, smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, and physical inactivity—that people recognize as unhealthy and yet continue to engage in, even when undesirable consequences occur. To date, interventions aimed at changing such behaviors have largely encouraged people to reflect on their behavior. These approaches are often ineffective, consistent with the observation that much human behavior is automatic and triggered by environmental stimuli, resulting in actions that are largely unaccompanied by conscious reflection. We propose that interventions targeting these automatic behavioral bases may be more effective. We discuss specific interventions and propose ways to determine if and how interventions targeting automatic processes can improve global disease prevention efforts.

title: Rethinking: Bounded rationality and heuristic processes in exercise-related judgments and decisions.
abstract: Theories currently used to understand, predict, and promote physical activity and exercise represent information-processing models of the mind. A fundamental assumption underpinning these theories is that human judgment and decision-making processes are rational. Therefore, interventions derived from these models aim to improve "data input" (e.g., to provide complete, accurate, and compelling information about health benefits) with the expectation that rational analysis of that data will result in the desired behavioral "output." will lead. Given the modest effectiveness of interventions based on these models, we designed two experiments that tested the validity of the rationality assumption, focusing specifically on exercise-related judgments and decisions. In Experiment 1, exercise ratings were modified by moving an arbitrary anchor, the presence of which should not affect these ratings. In Experiment 2, the mere addition of a third "bait" exercise option increased the preference between a targeted exercise session and an alternative. Together, these experiments demonstrate that important motivational variables, including perceived desirability of exercise, affective attitude, intention, affective prognosis, and exercise decisions, can be manipulated in a predictable direction without providing new relevant information, but only by targeting specific, well-known ones characterized heuristics. Therefore, these data provide evidence that the "limited" nature of human rationality is also manifested in exercise judgments and decisions. Researchers and exercise practitioners should consider incorporating heuristic processes into theoretical dual-process models of physical activity and exercise behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Changing physician behavior to improve disease prevention
abstract: Physicians often fail to provide the nationally recommended screening services for their patients. To address this, we reviewed selected literature on physician behavior change using the organizational construct of the transtheoretical “change readiness” model. This model suggests that behavior evolves through phases from pre-contemplation, through contemplation, to preparation, initiation, and maintenance of change. Traditional medical education can influence knowledge and beliefs, but rarely leads to behavioral change. However, motivational strategies such as practice feedback reports and influential peers can encourage level shifting. Successful interventions aimed at physicians preparing for change often use a practice systems approach that appeals not only to physicians but also to practice staff and patients. We illustrate how the change readiness model can guide the design and implementation of interventions and describe strategies used in a nationwide randomized controlled trial to improve primary care physician cancer prevention counseling and early detection. Partners for Prevention's multi-stage interventions include support from a health insurance carrier, a motivational videotape, a task-based practice manual, diagram flowcharts, patient activation forms, practice feedback reports, a designated prevention coordinator in each practice, and regular phone calls and office visits by project staff.

title: Changing medical behavior: what helps?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: There are various interventions for guideline implementation in clinical practice, but the impact of these interventions is generally unclear. We conducted a systematic review to identify effective ways to implement clinical research and clinical guidelines to change physician practice patterns in surgical and general practice. STUDY DESIGN: Systematic review of reviews. METHODS: We searched electronic databases (MEDLINE, EMBASE, and PubMed) for systematic reviews published in English that assessed the effectiveness of different implementation methods. Two reviewers independently assessed suitability for inclusion and methodological quality, and extracted relevant data. RESULTS: 14 reviews covering a wide range of interventions were identified. Intervention methods used include: audit and feedback, computer-based decision support systems, continuing medical education, financial incentives, local opinion leaders, marketing, passive information dissemination, patient-mediated interventions, reminders, and multiple interventions. Active approaches such as B. academic detailing, led to larger effects than traditional passive approaches. According to the results of 3 reviews, 71% of the studies included in these reviews showed a positive change in physician behavior when exposed to active educational methods and multifaceted interventions. CONCLUSIONS: Active forms of medical education and diverse interventions proved to be the most effective methods of translating guidelines into mainstream practice. In addition, active approaches to modifying physician performance have been shown to improve practice to a greater extent than traditional passive methods. Further primary research is needed to evaluate the effectiveness of these methods in a surgical setting.

title: Changing practice behaviors of physicians to measure and improve clinical outcomes
abstract: Physician behavior in the practice often leads to poor clinical outcomes when treating risk factors for cardiovascular disease, despite effective treatments and guidelines. The behavior of 165 physicians in 2 settings (suburban and urban) was examined. After collecting baseline clinical data, including systolic blood pressure and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, a series of interventions were performed, including academic detailing. Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol decreased by 10.4% in suburban patients with cardiovascular disease in the intervention group (p=0.001) and by 10.5% in the extended intervention group (p=0.001). Systolic blood pressure decreased by 1.11% (P=0.357) in the intervention group and by 5.13% (P<0.001) in the boosted intervention group. In urban hypertensive patients, systolic blood pressure decreased by 5.03% (P=0.001) and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol by 7.01% (P<0.001). Combining urban and suburban data, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol decreased 9.32% (p<0.001) and systolic blood pressure decreased 4.00% (p<0.001). Providing clinical outcomes to physicians, reviewing national guidelines, and setting expectations associated with modest practice system innovations can lead to significant, measurable clinical improvements.

title: Changed social relationships
Chapter: A review of self-management support in (occupational) musculoskeletal pain disorders.
abstract: The overview of self-management interventions for chronic diseases and musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs) presented in this chapter is narrative in nature. Individual qualitative and quantitative research studies as well as systematic reviews and other relevant reviews were considered. Four major databases were searched for relevant peer-reviewed literature published in the past 10 years. Publications prior to this period were included in the review if the work was considered seminal in terms of its contribution to the self-management knowledge base in the context of interest. The following terms were used as keywords and linked to Boolean operators: self-care, self-management, chronic illness, chronic illness, thematic patient education, patient-centred care, health behavior, back pain and musculoskeletal disorders. Because the focus of the review was on people of working age, the cutoffs used included English speakers and adults aged 15 to 64. Relevant gray literature and references from key authors in the field were also consulted. We did not formally assess the methodological quality of the included studies. The identified peer-reviewed studies were then examined for intervention components conceptually closely linked to self-management and involvement of chronic diseases, particularly MSDs, and otherwise excluded. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Chapter: Behavioral Economics and Treatment Engagement.
abstract: Behavioral economics is a field that integrates concepts from psychology and economics to explain how individuals make decisions. In recent years, this area has been increasingly integrated into healthcare to promote a healthier lifestyle. Typically, participants receive monetary incentives when a target behavior or goal is objectively confirmed. In this chapter we describe this evidence-based treatment, commonly referred to as emergency management. This chapter is divided into four parts. The Background section provides an overview of the historical background of incentive-based interventions as used in the treatment of substance abuse. The Application of Incentive-Based Interventions to Medical Goals section describes the application of these interventions to other medical goals, such as: B. vaccinations, medical check-ups, diabetes monitoring, physical activity and weight-loss programs. The Basic Elements and Concepts Embedded in Incentive-Based Interventions section explains basic concepts and elements embedded in effective incentive-based interventions, and the final section discusses issues related to the use and dissemination of incentive programs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Chapter: Escaping Cognitivism: Exercise as a Hedonic Experience.
abstract: Determining their social relevance should be a strategic goal of movement psychology. However, progress toward this goal has been slower than anyone in the field would have liked. In this chapter we have argued that the failure to provide intervention methods that can reliably and meaningfully increase physical activity levels may in part be due to an overly narrow metatheoretical perspective. We have shown that all the major theories that have been in vogue in movement psychology in recent decades are derivatives of the same (cognitivist) metatheoretical framework. As such, they all share a key limitation, namely their relative disregard for the motivational properties of affective constructs such as core affect, moods, and emotions. Research over the last 15 years has shown that the old adage "Exercise makes people feel better" is wrong. Therefore, the central thrust of this chapter has been to underscore the urgent need for the field of movement psychology to transition into the post-cognitivist era. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Characteristics of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes patients in Swiss primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although a variety of treatment guidelines for patients with type 2 diabetes are available, the majority of patients do not achieve the recommended goals. Our aim was to characterize primary care type 2 diabetes patients in Switzerland who are missing HbA1c treatment goals and to uncover factors associated with poorly controlled HbA1c levels. METHODS: Cross-sectional study embedded in the cluster-randomized controlled Chronic Care for Diabetes study. Type 2 diabetes patients with at least one HbA1c measurement >/= 7.0% during the past year were recruited from Swiss primary care. Data assessment included diabetes-specific and general clinical measures, treatment factors, and patient-reported outcomes. RESULTS: 326 type 2 diabetes patients from 30 primary care practices with a mean age of 67.1 +/- 10.6 years participated in the study. The patient findings for HbA1c were 7.7 +/- 1.3%, for systolic blood pressure 139.1 +/- 17.6 mmHg, for diastolic blood pressure 80.9 +/- 10.5 mmHg and for low density lipoprotein 2.7 +/- 1.1. 93.3% of the patients suffered from at least one comorbidity and were treated with 4.8 +/- 2.1 different drugs. No determining factor was significantly associated with HbA1c in the multiple analysis, but a significant clustering effect of general practitioners on HbA1c could be found. CONCLUSIONS: In our sample of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes patients, no "bullet points" could be identified that could be easily addressed by any type of intervention. It is precisely in this subset of diabetic patients, who would benefit most from appropriate interventions to improve diabetes control, that there appears to be a complex interaction between diabetes control, comorbidities, primary care management, and patient health behaviors. So far, this interaction has only been insufficiently described and understood.

title: Characteristics of successfully implemented telemedicine applications
abstract: Background In recent years, interest in the use of telemedicine applications in clinical practice has increased. Significant effort has been invested in trials and trial services. Still, surprisingly few applications have progressed beyond the research and development phase. The aim of this study is to examine characteristics of successfully implemented telemedicine applications. Methods An extensive search of the telemedicine literature was conducted to identify relevant articles. After a defined selection process, a small number of articles describing features of successfully implemented telemedicine applications were identified. These articles were qualitatively analyzed using key Grounded Theory (GT) techniques, including densification and categorization. The analysis resulted in a description of characteristics considered important for a successful implementation of telemedicine. Then these features were discussed in the light of Science and Technology Studies (STS) and the concept of “social negotiation”. Findings Telemedicine applications introduced into routine practice are typically characterized by the following six characteristics: 1) problems in the provision of local services were clearly identified, 2) telemedicine was seen as an advantage, 3) telemedicine was seen as a solution to political and medical issues, 4) there was collaboration between project promoters and users, 5) issues of organizational and technological arrangements were addressed, and 6) the future operation of the service was considered. Conclusion Our results support research that argues that technologies are not fixed entities that move from invention through dissemination to routine use. Rather, it is the interaction of technical and social factors that produces a specific result. The success of a technology depends on how this interaction is handled in the implementation process.

title: The survival of children in the third world: a functional analysis of oral rehydration therapy dissemination campaigns
abstract: PIP: Behavior analysts performed a functional analysis of different intervention strategies used in 14 oral rehydration therapy (ORT) campaigns in 10 developing countries. The intervention researchers manipulated histories, behaviors, and/or outcomes to improve diarrhea management. The strategies used radio announcements, posters and brochures to encourage behavior change. Only 2 campaigns (Thailand and Egypt) limited their intervention to these precursors. Only 3 programs manipulated histories, behaviors and consequences. The 1983 campaign in Bangladesh included schooling for siblings and home visitation as part of vocational training and as a result offered incentives for trainers (US$30). The 1985 project in The Gambia used health workers to educate mothers at home about ORT and awarded lucky baby lottery prizes (rice, sugar and soap). The skills training component of the 1984 campaign in Honduras included one-on-one instruction. A radio course on breastfeeding, school lessons for siblings and an illustrated health manual. The consequences were games and prizes for radio shows, free calendars, keychains, t-shirts and a trip to Tegucigalpa. The only program limited to a training component was the South India campaign in 1976. The training included the training of nurses to instruct mothers in the management of diarrhea. An obstacle in all campaigns was that the ORT does not immediately improve externally diarrhea and vomiting. Those campaigns that included a qualification component were more effective than those that did not. Behavior analysts could contribute to ORT campaigns by developing simple and effective training programs and developing economical and effective mechanisms to assess the effectiveness of such campaigns.

title: Childhood autism and related disorders
Screening and treatment practices of pediatric health care providers for childhood obesity
abstract: This study evaluated physicians' screening and treatment practices for childhood obesity. A 26-question survey was delivered to pediatric providers in person or by mail, email or fax throughout Louisiana. Fifty-seven providers participated in the survey, the majority in primary care clinics. Five providers met at least four out of seven clinical guidelines, but no provider met all guidelines. While 88% of providers screened for obesity, 7% met guidelines for referring obese patients to weight management services. Six providers offered interventions that included all of the recommended components (ie, diet, physical activity, and behavioral counseling). One intervention met intensity guidelines (ie, > 25 hours for at least six months). Barriers to service delivery included a lack of reimbursement and poor family compliance. Solutions should be found to overcome treatment barriers to improve the delivery of health services to children with obesity.

title: Childhood tonsillectomy: who is referred and what are the treatment options? Baseline findings from the North of England and Scotland Study of Tonsillectomy and Adenotonsillectomy in Children (NESSTAC)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Tonsillectomies are commonly performed, but there is variability in tonsillectomy rates. Clinicians use guidelines, but complex psychosocial influences on childhood tonsillectomy include anecdotal evidence of parental enthusiasm. Studies show that preferential treatment improves outcome. Despite the enthusiasm with which tonsillectomy is offered and sought, there is little evidence of its effectiveness. This led to a randomized controlled trial evaluating the cost-effectiveness of (adeno)tonsillectomy in children with recurrent sore throat. OBJECTIVE: To compare the characteristics of children enrolled in the randomized trial with those recruited into a parallel, non-randomized trial to determine trends in referral and patient preferences for treatment. DESIGN: Baseline data from a randomized controlled trial with parallel non-randomized preference study comparing surgery to medical management in children aged 4 to 15 years with recurrent sore throat related to five secondary ENT departments in northern England or western England Central Scotland. RESULTS: Centers assessed 1546 children";" 21% were not candidates for tonsillectomy. Among older children (8-15 years), girls were referred to secondary care significantly more frequently. Of 1015 eligible children, 268 (28.2%) consented to randomization, while 461 (45.4%) consented to the parallel non-randomized preference study, with a strong preference for tonsillectomy. Participants who reported hindering progress in school or who had more experience with persistent sore throats were more likely to seek a tonsillectomy. Referred boys were more likely than girls to choose medical treatment. Socioeconomic data showed no effect. CONCLUSION: Preference for tonsillectomy reflects educational impact and recent experience rather than age or socioeconomic status.

title: Children in the taxi: a chance for paediatricians and emergency doctors to save lives?
abstract: AIM: Child restraint devices (child seats, booster seats and seat belts) are effective in reducing the risk of injury";" however, a pattern of parental non-use or abuse of safety seats remains. The aim of this study was to assess parents' knowledge of and compliance with the National Highway and Traffic Association's safety seat guidelines in personal automobiles and taxi cabs of children presenting for emergency care. METHODS: Two hundred and forty-two caregivers of children (aged 2 weeks to 19 years) presenting for care in the pediatric emergency department of a city university hospital were approached to fill out a questionnaire administered by an interviewer, and 225 completed it . The questionnaire included knowledge, attitude and behavioral questions about protective equipment for children of different ages. RESULTS: Eleven (47.8%) of 23 children aged 1 year and younger reported frequently or always using child safety seats while traveling in private automobiles, compared to 8 (22.2%) of 36 children aged 12 and under 1 year or younger who reported using these in-car taxis (P < 0.05). Seventeen (85%) of 20 children older than 8 years reported frequently or always using seat belts in private cars versus 10 (41.7%) of 24 in taxis (P < 0.01). One hundred fifty-four (99.3%) of 155 subjects knew the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration recommended safety seat position for their child. Most parents believed in the effectiveness of child safety seats in preventing vehicle injuries and indicated that they would be more likely to use safety devices if they were given information about their use in the emergency room. CONCLUSIONS: Data from this survey shows that the use of safety seats in taxis is lower than in private cars and that this is more due to the inconvenience of transporting these seats to and from the taxi than to financial considerations or a lack of knowledge about their effectiveness. Strategies should be sought to increase the availability of child safety devices in taxis. The emergency room and pediatric office or clinic can be a place for an educational intervention for parents and caregivers about child safety.

title: children with head injuries
Cognitive performance and selective attention of children after recent community violence
abstract: Research has shown robust relationships between community violence and psychopathology, but relatively little is known about how community violence can affect cognitive performance and attention. The present study estimates the effects of police-reported community violence on the performance of 359 urban children on a computer-assisted neuropsychological task using a fixed-effects quasi-experimental design. Living near a recent violent crime predicted faster but slightly less accurate task performance for the full sample, evolutionarily adaptive patterns of "alert" attention (ie, less attention to positive stimuli, more attention to negative stimuli) for children who reported weak trait anxiety and possibly maladaptive patterns of "avoidant" attention in very anxious children. These results suggest that community violence can directly affect children's cognitive performance, while also having differential (and possibly orthogonal) effects on attention delivery, depending on the children's level of biological behavioral risk. Implications for mental health and sociological research are discussed.

title: Chiropractic care for pediatric and adolescent attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder: A systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Psychostimulants are the first line of therapy for pediatric and adolescent AD/HD. Evidence suggests that up to 30% of stimulants prescribed do not show clinically significant results. In addition, many children and adolescents suffer from side effects of these drugs. As a result, parents are looking for alternative interventions for their children. Complementary and alternative medicine therapies for behavioral disorders such as AD/HD are on the rise, with as many as 68% of parents having sought help from alternative medicine professionals, including chiropractors. AIM: The review aims to answer the question of whether chiropractic care can reduce symptoms of inattention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity in pediatric and adolescent AD/HD. METHODS: Electronic databases (Cochrane CENTRAL register of Controlled Trials, Cochrane Database of Systematic reviews, MEDLINE, PsycINFO, CINAHL, Scopus, ISI Web of Science, Index to Chiropractic Literature) were searched for English-language chiropractic studies from early to July 2009 and AD /HS. Inclusion and exclusion criteria were applied to selected studies. All randomized controlled trials were evaluated using the Jadad score and a checklist developed based on CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) guidelines. RESULTS: The search yielded 58 citations, 22 of which were intervention studies. Of these, only three studies were identified for pediatric and adolescent AD/HD cohorts. The methodological quality was poor and none of the studies qualified based on the inclusion criteria. CONCLUSIONS: To date, there is insufficient evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of chiropractic treatment for pediatric and adolescent AD/HD. The claim that chiropractic care improves pediatric and adolescent AD/HD is supported by little scientific evidence. In the interests of child and adolescent health, if chiropractic treatment for AD/HD is to continue, more rigorous scientific research must be conducted to study the efficacy and effectiveness of chiropractic treatment. Appropriately sized RCTs using clinically relevant outcomes and standardized measures to examine the effectiveness of chiropractic care compared to no treatment/placebo control or standard of care (pharmacological and psychosocial care) are needed to determine whether chiropractic care an effective alternative intervention for children and adolescents is AD/HD.

title: Wise Choices in Headache Medicine: The American Headache Society's list of five things doctors and patients should question
abstract: To raise awareness of tests and practices associated with poor quality treatment in headache medicine, the American Headache Society (AHS) joined the American Board of Internal Medicine Foundation's Choosing Wisely initiative. The AHS President has established an ad hoc AHS Choosing Wisely Working Group. The committee surveyed AHS members to create a list of candidates for the AHS "Top 5" list of low value treatments in headache medicine. Through a process of literature review and consensus, the final five-item list was selected. The draft recommendations went through several rounds of revision and a process of external review. The AHS Board of Directors approved the final list of the "Five Things." The five recommendations approved by the AHS board are: (1) do not conduct neuroimaging studies in patients with stable headaches who meet criteria for migraine; (2) do not perform computed tomography imaging for headache when magnetic resonance imaging is available, except in emergency situations; (3) do not recommend surgical deactivation of migraine trigger points outside of a clinical trial; (4) do not prescribe opioid or butalbital drugs as first-line treatment for recurrent headache disorders;" and (5) do not recommend prolonged or frequent use of over-the-counter pain relievers for headaches. We recommend that headache medicine specialists and other physicians who evaluate and treat headache disorders should use this list when discussing treatment with patients.

title: Choose Wisely: The American College of Rheumatology's top 5 list of things doctors and patients should question
abstract: AIM: We wanted to develop a list of 5 tests, treatments, or services commonly used in rheumatology practice whose necessity or value should be questioned and discussed by physicians and patients. METHODS: We used a multi-step process that combined consensus methodology and literature reviews to arrive at the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) top 5 list. Rheumatologists from different practices created items using the Delphi method. Items with high content agreement and perceived high prevalence became a survey of ACR members, who represent over 90% of the US rheumatology workforce. To increase the response rate, a nested random sample of 390 rheumatologists underwent more intensive survey follow-up. The samples were combined and weighting procedures applied to ensure generalizability. Articles with high ratings were subjected to a literature search. The final points were then selected and formulated by the task force. RESULTS: 105 unique articles were suggested and narrowed down to 22 articles during the Delphi rounds. A total of 1,052 rheumatologists (17% of those contacted) took part in the member-wide survey, while 33% took part in the nested random sample. The characteristics of the respondents were similar in both samples. Based on survey results and available scientific evidence, 5 items (relating to antinuclear antibodies, Lyme disease, magnetic resonance imaging, bone absorptiometry, and biologic therapy for rheumatoid arthritis) were selected for inclusion. CONCLUSIONS: The ACR Top 5 list is intended to encourage discussion between physicians and patients about rheumatology care practices that should be questioned and to support rheumatologists in delivering quality care.

title: Choose Wisely: The American Society for Radiation Oncology's Top 5 List
abstract: PURPOSE: To highlight 5 interventions patients should question as part of the Choosing Wisely campaign. This initiative, led by the American Board of Internal Medicine Foundation, encourages conversations between doctors and patients about treatments and tests that may be overused, unnecessary, or potentially harmful. METHODS AND MATERIAL: Potential items were initially compiled using an online survey. They were then evaluated and refined by a working group from the American Society for Radiation Oncology (ASTRO) Clinical Affairs and Quality, Health Policy and Government Relations Councils. Literature reviews were conducted to support the recommendation and report and to provide references for each point. A final list of 5 items was then selected by the ASTRO Board of Directors. RESULTS: ASTRO's 5 recommendations for the Choosing Wisely campaign are as follows: (1) Do not start whole-breast radiotherapy as part of breast-conservation therapy in women aged >/= 50 with early-stage invasive breast cancer without a shorter course of radiation in treatment plans to consider"; (2) do not initiate management of low-risk prostate cancer without discussing active surveillance; (3) do not routinely use extended fractionation regimens (>10 fractions) for palliation of bone metastases; (4) do not do not routinely recommend proton beam radiation therapy for prostate cancer outside of a prospective clinical trial or registry;" and (5) do not routinely use intensity-modulated radiation therapy to deliver whole-breast radiation therapy as part of breast-conservation therapy. CONCLUSIONS: The ASTRO list for the campaign " Choosing Wisely” highlights radiation oncology interests rventions that should be discussed between physicians and patients before initiating treatment. These 5 elements offer opportunities to offer higher quality and less expensive care.

title: Chronic care model and shared care in diabetes: randomized study of an electronic decision support system.
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effect of a specialized telemedicine intervention to improve diabetes care using the Chronic Care Model (CCM). PARTICIPANTS AND METHODS As part of the CCM, between July 1, 2001 and December 31, 2003, 97 primary care physicians at 6 primary care practices in Rochester, MN, referred 639 patients to a local diabetes counselor. At first referral, physicians were centrally randomized to receive telemedicine intervention (specialist advice and evidence-based communications on medication management for cardiovascular risk) or no intervention, blinding outcome assessors and data analysts to group assignment. After each subsequent clinical encounter, endocrinologists reviewed a summary of the patient's electronic medical record and emailed treatment recommendations and supporting evidence to treating physicians. The control physicians received regular emails with general information on cardiovascular risk reduction in diabetes. Outcome measures included diabetes care processes (diabetes test completion), outcomes (metabolic and cardiovascular risk factors, estimated coronary artery disease risk), and patient costs (payer perspective). RESULTS During the intervention, 951 (70%) of the 1361 endocrinological reviews detected performance gaps and resulted in a report; GPs reported using 49% of messages in patient care. At a mean follow-up of 21 months, the intervention did not significantly improve metabolic outcomes or reduce the estimated risk of coronary artery disease compared to the control group (adjusted mean difference -1%; 95% confidence interval -19% to 17%). The intervention group emerged lower costs (P=0.02), but no diabetes-related costs. CONCLUSION Specialized telemedicine did not significantly increase the value of CCM in primary care.

title: Health risk behaviors in chronic illness in people with a mental illness
abstract: OBJECTIVE: In people with mental illness, modifiable health risk behaviors contribute significantly to increased morbidity and mortality from chronic diseases. This study examined the prevalence of and interest in changing such behaviors among clients of community mental health services in Australia. METHOD: A telephone interview was conducted with clients from the Australian Community Psychiatric Service. Participants reported four unhealthy behaviors: tobacco smoking, fruit and vegetable consumption, alcohol consumption, and physical activity. Participants were classified as Vulnerable based on Australia's national guidelines. At-risk participants were asked if they were considering improving their health-risk behaviors over the next month. The association between psychiatric diagnosis and risk, as well as interest in improving health risk behaviors, was examined. RESULTS: The risk prevalence was highest for insufficient vegetable consumption (78.3%), followed by insufficient fruit consumption (60%), smoking (50.7%), physical inactivity (46.8%), short-term alcohol risk (40.3% ) and chronic alcohol use risk (35.3%). A majority of at-risk participants considered improving their health-risk behaviors related to smoking, physical inactivity, and insufficient fruit and vegetable intake (65.1%, 71.1%, and 53.3%, respectively). After adjusting for demographic factors, no diagnostic categories were associated with risk for any behavior. Those diagnosed with depression were more interested in quitting smoking and increasing physical activity. CONCLUSIONS: Regardless of the diagnosis, a high prevalence of unhealthy behaviors was found in chronic diseases, with many participants expressing an interest in improving these behaviors. Such findings reinforce recommendations that preventive treatments that address patients' chronic disease risks are routinely provided by psychiatrists. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ANZCTR) ACTRN12613000693729. URL: www.anzctr.org.au/.

title: Competence network for chronic inflammatory bowel diseases
abstract: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is an intermittent, often chronic disease that primarily affects young people in their 20s and 30s, affecting their quality of life and socioeconomic performance. The triggering factors for the development of IBD have not been fully clarified: in addition to environmental factors, there are clear indications of other genetic factors that influence the risk of disease and the pattern of intestinal inflammation in Crohn's disease. Pathophysiological findings lead to new therapeutic possibilities, which are carried out in large clinical studies with the significant participation of the CED competence network. The comprehensive structure of the network of university and non-university clinics and laboratories, the self-help organization DCCV and its vertical cooperation with general practitioners nationwide offers the opportunity to describe the diseases from a scientific and medical point of view at the same time. The IBD competence network thus provides the basis for the standardized integration of patient information, for the development of guidelines and the establishment of a quality management system, and thus leads to an improvement in scientific and clinical research.

title: Cigarette smoking prevalence among adults living with HIV compared to the general adult population in the United States
abstract: Background: The adverse health effects of cigarette smoking and HIV infection are synergistic. OBJECTIVE: To compare the prevalence of current cigarette smoking and smoking cessation rates between healthcare professionals living with HIV and adults in the general population. Design: Nationally representative cross-sectional surveys. Setting: United States. Patients: 4,217 adults living with HIV who participated in the Medical Monitoring Project and 27,731 US adults who participated in the 2009 National Health Interview Survey. Measurements: The main exposure was cigarette smoking. Outcome measures were weighted cigarette smoking prevalence and smoking cessation ratio (ratio of former smokers to sum of former and current smokers). to 45.1%) were current cigarette smokers, 20.3% (CI 18.6% to 22.1%) were ex-smokers, and 37.3% (CI 34.9% to 39.6%) had never smoked. Compared to the US adult population, in which an estimated 20.6% of adults smoked cigarettes in 2009, adults living with HIV smoked almost twice as often (adjusted prevalence difference, 17.0 percentage points [CI, 14.0 to 20.1 percentage points]) , but were less likely to quit smoking (rates, 32.4% vs. 51.7%). In adults living with HIV, factors independently associated with higher smoking prevalence were older age, non-Hispanic white or non-Hispanic black race, lower educational attainment, poverty, homelessness, incarceration, drug use, excessive alcohol use, depression and failure to achieve suppressed HIV viral load. Limitation: Cross-sectional design with some limitations in generalizability. Conclusion: Adults with HIV were more likely to smoke and less likely to quit smoking than the general adult population. Tobacco screening and tobacco cessation strategies are important considerations in routine HIV care.

title: The CIOMS Placebo Rule and the Promotion of Negligent Medical Practice
Civic obligation of the anorexic patient
abstract: Involuntary attachment appears to be a rarely used intervention in anorexic patients, in part due to clinician uncertainty as to its applicability to this patient population. Unlike overtly suicidal patients, anorexic patients typically fail to express intention to harm themselves, even though their actions can result in serious harm. However, an examination of the wording of civil obligation statutes suggests that when anorexic patients' behavior endangers their lives, they are usually institutionalized below severe disability standards. This appears to be consistent with the practices of professionals treating anorexia and practices in other countries as well. Compulsory confinement should be used as a last resort when patients refuse voluntary hospitalization and their physical safety is at risk. In addition, the civil obligation should probably also be limited to circumstances in which a therapeutic benefit can be expected from hospitalization. Many critically ill anorexic patients will be unable to make treatment decisions for themselves, allowing involuntary feeding and other procedures to take place if necessary. Civic engagement is a tool that can legitimately be used in emergency situations involving anorexic patients.

title: Classifications in the field of mental health
abstract: For the first time in the ninth revision of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-9), the chapter on mental disorders included brief glossary definitions for each category. A number of attitudinal and policy changes at international and national levels, particularly the reorientation of mental health programs towards behavioral and psychosocial issues, came at an opportune time and had a positive impact on the development of proposals for the mental health chapter Problems Behavioral Disorders in the Tenth Revision (ICD-10). This in turn enabled WHO to carry out an intensive and comprehensive assessment of the international need for the classification of mental disorders and, where the situation was ambiguous, to organize field trials to provide the empirical data needed to solve the problem. The result is a set of compatible classifications of mental and behavioral disorders based on ICD-10. The first, created mainly as a reference tool for statistical purposes, is included in ICD-10 with brief glossary definitions, as was the case in ICD-9. Other versions are published for practicing clinicians (with expanded glossary definitions followed by diagnostic guidelines) for research purposes (with full definitions, diagnostic guidelines and diagnostic criteria)"; for use in providing mental health services;" and for use in general health care (primary care). There will also be a multiaxial classification of mental disorders in children to identify the clinical syndrome, resulting disability and environmental factors. It is hoped that these versions, tailored to the needs of different groups working in the mental health field, will lead to further improvements in communication between those responsible for service and care delivery.

title: Classroom-based cognitive-behavioral therapy to reduce symptoms of depression in high-risk adolescents: pragmatic randomized controlled cluster study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To compare the effectiveness of class-based cognitive behavioral therapy with attentional control and usual school services for adolescents at high risk of depression. DESIGN Three-arm, randomized, controlled, parallel cluster study. RECRUITMENT Eight secondary schools in the UK. PARTICIPANTS Adolescents (n=5030) aged 12-16 in grades 8-11. Age groups were randomly assigned in a 1:1:1 ratio to cognitive behavioral therapy, attention control, or usual school offerings. Allocation was balanced according to school, year, number of pupils and classes, frequency of lessons and timetable. Participants were not blinded to treatment allocation. INTERVENTIONS Cognitive-behavioural therapy, attentional control, and usual school services offered to all eligible participants in the classroom. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Outcomes were collected through a self-completed questionnaire administered by the investigators. The primary endpoint was depression symptoms, which were assessed at 12 months using the short mood and emotion questionnaire in those who were at high risk of depression at baseline. Secondary outcomes were negative thinking, self-esteem, and anxiety. Analyzes were performed on a treatment intent basis and accounted for the clustered nature of the design. RESULTS: 1064 (21.2%) adolescents were identified as at high risk of depression: 392 in the class-based cognitive behavioral therapy arm, 374 in the attention control arm, and 298 in the usual school care arm. At 12 months, the adjusted means of the brief mood and feeling questionnaire did not differ for cognitive behavioral therapy versus attention control (-0.63, 95% confidence interval -1.85 to 0.58, p=0.41) or for cognitive behavioral therapy versus usual School offers (0.97, -0.20 to 2.15, P=0.12). CONCLUSION In adolescents with depressive symptoms, outcomes for attention control, usual school services, and cognitive behavioral therapy were similar. Classroom cognitive-behavioural therapy programs may result in increased self-esteem and reporting of depressive symptoms, but should not be undertaken without further evaluation and research. STUDY REGISTRATION Current controlled studies ISRCTN19083628.

title: Clinical and cost-effectiveness of booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation for chronic vertigo in primary care: single-blind, parallel-group, pragmatic, randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation with and without telephone support for chronic vertigo compared to routine care. DESIGN Single-blind, parallel-group, pragmatic, randomized, controlled study. SETTING 35 GP surgeries across southern England between October 2008 and January 2011. PARTICIPANTS Patients aged 18+ with chronic dizziness (average duration > five years) not due to non-vestibular causes (confirmed by GP) and which could be aggravated by head movement (confirmed by patient). INTERVENTIONS Participants were randomly assigned to receive routine medical care, booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation only, or booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation with telephone support. For the booklet approach, participants received self-management booklets with comprehensive advice on how to perform vestibular rehabilitation exercises at home daily for up to 12 weeks and how to use cognitive-behavioral techniques to promote positive beliefs and treatment adherence. Participants receiving telephone support were offered up to three short sessions of structured support from a vestibular therapist. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Dizziness Symptom Scale--Short Form and Total Health Costs Associated with Dizziness per Quality-Adjusted Life-Year (QALY). RESULTS Of 337 randomized participants, 276 (82%) completed all clinical measures at the primary endpoint, 12 weeks, and 263 (78%) at one year of follow-up. We analyzed clinical efficacy by treatment intent using analysis of covariance to compare groups post-intervention, controlling for symptom scores at baseline. At 12 weeks, scores on the dizziness symptom scale in the telephone support group were not significantly different from those in the routine care group (adjusted mean difference -1.79 (95% confidence interval -3.69 to 0.11), p=0.064 ). After one year, both intervention groups improved significantly compared to routine care (telephone support -2.52 (-4.52 to -0.51), P = 0.014"; brochure only -2.43 (-4.27 to -0, Analysis of cost-effectiveness-acceptance curves showed that both interventions were very cost-effective; at very low QALY scores, the brochure-only approach was most likely to be cost-effective, but the added telephone support approach was most likely to be cost-effective at QALY -Values over £1,200 ($1,488; $1,932).Using the booklet approach with telephone support, five (three to 12) patients would need to be treated for one patient to report subjective improvement at one year.CONCLUSIONS Booklet-based vestibular rehabilitation in chronic vertigo is a simple and inexpensive means of improving patient-reported outcomes in primary care STUDY REGISTRATION ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00732797.

title: Clinical evaluation of motherhood in infancy
abstract: Using reliable and valid measurements of motherhood can improve the ability of clinicians and researchers to identify problematic patterns that pose risks to maternal and infant health in the first year after birth. A critical review of observational and self-report instruments measuring components of motherhood is presented. Positive indicators of maternity are discussed and implications for interventions and referrals for problematic aspects of maternity are suggested.

title: Clinical biochemistry closer to the patient
Clinical features associated with SSRI drug prescribing in adolescents with major unipolar depression
abstract: Unipolar major depression (MD) clearly occurs during adolescence. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) UK recommends psychological therapies with concomitant selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), which are only prescribed in severe cases. Here we attempt to determine the extent and rationale for prescribing SSRIs in juvenile MD before entering a randomized clinical trial. SSRI prescription, along with its clinical characteristics, was determined in 465 adolescent patients with MD prior to receiving standardized psychological therapy as part of the Mood Improvement Through Psychoanalytic and Cognitive Therapies (IMPACT) clinical trial. A total of 88 (19%) were prescribed antidepressants prior to psychological treatment. Clinical correlations varied by gender: severity of depression in boys and self-harm in girls. Prescribing also differed between clinical research centers. Doctors consider the severity of depression in boys as an indicator for prescribing antidepressants. Self-harm in girls appears to be used as a prescribing aid, inconsistent with previous and current revised UK NICE guidelines.

title: Clinical effectiveness of a manual coping strategies program (START, STrAtegies for RelaTives) in promoting the mental health of caregivers of family members with dementia: pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess whether manual coping reduces symptoms of depression and anxiety in caregivers of family members with dementia compared to usual treatment. DESIGN Randomized parallel-group superiority study. SETTINGS Three community mental health services and one dementia outpatient neurological service in London and Essex, UK. PARTICIPANTS 260 carers of family members with dementia. INTERVENTION An eight-session manual coping intervention delivered by supervised psychology graduates for caregivers of family members with dementia. The program consisted of psychoeducation about dementia, caregiver stress and where to get emotional support, understanding the caregiver's behavior and behavior management techniques, changing unhelpful thoughts, promoting acceptance, communicating confidently, relaxing, planning for the future, increasing enjoyable activities and maintaining learned skills Caregivers practiced these techniques at home using the manual and relaxation CDs Caseness on the Hospital Scale for Anxiety and Depression, Quality of Life for both the caregiver (health status questionnaire, mental health) and the caregiver (quality of life – Alzheimer's disease) and caregiver's potential abusive behavior towards caregiver (Modified Conflict Tactics Scale) RESULTS 260 caregivers were recruited, 173 were randomized to the intervention and 87 to treatment as usual Mean total scores on the in-hospital anxiety and depression scale were lower in the intervention group than in the treatment-as-usual group over the eight-month assessment period: adjusted difference in mean scores -1.80 points (95% confidence interval -3.29 to -0, 31);" P=0.02) and absolute mean difference -2.0 points. Caregivers in the intervention group were less likely to have case-level depression (odds ratio 0.24, 95% confidence interval 0.07 to 0.76), and it showed a non-significant trend towards a reduced number of cases of anxiety (0.30, 0.08 to 1.05), the quality of life of the caregivers was higher in the intervention group (mean difference 4.09, 95% confidence interval 0.34 to 7, 83), but not in the care recipients (mean difference 0.59, -0.72 to 1.89) Carers in the intervention group reported less abusive behavior towards the care recipient compared to those in the care-as-usual group (odds ratio 0 .47, 95% confidence interval 0.18 to 1.23), although not significant A manual coping strategy was effective in reducing case-level mood symptoms and depression in family caregivers family members with dementia. The quality of life of the carers also improved. STUDY REGISTRATION Current controlled studies ISCTRN70017938.

title: Clinical effectiveness of health visitor training in psychologically informed approaches to depression in postnatal women: pragmatic randomized cluster study in primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the benefits of two psychologically-based interventions by health visitors to postpartum women. DESIGN Prospective cluster study, randomized by primary care practice, with 18-month follow-up. SETTING 101 GP practices in Trent, England. PARTICIPANTS 2749 women were allocated to the intervention, 1335 to the control. INTERVENTION Health visitors (n = 89 63 clusters) were trained to recognize depressive symptoms at six to eight weeks postpartum using the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS) and clinical assessment, and they were also trained to use psychologically informed sessions on cognitive-behavioural or person-centered principles, one hour per week for eight weeks. Health visitors in the control group (n=49 38 clusters) provided usual care. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Score > or = 12 on the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale at six months. Secondary outcomes were the Edinburgh Mean Postnatal Depression Scale, Clinical Scores on Routine Assessment Outcome Measurement (CORE-OM), State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI), SF-12, and Parenting Stress Index Short Form (PSI-SF)- Scores at six, 12, 18 months. RESULTS 4084 eligible women consented and 595 women had a 6-week EPDS score > or = 12. Of these, 418 had EPDS scores available at 6 weeks and 6 months. At six months, 34% (93/271) of women in the intervention group and 46% (67/147) in the control group had an EPDS score > or = 12. The odds ratio for a score > or = 12 at six months was 0.62 (95% confidence interval 0.40 to 0.97, P=0.036) for women in the intervention group compared to women in the control group. After adjusting for covariates, the odds ratio was 0.60 (0.38 to 0.95, P=0.028). At six months, 12.4% (234/1880) of all women in the intervention group and 16.7% (166/995) of all women in the control group had scores > or = 12 (0.67, 0.51 to 0.87 , P = 0.003) . The benefit for women in the intervention group with a 6-week EPDS score > or = 12 and for all women was maintained at 12 months postpartum. There was no differential utility for one of the psychological approaches versus the other. CONCLUSION Training health professionals to assess women, recognize symptoms of postnatal depression, and conduct psychologically informed sessions was clinically effective at six and twelve months postpartum compared to usual care. TRIAL REGISTRATION ISRCTN92195776.

title: Clinical global measures of dementia. Position paper of the International Working Group on Harmonization of Dementia Drug Guidelines
abstract: The following is the report of the committee working on clinical global measures for anti-dementia drug guidelines. The concepts of global scales, the distinction between change and severity scales, advantages and disadvantages of structured interviews and the anchoring of change scores are discussed and selected existing clinical global scales are described. In addition, the committee evaluated the usefulness of global scales in clinical trials for antidementia drugs. There was consensus among the members of the working group on the following: (1) Clinical global scales are based on interviews";" In most cases, they contain information obtained from caregivers as well as directly from patients, but they can only rely on information from the data subject. (2) Clinicians' global assessments are intended to assess clinically meaningful changes based on a multidimensional clinical assessment and take into account the clinical heterogeneity of dementia by assessing at least cognition, behavior and functioning. (3) There are two distinct types of clinical global measures: (a) interview-based global clinician severity scales, which generally involve classification by stage or disease severity, and (b) interview-based global clinician change scales, which include global assessment assessments of clinical change. The committee could not reach a consensus on whether global scales should be required in Phase II and III clinical trials or whether other specific assessments such as well-designed activities of daily living, cognition and behavioral measures might, if used in appropriate combinations, replace the global ones as assessments of clinical significance.

title: Clinical governance in the management of labor induction
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine whether the dissemination of explicit guidelines, developed in consensus with stakeholders, for labor induction (IOL) processes leads to a reduction in variability in clinical practice. DESIGN: A prospective behavior change intervention study. STUDY LOCATION AND DURATION: The study was conducted between January 1 and August 31, 2002 at the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Aga Khan University, Karachi. previously identified quality assessment indicators were measured. After collecting data from an initial 71 women (pre-intervention group), mutually agreed clinical practice guidelines were disseminated over a period of time among counselors, residents and nurses. These indicators were measured again on another 71 women (post-intervention group) to assess the extent of remaining nonconformities in these processes. RESULTS: After behavior-modifying interventions, deviations in doctor- and resident-dependent processes such as timely patient assessment by a specialist (72 vs. 1.4%, p-value <0.0001), documentation of the indication for the IOL (66.2 vs. 16.9 %, p-value < 0.0001), induction method for IOL (56.3 vs. 28.2%, p-value 0.0001) and calculation of Bishop score before IOL (38.0 vs. 4.2% , p-value < 0.0001) were significantly reduced. CONCLUSION: The proliferation of explicit guidelines developed in consensus with stakeholders significantly reduces variability in clinical practice. Our model can be used to improve the quality of care in other areas of obstetric healthcare.

title: Clinical inertia: a common barrier to changing provider prescribing behavior
abstract: BACKGROUND: A cross-sectional content analysis embedded in a randomized controlled trial was conducted to collect information about provider responses to computer alerts regarding guideline recommendations for patients with suboptimal hypertensive care. METHODS: Participants were providers treating 1,017 patients with uncontrolled hypertension on a single antihypertensive drug at Veterans Affairs primary care hospitals. All reasons for action or inaction were sorted into a frame to explain differences in guideline adaptation.
