RESULTS: The 184 negative responses from the provider to computer alerts included explanations for not changing the patient's treatment";" 76 Responses to the warnings were positive, meaning the provider would change the antihypertensive regimen. The negative responses were categorized as follows: inertia in practice (66%), lack of agreement with specific guidelines (5%), patient-related factors (17%), environmental factors (10%), and lack of knowledge (2%). . Most of the 135 providers classified as indolent of practice said, "Continue current medication and I will discuss it at next visit." The median number of days to next visit was 45 days (interquartile range, 29 to 78 days). DISCUSSION: Clinical inertia was the main reason for not undergoing a treatment change otherwise indicated in a subset of patients. A framework has been provided as a taxonomy for classifying vendor barriers.

title: Clinical Judgment Revisited: The Deflection of Quantitative Models
abstract: More than 25 years ago, a book entitled Clinical Judgment described how every act of patient care has an experimental structure using specifications of clinical reasoning. In the past two decades, these improvements have not occurred as extensively as expected, as many researchers working in clinical forms of clinical research have failed to address these fundamental scientific challenges related to data, taxonomy, and reasoning. Instead, researchers applied quantitative "models" drawn from non-clinical fields, focusing on hard data, randomized trials, Bayes' theorem, quantitative decision analysis, and psychometric strategies for clinometric measurement. Consequently, the key challenges of clinical assessment remain widely available for basic scientific research by investigative clinicians.

title: Handbook for developing guidelines for clinical practice: a quality-oriented approach to translating evidence into action
abstract: BACKGROUND: Guidelines translate best evidence into best practice. A well-designed guideline promotes quality by reducing variability in healthcare, improving diagnostic accuracy, promoting effective therapy, and discouraging ineffective or potentially harmful interventions. Despite a plethora of published guidelines, the methodology is often poorly defined and varies widely within and between organizations. PURPOSE: This manual describes the principles and practices successfully applied by the American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery to produce quality-driven, evidence-based guidelines that use an efficient and transparent methodology for action-ready recommendations with multidisciplinary applicability. The development process, which makes it possible to go from conception to completion in 12 months, emphasizes a logical sequence of key actions supported by supporting text, evidence profiles and recommendation grades that link actions to evidence. CONCLUSIONS: As clinical practice guidelines become more important as a key measure of quality healthcare, organizations must develop efficient production strategies that balance rigor and pragmatism. Equally important, clinicians need to understand what guidelines are - and are not - and how best to use them to improve care. The information in this guide is intended to help clinicians and organizations achieve these goals.

title: Clinical Practice Guideline: Otitis Media with Effusion (Update)
abstract: AIM: This update of a 2004 guideline co-developed by the American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery Foundation, the American Academy of Pediatrics, and the American Academy of Family Physicians provides evidence-based recommendations for treating otitis media with effusion (OME). , defined as the presence of fluid in the middle ear with no signs or symptoms of an acute ear infection. Changes from the previous guideline include consumer advocates added to the update group, evidence from 4 new clinical practice guidelines, 20 new systematic reviews and 49 randomized controlled trials, a greater emphasis on patient education and shared decision-making, a new algorithm to clarify the Action Statement Relationships and new and expanded recommendations for the diagnosis and treatment of OME. PURPOSE: The purpose of this multidisciplinary guideline is to identify opportunities for quality improvement in the management of OME and to provide explicit and actionable recommendations for implementing these opportunities in clinical practice. In particular, the goals are to improve diagnostic accuracy, identify children who are most susceptible to the developmental consequences of OME, and educate clinicians and patients about the favorable natural history of most OME and the clinical benefit of medical therapy (e.g., steroids , antihistamines, decongestants) ). Additional goals relate to OME monitoring, hearing and speech assessment, and management of OME detected by newborn screening. The target patient for the guideline is a child aged 2 months to 12 years with OME, with or without developmental disabilities or underlying diseases predisposing to OME and its sequelae. The guidance is intended for all clinicians likely to diagnose and treat children with OME and applies to all situations where OME is identified, monitored, or treated. However, this guideline does not apply to patients over the age of 12. ACTIONS: The update group made strong recommendations that clinicians (1) document the presence of middle ear effusion with pneumatic otoscopy when diagnosing OME in a child; (2) should perform pneumatic otoscopy to assess OME in a child with otalgia, hearing loss, or both; (3) should have tympanometry in children with suspected OME in whom the diagnosis is uncertain after performing (or attempting) pneumatic otoscopy; (4) should treat the child with OME who is not at risk with vigilant waiting 3 months from the date of onset of effusion (if known) or 3 months from the date of diagnosis (if onset is unknown); (5) should discourage the use of intranasal or systemic steroids to treat OME; (6) should discourage the use of systemic antibiotics to treat OME; and (7) should discourage the use of antihistamines, decongestants, or both to treat OME by parents of infants with OME who do not undergo newborn screening regarding the importance of follow-up to ensure hearing is normal when OME resolves and to rule out underlying sensorineural hearing loss; (2) should determine whether a child with OME is at increased risk of language, language, or learning difficulties due to middle ear effusion due to sensory, physical, cognitive, or behavioral factors; (3) children at risk for OME should be screened at the time of diagnosis of a risk disease and 12 to 18 months of age (if diagnosed at risk before that time); (4) Children should not be routinely screened for OME who do not pose a risk and do not have symptoms that could be due to OME, such as: (5) should educate children with OME and their families about the natural history of OME, the need for follow-up care, and the possible consequences; (6) should receive an age-appropriate hearing test if OME lasts 3 months or more OR for OME of any duration in a child at risk; (7) should counsel families of children with bilateral OME and documented hearing loss about the potential impact on speech and language development; (8) children with chronic OME should be reassessed at 3 to 6 month intervals until the effusion is resolved, significant hearing loss is noted, or structural abnormalities of the tympanic membrane or middle ear are suspected; (9) should recommend tympanostomy tubes when performing surgery for OME in a child /=4 years;” and (11) should document resolution of OME, improved hearing, or improved quality of life when treating a child with OME.

title: Clinical Practice Guideline: Tinnitus
abstract: AIM: Tinnitus is the perception of sounds without an external source. More than 50 million people in the United States have reported suffering from tinnitus, resulting in an estimated prevalence of 10% to 15% in adults. Despite the high prevalence of tinnitus and its potentially significant impact on quality of life, there are no evidence-based, multidisciplinary clinical practice guidelines to assist physicians in management. The focus of this guideline is on tinnitus that is both annoying and persistent (lasting 6 months or more), often affecting the patient's quality of life. The guideline is intended for all clinicians, including non-physicians, involved in the management of patients with tinnitus. The patient target population is restricted to adults (18 years and older) with persistent and bothersome primary tinnitus. PURPOSE: The purpose of this guideline is to provide evidence-based recommendations for physicians treating patients with tinnitus. This guideline provides physicians with a logical framework to improve patient care and mitigate the personal and social impact of persistent, bothersome tinnitus. It will discuss the evaluation of patients with tinnitus, including the selection and timing of diagnostic tests and referral to a specialist to identify potential underlying treatable pathologies. It then focuses on the assessment and management of patients with persistent primary tinnitus, with recommendations to guide the assessment and measurement of the impact of tinnitus and to determine the most appropriate interventions to improve symptoms and quality of life in tinnitus sufferers. ACTION: The development group strongly recommended that physicians differentiate patients with bothersome tinnitus from those with non-disruptive tinnitus. The development group strongly recommended that head and neck imaging should not be performed in patients with tinnitus, particularly to assess tinnitus that is not localized to one ear, is not pulsatile, and is not associated with focal neurological abnormalities or an asymmetric hearing loss. The panel made the following recommendations: clinicians should (a) conduct a targeted history and physical examination at the initial evaluation of a patient with suspected primary tinnitus to identify disorders that, if promptly recognized and treated, may relieve tinnitus; (b) obtain a prompt, comprehensive audiological evaluation in patients with tinnitus that is unilateral, persistent (>/= 6 months), or associated with hearing problems; (c) distinguish patients with bothersome tinnitus of recent onset from those with ongoing symptoms (>/= 6 months) to prioritize interventions and facilitate discussion of natural history and follow-up; (d) educate patients with persistent, bothersome tinnitus about treatment strategies; (e) recommend hearing aid evaluation for patients who have persistent, bothersome tinnitus associated with documented hearing loss; and (f) recommend cognitive behavioral therapy to patients with persistent, bothersome tinnitus against (a) antidepressants, anticonvulsants, anxiolytics, or intratympanic drugs for routine treatment of Patients with persistent, bothersome tinnitus; (b) ginkgo biloba, melatonin, zinc or other dietary supplements for the treatment of patients with persistent, bothersome tinnitus; and (c) transcranial magnetic stimulation for the routine management of patients with persistent, bothersome tinnitus. The development group provided the following options: "Physicians can have (a) an initial comprehensive audiological assessment in patients presenting with tinnitus (regardless of laterality, duration, or perceived hearing status);" and (b) patients with persistent tinnitus a Recommend sound therapy, annoying tinnitus The development group made no recommendation on the effect of acupuncture in patients with persistent, annoying tinnitus.

title: Clinical practice guideline: tonsillectomy in children
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Tonsillectomy is one of the most common surgical procedures in the United States, with more than 530,000 procedures performed annually in children under the age of 15. Tonsillectomy is defined as a surgical procedure, performed with or without an adenoidectomy, in which the tonsil, including its capsule, is completely removed by dissecting the peritonsillar space between the tonsil capsule and the muscular wall. Depending on the context in which it is used, it can indicate tonsillectomy with adenoidectomy, particularly in relation to sleep-disordered breathing. This guideline provides evidence-based recommendations for the preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative care and management of children aged 1 to 18 years who are being considered for tonsillectomy. In addition, this guideline is intended for all clinicians in all settings dealing with children aged 1 to 18 who may be candidates for tonsillectomy. PURPOSE: The primary purpose of this guideline is to provide physicians with evidence-based guidance for identifying children who are the best candidates for tonsillectomy. Secondary objectives are to optimize the perioperative management of children undergoing tonsillectomy, to emphasize the need for assessment and intervention in special patient groups, to improve the counseling and education of families of children who are considering tonsillectomy for their child, highlighting treatment options for patients with modifying factors; and reducing inappropriate or unnecessary variations in care. RESULTS: The panel made a strong recommendation that physicians give a single intraoperative dose of dexamethasone intravenously to children undergoing tonsillectomy. The panel issued a strong recommendation against clinicians who routinely give or prescribe perioperative antibiotics to children undergoing tonsillectomy. The panel made recommendations for (1) watchful waiting for recurrent throat infections if fewer than 7 episodes have occurred in the past year, or fewer than 5 episodes per year in the past 2 years, or fewer than 3 episodes per year in the past 3 years" ; (2) Evaluation of the child with recurrent throat infection who does not meet the criteria in Statement 2 for modifying factors that may nevertheless favor tonsillectomy, including but not limited to multiple antibiotic allergy/intolerance, periodic fever, aphthous stomatitis, pharyngitis, and History of adenitis or peritonsillar abscess; (3) interviewing caregivers of children with sleep disordered breathing and tonsillar hypertrophy about comorbid conditions that might improve after tonsillectomy, including growth retardation, poor school performance, enuresis, and behavior problems; (4) advising caregivers about the tonsillect tomie as a means of improving health in children with abnormal polysomnography who also suffer from tonsillar hypertrophy and sl eep-disordered breathing; (5) advising caregivers that sleep breathing disorders may persist or recur after tonsillectomy and may require further treatment; (6) advocating post-tonsillectomy pain management and educating caregivers on the importance of pain management and re-evaluation;" and (7) clinicians performing tonsillectomy should assess their rate of primary and secondary post-tonsillectomy bleeding at least annually. The panel offered options for recommending tonsillectomy for recurrent strep throat with a frequency of at least 7 episodes per year for the past year, or at least 5 episodes per year for 2 years, or at least 3 episodes per year for 3 years, with documentation in the medical record for each episode of sore throat and 1 or more of the following: temperature > 38.3 °C, cervical adenopathy, tonsillar exudate, or positive test for group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus.

title: Clinical practice guideline: ventilation tubes in children
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Tube insertion is the most common ambulatory surgery performed on children in the United States. Tympanostomy tubes are most commonly used for persistent middle ear fluid, frequent ear infections, or ear infections that persist after antibiotic therapy. Despite the frequency of tube placement, there are currently no clinical practice guidelines in the United States that address specific indications for surgery. This guideline is intended for all clinicians involved in the management of children aged 6 months to 12 years with ventilation tubes or who are being considered for ventilation tubes in any care setting as an intervention for otitis media of any type. PURPOSE: The primary purpose of this clinical practice guideline is to provide physicians with evidence-based recommendations on patient selection and surgical indications for and management of tympanostomy tubes in children. The development group discussed in detail indications for tube placement, perioperative management, the provision of indwelling tubes in children, and the outcome of tympanic tube surgery. Given the lack of currently published guidelines on surgical indications, the group focused on situations where tube insertion would be optional, recommended, or not recommended. Additional emphasis was placed on opportunities for quality improvement, particularly in relation to shared decision-making and the care of children with existing tubes. ACTIONS: The development group strongly recommended that physicians prescribe only topical antibiotic ear drops without oral antibiotics for children with uncomplicated acute tympanic tube otorrhea. The panel made recommendations that (1) clinicians should refrain from tube insertion in children with a single episode of otitis media with effusion (OME) less than 3 months; (2) Clinicians should have an age-appropriate hearing test if OME persists for 3 months or more (chronic OME) or prior to surgery if a child becomes a candidate for tympanostomy tubes; (3) Physicians should offer bilateral ventilation tubes for 3 months or more to children with bilateral OME (chronic OME) and documented hearing difficulties; (4) Clinicians should reassess children with chronic OME who have not received ventilation tubes at 3 to 6 month intervals until the effusion is resolved, significant hearing loss is noted, or structural abnormalities of the tympanic membrane or middle ear are suspected ; (5) Clinicians should refrain from tube insertion in children with recurrent acute otitis media (AOM) who do not have middle ear effusion in both ears at the time of evaluation for tube candidacy; (6) Clinicians should offer bilateral tympanostomy tubes to children with recurrent AOM who have unilateral or bilateral middle ear effusion at the time of evaluation for tube candidacy; (7) Clinicians should determine whether a child with recurrent AOM or with OME of any duration is at increased risk of language, language, or learning difficulties due to otitis media because of sensory, physical, cognitive, or behavioral factors; (8) In the perioperative period, clinicians should educate caregivers of children with tympanostomy tubes about the expected duration of tube function, the recommended follow-up schedule, and the detection of complications; (9) Clinicians should not encourage routine, prophylactic water precautions (use of earplugs, headbands; avoidance of swimming or water sports) in children with ventilation tubes in children with unilateral or bilateral OME for 3 months or longer (chronic OME) and symptoms likely to develop OME, including but not limited to balance disorders, poor school performance, behavior problems, ear problems, or reduced quality of life, and (2) clinicians may, in at-risk children with unilateral or bilateral OME that is not likely to resolve quickly, such as caused by a type B tympanogram (flat) or persistent effusion for 3 months or longer (chronic OME), insert a tympanostomy cannula.

title: Clinical practice guidelines for severe Alzheimer's disease
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although severe Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a widespread, serious, and costly public health problem, few practice guidelines exist to assist physicians in managing this condition. METHODS: A search of English-language medical databases was conducted from 1996 to the present for articles related to the management of AD. This review focused on studies that included patients with severe disease. The studies were evaluated considering the subjects, the study design, the analysis and the results. The recommendations were based on the best available evidence. RESULTS: Severe AD can be reliably defined and diagnosed using measures of cognition, function, behavior and global staging. Specific assessments would also include the health, safety and health of the caregiver. Disease specific treatment would include treatment with cholinesterase inhibitors and/or memantine. Treatment of neuropsychiatric symptoms begins with nonpharmacological behavioral and environmental approaches. Severe agitation, aggression, and psychosis that are potentially dangerous to the patient, caregiver, and others in the environment can be treated with atypical antipsychotics, bearing in mind their increased risk of cerebrovascular adverse events and mortality. All pharmacological approaches require careful monitoring and regular periodic reassessments to determine if continued treatment is needed. CONCLUSIONS: Evidence-based guidelines for the management of severe AD have the potential to improve the quality of life for patients and their caregivers. Further randomized controlled trials specifically targeting this phase of the disease are still urgently needed.

title: Clinical practice guidelines for improving shared decision-making about the use of assistive devices in home care: a pilot intervention study
abstract: This study examines whether clinical practice guidelines (CPG) for the introduction of assistive devices (ADs) in home care improve shared decision-making about the use of ADs and alter their social-cognitive correlates. The data was collected in an intervention study with a quasi-experimental design. Questionnaires were collected from 116 home nurses and home caregivers and their 140 clients with disabilities. Significant differences between the intervention and control groups showed that the implementation of guidelines improved the self-reported practice of home care workers and home care workers: the number of intervention methods used increased and the methods were used with increased intensity. In both the intervention group and the control group, nurses' attitudes towards introducing ADs into a shared decision-making process decreased over time. Client reports of caregivers' practice showed marginal agreement with the reports of the caregivers themselves. The complexity of the guideline and a significant time commitment were cited as the main barriers to involving clients in shared decision-making through the experimental guideline. Nonetheless, CPG promises shared decision-making between formal caregivers and people with disabilities in the community regarding AD use. The results indicate that these guiding principles can structure the communication between caregiver and client and support caregivers in promoting the self-determination of clients in dealing with their disability.

title: Clinical Practice Update: Expert Report on Endoscopic Bariatric Therapies
abstract: BACKGROUND & AIMS: Several endoscopic bariatric therapies (EBTs) are currently being evaluated or in clinical use in the United States. EBTs are well positioned to fill an important gap in the treatment of obesity and metabolic diseases. The purpose of this expert report is to keep gastroenterologists informed about these therapies and to provide practical advice on how to integrate them into clinical practice. METHODS: The evidence reviewed in this work is a distillation of a comprehensive search of multiple English-language databases and a manual review of relevant publications (including systematic reviews and conference abstracts). Best practice advice 1: EBTs should be considered in patients with obesity who have failed to reduce or maintain weight loss through lifestyle interventions. Best Practice Advice 2: EBTs can be used in patients with severe obesity as a bridge to traditional bariatric surgery. They can also be used as a bridge to allow for unrelated procedures that cannot be performed due to weight restrictions (e.g. orthopedic surgery, organ transplantation). Best Practice Advice 3: Clinicians should use EBTs as part of a structured weight loss program that includes nutritional interventions, exercise therapy, and behavior modifications in both the active weight loss phase and the long-term maintenance phase. Best Practice Advice 4: Clinicians should screen all potential EBT candidates with a comprehensive assessment for medical conditions, comorbidities, and psychosocial or behavioral patterns that contribute to their condition before enrolling patients in a weight loss program that includes EBTs. Best Practice Advice 5: Clinicians incorporating EBTs into their clinical practice should prospectively follow patients to capture the impact of the EBT program on weight and weight-related comorbidities and any associated adverse events. Poor responders should be identified and offered detailed evaluation and alternative therapy. Best Practice Advice 6: Clinicians beginning to integrate EBTs into their clinical practice should have a thorough understanding of the indications, contraindications, risks, benefits, and outcomes of individual EBTs, as well as a working knowledge of the risks and benefits of alternative therapies related to obesity. Best Practice Advice 7: Institutions should establish specific policies, applied consistently across disciplines, to grant privileges in EBTs that reflect the necessary knowledge and technical skills a clinician must achieve before earning privileges to conduct them procedure received.

title: Deviations in clinical practice with reduced fetal movements
abstract: BACKGROUND: Reduced fetal movements imply high-risk pregnancy. This condition occurs in a significant proportion of pregnancies, but the quality of information and clinical care varies. MATERIAL AND METHODS: All maternity wards in Eastern Norway and Bergen registered all consultations for reduced fetal movements as part of the international collaborative project “Fetal Movement Intervention Assessment” (Femina). From 23,933 births, 1200 pregnancies were examined. In 1043 pregnancies, the mother had spontaneously expressed concern about "restricted fetal movements" and these were included in the analyses. Results are presented with a 95% confidence interval. RESULTS: Asphyxia, death, growth restriction or preterm birth occurred in 19.6% 22.6%) of cases ranging between 9.1% and 26.5% between units. Standard procedures varied widely." Sonography was used in 39.0% to 98.6% and Doppler in 4.5% to 74.6% of cases. There was a correlation between the results and the methods used. Women who waited 24 hours with reduced or absent movements before contacting health services were at increased risk. Forty-seven percent (42-52%) of those with missing movements exhibited such risky behavior. INTERPRETATION: There is a need for quality improvement in the information provided to pregnant women and in the clinical management of affected pregnancies. This could have great health benefits. We propose new guidelines for information and management.

title: clinical practice. Later orthodontic complications caused by risk factors observed in early life
abstract: Primary preventive oral health strategies are an essential public health priority. Pediatricians have frequent contact with families during routine checkups during the child's early years and are in an ideal and unique position to advise families on the prevention of oral disease in their children. Primary prevention is always recommended in very young children to promote positive outcomes in childhood and later adulthood. The knowledge that pediatricians acquire about orofacial growth can improve the implementation and ultimate success of a prevention program. Given the widespread lack of orthodontic knowledge among pediatricians, this article describes the most common and characteristic symptoms that are common in the early stages of child development and are easily recognizable by clinicians. Because of its multifactorial origin, it is difficult to define preventative strategies to prevent malocclusion. However, there are some recognized behaviors that should be discouraged to allow for ideal craniofacial development and some that require early orthodontist referral. The following disorders are easily diagnosed by the pediatrician or parent and represent conditions where early intervention may be warranted to prevent possible future orofacial dysfunction: differential sucking habits persisting beyond age 3, mouth breathing, and significant deviations from established tooth eruption standards. It is recommended that early referral to a pediatric dentist or orthodontist is indicated if any of these conditions occur. In general, measures to prevent deformities should be based on providing good incentives to promote normal growth and development of the face and eliminating possible disorders that can affect these processes.

title: Clinical memories associated with echocardiographic reports from patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction increase beta-blocker use: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background – Although beta-blockers are known to prolong survival in patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction, they are often underused. We hypothesized that a reminder attached to the echocardiography report would increase the use of beta-blockers in patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction. METHODS AND RESULTS—We randomized 1546 consecutive patients with <45% left ventricular ejection fraction detected on echocardiography in 1 of 3 laboratories to beta-blocker use reminder or no reminder. Patients were excluded from the analysis if they died within 30 days of randomization (n = 89), were off medication through the Veterans Affairs system at 30 days (n = 180), or in > 1 laboratory (n = 6) underwent echocardiography. The primary endpoint was the prescription of an oral beta-blocker between 1 and 9 months after randomization. The mean age of the 1271 included patients was 69 years; 60% had a history of heart failure and 51% were receiving beta-blocker treatment at the time of echocardiography. More patients randomized to reminder received a subsequent beta-blocker prescription (74%, 458 of 621) compared to those randomized to no reminder (66%, 428 of 650; P=0.002). The effect of the reminder was not significantly different for subgroups based on patient status (inpatient versus outpatient) or prior beta-blocker use. Conclusions - A reminder attached to the echocardiography report enhanced the use of beta-blockers in patients with impaired left ventricular systolic function.

title: Clinical research on interventional pain management techniques: the clinician's perspective
abstract: Interventional pain management techniques are considered for patients whose pain proves refractory to conventional management. According to the guidelines of evidence-based medicine (EBM), the highest level of evidence for the efficacy and safety of a treatment is generated in high-quality randomized controlled trials and systematic reviews. A randomized controlled trial is defined as an experiment to determine the impact of an intervention on the natural history of the disease, meaning that the comparison group should receive a placebo, which in the case of interventional pain management techniques is a sham intervention. The systematic overview summarizes the results of the available information in a structured way. When randomized controlled trials are available, observational studies are often discarded. As new information about a treatment becomes available, the perceived value can change and thus determine the survival time of clinical evidence. This survival time does not differ when based on randomized or non-randomized studies. The inclusion criteria are an important part of the randomized controlled trial and are intended to test a treatment in a homogeneous patient population. Because interventional pain management techniques are primarily used to treat spinal pain, it must be emphasized that there is no gold standard for diagnosis. This lack of validated standard diagnostic procedures is the reason for different patient selection criteria, which makes the interpretation of the different randomized controlled trials and the meta-analyses very difficult. In addition, the translation of randomized controlled trials with carefully selected patient populations to daily practice is a major problem. Randomized controlled trials of interventional pain management techniques often prove underpowered, due to the difficulty in motivating patients and referring physicians to participate in a trial where there is a 50% chance of receiving a placebo/sham treatment for intractable pain obtain. In addition, the validity of sham interventions as a reflection of the natural course of the disease is questioned. It is concluded that any new technique should prove at least as effective as the best available treatment option, which offers the opportunity to compare two groups both receiving active treatment. The reference treatment may be a pharmacological or a rehabilitation (cognitive behavior) program, in which case blinding becomes a problem. It has been shown that large observational studies with a cohort or case-control design do not systematically overestimate the magnitude of associations between exposure and outcome compared to the results of randomized controlled trials. There is an urgent need for guidelines on conducting prospective cohort studies, which should be designed to confirm or refute the anecdotal findings from retrospective studies.

title: Clinical risk management in psychiatry
abstract: This paper addresses suicide and violence against others, which are currently the issues of greatest concern in risk management in mental health services. Most of the psychiatric claims managed by Harvard Medical Institutions' Risk Management Foundation over a 12-year period involved cases involving suicide, attempted suicide, or violence against self or others.'

title: Clinical risk prediction for preeclampsia in nulliparae: development of a model in an international prospective cohort
abstract: OBJECTIVES To develop a predictive model for preeclampsia based on clinical risk factors for nulliparous women and to identify an at-risk subgroup for whom referral to a specialist might be indicated. DESIGN Prospective multicenter cohort. SETTING Five centers in Auckland, New Zealand; Adelaide, Australia; Manchester and London, United Kingdom;' and Cork, Republic of Ireland. PARTICIPANTS 3572 "healthy" nulliparous women with a singleton pregnancy from a large international study";" Pregnancy outcome data were available for 3529 (99%). KEY OUTCOME MEASUREMENT Preeclampsia, defined as ≥ 140 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 90 mm Hg, or both, on at least two occasions four hours apart after 20 weeks gestation but before the onset of labor or after delivery, either with proteinuria or a multisystem complication. Pre-eclampsia was defined as women with pre-eclampsia who were delivered before 37 (+0) weeks gestation. In the stepwise logistic regression, women without preeclampsia were the comparison group. RESULTS Of the 3529 women, 186 (5.3%) developed preeclampsia, including 47 (1.3%) premature preeclampsia. Clinical risk factors in the 14th-16th gestation were age, mean arterial blood pressure, body mass index (BMI), family history of preeclampsia, family history of coronary artery disease, maternal birth weight, and vaginal bleeding for at least five days. Factors associated with reduced risk were a previous single miscarriage with the same partner that lasted at least 12 months before becoming pregnant, high fruit consumption, cigarette smoking, and alcohol consumption in the first trimester. The area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) was 0.71 when validated internally. Adding uterine artery Doppler indices did not improve performance (internal validation AUC 0.71). A framework for referral to a specialist was developed based on a model-generated probability of preeclampsia of at least 15% or an abnormal uterine artery Doppler waveform in a subgroup of women with single risk factors. Nine percent of nulliparae would be referred to a specialist, of which 21 percent would develop preeclampsia. The relative risk of developing preeclampsia and premature preeclampsia in women referred to a specialist compared to standard of care was 5.5 and 12.2, respectively. CONCLUSIONS The ability to predict preeclampsia in healthy nulliparous women based on clinical phenotype is modest and requires external validation in other populations. If validated, it could provide a personalized clinical risk profile for nulliparous women, to which biomarkers could be added. Test registration ACTRN12607000551493.

title: Cluster-randomized controlled trial of tailored interventions to improve management of female urinary tract infections and sore throat.
abstract: Aim: To evaluate the effectiveness of tailored interventions to implement guidelines for female UTI and sore throat Design: Unblinded, cluster-randomized pretest-post-test study Setting: 142 general practices in Norway Participants: 72 practices received interventions to implement guidelines for UTI and 70 practices received sore throat policy implementation interventions that served as controls for each other. 59 practices in the urinary tract infections group and 61 practices in the sore throat group completed the study. Outcomes were measured at 16,939 sore throat consultations and 9,887 urinary tract infection consultations. Interventions: Interventions were developed to address identified barriers to implementation of the guidelines. Key components of the tailored interventions included patient educational materials, computer-assisted decision-making and reminders, an increase in the fee for telephone consultations, and interactive courses for GPs and practice assistants antibiotics. Women with UTI symptoms in the intervention group were 5.1% less likely to have a laboratory test ordered. No significant differences between the groups were found for the other endpoints. Large differences were found between the included practices in rates of antibiotic prescribing, use of laboratory tests and telephone consultations, and in the magnitude of change for all three outcome measures Practice switch

title: Cluster-randomized study of a multifaceted decision support intervention in primary care for hereditary breast cancer risk.
abstract: Background. GPs are increasingly expected to meet the needs of patients concerned about their risk of inherited breast cancer, but may lack the skills or confidence to apply complex treatment guidelines. We have developed an evidence-based, multi-faceted intervention designed to promote confidence and skills in this area. objective. To evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention in improving primary care physicians' confidence in the treatment of patients concerned about genetic risk of breast cancer. methods. Design. Cluster randomized controlled trial. Setting. General practices in the Grampian region of Scotland. Subjects. GPs and the patients they referred for genetic counseling for breast cancer risk. main target parameter. GP self-reported confidence in four genetics-related activities; referral rates of patients at increased genetic risk; and referred patients' understanding of cancer risk factors. Results. No statistically significant differences were observed between the intervention and control arms in the primary or secondary endpoints. A possible effect of the intervention on the proportion of referred patients with an increased risk could not be ruled out. Only a small proportion of the intervention physicians took part in the training, knew the software or used it in practice. Conclusions. No convincing evidence of the intervention's effectiveness was found, likely due to barriers to its use in routine practice.

title: Cluster-randomized study of a multi-level, evidence-based quality improvement approach to adapting VA patient-aligned care teams to the needs of female veterans
abstract: Background The Veterans Health Administration (VA) has undertaken a major initiative to transform care through the introduction of Patient Aligned Care Teams (PACTs). Based on the concept of the Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH), PACT aims to improve access, continuity, coordination and completeness through team-based care that is patient-focused and patient-centered. However, how VA should adapt PACT to meet the needs of special populations such as female veterans (WVs) was not considered in the initial implementation guidelines. WVsÂ¡Â¯ numeric minority in VA healthcare facilities (approximately 7Â¨C8% of users) creates logistical challenges for the delivery of gender-biased comprehensive care. The primary objective of this study is to test an evidence-based quality improvement (EBQI) approach to tailor PACT to the needs of WVs, to include comprehensive primary care services and gender-sensitive care in gender-sensitive settings, thereby accelerating the achievement of PACT Principles for Women (WomenÂ¡Â¯ s Health (WH)-PACT). Methods/Design EBQI is a systematic approach to developing a multi-level research-clinic partnership that involves senior organizational leaders and local quality improvement (QI) teams in adapting and implementing new models of care in the context of prior evidence and local practice conditions, with researchers providing technical support , formative feedback and practice facilitation. In a 12-site, cluster-randomized study, we will assess the performance of the WH-PACT model through patient, provider, staff, and practice surveys and analyzes of secondary administrative and chart-based data. We will examine the impact of receiving WH-PACT care on the quality of chronic disease treatment and prevention, health status, patient satisfaction and experience of treatment, provider experience, utilization, and cost. Using mixed methods, we will assess the pre- and post-practice contexts; document the EBQI activities carried out in the participating institutions and their relationship to providers/staff and team actions/attitudes; document WH-PACT implementation;' and explore barriers/intermediaries to EBQI-assisted WH-PACT implementation through a combination of semi-structured interviews and monthly formative progress reports and administrative data. Discussion The lack of gender-sensitive comprehensive care has shown implications for the technical quality and assessment of care at WVs and may contribute to decisions to continue use or to seek treatment elsewhere under the US Affordable Care Act. We envision that EBQI's tailored PACT implementation can improve the experience and quality of care at many levels.

title: Cluster-randomized studies for pharmaceutical practice research
abstract: Introduction Cluster randomized trials (CRTs) are now the gold standard in health services research, including pharmacy-based interventions. Studies on behavior, epidemiology, lifestyle changes, educational programs, and healthcare delivery models leverage the power of cluster-randomized analysis. Methodology The key property of CRTs is the unit of randomization (cluster), which may differ from the unit of analysis (individual). The sample size of subjects, and ideally the number of clusters, is determined by the relationship between between-cluster and within-cluster variability. The correlation between participants recruited from the same cluster is called the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC). In general, more clusters with smaller ICC values result in smaller sample sizes. When selecting clusters, stratification prior to randomization can be helpful to reduce imbalances between study arms. Participant recruitment methods may differ from other types of randomized trials because blinding of a behavioral intervention is not always possible. When to use CRTs can provide results relevant to "real world" decisions. CRTs are often used in non-therapeutic intervention studies (eg, change in practice guidelines). The advantages of the CRT design in pharmaceutical research lie in the avoidance of contamination and the generalizability of the results. In this manuscript, a large CRT that investigated cooperative management of hypertension between physicians and pharmacists is used as a CRT example. The study, titled "Collaboration Among Pharmacists and medics To Improve Outcomes Now (CAPTION)" was conducted in the US in general practitioner offices for hypertensive patients. Limitations Limitations of the CRT design include the need for large numbers of clusters, high cost, increased training, increased monitoring, and statistical complexity.

title: Cluster-randomized, controlled study on computer-aided decision support for the selection of long-term antithrombotic therapy after acute ischemic stroke.
abstract: Background: The identification of appropriate long-term antithrombotic therapy after acute ischemic stroke is a challenging area in which computer-based decision support can help. Aim: To evaluate the impact on prescribing practice of a computerized decision support system (CDSS) that provided patient-specific estimates of expected ischemic and hemorrhagic vascular event rates under each potential antithrombotic therapy. Design: Cluster randomized controlled trial. METHODS: We recruited patients presenting for an initial evaluation for ischemic stroke or TIA symptoms, excluding patients with poor prognosis or serious contraindications to anticoagulation. After observation of routine prescribing practice (6 months) at each hospital, centers were randomized to either control (observed routine practice) or intervention (practice observed while the CDSS provided patient-specific information) for 6 months. We compared the risk reduction (estimated by the CDSS) in ischemic and hemorrhagic vascular events achieved by long-term antithrombotic therapy between control and intervention centers and the proportions of subjects prescribed the optimal therapy identified by the CDSS. RESULTS: Sixteen hospitals recruited 1,952 subjects. When the CDSS provided information, the mean relative risk reduction achieved by prescribing increased by 2.7 percent units (95% CI -0.3 to 5.7) and the odds ratio for prescribing optimal therapy was 1, 32 (0.83 to 1.80). Approximately 55% (5/9) of the physicians believed that the CDSS had influenced their prescription. Conclusions: Cluster-randomized studies offer excellent framework for the evaluation of novel clinical management methods. Our CDSS was feasible and acceptable to clinicians, but did not have a significant impact on prescribing practice for antithrombotic drugs after acute ischemic stroke.

title: COACH Study: A Randomized Controlled Trial of Cardiovascular Disease Risk Reduction by Nurses/Community Health Workers in Urban Health Centers: Rationale and Design
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite well-publicized guidelines on appropriate management of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and type 2 diabetes, implementation of risk-reduction practices remains inadequate. This paper describes the rationale and design of a randomized controlled clinical trial to evaluate the comparative efficacy of a comprehensive cardiovascular disease risk reduction program conducted by nurse (NP)/healthcare worker (CHW) teams to improved usual care in improving the proportion of patients in urban community health centers meeting national guidelines recommended targets for lipids, blood pressure, HbA1c and appropriate medication prescription. METHODS: The COACH (Community Outreach and Cardiovascular Health) study is a randomized controlled trial in which patients at accredited community health centers were randomly assigned to one of two groups: extensive intensive management of CVD risk factors for one year by an NP / CHW team or an extended control group for usual care. RESULTS: A total of 3899 patients were evaluated for eligibility and 525 randomized. The groups were similar at baseline for sociodemographic and clinical characteristics, with the exception of statistically significant differences in total cholesterol and hemoglobin A1c. CONCLUSIONS: This study is a novel amalgam of tiered interdisciplinary strategies for transferring highly effective therapies to low-income, government-funded health centers that care for patients who bear a disproportionate burden of cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and uncontrolled cardiovascular risk factors. The impact of such an intervention in a community clinic is potentially enormous.

title: Code of Conduct for the Clinical Evaluation of Authorized Medicinal Products in General Medicine
abstract: KIE: A Code of Practice for the Clinical Evaluation of Authorized Medicines by General Practitioners has been developed jointly by the British Medical Association, the Royal Society of General Practitioners and the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry. The new code, reproduced here in full, outlines the reasons why drug evaluations are required outside of hospitals"; defines the roles of pharmaceutical companies, ethics committees and investigators; lists items to be included in research protocols;" and provides policies on confidentiality, disclosure of results and compensation.

title: Cognitive behavioral therapy for chronic insomnia: a systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: Background: Because psychological approaches are likely to provide sustained benefits without the risk of tolerance or side effects associated with pharmacological approaches, cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-i) is now widely recommended as the first-line treatment for chronic insomnia. Purpose: To determine the effectiveness of CBT-i on diary measurements of nocturnal sleep in adults with chronic insomnia. Data Sources: Searches of MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsycINFO, CINAHL, the Cochrane Library and PubMed Clinical Queries from inception through March 31, 2015, supplemented by manual screening. Study selection: Randomized controlled trials evaluating the efficacy of face-to-face, multimodal CBT-i versus inactive comparators on nocturnal sleep in adults with chronic insomnia. Studies on insomnia comorbid with medical, sleep or psychiatric disorders were excluded. Data Extraction: Study characteristics, quality and data were assessed independently by 2 reviewers. Main outcome measures were sleep onset latency (SOL), waking up after sleep onset (WASO), total sleep time (TST), and sleep efficiency (SE%). Data Synthesis: Among 292 citations and 91 reviewed full-text articles, 20 studies (1162 participants [64% female; mean age 56 years]) were included. Approaches to CBT-i included at least 3 of the following: cognitive therapy, stimulus control, sleep restriction, sleep hygiene, and relaxation. At the time of post-treatment, SOL improved by 19.03 (95% CI, 14.12 to 23.93) minutes, WASO by 26.00 (CI, 15.48 to 36.52) minutes, TST by 7.61 ( CI, -0.51 to 15.74) minutes and SE% improved by 9.91% (CI, 8.09% to 11.73%). Changes seemed to be maintained at later dates. No side effects have been reported. Limitation: Narrow inclusion criteria limited applicability to patients with comorbid insomnia and other sleep problems, and the accuracy of estimates at later time points was less clear. Conclusion: CBT-i is an effective treatment for adults with chronic insomnia with clinically meaningful effect sizes. Primary Funding Source: None. (PROSPERO registration number: CRD42012002863)

title: Cognitive-behavioral therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder in women
abstract: Context The prevalence of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is increased in women who have done military service, but no previous study has examined the treatment of PTSD in this population. Previous research suggests that cognitive behavioral therapy is a particularly effective treatment for PTSD. Aim To compare prolonged exposure, a form of cognitive-behavioral therapy, with presence-centered therapy, a supportive intervention, for the treatment of PTSD. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS A randomized controlled trial of female veterans (n=277) and active-duty personnel (n=7) with PTSD recruited from 9 VA medical centers, 2 VA readjustment counseling centers, and 1 military hospital from August 2002 to October 2005. Intervention Participants were randomly assigned to prolonged exposure (n=141) or presence-centered therapy (n=143), delivered according to standard protocols in 10 weekly 90-minute sessions. Main Outcome Parameters The severity of symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder was the primary endpoint. Comorbid symptoms, functioning, and quality of life were secondary endpoints. Blinded reviewers collected data before and after treatment, and at 3 and 6 months follow-up. Results Women who received longer exposure experienced greater reductions in PTSD symptoms compared to women who received present-centered therapy (effect size 0.27 in; p=0.03). longer meet PTSD diagnostic criteria (41.0% vs. 27.8%; odds ratio 1.80; 95% confidence interval 1.10-2.96; P=0.01) and achieve complete remission (15.2 % vs 6.9%, odds ratio 2.43, 95% confidence). interval, 1.10-5.37;" P = 0.01). Effects were consistent over time in longitudinal analyzes although in cross-sectional analyzes most of the differences occurred immediately after treatment. Conclusions Prolonged exposure is an effective treatment for PTSD in female veterans and active duty military personnel It is possible to implement prolonged exposure in a range of clinical settings.

title: Cognitive-behavioral therapy vs. zopiclone for the treatment of chronic primary insomnia in older adults
abstract: Context Insomnia is a common condition affecting older adults and is associated with a range of adverse medical, social, and psychological consequences. Previous research has indicated positive outcomes from both psychological and pharmacological treatments, but blinded placebo-controlled studies comparing the effects of these treatments are lacking. Aim To investigate the short- and long-term clinical efficacy of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacological treatment in older adults with chronic primary insomnia. Design, setting and participants A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study in 46 adults (mean age 60.8 years; 22 women) with chronic primary insomnia conducted between January 2004 and December 2005 in a single outpatient at a Norwegian university clinic for Adult and elderly patients Intervention CBT (sleep hygiene, sleep restriction, stimulus control, cognitive therapy, and relaxation; n=18), sleep medication (zopiclone 7.5 mg each night; n=16), or placebo drug (n=12) total treatment duration 6 weeks, and the 2 active treatments were followed up at 6 months -wave sleep (assessed by polysomnography only) on all 3 assessment items Results CBT resulted in improved short- and long-term outcomes compared to zopiclone on 3 out of 4 outcome measurements For most outcomes, zopiclone differed not r of placebo. Participants receiving CBT improved their sleep efficiency from 81.4% at pre-treatment to 90.1% at 6 months follow-up, compared with a decrease from 82.3% to 81.9% in the zopiclone group. Participants in the CBT group spent much more time in slow wave sleep (stages 3 and 4) compared to those in other groups and spent less time awake during the night. Total sleep time was similar in all 3 groups; after 6 months, patients receiving CBT had better sleep efficiency with polysomnography than patients taking zopiclone. Conclusion These results suggest that CBT-based interventions are superior to zopiclone treatment for both short- and long-term treatments. Treatment of insomnia in older adults.

title: Cognitive Debiasing 2: Obstacles and Strategies to Change
abstract: In a companion article, we suggested that cognitive debiasing is a skill essential to developing sound clinical reasoning to reduce the incidence of diagnostic failure. We reviewed the origins of cognitive bias and some proposed mechanisms of how debiasing processes might work. In this paper, we first outline a general scheme of how cognitive changes occur and the limitations that may apply. We review a variety of individual factors, many of which are themselves biases that can impede change. We then examine the main strategies developed in the social sciences and medicine to achieve cognitive and affective debiasing, including the important concept of function forcing. The abundance and variety of approaches that exist in the literature and in individual clinical areas highlight the difficulties inherent in achieving cognitive change and also the need for such interventions. Ongoing cognitive debiasing is arguably the most important trait of the critical thinker and well-calibrated mind. We outline three groups of proposed interventions for the future: educational strategies, workplace strategies, and coercive functions. We emphasize the importance of environmental and contextual influences on the quality of individual decision-making and the need to consider factors known to affect decision-maker calibration. We also emphasize the importance of introducing these concepts and the concomitant development of critical thinking training in undergraduate medical education.

title: Cognitive debiasing through sparklines in clinical data displays
abstract: Sparklines, embedded contextual information graphics, can help reduce diagnostic errors by highlighting trends in data, simplifying cognitive tasks, and providing context for decision making. Application examples for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, cardiac catheterization and pediatric viral diseases illustrate the concept. Sparklines are ideal in situations where the limited textual representations of the data obscure interpretation, the graphics support interpretation of the data, and the graphics guide decision-making.

title: Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia in cancer patients
abstract: Sleep-wake disorders, particularly insomnia, are among the most common and debilitating symptoms that cancer patients suffer from. As a result of extensive interdisciplinary research conducted since 2000, cognitive behavioral therapy is now considered the standard of care for the management of insomnia in the general population and has also been upgraded to probably effective in the Oncology Nursing Society Putting Evidence category "weight of evidence". " in the doctor's office. Cognitive behavioral therapy is a multicomponent psychological and behavioral treatment designed to eliminate the persistent factors of insomnia. The most commonly used strategies are stimulus control, sleep restriction and relaxation therapies, paradoxical intention, sleep hygiene, and cognitive restructuring. Although this recommendation for treating insomnia has been well publicized, the nursing literature has not effectively translated the theories and principles of cognitive behavioral therapy into practical guidelines or considerations for use by oncology nurses and advanced physicians. This article attempts to demystify cognitive behavioral therapy and provide a basis for caregivers at various levels of practice to evaluate and potentially implement this promising insomnia intervention.

title: Cognitive behavioral therapy, imipramine, or their combination for panic disorder
abstract: Context Panic disorder (PD) can be treated with medication, psychosocial interventions, or both, but relative and combined efficacy has not been assessed unbiasedly. Aim To assess whether drug and psychosocial therapies for Parkinson's are each more effective than placebo, whether one treatment is more effective than the other, and whether combination therapy is more effective than either therapy alone. Design and Framework Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical study conducted from May 1991 to April 1998 in 4 anxiety research clinics. Patients A total of 312 patients with Parkinson's were included in the analysis. Interventions Patients were randomized to treatment with imipramine up to 300 mg/day only (n=83); cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) only (n=77); placebo only (n=24); CBT plus imipramine (n=65) or CBT plus placebo (n=63). Patients were treated weekly for 3 months (acute phase); Responders were then followed monthly for 6 months (maintenance phase) and then followed up for 6 months after treatment discontinuation. Main Outcome Measures Treatment response based on Panic Disorder Severity Scale (PDSS) and Clinical Global Impression Scale (CGI) by treatment group Results Both imipramine and CBT were significantly superior to placebo in the acute treatment phase as determined by the PDSS Intent-to-treat [ITT] analysis, 45.8%, 48.7%, and 21.7%; p=0.05 and p=0.03, respectively, but were not significantly different for the CGI (48 .2%, 53.9%, and 37.5%, respectively) After 6 months of maintenance therapy, imipramine and CBT were significantly more effective than placebo r both the PDSS (response rates, 37.8%, 39.5%, and 13.0%, respectively ; P=0.02 for both) and CGI (37.8%, 42.1%, and 13.0%, respectively). Among the responders, imipramine produced a higher quality response. The acute response rate for the combined treatment was 60.3% for the PDSS and 64.1% for the CGI; none differed significantly from the other groups. The 6-month maintenance response rate for the combination therapy was 57.1% for the PDSS (p=0.04 versus CBT alone and p=0.03 versus imipramine alone) and 56.3% for the CGI (p=0 .03 versus imipramine alone), but not significantly better than CBT plus placebo in either analysis. Six months after stopping treatment, the CGI response rates in the ITT analysis were 41.0% for CBT plus placebo, 31.9% for CBT alone, 19.7% for imipramine alone, 13% for placebo, and 26.3% for CBT in combination with imipramine. Conclusions The combination of imipramine and CBT appeared to confer a limited benefit acutely but a greater benefit at the end of maintenance. Each treatment worked well immediately after treatment and during maintenance.” CBT appeared durable in follow-up.

title: Collaborative care for depressed patients with chronic illness: a randomized study in Puerto Rico
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study investigated whether a collaborative care model for depression would improve clinical and functional outcomes for depressed patients with chronic systemic illnesses in primary care practices in Puerto Rico. METHODS: A total of 179 primary care patients with major depression and chronic systemic diseases were randomly assigned to collaborative or usual care. The collaborative care intervention included enhanced collaboration between physicians, mental health specialists, and care managers, coupled with depression-specific treatment guidelines, patient education, and follow-up. In usual care, the study staff informed the patient and the healthcare provider about the diagnosis and encouraged the patients to discuss treatment options with their healthcare provider. Depression severity was assessed using the Hopkins Symptom Checklist";" Social functioning was assessed using the 36-item short form. RESULTS: Compared to usual care, cooperative care significantly reduced depressive symptoms and improved social functioning in the six months after randomization. The integration of collaborative care into primary care practices has significantly increased the use of mental health services by depressed patients. CONCLUSIONS: Collaborative care improved clinical symptoms and functional status in depressed patients with co-existing chronic systemic diseases who received anti-depressant treatment in primary care offices in Puerto Rico. These findings underscore the promise of the collaborative care model in strengthening the relationship between mental health and primary care services in Puerto Rico.

title: Collaborative management to achieve treatment guidelines. Impact on depression in primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To compare the effectiveness of a multifaceted intervention in patients with depression in primary care versus the effectiveness of "usual care" provided by the general practitioner. DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial in primary care patients with major depressive disorder or minor depressive disorder. PATIENTS: Over a 12-month period, a total of 217 primary care patients classified by their primary care physicians as depressed and willing to take antidepressants were randomized, with 91 patients meeting criteria for major depression and 126 for mild depression. INTERVENTIONS: Intervention patients received increased intensity and frequency of visits (visits 1 and 3 to a general practitioner, visits 2 and 4 to a psychiatrist) for the first 4 to 6 weeks of treatment and continuous monitoring of adherence to medication regimens during the continuation and maintenance phases the treatment. Patient education at these visits was supplemented with videotaped and written material. KEY OUTCOME MEASUREMENTS: Primary outcome measures included short-term (30 days) and long-term (90 days) use of antidepressants at recommended doses, satisfaction with overall treatment for depression and antidepressants, and reduction in depressive symptoms. RESULTS: In patients with major depression, the intervention group demonstrated greater adherence than the usual care control group for 90 days or longer (75.5% vs. 50.0%; p<0.01) on appropriate dosing of antidepressant quality of care, for depression as good to excellent (93.0% vs. 75.0%; P<0.03) and rated antidepressants as somewhat to very helpful (88.1% vs. 63.3%; P<0.03). 0.01) 74% of the intervention patients with major depression showed an improvement of 50% or more on the Symptom Checklist-90 Depressive Symptom Scale compared to 43.8% of the control group (P < 0.01), and the intervention patients also showed a significant improvement greater decrease in depression severity over time compared to controls (P < 0.004) In patients with mild depression, the intervention group demonstrated significantly greater adherence versus the control group to appropriate dosing of antidepressants for 90 days or more (79.7 % vs. 40.3%; P<0.001) and were more likely to rate antidepressants as somewhat helpful to very helpful (81.8% vs. 61.4%; P<0.02). However, no significant differences were found between the intervention and control groups in the percentage of patients who were satisfied with the treatment of their depression (94.4% vs. 89.3%), in the percentage in which the depressive symptoms improved 50% or more decreases, or decreases in depressive symptoms over time of cooperative treatment by primary care physician and a consultant psychiatrist, intensive patient education, and monitoring of continuous antidepressant replenishment improved adherence in patients with major and mild depression, improved the Treatment satisfaction and led to more favorable depression outcomes in patients with major but not minor depression.

title: Collaborating to Improve Childhood Obesity Practice in Rural Clinics: the Healthy Eating Active Living Telehealth Community of Practice (HEALTH COP)
abstract: This study evaluated the effects of participation in a virtual quality improvement (QI) learning network on adherence to clinical guidelines for childhood obesity prevention in rural clinics. A total of 7 primary care clinics in rural California that are part of the TeleHealth Community of Practice for Healthy Eating and Active Living and 288 children treated at these clinics for good child care participated in this prospective, before-and-after, observational study. Clinics participated in a virtual QI learning network over 9 months to implement best practices and share improvement strategies. After the intervention, documentation of weight determination and counseling increased significantly. Children cared for by physicians who directed delivery of the intervention at their clinic showed significant improvements in diet and physical activity. Virtual QI learning networks in geographically dispersed clinics can significantly improve clinician compliance with childhood obesity guidelines and increase access to recommended care for rural and underserved children.

title: Collective action to implement: a realistic assessment of organizational collaboration in healthcare
abstract: Background Increasingly, it is suggested that translation gaps could be eliminated or reduced by bringing research users and producers closer together, a theory that is largely untested. This paper reports on a national study to fill a gap in the evidence on the conditions, processes and outcomes related to collaboration and implementation. Methods A realistic longitudinal evaluation using several case studies with qualitative methods was carried out with three Collaborations for Leadership in Applied Health Research in Care (England). Data was collected over four rounds of theory development, refinement, and testing. Over 200 participants were involved in semi-structured interviews, non-participant observation of events and meetings, and stakeholder engagement. A combined inductive and deductive data analysis process focused on refinement of the proposition and iterative testing over rounds of data collection. Findings The quality of existing relationships between colleges and local health services and views on whether implementation was a collaborative act created a path dependency. Where implementation was perceived as remote from the service and lacking in organizational links, this led to a focus on knowledge production and transfer rather than co-production. Collaborative architectures were counterproductive because they did not facilitate connectivity and had emphasized professional and epistemic boundaries. More distributed leadership was associated with greater potential for engagement. Creating cross-border roles was the most visible investment in implementation, and credible individuals in these roles led to cross-border work, facilitation and direct impact. The gap between academia and practice played out strongly as a context for motivation to engage, as ¡Â®whatÂ¡Â¯s in it for me¡Â¯ led to different levels of engagement along a collaborative-collaborative continuum. Learning within and between collaborations was patchy, depending on the emphasis placed on assessment. Conclusions These collaborations did not emerge from a vacuum and they took time to learn and develop. Her life cycle began with her position on Collaboration, Knowledge and Execution. More effective attempts at collective action at implementation could be determined by the conscious alignment of a range of characteristics, including underlying relationships, vision, values, structure and processes, and views on how to work together and implement.

title: Admission to colonoscopy in high-risk individuals with a family history of colorectal neoplasia: A multicenter, randomized study of tailored advice versus standard information
abstract: BACKGROUND: Colonoscopic screening is recommended for first-degree relatives of patients diagnosed with colorectal cancer (CRC) or colorectal adenomatous polyps (CAP) before age 60. This has the potential to reduce CRC-related morbidity and mortality, but uptake is currently insufficient. METHODS: The aim of the study was to compare the effectiveness of standard information versus a nurse-led tailored intervention aimed at promoting uptake of colonoscopy screening by siblings of CRC or CAP patients. A randomized controlled trial was conducted. Digestive surgeons and gastroenterologists recruited index patients who developed CRC or CAP before age 60. All index patients received standard screening information for their siblings according to current guidelines. Centrally computerized randomization of index patients resulted in all their siblings being assigned to the same group, intervention, or control. The tailored intervention initially targeted the index patient to help them relay information to their siblings. The nurse then provided the siblings with tailored information based on their responses to a self-questionnaire examining health behaviors and derived from psychosocial prevention models. The siblings then received a personalized information brochure to hand over to their general practitioner. The primary endpoint was the rate of documented colonoscopies performed on siblings within 1 year of the index patient's diagnosis. The intent-to-treat analysis included siblings who refused to participate in the study. Statistical analysis was adjusted for intra-familial correlation. RESULTS: A total of 304 siblings of 125 index patients were included: 160 in the intervention group and 144 in the control group. The uptake of a colonoscopy among siblings was 56.3% in the intervention group and 35.4% in the control group (p = 0.0027). The respective rates after eliminating rejections were 69.2% and 37.0% (P<0.0001). More lesions were detected in the intervention group (1 invasive cancer and 11 advanced adenomas versus 5 advanced adenomas; P=0.022). CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates the effectiveness of a nurse-led, tailored intervention designed to promote uptake of colonoscopy screening by siblings of patients diagnosed with CRC or CAP before age 60. Such tailored interventions, also involving physicians, should help reduce CRC-related mortality.

title: Combined diet and physical activity promotion programs for the prevention of type 2 diabetes among those at increased risk: A systematic review for the Community Prevention Services Task Force
abstract: Background: Studies have shown the effectiveness of programs that promote a strict diet and physical activity in reducing the incidence of diabetes and improving glycemic scores in adults at increased risk for type 2 diabetes. Purpose: To evaluate diet and physical activity promotion programs for people at increased risk of type 2 diabetes, mainly to reduce the risk of diabetes and to reduce body weight and blood glucose levels. Data sources: MEDLINE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, CAB Abstracts, Global Health and Ovid Health-STAR from 1991 to February 27, 2015, without language restriction. Study selection: 8 investigators reviewed articles for single group or comparative studies of combined diet and physical activity programs of at least 2 sessions for at least 3 months in participants at increased risk for type 2 diabetes. Data extraction: 7 investigators extracted data on study design, participant, intervention and outcome descriptions; and Outcomes and assessed study quality. DATA SYNTHESIS: 53 studies (30 on diet and physical activity programs vs. usual care, 13 on more intense vs. less intense programs, and 13 on individual programs) evaluated 66 programs. Compared with usual care, diet and exercise programs reduced the incidence of type 2 diabetes (risk ratio [RR], 0.59 [95% CI, 0.52 to 0.66]) (16 studies), decreased body weight (net change , -2.2% [ CI, -2.9% to -1.4%]) (24 studies) and fasting blood glucose level (net change, -0.12 mmol/L [-2.2 mg/dL] [ CI, -0.20 to -0.05 mmol/L {-3.6 to -0.9 mg/dL}]) (17 studies) and improved other cardiometabolic risk factors. The evidence for clinical events was limited. More intensive programs were more effective. Limitations: Large differences in diet and physical activity promotion programs limited the identification of the characteristics most relevant to efficacy. Evidence on clinical outcomes and in children was sparse. Conclusion: Combined diet and physical activity programs are effective in reducing the incidence of diabetes and improving cardiometabolic risk factors in at-risk individuals. More intensive programs are more effective.

title: Combination of intensive medical care counseling or brief counseling by the general practitioner with varenicline for smoking cessation in primary care: study protocol of a pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The combination of behavioral support and pharmacotherapy is most effective for smoking cessation and is recommended in clinical guidelines. Although GP support for smoking cessation can be effective, the dissemination of clinical practice guidelines and educational efforts have not resulted in GPs routinely providing smoking cessation advice. Intensive counseling by the practice nurse could contribute to better smoking cessation rates in primary care. However, the effectiveness of intensive counseling by a practicing nurse compared to usual care by a general practitioner in combination with varenicline is not yet known. MATERIALS AND METHODS: A pragmatic, randomized, controlled trial was conducted comparing: (a) intensive individual counseling by a nurse in the office and (b) brief counseling by a general practitioner”; both groups received open-label varenicline for 12 weeks. At least 272 adult daily smokers were recruited and treated in their routine primary care settings. The primary outcome was defined as prolonged abstinence from weeks 9 to 26, validated biochemically by exhaled carbon monoxide. Data were analyzed in a blinded, intention-to-treat fashion, and participants with missing data on their smoking status at follow-up were counted as smokers. Secondary endpoints included: one-year prolonged abstinence, short-term incremental cost-effectiveness, medication adherence, and baseline predictors of successful smoking cessation. DISCUSSION: This study is the first to provide scientific evidence for the efficacy, cost-effectiveness, and possible mechanisms of action of intensive care counseling combined with varenicline in real-world settings. This paper explains the methodology of the study and discusses the pragmatic and/or explanatory design aspects. STUDY REGISTRATION: Dutch Study Register NTR3067.

title: Comfort First: an evaluation of a procedural pain management program for children with cancer
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Comfort First (CFP) program provides children and their caregivers with early procedural pain management to reduce procedural pain and distress. This study evaluated whether the CFP was meeting its objectives and effectively implementing the Royal Australasian College of Physicians' guidelines for pediatric pain management. Methods: The study was conducted as a single site cross-sectional audit. One hundred and thirty-five patients (mean age 7.7 years) treated at the Royal Children's Hospital, Melbourne, Children's Cancer Center Day Oncology Unit were followed. Procedural aspects related to the treatment room, caregiver and staff behavior, child distress, and use of pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions were recorded using an audit tool developed for the study. RESULTS: The treatment room was regularly quiet and prepared before the child entered. The mean procedure time was 8 minutes. The mean waiting time for the procedure was 54 minutes. At least one nurse was usually present during the procedure. Comfort First (CF) clinicians were more likely to be present at procedures involving a significantly distressed child. Caregivers, nurses, and CF clinicians generally exhibited comfort-promoting behavior. Local anesthetic was used regularly. Non-pharmacological supports were used frequently, especially distraction. Patients younger than 8 years were significantly more likely to receive non-pharmacological support and to have a nurse and CF doctor present.
