Age was a significant predictor of stress, with higher stress rates in younger children. CONCLUSIONS: The CFP was found to be effective in implementing procedural pain guidelines. Regular audits are recommended to ensure compliance with pain management standards.

title: Coping with challenging behaviors: a cluster-randomized controlled trial of the effects of a multidisciplinary care program on challenging behaviors in dementia
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The Grip on Challenging Behavior care program was developed using current guidelines and models for dealing with challenging behavior in dementia in nursing homes. It was hypothesized that use of the nursing program would result in a decrease in challenging behavior and prescription of psychotropic drugs without an increase in the use of restraints. DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial was conducted using a step wedge design to implement the care program and assess the effects. Challenging behavior and psychoactive medication assessments were conducted at all participating units every 4 months, followed by the initiation of the care program in a group of 3 to 4 units. A total of 6 time measurements took place in 20 months. SETTING: Seventeen dementia specialty wards from various nursing homes. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 659 residents of special dementia wards. All residents with dementia on the ward were included. Units were assigned by random assignment software to 1 of 5 groups with different starting points for the implementation of the care program. INTERVENTION: A care program consisting of various assessment procedures and tools that ensure a multidisciplinary approach and structure the process of dealing with challenging behavior in dementia. MEASUREMENTS: Challenging behavior was measured using the Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory (CMAI) and the Neuropsychiatric Inventory. Research assistants (blind to the ward's intervention status) interviewed nurses on the wards about challenging behaviors. Data on psychoactive drugs and coercive measures were extracted from patient records. Results: A total of 2292 assessments were carried out on 659 residents (1126 control measurements, 1166 intervention measurements). The group of residents remaining in the intervention condition compared to the group in the control condition differed significantly in CMAI change scores between consecutive assessments [-2.4 CMAI scores, 95% confidence interval (CI) -4.3 to - 0.6]. No significant effects were found for the control-to-intervention group compared to the group that remained in the control group (0.0 CMAI points, 95% CI -2.3 to 2.4). Significant effects were seen in 5 of the 12 neuropsychiatric inventory entries and in the use of antipsychotics (odds ratio 0.54, 95% CI 0.37-0.80) and antidepressants (odds ratio 0.65, 95% CI 0.44). -0.94) found. No effect on the use of fixations was observed. CONCLUSIONS: The Grip on Challenging Behavior program was able to reduce some forms of challenging behavior and the use of psychotropic drugs.

title: Communicating with paediatricians: developing the practice of social work in primary care
abstract: While social work models of interdisciplinary collaboration suggest that communication is important, the research literature on social worker-physician collaboration rarely considers working with pediatricians or practices outside of the hospital setting. A cross-sectional survey was sent to a stratified random sample of social workers to determine their satisfaction with communication with pediatricians. The study found that social workers in health care facilities were more satisfied than those in mental health facilities. The implications of this finding for the development of co-localized, collaborative models of care are discussed.

title: Communication style and exercise compliance in physical therapy (CONNECT): a cluster-randomized controlled trial testing a theory-based intervention to improve patients with chronic low back pain's adherence to physical therapist recommendations: rationale, design, and methods of the study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity and exercise therapy are among the accepted clinical rehabilitation guidelines and are recommended self-management strategies for chronic low back pain. However, many back pain patients do not follow the recommendations of their physiotherapist. Poor patient adherence can reduce the effectiveness of counseling and home rehabilitation exercises. According to self-determination theory, support from healthcare professionals may promote patient self-motivation and greater long-term behavioral persistence (eg, compliance with physical therapist recommendations). The aim of this study is to evaluate the effect of an intervention designed to improve autonomy-supportive communication by physical therapists on adherence to physical activity and exercise therapy recommendations in patients with low back pain. METHODS/DESIGN: This study will be a single-blind, randomized, controlled cluster study. Outpatient physiotherapy centers (N = 12) in Dublin, Ireland (population = 1.25 million) will be randomly assigned to either the experimental or control arm using a computer-generated algorithm. Physiotherapists in the experimental arm (two hospitals and four primary care clinics) participate in an eight-hour communication training session. The training includes handouts, workbooks, video examples, role plays and discussions aimed at teaching physical therapists how to communicate in a way that promotes autonomous patient motivation. Physiotherapists in the control arm of the waiting list (two hospitals and four primary care clinics) do not receive this training. Participants (N=292) with chronic low back pain will complete the assessments at baseline, 1 week, 4 weeks, 12 weeks, and 24 weeks after their first physical therapy appointment. Primary outcomes include adherence to physical therapy recommendations, as well as back pain, function, and well-being. Participants will be blinded to treatment assignment as they will not be told if their physical therapist has received the communication training. Outcome raters are also blinded. We will use linear mixed modeling to test between-arm differences in both means and rates of change of outcome variables. We will use structural equation models to study the change process including assumed mediation effects. DISCUSSION: This study will be the first to test the effect of a self-determination theory-based communication skills training program for physical therapists on the adherence of their patients with back pain to rehabilitation recommendations.

title: Community occupational therapy for elderly patients with dementia and their caregivers: cost-effectiveness study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the cost-effectiveness of community-based occupational therapy versus usual care in elderly patients with dementia and their caregivers from a societal perspective. DESIGN Cost-effectiveness study alongside a single-blind randomized controlled trial. SETTING Memory clinic, day clinic of a geriatric ward and participants' homes. Patients 135 patients aged > or = 65 years with mild to moderate dementia living in the community and their primary caregivers. INTERVENTION 10 sessions of occupational therapy over five weeks, including cognitive and behavioral interventions to train patients on the use of tools to compensate for cognitive decline and caregivers on coping behaviors and supervision. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Incremental cost-effectiveness ratio expressed as the difference in mean total cost of care per successful treatment (ie, a combined patient and caregiver outcome measure of clinically relevant improvement on process, performance, and competency scales) three months after randomization. Bootstrap methods for determining confidence intervals for these measures. RESULTS The procedure cost 1183 euros (£848, $1738) (95% confidence interval 1128 euros (808 pounds sterling, $1657) to 1239 euros (888 pounds sterling, $1820)) per patient per general practitioner at three months. Visits to GPs and hospital doctors cost the same in both groups, but the median total costs were 1748 euros (£1279, $2621) lower in the intervention group, with the largest cost savings occurring in informal care. There was a significant difference in the proportions of successful treatments of 36% at three months. The number required for successful treatment at three months was 2.8 (2.7 to 2.9). CONCLUSIONS Community occupational therapy intervention for patients with dementia and their caregivers is successful and cost-effective, particularly with regard to informal care.

title: Community Outreach and Cardiovascular Health (COACH) Trial: A Randomized Controlled Trial of Cardiovascular Disease Risk Reduction by Nurses/Community Health Workers in Urban Health Centers
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite well-publicized guidelines on appropriate management of cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes, implementation of risk-reducing practices remains inadequate. This report describes the results of a randomized, controlled clinical trial evaluating the effectiveness of a comprehensive program to reduce cardiovascular disease risk, administered by teams of nurses/physicians (NP/CHW), compared to enhanced common care (EUC) to improve lipid and blood pressure, glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) and patient perceptions of the quality of their chronic disease care among patients in urban health centers. METHODS AND RESULTS: A total of 525 patients with documented cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, hypercholesterolemia, or hypertension and LDL-cholesterol, blood pressure, or HbA1c levels that exceeded goals set by national guidelines were randomized to NP/CHW ( n= 261) or EUC (n=264) groups. The NP/CHW intervention included aggressive pharmacological management and tailored educational and behavioral counseling for lifestyle modification and problem solving to remove barriers to compliance and control. Compared to EUC, patients in the NP/CHW group had a significantly greater 12-month improvement in total cholesterol (difference 19.7 mg/dl), LDL-cholesterol (difference 15.9 mg/dl), triglycerides (difference 16.3 mg/dl), systolic blood pressure (difference 6.2 mm Hg), diastolic blood pressure (difference 3.1 mm Hg), HbA1c (difference 0.5%) and perception of the quality of their treatment for chronic diseases (difference 1 ,2 points). CONCLUSIONS: An intervention delivered by an NP/CHW team using individualized treatment regimens based on treat-to-target algorithms can be an effective approach to assess risk factor status and chronic disease treatment perceptions in high-risk patients to improve.

title: Community-based care for the management of type 2 diabetes: an evidence-based analysis
abstract: UNRATIFIED: In June 2008, the Medical Advisory Secretariat began work on the Diabetes Strategy Evidence Project, an evidence-based review of the literature on strategies for successful management and treatment of diabetes. This project arose when the Department of Health and Long-Term Care's Health Systems Strategy Division subsequently asked the Secretariat to provide an evidence platform for the Department's newly published diabetes strategy. The Secretariat identified five key areas where evidence was needed. Evidence-based analyzes were produced for each of these five areas: insulin pumps, behavioral interventions, bariatric surgery, home telemonitoring, and community-based care. For each area, where appropriate, an economic analysis was carried out, which is described in a separate report. To view these titles within the Diabetes Strategy Evidence series, please visit the Medical Advisory Secretariat website, http://www.health.gov.on .ca/english/providers/program/mas/mas_about.html,DIABETES STRATEGY EVIDENCE PLATFORM: Summary of Evidence-Based AnalysesContinuous Subcutan Insulin Infusion Pumps for Type 1 and Type 2 Adult Diabetics: An Evidence-Based AnalysisBehavioral Interventions for Type 2 Diabetes: An Evidence-Based AnalysisBARIATRIC SURGERY FOR PEOPLE WITH DIABETES AND MORBIENT OBESITY: An Evidence-Based SummaryCommunity-Based Care for the Management of Type 2 Diabetes: An Evidence-Based AnalysisHome Telemonitoring for Type 2 Diabetes: An Evidence-Based AnalysisApplication of the Ontario Diabetes Economic Model (ODEM) to determine the cost-effectiveness and budgetary impact of selected type 2 diabetes Interventions in Ontario OBJECTIVE: The objective of this r The report seeks to assess the effectiveness of a specialized multidisciplinary community care for the management of type 2 diabetes compared to usual care. CLINICAL NEEDS: TARGET POPULATION AND CONDITION Diabetes (ie, diabetes mellitus) is a common chronic metabolic disorder that affects the body's ability to produce or use insulin effectively. The majority (90%) of diabetic patients have type 2 diabetes. (1) Based on the United Kingdom Prospective Diabetes Study (UKPDS), intensive glycemic and blood pressure control significantly reduce the risk of microvascular and macrovascular complications in type 2 diabetics. While many studies have documented that patients often fail to meet glycemic control goals set by national and international guidelines, factors related to glycemic control are less well studied, including healthcare provider(s). Multidisciplinary treatment approaches can be particularly important in diabetes management. According to Canadian Diabetes Association (CDA) guidelines, the diabetes health care team should be multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary. Currently, the core team of diabetes health care in Ontario consists of at least one general practitioner and/or diabetes specialist and diabetes educator (Registered Nursing and Registered Nutritionist). Strengthening the role of healthcare professionals in diabetes care and collaborating with physicians may represent a more cost-effective option for diabetes management. Several systematic reviews and meta-analyses have examined multidisciplinary care programs, but these have either been limited to a specific component of multidisciplinary care (e.g., intensified educational programs) or have been implemented as part of a broader disease management program, not all of which have been multidisciplinary in nature. Most reviews also do not clearly define the intervention(s) of interest, making evaluation of such multidisciplinary community programs difficult. EVIDENCE-BASED METHODS OF ANALYSIS: RESEARCH QUESTIONS: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of specialized multidisciplinary outpatient care provided by at least one registered nurse, one registered dietitian and one physician (primary care and/or specialist) for the management of type 2 diabetes compared to usual care is carried out? [Hereafter referred to as Model 1] What is the evidence of the effectiveness of specialized multidisciplinary community care provided by at least one pharmacist and one general practitioner for the management of type 2 diabetes compared to usual care? [Hereinafter referred to as Model 2] INCLUSION CRITERIA: English language complete reports published between 1 January 2000 and 28 September 2008, randomized controlled trials (RCTs), systematic reviews and meta-analyses, adult patients with type 2 diabetes (>/= 18 years). ) Total sample size >/= 30 Describe specialized multidisciplinary outpatient care, defined as outpatient care provided by at least two health care disciplines (at least one of which must be a specialist in diabetes) with integrated communication between care providers. Compared to usual care (defined as care provided by non-diabetes specialists, such as "primary care providers"; may include referral to other healthcare professionals/services as needed) >/= 6 months of follow-up EXCLUSION CRITERIA: Studies in which discrete Results on diabetes cannot be abstracted Predominantly home interventions Inpatient interventions for (rHbA1c) levels and systolic blood pressure (SBP) SEARCH STRATEGY: A literature search was conducted on September 28, 2008 using OVID MEDLINE, MEDLINE In-Process and Other Non-Indexed Citations, EMBASE, the Cumulative Index to Nursing & Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), the Cochrane Library and The International Agency for Health Technology Assessment (INAHTA) for studies conducted between January 1, 2000 and September 28 Published in 2008. Abstracts were reviewed by a single reviewer, and for studies that met the eligibility criteria met, full-text articles were obtained. Reference lists were also searched for additional relevant studies not identified by the search. Articles with unknown authority were reviewed with a second clinical epidemiologist and then with a panel of epidemiologists until consensus was reached. The quality of the evidence was rated as high, moderate, low, or very low according to the GRADE methodology. Given the high clinical heterogeneity of the items that met the inclusion criteria, specific models of specialized multidisciplinary community care were examined based on models of care currently supported in Ontario, as well as models of care that have been widely reported in the literature. Proposals from one session of the Expert Advisory Panel on January 21, 2009. SUMMARY OF RESULTS: The initial search yielded 2,116 unique citations from which 22 RCT studies and nine published systematic reviews were identified that met the selection criteria. Of these, five studies focused on care provided by at least one nurse, a dietician and a physician (primary care and/or specialist) as a model of care (Model 1; see Table ES 1), while three studies focused on care provided by at least one nurse Pharmacist and general practitioner (Model 2;” see Table ES 2). Based on moderate-quality evidence, specialized multidisciplinary community care model 2 has demonstrated a statistically and clinically significant 1.0% reduction in HbA1c compared to usual care. However, this model of SBP is uncertain compared to usual care, based on evidence from very low-quality Specialized multidisciplinary community care Model 2 has demonstrated a statistically and clinically significant reduction in both HbA1c of 1.05% (based on high-quality evidence) and SBP of 7.13 mmHg (based on moderate-quality evidence) compared to usual care. For either model, the evidence does not suggest a preferred setting of care (ie, primary care vs. outpatient hospital treatment). t-clinic vs. community clinic). Table ES1: Summary of the results of meta-analyses on the effects of the multidisciplinary care model 1ResultEstimate of the effect (95% CI)Heterogeneity I(2)(p-value)GRADEGlysylated hemoglobin (HbA1c [%])-1.00 [-1, 27, -0.73]4% (p=0.37) Intermediate quality subgroup: Intermediate to high quality - 0.91 [-1.19, -0.62]0% (p=0.74) Systolic Blood pressure (mm Hg) -2.04 [-13.80, 9.72 ]89% (p=0.002)Very low quality* Mean change from baseline to follow-up between intervention and control groups Heterogeneity I(2)(p value)GRADEGlyosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c [%])-1.05 [-1.57, -0.52]0% (p=0.75)High qualitySystolic blood pressure (mm Hg)-7.13 [-11, 78, -2.48] 46% (p=0.17) Moderate quality* Mean change between intervention and control groups between baseline and follow-up.

title: Community-based knowledge transfer and exchange: Supporting community-based organizations in linking research with action
abstract: Background Community-based organizations (CBOs) are important actors in health systems and are increasingly being called upon to use research to underpin their advocacy, programming, and service delivery efforts. CBOs are increasingly turning to community-based research (CBR) given their participatory focus and emphasis on linking research and action. To further facilitate the use of research evidence by CBOs, we have developed a community-based knowledge transfer and exchange (KTE) strategy that helps CBOs more effectively link research evidence to action. We developed the strategy by "outlining the primary characteristics of CBOs and why they are important stakeholders in health systems", describing the concepts and methodologies for CBR and CTE, and comparing CBR's efforts to link research findings to actions against which Discussion We find CBR to be particularly effective at developing a framework for community-based KTE that builds on both the strengths of CBR and existing KTE frameworks Foster a climate for the use of research evidence and the production of relevant research evidence on CBOs through community participation However, CBOs are not always as engaged in activities to link research results to larger-scale action or to evaluate these efforts, therefore focuses our strategy for community-based KTE on: an e extended model of 'connection and exchange' (ie producers and users of researchers asking and answering questions together); a greater emphasis on producing and disseminating systematic reviews that address topics of interest to CBOs; Development of a large-scale evidence service consisting of both 'push' and 'pull' facilitation efforts that highlight actionable messages from community-relevant systematic reviews in a user-friendly manner;' and rigorous assessments of efforts to link research evidence to action . Summary This type of strategy can better facilitate and continually refine the use of research evidence for CBO advocacy, program planning, and service delivery efforts through ongoing assessments of its impact.

title: Community-Based Primary Care: Improving and Assessing Diabetes Management
abstract: Morbidity and mortality associated with diabetes make diabetes a priority target for quality improvement research. Quality differences and racial/gender differences persist in this patient population, necessitating sustained improvement in the clinical management of diabetes. The authors of this study aimed to (1) provide a population perspective on diabetes management and (2) strengthen evidence-based clinical guidelines through a web-based educational module. The project also aimed to gain insights into working remotely with a community of rural doctors. This longitudinal pre-post intervention study involved 18 internists and included 3 items of abstraction from medical record data over 24 months. After the basic data abstraction, a web-based education module was introduced. This module contained chapters on clinical training, practice tools and self-assessment. Results showed sustained improvement in most clinical outcomes and demonstrated the effectiveness of using web-based media to strengthen clinical guidelines and change physician behavior.

title: Community-implemented trauma therapy for ex-child soldiers in Northern Uganda
abstract: Context The psychological rehabilitation of former child soldiers and their successful reintegration into post-conflict society are challenges. Despite high rates of impairment, there are no randomized controlled trials examining the feasibility and effectiveness of mental health interventions in former child soldiers. Objective To evaluate the effectiveness of a community-based intervention targeting post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms in formerly abducted individuals. DESIGN, SETTING AND PARTICIPANTS Randomized controlled trial of the recruitment of 85 ex-child soldiers with PTSD from a population-based survey of 1113 Northern Ugandans aged 12-25 years conducted between November 2007 and October 2009 in IDP camps. Participants were randomized into 1 of 3 groups: narrative exposure therapy (n = 29), an academic catch-up program with elements of supportive counseling (n = 28), or a waiting list (n = 28). PTSD symptoms and trauma-related guilt were measured using the Clinician-Administered PTSD Scale. The respective sections of the Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview were used to assess depression and suicide risk, and a locally adjusted scale was used to measure perceived stigma. Symptoms of PTSD, depression, and associated impairments were assessed before treatment and 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months after the intervention. Intervention treatments were delivered in 8 sessions by trained local lay therapists directly in the communities. Main outcome measure Change in PTSD severity grade assessed over 1 year after treatment. Secondary endpoints were depression symptoms, suicidal ideation severity, guilt, and perceived stigma. Results PTSD symptom severity (range 0-148) was significantly more improved in the narrative exposure therapy group than in the academic catch-up group (mean difference in change, ∅ 14.06 [95% confidence interval, ∅ 27.19 to ∅ 0.92 ]) and wait-and-see list (mean difference in change, ?13.04 [95% confidence interval, ?26.79 to 0.72]) groups. Contrast analyzes of the temporal treatment interaction of the mixed effects model of change in PTSD symptoms over time demonstrated a superiority of narrative exposure therapy compared to academic catch-up (F1,234.1 = 5.21, P = 0.02) and waiting times . Listing (F1,228.3 = 5.28, P = 0.02). Narrative exposure therapy produced a larger within-treatment effect size (Cohen d=1.80) than academic catch-up (d=0.83) and waitlist (d=0.81). Conclusion In former Ugandan child soldiers, short-term trauma-focused treatment resulted in greater reductions in PTSD symptoms compared to an academic catch-up program including supportive counseling or a waiting list.

title: Communitywide cardiovascular disease prevention programs and health outcomes in a rural county, 1970-2010
abstract: Significance Few comprehensive cardiovascular risk reduction programs, particularly in low-income rural communities, have sustained community-wide interventions for more than 10 years and demonstrated the effect of improvements in risk factors on reducing morbidity and mortality. Objective To document health outcomes associated with an integrated, comprehensive cardiovascular risk reduction program in Franklin County, Maine, a low-income rural community. Design, setting and participants Forty-year observational study of residents of Franklin County, Maine, a low-income rural population of 22-444 in 1970, using the previous decade as a baseline and comparing Franklin County to other Maine counties state averages. Interventions Community-wide programs targeting high blood pressure, cholesterol and smoking, and diet and physical activity sponsored by several community organizations including the local hospital and clinicians. Main results and measures “resident participation”, detection, treatment and control of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, smoking cessation rates, hospitalization rates from 1994 to 2006 adjusted for median household income, and mortality rates from 1970 to 2010 adjusted for household income and age. Results More than 150,000 individual contacts with county residents over 40 years of age Relevant health indicators improved over time as cardiovascular risk factor programs were added Hypertension control had an absolute increase of 24.7% (95% CI, 21.6% - 27.7% ) from 18.3% to 43.0%, from 1975 to 1978. Later, increased cholesterol control had an absolute increase of 28.5% (95% CI, 25.3% - 31.6%) from 0.4% to 28.9%, from 1986 to 2010 rates improved from 48.5% to 69.5%, better than the national average (Observed?-?Expected [O?-?E], 11.3 %, 95% CI, 5.5%-17.7%, P?<?.001), 1996-2000. These differences later disappeared as Maine's overall smoking cessation rate increased. Franklin County hospitaliz per capita were less than expected for the measured period 1994-2006 (O?-?E, -17 discharges/1000 population; 95% CI -20.1 to -13.9; P?<?.001) . Franklin was the only Maine county with a consistently lower than predicted adjusted mortality rate over the periods 1970-1989 and 1990-2010 (O?-?E, -60.4 deaths/100,000; 95% CI, -97.9 to - 22.8; P?<?.001 and -41.6/100?000; 95% CI, -77.3 to -5.8; P?=?.005). Changes to improve the health of one Maine county's population were associated with a 40-year reduction in hospital admissions and mortality rates compared to the rest of the state. Further studies are needed to assess the generalizability of such programs, particularly to other populations in the US -Counties to assess rural and other parts of the world.

title: Comparative benefits and harms of second-generation antidepressants for the treatment of major depressive disorder
abstract: Background: Second-generation antidepressants dominate the treatment of major depressive disorder (MDD), but the evidence on the comparative benefits and harms of these agents is conflicting. Purpose: To compare the benefits and harms of second-generation antidepressants for the treatment of MDD in adults. Data sources: English-language studies from PubMed, Embase, the Cochrane Library, PsycINFO, and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts from 1980 to August 2011, and reference lists of relevant reviews and gray literature. Study selection: 2 independent reviewers identified randomized studies of at least 6 weeks duration to assess efficacy and observational studies of at least 1000 participants to assess harm. Data extraction: The reviewers abstracted data on study design and conduct, participants, interventions and outcomes, and assessed study quality. A lead reviewer reviewed and endorsed extracted data and quality assessments. DATA SYNTHESIS: Meta-analyses and mixed-treatment comparisons of treatment response and weighted mean differences were performed on specific scales assessing depression. Based on 234 studies, no clinically relevant differences in efficacy or efficacy were identified for the treatment of acute, continuation and maintenance phases of MDD. No differences in efficacy were observed in patients with concomitant symptoms or in subgroups based on age, gender, race, or comorbid conditions. Individual drugs differed in onset of action, adverse events, and some measures of health-related quality of life. Limitations: Most studies were performed in highly selected populations. Publication bias may affect the estimates of some comparisons. Comparisons of mixed treatments cannot definitively rule out differences in efficacy. Evidence within subgroups was limited. Conclusion: The current evidence does not justify the recommendation of any particular second-generation antidepressant based on differences in efficacy. Differences in onset of action and side effects can be considered when choosing a drug.

title: Comparative benefits and harms of second-generation antidepressants: background paper for the American College of Physicians
abstract: Background: Second-generation antidepressants dominate the treatment of major depressive disorder, dysthymia, and subsyndromic depression. Evidence on the comparative benefits and harms is still growing. Purpose: To compare the benefits and harms of second-generation antidepressants (bupropion, citalopram, duloxetine, escitalopram, fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, mirtazapine, nefazodone, paroxetine, sertraline, trazodone, and venlafaxine) in the treatment of depressive disorders in adults. Data sources: MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsychLit, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts from 1980 to April 2007, limited to English language articles. Reference lists of relevant review articles were manually searched and the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research database was searched to identify unpublished research. Study selection: Abstracts and full-text articles were independently reviewed by 2 people. Six previous systematic reviews or meta-analyses of good or reasonable quality were included, as were 155 double-blind, placebo-controlled or directly randomized controlled trials of good or reasonable quality of at least 6 weeks duration. Duration. For harm, 35 observational studies with at least 100 participants and a minimum follow-up of 12 weeks were also included. and results. Data Synthesis: When data were sufficient, meta-analyses of head-to-head studies were performed to determine the relative utility of treatment response and weighted mean differences on specific depression rating scales. When sufficient evidence was not available, adjusted indirect comparisons were performed using meta-regressions and network meta-analyses. Based on 203 studies, second-generation antidepressants did not differ significantly in efficacy or efficacy in treating major depressive disorder";" however, the incidence of specific adverse events and onset of effect varied. There is insufficient evidence to draw any conclusions about the comparative efficacy, efficacy, or harms of these agents for the treatment of dysthymia and subsyndromic depression. Limitation: Adjusted indirect comparisons have methodological limitations and cannot definitively rule out differences in efficacy. Conclusion: The current evidence it does not justify choosing one second-generation antidepressant over another based on differences in efficacy and potency. Other differences in terms of onset of action and side effects may be relevant when choosing a drug.

title: Comparing the effectiveness of audit feedback versus additional physician communication training in improving cancer screening for patients with limited health literacy
abstract: BACKGROUND: We have developed a Continuing Medical Education (CME) program to teach primary care physicians (PCP) how to engage in cancer risk communication and shared decision-making with patients with impaired health literacy (HL). OBJECTIVE: We evaluated whether training primary care physicians in addition to audit feedback improves their communication skills and increases cancer prevention in patients with impaired HL to a greater extent than just providing feedback on clinical performance. DESIGN: 4-year cluster randomized controlled trial. PARTICIPANTS: Eighteen PCPs and 168 patients with limited HL who were overdue for colon/breast/cervical cancer screening. INTERVENTIONS: Communication intervention PCPs received skills training that included standardized patient (SP) feedback on counseling behavior. All GP practices underwent biannual chart audits of patient screening status for up to 24 months and received two annual performance feedback reports. MAIN INTERVENTIONS: PCPs experienced three unannounced SP encounters in which SPs rated PCP communication behavior. We examined differences between groups in changes in SP scores and patients' knowledge of cancer screening guidelines over 12 months, as well as changes in patients' cancer screening rates over 24 months. KEY RESULTS: There were no group differences in SP scores. Ratings of physician communication at baseline At follow-up, PCPs with communication intervention were rated higher in general communication about cancer risks and shared decision-making related to colorectal cancer screening than PCPs who received only performance feedback Screening rates increased in PCP patients in both groups ." However, there were no differences between the groups in screening rates, with the exception of mammography. The communication intervention did not improve patients' knowledge of cancer prevention. CONCLUSION: Compared to pure audit and feedback, PCP communication training improves patient-centered PCP counseling behavior but not cancer prevention in patients with impaired HL. Larger studies need to be conducted to determine whether lack of change in cancer screening is due to clinic/patient sample size or whether communication training is ineffective in changing outcomes.

title: Comparative efficacy and tolerability of 15 antipsychotic drugs in schizophrenia: a multi-treatment meta-analysis
abstract: Background The question of which antipsychotic drug should be preferred for the treatment of schizophrenia is controversial, and traditional pairwise meta-analyses cannot rank based on the randomized evidence. Our aim was to integrate the available evidence to create hierarchies of comparative efficacy, risk of discontinuation for all reasons, and major side effects of antipsychotics.";" Background The question of which antipsychotic drug should be preferred for the treatment of schizophrenia is controversial, and traditional pairwise meta-analyses cannot rank based on the randomized evidence. Our aim was to integrate the available evidence to create hierarchies of comparative efficacy, risk of discontinuation for all reasons, and major side effects of antipsychotics.

title: Comparative effectiveness of measures to promote hand hygiene in the hospital: systematic review and network meta-analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the relative effectiveness of the World Health Organization 2005 Campaign (WHO-5) and other interventions in promoting hand hygiene among healthcare workers in hospitals and summarize associated resource use information. DESIGN Systematic review and network meta-analysis. DATA SOURCES Medline, Embase, CINAHL, NHS Economic Evaluation Database, NHS Center for Reviews and Dissemination, Cochrane Library and the EPOC Registry (December 2009 to February 2014)”; Studies included in previous systematic reviews (1980-2009) REVIEW METHODS Studies included were randomized controlled trials, non-randomized trials, controlled before-and-after studies, and interrupted time-series studies investigating an intervention to improve adherence to hand hygiene by healthcare professionals in hospital settings and to Measurement of compliance or appropriate proxies implemented for it met predefined qualitative inclusion criteria Primary data were re-analyzed when studies had not used appropriate analysis methods Random effects and network meta-analysis were performed for studies reporting directly observed hand hygiene compliance when compared to interventions as were considered sufficiently homogeneous and participants extracted information on the resources required for the intervention and divided into three stages. RESULTS Of 3639 studies retrieved, 41 met the inclusion criteria (six randomized controlled studies, 32 interrupted time series, one non-randomized study and two controlled before-after studies). Meta-analysis of two randomized controlled trials showed that adding goals to WHO-5 was associated with improved compliance (pooled odds ratio 1.35, 95% confidence interval 1.04 to 1.76; I(2) = 81%) . Of 22 pairwise comparisons from interrupted time series, 18 showed a stepwise increase in hand hygiene compliance, and all but four showed a trend of increasing compliance after the intervention. The network meta-analysis indicated considerable uncertainty regarding the relative effectiveness of interventions, but still provided evidence that WHO-5 is effective and that compliance can be further improved by adding interventions such as goal setting, reward incentives, and accountability . Nineteen studies reported clinical outcomes; The resulting data was consistent with clinically meaningful reductions in infection rates that result from improved hand hygiene for some, but not all, major hospital pathogens. Reported intervention costs ranged from US$225 to US$4669 (£146 to £3035; £204 to £4229) per 1000 bed days. CONCLUSION Promotion of hand hygiene with WHO-5 is effective in increasing compliance among healthcare workers. Adding goal setting, reward incentives, and accountability strategies can lead to further improvements. Reporting on the resources required for such interventions remains poor.

title: Comparing the cost effects of two quality strategies to improve testing design in primary care: a randomized trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the costs and cost reductions of an innovative strategy to improve GP test ordering routines compared to a traditional strategy. DESIGN: Multicenter randomized controlled trial with group-level randomization of local GPs. SETTING: Primary care: Local groups of GPs in five regions of the Netherlands with diagnostic centers. STUDY PARTICIPANTS: Twenty-seven existing local GP groups, including 194 GPs. INTERVENTION: The test ordering strategy was developed systematically, combining feedback, policy education, and small-group quality improvement sessions. In regular quality meetings in local groups, GPs mutually discussed test order behavior, related it to guidelines and created individual and/or group plans for changes. Thirteen groups participated in the entire strategy (full intervention arm), while 14 groups received only feedback (feedback arm). MAIN OUTCOME MEASUREMENT: Ongoing costs, development costs and research costs were calculated for the intervention period per general practitioner per 6 months. The average costs of ordered tests per primary care physician for 6 months were assessed at baseline and at follow-up. RESULTS: The new strategy cost 702.00 while the feedback strategy cost 58.00. When only ongoing costs were taken into account, the intervention cost 554.70, compared with 17.10 per GP and 6 months in the feedback arm. Excluding the opportunity costs for the doctors' time, the intervention costs were 92.70 per doctor per 6 months in the entire intervention arm. The average cost reduction that physicians in this arm achieved by reducing unnecessary testing was 144 greater per physician per 6 months than physicians in the feedback arm (p=0.048). CONCLUSION: Based on our findings, including the expected non-monetary benefits, we recommend further long-term impact and cost-effectiveness studies on the implementation of the quality strategy.

title: To compare the effectiveness of staff and domestic staff instruction in an intervention to improve hypertension management
abstract: PURPOSE: To determine whether a resident physician can be as effective as a faculty opinion leader in changing physician adherence to a hypertensive practice guideline. METHOD: In a general internal medicine clinic affiliated with an internal medicine education program, sequential charts were reviewed for patients with uncontrolled or new-onset hypertension routinely assessed over a two-week period. Subsequently, 23 providers were randomly assigned to an academic intervention to implement a hypertension practice guideline led by a single second-year Resident Instructor (RI), and 21 providers were assigned to the same intervention led by a single staff member Internists (SI) with an interest in hypertension. The intervention included academic detailing, chart audit with feedback, and behavioral reinforcement. Six weeks later, the chart audit was repeated to assess the change in practice patterns among providers who were taught by the RI compared to those who were taught by the SI. RESULTS: Overall, guideline-compliant management improved from 32% (51/157) to 45% (56/123) (p<0.01) after the intervention. This change was due to improvement in care provided by SI-guided intervention providers: 28% (17/60) to 57% (26/46) (p<0.003). Providers of the RI-guided intervention showed no improvement: 35% (34/97) to 39% (30/77) (p = NS). CONCLUSIONS: This intervention was effective in improving provider adherence to a hypertension practice guideline, but only when guided by a faculty opinion leader. A resident trainer using the same format was unable to change the behavior of the providers.

title: Comparison of strategies to reduce meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus rates in surgical patients: a controlled multicenter intervention study.
abstract: Aim To compare the effect of two strategies (improved hand hygiene vs. methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) screening and decolonization) alone and in combination on MRSA rates in surgical wards. Design Prospective, controlled, interventional cohort study with 6-month baseline, 12-month intervention, and 6-month washout period. Establishment of 33 surgical wards in 10 hospitals in nine countries in Europe and Israel. Participants All patients admitted to the enrolled wards for more than 24 hours. Interventions The two strategies compared were (1) increased promotion of hand hygiene and (2) universal MRSA screening with contact precautions and decolonization (intranasal bathing with mupirocin and chlorhexidine) of MRSA carriers. Four hospitals were assigned to each intervention and two hospitals combined both strategies using targeted MRSA screening. Outcome measures Monthly rates of clinical MRSA cultures per 100 susceptible patients (primary outcome) and MRSA infections per 100 admissions (secondary outcome). A planned subgroup analysis for clean surgical wards was performed. Results After accounting for clustering and potential confounders, neither strategy was associated with significant changes in MRSA rates when used alone. The combination of both strategies was associated with a 12% reduction in the rate of clinical MRSA cultures per month (adjusted incidence rate ratios (aIRR) 0.88, 95% CI 0.79 to 0.98). On clean surgery wards, strategy 2 (MRSA screening, contact precautions, and decolonization) was with decreasing rates of clinical MRSA cultures (15% monthly decrease, aIRR 0.85, 95% CI 0.74 to 0.97) and MRSA infections (17% monthly decrease, aIRR 0.83, 95% CI 0.69 to 0.99). Conclusions On surgical wards with relatively low MRSA prevalence, a combination of improved standard and MRSA-specific infection control approaches was required to reduce MRSA rates. Delivering individual interventions was not effective except in clean operating rooms, where MRSA screening coupled with contact precautions and decolonization was associated with significant reductions in clinical MRSA culture and infection rates.

title: Comparing the instructional effectiveness of web-based CME to live interactive CME workshops: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: CONTEXT: Despite evidence that a variety of continuing medical education (CME) techniques can promote behavior change in physicians, there have been no randomized trials comparing the performance outcomes of physicians who participated in internet-based CME versus physicians who participated in a live -CME intervention with documented approaches to be effective. OBJECTIVE: To determine whether Internet-based CME can produce changes comparable to those achieved by live, small-group, interactive CME in physician knowledge and behaviors that impact patient care. DESIGN, SETUP AND PARTICIPANTS: Randomized controlled study conducted from August 2001 to July 2002. Participants were 97 general practitioners from 21 practice centers in Houston, Texas, including 7 community health centers and 14 private group practices. A control group of 18 physicians from the same centers received no intervention. INTERVENTIONS: Physicians were randomly assigned to an internet-based CME intervention that could be completed in multiple sessions over a 2-week period, or to a single, live, small-group interactive CME workshop. Both included similarly multi-faceted teaching approaches that have proven effective in live settings. The content was based on the guidelines of the National Institutes of Health National Cholesterol Education Program - Adult Treatment Panel III. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Knowledge was assessed immediately before the intervention, immediately after the intervention, and 12 weeks later. The percentage of high-risk patients who had adequate lipid panel screening and guideline-compliant pharmacotherapeutic treatment was documented with chart audits conducted over a 5-month period before the intervention and over a 5-month period after the intervention. RESULTS: Both interventions resulted in similar and significant immediate and 12-week knowledge gains, representing a large increase in the percentage of correct items (pretest to posttest: 31.0% [95% confidence interval {CI}, 27.0% - 35.0 %]", pre-test at 12 weeks: 36.4% [95% CI, 32.2%-40.6%]; P or = 93%) without significant post-interventional change However, the internet-based intervention was associated with a significant increase in Proportion of high-risk patients associated with pharmacotherapy according to guidelines (preintervention 85.3%; postintervention 90.3%; P=0.04).CONCLUSIONS: A properly designed, evidence-based online CME can produce objectively measured behavioral changes and sustained knowledge gains comparable to those or superior to that achieved through effective live activities.

title: Comparison of three methods of recalling patients for influenza vaccination.
abstract: Despite recommendations supporting annual influenza vaccination for people aged 65 and over, vaccination rates remain low. Several studies have examined the effect of sending reminder emails, but few have compared alternative ways of reminding patients to be vaccinated. In one from 23.10. In a randomized study conducted between December 31, 1984 and 939 patients over the age of 65 in four family practices, we compared three ways of reminding elderly patients about the vaccination: personal reminder by the doctor, reminder by telephone by the nurse and reminder by letter. The vaccination rates for the three groups were 22.9%, 37% and 35.1%, respectively. No reminder was issued to a control group and the rate was 9.8%. Some patients could not be reached by phone, others did not come to the doctor during the specified time. Among the patients the nurse actually contacted, the vaccination rate was 43.5%";" the rate for patients the doctor actually saw was 45.1%. Overall, a telephone reminder by the nurse was the most effective method, and at $16 an hour or less, it would also be the least expensive method. The reminders used in this study were automatically generated from a computerized medical record system. The study shows how a computerized system can be used to identify patients who are due for preventive measures.

title: Competence Network "Community Acquired Pneumonia" (CAPNETZ). A first interim report
abstract: Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) is a disease with high morbidity and mortality in Germany. However, there is no reliable data on the spectrum and resistance of pathogens, the course of the disease, evidence-based treatment guidelines and pathogen-host interactions. The Federal Ministry of Education and Research recognized these deficits and therefore decided to fund CAPNETZ, a competence network for community-acquired pneumonia. On the one hand, CAPNETZ integrates components of health research as well as clinical and basic research (horizontal network) and supports the cooperation between resident physicians, community hospitals and universities (vertical network). Since October 2002, 1547 patients with CAP have been recruited within the network. Preliminary results suggest that new observations regarding symptoms, spectrum of pathogens involved and treatment modalities will influence the formulation of new guidelines for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia.

title: Competency development in newly trained nurses: Closing the gap between education and practice
abstract: The gap between training a newly qualified nurse to practice and the actual requirements of a newly qualified nurse to practice has long been an accepted fact in nursing. This article describes the development of an intervention from the academic side of the gap to improve the competency of nursing students prior to graduation. The intervention is notable because it was developed in collaboration between academia and practice. The three-pronged intervention included the development of learning modules based on the 10 most common high-risk, high-volume patient conditions, "the development of teachers and trainers in relation to learning strategies to enhance competence development." and sharing products with the 84 nursing schools in Texas.

title: Complementary therapy in allergic rhinitis
abstract: The term complementary/alternative medicine (CAM) describes those therapeutic and diagnostic approaches that differ from conventional allopathic medicine. CAM can include homeopathy, acupuncture, herbal therapy, antioxidant therapy, and numerous holistic or behavioral techniques. Allergists and physicians of all specialties will encounter patients using CAM treatments, making it imperative that they become familiar with the scientific literature surrounding them. Given the high prevalence of allergic diseases and the associated costs of CAM treatments, evidence of CAM therapies is required to establish appropriate guidelines for their use. The effectiveness of CAM modalities should be demonstrated with randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled studies, including monitoring of adverse events. Of all CAM therapies studied for the treatment of allergic rhinitis, some herbal therapies and antioxidants show a trend towards some clinical efficacy. Researchers have yet to determine how these CAM modalities can be integrated into the general treatment paradigm of allergic rhinitis.

title: Complex pharmaceutical care interventions in pulmonary care: Part A. The process and job satisfaction of pharmacists
abstract: AIM: In the IPMP (Pulmonary Medication Profiling Principle) study, tailored pharmaceutical care interventions were provided for pulmonary patients selected for drug consumption deviating from Dutch guidelines. The aim was to solve drug-related problems and improve drug use among patients. This article describes the pharmaceutical care process tailored to the individual problems of the patients in the intervention arm of a randomized controlled trial and defines the care package. Methods: After preselecting patients using the IPMP algorithmic computer tool, trained Dutch community pharmacists conducted structured interviews with patients (aged 13-70 years) in the intervention arm to identify behavior and specific problems with their medication. Based on this identification process, a tailored intervention was constructed, which could include one or more of six pharmaceutical treatment modules. The modules have been grouped into sets that describe the complete program of care for a patient. When necessary, pharmacists consulted patients' doctors to improve the prescribed therapy. After the interventions, medication changes were evaluated with the patients. The medication prescribed and the refill rate were monitored in the pharmacy computer over 1 year. All activities and results were extensively monitored and documented. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Process description, ie number of pharmaceutical supply modules and medication changes provided. pharmacist satisfaction. RESULTS: Tailored interventions were offered to 199 patients at risk of suboptimal drug therapy. A total of 813 pharmaceutical supply modules were carried out and documented and clustered into four different programs. In addition to information and motivation to adhere to the prescribed medication for all 199 patients, a medication change was suggested in 124 cases. In 94 cases, patients and doctors agreed on a change. In 58 of 64 cases, a change of device was agreed, often at the same time as a change of medication. Pharmacists consulted physicians on 100 patients. Pharmacists expressed satisfaction with the pharmaceutical approach to care. CONCLUSION: Due to the extensive documentation, interventions could be fully described. Pharmacists observed better drug use after educating patients or solving their drug-related problems. In cooperation with doctors, the drug treatment could be improved.

title: Complex pharmaceutical care interventions in pulmonary care: Part A. The process and job satisfaction of pharmacists
abstract: In the IPMP (Pulmonary Medication Profile Interventions) study, pulmonary patients selected for drug consumption deviating from Dutch guidelines were offered customized pharmaceutical care interventions. The aim was to solve drug-related problems and improve drug use among patients. This article describes the pharmaceutical care process tailored to the individual problems of the patients in the intervention arm of a randomized controlled trial and defines the care package. After a pre-screening of patients using the IPMP algorithmic computer instrument, instructed Dutch community pharmacists had structured consultations with patients (aged 13-70 years) in the intervention arm to identify behavior and specific problems with their medication. Based on this identification process, a tailored intervention was constructed, which could include one or more of six pharmaceutical treatment modules. The modules have been grouped into sets that describe the complete program of care for a patient. When necessary, pharmacists consulted patients' doctors to improve the prescribed therapy. After the interventions, medication changes were evaluated with the patients. The medication prescribed and the refill rate were monitored in the pharmacy computer over 1 year. All activities and results were extensively monitored and documented. Process description, ie number of pharmaceutical supply modules and medication changes provided. pharmacist satisfaction. Tailored interventions were offered to 199 patients at risk of suboptimal drug therapy. A total of 813 pharmaceutical supply modules were carried out and documented and clustered into four different programs. In addition to information and motivation to adhere to the prescribed medication for all 199 patients, a medication change was suggested in 124 cases. In 94 cases, patients and doctors agreed on a change. In 58 of 64 cases, a change of device was agreed, often at the same time as a change of medication. Pharmacists consulted physicians on 100 patients. Pharmacists were satisfied with the pharmaceutical supply approach. Due to the extensive documentation, interventions could be described in full. Pharmacists observed better drug use after educating patients or solving their drug-related problems. In cooperation with doctors, the drug treatment could be improved.

title: Complexities of fall prevention in the clinical setting: a commentary
abstract: Falls and related injuries and mortality are a growing concern for aging Americans. Effective fall risk management is an intricate process that requires the involvement of both healthcare professionals and older adults for three related actions: (a) early detection to identify risk factors, (b) prescribing tailored interventions, and (c) implementing adherence and compliance Intervention by the older adult. Early identification of fall risk can prevent future falls;" However, the uptake of evidence-based screening and assessment protocols in the clinical setting has been limited. A variety of practice guidelines and financial incentives are available to healthcare professionals to facilitate adoption. However, a gap remains between recommended practices and current clinical activities. This commentary addresses the complexities of fall prevention practices and offers solutions that may facilitate adoption by clinical practice. To this end, this commentary presents two models (i.e., a clinical approach and a financial incentive approach ) to summarize current clinical recommendations and practice guidelines for fall risk management in clinical settings. The various factors driving the adoption of evidence-based fall risk management strategies are described. In this synopsis Later, we will discuss how understanding the various system-wide practice improvement initiatives and the factors driving action in physician groups can facilitate the adoption and implementation of fall risk management behaviors by clinicians. Additional efforts are needed to study and evaluate similar initiatives to adopt and implement fall risk management practices at different entry points into the system (e.g., community settings, patients, caregivers).

title: Compliance with the biopsy recommendations of a prostate cancer risk calculator
abstract: UNDESIGNED: Study type - diagnostics (cohort) Evidence level 2b What is known about this topic? and What does the study add? So far, only a few publications have shown that a predictive model influences the behavior of doctors and patients. To our knowledge, it was not known whether urologists and patients adhered to the recommendations of a prostate cancer risk calculator and their reasons for non-compliance. The European Randomized Study of Screening for Prostate Cancer Risk Calculator (ERSPC RC) recommendations on the need for prostate biopsy were followed in most patients. In most cases of non-compliance with the “no biopsy” recommendation, a PSA value >/= 3 ng/ml was decisive for the decision for a biopsy. Prior to large-scale implementation of the ERSPC-RC in urological practices, it is important to gain insight into the use of guidelines that may conflict with adoption of the RC based on conflicting recommendations. OBJECTIVES: To assess the compliance of urologists and patients with a "no biopsy" or "biopsy" recommendation from the European Randomized Study of Screening for Prostate Cancer (ERSPC) Risk Calculator (RC) and the reasons for non-compliance. Assess determinants of patient compliance. PATIENTS AND METHODS: The ERSPC RC calculates the probability of a positive sextant prostate biopsy (P(posb) ) using serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels, results of digital rectal examination and transrectal ultrasonography, and prostate volume determined by ultrasonography. A biopsy was recommended if P(posb) >/=20%. Between 2008 and 2011, eight urologists from five Dutch hospitals enrolled 443 patients (aged 55 to 75) after a PSA test without a prior biopsy. Urologists calculated P(posb) using RC in the presence of patients and completed a compliance questionnaire. Patients completed a questionnaire on prostate cancer knowledge, attitudes toward prostate biopsy, self-reported health (12-item Short Form Health Survey), anxiety (State Trait Anxiety Inventory-6, Memorial Anxiety Scale for Prostate Cancer), and decision-making measures (Decision Conflict Scale). RESULTS: Both urologists and patients met the RC recommendation in 368 of 443 (83%) cases. When a biopsy was recommended, almost all patients (96%; 257/269) followed, although 63 of the 174 (36%) patients were biopsied against the RC's recommendation. Those who followed a “no biopsy” recommendation had a lower mean P(posb) recommendation than non-compliers (9% vs. 14%; P=3 ng/mL) (78%; 49/63) and patients who because they wanted reassurance (60%; "38/63). CONCLUSIONS: The ERSPC RC recommendations for prostate biopsy were followed in most patients. The RC may therefore be a promising tool to support clinical decision-making.

title: Adherence to Adult Treatment Panel III guidelines for hyperlipidemia in a local outpatient clinic: a retrospective data analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: One in six adults (16.3% of the US adult population) has high levels of total cholesterol, and they are at twice the risk of heart disease compared to people with optimal levels. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate internist compliance with the latest National Cholesterol Education Program Adult Treatment Panel III (NCEP-ATP III) guidelines when treating patients with hyperlipidemia. DESIGN: Retrospective observational study. SETTING: Outpatient clinic, Saint Vincent Hospital, Worcester, Massachusetts. PATIENTS: Patients diagnosed with hyperlipidemia who attended the clinic during a 1-ear period from December 2009 to November 2010 and non-HDL cholesterol management. RESULTS: Seven hundred and seventy charts were reviewed. Only 212 (27.5%) met the inclusion criteria. Analysis of the data revealed better compliance with drug therapy (44% to 77%) and therapeutic lifestyle changes (44% to 83%) compared to follow-up recommendations (22% to 31%). An increase in compliance was also noted across all intervention areas when patients presented with an abnormal lipid profile. LIMITATIONS: Compliance was assessed based solely on electronic medical record documentation and therefore we may underestimate compliance with therapeutic lifestyle changes and follow-up recommendations. CONCLUSION: Internists' compliance in the diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up of patients with hyperlipidemia according to the NCEP-ATP-III guidelines was suboptimal and needs improvement.

title: Comprehensive asthma management for underserved children
abstract: In response to the "asthma epidemic," local organizations in San Francisco formed the Yes We Can Urban Asthma Partnership, which uses a comprehensive medical/social model for pediatric asthma care. The Yes We Can Urban Asthma Partnership reaches high-risk children in a variety of clinical settings: urgent visits, the hospital, a comprehensive specialist asthma clinic and through an expanded community health worker program. This article highlights the initial development, implementation and evaluation of the success of this innovative management program to address the problem of pediatric asthma in underserved urban areas.

title: Computer criticism integrated into daily clinical practice influences physician behavior - a randomized clinical trial with AsthmaCritic
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We developed AsthmaCritic, a non-prying criticism system integrated into GPs' electronic medical records. The system is based on the guidelines for asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) issued by the Dutch College of General Practitioners. This paper assesses the impact of AsthmaCritic on the monitoring and management of asthma and COPD by Dutch general practitioners in everyday practice. METHODS: A randomized clinical trial in 32 practices (40 Dutch general practitioners) using electronic medical records. AsthmaCritic was administered to an intervention group, while a control group continued to work as usual. The asthma and COPD guidelines, which are routinely distributed by the Dutch College of General Practitioners, were available to both groups. We measured the average number of contacts, FEV 1 (forced expiratory volume) and peak flow measurements per asthma/COPD patient per office";" and the average number of antihistamine, cromoglycate, deptropin, and oral bronchodilator prescriptions per asthma/COPD patient per practice. RESULTS: The number of contacts increased in the age group of 12-39 years. The number of FEV1, peak flow measurements, and proportion of coded measurements increased, while the number of cromoglycate prescriptions decreased in the 12-39 year age group. Conclusions: Our study shows that the AsthmaCritic guideline-based criticism system changed the way physicians observed their patients and, to a lesser extent, their treatment behavior. In addition, physicians changed their data collection habits.

title: Computed tomography of the body: when should it be used?
Computer reminders for chlamydia screening in general practice: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background: Chlamydia reporting is increasing in Australia, and the use of a computer alert prompting GPs to test young women is a potential way to increase opportunistic chlamydia testing. The aim of this study was to determine the effectiveness of a computer alert in general practice on chlamydia testing in young women. METHODS: In 2006, clinics (n=68) in Melbourne, Australia were randomized into 2 groups: The intervention group received a computerized notification prompting the GP to speak to their patient about chlamydia testing, which surfaced when the medical record a 16 - for 24-year-old female was opened"; the control group received no notification. The outcome was whether or not this patient received a chlamydia test at the level of a single consultation with an eligible patient. Fit of a mixed-effects logistic regression model for clustering was used to assess the impact of the alert on the proportion of women tested for chlamydia during the trial period (CI: 9.1, 15.3) (p<0.01) in the intervention group and 8.8 % (95% CI: 6.8, 10.7) to 10.6% (95% CI: 8.5, 12.7) (p<0.01) in the control group Overall, the intervention group had one n by 27% (OR = 1.3; 95% CI: 1.1, 1.4) larger increase in testing. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that alerts alone may not be sufficient to raise chlamydia testing levels high enough to have an impact on population chlamydia burden, but could be included as part of a more complex intervention .

title: Computer reminders to implement preventive care policies for hospital patients.
abstract: Background: Hospitalizations are a preventive option. Objective: To determine whether computer reminders, which have been shown to be effective in our outpatient care setting, increase the delivery of inpatient preventive care. Methods: Randomized, controlled study of the general medical inpatient service of a city, university public hospital. Study participants were 78 domestic workers rotating in the 6 general medical services. The intervention consisted of reminders to physicians printed on round-of-the-day reports of preventive care their patients were eligible for and suggested orders for preventive care provided through the physician's workstations. The guidelines for prevention were derived from the recommendations of the US Preventive Care Task Force. Adherence to preventive care policy and domestic staff attitude to providing preventive care to hospitalized patients were the key outcome criteria. Results: No significant differences were found between intervention and control physicians in overall adherence to prevention guidelines or in the analysis of individual preventive measures. This was true even though most physicians advocated the provision of most types of preventive care to hospitalized patients. Conclusions: Despite previous success in increasing preventive care in the outpatient setting, we have not been able to increase the provision of preventive care during hospital stays with a moderate-intensity intervention. The physicians attending during the hospital stay were not the patient's primary care physicians, which proved to be an important barrier. More intensive interventions or more direct links between inpatient and outpatient providers may be needed to overcome this resistance. Arch Intern Med. 1996";"156:1551-1556

title: Computer screen saver hand hygiene information curbs a negative trend in hand hygiene behavior.
abstract: Background Adequate hand hygiene for medical personnel is the most important measure for infection prevention";" However, compliance is generally low. For-profit messages (i.e., messages that emphasize the benefits of hand hygiene rather than the risks of non-compliance) may be most effective, but have not been tested. Methods The study was conducted in a 27-bed neonatal intensive care unit. We performed a discontinuous time-series analysis of objectively measured hand disinfection events. We used electronic devices in handheld alcohol dispensers that continuously documented the frequency of hand sanitization events. In addition, hand hygiene compliance was directly observed before and after the intervention period. Results The negative trend in hand hygiene events per patient day before the intervention (decrease of 2.3 [standard error, 0.5] per week) changed to a significant positive trend (increase of 1.5 [0.5] per week) after the intervention (P < .001). Direct observations confirmed these results, showing a significant improvement in hand hygiene compliance from 193 of 303 (63.6%) observed hand hygiene events at the pre-test to 201 of 281 (71.5%) at the post-test. Conclusions We conclude that hand hygiene messages displayed on screen savers with gain frames can improve hand hygiene compliance.

title: Computerized Clinical Rating Scales. a review
abstract: While clinically performed symptom rating scales are the most commonly used outcome measures in pharmaceutical research, error variance increases the risk of type II errors in multicenter clinical trials due to poor interrater reliability. Such error variance could obscure true differences between active drug and placebo or between two comparator compounds. One solution to this problem is provided by computerized versions of symptom rating scales originally developed for use by trained clinicians. In this paper, empirical data on the reliability, validity, and equivalence of computer-based rating scales are reviewed. Computer-administered versions of clinically-administered scales are now available for assessment of depression, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and social phobia. Validation studies demonstrate the reliability, validity and equivalence of these scales. Patient response was positive, with patients generally being more honest with the computer and often preferring it to assess sensitive areas such as suicide, alcohol or drug abuse, sexual behavior or HIV-related symptoms. Applications using Interactive Voice Response (IVR) technology facilitate long-term patient monitoring without requiring physician visits to collect data, improve physician accessibility of information, and improve the quality of patient care through more informed decisions. When used in accordance with established ethical guidelines, computers offer a reliable, inexpensive, accessible, and time-efficient means of assessing psychiatric symptoms.

title: Computerized Decision Support for Pediatric Asthma Management: Description and Feasibility of the Stop Asthma Clinical System
abstract: Clinical guidelines can be helpful in managing asthma. Decision Support Systems (DSSs) can improve adherence to clinical guidelines, but typically do not provide physicians with guidance on behavior modification strategies to encourage patient self-management. The Stop Asthma Clinical System (SACS) is a DSS designed for this purpose. To assess feasibility, seven clinicians used SACS to guide well visits in 26 predominantly persistent pediatric asthma patients. Data were collected through surveys and in-depth semi-structured interviews. SACS improved assessment of asthma severity and control, classification and intervention for problems with medications and environmental triggers, and development of an action plan (all p<0.05). Communication between doctor and patient has been improved. The biggest challenge was that SACS increased the visiting hours in the clinic. SACS may improve clinical behavior to improve patient asthma self-management, but further studies are warranted to mitigate time constraints and assess the impact on physician-patient communication and behavior, and clinical outcomes.

title: Computer-aided clinical decision support when ordering medication for patients with renal insufficiency.
abstract: Aim: To determine whether a computer-assisted clinical decision support system that provides real-time, patient-specific recommendations improves the quality of prescribing for patients with renal impairment in long-term care. Design: Randomized study within the long-term wards of a large long-term care facility. Randomization was within blocks by unit type. Alerts related to prescribing medications for residents with renal impairment were displayed to prescribers in the intervention units and hidden but tracked in the control units. Measurement: The proportions of final drug prescriptions that were appropriate were compared between intervention and control units within alert categories: (1) recommended drug doses”, (2) recommended administration frequencies, (3) recommendations to avoid the drug, (4) warning outcomes : Alert rates were nearly equal in the intervention and control units: 2.5 per 1,000 residential days in the intervention units and 2.4 in the control units. The proportions of dose alerts for which final drug prescriptions were appropriate were similar between the intervention and Control units (relative risk 0.95, 95% confidence interval 0.83, 1.1) for the remaining alert categories Significantly higher proportions of final drug prescriptions were appropriate in the intervention units: relative risk 2.4 for maximum frequency (1.4, 4.4) ; 2.6 for drugs to be avoided (1.4, 5.0);" and 1.8 for warnings about capturing missing information (1.1, 3.4). Overall, final drug prescriptions were significantly more appropriate in intervention units—relative risk 1 ,2 (1.0, 1.4) Conclusions: Clinical decision support for physicians prescribing drugs for long-term care users with renal impairment can improve the quality of prescribing decisions.

title: Computational Cholesterol Control in the Community (4C): Addressing the Challenge of Secondary Prevention.
abstract: Background: Dyslipidemia remains underdiagnosed and undertreated in patients with coronary artery disease. The Computer-based Clinical Decision Support System offers an opportunity to close these gaps. Aims: To study the impact of computer-assisted interventions on secondary prevention of CHD[1]. Methods: The CDSS[2] was programmed to automatically identify patients with CHD and assess the availability of an updated lipoprotein profile and treatment with lipid-lowering drugs. The program automatically created computer-generated monitoring and treatment recommendations. Adapted primary hospitals were randomized to intervention (n=56) or standard of care (n=56) arms. Reminders were sent every 4 months to the primary medical teams in the intervention arm to update them with current lipid levels and recommendations for further treatment. Compliance and lipid levels were monitored. The study group included all patients with CAD who were alive at least 3 months after hospitalization. Results: Follow-up was available for 7448 patients with CHD (median 19.8 months, range 6-36 months). Overall, 51.7% of patients were adequately screened and 55.7% of patients adhered to recommended lipid-lowering treatment. A significant decrease in low-density lipoprotein levels was observed in both arms, but was more pronounced in the intervention arm: 121.9 ± 34.2 vs. 124.3 ± 34.6 mg/dL (P<0.02). A significantly lower rate of cardiac readmissions was documented in patients adequately treated with lipid-lowering drugs, 37% vs. 40.9% (P<0.001). Conclusions: This initial review of our data represents a real snapshot in which physicians and CHD patients often fail to follow clinical guidelines, representing a major obstacle to implementing effective secondary prevention. Our automatic EDP-supported reminder system makes it much easier to comply with guidelines and supports comprehensive implementation.

title: Computer-aided decision support based on clinical practice guideline improves adherence to standards of care
abstract: PURPOSE: Clinical guidelines are intended to aid in the management of specific diseases”, however, these guidelines are often neglected in the provision of care at the patient visit To have a practice guideline based decision support system that provides a personalized treatment protocol for each patient using data from the At the clinic, 58 primary care physicians were randomized to receive either a dedicated interview form containing the computer-generated guideline recommendations or a standard interview form. The impact of computer-generated advice on clinical behavior was measured as the rate of adherence to the guideline recommendations. Data from 30 clinicians were analyzed; Data from 28 clinicians were excluded because these clinicians did not meet the predefined criteria for minimum exposure to diabetic care. RESULTS: The Ver Availability of patient management recommendations generated by the decision support system resulted in a two-fold increase in clinical compliance with diabetes mellitus treatment guidelines (P=0.01). The median compliance for the group receiving the referrals was 32.0% versus 15.6% for the control group. CONCLUSION: Decision support based on a clinical practice guideline is a powerful tool to support physicians in the management of diabetics. This decision support system provides a model of how a clinical practice guideline can be computer integrated into the nursing process to help clinicians manage a specific disease by helping them maintain standards of care.
