The use of decision support systems based on clinical practice guidelines could ultimately improve the quality of medical care.

title: Computer-aided decision support for drug dosing in renal failure: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Aim of the study Emergency physicians prescribe several discharge medications that require dose adjustments to patients with renal disease. The hypothesis for this research was that decision support in a computerized prescription entry system would reduce the rate of drug overdosing in patients with renal impairment. Methods This was a randomized, controlled study in an academic emergency department (ED) in which computerized physician order entry was used to write all prescriptions for patients discharged from the emergency department. The sample consisted of 42 physicians who were randomly assigned to the intervention (21 physicians) or control (21 physicians) group. The intervention was a decision aid that provided dosing recommendations for targeted drugs for patients 18 years of age and older when the patient's estimated creatinine clearance was below the threshold for dose adjustment. The primary endpoint was the proportion of targeted drugs that were overdosed. Results At 2,783 (46%) of the 6,015 patient visits, the decision aid had sufficient information to estimate the patient's creatinine clearance. The mean age of these patients was 46 years, 1768 (64%) were female and 1523 (55%) were black. Physicians in the intervention group who overdosed 31 (43%) prescriptions were given decision support 73 times. In comparison, control physicians overdosed a significantly larger proportion of drugs: 34 of 46, 74% (effect size = 31%; 95% confidence interval 14% to 49%; P = 0.001). Conclusion EMS physicians often overdosed drugs that require dose adjustments in renal impairment Computerized entry of physician orders with decision support significantly reduced overdosing of targeted drugs.

title: Computer-assisted decision support to reduce potentially inappropriate prescriptions to elderly patients in the emergency department: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of computer-assisted decision support in reducing potentially inappropriate prescriptions to older adults. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: An academic emergency department (ED) in Indianapolis, Indiana, where computerized physician order entry was used to write all drug prescriptions. PARTICIPANTS: Sixty-three emergency physicians were randomly assigned to the intervention (32 physicians) or control (31 physicians) groups. INTERVENTION: Decision support that advised against the use of nine potentially inappropriate drugs and recommended safer replacement therapies. MEASUREMENTS: The primary outcome was the proportion of ED visits by seniors that resulted in one or more prescriptions for an inappropriate drug. Key secondary endpoints were the proportions of medications prescribed that were inappropriate and intervention physicians' reasons for refusing decision support. RESULTS: The mean age of the patients was 74 years, two thirds were women and just over half were African American. Intervention physicians were given decision support 114 times, who accepted 49 (43%) of the recommendations. Intervention physicians prescribed one or more inappropriate medications in 2.6% of seniors' emergency department visits, compared with 3.9% of visits performed by control physicians (P = 0.02; "odds ratio = 0.55, 95 % confidence interval = 0.34-0.89) The proportion of all prescribed medications that were inappropriate decreased significantly from 5.4% to 3.4% The most common reason for refusing decision support was that the patient did not have any had previous problems with medication CONCLUSION: Computer-assisted physician prescribing with decision support significantly reduces prescribing of potentially inappropriate medications to seniors This approach could be used in other efforts to improve ED care.

title: Computerized reminders to promote cervical screening in the general practice.
abstract: randomized study compared three ways to increase cervical screening rates in women attending a primary care center. Based on computerized medical records, 1,587 women aged 18 to 35 who were overdue for a screening test were enrolled in the study. In a control group, no formal method was used to encourage patients to participate in screening, and 13.7 percent received a test within the study year. In one intervention group, the doctor received a message identifying the women who attended the center for a routine appointment and were due for screening. 16.1 percent were screened. Sending a letter to patients in a second group resulted in a 25.9 percent compliance rate. In a third group, the practice nurse called patients on the phone to advise them to take the test, and 20.0 percent complied. Doctor reminders represent a low-cost, opportunistic approach to reaching women who come to the office by chance, but this approach should be supplemented with telephone or written mailings from women who do not come to the office regularly.

title: Conducting research in community-based care settings: ethical and regulatory implications
abstract: Successful research in community care facilities requires collaboration between facility staff and researchers. Conducting research ethically involves respect for individuals, charity and justice. Research must comply with certain federal regulations and state laws. Interviews with 15 community care facility administrators revealed differences in understanding of how research is regulated and the impact research could have when an facility allows researchers access. A Facility Bill of Rights outlines principles related to the ethical conduct of research and issues to consider when deciding whether to allow researchers access to a facility.

title: confidentiality and research
Congenital rubella syndrome burden in Morocco: a rapid retrospective review
abstract: Background WHO recommends that countries considering the introduction of a rubella vaccine into their immunization program assess their burden of congenital rubella syndrome to determine whether vaccination is warranted. However, there are few guidelines for such assessments in developing countries. We retrospectively estimated the burden of congenital rubella syndrome in Morocco and evaluated our rapid case finding methods.";" Background WHO recommends that countries considering the introduction of a rubella vaccine into their immunization program assess their burden of congenital rubella syndrome to determine whether vaccination is warranted. However, there are few guidelines for such assessments in developing countries. We retrospectively estimated the burden of congenital rubella syndrome in Morocco and evaluated our rapid case-finding methods.

title: Consensus on guidelines for stereotactic neurosurgery in psychiatric disorders
abstract: BACKGROUND: Neurosurgical procedures may be considered in patients with psychiatric disorders who remain refractory to "standard" therapies. Guidelines for safely and ethically conducting such procedures have been previously and independently proposed by various local and regional expert groups. METHODS: To expand on these earlier documents, representative members of continental and international psychiatric and neurosurgical societies have come together to further elaborate and adopt a pragmatic worldwide set of guidelines. These are designed to address a wide range of neuropsychiatric disorders, brain targets, and neurosurgical techniques, while taking into account the cultural and social heterogeneities of the healthcare environment. RESULTS: The proposed consensus document highlights that while stereotactic ablative procedures such as cingulotomy and capsulotomy for depression and OCD are considered “established” in some countries, they still lack level I evidence. It is further noted that deep brain stimulation is still under investigation in all brain targets attempted to date and in all psychiatric or behavioral disorders. Researchers are encouraged to develop randomized controlled trials based on scientific and data-supported rationale for disease and brain target selection. Experienced multidisciplinary teams are imperative to safely and ethically perform any psychiatric neurosurgery, ensuring documented patient refractoryity, proper consent procedures that respect patient capacity and autonomy, multifaceted preoperative as well as postoperative long-term follow-up assessment, and reporting of effects and side effects for all patients. INTERPRETATION: This consensus document on the ethical and scientific conduct of psychiatric surgery worldwide is intended to improve patient safety.

title: Panic disorder consensus statement from the International Consensus Group on Depression and Anxiety
abstract: AIM: To provide primary care clinicians with a better understanding of treatment issues in panic disorder and to guide clinical practice with recommendations for appropriate pharmacotherapy. PARTICIPANTS: The 4 members of the International Consensus Group on Depression and Anxiety were James C. Ballenger (Chairman), Jonathan RT Davidson, Yves Lecrubier and David J. Nutt. Four faculty invited by the Chair also attended: David S. Baldwin, Johan A. den Boer, Siegfried Kasper and M. Katherine Shear. EVIDENCE: The consensus statement is based on the 6 reviews published in this supplement and on the scientific literature relevant to these topics. CONSENSUS PROCESS: Group meetings took place over a period of 2 days. On the first day, the group discussed each review paper and the chair and panelist (Dr. Kasper) identified key issues for further discussion. On the second day, the group discussed these key issues to come to a consensus. After the group sessions, the consensus statement was drafted by the chair and approved by all present. CONCLUSIONS: The consensus statement provides standard definitions of response and remission and identifies appropriate strategies for the management of panic disorder in primary care. Serotonin-selective reuptake inhibitors are recommended as the first-line treatment for 12 to 24 months of treatment. The pharmacotherapy should be withdrawn slowly over a period of 4 to 6 months.

title: Theory of resource conservation and research use in health systems
abstract: Background Health systems face challenges in using research results to improve policy and practice. These challenges are particularly evident in small and underresourced health systems, often located in locations (in Canada and globally) with poorer health conditions. Although organizational resources have been recognized as important for understanding research usage resources, knowledge translation (KT) theories have not been the focus. What resources are broadly required for KT and how does their presence or absence affect research exploitation? In this paper, we consider resource conservation theory (COR) as a theoretical basis for understanding the ability to use research evidence in health systems. Three components of the COR theory are examined in the context of KT. First, resources are needed for research uptake. Second, the risk of resource loss encourages resistance to research exploitation. Third, even in resource-constrained environments, resources can be optimized to build capacity for KT. Methods A scan of the KT literature examined organizational resources needed for research purposes. A multiple case study approach examined the three components of the COR theory outlined above. The multiple case study consisted of a desk review and key informant interviews with members of the research team, including government decision makers and health practitioners, through a retrospective analysis of four previously conducted applied health research studies in a resource-constrained region. Results The literature scan identified organizational resources influencing research use. The multiple case study supported these findings, helped develop a taxonomy of organizational resources, and demonstrated how fears of resource loss can impact research use. Some resources were found to fill other resource deficiencies. Resource requirements varied at different stages of the research exploitation process. Conclusions COR theory contributes to understanding the role of resources in research use, resistance to research use, and potential strategies to improve research use. Resources (and lack thereof) may account for the observed disparities in research uptake across health care systems. This paper provides a theoretical basis for further investigation of the COR-KT ideas and the necessary support for research deployment in resource-constrained environments.

title: Counseling training of nurses for cardiovascular prevention - a randomized study over 2 years duration
abstract: The aim of this study was to increase patient adherence to treatment for hypertension through nurse counseling. 33 nurses were included in the study. In the intervention group (IG), 19 nurses participated in a 3-day inpatient training course on the Stages of Change model, motivational interviewing, and guidelines for cardiovascular prevention and recruited 153 patients. Sixteen nurses in the control group (CG) recruited 59 patients. In both groups, a decrease in systolic and diastolic blood pressure and total cholesterol was observed over the 2 years. heart rate (p=0.027), body mass index (p=0.019), weight (p=0.0001), waistline (p=0.041), low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (p=0.0001), the Waist-to-hip ratio (p=0.024), and perceived stress (p=0.001) decreased sharply in the IG only. After 2 years, 52.6% of the patients in the IG (p = 0.13) reached the target of </= 140/90 mmHg blood pressure compared to 39.2% in the CG. There was a significant (p=0.021) difference between the groups for self-reported physical activity. The positive effects of counseling training on patients' weight parameters, physical activity, perceived stress, and the proportion of patients achieving blood pressure control emphasize counseling training and the use of behavioral models to motivate patients to adhere to treatment.

title: Consumer satisfaction among patients and their GPs about the involvement of nurses in the primary care of patients with urinary incontinence
abstract: BACKGROUND: Urinary incontinence (UI) is a very common problem, but existing guidelines on UI are not followed. To bring care in line with guidelines, we designed an intervention to involve UI nurses in primary care and evaluated this in a randomized controlled trial. In parallel with this intervention, we assessed consumer satisfaction among patients and general practitioners (GPs). Methods: Patients' satisfaction with the care provided by specialist nurses (intervention group) or general practitioners (control group) was measured using a self-completed questionnaire. GPs' views on nurse involvement were measured in a structured telephone interview. RESULTS: Patient satisfaction with nurse care was 8.4 (scale 1-10) versus 6.7 for primary care. Over 85% of patients would recommend the care of a nurse to their best friends, and 77% of GPs found the nurse's role beneficial, giving it an average rating of 7.2. CONCLUSIONS: Although the sample was relatively small and the stability of the results was only tentatively noted, the substitution of UI care from a primary care physician to a specialist nurse seems to be welcomed by both patients and primary care physicians. Small changes such as providing additional UI-specific information and paying more attention to UI (which previously received little attention) would provide an easy tool to stimulate patients to change their behavior in the right direction.

title: Current challenges in education for the nursing profession: education for nursing, midwifery and health visitation
Contemporary Perspectives in Tobacco Cessation: What Oncologists Need to Know
abstract: In the last 5 years there has been a large increase in research on smoking cessation, significantly encouraged by the publication of the 1996 Clinical Practice Guidelines for Treating Tobacco Use and Dependence. These federal guidelines, published by the Agency for Healthcare Policy and Research, provided extensive empirical evidence that tobacco cessation interventions are effective and encouraged routine implementation in healthcare settings. Since then, numerous tobacco cessation studies have increased the body of knowledge on successful smoking intervention modalities. Unfortunately, about a third of cancer-related deaths are still attributed to smoking. It is imperative that healthcare providers encourage and participate in the smoking cessation efforts of their patients and family members. This article provides an overview of the current literature on smoking cessation and describes first-line therapies with proven efficacy in smoking cessation. Physicians are encouraged to screen rigorously for tobacco use and to provide brief interventions of behavioral counseling and pharmacotherapy to manage their patients' tobacco dependence.

title: Emergency management to induce exercise among college students.
abstract: Aim: The effects of contingency management on physical activity induction were investigated in seven non-obese physically inactive undergraduate students by providing cash payments using a multiple baseline, changing criteria procedure. Methods: Participants participated in a baseline phase, a subsequent intervention phase consisting of three training sessions per week for 4 weeks, and a follow-up session 2 weeks after the intervention. A total of $145 was available for attendance and practice payments. Results: Results indicate that all participants significantly increased physical activity during the intervention from inactivity at baseline to three 30-minute sessions per week. Participants maintained some gains during follow-up. Limitations: The study used a small and homogeneous sample size and required participants to train in a laboratory setting, limiting external validity. Conclusions: These results suggest that incentive-based interventions are an effective and feasible means to induce physical activity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Continued driving habits of patients diagnosed with excessive daytime sleepiness
abstract: AIM: To describe the driving behavior of patients with excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) and the impact of diagnosis, therapy, legal guidelines and advice on their driving behavior. DESIGN: Inventory based on questionnaires. SETTING: Center for Sleep and Waking Disorders, The Hague, The Netherlands. Methods: A questionnaire was sent to all patients with EDS who were stable at least 6 months after therapy (n = 138). The questions concerned actual driving behaviour, EDL and the effects of diagnosis, therapy and advice from the centre. RESULTS: The response was 67% (n=92). Eighteen patients had never driven a car. Eighteen of the other 74 patients stopped driving or drove less. 56 patients did not change their behavior or drove even more. There was little impact on driving behavior from diagnosis, therapy and advice to give up driving. Conclusion: Patients with EDS often participate as drivers in modern road traffic. Legal requirements and medical advice have little influence on this behavior. Since general measures appear to be ineffective, approaches tailored to the individual patient may lead to more acceptable outcomes.

title: Controlled study of an audit facilitator on the diagnosis and management of childhood asthma in general practice.
abstract: Objective: To test whether an audit facilitator could change the diagnosis and treatment pattern of childhood asthma. DESIGN: Randomized stratified controlled trial. Surroundings: 12 GP surgeries in Tayside. Subjects: 3373 children aged 1 to 15 inclusive with symptoms suggestive of asthma or possible asthma from a systematic review of 10 725 general practice case files. Intervention: Children were specifically selected for clinical evaluation by their primary care physician or practice nurse. Main Outcome Measures: Asthma-related consultations, prescriptions, hospital visits, and healthcare costs 12 months before and after the study. Results: Compared to the control group (n=1563), the intervention group (n=1585) had more practice-initiated consultations for asthma (relative risk 2.18 (95% confidence interval 1.74 to 2.73)), new asthma diagnoses (2.83 (2.26 to 3.54)), previous diagnoses confirmed (1.30 (1.08 to 1.58)), and they were prescribed more inhaled cromoglycate (1.52 (1.02 to 2.25)). The number of inpatient hospitalizations decreased from 152 to 122 in the intervention group and increased from 69 to 117 in the control group between the year before and the year after the study. The total cost of primary care increased from £30,118 to £37,243 in the intervention group and fell from £29,131 to £27,990 in the control group. Hospital costs fell from £25,406 to £20,727 in the intervention group and rose from £12,699 to £19,650 in the control group. Conclusion: An audit facilitator can positively influence the diagnosis and treatment pattern of childhood asthma in the family practice. This can have an impact on healthcare costs.

title: Controlling conflicts of interest in the doctor-patient relationship: lessons from Moore v. Regents of the University of California
Cooperation between the company health insurance fund and occupational dermatologists: potential for optimization in quality assurance
abstract: BACKGROUND: Quality assurance is a task of the medical profession, but also a duty of the company health insurance company (OHV). Data on the quality of interaction between occupational dermatologists and the OHI are limited. MATERIAL AND METHODS: In October 2013, an online survey of 854 German members of the Working Group on Occupational and Environmental Dermatology was conducted. Items included demographic data, an assessment of the collaboration between dermatologists and OHI companies, an economic classification of the current remuneration scheme, and prioritization of optimization tasks. RESULTS: 182 members (21.3% of the invited population) participated in the survey. The cooperation with the OHI companies was rated as "very good" by 10.8%, "good" by 56.7%, "satisfactory" by 24.2%, "sufficient" by 7.0% and by 1.3% assessed as “unsatisfactory”. 93.4% of those surveyed name problems and potential for improvement in the cooperation between their practice or clinic and OHI companies. The main points of criticism were cost reimbursement (44.7%), followed by impairment of treatment options (36.5%) and delay or extent of treatment in the dermatologist's procedure (29.4%). CONCLUSIONS: While most occupational dermatologists assess their cooperation with OHI companies positively, there is potential for quality optimization in the reimbursement of dermatological services, especially in the time-consuming consultation for the prevention of occupational skin diseases, in the enabling of diagnostics and therapy procedures according to current guidelines and in a timely preventive Intervention to use the therapeutic window before skin diseases can become chronic.

title: Core outcome measurements for laboratory assessment studies of liability in human opioid abuse: IMMPACT recommendations
abstract: critical component in the development of opioid analgesics is the assessment of their abuse liability (AL). The standardization of approaches and measures to assess AL has the potential to facilitate comparisons between studies, research laboratories and medicines. The objective of this report is to provide consensus recommendations on core outcome measures for evaluating the abuse potential of opioid drugs in humans in a controlled laboratory setting. Although many of the recommended measures for assessing the AL of drugs from other drug classes are appropriate, the focus here is on opioid drugs because they present unique risks for both physiological (e.g., respiratory depression, physical dependence) and public health (e.g., B. Individuals) pose in pain) perspectives. A brief historical overview of AL testing is provided, and then those measures that can be considered primary and secondary outcomes and possible additional outcomes in AL assessment are discussed. These outcome measures include the following: subjective effects (some of which include the primary outcome measures, including drug liking), physiological responses, drug self-administration behavior, and cognitive and psychomotor performance. Before recommendations for standardized approaches and measures are presented in AL- assessments, the appropriateness of using these measures in clinical trials of pain patients is discussed.

title: Reduction of several risk factors for coronary artery disease. Vendor perspectives
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although primary care physicians understand the importance of preventive services for patients with multiple risk factors (MRF) for coronary artery disease, medical intervention is limited. This study examined (1) physicians' views on the challenges of treating patients with MRF, (2) the counseling and management methods they use, and (3) possible strategies for improving MRF intervention in primary care METHODS: Two focus groups were conducted with primary care physicians from different backgrounds to gain insight into the above issues.Each group was co-moderated by a physician and a behaviorist using a previously developed semi-structured interview guide recorded and then transcribed. Transcripts were analyzed using the constant comparison method for analysis. RESULTS: Physicians are challenged by knowledge limitations (contribution of individual risk factors to overall risk); limited support (guidelines, materials, and staff);" and logistical difficulties (organizational problems, time constraints). Their approach to MRF management is typically highly individualized with an initial preference for lifestyle modification interventions rather than prescription drugs under certain conditions. Physicians preferred a serial rather than parallel approach to MRF intervention, beginning with behaviors that the patient perceives to be paramount. Proposed solutions to current challenges emphasize medical education and the development of innovative approaches that involve medical assistance and a team approach. CONCLUSIONS: Physicians are aware and sensitive to the complexities of MRF management for their patients and themselves. However, future MRF interventions will require the involvement of non-physician staff and increased system support.

title: Management of coronary risk factors in the primary care practice in Shibuya, Tokyo
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Many large-scale clinical studies have confirmed that coronary risk factors such as hypertension, hyperlipidemia and diabetes mellitus predict a higher incidence of cardiovascular events and that controlling these risk factors reduces the incidence. However, the actual management of such risk factors and the consequent improvement in cardiovascular events in the primary care setting remains unclear. The Heart Care Network Shibuya, a volunteer study group of regional primary care physicians, examined management of coronary risk factors and clinical outcomes. METHODS: Behavioral patterns of coronary artery risk factor management and consequent changes in risk factors were investigated in 209 outpatients (mean age 65.6 +/- 11.2 years) with more than one hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus or previous myocardial infarction after 1 year. RESULTS: The prescriptions of antihypertensive drugs (from 1.3 +/- 0.8 to 1.4 +/- 0.8 drugs per patient) and antihyperlipidemic drugs (from 0.70 +/- 0.4 to 0.73 +/- 0.4 drugs per patient) did not increase significantly. Patient education for diet (93% to 97%, p=0.077), exercise (69% to 81%, p<0.05), and not smoking (66% to 86%, p<0.05) increased significantly at 1 year to. Blood pressure decreased from 142 +/- 16/81 +/- 10 to 138 +/- 78/78 +/- 9 mmHg (p<0.05), total serum cholesterol decreased from 215 +/- 39 to 203+ /- 39 mg/dl (p<0.05). As a result, more patients achieved the treatment goals recommended in the guidelines of the Japanese Society of Hypertension (34.6% to 46.8%) and the Japan Atherosclerosis Society (40.2% to 49.5%), respectively. However, none of the blood hemoglobin A1c levels, body mass index, or smokers changed significantly. CONCLUSIONS: Regional practitioners attempted to control for all coronary risk factors. Hypertension and hyperlipidemia, which are relatively more dependent on medical treatment, improved. In contrast, diabetes mellitus, obesity, or smoking, which require lifestyle changes, did not improve. The main problem with risk factor management is how doctors act, not specific actions.

title: Cost implications of implementing an electronic decision support system for ordering laboratory tests in primary care: Evidence from a controlled prospective study in the Netherlands
abstract: BACKGROUND: The economic implications of interventions to encourage rational, evidence-based use of laboratory testing by physicians are not fully understood. We evaluated the cost implications of using a computerized, guideline-driven decision support system (CDSS) for ordering blood tests in primary care. METHODS: We installed the CDSS in 118 practices [159 general practitioners (GPs)] in the Netherlands and calculated the cost of the intervention in this group. In a period of 6 months before and 6 months after installation of the CDSS, the test ordering behavior of 87 (109 general practitioners) of these 118 study practices was examined and the results compared with those of a non-historical control group that did not receive the CDSS. In addition, the costs for laboratory inquiries were calculated for both groups. RESULTS: The total intervention costs, consisting of development costs and installation costs, amounted to 79,000 euros (670 euros per practice). While the introduction of the CDSS did not impact the number of order forms sent to laboratories, it did reduce the number of blood tests per order form. As a result, the CDSS achieved an average cost savings for laboratory inquiries of 847 euros per practice and 6 months. Conclusions: This study shows that the provision of electronic decision-making aids for ordering blood tests in primary care represents an economically promising concept. Savings in laboratory costs can be achieved and are not offset by disproportionately high intervention costs.

title: Cost-effectiveness of a clinical decision support system based on the recommendations of the European Society of Cardiology and other societies for the management of hypercholesterolaemia: report of a cluster-randomized study.
abstract: Introduction and Objectives To evaluate the cost-effectiveness of a clinical decision support system (CDSS) based on the recommendations of the European Society of Cardiology and other societies for the management of hypercholesterolaemia (ESCHM). Study design and perspective A cluster-randomized, open-label, pragmatic study was conducted. To assess the impact on effectiveness and costs of a CDSS implementing an adapted version of the ESCHM recommendations, a parallel comparison with a usual care group was performed over 1 year. The recruitment period started in April 2000 and ended 1 year later. Efficacy was defined as meeting low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) reduction goals in patients with an initial cardiovascular risk (CVR) > 20% over 10 years (the goals are LDL-C < 115 mg /dl for patients). with coronary artery disease [CAD] or LDL-C < 130 mg/dl for patients without CAD) or maintenance of CVR < 20% at study end in patients with initial CVR < 20%. The costs for treatments, visits and laboratory tests were estimated from a social point of view (calculation year 2002). Methods The ESCHM guidelines, adapted by a steering committee, included therapeutic recommendations aimed at achieving LDL-C goals in a cost-effective manner. To promote a healthy cardiovascular lifestyle, items such as tablecloths and fridge magnets (with appropriate promotional messages) were distributed to intervention practices. All study physicians recorded patient data in a dedicated application installed on their computer. Interventionists had the CDSS installed as an additional module of this application and were encouraged to use it, but were otherwise free to accept or ignore the recommendations. Compliance with the guideline was monitored by the CDSS. Patients with hypercholesterolaemia were selected from 44 general practices in Spain, mainly in the Catalonia region. Main Outcome Parameters and Results 2221 patients were enrolled in the study (1161 in the usual care group and 1060 in the intervention group). The intervention was found to be as effective as usual care in both an unadjusted analysis and after adjustment for absolute CVR and prior treatment with lipid-lowering drugs (LLDs) [odds ratio (OR) 1.02; 95% CI 0.58, 1.77]. The intervention had no effect on lipid profiles. Intervention patients were less likely to be prescribed LLDs than usual care patients (OR = 0.37; 95% CI 0.26, 0.52; p = 0.0001), particularly when CVR was low. This resulted in significant savings in treatments (p=0.0001) and overall costs (p=0.001), estimated at 24.9% and 20.8%, respectively. The intervention increased the number of laboratory analyses. The CDSS recommendations were accepted in 71.3% of the visits. Discussion and conclusions The CDSS, based on the recommendations of the ESCHM, did not change the effectiveness of usual care, but resulted in significant savings.

title: Cost-effectiveness of a manual coping strategy program to promote the mental health of caregivers of people with dementia (the STrAtegies for RelaTives (START) study): a pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess whether the START (STRATEGIES FOR RELATTIVES) intervention is cost-effective in addition to usual care compared to usual care alone. DESIGN Cost-effectiveness analysis embedded in a pragmatic randomized controlled trial. SETTINGS Three psychiatric and one neurological dementia outpatient care centers in London and Essex, UK. PARTICIPANTS Family caregivers of people with dementia. INTERVENTION Eight-session, manual-based coping interventions delivered by supervised psychology graduates for caregivers of people with dementia, in addition to usual care compared to usual care alone. PRIMARY OUTCOME MEASURES Costs, measured from a health and social care perspective, were analyzed along with the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale Total Score (HADS-T) of affective symptoms and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) in cost-effectiveness analyzes over eight months from baseline. RESULTS Of the 260 participants recruited for the study, 173 were randomized to the START intervention and 87 to usual care alone. Mean HADS-T scores were lower in the intervention group than in the usual treatment group during the 8-month assessment period (mean difference -1.79 (95% CI -3.32 to -0.33)), indicating better outcomes in connection with the START intervention. There was a small improvement in health-related quality of life as measured by QALYs (0.03 (-0.01 to 0.08)). Costs did not differ between the intervention and usual treatment groups (£252 (-28 to 565) higher for the START group). The cost-effectiveness calculations indicated that START measured at a willingness-to-pay threshold of £30,000 per QALY gained and a high probability of cost-effectiveness in the HADS-T compared to usual treatment alone. CONCLUSIONS The manual-based coping intervention START, when added to usual care, was cost-effective compared to usual care alone on both endpoints (affective symptoms for caregivers and QALYs in need of care). TEST REGISTRATION ISCTRN 70017938.

title: Cost-effectiveness of strategies to combat neuropsychiatric disorders in sub-Saharan Africa and Southeast Asia: mathematical modeling study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the costs and effects of interventions to control five neuropsychiatric disorders (schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, depression, epilepsy and heavy alcohol use). DESIGN Cost-effectiveness analysis based on an epidemiological model. SETTING Two sub-regions of the world epidemiologically defined by the World Health Organization: countries in sub-Saharan Africa with very high adult and high child mortality (AfrE)” and countries in Southeast Asia with high adult and high child mortality (SearD). DATA SOURCES Published Studies, Cost Databases KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Cost per capita and cost per year of life prevented (DALY) per disability expressed in international dollars ($Int) for the year 2005. RESULTS Over 44 intervention strategies evaluated for the five neuropsychiatric disorders, the cost-effectiveness scores differed by up to two orders of magnitude (from 100-250 Int to 10,000-25,000 Int for a year of healthy life gained) In both subregions, inpatient treatment of schizophrenia with newer antipsychotics was the most expensive and least cost-effective strategy. Region, the most cost-effective intervention was drug treatment for epilepsy in primary care. The cumulative costs per capita of the most cost-effective interventions covering all five conditions were estimated to be 4.90 to 5.70 Int. This package includes interventions for epilepsy (older first-line antiepileptic drugs); depression (commonly manufactured newer antidepressants and psychosocial treatment); bipolar disorder (mood stabilizer lithium); schizophrenia (neuroleptic antipsychotics and psychosocial treatment);" and heavy alcohol use (increased taxation and enforcement, restricted access and, in the African subregion, advertising bans and brief counseling for heavy drinkers in primary care). CONCLUSIONS Reallocating resources to cost-effective intervention strategies would increase health gain , save money and help implement the much-needed expansion of neuropsychiatric services in under-resourced settings.

title: Cost-effectiveness of strategies to address vision and hearing loss in sub-Saharan Africa and Southeast Asia: mathematical modeling study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the relative costs, effects, and cost-effectiveness of selected interventions for the control of cataracts, trachoma, ametropia, hearing loss, meningitis, and chronic otitis media. DESIGN Cost-effectiveness analysis of or combined strategies to control vision and hearing loss through a lifetime population model. SETTING Two World Health Organization subregions where vision and hearing loss are major burdens: sub-Saharan Africa and Southeast Asia. DATA SOURCES Biological and behavioral parameters from clinical and observational studies and population surveys. Intervention effects and resource input based on published reports, expert opinion and the WHO CHOICE database. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Cost per prevented disability-adjusted life year (DALY) expressed in international dollars ($Int) for 2005. RESULTS Treatment of chronic otitis media, extracapsular cataract surgery, trichiasis surgery, treatment of meningitis, and annual screening of schoolchildren for refractive errors are among the most cost-effective interventions to control hearing and vision impairments, with a cost per DALY averted of <$285 in both regions. Screening school children (annually) and adults (every five years) for hearing loss costs about 1,000 Int per DALY avoided. These interventions can be considered very cost effective. Mass treatment with azithromycin to control trachoma can be considered cost-effective in the African but not in the Southeast Asian subregion. CONCLUSIONS Interventions to control visual and hearing impairments are generally cost-effective. To decide whether significant investment in these interventions is warranted, this finding should be considered in relation to the economic attractiveness of other existing or new healthcare interventions.

title: Cost-effectiveness of a nurse-based intervention (AIMS) to improve adherence in HIV-infected patients: design of a multicenter randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Non-compliance with HIV treatment can negatively impact treatment success rates, quality of life, infectivity, and patient life expectancy. Few adherence interventions have shown positive effects on adherence and/or virologic outcomes. The theory- and evidence-based Adherence Improving Self-Management Strategy (AIMS) is an intervention that has been shown to improve adherence and viral suppression rates in a randomized controlled trial. However, there is no evidence of profitability. Following a recent review suggesting that cost-benefit assessments of adherence interventions in chronic disease are rare and that the methodology of such assessments is poorly described in the literature, this manuscript presents the study protocol for a multi-center study to assess efficacy and Cost-Effectiveness of AIMS in a Heterogeneous Sample of Patients. Methods/Design The study used a multicenter, randomized, controlled study design to compare the AIMS intervention with usual care from a societal perspective. Embedded in this RCT is an experimental and model-based economic assessment. A planned number of 230 HIV-infected patients will be randomized to receive either AIMS or usual care. Relevant outcomes include changes in adherence, plasma viral load, quality of life, and societal costs. The time horizon for the trial-based economic assessment is 12-15 months. For the model-based economic assessment, costs and effects are extrapolated to a lifetime horizon. Discussion The present multicenter RCT aims to provide robust methodological evidence for the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of a nursing-based counseling intervention (AIMS) to support treatment adherence in a large and heterogeneous sample of HIV-infected patients in the Netherlands. The aim of the present paper is to describe the study protocol in sufficient detail to allow a full assessment of the quality of the study design. It is expected that AIMS, if proven cost-effective, can contribute to improved evidence-based counseling guidelines for HIV nurses and other health professionals.

title: Cost-effectiveness of alternative strategies for the initial medical management of non-ST elevation acute coronary syndromes: systematic review and decision-analytic modelling
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To identify and prioritize key areas of clinical uncertainty related to the medical management of non-ST elevation acute coronary syndrome (ACS) in current UK practice. DATA SOURCES: Electronic databases. Consultations with clinical advisors. Postal survey of cardiologists. REVIEW METHODS: Potential areas of significant uncertainty were identified and “decision problems” prioritized. A systematic literature search was carried out using standard methods. The constructed decision model consisted of a short-term phase applying the results of the systematic review and a long-term phase incorporating relevant information from a UK observational study to extrapolate the estimated costs and impacts. Sensitivity analyzes were performed to examine the dependency of the results on baseline parameters using alternative data sources. Expected value information analysis was performed to estimate the expected value of perfect information related to the decision problem. This provided an upper bound on the monetary value associated with additional research in this area. RESULTS: Seven current areas of clinical uncertainty (decision problems) in drug management for patients with unstable angina pectoris were identified. The active substances affected were clopidogrel, low molecular weight heparin, hirudin and intravenous glycoprotein antagonists (GPAs). Twelve published clinical guidelines for unstable angina or non-ST elevation ACS were identified, but few provided recommendations on the stated decision problems. The postal survey of clinicians showed that the greatest disagreement was with the use of small molecule GPAs and the greatest uncertainty with decisions related to the use of abciximab (a large molecule GPA). Overall, decision issues related to the GPA class of drugs were considered the top priority for further studies. Selected articles describing the clinical effectiveness of the treatment have been divided into three groups, each representing an alternative strategy. The strategy that included the use of GPAs as part of the initial medical management of all non-ST elevation ACS was the optimal choice, with an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) of 5738 pounds per quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) im Comparison without using GPAs. The stochastic analysis showed that if healthcare is willing to pay £10,000 per additional QALY, the probability of this strategy being cost-effective was around 82%, rising to 95% at a threshold of £50,000 per QALY. A sensitivity analysis including an additional strategy of using GPAs as part of the initial medical treatment only in patients at particularly high risk (defined by age, ST depression or diabetes) showed that this additional strategy was even more cost effective with an ICER of £3996 per QALY compared to no treatment with GPA. The value of information analysis suggested that there was significant value for additional research to reduce the level of uncertainty in the optimal decision. Using a threshold of £10,000 per QALY, the maximum possible value of such research in the base case has been calculated at £12.7m per year for the UK as a whole. Taking into account the greater uncertainty in the sensitivity analyzes involving clopidogrel, this figure has been increased to approximately £50m. CONCLUSIONS: This study proposes the use of GPAs in all non-ST elevation ACS patients as part of their initial medical management. The sensitivity analysis showed that virtually all of the benefit could be realized if only high-risk patients were treated. Further clarification of the optimal role of GPAs in the UK NHS depends on the availability of further high quality observational and experimental data. The value of information analysis derived from the model suggests that a relatively large investment in such research could be worthwhile. Further research should focus on identifying the characteristics of patients who benefit most from GPAs in the context of medical management, comparing GPAs with clopidogrel as an adjunct to standard of care, follow-up cohort studies on the costs and outcomes of high-risk non- ST elevation ACS over several years and examining how clinicians' decisions combine a normative, evidence-based decision model with their own personal behavioral perspective.

title: Cost-effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy as an adjunct to pharmacotherapy for treatment-resistant depression in primary care: economic assessment of the CoBalT study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Treating depression is expensive, but providing ineffective treatment is more expensive. This is the case for many patients who do not respond to antidepressants. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the cost-effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) plus usual care for primary care patients with treatment-resistant depression compared to usual care alone. METHOD: Economic evaluation at 12 months alongside a randomized controlled trial. Cost-effectiveness is assessed using a cost-consequence framework that compares costs to the health and social care provider, patients and society against a range of outcomes. Cost-benefit analysis comparing health and social costs with quality-adjusted life years (QALYs). RESULTS: The average cost of CBT per participant was £910. The difference in QALY gain between groups was 0.057, equivalent to 21 days of good health per year. The incremental cost-effectiveness ratio was £14,911 (representing a 74 percent probability that the intervention is cost-effective at the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence threshold of £20,000 per QALY). Loss of income and productivity costs were significant, but there was no evidence of a difference between intervention and control groups. CONCLUSIONS: Adding CBT to usual care is cost-effective in patients who have not responded to antidepressants. GPs should therefore be encouraged to refer such individuals for CBT.

title: Cost-effectiveness of guideline-compliant treatments for low back pain: a systematic review
abstract: The healthcare costs for back pain (LBP) are increasing rapidly. Therefore, it is important to offer treatments that are effective and inexpensive. The purpose of this systematic review was to examine the cost-effectiveness of guideline-compliant treatments for LBP. We searched nine clinical and economic electronic databases and the reference list of relevant systematic reviews and included studies for eligible studies. Economic reviews conducted in conjunction with randomized controlled trials evaluating treatments for LBP supported by American College of Physicians and American Pain Society guidelines were included. Two independent reviewers reviewed search results and extracted data. The data extracted included the nature and perspective of the economic assessment, the comparator treatments, and the relative cost-effectiveness of the comparator treatments. 26 studies were included. Most studies found that interdisciplinary rehabilitation, exercise, acupuncture, spinal manipulation, or cognitive-behavioral therapy was cost-effective in people with subacute or chronic LBP. Massage alone probably wasn't cost effective. There were conflicting results on the cost-effectiveness of counseling, insufficient evidence on spinal manipulation in people with acute LBP, and no evidence on the cost-effectiveness of medication, yoga, or relaxation. This review found evidence of the cost-effectiveness of guideline-recommended treatments of interdisciplinary rehabilitation, exercise, acupuncture, spinal manipulation, and cognitive-behavioral therapy for subacute or chronic LBP. There is little or conflicting evidence for other treatments recommended in the guideline.

title: Cost-effectiveness of HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis for drug injectors in the United States
abstract: Background: The health benefits and costs of HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for the total population of people who inject drugs (PWID) in the United States are unclear. Aim: To evaluate the cost-effectiveness and optimal delivery conditions of PrEP for PWID. Design: Empirically calibrated dynamic compartment model. Data sources: Published literature and expert opinion. Target population: US adult PWID. Time horizon: 20 years and lifetime. Intervention: PrEP alone, PrEP with frequent screening (PrEP+Screen), and PrEP+Screen with enhanced delivery antiretroviral therapy (ART) for people who become infected (PrEP+Screen+ART). All scenarios are considered with a coverage of 25%. Outcome measures: Infections averted, deaths averted, change in HIV prevalence, discounted costs (in 2015 US dollars), discounted quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), and incremental cost-effectiveness ratios. Base-case analysis results: PrEP+Screen+ART dominates other strategies, prevents 26,700 infections and reduces HIV prevalence in PWID by 14% compared to status quo. Earning these benefits costs $253,000 per QALY gained. At current drug prices, total PrEP+Screen+ART spending could be as high as $44 billion over 20 years. Sensitivity Analysis Results: The cost-effectiveness of the intervention is linear in the annual cost of PrEP and depends on PrEP medication adherence, individual risk of transmission, and community HIV prevalence. Limitation: US risk stratification data and achievable PrEP efficacy values for PWID are limited Benefits for the US population as a whole, but at current drug prices, it remains an expensive intervention, both in absolute terms and in terms of cost per QALY gained .

title: Cost-effectiveness of practice-initiated quality improvement in depression
abstract: Context Depression is a leading cause of disability worldwide, but treatment rates in primary care are low. Aim To determine the cost-effectiveness from a societal perspective of 2 quality improvement (QI) interventions to improve the treatment of depression in primary care and their impact on patient employment. Design group-level randomized controlled trial conducted from June 1996 to July 1999. Establishment of 46 primary care hospitals in 6 community-based managed care organizations. Participants One hundred eighty-one primary care physicians and 1356 patients with positive screening results for current depression. Interventions Adapted practices were randomly assigned to provide usual care (n=443 patients) or 1 of 2 QI interventions involving training for practice managers and nurses, enhanced training and assessment resources, and either medication follow-up nurses (QI-Meds ) offer ; n = 424 patients) or trained registered psychotherapists (QI therapy; n = 489) Practices were able to flexibly implement the interventions that did not assign any type of treatment to the main outcome parameters total health care costs, costs per quality-adjusted life year (QALY), days with depression burden and employment over 24 months compared between usual care and the 2 interventions ) and $485 (13%) for QI therapy (p=0.28); estimated costs per QALY gained ranged from $15,331 to $36,467 for QI drugs and $9,478 to $21,478 for QI therapy;" and patients were 25 (p=0.19) and 47 (p=0.01 ) fewer days with depression burden and were 17.9 (p = 0.07) and 20.9 (p = 0.03) more days employed during the study period.ConclusionsThe societal cost-effectiveness of practice-initiated QI efforts in depression is comparable to that of accepted of medical interventions The effects of interventions on employment may be of particular interest to employers and other stakeholders.

title: Costs Associated with the Implementation of a Computerized Clinical Decision Support System for Pregnancy and Maternity Care: Case Study of Kassena-Nankana District, Northern Ghana
abstract: AIM: This study analyzed the costs of implementing a computerized clinical decision support system (CDSS) in selected health centers in Ghana. Methods: A descriptive cross-sectional study was conducted in Kassena-Nankana District (KND). CDSS was used at selected health centers in KND as an intervention to manage patients attending maternity hospitals and the maternity ward. The CDSS users were mainly registered nurses. Activities and associated costs related to the implementation of CDSS (pre-intervention and intervention) were surveyed for the period 2009-2013 from a provider perspective. The ingredients approach was used for the cost analysis. The costs were divided into personnel costs, training, overhead costs (running costs) and equipment costs (capital costs). We have calculated the cost without annualized cost of capital to show the financial cost and the cost with the annualized cost of capital to show the economic cost. RESULTS: Twenty-two trained CDSS users (minimum 2 users per health center) participated in the study. Between April 2012 and March 2013, users managed 5,595 prenatal clients and 872 labor clients using the CDSS. We observed a decrease in the proportion of complications during childbirth (10.74% before intervention versus 9.64% after intervention) and a reduction in the number of maternal deaths (4 deaths before intervention versus 1 death after the intervention). The total financial cost of the CDSS implementation was $23,316, approximately $1,060 per trained CDSS user. Of the total implementation costs, 48% (US$11,272) was preintervention costs and 52% (US$12,044) was intervention costs. Equipment costs accounted for the largest portion of finance costs: 34% ($7,917). After accounting for economic costs, the total implementation cost was $17,128, 26.5% less than the financial cost. CONCLUSIONS: The study provides useful information in implementing CDSS in health care settings to improve adherence to practice guidelines by health care workers and to make accurate decisions to improve maternal health care.

title: Could a clinical audit improve the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis in Cuba, Peru and Bolivia?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of the clinical audit to improve the quality of diagnostic care for patients with suspected tuberculosis";" and to understand the contextual factors that hinder or facilitate their success. METHODS: Twenty-six health centers in Cuba, Peru and Bolivia were recruited. Clinical audits were introduced to improve diagnostic care for patients suspected of having tuberculosis. The standards were based on WHO and TB program guidelines on the appropriate use of microscopy, culture and radiological examinations. At least two audit cycles have been completed over 2 years. Improvement was determined by comparing performance between two six-month periods before and after the intervention. Qualitative methods were used to identify the facilitating and limiting contextual factors influencing the change in clinical behavior of healthcare professionals after the introduction of the clinical audit. RESULTS: We found significant improvement in 11/13 criteria in Cuba, 2/6 criteria in Bolivia, and 2/5 criteria in Peru. Twelve out of 24 audit criteria in all three countries met the agreed standards. Obstacles to quality improvement included conflicting goals for clinicians and TB programs, poor coordination within the healthcare system, and patient attitudes towards disease. CONCLUSIONS: Clinical audit can drive improvements in the quality of clinical care in resource-constrained settings. It is likely to be more effective if integrated with and supported by local TB programs. We recommend the development and evaluation of an integrated quality improvement model including clinical audits.

title: Counseling African Americans to Control Hypertension (CAATCH) study: a multi-step intervention to improve blood pressure control in hypertensive blacks
abstract: Despite strong evidence for effective interventions aimed at controlling blood pressure (BP), there is little evidence for translating these approaches into routine clinical practice in the care of hypertensive Black people. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a multi-stage, multi-component, evidence-based intervention compared to usual care in improving blood pressure control in Black hypertensive patients treated in community health centers. The primary outcomes are the BP control rate at 12 months and maintenance of the intervention at 1 year post-study. The secondary outcomes are the change in blood pressure within the patient from baseline to 12 months and the cost-effectiveness of the intervention. Counseling African Americans to Control Hypertension (CAATCH) is a randomized group clinical trial with 2 conditions: intervention condition and usual care. Thirty community health centers were randomly assigned to be equally divided into the intervention condition group (n = 15) or usual care group (n = 15). The intervention has 3 components for patients (interactive computer-assisted hypertension education, home blood pressure monitoring, and monthly behavioral counseling for lifestyle changes) and 2 components for physicians (monthly case rounds based on the Joint National Committee on Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment) . hypertension guidelines, reviewing the charts and providing feedback on patients' clinical performance and home blood pressure readings). All results will be evaluated at quarterly study visits for 1 year. Chart review will be performed at 24 months to assess maintenance of intervention effects and sustainability of the intervention. Poor blood pressure control is one of the main reasons for the mortality gap between blacks and whites. The results of this study, if successful, will provide important information needed for the translation and dissemination of evidence-based blood pressure control interventions in clinical practice for this high-risk population.

title: Counseling African Americans to control hypertension: Main effects of cluster-randomized clinical trials
abstract: BACKGROUND: There are limited data on the implementation of evidence-based, multilevel interventions aimed at controlling blood pressure (BP) in hypertensive Black people treated in resource-poor primary care practices. METHODS AND RESULTS: Counseling African Americans to Control Hypertension is a cluster-randomized clinical trial in which 30 community health centers were randomly assigned to intervention condition (IC) or usual care (UC). Patients at IC sites received patient education, home blood pressure monitoring, and monthly lifestyle counseling, while physicians attended monthly hypertension case rounds and received feedback on their patients' blood pressure readings and chart reviews at home. Patients and physicians at the UC campuses each received printed patient education materials and guidelines for treating hypertension. The primary endpoint was blood pressure control, and the secondary endpoints were mean changes in systolic and diastolic blood pressure values at 12 months, assessed using an automated blood pressure monitor. A total of 1059 patients (mean age 56 years; 28% male, 59% obese and 36% with diabetes mellitus) were enrolled. Blood pressure control rate was similar in both groups (IC = 49.3% versus UC = 44.5% odds ratio 1.21 [95% confidence interval 0.90-1.63] P = 0.21) In predefined subgroup analyses, the intervention associated with better blood pressure control in patients without diabetes mellitus (IC = 54.0% versus UC = 44.7%; odds ratio 1.45 [CI 1.02-2.06]) and small community health centers (IC = 51, 1% vs. UC = 39.6%, odds ratio 1.45 [CI 1.04-2.45]). CONCLUSIONS: A practice-based multicomponent intervention was no better than CU in improving blood pressure control in hypertensive Blacks. Future research on implementing behavior modification strategies to control hypertension in resource-constrained settings should focus on developing more efficient and tailored interventions in this high-risk population. CLINICAL TRIAL REGISTRATION URL: http://www.clinicaltrials.gov. Unique identifier: NCT00233220.

title: Building a sustainable, interprofessional team training program: first results
abstract: PURPOSE/OBJECTIVES: The purpose of this program evaluation was to investigate whether incorporating conscious learning concepts through the use of simulated patient scenarios to teach interprofessional collaboration skills to a healthcare team on an acute hospital unit would improve resuscitation response in the first 5 minutes on this device. DESIGN/SETTING: This was a pilot program evaluation using a department-based clinical nursing specialist in the delivery of an interprofessional training program that included a simulation in an acute medical care unit in a large tertiary care hospital. EXAMPLE: 84 employees took part in 17 simulations. The sample included first-year internists, registered nurses, respiratory therapists, and patient care technicians. METHODS: This was a program assessment using the TeamSTEPPS Teamwork Perceptions Questionnaire (T-TPQ) (Classroom Slides: TeamSTEPPS Essentials"; http://www.ahrq.gov/professionals/education/curriculum-tools/teamstepps/instructor /essentials/slessentials.html#s3) during the pre-simulation/post-simulation sessions to assess participants' perceptions of teamwork Expected intervention behaviors were captured through participant observations of the simulations and compared to American Heart Association guidelines (Circulation 2010 ;122:S685-S670, S235-S337). Common perceptions of participants regarding the experience were obtained through open-ended assessment questions. RESULTS: Fifty-three participants completed the pre- and post-T-TPQ. Average scores in the leadership category of T-TPQ decreased significantly (P=0.003) from pretest (median 2.167) to T-TPQ posttest (median 2.566) Only 35% of groups administered during the crest defibrillation simulation scenario, and only 1 group delivered this shock within the American Heart Association recommended time frame of 2 minutes (Circulation 2010;"122:S235-S337). CONCLUSION: A single resuscitation simulation was not enough intervention dose for the staff to improve the resuscitation process. A longitudinal study should be conducted to determine the effectiveness of the program after employees have repeated the program several times. IMPLICATIONS: A department-based simulation training program for quality improvement could help improve staff's first 5-minute reaction and resuscitation skills by increasing the frequency of department-based training overseen by the department's clinical nurse.

title: Creating spaces in intensive care medicine for safe communication: a video-reflexive ethnographic study
abstract: Background The physical environment in acute care is a new focus in patient safety research, with few studies primarily focusing on the design of ward environments and the placement and selection of physical objects such as lighting fixtures and hand basins. Methods We report an interventionist video-reflexive ethnographic (AER) study that examined how clinicians used the built environment to achieve secure communication in an intensive care unit (ICU) in a Sydney metropolitan hospital. We conducted 40 semi-structured interviews, 5 weeks of observation, and four reflective focus groups with a total of 87 participants (including medical, nursing, allied health, and office workers). Results We found that staff and patient accessibility in the open areas of the ICU was both a safety feature and a safety hazard, as it allowed for a safe flow of communication but also allowed for potentially unsafe interruptions. Staff managed disruptions while allowing a safe level of accessibility by creating temporary sheltered spaces, using physical markers such as curtains, tape and signs, as well as behavioral cues, movement and developing policies that limit activity in specific areas. In addition, clinicians could use the VRE method to gain insights into their own practices and problems, and to develop meaningful solutions to other problem areas. Conclusions ICU staff enable safe communication within their wards by creating temporary spaces that are both 'connected' and 'protected'. The flexibility of these “soft” strategies lends itself particularly well to the fast-paced clinical context of critical care.

title: Crisis Intervention: A Handbook for Immediate Person-to-Person Help., 4th ed.
abstract: Provides a framework for providing immediate problem-solving assistance to individuals in crisis situations. As a handbook, it presents core knowledge as well as methods tailored to the respective circumstances. The book is intended for family caregivers whose work involves regular or occasional crisis intervention efforts. The techniques are claimed to be applicable in crisis centers, hotlines, internet-based services, victim support programs, college counseling centers, hospitals, schools, correctional facilities, child and youth programs, and other social settings. Users of the concepts include counselors, social workers, psychologists, nurses, physicians, clergy, correctional officers, probation and parole officers, and lay volunteers. Each chapter ends with study questions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Cueing from prenatal providers impacts discussions about intimate partner violence
abstract: BACKGROUND: Intimate partner violence (IPV) during pregnancy poses a significant health risk to both the mother and the developing fetus. Practice guidelines recommend that prenatal providers evaluate and counsel their patients about IPV, but many physicians express reluctance or uneasiness about such discussions . The Health in Pregnancy (HIP) computer program was developed to improve the counseling of prenatal providers on behavioral risks. METHODS: English-speaking women 18 years and older who were less than 26 weeks pregnant and received prenatal care at one of five participating San Francisco-area clinics were randomized into parallel groups in a controlled study (since June 2006). ;" Data analyzed June 2007). Participants who reported one or more risks were randomized to intervention or control in stratified blocks. Providers received summary cueing sheets alerting them to their patients' risks and advice on counseling RESULTS: Thirteen percent (37/286) of the sample reported current IPV Provider cueing resulted in 85% of the IPV intervention group reporting conversations with their provider compared to 23.5% of the control group (p<0.001) CONCLUSIONS: IPV discussions have been strongly influenced by cueing providers Provider cueing is an effective and appropriate adjunct to routine risk counseling in prenatal care.

title: Cultivating a learning culture in primary care practice: an educational intervention
abstract: BACKGROUND: Primary care faces increasing challenges, including the rise of chronic diseases and their management in the community. This paper describes an educational initiative designed to help local General Practitioners (GPs) and primary care teams manage chronic conditions and address referral behavior. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the initiative by examining the experiences of participants and providers. METHODS: A variety of methods were used to collect data for analysis. This included feedback from participants in the form of workshop evaluation questionnaires, semi-structured interviews with participants and speakers, and focus groups with participants. RESULTS: After analyzing the data, five themes were identified across all methods used. This paper focuses on the key issues of practice change and referral behavior as they relate to the specific objectives of the initiative. The data showed that after participating in the educational initiative, participants had experienced actual changes in practice, including changes in individual practice and prescribing behavior, as well as in community health care delivery. The changes observed in referral behavior were evident in the feedback from both participants and speakers in secondary care. Participants noted proposed changes, including an expected reduction in dermatology referrals through better management of primary care conditions, as well as greater awareness of indications for early referral. The use of guidelines to support referral decisions was identified, and the content and information required in referral letters was also a key area. CONCLUSION: The evaluation of this educational initiative has identified changes in practice in primary care and shows how educational interventions can support and improve future developments in primary care.

title: Culturally Tailored Chronic Disease Interventions Targeted at Korean Americans: A Systematic Review
abstract: OBJECTIVE: As little is known about promising interventions for the prevention and control of chronic diseases in Korean Americans, we conducted a systematic literature review to examine: (1) theoretical frameworks and strategies used by interventions for Korean Americans; (2) cultural factors considered by these interventions;' and (3) the extent of their success in engaging Korean participants and improving their health. DESIGN: Following PRISMA guidelines, PubMed, PsycInfo, and Web of Science were searched to identify primary research articles evaluating chronic disease prevention or control interventions tailored to Korean Americans and published from 1980 to 2011. Of 238 identified items, 21 items describing 16 unique intervention tests met the inclusion criteria. These interventions targeted cancer (10), hypertension (2), diabetes (1), mental health (1), tobacco cessation (1), and general health (1). RESULTS: All included studies were published since 2000, reflecting the relatively recent establishment of intervention research involving Korean Americans. All 16 programs delivered linguistically appropriate messages and education. The 11 programs that achieved significant intervention effects also provided or coordinated social support from culturally relevant and well-trained medical laypersons, nurses, or family members during an intervention and/or follow-up period. CONCLUSIONS: Culturally appropriate and linguistically appropriate messaging and education may not be sufficient to prevent or control chronic diseases among immigrant Korean Americans. Culturally sensitive and engaged social support should be provided to catalyze behavior change and sustain the impact of the interventions.

title: Current management of transitional feeding issues in preterm infants born in Queensland, Australia
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many preterm infants have difficulty developing their suckling skills in the weeks following birth. Ineffective management of transitional feeding issues can lead to patient complications and contribute to a longer length of stay. OBJECTIVES: Recognizing that many neonatal nurseries appear to have different practices in dealing with newborn feeding, the aim of this study was to investigate and document the routine level of support and intervention currently available for preterm infants with transitional feeding problems at the different Level II (special care) Nurserys (SCNs) in Queensland, Australia. METHODS: A questionnaire was sent to all Queensland SCNs in 2005 (n=36). The questionnaire contained a series of closed-choice, short-answer questions aimed at gathering information from each SCN on their current practices in dealing with transitional feeding issues in preterm infants. The results were confirmed during a subsequent phone call. RESULTS: Responses were obtained from 29 SCNs (80.6%). None of these daycares reported having formal, written policies for managing transitional feeding issues in preterm infants. Large differences were reported in terms of suction feeding assessments and interventions used by staff in the different SCNs. Of the 29 day care centers, 4 (13.8%) reported using checklists or ratings to assess willingness to suck, and 5 (17.2%) reported using pulse oximetry to assess acceptability of attempts to suck. Eighteen SCNs (62.1%) reported providing some form of active intervention to help newborns with transitional feeding problems, with the most common intervention techniques reported being non-nutritional sucking during tube feeding, oral stimulation prior to feeding, and active stimulation of suckling formulas . Twenty-two SCNs (75.4%) reported having access to a lactation consultant to help mothers with breastfeeding challenges. CONCLUSIONS: Differences in routine management of transitional feeding problems in preterm infants have been reported across Queensland SCNs. It is suggested that evidence-based guidelines need to be developed and that this requires further research studies to identify current best practices and to answer remaining questions.

title: Current patterns and future directions in the treatment of insomnia
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite the high prevalence and burden of chronic insomnia, it remains largely unrecognized by physicians and often undertreated. METHODS: A literature review was conducted on barriers to acute and chronic management of insomnia and current studies of pharmacological and non-pharmacological agents for insomnia. RESULTS: Barriers to adequate management of the condition include outdated guidelines for treating insomnia, which have contributed to U.S. Food and Drug Administration restrictions on long-term prescribing of hypnotics; lack of research demonstrating the benefits of treating insomnia; and fears of tolerance and withdrawal effects from long-term use of hypnotics, and the lack of longer-term, randomized, double-blind, controlled trials of existing agents for the treatment of insomnia. CONCLUSIONS: There is evidence that improved sleep may improve outcome in some medical and psychiatric disorders. Both behavioral and pharmacological therapies have been shown to be effective for chronic insomnia. In addition, a recent 6-month randomized controlled trial demonstrated that at least one active ingredient may be safe and effective with long-term use.

title: Restricting the ordering of laboratory tests in a managed care environment by redesigning a computerized order form
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To increase the appropriate use of blood tests for folic acid and vitamin B12 ordered by primary care physicians in a managed care organization in Israel by redesigning a computerized order form. STUDY DESIGN: Pre-post-intervention. METHODS: A new version of the computerized order form was introduced. Utilization patterns were calculated for tests of vitamin B12, folic acid and ferritin, which were summarized earlier. Concomitant application patterns for hemoglobin and iron tests were evaluated as controls. RESULTS: Testing ordered for the 3 objectives decreased by 31% to 41% compared to the month before the intervention, with a further decrease to 36% to 53% the following month. In controls (-2% to 3%), negligible changes in usage patterns were observed during the post-intervention period. CONCLUSIONS: Simply restructuring a computerized order form significantly reduced the number of laboratory tests suspected of being unnecessary or redundant. If overuse of laboratory resources is suspected, managers should evaluate the effectiveness of the organization's current ordering processes before conducting resource-intensive interventions.

title: Kutane maligne Lymphome: Update 2006
abstract: Cutaneous lymphomas represent a unique group of lymphomas and are the second most common extranodal lymphomas. As with other neoplasms, the pathogenesis is mainly based on a stepwise accumulation of mutations of suppressor genes and oncogenes caused by genetic, environmental or infectious factors. The diagnosis includes clinical, histological, imaging and haematological examinations as well as in many cases immunohistochemical and molecular biological analyses. The current WHO/EORTC classification of cutaneous lymphomas distinguishes between “mature T-cell and NK-cell lymphomas”, “mature B-cell lymphomas” and “immature hematopoietic malignancies”, their variants and subgroups. It is compatible with the WHO classification for neoplasms of hematopoietic and lymphatic tissue and takes into account the organ-specific characteristics of primarily cutaneous lymphomas. The classification of the different types of cutaneous lymphoma into prognostic categories (prelymphomatous "abortive" diseases", "definitely malignant lymphomas of low-grade malignancy", "definitely malignant lymphomas of high-grade malignancy") provides essential information about the biological behavior and allows for appropriate planning of the therapeutic strategy, which may be topical or systemic and aggressive or non-aggressive. In addition to the classic therapy options, there are new and "experimental" strategies whose effectiveness must be examined in clinical studies.

title: Daily cotrimoxazole prophylaxis in severely immunocompromised HIV-infected adults in Africa starting with combination antiretroviral therapy: an observational analysis of the DART cohort
abstract: BackgroundCo-trimoxazole prophylaxis may reduce mortality from untreated HIV infection in Africa"; whether benefits occur alongside combination antiretroviral therapy (ART) is unclear.
