We estimated the effect of prophylaxis after ART initiation in adults infected with HIV in Africa;" whether benefits occur alongside combination antiretroviral therapy (ART) is unclear. We estimated the effect of prophylaxis after initiation of ART in adults.

title: Decision support for patients considering total knee arthroplasty with surgeon preference report: a randomized controlled pilot study
abstract: BACKGROUND: To evaluate the feasibility and potential effectiveness of a patient decision aid (PtDA) and surgeon preference report to reduce wait times and improve decision quality in patients with osteoarthritis considering total knee replacement. METHODS: A prospective two-arm randomized controlled pilot study. Patients with osteoarthritis were eligible if they understood English and were referred to a Canadian orthopedic joint testing clinic for a surgical consultation for an initial total knee arthroplasty. Patients were randomized to PtDA intervention or usual education. The intervention consisted of an osteoarthritis PtDA for patients and a one-page preference report summarizing the patients' clinical and decision data for their surgeon. The main feasibility outcomes were recruitment rate and questionnaire completion; the preliminary efficacy outcomes were latency and decision quality 71) or usual training (n=71). Data collection revealed a questionnaire completion rate of 93% with less than 1% missing items. After one year, 13% of patients remained on the surgical waiting list. The mean time from referral to waitlist appearance (censored using survival analysis techniques) was 33.4 weeks for the PtDA group (n=69, 95% CI: 26.0, 41.4) and 33.0 weeks for usual education (n=71, 95% CI: 26.1, 39.9) Patients exposed to PtDA had higher decision quality based on knowledge (71% vs. 47%; p<0.0001) , and the quality decision was an informed decision consistent with their values for option outcomes (56.4% vs. 25.0%; p<0.001). CONCLUSIONS: Recruitment of patients with osteoarthritis considering surgery and data collection was feasible. Since some patients were still on the surgical waiting list after one year, the follow-up should be extended to two years. Patients exposed to PtDA achieved higher decision quality compared to those who received usual training, but there was no difference in waiting time before surgery. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.Gov NCT00743951.

title: Decision-making in the surgical management of chronic low back pain: the performance of prognostic tests to select patients for lumbar spinal fusion
abstract: Chronic low back pain (CLBP) is one of the leading causes of disability in the western world with an enormous economic burden on society. To date, no specific underlying anatomical cause of CLBP has been identified. Imaging often reveals degenerative findings in the disc or facet joints of one or more lumbar motion segments. However, these findings can also be observed in asymptomatic individuals. It has been suggested that pain in degenerated discs may be caused by nerve fiber ingrowth into cracks or fissures of the annulus fibrosus or nucleus pulposus and by reported high levels of pro-inflammatory mediators. Since this so-called discogenic pain is often intensified by mechanical stress, the concept of pain relief through spinal fusion to stabilize a painful section of the spine was developed. Lumbar spine fusion is actually beneficial for some patients, but its results vary widely and are difficult to predict for the individual patient. To identify those CLBP patients who will benefit from fusion, many surgeons rely on tests that are believed to predict the outcome of spinal fusion. The three most commonly used prognostic tests in daily practice are immobilization in a lumbosacral orthosis, provocative discography, and trial immobilization with temporary external transpedicular fixation. In order to reach a consensus on the indications for lumbar fusion and to improve its outcomes through better patient selection, it is important to understand the role and value of these prognostic tests for CLBP patients in clinical practice. The overall objectives of the present work were: 1) to assess whether there is a consensus among spinal surgeons on the use and appreciation of prognostic tests for lumbar spinal fusion; 2) to verify that a thoracolumbosacral orthosis (TLSO) truly minimizes lumbosacral motion; 3) to verify whether a TLSO can predict the clinical outcome of fusion for CLBP; 4) to assess whether the provocative discography of adjacent segments actually predicts the long-term clinical outcome of the fusion; 5) to determine the incidence of postdiscographic discitis, and whether there is one, routine antibiotic prophylaxis is required; 6) to assess whether temporary external transpedicular fixation (TETF) can help predict spinal fusion outcome;" 7) to determine the prognostic accuracy of the most commonly used tests in clinical practice to assess fusion outcome for CLBP The results of a national survey of spinal surgeons in the Netherlands were presented in Study I. Surgeons were asked for their opinions on prognostic factors and the use of predictive tests for lumbar fusion in CLBP patients.The comments were combined with findings from the compared to current literature. The survey revealed a significant lack of uniformity in the use and appreciation of predictive tests. Also, prognostic factors known from the literature were not consistently included in the decision-making process of the surgeons. This heterogeneity in strategy is most likely explained by the lack of sol ider of scientific evidence for current predictive testing, and it was concluded that there is currently insufficient consensus among spinal surgeons in the Netherlands to establish national guidelines for surgical decision making in CLBP. In study II, the hypothetical mechanism of action of a pantaloon cast (ie, minimizing lumbosacral joint mobility) was investigated. In patients admitted for a temporary external transpedicular fixation test (TETF), infrared light markers were rigidly attached to the prominent ends of Steinman pins, which were fixed in two spinal planes. In this way, three-dimensional movements between these planes could be analyzed optoelectronically. Under dynamic test conditions such as walking, a cast, either with or without unilateral hip fixation, did not significantly reduce lumbosacral joint motion. Although not supported by sound scientific evidence, lumbosacral orthotics or pantaloon casts are commonly used in daily practice as a predictor of fusion outcome. A systematic literature review supplemented by a prospective cohort study was performed (Study III) to assess the value of a Pantaloon cast for surgical decision making. It was shown that only in CLBP patients without prior spinal surgery does a pantaloon cast test with significant pain relief indicate a favorable outcome of lumbar fusion compared to conservative treatment. The test is worthless in patients who have had previous spinal surgery. Many spine surgeons believe that provocative discography, as opposed to simple X-rays or magnetic resonance imaging, is a physiological test that can truly determine whether a disc is painful and relevant to a patient's pain syndrome, regardless of disc morphology. It has been suggested that in order to achieve a successful clinical outcome of lumbar fusion, suspect discs should be painful and adjacent control discs should not cause pain on provocative discography. Therefore, in study IV, a cohort of patients in whom the decision to perform lumbar fusion was based on an external fixation study (TETF) was analyzed retrospectively. The results of the preoperative discography excluding the planes adjacent to the fusion were compared with the clinical results after spinal fusion. It was shown that in this selected group of patients, the discographic status of intervertebral discs in addition to lumbar fusion had no influence on the clinical outcome. The most feared complication of lumbar discography is discitis. Although the incidence is low, it represents a serious complication for a diagnostic procedure and prevention through the use of prophylactic antibiotics has been advocated. In search of clinical guidelines, the risk of discitis was assessed according to the discography in study V using a systematic literature review and a cohort of 200 consecutive patients. Without the use of prophylactic antibiotics, an overall incidence of postdiscographic discitis of 0.25% was found. To prove that antibiotics would actually prevent discitis would require a randomized trial of 9,000 patients to be meaningful. Given the potential adverse effects of antibiotics, it was concluded that routine use of prophylactic antibiotics in lumbar discography is not indicated. In study VI, the medium and long-term results of external fixation (TETF) were evaluated as a test to predict the clinical outcome of lumbar fusion in a cohort of low back pain patients in whom the indication for surgery was in doubt. The test included a placebo study in which patients did not know whether the lumbar segment planes were fixed or dynamized. Using rigorous and objective criteria of pain reduction on a visual analog scale, the TETF test failed to predict the clinical outcome of fusion in this selected patient population. Pin track infections and nerve root irritations were recorded as complications of this invasive test. It was concluded that in patients with chronic low back pain and doubtful indication for fusion, TETF is not recommended as an additional tool for surgical decision-making. In Study VII, a systematic literature review was performed regarding the prognostic accuracy of tests currently used in clinical practice that are believed to predict the outcome of lumbar spinal fusion in CLBP. The tests of interest were magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), TLSO immobilization, TETF, provocative discography, and facet joint infiltration. Only 10 studies could be selected that reported on three different index tests (discography, TLSO immobilization and TETF) that actually reported on test qualifications such as sensitivity, specificity and likelihood ratio. The accuracy of all prognostic tests was found to be low, confirming that in many clinical practices, patients are scheduled for fusion based on tests with insufficient or, at best, unknown accuracy. Since the overall methodological quality of the included studies was poor, higher quality studies are needed that include both negative and positive patients for fusion. It was concluded that the current best evidence does not support the use of a prognostic test in clinical practice. No subgroup of patients with back pain could be identified for whom spinal fusion is a reliable and effective treatment. Several studies in the literature have reported that cognitive behavioral therapy or intensive exercise programs have similar outcomes to spinal fusion, but with significantly fewer complications, morbidity, and costs. Because the results of the present work show that the tests currently used do not improve fusion outcomes through better patient selection, these tests should not be recommended for surgical decision-making in standard of care. Additionally, spinal fusion should not be suggested as a standard treatment for chronic low back pain. The causality of non-specific spinal pain is complex and CLBP should not be considered as a diagnosis but rather as a symptom in patients with varying degrees of impairment and disability. Patients should be evaluated in a multidisciplinary setting or spine center according to the so-called biopsychosocial model, which aims to identify underlying psychosocial factors as well as biological factors. Treatment should be gradual, beginning with the least invasive treatment. CLBP's current approach, which places an emphasis on self-management and patient empowerment for active treatment to prevent long-term disability and chronicity, is recommended.

title: Declaration of Helsinki
abstract: Recommendations for physicians involved in biomedical research involving humans.

title: Decree n° 93-1155 of May 17, 1993 promulgating the Code of Ethics in Medicine.
Default options in the ICU: widely used but poorly understood
abstract: Purpose of Review Standard options have a dramatic impact on decision maker behavior and can serve as effective decision support tools in the ICU. Their use in medicine has increased to improve efficiency, reduce errors and harness the potential of health technology. Recent Findings Defaults often fall short of their predicted impact when used as quality improvement interventions in critical care. Investigations reporting the use of default values are often constrained by differences in relative impacts between sites. Pre-implementation experiments and long-term monitoring studies are lacking. Summary Default settings in the ICU can help or harm patients and clinical efficiency depending on format and use. When constructing and encountering failures, vendors should be aware of their powerful and complex influences on decision making. Additional evaluations for the appropriate design of care deficits and the resulting intended and unintended consequences are required. Keywords: behavioral economics, decision-making behavior, communication, critical care, decision-making

title: Default settings of the physician's computerized order entry system determine order habits.
abstract: Background: Physician Computer Assisted Order Entry (CPOE) systems are fast becoming ubiquitous, and sets of orders (“order sets”) to allow for easy order entry is a common feature. This provides a streamlined mechanism for viewing, modifying, and placing groups of related orders. This often serves as the electronic equivalent of a subject requirement. A feature of these job sets is that certain jobs can be predetermined as "preselected" or "default" whenever the job set is used, while others are "optional" or "default" (although there's usually an option to default to “disable” enabled tests in a given situation.While it seems intuitive that the default settings in an order set are often accepted, additional studies are needed to understand the impact of these “default” settings in an order set on ordering habits Study was to quantify the effect of changing the default settings of an order set.Methods: For the purpose of quality improvement, transfusion order sets were recently reviewed and modified to improve outcome monitoring.Initially, the default setting for post-transfusion hematocrit values was changed and changed the platelet count from "optional" to "preselected". The default platelet count settings were later changed back to "optional" to allow a natural experiment to examine the effect of default selection of an order set on physician ordering habits. RESULTS: Post-transfusion hematocrit values were ordered for 8.3% of RBC transfusions when the default choice for the sequence set was "Off" and for 57.4% of transfusions when the default choice was "preselect" (P < 0.0001). Post-transfusion platelet counts were ordered for 7.0% of platelet transfusions when the initial selection of the default order set was "optional", increased to 59.4% when the default was changed to "preselected" (P < 0.0001), and then reduced to 7.5% when the default choice was reset to optional. Post-transfusion platelet count rates during the two "optional" periods: 7.0% versus 7.5% - were not statistically different (P=0.620). Discussion: Default settings in CPOE prescription records can significantly affect physician selection of laboratory tests. Careful consideration should be given to all stakeholders, including clinicians and pathologists, when setting default settings in order sets.

title: Defensive medicine among high-risk specialists in a volatile malpractice environment
abstract: Initial situation How often doctors change their treatment behavior because of the threat of liability for medical errors, so-called defensive medicine, and what the consequences of these changes are, are central questions in the ongoing debate on the reform of medical liability. Objective To study the prevalence and characteristics of defensive medicine among physicians practicing in high liability specialties during a period of significant instability in the malpractice environment. Design, Setting, and Participants Mail survey of physicians in 6 high-risk litigation specialties (emergency medicine, general surgery, orthopedic surgery, neurosurgery, obstetrics/gynecology, and radiology) in Pennsylvania in May 2003. Main Outcome Measures Number of physicians in each specialty involving defense medicine or changes reported in the area of application and in characteristics of defensive medicine (safety and avoidance behavior). Results A total of 824 physicians (65%) took part in the survey. Almost all (93%) reported practicing defensive medicine. "Reassurance behaviors" such as ordering tests, performing diagnostic procedures, and referring patients for consultation were very common (92%). Of those defensive medicine practitioners who detailed their last line of defense, 43% reported using imaging technology in clinically unnecessary circumstances. Avoiding procedures and patients that were thought to increase the likelihood of litigation was also widespread. Forty-two percent of those surveyed said they had taken steps to limit their practice in the past three years, including eliminating complication-prone procedures like trauma surgery and avoiding patients who had complex medical problems or were perceived as contentious. Defensive behavior was strongly correlated with respondents' lack of confidence in their liability insurance and perceived burden of insurance premiums. Conclusion Defensive medicine is prevalent among Pennsylvania physicians, who pay the most for liability insurance, with potentially serious implications for cost, access, and both the technical and interpersonal quality of care.

title: Determining the optimal treatment with cholinesterase inhibitors in Alzheimer's disease
abstract: Despite the growing recognition that Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a global public health and social care crisis, diagnosis is often slow and many patients are still not receiving treatment at all. Of those receiving treatment, many remain on a lower-than-recommended dose. The Alzheimer's disease International Global Charter promotes awareness and understanding of AD and emphasizes the importance of optimal treatment. However, the definition of “optimal treatment” is unclear. Since cholinesterase inhibitors became available nearly 20 years ago, clinicians have developed a variety of protocols based on clinical experience. This review considers what is optimal for different aspects of cholinesterase inhibitor therapy, considering initiation strategies, dosages, modes of drug delivery (eg, oral vs. transdermal), and duration of treatment. Regardless of the treatment approach, people with AD, their families and caregivers have a right to timely diagnosis and access to the best treatment available.

title: Delivery of good childcare: a look in the door
abstract: AIM: To describe the provision of quality childcare and its components; to compare this performance to the recommendations in Bright Futures and to compare the provision of quality childcare for children with special health needs to that for children without special needs. METHODS: Over a 10-week period, 2 medical students observed and documented the characteristics of childcare visits by general pediatricians and mid-level pediatric specialists. Parents completed a demographic questionnaire and a children with special health needs screener. RESULTS: 483 total Visits from 43 pediatricians and 9 medium-sized providers with patients aged 0-19 years were observed Adjusted mean visit length was 20.3 minutes 38.9% of visits began with an open-ended parent/child question 7.2 Health monitoring/ Predictive counseling was covered at each visit. Clinicians covered an average of 42% of Bright Futures recommended age-specific health monitoring/anticipatory guides. Topics addressed less frequently than recommended were family support, parental wellbeing, behavior/discipline, physical activity, media screen time, risk reduction/substance use, puberty/sex, social interactions with peers, and violence. Shorter visits were associated with asking questions about parent/child concerns and addressing a greater proportion of recommended health surveillance/predictive counseling topics. Visits to child day care for children with special health needs were 36% longer than for children without special needs and addressed a similar amount of age-specific health monitoring/proactive counseling issues. More time was spent with children with special health needs to address issues of health monitoring/predictive counselling, other conditions (usually their chronic condition) and testing, prescriptions and referrals. CONCLUSIONS: Through direct observation of pediatrician visits, we found that parent/child concerns were raised less frequently than recommended. Less than half of the recommended visit-specific health monitoring/predictive counseling topics were addressed, and there was little agreement with some of Bright Futures' age group-specific recommendations. Notably, both seeking patient/parent concerns and greater adherence to health surveillance/predictive guidance recommendations were associated with shorter visits. Visits to child day care for children with special health needs were longer than for children without special needs; more time was spent addressing a similar number of health monitoring/predictive counseling issues and their chronic conditions.

title: Demand management for planned care: a realistic synthesis.
abstract: Â The task of matching fluctuating demand with available capacity is one of the fundamental challenges in any major service industry. This is a particularly pressing issue in modern healthcare systems, as increasing demand (aging populations, availability of new treatments, expanding patient knowledge, etc.) meets stagnant supply (capacity and funding constraints for staff and services, etc.). As a result, a very large portfolio of demand management strategies has evolved, based on wildly different assumptions about the cause of the problem and the means to solve it. This report provides a comprehensive overview of the effectiveness of key strategies for mitigating demand pressures in the planned supply space. The study starts with an overview of the most important ideas on the genesis of demand and capacity problems for health services. Many different diagnoses were uncovered: 'fluctuating demand meets inpatient capacity', 'territory protection' between different providers, social rather than clinical pressures on referral decisions, self-propelling diagnostic cascades, supplier-induced demand, demographic pressures on treatment and the informed patient, and demand inflation. We then conducted a review of the key ideas (program theories) underlying interventions designed to address demand imbalances.We found that there was not a close correspondence between alleged problems and advocated solutions.Demand management interventions take their starting point from the Searching for reforms at the levels of strategic decision-making, organizational restructuring, procedural modifications, and behavioral change In capturing reform ideas, we also identified a trend enz states that program theories are becoming “whole system” models, which policymakers have advocated over time The need for concerted action on all these fronts The remainder and core of the report provides a realistic summary of the empirical evidence of effectiveness on a broad subset of four major demand management activities: Referral Management Centers (RMCs); Employing Special Interest GPs (GPwSIs) at the interface between primary and secondary care; General Practitioner (GP) direct access to clinical tests; and referral policies. In all cases we encountered a colorful pattern of success and failure. The primary literature is replete with reports of unexpected problems and unintended effects. These programs only "work" under very limited conditions. To give just one brief example, we have found that the success of RMCs depends critically on the balance of control in their governance structures; GPwSIs only affect demand after close negotiations on an agreed and intermediate case mix; Direct access to testing by GPs leads to significant efficiencies, especially when diagnostic results are low and exclusion rates high.” and referral policies are more likely to work when implemented by staff who are responsible for their creation. The report concludes that there is no "preferred intervention" that can outperform all others. Instead, the review found many different, hard-won, local and adaptive solutions. Regardless of the starting point, the success of demand management depends on synchronizing a complex set of strategic interventions, organisational, procedural and motivational changes. The final chapter offers practitioners guidance on how to 'think through' all the interdependencies that balance demand and capacity. A detailed analysis of the implementation of different configurations of demand management interventions in different localities Mixed-methods contexts would be valuable in understanding the processes by which such interventions are tailored to local circumstances.There is also scope for further evidence synthesis d Welfare ubiquitous, and a realistic synthesis to compare the fortunes of different practitioners at different professional boundaries (eg. (e.g. nurses/doctors, dentists/dentists, radiologists/radiologists, etc.) would be valuable to identify the contexts and mechanisms through which substitution, support or short-circuit occurs. The National Institute for Health Research Health Services and Delivery Research Program.

title: Dementia care management: Breaking new ground in outpatient dementia care as part of a general practitioner randomized controlled intervention study
abstract: BACKGROUND: The increasing prevalence of dementia is a major challenge for the German healthcare system. The aim of the DelpHi-MV study (“Dementia: Life and person-centred help in Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania”) is to implement and evaluate an innovative subsidiary support system for people with dementia living at home and their caring relatives. METHODS: DelpHi-MV is a GP-based cluster randomized controlled intervention study. The aim of the DelpHi intervention is "optimal care" through the integration of multi-professional and multi-modal strategies for the individualization and optimization of dementia treatment within the established health and social system. The intervention is delivered in people's homes by Dementia Care Managers (DCMs) - nurses with dementia-specific training. Based on the German guidelines for evidence-based diagnosis and treatment of dementia, a comprehensive set of 95 intervention modules - the "DelpHi standard" - was defined. Each module consists of predefined trigger condition(s), a subsequent intervention task and at least one criterion for its completion. The intervention begins with a comprehensive inventory of the care situation, needs and resources. In close cooperation with the general practitioner, the DCM develops and implements an intervention plan tailored to the individual circumstances. EXPECTED RESULTS AND CONCLUSIONS: We expect statistically significant differences between the control and intervention groups on the primary endpoints (quality of life, behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia, pharmacotherapy, caregiver burden). The results can provide evidence of the effectiveness and effectiveness of dementia care management according to the "Delphi standard" - prerequisites for the implementation of this concept in everyday care.

title: depression
Creation and distribution of the MOVE! Weight Management Program for Veterans
abstract: BACKGROUND: Veterans Health Administration (VHA) practitioners identified comprehensive weight management as a high priority in early 2001. PROGRAM DESIGN: The MOVE! The Veteran's Weight Management Program was developed based on published guidelines from the National Institutes of Health and other organizations. The feasibility of the program was tested at 17 VHA sites and the program was refined during early implementation in 2005. DISTRIBUTION: MOVE! was distributed nationwide in January 2006. Local program coordinators and physician champions were appointed, and toolkits, online training, marketing materials and ongoing on-site support were provided. RATING: MOVE! has been implemented in almost all medical centers of the VHA. By June 2008, more than 100,000 patients had taken part in MOVE! with more than 500,000 visits. An assessment based on an established framework is ongoing. CONCLUSION: MOVE! is an example of the large-scale translation of research into practice. It has the potential to reduce the burden of disease from obesity and related diseases.

title: Design and evaluation of a computer reminder system to improve the prescribing behavior of general practitioners
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the implementation of a decision support system using reactive computer reminders to improve drug prescribing behavior. Methods: A clustered RCT with an incomplete block design was conducted in the south of the Netherlands: 25 GPs received reminders for antibiotics and asthma/COPD prescriptions, 28 GPs received reminders for cholesterol prescriptions. The prescription guidelines were integrated into the general practitioner information system that was installed in the general practitioners' practices of the intervention group. When the computer program was used, a reminder appeared if the GP deviated from the guidelines during the prescription. PRIMARY OUTCOME: Prescribing according to guidelines as a percentage of total prescriptions for a given drug. In addition, an evaluation of the user-friendliness of the CRS in general practice was carried out using questionnaires and interviews. RESULTS: Analyzes are currently being performed. Preliminary results show that the CRS study has confirmed our expectations. In general, the number of prescriptions seems to have decreased, following the recommendations of the computerized guidelines not to prescribe certain drugs. The final analysis will be carried out shortly. In general, the Computer Reminder System was perceived as stable and user-friendly. CONCLUSION: We have created a stable and user-friendly computer reminder system, adapted to the needs and requirements of GPs. Preliminary results on the effectiveness of the system seem to indicate that implementing a computer reminder system with reactive reminders improves drug prescribing behavior.

title: Conception and implementation of training courses to improve the handling of pediatric obesity
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Clinicians report low levels of proficiency in treating obese children and using behavior management strategies. This paper documents the design and implementation of a training program to improve physicians' skills in the assessment and behavioral management of pediatric obesity. METHODS: Two one-hour CME training courses were designed using published guidelines, research, and expert panel recommendations. The training was offered to clinicians in a managed care pediatric unit using novel screening and counseling tools and interactive exercises. Surveys and focus groups were conducted 3 and 6 months after the intervention to examine physicians' attitudes and practices regarding screening and counseling tools. RESULTS: After the intervention, the majority of clinicians agreed that the clinical practice guidelines (Resource for Pediatric Obesity Practice) and the BMI for the age percentiles provided useful information for clinical practice. Clinicians reported increased use of the recommended screening tools and changes in practice to implement these tools. They offered suggestions on how to improve the usability of the tools and how to overcome perceived barriers for physicians and/or patients. DISCUSSION: A short, low-cost, multi-faceted training and the provision of counseling tools were found helpful for clinical practice. Useful lessons were learned about tool design and methods of putting tools into practice. Training the entire healthcare team is beneficial for adopting new tools and practices.

title: Echo WISELY (Will Inappropriate Echocardiography Scenarios Reduce Significance) Study Design and Methods: An Investigator-Blinded, Randomized, Controlled Study of Education and Feedback Intervention to Reduce Inappropriate Echocardiograms
abstract: BACKGROUND: Appropriate use criteria (AUC) for transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) were developed to address concerns about inappropriate use of TTE. A previous pilot study suggests that an education and feedback intervention can reduce inappropriate TTEs ordered by trainee physicians. It is unknown whether this type of intervention is effective when targeted to treating physicians in a variety of clinical settings. OBJECTIVES: The aim of this international, multicenter study is to test the hypothesis that an AUC-based education and feedback intervention reduces the rate of inappropriate echocardiograms ordered by treating physicians in the outpatient setting. METHODS: Cardiologists and primary care physicians practicing in the outpatient setting are enrolled in an ongoing multicenter, investigator-blinded, randomized controlled trial in Canada and the United States. The intervention arm will receive (1) a lecture detailing AUC and the latest available evidence on the appropriate use of TTE, (2) access to the American Society of Echocardiography mobile phone app, and (3) individualized feedback reports that are provided monthly TTE order behavior including reference to inappropriate TTEs and brief explanations of the inappropriate designation are summarized by e-mail. The control group does not receive education on the appropriate use of TTE and orders TTEs as usual. CONCLUSIONS: The Echo WISELY study (Will Inadequate Scenarios for Echocardiography Lessen Significantly in an Education RCT) is the first multicenter randomized study of an AUC-based educational intervention. The study will examine whether an education and feedback intervention will reduce the rate of inappropriate outpatient TTEs ordered by treating cardiologists and primary care physicians (www.clinicaltrials.gov, identifier NCT02038101).

title: Design factors for the success or failure of guideline-based decision support systems: a case complexity hypothesis
abstract: Computer-based decision support systems (CDSSs) are currently mostly memory systems. However, the effectiveness of such systems in modifying physician behavior is not always observed. We believe that this approach is appropriate when physicians think they know how to prescribe and feel they do not need help, ie for simple clinical cases. In contrast, on-demand approaches that allow flexibility in interpreting the patient's condition are more appropriate for more complex cases, e.g. B. in the treatment of chronic diseases. ASTI is a CDSS that operates in two modes, a critique mode that operates as a memory-based system and a user-initiated guidance mode. Using a clinical case complexity score, a pre/post-intervention experiment was conducted with 10 general practitioners and 15 cases of hypertensive patients. Preliminary results tend to indicate that memory-based interaction is appropriate for simple cases and that physicians are willing to use on-demand systems when clinical situations become more complex, making both modes complementary.

title: Design of highly reliable healthcare organizations
abstract: To improve safety performance, many healthcare organizations have attempted to mimic highly reliable organizations from industries such as nuclear power, chemical processing, and military operations structures. Typical challenges and design options at each level are illustrated using a level model of organizational structures and practices, ranging from local autonomy and formal controls to open questioning and deep self-understanding. We propose how organizations can use the concepts and examples presented to improve their ability to self-design for security and reliability.

title: Conception of the Balance@Work project: systematic development, evaluation and implementation of an occupational health guideline for the prevention of weight gain in employees
abstract: BACKGROUND: Occupational health professionals can play an important role in preventive health promotion activities for employees. However, due to a lack of knowledge and evidence- and practice-based methods and strategies, interventions have so far hardly been implemented by occupational physicians. The aim of the Balance@Work project is to develop, evaluate and implement occupational health and safety guidelines to prevent employees from gaining weight. METHODS: Following the guideline development protocol of the Dutch Society for Occupational Medicine and the intervention mapping protocol, the guideline was developed on the basis of literature, interviews with relevant stakeholders and consensus of an expert group. The guide consists of a personal and an environmental component. The individual component provides recommendations for occupational health professionals to promote physical activity and healthy eating habits based on motivational interviewing principles. The environmental component includes a tool for assessing the obesogenic environment. The guideline will be evaluated in a randomized controlled study among 20 occupational physicians. Occupational physicians in the intervention group apply the guideline to eligible employees for 6 months. Occupational physicians in the control group provide care as usual. The measurements take place at the beginning of the study and 6, 12 and 18 months afterwards. The primary target parameters include waist circumference, daily physical activity and eating habits. Secondary outcome parameters include physical inactivity, determinants of behavior change, body weight and body mass index, cardiovascular disease risk profile, and quality of life. In addition, productivity, absenteeism and profitability are evaluated. DISCUSSION: Improving workers' daily physical activity and dietary habits can prevent weight gain and subsequently improve workers' health, increase productivity and reduce absenteeism. After an impact and process evaluation, the guideline will be adjusted and published after approval. Together with several implementation aids, the published guideline is widely disseminated by the Dutch Society for Occupational Medicine. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN73545254/NTR1190.

title: Design, implementation, and evaluation of a knowledge translation intervention to increase organ donation after cardiovascular death in Canada: a study protocol
abstract: Background The shortage of transplantable organs is a global problem. There are two types of organ donation: living and deceased. Organ donation from the deceased can occur after a neurological determination of death (NDD) or a cardiac death. Cardiocirculatory death (DCD) donation accounts for the largest increase in organ donation from the deceased worldwide. However, differences in the use of DCD exist within Canada and around the world. The reasons for these discrepancies are largely unknown. The purpose of this study is to design, implement, and evaluate a theory-based knowledge translation intervention to provide practical guidance on how to increase the number of DCD organ donors without decreasing the number of standard NDD donors. Methods We will use a three-step, mixed-methods approach. In step one, we conduct semi-structured interviews based on the Theoretical Domains Framework to identify and describe stakeholders' beliefs and attitudes towards DCD and their perceptions of the multi-level factors influencing DCD. We will identify: determinants of the evidence-practice gap, specific behavioral changes and/or process changes required to increase DCD, specific groups of clinicians or organizations (e.g., provincial-level donor organizations) that require behavioral change. " and specific goals for interventions. In step two, using the principles of intervention mapping, we will develop a theory-based knowledge translation intervention that includes behavior modification techniques to overcome the identified barriers and improve enablers for DCD. In step three, we will roll out the intervention in hospitals across the 10 Canadian provinces and assess its effectiveness using a multiple-paused time-series design. Discussion We will use a behavioral approach to define and test novel, theory-based, and ethically acceptable knowledge translation strategies to increase the number of available DCD organ donors in Canada. If this study is successful, it will ultimately lead to more transplants and reduce patient morbidity and mortality at the population level.

title: Design of a patient-centric personal health record to promote preventive care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence-based prevention services offer profound health benefits, yet Americans receive only half of the care indicated. A variety of government and professional society policy initiatives encourage the adoption of information technologies to engage patients in their care, such as: B. personal health records, but current systems may not utilize the full potential of the technology. METHODS: Using a previously described model to make information technology more patient-centric, we developed an interactive preventive health record (IPHR) designed to engage patients more in preventive care and health promotion. We recruited 14 primary care practices to promote IPHR to all adult patients and sought practice and patient input in designing IPHR to ensure its usability, relevance, and generalizability. Input included patient usability tests, practice workflow observations, learning collaborations, and patient feedback. IPHR usage was measured using practice appointment and IPHR databases. RESULTS: The IPHR that emerged from this process creates tailored patient recommendations based on guidelines from the US Preventive Services Task Force and other organizations. It extracts clinical data from the electronic health record of the practices and receives information for the health risk assessment of patients. Clinical content is translated and explained in lay language. Recommendations examine the benefits and uncertainties of services and possible actions for patients and physicians. Embedded in the recommendations are self-management tools, risk calculators, decision aids and community resources selected according to the patient's clinical circumstances. Within six months, practices had encouraged 14.4% of patients to use IPHR (ranging from 1.5% to 28.3% across the 14 practices). Practices successfully integrated IPHR into their workflow and used it to prepare patients for visits, enhance behavioral counseling, explain test results, automatically remind patients of overdue services, notify physicians of needed services, and formulate personalized prevention plans. CONCLUSIONS: The IPHR demonstrates that a patient-centered personal health record connected to the electronic medical record can provide a high level of individualized guidance to patients and can be successfully adopted by busy primary care practices. Further investigation and refinement is needed to make information systems even more patient-centric and to demonstrate their impact on care. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT00589173.

title: Designing a valid, randomized, pragmatic implementation study for primary care: the My Own Health Report (MOHR) project.
abstract: Background There is an urgent need for more attention to patient-centred health behaviors and psychosocial issues in primary care, and for practical tools, study designs, and outcomes of clinical and policy relevance. Our goal is to design a scientifically rigorous and validated pragmatic study to test whether primary care practices can implement patient information collection in a systematic way and provide patients with the counseling, goal setting, and counseling in response they need. Methods This manuscript reports the iterative design of the My Own Health Report (MOHR) study, a cluster-randomized delayed intervention study. Four months later, nine couples from different primary care practices are randomized to early or delayed intervention. The intervention consists of conducting the MOHR assessment, which addresses 10 domains of health behavior and psychosocial issues, and then providing the necessary counseling and support to patients presenting for wellness or chronic care. As a pragmatic participatory study, stakeholders, including practice partners and patients, were engaged throughout the study design to accommodate local resources and specifics. Participatory tasks include identifying MOHR assessment content, refining the study design, providing input on outcome measurements, and designing the implementation flow. Study outcomes include intervention reach (percentage of patients offered the MOHR assessment and who complete the MOHR assessment), efficacy (patients report being interviewed about issues, setting goals for change, and support for early versus delayed intervention practices). obtained), contextual factors influencing outcomes, and intervention costs. Discussion The MOHR study demonstrates how a participatory design can be used to promote the consistent collection and use of patient-reported health behavior and psychosocial assessments across a wide range of primary care settings. Although the study design is pragmatic in nature, it allows for valid comparisons to answer the research question posed, and the results are broadly generalisable to a range of primary care settings. According to the PRECIS framework (Pragmatic Explanatory Continuum Indicator Summary), the study design is much more pragmatic than other published studies. The methods and results should be of interest to researchers, practitioners and policy makers trying to make healthcare more patient-centric and relevant.

title: Recognition and management of alcohol consumption disorders in German primary care under the influence of non-clinical factors
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The primary objective was to determine the proportion of recognized and correctly referred patients in German primary care. The secondary objective was to identify patient and physician characteristics that predict detection and correct referral. Methods: In this clustered cross-sectional survey in German primary care, 3003 consecutive patients were invited to participate and asked to fill out a standardized health questionnaire. They were then screened for problem alcohol use using the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test. The physicians recorded their assessment of the presence of an alcohol use disorder and documented the course of treatment of all identified patients for 3 months. RESULTS: Correctly identified problem drinkers were 38.6% in a per-protocol analysis and 33.6% using a worst-case scenario. In 64.6% of the documented cases and in 27.0% in the worst-case scenario, the referral behavior of the physicians conformed to the guidelines. Several patient (e.g., gender, age) and provider (e.g., age) characteristics have been identified that influence patient diagnosis and referral. CONCLUSIONS: There is a clear need to improve the specific diagnostic and therapeutic skills of general practitioners so that they can indicate and implement secondary prevention. Further research should focus on the likely impact of implementing these diagnostic and management tools.

title: Detection of lymphocytotoxic antibodies in relatives of patients with type I diabetes
abstract: Lymphocytotoxic antibody levels were measured in serum samples from 19 patients recently diagnosed with type 1 diabetes and 43 healthy relatives (33 consanguineous and 10 non-consanguineous). The specificity of the reaction was tested at 15°C and 37°C against T lymphocytes and purified helper/inducer and cytotoxic/suppressor subsets. Lymphocytotoxic antibody levels were significantly higher in each of the three test groups than in the control group (type I patients, p<0.005", consanguineous relatives, p<0.001", and non-consanguineous relatives, p<0.002). . The detection frequency of the antibodies was also higher in each of the study groups (p<0.01, p<0.01 and p<0.05, respectively). Cytotoxicity affected both subgroups at 15°C but only cytotoxic/suppressor cells at 37°C. Findings of lymphocytotoxic antibodies in healthy relatives of type I diabetics, regardless of consanguinity, suggest that an environmental agent such as a virus is at least partially responsible for this lymphocytotoxic effect. Furthermore, the residual cytotoxic/suppressor cell killing at 37 degrees C may explain the suppressor cell defect seen in these patients.

title: Determinants of health-promoting lifestyles of students
abstract: This descriptive study of 151 college students in Boston, Massachusetts was conducted to determine the relationships of their perceived health status, gender, grade point average, and health and non-health majors to their health-promoting lifestyle using the Health Promoting Lifestyle Profile (HPLP) II , based on Pender's model. Students' perceived health status was significantly predictive of HPLP II overall, exercise, stress management, and spiritual growth. College women practiced significantly better nutrition, interpersonal relationships, health stewardship, and overall HPLP II than men. The entire sample performed worse on stress management than any previously studied group. Male students, those reporting poor health, and all students are targeted for intervention and research in their deficient areas. Guidelines for nursing practice are derived from the HPLP II questionnaire. These clinically significant findings can guide nurses to intervene in college student health awareness and practices.

title: Determinants of successful clinical networks: the conceptual framework and study protocol
abstract: Background Clinical networks are increasingly recognized as an important strategy to increase evidence-based practice and improve models of care, but success has varied and the characteristics of high-impact networks are uncertain. This study uses the variability in the functioning and outcomes of networks supported by Australia's New South Wales (NSW) Agency for Clinical Innovation non-mandatory model of clinical networks to examine the factors that contribute to the success of clinical networks. Methods/Design The aim of this retrospective study is to examine the relationship between external support, organizational and program-related factors and indicators of success in 19 clinical networks over a three-year period (2006-2008). The findings (health impact, system impact, programs implemented, engagement, user perceptions, and financial leverage) and explanatory factors are collected using a web-based survey, interviews, and recordings. An independent panel of experts will make judgments on the impact or scale of each network's health and systems impact initiatives. The expert panel ratings are the outcome used in multivariate analyses. Following the network success assessment, a qualitative study is conducted to examine the most successful networks in more detail. Discussion This is the first study to combine quantitative and qualitative methods to examine the factors that contribute to the success of clinical networks and is generally the largest study of clinical networks ever conducted. The adaptation of expert panel methods for evaluating the effects of networks is the methodical innovation of this study. The proposed project will identify the conditions that should be created or encouraged by agencies developing clinical networks and will be of direct use in developing strategies and programs to maximize the effectiveness of such networks.

title: Development of a managed clinical network in palliative care: a realistic assessment
abstract: BACKGROUND: Achieving evidence-based practice is at the forefront of the international practice development agenda. It is therefore imperative that robust assessment methods are available to test new approaches to service development. OBJECTIVES: This paper reflects the merits and challenges of a realistic assessment design in establishing a new Managed Clinical Network (MCN) approach to implementation of guideline addressing the care of individuals with cancer-related pain. DESIGN AND METHODS: There were three assessment items examining three versions of the MCN nursing approach. At each stage, steps were taken to identify the context, mechanisms, and outcomes associated with the version of the model being studied. Findings from patient-centred case studies were incorporated into realistic evaluation discussions with the management group. SETTING: A rural basic service in Scotland. PARTICIPANTS: Three elderly men, their families, and the doctors and nurses directly attending to them participated along with 13 members of the network management group. RESULTS: The research clarified the effort required by practitioners to implement the MCN nursing approach. Progress has been much slower than expected, frustrated at times by inexperience in change management and unfamiliarity with leading practice development projects and supporting practitioner learning. Issues related to the age adequacy of the evidence base related to caring for the frail elderly were also evident. The occupational group that experienced the most role changes were district nurses and community pharmacists. CONCLUSION: The collaborative approach encouraged by the realistic assessment framework was found to be particularly helpful, and there was consensus that assessment had become an integral part of the intervention itself. There were a number of methodological challenges and the need to limit the depth of "realistic unraveling". However, as a formative approach, realistic evaluation proved to be a worthy design in the chaotic world of interdisciplinary practice development.

title: Development of a pain assessment tool for use by nurses in an adult intensive care unit
abstract: Critically ill patients are particularly vulnerable to pain, which patients cite as the second most stressful factor in the ICU. Pain has also been identified as an aggravating factor in critical illness. Despite this, pain management is often not considered a priority by the ICU team. Effective treatment can only be achieved with an accurate pain assessment. However, this is difficult in the case of the seriously ill, since the patients are often unable to communicate verbally due to the presence of endotracheal/tracheal cannulas, sedatives and paralytics. Caregivers therefore rely on behavioral and physiological indicators to determine the presence of pain. However, since these also occur in situations and conditions that are not associated with pain, a systematic, objective assessment tool is required. Such a tool, consisting of a numerical and verbal rating scale to facilitate documentation and verification, was developed as a result of ongoing adaptation and evaluation. The tool assesses the patient's pain by incorporating behavioral and physiological indicators and is used in conjunction with the Glasgow Coma Score and the Modified Sheffield Sedation Scale to achieve a comprehensive neurological assessment. Because movement and intervention can exacerbate pain, assessment is done at rest and during procedures such as suctioning and manual handling. A flowchart and clinical guideline were also introduced to aid in pain assessment and management. Although a preliminary evaluation confirmed the instrument's effectiveness as a means of estimating and recording pain levels in individual patients, it was evident that the way pain is managed has not changed. To address this issue, nurses' knowledge of pain management was assessed and training was conducted to raise the profile of pain management in the department.

title: Developing a Science of Clinical Utility in Field Study Strategies for Diagnostic Classification Systems for ICD-11 Mental and Behavioral Disorders
abstract: The World Health Organization (WHO) Division of Mental Health and Substance Abuse has developed a systematic program of field studies to assess and improve the clinical usefulness of the proposed diagnostic guidelines for mental and behavioral disorders in the eleventh revision of the International Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems (ICD -11). The clinical usefulness of a diagnostic classification is critical to its function as an interface between health contacts and health information, and to making the ICD-11 a more effective tool to help the 194 member countries of the WHO, including the United States, manage the global burden of mental illness disturbances. This article describes the WHO's efforts to develop a science of clinical utility related to one of the two main classification systems for mental disorders. We present the rationale and methods for an integrated and complementary set of field study strategies, including large international surveys, formative field studies on the structure of clinicians' conceptualization of mental disorders, case-controlled field studies using experimental methods to assess the proposed impact of changes in diagnostic guidelines on diagnostic decision-making Physicians and environmental implementation Field studies with clinical utility in the global settings where the guidelines will ultimately be implemented. The results of these studies have already informed decisions about the structure and content of ICD-11. If clinical usefulness is indeed among the highest goals of mental disorder diagnostic systems, as their developers routinely claim, future revision efforts should continue to build on these efforts. (PsycINFO database entry

title: Development of an intervention to encourage young people's participation in asthma screening consultations with practicing nurses
abstract: AIM: The article is a report of a study to develop an evidence-based pre-counseling guide for young people to be used prior to a nurse's asthma assessment. BACKGROUND: Participation of young people aged 13-19 in consultations with health professionals may be limited by the lack of opportunities to learn the relevant skills in triadic consultations. Evidence-based interventions to encourage adult participation in consultation have been developed, but the needs of young people have not been specifically addressed. DESIGN: Design using multiple methods informed by guidelines for designing complex interventions. METHODS: In 2007, a pre-counselling guide for young people was developed through application of a health behavior change model, development of criteria by an expert panel and in consultation with young people using a nominal group technique. RESULTS: The concepts of the Health Action Process Approach model were applied to the development of criteria underpinning the pre-consultation guide. In the nominal groups, the young people agreed that they have different needs than other children and adults. The consensus was that the pre-counseling guide should include disease-specific information, realistic photographs rather than clipart, consistent fonts, bullets and colors, short words, and mature language. Statements and sample questions written by young people have been included in the evidence-based guide. CONCLUSION: Young people's views can inform the development of interventions aimed at promoting communication in consultations with caregivers. There is potential for this approach to be used to develop interventions in primary and secondary care for a range of long-term conditions.

title: Developing guidelines for child health workers in the community and examining referral pathways and treatment outcomes in supporting emotionally and behaviorally disturbed children
abstract: East Sussex's Public Health Commissioners had asked whether referral policies were needed to ensure the children with the greatest concerns received support from Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services (CAMHS). Community pediatricians and nurses recorded all contacts with children with emotional and behavioral difficulties (EBD) over a one-month period. Data on encountered difficulties and intervention pathways were collected. The same children were reassessed five months later and outcome was measured by clinical assessment and support provided. The work showed that child health workers handled cases both through individual counseling sessions and through planned ongoing support. In addition, the use of the three-step pathways recommended by the Ministry of Health was demonstrated. Analysis of the recorded data was used to describe referral pathways and provide guidance on the characteristics of children requiring referral to CAMHS.

title: Development of guidelines for smoking cessation interventions in pregnant adolescents
abstract: More than 400,000 deaths per year in the United States are attributed to active and passive tobacco smoke. The goals of Healthy People 2000 aim to reduce tobacco use among high-risk groups such as adolescents and pregnant women. This article describes smoking cessation guidelines for healthcare professionals working with pregnant adolescents and adolescent mothers who smoke.";" PIP: This article examines key components of smoking cessation and health promotion interventions for pregnant and parenting adolescents. It also describes smoking cessation guidelines for healthcare professionals when working with pregnant adolescents and adolescent mothers who smoke. Both pregnancy and tobacco use are increasing among youth in the United States. There is strong evidence that cigarette smoking among pregnant adolescents is even higher than the national rate. Such a habit in pregnant teenagers poses an immediate risk to the fetus, plus an increased risk of the teenager developing a smoking habit. Quitting smoking during pregnancy can have a significant impact on reducing infant mortality. To this end, it is suggested that health professionals can have a positive impact on maternal, infant and child health by encouraging and supporting smoking cessation efforts among young mothers. The physician is in a special position to offer this advice during health surveillance visits. Overall, the intervention guidelines presented in this article can be used in school clinics with pregnant schoolgirls and can easily be implemented in private practices or clinics.

title: Developing internet-based health interventions: a guide for public health researchers and practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND: Researchers and practitioners interested in developing online health interventions rely mostly on web-based and printed resources to guide them through the process of developing online interventions. While it is useful to understand many aspects of best practice for website development, these resources lack concrete examples of online health app development experiences from the perspective of those delivering online health interventions. AIM: This study is intended to serve as a series of case studies on the development of online health interventions to provide insights for researchers and practitioners considering technology-based interventional or programmatic approaches. METHODS: A sample of six study coordinators and five principal investigators at a large US-based land grant university were interviewed about the process of developing online interventions in the areas of alcohol policy, youth health, medication use, and human immunodeficiency virus prevention in transgender individuals and in men who have sex with men. Participants were asked questions that addressed each of the four phases of the User-Centered Design Process Map from the US Department of Health and Human Services Research-Based Web Design & Usability Guidelines. The interviews were tape-recorded and transcribed. Qualitative codes were developed using line-by-line open coding for all transcripts, and all transcripts were independently coded by at least 2 authors. Disagreements between the programmers were resolved through discussions. FINDINGS: We identified the following seven themes: (1) hire a strong (or at least the right) research team, (2) take time to plan before beginning the design process, (3) acknowledge that vendors and researchers have different values, goals, and language, (4) develop a detailed contract, (5) document all decisions and development activities, (6) use a content management system, and (7) plan additional ones Time to test and debug your intervention. Each of these areas is discussed in detail, with supporting citations from principal investigators and study coordinators. CONCLUSIONS: The values of the members of each participating organization involved in the development of the online intervention or program and the goals to be achieved with the website must be considered. These defined values and goals should stimulate an open and explicit discussion about the scope of work, budget and other needs from each organization's perspective. Because of the complexity of developing online interventions, researchers and practitioners should become familiar with the process and how it may differ from the development and implementation of in-person interventions or programs. To support this, the intervention team should consider augmenting the team with experts in computer science or learning technologies and utilizing institutional resources needed to successfully complete the project. Finally, we describe the trade-off between available resources for online intervention or program development and the complexity of the project.

title: Developing leadership capacity for guideline use: a randomized controlled trial with pilot clusters
abstract: MEANING: The importance of leadership in influencing the use of clinical guidelines by nurses is well documented. However, little is known about how leadership interventions can be developed and evaluated for use in guidelines. PURPOSE: The purpose of this study was to test a leadership intervention aimed at influencing nurses' application of guideline recommendations when caring for patients with diabetic foot ulcers in the home setting. This paper reports on the feasibility of implementing the study protocol, the study results in terms of nursing process outcomes and leadership behavior. METHODS: A mixed-methods pilot study was conducted using a post-only randomized controlled cluster study and descriptive qualitative interviews. Four units were randomized to control or experimental groups. Clinical and management leadership teams participated in a 12-week leadership intervention (workshop, conference calls). Participants received summarized chart audit data, identified change targets, and created a team leadership action. Criteria for evaluating the feasibility of the protocol included: design, intervention, measures, and data collection procedures. For the study, chart audits compared differences in nursing process outcomes. PRIMARY RESULT: 8-Point Nursing Evaluation Score. Secondary outcome: 5-point score of care based on change goals identified by intervention participants. Qualitative interviews described leadership behavior that influenced the use of guidelines. RESULTS: Conducting this pilot project showed that some aspects of the study protocol were feasible while others needed further development. The study results showed no significant difference in the primary endpoint. A significant increase was observed in the 5-point score chosen by intervention participants (p=0.02). In the experimental group, relationship-oriented leadership behavior, audit and feedback, and reminders were described as leadership strategies. CONCLUSIONS: The results suggest that a leadership intervention has the potential to influence nurses' use of guideline recommendations, but more work is needed to refine the intervention and outcome measures. A taxonomy of leadership behavior is proposed to inform future research.

title: Development of quality benchmarks for the management of suicidal behaviors in the emergency department
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Given the public health importance of suicidal behaviors and the corresponding gap in the performance measurement literature, we attempted to identify key process indicators (measures of quality of care) and structural measures (organizational resources and characteristics) that are relevant to the Emergency Department (ED) Management of Suicidal Behaviors in Children. METHODS: We reviewed nationally accepted guidelines and published research to compile an inventory of interventions. Next, we surveyed experienced pediatric ED clinicians to assess the level of agreement on the relevance (to patient care) and variability (across hospitals) of 42 candidate process indicators and to assess whether 10 hospital and regional structural measures could affect these processes . RESULTS: Twenty-three physicians from 14 pediatric tertiary care hospitals responded (93% of hospitals contacted). Possible process indicators identified as both most relevant to patient care (>/= 87% agreed or strongly agreed) and most varied across hospitals (>/= 78% agreed or strongly agreed) were waiting time for a medical evaluation”, referral to a crisis intervention staff/program; Mental health assessment, psychosocial or risk assessment required; any inpatient admission; inpatient psychiatric admission; treatment plan after discharge; waiting time for the first follow-up appointment; follow-up care received; and type of follow-up received. Key hospital and regional structural measures (>/=87% agreed or strongly agreed) were professionals and type of professionals in or available for the ED; regional policies, protocols or procedures;” and inpatient mental health services. CONCLUSIONS: This study highlighted candidate performance measures for ED management of suicidal behaviors in children. The 9 candidate process indicators (covering screening, assessment, admission, discharge and follow-up) and 4 hospital and regional structural measures deserve further development.

title: Developing team leadership to facilitate guideline application: planning and evaluating a 3-month intervention strategy
abstract: BACKGROUND: Research describes leadership as important to the use of guidelines. However, interventions to develop current and future leaders to this end are not well understood. OBJECTIVE: To describe the planning and evaluation of a leadership intervention to help caregivers apply guideline recommendations for diabetic foot ulcers in the home setting. METHOD: The planning of the intervention involved a synthesis of theory and research (qualitative interviews and chart audits). A workshop and three subsequent conference calls were held at two locations for nurse managers and clinical directors (n=15) responsible for 180 employed nurses. The evaluation included workshop surveys and interviews. RESULTS: The highest-scoring intervention components (four-point scale) were: identification of goal indicators (mean 3.7) and development of an action plan for team leadership (mean 3.5). The rating of the barriers before the workshop was rated the lowest (mean 2.9). Three months later, participants indicated that their leadership performance had changed as a result of the intervention, that they were more engaged with the employees and that they were clear about the implementation goals. CONCLUSIONS AND IMPLICATIONS FOR NURSING MANAGEMENT: Creating a team leadership action plan to operationalize leadership behaviors can aid in the delivery of evidence-based nursing. Access to clinical data and understanding of team leadership knowledge and skills prior to formal training assists nursing management in adapting intervention strategies to identify needs and gaps.

title: Development of the protocol for the evaluation of the Health Foundation's "Engagement with Quality Initiative" - an emerging approach
abstract: In 2004, UK charity The Health Foundation launched the Engaging with Quality Initiative to research and assess the benefits of engaging clinicians in quality improvement in healthcare. Eight projects from professional associations or specialist societies were commissioned in various areas of acute care. A development approach was chosen for the initiative, which was accompanied by a two-stage evaluation: eight self-assessments of the projects and an associated external evaluation. This paper describes how the protocol for external evaluation was developed. Challenges included major differences between and within projects (in approach, scope and context, and understanding of quality improvement), the need to support project teams in their self-assessments while maintaining the necessary objectivity, and the difficulty of assessing the mobile Goal created by the development approach adopted in the initiative. An initial phase in developing the assessment protocol proved invaluable in helping us investigate these issues.

title: Development and implementation of a tool for quality improvement in medical oncology for a regional oncology network: the Fox Chase Cancer Center Partners initiative
abstract: Fox Chase Cancer Center Partners (FCCCP) is a community hospital/academic partnership comprised of 25 hospitals in the Delaware Valley. Originally founded in 1986, FCCCP advances quality cancer care in the community through education, quality assurance and access to clinical trials research. An important aspect of quality assurance is an annual medical oncology audit that compares quality indicators and guidelines and provides a roadmap for quality improvement initiatives in community oncology clinical practice. Each year, the FCCCP team and partner Medical Oncologists create disease site and stage specific indicators based on the clinical practice guidelines of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) in oncology. Compliance with multiple indicators is assessed using 20 charts from each group practice. A report for each FCCCP medical oncology practice summarizes documentation, screening recommendations, use of new drugs, and research trends at a specific disease site. Descriptive statistics reflect the indicators achieved, the number of new cases per year, the number of cases at the site of disease from tumor registry information, and the total number of clinical trial results collected. Training and documentation tools are made available to oncology practice physicians and nurses. The FCCCP Clinical Operations Team, consisting of medical oncologists and oncology-certified nurses, has been conducting quality audits in medical oncology practices using NCCN-derived indicators for 7 years. Successful audits on gastric, colon and breast cancer have been the focus of recent assessments. In the 2005 assessment of stage II/III breast cancer, the average compliance per parameter was 88%, with 15 out of 16 practices achieving an average compliance greater than 80%. A large-scale quality assurance audit in a community cancer partner network is feasible. Recent assessment of localized breast cancer shows high compliance with guidelines and identifies areas for targeted education. The partnership between academic and local oncologists results in a quality review process that is broadly applicable and adaptable to changing medical knowledge.

title: Development and implementation of a program to assess medical patients' need for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis
abstract: Purpose. The development and implementation of a program to assess the need of medical patients for prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism (VTE) is described. Summary. Hartford Hospital's pharmacy, medical and information services departments have worked together to create a program to improve VTE prevention in medical patients. After assessing adherence to baseline VTE prophylaxis, departments designed an intervention consisting of a message to be displayed to providers using the institution's computerized order entry system (CPOE) as a reminder to Assess the current patient for VTE risk factors and the need for VTE prophylaxis. The message was displayed when a patient met predefined criteria for VTE risk factors. The message was no longer displayed once either mechanical or pharmacological VTE prophylaxis was an active prescription in the patient's medication profile. Hospital staff, pharmacists, doctors, nurses and nurses received extensive training on the program. The program was implemented in March 2007 on a medical pilot floor. To measure the impact of the program, a retrospective review of the charts was performed using the developed risk assessment tool. The VTE prophylaxis compliance rate after implementation was 93% compared to 49% before program implementation (p<0.001). Before the program, only 25% of patients with a contraindication to pharmacological therapy received mechanical prophylaxis compared to 100% after program implementation. Conclusion. The use of alerts through a CPOE system and an interdisciplinary team approach to assess patients' VTE risk appeared to improve the use of VTE prophylaxis in medical patients.

title: Development and implementation of non-pharmacological protocols for the treatment of patients with Alzheimer's disease and their families in a multiracial primary care setting
abstract: PURPOSE: Most patients and families with dementia are cared for in primary care hospitals. These clinics are rarely designed to provide the necessary comprehensive care. The purpose of this article is to describe non-pharmacological protocols for the management of patients with Alzheimer's disease and their families, administered as part of a multifaceted care management intervention program in a multiracial primary care clinic. DESIGN & METHODS: The non-pharmacological component for the integrated cooperative care program was developed based on a literature review and previous clinical experience. Care is coordinated by a geriatric nurse who meets with patients, families and GPs. The non-pharmacological protocols included general educational guidelines about Alzheimer's disease. Specific protocols have also been developed to treat the common behavioral disorders associated with Alzheimer's disease. A key component of the intervention is a monthly psychoeducational support group for family caregivers. RESULTS: The intervention was well received by patients, families, and physicians. Approximately half of the treatment group participated regularly in the self-help group. IMPACT: The integration of behavioral interventions and team nurturing within primary care has been successful.

title: Developing and testing a caring intervention for older adults with heart failure
abstract: The clinical burden and cost burden of heart failure (HF) continues to increase, creating an immediate need for cost-effective interventions aimed at improving health outcomes. This article describes the development and testing of a caring nursing intervention for older adults with advanced heart failure recently discharged from acute care.
