The development process and the components of the intervention are presented. A methodology for testing the intervention is also presented. Through an incremental development process, including research, this intervention can be refined and used to guide clinicians, administrators, and policy makers in providing quality care to older adults with heart failure.

title: Developing a behavior change intervention: A case study of the practical application of the theory
abstract: BACKGROUND: The use of theory in the implementation of complex interventions is widely recommended. In the Managing Osteoarthritis in Consultations (MOSAICS) study, a complex study intervention to improve self-management support for people with osteoarthritis (OA) needed to be implemented in primary care. One component of the study intervention was conducting an extended consultation for patients with osteoarthritis by general practitioners (GPs). The aim of our case study is to describe the systematic selection and use of theory to design a behavior change intervention to implement the GP delivery of extended consultation. METHODS: The development of the behavior change intervention was guided by four theoretical models/frameworks: i) an implementation of the change model to guide the overall approach, ii) the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF) to identify relevant determinants of change, iii) a model for the selection of Behavior change techniques to address identified determinants of behavior change, and iv) the principles of adult learning. Methods and measures to assess the effect of the behavior change intervention were identified. RESULTS: The behavior change intervention presented GPs with a well-defined proposal for change” addressed seven of the TDF domains (e.g., knowledge, skills, motivation, and goals); included ten behavior change techniques (eg, providing information, practicing skills). , persuasive communication);" and was delivered in workshops that valued the expertise and professional values of GPs. The workshops used a mix of interactive and didactic sessions, were moderated by opinion leaders, and utilized "contextual communication skills training". Among the methods selected and measures to assess the behavior change intervention included: assessment of satisfaction with the workshops, physician's report of intent to practice, and an assessment of videotaped consultations by primary care physicians with patients with OA.CONCLUSIONS: A stepwise approach to developing an intervention for Behavior change, with the use of theoretical frameworks to identify determinants of change, aligned with behavior change techniques, has enabled a systematic and theory-driven development of an intervention aimed at GP consultations improve patients with OA. The success of the practice behavior change intervention will be assessed in the context of the MOSAICS study as a whole and will inform the understanding of practice levels and patient outcomes in the study.

title: Development of a complex intervention for secondary prevention of coronary artery disease in primary care using the UK Medical Research Council framework
abstract: AIM: To apply the UK Medical Research Council (MRC) framework for the design and assessment of complex intervention studies to a primary health care intervention to promote secondary prevention of coronary artery disease. STUDY DESIGN: Case report of intervention development. METHODS: First, the literature on secondary prevention and lifestyle modification was reviewed. Second, a preliminary intervention was modeled based on literature reviews and focus group interviews with patients (n = 23) and staff (n = 29) from 4 general practices. Participants' experiences and attitudes towards the main components of the intervention were examined. Third, the preliminary intervention was piloted in 4 primary care practices. After conducting the pilot intervention, practitioners evaluated the training sessions and qualitative data on the experience of the intervention was collected using semi-structured interviews with staff (n=10) and patient focus groups (n=17). RESULTS: The literature review identified 3 intervention components: a structured callback system, physician education, and patient information. Initial qualitative data identified variations in recall system design, training requirements (drug prescribing, enabling behavior changes), and information appropriate to potential study participants. The identification of detailed structures within the intervention components clarified how the intervention can be tailored to the individual needs of the practice, physician and patient, while preserving the theoretical functions of the components. Findings from the pilot phase informed how to further model the intervention, reduce administrative time, increase the practical content of the training, and omit unhelpful patient information. CONCLUSION: Application of the MRC framework helped determine the feasibility and development of a complex intervention for primary care research.

title: Development of a complex intervention to promote appropriate prescribing and medication intensification in poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus in Irish primary care practice
abstract: Background Poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) can be viewed as failure to meet recommended goals for management of important risk factors, including glycemic control, blood pressure, and lipids. Insufficient control of risk factors is associated with significant morbidity, mortality and healthcare costs. Failure to escalate medication when indicated in patients with poor control of T2DM is termed clinical inertia and is a contributing factor to poor control of T2DM. Our aim was to develop a theory- and evidence-based complex intervention to improve appropriate prescribing and medication intensification for poorly controlled T2DM in Irish general practice. Methods The first level of the Medical Research Council Framework for the development and evaluation of complex interventions was used. To identify current evidence, we conducted a systematic review to examine the effectiveness of interventions targeting patients with poorly controlled T2DM in community settings. The theoretical approach of the behavior change wheel was used to identify suitable intervention functions. Workshops, simulation, collaborations with academic partners, and physician observation were used to operationalize the intervention functions and to design the elements of the complex intervention. Results Our systematic review showed that professional interventions, possibly through clinical decision support systems, could counteract poorly controlled T2DM. Appropriate intensification of antiglycemic and cardiovascular medication by general practitioners (GPs) for adults with poorly controlled T2DM has been identified as a key behavior to manage clinical inertia. Psychological skills were the primary driver for the behavior that needed to be changed, which suggested five key intervention functions (education, training, empowerment, environmental restructuring, and incentives) and nine key behavior change techniques operationalized in a complex intervention. The intervention consists of three components: (a) an educational program/academic detailing of target GPs, (b) a remote finder tool to help GPs identify patients with poor control of T2DM in their practice, and (c) a web-based clinical decision support system. Conclusions This paper describes a multifaceted process, including an examination of current evidence and a thorough theoretical understanding of the predictors of behavior, leading to the design of a complex intervention to promote the implementation of evidence-based guidelines through appropriate prescribing and medication intensification in poorly controlled T2DM.

title: Development of a minimization tool for assigning a hospital-level performance improvement intervention to reduce emergency department wait times in Ontario
abstract: Background A rigorous assessment of an intervention requires that its allocation be impartial to confounders; this is particularly difficult in complex, system-wide care interventions. We developed a brief survey instrument to identify factors for a minimization algorithm for a hospital referral-level intervention to reduce emergency department (ED) wait times in Ontario, Canada. Methods Potential confounders affecting intervention success were identified by Literature review identified and grouped by specific stages of change in health attitudes An international multidisciplinary (clinical, administrative, decision-making). Maker, Management) panel assessed these factors in a two-stage modified Delphi and nominal group process based on four domains: willingness to change, evidence base, spurious validity, and clarity of definition. The panel reduced the list to 12 in the first round of surveys. In the second survey experts rated each factor according to the four domains; Summary assessments and consensus discussion led to the final selection and measurement of four hospital-level factors to be used in the minimization algorithm: improved patient flow as a hospital's guiding priority; openness of doctors to organizational changes; bed management efficiency;" and physician incentives that support the change goal. Conclusion We developed a simple tool designed to collect data from senior hospital administrators on factors likely to influence the success of an intervention to improve hospital patient flow A minimization algorithm ensures a balanced allocation of intervention with respect to these factors in study clinics.

title: Development of an instrument to measure clinical competence in occupational therapy: a pilot study?
abstract: Clinical competency is generally defined as a combination of knowledge, ability and professional conduct. It is typically assessed using written tests, direct observation, chart audit, customer satisfaction surveys, and supervisor ratings. This paper describes the development and evaluation of a chart-stimulated recall (CSR) measurement that combines the methods of the chart audit and the clinician interview to assess the clinical competence of practicing occupational therapists. Developed using Canadian guidelines for client-centred practice, the CSR tool opens up global skill areas: use of theory, assessment, program planning, intervention, discharge planning, follow-up, program evaluation, clinical reasoning, and professional conduct. This pilot study involved two independent raters/interviewers who evaluated twelve occupational therapists on two occasions, each using a random sample of patient cases/records. The results show that the CSR tool is not only reliable and valid, but also sufficiently general to be used in a variety of real-world settings as a global measure of workplace performance.

title: Developing an exercise program for older adults: pre-exercise testing, exercise prescription, and program maintenance
abstract: Health professionals have the technical skills, frequency of contact and credibility with older adults to use physical activity as a health promotion and disease prevention intervention. This article familiarizes the physician with developing an exercise program specifically for older adults. The health-promoting and disease-preventing outcomes of physical activity in older adults, including an explanation of the three phases of exercise programming for older adults, are also reviewed. Level one is called the pre-workout test and discusses assessment protocols for aerobic capacity, body composition, flexibility and strength. Policies for who should and shouldn't exercise are also being explored. The second level of training programming is the training prescription. An explanation of how to develop an initial level of training and guidelines for setting goals based on initial pre-exercise testing are presented. Program maintenance is the third stage";" This includes suggestions for designing an exercise program that increases adherence to the program, reduces attrition, and prevents relapse into non-exercise behaviors.

title: Development of an ICF-based clinical practice guideline for functional assessment in head and neck cancer
abstract: BACKGROUND: The functional outcome after head and neck cancer is not regularly standardized in clinical practice. Clinical trials to assess functional outcome use many different tools. Therefore, the results are not always comparable and have limited clinical implications. The aim of this study was the identification, interdisciplinary evaluation and recommendation of functional outcome instruments for use in clinical practice and in clinical trials in patients with HNC. MATERIAL: Preliminary studies resulted in a shortlist of outcome instruments based on previously defined criteria. An interdisciplinary group of experts evaluated these instruments and decided which ones can be recommended for use in 3 application areas: screening, therapy evaluation/planning and clinical studies. Health care decision-makers included physicians (ENT and maxillofacial surgeons, radiation therapists, oncologists), medical psychologists, speech and language therapists, physical therapists, and social workers. RESULTS: 98 instruments were presented at the consensus conference. A total of 21 participants recommended a basic set of measures for assessing impairments in 6 functional areas for each of the 3 application areas: therapy follow-up, pain, nutritional intake, voice/speech, other organic problems and psychosocial problems. CONCLUSION: A multiprofessional pool of experts discussed and approved recommendations for the use of functional outcome instruments in clinical practice and/or research. The recommended instruments are now available for use in clinical routine.

title: Developing clinical practice guidelines for the care of people undergoing percutaneous coronary interventions: A collaboration between Australia and New Zealand
abstract: AIM: This paper describes the development of nursing guidelines for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) to support PCI nursing care are limited. METHOD: The National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&MRC) Guidelines for the Development of Health and Medical Practices were used for the guideline development process. A panel of experts (clinicians and consumers) attended a consensus conference to review existing evidence. The nurses' opinions were then collected via an online survey. A draft guideline was then refined in two rounds using a modified Delphi method. RESULTS: The consensus conference was attended by 41 participants (39 cardiovascular nurses and 2 consumer representatives). Eight other members joined the panel for the modified Delphi rounds, with 27 participants completing the online survey. The final guidance document consisted of 75 recommendations. Approval was then obtained from key cardiovascular bodies in Australia and New Zealand. DISCUSSION/CONCLUSION: Inconclusive evidence precludes definitive recommendations. Therefore, consultation and consensus are important in developing guidelines to achieve standardized maintenance and monitoring of outcomes. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Nurses play a critical role in PCI care, yet there are currently limited guidelines to inform practice. This paper describes the methodology for developing clinical practice guidelines and deriving consensus.

title: Development of geriatric skills for resident emergency physicians as part of an expert consensus process
abstract: BACKGROUND: The emergency department (ED) visit rate for elderly patients exceeds that of all age groups except infants. The aging population will increase utilization of older ED patients to 35% to 60% of all visits. Elderly patients can have complex clinical presentations and be resource intensive. There is evidence that emergency physicians do not consistently provide high quality care to older ED patients, leading to poor clinical outcomes. OBJECTIVES: The objective was the development of a consensus document on “Geriatric Competences for Emergency Medical Practitioners” by recognized experts. This is a minimum set of behavior-based performance standards that all residents should be able to demonstrate by completing their residency training. METHODS: This consensus-based process used an inductive, qualitative, multi-phased method to determine the minimum geriatric competencies needed by emergency medical professionals (EM). Face validity and reliability ratings were used throughout the project. RESULTS: In Phase I, participants (n=363) identified 12 domains and 300 potential competencies. In Phase II, a panel of experts (n=24) grouped the responses from Phase I, resulting in eight domains and 72 competencies. In phase III, the expert panel reduced the competencies to 26. In phase IV, the analysis of the spurious validity and reliability showed a 100% consensus for eight domains and 26 competencies. The domains identified were "atypical disease manifestations," trauma including falls, cognitive and behavioral disorders, intervention modification interventions, medication management, care transitions, pain management, and palliative care." and effect of comorbidities. CONCLUSIONS: The geriatric competencies for EM residents is a consensus document that can form the basis of EM residency curricula and assessments to meet the needs of our aging population.

title: Development, implementation and evaluation of a community pharmacy-based asthma care model
abstract: BACKGROUND Pharmacists are uniquely positioned in the healthcare system to address critical issues in the management of asthma in the community. Various programs have demonstrated the benefits of a pharmacist-led asthma care programme, however no such programs have been evaluated in Australia to date. OBJECTIVE To measure the impact of a specialized asthma service provided by community pharmacies in terms of patient objective clinical, humanistic and economic outcomes. METHODS A parallel controlled design was used, recruiting 52 intervention patients and 50 control patients with asthma at two different sites .In the intervention area, pharmacists were trained and delivered a 3-visit asthma care model over 6 months. This model was compared between and within groups based on clinical, humanistic and economic outcomes. RESULTS There was a significant reduction in asthma severity in the intervention group, 2.6 ± 0.5 to 1.6 ± 0.7 (mean ± SD; p < 0.001) versus the control group, 2.3 ± 0.7 to 1.6 ± 0.7 2.4±0.5. In the intervention group, peak flow indices improved from 82.7% ± 8.2% at baseline to 87.4% ± 8.9% (p<0.001) at the last visit, and there was a significant reduction in defined Daily dose of albuterol used by patients increased from 374.8 ± 314.8 µg at baseline to 198.4 ± 196.9 µg at last visit (p<0.015). There was also a statistically significant improvement in perceived asthma control and asthma-related knowledge scores in the intervention group compared to the control group between baseline and last visit. Annual savings of $132.84 (AU) in medication costs per patient and $100,801.20 for the entire group based on overall severity reduction have been demonstrated. CONCLUSIONS Based on the results of this study, it appears that a specialized treatment model for asthma offers community pharmacists the opportunity to contribute to improving asthma management in the Australian community.

title: Diabetes in Rural Cities: Effectiveness of Education and Feedback for Healthcare Providers in Changing Population-Level Diabetes Outcomes: Protocol for a Cluster-Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Type 2 diabetes is one of the fastest growing chronic diseases internationally. The health complications associated with type 2 diabetes can be prevented, delayed, or ameliorated with early diagnosis and effective management. This research aims to examine the impact of a primarily web-based educational intervention on diabetes care by general practitioners (GPs) in rural areas and resulting patient outcomes. A population-based approach to outcome assessment is used, via city-wide anonymized pathological records. METHODS/DESIGN: The study uses a cluster-randomized controlled trial with rural communities as the unit of analysis. Cities from four Australian states were selected and matched based on factors such as rurality, population size, proportion of Indigenous Australians in the population, and socioeconomic status. Eleven city pairs from two states were eligible for the trial, and one city from each pair was randomly assigned to the experimental group. GPs in cities assigned to the experimental group will be offered an intervention package that includes training on diabetes care best practices via an active online learning module, a moderated discussion forum, access to targeted and expert advice via an online inquiry form, and city-based performance feedback on diabetes monitoring and outcomes. The package is offered via repeated direct mail. DISCUSSION: The benefits of the study's findings are described along with the challenges and limitations associated with the methodology. STUDY REGISTRATION: Australia-New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry: ACTRN12611000553976.

title: Diabetes mellitus - refractory obesity
Diabetes Nurse Case Management and Motivational Interviewing for Change (DYNAMIC): Study Design and Baseline Features in the Chronic Care Model for Type 2 Diabetes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite evidence that diabetes is costly and devastating, the healthcare system is ill-equipped to meet the challenges of managing chronic diseases. The Penn State Institute of Diabetes & Obesity is evaluating a model of treating type 2 diabetes that incorporates nursing case management (NCM) and motivational interviewing (MI) to encourage behavior change. The primary care intervention is designed to improve patient self-care and reduce clinical inertia by having the provider use standardized clinical guidelines to achieve better diabetes outcomes. METHODS: This RCT tests the effectiveness of improved NCM intervention on outcomes in type 2 DM (n=549) patients mediated by changes in self-care behaviors and diabetes management. Outcome measures include: (a) effect on clinical parameters such as HbA1c (<7), BP (<130/80) and LDL (<100), depression scores and weight"; (b) process measures such as complication screening; (c) psychological and patient behavioral outcomes as measured by emotional distress (PAID), diabetes-specific quality of life (ADDQoL), patient satisfaction (DTSQ), self-care activities (SDSCA) and (d) physician satisfaction and cost-effectiveness of the intervention CONCLUSIONS: Baseline includes (average) Age = 58; BMI = 34.4; 57% female;" 47% Caucasian and 39% Hispanic. Patients had elevated HbA1c (8.4), BP (137/77), and LDL (114). Overall, the patients were depressed (CES-D=21.6) and had an extremely negative quality of life (ADDQoL=-1.58). We believe that improved NCM will both improve self-care and reduce emotional distress in patients with diabetes. With proven effectiveness, an increased NCM can be transferred to other chronic diseases.

title: Diabetes translation research: where do we stand and where do we want to be?
abstract: Translational research transforms currently available knowledge into useful measures for everyday clinical and public health. We review advances in diabetes translation research and identify future challenges and opportunities in this area. Several promising interventions to optimize the delivery of effective diabetes treatments are available. Many of these interventions, individually or in combination, need to be more formally tested in larger randomized or quasi-experimental field trials, using outcomes of particular interest to patients (e.g. patient satisfaction and quality of life) and policy makers (e.g. costs). become and profitability). The long-term outcomes (such as morbidity, mortality, quality of life, and costs) of strategies to improve diabetes care need to be evaluated. Translation research must also include ways of studying complex systems of care. The challenges and opportunities presented by translation research are enormous.

title: Diagnosis and Treatment of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The objective of this NIH Consensus Statement is to inform the biomedical research and clinical practice communities of the findings of the NIH Consensus Development Conference on the Diagnosis and Treatment of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). The statement provides up-to-date information on effective treatments for ADHD and presents the consensus panel's conclusions and recommendations on these issues. In addition, the statement identifies those areas of study that require further investigation. Upon completion of this educational activity, the reader should have clear practical clinical knowledge of the state of the art on the subject. The target group of clinicians for this statement includes psychiatrists, general practitioners, paediatricians, internists, neurologists, psychologists and behavioral medicine specialists. PARTICIPANTS: The participants were a panel of 13 representing the fields of psychology, psychiatry, neurology, pediatrics, epidemiology, biostatistics, education and the public. In addition, 31 experts in the same fields presented data to the panel and a conference audience of 1,215. EVIDENCE: The literature was searched via Medline and an extensive bibliography of references was made available to the panel and conference audience. Experts created abstracts with relevant citations from the literature. Scientific evidence was given priority over clinical anecdotal experience. CONSENSUS PROCESS: The panel answered predefined questions and developed its conclusions based on the scientific evidence and literature presented in the open forum. The panel produced a draft statement, which was read in its entirety and circulated to the experts and audience for comment. The panel then resolved conflicting recommendations and released a revised statement at the end of the conference. The panel completed the revisions within weeks of the conference. The draft statement was made available on the World Wide Web immediately after its publication at the conference and was updated with the final revisions of the panel. CONCLUSIONS: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, or ADHD, is a commonly diagnosed childhood behavioral disorder that poses a costly major public health problem. Children with ADHD have distinct disabilities and can experience long-term adverse effects on academic achievement, career success, and socio-emotional development that have profound effects on the individual, family, school, and society. Despite advances in the assessment, diagnosis, and treatment of ADHD, the disorder and its treatment have remained controversial, particularly the use of psychostimulants for both short- and long-term treatment. Although there is no independent diagnostic test for ADHD, there is evidence to support the validity of the disorder. Further research is needed on the dimensional aspects of ADHD, as well as the comorbid (coexisting) conditions present in both the childhood and adult forms. Studies (mostly short-term, approximately three months), including randomized clinical trials, have demonstrated the effectiveness of stimulants and psychosocial treatments in relieving the symptoms of ADHD and associated aggressiveness, and have shown that stimulants are more effective than psychosocial therapies in managing these symptoms . Due to the lack of consistent improvement beyond core symptoms and the lack of long-term studies (beyond 14 months), there is a need for longer-term studies of drugs and behavioral modalities and their combination. Although studies are ongoing, no definitive recommendations for long-term treatment can be made at this time. There is wide variation in the use of psychostimulants between communities and physicians, suggesting that there is no consensus on which ADHD patients should be treated with psychostimulants. (ABSTRACT

title: Diagnosis of a pulmonary embolism
Diagnostic evaluation of low back pain with an emphasis on imaging
abstract: Purpose: To review the evidence on the diagnostic accuracy of clinical information and imaging for patients with back pain in primary care. Data source: MEDLINE search (January 1966 to September 2001) for articles and reviews relevant to the accuracy of the clinical and radiological data Study of patients with low back pain. Study selection: The authors screened abstracts and selected articles for review based on a combined assessment. Clinical examination data were mainly based on recent systematic reviews, while imaging data were mainly based on original papers. Data extraction: The diagnostic results were extracted by one or the other author. The quality of the methods was identified informally assessed, but no quantitative data extraction nor scoring was performed, highest for magnetic resonance imaging (0.83 to 0.93) and radionuclide scanning (0.74 to 0.98);” the specificity was highest for magnetic resonance imaging (0.9 to 0.97) and radiography (0.95 to 0.99). Magnetic resonance imaging was the most sensitive (0.96) and specific (0.92) test for infection. The sensitivity and specificity of magnetic resonance imaging for herniated discs were slightly higher than those of computed tomography, but very similar for the diagnosis of spinal canal stenosis. Conclusions: The data suggest a diagnostic strategy similar to the 1994 guidelines of the Health Policy and Research Agency. In adults younger than 50 years of age without signs or symptoms of systemic disease, symptomatic therapy without imaging is appropriate. In patients 50 years and older or with findings suggestive of systemic disease, plain radiographs and simple laboratory tests can almost completely rule out underlying systemic disease. Extended imaging should be reserved for patients considering surgery or suspected systemic disease.

title: Dietary Management of Hypercholesterolemia: Do Dietitians Do It Any Better? A randomized controlled trial
abstract: PURPOSE: Current National Cholesterol Education Program (NCEP) guidelines recommend initial dietary counseling by physicians for most patients with hypercholesterolemia. Referral to a licensed dietician and lipid-lowering medications are recommended only for patients who remain hypercholesterolemic. We evaluated the added value of detailed nutritional advice from dietitians when added to general nutritional advice from physicians. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: Patients with hypercholesterolaemia, detected during a cholesterol screening project, were randomly selected to receive dietary advice from a physician only (70 patients) or from a physician and a licensed dietitian (66 patients). . Patients were followed for 1 year to assess compliance with NCEP guidelines. RESULTS: At 3 months, the mean (+/- SD) decrease in serum LDL-C was 7% +/- 11% in the physician group and 12% +/- 10% in the dietitian group (P<0.004). A reduction in LDL-C levels of 10% or more was observed in 25 patients (36%) in the physician group and 43 patients (65%) in the dietitian group (p<0.001). Only 40 (29%) patients in both groups achieved their NCEP goals at 3 months. The majority of these were low-risk patients with an LDL cholesterol target of 160 mg/dL. After 12 months, both groups lost about half of the beneficial effect on LDL cholesterol levels, and the difference between the two groups narrowed. CONCLUSIONS: The short-term reduction in LDL-cholesterol levels achieved by dietitian counseling is superior to that achieved by physicians. However, long-term compliance remains insufficient. In high-risk patients, a more aggressive dietary approach and possibly earlier introduction of lipid-lowering drugs should be considered.

title: Different indications, warnings and precautions, and contraindications for the same drug - an international comparison of prescribing information for commonly used psychotropic drugs
abstract: PURPOSE: Our goal is to derive an internationally applicable data set to improve the prescribing safety of psychotropic drugs. METHODS: We performed an in-depth analysis of the prescribing information concordance of 10 major psychiatric drugs in four major drug markets in terms of indications, warnings and precautions, and contraindications. RESULTS: The individual prescribing information covered an average of 71.4 +/- 30.3% of all indicated indications, 59.5 +/- 17.1% of all potential warnings and cautions, and 70.1 +/- 24.4% of all applicable ones contraindications. CONCLUSION: This significant variation in key prescribing information across countries underscores the need for better international collaboration and standardization of prescribing information.

title: Distinguishing between normal speech disorder and stuttering in children
abstract: The concept of stuttering refers to a lack of fluency or hesitation in a speech pattern. Incidence is reported as 1% worldwide, with a greater incidence in males to females (3:1). Theories of causation are briefly identified, including genetic predisposition and neurological factors. In the process of language acquisition, children of preschool age usually go through a transitional phase of language fluency disorder. This fact can make early stuttering behavior difficult to recognize, can be emotionally painful for the child, and can impair psychological development. The healthcare provider is in a key position to provide early diagnosis and intervention to the child with early stuttering. To do this, the healthcare provider must have the knowledge and ability to distinguish normal developmental disorder from early stuttering. Factors that distinguish these language patterns are identified along with referral guidelines. Current treatment modalities of speech therapists are described. Practical interventions that parents can offer to improve child fluency and reduce speech anxiety are summarized.

title: Difficulties in implementing a mental health guideline: an exploratory study using psychological theory
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evaluations of interventions to improve guideline implementation have not produced a clear pattern of outcomes that favors any particular method. While implementation depends on clinicians and managers changing a variety of behaviors, psychological theories of behavior and behavior change are rarely used to try to understand difficulties in implementation or to design interventions to overcome them. OBJECTIVES: This study applied psychological theory to explore explanations for implementation difficulties. It used a theoretical framework derived from an interdisciplinary consensus exercise to code interviews in 11 theoretical domains. The study focused on the recommendation of a National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence schizophrenia guideline that family interventions should be offered to the families of people with schizophrenia. METHODS: Participants were recruited from community mental health teams from three United Kingdom National Health Service (NHS) trusts; 20 members (social workers, nurses, team managers, psychologists and psychiatrists) participated. Semi-structured interviews were tape-recorded and transcribed. The interview questions were based on the theoretical areas and addressed the respondents' knowledge, attitudes and opinions regarding the guideline. Two researchers independently coded the transcript segments from each interview related to each theoretical area. A score of 1 indicated that the transcript segments related to the domain did not appear to contain a description of difficulties in implementing family therapy guidelines;" Similarly, a score of 0.5 indicates possible difficulties and a score of 0 indicates definite difficulties RESULTS: Coding respondents' responses to questions on the three areas of beliefs about consequences, social/professional role and identity, and motivation yielded the three highest overall scores, suggesting that factors related to these Areas not likely to pose difficulties in implementation “Environmental context and resources” was the lowest scoring area while “Emotions” scored the second lowest, suggesting that these are likely areas where intervention should be considered The two main resources that have been identified as problems n, were time and training. The emotions that appeared to potentially influence the offering of family therapy were self-doubt and fear. CONCLUSION: This exploratory study shows an approach to develop a theoretical understanding of implementation difficulties.

title: Digitization of Medicines: Artifact, Architecture and Time
Time dimension in case of illness: An objective view
Disability related to psychiatric comorbidity and health status among Bosnian refugees living in Croatia
abstract: Context The relationship between psychiatric symptoms and disability in refugee survivors of mass violence is unknown. Aim To determine whether risk factors such as demographics, trauma, health status and mental illness are associated with disabilities in Bosnian refugees. Design, Setting and Participants 1996 cross-sectional survey of adult Bosnian refugees living in a camp set up by the Croatian government near the city of Vara?din. One adult aged 18 or older was randomly selected from each of the 573 camp families; 534 (93%) agreed to participate (mean age 50 years; 41% male). Key Outcome Measures Culturally validated measures for depression and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) included the Hopkins Symptom Checklist 25 and Harvard Trauma Questionnaire, respectively. Disability measures included the Medical Outcomes Study Short-Form 20, a physical functioning scale based on World Health Organization criteria, and self-reports on the socioeconomic activity, levels of physical energy, and perceived health outcomes Respondents reported a mean (SD) of 6.5 (4.7) unduplicated trauma events, 18% (n = 95) had experienced 1 or more torture events, while 55.2 % reported no psychiatric symptoms, 39.2% and 26.3% reported symptoms meeting dsm-iv criteria for depression and ptsd, respectively, 20.6% reported comorbid symptoms for both disorders, 25.5% overall reported having a disability with comorbid symptoms for both depression and PTSD w are associated with an increased risk of disability compared to asymptomatic refugees (unadjusted odds ratio [OR], 5.02; 95% confidence interval Â¦Ã–, 3.05-8.26; adjusted or 2.06; 95%CI, 1.10-3.86). Older age, cumulative trauma, and chronic medical conditions were also associated with disabilities. psychiatric comorbidity was associated with disability independent of the effects of age, trauma, and health status.

title: Distinctive patterns of human immunodeficiency virus risk in healthy young adults
abstract: Previous research has questioned the effectiveness of existing methods for identifying individuals at high risk of contracting and transmitting human immunodeficiency virus and other sexually transmitted diseases. Therefore, new approaches are needed to provide these individuals with risk reduction strategies. We review our research on young adult sexual decision-making using theories and methods from the social and cognitive sciences. Four patterns of condom use and associated risks and beliefs were identified. These patterns suggest that it makes sense to tailor intervention strategies to individuals at different levels of risk. The findings also imply that the monogamous population may be at greater risk of infection than they realize. Primary care physicians are the first port of call for many people in the healthcare system and may be in the best position to screen at-risk individuals. Given the time involved and other obstacles, easily applicable, evidence-based guidelines for such screening are needed. We propose such guidelines for general practitioners to identify individual risk from which tailored intervention strategies can be developed.

title: Dismissal of members of the profession: Protection against dismissal due to professional acts
Discontinuation of cholinesterase inhibitors: results of a survey of Canadian dementia professionals
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cholinesterase inhibitors (ChEIs) are increasingly used in patients with severe Alzheimer's disease. Because there is little data to help physicians decide when it is safe and appropriate to discontinue ChEIs after long-term use, practices can vary widely. METHODS: A web-based survey was conducted among Canadian dementia professionals (geriatric psychiatrists, neurologists, geriatricians) involved in clinical trials research. ChEI discontinuation recommendations were determined based on responses to questions about patient/caregiver preferences, administrative considerations, efficacy, and adverse events. RESULTS: There was a reasonable consensus that ChEIs should be discontinued based on patient and caregiver preference and in the presence of serious troublesome adverse events. There was much less consensus on issues related to effectiveness -- particularly what constitutes a larger-than-expected decline. There was a general reluctance to rely on a single measure of cognition, function, and/or behavior, and in particular the MMSE was considered unhelpful in making discontinuation decisions. CONCLUSION: Recommendations for stopping ChEIs after long-term use from a survey of dementia professionals are presented. Ideally, clinical practice guidelines based on controlled withdrawal studies are needed.

title: Discussing randomized clinical trials of cancer therapy: assessment of a Cancer Research UK training programme
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate an educational intervention aimed at improving how healthcare professionals communicate with cancer patients about randomized clinical trials. DESIGN: Before and after evaluation of the training program. SETTING: Members of the National Cancer Research Network, Scottish Trials Network and Welsh Cancer Trials Network. PARTICIPANTS: 101 health professionals (33 clinicians and 68 research nurses). INTERVENTION: Four modules, conducted by a trained facilitator using videotapes and interactive exercises, to address common issues in discussing randomized clinical trials involving patients, issues specific to adjuvant trials, trials aimed at palliation, and trials in which Patients had a strong preference for one treatment, covering arm. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Before and after the intervention, participants were videotaped discussing a study with an actor portraying a patient. These consultations were evaluated for the availability of information required by the guidelines for good clinical practice. The actor patients provided a rating after each interview. Participants reported their confidence in the most important aspects of the study discussion. RESULTS: Analysis of the videotaped consultations showed that after the intervention, significantly more participants engaged in important communication behaviors, such as B. Explaining randomization (69 vs , P=0.002) and discussing standard of care (73 vs 88, odds ratio 4.75, P=0.005) and side effects (69 vs 85, odds ratio 3.29, P= 0.006). Participants' confidence increased significantly in all domains (P < 0.001). Actor patient ratings of participant communication showed significant improvements for 12/15 key items. CONCLUSION: This intensive 8-hour intervention significantly improved participants' confidence and competence in communicating about randomized clinical trials.

title: Discussion of sexual risk behaviors in HIV care is rare and appears ineffective: a mixed-methods study
abstract: Consensus guidelines in HIV care encourage clinicians to provide a brief sexual risk behavior intervention at each visit. Studies based on participant reports note that this is rare, but studies based on direct observation of clinical encounters are lacking. We conducted a mixed-method study using audio recordings from 116 routine outpatient visits from 58 different patients with HIV at five different practice centers. Transcripts of the visits were coded and analyzed using a quantitative system. In addition, we conducted a qualitative analysis of the dialogue segments in which sexual risk behavior was discussed. Discussion of sexual risk behaviors took place on 10 visits and was generally quite brief. Two visits included extensive sexual risk reduction counseling";" two others contained a lengthy discussion that was not obviously aimed at the patient's changing behavior. At seven additional visits, there were indications of the need or opportunity for such an interview, which the physicians did not pursue. Interactions about sexual risks had less patient engagement than interactions about other health behaviors. Physicians rarely provide sexual risk reduction counseling in HIV care, even when specific indications exist.

title: Digestive system diseases. jaundice
Dissemination of effectiveness and outcomes research
abstract: Efficacy and outcomes research aims to improve patients' health outcomes by improving the quality of the healthcare they receive. Dissemination of the results of this research is a necessary step in this process. This paper provides an overview of what is known about the design and dissemination of effective information packs for healthcare providers (mainly physicians), where effectiveness means promoting behavioral change on the part of practitioners that leads to better patient care. Practice-relevant research information is made available to providers through the publication of randomized clinical trial results, the dissemination of consensus recommendations, the development and use of computer-assisted clinical decision-making tools, and the provision of continuing medical education. Each of these areas offers numerous examples of the extremely modest behavioral response that can be expected from the mere provision of information. The literature also offers some principles that can improve the chances of success, including the desirability of techniques that involve face-to-face interaction, encourage active learner participation, repeat the message, make recommendations explicit and relevant to clinical practice, and use of opinion leaders and peer influence. So far, little basic research has been carried out on the motives of the providers and the actual decision-making processes. Research aimed at promoting a behavioral science of providers could also provide new insights into effective dissemination strategies.

title: Dissemination of evidence-based antipsychotic drug prescribing guidelines in nursing homes: A randomized cluster study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of efforts to translate and disseminate evidence-based guidelines on atypical use of antipsychotics in nursing homes (NHs). DESIGN: Three-arm, cluster-randomized study. SETTING: NH's. PARTICIPANTS: NHs in the state of Connecticut. MEASUREMENTS: Evidence-based guidelines for prescribing atypical antipsychotics were translated into a toolkit aimed at NH stakeholders, and 42 NHs were recruited and randomly assigned to one of three toolkit delivery strategies: toolkit mailing (minimum intensity), toolkit mailing with quarterly review and feedback reports on facility-level antipsychotic prescribing (moderate intensity);" and personal toolkit delivery with academic details, on-site behavior management training, and quarterly audit and feedback reports (high intensity). Results were evaluated using the Reach, Effectiveness, Adoption, Implementation, Maintenance (RE-AIM) framework. RESULTS: The toolkit awareness of 30% (7/23) of leaders of low-intensity NHs, 54% (19/35) of medium-intensity NHs, and 82% (18/22) of high-intensity NHs reflected adoption and implementation of the intervention. The highest levels of use and knowledge among direct care workers were reported in high-intensity NHs. Antipsychotic prescription amounts decreased over the study period, but there were no statistically significant differences between study arms or from secular trends. CONCLUSION: RE-AIM indicators suggest some success in disseminating the toolkit and differences in outreach, acceptance and implementation according to the dissemination strategy, but no measurable effect on antipsychotic prescription trends. Further dissemination to outside stakeholders such as mental health counselors and hospitals may be needed to influence antipsychotic prescription for NH residents.

title: Do decision support systems affect prescription variation?
abstract: BACKGROUND: The transfer of scientific knowledge into daily practice is problematic. All types of intervention strategies that use educational and/or directive strategies to change behavior have evolved, but have only been partially found to be successful. In this article, the focus is on (computer-aided) Decision Support Systems (DSSs). DSSs interfere with the day-to-day work of physicians, in contrast to interventions aimed at influencing knowledge in order to change behavior. We examined whether general practitioners (GPs) prescribe according to the recommendations of the DSS and whether there is less variation in prescribing when the DSS is used. Methods: Data from the Second Dutch National General Practice Survey (DNSGP2) from 2001 was used. A total of 82 diagnoses, 749811 contacts, 133 doctors and 85 practices were included in the analyses. General practitioners who use the DSS on a daily basis were compared to general practitioners who do not use the DSS. Multilevel analysis was used to analyze the data. Two outcome measures were chosen: whether or not the prescription met the recommendations of the DSS, and a measure of concentration, the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI). RESULTS: Primary care physicians who use the DSS daily prescribe more according to the DSS recommendations than primary care physicians who do not use the DSS. Contrary to our expectation, there was no significant difference between the HHIs for either group: the variation in prescription was comparable. CONCLUSION: We investigated the use of a DSS for drug prescribing in general practice in the Netherlands. The DSS is based on guidelines developed by the Dutch College of General Practitioners and implemented in GPs' electronic medical systems. Primary care physicians who use the DSS are more likely to prescribe in accordance with the DSS recommendations than primary care physicians who do not use the DSS. However, this finding does not mean that the variation is less";" The variation is the same for GPs using a DSS and for GPs not using a DSS. Implications of the study are that DSSs can be used to implement policies, but should not be expected to be limited in variation.

title: Do health care reforms affect the cost consciousness of health professionals? Results of a nationwide survey in the Balkans
abstract: BACKGROUND: As the largest market in the Western Balkans, Serbia has entered socio-economic transition with a significant lag compared to most countries in Eastern Europe. Her efforts to reform the health system over the past 15 years have been bold, but her results have been contradictory in several areas. The two waves of global recession that hit the Balkan countries were ultimately reflected in the health care financial situation. Serious difficulties in providing accessible medical care to citizens became a reality. In fact, a large part of the unbearable expenditure is spent on the open prescription of medicines required by physicians and various laboratory and imaging diagnostic procedures. Therefore, a broad national survey was conducted at all levels of the healthcare system hierarchy to determine the ability of cost-containment strategies to reshape the mindset and decision-making of physicians in practice. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate health professionals' perceptions of the economic impact of prescribed medical interventions and to assess health professionals' responsiveness to cost-awareness policies. STUDY DESIGN: Cross-sectional study. METHODS: From January 2010 to April 2013, a nationwide cross-sectional survey was conducted through a hierarchy of medical institutions in different geographic regions before and after policy interventions. In the middle of the observation period, the National Health Insurance Fund (RFZO) passed. strict cost containment measures. Independently, pharmacoeconomic guidelines for prescribing physicians have been disseminated. Administrations in large hospitals and community pharmacies have been forced to restrict access to medical care with heavy budget strains. The Questionnaire 29 on Economic Awareness of Health Professionals (EAHPQ-29), developed in Serbian, was used in face-to-face interviews. The questionnaire documented the physician's attitudes towards: clinical decision making between alternative interventions (CDMAI), quality of health care (QHC) and cost containment policy (CCP). The authors randomly and anonymously recruited 2000 health professionals, of whom 1487 responded; after eliminating incomplete surveys, 649 participants before and 651 after political intervention were included. RESULTS: Dentists (1.195 +/- 0.560) had a higher mean CDMAI score compared to physicians (1.017 +/- 0.453). The surgical group had a higher total EAHPQ-29 score, CCP score, and CDMAI score compared to the medical group. Political interference had a statistically significant negative impact on QHC score (F=4.958; df=1;" p=0.027). There were no significant effects of political interference on professional behavior and judgment related to the CDMAI, CCP, and EAHPQ-29 overall scores CONCLUSION: Although cost savings were enforced in practice, the impact on clinical decision-making was modest Physicians' perceptions of the quality of medical care were compromised due to the severely limited resources allocated to providers, less effectively explained.This pioneering achievement in the Balkans reveals the inefficiency of current policies to expand clinicians' cost awareness.

title: Do knowledge providers facilitate the implementation of the stroke guideline in clinical practice?
abstract: BACKGROUND: The implementation of clinical guidelines in rehabilitation practice is often tedious and incomplete. One intervention to improve the implementation of guidelines is the knowledge transfer program built around the activities of a knowledge facilitator (KB). This study investigates the use of KBs to implement guideline recommendations for intensive therapy and physical activity for post-stroke patients at 22 stroke units in hospitals and rehabilitation centers in the Netherlands. METHODS/DESIGN: This study included a quantitative assessment with an uncontrolled pre-post intervention design and a mixed-methods process assessment. Enterprising nurses and therapists are recruited from each stroke unit and trained as KB. The KB will work in its team on the implementation of the guideline recommendations for a year. To assess the effectiveness of KB, patients, healthcare professionals and KBs will be given a questionnaire at baseline (T0) and after one year (T1). In addition, semi-structured interviews of 5 KB are conducted at T1. The primary outcome of this implementation project will be the support of healthcare professionals who support patients to move and be physically active as self-reported by patients and healthcare professionals. Support immediately after the intervention is compared to support at the beginning of the intervention. In addition, we examine the influence of sociodemographic characteristics of health professionals and the determinants identified in the theory of planned behavior (intention, attitude, subjective norm, and perceived behavioral control) in changing the supportive behaviors of health professionals. Finally, the KBs complete a questionnaire about their own psychological and sociodemographic characteristics and organizational conditions needed for health care improvement, such as time, manpower, sponsorship, and management support. DISCUSSION: With this study we will gain insight into when and why knowledge brokers appear to be effective. Additionally, we will identify determinants that predict which healthcare professionals are vulnerable to behavior change. This study will provide guidance on how to implement guidelines and help improve stroke rehabilitation services.

title: Do nurses have a different physical health profile? A systematic review of experimental and observational studies on the physical health of nurses
abstract: AIM: To systematically review the evidence on nurse health. BACKGROUND: Nurses are one of the most important resources of a healthcare system. They are exposed to biological, socioeconomic, cultural and health system factors that determine their health. Although mental and physical health problems are prevalent among nurses, the literature is often contradictory. The literature on health care styles, health behaviors, and self-perceived health among caregivers is also unclear. DESIGN: Systematic review of experimental and observational studies of caregiver health. METHODS: 43 databases searched. Identified 2692 potentially interesting references";" 187 studies included. Only the results of physical health studies are presented. A meta-analysis was not possible. The Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network system was used to assess evidence. RESULTS: Nurses were at greater risk of musculoskeletal injuries and more susceptible to bloodborne pathogens than other healthcare workers. They had a higher risk of breast cancer than other female healthcare workers. Nurses in hospitals were at higher risk of tuberculosis. They had no increased risk of cancer in general, Hodgkin's disease, gastric, colon, rectal, pancreatic, ovarian, kidney, brain or thyroid cancer, or lymphosarcoma. They have a higher prevalence of occupational allergies than office workers. DISCUSSION: Nursing workers are more likely to suffer from musculoskeletal disorders, consistent with the nature of nursing work. They are at a higher risk of contracting tuberculosis, particularly when working in pulmonary, medical or human immunodeficiency virus wards, which could be due to repeated exposure to infected patients. Nurses are also more susceptible to bloodborne pathogens, which could be explained by exposure during work. Susceptibility to occupational allergies can be explained by exposure to a range of chemical agents. RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: Without in-depth knowledge of nurse health, it is not possible to develop specific workplace health programs.

title: Do pediatricians apply the 2009 NASPGHAN-ESPGHAN Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Management of Gastroesophageal Reflux After Being Trained?
abstract: BACKGROUND: According to a recent survey, the guidelines of the North American Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition and the European Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition on gastroesophageal reflux are poorly followed by European primary care physicians. The main problem that emerged from the survey was the prescription of unnecessary acid-suppressing medications, particularly in infants. The reasons were not asked. The primary aim of the present study was to evaluate the applicability of the guidelines among European primary care pediatricians undergoing specific training. METHODS: One hundred pediatricians participating in the previous survey agreed to participate and were randomly divided into two groups: one group was trained in the guidelines through an online podcast, and the other group was trained through a synopsis. During the following 3 months, each participating pediatrician was asked to enroll each successive infant, child, or adolescent with evidence of reflux symptoms. For each admitted patient, pediatricians completed a report detailing their diagnostic and therapeutic decisions. RESULTS: A total of 382 patients (boys/girls 186/196, infants/children/adolescents 194/123/65) were enrolled by paediatricians. Infants with unexplained crying and/or distressed behaviors who were prescribed proton pump inhibitors were 3.7% versus 45.2% of pre-exercise survey data (P<0.05). Infants with uncomplicated recurrent regurgitation and vomiting who were prescribed proton pump inhibitors were 4.5% versus 37.1% of baseline assessment data (p<0.05). The overall rate of children managed in full compliance with guidelines was 46.1% after training versus 1.8% before training (P<0.05). No significant differences were found between pediatricians from the podcast and synopsis groups. CONCLUSIONS: The guidelines of the North American Society of Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition – the European Society of Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition – for gastroesophageal reflux have good applicability, although currently poor adherence to them by European primary care pediatricians. Simple, low-cost training has proven effective in increasing pediatrician adherence to therapy. The increase in compliance clearly favors the role of continuing medical education through simple training tools and subsequent assessment of practice.

title: Do polypills lead to neglecting lifestyle risk factors? Results of a meta-analysis of individual participant data in 3140 patients at high risk for cardiovascular disease
abstract: AIM: The aim of this study was to investigate whether polypill-based treatment for the prevention of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in patients with CVD or high calculated cardiovascular risk is associated with a change in lifestyle risk factors compared to usual care is. METHODS: We performed an individual participant data meta-analysis of three studies with patients from Australia, England, India, Ireland, the Netherlands and New Zealand using a strategy using a polypill with aspirin, statin and antihypertensive therapy with usual care in patients compared to a previous CVD event or who were at high risk at their first event. The analyzes examined all the different effects on anthropometric measures and self-reported lifestyle habits. RESULTS: Among 3140 patients (75% male, mean age 62 years and 76% with a previous CVD event) there was no difference in lifestyle risk factors in those randomized to polypill-based treatment compared to usual Treatment for a median of 15 months, either across all participants or across a range of subgroups. In addition, narrow confidence intervals (CIs) ruled out larger impacts";" For example, differences between groups in body mass index were -0.1 (95% CI -0.2 to 0.1) kg/m2, in weekly duration of moderate-intensity physical activity -2 ( -26 to 23) minutes and the proportion of smokers was 16% versus 17% (RR 0.98, 0.84 to 1.15) at the end of the study. DISCUSSION: This analysis dispels concerns that polypill-based treatment might lead to neglect of lifestyle risk factors, at least in high-risk patients. Maximum effective preventive approaches should consider lifestyle factors alongside pharmaceutical interventions, as recommended by major international guidelines.

title: Documentation-based clinical decision support to improve antibiotic prescribing for acute respiratory infections in primary care: a randomized controlled cluster study
abstract: Background and Aim Clinical guidelines advise against prescribing antibiotics for many acute respiratory infections (ARIs), particularly for non-antibiotic-suitable diagnoses. Clinical decision support based on Electronic Medical Records (EHR) has the potential to improve antibiotic prescribing for ARIs. Methods We randomly assigned 27 primary care clinics to receive an EMR-integrated, documentation-based clinical decision support system for the care of patients with ARIs - the ARI Smart Form - or to provide usual care. The primary outcome was the antibiotic prescription rate for ARIs in an analysis of intention to intervention based on administrative diagnoses. Results During the intervention period, patients made 21,961 ARI visits to study sites. Intervention physicians used the ARI Smart Form in 6% of 11,954 ARI visits. The antibiotic prescribing rate in the intervention clinics was 39% versus 43% in the control clinics (odds ratio (OR) 0.8 inches; 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.6_1.2, adjusted for clustering by clinic). For antibiotics with reasonable ARI diagnoses, the antibiotic prescription rate was 54% in the intervention clinics and 59% in the control clinics (OR, 0.8; 95% CI, 0.5_1.3). % in the intervention clinics and 34% in the control clinics (OR, 0.9; 95% CI, 0.6_1.4) Using the ARI Smart Form, the antibiotic prescription rate based on the diagnoses recorded in the form was 49% overall 88 % for antibiotic-eligible diagnoses and 27% for non-antibiotic-eligible diagnoses. In an as-used analysis, the ARI Smart Form was associated with a lower antibiotic prescription rate for acute bronchitis (OR, 0.5; 95% CI, 0.3_0.8). Conclusions The ARI Smart Form did not reduce overall antibiotic prescribing nor significantly improve the adequacy of antibiotic prescribing for ARIs, but it was not widely used. When used, the ARI Smart Form can improve diagnostic accuracy compared to administrative diagnoses and reduce antibiotic prescribing for certain diagnoses.

title: Joint development and dissemination of multidisciplinary guidelines improves prescribing behavior: a pre/post study with concurrent controls and a randomized study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Controlling prescribing behavior in primary care practices is difficult. The purpose of this study was to assess the impact of a dissemination strategy of multidisciplinary guidelines on drug prescription volumes. METHODS: The study included two designs, a quasi-experimental pre/post study with a concurrent control group and a random sample of primary care physicians within the intervention group. The intervention area with 53 general practitioners was compared with a control group of 54 randomly selected general practitioners in the south and center of the Netherlands. In addition, the intervention group was randomized to form two arms with 27 general practitioners who were more intensively involved in the development of the guideline and 26 general practitioners in the control group. A multidisciplinary committee developed prescribing guidelines. These guidelines were then distributed to all general practitioners in the intervention region. Additional effects were examined in the subgroup study, in which general practitioners were invited to become more involved in the guideline development process. The guidelines contained 14 recommendations on antibiotics, asthma/COPD medications and cholesterol medications. The main outcome measures were prescribing dates over a three-year period (one year before and 2 years after the dissemination of the guideline) and the rate of change according to the recommendations. RESULTS: Significant short-term improvements were observed with one recommendation: mupirocin. Long-term changes have been noted in the prescription of cholesterol medications. No additional changes were observed in the subgroup for the randomized controlled trial. General practitioners did not accept the invitation to participate. Conclusion: The dissemination of multidisciplinary developed guidelines within a region does not have a clear impact on prescribing behavior, although general practitioners and specialists were more intensively involved in their development. Apparently, further efforts are needed to bring about changes.

title: Joint development and dissemination of multidisciplinary guidelines improves prescribing behavior: a pre/post study with concurrent controls and a randomized study.
abstract: Background It is difficult to control prescribing behavior in primary care practices. The purpose of this study was to assess the impact of a dissemination strategy of multidisciplinary guidelines on drug prescription volumes. Methods The study included two designs, a quasi-experimental pre/post study with a concurrent control group and a random sample of primary care physicians within the intervention group. The intervention area with 53 general practitioners was compared with a control group of 54 randomly selected general practitioners in the south and center of the Netherlands. In addition, the intervention group was randomized to form two arms with 27 general practitioners who were more intensively involved in the development of the guideline and 26 general practitioners in the control group. A multidisciplinary committee developed prescribing guidelines. These guidelines were then distributed to all general practitioners in the intervention region. Additional effects were examined in the subgroup study, in which general practitioners were invited to become more involved in the guideline development process. The guidelines contained 14 recommendations on antibiotics, asthma/COPD medications and cholesterol medications. The main outcome measures were prescribing dates over a three-year period (one year before and two years after publication of the guideline) and the rate of change according to the recommendations. Results Significant short-term improvements were observed with one recommendation: mupirocin. Long-term changes have been noted in the prescription of cholesterol medications. No additional changes were observed in the subgroup for the randomized controlled trial. General practitioners did not accept the invitation to participate. Conclusion The dissemination of multidisciplinary guidelines developed within a region does not have a clear impact on prescribing behavior, although GPs and specialists have been more involved in their development. Apparently, further efforts are needed to bring about changes.

title: Does methadone maintenance therapy work according to the new national guidelines in primary care?
abstract: BACKGROUND: General practitioners (GPs) are encouraged to treat more drug users, but there are few studies demonstrating the effectiveness of primary care. AIM: To determine whether patients receiving methadone maintenance treatment for a year in a modern UK primary care setting can achieve similar harm reduction outcomes with prescription protocols based on the new national guidance as in other settings, using objective outcome measures available. STUDY DESIGN: Longitudinal cohort study. SETTING: The Drug Dependence Primary Care Clinic, Sheffield. METHOD: The intervention consisted of methadone maintenance treatment administered by primary care physicians with prescribing protocols based on the 1999 national guidelines. The first 96 eligible consenting patients entering treatment were recruited";" 65 graduated. Outcome measures included current drug use, HIV risk behavior, social functioning, criminal activity, and mental and physical health, supplemented by urinalysis and criminal record data. Results: The frequency of heroin use was reduced (Chi 2 = 79.48, degrees of freedom) from an average of 3.02 episodes per day (standard deviation [SD] = 1.73) to an average of 0.22 episodes per day (SD = 0.54). [df ] = 2, P<0.001), confirmed by urinalysis. The mean number of convictions and warnings was reduced by 62% (z=3.378, P<0.001) for all offenses. HIV risk behaviors, social functioning, and physical and psychological well-being all showed significant improvements. CONCLUSION: Patients receiving methadone maintenance therapy in a primary care setting for one year may experience improvements in a range of harm reduction outcomes similar to those shown in studies in other, often more structured programs.

title: Does publication bias increase the apparent effectiveness of psychological treatment for major depressive disorder? A systematic review and meta-analysis of the US National Institutes of Health-Funded Trials
abstract: BACKGROUND: The effectiveness of antidepressants is empirically overestimated due to publication bias, but this has only been statistically deduced with regard to the psychological treatment of depression. We directly assessed the extent of study publication bias in studies examining the effectiveness of psychological treatment for depression. METHODS AND RESULTS: We identified US National Institutes of Health grants to fund randomized clinical trials comparing psychological treatment with control disorders or other treatments in patients diagnosed with major depressive disorder over the period 1972-2008, and determined whether these Grants led to publications. For unpublished studies, data were requested from the investigators and included in the meta-analyses. Thirteen (23.6%) of the 55 funded grants that began studies did not result in publications, and two others never began. Among the comparisons with control conditions, adding unpublished studies (Hedges' g=0.20"; CI95% -0.11~0.51; k=6) to published studies (g=0.52; 0.37~) reduced 0.68; k = 20) the psychotherapy effect size point estimate (g = 0.39; " 0.08~0.70) by 25%. Furthermore, these results may overestimate the "true" effect of psychological treatment for depression, since the bias in outcome reporting could not be quantitatively examined. Conclusion: The effectiveness of psychological interventions in depression is overestimated in the published literature, as is that of pharmacotherapy. Both are effective, but not to the extent that the published literature suggests. Funding agencies and journals should archive both original protocols and raw data from treatment studies to enable detection and correction of bias in outcome reporting. Clinicians, guideline developers, and policy makers should be aware that the published literature overestimates the impact of prevalent treatments for depression.

title: Does screening for and intervention for multiple unhealthy behaviors and mental health disorders in young people attending primary care improve health outcomes? A systematic overview
abstract: BACKGROUND: Adolescence and young adulthood are important developmental periods. Screening for unhealthy behaviors and mental disorders during routine primary care visits can help clinicians identify problem areas and take appropriate action. The aim of this systematic review is to examine whether screening and follow-up interventions for multiple unhealthy behaviors and mental health disorders in primary care improve health outcomes in young people. METHODS: Using the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines, literature searches were performed in the Medline, PsycINFO, Scopus and Cochrane Library databases (Prospero registration number CRD42013005828) using search terms representing four thematic concepts : Primary care, adolescents, screening, and behaviors that affect mental health and health. To be eligible for inclusion, studies had to: include a measure of health outcome; include at least 75% of participants under the age of 25; use a screening tool that assesses more than one area of health;” and be conducted in a primary care setting. Risk of bias was assessed using the quality rating scale. RESULTS: Out of 5051 articles identified, nine studies met the inclusion criteria and were reviewed: two randomized controlled trials (RCTs), one pilot RCT, two clustered RCTs, one randomized trial with multiple intervention groups and no control group, one cluster RCT with two active arms , a longitudinal study and a pre-post study. Seven studies, including two RCTs and one clustered RCT, found positive changes in substance use, diet, sexual health or risky sexual behaviors, alcohol-related risky behaviors, social stress, coping with stress, helmet use, sleep, and exercise. Of only two studies that reported harm, one reported negative health effects of increased alcohol consumption. CONCLUSIONS: There is evidence that the use of screening and intervention in young people for mental disorders or unhealthy behaviors in clinical settings improves health outcomes. Along with other evidence that young people value discussions about health risks with their providers, these discussions should be part of young people's routine primary care. More quality studies are needed to substantiate this evidence.

title: Does Shared Care Help Treat Depression?
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Shared or collaborative care in the management of depression is an evidence-based intervention that has been shown to be more effective than usual GP care in the management of depression, but is not yet part of UK government policy. Our goal was to bring together in one place all studies conducted up to mid-2009 to provide evidence that shared collaborative care has important benefits both in terms of depression outcomes and the cost benefits to do so argue the adoption of this approach in the UK and Europe. Methods: We performed a literature search using PUBMED to identify and describe all studies, systematic reviews, and meta-analyses that had been performed on shared care up to mid-2009. We also described a shared care service for depression that some of us helped develop and work in Luton in the late 1990s. We excluded articles that describe studies that have not yet been conducted and instead focused on the studies that have been reported. RESULTS: Numerous recent studies have shown that shared care in the management of depression, which includes training general practitioners in the management of depression and providing a specialist nurse or other primary care worker, provides psycho-education, ensures the Medication concordance and the provision of psychotherapy, if necessary, leads to improved treatment outcomes as well as increased doctor and patient satisfaction and offers some cost advantages despite slightly increased direct costs. This is the case in both adult and adolescent patients, while in diabetics, depression is ameliorated despite the lack of improvement in glycemic control. In patients with resistant depressive symptoms, the shared care intervention is still useful, but longer input is required in such cases. Patients with underlying depression do not benefit as much, and patients reported greater satisfaction when psychological interventions were offered. It is also true that cooperative or shared caregiving is effective in treating depression in the elderly. This is shown by studies involving elderly patients who also suffer from multiple health conditions, arthritis, diabetes, anxiety and PTSD, the poorer, those with suicidal thoughts and also ethnic minorities. DISCUSSION: The findings described above are based primarily on studies conducted in the US, but similar studies have been reported from the UK and are consistent with the experiences of the Luton ministry that we describe. Based on these findings, it appears important that shared, collaborative care with primary and secondary care physicians (GPs and psychiatrists) work as part of a single team, with the help of psychiatrists attached to, but easy access to, primary care Having secondary care is a productive way to optimize treatment for depression. However, the UK has not yet succeeded in developing such a service for the whole population. This is because in the UK, primary care trusts manage general medicine, while mental health trusts manage secondary care, including psychiatry.
