This has prompted the National Institute of Health and Clinical Excellence, and indeed local care officials, to focus on a tiered model for treating depression, with a key issue being access (or referral) to secondary care and discharge back to primary care is, with a group of mental health workers focused on facilitating (or overseeing) these processes, rather than focusing on actually optimizing treatment outcomes. CONCLUSION: The evidence supports the development of collaborative care between primary and secondary care for the treatment of depression. This requires common medication guidelines in both primary and secondary care, easy access to allow general practitioners to receive advice from psychiatrists about patients, and the engagement of mental health professionals to provide patients with psychoeducation, support for compliance with treatment and to offer psychotherapy. To achieve this, services may need to be restructured to allow for easy communication between professionals.

title: Does therapeutic writing help people with long-term illnesses? Systematic review, realistic synthesis and economic considerations
abstract: BACKGROUND: Writing therapy to improve physical or mental health can take many forms. The best-researched model of therapeutic writing (TW) is unaided, individually expressive writing (written emotional disclosure). Facilitated writing activities are less well researched. DATA SOURCES: Databases including MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsycINFO, Linguistics and Language Behavior Abstracts, Allied and Complementary Medicine Database, and Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature were searched from inception to March 2013 (updated January 2015). REVIEW METHODS: Four TW practitioners offered expert advice. Study procedures were carried out by one reviewer and reviewed by a second. Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and non-randomized comparative studies were included. Quality was assessed using the Cochrane Risk-of-Bias tool. Unfacilitated and facilitated TW studies were analyzed separately under the chapter headings of the International Classification of Diseases, Tenth Revision. Wherever possible, meta-analyses were performed using RevMan version 5.2.6 (RevMan 2012, The Cochrane Collaboration, The Nordic Cochrane Centre, Copenhagen, Denmark). Costs were estimated from the UK NHS perspective and three cost-consequence case studies were produced. The realistic synthesis followed the guidelines of Realist and Meta-narrative Evidence Synthesis: Evolving Standards. OBJECTIVES: To review the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of TW for people with long-term conditions (LTCs) compared to no writing or other controls, reporting all relevant clinical outcomes. Conduct a realistic synthesis to understand how TW might work and for whom. RESULTS: Out of 14,658 unique citations, 284 full-text articles were reviewed and 64 studies (59 RCTs) were included in the final efficacy reviews. Five studies examined facilitated TW"; these were extremely heterogeneous with unclear or high risk of bias, but suggested that facilitated TW interventions might be beneficial in individual LTCs. Unfacilitated expressive writing was assessed in 59 studies with variable or unreported quality Overall, there was very little or no evidence of benefit reported for the following conditions (number of studies): human immunodeficiency virus (six), breast cancer (eight), gynecological and genitourinary cancers (five), mental health (five), asthma (four) psoriasis (three) and chronic pain (four) In inflammatory arthropathies (six), there was a reduction in disease severity [n=191, standardized mean difference (SMD) -0.61, 95% confidence interval (CI) -0 .96 to - 0.26] in the short term on meta-analysis of four studies. For all other LTCs there were either no data or sparse data with ke inconsistent or conflicting evidence of benefit. Meta-analyses performed across all LTCs provided no evidence that unaided emotional writing had short- (n=1563, SMD -0.06, 95% CI -0.29 to 0.17, significant heterogeneity ) or long-term (n = 778, SMD -0.04, 95% CI -0.18 to 0.10, little heterogeneity) effects on depression follow-up or on anxiety, physiological or biomarker-based outcomes. One study reported cost, no study reported cost-effectiveness, and 12 studies reported resource use,” and a meta-analysis suggested reduced medication use but no impact on health center visits. Estimated intervention costs were low, but there was insufficient evidence to judge cost-effectiveness. The results of the realistic synthesis suggested that facilitated TW is a complex intervention and the group interaction contributes to the perception of benefit. From the available data, it was unclear who could benefit most from facilitated TW. LIMITATION: Difficulties in developing the theory of the realistic synthesis program meant that mechanisms operating during TW remain unclear. CONCLUSIONS: Overall, there is little evidence supporting the therapeutic efficacy or cost-effectiveness of unassisted expressive writing interventions in people with LTCs. Further research focusing on facilitated TW in people with LTCs could be instructive. STUDY REGISTRATION: This study is registered as PROSPERO CRD420120033 43. FUNDING: The Health Technology Assessment Program of the National Institute for Health Research.

title: Dominant inheritance of intracranial berry aneurysm
Dressings for venous leg ulcers: systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To review the evidence of effectiveness of dressings in venous leg ulcers. DESIGN Systematic review and meta-analysis. DATA SOURCES Hand searches of professional journals and searches of electronic databases, conference proceedings and bibliographies up to April 2006; Contacts to dressing manufacturers for unpublished studies. REVIEWED STUDIES All randomized controlled trials evaluating dressings for venous leg ulcers were eligible for inclusion. Data from eligible studies were extracted and pooled independently by two reviewers using a data extraction sheet Methodological quality was independently assessed by two reviewers RESULTS The search strategy identified 254 studies, 42 of which met the inclusion criteria Hydrocolloids were no more effective than simple weakly adherent dressings that be used under compression (eight trials; relative risk of healing with hydrocolloid 1.02, 95% confidence interval 0.83 to 1.28). For other comparisons, insufficient evidence was available to draw firm conclusions. None of the dressing comparisons showed evidence that any particular dressing class healed more ulcers. There were some differences in subjective outcome measures and ulcer healing rates between associations. The results were not influenced by the size or quality of the studies or the unit of randomization. There were insufficient data to draw conclusions about the relative cost-effectiveness of different dressings. CONCLUSIONS The type of dressing placed under compression was not shown to affect ulcer healing. The results of the meta-analysis showed that the application of hydrocolloid dressings under compression did not provide any advantage in terms of ulcer healing compared to the application of simple, low-adhesion dressings. No final recommendations can be made as to which type of dressing is most cost effective. Decisions about which dressing to apply should be based on local dressing costs and physician or patient preferences.

title: Driving simulators for occupational therapy screening, assessment and intervention
abstract: Simulation technology provides safe, objective, and repeatable performance measurements related to operational (e.g., collision avoidance) or tactical (e.g., lane keeping) driver behavior. Many occupational therapy researchers and others use driving simulators to test a variety of applications in different populations. A growing body of literature supports associations between simulated driving and actual on-road driving. A limitation of simulator technology is the incidence of simulator sickness, but management strategies exist to contain or mitigate its onset. Based on the literature review and a consensus process, five consensus statements are presented to support the use of driving simulation technology among occupational therapists. The evidence suggests that by using driving simulators, occupational therapists can identify underlying impairments in driving performance, can identify driving errors in risk drivers, can distinguish between driving performance of impaired and healthy control groups, can show driving errors with absolute and relative validity in comparison to on-road studies; and to mitigate the incidence of simulator sickness. Great strides have been made in the use of driving simulation technology among occupational therapy researchers and practitioners." However, empirical support is needed to further justify the use of driving simulators in clinical real-world settings as a valid, reliable, clinically useful, and cost-effective tool for driving assessment and intervention.

title: Drug formulations in hospitals
Drug recovery and patient rights
abstract: The challenge of a hypersensitive patient with a potentially harmful drug is of paramount importance in the development of medical knowledge. However, it does not always serve the interests of the patient concerned. In order to safeguard the interests of the individual patient, no contestation should be made unless it is vital to the patient's health at the time and cannot be substituted. Patient rights require the setting of limitations and guidelines for the re-challenge process in all its aspects. An approach is proposed that brings doctors closer to a solution that protects the patient from uncontrolled decisions and unnecessary risks.

title: Drug use and the role of patients and prescribers
abstract: In order to achieve rational drug use in any national or local setting, research methods need to be expanded. Both the public and private sectors need to be addressed. In the latter, the pharmacists could be examined using a tracer, a fictitious customer. An important factor influencing the prescription, the drug information, has hardly been scientifically investigated. However, experimental studies with group randomization are also feasible in developing countries. The individual person must be the focus of drug studies and health care and health must be the focus. The combination of qualitative and quantitative methods will help us achieve rational drug use that is culturally acceptable, economically feasible, and pharmacologically sound."; PIP: In an effort to promote rational drug use in local or national settings, particularly in developing countries improve The behavior of prescribers and users is the subject of the least research The effectiveness of medicines depends on a complex set of factors involved in the prescribing and acquisition situation One aspect that needs to be examined is the information that prescribers receive from drug advertisers and retailers, a shortage that is being addressed by an international network of prescribing doctors.In many countries, private sector pharmacies are the largest outlet for medicines, where medicines are often dispensed without a prescription ten diseases such as diarrhea in infants There are many factors involved in prescribing;" the process must be studied with an epidemiological approach, ie through description, analysis, intervention and evaluation. Standard treatment plans, essential drug lists, and targeted interventions with treatment guidelines should be reviewed by local therapeutic committees. Drug information should also be evaluated scientifically using the same principles of analysis. The experimental method of group randomization is suggested as a viable choice for developing countries. This technique involves observing or interviewing groups of physicians and collecting quantitative outcome data. The behavior of individual users is best studied from a case study perspective by combining anthropological and biomedical approaches. An example of a problem amenable to this approach is the potential use of shorter antibiotic treatment cycles to reduce the risk of developing resistant organisms.

title: DRUGS system to improve adherence to antibiotic use guidelines by Chinese surgeons during the perioperative period
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The irrational use of antimicrobials to prevent postoperative SSIs is a widespread phenomenon in China, leading to more bacterial resistance, higher hospital infection rates, and additional antimicrobial costs. The aim of the study is to evaluate the effect of the Drug Rational Usage Guidelines System (DRUGS) on the prescribing behavior of surgeons with antimicrobial agents. METHODS: 10 common surgical procedures with 1543 cases (whereby 778 cases with paper-based guidelines and 765 cases with DRUGS) were selected and their demographic and clinical data were collected. The surgeries selected included thyroid resection, breast mass resection, myomectomy, etc. The evaluation criteria were antibiotic administration categories, timing of loading dose, duration of administration, length of stay, cost of antibiotics, SSIs, and adverse drug reactions (ADRs). . RESULTS: The antimicrobials were administered mostly within 0.5 h to 2 h before the incision, 656 patients (85.75%) were intervened with drugs and 256 (32.90%) with paper-based guidelines according to the protocol. For clean wound incision, 547 patients (91.62%) were within 24 hours of stopping antibiotics with paper-based guidelines compared to 91 (14.79%) with the use of DRUGS. A total of 19 types of antibiotics were used in the 1543 cases. The top three on the frequency list were piperacillin and sulbactam sodium, cefathiamidine and cefoperazone. After the intervention, the frequency list changed to cefazolin, cefathiamidine, cefoperazone. Mean hospital stays were (7.00 +/- 4.31) days with paper-based guidelines and (2.54 +/- 1.57) days with DRUGS. The average cost of antibiotics was yen (3481.36 +/- 2584.46) with paper-based guidelines and yen (1693.39 +/- 1478.27) with DRUGS, respectively. However, there were no significant differences in the incidence of SSIs and ADRs between the two groups. CONCLUSION: In this study, the increased availability of antibiotic guidelines at the time of medication ordering, combined with DRUGS, was associated with improved surgeon adherence to guidelines.

title: Durable improvements in prostate cancer screening through online spaced education in a randomized controlled trial
abstract: CONTEXT: Prostate cancer screening with prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is often performed contrary to clinical practice guidelines. BACKGROUND: It has been hypothesized that an email-based intervention called "spaced education" could reduce inappropriate screening of clinicians for prostate cancer. DESIGN: The study was conducted as an RCT. SETTING/PARTICIPANTS: The study enrolled 95 primary care clinicians at eight Veterans Affairs medical centers from January 2007 to February 2009 (2 emails per week), while control physicians received no intervention. Each email presented a clinical scenario and asked if it was appropriate to get a PSA test. Participants received feedback immediately after submitting their answers. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: The primary outcome was the number and percentage of inappropriate PSA screening tests ordered. The use of PSA for prostate cancer screening in patients aged > 76 or < 40 years was defined as inappropriate testing. Screening adequacy was dichotomized based on the patient's age at the time of screening. Patients with PSA testing for non-screening reasons were excluded using a validated protocol. Logistic regression was performed with physician adjustment for patient grouping. The analyzes were carried out in 2009. RESULTS: During the intervention period (weeks 1-36), clinicians who received time-limited educational emails ordered significantly fewer inappropriate PSA screening tests than control clinicians (10.5% vs. 14.2%, p=0.041 ). During the 72-week post-intervention period (weeks 37-108), physicians with distance training continued to order fewer inappropriate tests compared to controls (7.8% vs. 13.1%, p=0.011), indicating a relative reduction in inappropriateness by 40% corresponds to screening. CONCLUSIONS: Spaced education consistently improves physicians' prostate cancer screening behavior and represents a promising new method to improve patient care in all health care systems.

title: Dynamic spread of happiness in a large social network: 20-year longitudinal analysis in the Framingham Heart Study
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess whether happiness can spread from person to person and whether happiness niches are forming in social networks. DESIGN Longitudinal Analysis of Social Networks. SETTING Framingham Heart Study social network. PARTICIPANTS From 1983 to 2003, 4739 people followed. wide range of attributes of social networks and diverse social ties. RESULTS Clusters of happy and unhappy people are visible in the network, and the relationship between people's happiness spans up to three degrees of separation (e.g., to friends of friends of one's friends). People who are surrounded by many happy people and those who are the focus of the network are more likely to become happy in the future. Longitudinal statistical models suggest that clusters of happiness result from the spread of happiness and not just from people's tendency to associate with similar individuals. A friend who lives within a mile and becomes happy increases the likelihood that a person will be happy by 25% (95% confidence interval 1% to 57%). Similar effects are found for spouses of the same age (8%, 0.2% to 16%), siblings who live within a mile (14%, 1% to 28%) and next-door neighbors (34%, 7% to 70 %) observed. There are no visible effects between colleagues. The effect wears off with time and geographic separation. CONCLUSIONS People's happiness depends on the happiness of others with whom they are connected. This provides further justification for seeing happiness, like health, as a collective phenomenon.

title: Dyslipidemia in Primary Care – Prevalence, Detection, Treatment and Control: Data from the German Metabolic and Cardiovascular Risk Project (GEMCAS)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Current European Society of Cardiology (ESC) guidelines define low thresholds for the diagnosis of dyslipidemia using total cholesterol (TC) and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) as guides for treatment. Although primarily a preventive tool, its thresholds are difficult to achieve in clinical practice, particularly in primary care. Methods: In a nationwide study with 1,511 general practitioners and 35,869 patients, we determined the prevalence of dyslipidemia, its detection, treatment and control rates. Diagnosis of dyslipidemia was based on TC and LDL-C. Basic descriptive statistics and prevalence rate ratios and 95% confidence intervals were calculated. RESULTS: Dyslipidemia was very common in primary care (76% overall). Doctors diagnosed dyslipidemia in 48.6% of male and 39.9% of female patients. However, lifestyle interventions controlled dyslipidemia in only about 10% of patients. A higher proportion (34.1% of men and 26.7% of women) were controlled on pharmacotherapy. The odds of being diagnosed and subsequently controlled using pharmacotherapy were higher in men (PRR 1.15"; 95% CI 1.12-1.17), in patients with concomitant cardiovascular risk factors, in patients with hypertension (PRR 1.20, 95% CI 1.05-1.37), and cardiovascular disease (PRR 1.46, 95% CI 1.29-1.64), prior myocardial infarction (PRR 1.32, 95% CI 1, 19-1.47) and if patients knew they were hypertensive (PRR 1.18; 95% CI 1.04-1.34) or knew about their previous myocardial infarction (PRR 1.17; 95% CI 1. 23-1.53). CONCLUSIONS: ESC thresholds appear difficult to meet. Simply requesting more aggressive treatment or greater patient compliance does not appear to be sufficient to increase the proportion of patients controlled. A shift towards a multifactorial treatment considering lifestyle interventions and pharmacotherapy for weight and lipid reduction, ka nn be the only way in a population where simply being normal is certainly not ideal.

title: Early administration of aspirin in patients treated with alteplase for acute ischemic stroke: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Intravenous alteplase thrombolysis is the only approved treatment for acute ischemic stroke. After alteplase-induced recanalization, reocclusion occurs in 14–34% of patients, probably due to platelet activation. Early administration of antiplatelet therapy after alteplase could reduce the risk of reocclusion and improve outcome. We compared the effects of early addition of intravenous aspirin to alteplase versus standard alteplase without aspirin.";" Background Intravenous alteplase thrombolysis is the only approved treatment for acute ischemic stroke. After alteplase-induced recanalization, reocclusion occurs in 14–34% of patients, probably due to platelet activation. Early administration of antiplatelet therapy after alteplase could reduce the risk of reocclusion and improve outcome. We compared the effects of early addition of intravenous aspirin to alteplase versus standard alteplase without aspirin.

title: Early coverage, access, use, and health effects of medicaid extensions to the Affordable Care Act: A quasi-experimental study
abstract: Background In 2014, only 26 states and DC elected to implement the Affordable Care Act (ACA) Medicaid extensions for low-income adults. Objective To assess whether state Medicaid expansions have been associated with changes in coverage, access to and use of health care, and self-reported health. Design Comparison of outcomes before and after expansions in states that have and have not expanded Medicaid. Recruitment US participants Citizens aged 19¨C64 with family income below 138% of the federal poverty level in the 2010¨C2014 National Health Interview Surveys. Measures "Health insurance coverage (private, Medicaid, uninsured)"; health insurance better than last year; visits to general practitioners and specialists; hospitalizations and ED visits; skipped or delayed medical care; usual source of care; diagnoses of diabetes, high cholesterol, and hypertension , Self-Reported Health Status, and Depression Results In the second half of 2014, low-income adults in expanding economies experienced increases in health insurance (7.4 percentage points; 95% CI, 11.3 to 3.4) and Medicaid (10.5 percentage points; 95 % CI, 6.5 to 14.5) and improved quality of insurance coverage compared to a year ago (7.1 percentage points; 95% CI, 2.7 to 11.5) compared to adults in states not using Medicaid expanded Medicaid expansion was associated with increased visits to general practice physicians (6.6 percentage points; 95% CI, 1.3 b is 12.0), hospital nights (2.4 percentage points; 95% CI, 0.7 to 4.2) and Diab diagnosis rates etes (5.2 percentage points; 95% CI, 2.4 to 8.1) and high cholesterol (5.7 percentage points; 95% CI, 2, 0 to 9.4); Changes in other endpoints were not statistically significant. Limitations Observational study may be prone to unmeasured confounders; based on self-reported data;' post-ACA limited timeframe provides information on short-term changes only. and higher chronic disease diagnosis rates in low-income adults.

title: Early detection and intervention assessment for people at risk of psychosis: multi-site randomized controlled trial
abstract: AIM To determine whether cognitive therapy is effective in preventing worsening of emerging psychotic symptoms occurring in help-seeking young people considered at risk for serious illnesses such as schizophrenia. DESIGN Single-blind, randomized, controlled, multisite study. RECRUITMENT Diverse services across five UK locations. PARTICIPANTS 288 participants aged 14-35 years (mean 20.74, SD 4.34 years) at high risk of psychosis: 144 were assigned to cognitive therapy plus mental status monitoring and 144 to mental status monitoring only. Participants were followed up for a minimum of 12 months and a maximum of 24 months. INTERVENTION Cognitive therapy (up to 26 (mean 9.1) sessions over six months) plus mental status monitoring versus mental status monitoring alone. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome were the results of the Comprehensive Assessment of Mental Risk States (CAARMS), which provides a dichotomous transition to the psychosis score and the ordinal scores for the severity of psychotic symptoms and distress. Secondary endpoints were emotional dysfunction and quality of life. RESULTS Transition to psychosis based on treatment intention was analyzed using discrete time survival models. Overall, the transition prevalence was lower than expected (23/288; 8%), with no significant difference between the two groups (proportional odds ratio 0.73, 95% confidence interval 0.32 to 1.68). Changes in symptom severity and distress and secondary endpoints were analyzed using random effects regression (analysis of covariance) adjusted for site and baseline symptoms. Stress from psychotic symptoms was not different (estimated difference at 12 months -3.00, 95% confidence interval -6.95 to 0.94), but its severity was significantly reduced in the group assigned to cognitive therapy (estimated effect size between groups according to 12 months -3.67, -6.71 to -0.64, P=0.018). CONCLUSIONS: Cognitive therapy plus surveillance did not significantly reduce the transition to psychosis or symptom-related distress, but it did reduce the severity of psychotic symptoms in high-risk young people. Most participants in both groups improved over time. The results have important implications for the concept of mental health risk. STUDY REGISTRATION Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN56283883.

title: Early detection of autism spectrum disorders: Screening between 12 and 24 months of age
abstract: PURPOSE: The purpose of this article is to present Nursing Practitioners (NPs) with information on screening for Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASDs) in children between the ages of 12 and 24 months. Recommendations for appropriate referrals and initiation of early intervention (EI) are also made. DATA SOURCES: Review of the published literature on ASD. CONCLUSIONS: Children with ASD exhibit impaired social interaction, verbal and nonverbal communication deficits, and repetitive, restricted, and stereotyped patterns of behavior or interests. Studies show that these children benefit from starting intensive EI as soon as possible. PRACTICAL IMPLICATIONS: Early detection allows children with suspected ASD to be evaluated by specialists and enrolled in treatment programs at the earliest possible time. Because of the importance of early diagnosis of ASD, it is critical that NPs use established screening tools to maximize the time and increase the reliability of the assessment.

title: Early Photography, Goiter and James Inglis
Early training to combat obesity in patients: a systematic review of nursing education
abstract: OBJECTIVES: This systematic review aims to identify studies that have evaluated educational interventions in nursing education related to obesity and to examine the effectiveness of the interventions. BACKGROUND: Obesity is a prominent global problem and nurses play an increasingly important role in managing patients' weight. The literature has identified several theory-based behavior modification techniques that successfully support weight management in patients. Therefore, training nurses in obesity-related behavior modification techniques is appropriate to prepare them for their future professional role. However, the effectiveness of these educational interventions has not yet been evaluated. METHODS: The guidelines of the Center for Reviews and Dissemination informed about this systematic review. Four databases were systematically searched and the articles evaluated using inclusion criteria. Data extraction and quality assessment forms were developed and completed to identify salient features in the articles. RESULTS: Eight studies met the inclusion criteria. Only two included both baseline and outcome measures, one of which was a randomized controlled trial. In addition, only one study included an explicitly identified behavior modification technique. The interventions were delivered through a range of methods, but quality assessment showed that all studies had poor methodologies and were at high risk of bias. CONCLUSIONS: Studies in this research area are sparse and methodologically not robust. Therefore, it is not possible to identify effective educational weight management interventions for nursing students. IMPLICATION: More robust research is needed to examine how nurses can be trained to facilitate weight management. Greater transparency of intervention descriptions, particularly with respect to what behavior change techniques were taught, would allow for replication and appropriate evaluation. Until then, it is not known whether current teaching adequately equips nurses to deal with obese and overweight patients.

title: Early treatment of migraine attacks with triptans: a strategy to improve outcomes and patient satisfaction?
abstract: Early treatment of migraine attacks with triptans can be more effective than late administration of the triptan. However, in published studies, the definition of "early" has varied (in terms of time, pain intensity, or the presence of allodynia) or is unclear. Therefore, no clear clinical indications have been identified. Appropriately designed studies to address this issue remain a priority. Early treatment with triptans can also have disadvantages, including inadvertently treating tension-type headaches and the risk of drug overuse. Currently, only those migraine sufferers with rapid pain worsening, high pain recurrence rate, and clinical signs of allodynia should be encouraged to take triptans as soon as possible. This recommendation implies the need for patient education and the need to carefully tailor treatment to individual needs.

title: Eating disorders in children and adolescents: pharmacological therapies
abstract: Anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa are present in childhood, often begin in adolescence, and can have serious medical and psychiatric consequences that impede physical, emotional, and behavioral development. Although we use the same definitions from the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-Version 4 [DSM-IV] to diagnose eating disorders in children, adolescents, and adults, these disorders may present somewhat differently in younger populations, requiring appropriate assessment and Treatment required are tailored to their developmental needs. In recent years, significant advances have been made in our understanding of the treatment of eating disorders in adults, and in particular the pharmacological management of these disorders. Several double-blind, placebo-controlled studies have documented the short-term effectiveness of antidepressants in bulimia nervosa. While the usefulness of pharmacological treatments for the acute management of anorexia nervosa is less clear, recent evidence suggests a role for drugs in the relapse prevention phase of the disease. The majority of drug studies for eating disorders have been conducted in adults, and the literature on pharmacological treatment of children and adolescents with these disorders is very limited. This review article summarizes the current literature on the role of drugs in the management of anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa, with a particular focus on studies conducted in children and adolescents.

title: Eating disorders in the context of preconception care: Knowledge, attitudes, and clinical practices of fertility specialists
abstract: OBJECTIVE(S): To measure the knowledge, clinical practices and training needs of fertility professionals related to eating disorders. DESIGN: Cross-sectional study. SETTINGS: Fertility clinics. PARTICIPANTS: Eighty Australian and New Zealand fertility specialists who were members of the Fertility Society of Australia. INTERVENTION(S): None. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Responses to an anonymously completed online questionnaire. RESULT(S): Approximately 54% of physicians correctly identified body mass index relevant to anorexia nervosa and 30% identified menstrual disorders for anorexia, while 63.8% of physicians misappropriated weight control behavior as a feature of binge eating designated disorder. While clinicians (83.7%) agreed that it was important to screen for eating disorders during preconception evaluation, 35% routinely screened for eating disorders and 8.8% reported that their clinics follow clinical practice guidelines for eating disorder management to have. A minority of participants (13.8%) were satisfied with their educational level in eating disorders, 37.5% of physicians felt confident in their ability to recognize eating disorder symptoms, and 96.2% reported a need for further education and clinical guidelines at. For most of the items examined, knowledge and clinical practice regarding eating disorders did not differ based on the physician's gender or years of clinical experience as a fertility specialist. Conclusion(s): Knowledge about eating disorders in the context of fertility treatment is important. This study underscores the uncertainty among fertility specialists in recognizing characteristics of eating disorders. Findings point to the importance of continuing education and training, including the development of clinical guidelines specific to fertility health providers.

title: Economic analyzes of the Be Fit Be Well program: a weight loss program for community health centers
abstract: BACKGROUND: The US Preventive Services Task Force has issued new guidelines on obesity that encourage primary care physicians to provide intensive, multicomponent behavioral interventions to obese patients. However, there are few studies of weight loss in primary care non-academic settings in the real world, and even fewer in predominantly racial/ethnic minority and low-income samples. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the recruitment, intervention, and repeat costs of a 2-year moderate-intensity weight loss and blood pressure control intervention. DESIGN: A comprehensive cost analysis was performed associated with a weight loss and hypertension management program implemented at three community health centers as part of a pragmatic randomized trial. PARTICIPANTS: Three hundred and sixty-five high-risk, low-income, inner-city minority patients (71% were Black/African American and 13% Hispanic) who were both hypertensive and obese. MAIN MEASURES: Measures included total recruitment and intervention costs, costs per participant, and incremental costs per unit of weight and blood pressure reduction. MAIN RESULTS: Recruitment and intervention costs were estimated at $2,359 per participant for the 2-year program. Compared to the control intervention, the cost per extra kilogram lost was $2,204/kg and for blood pressure $621/mmHg. Sensitivity analyzes suggest that if the program were offered to a larger sample and minor changes were made, the cost per participant could be reduced to the levels of many commercially available products. CONCLUSIONS: The costs associated with the Be Fit Be Well program were significantly higher than many commercially available products and much higher than the amount that the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid reimburses physicians for obesity counseling. However, given the serious and costly health consequences associated with obesity in high-risk, multimorbid, and socioeconomically disadvantaged patients, the resources required for interventions such as those described here may still prove cost-effective in bringing about long-term behavior change.

title: Economic evaluation of implementation strategies in healthcare
abstract: Economic assessments can make decisions about efficiency and allocation of resources to implementation strategies. Strategies specifically designed to educate caregivers and patients about the best available research and improve its use in their practices. These strategies are becoming increasingly popular in healthcare, especially given growing concerns about quality of care and limited resources. But such concerns have done little to motivate public health agencies and other decision-makers to invest in some form of economic evaluation in their assessments of implementation strategies. This editorial addresses the importance of economic evaluation in the context of implementation science, specifically how these analyzes can most efficiently be integrated into decision-making processes about implementation strategies.

title: Economic implications of evidence-based hypertension prescribing: can better care cost less?
abstract: Context Deviations from evidence-based guidelines in the management of hypertension are common, but their economic implications have not been thoroughly investigated. Suboptimal prescription patterns contribute to the high cost of medications for older patients and the difficulty in providing affordable prescription drug benefits to older Americans. Objective To calculate the potential savings from a healthcare payer perspective that would result from increased adherence to evidence-based recommendations for treating hypertension in patients over 65 years of age. Design Comparative analysis of prescribed medications with potential therapies suggested by evidence-based guidelines tailored to each patient's medical history, with calculation of costs of both actual and evidence-based therapies. Environment and Patients In 2001, a total of 133,624 patients were treated for hypertension enrolled in a large government drug assistance program that provides insurance for prescription drugs to the elderly. Main outcome measure Cost difference between drugs actually prescribed and treatment regimens suggested by evidence-based guidelines. Results The patients studied filled more than 2.05 million prescriptions for antihypertensive drugs in 2001, at an annual program cost of US$48.5 million (US$363 per patient). We identified 815,316 prescriptions (40%) for which an alternative regimen appeared more appropriate according to evidence-based recommendations. Such changes would have reduced payer costs by $11.6 million in 2001 (nearly a quarter of program spending on antihypertensive drugs) and overall would have been more clinically appropriate. Replacement of calcium channel blockers resulted in the greatest potential savings. Using price caps similar to those in the Medicaid program would have resulted in an even larger potential savings of $20.5 million (42% of the program cost). Conclusions Adherence to evidence-based hypertension prescribing guidelines could result in significant prescription cost savings for elderly patients with hypertension, resulting in savings of approximately US$1.2 billion nationally. Identifying similar areas where prescribing can be improved will be critical to the affordability of prescription drug benefit programs.

title: Editorial: Paroxysmal tachycardia in children
Editorial: Research Guidelines
Educational and organizational interventions to improve depression management in primary care: a systematic review
abstract: CONTEXT: Depression is a common occurrence in primary care but is often overlooked or treated suboptimally. A number of organizational and educational strategies to improve depression management have been proposed. The clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of these strategies have not yet been systematically reviewed. OBJECTIVE: To systematically evaluate the effectiveness of organizational and educational interventions to improve depression management in primary care. DATA SOURCES: We searched electronic medical and psychological databases from inception to March 2003 (MEDLINE, PsycLIT, EMBASE, CINAHL, Cochrane Controlled Trials Register, United Kingdom National Health Service Economic Evaluations Database, Cochrane Depression Anxiety and Neurosis Group register and Cochrane Effective Professional and Organizational Change Group register)"; Correspondence with authors;" and reference lists used. The search terms related to depression, primary care, and all policies and organizational and educational interventions. STUDY SELECTION: We selected 36 studies, including 29 randomized controlled trials and non-randomized controlled clinical trials, 5 before-and-after controlled studies, and 2 interrupted time-series studies. Findings related to the management and outcomes of depression were sought. Data extraction: Methodological details and results were extracted and reviewed by 2 reviewers. The summary relative risks have been calculated using the original data where possible, and an attempt has been made to correct the error of the analysis unit. DATA SYNTHESIS: Narrative synthesis was performed. Twenty-one studies with positive results were found. Strategies to improve patient outcomes have generally been those involving complex interventions involving training of clinicians, an increased role for the nurse (case management by nurses), and a greater degree of integration between primary and secondary care (counseling and liaison). Medication advice over the phone from practice nurses or trained advisors was also effective. Simple guideline implementation and educational strategies were generally ineffective. CONCLUSIONS: There is significant potential for improving depression management in primary care. Commonly used guidelines and parenting strategies are likely to be ineffective. Implementing the insights from this research will require significant investment in primary care and a major shift in how care is organized and delivered.

title: Educating primary care residents on how to know about and administer hepatitis B vaccination to patients with diabetes mellitus
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Although guidelines recommend hepatitis B virus (HBV) vaccination for adults with diabetes mellitus (DM), vaccination rates remain low. Our aim was to evaluate knowledge and practice related to HBV and to assess the effectiveness of a multifaceted educational program. METHODS: Primary care residents (n = 244) at three academic institutions were interviewed about various aspects of HBV. Residents in an exercise program were then randomly assigned to an educational intervention (E) (n=20) and a control group (C) (n=19). The E-group received a focused didactic lecture and regular email reminders with immediate feedback. We compared knowledge values before and after the intervention. Chart audits were conducted to assess residents' behavior. RESULTS: A total of 103 (42%) residents responded to the survey. The survey revealed that residents lacked the necessary knowledge and skills to assess the risk of HBV in patients with DM. In the controlled study of the e-intervention, both groups had similar baseline knowledge scores. The E group had a significant increase in knowledge scores immediately after the intervention from a mean of 29% at baseline to 70% (P<0.001) that was maintained at 6 months post-intervention (65%; P<0.001). In group C, the values did not differ from baseline at 6 months after the intervention (38% vs. 29%). No significant differences were observed in documentation skills. CONCLUSIONS: A combined educational program was effective in improving knowledge about HBV and vaccination in DM but had limited impact on physician practice. Further studies involving system changes along with educational initiatives are needed to improve clinical practice.

title: Educational interventions for general practitioners to identify and treat depression as a risk factor for suicide in young people: a systematic review and meta-analysis protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Suicide is a major public health problem and the second leading cause of death among young adults worldwide. Globally, there are 164,000 suicides per year among young people under the age of 25. Depression is a strong risk factor for suicide. Evidence shows that 45% of those who commit suicide, including young adults, are more likely to contact their GP than a psychiatrist in the month before they die. Additional evidence suggests that risk factors or early warning signs for suicide in young people go undetected and untreated by GPs. Health-based suicide prevention interventions aimed at general practitioners aim to improve the identification of at-risk young people. The rationale behind this type of intervention is that early identification and improved clinical management of at-risk individuals reduce morbidity and mortality. This systematic review will summarize evidence on the effectiveness of general practitioner education in identifying and treating depression as a suicide risk factor in young people. METHODS/DESIGN: We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis according to the guidelines of the Cochrane Manual for Systematic Reviews of Interventions and follow the reporting guidelines of the recommendations of the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) statement. Electronic databases are systematically searched for randomized controlled trials and quasi-experimental studies that review the effectiveness of general practitioner interventions in identifying and treating depression as a suicide risk factor in young people compared to any other intervention, no intervention, usual care, or watchful waiting . Gray literature is searched by screening study registers. Only studies published in English are considered. No date restrictions are applied. Two authors will independently review titles and abstracts of potential studies. The primary outcome is the detection and treatment of depression. Secondary endpoints were suicidal ideation, suicide attempt, intentional self-harm, knowledge of suicide risk factors and suicidal behaviors, attitudes about suicidal risk and suicidal behaviors, confidence in dealing with suicidal risk factors and suicidal behaviors. DISCUSSION: Our study will inform the development of future educational interventions and provide proof of concept and acceptability to help primary care physicians identify and manage suicidal behaviors in young people. REGISTRATION FOR THE SYSTEMATIC REVIEW: PROSPERO registration number: CRD42014009110.

title: Educational interventions to improve antibiotic prescribing and dispensing: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Excessive and inappropriate use of antibiotics contributes to growing antibiotic resistance, an important public health problem. Strategies need to be developed to improve antibiotic prescribing. Our goal is to review educational programs aimed at improving the prescribing of antibiotics by physicians and/or the dispensing of antibiotics by pharmacists, both in primary care and in hospitals. METHODS: We performed a critical systematic search and review of the relevant literature on educational programs aimed at improving antibiotic prescribing and dispensing practices in primary care and the hospital setting, published from January 2001 to December 2011. RESULTS: We identified 78 Studies for analysis, 47 in primary care and 31 in hospitals. The studies varied greatly in design, but reported mostly positive results. Outcomes measured in the studies reviewed were adherence to guidelines, total number of antibiotics prescribed, or both, attitudes and behaviors related to antibiotic prescribing, and quality of pharmacy practice related to antibiotics. Twenty-nine studies (62%) in the primary care setting and twenty-four (78%) in the hospital setting reported positive results for all measured endpoints,” fourteen studies (30%) in the primary care setting and six (20%) in the hospital setting reported positive results for some endpoints and Outcomes that in others were not statistically influenced by the intervention;" only four studies in the primary care setting and one study in the hospital setting failed to report significant improvements after the intervention for all outcomes. In 46% and 41% of all studies reviewed, respectively, an improvement in guideline adherence and a decrease in the total number of antibiotics prescribed after educational interventions were observed. Behavioral changes associated with antibiotic prescribing and an improvement in the quality of pharmacy practice were observed in four and one study, respectively. CONCLUSION: The results show that the use of antibiotics could be improved by educational interventions, which are mostly multifaceted interventions.

title: Educational visit and hypnosedative prescription in general medicine
abstract: Public concern about the prescribing of hypnosedatives (mainly benzodiazepines) led to a controlled attempt at an educational effort to encourage rational prescribing by General Practitioners (GPs). This paper describes the educational intervention and its process evaluation. In urban and rural New South Wales, 137 GPs were visited during office hours by a GP or pharmacist who had received communication training. Materials offered to GPs included relaxation bands and a brochure with problem-based treatment guidelines. The interview consisted of three phases: establishing a relationship, then educational material was presented, and finally the visitor sought the doctor's consent to screen five patients for long-term benzodiazepines. The visits were well received. Several measures were compiled to reflect physicians' motivation and interest in non-drug management”; There was virtually no correlation between any of these process measurements and the study outcome: a change in prescribing behavior. Self-reported benzodiazepine prescribing grossly underestimated actual self-reported prescribing incidents. We interpret this as a reminder that we don't always do what we want to do, and we don't always do what we think we're doing.

title: Effect of a computerized body mass index prompt on the diagnosis and treatment of obesity in adults.
abstract: Background: In overweight adults, physicians often fail to identify and recommend treatments for obesity. We sought to determine whether prompting for a computerized body mass index (BMI) chart would increase the likelihood that primary care physicians would diagnose patients with obesity and refer them for obesity treatment. METHODS: A total of 846 obese patients from 37 general practitioners were randomly assigned to either include a patient's BMI prompt in their electronic medical record (intervention group) or not to include a BMI prompt in their electronic medical record (comparison group). We then examined the patients' medical records for evidence of an obesity diagnosis and referral for specific obesity treatments. We also measured whether the presence of comorbidities in obese patients affects the likelihood of diagnosis and treatment by physicians. Results: Obese patients from physicians who had a BMI prompt in their medical records were significantly more likely to receive an obesity diagnosis than obese patients from physicians who did not receive a BMI prompt (16.6% versus 10.7%"; "P= .016). Patients from physicians provided with a BMI prompt were more likely to receive referral for diet treatment (14.0% vs. 7.3%, p=0.002) and exercise (12.1%) than patients from Physicians who were not prompted for a spreadsheet. versus 7.1%, P=0.016). Of the obesity comorbidities, only obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) was a predictor of a patient being diagnosed with obesity (OR=0.49, 95% CI=0.281, 0.869, P=0.014). Conclusions: The inclusion of a computerized BMI prompt increased the likelihood that physicians would diagnose obesity in obese patients and refer them for treatment.

title: Effect of minimal pharmacy intervention on improving adherence to asthma guidelines.
abstract: Aim To investigate the effectiveness of a minimal intervention strategy to improve adherence to pediatric asthma guidelines. Design and setting A group of pharmacists were encouraged to discuss key elements of asthma management with the GPs they normally work with. Adherence to the guidelines was assessed by studying prescriptions for children with asthma. We compared the treatment of children registered in pharmacies that participated in the study (intervention group) with a control group of children registered in other non-participating pharmacies (reference group) and with the results of a previous study. Main outcome measures The number of children who received no short-acting betamimetics, no inhaled corticosteroids during treatment with long-acting betamimetics, and more than one inhaler type. Results The number of children not receiving short-acting betamimetics was significantly lower in the intervention group (176/1447 vs. 534/3527; p<0.01) and fewer children were not receiving inhaled corticosteroids despite receiving long-acting betamimetics (6/ 219 vs 41/477; p=0.03). p<0.01). Conclusions Pharmacist support in adhering to pediatric asthma guidelines is beneficial. Pharmacists should be actively involved in the care of children with asthma.

title: Effect of a web-based guided self-help intervention on the prevention of major depression in adults with underlying depression
abstract: Significance Evidence-based treatments for major depressive disorder (MDD) are not very successful in improving functional and health outcomes. Increasing attention has been focused on the prevention of MDD. Aim To evaluate the effectiveness of a web-based guided self-help intervention for the prevention of MDD. Design, setting and participants Two-group randomized clinical study conducted between March 1, 2013 and March 4, 2015. Participants were recruited from the general population in Germany through a large statutory health insurance fund (ie an insurance funded by joint employers). . employee contributions). Participants included 406 self-selected adults with subliminal depression (Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale 16, not a current MDD according to the criteria of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders [Fourth Edition, text revision]). Interventions All participants had unrestricted access to usual care (GP visits) and were randomized to either a web-based guided self-help intervention (cognitive behavioral and problem-solving therapy supported by an online trainer"; n?= ?202) or a web-based psychoeducational program (n? =?204) Assessed by blinded diagnostic assessors using the telephone-conducted structured clinical interview for DSM-IV axis disorders at the 6 and 12 month follow-up covering the period up to the previous assessment Results Among 406 randomized patients (mean age 45 years ; 73.9% women), 335 (82%) completed the 12-month telephone follow-up Fifty-five participants (27%) in the intervention group experienced MDD compared to 84 participants (41%) in the control group Cox regression analyzes for the control Baseline The severity of the depres sive symptoms resulted in a hazard ratio of 0.59 (95% CI, 0.42-0.82; P?=?.002) at 12 months follow-up. The number requiring treatment to prevent a new case of MDD was 5.9 (95% CI, 3.9-14.6). Conclusions and Relevance In patients with underlying depression, the use of a web-based guided self-help intervention reduced the incidence of MDD over 12 months compared to improved usual care. Further research is needed to understand whether the effects on both depression onset and depression recurrence, as well as on efficacy, are generalizable without the use of an online trainer.

title: Effect of an educational program (PEGASE) on cardiovascular risk in patients with hypercholesterolaemia
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many studies have highlighted a gap between cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention guidelines and their implementation in clinical practice. AIM: The PEGASE educational program was developed with the aim of improving the management of patients at high risk for cardiovascular disease. METHODS: In a multicentre study conducted in France from 2001-2004, 96 participating physicians were divided into a "trained" group containing 398 "trained" patients and an "untrained" group containing 242 "untrained". ' Patients included, randomized. Educated" patients. Educated patients received six hospital-based educational sessions, four collective and two individual. Framingham score, smoking, lipid levels, glycemia, blood pressure, food intake and drug compliance, and quality of life were assessed at baseline (M0) and at 6 months (M6). The primary endpoint of the study was the effectiveness of the PEGASE program in reducing global risk of CVD in high-risk patients.RESULTS: The Framingham score was calculated for 473 patients.The Framingham score improved significantly at M6 vs. M0 in the educated group (13.0 +/- 8.21 vs. 13.6 +/- 8.48, d = -0.658, p = 0.016), but not in the uneducated group (12.5 +/- 8 .19 vs 12.4 +/- 7.81, d = +0.064, p = 0.836)";" the mean change between the two groups did not reach significance. Quality of life, LDL-c levels and nutritional values improved only in the “educated” group CONCLUSIONS: The PEG ASE training program improved risk factors for cardiovascular disease, although the global assessment using the Framingham score did not differ significantly between groups. This program, aimed at meeting the needs and expectations of patients and doctors, has been smoothly implemented in all hospital centers.

title: Effect of outpatient antimicrobial stewardship intervention on general practitioner prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics: a randomized trial.
abstract: Importance Antimicrobial stewardship programs have been effective for inpatients, often through the prescription of audits and feedback. However, most antibiotics are used in outpatients with acute respiratory infections (ARTIs). Aim To evaluate the effect of an antimicrobial stewardship intervention on antibiotic prescribing for outpatient pediatric patients. Design Cluster-randomized study of outpatient antimicrobial use comparing prescribing between intervention and control practices using a shared electronic health record. After excluding children with chronic diseases, antibiotic allergies, and prior antibiotic use, we estimated prescription rates for targeted ARTIs, standardized by age, sex, race, and insurance, from 20 months before the procedure to 12 months after (October 2008–June 2011). ). Setting and Participants A network of 25 pediatric primary care practices in Pennsylvania and New Jersey; 18 practices (162 clinicians) participated and provided feedback on prescribing bacterial and viral ARTIs or usual practice Rates of prescribing broad spectrum antibiotics (outside of guidelines) for bacterial ARTIs and antibiotics for viral ARTIs at 1 year post-procedure Results Prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics from 26.8% to 14.3% (absolute difference, 12.5%) in intervention practices compared to 28.4% to 22.6% (absolute difference, 5.8%) in controls (difference of differences [DOD], 6.7%; P=0.01 for differences). Out-of-guideline prescriptions for children with pneumonia decreased from 15.7% to 4.2% in intervention practices compared to 17.1% to 16.3% in controls (DOD, 10.7%; P<0.001) and in acute s inusitis from 38.9% to 18.8% in intervention practices and from 40.0% to 33.9% in controls (DOD, 14.0%; P=0.12). Out-of-guideline prescribing was unusual at baseline and changed little for streptococcal pharyngitis (intervention, from 4.4% to 3.4%; control, from 5.6% to 3.5%; DOD, -1.1 %; P=0.82) and for viral infections (intervention, from 7.9% to 7.7%; control, from 6.4% to 4.5%; DOD, -1.7%; P=0, 93). with usual practice, improved adherence to prescribing guidelines for common bacterial ARTIs, and the intervention had no impact on antibiotic prescribing for viral infections. Future studies should examine the drivers of these effects, as well as the generalizability, sustainability, and clinical outcomes of outpatient antimicrobial administration.

title: Effect of anemia and cardiovascular disease on surgical mortality and morbidity
abstract: Background Guidelines on hemoglobin thresholds for blood transfusions in surgical patients have been offered. However, good evidence is lacking as to which hemoglobin concentrations at which the risk of death or severe morbidity begins to increase and at which transfusion is indicated.";" Background Guidelines on hemoglobin thresholds for blood transfusions in surgical patients have been offered. However, good evidence is lacking as to the hemoglobin concentration at which the risk of death or severe morbidity begins to increase and at which transfusion is indicated.

title: Impact of peer-reviewed audit and feedback on primary care physician prescribing and trial ordering performance: a cluster-randomized controlled study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Much of the world's research focuses on cost containment and better compliance in healthcare. Research that focuses on professional behavior is often conducted in a well-controlled research environment. In this study, a large-scale implementation of a peer review strategy in terms of both trial ordering and prescribing behavior in primary care was tested as part of normal quality improvement. Methods: We planned a cluster RCT in existing local quality improvement collaborations (LQICs) in primary care. The study ran from January 2008 to January 2011. LQICs were randomly assigned to one of two study arms, with each arm receiving the same intervention of audit and feedback combined with peer review. Both arms were offered five different clinical themes and acted as blind controls for the other arm. The differences in trial order rates and prescription rates between both arms were analyzed in an intention-to-treat pre-post analysis and a per-protocol analysis. RESULTS: Twenty-one LQIC groups, including 197 general practitioners working in 88 practices, participated in the study. Intention-to-treat analysis showed no difference in changes in test design or prescribing performance between intervention and control groups. The per-protocol analysis showed positive results for half of the clinical subjects. The increase in total tests ordered was 3% in the intervention arm and 15% in the control arm. At prescription, the increase in prescriptions was 20% in the intervention arm and 66% in the control arm. It was observed that the groups with the highest order and prescription volumes at baseline showed the greatest improvements. CONCLUSIONS: Our study shows that the results of previous work could not be confirmed by our attempt to implement the strategy in the field. We did not see a decrease in test quantities ordered or medications prescribed, but rather a smaller increase. The implementation of peer review with audit and feedback has not proven feasible in primary care in the Netherlands. STUDY REGISTRATION: This study was registered on August 7, 2007 in the Dutch study registry under number ISRCTN40008171.

title: Impact of audit and feedback and reminder messages on referrals to primary care in radiology: a randomized study.
abstract: Background Radiological tests are commonly used by general practitioners (GPs). These tests can be overused and contribute little to clinical management. Our aim was to evaluate two methods for reducing GP requests for radiological testing according to the UK Royal College of Radiologists guidelines on lumbar spine and knee radiographs. Methods We assessed audit and feedback and educational reminder messages in six radiology departments and 244 general practices they served. The study was a pragmatic, cluster-randomized, controlled before-after study with a 2 x 2 factorial design. A randomly selected subset of medical records from primary care physicians was reviewed for compliance with the guidelines. The main outcome measure was the number of X-ray requests per 1000 patients per year. The analysis was intended to treat. Results The effect of educational reminder messages (ie change in request rate after intervention) was an absolute change of -1·53 (95% CI -2·5 to -0·57) for the lumbar spine and of -1·61 (-2 ·6 to -0·62) for knee radiographs, both relative reductions of about 20%. The effect of audit and feedback was an absolute change of -0·07 (-1·3 to 0·9) for lumbar spine from 0·04 (-0·95 to 1·03) for knee radiographs, both relative reductions of about 1%. The agreement between the groups did not differ significantly. Interpretation Biannual feedback of audit data is ineffective, but routinely attaching educational reminder messages to X-rays is effective and does not affect the quality of referrals. Any radiology department processing referrals from primary care could perform this intervention to good effect.

title: Impact of behavior change on outcome in early-to-moderate-stage chronic kidney disease: A cluster-randomized study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Due to recent changes in our understanding of the underlying cause of chronic kidney disease (CKD), the importance of lifestyle modification in preventing the progression of renal dysfunction and complications has become apparent. Additionally, effective collaboration between general practitioners (GPs) and nephrologists is essential to ensure a better delivery system for CKD treatment. In this cluster-randomized study, we examined the effect of behavioral modification on the outcome of early-to-moderate-stage CKD. DESIGN: Stratified open cluster randomized study. SETTING: A total of 489 general practitioners belonging to 49 local medical associations (clusters) in Japan. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 2,379 patients (1,195 in group A (standard intervention) and 1,184 in group B (advanced intervention)) between the ages of 40 and 74 years suffering from CKD who were consulted by primary care physicians. INTERVENTION: All patients were treated according to current CKD guidelines. Group B clusters received three additional interventions: patients received both an educational lifestyle change intervention and a CKD status letter to prevent them from stopping treatment, and Group B primary care physicians received data sheets to help reduce the to ease the gap between goal and practice. MAIN OUTCOME MEASUREMENT: The primary outcome measures were 1) the rate of noncompliance in accepting ongoing medical follow-up by patients, 2) the rate of cooperation between primary care physicians and nephrologists, and 3) progression of CKD. RESULTS: The rate of discontinuous doctor visits was significantly lower in group B (16.2% in group A vs. 11.5% in group B, p=0.01). Significantly higher referral and co-treatment rates were observed in group B (p<0.01). The mean eGFR deterioration rate tended to be lower in Group B (Group A: 2.6+/-5.8 mL/min/1.73 m2/year, Group B: 2.4+/-5.1 mL/min /1.73 m2/year, p = 0.07 ). A significant difference in eGFR deterioration rate was observed in patients with stage 3 CKD (Group A: 2.4 +/- 5.9 mL/min/1.73 m2/year, Group B: 1.9 +/- 4.4 mL/min/1.73 m2/year, p=0.03). CONCLUSION: Our care system achieved behavioral change in CKD patients, namely significantly fewer discontinuous clinical visits, and behavioral change in both primary care physicians and nephrologists, namely significantly higher referral and co-treatment rates, resulting in a delay in CKD progression, particularly in Patients with Stage 3 proteinuric CKD. STUDY REGISTRATION: The University Hospital Medical Information Network Clinical Trial Registry UMIN000001159.

title: Effect of behavioral interventions on inappropriate antibiotic prescribing in general practice: A randomized clinical trial
abstract: IMPORTANT: Behavioral science-based interventions could reduce inappropriate antibiotic prescribing. OBJECTIVE: To assess the impact of behavioral interventions and the incidence of inappropriate (non-guideline compliant) antibiotic prescriptions during outpatient visits for acute respiratory infections. DESIGN, SETUP, AND PARTICIPANTS: Cluster-randomized clinical study conducted among 47 primary care practices in Boston and Los Angeles. Participants were 248 enrolled physicians randomized to receive 0, 1, 2, or 3 interventions for 18 months. All clinicians received training on antibiotic prescribing guidelines at enrollment. Interventions began between November 1, 2011 and October 1, 2012. Follow-up for the last starting sites ended April 1, 2014. Adult patients with comorbidities and concomitant infections were excluded. INTERVENTIONS: Three behavioral interventions, performed individually or in combination: proposed alternatives presented e-prescription records proposing non-antibiotic treatments; a reasonable justification prompted clinicians to enter free-text justifications for antibiotic prescriptions in electronic medical records;" peer comparison emailed clinicians who compared their antibiotic prescription rates with those of "top performers" (those with the lowest inappropriate prescription rates) compared. KEY RESULTS AND MEASURES: Antibiotic prescribing rates for visits with antibiotic-inappropriate diagnoses (nonspecific upper respiratory tract infections, acute bronchitis, and influenza) from 18 months before the intervention to 18 months after, adjusting the impact of each intervention for concomitant interventions, and trends of the intervention, with random effects for practices and clinicians. RESULTS: There were 14,753 visits (mean patient age 47 years; 69% women) for antibiotic-inappropriate acute respiratory infections during the baseline period and 16,959 visits (mean patient age 48 years; 67% women) during the intervention period. Mean antibiotic prescription rates decreased from 24.1% at baseline to 13.1% at intervention month 18 (absolute difference, -11.0%) for control practices and from 22.1% to 6.1% (absolute difference, -16.0%) for suggested alternatives (difference in differences, -5.0% [95% CI, -7.8% to 0.1%]; P=0.66 for differences in trajectories); from 23.2% to 5.2% (absolute difference, -18.1%) for reasonable justification (difference in differences, -7.0% [95% CI, -9.1% to -2.9%] , P<0.001) and from 19.9% to 3.7% (absolute difference, -16.3%) for peer comparison (difference of differences, -5.2% [95% CI, -6.9% to -1.6%]; "P<0.001). There were no statistically significant interactions (neither synergy nor interference) between the interventions. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Among primary care practices, the use of reasonable justification and peer comparison as behavioral interventions resulted in lower rates of inappropriate antibiotic prescribing for acute respiratory infections. STUDY REGISTRATION: clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT01454947.

title: Impact of clinical decision support systems: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite increasing emphasis on the role of clinical decision support systems (CDSSs) in improving care and reducing costs, evidence of widespread use is lacking. PURPOSE: To evaluate the effect of CDSSs on clinical outcomes, healthcare processes, workload and efficiency, patient satisfaction, Cost and use and implementation of the provider. DATA SOURCES: MEDLINE, CINAHL, PsycINFO and Web of Science up to January 2011. STUDY SELECTION: Investigators independently reviewed reports to identify randomized studies published in English on electronic CDSSs implemented in clinical settings"; used by providers to determine the to support decision-making at the point of care;and reported clinical, medical care process, workload, relationship-centric, economic, or provider utilization outcomes.DATA EXTRACTION:Researchers extracted data on study design, participant characteristics, interventions, outcomes, and quality.DATA SYNTHESIS: 148 randomized controlled trials were included.A total of 1 assessed 28 (86%) health care process interventions, 29 (20%) assessed clinical outcomes, and 22 (15%) measured costs.Both commercially and locally developed CDSSs improved health care interventions process related to the implementation of preventive services (n = 25; odds ratio [OR], 1.42 [95% CI, 1.27 to 1.58]), ordering clinical trials (n = 20; OR, 1.72). [CI, 1.47 to 2.00]) and prescription of therapies (n=46; OR, 1.57 [CI, 1.35 to 1.82]). Few studies have measured potential unintended consequences or side effects. Conclusion: Both commercially and locally developed CDSSs are effective in improving health care process interventions in various settings, but evidence for clinical, economic, workload, and efficiency outcomes remains sparse. The review expands knowledge in this area by highlighting the benefits of CDSSs demonstrated outside of experienced academic centers.

title: Impact of the computer-aided implementation of the European best practice guideline on adherence and goal achievement: ORAMA results.
abstract: Background: The success of guidelines largely depends on their effective implementation and acceptance in clinical practice. The Optimal Renal Anemia Management Assessment (ORAMA) study evaluated the impact of the European Best Practice Guideline (EBPG) prompt on patient outcomes. METHODS: ORAMA was a prospective, international, multicenter, cluster-randomized study. 53 centers in eight European countries enrolled patients with stage V chronic kidney disease who were on chronic dialysis. Patients were either anemic (hemoglobin [Hb] < 11 g/dL [110 g/L]) or were being treated with agents to stimulate erythropoiesis and/or iron supplementation. The centers were randomized into two groups, with or without access to a Computerized Clinical Decision Support (CDS) system. In a post-hoc analysis, patients were further subdivided into adherence or non-compliance by investigators to the EBPG, regardless of use of CDS. The primary endpoint was the proportion of patients with Hb > 11 g/dL (110 g/L), reflecting the hematological targets in the revised EPBG. Results: In this population of 599 dialysis patients, the hematological goals did not differ in the presence or absence of a CDS system. There was a general shift towards improved patient distribution by Hb category, while the width of the distribution curves remained unchanged. The proportion of patients with Hb > 11 g/dl (110 g/l) was higher among adherents (79% and 84% with and without CDS use, respectively) than among non-adherents (59% and 57%, respectively) ). Conclusions: ORAMA is the first international study to show that adherence to EBPG improves the achievement of anemia indices. The availability of a CDS system had no impact on anemia management.

title: Effect of computer-assisted, evidence-based guidelines for the management of asthma and angina in adults in primary care: cluster-randomized controlled study.
abstract: Brief Description Aim: To evaluate the use of a computerized decision-making support system to implement evidence-based clinical guidelines for the management of adult asthma and angina in primary care. Design: A randomized, controlled, before-and-after, pragmatic cluster study using a two by two incomplete block design. Setting: 60 GP practices in the North East of England. Participants: GPs and practice nurses in the study practices and their patients aged 18 and over with angina pectoris or asthma. Main outcome measures: Adherence to guidelines based on review of case notes and patient-reported overall and condition-specific outcome measures. Results: The computer-based decision support system had no significant impact on consultation rates, the process of care interventions (including prescribing), or patient-reported outcomes for either condition. Software usage was low. Conclusions: No effect of computerized, evidence-based guidelines on the management of asthma or angina in adults in primary care was found. This was probably due to the low usage of the software, although the system was optimized as much as technically possible. Even when the technical issues involved in manufacturing a system that fully supports the management of chronic diseases have been solved, the challenge remains to integrate the systems into clinical encounters where busy physicians treat patients with complex, multiple conditions.

title: Effect of daily aspirin on long-term risk of cancer death: Analysis of individual patient data from randomized trials
abstract: Background Treatment with daily aspirin for 5 years or more reduces later risk of colorectal cancer. Several lines of evidence suggest that aspirin might also reduce the risk of other cancers, particularly of the gastrointestinal tract, but evidence in humans is lacking. We examined cancer-related deaths during and after randomized trials of daily aspirin versus control, which was originally performed to prevent vascular events.";" Background Treatment with daily aspirin for 5 years or more reduces later risk of colorectal cancer. Several lines of evidence suggest that aspirin might also reduce the risk of other cancers, particularly of the gastrointestinal tract, but evidence in humans is lacking. We examined cancer-related deaths during and after randomized trials of daily aspirin versus controls originally designed to prevent vascular events.

title: Effect of exercise recommendation programs in primary care on physical activity and improvement in health outcomes: systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the impact of exercise recommendation programs on physical activity and health outcomes. Design systematic review and meta-analysis. DATA SOURCES Medline, Embase, PsycINFO, Cochrane Library, ISI Web of Science, SPORTDiscus and ongoing trial registries up to October 2009. We also checked trial references. Study selection Design: randomized controlled trials or non-randomized controlled trials (cluster or single) published in peer-reviewed journals. POPULATION sedentary people with or without medical diagnosis. Exercise referral programs are defined as: clear referrals from healthcare professionals to outside service providers to increase physical activity or exercise, physical activity or exercise programs tailored to individuals, and initial assessment and monitoring throughout programs. Comparators: usual care, no intervention or alternative exercise recommendations. RESULTS Eight randomized controlled trials met inclusion criteria and compared exercise recommendation regimens with usual care (six trials), alternative physical activity interventions (two), and an exercise recommendation regimen plus a self-determination theory intervention (one). Compared to usual care, follow-up data for exercise programs showed an increased number of participants achieving 90-150 minutes of physical activity of at least moderate intensity per week (pooled relative risk 1.16, 95% confidence interval 1.03 to 1, 30) and a reduced level of depression (pooled standardized mean difference -0.82, -1.28 to -0.35). Evidence of a difference between groups in moderate- or vigorous-intensity physical activity or other health outcomes was conflicting at follow-up. We found no difference in outcomes between exercise referral programs and the other two comparison groups. None of the included studies separately reported results in people with specific medical diagnoses. Significant heterogeneity in the quality and nature of exercise recommendation schemes between studies may have contributed to the inconsistency of outcome findings. Conclusions There remains considerable uncertainty as to the effectiveness of exercise recommendation programs on increasing physical activity, fitness or health indicators, or whether they represent an efficient use of resources for sedentary people with or without a medical diagnosis.
