title: Effect of financial incentives given to physicians, patients, or both on lipid levels
abstract: Significance Financial incentives for doctors or patients are increasingly used, but their effectiveness is not well documented. Objective To determine whether financial physician incentives, patient incentives, or joint physician-patient incentives are more effective than control in reducing low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (LDL-C) levels in patients at high cardiovascular risk. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Four-group, multicenter, cluster-randomized clinical trial with a 12-month intervention conducted from 2011-2014 in 3 primary care practices in the Northeastern United States. 340 eligible general practitioners (PCPs) were enrolled from a pool of 421. Of 25-627 potentially eligible patients of these PCPs, 1503 were enrolled. Patients 18 to 80 years of age were eligible if they had a 10-year Framingham Risk Score (FRS) of 20% or greater, coronary artery disease equivalents with LDL-C levels of 120 mg/dL or greater, or had an FRS of 120 mg/dL 10% to 20% with LDL-C levels of 140 mg/dL or greater. Investigators were blinded to the study group, but participants were not. Interventions Primary care physicians were randomly assigned to control, physician incentives, patient incentives, or joint physician-patient incentives. Physicians in the Physician Incentive Group were eligible to receive up to $1024 per enrolled patient who met LDL-C goals. Patients in the patient incentive group were eligible for the same amount, distributed through daily lotteries tied to medication adherence. Physicians and patients in the shared incentive group shared these incentives. Physicians and patients in the control group received no incentives tied to outcomes, but all patient participants received up to $355 each for participating in the study. Main results and measures Change in LDL-C levels at 12 months. Results Patients in the joint doctor-patient incentive group achieved a mean reduction in LDL-C of 33.6 mg/dL (95% CI, 30.1-37.1 inches; baseline 160.1 mg/dL; Dec months 126.4 mg/dl); in physician incentives achieved a mean reduction of 27.9 mg/dL (95% CI, 24.9-31.0; baseline 159.9 mg/dL; 12 months, 132.0 mg/dL); those in patient incentives achieved a mean reduction of 25.1 mg/dL (95% CI, 21.6-28.5; baseline 160.6 mg/dL; 12 months, 135.5 mg/dL); and those in the control group achieved a mean reduction of 25.1 mg/dL (95% CI, 21.7-28.5; baseline). , 161.5 mg/dL; 12 months, 136.4 mg/dL; P? <?.001 comparing all 4 groups.) Only patients in the joint doctor-patient incentive group achieved statistically different reductions in LDL-C levels than those in the control group (8.5 mg/dL; 95% CI, 3.8-13.3; "P?=?.002). Conclusions and Relevance In primary care practices, joint financial incentives for physicians and patients, but not incentives for physicians or patients alone, resulted in a statistically significant difference in reductions in LDL-C levels at 12 months. However, this reduction was modest and more information is needed to understand if this approach represents good value.

title: Effect of Financial Incentives for Physicians, Patients, or Both on Lipid Levels: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
abstract: Relevance: Financial incentives for doctors or patients are increasingly used, but their effectiveness is not well documented. Objective: To determine whether financial physician incentives, patient incentives, or joint physician-patient incentives are more effective than control in reducing low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (LDL-C) levels in patients at high cardiovascular risk. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: Four-group, multicenter, cluster-randomized clinical trial with a 12-month intervention conducted from 2011 to 2014 in 3 primary care practices in the Northeastern United States. From a pool of 421, 340 qualified general practitioners (PCPs) were enrolled. Of 25,627 potentially eligible patients of these PCPs, 1503 were enrolled. Patients 18 to 80 years of age were eligible if they had a 10-year Framingham Risk Score (FRS) of 20% or greater, coronary artery disease equivalents with LDL-C levels of 120 mg/dL or greater, or had an FRS of 120 mg/dL 10% to 20% with LDL-C levels of 140 mg/dL or greater. Investigators were blinded to the study group, but participants were not. INTERVENTIONS: Primary care physicians were randomly assigned to control, physician incentives, patient incentives, or joint physician-patient incentives. Physicians in the Physician Incentive Group were eligible to receive up to $1024 per enrolled patient who met LDL-C goals. Patients in the patient incentive group were eligible for the same amount, distributed through daily lotteries tied to medication adherence. Physicians and patients in the shared incentive group shared these incentives. Physicians and patients in the control group received no incentives tied to outcomes, but all patient participants received up to $355 each for participating in the study. Main results and measures: Change in LDL-C levels at 12 months. Results: Only the patients in the joint doctor-patient incentive group achieved statistically different reductions in LDL-C levels from those in the control group (8.5 mg/dL; 95% CI, 3.8-13.3; P = 0.002). For comparison of all 4 groups, P<0.001. Conclusions and Relevance: In primary care practices, co-financial incentives for physicians and patients, but not incentives for physicians or patients alone, resulted in a statistically significant difference in reductions in LDL-C levels at 12 months. However, this reduction was modest and more information is needed to understand if this approach represents good value. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Effect of improving treatment for depression on pain and functional outcomes in older adults with arthritis: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Context Depression and arthritis are disabling and common health problems in old age. Depression is also a risk factor for poor health outcomes in arthritis sufferers. Aim To determine whether improving treatment for depression improves pain and functional outcomes in older adults with depression and arthritis. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Preplanned subgroup analyzes of Improving Mood-Promoting Access to Collaborative Treatment (IMPACT), a randomized controlled trial of 1801 depressed older adults (age 60 years) conducted in 18 primary care clinics of 8 health facilities from July 1999 to August 2001 to nursing organizations in 5 states of the United States. A total of 1001 (56%) reported co-existing arthritis at baseline. Intervention Antidepressants and/or 6 to 8 sessions of psychotherapy (problem solving treatment in primary care). Major outcome measures Depression, pain intensity (0 to 10 scale), impairment of daily activities due to arthritis (0 to 10 scale), general health status, and overall quality of life assessed at baseline, 3, 6, and 12 months. Results In addition to the reduction in depressive symptoms, the intervention group had lower mean scores (SE) for pain intensity compared to the usual care group at 12 months (5.62 [0.16] vs. 6.15 [0.16]", Difference between groups: 0.53, 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.92 to 0.14; P=0.009), impairment of daily activities due to arthritis (4.40 [0.18] vs. 4.99 [0.17]; difference between groups, 0.59; 95% CI, ≥1.00 to ≥0.19; p=0.004) and impairment of daily activities due to pain (2.92 [0.07] vs 3.17 [0.07]; difference between groups ≥ 0.26; 95% CI ≥ 0.41 to ≥ 0.10; "P = 0.002). Overall health and quality of life were also improved in intervention patients compared to control patients at 12 months. Conclusions In a large and diverse population of older adults with arthritis (mainly osteoarthritis) and comorbid depression, the benefits of improved depression treatment went beyond reduced depressive symptoms to include less pain and improved functional status and quality of life.

title: Effect of inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system and other antihypertensive drugs on renal outcomes: systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: Background There is consensus that angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) have specific renoprotective effects. Guidelines state that these are the drugs of choice for treating high blood pressure in patients with kidney disease. We have attempted to determine the extent to which this consensus is supported by the available evidence.";" Background There is consensus that angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) have specific renoprotective effects. Guidelines state that these are the drugs of choice for treating high blood pressure in patients with kidney disease. We have attempted to determine the extent to which this consensus is supported by the available evidence.

title: Effect of integrated care for chronic low back pain patients on sick leave: economic assessment alongside a randomized controlled trial
abstract: AIM: To evaluate the cost-effectiveness, cost-effectiveness, and value for money of an integrated care program compared to usual care for on-call chronic low back pain patients. DESIGN: Economic assessment alongside a randomized controlled trial with 12-month follow-up. SETTING: Primary care (10 physiotherapy practices, one occupational health service, one occupational therapy practice) and secondary care (five hospitals) in the Netherlands, 2005-9. PARTICIPANTS: 134 adults aged 18-65 years on call-off with chronic low back pain: 66 were randomized to integrated care and 68 to usual care. INTERVENTIONS: Integrated care consisted of a participatory ergonomics-based workplace intervention involving a supervisor and a graded activity program based on cognitive behavioral principles. The usual care was provided by general practitioners and occupational physicians according to Dutch guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: The primary outcome was time to sustained return to work. The secondary outcome was quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) measured with EuroQol. RESULTS: Total costs in the integrated care group (13,165 pounds, SD 13,600 pounds) were significantly lower than in the usual care group (18,475 pounds, SD 13,616 pounds). Cost-effectiveness levels and acceptance curves showed that integrated care was cost-effective compared to usual care for return to work and QALYs gained. The cost-benefit analyzes showed that every Euro1 invested in integrated care would yield an estimated Euro26. The net societal benefit of integrated care compared to usual care was £5744. CONCLUSIONS: Implementing an integrated care program for sick patients with chronic low back pain has great potential to significantly reduce societal costs, increase care effectiveness, improve quality of life, and improve functioning across the board. Integrated care therefore has great advantages for patients and society as well as for employers.

title: Effect of interactive group discussions among physicians in promoting rational prescribing
abstract: This study examined the effect of an educational intervention (interactive group discussion) on the prescribing behavior of 51 general practitioners from north-west Tabriz. The prescriptions were analyzed before and after the intervention (control and intervention groups) using a form with 8 indicators of correct prescription. The mean number of medications per prescription before the intervention was 3.82. The percentage of prescriptions for antibiotics, corticosteroids, and injections were 40.8%, 25.9%, and 58.0%, respectively. After the intervention, there were minor but non-significant changes in the indicators in both the intervention and control groups compared to the pre-intervention results.

title: Effect of an intervention aimed at increasing physical activity, reducing physical inactivity, and increasing fruit and vegetable consumption in children: Active for Life Year 5 (AFLY5), school-based, cluster-based, randomized, controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To investigate the effectiveness of a school-based intervention in increasing physical activity, reducing sedentary behavior, and increasing fruit and vegetable consumption in children. DESIGN cluster randomized controlled trial. RECRUITMENT 60 primary schools in South West England. PARTICIPANTS Elementary school children in 4th grade (age 8-9 years) at recruitment and baseline assessment, in 5th grade during intervention, and at the end of 5th grade (age 9-10) at follow-up assessment. INTERVENTION The Active for Life Year 5 (AFLY5) intervention consisted of teacher training, interactive classroom and child-parent homework schedules, all materials needed for classroom and homework, and written materials for school newspapers and parents. The intervention was conducted when the children were in their 5th grade (age 9-10 years). Schools allocated to the control received standard instruction. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES The pre-specified primary endpoints were accelerometer-measured minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity per day, accelerometer-measured minutes of sedentary behavior per day, and reported daily servings of fruit and vegetables. RESULTS 60 schools with more than 2221 children were recruited";" For the main analyses, valid data were available for fruit and vegetable consumption for 2121 children, for accelerometer physical activity and physical inactivity for 1252 children, and for secondary endpoints for 1825 to 2212 children. None of the three primary endpoints differed between children in schools assigned to the AFLY5 intervention and those assigned to the control group. The mean difference between the intervention group and the control group was -1.35 (95% confidence interval -5.29 to 2.59) minutes per day for moderate to vigorous physical activity, -0.11 (-9.71 to 9.49) minutes per day for sedentary behavior, and 0.08 (-0.12 to 0.28) servings per day for fruit and vegetable consumption. The intervention was effective on three of nine secondary endpoints after multiple tests were considered: self-reported time spent with screens at weekends (-21 (-37 to -4) minutes per day), self-reported portions of snacks per day (- 0.22 (-0.38 to -0.05)) and portions of high-energy drinks per day (-0.26 (-0.43 to -0.10)) were all reduced. Results from a series of sensitivity analyzes testing different assumptions about missing data and from per-protocol analyzes yielded similar results. CONCLUSION The results suggest that the school-based AFLY5 intervention is not effective in increasing physical activity levels, reducing physical inactivity, and increasing fruit and vegetable consumption in elementary school children. Changing these activities may require more intensive behavioral interventions in children or upstream interventions at the family, community, and school settings. These findings are relevant to researchers, policy makers, public health practitioners and physicians involved in health promotion, policy making and service procurement. Study registration Current controlled studies ISRCTN50133740.

title: Effect of offering different levels of support and free nicotine replacement therapy via an English national telephone quitline: randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To compare the effects of complimentary nicotine replacement therapy or proactive telephone counseling in addition to standard smoking cessation support provided through a telephone quitline. DESIGN Parallel group, 2 × 2 factorial, randomized, controlled trial. SETTING National Quitline, England. PARTICIPANTS 2,591 non-pregnant smokers aged 16 and over residing in England who called the quitline between February 2009 and February 2010 and agreed to set a quit date: 648 were each randomized to standard support, proactive support, or proactive support with nicotine replacement therapy, and 647 were randomized to standard support with nicotine replacement therapy. INTERVENTIONS In addition to standard support, two interventions were offered: six weeks of free nicotine replacement therapy and proactive counseling sessions (repeated phone calls from and interaction with cessation counselors). MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was self-reported smoking cessation for six or more months after the smoking cessation date. The secondary outcome was termination, validated by exhaled carbon monoxide measured at six or more months. RESULTS At six months, 17.7% (n=229) of those offered nicotine replacement therapy reported quitting compared to 20.1% (n=261) who were not offered such therapy (odds ratio 0.85, 95% confidence interval 0.70 to 1.04) and 18.2% (n = 236) of the proactive counseling provided reported quitting smoking compared to 19.6% (n = 254) of the offered standard support (0.91, 0.75 to 1.11). Data validated by carbon monoxide measurements altered outcomes only for nicotine replacement therapy, with smoking cessation validated in 6.6% (85/1295) of those offered nicotine replacement therapy compared to 9.4% (122/ 1296) who were not offered such therapy (0.67, 0.50 to 0.90). CONCLUSIONS The offer of free nicotine replacement therapy or additional (proactive) counseling to standard hotline support had no additional effect on smoking cessation. TRIAL REGISTRATION ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00775944.

title: Impact of Patient-Specific Assessments Compared to Traditional Guidelines on Assessment Decisions in Angina: Adequacy of Referral and Assessment in Angina (ARIA) Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Traditional guidelines have had limited impact on how physicians change test designs. We sought to determine the effect of patient-specific assessments versus conventional guidelines on appropriate assessment of angina. METHODS: Randomized controlled trial of 145 physicians who received patient-specific ratings (online prompt as to whether the specific vignette was considered appropriate or inappropriate for the study, with access to detailed information on how the ratings were derived) and 147 physicians who conventional guidelines were received from the American Heart Association and the European Society of Cardiology. Physicians provided recommendations for 12 web-based patient vignettes before and 12 after these procedures. The result was the proportion of reasonable investigative decisions as defined by 2 independent expert panels. RESULTS: Decisions to perform stress electrocardiography were more appropriate with patient-specific ratings (819/1491 [55%]) compared to conventional guidelines (648/1488 [44%]) (odds ratio [OR], 1.57", 95% Confidence interval [CI], 1.36-1.82) The effect was stronger for angiography (1274/1595 [80%] with patient-specific assessments compared to 1009/1576 [64%] with conventional guidelines [OR, 2.24 ; 95% CI, 1.90-2.62]).3.22) and for angiography (80% vs. 65%; OR 2.10; 95% CI 1.79-2.47). These effects were robust to physician specialty (cardiologists and general practitioners) and vignette characteristics, including older age, female gender, and nonwhite/racial origin.CONCLUSION: Patient-specific ratings, in contrast to traditional guidelines, have changed physician testing behavior and have the potential to bias to reduce in practice and the reasonable use z of investigations to increase.

title: Effect of physician recommendation and patient adherence on colorectal cancer testing rates.
abstract: This study examined: (1) patient characteristics associated with physician recommendation for colorectal cancer screening (CRC) and patient compliance, and (2) the combined effect of recommendation and adherence to CRC testing, broadly defined. Data are from the 1999 MA BRFSS and a recall survey of 869 BRFSS participants aged 50 years and older. Logistic regression was used to identify correlates of recommendation, compliance, and assessment. Patient-physician factors were positively associated with referral, adherence, and testing. Inadequate health insurance was negatively associated with recommendation (OR = 0.45, 95% CI = 0.27-0.78) and testing (OR = 0.64, 95% CI = 0.38-1.1). Men were no more recommended (OR = 1.1, 95% CI = 0.78-1.5) but were more likely to adhere (OR = 1.9, 95% CI = 1.2-2.0) and could be tested (OR = 1.4, 95% CI = 1.0-1.9). When considering health and risk factor measures, there were gender differences in recommendations. Research is needed to understand the differences in recommendation and adherence. Greater encouragement and enforcement may be needed for groups less likely to comply.

title: Influence of self-efficacy and social support on antihypertensive drug adherence
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVE: To determine the relationship between poor adherence and self-efficacy or social support after a pharmacist intervention. DESIGN: Post hoc analysis of data from two randomized controlled trials of collaborative physician-pharmacist interventions (6 and 9 months, respectively) to improve blood pressure control. SETTING: Eleven primary care university hospitals. PATIENTS: Five hundred eighty-four patients (aged 21-85 years) with uncontrolled primary hypertension; 296 were in the intervention group and 288 were in the control group. Intervention group MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Social support and self-efficacy questionnaires were administered at baseline and at the end of the study. In the control group (p=0.0053), but not in the intervention group, however, was baseline adherence was high in both groups. There were small but significant improvements in self-efficacy (p<0.04) and social support (p<0.05) scores in the intervention group but not in the control group at the end of the Social study Support and, to a lesser extent, self-efficacy improved as a function of study duration p articulation (9-month vs. 6-month intervention), regardless of whether the patient received the intervention. Blood pressure control in both groups improved significantly at the end of the study; however, mean blood pressure was significantly lower in the intervention group (129.7/76.6 mmHg) compared to the control group (140.8/78.9 mmHg; p<0.0001 for systolic, p=0.032 for diastolic) . CONCLUSION: Social support and self-efficacy improved significantly in the intervention group at the end of the pharmacist intervention Medication adherence was correlated with self-efficacy, although medication adherence did not improve significantly in the intervention group The fact that social support and self-efficacy improved as a function duration of study participation suggests that participation in a research study may have had a positive impact on these measures. Although changes in social support, self-efficacy, and medication adherence were modest, there was significantly better blood pressure control in the intervention group compared to the control group. These findings suggest that changes in medication adherence, self-efficacy, or social support probably played a minor role Bl pressure results in these studies.

title: Effect of telecare management on pain and depression in cancer patients: a randomized study
abstract: Context Pain and depression are two of the most common and treatable symptoms of cancer, but they often go undiagnosed, undertreated, or both. Aim To determine whether centralized telephone care management coupled with automated symptom monitoring can improve depression and pain in cancer patients. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PATIENTS Randomized controlled trial conducted in 16 community-based urban and rural oncology practices participating in the Indiana Cancer Pain and Depression (INCPAD) study. Recruitment took place from March 2006 to August 2008 and the follow-up was completed in August 2009. Participating patients had depression (Patient Health Questionnaire 9, score 10), cancer-related pain (Brief Pain Inventory [BPI] worst pain score ¡Ã 6), or both. Intervention The 202 patients randomly assigned to intervention and 203 to usual care were stratified by symptom type. Patients in the intervention group received centralized telecare management by a specialist team of nurses and physicians coupled with automated symptom monitoring at home through interactive voice recording or the Internet. Main outcome measures Blinded assessment at baseline and after 1, 3, 6 and 12 months for depression (20-item Hopkins symptom checklist [HSCL-20]) and pain severity (BPI). Results Of the 405 study participants, 131 had depression only, 96 had pain only, and 178 had both depression and pain. Of the 274 pain patients, 137 patients in the intervention group showed greater improvements in BPI pain severity over the 12 months of the study, whether measured as a continuous severity score or as a categorical pain responder (30% decrease in BPI). than the 137 patients in the usual care group (p<0.001 for both). Similarly, of the 309 patients with depression, the 154 patients in the intervention group showed greater improvements in HSCL-20 depression severity scores over the 12 months of the study, whether measured as a continuous severity score or as a categorical depression responder (¡Ã 50% decrease in HSCL) than the 155 patients in the usual care group (p<0.001 for both). The standardized effect sizes for between-group differences at 3 and 12 months were 0.67 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.33-1.02) and 0.39 (95% CI, 0.01-0.77) for pain and 0.42 (95% CI, 0.16-0.69) and 0.41 (95% CI, 0.08-0.72) for depression. Conclusion Centralized telecare management coupled with automated symptom monitoring resulted in improved pain and depression outcomes in cancer patients treated at geographically distributed urban and rural oncology practices.

title: Effects of telemedicine on quality of life and psychological outcomes over 12 months (Whole Systems Demonstrator Telehealth Questionnaire Study): Nested study of patient-reported outcomes in a pragmatic, cluster-randomized, controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effect of second-generation home telemedicine on health-related quality of life, anxiety, and depressive symptoms over 12 months in patients with long-term illnesses. DESIGN A study of patient-reported outcomes (The Whole Systems Demonstrator Telehealth Questionnaire Study"; Baseline n=1573) was embedded in a pragmatic, cluster-randomized telemedicine study (The Whole Systems Demonstrator Telehealth Trial, n=3230). Unit of randomization and Telemedicine was compared to usual care Data were collected at baseline, four months (short-term), and 12 months (long-term) Primary intention-to-treat analyzes tested treatment efficacy Multilevel models controlled by primary care practice for clustering and a Series of covariate analyzes were performed for 759 participants who completed questionnaire measurements at all three time points (full case cohort) and 1201 who completed baseline assessment plus at least one additional assessment (available case cohort) treatment efficacy and included 633 and 1108 participants, respectively the vo Complete case or the available case cohorts provide primary and secondary care from general practices, specialist nurses and hospital clinics in three different regions of England (Cornwall, Kent and Newham) with established integrated health and social care systems. PARTICIPANTS Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes, or heart failure recruited between May 2008 and December 2009 using the EQ-5D), anxiety (assessed by the six-item Brief State-Trait Anxiety Inventory), and depressive symptoms (assessed by the Center for Epidemiological Studies depression scale with 10 points). RESULTS In intention-to-treat analyses, differences between treatment groups were small and non-significant for all endpoints in the overall case (0.480 × P × 0.904) or available case (0.181 × 0.904). ¢â€°¤P Ã¢â€°¤0.905) cohorts. The magnitude of the differences between the study arms did not reach the study-defined minimum clinically relevant difference (0.3 standardized mean difference) for any endpoint at either 4 or 12 months in either cohort. Per-protocol analyzes replicated the primary analyses; the main effect of the study arm (telemedicine vs. usual care) was not significant for any outcome (complete case cohort 0.273 × P × 0.761; available case cohort 0.145 ×). °Â¤ P Ã¢â€°Â¤ 0.696) CONCLUSIONS Second-generation home-based telemedicine, as implemented in the Whole Systems Demonstrator Evaluation, was neither effective nor effective compared to usual care. Telemedicine did not improve quality of life or psychological outcomes for patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diabetes or heart failure over 12 months. The results suggest that concerns about potentially harmful effects of telemedicine are unfounded for most patients.

title: Effect of telephone contact on further suicide attempts in patients discharged from an emergency department: randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the impact over one year of telephone contact with patients one month or three months after discharge from an emergency department for intentional self-poisoning compared to usual care. DESIGN Multicenter, randomized controlled trial. SETTING 13 Emergency departments in northern France. PARTICIPANTS 605 people discharged from an emergency room after attempting suicide by intentional self-poisoning. INTERVENTION The intervention consisted of contacting patients by telephone one month or three months after discharge from an emergency department for attempted suicide to assess the success of recommended treatment or to adjust treatment. The control patients were treated as usual, in most cases they were referred back to their general practitioner. KEY OUTCOME MEASUREMENTS The primary outcome measures were the proportion of participants who attempted suicide again, the number of deaths from suicide, and the losses at 13 months of follow-up. Secondary endpoints were type and number of contacts with health care. RESULTS Based on intention to treat, the three groups did not differ significantly in terms of further suicide attempts, deaths from suicide, or loss of follow-up: contact at one month (intervention 23% (34/147) vs. controls 30% (93/312), Difference 7%, 95% confidence interval -2% to 15%), three months (25% (36/146) vs. 30%, difference 5%, -4% to 14%). Participants who were contacted after one month were less likely to report having attempted suicide again at follow-up (12% vs. 22% in the control group, difference 10%, 2% vs. 18%). CONCLUSION Contacting individuals by telephone one month after discharge from an emergency room for intentional self-poisoning may help reduce the number of repeat suicide attempts over a year.

title: Effect of training on acceptance of nutrition-related cancer prevention activities by primary care practices: results from a randomized controlled trial
abstract: AIM: The National Cancer Institute (NCI) developed a handbook to guide primary care practices in structuring their office environment and routine visits to improve nutritional screening, counseling/referral, and follow-up for cancer prevention. Acceptance of the handbook's recommendations by primary care practices was assessed by examining two strategies: training physicians to implement the handbook's recommendations versus simply mailing the handbook. This article reports the results of a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of these two strategies. DESIGN: A three-arm, randomized, controlled trial. SETTING: Freestanding primary care practices in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. INTERVENTION: Each study practice was randomly assigned to one of three groups. The training group practices were invited to send a member from their practice of choice to a 3-hour “train-a-trainer” workshop, the purely manual group practices received the nutrition manual in the mail, and the control group practices received no intervention. Training was provided for training group practices in the four main components of the Nutrition Handbook: how to organize the office environment to support nutrition-related cancer prevention activities; how to verify patient compliance with NCI dietary guidelines; how to provide dietary advice/referral;" and how to implement a patient follow-up system to support patients to make changes in their diet-related behaviors. MEASUREMENTS: The primary outcomes of the study were derived from two assessment tools. The observational tool documented the tools and procedures recommended by the nutritional manual, which were adopted in patient records and in the practice environment.The face-to-face structured interview assessed the physician's and staff's self-reported nutritional-related activities that reflected the recommendations of the nutritional manual.Data from these two instruments were used to four to generate adherence scores corresponding to the domains: practice organization, nutritional screening, nutritional counseling/referral, and patient follow-up MAIN RESULTS: Adoption of the manual's recommendations was high among practices in the training group on highest, which is reflected in their higher adherence scores. They organized their practice (P = 0.005) and assessed their patients' eating habits (P = 0.046) significantly more closely to the recommendations of the nutrition manual than practices in the manual-only group. Despite the highest level of compliance, however, only 54.9% of the training group practices adhered to the recommendations of the nutritional counseling/referral manual and 28.5% to the recommendations for office organization, 23.5% to the recommendations for nutritional screening and 14, 6% adhered to recommendations for patient follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: GP practices exposed to the nutritional manual in a training session adopted more of the manual's recommendations. In particular, practices that were invited to training sessions were more likely to conduct nutritional screening and design their office environment to be conducive to nutritional services for cancer prevention. The effects of exercise were moderate and not statistically significant for dietary counseling/referral or patient follow-up, which are important to achieve long-term dietary changes in patients. The overall low scores for adherence to diet-related activities indicate that there is much room for improvement in practices in the training group.

title: Effect of varying the number and location of alcohol-based hand sanitizer dispensers on use in a general inpatient medical unit.
abstract: We incrementally increased the number of wall-mounted alcohol-based hand sanitizer dispensers in a small medical unit to assess the impact on hand hygiene performance. Above a certain point, adding more dispensers did not increase hand hygiene frequency, which appeared to be influenced more by location than total number of dispensers.

title: Effect of written and computer-based decision aids for the US Agency for Health Care Policy and Research's depression guidelines on the assessment of hypothetical clinical scenarios.
abstract: Goal. The aim of this study was to compare the effects of written and computer-aided decision aids (DSAs) based on the United States Health Policy and Research Agency's depression guidelines. methods. Fifty-six internists were randomized to assess clinical scenarios with either a written or a computerized DSA after the initial assessment of scenarios without a DSA. The paired difference between supported and unsupported outcomes was determined for diagnostic accuracy, treatment choice, severity and subtype classification, antipsychotic use, and mental health counseling DSA decreased from 67% to 64% (p=0.0065). Residents who used the computerized DSA (vs. no DSA) requested fewer consultations (65% vs. 52%, P=0.028). In the post hoc analysis, written DSA increased sensitivity (66% to 89%, p<0.001) and computerized DSA improved specificity (66% to 86%, p=0.0020) but decreased sensitivity ( 67% to 49%, p=0.011). Conclusions. Written DSA improved diagnostic accuracy, while computerized DSA did not. However, computerized DSA improved specificity and reduced mental health consultations.

title: Effect on birth outcomes of a formalized treatment approach in hospital labor assessment units: international, randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether complex nursing and midwifery intervention in hospital units to assess labor activity would increase the likelihood of spontaneous vaginal delivery and improve other maternal and neonatal outcomes. DESIGN Multicenter, randomized, controlled trial with prognostic stratification by hospital. SETTING 20 North American and UK Hospitals. PARTICIPANTS 5002 nulliparous women who were in labor but not in active labor; 2501 were allocated to structured care and 2501 to usual care following a formalized approach to assessment of and interventions for maternal emotional status, pain and fetal position.MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Primary outcome was spontaneous vaginal delivery Nursing and indicators of maternal and fetal health during hospitalization and 6-8 weeks after discharge RESULTS Outcome data were collected from 4996 women. The spontaneous vaginal birth rate was 64.0% (n=1597) in the structured care group and 61.3% (n=1533) in the usual care group (odds ratio 1.12, 95% confidence interval 0.96 to 1.27) Fewer women assigned to structured care (n=403, 19.5%) rated helpfulness of staff rated less than very helpful those assigned to usual care (n=544, 26.4 %); Odds ratio 0.67, 98.75% confidence interval 0.50 to 0.85. Fewer women assigned to structured care (n=233, 11.3%) were disappointed with staff attention than women assigned to usual care (n=407, 19.7%); Odds ratio 0.51, 98.75% confidence interval 0.32 to 0.70. None of the other results met the specified level of statistical significance. CONCLUSION A structured treatment approach in hospital departments to assess labor activity increased satisfaction with care and pointed to a slight increase in the likelihood of spontaneous vaginal delivery. Further study to strengthen the intervention is warranted.

title: Impact of payment to primary health care providers for performance on maternal and child health services in Rwanda: an impact assessment
abstract: Background Evidence of best practice is urgently needed to accelerate progress towards the Millennium Development Goals. We assessed the effect of payment for performance (P4P) for healthcare providers on the utilization and quality of child and maternal care services in healthcare settings in Rwanda.; Background evidence on the best practices for accelerating progress towards the Millennium Development Goals is Urgently needed We examined the effect of payment for performance (“P4P”) for health care providers on the utilization and quality of child and maternal care services in health facilities in Rwanda.

title: Effective weight management practice: a review of the evidence for lifestyle interventions
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Despite the existence of obesity management guidelines, uncertainty remains as to which interventions comprise effective practice. This uncertainty could pose an obstacle for busy health professionals who may lack the time and expertise to fully assess the vast body of literature published each year on obesity management. Therefore, the aim of this review was to summarize the available evidence, identify the most effective and promising adult obesity management practices using an established methodology, and present this information according to its quality. ACQUIRING EVIDENCE: This summary review was conducted as of January 2009. A detailed search of relevant databases was conducted up to September 2010. The most effective and promising practices were defined using the Canadian Best Practice Initiative methodology background paper with systematic reviews (with/without meta-analysis) as the most rigorous methodology for developing recommendations deemed most effective (Tier 1), and non-systematic reviews for the development of recommendations deemed most promising (Tier 2). The literature was reviewed and classified across these two levels of accuracy and supplemented with primary studies to further refine the recommendations. RESULTS: Evidence from systematic reviews and meta-analyses was grouped into three intervention themes, or contextual areas, into which more specific, most effective, and/or most promising practice recommendations could be embedded. These intervention topics were (1) targeted multicomponent weight control interventions, (2) diet manipulation strategies, and (3) delivery of weight control interventions, including the roles of health professionals and the method of delivery. Specific recommendations accompanied each topic. CONCLUSIONS: This review highlights the value of multi-component interventions that are delivered over time and strengthens the role of healthcare professionals. Findings will help inform evidence-based practice for healthcare professionals working in obesity management and prevention.

title: Efficacy and cost-effectiveness of cardiovascular disease prevention in whole populations: model study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the potential cost-effectiveness of a population-wide risk factor reduction program for cardiovascular disease prevention. DESIGN Economic model analysis. SETTING England and Wales. Population Total population. Model Spreadsheet model to quantify cardiovascular disease reduction over a decade, assuming benefits are consistent for males and females across age and risk groups. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Prevented cardiovascular events, gained quality-adjusted life-years, and saved healthcare costs for a given efficacy”; Estimates of how much it would be worth spending to get a specific outcome. RESULTS A program for the entire population of England and Wales (approximately 50 million people) that reduced cardiovascular events by just 1% would result in healthcare savings of at least £30m ($34m; $48m). $) per year compared to no additional intervention. A 5% reduction in the population's average level of cholesterol or blood pressure (as already achieved through similar measures in some other countries) would result in annual savings of at least £80-100m. Legislation or other action to reduce dietary salt intake by 3g/day (current average intake is around 8.5g/day) would prevent around 30,000 cardiovascular events, with savings of at least £40m per year. Legislation to reduce industrial trans fat intake by around 0.5% of total energy could increase life by around 570,000 years and save NHS at least £230m a year. CONCLUSIONS Any intervention that produces even a modest population-wide reduction in a major cardiovascular risk factor would result in a net cost saving to the NHS and an improvement in health. Given the conservative assumptions used in this model, the true benefit would likely be greater.

title: Efficacy and cost-effectiveness of an exposure-based return-to-work program for patients on sick leave due to common mental disorders: design of a cluster-randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: To reduce the duration of sick leave and lost productivity due to common mental disorders (CMDs), we developed a return to work program administered by occupational health practitioners (OPs) based on the principles of in vivo exposure (RTW-E program ). This study evaluates the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of this program by comparing it to care as usual (CAU). The three research questions we have are: 1) Is a RTW-E program more effective in reducing sick leave among employees with common mental disorders compared to usual care? 2) Is an RTW-E program more effective in reducing sick leave for employees with anxiety disorders compared to employees with other common mental disorders? 3) Is a RTW-E program cost-effective from a societal perspective compared to usual care? METHODS/DESIGN: This study was designed as a pragmatic cluster-randomized controlled trial with a one-year follow-up and randomization at the operating room level. We aimed for 60 surgeries to enroll 200 patients. Patients in the intervention group received the RTW-E program. Patients in the control group were treated as usual. Eligible patients were on sick leave for a minimum of two weeks and a maximum of eight weeks due to common mental disorders. As primary outcome measures, we calculated time to full return to work and sick leave duration. Secondary endpoints were time to partial return to work, sick leave prevalence rate at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months of follow-up, and multiple symptoms of stress, anxiety, depression, somatization, and exhaustion; ability to work ; perceived working conditions; self-efficacy for returning to work; coping behavior; avoidance behavior; patient satisfaction;" and work adjustments. As process measures, we used indices of adherence to the intervention in the intervention group and employee-supervisor communication in both groups. The economic costs were calculated from a societal perspective. The total costs consisted of the costs of utilization of healthcare services, costs of lost production due to absenteeism and reduced productivity, and patient travel expenses to their operating room DISCUSSION: Results will be published in 2009. Strengths and weaknesses of the study protocol are discussed TEST REGISTRATION: ISRCTN72643128.

title: Efficacy and cost-effectiveness of knowledge transfer and behavior change interventions in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus - the INDICA study: a randomized controlled cluster study
abstract: Background Type 2 diabetes mellitus is a chronic disease whose health outcomes depend on patient and healthcare professional decision making. The Canary Islands Diabetes Intervention Study (INDICA study) aims to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of educational interventions supported by new technological decision-making aids for type 2 diabetes patients and healthcare professionals in the Canary Islands. Methods/Design The INDICA study is an open-label, community-based, multi-center, clinically controlled, randomized cluster assignment to one of three interventions or usual care. The setting is primary care, in which physicians and nurses can participate. Patients with diabetes diagnosis, 18 ¨C65 years old and regular mobile phone users were randomly selected. Patients with severe comorbidities were excluded. The clusters are primary health care practices with enough professionals and available space to deliver the intervention. The calculated sample size was 2,300 patients. Patients in Group 1 receive an eight-session educational group program every 3 months, led by registered nurses and monitored using protocols and a web-based platform and customized semi-automated SMS for ongoing support. Primary care professionals in Group 2 receive a brief diabetes knowledge update program that includes a decision support tool embedded in the electronic health record and a monthly feedback report on patient outcomes. Group 3 receives a combination of patient and professional interventions. The primary endpoint is the change in HbA1c at 2 years. Secondary endpoints are cardiovascular risk factors, macrovascular and microvascular complications of diabetes, quality of life, psychological outcomes, diabetes awareness, and health care utilization. Data are collected from interviews, questionnaires, clinical examinations and records. Generalized linear mixed models with repeated time measurements are used to analyze changes in outcomes. The cost-effectiveness analysis includes the direct medical costs per quality-adjusted life year gained and two time periods, an intra-study period and a lifetime Markov model, from the health services perspective. Deterministic and probabilistic sensitivity analyzes are planned. Discussion This ongoing study aims to establish the implementation of evidence-based programs in the clinical setting for chronic patients.

title: Effectiveness and efficiency in competition: The Cochrane test
Effectiveness of a behavioral intervention in preventing excessive weight gain in infancy (The Baby Milk Trial): study protocol for a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Childhood is a time of rapid growth and habit formation and may therefore be a critical time for obesity prevention. Excessive weight gain in infancy is linked to later obesity, and formula-fed infants are more likely to gain obesity than breastfed infants. The primary study result is a change in weight standard deviation from birth to 1 year of age. METHODS/DESIGN: We recruited 650 to 700 parents introducing formula within 14 weeks of the birth of their baby for a single (evaluator) blind, individually randomized, controlled, parallel group study. The focus of the intervention is on the caregiver (usually the mother) and the focus of the primary outcome is on the infant. The intervention group receives the behavioral intervention aimed at reducing formula milk intake, promoting appropriate nutrition and healthy weaning, and preventing excessive weight gain in infancy. The intervention is based on social cognitive theory and action planning (“implementation intentions”). It has three components: (1) a motivational component to increase parent motivation to follow baby milk feeding guidelines, (2) an action planning component to help turn motivation into action, and (3) a coping planning component to help Helping parents deal with difficult situations. It is delivered by trained facilitators (research nurses) over 6 months through three face-to-face contacts, two phone contacts and written materials. The control group will have an equal number of contacts with facilitators, and general dietary issues will be discussed. Anthropometric outcomes will be measured by trained research personnel, blinded to group assignment, at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months according to standard operating procedures. Validated questionnaires assess milk intake, temperament, appetite, sleep, maternal quality of life, and maternal psychological factors. At 8 months, a 4-day food diary is kept. DISCUSSION: The results of the study will help inform infant feeding guidelines and understand the links between infant feeding, behavior, appetite and growth. TEST REGISTRATION: ISRTCN20814693 . Registration date January 13, 2011.

title: Efficacy of a combined strategy to improve therapeutic compliance and level of control in patients with hypercholesterolemia: a randomized clinical trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cholesterol levels remain above guideline values in individuals with hypercholesterolemia. One of the limiting factors in achieving goals in such patients is non-compliance with therapy. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of an intervention to improve the control of patients with hypercholesterolemia, consisting of a combined strategy that includes the delivery of printed information, control charts for treatment adherence, and the sending of text messages as complementary measures of support of intervention in the general practice. METHODS/DESIGN: A randomized, parallel group clinical trial will be conducted in the outpatient family medicine facilities of eight health centers in three of Spain's Autonomous Regions (Comunidades Autonomas) and will include a total of 358 subjects aged 18 and over with a diagnosis of hypercholesterolemia. Patients in the intervention group are provided with printed materials with information about the disease and its management, cell phone text messages with guideline summaries, reminders of upcoming appointments and/or rescheduling for no-shows, and self-report cards to check adherence to recommendations. Both groups – intervention and control – receive routine referrals from their physicians according to current European clinical practice guidelines for hypercholesterolemia and cardiovascular risk management. In terms of the measurements to be taken, the key variable is the proportion of subjects achieving target low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol levels over a 24-month follow-up period. The secondary variables are as follows: "Adherence to lifestyle recommendations and adherence to drug treatment", variation in lipid profiles and cardiovascular risk levels, occurrence of cardiovascular events, physical activity, food intake, smoking habits, anthropometric measurements, blood pressure, health problems ; use of hypolipidemic agents; socio-demographic data; beliefs and expectations regarding preventive recommendations;" and level of satisfaction with the combined strategy. DISCUSSION: If this intervention proves effective, a recommendation could be made to use this combined strategy in patients with hypercholesterolaemia. It's a simple, relatively inexpensive procedure. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT02314663.

title: Effectiveness of a transfusion monitoring system for self-assessment by a prospective physician.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The purpose of this study was to search for a more effective transfusion surveillance system than the existing system of retrospective peer review. STUDY DESIGN AND METHODS: This study used a study control, preintervention, and postintervention design to evaluate the effectiveness of a physician self-monitoring transfusion monitoring system that operated without the direct involvement of transfusion service physicians. This study also evaluated the effectiveness of issuing a transfusion guideline memo to physicians. Three process indicators were used to assess the physician's behavior at various stages of the blood ordering process: 1) the number of crossmatches ordered per intake, 2) the transfusion-to-crossmatch ratio, and 3) the number of blood units returned to the blood center laboratory after physician self control. The study used two outcome indicators to reflect total blood utilization: 1) the percentage of patients who received RBC transfusions and 2) the number of blood units transfused monthly per recipient. RESULTS: The prospective physician self-monitoring system implemented at the study hospital did not reverse physicians' transfusion decisions, and the process of issuing a memo containing transfusion guidelines to physicians at the control hospital failed to reduce blood consumption. However, a transient reduction in blood utilization was observed at the study hospital. CONCLUSION: The reduction was hypothesized to be due to a Hawthorne effect, in which the observed behavior is influenced by the subject's awareness of the research study.

title: Efficacy of scientific detailing to optimize primary care physicians' drug prescribing behavior
abstract: PURPOSE: To synthesize current knowledge on the effectiveness and magnitude of impact of Academic Detailing (AD) as a standalone intervention to change prescribing behaviors of primary care physicians (FPs). METHODS: Between January 1983 and July 2010, a search of all English-language articles was performed in the MEDLINE, EMBASE, CENTRAL, and Web of Science databases. We hand-searched the bibliographies of articles retrieved from electronic search to identify additional studies. Inclusion criteria were: full-length articles describing the original research; randomized controlled trial (RCT) or observational study design with a control group; AD studies delivered to FPs; AD as a standalone intervention; Drug Prescribing as Target Behavior. Data extraction was performed independently by two reviewers. Outcomes evaluated were: the difference in relative change in prescription rate between the intervention and control groups, the difference in absolute change in prescription rate between the intervention and control groups, and effect size calculated as the standardized mean difference. RESULTS: 11 RCTs and 4 observational studies were included Five RCTS described results demonstrating efficacy while 2 RCTs reported a beneficial effect on some of the target drugs Two observational studies found that AD was effective while 2 did not The median difference in relative change between of the studies reviewed was 21% (interquartile range 43.75%) for RCTs and 9% (interquartile range 8.5%) for observational studies. The median effect size among the studies reviewed was -0.09 (interquartile range 2.73). systematic review shows that AD in O optimizing drug prescribing by FPs can be effective. Although variable, the magnitude of the effect is moderate in most studies. This systematic review also provides evidence supporting the use of AD as a strategy to promote evidence-based drug prescribing or the incorporation of clinical guidelines into clinical practice. This article is open to POST-PUBLICATION REVIEW. Registered readers (see "For readers") can comment by clicking ABSTRACT on the content page of the issue.

title: Effectiveness of an acoustic reminder of hand hygiene compliance
abstract: Multimodal interventions aim to improve compliance of healthcare workers with hand hygiene guidelines. Visitors are not primarily targeted, but can spread epidemic infections. Effective measures are needed to improve visitor compliance with hand hygiene guidelines to prevent transmission of epidemic infections into or out of healthcare facilities. Methods An acoustic hand hygiene reminder triggered by an electronic motion sensor was installed at the entrances to the hospital wards. An 8-month preinterventional and postinterventional study was conducted to measure compliance of hospital visitors and staff with hand hygiene guidelines. Results General hand hygiene adherence increased from 7.6% to 49.9% (p<0.001). Visitor and nonclinical staff adherence increased immediately from 10.6% to 63.7% and from 5.3% to 34.8%, respectively (P<0.001). Adherence from physicians, nurses, and physical therapists increased gradually from 4.5% to 38.3%, from 5.4% to 43.4%, and from 8.7% to 49.5%, respectively (p<0.001). Improved adherence to therapy was maintained in visitors and clinical staff (P<0.001), but not in nonclinical staff (P=0.341). Conclusions The electronic motion sensor immediately triggered an audible reminder and improved and sustained compliance with hand hygiene guidelines by hospital visitors and clinicians. This is an effective complement to multimodal hand hygiene measures and can help control epidemic infections.

title: Effectiveness of a clinical quality alert for electronic medical records generated by offline data analysis
Efficacy of an information technology intervention to improve prophylactic antibacterial use in the postoperative period.
abstract: Background A 2005 report by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services and the Centers for Disease Control Surgical Infection Prevention Program showed that only 41% of prophylactic antibiotics were correctly discontinued within 24 hours of the end of surgery. Electronic prescription records have shown promise as a means of integrating guideline information into electronic prescription entry systems and facilitating safer and more effective care. Aim The aim was to investigate the effectiveness of a computerized antibacterial prescription kit in order to increase the proportion of patients in whom antibacterial wound prophylaxis was discontinued in a reasonable time. Design The authors performed a quasi-experimental interrupted time-series analysis over an 8-month study period with the implementation of a computerized ordering system designed to prevent excessive duration of surgical antibiotic prophylaxis. Measurement The primary outcome was the proportion of surgeries using antibiotics that were terminated within a reasonable time frame. Additionally, we assessed the percentage of surgeries following the implementation of electronic intervention with chart documentation of infections among surgeries where the prescriber indicated treatment as a reason for antibacterial therapy. Results The computer-assisted prescription intervention significantly improved the proportion of surgeries with timely withdrawal of antibiotics from 38.8% to 55.7% (p<0.001) at the intervention hospital, while the control hospital remained at 56–57% (p=0.006 for the difference between treated and control hospitals). In post-intervention surgeries where a prescriber indicated treatment as the reason for antibacterial therapy, the prevalence of the infection documented in the table was only 14%. Conclusions A computer-based electronic prescription intervention increased the timely discontinuation of postoperative antibiotics.

title: Efficacy of an intervention to improve adherence to the occupational physician guideline on the length of sick leave among employees with frequent mental disorders: A cluster-randomized controlled study
abstract: Purpose Evidence-based guidelines in occupational health care improve the quality of care and can shorten the duration of illness. Despite this, compliance by occupational physicians (ORs) with guidelines is limited. Based on the literature on guideline implementation, an intervention was developed that has been shown to effectively improve self-reported adherence to OPs. The aim of the present study was to assess whether this intervention leads to an earlier return to work (RTW) in workers with common mental disorders (CMD). Methods In a two-arm randomized controlled cluster study, 66 OPs were randomized. The study included 3379 workers, 1493 in the intervention group and 1886 in the control group. Outcome measures were: time to complete RTW, time to first RTW, and total hours of sick leave. Cox regression analyzes and generalized linear mixed model analyzes were used for the evaluations. Results The median time to RTW was 154 days for the 3228 workers with TMD. There were no significant differences in (time to) complete RTW between intervention and control groups HR 0.96 (95% CI 0.81-1.15) or for the first RTW HR 0.96 (95% CI 0, 80-1:15) on. The average duration of sick leave was 478 hours in the intervention group and 483 hours in the control group. Conclusions The intervention to improve ORs' compliance with guidelines did not result in earlier RTW for workers with TMD managed by the ORs. Possible explanations are the remaining external barriers to guideline use and that perceived guideline compliance may not represent actual guideline compliance and improved care. Registration of the attempt: ISRCTN86605310.

title: Effectiveness of brief training sessions in cognitive-behavioral therapy techniques for palliative care professionals
abstract: We describe training in CBT techniques for 20 palliative care workers delivered over a six-month period as 12 days of equivalent instruction plus skill-building supervision. Tapes of the trainees' interactions with patients during their usual work were graded using a specially developed Cognitive First Aid Rating Scale (CFARS). The CFARS was of high internal consistency (Cronbach's alpha 0.93) and the interrater reliability was high. The trainees showed a significant increase in CBT competence over a period of six months (p = 0.001). After initial training, half of trainees were randomized to drop out of supervision";" Their measured CBT skills dropped, as did their self-reported confidence, when they were reassessed six months later, while those who continued to have supervision gained more skills and maintained their confidence (p=0.007). Palliative care professionals can be trained in CBT skills through a simple and short training course and supportive, skill-building supervision. These skills are consistent with national guidelines for providing psychological support to patients at all stages of cancer. Supervision is necessary to ensure the maintenance of skills and confidence in their use.

title: Efficacy of cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine for the treatment of dementia: review of evidence for a guideline for clinical practice
abstract: Background: The effectiveness of US Food and Drug Administration-approved pharmacological therapies for dementia in achieving clinically relevant improvements is unclear. Purpose: To review the evidence for the efficacy of cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine, and tacrine) and the neuropeptide-modifying drug memantine in achieving clinically relevant improvements, primarily related to cognition, global function, behavior, and quality of life, e.g. in patients with dementia. Data sources: Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, MEDLINE, PREMEDLINE, EMBASE, Allied and Complementary Medicine Database, CINAHL, AgeLine and PsycINFO from January 1986 to November 2006. Study selection: English-language randomized controlled trials were included in the review if they used pharmacological agents for Evaluated adults diagnosed with dementia, did not use a crossover design, and had a quality score of at least 3 on the Jadad scale. Data extraction: Data on study characteristics and outcomes, including adverse events, were extracted. Effect sizes were calculated and the data combined where appropriate. Data synthesis: 96 publications representing 59 unique studies were eligible for this review. Both cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine had consistent effects on cognition and global assessment, but summary estimates showed small effect sizes. Outcomes in the areas of behavior and quality of life were evaluated less frequently and showed less consistent effects. Most studies were of short duration (6 months), which limited their ability to detect delays in the onset or progression of dementia. Three studies directly compared different cholinesterase inhibitors and found no differences in cognition and behavior. Limitations: Limitations of the available studies included short duration, enrollment of only patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease, poor reporting of adverse events, lack of clear definitions of statistical significance, limited assessment of behavior and quality of life, and the limited direct comparison of different treatments. Conclusions: Treatment of dementia with cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine can lead to a statistically significant but clinically marginal improvement in cognitive and global assessment of dementia.

title: Effectiveness of cooperative care for older adults with Alzheimer's disease in primary care: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: CONTEXT: Most older adults with dementia are cared for by primary care physicians, but the primary care environment presents significant challenges to the delivery of quality care. AIM: To test the effectiveness of a collaborative care model for improving the quality of care for patients with Alzheimer's disease. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PATIENTS: Controlled clinical trial of 153 older adults with Alzheimer's disease and their caregivers randomized by a physician to receive collaborative care management (n=84) or expanded usual care (n=69) in primary care practices within 2 Years to obtain US university health care systems from January 2002 to August 2004. Eligible patients (identified by screening or medical records) met diagnostic criteria for Alzheimer's disease and had a self-identified caregiver. INTERVENTION: Intervention patients received 1 year of care management by an interdisciplinary team led by an experienced nurse working with the patient's family caregiver and integrated into primary care. The team used standard protocols to initiate treatment and to identify, monitor and treat behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia, with an emphasis on non-pharmacological treatment. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) administered at baseline and at 6, 12 and 18 months. Secondary endpoints included the Cornell Scale of Depression in Dementia (CSDD), cognition, activities of daily living, resource use, and caregiver depression severity. RESULTS: Initiated by reports from caregivers, 89% of intervention patients triggered at least 1 protocol for behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia, with a mean of 4 per patient out of a total of 8 possible protocols. Intervention patients were more likely to receive cholinesterase inhibitors (79.8% vs. 55.1%; p=0.002) and antidepressants (45.2% vs. 27.5%; p=0.03). by total NPI score at 12 months (mean difference -5.6; p=0.01) and at 18 months (mean difference -5.4; p=0.01) Intervention caregivers also reported significant improvements in burden that NPI was measured by caregiver at 12 months;" at 18 months, caregivers showed improvement in depression as measured by the Patient Health Questionnaire-9. There were no group differences in CSDD, cognition, activities of daily living, or hospitalizations, placement in nursing homes or deaths.CONCLUSIONS:Collaborative care for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease resulted in significant improvements in the quality of care and behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia in primary care patients and their caregivers.These improvements were achieved without the use of Significantly increase antipsychotics or sedative-hypnotics UNG: clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT00246896.

title: Effectiveness of computer-based instruction in increasing rates of universal behaviors related to precaution.
abstract: Background: Given the widespread non-compliance with universal precautions, an experimental study was designed to compare rates of universal precautions-related behaviors among nurses participating in computer-based instruction. This study also examined the relationship between rates of universal behaviors related to precautionary measures and subjects' demographic and experiential characteristics and history of occupational exposure to blood. METHODS: Data were collected using a questionnaire to collect information about the subjects' demographic and experiential characteristics and history of occupational exposure to blood. The Universal Precautions Assessment Tool was used to collect data on the rates of universal precautions-related behaviors in two groups of registered nurses with 30 subjects per group. Results: The null hypothesis was rejected by analysis of variance. The intervention used in this study increased behaviors related to taking universal precautions. Multiple regression was used to analyze the research question and none of the variables were significant. Forty (67.8%) subjects reported having suffered a needlestick or cut from a needle or sharp object that was actually or potentially contaminated with blood or bodily fluids. From these exposures, one patient was known to be HIV antibody positive. Conclusion: Replication studies of computer-based instructional interventions are needed, as are studies exploring other potentially effective interventions.

title: Effectiveness of management of diabetes and hypertension by rural primary health care workers (Behvarz workers) in Iran: a nationally representative observational study
abstract: Background NCDs and their risk factors are the main contributors to the burden of disease in Iran and other middle-income countries. There is little evidence that the primary health care system is effective in managing noncommunicable diseases and risk factors at the population level. Our aim was to investigate the effectiveness of Iran's rural primary health care system (the Behvarz system) in treating diabetes and hypertension, and to assess whether the impact depends on the number of health workers in the community."; " BackgroundNoncommunicable diseases and their risk factors are the major contributors to the burden of disease in Iran and other middle-income countries. There is little evidence that the primary health care system is effective in managing noncommunicable diseases and risk factors at the population level. Our aim was to investigate the effectiveness of Iran's rural primary health care system (the Behvarz system) in treating diabetes and hypertension and to assess whether the impact depends on the number of health workers in the community.

title: Effectiveness of eye protection in the metalworking industry
Efficacy of guideline-based occupational health care when returning to work for workers with common mental disorders: design of a cluster-randomized controlled study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Absence from sickness due to common mental disorders (e.g. depression, anxiety disorder, adjustment disorder) is a problem in many Western countries. Long-term sick leave has significant societal and financial costs. For workers with frequent mental disorders, the cost of illness is much higher than the medical cost. In the Netherlands, a best practice guide has been developed that promotes an activating approach by the occupational health practitioner to achieve a faster return to work by improving workers' problem-solving skills, particularly in relation to their work environment. Studies on this guideline indicate a promising association between guideline adherence and reduced sick leave duration, but also minimal guideline adherence by occupational physicians. Therefore, this study evaluates the effect of guideline-based care on full return to work for workers on sick leave for common mental disorders. Methods/design: This is a two-arm cluster-randomized controlled study with randomization at company doctor level. For one year, occupational physicians in the intervention group receive innovative training to improve their guideline-based care, while occupational physicians in the control group provide care as usual. A total of 232 employees who were on sick leave due to frequent mental disorders and who received advice from participating company doctors are included. The data is collected via the reporting system of the occupational health service and through questionnaires at the beginning of the study and after 3, 6 and 12 months. The primary outcome is time to full return to work. Secondary outcomes are partial return to work, total number of sick days, symptoms and ability to work. Personal and professional characteristics are the prognostic measures. Other parameters are coping, self-efficacy, remoralization, personal experiences, satisfaction with occupational health consultations and with contact with the supervisor, experiences and behavior of the supervisor, and extent of adherence to guidelines. DISCUSSION: If the results show that guideline-based care actually leads to faster and sustainable return to work, this study will help reduce personal, societal, and financial costs. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN86605310.

title: Efficacy of medical nutrition therapy administered by dietitians in the management of non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus: a randomized controlled clinical trial.
abstract: Aim To evaluate the effect of medical nutritional therapy (MNT) administered by dietitians on medical and clinical outcomes in adults with non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM) and to compare MNT administered according to the practice dietary guidelines (PGC). . to MNT administered with Basal Nutrition (BC). Design A prospective, randomized, controlled clinical trial using two levels of MNT for metabolic control in individuals newly diagnosed with or currently being treated for NIDDM was conducted at diabetes centers in three states (Minnesota, Florida and Colorado). BC consisted of a single visit to a nutritionist; PGC included an initial visit to a dietician, followed by two visits during the first 6 weeks of the study period. Data were collected at study entry and at 3 and 6 months. Subject results are reported for 179 men and women aged 38 to 76 years: 85 were randomly assigned to BC and 94 to PGC. This represents 72% of the 247 enrolled subjects. An additional 62 adults with NIDDM at one site who had no contact with a dietician were impacted as a non-random comparison group identified. Outcomes Medical outcome measures included fasting plasma glucose (FPG), glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) and serum lipid levels. Clinical outcomes included weight, body mass index, hip-to-hip ratio, and medical changes Therapy Statistical Analyzes The initial analysis of the discrete variables was performed using the ?2 statistic with Yates correction The initial Analysis of continuous variables was performed by analysis of variance. Changes in variables between periods w They were analyzed by paired t-test and comparisons between groups were analyzed using at-test for independent groups. Results At 6 months, PGC resulted in significant improvements in glycemic control as indicated by FPG and HbA1c levels, and BC resulted in significant improvements in HbA1c levels. Participants assigned to the PGC group had a mean FPG score at 6 months that was 10.5% lower than the score at entry, and those in the BC group had a 5.3% lower score. Among patients who had diabetes for more than 6 months, those who received PGC had significantly better HbA1c at 3 months than those who received BC. The comparison group showed no improvement in glycemic control over a comparable 6 months. PGC subjects showed significant improvements in cholesterol levels at 6 months, and subjects in both the PGC and BC groups had significant weight loss. Conclusions MNT provided by dieticians resulted in significant improvements in medical and clinical outcomes in both the BC and PGC groups and is beneficial for individuals with NIDDM. People with diabetes longer than 6 months tended to do better with PGC than with BC. Because of the upward trend in glucose levels at 3 months, continuous MNT by nutritionists is important for long-term metabolic control. J Am Diet Assoc. 1995;" 95:1009-1017.

title: Effectiveness of motivational interviewing in improving lipid levels in patients with dyslipidemia supported by general practitioners: Dislip-EM study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: The non-pharmacological approach to cholesterol control in patients with hyperlipidemia is based on the promotion of a healthy diet and physical activity. Therefore, in order to help patients change their habits, it is important to find the most effective approach. Many efforts have been made to explain changes in, or adherence to, certain health behaviors. These efforts have led to the development of theories that have been applied in prevention campaigns, involving brief counseling and counseling services. In this context, motivational interviewing has been shown to be effective in changing health behaviors in specific cases. However, more robust evidence is needed on the effectiveness of motivational interviewing in treating chronic pathologies - such as dyslipidemia - in patients cared for by general practitioners. This article describes a protocol to evaluate the effectiveness of MI versus general practice (brief consultation) with the aim of improving lipid level control in patients with dyslipidemia by a general practitioner. METHODS/DESIGN: An open-label, two-arm, parallel, multi-center, cluster, controlled, randomized, clinical study will be conducted. A total of 48-50 general practitioners from 35 public primary care centers in Spain will be randomized and recruit 436 patients with dyslipidemia. They conduct an intervention based on motivational interviewing or the usual brief counselling. After an initial assessment, follow-up visits are performed at 2, 4, 8, and 12 months. Primary endpoints are lipid levels (total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides) and cardiovascular risk. The study will assess the degree of improvement in diet and physical activity, weight loss in obese patients and adherence to treatment guidelines. DISCUSSION: Motivational interviewing skills are the primary strategies primary care physicians use to treat their patients. Economical, simple, effective and applicable techniques are essential for healthcare professionals to help their patients make lifestyle changes and improve their health.
