This study will provide scientific evidence of the effectiveness of motivational interviewing and will be conducted under strict control of the data collected to ensure therapeutic integrity is maintained. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01282190).

title: Effectiveness of motivational interviewing in patients with dyslipidemia: a randomized cluster study
abstract: BACKGROUND: It is well known that getting people to change their habits is difficult. Identifying the most effective approach that General Practitioners (GPs) should use to help their patients change unhealthy habits is crucial. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a multifactorial intervention based on motivational interviewing conducted by general practitioners to increase lipid levels in patients with dyslipidemia compared to standard of care. METHODS: A multicenter, controlled, randomized, two-armed, cluster study with a 12-month follow-up conducted in 25 community health centers in Spain. 38 general practitioners and 227 primary care patients with uncontrolled dyslipidemia were included in the study. GPs delivered an intervention based on either motivational interviewing (MI) or standard practice. Lipid levels were measured and the level of control was analyzed based on clinical guideline criteria. RESULTS: 107 were assigned to the experimental group (EG) and 120 to the control group (CG). Overall, there was an improvement in total cholesterol (mean difference -MD- = -19.60"; 95% CI: -15.33 at -23.87 mg/dL; p<0.001), LDL-cholesterol (MD = - 13.78; 95% CI: -9.77 at -17.79 mg/dL; p<0.001) and triglycerides (MD = -19.14; 95% CI: -11.29 at -26.99 mg/dL; dl; p<0.001) No differences were found between the two groups, however, when we assessed the level of lipid control by combining the parameters cholesterol <200 mg/dl and LDL-cholesterol <130 mg/dl, it was observed that a higher percentage of patients achieving target EG compared to CG (13.1% vs 5.0%, adjusted OR = 5.77, 95% CI: 1.67-19.91) CONCLUSION: A motivational interview-based approach , carried out by general practitioners and addressed to patients with dyslipidemia, achieved a significant reduction in all lipid parameters, cardiovascular risk and weight reduction and compliance with the Mediterranean rdiet, similar to the usual intervention and superior in the proportion of pa patients achieving combined lipid control goals and physical activity level. STUDY REGISTRATION: The study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01282190;" January 21, 2011).

title: Efficacy of multicomponent interventions in primary health care to promote continuous smoking cessation in adults: a systematic review
abstract: AIM: The aim of the present review is to evaluate primary care (PC) interventions with multiple components/complexes for their effectiveness in continuing smoking cessation in adult smokers. DESIGN: A systematic review of randomized and non-randomized controlled trials was conducted. ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA FOR INCLUDED STUDIES: Selected studies met the following criteria: assessed effects of a multicomponent/complex intervention (with 2 or more intervention components) in achieving at least 6 months abstinence in adult smokers who sought PC, biochemical confirmation of abstinence, intention -to-treat analysis and results published in English/Spanish. METHODS: We followed the PRISMA directive to report the review. We searched the following data sources: MEDLINE, Web of Science, Scopus (from inception to February 2014), 3 major journals and a tobacco research bulletin. The checklists of the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network were used to assess the methodological quality. Data selection, analysis, and extraction were performed independently using a paired review approach. Due to the heterogeneity of the interventions in the included studies, no meta-analysis was carried out. RESULTS: From 1147 identified references, 9 studies were selected (10,204 participants, up to 48 months follow-up, acceptable methodological quality). The methods used were mainly individual or group sessions, phone calls, smoking cessation brochures or kits, medication and economic incentives for doctors, and free medication for smokers. Complex interventions achieved long-term continuous abstinence between 7% and 40%. Behavioral interventions were effective and had a dose-response effect. Both nicotine replacement and bupropion therapy were safe and effective, with no observed differences. CONCLUSIONS: Multicomponent/complex interventions for PC are effective and safe, and appear to achieve longer-term sustained smoking cessation than usual care and counseling alone. Selected studies were heterogeneous and some had significant follow-up losses. Our results indicate that smoking interventions should include more than one component and intensive patient follow-up to maximize outcomes.

title: Efficacy of nursing interventions in people with personality disorders
abstract: BACKGROUND: Nurses typically provide day-to-day care for people with personality disorders. Consequently, it is important to determine how effective nursing interventions are for people with personality disorders, both in terms of general management and more specific therapeutic approaches. These are also topics of the current political and professional debate. However, the crucial question for planners, providers and clients of services is: What research evidence is there for effectiveness? It also needs to be determined what further research is needed to evaluate programs to control or change behavior. OBJECTIVE: The objective of this paper is to report a systematic literature review on the effectiveness of nursing interventions in people with personality disorders, whether performed by nurses alone or in combination with other health professionals. METHOD: The review was conducted according to the guidelines of the United Kingdom National Health Service Center for Reviews and Dissemination. Literature was identified by searching electronic databases, searching footnotes, hand-searching journals, and contacting study authors. Narrative synthesis was performed in relation to study design, participants, and type of intervention. RESULTS: Eighteen separate studies were included in the review: four randomized controlled studies, four non-randomized controlled studies, seven before-and-after studies, and three case studies. CONCLUSIONS: There is a weak evidence base for what constitutes an effective nursing intervention in people with personality disorders. There is stronger evidence from interdisciplinary intervention studies than from nursing-only intervention studies. Studies of interventions based on psychological approaches show greater improvements in outcomes than studies of nursing management.

title: Effectiveness of pharmacist care for patients with reactive airway disease: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Context It is not known whether effective pharmacist-patient interactions improve patient outcomes. Objective To assess the effectiveness of a pharmaceutical care program for patients with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Randomized controlled trial conducted at 36 community drug stores in Indianapolis, Indiana. We enrolled 1113 participants with active COPD or asthma from July 1998 to December 1999. Results were evaluated in 947 (85.1%) participants at 6 months and 898 (80.7%) at 12 months. Interventions The pharmaceutical care program (n=447) provided pharmacists with up-to-date patient-specific clinical data (peak expiratory flow rates [PEFRs], emergency department [ED] visits, hospitalizations, and medication compliance), training, customized patient education materials, and resources to facilitate program delivery. The PEFR monitoring control group (n=363) received a peak flow meter, instructions on how to use it, and monthly calls to determine PEFRs. However, no PEFR data was provided to the pharmacist. Patients in the normal care group (n = 303) received neither peak flow meters nor instructions on how to use them; no PEFR rates were collected from monthly telephone interviews. Pharmacists in both control groups received training but did not receive drug components Treatment intervention Key outcome measures Peak expiratory flow rates, respiratory-related emergency department visits or hospital visits, health-related quality of life (HRQOL), medication compliance, and patient satisfaction Outcomes At 12 months, patients receiving pharmaceutical care had significantly higher peak flow rates Rates than the usual care group (p=0.02) but not as PEFR monitoring controls (p=0.28) There were no significant differences between the groups in terms of medication compliance or HRQOL in asthmatic patients receiving a pharmaceutical Those receiving treatment had significantly more breathing problems at emergency room or hospital visits than the usual care group (odds ratio 2.16; 95% confidence interval 1.76-2.63; P<0.001). Patients receiving pharmaceutical care were more satisfied with their pharmacist than the usual care group (P=0.03) and the PEFR monitoring group (P=0.001), and were more satisfied with their health care than the usual care group after only 6 months (P=0.01). Despite numerous ways to implement the program, pharmacists only accessed patient-specific data about half the time and documented actions about half the time records were accessed. Conclusions This pharmaceutical care program increased patients' PEFRs compared to usual care, but provided little benefit compared to peak flow monitoring alone. Pharmaceutical care increased patient satisfaction, but also increased the amount of demand for respiratory-related medical care.

title: Efficacy of physical therapy for patients with neck pain: an individualized approach using a clinical decision-making algorithm
abstract: AIM: The purpose of this study was to determine the effectiveness of an individualized physical therapy intervention in the management of neck pain based on a clinical reasoning algorithm. Treatment effectiveness was evaluated by assessing changes in impairment, physical capacity, and disability in response to the intervention. Design: A treatment group of 30 patients with neck pain completed a physiotherapy session. The comfort control group was formed from a cohort group of 27 subjects who also had neck pain but did not receive treatment for various reasons. There were no significant differences between the groups in the demographics and the initial test scores of the outcome measures. A quasi-experimental non-equivalent pretest-posttest control group design was used. A physical therapist provided the treatment group with an eclectic intervention based on a clinical decision-making algorithm. Treatment outcome measures included the following five dependent variables: cervical range of motion, numerical pain score, time-weighted overhead endurance, the supine capital flexion endurance test, and the patient-specific functional scale. Both the treatment and control groups completed the initial and follow-up visits, with an average duration of 4 weeks between tests. Results: Five mixed analyzes of variance with follow-up tests showed a significant difference for all outcome measures in the treatment group compared to the control group. After an average of 4 weeks of physiotherapy intervention, patients in the treatment group showed a statistically significant increase in cervical range of motion, a decrease in pain, an increase in physical capacity, and a decrease in the degree of disability. The control group showed no differences in all five outcome variables between the initial and follow-up test results. Conclusions: This study outlined algorithm-based clinical reasoning strategies for the assessment and management of patients with cervical pain. The algorithm can help physicians classify patients with cervical pain into clinical patterns and provides pattern-specific guidelines for physical therapy interventions. An organized and specific physical therapy program was effective in improving the condition of patients with neck pain.

title: Efficacy of physical therapy exercises after total knee arthroplasty for osteoarthritis: systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effectiveness of physical therapy exercises after elective primary total knee arthroplasty in patients with osteoarthritis. DESIGN Systematic review. DATA SOURCES Database searches: AMED, CINAHL, Embase, King's Fund, Medline, Cochrane Library (Cochrane Reviews, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, DARE), PEDro, Department of Health National Research Register. Hand searches: Physiotherapy, Physical Therapy, Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery (Britain) Conference Proceedings. Review methods Randomized controlled trials were reviewed if they included a physical therapy exercise intervention versus usual or standard physical therapy care or compared two types of physical therapy exercise interventions that met review criteria after discharge from hospital after elective primary knee arthroplasty for osteoarthritis. OUTCOME MEASURES Functional activities of daily living, walking, quality of life, muscle strength, and knee range of motion. The quality of the study was comprehensively evaluated. Narrative synthesis plus meta-analyses using fixed-effects models, weighted mean differences, standardized effect sizes, and heterogeneity tests. RESULTS Six studies were identified, five of which were eligible for inclusion in meta-analyses. There was a small to moderate standardized effect size (0.33, 95% confidence interval 0.07 to 0.58) in favor of functional exercise for function three to four months postoperatively. There were also small to moderate weighted mean differences of 2.9 (0.61 to 5.2) for joint range of motion and 1.66 (-1 to 4.3) for quality of life in favor of functional exercise three to four months postoperatively . After a year, the benefits of the treatment were no longer apparent. CONCLUSIONS Interventions including post-discharge physiotherapy functional exercises result in short-term benefits after elective primary knee arthroplasty. Effect sizes are small to moderate with no long-term benefit.

title: Effectiveness of provider incentives for anemia reduction in rural China: a randomized cluster study
abstract: OBJECTIVES To test the impact of provider payment for anemia reduction in rural China. DESIGN A cluster-randomized study of information, subsidies, and incentives for school leaders to reduce anemia in their students. Enumerators and study participants were not informed of study arm assignment. SETTING 72 randomly selected rural primary schools in Northwest China. PARTICIPANTS 3553 fourth and fifth grade students aged 9-11 years. All fourth and fifth graders in sample schools participated in the study. INTERVENTIONS Sample schools were randomly assigned to a no-intervention control group or to one of three treatment arms: (a) an information arm in which school principals received information about anemia; (b) a grant arm, in which principals received information and unconditional subsidies;" and (c) an incentive arm, in which principals received information, subsidies, and financial incentives to reduce anemia in students. Twenty-seven schools were assigned to the control arm (1816 students at baseline , 1623 at endpoint), 15 assigned to the information arm (659 students at baseline, 596 at endpoint), and 15 assigned to the subsidy arm (726 students at baseline, 667 at endpoint), and 15 assigned to the incentive arm (743 students at baseline, 667 am MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Student hemoglobin concentrations RESULTS Student mean hemoglobin concentration increased by 1.5 g/L (95% CI -1.1 to 4.1) in information schools, by 0.8 g/L (-1, 8 to 3.3) in subsidy schools and by 2.4 g/L (0 to 4.9) in incentive schools compared to the control group.This hemoglobin increase corresponded to a reduction in the prevalence of anemia (H b < 115 g/l) by 24% in special needs schools. Interactions with pre-existing incentives for school leaders to do well at school resulted in significantly larger gains in the information and incentive arms: when combined with incentives to do well at school, the associated impact on student hemoglobin concentration was 9.8 g/L (4.1 to 15.5). greater in information schools and 8.6 g/L (2.1 to 15.1) greater in performance schools. CONCLUSIONS Financial incentives to improve health were only moderately effective. Understanding the interactions with other motives and pre-existing incentives is crucial. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER ISRCTN76158086.

title: Effectiveness of screening and brief alcohol intervention in primary care (SIPS study): pragmatic randomized controlled cluster study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effectiveness of different brief intervention strategies in reducing hazardous or harmful drinking in primary care. The hypothesis was that more intensive intervention would result in greater reductions in hazardous or harmful drinking. DESIGN Pragmatic cluster-randomized controlled trial. RECRUITMENT Primary care practices in the North East and South East of England and London. PARTICIPANTS 3562 patients 18 years and older routinely presenting in primary care, of whom 2991 (84.0%) were eligible to participate in the study: 900 (30.1%) tested positive for hazardous or harmful alcohol use and 756 ( 84.0%) received a brief intervention. The sample was predominantly male (62%) and white (92%), and 34% were current smokers. INTERVENTIONS The practices were randomized to three interventions, each building on the previous one: a patient briefing control group, five minutes of brief structured counseling, and 20 minutes of brief lifestyle counseling. The package leaflet and brief advice were handed out directly after the screening and a brief lifestyle consultation in a follow-up meeting. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was patient self-reported hazardous or harmful alcohol use as measured by the Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test (AUDIT) at six months. A negative AUDIT result (score <8) indicated safe or safe drinking. Secondary endpoints measured a negative AUDIT result at 12 months, experience of alcohol-related problems (drinking problem questionnaire), health benefit (EQ-5D), use of services, and patients' motivation to change drinking behavior (willingness to change). an a Modified Ready Ruler. RESULTS Patient follow-up rates were 83% at six months (n=644) and 79% at 12 months (n=617). At both time points, an intention-to-treat analysis revealed no significant differences in AUDIT-negative status between the three interventions. Compared to the package leaflet group, the odds ratio for a negative AUDIT result was 0.85 (95% confidence interval 0.52 to 1.39) for the briefing and 0.78 (0.48 to 1.39) for the lifestyle briefing. 25). A per-protocol analysis confirmed these results. CONCLUSIONS All patients received simple feedback on their screening result. Beyond this input, however, there was no evidence that short advice or short lifestyle advice offered an important additional benefit in reducing dangerous or harmful drinking compared to the package leaflet. STUDY REGISTRATION Current controlled studies ISRCTN06145674.

title: Effectiveness of screening and treatment for depression in outpatients in need
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of screening and treatment for depression in ambulatory needy patients who visit primary care physicians. DESIGN: Two-group, randomized study (N=33 intervention, N=28 usual care) with baseline, 6-month, and 12-month outcome measures. SETTING: Internal Medicine Clinic. PATIENTS: Clinical patients over the age of 18 who tested positive for depression during a visit to their resident physician at PRIME-MD. Patients did not receive treatment or seek help for emotional problems. All patients were either enrolled in Medicaid or had an income below the poverty line. INTERVENTION: Resident physicians were trained to follow AHCPR (AHRQ; Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality) guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of depression in primary care. For patients in the intervention group, a screening nurse counseled residents about positive screening, provided them with a standardized draft protocol, and attempted to arrange behavioral support. Patients in the usual care group received the results of the screening from the screening nurse prior to their visit to the resident and were directed to seek treatment for their symptoms. MAIN RESULTS: Results for the primary endpoint of depression symptoms, as measured by the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI), showed that the intervention was successful in reducing symptoms compared to usual care (difference = -4.9 BDI points, P = 0.05, 95% confidence interval [CI], -9.8 to -0.005 effect size = -0.41). During the 12-month follow-up, 70% of intervention patients were treated for depression (91% with antidepressants), while 15% of standard care patients were treated with antidepressants for depression. Depression was identified in an additional 18% of the usual care group, but no treatment was identified. BDI differences between intervention and control groups were similar at the 6- and 12-month measurements. Quality of life and costs were also measured, but the differences between the groups were not significant in this respect. CONCLUSION: Screening and treatment of depression by private physicians was successful in reducing symptoms compared to usual care in a needy population. Almost twice as many intervention patients as controls with normal care showed a significant reduction (10 BDI points) in symptoms associated with depression.

title: Efficacy of dissemination strategies and implementation of clinical guidelines for the treatment of impacted and non-erupted third molars in primary dental care, a cluster-randomized controlled trial
abstract: AIM: To investigate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of different strategies for implementing guidelines using the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline 42 “Management of unsupervised and impacted third molars” (published 2000) as a model. DESIGN: A pragmatic cluster RCT (2x2 factorial design). TOPICS: Sixty-three dental practices across Scotland. Clinical records of all 16- to 24-year-old patients over two, four-month periods in 1999 (pre-intervention) and 2000 (post-intervention) were searched by a clinical investigator blinded to the intervention group. Data on the costs of the interventions were also collected. INTERVENTIONS: Group 1 received a copy of the SIGN 42 guideline and had the opportunity to attend a Postgraduate Education Course (PGEC). In addition, Group 2 received audit and feedback (A and F). Group 3 received a Computer Aided Learning (CAL) package. Group 4 received A and F and CAL. KEY OUTCOME MEASURE: The proportion of patients whose treatment met the guideline. RESULTS: The weighted t-test for A and F versus no A and F (p=0.62) and CAL versus no CAL (p=0.76) were not statistically significant. Due to the effectiveness results (no difference), the profitability calculation became a cost minimization calculation. The minimal cost intervention in the study was to provide general dentists (GDPs) with guidance and the opportunity to take PGEC courses. Routine data, which later became available, showed a reduction in pre-data collection withdrawals across Scotland. CONCLUSION: In a setting where preinterventional compliance was unexpectedly high, neither CAL nor A and F increased dentists' compliance with the SIGN guideline compared to mailing the guideline and being able to attend a postgraduate course. The cost of the CAL arm of the study was higher than that of the A and F arms. More work is needed to understand dentist behavior in response to guideline implementation strategies.

title: Efficacy of thigh-length graduated compression stockings in reducing the risk of deep vein thrombosis after stroke (CLOTS Study 1): a multicenter, randomized, controlled trial
abstract: BackgroundDeep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism are common after stroke. In small studies of patients undergoing surgery, graduated compression stockings (GCS) reduce the risk of DVT. National stroke guidelines extrapolated from these studies recommend its use in patients with stroke despite insufficient evidence. We evaluated the efficacy of thigh-length GCS in reducing DVT after stroke.";" BackgroundDeep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism are common after stroke. In small studies of patients undergoing surgery, graduated compression stockings (GCS) reduce the risk of DVT. National stroke guidelines extrapolated from these studies recommend its use in patients with stroke despite insufficient evidence. We evaluated the effectiveness of thigh-length GCS in reducing DVT after stroke.

title: Efficacy of community pharmacist visits in patients with heart failure: HeartMed's randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To study whether drug review and symptom self-management and lifestyle counseling intervention by community pharmacists could reduce hospital admissions or mortality in patients with heart failure. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial. SETTING Home-based intervention in patients with heart failure. PARTICIPANTS 293 patients diagnosed with heart failure were enrolled after an emergency department visit (149 intervention, 144 control). INTERVENTION Two home visits by one of 17 community pharmacists within two and eight weeks of discharge. Pharmacists reviewed medications and provided symptom self-management and lifestyle advice. Controls received usual care. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was the total number of hospital readmissions at six months. Secondary endpoints included mortality and quality of life (Questionnaire on Living in Minnesota with Heart Failure and EQ-5D). RESULTS Primary outcome data were available for 291 participants (99%). 136 (91%) intervention patients received one or two visits. 134 admissions occurred in the intervention group compared to 112 in the control group (rate ratio = 1.15, 95% confidence interval 0.89 to 1.48", P = 0.28, Poisson model). 30 intervention patients died compared to 24 controls (hazard ratio = 1.18). , 0.69 to 2.03; P=0.54). none of the differences were statistically significant. CONCLUSION This pharmacist intervention did not result in a reduction in hospital admissions, in contrast to those found in studies of nurse-led heart failure interventions Given that heart failure accounts for 5% of hospital admissions, these findings pose a problem for policymakers who face a lack of specialized care and have hoped that qualified community pharmacists could achieve the same benefit.TEST REGISTRATION NUMBER ISRCTN59427925.

title: Effects of a behavior-independent financial incentive on the prescribing behavior of general practitioners
abstract: Rationale and objectives: It is difficult to control prescribing behavior in general medicine. The purpose of this study was to assess the initial impact of a behavior-independent financial incentive on the volume of drug prescriptions by primary care physicians (GPs). DESIGN: 2-year controlled before-after study with an intervention region and a concurrent control region. SETTING AND PARTICIPANTS: Primary care physicians in two regions in the Netherlands (n=119 and n=118). INTERVENTION: A financial incentive to prescribe a specific drug or class of drugs, in accordance with local guidelines. The financial incentive consisted of a one-time payment that was independent of behavior. MAIN OUTCOME MEASUREMENT: Change in the number of prescriptions for 10 targeted drugs or drug groups. RESULTS: Significant changes were observed only with three types of antibiotics and with the recommended gastric drugs. In almost all cases, the effects were temporary. Conclusion: Non-behaviour-independent financial incentives can help to change primary care physician prescribing behavior, but the effects are localized and transient.

title: Effects of a physician referral and exercise program for men who have completed active treatment for prostate cancer: A multicenter, randomized controlled cluster study (ENGAGE)
abstract: BACKGROUND: The purpose of this study was to determine the effectiveness of a physician referral and exercise program in improving exercise levels and quality of life in men with prostate cancer. METHODS: This was a multicentre, randomized, controlled, cluster study in Melbourne, Australia, in which 15 clinicians participated: 8 clinicians were randomized to refer eligible participants (n=54) to a 12-week training program that supervised 2 each Gym sessions and 1 home session included week, and 7 physicians were randomized to follow usual care (n=93). The primary endpoint was self-reported physical activity; the secondary endpoints were quality of life, anxiety, and depressive symptoms. confidence interval [CI], 0.09-0.82; P=0.010), but not for combined moderate and vigorous exercise levels (effect size: d, 0.08; 95% CI, -0.28 to 0.45; P=0.48). were also observed for adherence to training guidelines (>/= 150 min/week; odds ratio 3.9; 95% CI 1.9-7.8; P=0.002); Positive intervention effects were observed in the intervention group for cognitive functioning (effect size: d, 0.34; 95% CI, -0.02 to 0.70; p=0.06) and depression symptoms (effect size: d, -0.35; 95% CI, -0.71 to 0.02; p=0.06). Eighty percent of participants reported that physician referral influenced their decision to participate in the exercise program. CONCLUSIONS: Physician referral and the 12-week exercise program significantly improved intense exercise levels and had a positive impact on the mental health of men with prostate cancer.More research is needed to determine the sustainability of the exercise program and its generalizability to other cancer populations.

title: Effects of a fixed combination of perindopril and indapamide on macrovascular and microvascular outcomes in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (the ADVANCE study): a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Blood pressure is an important determinant of the risk of macrovascular and microvascular complications in type 2 diabetes, and guidelines recommend intensive blood pressure reduction for diabetics with hypertension. We evaluated the effects of routine administration of an angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor-diuretic combination on major vascular events in patients with diabetes, regardless of baseline blood pressure readings or use of other antihypertensive drugs.";" Background Blood pressure is an important determinant of the risk of macrovascular and microvascular complications in type 2 diabetes, and guidelines recommend intensive blood pressure reduction for diabetics with hypertension. We evaluated the effects of routine administration of an angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor-diuretic combination on major vascular events in patients with diabetes, regardless of baseline blood pressure readings or use of other antihypertensive drugs.

title: Impact of a multifaceted intervention on cardiovascular risk factors in high-risk hypertensive patients: the ESCAPE study, a pragmatic cluster-randomized study in general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Several observational studies of hypertensive patients have revealed a discrepancy between the therapeutic goals recommended in guidelines and those achieved in daily practice. The aim of the ESCAPE study was to determine whether a multifaceted intervention focused on general practitioners (GPs) could significantly increase the proportion of high-risk hypertensive patients in primary prevention who met all of their recommended therapeutic goals. METHODS: A pragmatic, cluster-randomized study with 257 general practitioners randomized by region. The general practitioners in the intervention group had a one-day training course and received an electronic blood pressure monitor and a short recommendation brochure. In addition to the usual follow-up, they focused on a consultation on hypertension and other cardiovascular risk factors every six months for two years. They also received feedback on their patients' clinical and biological parameters at baseline and after one year. The main outcome measures were the change in the proportion of patients who achieved all of their therapeutic goals and each individual therapeutic goal at two years, and quality of life. RESULTS: 1,832 high-risk hypertensive patients were included. After two years, the proportion of patients achieving all of their therapeutic goals increased significantly in both groups, but significantly more in the intervention group: OR (odds ratio) 1.89, (95% confidence interval (CI) 1.09 to 3 .27, P=0.02). ). Significantly more patients achieved their blood pressure goals in the intervention group than in the usual care group: OR 2.03 (95% CI 1.44 to 2.88, p<0.0001). Systolic and diastolic blood pressure decreased significantly more in the intervention group than in the usual care group, by 4.8 mmHg and 1.9 mmHg, respectively (p<0.0001 for both). There was no significant difference between the groups in terms of physical and mental quality of life. CONCLUSION: An easy-to-deliver, multifaceted intervention targeting primary care physicians only significantly increased the proportion of high-risk hypertensive patients in primary prevention who met their recommended therapeutic goals. STUDY REGISTRATION: This study was registered with ClinicalTrials.gov under number NCT00348855.

title: Effects of brief treatment with eszopiclone on continuous positive airway pressure adherence
abstract: Background: Short-term continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) compliance can predict long-term use. Unfortunately, initial CPAP intolerance can lead to poor adherence to therapy or discontinuation of therapy. Aim: To determine whether a short course of eszopiclone at baseline improves long-term CPAP compliance more than placebo in adults with obstructive sleep apnea. Design: Parallel, randomized, placebo-controlled study from March 2007 to December 2008. Randomization, maintained and hidden centrally by pharmacy staff, was computer-generated using fixed blocks of 10. Referring physicians, investigators, and patients were opposed to treatment assignment until after the final data blinded were collected. (ClinicalTrials.gov registration number: NCT00612157) Setting: Academic Center for Sleep Disorders. Patients: 160 adults (mean age 45.7 years [SD, 7.3]); mean apnea-hypopnea index, 36.9 events/h [SD , 23]) with newly diagnosed obstructive sleep apnea who initiated CPAP. Intervention: Eszopiclone, 3 mg (n?=76) or matched placebo (n?=78) for the first 14 nights of CPAP. Measurements: CPAP use was measured weekly for 24 weeks. CPAP adherence (primary endpoint) and rates of CPAP discontinuations and improvement in symptoms (secondary endpoints) were compared. Follow-up at 1, 3, and 6 months was performed of 150, 136, and 120 patients completed Results: Patients in the eszopiclone group used CPAP for 20.8% more nights (95% CI, 7.2% to 34.4%; P?=0.003), 1.3 hours more per night for all nights (CI, 0.4 to 2.2 hours; P? = 0.005) and 1.1 more hours of CPAP use per night (CI, 0.2 to 2.1 hours; P? = 0.019 ). The hazard ratio for stopping CPAP was 1.90 (CI, 1.1 to 3.4; P? = 0.03 3) times higher in the placebo group. Side effects were reported in 7.1% of patients and did not differ between groups. Limitations: Patients had severe obstructive sleep apnea treated at a specialized sleep center with frequent follow-up; results may not be generalizable to different CPAP settings and reasons for discontinuation have not been assessed. Conclusion: Compared to placebo, a short course of eszopiclone during the first 2 weeks of CPAP therapy improved adherence and resulted in fewer patients discontinuing therapy. Primary Funding Source: Sepracor.

title: Effects of an automated electronic reminder in changing antiplatelet prescribing behavior among Italian general practitioners in diabetics: an intervention study
abstract: AIM – To evaluate whether an electronic reminder integrated into a routine computer system increases the use of antiplatelet drugs in diabetics among Italian General Practitioners (GPs). RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS - A randomized controlled trial was conducted among 300 general practitioners and their patients selected from the Health Search Database. Of these, 150 GPs (intervention group) received instructions to activate an electronic reminder and a letter summarizing the beneficial effects of antiplatelet therapy in diabetics with at least one additional cardiovascular risk factor (“high risk”), the other 150 GPs (control group) received only the letter. The electronic reminder, integrated into a standard software system for managing daily clinical routine, was displayed when each participating general practitioner opened the medical records of diabetic patients aged 30 years. Only high-risk diabetics were included in the analysis. Patients were considered for antiplatelet treatment if they received two or more prescriptions at baseline and during follow-up. RESULTS - We selected 15,343 high-risk diabetics, 7,313 from control group GPs and 8,030 from intervention group GPs. A total of 1672 patients (22.9%) in the control group and 1886 (23.5%) patients in the intervention group received antiplatelet therapy at baseline (P = NS). At the end of the follow-up, the number of treated patients in the intervention group (odds ratio 1.99, 95% CI 1.79-2.22) was significantly higher than in the control group. The effect of electronic reminder was more relevant in patients with one or more cardiovascular risk factors but no prior cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) than in patients with CVDs. CONCLUSIONS â€“ These findings support the effect of electronic reminders in influencing the prescribing behavior of general practitioners.

title: Effects of an Evidence Service on the Use of Research Evidence by Community-Based AIDS Service Organizations: A Protocol for a Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: Background To support the use of research evidence by community-based organizations (CBOs), we have developed Synthesized HIV/AIDS Research Evidence (SHARE), an evidence service for those working in the HIV sector. SHARE consists of several components: an online searchable database of HIV-related systematic reviews (retrievable based on a taxonomy of HIV/AIDS-related topics and an open text search), regular email updates, access to user-friendly summaries; " and peer relevance ratings. Our goal is to assess whether this "full-serve" evidence service increases the use of research evidence by CBOs compared to a "self-service" evidence service. Methods/Design We will conduct a two-arm randomized controlled trial (RCT) along with a subsequent qualitative process study to further investigate the results. All CBOs affiliated with the Canadian AIDS Society (n=120) will be invited to participate and will be randomly assigned to receive either the "full-serve" version of SHARE or the "self-service" version (a list of relevant systematic reviews with links to PubMed records and worksheets that help CBOs find and use research evidence) using a simple randomized design. All managers and employees of each organization get access to the version of SHARE that their organization is associated with. The test duration is 10 months (two-month baseline period, six-month intervention period and two-month crossover period), the primary outcome measure is the average number of enrollments/month/organization (averaged over the number of users from each organization) between the baseline and the end of the intervention period. The secondary outcome is the intent to use research evidence measured through a survey conducted at a key decision maker from each organization. For the qualitative study, one key organizational decision maker will be specifically selected from 15 organizations in each study arm (n=30). Semi-structured one-on-one interviews are conducted by telephone about their views on and experiences with the evidence service they received, how helpful it was in their work, why it was helpful (or not helpful), what aspects were most and least helpful and why and recommendations for next steps. Discussion To our knowledge, this will be the first RCT to assess the impact of an evidence service specifically designed to assist CBOs in locating and using research evidence.

title: Impact of an evidence service on the use of research evidence by health system decision makers: A protocol for a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Health care policy makers need timely access to synthesized research results to inform policy making. No efforts to address this need have been evaluated using an experimental quantitative design. We have developed an evidence service that draws input from Health Systems Evidence, a database of policy relevant systematic reviews. The reviews were categorized (a) by topic and review type; (b) coded by the last year in which studies were searched for and the countries in which included studies were conducted; (c) assessed for quality;' and (d) links to available user-friendly summaries, scientific abstracts and full-text reports. Our goal is to assess whether a "full-serve" evidence service increases the use of synthesized research evidence by policy analysts and consultants at the Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care (MOHLTC) compared to a "self-serve" evidence service. Methods/Design We will conduct a two-arm randomized controlled trial (RCT) along with a subsequent qualitative process study to further investigate the results. For the RCT, all policy analysts and policy advisors (n=168) in a single department of the MOHLTC are invited to participate. Using a stratified, randomized design, participants will be randomized to receive either the "full-service" evidence service (database access, monthly email alerts, and availability of full-text articles) or the "self-service" evidence service (database access). just). The duration of the trial is ten months (two-month baseline period, six-month intervention period and two-month cross-over period). The primary outcome is the average number of website visits/month/user between baseline and the end of the intervention period. The secondary outcome will be participants' intent to use research evidence. For the qualitative study, 15 participants from each study arm (n = 30) will be specifically selected. Semi-structured one-on-one interviews are conducted by telephone about their views on and experiences with the evidence service they received, how helpful it was in their work, why it was helpful (or not helpful), what aspects were most and least helpful and why and recommendations for next steps. Discussion To our knowledge, this will be the first RCT to assess the impact of an evidence service specifically designed to assist health system decision-makers in locating and using research evidence.

title: Effects of computer reminders for influenza vaccination on morbidity during influenza epidemics.
abstract: To examine the impact of computer-generated reminders for influenza vaccination in patients at high risk of winter lung disease, we selected 4555 such patients from a population of 15,000 adults who participated in a three-year randomized trial of reminders for prevention. The physicians who received the reminders vaccinated eligible patients twice as often as the control physicians (P=0.0001). There was a linear increase in influenza incidence in our region during the three winters studied (from 1000 to 33,451 to 71,075 cases per year), and we modeled the percentage of patients with hospitalizations, emergency room visits with chest X-rays, and blood gas determinations as a logistic function this increase. The difference in linear trends between patients in the intervention group (whose physicians received reminders) and those in the control group was significant for emergency department visits (p < 0.05), hospitalizations (p < 0.01), and blood gases (P less than 0.001). The most likely explanation for the difference is the greater use of influenza vaccines in the intervention group.

title: Effects of computer reminders on peripheral venous catheter complications and guideline adherence in pediatric nurse care--a cluster-randomized study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Reminder systems in electronic medical records (EHR) have been shown to affect both healthcare professional behavior and patient outcomes. The aim of this cluster-randomized study was to investigate the impact of implementing a clinical practice guideline (CPG) for peripheral venous catheters (PVK) in pediatric care, in the form of reminders integrated into the EPAs, on PVC-related complications and on registered self-reported Adherence to the guideline by RNs. Another aim was to examine the relationship between contextual factors and outcomes of the intervention. Methods: The study included 12 inpatient wards of a pediatric university hospital. The reminders covered the choice of PVC, hygiene, maintenance and daily inspection of the PVC plant. The primary endpoint was documented signs and symptoms of PVC-related complications at removal retrieved from the EPR. The secondary outcome was nurse adherence to a PVC policy, which was collected via a questionnaire that also included nurses' perceived work context, measured with the Alberta Context Tool. The units were divided into two tiers based on the occurrence of PVCs. A blinded single drawing of lots from each stratum randomized six units to the control and intervention groups, respectively. Units were not blinded. The intervention group included 626 PVCs at baseline and 618 post-intervention, and the control group comprised 724 PVCs at baseline and 674 post-intervention. At baseline, 212 (65.4%) and 208 (71.5%) RNs were included after the intervention. RESULTS: No significant effect was found for computer recalls on PVC-related complications or on RNs' adherence to guideline recommendations. The complication rate at baseline and after the intervention was 40.6% (95% confidence interval (CI) 36.7-44.5) and 41.9% (95% CI 38.0-45.8) for the intervention group and 40 .3% (95% CI 36.8-44.0). ) and 46.9% (95% CI 43.1-50.7) for the control. In general, nurses' self-rated work context varied from moderately low to moderately high, indicating that conditions for successful implementation were less than optimal. CONCLUSIONS: The warnings could potentially have been accompanied by a tailored intervention targeting specific barriers such as the low frequency of recorded reasons for removal, low compliance with daily inspection of PVC sites, and lack of regular feedback to RNs. STUDY REGISTRATION: Current controlled studies ISRCTN44819426.

title: Implications of computerized guidelines for the treatment of heart disease in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Electronic information systems have been proposed as a means to reduce medical errors (doing the wrong thing) and omissions (not treating indicated). OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the impact of computer-assisted cardiac care proposals. DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial for general practitioners and pharmacists. SUBJECTS: A total of 706 outpatients with heart failure and/or ischemic heart disease. ACTIONS: Evidence-based cardiac care proposals, approved by a panel of local cardiologists and general internists, were presented to physicians and pharmacists in the care of enrolled patients. MEASUREMENTS: Adherence to care recommendations, general and condition-specific quality of life, acute exacerbations of their heart disease, medication compliance, healthcare costs, satisfaction with care, and physician attitudes to guidelines. RESULTS: Subjects were followed for 1 year during which they made 3,419 primary care visits and were eligible for 2,609 separate cardiac care proposals. The intervention had no impact on physicians' adherence to treatment recommendations (23% in intervention patients vs. 22% in control patients). There were no intervention-control differences in quality of life, medication compliance, health care utilization, cost, or satisfaction with care. Physicians viewed guidelines as helpful information, but limiting their practice and not helpful in making decisions for individual patients. CONCLUSIONS: Treatment suggestions generated by a sophisticated electronic medical record system failed to improve adherence to accepted practice guidelines or outcomes for patients with cardiac disease. Future studies must weigh the benefits and costs of different (and perhaps more draconian) methods of influencing clinical behavior.

title: Effects of family doctor training and family support services on the care of dementia patients in the home environment - results of a controlled cluster-randomized study
abstract: BACKGROUND: More than 90% of dementia patients are cared for by their general practitioners, who are instrumental in diagnosis, therapy and recommendation of support services. AIM: To test whether special training of general practitioners changes the care of dementia patients through their systematic recommendation of care counseling and self-help groups. METHOD: 129 general practitioners enrolled 390 dementia patients and their informal caregivers in a prospective, three-arm, cluster-randomized, 2-year study. Arm A represented the usual care, in arms B and C self-help groups and care counseling (in arm B one year after the start of the study, in arm C at the start of the study) were recommended by the primary care physicians. The general practitioners received arm-specific training. The diagnostic and therapeutic behavior of the physicians was recorded at the start of the study. In the 2-year follow-up, informal caregivers were asked about the use of support services. Results: The diagnostic behavior of general practitioners corresponds to the relevant guidelines. The procedure for newly diagnosed patients does not differ from patients who have already been diagnosed, with the exception of the referral rate to a specialist. About a third of newly diagnosed dementia patients receive an anti-dementia drug. Utilization of self-help groups and counseling increased fivefold and fourfold, respectively. Utilization of other support services remained low (<10%), with the exception of home nursing and short-term institutional care. Conclusion: Trained general practitioners usually act in accordance with the guidelines in dementia diagnostics and partially in accordance with the guidelines with regard to the recommended drug therapy. Recommendations for support services for caring relatives by the general practitioner are successful. They cause a significant increase in the use of the recommended services compared to offers that are not recommended by the general practitioner. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN68329593.

title: Impact of Interactive Voice Response Self-Monitoring on Natural Resolution of Alcohol Problems: Usage and Behavioral Economics Factors.
abstract: Aim: Most problem drinkers do not seek help, and many recover on their own. Whether assistive interactive voice response (IVR) self-monitoring facilitates such "natural" resolutions was investigated in a randomized controlled trial. Based on behavioral economics, it was hypothesized that the impact on drinking outcomes varies with drinkers' basic "time horizons", reflecting preferences between goods of different values, available via different delays and with their IVR usage. Method: Recently resolved, untreated problem drinkers were randomized to a 24-week IVR self-monitoring program (n = 87) or a control-only condition (n = 98). Baseline interviews assessed outcome predictors, including behavioral economic measures of reward preferences (discounting delays, pre-dissolution money allocation for alcohol vs. savings). The six-month results were categorized as abstinent-resolved, non-abstinent-resolved, unresolved, or missing. Compler Average Causal Effect (CACE) models examined IVR self-monitoring effects. Results: IVR self-monitoring compliers (>=70% completed scheduled calls) were older and had greater pre-resolution alcohol control and lower rebates than non-compliers (<70%). A CACE model interaction showed that observed compliance adherents in the IVR group with shorter time horizons (as expressed by higher pre-dissolution alcohol expenditures than savings) were more likely to achieve moderation than abstinent dissolutions compared to predicted compliance adherents in the Control group with shorter time horizons and with all noncompliers. Intention-to-treat analysis models showed no IVR-related effects. More balanced spending on savings versus alcohol predicted moderation for both approaches. Conclusions: IVR interventions should consider factors affecting IVR use and drinking outcomes, including individual-specific behavioral economic variables. CACE models provide tools for evaluating expanded participation interventions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Effects of treatment for depression and low perceived social support on clinical events after myocardial infarction: The Enriching Recovery in Coronary Heart Disease Patients (ENRICHD) randomized trial.
abstract: Determines whether mortality and recurrent heart attacks are reduced by treatment of depression and low perceived social support (LPSS) with cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) supplemented with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant, if indicated, in patients who die within 28 Days after myocardial disease were recorded reduced infarction (MI). A randomized clinical study was conducted with 2481 MI patients. LPSS was determined by the ENRICHD Social Support Instrument (ESSI). Random assignment was to usual medical care or to a CBT-based psychosocial intervention. CBT was started a median 17 days after index MI, plus group therapy, when possible, with SSRIs for patients who scored greater than 24 on the Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression or had less than a 50 percent reduction in scores of the Beck depression inventory at 5 weeks. Improvement in psychosocial outcomes at 6 months of favored treatment: mean change in HRSD score, -10.1 in the depression and psychosocial intervention group versus -8.4 in the depression and usual care group";" mean change in ESSI score, 5.1 in the LPSS and psychosocial intervention group versus 3.4 in the LPSS and usual care group. After a mean follow-up of 29 months, there was no significant difference in event-free survival between usual care and psychosocial intervention.

title: Efficacy and safety of corticosteroid injections and other injections for the treatment of tendinopathies: a systematic review of randomized controlled trials
abstract: Background There are few evidence-based treatment guidelines for tendinopathies. We conducted a systematic review of randomized trials to determine the clinical efficacy and risk of adverse events of treatment by injection.";" Background There are few evidence-based treatment guidelines for tendinopathies. We conducted a systematic review of randomized trials to determine the clinical efficacy and risk of adverse events for treatment by injection.

title: Efficacy and safety of sucrose for procedural pain relief in preterm and newborn infants
abstract: BACKGROUND: Premature and acutely ill neonates admitted to a NICU undergo multiple common invasive and painful procedures aimed at improving their outcome. Although several studies have been developed to determine the efficacy of sucrose for treating surgical pain in preterm and acutely ill neonates, these have generally lacked methodological rigor and have not provided physicians with clear practice guidelines. OBJECTIVES: To compare the efficacy and safety of three interventions for alleviating procedural pain associated with heel pricking in preterm and term newborns, and to investigate the influence of contextual factors such as gender, disease severity, and prior painful procedures on pain responses. METHODS: In a randomized controlled trial, 190 neonates were stratified by gestational age and then randomized to receive (a) sucrose and non-nutritional sucking (n=64), (b) sucrose alone (n=62), or (c) sterile water and non-nutritional sucking (control) (n = 64) to assess efficacy (pain response as measured by the Premature Infant Pain Profile) (Stevens, Johnson, Petryshen, & Taddio, 1996) and safety (side effects) after a scheduled heel prick during the first week of life. Stratification was used to control for the effects of age on pain response. RESULTS: There were significant differences in pain response between treatment groups (F=22.49, p<0.001), with the sucrose and no nutritive sucking groups having the lowest mean pain profile scores in preterm infants. Efficacy of sucrose after heel prick was not affected by disease severity, postnatal age, or number of painful procedures. Intervention group and gender explained 12% of the variance in pain profile scores for preterm infants. Few adverse events occurred (n=6), and none required medical or nursing intervention. CONCLUSIONS: The combination of sucrose and non-nutritive sucking is the most effective intervention for single-heel pricking. Studies on the effects of gestational age on the efficacy and safety of repeated doses of sucrose are needed.

title: Efficacy and safety of very early mobilization within 24 h after stroke (AVERT): a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Early mobilization after stroke is thought to contribute to the effects of stroke unit care; however, the intervention is poorly defined and not supported by strong evidence. Our aim was to compare the efficacy of frequent, very early, higher dose mobilization versus usual care after stroke.; Background Early mobilization after stroke is thought to contribute to the effects of stroke care; however, the intervention is poorly defined and not supported by strong evidence. Our aim was to compare the efficacy of frequent, very early, higher dose mobilization versus usual care after stroke.

title: Efficacy of cognitive and behavioral psychotherapy used by primary care psychologists in patients with mixed anxiety-depressive disorder: a research protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Contrary to the recommendations of clinical practice guidelines, the most common treatment for anxiety and depressive disorders in primary care is pharmacological. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a cognitive-behavioral intervention performed by primary care psychologists in patients with mixed anxiety-depressive disorder compared to usual care. METHODS/DESIGN: This is an open label, multicenter, randomized and controlled study with two parallel groups. A random sample of 246 patients with mild to moderate mixed anxiety-depressive disorder will be recruited from the target population on the lists of 41 general practitioners. Patients will be randomly assigned to the intervention group, which will receive standardized cognitive-behavioral therapy administered by psychologists along with usual care, or a control group, which will receive only usual care. The cognitive behavioral therapy intervention consists of eight individual 60-minute face-to-face sessions conducted over eight consecutive weeks. A follow-up session is conducted 6 months after the procedure by phone for reinforcement or referral, as needed. The primary outcome variable is change in Short Form-36 General Health Survey scores. We will also measure the change in frequency and intensity of anxiety symptoms (State-Trait Anxiety Inventory) and depression (Beck Depression Inventory) at baseline and 3, 6 and 12 months later. In addition, we will collect information on drug use and health services. DISCUSSION: The aim of this study is to assess the effectiveness of a primary care physician's cognitive-behavioural intervention in patients with mixed anxiety-depressive disorder. International scientific evidence has shown the need for psychologists in primary care. However, given the differences between health policies and health services, it is important to test the impact of these psychological interventions in our geographic setting. TEST REGISTRATION: NCT01907035 (July 22, 2013).

title: Efficacy of a nurse-led email reminder program in reducing the risk of cardiovascular prevention in hypertensive patients: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many strategies have been evaluated to improve the prevention and control of cardiovascular (CVD) risk factors. Individualized lifestyle education programs for telephone and teleconsultation care have been found to improve blood pressure control and adherence to lifestyle recommendations. This study tested the effectiveness of a nurse-led email reminder program (NRP-e) in improving CVD risk factors in adults with hypertension. METHODS: All participants received standard CVD prevention and a guideline-based educational program. Subjects in the NRP-e group also received weekly email notifications and phone calls from a care provider for 6 months. The emails included a reminder program to follow a healthy lifestyle based on current guidelines. Follow-up visits were scheduled at 1, 3, and 6 months after admission; randomization was centralized and blood samples were evaluated in a single laboratory. RESULTS: The final sample consisted of 98 (control) and 100 (NRP-e) subjects (mean age 59.0 +/- 14.5 years; 51.0% males). After 6 months, the following CVD risk factors improved significantly in both groups: body mass index, alcohol and fruit consumption, cigarette smoking, adherence to therapy times, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, fasting blood sugar, low-density lipoproteins (LDL) and total cholesterol, triglycerides and physical activity. However, in the NRP-e group, the prevalence of several risk behaviors or conditions decreased significantly more than in the control group: obesity (-16%), low fruit consumption (-24%), uncontrolled hypertension (-61%). , LDL (-56%) and total cholesterol (-40%). CONCLUSIONS: The NRP-e improved a number of CVD risk factors. The program was low in cost, required an average of <20 minutes per day in addition to normal practice, and may merit further evaluation for inclusion in existing nursing management approaches.

title: Effectiveness of a self-help manual for increasing resilience in caregivers of adults with depression in Thailand
abstract: Caring for a person with a mental illness can have adverse effects on family carers', but little is known about how best to help these family carers. The aim of the present study was to investigate the effectiveness of a cognitive-behavioral-led self-help manual in increasing resilience in caregivers of people with depression compared to caregivers receiving only routine support. A randomized controlled trial was conducted according to CONSORT guidelines , where 54 nurses received a parallel intervention (self-help manual) (n = 27) or control groups (standard support) (n = 27). Exercise capacity was assessed at baseline, post-test (week 8), and at follow-up (week 12). Intention-to-treat analyzes were performed. Repeated ANOVA measures indicated a significant difference in resilience scores between the three time points, demonstrating a large effect. Pairwise comparisons between intervention and control groups showed resilience between baseline and post-test and between baseline and follow-up, but not between Post test and follow up. Overall, the intervention group showed a slightly greater increase in resilience over time than the control group; however, the time-group interaction was not significant. Guided self-help is helpful in improving the resilience of caregivers and could be used to supplement the limited support provided to caregivers by psychiatric nurses and other clinicians.

title: Efficacy of evidence-based clinical decision support in general practice
abstract: Significance There is consensus that the inclusion of clinical decision support in electronic health records will improve quality of care, contain costs and reduce overtreatment, but this potential has yet to be demonstrated in clinical trials. Aim To evaluate the impact of a tailored evidence-based clinical decision support tool on management of respiratory infections and on the effectiveness of integrating evidence at the point-of-care. Design, Setting and Participants In a randomized clinical trial, we implemented 2 well-validated built-in clinical prediction rules, namely the Walsh rule for streptococcal pharyngitis and the Heckerling rule for pneumonia. INTERVENTIONS AND MAIN RESULTS AND MEASURES The intervention group had access to the integrated clinical prediction rules tool and decided whether to fill out risk assessment calculators, order medications, and create progress notes to help with complex decisions at the point of care. Results The intervention group completed the integrated clinical prediction rule tool at 57.5% of visits. Providers in the intervention group were significantly less likely to order antibiotics than those in the control group (age-adjusted relative risk 0.74 inches; 95% CI 0.60-0.92). The absolute risk of the intervention was 9.2% and the required number of treats was 10.8. The intervention group was significantly less likely to order rapid strep testing than the control group (relative risk 0.75; 95% CI 0.58-0.97; P?=?.03). Conclusions and Relevance The integrated clinical prediction rule process to integrate complex evidence-based clinical decision-making reports is of relevant importance for national initiatives such as "Meaningful Use".

title: Efficacy of a standardized manual therapy and home exercise program in chronic rotator cuff disease: randomized placebo-controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effectiveness of a program of manual therapy and exercise compared to placebo treatment by physical therapists for people with chronic rotator cuff disease. DRAFT Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Participant- and Single-Investigator-Blinded Trial. SETTING Melbourne metropolitan area, Victoria, Australia. PARTICIPANTS 120 participants with chronic (>3 months) rotator cuff disease who were recruited from physicians and from the community. INTERVENTIONS Active treatment included manual therapy and a home exercise program; placebo treatment included inactive ultrasound therapy and application of an inert gel. Participants in both groups received 10 sessions of individual standardized treatment over 10 weeks. For the following 12 weeks, the active group continued the home exercise program and the placebo group received no treatment. Perceived global assessment of overall change RESULTS 112 (93%) participants completed the 22-week study At 11 weeks, there was no difference between groups in change in shoulder pain and disability index (3.6, 95% confidence interval -2.1 to 9, 4) or noted change in pain (0.7, -0.1 to 1.5);" both groups showed significant improvements. More participants in the active group reported a successful outcome (defined as "much better"), though the difference was not statistically significant: 42% (24/57) of the active participants and 30% (18/61) of the placebo participants (relative risk 1.43, 0.87 to 2.34).The active group showed post At 22 weeks, there was a significantly greater improvement in shoulder pain and disability index than the placebo group (difference between groups 7.1; 1.7) or for the percentage of participants reporting a successful treatment outcome (relative risk o 1.39, 0.94 to 2.03). Several secondary endpoints favored the active group, including shoulder pain and disability index functional score, muscle strength, activity impairment, and quality of life. CONCLUSION A standardized program of manual therapy and home exercise provided no additional immediate benefit for pain and function compared to realistic placebo treatment controlling therapist contact in middle-aged to elderly adults with chronic rotator cuff disease. However, greater improvements were seen at follow-up, particularly in shoulder function and strength, suggesting that the benefits of active treatment are taking longer to manifest. STUDY REGISTRATION Clinical Studies NCT00415441.

title: Effectiveness of guidelines and training program: A training process for diagnosing low back pain
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Italian National Health Plan has included low back pain (LBP) among the pathologies for which clinical guidelines should be established and disseminated. Changing the clinical behavior of physicians requires forms of intervention whose effectiveness is not fully known. OBJECTIVES: This study proposes to evaluate the effectiveness of a multifaceted intervention, including educational materials, lectures, workshops, and local consensus processes, to modify the clinical management of LBP by general practitioners (GP). METHODS: Changes in diagnostic capacity were assessed by a controlled (before/after) study based on frequency of etiologic diagnoses of LBP, assessment of clinical knowledge with multiple-choice tests, and on priorities in confronting problems the treatment of LBP were assigned to the three general practitioner groups who had voluntarily participated in the study. RESULTS: A statistically significant increase in diagnostic capacity (frequency of exact answers in the multiple-choice test) was achieved. There has also been a shift in priorities in addressing problems in the management of LBP, from diagnosis as the primary problem before intervention to communicating with the patient. CONCLUSIONS: In the Italian context, the study also confirms the efficiency of a multifaceted intervention based on a training process aimed at modifying the clinical behavior of the GP in relation to LBP.

title: EHRA Research Network Surveys: 6 years of EP Wire activity
abstract: Clinical practice should follow guidelines and recommendations based primarily on the results of controlled studies, often conducted in selected populations and under specific conditions, while clinical practice may be influenced by factors different from controlled scientific studies. Therefore, the real environment is better assessed by the observational registries, which enroll patients for longer periods of time. However, this can be difficult, expensive and time consuming. In 2009, the Scientific Initiatives Committee of the European Heart Rhythm Association (EHRA) initiated a series of surveys addressing controversial issues in clinical electrophysiology (EP). With this in mind, an EHRA-EP research network was created, comprising EP centers in Europe, among which the 'hot topic' surveys were disseminated. This review summarizes the overall experience of performing EP wires over the last 6 years, categorizes and ranks the issues regarding clinical EP, and assesses the acceptability and feedback from the responding centers to improve survey participation and research needs to address efforts of the European EP community.

title: Electronic alerts to prevent venous thromboembolism in hospitalized patients
abstract: BACKGROUND Prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis in hospitalized patients is still underutilized. We hypothesized that using a computer alert program to promote prophylaxis could reduce the incidence of deep vein thrombosis in high-risk hospitalized patients. METHODS We developed a computer program linked to the patient database to identify consecutive hospitalized patients at risk for deep vein thrombosis without prophylaxis. The program used medical record numbers to randomly assign 1,255 eligible patients to an intervention group in which the responsible physician was alerted to a patient's risk of deep vein thrombosis and 1,251 patients to a control group in which no alert was issued. The physician had to acknowledge the alarm and could then refuse or order prophylaxis including graduated compression stockings, pneumatic compression boots, unfractionated heparin, low molecular weight heparin, or warfarin. The primary endpoint was clinically diagnosed, objectively confirmed deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism at 90 days. RESULTS More patients in the intervention group than in the control group received mechanical prophylaxis (10.0 percent vs. 1.5 percent, P<0.001) or pharmacologic prophylaxis (23.6 percent vs. 13.0 percent, P<0.001) . The primary endpoint occurred in 61 patients (4.9 percent) in the intervention group versus 103 (8.2 percent) in the control group,” according to the Kaplan-Meier estimate of the probability of being free of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism at 90 days were 94.1 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 92.5 to 95.4 percent) and 90.6 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 88.7 to 92.2 percent) (P < 0.001) respectively Computer alert reduced the risk of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism by 41 percent at 90 days (hazard ratio, 0.59; 95 percent confidence interval, 0.43 to 0.81; P=0.001). CONCLUSIONS The establishment of a computer alert program increased the use of prophylaxis by physicians and significantly reduced the rates of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism in at-risk patients hospitalized.

title: Electronic alerts versus on-demand decision support to improve dyslipidemia treatment: a randomized controlled cluster study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Indirect evidence shows that alerting users with clinical decision support systems appears to change behavior more than requiring users to actively initiate the system. However, randomized trials comparing these methods in a clinical setting are lacking. We examined the effect of both alerting and on-demand decision support in relation to the screening and treatment of dyslipidemia based on the guidelines of the Dutch College of General Practitioners. METHODS AND RESULTS: In a clustered randomized study design, 38 Dutch general practices (77 physicians) and 87,886 of their patients (39,433 men aged 18 to 70 years and 48,453 women aged 18 to 75 years) used the ELIAS electronic medical record. Each practice was assigned to receive notifications, on-demand support, or no intervention. We measured the percentage of patients who were screened and treated after 12 months of follow-up. In the alert group, 65% of patients requiring screening were screened (relative risk versus control = 1.76", 95% confidence interval, 1.41 to 2.20) compared to 35% of patients in the need group (relative risk versus control = 1.28; 95% confidence interval 0.98 to 1.68) and 25% of patients in the control group In the warning group, 66% of the patients requiring treatment were treated (relative risk versus control = 1.40; 95% -Confidence interval: 1.15 to 1.70) ) compared to 40% of patients (relative risk versus control = 1.19; 95% confidence interval, 0.94 to 1.50) in the on-demand group and 36% of patients in the control group CONCLUSIONS: The alerting version of the Clinical Decision Support System significantly improved screening and treatment performance for dyslipidemia by general practitioners.

title: Electronic Antibiotic Stewardship - Reduced use of broad spectrum antibiotics using a computerized antimicrobial licensing system in a hospital setting.
abstract: Objectives Antibiotic stewardship is important, but the ideal strategy for delivering stewardship in a hospital setting is unknown. A practical, sustainable and transferrable strategy is needed. This study evaluates the impact of a novel computerized antimicrobial drug approval system on antibiotic prescribing behavior in a hospital setting. The effects on drug consumption, antibiotic resistance patterns of local bacteria, and patient outcomes were monitored. Methods The study was conducted at a referral tertiary hospital in Melbourne, Australia. The system was introduced in January 2005 and directed the use of 28 restricted antimicrobials. Data was collected over 7 years: 5 years before and 2 years after deployment. The uptake of the system was assessed using a built-in audit trail. Drug use was prospectively monitored using pharmacy data (defined as daily doses per 1000 bed days) and analyzed using time series analysis with segmental linear regression. Antibiograms of local bacteria were evaluated prospectively. In-hospital mortality and length of stay in patients with Gram-negative bacteremia have also been reported. Results In 2006, between 250 and 300 registrations were registered monthly. The gradients using third and fourth generation cephalosporins (+0.52, -0.05, -0.39"; P<0.01), glycopeptides (+0.27, -0.53; P=0 .09), carbapenems (+0.12, -0.24; P=0.21), aminoglycosides (+0.15, -0.27; P<0.01), and quinolones (+0.76, + 0.11; "P = 0.08) all fell after use, while extended-spectrum penicillin use increased. Trends in increased susceptibility of Staphylococcus aureus to methicillin and improved susceptibility of Pseudomonas spp. too many antibiotics were observed. No increase in side effects was observed in patients with Gram-negative bacteremia. Conclusions The system was successfully implemented and significant changes in antimicrobial use were demonstrated.

title: E-Isotretinoin Electronic Prescribing Chart: Improving Physician Adherence to Isotretinoin Prescribing Guidelines
abstract: Oral isotretinoin is a highly effective treatment for refractory nodulocystic acne. However, it can be associated with serious side effects such as teratogenicity and hepatitis. Inadequate cumulative dosing can also lead to decreased therapeutic efficacy and higher disease relapse. A preliminary review had previously found poor and inconsistent compliance by physicians with local isotretinoin prescribing guidelines. To achieve greater than 90% adherence to isotretinoin guidelines for all acne patients prescribed systemic isotretinoin at the National Skin Centre, Singapore, key areas and the reasons for non-compliance were identified. Within the Electronic Medical Record (EMR) system, a purpose-built “one-stop” isotretinoin electronic spreadsheet has been introduced to address key areas of safety”; namely, patient informed consent, pregnancy testing, baseline laboratory testing, and automatic calculation of cumulative and target doses of isotretinoin. Physician adherence to prescribing guidelines improved from a baseline of 50-60% to greater than 90% (range 95-100%) for 30 consecutive months after the intervention. The E-Isotretinoin graph has resulted in a significant improvement in physician compliance with isotretinoin prescribing guidelines and underscores the utility of EMR technology in influencing physician safe prescribing behavior.

title: Decision support for electronic health records and quality of care for children with ADHD.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of electronic health record (EHR) decision support on physician management and documentation of care for children with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). METHODS: This study enrolled 79 general pediatricians in 12 pediatric primary care practices using the same EHR and caring for 412 children aged 5 to 18 years previously diagnosed with ADHD. We conducted a cluster-randomized study of EHR-based decision support that included (1) clinical reminders to assess ADHD symptoms every 3 to 6 months and (2) an ADHD note template with structured fields for symptoms, treatment efficacy, and side effects.
