The key outcome measures were (1) the proportion of children with visits during the 6-month study period in which ADHD was assessed and (2) the quality of documentation of the ADHD assessment. Generalized estimating equations were used to control for clustering by providers. RESULTS: Children at intervention sites were more likely to have had a visit during the study period when their ADHD was being assessed. The ADHD template was used in 32% of visits where patients were specifically scheduled for ADHD assessment, and its use was associated with improved documentation of symptoms, treatment efficacy, and treatment side effects. CONCLUSIONS: EHR-based decision support improved the likelihood that children with ADHD had visits and care-related treatment for this condition. A better understanding of how to optimize provider use of decision support and templates could facilitate further improvements in care.

title: Feedback on electronic health records to improve antibiotic prescribing for acute respiratory infections
abstract: Aim: To study whether the Acute Respiratory Infection (ARI) Quality Dashboard, an electronic medical record (EHR)-based feedback system, has changed antibiotic prescribing. Study design: Cluster-randomized controlled study. Methods: We randomly assigned 27 primary care practices to receive the ARI Quality Dashboard or usual care. The primary outcome was the prescription rate of antibiotics for ARI visits. We also compared antibiotic prescribing between users and non-users of the ARI Quality Dashboard. Results: During the 9-month intervention, there was no difference between intervention and control practices in prescribing antibiotics for all ARI visits (47% vs = 0.68) or non-antibiotic-eligible ARI visits (38% vs 40%; P=0.70). Among the 258 interventional physicians, 72 (28%) used the ARI Quality Dashboard at least once a lower overall prescription rate of ARI antibiotics (42% vs. 50% for non-users; P=0.02). This difference was due to less antibiotic prescribing for non-antibiotic-eligible ARIs (32% vs. 43%; P=0.004). including nonstreptococcal pharyngitis (31% vs. 41%; P=0.01) and non-specific upper respiratory tract infections (19% vs. 34%; P=0.01) Conclusions: The ARI Quality Dashboard was not associated with an overall change in antibiotic prescribing for ARIs, although it has been associated with improved antibiotic prescribing when used. EHR-based quality reporting as part of 'wise use' m cannot improve care in the absence of other changes in primary care practice will. (Am J Manag Care. 2010;"16(12 Spec No.):e311-e319)

title: Decision support based on electronic health records to improve asthma care: a cluster-randomized study.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Asthma remains one of the most common chronic childhood diseases, affecting _x0001_6 million children in the United States. Although there are guidelines from the National Asthma Education Prevention Program that are widely recognized, previous studies have shown low compliance by physicians across a wide range of populations. We wanted to determine whether clinical decision support (CDS) embedded in an electronic health record (EHR) would improve clinical adherence to national asthma guidelines in primary care. METHODS: We conducted a prospective cluster-randomized study at 12 primary care sites over a 1-year period. Practices were stratified for analysis according to whether the location was urban or suburban. Children aged 0 to 18 years with persistent asthma were identified using the International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision Codes for Asthma. The 6 intervention practice sites had CDS alerts embedded in the EHR. Findings of interest were the proportion of children with at least 1 prescription for control medication, a current asthma care plan, and use of outpatient spirometry. RESULTS: The increase in the number of controller drug prescriptions was 6% higher (P 0.006) and 3% higher for spirometry (P 0.04) over time in the urban interventional offices. Submission of a current asthma care plan improved 14% (P 0.03) and spirometry improved 6% (P 0.003) in the suburban practices with the intervention. CONCLUSION: In our study, which used a cluster-randomized study design, CDS in the EHR at the point-of-care improved physician adherence to National Asthma Education Prevention Program guidelines. Pediatrics 2010;"125:e770-e777

title: Electronic health records for intervention research: a cluster-randomized study to reduce antibiotic prescribing in primary care (eCRT study)
abstract: PURPOSE This study aimed to conduct a point-of-care, randomized cluster study using electronic medical records. We evaluated the effectiveness of electronically delivered decision support tools in reducing antibiotic prescribing for respiratory infections in primary care. METHODS General practices from England and Scotland participating in the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD) were included in the study; 53 family practices were assigned to intervention and 51 practices to usual care. Patients aged 18 to 59 consulted for possible respiratory infections. The intervention was delivered through remotely installed, computer-aided decision support tools accessed during the consultations. Control practices represented usual care. The primary outcome was the proportion of consultations for respiratory infections with an antibiotic prescribed based on electronic medical records. Shares specific to GPs were included in an analysis at cluster level. RESULTS Data were analyzed for 603,409 patients: 317,717 in intervention practices and 285,692 in control practices. The utilization of the intervention was lower than expected and varied between practices in the proportion of consultations with prescription antibiotics bed of 1.85% (95% CI, 0.10%-3.59%, P = 0.038) and in the prescription rate of antibiotics in respiratory infections (9.69%; 95% CI, 0.75%-18.63%, fewer prescriptions per 1,000 patient-years, P=0.034). There were no adverse events. CONCLUSIONS Cluster-randomized trials can be efficiently implemented in large routine care samples using electronic medical records in primary care. Future studies should develop and test multicomponent methods for remote interventions.

title: Electronic Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) Clinical Reminder System Improves Adherence to Practice Guidelines in the University of Washington HIV Study Cohort.
abstract: We conducted a prospective study of an electronic clinical reminder system in a specialist human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) clinic at an academic medical center. Published performance indicators were used to examine adherence to HIV practice guidelines before and after implementation in 1204 patients. Greater than 90% of patients received monitoring of CD4 cell count and HIV type 1 (HIV-1) RNA levels every 3 to 6 months for both periods, and 80% of patients with a nadir CD4 cell count < 350 cells/mm3 received highly active antiretroviral therapy. Patients were significantly more likely to receive prophylaxis against Mycobacterium avium complex (hazard ratio, 3.84 inches; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.58-9.31; p=0.003) to avoid annual cervical cancer screened (OR, 2.09; 95% CI, 1.04-4.16; P=0.04) and underwent serological screening for Toxoplasma gondii (odds ratio [OR], 1.86; 95% CI, 1.05–3.27; P=0.03) and undergoing syphilis infection (OR, 3.71; 95% CI, 2.37–5.81; p<0.0001). Clinical HIV reminders submitted at the time of HIV care were associated with more timely initiation of recommended practices.

title: Electronic laboratory medicine ordering with evidence-based order sets in primary care (ELMO study): protocol for a cluster-randomized study
abstract: Background Laboratory testing is an important clinical process with a valuable role in the screening, diagnosis, management, and monitoring of disease or therapy. However, inappropriate laboratory test orders are common, straining healthcare spending and negatively impacting the quality of care. Inappropriate testing can also lead to false positive results and potentially cause excessive downstream activities. Clinical decision support systems (CDSSs) have shown promising results in influencing physician test ordering behavior and improving appropriateness. Order Sets, a form of CDSS that proposes a limited set of evidence-based tests for a range of indications integrated into a computerized physician order entry (CPOE), has been shown to be effective in reducing the volume of laboratory tests ordered, but is convincing evidence that they affect appropriateness is lacking. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effect of prescription sets on the quality and quantity of laboratory test prescriptions by physicians. We also aim to assess the impact of job sets on diagnostic errors and examine the impact on downstream or cascaded activities. Methods We conduct a cluster-randomized controlled study in Belgian GP practices. The study is designed to measure two outcomes. We will primarily measure the impact of our CDSS on the adequacy of laboratory test orders. In addition, we also measure the impact on diagnostic errors. We will also examine the impact of our intervention on cascading activities due to altered outcomes of inappropriate testing. Discussion We designed a study to show whether CDSS aimed at diagnostic testing can not only affect adequacy, but is also safe from diagnostic errors. These findings will feed into a larger nationwide implementation of this CDSS. Trial Registration ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT02950142.

title: Electronic health records to improve clinical management of tobacco dependence: a systematic review
abstract: CONTEXT: The expanded use of electronic medical records (EMRs) may provide an opportunity to increase the use and impact of clinical guidelines to promote tobacco cessation treatment in primary care. The aim of this systematic review is to assess the evidence for such an effect. Evidence gathering: After a systematic search of the English-language literature on an EMR effect on either smoking cessation or clinical behavior, relevant articles were summarized and results from both observational studies and RCTs were summarized. Evidence Synthesis: Out of ten identified studies on EMRs and tobacco, only two RCTs were found. The addition of tobacco status as a vital sign led to an increase in some measures recommended by clinical guidelines, notably the documentation of smoking status. There was insufficient evidence to quantify the effect of EMR on changes in patients' smoking behavior. CONCLUSIONS: While the use of EMRs for prompting or feedback for clinical management of tobacco dependence shows some promising results, significant additional research is needed to understand the impact of EMRs on provider and patient behavior.

title: Electronic prescribing increases acceptance of clinical pharmacologist recommendations in the hospital environment
abstract: OBJECTIVES To determine whether e-prescribing facilitates the implementation of clinical pharmacologists' recommendations to improve drug safety in hospitalized patients. METHODS Electronic case records and prescription tables (either electronic or paper) from 502 patients admitted to medical wards in a large Swiss teaching hospital between January 2009 and January 2010 were reviewed by four junior and four senior pharmacologists. Drug-related problems were identified and interventions suggested. The implementation and time delays of these proposed interventions were compared between the patients for whom paper medication cards were used and the patients for whom electronic medication cards were used. RESULTS From 109 hospital admissions, 158 drug-related problems were identified and 145 recommendations made, of which 51% were implemented. It was found that admissions with an electronic prescription card (n = 90) were 2.74 times more likely to implement the change than those with a paper prescription card (n = 53) (95% confidence interval 1.2, 6.3 , p=0.018, adjusted). for each dependency introduced by a patient, unit or clinical team";" follow-up for two missing cases). The time lag between making recommendations and implementing them (if any) was minimal (median 1 day) and did not differ between the two groups. CONCLUSIONS Electronic prescribing in this hospital setting was associated with improved drug safety improvement compared to increased implementation of clinical pharmacologist recommendations

title: Electronically distributed, computer-generated, individualized feedback enhances the use of a computer-assisted practice guide
abstract: Clinical guidelines were developed to aid in the management of patient care";" However, these guidelines are often neglected in clinical practice. Computer-generated reminders improve policy usage, but these systems often fail to achieve high policy usage rates. This study was designed to test the hypothesis that computer-generated, individualized feedback regarding adherence to treatment guidelines will significantly improve clinical compliance with guideline recommendations presented through a computer-assisted treatment protocol. Half of the 45 primary care clinicians employed at a primary care clinic affiliated with an academic medical center were randomized to receive an email message every two weeks consisting of a computer generated report detailing their/ his reaction to the recommendations of the care guideline for the diabetics examined were summarized in the last 2 weeks. Clinical compliance with guideline recommendations was the primary endpoint. This study showed that the intervention significantly increased clinical compliance with guideline recommendations without incurring high maintenance costs. Median compliance in the intervention group was 35% versus 6.1% in the control group (p<0.01). Electronically distributed, computer-generated, individualized feedback on physician application of nursing guideline recommendations is an effective way to improve adherence to a nursing guideline.

title: Email for clinical communication between healthcare professionals
abstract: BACKGROUND: Email is one of the most widely used communication methods, but its use in healthcare is still uncommon. Where email communication has been used in healthcare, its purpose has included clinical communication between healthcare professionals, but the impact of using email in this way is unknown. We have updated a 2012 review on the use of email for two-way clinical communication between healthcare professionals. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the impact of email for clinical communication between healthcare professionals on healthcare professional outcomes, patient outcomes, healthcare service performance, and service efficiency and acceptability compared to other forms of clinical information communication. SEARCH METHODS: We searched: Cochrane Consumers and Communication Review Group Specialized Register, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL, The Cochrane Library, Issue 9 2013), MEDLINE (OvidSP) (1946 to August 2013), EMBASE (OvidSP) (1974 to August 2013), PsycINFO (1967 to August 2013), CINAHL (EbscoHOST) (1982 to August 2013) and ERIC (CSA) (1965 to January 2010). We searched gray literature: theses/dissertations repositories, study registers and Google Scholar (search November 2013). We used additional search methods: checking reference lists and contacting authors. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials, quasi-randomized trials, controlled before-and-after trials, and interrupted time-series studies evaluating interventions in which healthcare professionals used email to deliver clinical information in the form of: 1) unsecured email, 2) more secure email, or 3) web messaging. All healthcare professionals, patients and caregivers in all settings were considered. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two authors independently assessed study inclusion, assessed the risk of bias of the included studies, and extracted data. We contacted the study authors for more information and reported all actions as per the study report. MAIN RESULTS: The previous version of this review included a randomized controlled trial with 327 patients and 159 healthcare providers at baseline. It compared an email to physicians containing patient-specific osteoporosis risk information and guidelines for assessment and treatment versus usual care (no email). This study had a high risk of bias in the assignment concealment and blinding domains. The email reminder significantly changed the actions of health care workers, as physicians were more likely to provide guideline-recommended osteoporosis treatment (bone densitometry or osteoporosis medication, or both) compared to usual care. Evidence of its effects on patient behavior or actions was inconclusive. One measure found that the electronic medical reminder message had a positive effect on patient behavior (patients had higher calcium intake), and two found no difference between the two groups. The study did not assess health outcomes or harm. No new studies were identified for this update. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: Only one study was identified for inclusion, providing insufficient clinical practice evidence related to the use of email for clinical communication between healthcare professionals. Future research should aim to use high-quality study designs that take advantage of the latest advances in information technology, while considering the complexities of email as an intervention.

title: Email for clinical communication between healthcare professionals
abstract: BACKGROUND: E-mail is a popular and commonly used method of communication, but its use in healthcare is not routine. Where email communication has been used in healthcare, its purpose has included use for clinical communication between healthcare professionals, but the impact of using email in this way is unknown. This review evaluates the use of email for two-way clinical communication between healthcare professionals. OBJECTIVES: To assess the impact of healthcare professionals using email to communicate clinical information on healthcare professional outcomes, patient outcomes, healthcare service performance, and service efficiency and acceptability compared to other forms of clinical information communication. SEARCH METHODS: We searched: Cochrane Consumers and Communication Review Group Specialized Register, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL, The Cochrane Library, Issue 1 2010), MEDLINE (OvidSP) (1950 to January 2010), EMBASE (OvidSP) (1980 to January 2010), PsycINFO (1967 to January 2010), CINAHL (EbscoHOST) (1982 to February 2010) and ERIC (CSA) (1965 to January 2010). We searched gray literature: theses/dissertations repositories, study registers and Google Scholar (search July 2010). We used additional search methods: reviewing bibliographies, contacting authors. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials, quasi-randomized trials, controlled before-and-after trials, and discontinuous time-series studies investigating interventions in which healthcare professionals used email to communicate clinical information and did so in the form of 1) unsecured email 2) secure email or 3) web messaging. All healthcare professionals, patients and caregivers in all settings were considered. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two authors independently assessed study inclusion, assessed the risk of bias of the included studies, and extracted data. We contacted study authors for more information. We report all measures according to the study report. MAIN RESULTS: We included a randomized controlled trial with 327 patients and 159 healthcare providers at baseline. It compared an email to physicians containing patient-specific osteoporosis risk information and guidelines for assessment and treatment with due diligence (no email). This study had a high risk of bias in the assignment concealment and blinding domains. The email reminder significantly changed how healthcare professionals act, as physicians are more likely to administer guideline-recommended osteoporosis treatment (bone densitometry and/or osteoporosis medication) compared to usual care. Evidence of its effects on patient behavior/acts has been inconclusive. One measure found that the electronic medical reminder message had a positive impact on patient behavior: patients had higher calcium intake, and two found no difference between the two groups. The study did not assess the outcomes or harms of primary health care. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: Because only one study was identified for inclusion, the results are insufficient to inform clinical practice regarding the use of email for clinical communication between healthcare professionals. Future research must use high-quality study designs that take advantage of the latest advances in information technology, while considering the complexity of email as an intervention and the cost.

title: Emergency psychiatric care for self-harming refugees and asylum seekers
abstract: This article describes the structure and function of emergency mental health care practice for self-harming refugees and asylum-seekers on temporary protection visas. Emergency nurses in accident and emergency rooms or as part of crisis intervention teams see self-harming refugees and asylum seekers on the brink of distress. This clinical paper is intended to support caregivers in their practice should they encounter an adult asylum seeker in need of emergency psychiatric care. Practical strategies are presented to help psychiatric nurses to assess, care for and comfort refugees and asylum seekers in this predicament. Where possible, mental health nurses should work closely with asylum seekers, their carers and accredited interpreters and translators to ensure appropriate language use when dealing with mental and emotional health issues, without further isolating the asylum seeker from appropriate services. To strengthen the continuity and integration of mental health support for refugees and asylum seekers, well-resourced care needs to be experienced as coherent and connected. A coherent, interdisciplinary and team-oriented approach will synthesize different points of view to shape clinical practice and create workable solutions in local situations.

title: Empower patients or general practitioners? A randomized clinical trial to improve the quality of reproductive healthcare in Belgium
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence-based clinical guidelines on contraceptive use have been developed and distributed to all Flemish General Practitioners (GPs) in Belgium. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of two strategies for implementing an oral contraceptive guideline to improve the quality of primary contraceptive advice in general practice, either by empowering patients or by introducing a computerized decision support system (CDSS). Method: A random sample of 45 general practitioners was divided into three study groups. One group was visited by an 'empowered patient', one group's electronic medical record was supplemented with a CDSS, and one group served as a control group. Simulated patients (SPs) evaluated the performance of general practitioners in daily practice before and after the procedures using a validated 48-item checklist. RESULTS: The baseline mean of the 43 general practitioners was 26.16 (SD = 5.76). The SPs received adequate information about taking the pills correctly, but not about factors related to pill failure and drug interactions. After the intervention, the mean value of the general practitioners was 26.39 (SD = 6.86). Only the intervention group with the “empowered patient” performed significantly better (29.92 [SD = 7.11]). The computer group and the control group performed worse (24.36 [SD = 6.60] and 24.82 [SD = 5.65], respectively). CONCLUSION: The development and dissemination of an evidence-based guideline has not changed the behavior of general practitioners. However, empowering patients to participate more proactively significantly improved primary care physician performance during contraception counseling. A CDSS does not.

title: Encouraging post-stroke patients to be more active seems possible: Results of an intervention study with knowledge facilitators
abstract: PURPOSE: Although physical activity and exercise are strongly recommended for stroke survivors for speedy recovery, patients in hospitals and rehabilitation centers are not sufficiently encouraged to be physically active. In this study, we examined the impact of knowledge facilitators (KBs), enterprising nurses, and therapists on health worker (HP) performance to encourage inpatient stroke survivors to engage in physical activity. METHOD: This multicenter intervention study used a pre-post test design. Two or three AIs were trained in each stroke unit of 12 hospitals and 10 rehabilitation centers in the Netherlands. Questionnaires were filled out by patients and HPs before and after the AI intervention. The primary outcome was the HPs' encouragement to their patients to be physically active, as reported by patients and HPs. RESULTS: After the AI intervention, many more patients (48%; N=217) reported at least some encouragement from HPs to be physically active than before (26%; N=243, p<0.000). HPs (N=288) were, on average, more likely to report encouraging patients after the intervention, but this difference was only significant for occupational therapists and KBs. CONCLUSIONS: Based on the patient reports of HP behavior, the AI intervention appears to be effective as more patients felt encouraged to be physically active after the intervention compared to before. Replication of this study in an experimental design is required to allow causal conclusions. Implications for Rehabilitation We advise rehabilitation teams to use knowledge brokers (KBs) because the KB intervention increases the perceived encouragement for physical activity by stroke patients. It makes sense to involve physicians, nurses and patients' relatives more often in efforts to encourage stroke patients to be physically active.

title: Improved implementation of guidelines for back pain in general practice: study protocol of a randomized controlled cluster study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence-based clinical practice guidelines can improve quality of care, but uptake of guideline recommendations is often incomplete and slow. New guidelines for back pain have recently been introduced in Denmark. The guidelines aim to reduce personal and public costs. The aim of this study is to evaluate whether a complex, multifaceted implementation strategy of the low back pain guidelines reduces referral to secondary care and improves patient outcomes compared to the usual simple implementation strategy. METHODS/DESIGN: 100 general practices (clusters) and 2,700 patients aged 18 to 65 years from the region of Northern Denmark are included in a two-arm randomized cluster study. Practices are randomly assigned 1:1 to a simple or a complex implementation strategy. Intervention practices receive a complex implementation strategy, including guideline facilitator visits, stratification tools, and quality reports for treating low back pain. The primary outcome is referral to secondary care. Secondary endpoints are pain, physical functioning, health-related quality of life, patient satisfaction with care and treatment outcome, employment status, and sick leave. Primary and secondary results relate to the patient level. The assessment of the results is blinded and follows the intention-to-treat principle. In addition, a process assessment will assess the degree to which the intervention elements are being delivered as planned, as well as measure changes in beliefs and behaviors among primary care physicians and patients. DISCUSSION: This study provides knowledge about the process and impact of an intervention to implement guidelines for low back pain in general practice and will provide insight into key elements that should be included in future implementation strategies in general practice. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Registered as NCT01699256 on ClinicalTrials.gov.

title: Improved physician adherence to antibiotic use guidelines through increased availability of guidelines at the time of drug ordering in the hospital.
abstract: Purpose Some studies have shown that prescribing practice could be improved if practical guidelines are made available to physicians when making clinical decisions. The aim of the study was to assess the utility of the effects on physician adherence of the intervention, which consisted of embedding previously paper-based antibiotic guidelines into a teaching hospital's computerized drug prescription entry system, in order to make these guidelines available to physicians at the time the antibiotic order. Before the operation, these guidelines were available as a brochure on all wards of the hospital. Methods Adherence to guidelines was assessed for 471 consecutive antibiotic prescriptions for pneumonia, 104 immediately before and 367 immediately after the intervention. The evaluation criteria were: the choice of antibiotic in relation to the context of acquiring pneumonia, the daily dose, the planned duration of treatment. Antibiotic prescriptions were assessed at the start of antibiotic treatment. Results The intervention was followed by a significant decrease in the proportion of antibiotic prescriptions containing at least one criterion of nonconformity with guidelines, 33% after vs. 51% (p?<?0.001) before the intervention. Proportion of non-compliant orders in the post- vs. pre-intervention phase for the daily antibiotic dosage respectively 12.2% vs. 26.9% (p? <? 0.001), for the planned treatment duration 7.3% vs. 18, respectively .3% (p?<?0.001), while the improvement in the choice of antibiotic relative to the context of acquiring pneumonia did not reach statistical significance, 18.2% vs. 25% respectively (p?=?0.12). Conclusion In this study, the increased availability of antibiotic guidelines at the time of drug ordering, combined with regular rounds of reinforcement education, was associated with improved physician adherence to these guidelines. Copyright © 2010 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

title: Improving Access to Pharmacotherapy and Treatment of Alcohol Use Disorders in Primary Care: ADaPT-PC
abstract: Background Only 7.8% of individuals who meet diagnostic criteria for alcohol use disorder (AUD) receive treatment in any given year. Most individuals with AUDs are identified in primary care (PC) and referred to substance use disorder (SUD) clinics. However, only a minority of referred individuals participate in treatment services. There are safe and effective pharmacological treatments for AUD, but they are rarely prescribed by PC providers. The aim of this study is to refine, implement, and evaluate an intervention to integrate pharmacological AUD treatment options into PC settings. This paper contains a detailed description of the intervention design and the evaluation components. Methods/Design Three major Veterans Health Administration (VHA) facilities are participating in the intervention. The intervention targets stakeholders with tailored strategies based on implementation theory and previous research that identify barriers to implementing AUD pharmacotherapy. Local SUD providers and mental health integration (PCMHI) providers in primary care will be trained to act as local implementation/clinical champions and receive external support. PC providers gain access to advice from local and national clinical champions, educational materials and a dashboard from patients with AUD to their caseloads for case identification. Veterans with AUD diagnoses will receive intelligence information in the mail just before a scheduled PC visit. The effectiveness of the intervention will be assessed through an intermittent time series with matched controls to monitor the change in facility-level AUD pharmacotherapy prescribing rates. According to Stetler's four-phase formative evaluation (FE) strategy, FE methods include (1) development FE (pre-implementation interviews with champions, PC vendors and veterans), (2) implementation-oriented FE (tracking attendance at facilitation meetings, efforts to academic detailing through local champions and use of patient dashboard), (3) progression-oriented RD (tracking AUD pharmacotherapy prescription rates and referral rates to PCMHI and SUD specialty care), and (4) interpretive RD (post-implementation interviews with champions and PC -providers). Analysis of the FE data is guided by the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research (CFIR). Discussion If proven successful, this implementation strategy will provide a reproducible, feasible, and relatively inexpensive method of integrating AUD treatment services into PC settings, thereby increasing access to AUD treatment.

title: Improving evidence-based control of diabetes and chronic diseases in local health authorities: a multi-phase dissemination study with a randomized study component with step wedge clusters
abstract: Background Diabetes and pre-diabetes rates are increasing in the United States, severely affecting the quality of life and life expectancy of those diagnosed and placing a financial burden on society. Premature death and disability can be prevented through the implementation of evidence-based programs and policies (EBPPs). Local Health Departments (LHDs) are uniquely positioned to implement EBPPs for diabetes control because they understand and focus on community-level needs, contexts and resources. However, there is a significant gap between the known diabetes control EBPPs and the actual diabetes control activities performed by LHDs. The purpose of this study is to determine how best to support the use of evidence-based public health for the control of diabetes (and related chronic diseases) by public health practitioners at the local level. Methods/Design This paper describes the methods for a two-phase, randomized, stepped-wedge cluster study that will evaluate dissemination strategies to increase uptake of public health knowledge and EBPPs for diabetes control among LHDs. Phase 1 includes the development of measures to assess practitioner views on and organizational support for evidence-based public health, data collection using an online national survey of chronic disease LHD practitioners, and a needs assessment of factors supporting the uptake of EBPPs for Diabetes control at LHDs affect within one state in the US. Phase 2 involves conducting a randomized step-wedge cluster study to evaluate the effectiveness of outreach strategies with practitioners at the local level in LHDs to improve capacity and organizational support for evidence-based diabetes prevention and control. Twelve LHDs will be selected and randomly assigned to one of three groups that deviate from standard practice to receive the intervention (dissemination) strategies at 8-month intervals”; The intervention duration for groups is 8 to 24 months. Intervention (dissemination) strategies may include multi-day face-to-face workshops, electronic information-sharing methods, technical support from a knowledge broker, and organizational changes to support evidence-based public health approaches. Assessment methods include surveys at baseline and at the three transition points, abstraction of program plans and progress reports on diabetes and chronic diseases at the local level, and social network analysis to understand the relationships and contextual issues affecting EBPP adoption.

title: Improving referral for mammography in primary care
abstract: Background. This 1-year, randomized study tested the effectiveness of behavioral techniques in increasing the number of primary care physician referrals for mammography in small group practices. METHODS: Sixty-one practices were randomly assigned to one of three conditions: (1) education control only, (2) education plus cue enhancement with mammography chart stickers, and (3) education plus cue enhancement plus feedback and token rewards. Quarterly desk reviews of a defined sample (N = 11,716) of female patients aged 50 years and older were conducted to document mammography referrals, completion, and compliance. Results. Referral and completion rates increased from baseline through Q1 and then gradually declined thereafter. Overall, these rates were higher in the cuing condition than in the control condition. In contrast, compliance rates in both experimental conditions increased over the year while remaining static in the control condition, showing a strong and persistent effect for cue improvement. The increases in compliance were greatest among older non-white physicians with a second specialty, in single practice, without members of the AMA, without residency training, and without board certification. Conclusions. Chart stickers can significantly increase the use of mammography in small group practices. These practices are an efficient way to reach large numbers of older women who need mammography screening.

title: Strengthening of the African Bioethics Initiative
abstract: BACKGROUND: Medical ethics has existed since Hippocrates. However, formal training in bioethics only became established a few decades ago. Bioethics has gained a firm place in the health sciences in developed countries, particularly in Europe and North America. The situation is very different in many developing countries. Bioethics, as established and practiced in the West today, does not exist in most African countries or only exists in a rudimentary form. DISCUSSION: Although bioethics has come of age in developed and some developing countries, it is still largely 'alien' to most African countries. A number of bioethics conferences have been held in some parts of Africa over the past decade to raise awareness of research ethics and ensure conformance with international guidelines for research involving human participants. This idea arose in recognition of the real need to develop research ethics review capacities in Africa. It is also a condition required by external sponsors of collaborative research in Africa. The awareness and interest generated by these conferences needs to be further strengthened and extended beyond research ethics to clinical practice. Broadly speaking, bioethics education in schools that train physicians and other healthcare providers is the hook that enshrines both research ethics and clinical ethics. SUMMARY: This communication provides an overview of the current situation of bioethics in Africa in relation to research ethics workshops and suggests that despite current efforts to integrate ethics into biomedical research in Africa, much remains to be done to do so reach. A more comprehensive approach to bioethics with overarching benefits is to integrate formal ethics education into health education institutions in Africa.

title: Improving the algorithm for developmental behavior monitoring and screening in children aged 0-5 years
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine whether the American Academy of Pediatrics' 2006 developmental monitoring and screening algorithm is appropriate or whether revisions are needed. METHODS: A comprehensive literature review was conducted to assess a clinician's ability to conduct developmental and behavioral monitoring in children aged 0 to 5 years. RESULTS: Although broad-spectrum developmental screening is typical, pediatricians should refer when they confidently suspect a delay but be much more suspicious of children who appear asymptomatic. Regular screening improves surveillance by improving early detection and early intervention (EI) eligibility rates. Still, children with worrying screens are not consistently referred to EI and connected to each other. After referral, approximately half are considered EI ineligible, although they typically underperform significantly and have numerous, predictive academic and psychosocial risk factors. Meanwhile, clinicians are struggling to track down children at risk. CONCLUSION: Revisions are needed to streamline early detection, prevention, and surveillance. Greater emphasis needs to be placed on encouraging developmental behavior and coordinating referral provision.

title: Improving the quality of antibiotic prescribing in primary care: qualitative evaluation of a blended learning intervention
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Stemming the Tide of Antibiotic Resistance (STAR) educational program aims to improve the quality of antibiotic prescribing and raise awareness of antibiotic resistance among general practitioners. It consists of a seven-part, theory-based, blended learning program that includes online reflections on clinicians' own practice, presentation of research and guidelines, a practice-based seminar focusing on participants' own antibiotic prescribing, and resistance rates in urine samples from their practice , communication training with videos of simulated patients in routine operations and participation in a web forum. Efficacy was assessed in a randomized controlled trial involving 244 home health nurses and 68 general practices. This paper reports part of the process evaluation of this study. Methods: Semi-structured, digitally recorded and transcribed telephone interviews with 31 specifically selected study participants, who were evaluated using thematic content analysis. RESULTS: The majority of participants reported increased awareness of antibiotic resistance, greater confidence in reducing antibiotic prescribing, and at least some change in counseling style and antibiotic prescribing behavior. Reported practical changes included the adoption of a practice-wide policy to reduce antibiotic prescribing. Many GPs also reported better insight into patient expectations, ultimately contributing to an improved doctor-patient relationship. The components of the intervention that have the greatest impact on changing clinical behavior were up-to-date research resources, simple and effective communication skills presented in online videos, and the presentation of real-world antibiotic prescription levels combined with a review of local resistance data . CONCLUSION: Participants considered this complex blended learning intervention acceptable and feasible and reported widespread, positive changes in attitude and clinical practice as a result of participation in the STAR educational program. STUDY REGISTRATION: Current controlled studies ISRCTN63355948.

title: Epidemiology for the uninitiated. Etiology of the disease - selection of controls
Epidemiology of presenile dementia from Alzheimer's in Scotland, 1974-88
abstract: OBJECTIVE To describe the epidemiology of presenile Alzheimer's disease in Scotland from 1974 to 1988. DESIGN To retrospectively review the hospital records of patients less than 73 years of age admitted to psychiatric hospitals with various diagnoses of dementia. Diagnoses were classified using the National Institute for Communicative Disorders and Stroke and Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association criteria and the Hachinski score. The completeness of the study sample was assessed by reviewing the neurological outpatient and general hospital records. RECRUITMENT All general psychiatric hospitals in Scotland. PARTICIPANTS All patients with incipient dementia aged 40-64. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Probable and prevalent Alzheimer's disease, patient gender, age at onset. RESULTS 5874 records from psychiatric hospitals, 129 records from neurological outpatient departments and 89 records from non-psychiatric hospitals were examined. 317 patients met criteria for probable Alzheimer's disease, 569 met criteria for broad Alzheimer's disease, and 267 met criteria for multi-infarct dementia. The minimum incidences per 100,000 population aged 40 to 64 were 22.6 (95% confidence interval, 20.2 to 25.2) and 40.5 (38.9 to 42.3) per 100,000 for the probable and broad Alzheimer's disease. In the 1981 census year, the annual incidence of probable Alzheimer's disease was 1.6 (1.0 to 2.6). Women were at higher risk with incidence rates for probable Alzheimer's disease of 28.2 (24.5 to 32.4) per 100,000 compared to 16.5 (13.8 to 19.8) per 100,000 in men. The incidence per 100,000 for multi-infarct dementia was higher in men (25.1, 23.3 to 27.1) than in women (13.4, 12.1 to 14.8). CONCLUSION Female gender appears to be positively associated with developing Alzheimer's disease before the age of 65 years.

title: epilepsy and employment
Erratum on: Towards common terminology: a simplified intervention framework for promoting and integrating evidence into health care practices, systems and policies
ESHRE guideline: Routine psychosocial support for infertility and medically assisted reproduction - a guide for fertility workers
abstract: STUDY QUESTION: Based on the best available evidence in the literature, what is the optimal management of routine psychosocial care in infertility and medically assisted reproductive (MAR) clinics? SUMMARY ANSWER: Using the structured methodology of the European Society for Human Reproduction and Embryology (ESHRE) Guideline Development Manual, 120 recommendations were formulated that answered the 12 key questions on how best to manage routine psychosocial care by all fertility workers. WHAT IS ALREADY KNOWN: The 2002 ESHRE Guidelines for Infertility Counseling have been a reference point for the best infertility mental health care for years, but this guideline needed updating and did not focus on routine mental health care provided by all fertility workers can. STUDY, DESIGN, SIZE, DURATION: This guideline was developed by a group of experts in the field according to the 12-step process outlined in the ESHRE guideline development guide. After defining the scope of the guideline and listing a set of 12 key questions in PICO (Patient, Intervention, Comparison and Outcome) format, a thorough systematic literature review was conducted";" Evidence from papers published up to April 2014 was collected, assessed for quality and analyzed. In response to each of the key questions, a summary of the evidence was written, which served as the basis for recommendations defined by consensus within the Guideline Development Group (GDG). Patient and additional clinical input was collected during the scoping and review phase of guideline development. PARTICIPANTS/MATERIALS, SETTING, METHODS: The guideline panel, consisting of psychologists, two physicians, a midwife, a patient advocate and a methodology expert, met three times to discuss evidence and reach consensus on the recommendations. KEY FINDINGS AND THE ROLE OF CHANCE THE GUIDELINE OFFERS: 120 recommendations aimed at guiding fertility clinic staff in providing optimal evidence-based routine psychosocial care for patients with infertility and MAR. The policy is divided into two sections. The first section describes patients' preferences regarding the psychosocial care they would like to receive in clinics and how this care relates to their well-being. The second section of the guideline provides information on the psychosocial needs of patients throughout their treatment course (before, during and after treatment) and how fertility clinic staff can identify and address them. Needs refer to conditions that are believed to be necessary for patients to have a healthy experience of fertility treatment. Needs can be behavioral (lifestyle, exercise, diet, and compliance), relational (relationship with partner, if any, family, friends, and larger network and work), emotional (well-being, e.g., anxiety, depression, and quality of life), and cognitive (treatment concerns). and know). LIMITATIONS, REASONS FOR CAUTION: We have identified many areas of nursing where robust evidence is lacking. Evidence gaps have been filled by formulating good practice points based on GDG expert opinion, but it is crucial that such recommendations are empirically validated. SUBSEQUENT IMPLICATIONS OF RESULTS: The evidence presented in this guideline demonstrates that the provision of routine mental health care is associated with, or has the potential to reduce, stress and concerns about medical procedures, and the outcomes of lifestyle, knowledge about To improve fertility, patient well-being and treatment adherence. Because only 45 (36.0%) of the 125 recommendations were based on high-quality evidence, the guideline group made recommendations for future research aimed at expanding the evidence base.

title: Essential elements of an early intervention service for psychosis: the opinions of experienced clinicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: Early intervention teams attempt to improve outcome in schizophrenia through earlier detection and the provision of phase-specific treatments. As the number of early intervention teams grows, there is a lack of clarity about their essential structural and functional elements. METHODS: A 'Delphi' exercise was conducted to determine the degree of consensus on the essential elements of early intervention teams in a group of 21 UK specialist physicians. Using published guidelines, an initial list was created containing 151 items across ten categories of team structure and function. RESULTS: Overall, there was expert consensus on the importance of 136 (90%) of these items. Of the items for which there was consensus, 106 (70.2%) were rated as essential, meaning that without them the team's ability to function would be severely impaired. CONCLUSION: This level of consensus on key elements suggests that it is reasonable to define a model for UK early intervention teams from which a measure of accuracy could be derived.

title: Fundamentals of research ethics for healthcare professionals
abstract: Whether conducted in a university setting or in the healthcare setting, research involving humans raises a variety of ethical issues for healthcare professionals. In the ongoing professional development of ethical research methods, both clinicians and researchers need to expand their knowledge to obtain answers to the following questions: Which ethical theories serve as a basis for ethical principles in research ethics? What ethical principles should a researcher respect when conducting research involving human subjects? What does it mean to conduct ethical research? What ethical dilemmas does a researcher face when conducting research? This paper provides an overview of ethical theories and the ethical basis of guidelines developed and used to guide research involving humans. Ethical behavior and the personal responsibility of the researcher conducting research involving humans are discussed along with ethical considerations in research designs and methods.

title: Establishing collaborations in translational and clinical cancer research between high- and low-income countries
abstract: Both infectious and non-infectious malignancies are a growing problem in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). It is difficult to extrapolate cancer treatment data and guidelines from high-income countries (HIC) to cancer patients in LMIC. With noncommunicable cancer rates rising, there is a growing gap between the need for evidence-based treatments for cancer control plans and existing research capacities. Surgeons often provide all surgical and medical oncology treatments to patients in LMIC for diseases such as breast, gastric, cervical, and colon cancer. However, clinical and translational research collaborations in surgical oncology are lacking. There are several successful consortia that focus on HIV and infection-related malignancies. These collaborations can serve as an example for future surgical research efforts. The collaboration between Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and Nigeria, focused on colon cancer, is used as an example of how to initiate a research collaboration that can build research infrastructure and provide the necessary data to create realistic treatment guidelines. The need for expanded surgical oncology research and the growing population of patients with non-infectious malignancies at the LMIC has created a unique opportunity for surgeons to initiate and lead clinical and translational research collaborations between the HIC and the LMIC.

title: Ethical Aerobics: ACHRE's escape from responsibility
abstract: The President's Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experimentation (ACHRE) was tasked with conducting a comprehensive ethical review of US government-funded radiation experimentation. In these experiments, several hundred thousand people were used as test subjects in several thousand experiments. This paper provides an overview of the ACHRE final report issued in October 1995. ACHRE did not recommend an apology or compensation for the vast majority of victims. Her justification for this decision was plagued with inconsistencies. Whenever facts could not be recontextualized to reduce the apparent wrongdoing of government-funded researchers, ACHRE engineered ethical loopholes to avoid conviction of the perpetrators. We critique ACHRE's recommendations through a careful analysis of their own recordings and transcripts. We. Providing an accurate history of informed consent standards in human research, in contrast to ACHRE's inconsistent history. We also provide a detailed review of ACHRE's flawed risk analysis in two representative sets of experiments.

title: Ethical and Institutional Review Board Questions
abstract: IRBs play an important role in protecting research subjects/patients. As healthcare professionals, researchers have an inherent potential conflict of interest";" As physicians, they are dedicated to promoting the well-being of individual patients, while as researchers, they seek knowledge that can be generalized and applicable to people other than the individual patient being studied. The second goal may conflict with the first. IRBs have a primary responsibility to protect the rights and welfare of human research subjects. Although the IRB system is not perfect, conscientious IRBs assure the public that the rights and welfare of human subjects are given serious consideration by those who have no vested interest in the outcome of the research. By discharging their responsibilities, IRBs promote the protection of human subjects. IRB approval represents a significant endorsement of the scientific and ethical quality of the research and therefore provides important validation for research and research researchers. IRBs, acting in accordance with the guiding principles of the Belmont Report and within the regulatory guidelines of 45.CFR.46, are intended to strike a balance between the societal interest in advancing scientific knowledge and the mandate to protect the rights and well-being of human subjects.

title: Ethical and legal risks of archival research
abstract: Psychiatric facilities and practitioners typically allow researchers direct access to patient records for archival research purposes without the informed consent of patient participants. Typically, these researchers have access to any information in such records so long as they agree to maintain confidentiality and remove any identifying data from subsequent research reports. Changes in the American Psychological Association's Code of Ethics (American Psychological Association, 1992) raise ethical and legal issues that need to be considered by practitioners, researchers, and the institution's institutional review boards. This article addresses these issues and provides recommendations for changes in ethical standards and alternative ways of conducting research using archived mental health records.

title: Ethical complications of clinical therapeutic research in children
abstract: The usual discussion by ethicists and physicians about the ethical implications of research into children with catastrophic diseases and the guidelines established by the federal government for that research is based on the application of general moral principles to problems. Whatever the merits of this approach to policy-making, it does not adequately reflect the life situation of patients and the complexity of a single regimen that is both therapeutic and research-oriented at the same time. The problems also become more complex when parents disagree about the course of treatment. We believe that such cases are properly resolved by considering the degree of paternalism that the clinician-researcher must exercise.";" KIE: Much of the discussion of ethical issues in therapeutic research involving children is based on the application of general moral principles to problem categories. The authors believe that this approach does not adequately reflect the complexity of a treatment regimen that is both therapeutic and research-oriented for catastrophically ill children. Using a case study to illustrate the possible complications of such a situation, they argue that medical paternalism is justified in therapeutic research on children even when it compromises the patient's autonomy, since the patient's well-being must prevail over the preservation of the child's fullness Autonomy.

title: Ethical considerations for human research
Ethical considerations in recruiting study participants from hospitalized cardiovascular patient populations
abstract: Cardiovascular research nurses play an important role in ensuring that subject recruitment is conducted in an ethical manner. However, as research progresses, these caregivers encounter many ethical challenges. Sole reliance on regulatory mechanisms such as oversight by institutional review boards and compliance with legal requirements does not necessarily ensure the protection of human subjects or the scientific integrity of researchers (J Law Med Ethics. 2002";"30:411-419). Therefore, this article discusses 3 additional ethical considerations related to the recruitment of hospitalized cardiovascular patients for research studies. These include (a) the role of family and patient-delegated gatekeepers, (b) the impact of transient and subtle changes in mental status on the consent process, and (c) the impact of conflicting patient priorities. This content is illustrated through the authors' experiences in recruiting patients undergoing in-hospital coronary artery bypass graft surgery for a research study.

title: Ethical dilemmas in qualitative research: how do we respect autonomy?
abstract: This paper sheds light on the concept of nursing research and specifically examines the principle of respect for autonomy, its relationship and limitations in the field of human research during qualitative research. This paper will also show how ethical dilemmas involving respect for autonomy can evolve during research and will present a systematic method of critical ethical analysis to show how nursing researchers can resolve such issues, if and when they occur. It is necessary to focus on one aspect of the research process to illustrate the "depth" of thought required to ensure that such research is of the highest quality.

title: Ethical genetic research in humans
abstract: Since the Nuremberg Trials and the Nazi Doctors' Trial after World War II, international ethical protocols have emerged aimed at protecting people from the cruelty of medical experimentation, which was literally routine under the Nazis. Some of the obvious "lessons" of the Nazi era were summed up in the Declaration of Helsinki, perhaps the leading medical ethics protocol. This paper argues that these protocols were not particularly conducive to human welfare or the protection of human rights in the field of human genetics research. The paper proposes new protocols and a new approach to the ethics of human research.

title: Ethical issues in the management of chronic non-malignant pain
abstract: Chronic pain presents a challenge for patients, families, employers and the doctors who care for these individuals. Opioids remain the mainstay of analgesic drugs for the treatment of both acute and chronic pain. Controlled-release preparations of morphine, oxycodone, fentanyl, and long-acting opioids such as methadone and levorphanol are medically and ethically accepted in the management of chronic cancer pain. However, the continued use of these drugs in patients with chronic non-cancer pain has been hotly debated. This article attempts to reconcile the medical and ethical dilemmas of using opioid medications for chronic non-cancer pain. Increasing clinical experience in the field of pain medicine has helped to clarify: (1) the misconception of addiction, physical dependence, and analgesic tolerance, (2) the misconception that chronic opioid therapy inevitably causes personality changes, depression, and impairment of cognitive and physical function , (3) the lack of information on the correct use of opioid analgesics with regard to titration and the management of associated side effects. The behavioral management of pain patients undergoing chronic opioid therapy is also discussed. A protocol for optimal patient management is proposed. Particular attention is paid to the form of consent, behavioral agreements and the consequences of non-compliance. It emphasizes the importance of psychological assessment prior to long-term opioid trials to minimize future complications. Although most patients do well on opioid therapy, special attention needs to be paid to patients with current addiction, a history of addiction, or current abuse of opioid drugs. In patients with significant behavioral problems, pharmacological and conservative interventions are often warranted. When such strategies fail and chronic opioid therapy is deemed necessary, some treatment guidelines are offered.

title: Ethical rules for innovative surgery: the final frontier?
abstract: BACKGROUND: There are no clear federal regulations for innovative surgery, although general guidelines for human research do exist. We hypothesized that US surgeons are unaware of Department of Health regulations, rarely seek IRB review, are generally resistant to external regulation of innovative surgery, and are uncertain about what constitutes innovation and research. These circumstances, if true, would pose a significant ethical problem and potentially harm patients as ignorant research subjects. STUDY DESIGN: In a pilot study, we reviewed 527 issues of US surgical and medical journals and selected 59 articles published between 1992 and 2000 that described innovative surgery. Corresponding authors from university hospitals (71%) and other institutions (29%) received an anonymous questionnaire. RESULTS: The survey was conducted between November 2000 and May 2001. Twenty-one completed questionnaires were returned, representing an overall response rate of 35%. Fourteen authors confirmed that their work was research, but only six had requested prior review by the IRB. The majority of authors (15 out of 21) did not submit their protocol to the IRB. Only seven authors had mentioned the innovative nature of the procedure in the informed consent form. Seven authors reported being familiar with the Office for Human Research Protections definitions of research and human subject. Two-thirds of respondents indicated that government regulations protecting human subjects undergoing innovative surgery are not adequate. CONCLUSIONS: The current system of definitions, ethical theories, and voluntary professional guidelines may not be sufficient to meet the challenge of surgical innovation. Further research is proposed to assess the adequacy of existing guidance.

title: Ethical requirements that must be met before introducing new processes
abstract: In order for the orthopedic care of patients to continue to improve, new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches must be constantly developed. In order to verify that a new approach actually delivers better results, these innovations must be subjected to rigorous scientific investigations. However, since the results of clinical interventions can only be examined in humans, these studies must not only meet scientific criteria, but also strict ethical criteria. The Declaration of Helsinki, a World Medical Association document originally drafted in 1964, revised substantially in 1975 and last revised in 1996, provides guidelines for such studies. In addition to meeting ethical requirements, clinical investigators are also faced with various complex issues that need to be addressed when conducting clinical research studies. One of the most difficult issues is the conflict between a physician's concern for the well-being of their patients and the need for protocol-driven studies. No matter how excited surgeons may be about a new therapeutic approach, they must recognize that they have a responsibility to scientifically validate their innovative approach with a well-controlled clinical trial using valid functional outcome measures.

title: Ethical review of proposals to evaluate health promotion programs
abstract: Some guidelines state that program evaluation falls within the scope of administrative research that does not require review by an ethics committee. We suggest that some evaluations of health promotion programs include at least one research element and can be distinguished from quality assurance. Although American and Canadian evaluation societies provide important guidelines and standards for evaluation practitioners, processes for public accountability are provided by research ethics committees. The field of health promotion is inherently fraught with challenges for existing research ethics committees. Given the paucity of published literature on the ethics of evaluation or health promotion practice, the area could benefit from the open debate encouraged by reviews of proposals.

title: ethics committees and the achievement of good clinical practice
abstract: Local ethics committees (Institutional Review Boards or similar bodies) have been established at (bio)medical research institutions worldwide over the last few decades to act as review boards of proposed research projects (including clinical trial protocols) and also to monitor whether the ethical principles, including the Good practice requirements (clinical, laboratory and scientific) are respected and fulfilled when conducting research projects. The existing pluralism of the philosophical background on which contemporary theories of bioethics are developed seriously challenges the ancient traditions of Hippocratic, non-utilitarian medical ethics and seeks to promote more utilitarian and secular approaches. Individual physicians or researchers, as well as the ethics committee itself, are today confronted with complicated ethical dilemmas, which often have to be resolved in an atmosphere of considerable social, collegial, economic and time pressures, and sometimes without helpful guidance and adequate legislation. An interesting way to overcome some of the pitfalls of the ethics review process is to establish shared ethical responsibility for the research project or study protocol in a statement by most (or all) of the parties involved (e.g. ethics committee, patient, "society"). Such an approach has proved helpful to improve the concrete deliberations of the ethics committees established in Slovakia since 1991 according to the requirements of the national guidelines issued by the Slovak Ministry of Health.

title: Ethics committees and pediatric research: a personal perspective
abstract: The monitoring of clinical research involving children or tissue removed from them is becoming more formalized and sophisticated. It can be assumed that many physicians and most paediatricians will be offered the opportunity to serve on pediatric institutional ethics committees (IECs) at some stage in their careers. Fearless and independent ethics committees have significant influence on both the design and conduct of clinical research and the subjects of valid research involving infants and children. The composition of IECs is generally intended to provide a balance of gender, professional background, and institutional and non-institutional affiliations. In addition to these now well-established compositional guidelines, IECs making decisions about pediatric research have a pragmatic requirement for three additional specific roles: that of in loco parentis, in loco infanti, and the special role of nursing staff. These roles and the ethical basis for them are defined. Furthermore, the role of in loco parentis is ethnically complex and an IEC considering this role should be aware of its implications. Pediatric research projects involve not only specific risks inherent in the project concerned, but also more general risks inherent in any clinical research project itself. Pediatric IECs should act in a manner of encouragement rather than just 'physician observers' and should insist from the outset on the publication of results as a condition of permission to conduct the research in question. A particularly effective form of ethical review is the national and international peer review that follows such publication of pediatric research. This report discusses these specific issues in the evolving context of increased surveillance of pediatric research.

title: Ethics committees in Italy: a survey of oncologists
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND BACKGROUND: The mission of physicians and the purpose of clinical research can lead to a conflict between medical ethics and human rights. All recommendations, guidelines, and laws regarding experimental interventions require a formal protocol, approval by an ethics committee (EC), and written informed consent from potential participants. In Italy, new guidelines on handling submissions to EC were published in 1998. A year later, there was a feeling among those involved in EC activities that the new rules (i.e. decentralization and emphasis on pharmacological aspects of the studies) would have an immediate negative impact. A prospective study was launched to evaluate oncologists' opinions on the functioning of the Italian EG. METHODS AND STUDY DESIGN: A questionnaire was distributed twice to 110 oncologists participating in two multicenter studies. Nine questions were included on the following aspects: existence of an EC at the hospital level, personal experience of an EC, average time taken to evaluate submitted proposals, and level of satisfaction with key functions of the EC. RESULTS: Responses were received from 93 (first survey) and 69 (second survey) physicians. In both surveys, clinicians indicated that they were satisfied with the scientific and ethical aspects of the EC function but dissatisfied with the educational activities and training, and the bureaucratic and bureaucratic requirements. In the second survey, the average time required for the evaluation after submission of a study protocol was about 2.4 months and dissatisfaction was still high for some critical aspects such as bureaucracy (44%) and educational activities and training (64%). . The analysis of the change over time documented small differences (from -8% to +7%) in all assessed aspects. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the limitations of the present study, i.e. the small sample size and the intrinsic characteristics of the Italian environment, the results add empirical evidence regarding the functioning of the local EC and the opinions of clinical researchers. This experience confirms that empirical studies of medical ethics are feasible and can provide useful information to facilitate the implementation of EC in the medical and lay community.

title: Ethics of Innovative Surgery: Definitions, Knowledge, and Attitudes of US Surgeons
abstract: BACKGROUND: Innovative surgery is not clearly defined, nor is it formally regulated by governing bodies, as is the case with drug and medical device development. This unclear status and the associated questionable applicability of existing federal guidelines for human research give rise to ethical concerns. To clarify his position, we asked US surgeons for definitions, opinions and attitudes towards innovative surgery. Surgeons were also invited to share their knowledge of the current federal regulations governing human research and the rules for informed consent and IRB review of clinical research itself. STUDY DESIGN: A group of US surgeons received a 46-item questionnaire addressing the definition of innovative surgery versus research and practice, human research regulations, the need for specific informed consent, and the IRB review of surgical innovations. RESULTS: A total of 665 responses were included in the content analysis. Respondents expressed a rather cautious attitude when assessing hypothetical innovative scenarios. Characteristics of experimentation and clinical research as modes of innovation have been more clearly defined for the surgical situation. CONCLUSIONS: There are defining criteria that lead to additional consideration and prior review of surgical innovations. Some forms of innovation clearly fall within current human research regulations";" others may not fully meet the definition but may require additional monitoring.

title: Ethics of randomized clinical trials and the “ALARA” approach
abstract: A balanced discussion of the ethics of randomized clinical trials should not be based on a single ethical issue such as respect for patient autonomy. Rather, the analysis should take into account the four ethical principles – respect for autonomy, non-maleficence, charity and justice – in their validity for all groups of people concerned. We present the ethical benefits and costs of current practice of randomized clinical trials for four groups: patients enrolled in clinical trials, patients not enrolled in trials, participating physicians, and society. Then, the ALARA approach (As Low As Reasonably Achievable) is presented and practical measures are suggested to achieve a positive balance between ethical benefits and costs of randomized trials.

title: Research ethics relating to human subjects/patients
Ethics of research with psychiatric patients: principles, problems, and the primary responsibilities of researchers
abstract: This paper outlines some of the general issues related to recently published guidelines for research ethics committee practice, with a particular focus on the difficulties raised by research involving psychiatric patients. Research differs from ordinary clinical practice in its intent to advance knowledge. So defined, research with psychiatric patients should be governed by the same four principles as research with any other group—knowledge, necessity, utility, and consent. However, in applying these principles, particularly the consent principle, psychiatric patients encounter many acute difficulties. A number of proposals to solve these difficulties are discussed. It should be noted that notwithstanding the value of published guidelines and the assistance that may be available from research ethics committees, the primary responsibility for maintaining high standards of research practice rests with the researchers themselves.

title: EUROASPIRE III: a survey on lifestyle, risk factors and use of cardioprotective drug therapies in coronary patients from 22 European countries
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of the European Action on Secondary and Primary Prevention by Intervention to Reduce Events III (EUROASPIRE III) Survey was to determine whether the Joint European Societies guidelines on cardiovascular prevention are followed in everyday clinical practice and to describe lifestyle, risk factor and therapeutic factors Management of patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) in Europe. METHODS: The EUROASPIRE III survey was conducted in 2006-2007 in 76 centers from selected geographical areas in 22 countries in Europe. Consecutive patients with a clinical diagnosis of CHD were identified retrospectively and then followed up, interviewed and examined at least 6 months after their coronary event. RESULTS: Thirteen thousand nine hundred and thirty-five medical records (27% women) were reviewed and 8966 patients were interviewed. When surveyed, 17% of patients smoked cigarettes, 35% were obese and 53% were centrally obese, 56% had blood pressure > or = 140/90 mmHg (> or = 130/80 in people with diabetes mellitus), 51% had a Total serum cholesterol > or = 4.5 mmol/L and 25% reported a history of diabetes, of which 10% had a fasting plasma glucose value of less than 6.1 mmol/L and 35% had a glycated hemoglobin A1c value of less than 6.5%. The use of cardioprotective drugs was: antiplatelet drugs 91%; beta blockers 80%; angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors/angiotensin receptor blockers 71%;“ calcium channel blockers 25% and statins 78%. CONCLUSION: The EUROASPIRE III survey shows that a majority of coronary patients are not meeting the lifestyle, risk factors and therapeutic goals for cardiovascular disease prevention. There are large differences between countries in the prevalence of risk factors and the use of cardioprotective drug therapies. There is still significant potential across Europe to improve standards of preventive care to reduce the risk of recurrent disease and death in patients with CHD.

title: EUROASPIRE IV: A European Society of Cardiology survey on lifestyle, risk factors and therapeutic management of coronary patients from 24 European countries
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To determine whether the Joint European Society guidelines on cardiovascular prevention are followed in everyday clinical practice of secondary prevention and to describe the lifestyle, risk factors and therapeutic management of coronary patients across Europe. METHODS AND RESULTS: EUROASPIRE IV was a cross-sectional study conducted at 78 centers from 24 European countries. patients /= 6 months later. A total of 16,426 medical records were viewed and 7,998 patients (24.4% women) were interviewed. At the time of the survey, 16.0% of the patients smoked cigarettes and 48.6% of the smokers at the time of the event were regular smokers. 59.9% reported little or no physical activity; 37.6% were obese (BMI >/= 30 kg/m(2)) and 58.2% centrally obese (waist circumference >/= 102 cm for males or >/= 88 cm). in women); 42.7% had blood pressure >/= 140/90 mmHg (>/= 140/80 in diabetics); 80.5% had low-density lipoprotein cholesterol >/= 1.8 mmol/L and 26.8% reported having diabetes Cardioprotective medication was: antiplatelet agents 93.8%, beta-blockers 82.6%, angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors/angiotensin receptor blockers 75.1%;” and statins 85.7%. 50.7% of patients were recommended to participate in a cardiac rehabilitation program, and 81.3% of recommended patients attended at least half of the sessions. CONCLUSION: A large majority of coronary patients do not meet guideline standards for secondary prevention with high prevalences of persistent smoking, unhealthy diet, physical inactivity and consequently most patients are overweight or obese with a high prevalence of diabetes. Risk factor control is inadequate, despite the commonly reported use of medication, and there are large differences in secondary prevention practice between centers. Less than half of coronary patients participate in cardiac prevention and rehabilitation programs. All coronary and vascular patients require a modern preventive cardiology program, appropriately adapted to the medical and cultural context of each country, to achieve a healthier lifestyle, better control of risk factors and adherence to cardioprotective medications.

title: Evaluation of an educational activity to improve asthma management in four European countries. Drug education project group
