abstract: In the international Drug Education Project, a new training program for peer groups of doctors was developed and tested to improve the treatment of asthma patients in the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Slovakia. Individual feedback on the prescription and the underlying decision-making strategy was presented and discussed within the physician group in relation to existing guidelines. In a parallel, randomized, controlled design, the effect on competence and actual prescription was tested. The results were linked to national guidelines. In general, the program improved doctors' attitudes and some of their prescribing behavior. The proportion of patients treated with inhaled corticosteroids improved significantly in the Netherlands (effect size 1.27) and the proportion of patients using oral corticosteroids for exacerbation treatment increased in both the Netherlands and Norway (effect sizes 1.99 and 0 ,87). The general attitude of Dutch and Norwegian physicians also improved significantly (effect size 1.06 and 0.87, respectively), as did both knowledge (effect size 1.06) and attitude (effect size 1.49) towards exacerbation treatment in Slovakia . No significant improvements could be measured in Sweden. In conclusion, improvements in asthma management are possible with an educational program based on self-learning in small peer groups, although the impact in one healthcare setting may not be apparent in another healthcare setting. Possible explanatory factors may include different attitudes and experiences with guidelines and continuing medical education programs and differences in the possibilities for change, including prevailing trends in prescribing behaviour.

title: Evaluation of computer science applications - some alternative approaches: theory, social interactionism and the demand for methodological pluralism
abstract: review of the review literature on CDSSs shows that randomized controlled clinical trials (RCTs) are the "gold standard" for review. While this approach is excellent for studying system or clinical performance, it is not well suited to answering questions about whether systems are being used or how they are being used. As underutilization of CDSS has been a concern for a number of years, other evaluation research designs are needed to address these issues. This paper critiques RCT and experimental assessment approaches and presents alternative assessment approaches that address questions that fall outside the scope of usual RCT and experimental designs. A wide range of literature is summarized to illustrate the value of evaluations that take into account social, organizational, professional, and other contextual considerations. Many of these studies go beyond standard measures of system performance or physician behavior by focusing on the system's "fit" with other aspects of professional and organizational life. Since there are few explicit theories informing many evaluations, the paper then reviews CDSS evaluations based on social science theories. Finally, it proposes a theoretical social science basis for social interactionism. An example of such an approach is given. It includes a CDSS in Psychiatry and is based on Kaplan's 4Cs, which focus on communication, control, care and context. Although the example is a CDSS, the scoring approach is also useful for clinical guideline implementation and other medical informatics applications. Similarly, while the discussion revolves around social interactionism, the more important point is the need to broaden evaluation through a variety of methods and approaches that examine social, cultural, organizational, cognitive, and other contextual concerns. Methodological pluralism and a variety of research questions can improve the understanding of many influences on the development and use of computer science applications.

title: Evaluation of the effectiveness of a clinical practice change intervention in increasing the clinical delivery of preventive care in a network of community-based mental health services: a study protocol of a multi-baseline, non-randomized trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: People with mental illness suffer significant health disparities, including increased rates of morbidity and mortality caused by potentially preventable chronic diseases. One factor contributing to such inequality is a higher prevalence of modifiable health risk behaviors such as smoking, insufficient fruit and vegetable consumption, harmful alcohol consumption, and insufficient physical activity. Evidence supports the effectiveness of screening in reducing such risks, and guidelines recommend that screening to manage such risks be integrated into routine clinical care. Although community-based mental health services represent an important potential environment to ensure that people living with a mental illness receive such care, research suggests that their delivery is currently suboptimal. A study will be conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of a clinical practice change intervention in improving the routine delivery of preventive care by clinicians in community mental health settings. METHODS/DESIGN: A two-group multiple baseline design is used to assess the effectiveness of a multi-strategic intervention implemented over 12 months to improve the clinical offer of preventive care. The intervention will be delivered sequentially in the two groups of community mental health services to improve the delivery of client assessments, brief counseling, and referrals for four unhealthy behaviors (smoking, insufficient fruit and vegetable consumption, harmful alcohol use, and insufficient physical activity). . Outcome measures of interest are collected via repeated cross-sectional computer-assisted telephone interviews conducted weekly for 36 months with mental health patients in the community. DISCUSSION: This study is the first to evaluate the effectiveness of a multi-strategic clinical practice change intervention in improving the routine clinical delivery of preventive care for behavioral risk factors of chronic disease within a network of community mental health services. Findings will inform future policy and practice regarding the ability of clinicians in mental health settings to improve the delivery of preventive care as a result of such interventions. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australian and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ANZCTR) ACTRN12613000693729.

title: Assessing the effectiveness of educational interventions for delirium prevention
abstract: The aim of this study was to combine knowledge of how clinicians learn with a review of delirium prevention training in hospitalized patients. The primary goal was to evaluate the effectiveness of approaches to delirium clarification. A detailed search of educational and medical databases was conducted. The type of intervention used was classified according to Green and colleagues' PRECEED model using factors relevant to behavior change in health promotion. The effectiveness of the intervention was determined by assessing changes in staff performance and patient outcomes. Nineteen studies of variable design and quality were identified. Studies that used predisposing, enabling, and reinforcement strategies together were more likely to be effective in inducing changes in staff behavior and patient outcomes. Education and policies used together or in combination have little effect. When strategies to enable and reinforce changes in clinical practice are used in conjunction with educational sessions, patient outcomes are more positive.

title: Evaluation of the Stage-of-Change Model for a Cervical Cancer Screening Intervention in Appalachian Women of Ohio
abstract: Cervical cancer incidence and mortality rates are disproportionately high among women living in Appalachia, Ohio. This study used the transtheoretical model to examine screening barriers before and after a lay health advisor (LHA) intervention (2005-2009) to increase screening rates for cervical cancer. Appalachian women in Ohio (n=90) requiring a Pap test were randomized to a 10-month LHA intervention based on risk-appropriate guidelines and received two in-person visits, two phone calls, and four targeted postcards in the mail at the change phase of the participant. Results showed that 63% had stage progression 10 months post-procedure. The most commonly reported barriers to screening were time constraints, missed appointments, and cost. Women who reported the following barriers: physician did not recommend the test; cannot afford the test; and embarrassment, nervousness, or anxiety about a Pap test—were less likely to be in the action phase. Understanding the stages of change associated with Pap testing and reported barriers in this underserved population can help inform researchers and clinicians about this population's readiness for change and the setting of realistic intervention goals.

title: Assessing the uptake and impact of the computerized decision support system NHGDoc on the quality of primary care: Protocol for a large-scale randomized controlled cluster study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Computer-aided decision support systems (CDSSs) are increasingly used to improve the quality of care. There is evidence of moderate to large effects from randomized controlled trials (RCTs), but evidence of their effectiveness when implemented nationally is lacking. In the Netherlands, the Dutch College of General Practitioners (NHG) initiated its successful guideline program 30 years ago. NHGDoc, a CDSS based on these NHG guidelines covering multiple disease areas for general practice, was developed in 2006 with the aim of improving the quality of primary care. In this paper, a protocol is presented to assess the uptake and effect of NHGDoc. METHODS: A cluster RCT is conducted among 120 general practitioner practices in the Netherlands. Eligible general practices will be randomized to receive either the regular NHGDoc decision support modules (control arm) or the regular modules plus an additional heart failure module (intervention arm). The Heart Failure module consists of patient-specific alarms to manage patients with heart failure. The impact assessment focuses on performance indicators (e.g. prescription behaviour) as well as patient outcomes (e.g. hospital admissions) that are relevant in the area of heart failure. In addition, a process assessment will be conducted to gain insight into the barriers and promoters affecting the uptake and impact of NHGDoc. DISCUSSION: The results of this study will provide insight into the uptake and impact of a multi-domain primary care CDSS implemented by a national guideline organization to improve the quality of primary care. While the study focuses on a specific area of care - heart failure - the conclusions of this study will shed light on the functioning of CDSSs covering multiple disease areas for primary care, particularly as this study also examines the factors contributing to the uptake and effectiveness of the system contribute. STUDY REGISTRATION: Clinical Studies NCT01773057.

title: Evaluation of training methods for transporting emergency management to therapists
abstract: The effects of three increasingly intensive training methods on the use of therapists, the knowledge and the adherence to implementation of emergency management (CM) in substance-abusing adolescents were evaluated. Ten public sector organizations providing substance abuse or mental health services were randomly assigned to one of three training conditions: workshop and resources (WS+), WS+ and computer-based training (WS+/CAT), or WS+/CAT and supervisory support (WS+/CAT/SS) . Across conditions, 161 therapists participated in the training experiences, and measures were collected at baseline and at 2-month intervals for 12 months after workshop participation. Across the training conditions, therapists reported increased CM use, proficiency, and implementation adherence during the 12-month follow-up. Findings indicate that community practitioners are open to adopting evidence-based treatments when given access to useful resources. Additionally, high-quality workshops combined with access to resources can increase knowledge of evidence-based treatment and increase intervention adherence to levels needed to improve youth outcomes.

title: Evaluation of a complex intervention to change occupational behavior: the Evidence Based Out Reach (EBOR) Trial
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To identify the effect of a complex intervention (pharmacist educational visits) aimed at changing the prescription of general practitioners (GPs) at each step of a hypothetical change pathway leading to the final primary study outcome of a prescription change. METHOD: The study was conducted in six health authorities in Northern England and six in London. We have described three steps leading to this result: the consent of the GP practices to participate, the participation of the GPs in each practice in the visiting service carried out by the pharmacists; and GP prescribing practices are influenced by these visits. The results of each step were assessed using a combination of quantitative and qualitative methods. RESULTS: Of the 102 randomly selected practices, 75 (73.5%) agreed to participate. The probability that all physicians in small practices (ie 1-2 partners) participated in the consultation was 6.7 (95% CI: 4.4-23.5) compared to other practices (ie > 3 partners). Although pharmacists reported that they had developed a good relationship at 100 (72%) initial visits and agreed on treatment plans for 110 (79%) of those visits, they were confident that the practice was likely to change their prescription in only 41%. these visits. Pharmacist and GP satisfaction with outreach visits did not necessarily lead to post-visit prescription changes, and GP knowledge of pharmacist-promoted guidelines did not necessarily lead to changes in clinical practice. The pharmacists identified organizational difficulties during follow-up appointments, GPs' skepticism about the evidence presented to them and the lack of interest on the part of physicians in changing their prescribing behavior as the main obstacles to implementing the guidelines. CONCLUSIONS: Although limited to a post-hoc rather than a pre-hoc design, our study provides a pragmatic approach to understanding the factors influencing the pathway of prescribing behavior change in response to academic visits.

title: Evaluation of a decision support system for pressure ulcer prevention and treatment: preliminary results
abstract: Based on the AHCPR guidelines and other sources, a decision support system for the prevention and treatment of pressure ulcers was developed. The system was implemented in a 20-bed clinical care unit for 21 weeks. Fifteen nurses on this ward volunteered to be subjects of the intervention to see if using the system would have a positive effect on their knowledge of pressure ulcers and their ability to make decisions about the subject. A similar care unit served as a control. In addition, the system was rated by experts for its didactic adequacy and by end users for their satisfaction with the system. Preliminary results show no impact on knowledge about pressure ulcers and no impact on clinical decision-making skills. The system was rated positively for didactic adequacy and positively for user satisfaction. User satisfaction interviews supplemented the quantitative findings. A discussion of the problems in conducting experiments such as this in today's clinical setting is included.

title: Evaluation of a dental health program for old-age pensioners in Denmark
abstract: high priority is given to improving the oral health of older people in Scandinavia. In 1987, a Danish municipality established a dental public health care program for pensioners. All 67-year-old citizens were offered school-based preventive and curative care according to the guidelines and principles set by the Danish Municipal Dental Service for Children. The care was free. Citizens who do not wish to receive care through the public system can do so with private dentists. Reimbursement for services from the private system was provided by the state health insurance and the municipality. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the results of the program after three years of operation. A follow-up design was used and data were collected through interviews and clinical registrations. At the beginning and at the follow-up examination, 216 (71%) and 235 (77%) retirees were asked about their self-assessment of their dental health, dental knowledge, attitudes and behavior. Clinical data were collected only for older people participating in the public program and included 194 people at baseline and 187 at follow-up. This data included information about tooth loss, tooth decay, periodontal health, and the presence and function of removable dentures. At follow-up, 86 percent of all respondents saw a dentist regularly at least once a year, compared to 46 percent at baseline";" 75 percent took part in the public program and 11 percent were treated by resident doctors. At the end of the intervention period, fewer older people reported symptoms of poor oral health or impaired denture function.

title: Evaluation of a diabetes specialist-led diabetes treatment program in primary care
abstract: PURPOSE: An initial pilot program showed promising results in improvements in glycated hemoglobin (HbA(1c)), low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), and systolic blood pressure (SBP) and prompted us to expand these results into a controlled study to test . The purpose of the clinical study DAMET-2 (Diabetes-focused, Algorithm-directed care, Midlevel Practitioner-admitted, Electronically coached, Treatment) program (DAMET-2) was to assess the benefits of a novel program to disseminate treatment guidelines from diabetes from a central specialist clinic to primary care centers with access to middle-care provider services. DATA SOURCES: DAMET-2 included standardized treatment algorithms and training disseminated through computer-assisted and traditional telemedicine methods. Two primary care practices were selected and patients diagnosed with type 2 diabetes > or = 6 months, > or = 18 years with one or more cardiovascular risk factors (identified by chart review) were eligible for enrollment. Intermediate-level practitioners for subjects in the experimental group (N=34) received training in American Diabetes Association treatment algorithms, had telephone consultations every 2 to 4 weeks and bimonthly visits to diabetes specialists, and received specialist treatment referrals within 24 hours of remote diabetes . Weekly diabetes clinics were provided to subjects in the experimental group. After 12 months, the latest available subject data were extracted from the subject horoscopes and compared to 12-month horoscope data from a control group (N = 101) that received no additional coursework. CONCLUSIONS: Mean HbA(1c) levels decreased from baseline by 0.46% in the active treatment group compared to 0.06% in the control group; however, reductions in HbA(1c) did not reach statistical significance, possibly due to the small sample size of the experimental group. Mean SBP levels were significantly reduced in both groups;" however, LDL-C was significantly reduced only in the control group, where more aggressive use of statins may have had an effect. PRACTICAL IMPLICATIONS: Despite the inconsistencies in reducing risk factors versus the pilot program, the DAMET-2 program provided insights into the importance of electronic records and provider notifications, patient compliance, prioritization of provider resources by patient risk factor level, and access to self-management education.

title: Evaluation of a knowledge transfer program to improve health promotion and disease prevention policy making and practices in French regions: a realistic study protocol
abstract: Background Evidence-based decision-making and practice are central to public health. However, barriers remain and they relate to evidence properties, organizations and contexts. To address these important knowledge transfer (KT) questions, we need to rethink how knowledge is produced and used to improve our understanding of decision-making processes, logics and mechanisms, and to examine the ability of public health services to integrate research results into their decisions and surgeries. This article presents a realistic evaluation protocol to evaluate a KT system in prevention policy and practice at local level in France. Methods/Design This study is a comparative multiple case study that uses a realistic approach to evaluate a KT system in Regional Health Services (ARS) and Regional Nonprofit Health Education and Promotion Organizations (IREPS) by considering the configurations contexts/mechanisms/ results of it. The assessed KT scheme is designed to use six reviews of systematic reviews on the following topics: diet, alcohol, tobacco smoking, physical activity, emotional and sexual life, and psychosocial skills. It combines the following activities: supporting access to and adaptation of scientific and usable evidence"; strengthening professionals' abilities to analyse, adopt and use the evidence throughout their practice and decision-making process;" Facilitate the use of evidence in the organizations and processes. RAMESE II reporting standards for realistic assessments were used. Discussion The objective of this study is to examine and characterize the factors related to the program's ability to enable public health stakeholders to address the challenges of CT and integrate scientific knowledge into policy and practice. We will use the realistic approach to document the parameters of successful KT strategies in the specific healthcare contexts in France, while attempting to determine the transferability of such strategies.

title: Evaluation of a novel individualized communication skills training intervention to improve physicians' confidence and communication skills at the end of life
abstract: BACKGROUND: We have developed a novel individualized end-of-life communication training program that is time-saving for busy junior physicians working in hospitals. OBJECTIVE: Our aim was to test this short individualized training program with young physicians to examine its acceptability, feasibility, and effect on physicians' self-confidence, communication skills, attitudes towards psychosocial care, and burnout. DESIGN: The content of the training intervention was supported by a systematic literature review and evidence-based clinical practice guidelines on end-of-life communication. The intervention was based on sound pedagogical principles and consisted of three one-hour classroom sessions over a three-week period, including two one-on-one sessions with an experienced facilitator and a simulated patient/carer. In addition, participants received written and audiovisual learning materials to take home. PARTICIPANTS were videotaped with a simulated patient/carer before and after the training session to assess the impact of the course on their communication skills. PARTICIPANTS completed anonymized pre/post-training questionnaires including self-rated self-confidence, attitudes towards mental health care and the Maslach Burnout Inventory. PARTICIPANTS: PARTICIPANTS were 22 junior physicians from a large teaching hospital in Sydney, Australia. RESULTS: All participants reported that the training was useful, helpful in their communication with patients and that they would recommend the training to others. Significant improvements were seen in participants' communication skills (in seven of 21 specific and all three global communication behaviors assessed, range P = 0.02 to < 0.001), confidence in communicating about relevant issues (P < 0.001), attitudes towards mental health care ( P=0.03) and the sense of personal accomplishment (P=0.043). Overall, there were no differences in the burnout level of the participants. CONCLUSION: This intervention shows promise and warrants further formal evaluation.

title: Evaluation of a medically oriented educational intervention for medical children with asthma
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act 1990 required screening of drug use in response to inappropriate drug use. Under the Pennsylvania Medicaid program, pediatric asthma is associated with high healthcare utilization and costs. OBJECTIVE: To determine the impact of a physician-centered educational intervention on asthma drug use and health care utilization. METHODS: The pre- and post-intervention comparison design was used in children aged 5 to 18 years who were enrolled from July 1, 1998 to March 31, 1999 (pre-intervention) and from March 1, 1999 to March 31, 2000 (post-intervention ). The intervention package included patient drug profiles, medical history, a monograph of national asthma management guidelines, and patient education materials for physicians. The main outcome measures are changes in asthma medication use in frequent users of short-acting beta(2)-agonists (SAB). RESULTS: The intervention focused on 2 criteria for asthma drug use: (1) high use of fast-relieving drugs and (2) use of salmeterol without availability of a fast-relieving drug. The intervention reduced the use of fast palliative medications by 26% in patients with higher use without significant changes in long-term control medications. In addition, 82% of recipients evaluated showed a positive change in salmeterol use, either by adding an SAB inhaler after the intervention or by discontinuing salmeterol after the intervention. There was no significant change in emergency room visits or asthma-related hospitalizations. CONCLUSIONS: Although treating physicians agreed on the usefulness of the educational materials, the results suggest that the intervention had limited success in improving pharmacological management and had no impact on health outcomes. We believe that educational materials mailed to physicians can be effective in changing prescribing behavior";" however, a more multifaceted intervention may be needed to improve health outcomes.

title: Evaluation of a tailored intervention to improve the management of overweight and obesity in primary care: study protocol of a randomized controlled cluster study
abstract: BACKGROUND: In the UK around 22% of men and 24% of women are obese, and there are different but worrying figures in other European countries. Obesity is a chronic disease that poses a significant health risk. National guidelines for use in England to manage overweight or obese people have been published by the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE, 2006). NICE recommendations for primary care teams are: "Assess the level of overweight and obesity," assess lifestyle, comorbidities, and readiness for change, provide multicomponent management of overweight and obesity, and refer to outside services as appropriate. These Study examines a tailored intervention to improve implementation of these recommendations by primary care teams METHODS/DESIGN: The study is a cluster-randomised controlled trial. Primary care teams will be recruited from the East Midlands of England and randomized into two study arms: 1) the study group in which primary care teams A range of tailored interventions will be offered to support the implementation of NICE's overweight and obesity guidelines." or 2) the control group, in which primary care teams continue to provide usual care. The primary outcome is the proportion of overweight or obese patients for whom the GP team adheres to NICE guidelines. Secondary endpoints include the proportion of patients with lifestyle assessment records, referral to outside weight loss services, proportion of obese patients who lose weight during the intervention period, and mean weight change over the same period. DISCUSSION: Although often recommended, the methods for adapting implementation interventions to the determinants of practice are not well developed. This study is part of a study program designed to develop methods for tailor-made implementation. STUDY REGISTRATION: Current controlled studies ISRCTN07457585. Registered on 09/08/2013. The randomization started on 08/30/2013.

title: Evaluation of a toolkit to improve cardiovascular disease screening and treatment in people with type 2 diabetes: protocol for a cluster-randomized pragmatic study
abstract: BACKGROUND: The discrepancy between the level of care recommended by evidence-based clinical practice guidelines and actual patient care in practice is well known. The Canadian Diabetes Association (CDA) has developed an implementation strategy to improve implementation of its 2008 guidelines. This study will assess the impact of the strategy to improve cardiovascular disease (CVD) screening, prevention and treatment for people with diabetes. DESIGN: A pragmatic cluster-randomized study is conducted to evaluate the CDA's CVD toolkit. All primary care physicians in Ontario, Canada were randomly assigned to receive the toolkit, which includes several printed educational materials on CVD screening, prevention, and treatment, in either Spring 2009 (intervention arm) or Spring 2010 (control arm). The randomization took place at the practice level. Forty primary care physicians from each arm will be recruited to participate, and the medical records of 20 of their diabetics at high risk for cardiovascular disease will be retrospectively reviewed. Outcome measures will be evaluated for each patient between July 2009 and March 2010. The primary outcome will be that the patient receives a statin. Secondary outcomes include 1) intake of an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker, 2) various intermediate measurements (A1c, blood pressure, LDL-cholesterol, total/HDL-cholesterol ratio, body mass index, and waist circumference), and 3) clinical inertia (failure to change therapy in response to abnormal A1c, blood pressure, or cholesterol). The analysis is performed using multilevel hierarchical logistic regression models to account for the clustered nature of the data. Group assignment is a physician-level variable. In addition, a process assessment study with six primary care physician focus groups will assess the acceptability of the CDA toolkit and examine factors contributing to change or non-change in behavior from a primary care physician perspective. DISCUSSION: Printed physician educational materials have been shown to bring about small to moderate changes in patient care. CDA's CVD toolkit is an example of a strategy for implementing guidelines that can be disseminated to a wide audience relatively inexpensively. Therefore, demonstrating their effectiveness in improving diabetes care could have important ramifications for guideline developers, policy makers, and clinicians.

title: Evaluation of abnormal mammography results and palpable breast abnormalities
abstract: Background: Because approximately 1 in 10 women with a breast lump or an abnormal mammogram result will have breast cancer, a number of decisions must be made by a primary care physician to rule out or diagnose breast cancer in these women. Purpose: To determine the most accurate and least invasive means to evaluate an abnormal mammogram result and palpable breast abnormality with abnormal mammogram results or palpable breast abnormalities. Study selection: The authors reviewed abstracts and selected articles that provided relevant primary data. Studies were included if 1) a mammogram, fine-needle aspiration biopsy, or core needle biopsy was performed before a definitive diagnosis was made; 2) the study sample included 100 or more women;" and 3) breast cancer status was determined by histopathological review of excisional biopsy specimens, linkage to a state cancer registry or the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results program, or clinical follow-up of 95% or more of the study sample definitely. Data Extraction: An investigator abstracted the results. The methods were evaluated for major potential biases, but no methodological evaluation was performed. Data Synthesis: Odds ratios for primary mammography screening were 0.1 for the Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) assessment category of negative or benign finding and 1.2 for probably benign finding, 7 for need for additional imaging study, 125 for suspicious abnormalities and 2200 for findings strongly suggestive of malignancy. In a fine-needle aspiration biopsy of a palpable nodule performed by formally trained physicians, the odds ratio was infinity for a malignant rating, 2.6 for atypical/suspicious, and 0.02 for benign. When diagnostic mammography was used to evaluate a palpable lump or non-palpable breast abnormality, positive likelihood ratios were 5.6 and 9.4 and negative likelihood ratios were 0.15 and 0.19, respectively, indicative of malignancy, are at high risk of breast cancer and should undergo core needle biopsy or needle localization with surgical biopsy. Women whose mammography screening results are interpreted as requiring additional imaging are at moderate risk of breast cancer and should undergo diagnostic mammography or ultrasonography to decide whether an unpalpable breast lesion should be biopsied. Women whose screening mammography results are interpreted as probably benign have a low risk of breast cancer and can have a follow-up mammography in 6 months. Either fine-needle aspiration biopsy or ultrasonography is recommended as the first diagnostic test of a palpable breast abnormality to distinguish simple cysts from solid tumors. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy also allows characterization of a solid mass. Diagnostic mammography does not help decide whether a palpable breast mass should be biopsied and should not influence the decision to perform a biopsy.

title: Evaluation of an information leaflet on AIDS/HIV infection aimed at healthcare professionals in Catalonia
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the understanding and acceptance of a periodic information booklet on HIV/AIDS by healthcare professionals. DESIGN: Crossover. SETTING: Primary care teams from Institut Catala de la Salut. PARTICIPANTS: A random sample of 300 physicians, registered nurses, and social workers. INTERVENTION: A self-completed, anonymous questionnaire returned by regular mail. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: The questions covered the following subject areas: clinical care for people infected with HIV/AIDS and requests for diagnostic testing for infection, perceptions of skills to promote changes in patients' sexual behavior and drug use, provision of psychological support and guidelines for Integrating HIV+ children in schools and information on social resources. 60% knew the publication. Topics that aroused great interest were: psychological support for those affected, prevention of HIV infection in the healthcare system, clinical counseling and diagnostics. 77% had received requests for diagnostic tests and 88% had visited infected people. CONCLUSIONS: Despite the low response rate (50%) and the relative variability between professionals and the health regions they came from, this initial assessment allowed us to identify specific educational needs in the care and prevention of HIV/AIDS infection in the primary school care framework and also to improve the distribution methods we use.

title: Evaluation of an internet-based decision support system for the application of the ATS/CDC guidelines for tuberculosis prevention therapy.
abstract: Preventive therapy for patients infected with tuberculosis (TB) remains an important part of TB control. To guide physicians in using preventive therapy, the American Thoracic Society and the Centers for Disease Control (ATS/CDC) have developed guidelines based on PPD reactivity and likelihood of infection prior to testing. The guidelines have become complex and many clinicians find them difficult to apply. The authors developed a computerized decision support system to assist physicians in applying ATS/CDC guidelines. This tool, published on the World Wide Web using hypertext markup language, provides patient-specific recommendations based on patient-specific information provided by the physician. Four local TB experts derived eight TB infection scenarios and validated the web-based tool, which was tested for efficacy using randomly divided two groups of general practitioners. Group A (n = 12) used the web-based tool and Group B (n = 17) used a pre-existing understanding of the guidelines and/or written resources to determine the need for preventive therapy in the case studies. Group A used the therapy correctly in 92/96 possible cases (95.8%), group B only in 77/136 (56.6%) (p<0.001). Group A needed an average of three mouse clicks and 1.5 minutes per scenario to make their choices and rated the web-based tool as intuitive and effective. These data show that a computer-based decision support system for applying TB treatment guidelines can be delivered over the Internet and is an efficient and effective resource for clinicians.

title: Evaluation of a computerized clinical decision support system and risk table for the management of hypertension in primary care: randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Objectives: To study the effect of a computer-assisted clinical decision support system and risk table on absolute cardiovascular risk, blood pressure, and cardiovascular drug prescription in hypertensive patients. Design: Cluster randomized controlled trial. Recruitment: 27 GP practices in Avon. Participants: 614 patients between the ages of 60 and 79 years with hypertension. Interventions: Patients were randomized to a computer-assisted clinical decision support system plus cardiovascular risk chart”; cardiovascular risk graph only;' or usual care. Main outcome measures: Percentage of patients in each group with a five-year cardiovascular risk = 10%, systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, cardiovascular medication prescription. Results: Patients in the computer-assisted clinical decision support system and in the table groups were no more likely to have cardiovascular risk reduced to less than 10% than patients receiving usual care. Patients in the computer-assisted clinical decision support group were more likely to have cardiovascular risk = 10% than patients alone, odds ratio 2.3 (95% confidence interval 1.1 to 4.8). The chart-only group had a significantly lower systolic blood pressure compared to the usual care group (mean difference -4.6 mm Hg (95% confidence interval -8.4 to -0.8). The reduction in diastolic blood pressure did not differ between the three groups.The graph-only group was twice as likely to be prescribed two classes of cardiovascular drugs and more than three times as likely to be prescribed three or more classes of drugs compared to the other groups B. for absolute risk reduction or blood pressure control and requires further development and evaluation before use in clinical care can be recommended.

title: Evaluation of internet-based clinical decision support systems.
abstract: Background: Scientifically based clinical guidelines are increasingly being used to train physicians and to improve the quality of care. While individual guidelines may be useful, repeated studies have shown that guidelines are ineffective in changing physician behavior. The Internet has emerged as a potentially useful tool for guideline education, dissemination, and implementation because of its open standards and ability to provide concise, relevant clinical information where and when it is needed. Aim: Our aim was to develop and test decision support systems (DSS) based on clinical guidelines that can be delivered over the Internet for two disease models: asthma and tuberculosis (TB) preventive therapy. Methods: Using open HTML and CGI standards, we developed a DSS for assessment of acute asthma severity and a DSS for preventive treatment of tuberculosis based on content of national guidelines recognized as treatment standards. Both DSS are published on the web and use a decision algorithm developed from the overarching guidelines with clinical information provided by the user at the time of clinical care. We tested the effectiveness of each DSS in influencing physician decisions using clinical scenario testing. Results: First, we validated the asthma algorithm by comparing the decisions made by asthma professionals with the decisions made by nonpulmonary nurses using the computerized DSS. Using the DSS, nurses performed the same as experts (89% vs. 88%; p=NS). Using the same scenario testing instrument, we next compared internists using the DSS to residents using a printed version of the National Asthma Education Program 2 guidelines. Residents using the computerized DSS performed significantly better than residents using the used paper-based guidelines (92% vs. 84%; p<0.002). Similarly, we compared residents using the computerized TB-DSS to residents using a printed reference card; residents who used the computerized DSS performed significantly better (95.8% vs. 56.6% correct;" p<0.001). Conclusions: Previous work has shown that guidelines disseminated through traditional educational interventions are only have minimal impact on physician behavior. Although computerized DSS has been effective in changing physician behavior, many of these systems are not widely available. We have developed two clinical DSS based on national guidelines and published them on the web. Both systems improved the Physician compliance with national guidelines when tested in clinical scenarios By providing information coupled to relevant activities, we expect these widely used DSSs to serve as effective educational tools to positively influence physician behavior .

title: Evaluation of studies on the effectiveness of clinical services provided by pharmacists
abstract: quantitative review of randomized trials of counseling, educational, and other clinical services provided by pharmacists was conducted. Data sources were MEDLINE and the bibliographies of published articles. Pharmacists' services were categorized as patient consultation, physician consultation, patient and physician consultation, and patient care. The extracted results were measures of patient behavior, disease, symptoms, and patient knowledge. Thirty-two studies met the inclusion criteria. The pharmacists were identified as clinical pharmacists in 24 studies and as practicing pharmacists in 2 studies. In six open-label patient counseling studies, the results in each study favored the counseled patients over the control patients, and the effects were statistically significant in five studies (the outcome was medication adherence in these five studies). In seven trials of counseling patients and their physicians, patient outcomes were significantly better in the intervention group in six trials, four of which were single-blind. Two studies in which patients were randomized to either a doctor's consultation or a control group yielded conflicting results. In a study in which physicians were randomized to receive advice from pharmacists, the proportion of prescriptions that met guidelines was higher in the advice group than in the control group. Four studies of patient care by pharmacists were inconclusive. These studies showed that pharmacists' counseling of patients and their physicians can improve treatment outcomes. Evidence that counseling patients alone improved patient outcomes was good, albeit weaker due to the suboptimal study design.

title: Evaluation of Talking Parents, Healthy Teens, a new workplace parenting program to encourage communication between parents and youth about sexual health: randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate a corporate parenting program - Talking Parents, Healthy Teens - designed to help parents address sexual health issues with their adolescent children. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial (April 2002-December 2005). SETTING 13 construction sites in Southern California. PARTICIPANTS 569 parents completed baseline surveys at work, gave permission to send confidential surveys to their adolescent children, and were randomly assigned to intervention or control groups. Parents and adolescents took part in follow-up surveys one week, three months and nine months after the program. INTERVENTION Talking Parents, Healthy Teens consists of eight weekly one-hour workplace sessions for parents of adolescent children in grades 6 through 10 (ages approximately 11 to 16). KEY OUTCOMES Communication between parents and young people about a list of sexual topics; whether parents taught the adolescent how to use a condom; ability to communicate with parents/adolescents about sex; Openness of parent-adolescent communication about sex. RESULTS Differences between intervention and control groups were significant for the mean number of new sexual topics that parents and adolescents reported discussing between baseline and each follow-up (p<0.001 for each); Intervention parents were less likely than controls to discuss no new topics (8% vs. 29%, 95% confidence interval for difference 16% to 24%) and were more likely to discuss seven or more new topics (38% vs. 8%, 19% to 41 %) at nine months. Some differences increased after program completion: at One week after program, 18% of adolescents in the intervention group and 3% in the control group (6% to 30%) reported that their parents had checked in since the start of the study how to use a condom (p<0.001);" this increased to 29% vs. 5% (13% to 36%) (P<0.001) at nine months. Compared to controls at nine months, parents and adolescents reported in of the intervention group reported a greater ability to communicate about sex with one another (P < 0.001) and more openness in communicating about sex (P < 0.001).CONCLUSIONS An occupational program can have a significant impact on communication between Parents and adolescents have about sexual health. STUDY REGISTRATION Clinical Studies NCT00465010.

title: Evaluation of two school smoking education programs under normal classroom conditions
abstract: OBJECTIVES To evaluate the effectiveness of two school-based smoking education projects in delaying the onset of smoking behavior and improving health literacy, beliefs, and values. DESIGN Cluster randomized controlled trial of two projects taught under normal classroom conditions. Schools were assigned to one of four groups to complete the Family Smoking Education Project (FSE), the Smokers and Me Project (SAM), both projects in sequence (FSE/SAM); or not intervened at all. LOCAL AREA 39 schools in Wales and England, matched in size and catchment profile. PARTICIPANTS All first graders in the schools were included and assessed on three occasions (4538 before class (1988), 3930 immediately after class (1989), 3786 after one year of follow-up (1990)). KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Self-reported smoking behavior (supported by a saliva sample) and change in relevant health knowledge, beliefs, and values. RESULTS No consistent significant differences in smoking behavior, health knowledge, beliefs, or values were found between the four groups. Among the never-smokers at baseline, the rate of remaining never-smokers in 1990 was 74% (594/804) in the control group, 65% (455/704) in the FAE group, 70% (440/625) in the SAM group, and 69% (549/791) in the FAE/SAM group (chi 2adj = 6.1, df = 3, p = 0.1). Knowledge of the effects of smoking increased in all groups from an average score of 5.4 in 1988 to 6.4 in 1989 and 6.5 in 1990. CONCLUSIONS To reduce smoking among teenagers, interventions are more comprehensive than those school health education required. Other measures, including further restrictions on access to cigarettes and the promotion of tobacco products, need to be considered. Further research is needed to develop effective school-based health education projects, which should be formally tested under normal field conditions before being widely disseminated.

title: Evidence-based behavioral medicine: what is it and how do we achieve it?
abstract: Ultimately, the goal of evidence-based medicine is to improve patient outcomes and the quality of care. Systematic reviews of the available published evidence are needed to identify interventions that result in improvements in behavior, health, and well-being. Relevant literature reviews depend on the quality of published research and research reports. The Consolidated Standards for Reporting Trials (CONSORT) Statement (www.consort-statement.org) was developed to improve the design and reporting of randomized clinical trials (RCTs) interventions in medical journals. We describe the 22 CONSORT guidelines and explain their application in behavioral health research and evidence-based practice. Additional guidelines specific to behavioral medicine (e.g. adherence to therapy) are also presented. The use of these guidelines by clinicians, educators, policymakers, and researchers who design, report, and evaluate or review RCTs will empower the research itself and accelerate efforts to apply behavioral health research to improve the processes and outcomes of behavioral health practice.

title: Evidence-based care of older people with suspected cognitive impairment in general practice: protocol for the randomized IRIS cluster study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dementia is a common and complex disease. There are evidence-based guidelines for the management of people with dementia in general practice";" However, detection, diagnosis and disclosure of dementia have been identified as potential evidence-practice gaps. Interventions to put guidelines into practice have had varying degrees of success. The use of theory in designing implementation interventions has been limited, but is advocated because it has the potential to produce more effective interventions and to aid in understanding factors that modify the magnitude of intervention effects across studies. This protocol describes methods of a randomized trial testing a theory-guided implementation intervention that, if effective, may provide benefits for patients with dementia and their caregivers. OBJECTIVES: This study aims to assess the effectiveness of a theory-driven intervention to increase adherence to a clinical guideline for the detection, diagnosis and treatment of dementia in general practice by primary care physicians (in Victoria, Australia) compared to the provision of General practitioners with a printed copy of the guideline. Primary objectives include testing whether the intervention is effective in increasing the percentage of patients with suspected cognitive impairment receiving treatment that is consistent with two key guideline recommendations: obtaining ai) formal cognitive assessment and ii) a depression rating using a validated scale (primary outcomes for the trial). METHODS: The design is a parallel cluster randomized trial, where clusters are general practices. Our goal is to recruit 60 practices per group. Practices are randomly assigned to the intervention and control groups by means of limited randomization. Patients who meet the inclusion criteria and the general practitioners' recognition and diagnosis behavior towards these patients will be identified and measured nine months after the start of the intervention via an electronic search in the medical records. Practitioners in the control group receive a printed copy of the guideline. In addition to receiving the printed guideline, practitioners in the intervention group will be invited to participate in an interactive, opinion leader-led, face-to-face workshop. The theory-led intervention aims to address identified barriers and enablers to implementing recommendations. Researchers responsible for identifying the cohort of patients with suspected cognitive impairment and their detection and diagnosis outcomes are blind to group assignment. STUDY REGISTRATION: Australia-New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry: ACTRN12611001032943 (Registration Date 28 September 2011).

title: Evidence-based guidelines for teaching patient-centered interviewing
abstract: In a rare study on the effectiveness of an interviewing method, we previously reported a randomized controlled trial that showed that training in a stepwise patient-centered interviewing method improved residents' knowledge, attitudes, and skills and had a consistently positive effect on the trained patients residents. For those who would like to use this evidence-based, patient-centered method as a template for their own teaching, here we describe our training program for the first time—and suggest that the training be for students, physicians, nurses, physician assistants, and other new learners. The training was competency-based and experiential, fostered a positive attitude towards patient-centred interviewing, and used a learner-centred approach that paid particular attention to the teacher-resident relationship and the resident's self-esteem. The skill training was guided by a newly identified patient-centered interview method that described the step-by-step application of specific behaviors.

title: Evidence-Based Guidelines for the Management of Bipolar Disorder: Revised Recommendations from the Third Edition of the British Association for Psychopharmacology
abstract: The British Association for Psychopharmacology guidelines specify the scope and goals of treatment for bipolar disorder. The third version is explicitly based on the available evidence and, like previous clinical practice guidelines, is presented as a recommendation to support clinical decision making for practitioners: it can also serve as a source of information for patients and carers and support audits. The recommendations are presented together with a more detailed review of the relevant evidence. A consensus meeting, attended by experts in bipolar disorder and its treatment, reviewed key areas and reviewed the weight of evidence and clinical implications. The guidelines were created after extensive feedback from these participants. The best evidence from randomized controlled trials and, where available, observational studies with quasi-experimental designs was used to evaluate treatment options. The strength of the recommendations was described using the GRADE approach. The guidelines cover the diagnosis of bipolar disorder, clinical management, and strategies for drug use in the short-term treatment of episodes, prevention of recurrence, and discontinuation of treatment. The use of medication is integrated into a coherent approach to psychoeducation and behavior change.

title: Evidence-based health care for children: what are we missing?
abstract: With the enactment of major healthcare reform, reimbursement for a variety of healthcare services will likely depend on evidence supporting that provision. Understanding what constitutes “evidence” will have profound implications for the range of clinical care provided. Too narrow a definition can have significant implications for pediatric care in particular: much of current pediatric care requires consideration of a broader evidence base than is typically relied on when developing clinical guidelines. This is especially true when treating behavioral and developmental problems. The current standard for evaluating evidence uses study design as a proxy for the quality of evidence";" it may therefore inadvertently exclude many important findings and fail to support further relevant research. The project described here has produced a new, broader framework for clinical practice assessment that should be of value to both clinicians and policy makers.

title: Evidence-based medicine and headache patient management by general practitioners in Italy
abstract: The study examines the awareness of Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) terms and the manner in which patients with migraine are treated in a random sample of 500 general practitioners (GPs). A mailed questionnaire included questions about GP demographics and practice characteristics, awareness of EBM, sources of information about migraine and EBM; and treatment behavior of the patient. Only 27.2% of GPs agreed that clinical trials are needed to evaluate the effectiveness of treatments, and this awareness was higher among those who learned about migraine from scientific journals or continuing education courses and attended courses on EBM. For two-thirds of primary care physicians, a disability equates to a disease diagnosis, and this behavior was more common among those who agreed that clinical trials are needed to evaluate the effectiveness of preventive or curative treatments for migraine and that the clinical approach to migraine evaluation requires clinical efficacy in those who treated smaller numbers of headache sufferers who were elderly and in those who did not follow guidelines. The majority (93.1%) of GPs indicated that it was important to integrate clinical practice and the best available evidence, and this behavior was significantly more common among those who agreed that the clinical approach to treating migraine was a clinical efficacy evaluation requires, ie clinical trials required to evaluate the effectiveness of preventive or curative treatments of migraine and among those who have attended EBM courses. Training and education programs on EBM and headache management guidelines for primary care physicians are urgently needed.

title: Evidence-based Medicine and Women: Do EBM Principles and Practice Promote Women's Health?
abstract: Clinicians and policy makers around the world embrace Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM). The promise of EBM is to use summaries of research to determine which health interventions are effective and which are not, so patients can benefit from effective interventions and be protected from useless or harmful ones. EBM provides a seemingly rational objective means of deciding whether or not an intervention should be provided based on its effectiveness, theoretically leading to fair and effective healthcare for all. In this paper, I examine these claims from the perspective of women's health care, using relevant examples. I contend that the current processes of evidence-based medicine contain a number of prejudices against women. These biases appear in the production of research that informs evidence-based medicine, in the methods used to analyze and synthesize the evidence, and in the application of EBM through the use of guidelines. Finally, the biomedical model of health that underpins most of the medical research used by EBM ignores the social and political context that contributes so much to women's ill health.

title: Medicine based on facts. Interpreting studies and setting policies
abstract: The rise of EBM has been accompanied by a greater awareness of its shortcomings. The cost, length and difficulty of conducting RCTs makes it increasingly clear that studies cannot be conducted on every medical issue. Good evidence is often lacking in medicine. Epistomologists question the very notions of evidence and the suitability of current study designs and measurement tools to examine the salient problems faced by patients and others concerned with quality. The lack of evidence of effectiveness does not prove ineffectiveness, but in response to EBM, insurance companies and governments often make this conclusion to justify decisions to withhold coverage or research support. The unbridled enthusiasm for the evidence-based practice guideline of the early 1990s has been tempered by a more mature understanding of its limitations. Not many practice guidelines are well developed, and implementing flawed guidelines can be damaging. The seven-step process outlined above is slow, tedious, and expensive (sometimes costing hundreds of thousands of dollars). Furthermore, there is little evidence that either the rigor of the methods or the guidelines themselves have any meaningful impact on practice behavior or patient outcomes. To the most cynical observer, the only consistent beneficiaries of policies are payers, who use policies with notable success in reducing costs, dwell time, and usage rates. Even ardent supporters of guidelines recognize that the dissemination of reviews and recommendations alone does not motivate clinicians to increase the delivery of effective interventions and abandon ineffective ones. This lack of response has prompted a closer look at the barriers to behavior change and the development of thoughtful implementation strategies that start with simple policies but go beyond. Tools such as reminder systems, standing orders, academic detailing, peer review and audit, feedback and healthcare system changes recognize that knowing what to do is just one piece of an increasingly complex puzzle. The highly competitive market for managed healthcare has added new economic influences on clinician behavior, but it is also fueling the private sector's interest in good research. Patients, physicians and policy makers will continue to seek better data on what works and what doesn't in medicine.

title: Examining the Analytical Quality of Randomized Clinical Trials in Behavioral Health
abstract: Adopting an evidence-based practice policy (EBP) has implications for clinicians and researchers alike. In areas that have already adopted EBP, evidence-based practice guidelines derive from systematic reviews of research. Ultimately, such guidelines serve as tools used by practitioners. Systematic reviews of treatment efficacy and effectiveness reserve their strongest recommendations for treatments, supported by high-quality randomized clinical trials (RCTs). It is unknown how well RCTs reported in behavioral science journals compare to quality standards set in areas that pioneered the evidence-based movement. We compared analytical quality characteristics of all behavioral health RCTs (n = 73) published between January 2000 and July 2003 in three leading behavioral journals and two leading medical journals for an acute or chronic physical disease or condition. The results revealed weaknesses in analytical aspects of the behavioral health RCTs reported in both journal series. Weaknesses were more pronounced in behavioral journals. The authors provide recommendations for improving the analytical quality of behavioral health RCTs to ensure that evidence on behavioral therapies is heavily weighted in systematic reviews.

title: Investigating Clinical Assessment in an Adaptive Intervention Design: The Fast Track Program
abstract: Although clinical judgment is commonly used in assessment and treatment planning, research has rarely examined its reliability, validity, or impact in practice. This study adjusted the frequency of home visits in a prevention program for aggressive-disruptive children (n = 410; 56% minority) based on two types of clinical assessment: ratings of parental functioning using a standardized multi-item scale and global assessments of family needs for services. The 1st type of clinical assessment showed stronger reliability and better concurrent and predictive validity than the 2nd type. Exploratory analyzes suggested that using assessments of parental functioning to adjust treatment recommendations improved the effect of the intervention up to Late 3rd grade improved, but use of more global family needs assessments did not.

title: Exceptional Births: Home Births as Ethical Anomalies in American Obstetrics
abstract: Interest in home births appears to be growing among American women, and most obstetricians can expect to encounter patients who are considering home births. In 2011, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) released a statement to help obstetricians manage such patients. In this article, I examine the ACOG Statement in light of the historical and contemporary clinical realities surrounding homebirth in the United States, an investigation guided in part by my own experiences as an obstetrician in relation to pro-homebirth and anti-homebirth medical milieus. Comparison with other guidelines shows that ACOG treats home birth as an ethical exception: Comparable evidence leads to strikingly different recommendations in the case of home birth and in the case of trial labor after a previous cesarean section";" and ACOG treats other controversial issues that involve similar ethical issues very differently. By providing information not only as the primary but the sole ethical responsibility of the obstetrician, the ACOG Statement circumvents the obstetrician's responsibility to provide appropriate clinical care and the safest clinical environment for those mothers who choose to have a home birth, and to create for their newborns. What at first glance seems like a declaration of respect for women's autonomy implicitly authorizes behaviors that unethically limit genuinely autonomous choices. Obstetricians don't have to attend home births, I argue. However, our ethical duties oblige us to (1) refer clients to qualified clinicians who attend a home birth, (2) continue respectful prenatal care for women who choose to have a home birth, (3) provide appropriate counseling to home birth attendants, and (4) to ensure that the transfer of care is smooth and unpunished.

title: Exercise advice: the public health panacea for promoting physical activity? A Critical Perspective of Exercise Referral Programs";" their development and evaluation
abstract: This review critically examines the development, impact and evaluation of exercise referral schemes (ERS) in the UK. Rapid expansion of the use of such ERSs has been recorded in recreational and primary care settings, but evidence supporting their implementation has been sparse and mostly limited to randomized controlled trials (RCT) research design. Consequently, the understanding of the exercise recommendation as a “real world” intervention was limited. Given the increasing importance placed on evidence-based practice and clinical effectiveness, it is no longer sufficient for providers of exercise recommendations to ignore the need to evaluate programs. The assessment guidelines provided by the National Quality Assurance Framework for Exercise Referral are limited, so practitioners are often unsure of which measures to assess effectiveness are most appropriate. Training professionals focus mostly on collecting physiological data, but ignore relevant psychological and environmental parameters. Also, few UK studies have followed participants long-term to see if physical activity behaviors persist over time. Evidence from two ongoing large-scale (n=1600/year) evaluation studies of exercise recommendation schemes based in urban locations in North West England is described here. A participatory action research framework for assessment was used and integrated multi-method research approaches for assessment of both ERS participants and health professionals involved in delivery of interventions. This framework is an appropriate methodology for the assessment and development of complex interventions and here includes case studies, focus groups, interviews and questionnaires. Included was a 12-month follow-up study of a cohort of participants with exercise recommendation (n = 342) measuring the amount of leisure physical activity (Godin leisure score) at baseline (entry into exercise recommendation) and thereafter at 3-month intervals measured . ERS compliance was around 35-45%, with older participants more likely to complete. Physiological changes during the ERS, while statistically significant, were not of a magnitude to convey any real health benefit to an individual's health status. Although small in scale, all physiological changes were in a positive direction (e.g., lowering blood pressure) and, if sustained over time, could confer population-level health benefits. Participants referred by cardiac and practice nurses had higher adherence than participants referred by general practitioners. Scheme B showed that participants (n=103) who adhered to the end of the ERS (12 weeks) were able to sustain a small increase in physical activity at the end of 12 months (increase of 21 minutes of moderate activity/week vs to baseline). In summary, this research shows that the exercise recommendation process benefits certain segments of the population, but not necessarily all.

title: Expanded HIV screening in the United States: Implications for clinical outcomes, HIV transmission, and costs
abstract: Background: A large body of literature supports expanded HIV screening in the United States. However, the question of who to test and how often remains controversial. Aim: To inform the design of HIV screening programs by identifying combinations of screening frequency and HIV prevalence and incidence where screening is cost-effective. DESIGN: Cost-effectiveness analysis linking simulation models of HIV screening to published reports on the risk of HIV transmission with and without antiretroviral therapy. Data sources: Published randomized trials, observational cohorts, national cost and service use surveys, the Red Book, and previous modeling results. Target Population: US communities with low to moderate HIV prevalence (0.05% to 1.0%) and annual incidence (0.0084% to 0.12%). Time horizon: lifetime. Perspective: Social. Interventions: One-time and increasingly frequent voluntary HIV screening of all adults with a rapid same-day test. Outcome measures: HIV infection detected, secondary transmission prevented, quality-adjusted survival, lifetime medical cost, and societal cost-effectiveness expressed in discounted 2004 dollars per quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) gained. Base-case analysis results: Using moderately favorable assumptions about the effect of HIV patient care on secondary transmission, routine HIV screening in a population with an HIV prevalence of 1.0% and an annual incidence of 0.12% an incremental cost-effectiveness of $30,800/QALY (one time screening), $32,300/QALY (screening every 5 years), and $55,500/QALY (screening every 3 years). In settings with an HIV prevalence of 0.10% and an annual incidence of 0.014%, a single screening resulted in a cost-effectiveness of $60,700/QALY. Results of the sensitivity analysis: The cost-effectiveness of screening measures varied within a narrow range as assumptions about the effect of screening on secondary transmission varied from favorable to unfavorable. Assuming moderately beneficial effects of antiretroviral therapy on transmission, in settings with an HIV prevalence of only 0.20%, the cost-benefit ratio remained for routine HIV screening on a one-time basis and with prevalences as low as 0, 45% and below $50,000/QALY annually Incidences as low as 0.0075% for screening every 5 years. Limitations: This analysis does not address the difficulty of determining the prevalence and incidence of undetected HIV infection in a specific patient population. Conclusions: Routine rapid HIV testing is recommended for all adults except in settings where there is evidence that the prevalence of undiagnosed HIV infection is below 0.2%.

title: Expanding the use of continuous sedation until death: Going beyond last resort for the terminally ill
abstract: As currently practiced, the use of continuous sedation until death (CSD) is controlled by clinicians in a way that may deny patients an important choice in controlling their dying process. Ethical guidelines from the American Medical Association and the American Academy of Pain Medicine describe CSD as a "last resort," and a statement from the American Academy of Hospice and Palliative Medicine describes it as "an intervention reserved for extreme situations." Accordingly, patients must progress to incessant pain and suffering and reach a final intermediate stage before the option of pursuing CSD is considered. Alternatively, we present and defend a new guideline in which competent, terminally ill patients with a life expectancy of less than six months can request CSD before exposing the refractory condition to “last resort” treatment.

title: Experience-based design: from redesigning the system around the patient to co-designing services with the patient
abstract: Involving patients in service improvement and listening and responding to what they say has played a key role in redesigning healthcare delivery processes over the last five years and more. Patients and users have attended stakeholder events, participated in Discovery interviews, completed surveys, mapped healthcare processes, and even designed new hospitals with healthcare workers. So far, however, efforts have not necessarily focused on the patient's experience, apart from what has been good and what has not been. No questions were asked to find out details about how the experience was or should be ('experience' is different from 'attitudes') and the information was then used systematically to design services together with patients. The knowledge of the experience that only the patient possesses is unique and precious. This paper draws attention to the emerging discipline of design science and experience-based design, in which the traditional view of the user as the passive recipient of a product or service has begun to give way to the new view of the user as an integral part of the improvement and innovation process.

title: Expert panel vs. recommendations for decision analysis for coronary angiography after myocardial infarction discharge
abstract: Context Panels of experts and decision-analytic techniques are increasingly used to determine the appropriateness of medical interventions, but these two approaches use different methods of processing evidence. Aim To compare the adequacy ratings of the expert panel on coronary angiography after myocardial infarction (from the time of hospital discharge to 12 weeks after the infarction) with the health gains and cost-effectiveness predicted by a decision analytical model. Design To compare the degree of importance of clinical variables considered in expert panel adequacy ratings with a previously published decision analytic model. Identification of 36 clinical scenarios from the expert panel that could be simulated by the decision analytical model. Main outcome measures adequacy score and adequacy classification (expert panel) vs. gain in quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) and incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (decision analytical model). Results The key clinical variables were similar between the two approaches, with the exercise tolerance test result having the greatest impact on the strength of the recommendation for angiography. Among the expert panel clinical scenarios that were considered appropriate for coronary angiography and could be simulated in the decision analysis model, the median (interquartile range) health gain and incremental cost-effectiveness ratio was 0.59 (0.41-0.76) QALYs and $27,000 ($23,000). -$35,000) per QALY won. Among the clinical scenarios deemed inappropriate by expert panels, the corresponding medians (interquartile ranges) were 0.24 (0.19-0.34) QALYs and $54,000 ($36,000-58,000) per QALY gained. The Spearman rank correlation between the adequacy score and QALY gain was 0.58 (P<0.001) and between the adequacy score and the estimated incremental cost-effectiveness ratio was 0.66 (P<0.001). Conclusions For the 36 expert panel scenarios that could be simulated by the decision analytic model, there was moderate to good agreement between the adequacy score and both the health gain and the incremental cost-effectiveness of coronary angiography compared to no angiography Convalescent phase of acute myocardial infarction, but several scenarios judged inappropriate by the expert panel approach had cost-effectiveness comparable to many commonly recommended medical interventions. A formal synthesis of expert judgment and decision modeling is warranted in future guideline development efforts.

title: Explaining the impact of two different strategies to promote hand hygiene among hospital nurses: a process evaluation alongside a randomized controlled cluster study
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is limited understanding of why hand hygiene improvement strategies succeed or fail. It is therefore important to look into the "black box" of such strategies to determine which components of a strategy work well and which work less well. This study examined which components of two strategies to improve hand hygiene were associated with increased hand hygiene compliance by caregivers. METHODS: A process evaluation of a randomized controlled cluster study was performed in which a portion of the nursing wards of three hospitals in the Netherlands received a state-of-the-art strategy including education, reminders, feedback, and optimization of materials and facilities. ;" Another part received a team and leadership oriented strategy that included all elements of the state-of-the-art strategy, complemented by activities aimed at social and leadership improvement. This process evaluation used four sets of measures: Impact on nurses' hand hygiene compliance, adherence to improvement strategies, contextual factors, and nurses' experiences with strategy components.Analysis of variance and multiple regression analyzes were used to examine changes in nurses' hand hygiene compliance and thereby better understand study effects.RESULTS:Both strategies were performed with good adherence to protocol Two contextual factors were associated with changes in hand hygiene compliance: a long-term hospital effect (p<0.05) and high baseline hand hygiene scores were associated with smaller effects (p<0.01). correlated changes in the hand hygiene compliance of the nurses positively with the experience feedback about their hand hygiene performance (p < 0.05). In the long term, several items of the components "social influence" (ie addressing each other in the event of undesirable hand hygiene behavior p < 0.01) and "leadership" (ie ward management holds team members responsible for hand hygiene performance p < 0.01) correlated positively with changes in hand hygiene compliance of the nursing staff. CONCLUSION: This study illustrates the use of process evaluation to uncover mechanisms underlying change in strategies to improve hand hygiene. Our study results demonstrate the added value of specific aspects of social influence and leadership in hand hygiene improvement strategies, and thus provide an interpretation of the study effects. TRIAL REGISTRATION: The study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, dossier number: NCT00548015.

title: Discussing variations in primary care physician referral rates for back pain X-rays
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite the availability of clinical guidelines for the management of low back pain (LBP), large disparities in general practitioner (GP) referral rates for lumbar spine (LSX) X-rays remain. This study aims to explain the differences in primary care physician referral rates for LSX from their reports of treating patients with back pain. METHODS: Qualitative, semi-structured interviews with 29 GPs with high and low referral rates for LSX in North East England. The thematic analysis used constant comparison techniques. RESULTS: Common and divergent themes were identified among heavy and light users of LSX. Topics that were similar in both groups included awareness of current guidelines for use of LSX in patients with LBP and pressure from patients and institutional factors to order an LSX. Differentiating themes for the high-user group included: belief that LSX offers patients safety that can outweigh the risks, pessimism about treatment options for LBP, and belief that rejection of LSX will harm the physician relationship and would affect the patient.
