Two specific differentiating issues are considered in more detail: primary care physicians' awareness of their use of lumbar spine radiology compared to others, and the perceived risks associated with LSX irradiation. CONCLUSION: Several key factors differentiate the reports of high and low referral rates for LSX by primary care physicians despite being aware of the clinical guidelines recommendations. Intervention studies aiming to increase compliance with guideline recommendations on the use of LSX by changing the regulatory behavior of primary care physicians should focus on these factors.

title: Explanation of the differences in prescription costs across England
abstract: OBJECTIVE To derive a predictive model for national prescribing behavior in relation to underlying morbidity and demographic factors. DESIGN 24 Demographic, morbidity, and practice factors were input into multiple regression analysis to determine the net cost of ingredients per patient. SETTING The 90 family health authorities in England for 1989. RESULTS For the net component cost per patient, only two demographic factors (number of pensioners and the mobility of the registered population as measured by list inflation) and two morbidity-related factors (standardized mortality rates and numbers). of advance payment certificates issued) contributed significantly to a multiple regression model. This model explained 81% of the differences in net ingredient costs per enrolled patient between family health authorities. The model also allowed the derivation of a weighting factor of 4.6 (95% confidence interval 3.2 to 6.7) for the net drug cost for elderly patients (compared to the existing prescription unit factor of 3). CONCLUSIONS The model shows that variations in prescription costs largely reflect demand. It also suggests that the current prescription unit value of 3 for patients 65 years and older underestimates the additional cost of prescribing for older patients.

title: Exploratory analysis of patients' motivation to quit smoking and to participate in smoking cessation courses
abstract: BACKGROUND AND AIMS: Significant research has examined the effects of smoking, the effects of exposure to secondhand smoke, the effectiveness of a variety of social and individual smoking cessation interventions, and the frequency with which physicians talk to their patients about smoking cessation. Little research has addressed barriers to physician-initiated discussions and interventions related to smoking cessation, particularly in relation to office-based physicians treating low-income patients. Existing research shows that physicians have low expectations of patients' desire to quit and often wait to discuss smoking cessation with patients until the patient raises the issue. The purpose of this pilot project was to identify trends in smoking, the desire to quit smoking, and the desire to participate in smoking cessation courses in the general practitioner's office. METHODS: Patients completed a survey collecting demographic information, smoking behavior, presence of a chronic disease, desire to quit, and reasons for wanting to quit. RESULTS: Higher rates of smoking and lower rates of desired smoking cessation were noted. However, among patients considering smoking cessation, a relatively high number wanted smoking cessation courses. A higher number of failed quit attempts was an indication that both the likelihood of wanting to quit and the desire for quit classes would increase. Other predictors of the desire to complete and attend classes are discussed. CONCLUSIONS: Based on the current research, physicians are encouraged to follow practice guidelines, survey smoking behavior of all patients, and assist in their smoking cessation efforts, particularly those who have previously been unsuccessful.

title: Exploring the perspectives of nurses and patients regarding setting boundaries in a mental health forensic setting
abstract: Boundary setting is an intervention commonly used by mental health care workers. However, setting limits is poorly designed, its purpose is unclear, and there are few evidence-based guidelines to help caregivers set limits in a safe and effective manner. What is known is that how caregivers set boundaries affects patients' perceptions of the interactions and their emotional and behavioral responses. In this qualitative study, 12 nurses and 12 patients participated in face-to-face, semi-structured interviews aimed at examining boundary setting and proposing principles for practice. The results suggest that: (i) setting boundaries is important for safety in psychiatric hospitals; (ii) empathetic patient involvement is required in setting boundaries (when caregivers engage empathetically, the therapeutic relationship is more likely to be sustained and the risk of aggressive responses is reduced);" and (iii) an authoritative (fair, respectful , consistent and knowledgeable) rather than authoritarian (controlling and indifferent) Boundary style improves positive outcomes in terms of adherence, reduced likelihood of aggression, and maintenance of the therapeutic relationship Authoritarian interpersonal style Explaining the components of this style is critical to effective mental health nurse education and best practice, and to reducing aggressive responses to boundary setting.

title: Exploring the feasibility of conjoint analysis as a tool to prioritize innovation for implementation
abstract: Background In an era of scarce and competing implementation priorities, choosing what to implement is a key decision point for many behavior change projects. The values and attitudes of the professionals and managers involved inevitably influence the priority of decision options. Recording such values reliably is a challenge. Methods This paper presents an approach to capturing and incorporating professional values in prioritizing health innovations to be considered for adoption. Conjoint Analysis (CA) was used in a single UK Primary Care Trust to measure the priorities of healthcare professionals working with women with postnatal depression. Assessment-based CA data was collected using a questionnaire and then assigned to 12 interventions considered as a means of improving the management of postnatal depression. Findings The "patient care impact" and "quality of evidence" associated with the potential innovations were the most influential in shaping the priorities. Professionals were least influenced by whether an innovation was an established national or local priority or whether current practice in the Trust met minimum standards. Ranking the 12 innovations by potential adopter preferences found that ¡Â®guided self-help¡Â¯ was the top priority for implementation and ¡®screening questions for postnatal depression¡Â¯ the least. When other factors were considered (such as the existence of routine data or planned implementation activities elsewhere in the Trust), the project team chose to combine the eight related treatments and implement them as a single innovation, dubbed ¡ÂPsychological Therapies will. A. Conclusions Using conjoint analysis to prioritize potential innovation implementation options is a viable means to capture stakeholder benefits and thus increase the chances that an innovation will be adopted. There are some practical obstacles that need to be overcome, such as: B. Increasing response rates on collaborative surveys before routine and unevaluated use of this technique should be considered.

title: Investigating the gap between knowledge and behavior: a qualitative study of clinical action after an educational intervention
abstract: PURPOSE: Many medical education interventions improve clinician knowledge but do not change behavior. The authors uncovered this gap between knowledge and behavior through standardized clinical interactions, allowing for an in-depth study of the contributing factors. METHOD: A typical evidence-based educational intervention in a clinical setting (early signs of autism) was delivered to resident physicians at the University of Toronto in 2001-02, and change in knowledge was assessed by a multiple-choice test. Six to eight weeks later, the participants' relevant knowledge was documented and their clinical behavior was observed in four interactions with standardized patients. Factors causing a discrepancy between knowledge and behavior were then examined using semi-structured interviews that were tape-recorded, transcribed and analyzed using grounded theory methods. RESULTS: Half of the participants showed varying degrees of knowledge-behavior gaps. Eight major rationalizations (relationships, patient agenda, knowledge deficits, clinical style, means to an end, ideals, autism stigma, and system barriers) were used to justify clinical behavior choices, and the same rationalizations were used to justify opposing behavioral choices. Two conditions have been identified that promote knowledge-based clinical action (level of certainty and sense of urgency). CONCLUSION: The knowledge-behaviour gap was revealed and factors influencing clinicians' decision to implement new knowledge were identified. That identical rationalizations were used to justify opposite behaviors implies that these factors may not be behavioral determinants. The sense of urgency and level of certainty encourages clinical action based on knowledge";" Focusing on these can increase the impact of education on practice.

title: Exploring the roots of unintended security threats associated with the deployment of e-prescribing systems in hospitals and strategies to avoid and/or mitigate candidates: a qualitative study
abstract: Objective Hospital electronic prescribing systems (ePrescribing) offer a variety of patient safety benefits. However, like other health informatics interventions in hospitals, they can also introduce new areas of risk. Despite recent advances in identifying these risks, the development and use of ePrescription systems still leads to numerous unintended consequences that can undermine improvements and jeopardize patient safety. These negative consequences must be analyzed when designing, implementing and using these systems. Our goal was therefore to understand the roots of these reported threats and identify potential avoidance/mitigation strategies. Methods We analyzed a qualitative longitudinal study of the implementation and introduction of ePrescription systems in six English hospitals, each designed as a case study. The data included semi-structured interviews, observations of implementation meetings and system usage, and a collection of relevant documents. We analyzed data first within and then across the case studies. Results Our dataset comprised 214 interviews, 24 observations and 18 documents. We have developed a taxonomy of factors underlying unintended security threats, in: (1) suboptimal system design, including lack of support for complex medication administration regimens, lack of effective integration between different systems, and lack of effective automated decision support tools"; (2) inappropriate usage of systems - particularly over-reliance on the system and the introduction of workarounds;" and (3) sub-optimal implementation strategies resulting from partial rollouts/dual systems and lack of adequate training. We have identified a number of systems and organizational strategies that address these Risks could potentially be avoided or reduced Conclusions Imperfections in the design, implementation and use of ePrescription systems can lead to unintended consequences, including security risks Hospitals and suppliers must implement short- and long-term strategies in technical and organizational terms to minimize unintended security risks.

title: External validity of randomized controlled trials: "To whom do the results of this study apply?"
abstract: When making treatment decisions, physicians and patients must consider relevant randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and systematic reviews. Relevance depends on external validity (or generalizability), ie whether the results can be meaningfully applied to a definable group of patients in a specific clinical setting in routine practice. Clinicians are concerned that external validity is often poor, particularly for some pharmaceutical industry studies, a perception that has led to underutilization of effective treatments. Yet researchers, funding agencies, ethics committees, the pharmaceutical industry, medical journals, and government regulators alike neglect external validity, leaving clinicians to make judgments. However, the reporting of the determinants of external validity in study publications and systematic reviews is usually inadequate. This review discusses these determinants, presents a checklist for clinicians, and makes recommendations for giving more consideration to external validity in the design and reporting of RCTs.

title: Facilitating patient self-management of diabetes: a primary care intervention framework
abstract: A primary care quality framework for diabetes self-management (DSM) is presented based on the prevailing changes in the practice environment. Recent DSM research and literature is reviewed in relation to (a) patients' DSM perceptions and experiences of office visits, and (b) more effective practice-based DSM programs. This high-quality primary care framework enables caregivers to more consistently assess and integrate individual patient factors, while diverting typically limited clinical resources into physician visits to optimize outcomes for DSM patients.

title: Faculty Surveys: Using Vignettes to Examine Professional Judgment.
abstract: Decision-making is becoming an increasingly central feature of social work practice, yet there is limited research on the subject. Experimental methods of studying decision-making are typically limited by practical and ethical difficulties, while questions of validity and generalizability concern ethnographic and other descriptive methods. It is argued here that factorial survey addresses these methodological difficulties as a research design to study how professionals make decisions in real life. In this research design, real-life vignettes (case scenarios or paper cases) are presented to social workers or other staff to make a judgment about a known type of scenario. The randomized factors within the vignettes, combined with the randomization of the selection of vignettes for each decision maker, give factorial survey, as opposed to the more common factorial experiment, a unique ability to examine the effect of multiple factors in complex decisions. The method is explained and perspectives and questions for the development of this research design for researching professional judgment in social work are discussed. Factorial survey has potential as a method to rigorously study the influence of client, family, and context factors on social worker and social worker decisions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Factors affecting the feasibility and acceptability of a practice-based educational intervention in support of evidence-based prescribing: a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Inappropriate and costly GP prescriptions are a major problem for primary care trusts. Awareness-raising in practice, as well as other measures such as audit and feedback, have the potential to make GP prescribing more evidence-based. High GP prescription costs are associated with GPs visiting pharmaceutical company representatives; tend to end consultations with prescriptions;" and "try out" new drugs on an "ad hoc basis" and use this as evidence of the drug's effect. To address these and other educational needs, an educational intervention called developed “reflective practice.” The design of the intervention was informed by studies that have identified the prerequisites for successful behavior change in general practice.OBJECTIVES: The study examined the following: (i) Is it feasible for GPs to attend the sessions that included in the pedagogical intervention? (ii) Is the intervention acceptable to the participants and the session leaders? (iii) What are the barriers to the group building processes and how can these be overcome? METHODS: Four practices were recruited in South West England, all of which had problems with the appropriateness and cost of the prescription Lessons (including a videotaped scenario) were conducted in each of these exercises, and qualitative methods were used to examine the participants' complex attitudes and behaviors. A researcher observed and taped sessions at each practice. At the end of the program, a sample of doctors and all moderators were asked about their experiences. The recorded data were transcribed and analyzed using standard qualitative methods. RESULTS: Physicians in the largest partnerships had the most difficulty attending the sessions. Elsewhere, physicians were reluctant to get involved, given their previous experience of top-down management initiatives to prescribe quality. The presenters came from a wide range of professional backgrounds. While knowledge of issues related to the management of prescribed medicines was important, the professional background of the facilitator was less important than group facilitation skills in order to create a group process that the participating GPs found satisfactory. The videotaped scenario proved useful in staging the discussion. Maintaining the anonymity of the GPs' responses in the early stages of the sessions was important to ensure honesty in the discussion. Reaching consensus on how to treat common conditions has sometimes been difficult, partly because the use of the term "best buy" implies economic pressures rather than patient benefits, and partly because of the value that general practitioners attach to the concept of clinical attribute autonomy. Reflective practice seemed to have the potential to make GPs aware of the link that needs to be made between their clinical management decisions and the evidence of the British National Formulary and Clinical Evidence. CONCLUSION: The study demonstrates the importance of adequately preparing practice, including providing protected time for all GPs to participate in the training intervention. Scenarios and the structure of the sessions need to make the links between everyday practice and published evidence of effectiveness clearer. Emphasizing cost-effectiveness can be counterproductive and broader benefits need to be emphasized. We also identified the skill profile of the facilitator role. Our study points to the need for a clearer understanding of primary care physicians' perceptions of clinical autonomy and how this conflicts with the goal of agreeing on treatment guidelines for practice. The intervention is now ripe for further development, perhaps through integration with other behavior modification interventions. The improved intervention should then be evaluated in a randomized controlled trial.

title: Factors associated with nursing interventions to reduce incontinence in hospitalized older adults
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The problem of incontinence in elderly hospitalized patients is rarely documented, and there is little research determining why caregivers do or do not help with this problem. Are hospital nurses' attitudes and beliefs about incontinence related to their perceived ability to help the patient with the problem? What do hospital nurses know about causes and measures related to incontinence? METHODS: Two vignettes, one describing a patient with stress urinary incontinence and one describing a patient with urge urinary incontinence, were created. Questions were developed that measured variables of a support model, and nurses were asked to mark on a Likert scale when answering each question. RESULTS: One hundred and fifty respondents, along with three nursing professionals, returned completed questionnaires. Many hospital nurses believed that incontinence was temporary and part of aging. As a group, they had a more positive attitude towards intervention for urge urinary incontinence and believed that the doctor and their nurse expected them to help the patient with urge urinary incontinence. Respondents tended to believe that the patient was the least likely to expect help. Regarding the possibility of providing help for stress or urge incontinence, the opinions of those surveyed were evenly divided. Less than half of nurses correctly listed causes and interventions for stress or urge incontinence. CONCLUSIONS: Other clinical problems that are perceived as more pressing and a lack of knowledge about appropriate supportive measures impair nurses' perception of opportunities to intervene when elderly hospitalized patients are incontinent. Assessment and intervention are essential to quality nursing care. Basic nursing education and ongoing staff education about incontinence are critical if assessments and interventions are to be accurate. Patients, as consumers of healthcare, need to be better informed about incontinence and make the choice to have the problem treated during the hospital stay. The Agency for Health Care Policy and Research Clinical Practice Guidelines is an important recommended reference.

title: Factors associated with poor mental health among Guatemalan refugees living in Mexico 20 years after the civil war
abstract: Context From 1981 to 2001, 46,000 refugees fleeing Guatemala's 36-year civil war to Chiapas, Mexico, were under the protection of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Objectives To estimate the prevalence of mental illness and factors associated with poor mental health in underserved Guatemalan refugee communities in Chiapas, Mexico, since 1981 and identify mental health service needs. Design, Setting, and Participants Cross-sectional survey of 183 households in 5 Mayan refugee camps in Chiapas with an estimated population of 1546 (adults and children) conducted November-December 2000. Main Outcome Measures Symptom criteria of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), anxiety, and depression as measured by the Harvard Trauma Questionnaire and the Hopkins Symptom Checklist-25 (Hopkins-25). Results One adult (age = 16 years) per household (n = 170 respondents) who consented to participate was included in the analysis, representing an estimated 93% of households. All respondents reported having experienced at least 1 traumatic event, with a mean of 8.3 traumatic events per person. Of the respondents, 20 (11.8%) had all symptom criteria for PTSD. Of the 160 who completed the Hopkins Symptom Checklist-25, 87 (54.4%) had anxiety symptoms and 62 (38.8%) had depression symptoms. witnessing the disappearance of family members (adjusted odds ratio [AOR], 4.58", 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.35-15.50), being close to death (AOR, 4.19, 95% CI, 1, 03–17.00) or alive with 9 to 15 people in the same household (AOR, 3.69; 95% CI, 1.19–11.39) were associated with symptoms of PTSD. A protective factor for lack of adequate food (AOR, 0.08; 95% CI, 0.01-0.59). Increased anxiety symptoms were associated with witnessing a massacre (AOR, 10.63; 95% CI, 4.31-26.22) , one wound (AOR, 3.22; 95% CI, 0.95-10.89) and experiencing 7 to 12 traumatic events (AOR, 2.67; 95% CI, 1.14-6.27 ) and 13 to 19 traumatic events (AOR, 2.26; 95% CI, 0.65-7.89) Increased symptoms of depression were associated with being a woman (AOR, 3.64; 95% CI , 1.47-9, 04), widowed (AOR, 27.55; 95% CI, 2.54-299.27), married (AOR, 1.93; 95% CI, 0.59-6.33), witnessed disappearance be (AOR, 2.68; 95% CI, 1st ,16). -6.19), experiencing 7 to 12 traumatic events (AOR, 1.57; 95% CI, 0.64-3.88), or experiencing 13 to 19 traumatic events (AOR, 7.44; " 95% CI, 2.18-25.37.) Conclusion Psychiatric morbidity related to human rights violations, traumatic events, and refugee status was widespread among Guatemalan refugees interviewed 20 years after the Guatemalan Civil War.

title: Failure of computer-assisted treatment suggestions to improve health outcomes in outpatients with uncomplicated hypertension: results from a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: study objective. Assessing the impact of evidence-based treatment proposals for hypertension made to physicians and pharmacists using a comprehensive electronic medical record system. Design. Randomized controlled trial with a 2×2 factorial design of physician and pharmacist interventions, resulting in four patient groups: physician intervention only, pharmacist intervention only, physician and pharmacist intervention, and neither physician nor pharmacist intervention (control). Setting. Academic family doctor practice for internal medicine. Subjects. Seven hundred and twelve patients with uncomplicated hypertension. Measurements and main results. The suggestions were shown to doctors at computer workstations to create outpatient prescriptions and to pharmacists when filling out prescriptions. The primary endpoint was overall health-related quality of life. Secondary endpoints were symptom profile and side effects of antihypertensive drugs, number of emergency department visits and hospital admissions, blood pressure measurements, patient satisfaction with physicians and pharmacists, adherence to drug therapy, and healthcare costs. In the control group, 26% of the patients observed the implementation of care changes in accordance with treatment suggestions. In the intervention groups, compliance with suggestions was poor, with treatment suggestions being implemented in 25% of patients for whom suggestions were shown to pharmacists only, 29% of patients for whom suggestions were shown only to physicians, and 35% of the group for whom both Physicians as well as pharmacists received suggestions (p=0.13). Differences between groups were neither statistically significant nor clinically relevant for overall health-related quality of life, symptom and adverse reaction profiles, number of emergency department visits and hospital stays, blood pressure measurements, fees, or drug therapy adherence. Conclusion. Computer-assisted intervention using a sophisticated electronic physician order entry system did not improve adherence to treatment recommendations or outcomes in patients with uncomplicated hypertension.

title: Fall prevention in acute care hospitals: a randomized study.
abstract: Context Falls cause injury and death in people of all ages, but the risk of falls increases significantly with age. Hospitalization further increases risk, but there is no evidence to support short-term hospital-based fall prevention strategies to reduce patient falls. Aim To study whether a Fall Prevention Toolkit (FPTK) using Health Information Technology (HIT) reduces the falls of patients in hospitals. Design, setting, and patient cluster randomized study conducted January 1, 2009 to June 30, 2009 comparing fall rates of patients at 4 metropolitan US hospitals in units receiving usual care (4 units and 5104 patients) or the intervention (4 units and 5160 patients). Intervention The FPTK integrated existing communication and work processes into the HIT application. Based on a valid fall risk rating scale filled out by a nurse, the FPTK software adjusted fall prevention interventions to account for the specific determinants of patients' fall risk. The FPTK produced bedside posters consisting of short text with an accompanying symbol, patient education handouts, and care plans, all of which conveyed patient-specific warnings to key stakeholders. Main Outcome Parameters The primary objective was patient falls per 1000 patient-days, adjusted for site and patient care unit. A secondary endpoint was fall-related injuries. Results During the 6-month intervention period, the number of patients with falls differed between control (n = 87) and intervention (n = 67) units (P = 0.02). Site-adjusted fall rates were significantly higher in control units (4.18 [95% confidence interval {CI}, 3.45-5.06] per 1,000 patient-days) than in intervention units (3.15 [95% CI, 2.54-3, 90] per 1,000 patients). -days"; P=0.04). FPTK was found to be particularly effective in patients 65 years of age and older (adjusted rate difference 2.08 [95% CI, 0.61-3.56] per 1000 patient-days; " P = .003). No significant effect was found for fall-related injuries. Conclusion The use of a fall prevention toolkit in hospital departments significantly reduced the rate of falls compared to usual care.

title: Requests from family members for extension of physiological support after determination of brain death: a case series analysis and proposed guidelines for clinical management
abstract: We describe and analyze 13 cases processed by our Ethics Advisory Service (ECS) in which families requested continuation of physiological support for loved ones after death had been declared using neurological criteria (DNC). These ethics consultations took place between 2005 and 2013. The age of the patients ranged from 14 to 85 years. Continued mechanical ventilation was the key intervention sought by all families. The ECS's advice and recommendations generally encouraged "appropriate accommodation" of the requests by balancing compassion for grieving families with other ethical and moral concerns such as resource stewardship, professional integrity, and moral suffering. In cases that we characterized as arrangements with finite goals, a “reasonable accommodation” strategy proved effective in balancing the interests and goals of those involved and enabling steady progress toward a resolution. When a family directly objected to a DNC declaration and requested an indefinite accommodation, the “reasonable accommodation” approach offered little practical guidance to physicians and a resolution required definitive action by either the family or the clinical team. Based on our analysis and reflections on these 13 cases, we propose ethically justifiable and practical guidance to support healthcare professionals, administrators and ECSs facing similar cases.

title: Family-based interventions to increase physical activity in children: a meta-analysis and realistic synthesis protocol
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Despite the proven association between physical activity and health, data suggest that many children are underactive and that levels decline into adolescence. Involving the family in interventions can increase and maintain children's physical activity levels at the critical juncture prior to secondary school. The synthesis of existing evidence will inform future studies, but the heterogeneity of the target populations recruited, the behavior modification techniques and intervention strategies employed, and the measurements taken may require a multifaceted verification methodology. Therefore, the primary goal of this work will be to summarize evidence from intervention studies that explicitly involve the family unit to increase physical activity in children by using an innovative dual meta-analysis and a realistic approach. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Peer-reviewed studies are independently reviewed for inclusion by two authors based on (1) including "healthy" participants aged 5-12 years";" (2) have a substantive intervention goal of increasing physical activity by involving the family, and (3) report on physical activity. The duplicate data extraction and quality assessment is performed using a specially designed form or quality assessment tool of the Effective Public Health Practice Project. STATA software is used to calculate effect sizes for meta-analyses, performing subgroup analysis to identify moderating traits. Realistic syntheses are carried out according to RAMESES quality and publication guidelines, including the development of a program theory and evidence mapping. DISSEMINATION: This review will be the first to use a traditional review framework to perform a dual meta-analysis and realistic synthesis and examine interventions that involve the family to increase physical activity in children. Findings are disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, conferences, formal presentations to policymakers and practitioners, and informal meetings. The evidence generated from this synthesis will also be used to inform the development of theory-guided, evidence-based interventions aimed at involving the family to increase physical activity levels in children. REGISTRATION OF THE PROTOCOL: International Prospective Register for Systematic Reviews (PROSPERO): number CRD42013005780.

title: Family member DOTS and community DOTS for tuberculosis control in Nepal: cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BackgroundAn important part of the DOTS strategy for tuberculosis control (short-course chemotherapy according to WHO guidelines) is the direct observation of the treatment. WHO technical guidelines recommend that health workers should take on this part of the strategy, but also accept direct observation of treatment in the community.” WHO does not agree that a family member should take on this role. Evidence for these recommendations is not available. The Nepal National Tuberculosis Program asked us to develop and test a strategy for direct observation of treatment for the mountainous districts of Nepal where direct observation of treatment by health workers is not possible. We wanted to evaluate the success rates of two DOTS strategies developed for Background A key component of the DOTS strategy for tuberculosis control (short-course chemotherapy according to WHO guidelines) is direct observation of treatment. WHO technical guidelines recommend that health workers should take on this part of the strategy, but also accept direct observation of treatment in the community;' WHO does not agree that a family member should take on this role. Evidence for these recommendations is lacking The Nepal National Tuberculosis Program asked us to develop and test a direct observation of treatment strategy for the mountainous districts of Nepal where direct observation of treatment by health workers is not possible.Our aim was to compare the success rates of two DOTS strategies to evaluate that have been developed for such areas.

title: Rapidly tracing the design of theory-based KT interventions through a consensus process
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite available evidence for optimal management of spinal pain, poor adherence to guidelines and large disparities in healthcare remain. One of the goals of the Canadian Chiropractic Guideline Initiative is to develop and evaluate targeted theory- and evidence-based interventions to improve chiropractor management of non-specific neck pain. To systematically develop a knowledge translation (KT) intervention underpinned by the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF), we examined the factors influencing the use of multimodal care to treat nonspecific neck pain and domain-assigned key theories to behavior modification techniques. METHODS: One-on-one telephone interviews were conducted with a targeted sample of 13 chiropractors, examining beliefs about coping with neck pain. The interview guide was based on the TDF. The interviews were digitally recorded, transcribed verbatim and evaluated by two independent experts using thematic content analysis. A 15-person panel of experts formally met to design a KT intervention. RESULTS: Nine TDF domains were identified as likely relevant. Key beliefs (and relevant areas of the TDF) included the following: influence of formal education, peers, and patients on clinicians (social influences), availability of educational materials (environmental context and resources), and better clinical outcomes that support the use of multimodal procedures reinforce caring (reinforcement). Supporting factors considered important included better communication (skills), audits of patients' treatment-related outcomes (behavioural regulation), awareness and compliance with guidelines (knowledge);" and tailoring of multimodal care (memory, attention, and decision-making processes). Clinicians mediated conflicting beliefs about perceived threats to professional autonomy (social/professional role and identity) and the speed of recovery by applying or ignoring the practice recommendations (beliefs about consequences).The expert panel mapped behavior modification techniques to important theoretical areas and identified relevant KT Strategies and modes of delivery to increase the use of multimodal care among chiropractors CONCLUSIONS: A multifaceted KT educational intervention has been developed that targets the management of neck pain d targeted by chiropractors. The KT intervention consisted of an online educational webinar series, clinical vignettes, and a video underpinned by the short action planning model. The intervention was designed to reflect key theoretical areas, behavior change techniques, and intervention components. The effectiveness of the proposed intervention has yet to be tested.

title: Feasibility and acceptability of two incentive-based implementation strategies for psychotherapists implementing cognitive behavioral therapy: a pilot study informing a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Informed by our previous work suggesting that therapists do not feel recognized or rewarded for implementing evidence-based practices, we tested the feasibility and acceptability of two incentive-based implementation strategies aimed at increasing therapist adherence to cognitive behavioral therapy for improve youth. an evidence-based practice. Methods This study was conducted over 6 weeks in two community mental health facilities with therapists (n?=?11) and leaders (n?=?4). Therapists were randomized to receive either a financial or social incentive if they met a predetermined criterion for adherence to cognitive behavioral therapy. In the first phase of the intervention (Block 1; 2 weeks), therapists received the reward originally randomized to them if they met the criterion. In the second intervention phase (Block 2; 2 weeks), therapists received both rewards if they met the criterion. The therapists recorded 41 sessions with 15 individual clients during the project period. The primary endpoints included feasibility and acceptability. The feasibility was evaluated quantitatively. Fifteen semi-structured interviews were conducted with therapists and leaders to assess acceptability. As an exploratory result, the difference in therapist adherence depending on the condition was examined. Adherence scores were determined using an established and validated observational coding system of cognitive behavioral therapy. Results Both implementation strategies were feasible and acceptable - however, study design changes will be required for the larger study based on participant feedback. Regarding our exploratory analysis, we found a trend suggesting that financial reward had a stronger effect on therapist loyalty than social reward. Conclusions Incentive-based implementation strategies can be implemented in community mental health settings with good acceptance, although iterative piloting is essential. Larger, full-fledged studies are needed to compare the effectiveness of implementation strategies to encourage therapists to adhere to and improve on evidence-based practices such as cognitive behavioral therapy.

title: Feasibility and impact of a computer-assisted clinical decision support system on assessment and initial management of new onset chest pain: a mixed-methods study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical decision support systems (CDSS) can modify clinical behavior, but the factors that influence their action are still poorly understood. This study evaluates the feasibility and acceptability of a CDSS to support diagnosis and treatment decisions in patients with suspected stable angina. METHODS: Intervention The Optimizing Management of Angina (OMA) program includes a lead CDSS assessment and medication decisions for physicians treating patients with emerging stable angina based on English national guidelines introduced through an educational intervention. Design and participants A mixed methods study i. A study of outcomes in patients with suspected angina in three chest pain clinics in England before and after the introduction of the OMA programme. ii. Observations of clinical processes, interviews and a focus group with healthcare professionals in two chest pain clinics after implementation of the OMA program. RESULTS: Medication and cardiovascular imaging studies performed within six months of presentation and their compliance with CDSS recommendations. Thematic analysis of qualitative data to understand how the CDSS was used. RESULTS: Data from 285 patients attending chest pain clinics were analyzed: 106 before and 179 after the OMA program. 40 consultations were observed, 5 clinicians were interviewed, and a post-intervention focus group was held. The proportion of patients eligible for diagnostic testing who received one was 50% (95 CI 34-66%) of pre-OMA patients and 59% (95 CI 48-70%) of post-OMA patients. Despite the high use of the CDSS (84% of consultations), observations and interviews revealed difficulties in entering data into the CDSS and structural and practical barriers to its use. In most cases, the CDSS was not used for real-time decision making, but was only consulted after the patient left the room. CONCLUSIONS: The OMA CDSS for the treatment of chest pain is not feasible in its current form. The CDSS was not used to support individual patient care decisions. A number of barriers to using the CDSS have been identified, some of which can be easily addressed, such as: e.g., under-assessment of cardiovascular risk, while others are more deeply embedded in current practice, e.g. B. the unavailability of some tests or no prescribing privileges for nurses.

title: Feasibility of Conducting a Randomized Controlled Trial of Elementary Health in Children Diagnosed with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder in Underserved Communities
abstract: AIM: Elementary Health (TMH), the use of video teleconferencing to deliver care services that are typically delivered in person, is increasingly being used to address inequalities in access to care. However, few studies have been conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of TMH as a service delivery model. The Children's Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) Elemental Health Treatment Study (CATTS) is a randomized clinical trial (RCT) of TMH conducted in multiple underserved communities. This article reports on the feasibility of an efficacy study of TMH in children. METHODS: The CATTS study used video conference calls to provide guideline-based care and secure websites to coordinate important aspects of study delivery, such as: RESULTS: The CATTS study involved seven communities and 150 primary care physicians as study partners and included 223 children aged 5.5 to 12.9 years. The intervention group completed an average of 5.3 out of 6.0 scheduled sessions and 96% of the control group completed a TMH consultation. Both groups completed an average of 4.8 of the 5.0 assessments. Clinicians demonstrated high fidelity to their treatment protocols. Minor technical difficulties did not affect the supply. CONCLUSIONS: The CATTS study demonstrated the feasibility of conducting an RCT of TMH with children living in multiple underserved communities. Telecommunication technologies can facilitate the coordination of research activities across sites and clinicians. Future studies should work closely with study partners to ensure referral of a representative study sample. Further studies are needed to establish the effectiveness of TMH as a model for service delivery. TRIAL REGISTRATION: http://clinicaltrials.gov/show/NCT00830700.

title: Feasibility study of an asthma intervention to communicate and educate general practitioners in Australia
abstract: The Physician Asthma Care Education (PACE) program has significantly improved the prescribing and communication behavior of US primary care pediatricians. We tested the feasibility and acceptability of a modified PACE program with Australian General Practitioners (GPs) and measured its impact on self-reported counseling behavior in a pilot study. Recruitment was through a local GP department. Twenty-five GPs completed two PACE Australia workshops that included pediatric asthma management in line with Australian Asthma Guidelines and focused on effective communication strategies. Feasibility, usefulness and perceived benefits of the program were measured by questionnaires before the workshop and one month later, and by an evaluation questionnaire after each workshop. GP were consistently enthusiastic and supported the workshops. The most useful items they reported were communication skills, case studies, device demonstrations and the toolkit provided. GP self-reports of perceived helpfulness of key communication strategies and their confidence in their use and reported frequency of use increased significantly after the workshops. The PACE program shows promise in improving the way Australian GPs manage asthma consultations, particularly in terms of doctor-patient communication. The impact of the modified PACE Australia program on the processes and outcomes of primary care for children with asthma will now be measured in a randomized controlled trial.

title: Feasibility, accuracy, and clinical impact of point-of-care Xpert MTB/RIF testing for primary care tuberculosis in Africa: a multicenter, randomized, controlled study
abstract: BackgroundThe Xpert MTB/RIF test for tuberculosis is being introduced in many countries, but evidence is lacking for its implementation outside of laboratories, the ability to make same-day treatment decisions at the point-of-care, and the clinical impact on the tuberculosis related morbidity. Our objective was to evaluate the feasibility, accuracy and clinical impact of point-of-care Xpert MTB/RIF testing in primary care settings in Southern Africa.";" BackgroundThe Xpert MTB/RIF test for tuberculosis is being introduced in many countries, but evidence is lacking for its implementation outside of laboratories, the ability to make same-day treatment decisions at the point-of-care, and the clinical impact on the tuberculosis related morbidity. Our aim was to evaluate the feasibility, accuracy and clinical impact of point-of-care Xpert MTB/RIF testing in primary care healthcare settings in Southern Africa.

title: Feedback as a behavior change strategy: The devil is in the details
abstract: BACKGROUND: Performance feedback is one of several strategies to improve clinical practice among students and physicians. OBJECTIVES: The objective of this paper was to examine conceptual foundations and essential components for audit and feedback strategies, assess the extent to which recently published audit and feedback interventions incorporate these components, and recommend future directions for feedback to improve its educational and behavioral impact . METHODS: Based on the actionable feedback model, we examined the presence of four theoretical constructs - timeliness, individualization, lack of punishment, and adaptability - in studies published between 2009 and 2010 that included a feedback intervention. RESULTS: There were large differences in the definition, implementation, and outcomes of "feedback" interventions, making comparison between studies difficult. None of the studies we reviewed included all of the components of the actionable feedback model. CONCLUSIONS: Feedback interventions reported to date, even when the outcomes are positive, often do not include concepts of behavior change. This can partly explain the large differences in the approaches and outcomes of such interventions and poses major challenges for the repetition of a given intervention. If feedback processes are to be used, disseminated and implemented successfully, there needs to be some standardization and certainly more clarity in the specific ones Action steps for applying behavior theory in practice.

title: Fibromyalgia treatment update
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: Fibromyalgia is a common chronic pain disorder characterized by complex symptomatology and few consistently effective treatments. The purpose of this review is to highlight the current literature from April 2005 to September 2006 with treatment options. RECENT RESULTS: Previous evidence suggests that medication and self-treatment approaches can improve symptoms, functioning and well-being in this patient population. Recent studies examining the effectiveness of two serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors - duloxetine and milnacipran - and the anticonvulsant drug pregabalin are encouraging. Studies evaluating different forms of exercise continue to support the belief that increased physical activity is an essential part of any treatment plan for patients with fibromyalgia. Three studies contributed to the understanding of treatment adherence. Finally, three studies evaluating the effectiveness of acupuncture in treating fibromyalgia showed conflicting results, but added the knowledge doctors need to have substantive conversations with patients. SUMMARY: Recent studies support the recommendation of a multimodal treatment approach with individualized, evidence-based pharmacotherapy and self-management. Treatment goals should include improving symptoms, particularly pain and sleep, and promoting positive health behaviors with the goal of improving physical function and emotional well-being.

title: Financial incentives for smoking cessation in pregnancy: randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effectiveness of a financial incentive added to routine specialist smoking cessation services versus routine care to help pregnant smokers quit smoking. DESIGN Phase II therapeutic exploration study in a single center, individually randomized, parallel-group, controlled, superiority study. SURROUNDING A large healthcare area with a materially disadvantaged inner-city population in western Scotland, UK. PARTICIPANTS 612 self-reported pregnant smokers in the NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde who spoke English, were at least 16 years old, were less than 24 weeks pregnant and had an exhaled carbon monoxide breath test result of 7 ppm or greater. 306 women were randomly assigned to the incentive group and 306 to the control group. INTERVENTIONS The control group received routine care, i.e., offering an in-person appointment to discuss smoking and smoking cessation and, for those who attended and setting a smoking cessation date, offering 10 weeks of free nicotine replacement therapy provided by pharmacy services, and four weekly support calls. The intervention group received routine care, as well as the offer of shopping vouchers worth up to £400: £50 to attend an in-person appointment and set an appointment to quit, then a further £50 if confirmed at four weeks after quitting smoking exhaled carbon monoxide quit smoking A further £100 was provided for continued confirmed abstinence from exhaled carbon monoxide at 12 weeks A final voucher of £200 was provided for confirmed abstinence from exhaled carbon monoxide at 34 to 38 weeks gestation Commitment and self-reported discontinuation at four weeks RESULTS Recruitment was extended from 12 to 15 months to reach target sample size Follow-up continued through September 2013 Did not want their data used, leaving 306 intervention and 303 control group participants in intention- to-treat analysis Sc financial incentives were not documented. Significantly more smokers in the incentive group than in the control group quit smoking: 69 (22.5%) versus 26 (8.6%). The relative risk of not smoking at the end of pregnancy was 2.63 (95% confidence interval 1.73 to 4.01) P<0.001. The absolute risk difference was 14.0% (95% confidence interval 8.2% to 19.7%). The treatable number (where financial incentives must be provided to achieve an additional late pregnancy quitter) was 7.2 (95% confidence interval 5.1 to 12.2). Mean birth weight was 3140 g (SD 600 g) in the incentive group and 3120 (SD 590) g in the control group (P = 0.67). CONCLUSION This phase II randomized controlled trial provides substantial evidence for the effectiveness of incentives to quit smoking in pregnancy." Kingdom STUDY REGISTRATION Recent controlled trials ISRCTN87508788.

title: FIRE (Facilitating Implementation of Research Evidence): ein Studienprotokoll
abstract: Background Research supports best practice but is not always used in healthcare. The Promoting Action on Research Implementation in Health Services (PARIHS) framework suggests that the type of evidence, the context in which it is used, and whether those trying to use the evidence are helped (or facilitated). , which influenced the use of evidence. Urinary incontinence has a major impact on the quality of life of older people, has a high prevalence and is a key priority in European health and social care policies. Improving continence care has the potential to improve the quality of life for older people and reduce the costs associated with the provision of incontinence devices. Aims This study aims to advance understanding of the contribution that facilitation can make to the translation of research into practice by: expanding current knowledge of facilitation as a process of translating research into practice; assesses the feasibility, effectiveness, and cost-effectiveness of two different procedural models of facilitation in promoting uptake of continence management research; Assessing the impact of contextual factors on the processes and outcomes of implementation;" and implementing a proactive knowledge transfer and dissemination strategy to disseminate study results to a broad community of policy and practice. Setting and sample Four European countries each with six long-term care centers (total of 24 sites ) for people 60 years and older with documented urinary incontinence Methods and design Pragmatic randomized controlled trial with three arms (standard distribution and two different programs of facilitation), with embedded process and economic evaluation. The primary outcome is compliance with the continence recommendations. Secondary endpoints include the proportion of residents with incontinence, the incidence of incontinence-related dermatitis, urinary tract infections, and quality of life Outcomes will be reported at baseline and then 6, 12, 18, and 24 months after the start of the moderation measures evaluates. Detailed contextual and process data is collected throughout using staff, resident and family interviews, observations, contextual assessments using the Alberta Context Tool, and documentary evidence. A realistic evaluation framework is used to develop an explanatory theory about what works for whom and under what circumstances.

title: First online survey by an international multidisciplinary working group (MightyMedic) on current practice in the diagnosis, therapy and follow-up of dyslipidemia
abstract: The MightyMedic (Multidisciplinary International Group for Hemapheresis Therapy and Metabolic Disturbances Contrast) Working Group was founded in 2013. The guiding principle was the establishment of an international network of an interdisciplinary nature with the aim of cross-border research projects, clinical studies, educational initiatives (conferences, workshops, summer schools) in the field of metabolic diseases, namely hyperlipidemia, and diabetes, preventive cardiology and atherosclerosis. Therapeutic apheresis, its indications and techniques, is a parallel area of research. The Group's first online survey was completed in the first half of 2014. The survey included #24 centers in Italy, Germany, Greece, UK, Sweden, Japan and the US. Relevant data on current practice in the diagnosis, therapy and follow-up of dyslipidemia were collected. The survey reported 240 patients with hyperlipidemia treated with lipoprotein apheresis, but a large percentage of patients (35%) who could benefit from this therapeutic option are still treated with a conventional drug approach. Genetic molecular diagnostics is performed in only 33% of patients, while lipoprotein(a) (Lp(a)) is included in cardiovascular disease risk assessment in 71% of participating centers. New detailed investigations and prospective multicenter studies are required to assess changes caused by the impact of updated indications and strategies, as well as new treatment options aimed at standardizing therapeutic and diagnostic approaches.

title: First episode psychosis: a window of opportunity for best practices
abstract: Patients experiencing a first psychotic episode or early stages of psychosis pose important diagnostic problems for clinicians. At the time of the first episode of psychosis, it is crucial that physicians select the most effective treatment option, as prompt intervention offers the best chance of containing the disease. During this time, it is also important to choose the best treatment option, since dysfunction occurs most rapidly in this early phase, which can affect the patient's future prognosis, the extent of necessary treatment, and morbidity. Although research has shown a decrease in brain gray matter for those who develop psychosis, along with signs of functional impairment, many patients with psychosis remain untreated for long periods of time and do not seek medical attention because of reluctance, fear of stigma have or do not recognize the problem or complexity of their care system. Previous studies have shown that if psychosis is left untreated, patient outcomes are poorer than in a patient treated earlier in the disease course. There are a number of treatment options for treating psychosis, including the use of first- or second-generation antipsychotics. Clinicians should note that both drug types are associated with certain side effects, such as: B. tardive dyskinesia or weight gain. For both types of drugs, doses should be lower in patients with a first psychotic episode than in patients with chronic psychosis. Finally, patients may have various comorbidities such as B. Substance abuse, which can also affect treatment. This expert roundtable supplement addresses the diagnosis and treatment selection for initial episodes of psychosis and comorbidities associated with the disorder. The use of first- or second-generation antipsychotics to treat psychosis, dosing guidelines, and the side-effect profile of antipsychotics are also discussed.

title: Changing the format of a lab test order form affects the behavior of the physician
abstract: PURPOSE: Our study was designed to find out if a change in physician ordering of laboratory testing can be achieved through the simple strategy of changing the setup of the checkbox laboratory order form embedded in a computerized medical record. METHODS: This prospective intervention study was conducted at Maccabi Healthcare Services, a preferred provider organization that has used a computerized medical record since 1992. We examined the data of 865 general practitioners over 3 years. In May 2005 we changed the order form and reduced the number of tests that can be ordered via a checkbox form from 51 to 26. 27 tests were removed from the form and two tests were added. The total number of laboratory test orders and the median rate of test orders per physician visit during each study period were calculated for each test separately. RESULTS: Tests added to the computerized laboratory order form showed a 60.7% increase in the first year and a further 90% increase the following year. For the unchanged tests, the percentage changes over the same time periods were +18.4% and -22.4%. For the deleted tests, the change was -27% and -19.2% for the respective years. CONCLUSIONS: Changes in the format of laboratory test order forms can alter the ordering of physician tests and be useful along with other interventions to improve laboratory test adequacy. A well-designed test order form can strengthen clinical guidelines for conducting some preventive tests and follow-up visits.

title: Formative evaluation of practice changes to treat depression within a shared care model in primary care
abstract: Objective To study the implementation and initial impact of the Physician Integrated Network (PIN) mental health indicators specific to the screening and management of follow-up care for depression in three primary shared mental health care practices in Manitoba. BACKGROUND: Manitoba Health conducted a primary care renewal initiative called PIN in 2006, which involved the development of mental health indicators specifically for screening and managing follow-up care for depression. These indicators have been implemented at three PIN group practice centers in Manitoba, which are also part of Shared Mental Health Care. Methods: The design was a non-experimental longitudinal design. A formative evaluation examined the implementation and initial impact of the mental health indicators using mixed methods (document review, survey and interview). Quantitative data were examined with descriptive and comparative statistics and a content and topic analysis of the qualitative interviews was carried out. Survey responses were received from 32 out of 36 physicians at the three sites. Interviews were conducted with 15 providers. Findings This evaluation illustrated providers' perceived attitudes, knowledge, skills, and behaviors related to identifying and treating depression and expanded our understanding of primary care processes related to managing depression in the context of implementing a new initiative. Depression is recognized as an important problem in primary care practice that is time consuming to diagnose, treat and treat and requires further investigation. Implementation of the mental health PIN indicators varied by location and provider. Use of the indicators increased over time and there was a general consensus that the benefits of screening outweighed the costs";" However, the usefulness of screening for depression remains unclear. Consistent with current guidelines, the results of this review raise the question of whether there are more effective ways of influencing depression in primary care than screening.

title: Promoting the translation of research into practice in healthcare: a consolidated framework for advancing the science of implementation
abstract: Background Many interventions that have been shown to be effective in health care studies do not translate into meaningful patient care outcomes across multiple contexts. Healthcare researchers recognize the need to assess not only summative outcomes but also formative outcomes to assess the extent to which implementation in a given setting is effective, prolongs sustainability, and promotes dissemination in other settings. Many implementation theories have been published to promote effective implementation. However, they overlap significantly in the constructs embodied in individual theories, and a comparison of the theories shows that each lacks important constructs embodied in other theories. In addition, terminology and definitions are not consistent across the theories. We describe the Consolidated Framework For Implementation Research (CFIR), which provides an overarching typology to encourage the development of implementation theory and the review of what works, where, and why in multiple contexts. Methods We used a snowball sampling approach to identify published theories that were evaluated to derive constructs based on strength of conceptual or empirical support for impact on implementation, consistency in definitions, agreement with our own evidence, and measurement capabilities identify. We combined constructs across published theories that had different labels but were redundant or overlapped in definition, and we analyzed constructs that mixed underlying concepts. Findings The CFIR consists of five main areas: intervention characteristics, external environment, internal environment, characteristics of the people involved and the implementation process. Eight constructs were identified in relation to the intervention (e.g. strength and quality of evidence), four constructs were identified in relation to the external environment (e.g. patient needs and resources), 12 constructs were identified in relation to the internal environment (e.g. culture, leadership engagement) five constructs related to individual characteristics and eight constructs related to the process (e.g. planning, evaluating and reflecting) were identified. We present explicit definitions for each construct. Conclusion The CFIR provides a pragmatic structure for dealing with complex, interacting, multi-level, and transient states of real-world constructs by incorporating, consolidating, and unifying key constructs from published implementation theories. It can be used to guide formative evaluations and build the knowledge base for implementation across multiple studies and settings.

title: Founders and recurrent CDH1 mutations in families with hereditary diffuse gastric cancer
abstract: Background Hereditary diffuse gastric cancer is caused by germline mutations in the epithelial cadherin (CDH1) gene and is characterized by an increased risk of diffuse gastric cancer and lobular breast cancer. Objective To determine whether recurrent germline CDH1 mutations occurred as a result of independent mutational events or common ancestry. Design, setting and patients Thirty-eight families diagnosed with clinically hereditary diffuse gastric cancer were enrolled between November 2004 and January 2006 and analyzed for CDH1 mutations in an ongoing British Columbia Cancer Agency study. 26 families had at least 2 cases of gastric cancer, including 1 case of diffuse gastric cancer in a person under 50 years";" In 12 families, either a single case of diffuse gastric cancer in a person younger than 35 years of age or multiple cases of diffuse gastric cancer in people older than 50 years were diagnosed. Main outcome measures Classification of family members as carriers or non-carriers of CDH1 mutations. Haplotype analysis to assess recurring mutations for common ancestors was performed on 7 families from this study and 7 previously reported families with the same mutations. Results Thirteen mutations (6 new) were identified in 15 of the 38 families (40% detection rate). The 1137G>A splicing mutation and the 1901C>T (A634V) missense/splicing mutation occurred in common haplotypes in 2 families but in different haplotypes in a third family. The 2195G>A (R732Q) missense/splicing mutation occurred in 2 families with different haplotypes. The 2064-2065delTG mutation occurred in a common haplotype in 2 families. Two families from this study plus two other families carrying the novel 2398delC mutation shared a common haplotype, suggesting a founder effect. All 4 families are from the southeast coast of Newfoundland. Based on the concentrations of lobular breast cancer cases, 2 branches of this family were diagnosed with hereditary breast cancer and tested for BRCA mutations. Within these 4 families, the cumulative risk at age 75 in mutation carriers for clinically detected gastric cancer was 40% (95% confidence interval [CI], 12%-91%) for males and 63% (95% CI, 19%-99% ) for females and the risk of breast cancer in female mutation carriers was 52% (95% CI, 29% - 94%). Conclusions Recurrent CDH1 mutations in families with hereditary diffuse gastric cancer are due to both independent mutational events and common ancestors. The presence of a founder mutation from Newfoundland is strongly supported.

title: Framework for direct observation of healthcare performance and safety
Framework for quality improvement of pharmacy services - a bridge to bridge the quality gap. Part I. The Opportunity and the Tool
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To review the literature on quality improvement principles and methodologies applied to pharmacy services and provide a framework for current and future efforts to improve quality of pharmacy services and effective drug therapy management. BACKGROUND: The Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy produced the Catalog of Pharmacy Quality Indicators in 1997, followed by the Summary of National Pharmacy Quality Measures in February 1999. In April 2002, AMCP introduced the Pharmacy's Framework for Drug Therapy Management in the 21st Century. The framework documents include a self-assessment tool that describes more than 250 specific “components” that describe roles, behaviors, skills, roles, duties, and responsibilities that help meet client expectations for effective drug therapy management. RESULTS: There are many opportunities to improve the quality of clinical, service and cost outcomes associated with drug therapy management. These may include: patient safety, incidence of medical errors, adverse drug reactions, patient compliance, achievement of target blood pressure, glucose, and lipid levels, risk reduction for adverse cardiac events and osteoporosis-related fractures, patient satisfaction, risk of hospitalization or mortality; and cost of care Healthcare professionals can measure improvements in quality of care in a variety of ways, including (a) better patient outcome at the same cost, (b) same patient outcome at a lower cost, (c) better patient outcome at a lower cost, or (d) significantly better Patient outcome at moderately higher cost Measurement enables effective management A framework of component factors (e.g. tasks) is necessary to facilitate changes in the key processes and critical factors affecting individual physicians and healthcare systems h helping to meet customer expectations for drug therapy, thereby improving those outcomes. CONCLUSIONS: Health service quality improvement in the United States will occur in incremental changes based on a structure-process-outcome model. The structure is provided by evidence derived from controlled randomized trials and other studies of care and systems outcomes based on the scientific method. The process portion is created through the application of evidence in the form of clinical practice guidelines, clinical practice models and self-assessment tools such as the Pharmacy's Framework for Drug Therapy Management. Incremental changes in structure and process will lead to the desirable outcome of meeting customer needs for more effective drug therapy and disease management.

title: Framework options as choice or opportunity: does the framework influence decisions?
abstract: objective. Healthcare professionals must enable patients to make informed decisions about healthcare choices by presenting all options with an open mind. This study examined whether presenting the decision as an "opportunity" rather than a "choice" affected individuals' preferences related to study participation for cancer treatment. methods. Self-selecting healthy females (N=124) were randomly assigned to the following decision frames: opportunity to participate in the study (opt-in), opportunity to be excluded from the study (opt-out), and opportunity to have standard treat or participate in the study (choice). The computer-based task required the women to make a hypothetical decision about a real cancer treatment study. The software presented the framed scenario, recorded initial preference, presented comprehensive and balanced information, tracked participants' use of information during decision-making, and recorded the final decision. A post-task paper questionnaire assessed perceived risk, attitudes, subjective norm, perceived behavioral control, and satisfaction with the decision. Results. Framing influenced women's immediate preferences. Frameworks of opportunity, whether opt-in or opt-out, introduced bias as they discouraged women from opting into standard treatment. By using the marquee, this distortion was avoided. The opt-out opportunity framework also had an impact on women's perceived social norm";" Women felt that others favored the trial option. The framing bias was gone after participants were able to view detailed information about the options in a patient decision support format. There were no group differences in information gathering and final decisions. 16 percent changed their initial preference after receiving complete information. Conclusions. A "choice frame" in which all treatment options are explicitly listed is less likely to influence preferences. Presenting complete information in parallel option-by-attribute format is likely to "bias" the decision framework. Tailoring information to initial preferences would not be advisable as preferences can change after detailed information.

title: Fraud and misconduct in clinical research
Fraud and misconduct in clinical research: do they threaten patient safety?
From clinical evidence to everyday practice: implementation of findings from a cost-benefit analysis of endoscopic injection therapy for gastrointestinal bleeding
abstract: BACKGROUND: A previous upper gastrointestinal bleeding study showed that patients treated with repeated injections of fibrin glue for upper gastrointestinal bleeding had significantly less rebleeding than patients treated with polidocanol. AIM: To analyze the cost and effectiveness of repeated fibrin glue injections and whether these results are changing physician attitudes. DESIGN: A retrospective random sample of five hospitals from the previous study, collection of cost identification and follow-up data from 320 patients (155 in the polidocanol group, 165 in the fibrin glue group). METHODS: An incremental cost-effectiveness analysis and comparison of outcomes was performed using chi-square tests and Kaplan-Meier survival analysis. In the five hospitals, a survey on the local guidelines for the management of ulcer bleeding was carried out using a questionnaire and the results were analyzed qualitatively. The measure of effectiveness is the number of postoperative bleedings prevented. Other variables included length of hospital stay and length of stay in the intensive care unit (ICU). RESULTS: The cost of preventing further rebleeding by repeated fibrin glue treatment is 14,316 +/- 4,981 euros (incremental cost-benefit ratio). There were no significant differences in the length of stay in the ICU or in the hospital. Doctors did not change their treatment plans for patients with upper GI bleeding. A survey found that other factors, such as local policies, attitudes toward new treatment options, and ease of use of medication, are more important in changing physician behavior than the outcome of a single study. CONCLUSIONS: The study was not designed to answer a pharmacoeconomic question. Since relevant variables (e.g. length of stay in the intensive care unit) could not be reliably determined retrospectively, this can lead to distorted estimates of the incremental cost-benefit ratio.

title: From evidence to expertise: concordance in the topical treatment of psoriasis
abstract: Vulgar psoriasis is an inflammatory cutaneous-systemic disease, chronic and intermittent. The etiology is undefined and there is a higher risk of comorbidities affecting patients' quality of life. The objectives of this study were to establish consistency between the Guia de Practica Clinica (GPC) of pharmacological treatment of plaque psoriasis and the clinical practice of a group of Mexican dermatologists, experts in the topical treatment of psoriasis";" and balancing interest and knowledge about quality of life and therapy adherence. A Delphi questionnaire was used among 30 experts to examine their therapeutic behavior and attitudes toward assessing quality of life and adherence to therapy. A subgroup meeting of 10 dermatologists was held to analyze the results. A second questionnaire was answered to distinguish the decisions made for topical treatment in institutional and private practice, as well as other items not examined in the first questionnaire. After analyzing the questionnaire results, it was clear that the data published in the Guia de Practica Clinica and the prescribing attitude of the experts regarding the topical treatment of plaque psoriasis are consistent. There is also agreement between the physicians in private and institutional medical care on the attitude to drug prescription, although vitamin D analogues and corticosteroids are more likely to be used in private practices and salicylic acid replaces corticosteroids in the facilities.

title: From hypertension control to global cardiovascular risk management: an educational intervention in a cluster-randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hypertension management guidelines recommend adjusting therapeutic efforts according to global cardiovascular risk (CVR) and not just blood pressure readings. However, this paradigm shift has not yet arrived in German general practice. We evaluated the effect of an educational visit to general practitioners (GPs) and encouraged them to consider CVR in treatment decisions for patients with hypertension. METHODS: Prospective cluster-randomized study of 3443 patients with known hypertension treated by 87 general practitioners. Practices were randomly assigned to complex (A) or simple (B) interventions. Both groups received a guide by email";" Group A also received a complex peer intervention that promoted the concept of global CVR. Clinical data were collected at baseline and 6-9 months after the intervention. The main result was the improvement of the calculated CVR in the predefined subpopulation of patients with a high CVR (10-year mortality >/= 5%) but without overt cardiovascular disease. RESULTS: Adjusted for baseline, the follow-up CVR was 13.1% (95% CI 12.6% - 13.6%) (A) and 12.6% (95% CI 12.2% - 13, 1%) (B) with a group difference (A vs. B) of 0.5% (-0.2%-1.1%), p=0.179. The group difference was -0.05% in patients from GPs familiar with global CVR and 1.1% in patients from GPs unfamiliar with global CVR. However, this effect modification was not significant (p = 0.165). Pooled across groups, the absolute reduction in CVR from baseline was 1.0%, p<0.001. The ICC was 0.026 (p=0.002). Hypertension control (BP < 140/90 mmHg) improved in the same subpopulation from 38.1 to 45.9% in the complex intervention group and from 35.6 to 46.5% in the simple intervention group, with adjusted follow-up control rates of 46.7% (95% CI 40.4%-53.1%) (A) and 46.9% (95% CI 40.3%-53.5% (B) and an adjusted odds ratio (A vs. B) of 0.99 (95% CI 0.68-1.45), p=0.966 CONCLUSIONS: Our complex educational intervention, including a clinical visit, had no significant effect on the CVR of Patients with known hypertension at high risk compared to simple postal intervention.

title: From interdisciplinary to integrated care for the child with autism: the essential role for a code of ethics
abstract: To address the developmental deficits of children with autism, several disciplines have come to the fore within intervention programs. These are speech therapists, psychologists/counsellors, occupational therapists/physiotherapists, special education teachers, behavior analysts and physicians/medical staff. As the field of autism therapy moves toward a more comprehensive, holistic, and interdisciplinary model, the complexity of an interdisciplinary model of service delivery could pose significant challenges. The difficulty in implementing this approach could result in underperforming programs being set up. Since integration between disciplines is a necessity, the ethical principles and language common to all contributing disciplines are argued as an appropriate integrative force. An overview of these principles and a draft code of ethics are offered to establish high standards and expectations for all participants in such a program.
