title: From Protocol to Practice: Translating Clinical Data into Clinical Practice
abstract: Physicians must be prepared to treat individual patients based on evidence-based risk assessments. However, ethnic minorities, the elderly and women have been underrepresented in large studies, potentially lacking data to support clinical decisions for patients in these groups. A notable example is the Framingham Heart Study, with a study population consisting of a nearly homogeneous population of a small American town. Future studies clearly need to include more representative samples from these populations. In the meantime, the Adult Treatment Panel III guidelines should be widely applied.

title: From specialist care to self-directed treatment
Functional recovery after myocardial infarction in men: The independent effects of social class
abstract: Background: Social class has been repeatedly associated with cardiovascular disease and death, but no studies have examined the effect of social class on recovery after myocardial infarction. In addition, few studies have simultaneously assessed a wide range of demographic, clinical, and psychosocial factors that may influence health outcomes after myocardial infarction. Objective: To determine whether social class remains independently associated with functional recovery after myocardial infarction, even after controlling for clinical, demographic, and psychosocial factors known to influence post-infarction outcomes. DESIGN: Analysis of prospective data from a multicenter, randomized, double-blind clinical study. Scope: 25 hospitals or clinical sites in the United States and Canada that participated in the Beta-Blocker Heart Attack Trial, including the health insurance substudy. Patients: 2145 males aged 29-69 years hospitalized with acute myocardial infarction who were recruited for the beta-blocker myocardial infarction study. Measures: The primary outcome was a change in New York Heart Association functional class between baseline assessment and 12 months after in farction, dichotomized as improved or not improved (ie, no change, decrease in at least one category, or death). Results: Social class maintained its independent effect on improved functional status even after controlling for relevant prognostic factors. Persons with a high social class had an improved functional status 1 year after the infarction significantly more frequently than persons with a lower or middle social class. Certain clinical, demographic, and psychosocial characteristics were associated with recovery, but the effect of social class could not be explained by these additional characteristics. Conclusions: Social class has a significant impact on recovery after myocardial infarction and may explain differences in clinical outcomes.

title: Functional somatic syndromes
abstract: The term functional somatic syndrome has been applied to several related syndromes characterized by symptoms, distress, and disability rather than consistently detectable tissue abnormalities. These syndromes include multiple chemical sensitivity, sick building syndrome, repetitive stress injuries, the side effects of silicone breast implants, Gulf War syndrome, chronic whiplash, chronic fatigue syndrome, irritable bowel syndrome, and fibromyalgia. Patients with functional somatic syndromes have explicit and highly elaborate self-diagnoses, and their symptoms often defy reassurance, explanation, and standard treatment of symptoms. They share similar phenomenologies, high co-occurrence rates, similar epidemiological characteristics, and a higher than expected prevalence of psychiatric comorbidity. Although discrete pathophysiological causes may ultimately be found in some patients with functional somatic syndromes, the suffering of these patients is exacerbated by a self-perpetuating, self-affirming cycle in which common, endemic, somatic symptoms are falsely attributed to serious abnormalities, reflecting those of the Patient's belief that he or she has a serious illness. Four psychosocial factors drive this cycle of symptom amplification: the belief that one has a serious illness, the expectation that one's condition is likely to get worse, the "sickness role", including the implications of litigation and compensation; and the alarming portrayal of the condition as catastrophic and disabling. The climate surrounding functional somatic syndromes includes sensationalist media coverage, profound mistrust of medical expertise and physicians, the mobilization of parties with a vested interest in the status of functional somatic syndromes, litigation, and a clinical approach that overemphasizes the biomedical and ignores the psychosocial factors. All of these influences exacerbate and perpetuate the somatic burden of patients with functional somatic syndromes, increasing their fears and pessimistic expectations, prolonging their disability, and enhancing their ill role. A six-step strategy for supporting patients with functional somatic syndromes is presented here.

title: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease
abstract: Heartburn 2 or more days per week requires medical attention as patients are likely to have gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Chronic GERD can lead to the development of complications, including erosive esophagitis, stricture formation, and Barrett's esophagus, increasing the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma. A trial of a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is the quickest and least expensive way to diagnose GERD and is at least as sensitive as 24-hour intraesophageal pH monitoring. Since PPIs only bind to actively secreting proton pumps, they should be administered 30 to 60 minutes before a meal. Despite these recommendations, a recent survey of over 1,000 primary care physicians in the US found that 36% instructed their patients to take a PPI with or after a meal, or did not tell when to take it. The patients who respond best to surgical therapy for GERD are those who have had clearly documented acid reflux with typical symptoms and who have responded to PPI treatment. Unfortunately, the same survey found that most doctors recommend antireflux surgery for patients who have failed medical therapy.

title: Fund holding general medicine
Information search strategies of trainees in general medicine for clinical questions in daily practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Previous studies have shown that clinical questions are common among physicians. However, data on the information-seeking behavior of general practitioner trainees is sparse and the numbers examined are small. OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to determine how often and how GP trainees search for answers to clinical questions they encounter in daily clinical practice. METHODS: On eight consecutive practice days, trainee general practitioners in their third year kept records of all patient contacts. Information was collected on patient contacts (description), clinical inquiries (frequency, type), search behavior (frequency, time, reason for not searching, resources used, duration of search), and responses (frequency, impact). Descriptive analyzes were performed";" Frequencies and percentages were calculated. We calculated the number of clinical queries per patient, the number of searches per query, and the number of responses per search. RESULTS: Seventy-six trainees reported 1533 clinical queries on 7300 patients with 7619 complaints [mean of 0.2 queries per patient, standard deviation (SD) 0.1]. For most questions, trainees tracked an answer (mean 0.8 per question, SD 0.2), mainly during counseling (61% of searches), and frequently retrieved answers (mean 0.8 per search, SD 0.17 ) reported improving clinical decision making accounted for 26%. The most common resources were colleagues or supervisors (28%) and national GP guidelines (26%). The median duration of a search was 4 minutes (interquartile range 3). CONCLUSION: GP trainees have one clinical inquiry for every five patients. They often attempted to find answers and reported success in most searches, largely through consultation with supervisors or peers and national GP guidelines.

title: Primary care physician views on the determinants of testing regimen: a theory-based qualitative approach to developing an intervention to improve immunoglobulin requirements in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Research suggests that variations in lab request patterns may indicate unnecessary test usage. Requirement patterns for serum immunoglobulins vary significantly between general practitioners (GPs). This study aims to examine primary care physicians' views on testing to identify the determinants of behavior and recommend feasible intervention strategies to improve the use of immunoglobulin testing in primary care. METHODS: Qualitative semi-structured interviews were conducted with GPs who requested laboratory tests at Cork University Hospital or University Hospital Kerry in southern Ireland. GPs were identified from a Health Service Executive laboratory list of GPs in the Cork-Kerry area. A random sample of general practitioners (stratified according to GP inquiry patterns) was created from this list. General practitioners were specifically qualified according to the criteria of location (urban/rural)"; duration;" selected. and exercise size (single-hand/group). The interviews were conducted between December 2014 and February 2015. The interviews were transcribed verbatim using NVivo 10 software and analyzed using the framework analysis method. New themes have been mapped to the Theory Domains Framework (TDF), which outlines 12 domains that may enable or inhibit behavior change. The Behavior Change Wheel and Behavior Change Technique (BCT) taxonomy were then used to identify potential intervention strategies. RESULTS: Sixteen general practitioners were interviewed (ten males and six females). The results suggest that intervention strategies should specifically target the key barriers to effective testing while considering the context of primary care practice. Seven domains from the TDF were found to influence immunoglobulin test ordering behavior and identified as "mechanisms for change" (knowledge, environmental context and resources, social/professional role and identity, beliefs about ability, beliefs about consequences, memory, attention, and Decision). -manufacturing processes and behavioral regulation). Using these TDF domains, seven BCTs emerged as feasible “intervention content” to address GP ordering behavior. This included instructions on how to request the test effectively (behavioural administration), information on how GPs use the test (behavioural feedback), information on the consequences for the patient of not undertaking the test (health consequences information), laboratory/counselor-based advice /education (credible source), modifying the test order form (restructuring the physical environment), providing guidelines (prompts/notices), and adding interpretive comments to the results (adding objects to the environment). These BCTs target four intervention functions: education, persuasion, environmental restructuring, and empowerment. CONCLUSIONS: This study effectively applied behavior change theory to identify viable strategies for improving the use of immunoglobulin testing in primary care using the TDF, the 'behaviour change wheel' and the BCT taxonomy. The identified BCTs form the basis for a theory-based intervention to improve the use of immunoglobulin testing in general practitioners. Future research will include the development and evaluation of this intervention.

title: Primary care physicians' reasons for the failure of a randomized controlled trial (The TIGER Trial) on the implementation of epilepsy guidelines in primary care
abstract: PURPOSE: To explore the reasons for the failure of a randomized controlled trial to influence the implementation of epilepsy guidelines in primary care and to develop a theory about likely associations in which guidelines would lead to changes in clinical behavior. METHODS: Qualitative study based on focus groups and a single in-depth interview. Participants included 47 primary health care workers selected from a targeted sample of 13 urban and rural primary care practices. RESULTS: The main reason for the lack of implementation of the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network epilepsy guideline was an established pattern of GP behavior that was supported by practice staff and had little perceived need for change. This was followed by a lack of knowledge of the existence and/or content of the guideline and perceived difficulties in putting it into practice due to scarcity of resources and potential patient resistance. The individual behavior of clinicians was therefore rooted in broader service structures and policies. CONCLUSIONS: Policies are more likely to be implemented when there are perceived problems with current service delivery. Attempts to facilitate the implementation of guidelines could also focus on areas where there is already a perceived need for guidelines or a disruption in one of the underlying variables that perpetuate the role and practice of health professionals. They may also be more likely when initiatives are broader than individual physician behavior and more broadly focused on redesigning the broader systems of care by engaging other providers to provide care coordination, improve patient self-management, and use information technology tools.

title: The uptake of clinical practice guidelines by general practitioners: a qualitative study
abstract: AIM: To explain the recent rapid reviewed changes in the uptake of locally implemented, evidence-based clinical guidelines for asthma and angina in primary care. METHODS: A primary care case study in two matched, neighboring districts in northern England, focusing on a stratified random sample of 49 general practitioners (GPs) from eight primary care groups. Data was collected from three cycles of mainly qualitative interviews conducted every six months before and after local policy dissemination and after audit data collection. Interviews examined attitudes, awareness and impact of the locally disseminated asthma and angina guidelines and the subsequent audit. Audit data on guideline use were also available from a parallel study. RESULTS: The rapid increase in guideline utilization observed in both the intervention and control groups was not explained by individual physicians or practice factors. Findings are attributed to primary care physicians' awareness of evidence-based medicine guidelines, new healthcare settings, and the clinical leadership activities of primary care groups. Changes in behavior reflect primary care physicians' decisions about what to record in case notes, as well as their clinical decisions, so the results may reflect a changing perception about accountability rather than preferred treatment regimens. CONCLUSIONS: The production and dissemination of guidelines is best seen in the broader context of policy change. Guideline implementation studies should report before-and-after data and include significant qualitative components to identify important contextual factors.

title: Antibiotic responsibility of the general surgeon: climbing the Rogers diffusion of the innovation curve - prospective cohort study
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The primary objective of this study was to establish compliance of general surgeon prescribing practices with local guidelines for intravenous and oral antibiotics. The secondary objective was to evaluate the effect of introducing antibiotic education. The Rogers Diffusion of Innovation Model was used to study the adoption of antibiotic stewardship practices. METHODS: In this prospective cohort study, data were collected from 100 patients before and 100 after the awareness intervention program. The educational intervention included raising awareness of a) the guidelines b) the pre-intervention outcomes c) the introduction of an IV oral antibiotic prompt sheet. Conformity with local guidelines was compared between pre- and post-intervention groups using Fisher's Exact Test or Pearson's Chi Test (SPSS Statistics V22). RESULTS: General surgeons' compliance with local IV oral antibiotics guidelines was poor and did not improve significantly after the awareness program. There was no inclusion of the antibiotics entry form. There was a trend towards an increase in the number of patients who switched from IV to oral antibiotics between 48 and 72 h and a significant increase (p<0.05) in the number of patients with a clearly documented intent to switch to IV antibiotics check. CONCLUSION: Antibiotic governance measures failed to inspire even a first group of innovators to use the antibiotic prompt sheets. It appears that educational interventions are effective in improving prescribing behavior and intention in a group of early adopters, but this does not reach critical mass. To improve antibiotic governance and begin the Rogers Diffusion of Innovation Curve, more needs to be done to involve general surgeons in timely and judicious antibiotic prescribing.

title: Egg Donor Genetic Evaluation: Recipient Pair Preferences and Test Result
abstract: AIM: To report preferences of recipient pairs for genetic testing of their egg donors. DESIGN: Observational report of the results of a genetic testing option form implemented as part of routine care. SETTING: Private practice. PATIENT(S): Recipients and egg donors. INTERVENTION(S): Prior to screening their egg donor, recipient couples completed a form detailing the required screening and recommended testing, which the couple could accept or decline. The couples were given information about the frequency of carriers, the risk to their child if the results were abnormal, and the costs. KEY OUTCOME MEASUREMENT(S): Percentage of couples accepting optional tests. RESULT(S): Of the 63 couples with available data from their first test option form, 42 (67%) accepted a fragile X test and 21 (33%) rejected it, whereas 34 (54%) accepted and 29 (46%) Karyotyping rejected. When asked if they would accept additional testing from their donor if recommended by a genetic counselor, 15 (24%) said they would accept additional testing regardless of cost, 35 (56%) said they would not, and 13 (20%) indicated that their decision would depend on cost. In many cases, the genetic counselor took a history or obtained test results that influenced further testing, decisions to proceed, or provided information important to the child. CONCLUSION(S): Recipient pairs sometimes chose to decline testing that we recommended but did not require, despite the relatively low cost of these tests compared to the overall cost of the oocyte donation cycle.

title: Genetic testing for children and adolescents. Who decides?
abstract: In the future, there will likely be a wide range of DNA-based tests to diagnose single gene diseases and to identify predispositions to genetically influenced diseases. This article focuses on the ethical, legal, and psychological implications of screening healthy children and adolescents for such disorders. Testing may provide medical or psychological benefits but may affect parent-child bonds or the child's self-concept. Physicians may encounter situations where they must balance the wishes of the child or young person against the wishes of the parents. We examine the legal history and current status of minors as consumers of health care, psychosocial research on their decision-making maturity, impact of testing on family relationships, national commission views on appropriate ages of consent and full informed consent, ethical and legal requirements for literacy in children, and adolescents;" and disclosure of genetic information. We propose guidelines for predictive genetic testing and counseling of children, and discuss the risks and benefits of testing.

title: Genetic support for general practitioners - a demonstration project
abstract: Primary care physicians need to be supported by specialized genetics services so that they can effectively manage the increasing relevance of genetics to their patients. Genetic counselors could be effective in such a role. This exploratory project aimed to improve the primary-tertiary interface by piloting such a GP service for a year. Tailored genetic education was carried out by a genetic counselor for 12 months in ten randomly selected GP practices in central England. A range of services were offered to practices, including facilitated genetic update sessions, a responsive counseling service and referral guidelines. The service was evaluated through pre- and post-intervention questionnaires and through seven semi-structured interviews. This article describes the development and delivery of this service and also reports on the experiences of a sample of the participants. Participants reported positive attitudes towards the service, saying that they gained knowledge and confidence, and recognized limitations and gaps in their current knowledge. The consistent connection with a genetic specialist service through a genetic counselor had a positive effect during the project and the participants have continued to use the genetic counselor for advice and support with genetic patient problems since the end of the project. This is the first example of this service delivery model. Further research using a larger sample and other behavior change measures needs to be conducted to assess whether this model should be adopted more widely.

title: German translation of Suicidal Patient Observation Chart (SPOC) - a tool for practice
abstract: Caring for inpatients with suicide is a complex and responsible task. Direct and immediate intensive care and therapeutic support, also referred to as special observation, is still recommended in guidelines (DGPPN, 2012) and is perhaps one of the most commonly used interventions in the in-hospital care of suicidal patients. It involves many ways of developing the relationship between the observer and the patient. The original SPOC was developed in Sweden with the aim of increasing the quality of systematic documentation in the care of suicidal patients. It is an instrument for the systematic documentation of observational behavior or abnormal moods during an acute suicide crisis, for example feelings such as "worried, anxious" or other possible influencing factors such as "sudden mood swings". In this way, the SPOC can ensure the process of systematic documentation of special observations and increase its quality, ie who documented what at what time. In addition, SPOC can allow better communication of the observation process to the multidisciplinary team and also to the patient. The SPOC includes the 28 items and covers 24 separate observation periods. The aim of this work is to present the translation process from the English to the German SPOC version. The translation process followed a five-step model. In the first step, the English version was translated by two German native speakers. In the second step, the first two translation results were discussed by the group of experts (authors) and a new version was developed. In the third step, the first German version (two English native speakers) was translated back into English. In the fourth step, the results were viewed by the expert groups (authors) and the so-called "preliminary version" was created. The last step involves proof of content validity by 52 nurses. The evidence uncovered some misunderstandings and helped improve the tool in its final version. With the translation, the German-speaking nursing practice in psychiatry has a tool that can be used by psychiatric nursing staff for their complex interventions in this special patient group.

title: Gestational diabetes and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy as vascular risk signals: a review and classification of the evidence
abstract: The emergence of common pregnancy-related medical disorders identifies women at high risk of developing future vascular disease. Systematic reviews of cohort studies show that gestational diabetes carries a 7-fold risk of type 2 diabetes and pre-eclampsia carries a 1.8-fold risk for type 2 diabetes and 3.4-fold risk for hypertension. Gestational diabetes and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP) increase the risk of premature vascular disease, but the 2-fold risk increase associated with preeclampsia can only be partially explained by the development of traditional vascular risk factors. Despite the compelling evidence supporting gestational diabetes and HDP as indicators of vascular risk, there are no published Canadian vascular prevention guidelines that recognize these women after childbirth. In contrast, the American Heart Association's 2011 guidelines on cardiovascular disease in women include gestational diabetes and HDP in their vascular risk assessment. Studies show that the importance of monitoring vascular risk factors in these women after pregnancy is underestimated by the women themselves and their doctors. Although the American Diabetes Prevention Program study showed that a mindful diet and physically active lifestyle reduce the risk of diabetes in women with a history of gestational diabetes, acceptance of these health behaviors is low. Qualitative studies confirm the need for tailored strategies that address barriers and provide social support. Further research is also needed on approaches to reduce vascular risk in women with gestational diabetes and a history of HDP. Failure to do so will miss an early window for chronic disease prevention in high-risk young women.

title: Get the most out of financial incentives for weight loss
Global Initiatives to Improve Cancer Care in Resource-Constrained Areas: What ASCO Members Are Doing and How You Can Get Involved
abstract: Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. In 2008, 7.6 million deaths were due to cancer, accounting for 13% of all deaths. It is estimated that around 30% of cancer deaths can be attributed to the top five behavioral and dietary risks. These include a high body mass index, low fruit and vegetable consumption, lack of exercise, and tobacco and alcohol consumption. A number of viral infections such as hepatitis B and C and HPV are responsible for about 20% of cancer deaths. About 70% of cancer deaths occur in low- and middle-income countries. Due to the increasing number of older people and improved control of comorbidities, the number of cancer deaths worldwide is projected to continue increasing, with an estimated 13.1 million deaths in 2030. To meet this need, the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO ) is developing a truly international organization. Over a third of ASCO members practice in over 100 countries and represent the world's largest collection of expertise and insight into the treatment of cancer. More than half of the attendees at the ASCO annual meeting are from outside the United States. The Journal of Clinical Oncology is read by more than 24,000 subscribers worldwide and is available in various languages. To fulfill its mission, ASCO has a number of international programs to share knowledge and provide tools to help physicians around the world treat their patients. These programs include mentoring and knowledge sharing, educational initiatives, and scientific and educational meetings. This provides ample opportunity for a commitment to improving cancer care worldwide.

title: Global Minimum Requirements: A Pathway to Competency-Based Medical Education
abstract: With the increasing globalization of medicine and the emerging concept of a "global medical profession", the question of the essential competencies that all doctors must have comes into focus. If defined, these competencies would help indicate what teachers should teach, what students should learn, and what educational experiences all physicians must have. The “minimum essential competencies” that all graduates must have if they want to become a doctor were identified by the Institute for International Medical Education (IIME), sponsored by the China Medical Board of New York, through working groups of education and health policy experts and representatives of the most important international medical training organizations. In the first phase of the project, seven domains were identified that define the knowledge, skills, professional behavior and ethics required of all physicians, regardless of where they received their general practice training. Appropriate instruments for evaluating the individual areas were identified. In the second phase of the project, the "Global Minimum Essential Requirements" (GMER) will be implemented experimentally at several Chinese medical schools. The goal of the third phase will be to share the results of this educational experiment aimed at improving the quality of medical education with the global educational community.

title: Global, regional, and national life expectancy, all-cause mortality, and cause-specific mortality for 249 causes of death, 1980–2015: a systematic analysis for the 2015 Global Burden of Disease Study
abstract: BackgroundImproving survival and extending life expectancy for all populations requires timely, robust evidence of local mortality levels and trends. The Global Burden of Disease 2015 Study (GBD 2015) provides a comprehensive assessment of all-cause and cause-specific mortality for 249 causes in 195 countries and territories from 1980 to 2015. These results were the basis of an in-depth examination of observed and expected mortality patterns based on sociodemographics dimensions.";" BackgroundImproving survival and extending life expectancy for all populations requires timely, robust evidence of local mortality levels and trends. The Global Burden of Disease 2015 Study (GBD 2015) provides a comprehensive assessment of all-cause and cause-specific mortality for 249 causes in 195 countries and territories from 1980 to 2015. These results were the basis of an in-depth examination of observed and expected mortality patterns based on sociodemographics dimensions.

title: walk
GRADE Evidence to Decision (EtD) Frameworks: a systematic and transparent approach to make informed decisions in healthcare. 2: Guidelines for clinical practice
abstract: Summary Points Clinicians regularly face situations with two or more alternative measures. Each alternative often has different pros and cons, including differences in effectiveness, side effects, cost, and other factors

title: Gradual versus abrupt smoking cessation
Cognitive-behavioural therapy in the first episode psychosis group: who is referred, who attends, and who administers it?
abstract: AIM: Most national guidelines recommend psychological therapy for people with first-episode psychosis (FEP), but interventions that have been shown to be effective in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) in research settings do not always translate effectively to real clinical settings. In a limited healthcare system, it is important to understand the system and patient barriers to participating in effective treatment. We sought to determine which patient characteristics influenced clinicians' decision to refer or not to refer cognitive behavioral therapy for FEP and which characteristics were associated with referred patients participating/non-participating and adhering/non-participating in the program. METHODS: Between 2006 and 2008, all cases of confirmed FEP from a defined geographic region were analyzed using the Structured Clinical Interview diagnoses for DSM-IV-TR-Axis I disorders for the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition (DSM- IV) Examined the Positive Symptom Rating Scale, Negative Symptom Rating Scale, Calgary Depression Scale for Schizophrenia, and Birchwood Insight Scale. The duration of the untreated psychosis was determined using the Beiser scale. RESULTS: Of the 124 (77 males, 47 females) individuals in the final sample, 88 (72%) were referred for cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), 52 (59%) participated, and 12 (23%) did not complete CBT . Those with a higher level of insight into the need for treatment (U = 740.00, z = -2.63, P = 0.008) and a higher level of positive symptoms (t(120) = -3.064, P = 0.003) were more likely to be referred to CBT. Those with higher educational attainment (chi(2) = 9.48, P = 0.03) and fewer negative symptoms, particularly related to global attention (t(85) = 2.32, P = 0.03), participated rather attended and completed CBT. CONCLUSION: Within an early intervention service for FEP, it appears that individuals with less education, more negative symptoms, and less insight faced significant barriers to successfully completing group CBT. More information for referring clinicians about the benefits of CBT in FEP could help increase referral rates. Reaching out to people at risk of disengagement or non-compliance should also be considered.

title: Group therapy for adolescents with repeated self-harm: randomized controlled trial with economic assessment
abstract: AIM To investigate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of group therapy for self-harm in young people. DESIGN Two-arm, individually (assessor)-blinded, parallel, randomized, allocation study of a group therapy intervention in addition to routine care versus routine care alone. Randomization was by minimization, controlling for baseline incidence of self-harm, presence of behavioral disorders, depressive disorders, and severity of psychosocial stress. PARTICIPANTS Adolescents aged 12 to 17 with at least two prior episodes of self-harm within the past 12 months. Exclusion criteria were: no English speaking, low weight anorexia nervosa, acute psychosis, significant learning disabilities (defined by need for a special school), current placement in secure care. Establishment Eight psychiatric services for children and adolescents in North West Britain. INTERVENTIONS Manual, developmental group therapy program designed specifically for youth who are self-harming, with an acute phase over six weekly sessions, followed by a refresher phase with weekly groups for as long as needed. Details of routine care were collected from the participating centers. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary endpoint was the frequency of subsequent recurrent episodes of self-harm. Secondary outcomes were the severity of subsequent self-harm, mood disorders, suicidal ideation, and global functioning. Total costs of health, social care, education, and criminal justice services, as well as family-related costs and lost productivity were recorded. RESULTS 183 adolescents were assigned to each arm (total n=366). Loss to follow-up was low (<4%). For all endpoints, the overall study cohort showed significant improvement from baseline to follow-up. For the primary endpoint of self-harm incidence, the proportional odds ratio of group therapy versus routine care, adjusted for relevant baseline variables, was 0.99 (95% confidence interval 0.68 to 1.44, P=0.95) after 6 months and 0.88 (0.59 to 1.33, P=0.52) at 1 year. For the severity of subsequent self-harm, the equivalent odds ratios were 0.81 (0.54 to 1.20, P=0.29) at 6 months and 0.94 (0.63 to 1.40, P=0.75 ) after 1 year. The total cost for one year was higher in the group therapy arm (£21,781) than in routine care (£15,372), but the difference was not significant (95% CI -1416 to 10782, P=0.132). CONCLUSIONS The addition of this targeted group therapy program did not improve self-harm outcomes for adolescents who self-harm repeatedly, nor was there evidence of cost-effectiveness. Results to endpoint for the cohort as a whole were better than current clinical expectations. Test registration ISRCTN 20496110.

title: Growth and nutritional risk in developmentally delayed children
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Nutritional risk affects outcome in developmental delay. The main goals were to identify the frequency and the factors that contribute to growth retardation. METHODS: The review of clinical data was completed for 500 developmentally delayed patients admitted to an early intervention service. Data were collected using the standardized parental nutritional screening checklist before and at the time of the initial nutritional assessment. The data was compared to nutritional assessment data, GOSH and FSAI dietary guidelines. Weight category was determined using RCPCH growth and BMI charts. Statistical analysis was performed using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences Version 20 (IBM Statistics 20.0). RESULTS: A nutritional risk was identified in 48.6%. The weight categories were stunted (13.5%), underweight (7.7%), overweight (8.4%), and obese (4.3%) at the initial assessment. Stunting was correlated with age < 1 year (p=0.000) and with gestational age (p=0.017), with the highest rates identified in those aged 32 to 36 weeks (3.6%). Weight class was associated with introduction of solids 17 weeks prior (10.1%), ANOVA showed significance (P = 0.013). In 22.7% of the people examined, the nutritional risk was poorly recognized by the parents. Feeding difficulties were common: 4.2% were receiving enteral feeding, 7.7% were receiving prescribed nutritional supplements, 29.1% (n=121) had feeding difficulties, and 13.9% (n=58) had behavioral feeding difficulties. The iron intake did not correspond to the recommended intake in 20.9% (n = 87), the calcium intake in 4.5% (n = 19). The prevalence of constipation was 21.6, of which 11.8% required medical attention. CONCLUSIONS: Developmental delay predisposes to nutritional deficiencies, which affect outcome. Screening, assessment, and timely interventions are warranted to prevent poorer developmental outcomes.

title: Conformity with guidelines in the treatment of stable chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases
abstract: BACKGROUND: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is the single leading cause of death with increasing morbidity and mortality. Clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) to optimize pharmacotherapy for patients with COPD have been updated based on promising results from randomized clinical trials. We examined the frequency and factors of guideline adherence by physicians in clinical practice at a university hospital. METHODS: Patients with a spirometry-confirmed clinical diagnosis of COPD presenting to the outpatient clinics were included. The primary outcome was provider compliance with the 2007 Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) guidelines. Subjects who received a rescue inhaler (all patients) or at least one long-acting bronchodilator (stage II) or at least one long-acting bronchodilator plus an inhaled corticosteroid (stage III-IV) were classified as conforming to the guidelines. Demographics, clinical information, and provider type were recorded. Provider type was classified by both as primary care physician (PCP), pulmonologist, or co-management. RESULTS: Of 450 subjects who met study criteria, 246 (54.7%) received guideline-compliant treatment. Age, gender, race, disease severity, and comorbidities were not associated with guideline adherence. Multivariate analysis showed that patients treated by a general practitioner and a pulmonologist together were more likely to receive guideline-compliant treatment than those treated by one or the other (odds ratio: 4.59; 95 % confidence interval: 2.92, 7.22, p<0.001). Conclusions: Slightly more than half of the stable COPD patients are treated in accordance with the guidelines. Joint treatment by a general practitioner and a pneumologist increases the likelihood of receiving guideline-compliant inhalation therapy.

title: Guideline implementation in allied health professions: a systematic literature review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical guidelines aim to improve the safety and quality of patient care by providing physicians with graded recommendations based on best practice. OBJECTIVE: To assess the impact of the introduction of clinical guidelines for healthcare professionals and assess the effectiveness of the strategies used to disseminate and implement the guidelines. METHODS: A comprehensive search of six electronic databases up to June 2006 and the Cochrane Effective Practice and Organization of Care database was performed. Randomized controlled trials, controlled clinical trials, controlled before-and-after studies, and interrupted time-series studies were included when the intervention aimed to implement guidelines in the allied health professions. The articles were checked for suitability and their methodological quality was assessed";" Data were independently extracted by two reviewers. RESULTS: Fourteen studies met the inclusion criteria. Methodological quality varied widely, with the proportion of quality criteria met ranging from 0 to 6 out of 7. In most studies, the reported effects on patient and process outcomes were small and in favor of the intervention group. Of the 14 included studies, 10 focused on educational interventions. Six of the 14 studies used a single intervention strategy and seven used a multifaceted implementation strategy. One study compared both single and multi-faceted strategies. Multifaceted interventions were no more effective than single intervention strategies, and the effects of the same strategy varied between studies. CONCLUSIONS: There is no evidence to support a defined strategy for implementing guidelines for healthcare professionals. When implementing clinical guidelines, it is important to first identify specific barriers to change using theoretical frameworks for behavior change and then to develop strategies that deal with these barriers. When measuring the effectiveness of these strategies, professionals should consider the use of patient and process outcomes and select outcomes that reflect their goals.

title: Guideline implementation: What the literature doesn't tell us
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite numerous studies and literature reviews on guideline implementation, it remains unclear whether and how clinical guidelines can be used to improve the quality of care. This study sought to find out whether these studies and reviews recognized the importance of systems thinking and organizational change for implementation. METHODS: A literature search was performed for systematic reviews of guideline implementation or studies to improve practice. Each review was examined for the extent to which it identified or discussed the value of system changes, organizational support, practice environment factors, and use of a change process. RESULTS: Forty-seven high-quality systematic reviews were found. They broadly agreed that using reminders and possibly using feedback during the course of clinical encounters are the most effective methods of policy implementation. However, those same reviews rarely identified these strategies as system changes, and there was little discussion of the need for organizational support or attention to various environmental variables that might affect implementation. The change process to introduce a new or modified practice system received even less attention. CONCLUSION: Reviews of guideline implementation studies have focused on how to change the behavior of individual physicians. Little attention has been paid to the impact of practice systems or organizational support of clinical behavior, the process by which change is brought about, or the role of the practice environment context in which change is sought. Recent attention to these issues can help us better understand and implement the process of improving medical care.

title: “Overweight” guideline for children’s health
abstract: The "5. National Growth Study” shows that the percentage of overweight children in the Netherlands has increased from 9-12% in 1997 to 13-15% in 2009. Children who can be offered tailored prevention. The detection of childhood obesity and the intervention of Child Health Care takes place in a multidisciplinary framework that brings together general practitioners, paediatricians, nutritionists, teachers, physiotherapists, educators and psychologists. A transition plan is created for overweight children based on exercise, outdoor play, daily breakfast, minimizing the use of sweetened beverages and fast food, less time in front of the television or computer, and fewer high-energy snacks. As recommended in the Dutch CBO obesity guideline, obese children are referred to a general practitioner or paediatrician.

title: Guideline-based early rehabilitation after myocardial infarction. A pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To determine the effectiveness of individualized behavioral therapy provided by in-hospital cardiac nurses compared to usual care in patients after acute myocardial infarction. METHODS: One hundred and fourteen consecutive patients were randomized to receive the intervention or usual care. Outcome assessment was by a self-report questionnaire (Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale and Dartmouth COOP Health Status), an interview at 1 month, and a self-report at 3 and 12 months. The primary outcome was improvement in Dartmouth COOP total score from baseline to 3 months. RESULTS: Four patients required treatment to achieve improvement in one additional patient at 3 months (number required to treat [NNT] 4, 95% confidence interval [CIs] 3 to 12). The intervention group was more confident about returning to activity one month after hospital discharge. Treated patients had fewer further treatment needs. CONCLUSIONS: Individualized behavioral therapy delivered by in-hospital cardiac nurses can have significant benefits. A large-scale pragmatic RCT is required.

title: Community pharmacists' guidelines and educational visits to improve general practice prescribing: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of guidelines with and without face-to-face educational visits by community pharmacists in improving the general prescribing of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). METHODS: Cluster randomized study of 20 general practices in Avon, England. The practices were randomized into three groups: “control”; mailed guidelines;” mailed guidelines plus educational visits. General practitioners (GPs) in the latter group received two individual visits from pharmacists in the community. Prescribing changes were measured using results derived from Prescribing Analysis and Cost (PACT) data. The primary endpoint was the change in prescription volume of ibuprofen, diclofenac and naproxen as a percentage of total NSAID prescription. Six secondary endpoints included other measures of prescribing quality and quantity. A cost-benefit analysis was carried out. RESULTS: No significant differences were observed for the primary endpoint: practices that received outreach visits prescribed only 2.1% [95% confidence interval (CI): -0.8 to 5.0] more of the three recommended NSAIDs than the control practices and 1.6% (95% CI: -1.4 to 4.7) more than practices receiving guidelines only. After adjustment for multiple comparisons, only one secondary endpoint showed a statistically significant difference between the groups: the proportion of prescriptions for the five most commonly used drugs was 2.2% (95% CI: 0.9 to 3. 6) higher in the outreach group than the control group. Both interventions showed a net increase in costs. CONCLUSIONS: Although good baseline prescribing at participating practices limited opportunities for improvement, this study provides no evidence that guidelines with or without educational visits by community pharmacists lead to significant improvements in prescribing behavior.

title: Guidelines and the psychology of medical decision-making in the treatment of depressive disorders
abstract: Guidelines aim to improve medical decision-making. In contrast to textbooks and journals, which aim to improve medical knowledge, guidelines attempt to influence medical behavior. Scientific models of medical decision-making such as action theory and empirical data on the effectiveness of guidelines suggest that guidelines do not always achieve their goal and can even worsen medical quality. The guideline problem in medicine is discussed in connection with depressive illnesses. The problem still applies to medicine as a whole. Therefore, it must be tested in controlled clinical trials whether physicians who are exposed to the guidelines achieve better results in their patients than physicians who are naïve to the guidelines. Only such guidelines should be designated as evidence-based for which positive effects have been empirically proven.

title: Guidelines as rationing instruments: A qualitative analysis of psychosocial patient selection criteria for cardiac interventions
abstract: BACKGROUND: Guidelines for cardiac interventions often include psychosocial criteria for patient selection, which may introduce social value judgments into clinical and care rationing decisions. The aim of this study was to examine the terms, justifications and meanings of psychosocial patient characteristics in cardiological guidelines. METHODS: We selected English language guidelines published since 1990 and chapters in textbooks published since 1989. These guidelines have brought together multiple sources of evidence and expertise and made recommendations for patient selection for specific procedures. A multidisciplinary team of medical and social scientists extracted passages on psychosocial criteria and developed categories and conceptual contexts to describe and interpret their content. RESULTS: Sixty-five papers met the criteria for inclusion in the study. Forty-five (69%) cited psychosocial criteria as procedure indications or contraindications. The latter fell into several categories, including behavioral and psychological problems, relationships with significant others, financial resources, social roles, and environmental circumstances. INTERPRETATION: Psychosocial characteristics play two roles in patient selection: as risk factors inherent in the candidate or as indicators of the need for a specific intervention. Guidelines typically simply list psychosocial contraindications without clarifying their specific nature or justifying their use. Psychosocial considerations can be helpful in evaluating patients for cardiac procedures, but become ethically controversial when used to limit access. The use of psychosocial indications and contraindications could be improved by more detailed descriptions of the psychosocial problem in question, explanations of why the criterion is important, and justification of the characteristic with a biological rationale or research evidence.

title: Guidelines for youth prevention services: the GAPS in practice
abstract: DESIGN: Pre- and Post-Guidelines for Adolescent Preventive Services (GAPS) comparison of results collected through chart audit. SETTING: A general pediatric clinic in a rural hospital. PARTICIPANTS: Adolescents who underwent annual screening between April 1, 1998 and March 31, 2001. A random sample of 441 medical records was reviewed. INTERVENTION: Training on the GAPS model and use of the questionnaire began in April 1998. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Identification, discussion and referral of GAPS-related risk behaviors. RESULTS: The medical records of 162 younger adolescents (aged 11-15 years) and 279 older adolescents (aged 16-19 years) were reviewed. Detection of risk behavior increased from 19% at baseline to 95% with the initial GAPS and 87% with the regular GAPS. The most common risk factor was having a rifle or firearm in the household (younger adolescents 47% and older adolescents 39%). The mean number of documented risky behaviors and health concerns was higher in the initial GAPS (4.8 and 1.3, respectively) than in the periodic GAPS (3.8 and 0.7) (P = 0.01 and 0.006). The GAPS questionnaires revealed lower levels of risky behavior compared to a local youth risky behavior survey. Controlling for gender, age, and clinician, discussion of psychosocial issues increased during the study period";" However, there were significant differences between clinicians in terms of the subjects treated. The GAPS-related recommendation rate did not change significantly. CONCLUSION: The GAPS model improves the recognition and discussion of risky behaviors by clinicians.

title: Guidelines for assessing postnatal problems: introducing evidence-based guidelines to Australian general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Postnatal morbidity is high and many primary care physicians lack the confidence and knowledge to deal with common postnatal problems. There is a high rate of consultation, but few women report general health problems. OBJECTIVE: The aim of the present study was to increase the knowledge and skills of primary care physicians to enable them to recognize and manage common health problems of women in the year after childbirth. METHODS: An educational program [Guidelines for Assessing Postnatal Problems (GAPP)] embedded in a large randomized community intervention study [Program of Resources, Information and Support for Mothers (PRISM)] with a before/after assessment was conducted by Australian GPs who in four metropolitan and four rural communities. The program included audits, interactive workshops, role plays, and evidence-based guidelines, and was evaluated at baseline and at 6 months through written questionnaires and a surgical consultation with a trained rater on simulated patients. RESULTS: A total of 68 (86%) general practitioners participated in the full GAPP program. The likelihood that a primary care physician improved on knowledge items ranged from 1.0 to 16, with the largest change occurring in knowledge of the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy for maternal depression. Of the GPs with an incorrect answer at baseline, the percentage who showed improved knowledge at follow-up ranged from 22 to 100%. About half of the primary care physicians demonstrated excellent communication skills at baseline. Of the remaining GPs, more than half demonstrated greatly improved skills to identify common postnatal follow-up problems. At the simulated baseline patient visit, 70% of primary care physicians inquired about sexual problems but none about the possibility of abuse, while at follow-up 94% asked about sexual problems and 51.5% facilitated disclosure of physical and emotional abuse. Anonymous feedback on the program from participating GPs showed that 89% felt the program had positively impacted their actual practice. Interestingly, general practitioners demonstrated greater knowledge and skills in the simulated setting than on the written questionnaire. CONCLUSIONS: This relatively short, multifaceted educational program helped many participants improve their knowledge and skills needed to improve both physical and emotional health after childbirth. Despite being experienced clinicians and actively participating in an interviewing program, half of the primary care physicians did not facilitate disclosure of the underlying sensitive issue (abuse) during follow-up and could benefit from further in-depth training in effective communication skills.

title: Guidelines for family-centered care in the neonatal, pediatric, and adult intensive care unit
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To provide clinicians with evidence-based strategies to optimize family support of critically ill patients in the ICU. METHODS: We used the Council of Medical Specialty Societies Principles for Clinical Guideline Development as a framework for guideline development. We assembled an international multidisciplinary team of 29 members with expertise in guideline development, evidence analysis and family-centred care to revise the 2007 clinical practice guidelines for family support in the patient-centred ICU. We conducted a scoping review of qualitative research examining family-centered care in the ICU. Thematic analyzes were conducted to support the development of population, intervention, comparison and outcome questions. Patients and families acknowledged the importance of interventions and outcomes. We then conducted a systematic review using the Recommendation Classification, Assessment, Development and Evaluation methodology to make recommendations for practice. The recommendations were subject to electronic voting with predetermined voting thresholds. No industry funding was associated with the development of the guideline. RESULTS: The scoping review identified 683 qualitative studies; 228 were used for thematic analysis and development of population, intervention, comparison, and outcome questions. 238 studies met the inclusion criteria. We made 23 recommendations at moderate, low, and very low evidence levels on: communication with family members, family presence, family support, consultations and ICU team members, and operational and environmental issues. We provide recommendations for future research and working tools to support the implementation of the recommendations into practice. CONCLUSIONS: These guidelines identify the evidence base for best practices for family-centered care in the ICU. All recommendations were weak, underscoring the relative emergence of this area of research and the importance of future research to identify the most effective interventions to improve this important aspect of critical care.

title: Guidelines for improving treatment entry and retention and antiretroviral adherence for people living with HIV: evidence-based recommendations from a panel of the International Association of Physicians in AIDS Care
abstract: DESCRIPTION: After HIV diagnosis, timely entry into and maintenance of HIV medical care is critical to the delivery of effective antiretroviral therapy (ART). Adherence to ART is one of the key factors for a successful HIV treatment outcome and is essential to minimize the emergence of drug resistance. The International Association of Physicians in AIDS Care convened a panel to develop evidence-based recommendations to optimize entry into, retention of, and adherence to ART for people living with HIV. METHODS: A systematic literature review was performed to generate an evidence base limited to randomized controlled trials and observational versus comparative trials that had at least 1 measured biological or behavioral endpoint. A total of 325 studies met the criteria. Two reviewers independently extracted and coded data from each study using a standardized data extraction form. Panel members drafted recommendations based on the evidence for each method or intervention, and then rated the overall quality of the evidence and the strength of each recommendation. RECOMMENDATIONS: Recommendations are made for monitoring entry and retention in care, interventions to improve entry and retention in care, and monitoring and interventions to improve ART adherence. Recommendations include ART strategies, adherence tools, education and counseling, and interventions in health systems and service delivery. In addition, they deal with specific topics related to pregnant women, prisoners, the homeless and emergency shelters, children and young people, as well as addictive substances and mental disorders. Recommendations for future research in all areas are also given.

title: Guidelines for the interaction of the therapeutic team in the inpatient treatment of patients with chronic neurotic diseases
abstract: When treating inpatients with chronic neurotic disorders, we tried both to reduce the burdens on the therapeutic team (doctors, nurses, other therapists) that are usually caused by these patients, and to improve the treatment outcome. Therefore, three to five guidelines for dealing with the patient were given to the therapeutic team and illustrated by possible verbatim statements to the patient. The guidelines aimed at a general interaction-oriented approach to the patient and did not specify any specific therapeutic interventions. They were constructed according to the principles of brief therapy as developed at the Mental Research Institute in Palo Alto. The results of our intervention in the treatment of ten patients are reported. Overall, the therapeutic team assessed the guidelines as positive. The success of the therapy varied greatly. A comparison with a matched-pair control group showed a favorable trend. Initial evaluations by the prescribing team predicted eventual improvement in patients.

title: Medical Treatment Guidelines for Stroke Prevention
Apallic Syndrome/Vegetative State Quality Management Guidelines
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Epidemiology in Europe shows steadily increasing numbers of apallic syndrome (AS)/vegetative state (VS) as a consequence of advanced rescue, emergency services, intensive care after acute brain injury and high-level activating home nursing for fully dependent end-cases in the secondary stage of progressive neurological disease. The treatment of patients with irreversible permanent AS/VS has been the subject of ongoing scientific and moral-legal debates over the past decade. METHODS: Under the auspices of the Scientific Panel on Neurotraumatology of the European Federation of Neurological Societies, a Task Force on AS/VS Quality Management Guidelines was established to address key issues related to AS/VS prevalence and quality management. The collection and analysis of scientific data on Class II (III) evidence from the literature and recommendations based on best practice, emerging from the expertise of the task force members, are in line with the EFNS guidelines. RESULTS: The overall incidence of new full-stage AS/VS cases of any etiology is 0.5-2/100,000 population per year. About one-third are traumatic and two-thirds non-traumatic cases. Increasing numbers of hypoxic brain damage and progressive neurological disease have been noted. The central conceptual criticism rests on the assessment and diagnosis of all the different AS/VS stages solely on the basis of behavioral findings without knowledge of the exact or uniform pathogenesis or neuropathological findings and the uncertainty of the clinical assessment due to different inclusion criteria. No specific diagnostics, no specific medical management can be recommended for the treatment and rehabilitation of AS class II or III. For this reason, the diagnosis of the clinical features and the appropriate treatment of AS/VS patients in the "AS full, remission, defect and end stages" require an indispensable prerequisite for the professional training and expertise of physicians and rehabilitation staff. INTERPRETATION: The management of AS aims at the social reintegration of the patients or must ensure humanistic active care in case of therapy failure. The outcome depends on the cause and duration of AS/VS and the age of the patient. There is no single AS/VS specific laboratory test, regimen, or stimulatory intervention that can be recommended to improve higher cerebral function. Quality management requires at least 3 years of advanced training and ongoing training to obtain recognition of qualification for AS/VS treatment and expertise. Sine qua non areas, which include AS/VS facilities for early and long-term rehabilitation, are required on a population basis (prevalence of 2/100,000/year) to expedite functional recovery and prevent or treat complications. Nursing homes are needed for respectful human care, including basal sensorimotor stimulation techniques. Passive euthanasia is viewed by physicians as an act of mercy in relation to withholding treatment";" However, ethical and legal issues related to food and hydration deprivation and end-of-life discussions are of great concern. The purpose of the guideline is to inform neurologists, neurosurgeons, other physicians working with AS/VS patients, neurorehabilitation staff, patients, family members, and health authorities.

title: Guidelines for reporting health interventions using mobile phones: Mobile Health (mHealth) Evidence Reporting and Assessment (mERA) checklist
abstract: To improve the completeness of reporting on mobile health interventions (mHealth), the WHO mHealth Technical Evidence Review Group developed the mHealth Evidence Reporting and Assessment (mERA) checklist. The development process for mERA consisted of convening an expert panel to recommend an appropriate approach, convening a global expert review panel to develop the checklist, and piloting the checklist. The guiding principle for the development of these criteria was to identify a minimum set of information needed to define what the mHealth intervention is (content), where it is implemented (context) and how it was implemented (technical characteristics ) to help them repeat the procedure. This paper presents the resulting 16-point checklist and a detailed explanation and elaboration for each point, with illustrative report examples. We expect that the use of these guidelines, through widespread adoption, will standardize the quality of mHealth evidence reporting and indirectly improve the quality of mHealth evidence. #### Summary points Mobile technologies have the potential to fill the systemic gaps needed to improve access to and use of health services, particularly among underserved populations. mHealth, defined as the use of mobile and wireless technologies for health, aims to leverage the rapid adoption of information and communication technologies (ICT) to improve health system efficiency and health outcomes. In the last ten years worldwide enthusiasm and interest in development Ã¢â‚¬Â¦

title: Guidelines for the Use and Interpretation of Assays for Monitoring Autophagy (3rd Edition)
Guidelines in medical-related professions
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines aim to reduce inappropriate practice variation and promote the delivery of evidence-based healthcare. OBJECTIVES: To identify and assess the impact of studies introducing clinical practice guidelines in nursing (including health visits), midwives and other medicine-related professionals. SEARCH STRATEGY: We searched the Cochrane Effective Practice and Organization of Care Group Index, MEDLINE (1975 to 1996), EMBASE, Cinahl and Sigle to 1996, the NHS Economic Evaluations Database (1994 to 1996), DHSS-Data (1983 to 1996). ), the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effectiveness (1994 to 1996), and reference lists of articles. We also hand-searched the Quality in Health Care journal, made personal connections with content experts, and contacted libraries selected by a panel of experts. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized trials, controlled before-and-after trials, and interrupted time-series analyzes of intervention implementation compared 1. Clinical guidelines plus dissemination and/or implementation strategies versus no guidelines”; 2. Guidelines plus dissemination and/or implementation strategies versus guidelines plus alternative dissemination and/or implementation strategies and 3. (post hoc) guidelines used by healthcare professionals versus standard healthcare The participants were nurses, midwives and other healthcare professionals DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently extracted data and assessed study quality. MAIN RESULTS: Eighteen studies were included, involving more than 467 healthcare professionals. Reporting on study methods was inadequate for all studies. In all but one study, nurses were the targeted occupation." One study was aimed exclusively at dieticians. The different behaviors that were targeted included the management of hypertension, low back pain and hyperlipidemia. Nine studies were identified for comparison 1. Three out of five Studies observed improvements in at least some nursing processes and six out of eight studies observed improvements in patient outcomes Only one study included a formal economic assessment with equivocal results For comparison 2, three studies were identified but poor methodologies made it difficult to draw firm conclusions Six studies were identified (post hoc) for comparison 3. These studies generally supported the hypothesis that there was no difference between nurse care following clinical guidelines and standard practice. REVIEWER'S CONCLUSIONS: There is evidence that guideline-based nursing is effective in transforming the process and outcome of nursing by medical-related professionals. However, caution should be exercised when generalizing the results to other professions and settings.

title: Guidelines for managing smoking during the perioperative period
abstract: Smoking is a public health issue of particular concern during the perioperative period, as it puts patients scheduled for surgery at risk of a 20% increase in in-hospital mortality and a 40% increase in the risk of major postoperative complications. In addition, current smoking increases almost all specific surgical complications. The perioperative period offers a real opportunity for smoking cessation. The rate of preoperative smoking cessation can be significantly increased by behavioral management and the prescription of a nicotine substitute before a planned surgical intervention. Preoperative smoking cessation should be routinely recommended regardless of the time of intervention, although benefit increases proportionally with the duration of smoking cessation. All professionals in the care pathway (GPs, surgeons, anaesthesiologists, ICUs, nurses) need to educate smokers about the positive effects of smoking cessation and provide them with dedicated management and personalized follow-up. For children, cessation of parental smoking or removal of the child from environmental tobacco smoke for as long as possible prior to surgery is essential.

title: Guidelines, editors, pharma and the biological paradigm shift
abstract: Private investment in biomedical research has increased in recent decades. In most places it has been hailed as the next best thing after technology itself. Much of the intellectual talent from academic institutions is absorbed into lucrative positions in industry. Applied research finds willing collaborators in the venture-backed industry, ensuring symbiotic growth for both. There are also significant costs involved. As academia interacts with industry, major conflicts of interest have arisen that are particularly true in biomedical research. They relate to disputes over patents and royalties, hostile encounters between academia and industry and between public and private companies, legal entanglements, scientific misconduct of various kinds, antagonistic press and patient advocacy lobbies, and a general atmosphere in which commercial interest takes precedence over patient welfare. The pharma image stinks because of a series of omissions and order errors. A recent example is the suppression of negative sentiment about Bayer's Trasylol (aprotinin) and Eli Lilly's Xigris (rhAPC) marketing maneuvers. Whenever there is a conflict between patient vulnerability and profit motives, the pharmaceutical industry often leans toward the latter. In addition, there are documents that bring to light how companies often cross the line between patient welfare and profit-oriented behavior. A voluntary moratorium on pharmaceutical spending to spoil drug prescribers is needed. A code of practice recently adopted by OPPI in India to limit drug company spending on junkets and jewelry is a welcome move. Clinical Practice Guidelines (CPG) are considered important as they guide the diagnostic/therapeutic regimen of a large number of physicians and hospitals and provide recommendations on drugs, their dosages and selection criteria. In addition to clinical trials, they are another area of growing influence for the pharmaceutical industry. For example, a relatively recent 2002 survey found that approximately 60% of 192 authors of clinical practice guidelines reported having financial ties to the companies whose medicines were being considered. There are strong arguments for creating CPGs based not only on effectiveness but also on cost-efficiency. The various effects of this must be explained. The work of bodies like the Appraisal of Guidelines Research and Evaluation (AGREE) Collaboration and Guidelines Advisory Committee (GAC) is also worth looking at. Even the actions of foundations dedicated to improving disease have come under scrutiny. The process of creating best practice guidelines for interactions between the pharmaceutical industry and physicians has already begun and can have important implications for patient care. Similarly, Good Publication Practices (GPP) for pharmaceutical companies have also been established, aiming to improve the behavior of pharmaceutical companies in reporting drug trials. The rapidly increasing trend towards industry influence and control has become a problem for many. It is of such importance that the Association of American Medical Colleges has issued two relatively recent documents - one in 2001 on "Managing Individual Conflicts of Interest" and the other in 2002 on "Managing Institutional Conflicts of Interest in Conducting Clinical Research." Academic Medical Centers (AMCs), like medical education and research organizations elsewhere, must take means to minimize their institutional conflicts of interest in conducting clinical research, and documents are now available addressing these issues The ICMJE- The 2001 revision requires full disclosure of the sponsor's role in the research, as well as assurances that investigators are independent of the sponsor, responsible for study design and conduct, have independent access to all study data, and control all editorial and publishing ion decisions. However, the results of a 2002 study suggest that academic institutions routinely participate in clinical research that does not adhere to ICMJE standards for accountability, access to data and control of publication, industry profitability and outflow of research grants to the Science. Industry supports new, non-traditional therapies, regardless of what is effective. Whatever traditional therapy is supported is most likely because the company in question has a product with a large stake there that has remained a "gold standard" or that this player believes has some "juice" left. Industry sponsorship mainly concerns potential drugs. not to determine whether there may be non-pharmacological interventions that are just as good, if not better. In the paradigm shift towards biological psychiatry, the role of industry sponsorship is not obvious, but is probably more far-reaching than many have realized or right thinking might warrant for the long-term health of the industry. A topic of great importance is protection of interests of research subjects. Patients agree to become objects of research, not only for personal medical benefit, but also for the benefit of the rest of the patient population and to further medical research. We all accept that industry needs to make a profit and invest in research and development. The pharmaceutical industry is huge. However, we must also accept that there is a fundamental difference between marketing strategies for other companies and those for pharmaceuticals. The ultimate barometer is patient well-being, and no drug that affects it can stand the test of time. So how does it make long-term economic sense to market inferior products? The biggest mistake veteran players in the industry can make is trying to adopt the shady techniques of the up-and-coming newcomer. Keeping secret marketing/sales tactics, manufacturing process, other business expansion strategies and plans, anti-competitive strategies are good business tactics. But it's critical that secrecy as a tactic does not extend to reporting research findings, particularly those that contradict one's product. Pharmacy has no choice but to make a quality product, develop comprehensive side effect profiles, and only commercialize it if it passes both tests. Why do pharma resort to questionable tactics? There are two main reasons for this: Despite all the constraints, a drug comes to the pharmacy after enormous investments. There are crippling overheads and infrastructure costs that need to be recouped. And massive profit margins must be maintained. Relying solely on real drug discoveries would be too much of a risk. Industrial companies have to find the right balance between profit and credibility. When it comes to making a profit, the marketing champions play their part. Credibility assessments have researchers and paid spokespersons playing their part. Everything is fine until marketing is based on credibility. When there is nothing for credibility, something is projected as a whole and marketing is done in the calculated hope that profits can accrue, since making profits must go on endlessly. This is what drives the pharmaceutical industry to use even questionable means to make a profit. There are essentially four types of medicines. First, drugs that work and have minimal side effects; second, drugs that work but have serious side effects; third, drugs that don't work and have minimal side effects; and fourth, drugs that work minimally but have serious side effects. It is the second and fourth types that cause major problems for the industry. Often the industry tries to project the fourth type as the second to escape censorship. The great cat-and-mouse game played by conscientious researchers is to expose the third and fourth types as what they are, and not allowing the industry to portray them as the first and second types respectively. The main game is to prevent the second type from being projected as the first. The third kind is essentially harmless, so they draw criticism and some hilarity at the antics to market them. But they escape anything more than a rap on the knuckles, except when projected as the first type. What captains of industry and veteran players need is to realize: Their prime mover can only bring out the first type. They only accept the second type until they can lay their hands on the first. 3. The third type can occasionally be toyed with to secure gains, but never by projecting them as the first type. 4. The fourth type are the laggards, a real threat to credibility and therefore do not deserve market hype or publicity. Finding out why most pharmaceutical companies indulge in questionable tactics leads us to some interesting solutions to prevent such tactics with the least amount of trouble for everyone involved, even while keeping both profits and credibility intact.

title: Guideline-based indicators for measuring the quality of prenatal care
abstract: Rationale, Aims and Goals: No comprehensive measurement of the quality of prenatal care is available. Late posting or low number of checks are often used as substitutes for poor quality, leaving uncertainty about the actual content of the care received. To close this gap, we reviewed two clinical guidelines and developed corresponding quality indicators. METHOD: A panel of clinicians and methodologists reviewed the National Institute for Clinical Excellence clinical guidelines for prenatal care and the list of recommended prenatal care interventions by the Research and Development Group, both based on evidence of the effectiveness of specific interventions. We have identified individual aspects in three areas: (1) utilization of services, (2) screening and (3) interventions. For each indicator we have defined: (1) suitability, ie the characteristics of the women to whom the indicator applies; (2) standard, which is the situation in which the goal is achieved;" and (3) moderators, which are any conditions lawfully impeding the achievement of the standard. RESULTS: We developed four indicators for service utilization, 25 for screening, and 17 for intervention.
