The respective suitability, standard and moderator criteria were described for each indicator. While many indicators could be evaluated retrospectively using medical records, the quality of communication with the provider, screening for sensitive issues, and advice on behaviors to avoid could only be achieved with prospective data collection. CONCLUSIONS: The indicators of the quality of prenatal care, complemented by measures of social position, social support, and migrant/ethnic status, allow for a thorough characterization of the gaps in the quality of care for specific groups of women.

title: Stopping Antipsychotic Use in Long-Term Care (HALT): a single-arm, longitudinal study aimed at reducing inappropriate antipsychotic use in long-term care residents with behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia
abstract: BACKGROUND: The inappropriate use of antipsychotics to treat behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD) continues despite revised guidelines and evidence on the associated risks and side effects. The goal of the Halting Antipsychotic Use in Long-Term Care (HALT) project is to identify residents of long-term care facilities (LTC) who are taking antipsychotic medications and to implement an intervention to discontinue (or discontinue) these medications and non-pharmacological ones improve behavior management. METHODS: LTC facilities are recruited across Sydney, Australia. Inclusion criteria for residents are over 60 years of age, regularly treated with antipsychotics, and without a primary psychotic illness or very severe BPSD as measured by the Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI). The data collection takes place one month and one week before the start of the prescription";" and 3, 6 and 12 months later. In the pre-description period, nursing staff will be trained on how to reduce and manage BPSD using person-centered approaches, and academic details will be provided to participants' GPs. The primary outcome measure is the reduction of regular antipsychotic medication without the use of psychotropic substitutes. Secondary outcome measures are NPI total and domain scores, Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory scores, and adverse events including falls and hospitalizations. CONCLUSION: While previous studies have described strategies to minimize the inappropriate use of antipsychotic medications in people with dementia living in long-term care, sustainability and a prescribing culture for BPSD in elderly care remain challenges. The HALT project aims to assess the feasibility of a multidisciplinary approach to antipsychotic drug cessation in this population.

title: Harnessing the power of standard options to improve healthcare
abstract: Decision makers are sometimes faced with a default choice - the option that will be implemented if an alternative is not actively chosen. The quality of healthcare can be improved through standard options such as B. Giving vaccinations to eligible hospital patients who do not refuse them. The authors argue that these options should be considered strategically and used to improve public health.

title: hazards at work
Lead to lifestyle behaviors of children, parents' weight perception and body mass index
abstract: This study examined lifestyle behaviors (food intake, active play, and screen time), parental perceptions of children's weight, and body mass index (BMI) of children participating in Head Start. 96 parent-child dyads participated. The prevalence of obesity (15.6%) was higher than the national average (10.4%)";" However, most parents (86.5%) of obese children did not identify their children as obese. Regardless of BMI, food intake and active play levels generally did not meet recommended guidelines. In addition, less active children were more likely to eat snacks (chi(2) = 6.24, p < or = 0.04). The role of pediatric nurses in counseling and referral to head-start families is explored.

title: Heal Yourself or Heal Your System: Can Doctors Help Improve Medical Care?
Health and nutrition education unit in a children's hospital
Health information, behavior modification and decision support for patients with type 2 diabetes: development of a customized, preference-sensitive health communication application
abstract: PURPOSE: Patient involvement in diabetes management, such as B. shared decision-making and patient self-management, has significant implications for clinical parameters. Adequate and preference-sensitive information for patients is a prerequisite for active participation. Interactive Health Communications Applications (IHCAs), which combine web-based patient health information with additional support, offer the opportunity to cost-effectively reach large numbers of patients and provide them with high-quality information and support at the time, place and learning speed they prefer. Nevertheless, web-based interventions often suffer from high attrition. Tailoring the intervention to patients' needs and preferences could reduce turnover and should thereby increase effectiveness. The purpose of this study was to develop a customized IHCA that provides evidence-based, preference-sensitive content and treatment decision support to patients with type 2 diabetes. The content was developed based on a needs analysis and two evidence-based treatment guidelines. The delivery format is a conversational, tunneled design that tailors the content and tone of the conversation to relevant patient characteristics (health literacy, attitudes toward self-care, and psychological barriers to insulin treatment). Both content and editing were revised by an interdisciplinary advisory board. CONCLUSION: The World Wide Web holds great potential for patient information and self-management interventions. With the development and evaluation of a tailor-made IHCA, we complement the personal discussions that patients have with their treating physicians and make them more efficient and mutually satisfying. Effects of the application are currently being tested in a randomized controlled study.

title: Health literacy training for public health nurses in Fukushima: a case study of program adaptation, implementation and evaluation
abstract: Health literacy encompasses not only an individual's ability to access, understand and use health information, but also the ability of health care providers to make health information accessible and usable. The Fukushima nuclear accident has posed challenges in communicating radiation-related health information. Public health nurses are the gatekeepers of community health in Japan and have primary responsibility for communicating this complex science and risk information to lay members of the community. A health literacy training program was designed to improve the communication skills of participating nurses with two main goals: changing communication practices and norms among public health nurses and improving access to information for community residents. The training content included an overview of health literacy (including numeracy), processes for evaluating written materials and visual representations, and guidelines for text improvement. The workshop extended over two days with two-hour sessions each. A proximal post-training assessment survey was conducted, followed by a more distal one-month follow-up assessment to evaluate the application of learned skills in practice. 26 nurses from Fukushima City attended the first hearing. Post-training evaluations were very positive, with 85-100% of participants agreeing on the appropriateness and usefulness of the workshop. During a month-long follow-up, the nurses reported that they applied new knowledge and skills to develop written materials. However, they struggled to share their new skills with peers and embraced the challenges of changing work norms. Participants also encountered difficulties in using graphics and explaining risks in practice. This paper underscores the importance of providing health literacy training opportunities for professionals to strengthen the health system's ability to provide accessible information and services. This program also serves as an important reference for future disaster management efforts.

title: The attitude of health professionals to the treatment of acute diarrhea
abstract: BACKGROUND: Traveler's diarrhea is the most common health problem in international travelers and is responsible for many consultations abroad and on return home. METHODS: A questionnaire assessing attitudes towards treatment and management of travel-related and non-travel-related diarrhea was distributed to 542 general practitioners, nurses, and pharmacists. RESULTS: Healthcare professionals' attitudes towards the management of acute diarrhea vary, with marked variation in terms of adherence to published good practice guidelines and recommendations. There are inconsistencies in the stated attitudes towards antispasmodic and antimotility drug prescribing and actual prescribing behavior. CONCLUSIONS: Current treatment guidelines may be outdated. Inappropriate or delayed treatment puts the patient at a disadvantage. Restricting the use of antidiarrheal drugs may deny people suffering from diarrhea access to a drug that can shorten symptoms and morbidity and speed the return to normal. The review of adult diarrhea management guidelines is overdue, as is the standardization of treatment response. Educational initiatives are needed to encourage active intervention and improved care.

title: Health Promotion in Adolescent and Young Adult Cancer Survivors: Mobilizing Compliance in a Multifaceted Risk Profile
abstract: As cure rates from childhood cancer increase, nurses have an increased chance of encountering a large survivor cohort in the practice. There are a variety of late effects programs";" However, funding for these programs is limited and not accessible to all patients. Primary care providers can increasingly act as medical homes for childhood cancer (CCS) survivors. Understanding the inherent risks of cytotoxic treatment and the progressive consequences of late sequelae is crucial to limit morbidity and mortality. Adolescent and young adult survivors (AYA) are particularly prone to make health behavior choices that create risks for comorbidities. Developmentally appropriate experimentation with drug, alcohol, or tobacco use and increased exposure to UV rays increases the risk of secondary malignancies and novel diseases. The lack of evidence-based surveillance guidelines and survival-specific health promotion programs cumulatively widens the gap in noncompliance and misinformation. This article gives an overview of the risk profile of CCS. It examines health practices as well as new health promotion techniques within the AYA survivor population and the role nurses play in improving health maintenance.

title: Evaluation of health systems counseling - a critical interpretation synthesis
abstract: Background Health systems guidelines (HSGs) are systematically developed statements that assist in making decisions about options for addressing health system challenges, including related changes in health system arrangements. However, the development, assessment and reporting of HSG poses unique conceptual and methodological challenges related to the different types of relevant evidence, the complexity of healthcare systems and the primacy of contextual factors. To fill this gap, we are conducting a research program that aims to create a tool to support the assessment of HSG and to further improve HSG development and reporting. The focus of this work was to perform a knowledge synthesis of the published and gray literature to determine quality criteria (concepts) relevant to this process. Methods We applied a critically interpretive synthesis approach (CIS) to knowledge synthesis, which allowed for an iterative, flexible, and dynamic analysis of different literature collections to create a candidate list of concepts that will form the basic components of the HSG tool. Using our review questions as a compass, we were able to direct the search strategy to look for articles based on their potential relevance to the HSG's assessment, development and reporting. The search strategy included various electronic databases and sources, specialized journals, conference abstracts, research reports, book chapters, unpublished data, dissertations, and policy documents. Paper screening and data extraction were performed independently and in duplicate, and a narrative approach to data synthesis was employed. Results We identified 43 articles that met the eligibility criteria. No existing review was found on this topic and no HSG assessment tool was identified. Over a third of the authors implicitly or explicitly identified the need for a high-quality tool aimed at systematically evaluating HSG and contributing to its development/reporting. We identified 30 concepts that might be relevant to the assessment of the HSG and were able to group them into three meaningful areas: process principles, content principles and context principles. Conclusions Our study demonstrated the role that the quality criteria play in the development, assessment and reporting of the HSG and revealed the connection and resonance within and between the different concepts in the three domains.

title: Health technologies for monitoring and treating diabetes: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: The primary objective of this review was to increase the strength of evidence for the effectiveness of self-monitoring devices and technologies for people with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) or type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) based on specific health-related outcomes determine dimensions. Self-monitoring devices included those that help patients manage diabetes and prevent cardiovascular complications (CVCs). A secondary objective was to examine issues of feasibility, usability, and compliance among patients and providers. METHODS: Study criteria included subjects > or = 14 years and adolescents (7-14 years) with T1DM or T2DM, intervention with a self-monitoring device, assessment of clinical outcomes with the device, literature in English, and > or = 10 participants. Relevant published literature was searched from 1985 to 2008. Randomized controlled trials and observational studies were included. Data on clinical outcomes, feasibility and compliance methods and outcomes were extracted. Selected studies were independently evaluated using a validated methodological quality assessment tool. RESULTS: Eighteen studies were selected. The predominant types of device interventions included self-monitoring of blood glucose, pedometers, and cell phones or wireless technologies. Feasibility and compliance were measured in most studies. CONCLUSIONS: Blood glucose self-monitoring remains an effective tool in the management of diabetes. Wireless technologies can improve diabetes self-care, and pedometers are powerful lifestyle change tools. The results of this review indicate a need for additional controlled trial research on existing and emerging technologies for diabetes self-monitoring, health outcomes associated with diabetes and CVC, and device feasibility and compliance.

title: Health care system utilization by risky alcohol drinkers: A secondary data analysis
abstract: PURPOSE: To investigate the impact of hazardous alcohol use on health care consumption patterns and health outcomes. DATA SOURCES: Using the National Health Interview Survey and the Medical Expenditure Panel Survey, an overall sample of 4449 adults, mean age 45 years (SD 15), were grouped according to responses to the question, "In the past year, on how many days did you have 5 or more alcoholic beverages?" CONCLUSIONS: Three categories of respondents were grouped as follows: no risk group = 0 days with 5+ drinks/day (n = 2991, 67%); the low risk group = 1-11 days with 5 + drinks/day (n=796, 18%) and the high-risk group = 12-365 days with more than 5 drinks per day (n=662, 15%) Health care outcomes High-risk alcohol drinkers used the health care system less often than other drinkers. When split between rural and urban living, high-risk alcohol drinkers in rural areas reported more emergency room visits and all rural residential groups reported worse physical and physical pro have more mental health problems than their urban counterparts PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: Hazardous alcohol use, defined as drinking above low-risk guidelines, affects 3 in 10 adults, and hazardous alcohol use plays a role in over 60 chronic conditions in multiple practice settings. It can be difficult to identify the underlying al alcohol problems, particularly in people living in rural areas;" However, identifying high-risk drinkers is essential for prompt intervention in the potential progression from high-risk alcohol use to an alcohol use disorder.

title: Hand decontamination practices of healthcare workers: adherence to recommended guidelines
abstract: AIM: This paper reports a study of the handwashing/hand hygiene practices of healthcare workers from a behavioral perspective. BACKGROUND: Hospital-acquired infections pose a very real and serious threat to all who are hospitalized. Pathogens are easily transmitted to the hands of healthcare workers and hand hygiene significantly reduces this transmission. There are evidence-based guidelines for healthcare workers' hand hygiene practices, but compliance with these guidelines is low internationally. METHODS: A quasi-experimental design was used with an appropriate sample. As a theoretical framework, the predisposition, reinforcement, and enabling constructs in educational diagnostics and evaluation of health education theory were used, and the data were collected in 2001. beliefs and knowledge) about compliance with hand hygiene guidelines (questionnaire, n = 62). Nurses, physicians, physical therapists, and nursing assistants who work in direct patient care at the study unit participated in the study. The interventional hand hygiene program aimed to prepare medical staff for hand hygiene behavior (poster campaign and educational leaflet), reinforce the behavior (feedback on pre-test results) and enable it (provision of alcohol-based hand disinfection next to each patient bed). RESULTS: Implementation of the multifaceted interventional behavioral hand hygiene program resulted in an overall improvement in adherence to hand hygiene guidelines (51-83%, P<0.001). Additionally, healthcare workers believed their skin condition improved (P<0.001). An increase in knowledge of handwashing guidelines was also noted. CONCLUSIONS: To be effective, efforts to improve handwashing compliance must be multifaceted. Alcohol-based hand sanitizers (with emollients) must be provided at the bedside of each patient. Problems related to skin irritation in healthcare workers need to be addressed urgently.

title: The self-reported effect of an intervention program on healthcare worker knowledge and behavior related to infection control
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Adherence to infection control guidelines is low and several efforts have been made to improve the performance of healthcare workers on infection control interventions. This study describes the implementation and evaluation of a hospital-wide infection control program. The most important measure was the distribution of an infection protection newsletter. METHODS: In evaluating the program, a randomized sample of health professionals received a questionnaire to assess the degree to which health professionals were aware of the program and whether they reported behavioral changes and refreshed knowledge as a result of the program. RESULTS: The intervention made it possible to reach >80% of the staff in a Norwegian university hospital. Of those who actually read the Infection Control Newsletter, 92.9% said their knowledge was refreshed and 60.6% reported changes in behavior. DISCUSSION: The intervention had a significant impact on nurses' and nursing assistants' reports of knowledge and behavior related to infection control. Our study supports the importance of a long-term and multimodal approach for healthcare workers when working on infection control. The time and resources devoted to the creation and distribution of the Infection Control Newsletter was an effective way to reach a large number of healthcare workers.

title: Live a healthy, active life: exercise guidelines for children and young people
abstract: The childhood obesity epidemic is increasing worldwide. Although risk factors for obesity are multifactorial, many are lifestyle-related and may be amenable to intervention. These factors include sedentary time and thermogenesis without physical activity, as well as the frequency, intensity, amount, and type of physical activity. Frontline health practitioners are ideally placed to monitor the physical activity levels of children, adolescents and their families, assess lifestyle choices and provide appropriate advice. This statement provides guidelines for reducing sedentary time and increasing physical activity in the pediatric population. Development-appropriate recommendations for physical activity are given for infants, toddlers, pre-school children, children and adolescents. Advocacy strategies for promoting healthy, active living at local, municipal, provincial/territorial and federal levels are included.

title: Healthy Living After Cancer: A Dissemination and Implementation Study Evaluating a Telephone-Delivered Healthy Lifestyle Program for Cancer Survivors
abstract: BACKGROUND: Recognizing that physical activity, a healthy diet, and weight management can improve cancer outcomes and reduce the risk of chronic disease, major cancer organizations and health authorities have endorsed guidelines for cancer survivors. Despite this and a growing evidence base of effective lifestyle interventions, there is limited uptake in survival care. METHODS/DESIGN: Healthy Living after Cancer (HLaC) is a national dissemination and implementation study that will evaluate the integration of an evidence-based lifestyle intervention for cancer survivors into an existing cancer information and support phone service provided by Australian Government Cancer Councils. Eligible participants (adults who have completed cancer treatment with curative intent) will receive 12 health coaching calls from Nurses/General Health Professionals at the Cancer Council over a 6 month period targeting national guidelines for physical activity, healthy eating and weight management . Using the RE-AIM evaluation framework, the primary outcomes are service-level indicators of program outreach, acceptability, implementation/cost, and maintenance, with secondary (efficacy) outcomes of patient-reported anthropometric, behavioral, and psychosocial variables measured before and after of the treatment were collected. program completion. The overall target for the accumulation of participants across four participating Cancer Councils is 900 over 3 years. DISCUSSION: The national scope of the project and the broad involvement of cancer survivors, in addition to assessing service level indicators, associated costs and patient-reported outcomes, will provide the necessary practice-based evidence needed to support future resource allocation of healthy living among cancer survivors. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australian and New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ANZCTR) – ACTRN12615000882527 (registered 2015-08-24).

title: Height, body mass index and socioeconomic status: Mendelian randomization study in the UK Biobank
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether height and body mass index (BMI) play a causal role in five measures of socioeconomic status. DESIGN Mendelian randomized study testing for causal effects of differences in stature and BMI on five measures of socioeconomic status. Mendelian randomization exploits the fact that genotypes are randomly assigned at conception and are therefore not confounded by non-genetic factors. SETTING UK Biobank. PARTICIPANTS 119,669 men and women of British descent between the ages of 37 and 73. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Age Full-time education completed, education completed, occupation class, annual household income, and Townsend Disadvantage Index. RESULTS In the UK Biobank study, shorter stature and higher BMI were observed to be associated with several measures of lower socioeconomic status. Associations between shorter stature and lower socioeconomic status tended to be stronger in males, and associations between higher BMI and lower socioeconomic status tended to be stronger in females. For example, a 1 standard deviation (SD) higher BMI with a £210 (£276; $300; 95% confidence interval £84 to £420; P =6 × 10(-3)) lower annual household income in males and around 1890 £ (1680 to £2100; P=6 × 10(-15)) lower annual household income for women. Genetic analyzes demonstrated that these associations were partially causal. A genetic height of 1 SD (6.3 cm) caused a 0.06 (0.02 to 0.09) year increase in age at the completion of full-time education (P = 0.01). a 1.12 (1.07 to 1.18) times greater likelihood of working in a skilled occupation (P=6 × 10(-7)) and £1130 (£680 to £1580) higher annual household income (P=4 × 10(-8)). Associations were stronger in men. A genetically 1 SD higher BMI (4.6 kg/m(2)) caused a £1680 to £4200;" P = 1 × 10 (-5)) lower annual household income and a 0.10 (0 .04 to 0.16) SD (P=0.001) higher levels of disadvantage only in women CONCLUSIONS These data support evidence that height and BMI play an important sub-role in determining several aspects of an individual's socioeconomic status, particularly BMI of women for income and deprivation and the height of men for education, income and occupational class.These results have important social and health implications and support the evidence that obese people, especially women, are disadvantaged and taller people, especially men, are at an advantage.

title: Helicobacter pylori management: how to improve therapeutic confusion in practice
abstract: There appears to be a discrepancy between current guidelines for Helicobacter pylori testing and treatment and clinical practice, including physician beliefs and actual prescribing patterns. In particular, there are clearly different approaches in primary and secondary care as well as country-specific differences in eradication therapy for Helicobacter pylori infection. Although most physicians do not believe that Helicobacter pylori causes non-ulcer dyspepsia, the majority seem to prescribe eradication. Less information is available on the management of Helicobacter pylori infection and gastroesophageal reflux disease, and there are more marked differences in attitudes and practices in this condition. Even in the case of peptic ulcer disease, where most clinicians in both primary and secondary care believe that Helicobacter pylori should be eradicated, putting this belief into practice often fails. There is also confusion regarding the treatment regimens used to eradicate Helicobacter pylori. Eradication regimens are less successful in practice than in clinical trials. Furthermore, a significant proportion of peptic ulcer patients remain symptomatic despite healing of the ulcer diathesis, which can undermine confidence. Therapeutic confusion about what to prescribe, side effects that limit compliance, bacterial resistance, and socioeconomic factors can compromise the therapeutic success of eradication therapy in practice. Unfortunately, it is well documented that policies alone are likely to have little or no impact on practice. Publication in a peer-reviewed journal is unlikely to lead to effective implementation in primary care. Based on the available evidence, clinical behavior is most likely to be modified when guidelines are developed by the clinician peer group for which they were intended, disseminated through a specific educational program, and implemented through specific reminders through use, preferably during consultation .

title: Help doctors and patients understand health statistics
abstract: Many doctors, patients, journalists and politicians do not understand the importance of health statistics or draw wrong conclusions without realizing it. Collective statistical illiteracy refers to the widespread inability to understand the meaning of numbers. For example, many citizens are unaware that higher survival rates with cancer screening do not mean longer lives, or that saying that mammography screening reduces the risk of dying from breast cancer by 25% actually means 1 in 1,000 fewer women are dying becomes the disease. We provide evidence that statistical illiteracy (a) is common among patients, journalists and physicians”; (b) arises from opaque information gathering, which is sometimes an unintended result of a lack of understanding, but can also be the result of deliberate efforts to manipulate or persuade people; and (c) can have serious health consequences. The causes of statistical illiteracy should not be attributed solely to cognitive biases, but to the emotional nature of the doctor-patient relationship and conflicts of interest in the healthcare system. The classic doctor-patient relationship is based on (doctor) paternalism and (patient) trust in authority, which makes statistical education seem unnecessary; as well as the traditional combination of determinism (doctors look for causes, not opportunities) and the illusion of certainty (Patients seek certainty when there is none). We show that information leaflets, websites, pamphlets distributed to physicians by the pharmaceutical industry, and even medical journals often report opaquely on evidence pointing to major benefits and minor harms of the presented interventions. Without understanding the numbers involved, the public is vulnerable to political and commercial manipulation of their fears and hopes, undermining the goals of informed consent and shared decision-making. what can be done We discuss the importance of teaching statistical thinking and transparent presentations in primary, secondary and medical schools. However, this requires introducing children to the concept of probability from an early age and teaching statistical literacy as the art of solving real-world problems, rather than applying formulas to toy problems involving coins and dice. An essential prerequisite for statistical competence is transparent risk communication. We recommend using frequencies instead of single event probabilities, absolute risks instead of relative risks, mortality rates instead of survival rates, and natural frequencies instead of conditional probabilities. Psychological research on transparent visual and numerical forms of risk communication and the training of physicians in their use are required. Statistical literacy is a necessary requirement for educated citizenship in a technological democracy. Understanding and critically examining risks can also shape the emotional climate in a society, making hopes and fears less easily manipulated from outside and allowing citizens to develop a more informed and relaxed attitude towards their health.

title: Helping hands: a cluster-randomized study to evaluate the effectiveness of two different hand hygiene promotion strategies in hospital nurses
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hand hygiene regulations are the most important measure to prevent hospital infections. However, compliance rates are generally below 50% of all hand hygiene opportunities. The aim of this study is to evaluate the short- and long-term effects of two different strategies to promote hand hygiene among nurses in hospitals. METHODS/DESIGN: This study is a cluster-randomized controlled study with inpatient wards as the unit of randomization. Hand hygiene guidelines are implemented in this study. Two strategies are being pursued to improve compliance with hand hygiene guidelines. The state-of-the-art strategy is derived from the literature and includes education, reminders, feedback and alignment with appropriate products and facilities. The expanded strategy also includes activities to influence social influence in groups and strengthen leadership. The unique contribution of the extended strategy builds on relevant behavioral science theories. The expanded strategy incorporates all elements of the state-of-the-art strategy, complemented by active commitment and initiative from the ward manager, modeling by informal leaders on the ward, and setting norms and goals within the team. The data collection takes place at four points in time at intervals of six months. At any one time, an average of 3,000 hand hygiene opportunities are observed by approximately 900 nurses. DISCUSSION: Conducting and evaluating an implementation strategy that also targets the social context of teams can significantly increase general knowledge in this area. The results of our study will allow us to draw conclusions on the impact of different strategies to implement hand hygiene guidelines and based on these results we will be able to define a preferred implementation strategy for hospital care. STUDY REGISTRATION: The study is registered as a clinical trial at ClinicalTrials.gov, dossier number: NCT00548015.

title: Helping someone with problem drug use: a Delphi consensus study of consumers, caregivers, and physicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: Problem illicit drug use (ie, substance abuse or addiction) is associated with significant health and social harm, underscoring the need for early intervention and involvement of health services. Family members, friends and colleagues play an important role in supporting and assisting people with problem drug use to seek professional help, however there are conflicting views on how and when such support should be provided. This paper reports the development of mental health first aid guidelines for adult problem drug use to inform community members how to help someone who is developing problem drug use or experiencing a drug-related crisis. METHODS: A systematic review of the academic and community literature was conducted to develop a 228-item survey containing potential first-aid strategies to help someone developing a drug problem or experiencing a drug-related crisis. Three expert panels (29 consumers, 31 caregivers, and 27 physicians) were recruited from Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, and the United States. Panel members independently evaluated the points in three rounds, with the strategies reaching consensus on importance and being incorporated into the guidelines. RESULTS: The overall response rate over three rounds was 80% (86% consumers, 81% caregivers, 74% physicians). 140 first aid strategies were endorsed as essential or important by at least 80% of panel members. The recommended strategies provide information and advice on problem drug use and its consequences, how to approach a person about their problem drug use, tips for effective communication, what to do if the person is unwilling to change their drug use, what to do is whether the person wants (or doesn't want) professional help, what are drug-related conditions and how to manage them, how to manage side effects that lead to a medical emergency, and what to do if the person is aggressive. CONCLUSIONS: The guidelines provide a consensus-based resource for community members who want to help someone with a drug problem. It is hoped that the guidelines will lead to better support and understanding for people with problem drug use and facilitate the onboarding of professional help.

title: Revision of the Helsinki Declaration continues
Liver reactions associated with ketoconazole in the UK
abstract: Ketoconazole was introduced in the UK in 1981. By November 1984, the Drug Safety Committee had received 82 reports of possible hepatotoxicity related to the drug, including five deaths. An analysis of the 75 cases that were followed up appropriately found that 16, including three deaths, were likely related to treatment with the drug. Of the remainder, 48 were possibly related to treatment, five were unlikely, and six were unclassifiable. The mean age of the patients in the 16 probable cases was 57.9 years, with hepatotoxicity occurring more frequently in women. The mean duration of treatment before the onset of jaundice was 61 days. None of these well-validated cases occurred within the first 10 days after treatment. Results of serum liver function tests indicated hepatocellular damage in 10 (63%)";" the rest showed a mixed pattern. In contrast, the results of histological examination of the liver often showed evidence of cholestasis. The characteristics of the 48 patients in the possible cases were similar. Allergic manifestations such as rash and eosinophilia were rare. Hepatitis was usually reversible when treatment was stopped, with liver function test results returning to normal after an average of 3.1 months. In two of the three deaths believed to be related to treatment with ketoconazole, the drug was continued after jaundice and other symptoms of hepatitis developed. Periodic clinical and biochemical monitoring for signs of hepatitis is recommended during long-term treatment with ketoconazole to prevent possible serious liver injury.

title: Competence network Hepatitis (Hep-Net).
abstract: In Germany, almost 1 million people are affected by chronic viral hepatitis. Despite the improved therapy options for the treatment of hepatitis B and C, some questions about epidemiology, pathophysiology and therapy remain unanswered. Vaccines against hepatitis C and D viruses are not yet available. In addition, many patients and their relatives need information on infectiousness, the course of the disease and therapy options. By involving medical practices and patient representatives, Hep-Net aims to provide information about the infection and tries to give all patients with treatment indications access to qualified treatment strategies. After 18 months, the Hep-Net homepage already has more than 9000 hits per day. Telephone consultation hours, e-mail services and numerous offers of cooperation with the Deutsche Leberhilfe eV are very popular. In the Hep-Net study house, high-quality clinical studies with initial successful results are organized centrally. In addition, fundamental questions from the fields of epidemiology, virology and immunology are dealt with in cooperative research projects within the network.

title: Hepatitis A
Herding: a new phenomenon affecting medical decision-making in multiple sclerosis care? Lessons learned from DISCUTIR MS
abstract: PURPOSE: Herding is a phenomenon in which individuals follow the behavior of others rather than making independent decisions based on their own private information. A herd-like phenomenon can occur in multiple sclerosis (MS) when a neurologist follows a therapeutic recommendation from a colleague, although this is not supported by best clinical practice guidelines. There is currently limited information on the role of herding in healthcare. The aim of this study was to determine the prevalence (and associated factors) of herding behavior in the treatment of MS. METHODS: We conducted a study among neurologists with expertise in MS care across Spain. Participants answered questions on how to deal with 20 case scenarios commonly encountered in clinical practice and completed 3 surveys and 4 experimental paradigms based on behavioral economics. The herding experiment consisted of a case study of a 40-year-old woman who had been stable on subcutaneous interferon for 3 years and developed a self-limiting neurological event. There were no new lesions on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Her neurological exam and disability scores were unchanged. She was advised by an MS neurologist to switch from interferon to fingolimod, contrary to best practice guidelines. Multivariable logistic regression analysis was performed to assess factors related to herd behavior. RESULTS: Of 161 neurologists invited to participate, 96 completed the study (response rate: 60%). Herding was present in 75 (78.1%), with a similar prevalence in MS experts and general neurologists (68.8% vs. 82.8%; P=0.12). In multivariate analyses, the number of MS patients treated per week was positively associated with herd behavior (odds ratio [OR] 1.08, 95% CI 1.01-1.14). Conversely, age, gender, years of practice, practice attitude, or physician risk preferences were not associated with hats. CONCLUSION: Herding was a common phenomenon affecting nearly 8 out of 10 neurologists caring for MS patients. Herding can influence medical decisions and lead to poorer outcomes in MS.

title: Heterogeneity: we cannot live with it and we cannot live without it
Heterogeneous demographic and cultural profiles of Chinese American patients who do not comply with colorectal cancer screening: a latent class analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is one of the leading causes of cancer death among Chinese Americans, but their CRC screening rates remain low. OBJECTIVE: We studied subgroups of Chinese American patients who did not comply with CRC screening guidelines to better inform clinical practices and effectively promote screening. METHODS: Using a latent class analysis of data from 327 participants recruited from 18 primary care clinics, we classified nonadherent patients based on sociodemographics, screening barriers, and attitudinal and clinical factors for CRC screening. RESULTS: The best fitting latent class analysis model described 3 distinct classes: western health class (36%), eastern health class (18%) and mixed health class (46%). Patients in the Western health class were highly educated, had an average US residency of 20 years, high levels of English proficiency, the least Eastern cultural views on care, and the most exposure to physician referrals, but reported no time for checkups . Eastern Health Class patients were highly educated seniors and recent immigrants with the least knowledge of CRC and the most Eastern cultural views. The mixed health class patients had a low level of education, had lived in the United States for 20 years, and half had sought the services of their physician for at least 3 years, but their knowledge and cultural views were similar to those of the eastern health class patients. CONCLUSIONS: Nonadherent Chinese American patients are heterogeneous. It is important to have future intervention programs tailored to address specific screening beliefs and barriers for subtypes of non-adherent patients. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Educating primary care physicians to recognize the diverse demographics and beliefs of patients in healthcare settings can facilitate physician communication with patients to overcome their barriers and improve screening behaviors.

title: Heterogeneous Effect of an ER Expert Diagram System
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVE: We compare results from different modules (occupational exposure to blood and body fluids, back pain and fever in children) of the Emergency Department Expert Charting System. Each module of this electronic health record provides real-time advice based on clinical guidelines embedded in the software. METHODS: We used a tiered off-on-off punctuated time-series design with an intent-to-treat analysis to evaluate the Emergency Department Expert Charting System in a university hospital emergency room for treatment of pediatric fever, low back pain, and occupational exposure to blood and body fluids. We measured quality of documentation by percentage of essential items in medical record and discharge instructions, percentage of reasonable testing and treatment decisions, mean fees per patient visit, physician satisfaction using pre- and post-trial questionnaires, and patient satisfaction by telephone Questionnaire. RESULTS: The ER Expert Charting System improved documentation rates for all modules. The emergency department's expert charting system has consistently improved the adequacy of diagnostic testing and treatment decisions for patients with occupational exposure to blood and body fluids, while reducing median costs. For the pediatric low back pain and fever modules, improvements in test and treatment appropriateness were less consistent and did not result in fee reductions. Although physicians were generally favorable to the intervention, physician use of the ED expert recording system and satisfaction with the modules was highest for occupational exposure to blood and body fluids and lowest for fever in children. For each complaint submitted, the mean patient satisfaction was highest during the ED Expert Chart System phase. CONCLUSION: The provision of guidelines through an electronic medical record with background decision support improved documentation, patient care and patient satisfaction, although the effects were heterogeneous for all complaints. The optimal strategy for implementing the guideline is likely to depend on the nature of the clinical problem and the nature of the healthcare delivery. For selected problems, the delivery of guidelines in this format over the Internet holds promise to change physician behavior and improve care (see http://www.needlestick.mednet.ucla.edu).

title: High-risk management guidelines for elderly suicidal patients in primary care
abstract: Older adults, particularly older white males, are more likely to commit suicide than other age groups. The assessment and treatment of suicidal ideation and behavior in older people is particularly relevant for primary care physicians, since many patients visit their physician shortly before committing suicide. In 1993, the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research (AHCPR) published clinical practice guidelines for treating depression in primary care. The AHCPR guidelines provided some guidance regarding the identification and treatment of suicidal patients. However, these guidelines lacked detailed and specific instructions for dealing with high-risk patients in the context of intervention research. The current set of guidelines builds on this earlier work by (1) describing a general approach to interacting with suicidal patients; (2) structured assessments to determine the level of suicide risk; (3) crisis intervention strategies;' and (4) ongoing management procedures for working with suicidal patients in primary care.

title: Historical background to the changes in the FDA policy on drug testing and evaluation in women
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) recently made two important changes to its policy for testing and evaluating drugs in women: (1) gender-specific analyzes of drug safety and efficacy will be required as part of all new drugs, and (2) it is no longer recommended to prohibit women of childbearing potential from participating in the earliest stages of drug trials. These changes are the result of ongoing efforts to individualize therapy, improve drug safety and efficacy, and answer important questions about whether the drug development process provides adequate information about drug effects in women. These efforts, in turn, are the result of a long history in the United States of changes in the clinical care of women, changes in the use of women as research subjects, changing attitudes about the balance between protection and risk for women in clinical trials, and national movements of women to focus on health care issues and change the male-centric model of clinical research. The new FDA guidelines, released in July 1993, will guide researchers in gathering valuable information about how drugs work in women and will allow physicians and other caregivers to consider the impact of gender on health and treatment.

title: History of evidence-based medicine. Oranges, lime and leeches: obstacles to teach old dogs new tricks
abstract: Knowledge translation is the process of extracting knowledge from research and applying it in clinical practice. In this article, I will cite some pivotal moments in the history of medicine to highlight the difficulties and delays involved in putting evidence into practice. These historical examples have much in common with modern medical studies and quality improvement processes. I will also examine the reasons why evidence is not used and what factors facilitate the inclusion of evidence. Understanding these concepts will make it easier for individual clinicians and institutions to change clinical behavior and provide a starting point for those concerned with implementing “new” practices, new therapies, and clinical guidelines. In conclusion, I offer a list of criteria that clinicians can consider when deciding whether or not to adopt a new practice, treatment, or concept.

title: HIV prevention in Mexican schools: prospective randomized evaluation of the intervention
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the impact of a school HIV prevention program that promotes condom use with and without emergency contraception on condom use and other sexual behaviors. DESIGN cluster randomized controlled trial. ESTABLISHING 40 public high schools in the Mexican state of Morelos. PARTICIPANTS 10 954 first graders. INTERVENTION Schools were randomly assigned to one of three streams: an HIV prevention course that promoted condom use, the same course with emergency contraception as a backup, or the existing sex education course. Self-administered anonymous questionnaires were completed at baseline, four months and 16 months. Students in intervention schools received a 30-hour (over 15 weeks) course on HIV prevention and life skills designed in accordance with the guidelines of the United Nations Joint Program on HIV/AIDS. Two additional emergency contraceptive classes were given to students in the Condom Promotion with Contraception stream. PRIMARY OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome measure was reported condom use. Other outcomes were reported sexual activity, knowledge and attitudes about HIV, and emergency contraception; and attitudes and confidence towards condom use. RESULTS The intervention had no impact on reported condom use. Knowledge about HIV improved in both intervention arms, and knowledge about emergency contraception improved in the condom advertising with contraception arm. Reported sexual behaviors were similar in the intervention arms and the control group. CONCLUSION A rigorously designed, implemented, and evaluated HIV education course in public high schools has not reduced risky behaviors, and such courses need to be redesigned and evaluated. The addition of emergency contraception did not reduce reported condom use or increase risky sexual behaviors, but it did increase reported emergency contraceptive use.

title: Research group Competence Network HIV/AIDS presents first results
abstract: Clinical HIV research in Germany is underrepresented internationally. This deficit is mainly due to the fact that there are no clinical studies with nationwide patients and that there is no national patient cohort system in Germany that could provide a basis for such clinical studies. The HIV/AIDS Competence Network closes this gap by functioning as a comprehensive, nationwide research network. Establishing a patient cohort involves 20 projects. The success of this new structure is becoming apparent.

title: Home blood pressure management and improved blood pressure control: results of a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: To determine which of the 3 interventions was most effective in improving blood pressure (BP) control, we conducted a 4-arm randomized trial with 18 months of follow-up in the primary care clinics of a Veterans Affairs Medical Center. METHODS: Eligible patients were randomized to either usual care or 1 of 3 telephone intervention groups: (1) nursing behavior management, (2) nursing and physician medication management, or (3) a combination of both. Of the 1551 eligible patients, 593 were randomized";" 48% were African American. The intervention phone calls were triggered based on home BP values transmitted via telemonitoring devices. Behavior management included the promotion of health behaviors. Medication management included medication adjustment by a study physician and nurse based on hypertension treatment guidelines. RESULTS: The primary endpoint was change in blood pressure control measured at 6-month intervals over 18 months. Both behavioral management and medication management alone showed significant improvements at 12 months - 12.8% (95% confidence interval [CI], 1.6% - 24.1%) and 12.5% (95% CI, 1, 3% - 23.6%) - but not at 18 months. In subgroup analyses, systolic blood pressure decreased by 14.8 mm Hg (95% CI, -21.8 to -7.8 mm Hg) at 12 months and by 8.0 mm Hg in those with poor baseline BP control in the combined intervention group (95% CI, -15.5 to -0.5 mm Hg) at 18 months relative to usual care. CONCLUSIONS: The intervention effects were moderate overall, but the effects were greater in subjects with poor blood pressure control at baseline. This study demonstrates the importance of identifying individuals who are most likely to benefit from potentially resource-intensive programs. STUDY REGISTRATION: clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT00237692.

title: Home Nurses as a New Channel for Smoking Cessation Treatment: Findings from the CARES (Community-nurse Assisted Research and Education on Smoking) Project
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical smoking cessation guidelines may not be sufficient to help some subgroups of smokers to quit. Incorporating smoking cessation into home health care can proactively reach at-risk smokers who may not have access to (or spontaneously seek) smoking cessation. METHOD: Homecare nurses (N = 98) were randomly assigned to offer their patients either Motivational Enhancement (ME); motivational interviewing + carbon monoxide feedback) or standard care (AHCPR guidelines for smoking cessation). Seventy percent of patients were eligible and willing to participate (N=273; 54% female, mean age=57 years, 83% Caucasian, 41% 0.05). ME reported more cessation attempts and a significantly greater reduction in the number of cigarettes smoked per day at all follow-ups through 12 months post-treatment (all P-values < 0.05). CONCLUSIONS: Using an existing public health channel such as home health care to reach smokers who differ in their motivation to quit could have the potential for large public health implications.

title: Hormonal breast cancer drugs: implications for the general practitioner
abstract: PURPOSE: Over 2 million breast cancer survivors live in the United States, making women with breast cancer the largest group of cancer survivors. The purpose of this article is to review the current knowledge on survival issues in women with estrogen receptor-positive early breast cancer, with a focus on advances in hormonal therapies to reduce the risk of recurrence. DATA SOURCES: Published research studies, clinical treatment guidelines, and ongoing clinical studies. CONCLUSIONS: Innovations in antiestrogenic and estrogen modulator therapies are an important aspect of ongoing care after primary breast cancer treatment. GPs can play an important role in monitoring possible complications of anti-estrogen treatment. PRACTICAL IMPLICATIONS: This article provides an overview of the current state of the art regarding hormonal breast cancer drugs for breast cancer survivors. Given the high incidence and prevalence of breast cancer, primary care physicians need to be aware of the potential short- and long-term health risks and benefits of hormone therapies for breast cancer survivors.

title: Hormone Therapy Discontinuation: Physician Practices Following the Women's Health Initiative
abstract: OBJECTIVE: No guidelines or randomized trials address best practices for stopping hormone therapy (HT). METHODS: We conducted a survey study to examine the practice of HT termination at Group Health and Harvard Vanguard, large integrated health care systems in the Northwest and Northeast United States, focusing on differences between specialties and study location. RESULTS: The response rate to the written questionnaire (sent between December 2005 and May 2006) was 78.5% (736/928)”; this article reports the results for 483 eligible physicians. Most physicians (91%) advised stopping oral HT gradually, not immediately (8%), and most (60%) suggested reducing both the dose and the days per week. Almost 60% of physicians reported no experience with tapering patches. Harvard Vanguard physicians were more likely than Group Health physicians to advise discontinuation of HT and are less likely to advise resuming HT if a woman's symptoms returned after stopping HT. Physicians were most influenced by their own experience (48%), the advice of colleagues (25%), and the woman's preference (19%) in choosing a stopping strategy;" only 2% relied on research. Physicians advocated different approaches to managing symptoms after HT discontinuation, most commonly behavior modification (44%) and increased exercise (37%), and these approaches were more frequently endorsed by Harvard Vanguard physicians and OB/GYNs than by Group Health physicians or primary care physicians, or Internists. CONCLUSIONS: Two health care plans in the Northwest and Northeast United States do not have a standard protocol for discontinuing HT. Physicians have tailored approaches influenced by their location, peers, and specialty. Research is needed to validate approaches to discontinuing HT to direct HT.

title: Hospital building in the NHS. Ideas and Designs II: Harness and Nucleus
Clinician responsiveness to feedback on assay costs: a prospective blinded controlled intervention study.
Smoking behavior of hospital physicians and their attitudes towards smoking cessation interventions for patients: a survey in an Italian Comprehensive Cancer Center
abstract: PURPOSE: Tobacco control guidelines recommend that all healthcare professionals ask patients about their smoking status and provide them with at least minimal smoking cessation advice. However, little data is available on the daily practice of clinicians working with smoking cancer patients. This study evaluates physicians' smoking habits, their clinical practice in providing smoking cessation interventions to smoking patients, and the training they have received in this area at a comprehensive cancer center. METHODS: A web-based survey was sent to 285 physicians. RESULTS: The survey response rate was 75%. 62%, 24%, and 14% of responders were never, former, and current smokers, respectively. Six percent of all responding physicians have already attended smoking cessation training and 43% of them agreed to receive training. 86% of all responding physicians asked about patients' smoking status, 50% routinely advised patients to quit smoking, and 32% rated their motivation for doing so. Smoking cessation guidelines were not followed mainly due to lack of time, fear of increasing patient stress, and lack of smoking cessation education. 94% of the responding physicians were aware of the outpatient smoking cessation service and 65% referred at least one patient, 66% of the responding physicians were aware of the inpatient service and 36% of them requested at least one procedure on the ward. CONCLUSIONS: This study indicated partial adherence to smoking cessation guidelines by physicians at a leading cancer center. Physicians' smoking habits did not influence training and clinical practice in providing smoking cessation interventions to patients.

title: Studies show that household income directly affects child development
abstract: Children in low-income households have poorer cognitive, social, and health outcomes, concludes a new report from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, a social policy research charity.1 The report says money makes a direct difference to children, and not just because low income correlates with parental education, attitudes toward child-rearing, and other parental factors. Kerris Cooper and Kitty Stewart of the Center for â‚¬Â¦

title: How did formative research influence the development of a women's group intervention in rural Nepal?
abstract: The inability to reduce neonatal and maternal mortality in poor countries is sometimes attributed to a lack of contextual knowledge of caregiving practices and behaviors. There is a lack of knowledge on how to translate formative research into effective interventions to improve maternal and newborn health. We describe the results of the formative research and how they were used to inform the development of such an intervention in rural Nepal. Formative research was conducted in four parts. Part 1 included study area familiarization and literature review, and Parts 2, 3, and 4 included community mapping, health services review, and qualitative and quantitative studies of perinatal caregiving behaviors. Participatory approaches have proven successful in reducing neonatal mortality and may be appropriate in our context. Community mapping and profiling helped describe the community context, and we found that community-based organizations often attempted to involve the female community health volunteer in community mobilization. She did not routinely hold monthly meetings and found it difficult to maintain them without support and oversight. In health care facilities, most primary care workers were posted, but referral centers lacked physicians and nurses. Mortality estimates reflected under-reporting of deaths, and hygiene and infection control strategies had poor coverage. Most women give birth at home with their mother-in-law, friends and neighbors. Care during perinatal illnesses was usually sought from traditional healers. Cultural issues such as shyness, fear, and normality constrained women's behavior during pregnancy, childbirth, and the postpartum period, and decisions about their health were usually made after communicating with family and community. The formative research indicated the type of intervention that could be successful. It should be community based and not exclusively for pregnant women. It should address negotiations within families and tailor information to the needs of local groups and specific stakeholders such as mothers-in-law and traditional healers. The intervention should not only accept cultural constructs, but also be a forum to discuss ideas of pollution, shame and seclusion. We used these guidelines to develop a participatory, community-based women's group intervention facilitated through a community cycle of action. The success of our intervention may be due to their acceptance at the community level and their sensitivity to the needs and beliefs of families and communities.

title: How do clinicians prefer cultural competence training? Results from the DSM-5 Cultural Formulation Interview Field Trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study is to analyze training methods rated as most helpful and least helpful by clinicians during the DSM-5 field trial with cultural formulation interviews, to analyze reasons for this, and to analyze associations between demographic characteristics and method preferences. METHOD: The authors used mixed methods to analyze interviews with 75 clinicians on five continents about their training preferences after a standardized training session and the first time clinicians conducted the Cultural Formulation Interview. The content analysis identified the most and least helpful educational methods by reason. The bivariate and logistic regression analysis compared clinical characteristics with method preferences. RESULTS: Most frequently, clinicians cited case-based behavioral simulations as "most helpful" and video as "least helpful" training methods. Bivariate and logistic regression models, first unadjusted and then clustered by country, found that each additional year of physician age was associated with a preference for behavioral simulations: OR = 1.05 (95% CI: 1.01-1.10" ;" p=0.025) . CONCLUSIONS: Most clinicians preferred active behavioral simulations in cultural skills training, and this effect was most pronounced in older clinicians. Effective training is best achieved through a combination of written policy reviews, video demonstrations, and behavioral simulations. Future work may examine the impact of satisfaction with clinical training on patient symptoms and quality of life.

title: How does the self-reported clinical treatment of patients with back pain relate to the attitudes and beliefs of healthcare professionals? A survey of UK GPs and physiotherapists
abstract: Guidelines for the management of low back pain (LBP) have existed for many years, but compliance by healthcare professionals (HCPs) remains suboptimal. The aim of this study was to measure the attitudes, beliefs and reported clinical behaviors of UK physiotherapists (PTs) and general practitioners (GPs) about LBP and to explore the associations between these. A cross-sectional postal survey of primary care physicians (n=2000) and PTs (n=2000) was conducted that included the Pain Attitude and Belief Scale (PABT.PT) and a vignette of a patient with nonspecific LBP (NSLBP). with questions about recommendations for work, activity, and bed rest. Data from 1022 respondents (442 GPs and 580 PTs) who had recently treated patients with LBP were analyzed. Although the majority of HCPs indicated that they had given advice to vignette patients that was broadly in line with guideline recommendations, 28% indicated that they would advise this patient not to work. Job counseling was significantly related to PABS.PT scores, with higher biomedical (F(1,986)=77.5, p<0.0001) and lower behavioral (F(1,981)=31.9, p<0.001) scores associated with the advice to stay away from work. We have shown that UK GPs' and PTs' attitudes and reported practice behavior towards patients with NSLBP differ. Many HCPs believed that LBP required some avoidance of activities and work. The attitudes and beliefs of these HCPs were linked to their self-reported clinical behaviors regarding advice about work. Future studies need to investigate whether approaches aimed at modifying these HCP factors can lead to improved patient outcomes.

title: How many steps/day is enough? for children and young people
abstract: Global physical activity public health guidelines place particular emphasis on child (typically 6-11 years) and adolescent (typically 12-19 years) populations. Existing guidelines are usually expressed in terms of frequency, time and intensity of the behavior. However, simple step output from both accelerometers and pedometers is gaining credibility in research and practice as a reasonable approximation of daily ambulatory physical activity volume. Therefore, the purpose of this article is to review the existing literature on objectively monitored step-based physical activity in children and adolescents in order to provide researchers, practitioners, and laypersons using accelerometers and pedometers with evidence-based translations of these public health guidelines in relation to steps for to provide / day. In terms of normative data (ie expected values), the updated international literature indicates that 1) we can expect children to average 12,000 to 16,000 steps/day and girls to average 10,000 to 13,000 steps/day” and 2) adolescents to Decrease steadily every day until approximately 8,000-9,000 steps/day are observed in 18-year-olds. Controlled cadence studies show that continuous MVPA walking produces 3,300-3,500 steps in 30 minutes or 6,600-7,000 steps in 60 minutes 10- to 15- Year-olds: Limited evidence suggests that a daily volume of physical activity totaling 10,000 to 14,000 steps/day is associated with 60 to 100 minutes of MVPA in preschool-aged children (approximately 4 to 6 years). Across studies, 60 minutes of MVPA in elementary/elementary school children appears to be achieved on average within a total volume of 13,000 to 15,000 steps/day in boys and 11,000 to 12,000 steps/day in girls, in adolescents (both boys and girls) 10,000 to 11,700 can be paced 60 miles are associated nutrients from MVPA. Translations of time- and intensity-based guidelines may be higher than existing normative data (eg, in adolescents) and are therefore more difficult to achieve (but not impossible or contraindicated). The recommendations are preliminary and more research is needed to confirm and extend the values for measured cadences, associated speeds and MET values in young people; continue to collect normative data (expected values) for both steps/day and MVPA across age groups and populations;" and to conduct longitudinal and interventional studies in children and adolescents needed to provide information on the shape of the staged dose-response To obtain curves of physical activity associated with various health parameters.

title: How much does the quality of childcare vary between health professionals with different lengths of training? An observational multi-country study
abstract: Background In countries with high infant mortality rates, there tends to be a shortage of qualified health workers. Little rigorous evidence has been presented to assess how much the quality of care varies between types of health workers. We compared the performance of different categories of health professionals trained in Integrated Management of Childhood Illnesses (IMCI).";" Background In countries with high infant mortality rates, there tends to be a shortage of qualified health workers. Little rigorous evidence has been presented to assess how much the quality of care varies between types of health workers. We compared the performance of different categories of health professionals trained in Integrated Childhood Illness Management (IMCI).

title: How organizational escalation prevention potentials affect the implementation success of innovations: Electronic patient files in hospitals
abstract: Background Escalation of engagement is the tendency for (innovation) projects to continue even when it is clear that they will not be successful and/or become extremely costly. Escalation Prevention Potential (EPP), an organization's ability to stop or control implementation processes that are not meeting their expectations, can prevent an organization from wasting time and money on unsuccessful projects. EPP is a set of checks and balances built into management practices that can protect management from irrational (yet very human) decisions and limit the escalation of implementation projects. We examine whether the successful implementation of electronic medical records (EMRs) is related to EPP and examine the organizational factors responsible for this relationship. Methods Structural equation modeling (SEM) using questionnaire data from 427 physicians and 631 nurses experienced in the implementation and use of EMRs in hospitals was applied to examine whether formal governance and organizational culture alter the relationship between EPP and the perceived value of mediate EMRs. Results Physicians and nurses in hospitals with more EPPs report more successful implementation of EMR (in terms of perceived added value of EMR). Formal governance conveys the connection between EPP and implementation success. We found no evidence that an open or innovative culture explains the relationship between EPP and implementation success. Conclusions There is a positive correlation between the EPP level and the perceived added value of EMRs. This relationship is explained through formal organizational governance mechanisms. This gives management a solid set of tools to positively influence the success of innovation processes. But it also means that management must be able to critically reflect on its (past) actions and decisions, and be willing to change plans if elements of EPP indicate that the implementation process will be hindered.

title: How remuneration systems affect the care behavior of doctors - an experimental study
abstract: Understanding how physicians respond to reimbursement incentives is a central concern of health economics research. We conduct a controlled laboratory experiment to analyze the impact of fee and per capita incentives on physician service delivery. In our experiment, physicians select sets of medical services for patients with different health conditions. We find that physicians provide significantly more services based on effort than on effort. Patients are oversupplied when it comes to fee payments and undersupplied when it comes to per capita payments. However, incentives to pay are not the only motivation for physicians' volume decisions, as patient health benefits are also of significant importance. We find that patients who require a high (low) level of medical care receive greater care at a per-service (per-fee) basis.

title: How Science Thinks and How Practice Acts: Bridging the Gap in Adolescent Weight Control Interventions
abstract: BACKGROUND: Adolescent obesity requires evidence-based treatment approaches given its long-term physical and psychosocial consequences. However, research shows that there are many problems in translating scientific knowledge into practice. AIM: The aim of this study was to develop science- and practice-based recommendations for planning future weight management interventions in adolescents. METHODS: We conducted (i) literature searches on intervention studies on adolescent obesity management and Dutch clinical guidelines for obesity, as well as practice-based documents and gray literature on obesity management and adolescent health program delivery, and (ii) semi-structured studies through interviews with eight clinicians and four non-clinicians working in the treatment, management, and prevention of obesity to explore prospects for treating adolescent obesity and to use evidence in practice. RESULTS: After pooling the results from literature reviews and interviews, four problems emerged: (i) little reporting on theoretical models used in intervention studies, Dutch clinical guidelines and semi-structured interviews; (ii) inconsistency in age-specific considerations for treatment of adolescent obesity in intervention studies and Dutch clinical guidelines;" (iii) inconsistency in addressing the social nature of obesity in intervention studies and Dutch clinical guidelines, and (iv) how professional responsibility should be shared , is unclear from intervention studies, Dutch clinical guidelines and semi-structured interviews.CONCLUSIONS: Future interventions require joint action between science and practice.Future interventions should include issues relevant to the stage of adolescence and focus more on the complex social nature of obesity Finally, practitioners can generate more practice-based evidence by starting their own practice-based research.

title: Attribution of causality in quality improvement: Lessons from epidemiology
How to improve medical and public acceptance and application of colorectal cancer screening recommendations
abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) screening is a multidisciplinary effort that aims to reduce mortality and incidence from CRC without compromising the health status of participants. Adopting a public health perspective requires a commitment to ensure equitable access and the sustainability of the program over time. We reviewed available evidence on predictors of CRC screening uptake and the effects of interventions to improve screening acceptance using conceptual frameworks that define the role of determinants of preventive behavior and the scope and goal of interventions. The results of this review indicate that policies to support the delivery of screening, as well as organizational changes that affect the operational characteristics of preventive services, need to be implemented so that individual motivation can eventually be realized. To ensure coverage and equitable access, and to maximize the impact of the intervention, strategies should be adopted to implement organized programs that ensure that financial barriers do not limit participation in screening and any follow-up assessment. Participant and provider beliefs can determine responses to different screening modalities. To achieve the desired health outcome, an active follow-up of individuals with screening abnormalities should be undertaken, supported by the introduction of infrastructural changes and multidisciplinary teamwork that can ensure the sustainability of effective interventions over time. Ongoing monitoring and the adoption of plans to evaluate program effectiveness are critical steps in implementing a successful program.

title: How to implement clinical practice guidelines in Iran
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence-based medicine would result through evidence-based implementation. Clinical Practice Guidelines (CPG) as one of the evidence-based knowledge products require appropriate interventions after they are created in order to be applied. OBJECTIVES: The aim of this qualitative study was to identify the strategies for the application of Iranian-made CPGs. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Targeted snowball sampling was performed and continued until theoretical saturation was reached. Detailed semi-structured individual interviews and focus group discussions (FGD) were conducted with the aim of triangulation. The thematic framework approach was used for the analysis. RESULTS: Twelve interviews were conducted with three policy makers and health system decision makers, four with experience in producing or adapting clinical practices, and five experts in the development and education of evidence-based medicine. In addition, 11 policy makers, managers and health system decision makers participated in FGD. The proposed interventions were grouped into the following themes: health worker-centred, financial, organizational, regulatory, and multifaceted interventions. CONCLUSIONS: Along with the process of adapting and developing CPGs, their use should also be planned";" otherwise the time and money spent would be wasted. Certainly, enforcing the above interventions with the ultimate goal of sustainable behavioral change among health care providers is beyond the capacity of any particular group or fewer academic centers. It requires the participation of all practitioners under the supervision and support of the Department of Health and Medical Education. The introduction of the GP plan and referral system is an opportunity that must be viewed as a trophy.

title: How do you translate therapy recommendations in clinical practice guidelines into rules for criticizing medical prescriptions? Methods and application to five guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines provide recommendations on what to do in different medical settings, including therapeutic recommendations for drug prescribing. An effective way to computerize these recommendations is to design critical decision support systems, i.e. systems that criticize the doctor's prescription when it does not follow guidelines. These systems are usually based on a list of "if conditions, then criticism" rules. However, writing these rules from the guidelines is not a trivial task. The aim of this article is to propose methods that (1) simplify the translation of therapeutic recommendations from guidelines into systems of criticism by automatically translating structured therapeutic recommendations into a list of “if conditions, then criticize” rules, and (2) generate an appropriate text label to explain to the physician why his/her prescription is not recommended. METHODS: We worked on the therapeutic recommendations in five clinical practice guidelines on chronic diseases related to cardiovascular risk management.
