We evaluated the system on a test basis of more than 2000 cases. RESULTS: Algorithms for automatically translating therapy recommendations into "if conditions then criticize" rules are presented. It also proposes eight general recommendations";" They are guideline independent and can be used as default behaviors for dealing with various situations usually implied in the guidelines, such as: B. reducing the dose of a poorly tolerated drug. Finally, we provide models and methods for generating a human-readable textual critique. The system was successfully evaluated on the test basis. Conclusion: We show that it is possible to criticize and understand medical prescriptions based on a structured clinical guideline. We are now planning a randomized clinical trial to assess the impact of the system on practice.

title: How well do clinicians follow dementia practice guidelines?
abstract: Although there are numerous clinical guidelines on the management of dementia, there are few studies on their implementation in practice. Clinicians at six United States Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers (n=200, 85% response rate) were surveyed regarding their use of the practices recommended in the California Workgroup guidelines for the management of Alzheimer's disease. The majority of providers (89% to 73%) reported that they routinely performed neurological exams, obtained medical histories from caregivers, discussed the diagnosis with the patient's family, discussed a permanent power of attorney, and prepared statutory reports on drivers with dementia. About two-thirds of providers reported routinely performing cognitive screening, screening for depression, reporting elder abuse, and discussing care needs and decision-making issues with patients' families. Only half of all outpatient providers established care practices for at least half of their patients. Clinicians' drug choices for cognition, mood, and behavior problems were broadly consistent with current practice guidelines. These results suggest possible priorities for quality improvement efforts. Further research is needed to clarify the reasons for specific gaps between guidelines and practice and to identify specific targets for interventions.

title: Human experimentation and medical ethics
Human experimentation in historical and ethical perspective
abstract: KIE: This article, prepared as background material for a World Health Organization/Council on International Organizations for the Medical Sciences document, Proposed International Guidelines for Biomedical Research Involving Human Subjects (1982), reviews historical aspects of human experimentation and considers several current problems. It refers to early experimentation, including physicians' self-experimentation, "tracing the history of drug testing through the pharmacotherapeutic revolution and the thalidomide tragedy;" and describes the formulation of ethical requirements during the Weimar Republic in Germany. Current issues discussed are the use of controls and placebos, investigators as subjects, special categories of subjects, and informed and vicarious consent. The text of the proposed WHO/CIOMS guidance is attached.

title: Human fetal tissue for medical research
Human tissue research: EORTC recommendations on their practical implications
abstract: Improvement in cancer treatment is possible through the application of new treatment modalities resulting from insights and discoveries from laboratory research. This is made possible by international cooperation and the collection of tumor tissue. The establishment of a European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) tumor bank is a natural step in this direction by offering the collection of tumor samples from patients participating in EORTC studies. The goal of such a bank is not only to improve the diagnostic review process, but also to facilitate translational research by allowing clinicians and basic scientists to work closely together. The EORTC Tissue Research Policy was developed to ensure ethical and scientific review of research projects, ensure patients receive adequate information, establish procedures for the use of materials, including legal aspects, and publication guidelines within the EORTC legal framework. As part of the EU TubaFrost project, the EORTC will provide a common international platform for the use of tissues for research, in order to find a balance between different laws and ensure scientific progress.

title: Hypertension Improvement Project (HIP): Study protocol and implementation challenges
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hypertension affects 29% of the US adult population and is a leading cause of heart disease, stroke and kidney failure. Despite numerous effective treatments, only 53% of people with hypertension achieve their blood pressure goal. The chronic care model suggests that blood pressure control can be achieved by patients and physicians improving patient self-care. METHODS AND DESIGN: This paper describes the protocol of a nested 2 x 2 randomized controlled trial to test the separate and combined effects of a behavioral intervention for patients and a quality improvement-type intervention for physicians on systolic blood pressure. General practitioner practices were randomly assigned to the medical intervention or the medical control condition. The physicians were randomized at the clinic level. Medical intervention included training and performance monitoring. The training consisted of two web-based modules that outlined both the JNC-7 hypertension guidelines and lifestyle changes for hypertension. Performance data was collected for 18 months and feedback was provided to physicians every 3 months. Patients attending both intervention and control clinics were individually randomized to patient intervention or usual care. Patient intervention consisted of a 6-month behavioral intervention delivered by trained interventionists in 20 group sessions, followed by 12 monthly telephone contacts by community health workers. Follow-up measurements were carried out after 6 and 18 months. The primary endpoint was the mean change in systolic blood pressure at 6 months. Secondary endpoints were diastolic blood pressure and the proportion of patients with adequate blood pressure control at 6 and 18 months. DISCUSSION: A total of 8 practices (4 per treatment group), 32 physicians (4 per practice; 16 per treatment group) and 574 patients (289 control and 285 intervention patients) were included. Baseline characteristics of patients and providers and challenges in conducting the study are presented. The HIP interventions can improve blood pressure control and reduce cardiovascular disease risk in a primary care setting by addressing key components of the chronic care model. The study design allows for separate assessments of the effectiveness and costs of interventions by physicians and patients, allowing healthcare organizations to make informed decisions about implementing either or both interventions in the context of local resources. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT00201136.

title: Hypertension Improvement Project: Randomized Study of Quality Improvement for Physicians and Lifestyle Modification for Patients
abstract: Despite widespread high blood pressure treatment guidelines for physicians and lifestyle recommendations for patients, blood pressure control rates remain low. In community-based primary care hospitals, we conducted a nested, 2 x 2 randomized controlled trial of physician intervention versus control and/or patient intervention versus control. Physician intervention included internet-based training, self-monitoring, and quarterly feedback reports. Patient intervention consisted of 20 weekly group sessions followed by 12 monthly telephone counseling sessions, and focused on weight loss, nutritional approaches to control hypertension, dietary patterns, exercise, and reduced sodium intake. The primary endpoint was change in systolic blood pressure at 6 months. Eight primary care practices (32 doctors) were randomly assigned to a medical intervention or control group. Within these practices, 574 patients were randomized to patient intervention or control groups. The mean age of the patients was 60 years, 61% were women and 37% were black. Blood pressure data were available for 91% of patients at 6 months. The main effect of the physician's intervention on systolic blood pressure at 6 months adjusted to baseline was 0.3 mm Hg (95% CI: 1.5 to 2.2 inches; P=0.72). The main effect of the patient's intervention was 2.6 mm Hg (95% CI: 4.4 to 0.7; P=0.01). The interaction of the two interventions was significant (P=0.03), with the greatest effect being observed in the combination of physician and patient intervention (9.7 +/- 12.7 mm Hg). Differences between the treatment groups did not persist after 18 months. Combined doctor-patient interventions lower blood pressure.” Future research should focus on improving the effectiveness and sustainability of these interventions.

title: Hypertension in black patients: an update
abstract: Black people are at high risk of hypertension and particularly increased morbidity from cardiovascular and kidney diseases. A better understanding of racial disparities in hypertension in relation to risk factors, patient/physician behavior and patient outcomes is key to improving racial care for black patients. Recent data suggest that black patients progress more quickly from prehypertension to hypertension, underscoring the need for early and immediate intervention. Unfortunately, adherence and persistence to antihypertensive therapy in black patients is generally poor and is compounded by the increased need for multidrug therapy in this patient population. Treatment strategies currently under investigation focus on methods to improve self-care behavior and medication adherence. As this is a constantly and rapidly evolving field of study, this article provides an update on the latest findings that should be of relevance and interest to practicing clinicians.

title: Identification and assessment of the salient beliefs of colorectal cancer survivors about physical activity
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity (PA) has been associated with a lower risk of disease recurrence and longer survival in colorectal cancer (CRC) survivors. however, less than one-third of CRC survivors meet PA guidelines. Interventions to promote PA in CRC survivors need to understand the most critical beliefs that influence PA behavior. OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to examine the strength of associations between the most common PA beliefs of CRC survivors and motivational constructs from Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) and PA behavior. INTERVENTION/METHODS: Colon cancer survivors (n=600) residing in Alberta, Canada, completed self-report questionnaires that assessed medical and demographic variables, PA beliefs, constructs from the TPB, and PA behaviors. RESULTS: Colorectal cancer survivors identified improved fitness (69.5%), family members (67.3%), and medical/health problems (8.8%) as the most prevalent behavioral, norm, and control beliefs, respectively. All PA beliefs were significantly correlated with all TPB constructs and PA. CONCLUSIONS: Physical activity interventions for CRC survivors should target many salient beliefs, including behavioral, normative, and control loci. PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: Insights into the preeminent beliefs of PA in CRC survivors can guide caregivers in developing successful strategies to promote PA in this population, likely to improve quality of life and possibly disease progression.

title: Identifying perceived barriers to pain management in Iranian children: a qualitative study
abstract: Children in the hospital often receive inadequate treatment for their pain. Pediatric nurses experience these inadequacies more often than other members of the healthcare team. This research was an attempt, in the form of a phenomenological study, to uncover some of the major barriers to pain management in children, as perceived by caregivers. Sixteen nurses were interviewed in the medical, surgical and infectious pediatric departments of a hospital in Iran. The data analysis was based on the Colaizzi method, which revealed three main issues in different areas, namely: organizational barriers, limitations related to the child's characteristics, and barriers related to the nature of the disease and its treatment. Study results have revealed organizational limitations that add to the lack of authority to perform some medical procedures, inadequate equipment and supplies, and the unavailability of opioids as the most important pain-controlling and limiting factors. Other factors related to the child's characteristics, such as age, temperament, behavior, expression and gender influence the assessment and management of pain. The results showed identified barriers in real context. It seems that some guidelines are needed to achieve optimal pain management.

title: Identification, assessment and management of obesity in an academic primary care center
abstract: BACKGROUND: The rapidly increasing prevalence of childhood obesity is one of the most difficult dilemmas facing pediatricians today. As the medical community struggles to develop effective strategies to treat this epidemic, timely detection of obesity by pediatric healthcare providers remains the critical first step in obesity management. OBJECTIVE: A direct assessment of the performance of pediatric clinicians in the detection and management of obesity in clinical practice has not been conducted. The aim of this study was to determine the detection rates of obesity by pediatric residents, nurses, and faculty members in a primary care academic setting and to describe the actions taken by these providers in their assessment and management of obesity. DESIGN: A retrospective review of the medical records of all health surveillance visits for children aged 3 months to 16 years examined between December 1, 2001 and February 28, 2002 was performed. In children, 120% of the 50th percentile of body weight was defined as obese. For children > or = 5 years, a body mass index > 95th percentile for age and sex was defined as obese. FACILITIES: A large primary care practice in a tertiary-care academic children's hospital serving a predominantly urban minority (70% African American) who are insured for medical assistance (90%). PARTICIPANTS: Primary care providers, including paediatricians, nurse practitioners, and faculty physicians. RESULTS: Of the 2515 visits examined, a total of 244 patients met the study definition of obesity, yielding an estimated prevalence of obesity visits of 9.7% among health surveillance visits for children aged 3 months to 16 years. This prevalence of obesity visits cannot be used to estimate the prevalence of obesity in the population because of the skewed distribution of visits among very young children. For all children who met the study definition of obesity, providers documented obesity in their assessments in only 53% of the visits reviewed (129 visits). Although the majority of the charts (69%) included an appropriate dietary history, only 15% included a description of the child's activity level or television viewing. Physical examination revealed obesity in 39% of cases. In children for whom obesity was identified as a problem by their physicians (129 patients), 81% of the charts included an appropriate dietary history, while 27% included a description of the child's activity level or television viewing. Physical examination revealed obesity in 64% of cases. Most children identified as obese by their providers received treatment specifically targeted for their obesity, including education, screening, and referral to a specialist. Dietary changes were recommended for 71%, increasing activity for 33% and reducing TV viewing for only 5%. 83% of providers recommended close follow-up. Other recommendations included referral to a dietician (22%), screening laboratory studies (13%), a food diary (9%), endocrine disease referral (5%), or referral to preventive cardiology (3%). The identification of the obesity provider was influenced by the age of the patient and by the degree of obesity. Obesity detection was lowest in preschool children (31%) and highest in adolescent patients (76%). Providers who screened older and heavier children were also more likely to collect activity histories, note obesity on physical exam, recommend changes in activity, refer the patient to a dietitian, obtain screening laboratory studies, and recommend close follow-up. The identification of obesity and other outcome variables were not significantly affected by physician training level or patient gender. CONCLUSIONS: Although the prevalence of childhood obesity has now reached epidemic proportions, it has been under-recognized and under-treated by pediatric primary care physicians in our study. Providers identified obesity as a problem for only half of the obese children screened for health surveillance. The lowest rates of obesity identification occurred in children under 5 years of age and those with milder degrees of obesity. Identification did not improve with additional years of pediatric education. Even for the subset of children classified as obese by their providers, evaluation and treatment often fell short of current recommendations. For example, more attention has been paid to the role of diet versus activity in assessing obesity. In particular, only a small number of providers (5%) recommended reducing television viewing for their obese patients, although there was evidence of an association between television viewing and pediatric obesity. This finding is worrying because obesity is known to be a multifactorial disease that only responds to significant changes in both diet and activity behaviors. Only 13% of providers requested laboratory testing as part of their referrals. The American Academy of Pediatrics currently recommends profiling lipids, total cholesterol, and a screening test for type 2 diabetes mellitus as part of the obesity assessment. The majority of physicians who requested laboratory studies included thyroid function tests, which the American Academy of Pediatrics does not recommend because of the very low likelihood of hypothyroidism as a cause of obesity. Although the level of assessment and management for children identified as obese did not meet current guidelines, it was far superior to that for patients not identified as obese by their providers. This demonstrates the importance of timely detection as a crucial first step in treating obesity. The results of this study are discouraging, especially given the growing evidence of the importance of early intervention in preventing the medical and psychosocial consequences of obesity, as well as the persistence of obesity into adulthood. This study underscores the need for greater awareness and identification of obesity in primary care, particularly among younger children and those with mild obesity.

title: Identify and reduce errors with surgical simulation
abstract: The most important determinant of a patient's safety and outcome is the skill and judgment of the surgeon. While knowledge base and decision making are assessed during the internship, technical skills - which are the core of the profession - are not assessed. Innovative, state-of-the-art simulation devices that train both surgical tasks and skills without risk to patients should enable the detection and analysis of errors and "near misses". Studies have validated the use of a sophisticated Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (ES3) simulator for procedural training of residents. It is currently being evaluated whether the integration of a comprehensive ES3 training program into the residency curriculum will have a long-term impact on surgical performance and patient outcomes. Using different ENT residencies, subjects will be exposed to supervised training on the ES3 as well as minimally invasive trainers such as the MIST-VR. Technical errors are identified and quantified on the simulator and intraoperatively. Individual performance can be compared with a national standard via a web-based database. An updated version of the ES3 is being developed that will support patient-specific anatomical models. This advance allows for the study of the effects of a simulated sample of patient-specific procedures (mission rehearsal) on patient outcomes and surgical errors during the actual procedure. Information gleaned from these studies will help usher in the next generation of surgical simulators, which are expected to have a significant impact on patient safety.

title: Identifying the barriers and requirements to triage, treatment, and transfer of clinical interventions to treat acute stroke patients in the emergency department: a systematic review using the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical guidelines recommend that evaluation and treatment of patients with stroke begin early, including in the emergency department (ED). To inform the development of an ED-focused implementation intervention, we conducted a systematic review of qualitative and quantitative studies to identify relevant barriers and enablers for six key clinical behaviors in acute stroke care: appropriate triage, thrombolytic administration, monitoring, and management of the Temperature, blood glucose levels and dysphagia and transfer of stroke patients to ED. METHODS: Studies of any type conducted in the emergency department that identified barriers or enablers based on primary data for one or more of these six clinical behaviors. Major biomedical databases (CINAHL, OVID SP EMBASE, OVID SP MEDLINE) were searched using comprehensive search strategies. The barriers and enablers were categorized using the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF). The behavior modification technique (BCT) that best fitted the strategy that each enabler represented was selected for each of the reported enablers using a standard taxonomy. RESULTS: Of the 44 studies identified, five qualitative studies and four surveys met the selection criteria. The majority of the reported barriers corresponded to the TDF domains "environment, context and resources" (e.g. stressful working conditions or lack of resources) and "knowledge" (e.g. lack of guideline awareness or familiarity). The majority of enablers corresponded to the areas of 'knowledge' (e.g. educating physicians about the calculated risk of bleeding after intravenous thrombolysis [tPA]) and 'skills' (e.g. providing the ability to treat stroke cases of varying complexity). The total number of BCTs assigned was 18. The most commonly assigned BCTs to reported enablers were 'Focus on past achievements' and 'Information on health outcomes'. CONCLUSIONS: Obstacles and prerequisites for the delivery of important evidence-based protocols in an emergency setting were identified and interpreted within a relevant theoretical framework. This new knowledge has since been used to select specific BCTs to implement evidence-based care in an ED setting. It is recommended that findings from similar future reviews follow a similar theoretical approach. In particular, the use of existing matrices to support the selection of relevant BCTs.

title: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Prevailing and evolving hypotheses about its pathogenesis and implications for therapy
abstract: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a progressive and usually fatal lung disease characterized by fibroblast proliferation and extracellular matrix remodeling, resulting in irreversible distortion of lung architecture. Although the pathogenetic mechanisms have yet to be determined, the prevailing hypothesis is that fibrosis is preceded and provoked by a chronic inflammatory process that injures the lung and modulates pulmonary fibrogenesis, resulting in an end-stage fibrotic scar. However, there is little evidence that inflammation is prominent in the early stages of the disease, and it is unclear whether inflammation is relevant to the development of the fibrotic process. There is evidence that inflammation does not play a critical role. Inflammation is not a prominent histopathologic finding, and epithelial injury in the absence of ongoing inflammation is sufficient to stimulate the development of fibrosis. In addition, the inflammatory response to fibrogenic pulmonary infarction is not necessarily related to the fibrotic response. Clinical measures of inflammation do not correlate with stage or outcome, and effective anti-inflammatory therapy does not improve outcome. This review presents a growing body of evidence suggesting that idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis involves abnormal wound healing in response to multiple microscopic sites of persistent alveolar epithelial injury and activation associated with the formation of patchy fibroblast-myofibroblast foci that progress to fibrosis . Advances in understanding the fibrogenic mechanisms in the lungs will likely lead to more effective therapies.

title: If Only It Were: Medical Physics, U.S. Radiation Experiments, and the Final Report of the Presidential Advisory Committee (ACHRE)
Influence of a clinical decision support system on antibiotic prescribing for acute respiratory infections in primary care: quasi-experimental study
abstract: Objective To evaluate the effect of a clinical decision support system (CDSS) integrated with an electronic health record (EHR) on antibiotic prescribing for acute respiratory infections (ARIs) in primary care. Materials and methods Quasi-experimental design with nine intervention practices and 61 control practices in the Practice Partner Research Network, a network of practices all using the same EPA (Practice Partner). The nine intervention practices were located in nine US states. The design included a 3-month baseline data collection (October to December 2009) prior to the introduction of the intervention and 15 months of follow-up (January 2010 to March 2011). The key outcome measures were antibiotic prescription for ARI episodes for which antibiotics are inappropriate and broad spectrum antibiotic prescription for all ARI episodes. Results In adult patients, antibiotic prescribing for ARI episodes when antibiotics are inappropriate decreased more in intervention practices (-0.6%) than in control practices (+4.2%) (p=0.03). In adults, however, CDSS intervention improved broad-spectrum antibiotic prescribing, with a 16.6% decrease in intervention practices versus a 1.1% increase in control practices (p<0.0001). A similar effect on the prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics was seen in pediatric patients with a 19.7% decrease in intervention practices compared to a 0.9% increase in control practices (p<0.0001). Conclusions CDSS embedded in an electronic medical record had a modest impact on changing adult prescriptions when antibiotics were inappropriate, but had a significant impact on changing overall prescriptions of broad-spectrum antibiotics in pediatric and adult patients.

title: Effects of a computerized clinical decision support system on reducing inappropriate antimicrobial use: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Objective: Many hospitals are using antimicrobial management teams (AMTs) to improve patient care. However, most work with minimal computer assistance. We evaluated the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a computer-assisted clinical decision support system for the management of antimicrobial use. DESIGN: A randomized, controlled study in adult hospitalized patients between May 10 and August 3, 2004. Antimicrobial use was managed by an existing AMT, using the system in the intervention arm and without the system in the control arm. The system is designed to alert the AMT to potentially inadequate antimicrobial therapy. Measurements: Outcomes assessed were hospital expenditure on antimicrobials, mortality, length of hospital stay, and time spent administering antimicrobial use. Results: The AMT intervened in 359 (16%) of 2,237 patients in the intervention arm and in 180 (8%) of 2,270 in the control arm, while spending approximately one hour less each day in the intervention arm. Spending on in-hospital antibiotics was $285,812 in the intervention arm and $370,006 in the control arm, a savings of $84,194 (23%), or $37.64 per patient. No significant difference in mortality (3.26% vs. 2.95%, p=0.55) or length of hospital stay (3.84 vs. 3.99 days, p=0.38) was observed. Conclusion: Using the system facilitated the management of antimicrobial use by allowing the AMT to intervene in more patients receiving inadequate antimicrobial therapy and achieving significant time and cost savings for the hospital. This is the first study to demonstrate in a patient randomized controlled trial that computerized clinical decision support systems can improve existing antimicrobial management programs.

title: Influence of a computerized decision support system on policy adherence to antibiotics prescribed for urinary tract infections in emergency departments: a multicenter prospective controlled intervention study before and after
abstract: Targets Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are a leading reason for antibiotic prescriptions in emergency departments (EDs), with half of these antibiotics being improperly prescribed. Our aim was to assess the impact of a computerized decision support system (CDSS) on adherence to guidelines on empiric antibiotic prescribing (antibiotics and duration) for UTIs in EDs. Methods From March 19 to October 28, 2012, a multicenter, prospective, controlled intervention study was conducted. All adults diagnosed with community-acquired UTI (cystitis, pyelonephritis, or prostatitis) in three French emergency departments were included. Antibiotic therapy was considered guideline-compliant when the antibiotic and the prescribed duration met national guidelines. The data was collected using electronic patient files. Paired tests were used when comparing periods within each ED, and global analyzes used multivariate logistic mixed models. Results Nine hundred and twelve patients were enrolled during the 30-week study period. The CDSS was used in 59% of cases (182/307). CDSS intervention improved antibiotic prescription compliance in only one ED in a bivariate analysis (absolute increase +20%, P?=?0.007). Antibiotic choice was improved in multivariate analyses, but only when the CDSS was used [OR?=?1.94 (95% CI 1.13-3.32)]. The CDSS also changed the initial diagnosis in 23% of cases in all three EDs. Conclusions The CDSS only partially improved adherence to antibiotic prescribing guidelines in UTIs.

title: Effects of a computerized template on prescribing antibiotics for acute respiratory infections in children and adolescents
abstract: Background. Computerized decision support (CDS) can potentially improve patient safety and guideline compliance. Authors developed an interactive acute respiratory disease (ARI-IT) template within an electronic health record (EHR) to manage pediatric ARIs and assessed the impact on antibiotic prescribing. methods. They randomized 12 practices to receive either the ARI-IT or the control group. Antibiotic rates of all candidate ARI diagnoses were compared at control and intervention ARI visits, controlling for grouping by clinician. Results. There was no difference in the total number of antibiotic prescriptions between control and intervention clinics. Use of the ARI-IT reduced antibiotic prescribing (31.7% vs. 39.9%; P=0.02) and macrolide use (6.2% vs. 9.5%; P=0, 02) in the visits compared to the eligible visits where it was not used. Conclusion. Use of the CDS reduced antibiotic and macrolide prescriptions in children with ARI. Nonetheless, the low overall utilization led to an ineffective intervention.

title: Effects of a multifaceted intervention on cholesterol management in primary care offices: guideline adherence for a randomized heart health trial
abstract: Background Physicians' adherence to the National Cholesterol Education Program clinical practice guidelines was inadequate. Methods We recruited 68 primary care and internal medicine practices; 66 were randomly assigned to a study arm; 5 practices dropped out, resulting in 29 receiving the Third Adult Treatment Panel (ATP III) intervention and 32 receiving an alternative intervention focused on the Seventh Joint National Committee on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment report of High Blood Pressure (JNC-7). ATP III providers received a personal digital assistant who provided the Framingham risk scores and ATP III treatment recommendations. All practices received copies of each clinical practice guideline, an introductory lecture, 1 performance feedback report, and 4 visits for procedure-specific scientific detailing. Data were drawn at 61 practices from random samples of medical records of patients treated from June 1 through May 31, 2003 (baseline) and from May 1, 2004 to April 30, 2006 (follow-up) The proportion was screened with subsequent appropriate decision n manufacture (primary outcome) was calculated. Generalized estimating equations were used to compare results by arm, accounting for clustering of patients within practices. Results We examined 5,057 medical records at baseline and 3,821 follow-up visits. The screening rate for lipid levels increased from 43.6% to 49.0% (ATP III practices) and from 40.1% to 50.8% (control practices) (net difference -5.3% [p=0.22] ). Adequate management of lipid levels decreased slightly (73.4% to 72.3%) in the ATP III practices and more significantly (79.7% to 68.9%) in the control practices. The net change in appropriate management favored the intervention (+9.7%; 95% confidence interval [CI], 2.8%-16.6% [p<0.01]). Adequate drug prescription at 4 months decreased in both arms (38.8% to 24.8% in ATP III practices and 45.3% to 24.1% in control practices; net change, +7.2% [P = 0.37]). Overtreatment decreased from 6.6% to 3.9% in ATP III and increased from 4.2% to 6.4% in control practices (net change -4.9% [P=0.01]) Conclusions A multifactor Intervention, including personal digital assistant-based decision support, can improve primary care physician adherence to ATP III guidelines.

title: Impact of a multifaceted intervention on nurses' and physicians' attitudes and behavior towards family presence during resuscitation
abstract: Recent studies of healthcare provider attitudes toward the presence of family members during CPR and invasive procedures (family presence) have focused on retrospective or cross-sectional surveys of staff. Research shows that clinicians' opinions on the value of this practice are mixed. Although guidelines for implementing family presence have been proposed, few reports describing actual programs or effective strategies for changing the practice have been published. As staff committed to implementing a family attendance program in our own emergency department, we were interested in evaluating staff attitudes before and after the family attendance program was implemented. We also wanted to see if attitudes differ between nurses and doctors. In this article, we report our experience implementing a family attendance program in the emergency department of a large academic teaching hospital.

title: Impact of a quality improvement program on the care and outcomes of children with asthma.
abstract: Objective To test a quality improvement intervention, collaborative learning based on the Institute for Healthcare Improvement Breakthrough Series methodology, specifically designed to improve care and outcomes for patients with childhood asthma. Design Randomized study in primary care practices. Practices in Greater Boston, Massachusetts and Greater Detroit, Mich. Participants Forty-three practices with 13,878 pediatric patients with asthma randomly assigned to intervention and control groups. Intervention Participation in a collaborative learning project based on the Breakthrough Series methodology for continuous quality improvement. Main outcome measure Change from baseline in the proportion of children with persistent asthma who received appropriate asthma medication and the proportion of children whose parents received a written treatment plan for their child's asthma, as determined by telephone interviews with parents by 631 children. Results After adjustment for federal state, practice size, child's age, sex and clustering within the practice, no overall effect of the intervention was found. Conclusions This methodologically rigorous review of a widely used quality improvement technique showed no significant impact on processes or outcomes in the care of children with asthma. Possible shortcomings in program implementation, project duration, sample selection and data sources preclude the general conclusion that this type of improvement program is ineffective. More rigorous studies should be conducted under more optimal conditions to evaluate the effectiveness of this method for improving care.

title: Impact of a web-based antimicrobial licensing system on the use of broad-spectrum cephalosporins in a teaching hospital.
abstract: Aim: To achieve a sustainable improvement in the use of cefotaxime and ceftriaxone (CEFX) in a large teaching hospital, measured against national antimicrobial guidelines. DESIGN AND SETTING: Pre- and post-intervention survey on CEFX use at Royal Melbourne Hospital, a tertiary hospital in Melbourne, Victoria. Intervention: Web-based antimicrobial registration system in conjunction with national antimicrobial policies was developed by a multidisciplinary team and implemented in March 2001, 8 months before and 15 months after the intervention";" Compliance of the indication for CEFX with the national antimicrobial guidelines before and after the intervention. Results: CEFX use decreased from a mean of 38.3 DDDs/1000 bed-days before the intervention to 15.9, 18.7, and 21.2 DDDs/1000 bed-days at 1, 4, and 15 months after the intervention. Compliance with national antimicrobial guidelines increased from 25% of courses before intervention to 51% within 5 months after intervention (p<0.002). Gentamicin use also increased from a mean of 30.0 to 48.3 DDDs/1000 bed days (p=0.0001). Conclusion: The web-based antimicrobial approval system resulted in a sustained reduction in CEFX use over 15 months and increased prescription compliance with antimicrobial guidelines. It has potential for linking to e-prescribing and for wider use for other medicines, as well as for research into the epidemiology of antibiotic use.

title: Impact of an educational effort to improve prescribing by private physicians in Uganda
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Private urban practitioners in Uganda treat a large percentage of the most common adult medical conditions. Improving their prescribing would not only encourage more rational drug use, but would also reduce costs for patients. Interventions to improve drug use are generally more successful when face-to-face methods are incorporated. OBJECTIVES: To determine the effectiveness of a personal training intervention for the treatment of acute respiratory infections (ARI), malaria and non-dysenteric diarrhea by private physicians in three urban areas of Uganda. METHODS: The study used an intervention with a comparison group design to evaluate the effect of the educational intervention. A total of 108 resident physicians were divided into intervention (n = 30) and control groups (n = 78). Surrogate patients trained to simulate the symptoms and signs of the target conditions were used to collect data on physicians' medical practices and prescribing behavior. Intervention physicians were invited to a one-day interactive training seminar moderated by local thought leaders on the principles of rational drug use and national standard treatment guidelines for treating the target disorders. Data on basic practices were also made available to physicians. RESULTS: Baseline data showed high rates of inappropriate treatment practices in both the intervention and control groups. There was near-universal use of antibiotics for ARI (over 90%), high rates of injections recommended for malaria (over 30%), and high rates of polypharmacy (more than three drugs per patient). After the intervention, some significant improvements in key practices were observed in the intervention group. Compared to control physicians, antibiotic prescriptions for ARIs in the intervention group decreased by 23%, use of combination products for malaria decreased by 28%, there were trends towards better adherence to guidelines for ARIs and malaria, and modest reductions in drug costs . However, the overall impact of the intervention was limited, particularly in terms of quality indicators related to history taking, appropriate assessment, and patient counseling. CONCLUSION: The face-to-face educational intervention resulted in some small improvements in key private practitioner prescribing practices. However, achieving greater improvements would require an intervention that involves repeated contacts with prescribing physicians and takes economic considerations into account. Private practitioners need to be made aware and encouraged to use the national standard of care guidelines, and attempts to improve their prescribing should be supported by community education.

title: Impact of clinical practice guidelines on clinician behavior: tonsillectomy in children
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study was conducted to assess to what extent the development and implementation of clinical practice guidelines for listing children for tonsillectomy (with or without adenoidectomy) affected the behavior of the participating ENT surgeons. METHOD: A before-and-after study in which the intervention (the development and dissemination of local practice guidelines) was sequentially implemented in different hospitals and surgical practices. The study was conducted in four ENT surgeons in Northern England with 16 consultant ENT surgeons and their offspring on 1190 children aged 0-14 who were assessed prior to consultation with an ENT surgeon who were referred for throat problems for which tonsillectomy was a possible treatment option were included in the study. Surgeons' decision and proportion of decisions that conformed to the new guidelines. RESULTS: Of the clinical decisions to admit children for tonsillectomy made before the introduction of locally agreed guidelines, 73% (486/660) met the criteria of the subsequent guidelines, 15% (97/660) did not, and 12% (77/ 660), it was impossible to judge. After the intervention, the corresponding numbers were 73% (386/530), 14% (73/53), and 13% (71/530), respectively. When decisions were made to violate guidelines, this was more likely to include tonsillectomy when not indicated - 83% (141/170) - than to refuse tonsillectomy when indicated - 17% (29/ 170) . Aspects of the guidelines that were violated in decisions to perform tonsillectomy were: the child's age was younger than the recommended guidelines - 54% (75/141)”; there were febrile attacks of tonsillitis than the recommended guidelines - 22% (32/141);" and there were "significant" symptoms not included in the guidelines - 20% (29/141). CONCLUSIONS: Despite strong evidence for that On the contrary, local guidelines were formulated at a level that the majority of surgeons have already achieved. Guideline development and implementation therefore had very little impact on clinical practice. The process of local guideline formulation was not sufficient to drive a change towards to achieve evidence-based practice"; "The clinical preference proved to be quite persistent. There is a need to improve the skills of clinicians in evaluating and interpreting research results. Previous work has emphasized the need to examine factors affecting the clinical Influencing behavior towards evidence-based practice Our study suggests that More research is needed into why clinicians continue to follow clinical preferences, even when asked to base agreed local clinical guidelines on evidence.

title: Impact of Clinical Trial Results on National Trends in O-Blocker Prescribing, 1996-2002
abstract: Context Research on factors influencing prescribing patterns and magnitude of changes induced by clinical trial results is limited. Aim To examine the changes in the prescribing of beta-blockers for the treatment of hypertension before and after the publication of the April 2000 adverse early termination of the Treatment of Hypertension and Lipid Lowering for the Prevention of Heart Attack (ALLHAT) study involving the doxazosin mesylate arm of the study. Prescribing changes were considered in the context of other potential concurrent influences on drug use between 1996 and 2002, including price changes in A-blocker drugs, switching to generics, drug advertising, and competition. Design, setting and patients Using 2 national pharmaceutical market research reports published by IMS HEALTH, a-blocker prescription orders reported in the National Prescription Audit - a random computerized sample of approximately 20,000 out of 29,000 retail, independent and mail-order pharmacies and bulk and discount retailers - and A-blocker prescription patterns by physicians in private practice reported in the National Disease and Therapeutic Index - a randomly stratified sample of approximately 3500 physician offices. Outcome Measurement Trends in physician-reported A-blocker use and in U.S. pharmacy prescribing and dispensing of A-blockers. Results From 1996 to 1999, there was a steady increase in new alpha-blocker prescriptions, prescriptions dispensed, and physician consumption of drugs. After the early demise of ALLHAT and subsequent releases in early 2000, there was a slight reversal in these trends. Between 1999 and 2002 new annual a-blocker prescription orders fell 26% (from 5.15 million to 3.79 million), prescriptions filled fell 22% (from 17.2 million to 13.4 million) and that from physicians reported drug use by 54% (from 2.26 million to 1.03 million). Other potential influences do not appear to have contributed significantly to this decline, although the cessation of marketing A-blockers may have accelerated the decline. Conclusions Moderate but statistically significant decreases in the use of doxazosin and other beta-blockers coincided with early termination of the ALLHAT doxazosin arm. Although physicians responded to these new findings, strategies to amplify the impact of clinical trials on clinical practice are warranted.

title: Effects of computer-based decision support on blood pressure management and control: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: BACKGROUND We conducted a cluster-randomized controlled trial to investigate the effectiveness of computer-assisted decision support (CDS) designed to improve hypertensive care and outcomes in a racially diverse sample of primary care patients. METHODS We randomized 2,027 adult patients receiving hypertensive treatment in 14 primary care practices either for 18 months from their physicians, who received CDS for each hypertensive patient, or to usual care without computer assistance for the control group. We assessed the prescription of guideline-recommended drug therapy and the extent of blood pressure control for patients in each group, and examined whether the effects of the intervention differed according to the race/ethnicity of the patients using interaction terms. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS Blood pressure control rates were 42% at baseline and 46% at outcome visit, with no significant differences between groups. After adjusting for patient demographics and clinical characteristics, number of previous visits, and level of baseline blood pressure control, there were no differences between the intervention groups in the likelihood of blood pressure control success. Provider use of CDS significantly improved Joint National Committee (JNC) guideline-compliant prescribing of medications compared to usual care (7% vs. 5%, P?OR] 1.39 [CI, 1.13-1 ,72]) and the effects of the intervention did not differ according to the race and ethnicity of the patients. CONCLUSIONS CDS improved the prescription of appropriate medications without improving differences in care and overall blood pressure control. Future Work is needed that focuses on improving these interventions and examining other practical interventions to reduce disparities in hypertension-related outcomes.

title: Influence of decision support in electronic health records on lipid management in primary care.
abstract: Electronic decision support tools can help improve the management of hyperlipidemia and other chronic diseases. This study examined the effects of lipid management tools integrated into an electronic medical record (EMR) in general practitioner offices. This randomized controlled trial was conducted in a national network of physicians using outpatient EMR. Adult primary care physicians were randomized from practice to receive an electronic form embedded in the EMR. The form included suboptimal care prompts based on Adult Treatment Panel-III (ATP-III) guidelines and reporting tools to identify off-office patients whose lipid management was suboptimal. All active patients aged 20 to 79 years whose physicians participated in the study were classified as high, moderate, or low cardiovascular risk, and the proportion tested for hyperlipidemia, at lipid target, and on lipid-lowering drugs when off-target were measured according to ATP III guidelines. A total of 105 physicians from 25 practices and 64,150 patients were included in the study. Outcomes improved for most measures from before to 1 year after the intervention (November 1, 2005 to October 31, 2006). However, after controlling for confounding variables and clustering in multilevel modeling, only the current lipid determination for high-risk patients in the intervention group was statistically better than in the control group (adjusted odds ratio 15.0, P?<?0.05). This study showed few differences in the quality of lipid management after implementing an EMR-based disease management intervention in primary care. Future studies may need to explore broader interventions that involve office staff in a team approach to care. (Population Health Management 2009";"12:221-226)

title: Effects of EHR-based clinical decision support on compliance for patients using NSAIDs: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: PURPOSE: Electronic health records (EHRs) with clinical decision support promise to improve quality of care, but their impact on chronic disease management has been mixed. This study evaluated the impact of EHR-based clinical decision support on adherence to guidelines to reduce gastrointestinal complications in primary care patients on nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). METHODS: This randomized controlled trial was conducted in a national network of primary care practices using an EHR and focused on patients taking traditional NSAIDs and having factors associated with a high risk of gastrointestinal complications (a history of peptic ulcer disease); concomitant use of anticoagulants, antiplatelet agents [including aspirin], or corticosteroids, or an age of 75 years or older) Offices were randomized to receive EHR-based guidelines and warnings for high-risk patients on NSAIDs or usual care was the proportion of patients who during the RESULTS: Participants included 27 practices with 119 physicians and 5,234 high-risk patients. Intervention patients were more likely than standard care patients to receive guideline-compliant care (25.4% vs. 22.4%, adjusted odds ratio = 1.19; 95% confidence interval, 1.01-1.42). In some high-risk groups, patients taking low-dose aspirin were more likely to receive guideline-compliant care compared to usual care (25.0% vs. 20.8%, adjusted odds ratio = 1.30; 95% confidence interval, 1.04-1, 62 ), but there was no significant difference for patients in other high-risk groups. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrated only a small impact of EHR-based clinical decision support for high-risk patients on NSAIDs in primary care settings. These results add to the growing literature on the complexity of EHR-based clinical decision support to improve the quality of care.

title: Influence of environmental olfactory stimuli on hand hygiene behavior in a simulated hospital setting: a randomized study
abstract: This study examined the impact of a fresh scent on the rate of hand hygiene compliance (HHC) in inexperienced healthcare providers. A total of 165 participants studied a standardized patient, with one sample exposed to fresh scent (N=79) and the other exposed to the standard environment (N=86). Hand hygiene behavior was tracked prior to patient contact using video surveillance. The standard environment group had a 51% HHC rate, while participants in the fresh scent group had a higher 80% HHC rate (P<0.001). These data show that hand hygiene behavior can be subconsciously influenced by environmental cues.

title: Impact of environmental patient education on preventive medical practices
abstract: BACKGROUND: Studies show that provider-focused reminders alone are less effective in increasing physician adherence to prevention guidelines than combinations of patient- and provider-focused physician reminders. The effectiveness of environmental patient education (ie practice-based videos, booklets and posters) without the involvement of individual staff or educators is not well documented. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of environmental patient education in increasing the amount of preventive services patients receive. METHODS: A non-randomized controlled trial with historical controls was conducted in a model primary care practice at the University of New Mexico School of Medicine in Albuquerque. The study group (n = 389) included adult women who were seen in the clinic at a time when educational materials were available in the waiting area. The control group (n = 381) consisted of similarly selected patients treated in the same period of the previous year when such materials were not available. During the procedure, patients in the waiting area were exposed to educational materials encouraging them to ask their doctors about cholesterol tests, Papanicolaou (Pap) smears, tetanus boosters, and mammograms. For both the control and study groups, physician orders for preventive services were monitored over a 4-month follow-up period by reviewing medical records. RESULTS: There were no statistically significant changes in the number of cholesterol tests, Pap smears, tetanus boosters, or mammograms ordered after the environmental patient education intervention, despite reasonable statistical power. CONCLUSIONS: Environmental patient education materials were not effective in increasing the number of preventive services performed by physicians in this study. Although such interventions are inexpensive, easily understood, and well-intentioned, they may be ineffective in increasing the performance of patient prevention services.

title: Influence of feedback and didactic sessions on the reporting behavior of upper endoscopic findings by physicians and nurses
abstract: BACKGROUND & AIMS: Guidelines for reporting Barrett's esophagus and hiatal hernia measurements and reflux esophagitis grades were developed to improve consistency, communication, and ultimately patient care. Our objectives were to assess the percentage of cases where findings were reported in accordance with the guidelines and to assess the impact of education and feedback on reporting behavior. METHODS: A prospective cross-sectional study design was used. Chart reviews were performed for all adult patients undergoing esophagogastroduodenoscopy at a tertiary care center during three 2-month periods during a 12-month interval: Timepoint 1 (March 1, 2004 – March 30, 2004 – August 31, 2004) and Time 3 (March 1, 2005-April 30, 2005). Standardized educational sessions started 2 years before time point 1. No intervention took place between time point 1 and time point 2";" Data was collected to examine secular change. Between Time 2 and Time 3, individual and group feedback and refresher sessions were given. RESULTS: Five thousand six hundred and nine appropriate esophagogastroduodenoscopies were performed, of which 2675 demonstrated Barrett's esophagus, hiatal hernia, and/or reflux esophagitis. At baseline, Barrett's esophagus and hiatal hernia measurements were correctly dictated in a median of 67% and 86% of cases, respectively, which translates to 100% (p<0.05) and 98% (p<0.01) of cases improved. The Los Angeles classification system was used in a median of 100% of cases at baseline and at follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: Anonymous individual and group feedback combined with short, structured didactic training sessions significantly improves adherence to established guidelines for reporting Barrett's esophagus and hiatal hernia. Once successfully introduced into clinical practice, compliance with the Esophagitis Los Angeles Classification System is easy to maintain.

title: Influence of information leaflets on the behavior of patients with gastroenteritis or tonsillitis: a randomized cluster study in French primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To assess the impact of four patient information leaflets on patient behavior in primary care. DESIGN: Cluster randomized multicenter controlled trial between November 2009 and January 2011. PARTICIPANTS: French adults and children who consulted a participating primary care physician and were diagnosed with gastroenteritis or tonsillitis. Patients were randomized to receive package inserts or not, according to their primary care physician's cluster randomization. INTERVENTION: Adult patients or adults accompanying a child diagnosed with gastroenteritis or tonsillitis were informed about the study. The doctors of the intervention group gave the patients an information leaflet about their condition. Two weeks after the consultation, the patients (or their companion) answered a telephone questionnaire about their behavior and knowledge about the disease. MAIN MEASURES: The main and sub-outcomes, mean behavioral and knowledge scores, respectively, were calculated from the responses to this questionnaire. RESULTS: 24 physicians enrolled 400 patients. Twelve patients were lost to follow-up (3%). In the group receiving the leaflet, patient behavior was closer to guideline recommendations than in the control group (mean behavior score 4.9 versus 4.2, p<0.01). The knowledge of the adults who received the leaflet was better than that of the control group (mean knowledge value 4.2 versus 3.6, p<0.01). There were fewer visits for the same symptoms by household members of patients given brochures (23.4% vs. 56.2%, p<0.01). CONCLUSION: Patient information leaflets distributed by the physician during the consultation significantly alter the patient's behavior and knowledge about the disease compared to patients who do not receive the leaflets for the disorders studied.

title: Impact of the introduction of rapid malaria tests on antibiotic prescribing: Analysis of observational and randomized trials in public and private health
abstract: Objectives: To study the impact of the use of rapid malaria tests on the prescribing of antimicrobials, particularly antibiotics, in acute febrile illness in Africa and Asia (randomized trials and an observational study). SettingÃ‚Â Public and Private Health Services, 2007-13, in Afghanistan, Cameroon, Ghana, Nigeria, Tanzania and Uganda. Participants 522 â‚¬â€°480 children and adults with acute febrile illness.Interventions Rapid malaria testing.Main outcome measures Proportion of patients prescribed an antibiotic in experimental groups who underwent rapid testing compared to controls and in patients with negative test results compared to patients with positive results. A second objective was to compare classes of antibiotics prescribed in different settings. Results Antibiotics were prescribed to 127,052/238,797 (53%) patients in control groups and 167 patients to 714/283,683 (59%) patients in intervention groups. Antibiotics were prescribed to 40% (35,505/89,719) of patients with a positive malaria test result and 69% (39,400) of patients /57â‚¬â€°080) of those with a negative result. All but one study showed a trend towards more antibiotic prescriptions in groups undergoing rapid diagnostic tests. Meta-analysis of random effects of the studies showed that the overall risk of antibiotic prescription in interventional settings was 21% higher (95% confidence interval 7% to 36%). In most intervention settings, patients with negative test results received more antibiotic prescriptions than patients with positive results for all of the most commonly used classes: penicillins, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (one exception), tetracyclines, and metronidazole. Conclusions: Introduction of rapid diagnostic tests for malaria to reduce the unnecessary use of antimalarial drugs - a positive public health outcome - could drive the indiscriminate use of antibiotics. That 69% of patients were prescribed antibiotics despite testing negative is likely to represent overprescribing. This included antibiotics from multiple classes, including those such as metronidazole, which are rarely appropriate for febrile illness, in diverse clinical, healthcare system, and epidemiological settings . It is often assumed that better disease-specific diagnostics will reduce antimicrobial overuse, but they may simply shift it from one antimicrobial class to another. The current global rollout of malaria testing could increase the indiscriminate use of antibiotics and needs to be reviewed.

title: Impact of Mediterranean diet education versus published booklets on dietary habits and serum cholesterol in a high-risk population for cardiovascular disease
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To investigate the effects of intensive group training on the Mediterranean diet on food intake and serum total cholesterol at 16 and 52 weeks in comparison to a posted brochure with the Dutch dietary guidelines in the context of primary prevention of cardiovascular diseases (CVD). DESIGN: Controlled comparative study of an intervention group with intensive group training about the Mediterranean diet and a control group of people with hypercholesterolemia under usual care by general practitioners (GPs). SETTING: A socioeconomically disadvantaged area in the Netherlands with an increased mortality rate from coronary heart disease (CHD). PARTICIPANTS: Two hundred and sixty-six hypercholesterolemic subjects with at least two other CVD risk factors. RESULTS: At 52 weeks, the intervention group decreased total fat and saturated fat intake more than the control group (net differences were 1.8 en% (95% CI 0.2-3.4) and 1.1 en% (95% CI 0.4–1.9) respectively). According to the Mediterranean dietary guidelines, consumption of fish, fruit, poultry and bread increased more in the intervention group than in the control group. Within the intervention group, the consumption of fish (+100%), poultry (+28%) and bread (+6%) was significantly increased after 1 year (P<0.05). The intensive nutrition education program did not reduce serum cholesterol significantly more (-3%) than the package insert (-2%) (net difference 0.06 mmol l-1, 95% CI -0.10 to 0.22). Initially, the body mass index (BMI) decreased more in the intervention group, but after 1 year both the intervention and control groups increased equally (+1%). CONCLUSIONS: Despite positive changes in dietary habits in the intervention group compared to the control group, BMI increased at 1 year and total fat and saturated fat intake was still excessive.

title: Impact of alarms on uninterrupted medication monitoring in ambulatory care.
abstract: Objective: Disruptive alarms in electronic applications can cause “alarm fatigue” if they are triggered too frequently or are only sometimes clinically useful. We evaluated the impact of uninterrupted, real-time medication lab alerts on vendor lab test ordering. DESIGN: We included 22 outpatient practices in a prospective, randomized, controlled study. Clinics either used the existing system or received on-screen recommendations for basic laboratory tests when prescribing new drugs. Because the alerts were non-disruptive, providers did not have to respond to the notification or acknowledge the notification to complete a medication request. Measurements: Data was collected each time providers performed proposed laboratory tests within 14 days of a new prescription order. The results were adjusted for patient and service provider characteristics as well as patient clusters within hospitals. RESULTS: Among 12 clinics with 191 providers in the control group and 10 clinics with 175 providers in the intervention group, there were a total of 3673 events for which basic laboratory testing would have been recommended: 1988 events in the control group and 1685 in the intervention group. In the control group, source laboratories were requested for 771 (39%) of the drugs. In the intervention group, baseline labs were ordered by clinicians in 689 (41%) cases. Overall, there was no significant association between the intervention and the rate of ordering appropriate baseline laboratory tests. Conclusion: We found that non-interruptive drug laboratory monitoring alerts were not effective in improving compliance with recommended baseline monitoring of drug laboratory tests. More work is needed to improve compliance with non-critical recommendations.

title: Effects of dual pharmacist-physician intervention on prescribed benzodiazepines in prisoners: a retrospective study
abstract: High-dose benzodiazepines (BDZs) represent an important risk factor for addiction, particularly in the prison setting. In Lyon prison, patients with mental disorders are often prescribed BDZs and/or maintenance opioids. The aim of this retrospective study was to evaluate the impact of psychiatrist-pharmacist collaboration on reducing the dose of BDZ prescribed to prison patients. Since 2001, clinicians and pharmacists have held monthly meetings to develop prescribing guidelines and discuss patients receiving high-dose BDZ. All psychotropic drugs prescribed were noted for each enrolled patient in the control (before guidelines) and intervention groups. The criteria used to define each patient profile included age, diagnosis (mental disorder), and concomitant treatment (opioids, antidepressants). To compare each group, the daily dose of the prescribed BDZs was used as a quantitative variable and expressed in diazepam equivalents. Four hundred and seventy-three patients were included, 222 in the control group and 251 in the intervention group. The two groups showed no difference in terms of diagnosis. The daily dose of BDZ was higher in the control group when all patients were considered (mean (CONTROL GROUP) = 46 mg in diazepam equivalent vs. mean (INTERVENTION GROUP) = 34 mg) and for each of the following patient categories: "mental disorder" (48 mg vs. 30 mg), "no treatment with opioids" (44 mg vs. 31 mg), "treatment with buprenorphine" (58 mg vs. 63 mg), "no treatment with antidepressants" (41 mg vs. 29 mg) and “antidepressant treatment” (53 mg vs. 38 mg). The results of this retrospective study demonstrate the beneficial effects of a multidisciplinary intervention in reducing the daily dose of BDZs prescribed. This experience confirms the positive impact that pharmacist feedback on prescribing and the development of treatment guidelines through collaboration between clinicians and pharmacists has on improving prescribing practice in a prison setting.

title: Effects of asthma care physician education on patient outcomes
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We evaluated the effectiveness of a continuing medical education program, Physician Asthma Care Education, in improving the asthma therapeutic and communication skills of pediatricians and the utilization of medical care by asthma patients. METHODS: We conducted a randomized study in 10 regions in the United States. Primary providers were recruited and randomly assigned by location to receive the program provided by local faculty. The program included two interactive seminar sessions (2.5 hours each) that reviewed national asthma guidelines, communication skills and key educational messages. The format included short lectures, case discussions and a video on modeling communication techniques. We collected information about parents' perceptions of doctor communication, the child's asthma symptoms, and patients' utilization of asthma health care. We used multivariate regression models to determine differences between control and intervention groups. RESULTS: A total of 101 general practitioners and a random sample of 870 of their asthma patients participated. After 1 year, we conducted telephone follow-up interviews with the parents of 731 of the 870 patients. Compared to controls, parents reported that physicians in the intervention group were more likely to inquire about patients' concerns about asthma, encourage patients to be physically active, and set goals for successful treatment. Patients from physicians who participated in the program had greater reductions in asthma symptom-limited days (8.5 vs. 15.6 days) as well as fewer asthma emergency room visits (0.30 vs. 0.55 visits per year ). CONCLUSIONS: The asthma care physician training program was used in a number of locations and was effective in improving the communication skills of parent-reported providers, the number of days affected by asthma symptoms, and asthma health care utilization. Patients with more frequent asthma symptoms and higher health care utilization at baseline were more likely to benefit from their physician's participation in the program.

title: Effects of regular collaboration between infectious disease and critical care physicians on antimicrobial use and patient outcome
abstract: AIM: Antimicrobial stewardship programs have been shown to help reduce the use of unnecessary antimicrobials in hospital settings. So far, there is very little data that focuses on high-traffic areas such as the medical intensive care unit. A prospective intervention was conducted to assess guideline adherence, antimicrobial spending, and healthcare costs when an infectious disease worker regularly interacts with the ICU medical team. DESIGN: A 3-month retrospective chart review was followed by a 3-month prospective intervention the following year. A total of 246 charts were reviewed to assess generally accepted compliance, demographics, and microbiological results. SETTING: 24-bed medical intensive care unit at an 861-bed tertiary care teaching hospital in North Carolina. SUBJECTS: Patients receiving antibiotics in the medical intensive care unit. INTERVENTION: During the intervention period, the infectious disease colleague reviewed the spreadsheets, including physician notes and microbiological data, and discussed antimicrobial use with the ICU medical team. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Antimicrobial use, duration of treatment, acute physiology and chronic health assessment II scores, length of stay, days on mechanical ventilation, and mortality rates were compared during the two periods. RESULTS: No statistically significant differences were found in the two groups at baseline (ie, age, gender, race, or acute physiology and chronic health assessment II scores). Indications for antibiotics included hospital-acquired (53%) and community-acquired pneumonia (17%). Significant reductions were observed in extended-spectrum penicillins (p=0.0080), carbapenems (p=0.0013), vancomycin (p=0.0040), and metronidazole (p=0.0004) after the intervention. Antimicrobial modification resulted in an increase in narrow-spectrum penicillins (p=0.0322). The intervention group had a significantly lower rate of non-guideline-compliant treatments (p < 0.0001). There was a reduction in days on ventilation (p=0.0053), length of stay (p=0.0188), and in-hospital mortality (p=0.0367). The annual calculated healthcare savings were $89,944 just from stopping antibiotics early. CONCLUSION: Active communication with an infectious disease physician can significantly reduce antibiotic overuse in the ICU through earlier modification or cessation of antibiotics without increasing mortality. This, in turn, can reduce healthcare costs, promote excellence in education, and strengthen subspecialty relationships.

title: Impact of the WHO depression guideline on patient care by psychiatrists: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Scientific literature reviews aim to summarize the state of knowledge and published empirical evidence. In contrast, medical guidelines are intervention tools aimed at improving physician behavior and patient outcome. They can have positive as well as negative effects. Their effectiveness needs to be verified through research. Methods: In a randomized controlled study, 103 psychiatrists in private practice were either only provided with the WHO guidelines for depression (information group) or provided with the WHO guidelines for depression and trained in these guidelines for one day (intervention group) or left uninformed (control group). They then treated a total of 497 patients based on individual clinical considerations and patient needs. Observation of routine treatment lasted 12 weeks. Physicians and patients documented the course of the disease and treatment, including the doctor-patient interaction. RESULTS: Psychiatrists in the intervention group saw more psychosocial stressors in their patients, prescribed higher doses of medication, had fewer dropouts, and rated treatment outcome as better. Ratings of patient-physician interactions revealed greater strain in their relationships. CONCLUSIONS: The results show both positive and negative effects of guideline exposure, but only in the training group and not in the information group. Guidelines should be empirically tested before they are labeled “evidence-based”. Each policy should also set out how it can or must be implemented in order to be effective.

title: Impaired self-esteem after moderate to severe traumatic brain injury
abstract: Patients with moderate to severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) may experience self-esteem issues several months or years after the injury. Patients may underestimate cognitive and behavioral difficulties that are the true remnants of their brain injury. Research increasingly indicates that the remnants of these disorders of consciousness strongly influence the course and outcome of rehabilitation. A current model for conceptualizing disturbances in self-awareness after different forms of brain injury is reviewed.

title: Implementation and roll-out of nationwide electronic health records in secondary care in England: Final qualitative results of a prospective national assessment in early adopter hospitals
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess the implementation and roll-out of the NHS Detailed Care Records service in early adopter hospitals in England. DESIGN Theoretically sound, qualitative longitudinal assessment based on case studies. SETTING 12 early adopter NHS acute hospitals and specialist care facilities studied over two and a half years. DATA SOURCES Data was collected through in-depth interviews, observations and relevant documents that directly related to case study sites and broader national developments that were believed to impact the implementation strategy. The data were analyzed thematically, first within and then across cases. The dataset consisted of 431 semi-structured interviews with key stakeholders including hospital staff, developers and government officials, 590 hours of observing strategic meetings and use of the software in context, 334 notes from observations, field notes from researchers and notes from national conferences, 809 NHS documents and 58 regional and national documents RESULTS Implementation was slower, with a narrower scope and much less clinical functionality than originally planned The national strategy had a significant local impact (grouped under five main themes) of care and end-user needs for training and support . Other factors hampering progress have been the changing milieu of NHS policy and priorities, constantly renegotiated national contracts, the varying stages of development of different NHS care record service systems; ' and a complex process of communication between different stakeholders, together with contractual arrangements that largely excluded NHS providers. There was early evidence that the use of systems led to important learning within and between organizations and the development of relevant skills within NHS hospitals. CONCLUSIONS Implementing the NHS Care Records Service in early adopter locations proved time consuming and challenging , with as yet limited discernible benefits for clinicians and no clear benefits for patients. Although our results may not be directly transferrable, as the functionalities we evaluated were new and untried in the English context, they shed light on the processes involved with implementation of new systems and sheds light on the processes involved in the implementation of important new systems is welcomed by the NHS, but it is important that the policy does not lose sight of the overall objective of an integrated interoperable solution.

title: Implementation and success of nurse telephone counseling in linguistically isolated Korean-American patients with hypertension
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Telephone counseling by nurses can improve management of chronic illness, but the effectiveness of this approach in underserved populations is unclear. This study evaluated the use of bilingual telephone counseling by nurses among Korean-Americans (KAs) participating in a community-based intervention study to improve hypertension management. METHODS: KAs were randomized to receive more intensive (biweekly) or less intensive (monthly) hypertension telephone consultations for 12 months. Counseling protocols were maintained for 360 PRs who completed the pre- and post-intervention evaluations. RESULTS: The overall success rate for the intervention was 80.3%. The level of success was significantly influenced by the dose of counseling, employment status, and years of US residency. Over the 12-month counseling period, both groups showed improvements in medication intake, alcohol consumption, and exercise, but no smoking, with no significant group differences. CONCLUSION: Bilingual telephone counseling could reach monolingual KAs and improve their behavior in dealing with hypertension. PRACTICAL IMPLICATIONS: Bilingual telephone nursing advice can have broad applicability and serve as an effective means of disseminating evidence-based guidance on managing chronic illness in a linguistically isolated community with limited health resources and information.

title: Trajectories to implementation fidelity of a health promotion program in multidisciplinary settings: managing tension in rehabilitation care
abstract: Background Although the importance of assessing implementation fidelity is recognized, little is known about the heterogeneity of fidelity over time. The aim of this study is to gain insights into the heterogeneity of trajectories of compliance of a health promotion program in multidisciplinary settings and the relationship to changes in patient health behaviors. Methods This study used longitudinal data from the nationwide implementation of an evidence-based physical activity promotion program in Dutch rehabilitation care.
