Loyalty scores were calculated based on annual surveys completed by participating professionals (n?=?Â¡Ã€?70). Higher precision values indicate a more complete implementation of the program's core components. A hierarchical cluster analysis was performed on the implementation fidelity scores of 17 organizations at three different time points. Quantitative and qualitative data were used to examine organizational and professional differences between the identified careers. Regression analyzes were performed to determine differences in patient outcomes. Results Three trajectories were identified as follows: "Stable High Fidelity" (n?=?9), "Moderate and Improving Fidelity" (n?=?6), and " unstable fidelity (n?=?2). The stable, high-fidelity organizations were generally smaller, started earlier, and implemented the program in a more structured way compared to moderate and improving fidelity organizations. At the beginning and end of the implementation phase, physician and physical therapist support, professional esteem, and program compatibility were rated more positively by professionals working in stable, high-fidelity organizations than in organizations with moderate and improving fidelity (S ?< ?.05). Qualitative data showed that the stable, high-fidelity organizations often had a clear vision and strategy for program implementation. Interestingly, the trajectories were not associated with the patients' self-reported physical activity scores (fitted model Â¦Ã‚?=???651.6, t(613)?=???1032, p?=?.303) . Conclusions Differences in the trajectories of implementation fidelity at the organizational level did not lead to differences in outcomes at the patient level. This suggests that effective implementation fidelity depends on local organization conditions. More specifically, achieving stable and high implementation fidelity required managing tensions: realizing a localized vision for change while protecting the standardized core components of the program and involving the scarce physicians throughout the process. In expanding evidence-based health promotion programs, we propose to adapt the management of implementation tensions to the starting position, size, and circumstances of local organizations.

title: The implementation of a new guideline leads to a decrease in pressure ulcer incidence
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the impact of a new guideline on the efficiency of pressure ulcer treatment. DESIGN: Series of one-day pre- and post-implementation pressure ulcer surveys. SETTING: A 900-bed university hospital in the Netherlands. PARTICIPANTS: On the survey days, 657 patients were enrolled before implementation, 735 patients 4 months after implementation, and 755 patients 11 months after implementation. INTERVENTION: Implementation of a hospital guideline for decubitus care combined with the introduction of viscoelastic foam mattresses for the efficiency of the prevention and treatment of decubitus. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Comparisons were made before and after implementation regarding nursing behaviors of nurses and frequency of pressure ulcer patients. RESULTS: Inadequate prevention decreased from 19 to 4% at 4 months and 6% at 11 months (p<0.001), and inadequate treatment decreased from 60 to 31% (p=0.005). Apart from the use of mattresses as a positive indicator of nursing behavior, we found no significant increase in adequate nursing care for pressure ulcer prevention. Even with adequate treatment activities, we found no significant difference. Overall, we found a significant decrease in the incidence of hospital-acquired pressure ulcers from 18 to 13% (p=0.003) at 4 months and 11% (p<0.001) at 11 months. CONCLUSION: The number of pressure ulcer patients in the hospital can be successfully reduced. General measures such as the introduction of adequate mattresses and guidelines for prevention and treatment are promising tools in this regard.

title: Implementing an Effective Intervention for High-Risk Women in Mexico: Protocol for a Multisite Randomized Trial with a Parallel Study on Organizational Factors
abstract: Background Studies on the implementation of effective human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) prevention interventions are rare, particularly in resource-constrained settings, but are important because they have the potential to increase the impact of interventions by improving acceptability and sustainability. Few studies have focused on provider and organizational factors that may affect uptake and adherence to core intervention components. Using a hybrid design, we will examine the implementation of an effective intervention to reduce sexually transmitted infections (STIs) among female sex workers (FSWs) in 12 cities across Mexico. Our protocol will test a ¡Â®train-the-trainer¡¯ implementation model to transport Mujer Segura (Healthy Woman) intervention to community-based organizations (CBOs). Methods We partnered with the Mexican Foundation for Family Planning (Mexfam), an NGO that has CBOs across Mexico. At each CBO, trained ethnographers interview CBO staff about characteristics of their organization and their attitudes towards their CBO and implementation of Evidence-Based Interventions (EBIs). After CBO staff recruits a sample of 80 eligible FSWs and 40 women randomly selected from this pool perform standard didactic treatment, a Mexfam staff member is trained in Mujer Segura's intervention and then trains other counselors on the Perform Mujer Segura to the remaining 40 participating FSWs. FSW participants receive a baseline behavioral assessment and are tested for HIV and STDs (syphilis, gonorrhea, and chlamydia).";" They will be reassessed six months after the intervention to measure possible intervention effects. At the same time, both qualitative and quantitative data on the implementation process will be collected, including measures on the advisors' loyalty to the intervention model. After data collection is completed at each CBO, the relative effectiveness of the Mujer Segura intervention will be analyzed and, across CBOs, correlations between individual and organizational provider characteristics and intervention effectiveness will be examined. Discussion This collaborative, binational research study will provide important insights into barriers and facilitating factors associated with implementing interventions in CBOs using the ¡Â®train-the-trainer¡Â¯ model. Our work builds on similar scale-up strategies that have been successful in the United States. This study has the potential to advance our knowledge of the generalizability of such strategies across health issues, national contexts, and organizational contexts.

title: Implementation of clinical guidelines through an electronic medical record: physician use, satisfaction and assessment
abstract: CONTEXT: We developed and evaluated the Emergency Department Expert Charting System (EDECS) to provide real-time guidance on the management of low back pain in adults, fever in children, and occupational exposure to blood and body fluids in healthcare workers by embedding clinical guidelines within an electronic patient record. OBJECTIVE: To describe the behaviors and attitudes of physicians who have used EDECS. DESIGN: Pre-post questionnaires were used to assess physicians' attitudes. Intervention phase time studies were observational studies using clocks embedded in the software. PARTICIPANTS: One hundred and forty-two residents and residents in emergency, pediatric, internal and family medicine and patients with the above conditions. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: Physician's use of EDECS, time spent with EDECS, physician satisfaction, and beliefs. RESULTS: 84% of the 142 licensed physicians used EDECS at least once. 591 of 789 (75%) eligible cases were closed with EDECS. Mean session time decreased from 12 minutes for session 1 to 5.5 minutes for sessions 16 and above. Physicians generally agreed that EDECS care was better than standard care, particularly with regard to documentation. There was, however, considerable heterogeneity in belief among the complaints. CONCLUSIONS: These data shed light on both the potential of computer-assisted decision-making and the need for context-specific approaches when trying to implement policy.

title: Implementation of clinical practice guidelines for the prevention of thromboembolism in spinal cord injury.
abstract: Background/aims: The aim of this study was to determine whether the publication of the clinical practice guideline (CPG) "Prevention of thromboembolism in spinal cord injury" has changed patient management and whether adherence to the CPG recommendations has improved following a targeted implementation strategy. METHODS: Data were collected from medical records of 134 and 520 patients with acute and chronic spinal cord injury (SCI), respectively, from 6 Veterans Affairs Medical Centers over 3 time periods: pre-release (T1), pre-implementation (T2), and post-implementation (T3) of the CPG. Targeted interventions were designed to address provider-perceived barriers to compliance based on the outcomes of the focus groups conducted at each site. The interventions included two implementation strategies: standardized documentation templates/standing orders and social marketing/outreach visits. Results: The use of the indicated duration for pharmacological prophylaxis increased from 60% to 65% to 75% of patients with acute SCI at T1, T2 and T3, respectively (p = 0.060 and 0.041 for T1 vs. T2 and T2 vs. T3, respectively) . ). Usage rates for individual prophylactic pharmacological agents changed significantly over the course of the study, with use of low molecular weight heparin increasing from 7% in T1 to 42% in T3. Physical examinations for thrombosis on hospital days 1 and 30 improved between T2 and T3. Use of prophylaxis in chronically injured patients with new risk factors for thromboembolism increased from 16% to 31% to 34% during T1, T2, and T3 (p=0.001 and 0.87, respectively). Conclusions: The publication of the guideline had only a modest impact on practice. The use of a structured implementation further increased compliance with some CPG recommendations for thromboembolism prophylaxis. Similar implementation strategies should be considered for CPG recommendations with low adherence and high morbidity and mortality potential.

title: Conducting Diagnosis in Asymptomatic Patients with Aortic Stenosis: Conducting Diagnosis in Asymptomatic Patients with Aortic Stenosis registry
abstract: In clinical practice, some physicians often refer patients with aortic stenosis for an invasive approach in the asymptomatic phase of the disease. This empirical behavior, contrary to the recommendations of the current international clinical guidelines, is based on the perception that the prognosis of these patients is actually worse than assumed. Indeed, the treatment of asymptomatic patients with aortic stenosis remains controversial and there is no clear consensus on how to reduce excessive clinical events associated with the presence of aortic stenosis mortality and morbidity demonstrated in recent randomized clinical trials in these patients. The prevailing attention of the attending physicians is often limited to assessing the severity of aortic stenosis and the occurrence of symptoms, but it has become clear that the prognosis of these patients is accompanied by excessive left ventricular mass growth and increased atherosclerosis, which leads to coronary artery disease, heart failure , stroke and death. Therefore, in addition to the markers of faster aortic stenosis progression, many other clinical and echocardiographic variables should be considered, collected and used together with the clinical/echocardiographic prognostic scores recently validated by several authors in clinical practice, where the vast majority of these variables reside culpably not considered. The registry for performing the diagnosis in asymptomatic patients with aortic stenosis is a prospective study with the aim of improving the diagnostic work-up and prognostic stratification of patients with asymptomatic aortic stenosis.

title: Implementation of evidence-based rehabilitation for non-specific back pain and frequent psychological problems: A process evaluation of a nationwide initiative
abstract: BACKGROUND: The nationwide implementation of guaranteed access to evidence-based rehabilitation was introduced in Sweden in 2009 by a Swedish government law. The primary goal of the rehabilitation guarantee was to increase the reintegration rate, reduce and prevent long-term absences after diagnoses related to back pain and common mental health problems. The aim of this study is to develop knowledge about factors influencing the large-scale implementation of complex and large-scale healthcare interventions. METHODS: Three different data sources questionnaires, interviews and documents were used in data collection and analysis. The data were analyzed using iterative thematic analysis. RESULTS: The following main sponsors contributed to the realization of the Rehabilitation Guarantee: financial incentives, building a project organization, recruitment, in-service training and previous experience of working in similar projects. Obstacles were: the short-term project form of the rehabilitation guarantee, the attitude and competence of the clinicians when working on the return to work, the lack of guidelines describing treatment modalities in multimodal rehabilitation, and the lack of clearly defined criteria for patient admission. Documents showed that the goal of returning to work was less pronounced during the implementation process. Instead, care and health were more often described in documents used to disseminate information about the Rehabilitation Guarantee. As interim results, a more adequate priority of patients with rehabilitation needs, an increased willingness for future implementation efforts as well as an increased general competence in psychotherapy and teamwork were determined, which were thus also available to other patient groups than those covered by the rehabilitation guarantee. CONCLUSIONS: To facilitate the implementation of established national policy goals in clinical practice, tools specifically aimed at changing clinician attitudes and behaviors towards such goals are needed. Our results underline the importance of investing both time and sufficient resources in the activities and supporting the implementation process.

title: Implementation of evidence-based treatment protocols for treating fever, hyperglycemia, and dysphagia in acute stroke (QASC): a randomized, controlled cluster study
abstract: BackgroundWe evaluated patient outcomes 90 days after stroke hospitalization after a multidisciplinary intervention aimed at evidence-based treatment of fever, hyperglycemia, and dysphagia in acute stroke units (ASUs). Background We evaluated patient outcomes 90 days after stroke hospitalization following a multidisciplinary intervention aimed at providing evidence-based treatment for fever, hyperglycemia, and dysphagia in acute stroke units (ASUs).

title: Implementation of the Spanish adaptation of the European guidelines for the prevention of cardiovascular diseases in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Successful implementation of cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention guidelines is highly dependent on primary care physicians (PCPs) providing risk factor assessment, intervention, and patient education. The aim of this study was to determine the level of awareness and the implementation of the Spanish adaptation of the European guidelines for CVD prevention in clinical practice (CEIPC guidelines) among general practitioners. METHODS: A cross-sectional survey of primary care physicians was conducted in Spain between January and June 2011. A random sample of 1,390 general practitioners was obtained and stratified by region. The data was collected by means of a self-fillable questionnaire. RESULTS: More than half (58%) of the physicians were aware and aware of the recommendations, and 62% of physicians reported using them in clinical practice, although general practitioners (non-specialist doctors) did so less often than primary care physicians. Most general practitioners (60%) did not assess cardiovascular risk, with the limited time available for surgery being cited as the main barrier by 81%. The main reason for skepticism about recommendations, given by 71% of physicians, was that there are too many guidelines. Nearly half of the physicians cited a lack of training and skills as the top barrier to implementing lifestyle and behavior change recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: Most general practitioners were aware of the Spanish adaptation of the European guidelines for the prevention of cardiovascular diseases (CEIPC guidelines) and knew their content. However, only a third of GPs used the guidelines in clinical practice and less than half used the cardiovascular disease risk assessment tools.

title: Implementing the NHLBI Integrated Guidelines for Cardiovascular Health and Risk Reduction in Children and Adolescents: Rationale and Study Design for Young Hearts, Strong Starts, a Cluster-randomized Study Targeting Body Mass Index, Blood Pressure, and Tobacco
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) and the underlying atherosclerosis have an onset in childhood, and their presence and intensity are associated with known risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Attention to controlling risk factors in childhood has the potential to reduce later risk of cardiovascular disease. OBJECTIVE: The Young Hearts Strong Starts study was designed to test strategies that facilitate adoption of the National, Heart, Lung and Blood Institute-supported Integrated Guidelines for cardiovascular health and risk reduction in children and adolescents. This study compares guideline-based quality measures for body mass index, blood pressure, and tobacco using two strategies: a multifaceted, practice-oriented intervention versus standard delivery. STUDY DESIGN: Two primary care research networks recruited practices and provided support for the intervention and outcome assessments. Individual practices were randomly assigned to the intervention or control groups using a cluster-randomized design based on network affiliation, number of clinicians per practice, urban versus non-urban location, and practice type. The observation units are individual children, since compliance with the measure is abstracted from the medical records of the individual patients. The units of randomization are medical practices. This leads to a tiered design where patients are nested within practices. The intervention practices received toolkits and supported the implementation of guidelines, including academic detailing, an ongoing e-learning group. This project addresses the American Board of Pediatrics' requirements for maintaining certification, including monthly self-statements for physicians, webinars, and other elements of the study. INTEREST: This study offers an opportunity to demonstrate tools and strategies to improve CV prevention in children through guideline-based interventions.

title: Implementation of the tobacco tactics intervention compared to usual care in Trinity Health community hospitals
abstract: BACKGROUND: Guided by the RE-AIM (Reach, Effectiveness, Adoption, Implementation, and Maintenance) implementation framework, a study sponsored by the National Institutes of Health compared nurse-administered tobacco tactics intervention to usual care. A previous paper describes the effectiveness of tobacco tactics intervention. This subsequent paper contains data describing the remaining constructs of the RE-AIM framework. METHODS: This pragmatic study used a mixed-method, quasi-experimental design in five Michigan community hospitals, three of which received the tobacco tactics intervention administered by nurses and two received usual care. Nurses and patients were interviewed before and after the intervention. Measures included outreach (patient participation rates, characteristics and utilization of services), acceptance (participation rates and characteristics of nurses), implementation (changes in nurse attitudes before and after training, service delivery, barriers to implementation, opinions on training ). , documentation of achievements and number of follow-up phone calls from volunteers) and maintenance (continuation of the intervention after the end of the study). RESULTS: Reach: Patient participation rates were 71.5%. There were significant increases in self-reported receipt of printed materials at the intervention hospitals before and after the intervention compared to unmodified controls (n=1370, p<0.001). Adoption: In the intervention hospitals, all targeted units and several non-targeted units participated";" 76.0% (n=1028) of the targeted nurses and 317 support staff participated in the training, and 92.4% were extremely or fairly satisfied with the training. EXECUTION: Nurses at the intervention hospitals reported an increase in the provision of cessation advice, counseling, medication, handouts, and DVD (all p<0.05) and reported fewer barriers to implementing smoking cessation services (p<0.001). Qualitative comments were very positive ('user-friendly', 'streamlined' or 'saves time'), although problems were noted with showing the DVD and recording it in the electronic medical record for patients. Maintenance: Nurses continued to perform the intervention after the study ended. CONCLUSIONS: Given that nurses represent the largest group of first responders, this intervention, which conforms to the Joint Commission's guidelines for the treatment of inpatient smokers, has the potential to have a large impact on smoking, morbidity, and mortality among inpatient smokers. As we move towards more population-based interventions, the RE-AIM framework is a valuable guide for implementation. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT01309217.

title: IMPLEmenting a Clinical Practice Guideline for Acute Low Back Pain Evidence-Based Management in General Practice (IMPLEMENT): Cluster-randomisierte kontrollierte Studie Studienprotokoll
abstract: BACKGROUND: Evidence from reliable research is not often translated into clinical practice. Evidence-based clinical practice guidelines are a potential means of achieving this. A recent systematic review of guideline dissemination implementation strategies concluded that there is a lack of evidence on effective strategies to promote guideline adoption. Recommendations from this review and other studies have suggested the use of theory-based interventions as they may be more effective than those that are not. Evidence-based clinical practice guideline for the management of acute low back pain was recently developed in Australia. This provides an opportunity to design and test a theory-based implementation intervention for a condition that is common, has a high burden, and for which there is an evidence-practice gap in primary care. AIM: This study aims to test the effectiveness of a theory-based intervention to implement a clinical practice guideline for acute low back pain in general practice in Victoria, Australia. Specifically, our primary goal is to determine whether the intervention is effective in reducing the percentage of patients who are referred for a plain radiograph and improving the patients' mean degree of disability three months after the consultation. METHODS/DESIGN: This study protocol describes the details of a randomized, controlled cluster study. 92 general practices (clusters) to which at least one consenting general practitioner belongs are assigned to an intervention or control arm by means of limited randomization. Patients 18 years and older who see a participating physician for acute non-specific back pain lasting less than three months are eligible for inclusion. An average of 25 patients are recruited per GP practice, resulting in a total of 2,300 patient participants. General practitioners in the control arm have access to the guideline via the existing dissemination strategy. Practitioners in the intervention arm will be invited to participate in facilitated face-to-face workshops that have been underpinned by behavioral theory. Investigators (not involved in delivering the intervention), patients, outcome evaluators, and the study statistician will be blinded to group assignment.

title: Implementation of a guideline for the treatment of type 2 diabetics: Results of a cluster-randomized controlled trial (C-RCT)
abstract: BACKGROUND: In Italy, many diabetics still lack adequate care in the general practitioner's office. We evaluated the effectiveness of different strategies to implement an evidence-based guideline for the management of uncomplicated type 2 diabetes among general practitioners (GPs) of the Lazio region. Methods: Three-arm cluster-randomized controlled trial with GPs as randomization units (clusters). 252 general practitioners were randomized to either an active strategy (educational module with guideline), passive dissemination (guideline only), or usual care (control). Data on test and drug prescriptions were collected from existing information systems, while patient data came from GP databases. Process outcomes were measured at cluster level one year after the intervention. The primary outcomes involved measuring glycated hemoglobin and commissioning tests to assess micro- and macrovascular complications. Secondary endpoints were also calculated to assess physician prescribing behavior. RESULTS: Primary care physicians identified 6395 uncomplicated type 2 patients with a high prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors. GP baseline performance data shows low levels of glycosylated hemoglobin in the assessment. The results of the C-RCT analysis show that the active implementation strategy was ineffective for all primary endpoints (OR 1.06 [95% IC: 0.76-1.46], OR 1.07 [95% IC: 0.80–1.43], “OR.” 1.4 [95% IC:0.91–2.16] Passive dissemination of the guideline also showed no effect not improved by a structured learning program, the implementation through organizational measures seems indispensable induce behavioral changes STUDY REGISTRATION: ISRCTN80116232.

title: Implementing a Mixed Public-Private Model for Tuberculosis Treatment in Urban Pakistan: Lessons and Experiences
abstract: SETTING: Six cities in Karachi, Pakistan. OBJECTIVES: 1) Strengthen the capacity of general practitioners (GPs) in delivering tuberculosis (TB) treatment through DOTS” and 2) improve collaboration between the public and private sectors on TB management and case reporting. DESIGN: A quasi-experimental study design was chosen to ensure enrollment of TB patients by trained primary care physicians with support from laboratory networks and to improve case detection rate. RESULTS: The following challenges were encountered when implementing the model in urban settings: It was not systematic List of general practitioners available ; the majority of GPs were untrained naturopaths working in squatter settlements where formally trained GPs are most needed; motivation of GPs with high patient burden is very low;" and access to a laboratory is difficult. Of 35 patients admitted in Q1 (Q3 2009), 87% successfully completed their treatment. CONCLUSION: Public-Private -Mix (PPM) DOTS is feasible in the cities of Pakistan, however, the cost, time and labor required to set up the program is higher than many other developing countries.

title: Implementing academic detail for breast cancer screening in underserved communities
abstract: BACKGROUND: Black and Hispanic women living in the New York boroughs of North Manhattan and South Bronx are generally underserved for breast cancer prevention and screening, although they are more likely to die from breast cancer than other women. Primary care physicians (PCPs) are critical in recommending breast cancer screening to their patients. Academic detailing is a promising strategy to improve PCP performance in recommending breast cancer screening, however little is known about the impact of academic detailing on breast cancer screening among physicians practicing in medically underserved areas. We evaluated the effectiveness of an improved, multicomponent academic intervention to increase referrals for breast cancer screening within a sample of community-based city physicians. METHODS: Two medically underserved communities were matched and randomized to intervention and control arms. Ninety-four general practitioners (ie, non-hospital-based) primary care physicians in northern Manhattan were compared with 74 physicians in the South Bronx boroughs of the New York City metropolitan area. Intervention participants received enhanced, physician-led academic detailing using American Cancer Society guidelines for breast cancer screening. The physicians in the control group received no intervention. We conducted interviews to measure primary care physicians' self-reported referrals for mammography and clinical breast examination (CBE) and to determine whether primary care physicians taught women how to perform breast self-examination (BSE). RESULTS: Using multivariate analyses, we found a statistically significant intervention effect on the recommendation of CBE for patients aged 40 years and older";" Mammography and breast self-examination reports increased in both arms from baseline to follow-up, according to physician self-report. Post-test, physician involvement in additional educational programs, improved self-efficacy in counseling for prevention, routine use of chart reminders, computer-based rather than paper-based prompting and follow-up approaches, printed patient educational materials, mammography performance goals, and increased involvement of nurses and other office staff were associated with increased screening. CONCLUSION: We found some evidence of improvement in breast cancer screening practices due to improved academic detail among primary care physicians practicing in urban underserved communities.

title: Implementing the best evidence in smoking cessation treatment for hospitalized veterans: results of the VA-BEST study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although the US Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) has encouraged compliance with smoking cessation guidelines since 1997, in-hospital smokers do not consistently receive support to quit. METHODS: In a pre-post guideline implementation study at the inpatient medical units of four VA hospitals, the effectiveness of a multimodal intervention (improved academic detailing, changing the nursing admission template, patient education materials and quitline referral, practice facilitation, and staff feedback ) examined ) changed practical behavior evaluated. Pre-discharge interviews were conducted with 824 patients to assess the receipt of the 5A (Ask, Counsel, Assess, Assist, Organize) by nurses and physicians in hospitalized smokers. RESULTS: Subjects were significantly more likely to have received each of the 5A's from a nurse (except for “advice to quit”) during the post-implementation period. More patients were assisted to quit (75% versus 56%, adjusted odds ratio [OR] = 2.3, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 1.6, 3.1) and ordered follow-up (23% versus 18 %, adjusted OR = 1.5, 95% CI = 1.0, 2.2) by one caregiver during the post-implementation period. However, unadjusted results showed no improvement in seven-day point prevalence at six-month follow-up (13.5% vs. 13.9%). Nurses' self-efficacy in giving counseling, measured in a survey of 166 ward nurses, improved after implementation of the guideline. DISCUSSION: A multifaceted intervention, including improved scientific detailing, is an effective strategy to improve the delivery of smoking cessation services to inpatients. To promote long-term cessation, more intensive interventions are needed to ensure motivated smokers receive guideline-based treatment (including pharmacotherapy and referral to outpatient cessation counseling).

title: Implementation of clinical guidelines for the treatment of diabetes mellitus in general medicine. Evaluate the effort, process, and patient outcome associated with the implementation of a computerized decision support system
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the implementation of clinical guidelines for diabetes mellitus in general practice using a specific computer-assisted clinical decision support system (CDSS) as part of the intervention. METHODS: Health center-as-a-unit randomized study. Common practice in the provinces of Sor- and Nord-Trondelag in Norway, population 380,000. 17 health centers with 24 physicians and 499 patients with diabetes mellitus were in the intervention group and 12 health centers with 29 physicians and 535 patients in the control group. Main outcome measures were group differences in proportions of patients not registered (process assessment) and mean group differences for the same variables (patient outcome assessment). RESULTS: Statistically significant group differences were found for fractions of patients with no cigarette smoking registration (intervention group, 82.6%; control group, 94.5%), body mass index (78.2% vs. 93.0%), and sufficient registrations for the risk calculation established a score for myocardial infarction (91.1% vs. 98.3%)” all at 18 months. Large center variations were shown for all variables. The only statistically significant group difference was -2.3 mm Hg (95% CI, -3.8, -0.8) in diastolic blood pressure in favor of the intervention group. Statistically insignificant differences in favor of the intervention group were HbA1c, -0.1% (95% CI, -0.4, 0.1), systolic blood pressure, -1.2 mm Hg (95% CI, -4.4, 2 ,0). Statistically insignificant differences in favor of the control group were proportion of smokers, +3.0% (95% CI, -4.0, 10.0), body mass index, +0.3 kg/m2 (95% CI, -0 .8, 1.4), risk score in females +0.1 (95% CI, -5.1, 5.2) and risk score in males +2.6 (95% CI, -14.2 , 19.5). CONCLUSIONS: The implementation of clinical guidelines for diabetes mellitus in general practice using a CDSS and multiple implementation procedures did not lead to a clinically significant change in physician behavior or patient outcome.

title: Implementation of clinical guidelines for the treatment of hypertension in general medicine.
abstract: Discrepancies between clinical guidelines and clinical practice require practical implementation strategies. This study evaluates the implementation of clinical guidelines for hypertension in general practice with a specific computer-assisted clinical decision support system (CDSS) as part of the intervention. We conducted a randomized study in general medical centers in the counties of Sør- and Nord-Trøndelag in Norway (380,000 inhabitants). A total of 17 health centers with 24 physicians and 984 patients were included in the intervention group. Data from 887 patients were used for the analyses. There were 12 health centers with 29 doctors and 1255 patients in the control group. Data from 1127 control patients were used in the analyses. The main outcome parameters were the physician's behavior as measured by adherence to the registration of the recommended variables in the Norwegian clinical guidelines for hypertension. The goal of the intervention was to reduce the proportion of unregistered patients. However, there were no clinically significant differences between the intervention group and the control group for fractions of patients without recording of blood pressure (intervention group 14.3%, control group 14.2%) or serum cholesterol (62.3% vs. 56.8%) during 12 months, still during 18 months for some of the patients without registering cigarette smoking (82.9% vs. 87.1%), cardiovascular heredity (79.5% vs. 73.4%) and body mass index (81.5% vs. 89.2%). 91.7% of patients in the intervention group and 91.9% of patients in the control group were missing one or more variables required for the calculation of the risk score for myocardial infarction. Large center variations were shown for all variables. The implementation of clinical guidelines in the treatment of hypertensive patients in the general practice through a CDSS and several implementation procedures did not result in any clinically significant changes in physician behavior. Of importance are both the lack of user-friendliness of the specific CDSS and problems when performing time-consuming multidimensional procedures.

title: Implementation of evidence-based guidelines for radiography for acute low back pain: a pilot study in a chiropractic community
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the ability of a systematic educational intervention strategy to change chiropractors' simple X-ray ordering behavior toward evidence-based practice for patients with acute low back pain (LBP). DESIGN: A quasi-experimental method was used to compare the results before and after the intervention with those of a control community. SETTING: Two communities in southern Ontario. DATA SOURCE: Postal survey data on management of acute LBP. Outcome measures Rates for the use of radiographs in acute LBP, based on responses to mailed surveys. RESULTS: After the intervention, there was a 42% reduction in the self-rated need for a plain radiograph in uncomplicated acute LBP (P 0.05). CONCLUSIONS: The educational intervention strategy used in this study appeared to have an effect in reducing the perceived need for a plain radiograph in acute LBP.

title: Implementing Evidence-Based Practice: Effectiveness of a Structured, Multifaceted Mentoring Program
abstract: AIM: This paper is a report on the effectiveness of a structured, multifaceted mentoring program designed to implement evidence-based practice in an intense clinical research setting. BACKGROUND: Barriers to implementing evidence-based practice are well documented in the literature. Evidence-based practice is associated with higher quality care and better patient outcomes than traditional care. However, the integration of evidence-based practice implementation into daily clinical practice remains patchy, and the gap between research and bedside practice remains significant. METHODS: This quasi-experimental, mixed-methods study included three focused discussions with nursing management and shared governance staff, and pre- (N = 159) and post-interventional (N = 99) questionnaires administered between June 2006 and February 2007 . Online questionnaires included measures of organizational readiness, evidence-based practice beliefs, evidence-based practice implementation, job satisfaction, group cohesion, and intention to leave care and the current job. Results. Participants in the evidence-based practice mentoring program had greater increases in perceived organizational culture and readiness for evidence-based practice and values for belief in evidence-based practice than those who did not participate. Qualitative results indicated that leadership's support for a culture of evidence-based practice and the provision of resources for the sustainability of the initiative needed to be a priority for engaging staff at all levels. CONCLUSION: These results confirm other studies showing that nurses' beliefs about evidence-based practice are significantly correlated with evidence-based practice implementation and that the presence of a mentor leads to stronger beliefs and implementation by nurses, as well as greater group cohesion, which is a more potent Predictor for fluctuation rates in nursing.

title: Depression implementation guidelines for prescribing antidepressants in general practice: a quasi-experimental review
abstract: BACKGROUND: International guidelines for depression recommend a tiered treatment approach, meaning that antidepressants should not be offered as first-line treatment for patients with underlying or mild depression. In the Netherlands, prescription rates of antidepressants in general practitioners as the first step in treatment are considered high. The aim of this study was to evaluate the implementation of guideline recommendations for the prescription of antidepressants. METHODS: A quasi-experimental study with a non-equivalent naturalistic control group and 3-year follow-up was conducted in a general practice in the Netherlands. General practitioners (GPs) participated in a national quality improvement collaboration (QIC) focused on implementing a guideline-based model for a tiered approach to care for depression. The model consisted of self-help and psychological treatment options for patients with milder symptoms as an alternative to antidepressants in the general practitioner's office. Changes in GP prescription rates for antidepressants were documented over a three-year period and compared to that of a control group of GPs selected from an ongoing national registry network. RESULTS: A 23.3% (49.4% - 26.1%) decrease in the antidepressant prescription rate for newly diagnosed patients with depressive symptoms was noted within the intervention group, while there was no difference in the reference group (50.3% – 52.6%). The decrease over time was significant compared to the usual care group (OR 0.44, 95% CI: 0.21-0.92). CONCLUSIONS: An implementation program using step-care principles for the allocation of depression interventions resulted in reduced antidepressant prescription rates in primary care. General practitioners can change prescribing behavior as part of a QIC.

title: Implementation of guidelines for the prevention of opportunistic infections in inflammatory bowel disease
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Opportunistic infections are an important safety issue in the management of patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Despite the existence of international guidelines, many gastroenterologists have not established routine screening and vaccination. The aim of this study was to modify clinical behavior using a simple screening tool. METHODS: A screening and vaccination form for hepatitis B, varicella, influenza, pneumococcus, human papillomavirus, tuberculosis, hepatitis C, and HIV was provided to each participating gastroenterologist. Gastroenterologists were surveyed before and after the form's awareness of vaccination recommendations and current practice. Immunity rates and the proportion of patients who received the recommended screening and immunizations were documented. RESULTS: 30 gastroenterologists in 8 different IBD centers participated in the evaluation. A total of 919 patients were included (55% female, 65% Crohn's disease, 33% ulcerative colitis, 2% undetermined IBD). The introduction of proforma screening increased self-reported gastroenterologist screening from 47% to 97% before and after intervention, respectively, p<0.001. Following application of the form, vaccination against hepatitis B, chickenpox, influenza, and pneumococcus was recommended in 67%, 2.5%, 75%, and 69% of patients, respectively. Of these, 42%, 39%, 66%, and 49% of patients followed recommendations and were vaccinated. Cervical swabs were recommended in 31%, with 62% receiving the recommended cervical swab. CONCLUSIONS: The implementation of a screening and vaccination form significantly changed the self-reported behavior of gastroenterologists. Patient compliance with these recommendations was sub-optimal, suggesting the need for further patient education in addition to other forms of support.

title: Implementation of International Guidelines for the Management of Osteoarthritis in Primary Health Care: Study Protocol for the SAMBA Steped Wedge Cluster Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: Background Previous research indicates that people with osteoarthritis (OA) are not receiving the recommended and optimal treatment. Based on international treatment recommendations for hip and knee OA and previous research, the SAMBA model for integrated OA care in Norwegian primary care was developed. The model includes physical therapist (PT)-led OA patient education sessions and an exercise program lasting 8 to 12 weeks. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness, feasibility and cost of a tailored strategy to implement the SAMBA model. Methods/Design A cluster-randomized controlled study with a graded wedge design including impact, process and cost evaluation is carried out in six municipalities (clusters) in Norway. Communities will be randomized for timing of transition from current usual care to implementation of the SAMBA model through a tailored strategy. The tailored strategy includes interactive workshops for general practitioners (GPs) and PTs in primary care covering the SAMBA model for integrated OA care, training materials, fact-finding visits, feedback and reminder materials. Outcomes will be measured at the patient, GP, and PT levels using self-reports, semi-structured interviews, and registry-based data. The primary outcome criterion is patient-reported quality of care (Osteoarthritis Quality Indicator Questionnaire) at 6 months follow-up. Secondary outcomes include referrals to PT, imaging, and referrals to orthopedic surgeons, as well as participants' treatment satisfaction, symptoms, physical activity, body weight, and self-reported and measured lower extremity function. Actual exposure to the tailored implementation strategy and user experiences is measured in a process evaluation. In the economic assessment, the difference in the costs of usual OA care and the SAMBA model for integrated OA care is compared to the difference in health outcomes and reported by the incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER). Discussion The results of the present study will complement current knowledge on tailored strategies aimed at improving the acceptance of evidence-based OA care recommendations and improving the quality of OA care in primary care. The new knowledge can be used in national and international initiatives to improve the quality of OA care. Trial Registration ClinicalTrials.gov NCT02333656

title: Implementation of nutritional guidelines - the effect of systematic training for nutritionists in nursing
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Approximately 40% of patients admitted to hospital are malnourished. The implementation of dietary guidelines could reduce the incidence of malnutrition and requires education and training for hospital staff. OBJECTIVE: It was hypothesized that an educational program focused on staff behavior would increase recognition of eating difficulties, improve patients' knowledge of appropriate food choices, and increase the number of snacks eaten between meals, thereby increasing the risk of eating disorders would reduce malnutrition. METHODS: A pre- and post-test design was used to evaluate the effect of the nurse training program. The training was conducted in five modules over 1 year and combined questions about nutrition with questions about implementation and theories about the planned change. The program was based on experimental learning theories and the steps of looking, thinking and doing. The effect on patients was measured by a patient questionnaire. RESULTS: After implementing the guidelines, more patients discussed their eating difficulties with staff, received relevant support during the meal, and were served the type of food they ordered and could chew. Patients' knowledge of choosing appropriate foods from the menu increased, suggesting that patients' food intake had improved. CONCLUSION: Our results suggest that a strategy based on the principles of experiential learning theory and the phases of the look-think-act model facilitates the implementation of dietary guidelines in a hospital setting.

title: Implementation of clinical guidelines using a computer charting system. Impact on first aid for medical personnel exposed to bodily fluids.
abstract: Context. â€“ While clinical guidelines are seen as an important mechanism for improving the quality of medical care, implementation problems can limit their effectiveness. There is little empirical data on the effect of computerized systems for applying clinical guidelines on quality of care. objective. â€“ To determine if real-time presentation of clinical guidelines using an electronic medical record can improve adherence to guidelines. Design. - Prospective off-on-off, discontinuous time series with intent-to-treat analysis. Setting. â€” University Hospital Emergency Department. Subjects. Patients were 280 healthcare workers (50 in the baseline control period, 156 in the intervention period, and 74 in the post-intervention period) presenting for initial treatment for occupational exposure to body fluids, including 89% (248/280) who sustained stab injuries and 81 % (208/257) exposed to blood. Physicians included general practitioners and treating physicians who worked in the emergency department during the study. interventions. -Implementation of a computer charting system that provides real-time information on medical history and recommendations for laboratory testing, treatment and disposition based on rules derived from clinical guidelines. main target parameter. – Quality of care, as determined by key elements documented in medical records and follow-up instructions, compliance with testing and treatment guidelines, and total charges and percentage of charges attributable to policy-recommended activities. Results. - The average percentage of documentation of 7 key patient history items in the medical record increased from 57% during the baseline period to 98% in the intervention phase (42% increase); 95% confidence interval [CI], 34%-49%) and 11 items in the follow-up instruction increased from 31% at baseline to 93% during the intervention period (62% increase; 95% CI, 51%-74%), but both resolved returned to baseline when the computer system was removed Compliance with 4 laboratory test guidelines increased from 63% at baseline to 83% during the intervention period (20% increase; 95% CI, 9% - 31%), but decreased to 52% when the computer system was removed guidelines increased from 83% at baseline to 96% during the intervention period (13% increase; 95% Ci, 9%-17%) and decreased to 84% post-intervention from 44% at baseline to 81% during the intervention phase (37% increase; "95% CI, 22%-52%) and decreased to 36% after the intervention. The mean total costs per patient were $460, $384, and $373 at each stage, respectively. Conclusions. - Utilization of a computerized clinical guidelines system to manage patients with occupational exposure to bodily fluids, improved documentation, compliance with guidelines and percentage of fees spent on reported activities while reducing overall fees. The parameters returned to the initial value when the computer system was removed.

title: Translating Research Findings into Practice with Clinical Opinion Leaders: Barriers and Lessons Learned
abstract: BACKGROUND: An opinion leader-led intervention to improve guideline-based medication management for patients with schizophrenia was tested at four Department of Veterans Affairs health care facilities. The concept of using opinion leaders as multipliers of research results and internal agents of change has been widely reported. PROJECT OVERVIEW: Each intervention site received an intensive multi-component intervention over the course of a year. The project's process evaluation included brief, ongoing surveys of physician attitudes and behavior, report minutes of opinion leader conferences, and interviews with the opinion leaders towards the end of the implementation period. OBSTACLES OR PROBLEMS AND POSSIBLE SOLUTIONS: Several obstacles or problematic issues emerged: (1) physicians do not always agree on who is an opinion leader; some websites may not have an opinion leader; (2) some sites had poorly developed formal and informal social networks among physicians; (3) a focus on physicians only as agents of change;" and (4) how much direction should opinion leaders be given on how to influence attitudes and behavior? DISCUSSION: Four main problems that emerged during the project offer possible solutions for overcoming them.

title: NHS information technology program implementation: qualitative survey of progress in acute trusts
abstract: OBJECTIVES To describe progress and perceived challenges in the implementation of the NHS Information and Technology (IT) program in England. DRAFT Case studies and in-depth interviews with issues identified using a framework developed from Grounded Theory. We interviewed employees who had been interviewed 18 months ago or new employees in the same positions. RECRUITMENTS Four NHS Trusts for Acute Hospitals in England. PARTICIPANTS Senior fiduciary managers and clinicians including CEOs, IT directors, medical directors and nursing directors. RESULTS Respondents unreservedly supported the objectives of the program but had several serious concerns. Implementation continues to be hampered by local budget shortfalls, delays in implementing program-compliant patient management systems, and poor communication between Connecting for Health (the agency responsible for the program) and local managers. New topics were raised. Local managers are unable to prioritize the implementation of the program due to competing financial priorities and uncertainties surrounding the program. They see a growing risk to patient safety related to delays and a lack of integration of program components, and are dissatisfied with "choose and book" (electronic booking for primary care referrals). CONCLUSIONS We recommend that the program sets realistic timelines for individual trusts and advises managers on interim IT systems they need to acquire due to delays beyond their control. Advice must take into account the need for trusts to ensure longer-term compatibility with the program and value for money. Trusts need assistance in prioritizing IT modernization, for example by including the implementation of the program in the performance management framework. Even though Connecting for Health takes a different approach of setting central standards with local implementation, these issues still need to be addressed. Lessons learned in the NHS have broader relevance as healthcare systems such as France and Australia seek to realize the potential of large-scale IT modernisation.

title: Impact of stroke prevention trials: addressing the global risk
abstract: Clinical trials have shown that blood pressure (BP) reduction and statin therapy can reduce the risk of cardiovascular events in patients with stroke regardless of the presence of specific risk factors. These results suggest an alternative approach to secondary stroke prevention that focuses more on global risk than identifying and modifying individual categorical risk factors such as hypertension, dyslipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. A risk-based approach is warranted because stroke survivors are at high risk for multiple cardiovascular events, not just stroke, and because physiological risk factors such as blood pressure show a continuous or log-linear relationship with cardiovascular risk. The development of adequate risk stratification models for stroke patients is essential for the implementation of such an approach. However, based on the limited evidence available, it appears that most patients who experience an ischemic stroke or TIA are at high long-term absolute risk for a subsequent cardiovascular event and should be treated with all available risk reduction strategies.

title: Role of characteristics and modalities of physical activity and exercise in defining cardiovascular health benefits in the general population: Recommendations of the EACPR (Part I)
abstract: Evidence has accumulated over the past few decades that physical activity (PA) and exercise interventions are essential components in the primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease. However, it is less clear whether and what type of PA and exercise intervention (aerobic exercise, dynamic resistance training, or both) or characteristics of exercise (frequency, intensity, time, or duration and volume) would provide greater benefit in achieving cardiovascular health . This paper, the first in a series of three, will provide specific recommendations on the importance of these characteristics for cardiovascular health in the population at large. The guidelines offered in this series of publications are intended for physicians, health practitioners, kinesiologists, physical and exercise therapists, politicians, public health decision makers and the individual member of the public. Based on previous and current literature, recommendations of the European Association on Cardiovascular Prevention and Rehabilitation regarding the type, extent and intensity of PA and exercise are formulated.

title: Improved asthma outcomes through a coordinated treatment approach in a large medical group.
abstract: The aim of this study was to review the development of a multidisciplinary asthma management program in a large medical group practice in an urban area and to evaluate the impact of the program on the processes of care delivery and access to health care for adults and children with asthma. The disease management intervention included the development of a patient registry, a systematic approach to assessing asthma control using the Asthma Therapy Assessment Questionnaire (ATAQ), case management, and physician education. An administrative database was used to study hospital admissions and emergency department (ED) visits. A medical record review was conducted to verify documented adherence to asthma guidelines and documentation practices. The study population at baseline consisted of 3,486 adults and children with asthma. The ATAQ indicated that control problems were common at baseline, with 34% of adult respondents being unemployed due to asthma. ATAQ has also identified several areas for improvement in care. For example, only 20% of adult respondents reported having a written treatment plan. The chart review and analysis of administrative entitlements showed that the program achieved positive results in several areas. Medical record documentation improved for asthma diagnosis (83.3% vs. 98.6%; p<0.001) and patient education (15.7% vs. 26.1%; p<0.001). No improvements were noted in the documentation of possession/use of Peak Flow, smoking cessation counseling, or influenza vaccination. ED visits related to asthma decreased from 148 per 1000 to 88 per 1000 (p<0.001), and hospitalizations related to asthma decreased from 81 per 1000 to 37 per 1000 (p<0.001). Results suggest that this program was associated with significant reductions in hospitalizations and ED use in asthma, as well as significant improvements in several essential care processes.

title: Improved clinical performance and teamwork of pediatric interprofessional resuscitation teams with a simulation-based educational intervention
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To measure the effect of a 1-day team training course for pediatric interprofessional resuscitation team members on adherence to Pediatric Advanced Life Support guidelines, team efficiency, and teamwork in a simulated clinical setting. DESIGN: Multicenter prospective interventional study. USE: Four tertiary care children's hospitals in Canada from June 2011 to January 2015. SUBJECTS: Interprofessional pediatric resuscitation teams including resident physicians, ICU nurses, board registered nurses, and board registered respiratory therapists (n=300", 51 teams). INTERVENTIONS: Es a one-day simulation-based team training course was conducted that included an interactive lecture, group discussions, and four simulated resuscitation scenarios, each followed by a debriefing.The first scenario of the day (PRE) was conducted before each team training session.The last scenario of the day (POST) was the same Scenario with a slightly modified patient history All scenarios included standardized distractors designed to elicit and challenge specific teamwork behaviors MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN OUTCOMES: The primary outcome measure was change (before and after d em training) while adhering to Pediatric Advanced Life Support guidelines, measured using the Clinical Performance Tool. Results were as follows: 1) change in times to onset of chest compressions and defibrillation, and 2) teamwork performance, measured using the Clinical Teamwork Scale. The correlation between the Clinical Performance Tool scores and the Clinical Teamwork Scale was also analyzed. Teams significantly improved Clinical Performance Tool scores (67.3-79.6%; p<0.0001), time to start of chest compressions (60.8-27.1 s; p<0.0001) , time to defibrillation (164.8-122.0 s; p<0.0001), and Clinical Teamwork Scale scores (56.0-71.8%; p<0.0001). A positive correlation was found between the Clinical Performance Tool and the Clinical Teamwork Scale (R = 0.281; p < 0.0001). CONCLUSIONS: Participation in a simulation-based team training educational intervention significantly improved surrogate measures of clinical performance and time to start of key clinical trials Tasks and teamwork during simulated pediatric resuscitation A positive correlation between clinical and teamwork performance suggests that effective teamwork improves the improved clinical performance of resuscitation teams.

title: Improved delivery of cardiovascular care (IDOCC) through outreach facilitation: study protocol and implementation details of a randomized controlled cluster study in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Innovative approaches need to be found to transfer best practices for the management of chronic diseases into the daily practice of primary care. Primary care plays a crucial role in the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease. However, there is a significant care gap and there are many challenges in implementing evidence-based care. The Improved Delivery of Cardiovascular Care (IDOCC) project is a pragmatic effort that aims to improve the delivery of evidence-based care for the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease in primary care practices through practice-based brokerage. METHODS: The IDOCC project is a graded wedge cluster, randomized controlled trial in which practice outreach facilitators collaborate with primary care practices to improve prevention and management of cardiovascular disease for patients at highest risk. Primary care practices in a large healthcare region in eastern Ontario, Canada were eligible to participate. The intervention consists of regular monthly meetings with the Practice Outreach Facilitator over a period of one to two years. Beginning with audit and feedback, consensus building and goal setting, practices are supported to change practice behaviors by incorporating elements of the chronic care model. These elements include (a) evidence-based decision support for providers, (b) redesign of the delivery system for practices, (c) improved self-management support tools made available to practices to help them engage patients, and (d) increased linking of community resources to practices to improve patient referrals. The primary outcome is a composite score measured at the patient level to represent each practice's adherence to evidence-based guidelines for cardiovascular care. A qualitative analysis of practice outreach facilitators' written accounts of their ongoing practice interactions is conducted. These textual analyzes will provide further insights into understanding critical factors affecting project implementation. DISCUSSION: This pragmatic, randomized, controlled, graded wedge study with both quantitative and process evaluation demonstrates innovative methods for implementing large-scale quality improvements and evidence-based approaches to care. This is the first Canadian study to examine the impact of a large-scale, multifaceted program to improve cardiovascular quality in primary care. By evaluating IDOCC, it is expected that we will demonstrate an effective, practical and sustainable means of improving the cardiovascular health of patients across Canada. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT00574808.

title: Improved perioperative antibiotic use and reduced wound infections through computer decision analysis.
abstract: prospective study was conducted over a two-year period to determine whether computer-generated reminders of perioperative antibiotic use could improve prescribing habits and reduce postoperative wound infection. During the first year, baseline patterns of antibiotic use and postoperative infection rates were determined. During the second year, computer-generated reminders regarding perioperative antibiotic use prior to surgery were recorded in the patient's medical record, and patterns of antibiotic use and postoperative wound infections were monitored. Hospitalized patients undergoing non-emergency surgery from June to November 1985 (3,263 patients) and June to November 1986 (3,568) were monitored for indications for perioperative antibiotic use, timing of antibiotic use, and postoperative infectious complications. Perioperative antibiotics were considered advisable in 1,621 (50%) patients in the 1985 sample and in 1,830 (51%) patients in the 1986 sample. Among these patients, antibiotics were administered within two hours prior to surgical incision in 638 (40%) of the 1985 sample and 1,070 (58%) of the 1986 sample (p<0.001). Overall, postoperative wound infections were noted in 28 (1.8%) of 1,621 patients in 1985 compared to 16 (0.9%) of 1,830 such patients in 1986 (p<0.03). We conclude that computer-generated reminders of perioperative antibiotic use improved prescribing habits with a concomitant decrease in postoperative wound infections.

title: Improved therapeutic surveillance with multiple interventions: a randomized trial.
abstract: Background Medication errors are often due to improper drug selection or improper laboratory parameter adjustments. The differences between the guideline recommendations and the actual frequency of therapeutic laboratory monitoring are significant. This study evaluated interventions to improve laboratory monitoring at the start of drug therapy. Methods This cluster-randomized study compared 3 usual care interventions for 10 drugs in 15 primary care clinics in a healthcare organization with an electronic medical record system. Eligible patients, identified from electronic databases, had not received recommended laboratory monitoring within 5 days of study drug re-administration. Interventions included an electronic medical record reminder to the prescribing healthcare professional, an automated voice message to the patient, and pharmacy team contact with the patient. The primary outcome was the completion of all recommended baseline laboratory monitoring. Results A total of 961 patients took part in the study. At 25 days, 95 (48.5%) of 196 patients were in the electronic medical record reminder group, 177 (66.3%) of 267 in the automated voice message group, 214 (82.0%) of 261 in the The pharmacy team contact group and 53 (22.4%) of 237 patients in the usual care group had completed all recommended baseline laboratory controls (p<0.001). After adjustment, the hazard ratios for performing laboratory monitoring versus usual care were 2.5 (95% confidence interval, 1.8-3.5) for electronic health record reminder, 4.1 (95% confidence interval, 3.0-5 .6) for automated voice message and 6.7 (95% confidence interval, 4.9-9.0) for contacting pharmacy team. Conclusions All 3 interventions were effective in improving laboratory surveillance during the introduction of new drugs in primary care. More work is needed to determine whether these interventions improve treatment outcomes.

title: Improving antibiotic prescribing in outpatient care: a cluster randomized intervention study using a sentinel surveillance network of physicians
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Evaluation of the effectiveness of the implementation of guidelines, combined with individual feedback, on the antibiotic prescribing behavior of general practitioners in Switzerland. Methods: 140 general practices from a representative Swiss Sentinel network of general practitioners participated in this cluster-randomized prospective intervention study. The intervention consisted of providing guidelines on the management of respiratory tract infections (RTIs) and uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections (UTIs) coupled with sustained, regular feedback on individual antibiotic prescribing behavior over 2 years. The main objectives were: (i) to increase the percentage of penicillin prescriptions for all antibiotic-treated UTIs; (ii) increase the percentage of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole prescriptions for all uncomplicated antibiotic-treated UTIs; (iii) to reduce the percentage of quinolone prescriptions for all cases of exacerbated COPD (eCOPD) treated with antibiotics;” and (iv) to reduce the proportion of sinusitis and other upper RTIs treated with antibiotics. The study was registered with ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT01358916). RESULTS: While the percentage of antibiotics prescribed for sinusitis or other upper RTIs and the percentage of quinolones prescribed for eCOPD did not differ between the intervention group and the control group, there was a significant increase in the percentage of penicillin- Prescriptions for all treated RTIs with antibiotics [57% versus 49%, OR=1.42 (95% CI 1.08-1.89), P=0.01] and percentage of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole prescriptions for all uncomplicated lower UTIs treated with antibiotics [35% versus 19%, OR=2.16 (95% CI 1.19-3.91), P=0.01] in the intervention group. CONCLUSIONS: In our setting, implementation of guidelines coupled with sustained individual feedback did not reduce the proportion of antibiotic-treated sinusitis and other upper RTIs, but increased the use of recommended antibiotics for RTIs and UTIs, as defined in the guidelines.

title: Improving hypertension management through structured physician training and feedback system: Cluster-randomized study
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Our aim was to assess whether treating hypertension with a structured physician information program and feedback system results in improved blood pressure (BP) control and cardiovascular outcomes. Methods: Cluster-randomized (3:1), open-label, supervised, multicenter study in Germany. Primary care physicians in the information group (IG) received detailed hypertension guidelines training, feedback on target achievement, and a reminder to step up treatment after each patient visit, while the observation/control group (CG) received no such interventions. A three-stage mixed model was developed. Time-independent level differences between groups, group-independent changes and non-parallel group-specific changes over time were tested. RESULTS: A total of 15,041 (78.1%) hypertensive patients were in the IG and 4,213 (21.9%) in the CG. After 1 year of follow-up, 82.9% of patients in the IG and 81.5% in the CG remained in the study. The guideline-based blood pressure goal was achieved by 56.8% in the IG and 52.5% in the CG (+4.3%, P=0.03), while the individual blood pressure goal was 57.0% in the IG and 51% was achieved in the CG (P = NS). Blood pressure control in the IG was achieved 2 months earlier on average. Clinical inertia, defined as the lack of medication changes despite uncontrolled blood pressure, was significantly less common in the IG group. Cardiovascular outcomes at one year did not differ between groups. CONCLUSION: The provision of systematic information coupled with a feedback system reduces clinical inertia and improves guideline adherence. Although the blood pressure control rates achieved are higher compared to previous studies, there is still considerable room for improvement.

title: Improvement of intraoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in lengthy heart operations through automated alarms in the OR
abstract: Aim: To evaluate the impact of an automated intraoperative alert for re-dosing of prophylactic antibiotics during prolonged cardiac surgery. Design: Randomized, controlled, rater-blinded study. Setting: university hospital. Patients: Patients undergoing cardiac surgery lasting more than 4 hours after preoperative administration of cefazolin unless receiving therapeutic antibiotics at the time of surgery. Intervention: Randomization to an audio and visual reminder on the operating room computer console 225 minutes after administration of preoperative antibiotics (reminder group, n=137) or control (n=136). After a further 30 minutes, the circulating nurse had to indicate whether a follow-up dose of antibiotics had been administered. Results: In the reminder group (93 of 137; 68%), intraoperative re-dosing was significantly more frequent than in the control group (55 of 136; 40%) (adjusted odds ratio 3.31; 95% confidence interval 1.97 to 5.56; P<0.0001). The effect of recall was even greater compared to the 6 months prior to the study period (129 of 480; 27%; P<0.001), suggesting some spillover effect to the control group recovered without re-dosing in 19 of the 44 patients in the memory group. The rate of postoperative wound infections in the memory group (5 of 137; 4%) was similar to that in the control group (8 of 136; 6%; P=.42), but significant lower than in the pre-study period (48 of 480; 10%;" P = .02). Conclusion: The use of an automatic reminder system in the OR improved adherence to the guidelines for perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis.

title: Improving adherence to hypertension medication guidelines: cluster randomized controlled trial of general versus patient-specific recommendations
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine whether an intervention that directs physician attention to drug choice for the treatment of hypertension improves agreement between drug regimens and guidelines. STUDY DESIGN: Cluster-randomized controlled trial comparing an individualized intervention with general guideline implementation in geographically distributed primary care hospitals of a campus-affiliated Department of Veterans Affairs health care system. METHODS: Participants were 36 treating physicians and nurses (16 in the general group and 20 in the individualized group), with results based on 4500 hypertensive patients. A general guideline implementation for all clinicians, including education on guideline-based medication recommendations and goals for adequate blood pressure control, was compared to a printed individualized consultation mailed to clinicians at each patient visit, indicating whether or not the patient was on an antihypertensive medication regimen was in line with guidelines. We measured the change from baseline to endpoint in the proportion of patients from physicians whose drug therapy was guideline compliant. RESULTS: The individualized intervention resulted in more than twice the improvement in guideline agreement compared to the general intervention (10.9% vs. 3.8%, t=2.796, p=0.008). Bootstrap analysis showed that belonging to the individualized group increased the likelihood of agreement by 1.5-fold (P = 0.025). The proportion of patients with adequate blood pressure control increased within each study group";" however, the difference between the groups was not significant. CONCLUSION: Individualized counseling regarding drug therapy for hypertension given to the physician at each patient visit was more effective in changing physician prescribing behavior than implementation of a general guideline.

title: Improving Adherence and Clinical Outcomes While Containing Costs: Opportunities through Increased Use of Generic Drugs: Best Practice Advice from the Clinical Guidelines Committee of the American College of Physicians
abstract: Description: The mismatch between healthcare spending and outcomes in the United States has fueled efforts to identify and address situations in which unnecessarily expensive therapies are being used when less expensive, equally effective options are available. The underuse of generic drugs is an important example. Methods: A literature review was conducted to answer 5 questions about generic drugs: 1) How common are branded drugs when a generic version is available? 2) How does generic drug use affect adherence? 3) What evidence is there that brand name and generic drugs have similar clinical effects? 4) What are the barriers to increasing generic drug use? 5) What strategies can be used to promote cost savings through increased use of generics? This article has been reviewed and approved by the American College of Physicians Clinical Guidelines Committee. Advice on best practice: Doctors should prescribe generic drugs whenever possible, rather than more expensive branded drugs.

title: Improving antibiotic prescribing for adults with community-acquired pneumonia: does a computerized decision support system achieve more than academic detail? - A time series analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: The ideal method for promoting the uptake of clinical guidelines in hospitals is unknown. Several strategies have been proposed. This study evaluates the effects of academic detail and a computer-assisted decision support system (CDSS) on physician prescribing behavior for patients with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). METHODS: The management of all patients presenting to the emergency department for three consecutive periods was assessed";" the baseline, academic detail, and CDSS periods. The frequency of the empirical and recommendation-compliant prescription of antibiotics was examined in a temporal comparison with previous and subsequent periods as well as with an interrupted time series analysis. Results: The odds ratio for concordant therapy in the academic detailing period after adjustment for age, disease severity and suspected aspiration compared to the baseline period was OR = 2.79 [1.88; 4.14], p < 0.01, and for the computer-assisted decision mentoring period versus academic detailing period was OR = 1.99 [1.07, 3.69], p = 0.02. During the first few months of the computer-assisted decision support phase, an improvement in antibiotic prescription adequacy was demonstrated that was greater than what would have been expected based on binary logistic model predictions alone over time and academic detail. CONCLUSION: The use of a computerized decision support system was associated with an early improvement in antibiotic prescribing practices that was greater than the changes observed with academic detailing. The sustainability of this intervention needs to be further evaluated.

title: Improving the use of antibiotics by hospital physicians: an academic pilot with a public health approach
abstract: BACKGROUND: The inappropriate use of antibiotics is a major clinical and public health problem. We designed and implemented a clinician-led academic pilot study detailing interventions to improve antibiotic prescribing patterns for inpatients. OBJECTIVE: To improve antibiotic prescribing patterns in the inpatient setting of an academic medical center. DESIGN, SETUP, AND PARTICIPANTS: Clinicians were recruited to participate in this pre- and post-intervention pilot study at Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center (JHBMC). In developing the intervention, public health principles were used to create a conceptual framework based on behavior change theory. METHODS: Antibiotic prescribing patterns from 17 hospital practitioners were retrospectively reviewed. Antimicrobial prescriptions were rated as appropriate, effective but inappropriate, or inappropriate. Each hospital worker was profiled and a session arranged to scientifically detail the intervention. The session reviewed improper prescribing practices as well as current practice guidelines. After the detailed discussion, the hospitalists' prescribing patterns were prospectively followed.
