KEY OUTCOME MEASUREMENTS: The key outcome measures were the proportions of antibiotics inappropriately prescribed before the intervention, during the detailing period, and after the intervention. RESULTS: Seventeen hospital practitioners participated in the study. A total of 247 prescriptions were checked in the pre-intervention phase and 129 prescriptions in the post-intervention phase. Before scientific detailing, 43% (95% CI 37%-49%) of the prescriptions were appropriate and 57% (95% CI 51%-63%) inappropriate. After the intervention, 74% (95% CI 65% - 81%) of the prescriptions were appropriate and 26% (95% CI 19% - 35%) inappropriate";" P<0.0001. CONCLUSIONS: A carefully planned and methodically implemented intervention can result in behavior change, even in busy hospital workers. The academically detailed intervention, which included a practice-based learning component, improved clinicians' antibiotic prescribing practices at the JHBMC.

title: Improving Asthma Care in Emergency Departments: Findings from a Multi-Hospital Collaborative Quality Initiative in Rural Western North Carolina
abstract: BACKGROUND: In North Carolina, nearly a quarter of people with asthma visit an emergency department (ED) or emergency center at least once a year for a worsening of asthma symptoms. The ER Asthma Program was a quality improvement initiative aimed at better understanding the patient population using the ER for asthma treatment in rural western North Carolina and to show whether the ER in small hospitals is doing so through the implementation of treatment of the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program could do guidance, improve asthma care and reduce subsequent asthma-related emergency room visits. METHODS: Eight western North Carolina hospitals participated in the project, which ran from November 2003 to December 2007. The intervention consisted of a series of individualized and structured continuing medical education events for ED physicians and staff. In addition, patients presenting to emergency departments with asthma-related problems were selected to complete a brief patient questionnaire to assess their basic understanding of asthma and barriers to asthma management in order to undergo an asthma rating by the treating physician undergo and receive targeted bedside asthma education, a respiratory therapist and finally, at the discretion of the treating physician, receive a complimentary pre-discharge asthma medication package, including rescue therapy with a beta-agonist and corticosteroid therapy administered via a metered-dose inhaler - During the month-long project, a total of 1,739 patients were presented to participating emergency departments for 2,481 asthma-related treatments;" at 11% of these visits, patients received the intervention, with nearly 100 ED physicians referring patients to the program. Most patients receiving the ED used to treat asthma had the mildest stages, and nearly half were uninsured or covered by Medicaid. A general practitioner or practice was identified in only 20% of the visits. The patient's intervention did not appear to reduce the rate of revisit visits for asthma-related symptoms at 30 and 60 days. LIMITATIONS: Selection bias is likely because patients enrolled in the study were more likely to be adult and insured than patients in the target sample. Because we did not measure ED staff participation in training or their knowledge and attitudes about asthma care before and after the training program, we cannot draw conclusions about the effectiveness of the program in changing their knowledge, attitudes, or behavior. CONCLUSIONS: Many patients who use the emergency department for care appear to have mild, intermittent asthma and cannot find a regular source of primary care. Efforts to improve asthma management on a community-wide basis and reduce avoidable exacerbations should include emergency department care, as this may be the only source of asthma treatment for many asthmatics. The project showed that regional, collaborative efforts to improve performance in EDs are possible, but that many obstacles stand in the way of this approach.

title: Improving asthma-related health outcomes in low-income, multiracial, school-age children: results of a demonstration project that combined continuous quality improvement and strategies by community health workers
abstract: OBJECTIVE. The purpose of this work was to improve asthma-related health outcomes in an ethnically and geographically diverse population of economically disadvantaged school-age children using a team-based approach with continuous quality improvement and community health workers. PATIENTS AND METHODS. A demonstration project was carried out with 7 community clinics treating _x0001_3000 children aged 5 to 18 with asthma. The entire hospital population with asthma was examined for changes in the care process using random cross-sectional analyzes at baseline and after 24 months (N 560). A subset of patients with either moderate or severe persistent asthma or poorly controlled asthma (N 405) was assessed for specific asthma-related clinical outcomes, satisfaction with care, and confidence in managing asthma through family interviews at baseline and at 12 or 24 months monitored longitudinally. Patient-centered and care-process related outcomes included patient/parent assessment of quality of care and confidence in self-management, review of the asthma action plan, and documentation of guideline-based indicators of quality of care. Direct clinical outcomes included daytime and nighttime symptoms, use of rescue medication, acute care and emergency department visits, hospitalizations, and missed school days. The level of adherence to the intervention model at each clinic site was assessed and ranked to examine the correlation between adherence to the model and outcomes.

title: Improving blood pressure control through provider education, provider alerts and patient education
abstract: Background: Inadequate blood pressure control is a persistent gap in quality care. Aim: To evaluate provider and patient interventions to improve blood pressure control. Design: Cluster randomized controlled study. Setting: 2 hospital-based and 8 community-based clinics in the Veterans Affairs Tennessee Valley Healthcare System. Patients: 1341 veterans with essential hypertension served by 182 providers. Eligible patients had 2 or more blood pressure measurements greater than 140/90 mmHg in a 6 month period and were taking a single antihypertensive drug. Intervention: Providers caring for eligible patients were randomly assigned an email with a web-based link to the guidelines of the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC 7). (Provider Awareness)"; Provider Education and a patient-specific computerized hypertension alert (Provider Awareness and Alert); or Provider Education, Provider Alert on Hypertension and Patient Education, in which a letter was sent to patients stating that they for medication adherence, lifestyle changes, and discussions with providers (patient education) Measurements: Proportion of patients with systolic blood pressure below 140 mm Hg at 6 months, intensification of antihypertensive medication Results: Mean baseline blood pressure was 157/83 mm Hg with no differences between groups (P=0.105) Six-month follow-up data were available for 975 patients (73%), patients from providers randomly assigned to patient education had better blood pressure control (138/75 mm Hg) than those in the patient education group Groups with training provided by the provider and alarm or training provided by the contractor alone bidder (146/76 mm Hg or 145/78 mm Hg). More patients in the patient education group had a systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg or less compared to patients in the provider education or provider education and alert groups (adjusted relative risk for patient education group versus provider education alone group, 1.31 [95% CI, 1.06 to 1.62];" P = 0.012). Limitations: Follow-up blood pressure measurements were absent in 27% of study patients. The study failed to identify a mechanism by which patient education improved blood pressure control. Conclusions: A multifactorial intervention including Patient education improved blood pressure control compared to provider education alone.

title: Improving blood pressure control through provider education, provider alerts, and patient education: a cluster-randomized study.
abstract: Background: Inadequate blood pressure control is a persistent gap in quality care. Aim: To evaluate provider and patient interventions to improve blood pressure control. Design: Cluster randomized controlled study. Setting: 2 hospital-based and 8 community-based clinics in the Veterans Affairs Tennessee Valley Healthcare System. Patients: 1341 veterans with essential hypertension served by 182 providers. Eligible patients had 2 or more blood pressure measurements greater than 140/90 mmHg in a 6 month period and were taking a single antihypertensive drug. Intervention: Providers caring for eligible patients were randomly assigned an email with a web-based link to the guidelines of the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC 7). (Provider Awareness)"; Provider Education and a patient-specific computerized hypertension alert (Provider Awareness and Alert); or Provider Education, Provider Alert on Hypertension and Patient Education, in which a letter was sent to patients stating that they for medication adherence, lifestyle changes, and discussions with providers (patient education) Measurements: Proportion of patients with systolic blood pressure below 140 mm Hg at 6 months, intensification of antihypertensive medication Results: Mean baseline blood pressure was 157/83 mm Hg with no differences between groups (P=0.105) Six-month follow-up data were available for 975 patients (73%), patients from providers randomly assigned to patient education had better blood pressure control (138/75 mm Hg) than those in the patient education group Groups with training provided by the provider and alarm or training provided by the contractor alone bidder (146/76 mm Hg or 145/78 mm Hg). More patients in the patient education group had a systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg or less compared to patients in the provider education or provider education and alert groups (adjusted relative risk for patient education group versus provider education alone group, 1.31 [95% CI, 1.06 to 1.62];" P = 0.012). Limitations: Follow-up blood pressure measurements were absent in 27% of study patients. The study failed to identify a mechanism by which patient education improved blood pressure control. Conclusions: A multifactorial intervention including Patient education improved blood pressure control compared to provider education alone.

title: Improving cardiovascular risk management: a randomized controlled trial of the effect of a decision support tool for patients and physicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is suboptimal adherence of general practitioners (GPs) and patients to cardiovascular risk-reducing interventions. GPs find it difficult to include multiple risk factors in an accurate cardiovascular risk assessment. In addition, communicating cardiovascular risk to patients has proven difficult. OBJECTIVES: To improve primary prevention of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in primary care by improving patient involvement in the use of a decision support tool. DESIGN: Cluster randomized study. METHODS: Thirty-four general practitioners enrolled patients (40-75 years old) without cardiovascular disease. In a 4-hour interactive small group training session, the general practitioners of the intervention group were trained in how to use the cardiovascular risk guidelines and a decision-making tool. The control group received paper-based educational materials on the guidelines. GP clinical performance and patients' risk perceptions and self-reported lifestyle were measured at baseline and 6 months. RESULTS: Thirty-four general practitioners recorded 490 consultations, 276 in the intervention and 214 in the control group. After 6 months there was no significant effect of the intervention on the performance of the general practitioners or the risk perception of the patients. There was only an effect on self-reported lifestyle, with more men in the intervention group than in the control group increasing their physical activity (odds ratio 3.8, 95% confidence interval 1.7–8.7). CONCLUSION: The 4-hour interactive small group training did not guarantee correct use of the decision support tool and therefore could neither improve the performance of the general practitioners nor correct the risk perception of the patients. The positive effect on physical activity warrants further research on patient involvement.

title: Improving the care of minority children with asthma: vocational training in public health clinics
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Recent studies have shown that the lack of consistent primary care for asthma is associated with increased morbidity in low-income minority children. Although effective preventative therapy is available, many African American and Hispanic children receive episodic asthma treatment that does not meet current treatment guidelines. To see if the access, continuity, and quality of care at pediatric hospitals for low-income children in New York City could be improved, we trained staff at the New York City Bureau of Child Health's hospitals to provide ongoing, preventive asthma care to offer. METHODS: We evaluated the effect of the intervention over a period of 2 years in a controlled study at 22 hospitals. Training for intervention center staff was based on National Asthma Education and Prevention Program guidelines for the diagnosis and management of asthma and included screening to identify new cases and health education to improve family management. The intervention included strong administrative support from the Bureau of Child Health to encourage staff behavior change. We hypothesized that post-intervention clinics that received the intervention would have an increased number of children with asthma treated continuously in the clinics compared to control clinics, and that staff would reinforce new pharmacological and educational treatments uses. RESULTS: In both the first and second years of follow-up, the intervention clinics showed greater positive changes than the control clinics in terms of access, continuity, and quality of care. Second-year follow-up data include: for access, a higher rate of new asthma patients (40/1000 vs. 16/1000 in; P<0.01); for continuity, a greater percentage of asthmatic patients returning to treatment 2 years in a row (42% vs. 12%; P<0.001) and a greater annual frequency of planned visits for asthma per patient (1.85 vs. 0.88 ; P<0.001) and for quality, a greater percentage of patients receiving inhaled beta-agonists (52% vs. 15%; p<0.001) and inhaled anti-inflammatory drugs (25% vs. 2%; p<0.001) and a greater percentage of parents who reported receiving patient education on 12 subjects from Bureau of Child Health physicians (71% vs 58%; P<0.01) and nurses (61% vs 44%; "P< CONCLUSION: We conclude that the intervention of the Bureau of Child Health staff significantly improves the ability to identify children with asthma, engage them in ongoing care, and provide them with state-of-the-art treatment for asthma Has.

title: Improving prevention and early detection of chronic diseases in primary care: Results of the BETTER pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Primary care provides most of the evidence-based chronic disease prevention and preparedness services offered by the health care system. However, a gap remains between recommended preventive services and actual practice. This study (the BETTER study) aimed to improve preventive management of heart disease, diabetes, colorectal, breast and cervical cancer and relevant lifestyle factors through a practice facilitation intervention in primary care. Methods: Pragmatic two-way factorial cluster RCT with primary care practices as the allocation unit and individual patients as the analysis unit. The setting was urban practices of primary care teams in two Canadian provinces. Eight practices of the primary care team were randomly assigned to receive practice-level intervention or wait-list control. 4 physicians in each team (32 physicians) were randomly assigned to receive patient-level intervention or wait-list control. Patients, randomly selected from the physicians' lists, were divided into two groups: 1) general and 2) moderate mental illness. The interventions included a multi-faceted, evidence-based, tailored, practice-level intervention with a practice facilitator, and a patient-level intervention, which included a one-hour visit with a prevention practitioner, where patients received a tailored “prevention prescription.” The primary outcome was a composite summary quality index of 28 evidence-based chronic disease prevention and screening interventions with predefined goals, expressed as the ratio of eligible interventions at baseline to achieved at follow-up. An economic analysis was carried out. RESULTS: 789 of 1,260 (63%) eligible patients participated. On average, patients were eligible for 8.96 (SD 3.2) measures at baseline. In the adjusted analysis, control patients achieved 23.1% (95% CI: 19.2% to 27.1%) of target actions compared to 28.5% (95% CI: 20.9% to 36.0%) who received the practice-level intervention, 55.6% (95% CI: 49.0% to 62.1%) received the patient-level intervention, and 58.9% (95% CI: 54.7% to 63 .1%) received practice-level and patient-level interventions (patient-level intervention versus control, P<0.001). The benefit of the intervention at the patient level was seen in both strata. The additional cost of the intervention was CAN$26.43 (95% CI: $16 to $44) per additional action taken. CONCLUSIONS: A prevention expert can cost-effectively improve the delivery of clinically important prevention and screening procedures for chronic diseases.

title: Improving clinical handover between the ICU and general ward professionals upon discharge from the ICU.
abstract: Purpose To systematically review and evaluate the effectiveness of interventions to improve the safety and efficiency of patient transfer between the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) and general unit medical staff at ICU discharge. Methods PubMed, CINAHL, PsycINFO, EMBASE, Web of Science and the Cochrane Library were searched for intervention studies published up to and including June 2013 aiming to improve clinical handoff between ICU and general ward healthcare professionals. Methods for article inclusion and data analysis were pre-established and aligned with the recommendations of the PRISMA guideline. Two reviewers independently extracted data (study purpose, setting, population, sampling method, sample size, intervention characteristics, outcome, and implementation activities) and assessed the quality of the included studies. Results Of the 6,591 citations originally extracted from the six databases, we included 11 studies in this review. Of these, six (55%) reported statistically significant effects. Effective interventions included liaison nurses to improve communication and coordination of care, and forms to facilitate timely, complete, and accurate handover information. Effective interventions resulted in improved continuity of care (eg, shorter delay in discharge) and fewer adverse events. Contradictory effects were observed with regard to the use of care, namely a reduction in the length of stay compared to an increase in readmissions to higher care. No statistically significant effects in reducing mortality were found. The overall methodological quality of the 11 studies reviewed was relatively low, with an average score of 4.5 out of 11 points. Conclusions This review shows that liaison nurses and transfer forms are promising interventions to improve the quality of patient transfer between the ICU and the general ward. More robust evidence of the effectiveness of interventions aimed at improving ICU handover and supportive implementation strategies is needed.

title: Improving compliance with immunization in older adults: results from a randomized cohort study.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To compare three approaches to improving compliance with influenza and pneumococcal vaccination in elderly patients. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial of three parallel group practices in a public urban teaching hospital. SETTING: Public teaching hospital. PARTICIPANTS: All patients aged 65 years and older (n = 1202) treated by general practitioners (n = 66) in three outpatient medical practices from October 1, 1989 to March 31, 1990 Vaccination standards. The control group received no further intervention. Staff in the second group offered education to patients during their visits. In the third group, the prevention team, a flowchart was used, patient education was offered, and staff roles were redefined to facilitate compliance";" in the case of vaccinations, e.g. B. Vaccinate nurses independently of MD initiatives. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: The medical records of the 1202 patients studied, including 756 patients treated during both the 1988-89 and 1989-90 influenza seasons, were reviewed to determine documented vaccination provision and receipt. During the intervention period (1989-90), influenza vaccination was offered to patients in the prevention team (68.3%) significantly more often than patients in the patient education (50.4%) or control (47.6%) groups (p=0.006). even after adjustment for patients' previous vaccination status, age, sex, race, and high-risk comorbidity, and for physicians' level of education. Likewise, previously unvaccinated patients in the prevention team were offered pneumococcal vaccinations more frequently (28.3%) than patients in the patient education group (6.5%) or the control group (5.4%) (p=0.001), even after adjusting for factors using multivariate Analysis. For both vaccines, compliance rates did not differ between patient education and controls. Pre-procedure surveys of physicians documented perceived rather than actual compliance for both vaccines, with 89.0% and 52.8% of physicians believing they were complying with vaccination guidelines for influenza and pneumococcus, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: The results of this study provide strong support for organizational changes involving non-physician workers to increase immunization coverage among older adults.

title: Improving health care with the Comprehensive Annotated Reminder Tool (CART)
abstract: OBJECTIVES: We assessed the effect of the Comprehensive Annotated Reminder Tool (CART) on physician adherence to preventive care recommendations. STUDY DESIGN: Using a randomized pretest/posttest control group design, we assigned physicians to the CART group or the control group, followed prospectively, and assessed appropriate adherence to guidelines. The 3 age-specific versions of the annotated CART history and physical examination form contained up to 49 preventive service recommendations. POPULATION: All resident physicians in a large family practice residency program were studied over the course of one academic year. OUTCOMES MEASURED: We performed blinded chart reviews to assess the adequacy of physician-ordered preventive services prior to CART introduction, during its use, and after its removal. A multiple-choice test administered before and after using the CART forms assessed knowledge. RESULTS: When the CART was used, the overall adequacy of physician preventive behavior increased by 21%. The adequacy of history, physical examination, and laboratory procedures increased by 33%. When the CART was removed, the physician's behavior returned to baseline (P < or = 0.0025 for 16 of 20 procedures). No significant differences were observed in the control group over time. Knowledge increased over the study period in all physicians (P < or = 0.005), but was not significantly different between the treatment and control groups (P = 0.608). CONCLUSIONS: Use of the CART significantly improved the physician's performance in providing appropriate preventive care.

title: Improving treatment for depression through an online learning community
abstract: Depression is a leading cause of disability worldwide, and many internists diagnose and treat depression. This study aimed to investigate the impact of a practice improvement intervention on the screening and management of patients with depression in primary care. This before-and-after study design included a physician practice survey aimed at capturing what they thought physicians were doing in practice, a chart audit tool to capture what physicians were actually doing in practice, and an intervention , which included an evidence-based training program. Online toolkit and coaching conference calls to improve practice that encouraged group learning. After completing the intervention, participants increasingly used the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 to identify, diagnose, and measure treatment success for depression and reported increased use of guidelines and team-based care. Although barriers to improving depression treatment exist, this study suggests that evidence-based quality improvement programs can positively impact practice.

title: Improving Diabetes Care: Strategies to Reduce the Risk of Multicomponent Cardiovascular Disease for People with Diabetes in South Asia - the Multicenter CARRS Translational Study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in people with diabetes in South Asia. The CARRS translation study will test the efficacy, cost-effectiveness and sustainability of a clinically-based, multi-component intervention to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease in people with diabetes in India and Pakistan. METHODS: We randomly assigned 1146 adults with diabetes, recruited from 10 city clinics, to receive usual care provided by physicians or to receive an integrated intervention to reduce the risk of multi-component cardiovascular disease. The intervention includes electronic health record management, decision support prompts for the health care team, and support from a care coordinator to actively facilitate patient and provider adherence to evidence-based guidelines. The primary outcome is a combination of control of multiple cardiovascular risk factors (blood glucose and either blood pressure or cholesterol, or all three). Further results are the control of the individual CVD risk factors, process and patient-centred measures, cost-effectiveness and acceptability/feasibility. CONCLUSION: The CARRS translation study is testing a low-cost diabetes care model in urban areas of South Asia to achieve comprehensive case management for cardiometabolic disease in high-risk patients (clinicaltrials.gov number: NCT01212328).

title: Improving physician prescribing behavior through policy reflection and prescribing feedback: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Translating research findings into clinical practice, whether through guidelines or feedback on prescriptions, is difficult. AIM: To investigate the effect on prescribing quality of a combined intervention of individual feedback and derivation of quality criteria based on guideline recommendations in peer-review groups. METHODS: 199 general practitioners in 32 groups were randomized to participate in peer-reviewed meetings related to asthma or urinary tract infections. The dispensing of anti-asthmatics and antibiotics by the participating physicians in the year before the intervention period formed the basis for the prescription feedback. The intervention feedback was designed to describe the treatment in relation to the recommendations in the national guidelines. Based on these recommendations, the physicians in each group agreed on quality criteria for their own treatment of the respective diseases. Comparing their prescription feedback to their own quality criteria gave each physician the proportion of acceptable and unacceptable treatments. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Difference in prescribing behavior between the year before and the year after the intervention. RESULTS: Before the intervention, the mean proportion of acceptably treated asthma patients in the asthma and urinary tract infection (control) groups were 28% and 27%, respectively. The average proportion of acceptably treated patients in the asthma group was increased by 6% compared to the control group";" this difference was statistically significant. The average proportions of acceptable pre-procedure UTI treatments in the UTI group and the asthma (control) group were 12% for both groups, which increased by 13% in the UTI group compared to the control group. Based on the mean values before the intervention, this meant a treatment improvement of 21% in the asthma group and 108% in the urinary tract infection group. CONCLUSIONS: The derivation of prescribing quality criteria through discussion of guideline recommendations provided physicians with a basis for assessing their treatment of individual patients as acceptable or unacceptable. With feedback on their own prescription, they learned what they were doing right and wrong. This provided a basis for improvement, and the process thus initiated resulted in physicians providing better quality patient care.

title: Improving empirical antibiotic selection through computer decision support.
abstract: Background: Physicians must often start antibiotic therapy before the results of bacterial cultures and antibiotic susceptibility tests are available. We have developed and evaluated a computerized antibiotics advisor to assist physicians in selecting appropriate empiric antibiotics. METHODS: We used a two-stage, randomized sample study to compare antibiotic consultant-recommended antibiotics with 482 associated antibiotic susceptibility outcomes and physician-prescribed antibiotics concomitantly. The antibiotics prescribed by randomized physicians were then compared between transition periods of antibiotic counselor use. Results: The antibiotics consultant recommended an antibiotic regimen to which all isolated pathogens were susceptible in 453 (94%) of 482 culture results, while the physicians recommended an antibiotic regimen to which all isolated 369 culture results (77%). pathogens were susceptible. ) (P<0.001). The doctors who prescribed antibiotics, to which all pathogens were susceptible, did so a median of 21 hours after collecting the culture samples. Physicians ordered appropriate antibiotics significantly more frequently within 12 hours after culture collection when using the antibiotic advisor than before (P < 0.035). In addition, 88% of physicians said they would recommend the program to other physicians, 85% said the program improved their antibiotic choices, and 81% said using the program improved patient care. Conclusions: Information from computerized medical records can be used to improve physician selection of empiric antibiotics for infections. (Arch Intern Med. 1994";"154:878-884)

title: Improving empiric antibiotic treatment with TREAT, a computer-assisted decision support system: cluster-randomized study.
abstract: Background: Adequate antibiotic treatment reduces mortality, while unnecessary treatment is associated with antibiotic resistance. We have developed a computer-assisted antibiotic treatment decision support system (TREAT) that addresses these outcomes. METHODS: Prospective cohort study comparing TREAT advice to physician care, followed by a cluster randomized study comparing wards with TREAT (intervention) to antibiotic monitoring without TREAT (control). We included patients with suspected bacterial infections in three hospitals (Israel, Germany and Italy). The primary endpoint, appropriate antibiotic treatment, was evaluated in patients with microbiologically documented infections (MDI). All enrolled patients were compared length of hospital stay, adverse events, mortality (interventional study), and antibiotic costs (both studies), including costs associated with future antibiotic resistance. Results: Among the 1203 patients included in the cohort study (350 with MDI), TREAT was significantly more likely to prescribe appropriate empiric antibiotic treatment than physicians (70% vs. 57%, P<0.001) who used fewer broad-spectrum antibiotics at half the physician's antibiotic costs. The randomized study included 2326 patients, 570 with MDI. The rate of appropriate empiric antibiotic treatment was higher on intervention wards than on control wards [73% versus 64%, odds ratio (OR): 1.48, 95% confidence interval (CI): 0.95–2.29, intention to treat, adjusted for location and cluster formation]. In patients treated in intervention units according to TREAT recommendations, the difference from controls was highly significant (OR: 3.40, 95% CI: 2.25-5.14). Length of hospital stay, costs associated with future resistance, and total antibiotic costs were lower in intervention wards than in control wards. Conclusions: TREAT improved the rate of appropriate empiric antibiotic treatments while reducing antibiotic costs and the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

title: Improving empiric antibiotic treatment with TREAT, a computer-assisted decision support system: cluster-randomized study.
abstract: Background: Adequate antibiotic treatment reduces mortality, while unnecessary treatment is associated with antibiotic resistance. We have developed a computer-assisted antibiotic treatment decision support system (TREAT) that addresses these outcomes. METHODS: Prospective cohort study comparing TREAT advice to physician care, followed by a cluster randomized study comparing wards with TREAT (intervention) to antibiotic monitoring without TREAT (control). We included patients with suspected bacterial infections in three hospitals (Israel, Germany and Italy). The primary endpoint, appropriate antibiotic treatment, was evaluated in patients with microbiologically documented infections (MDI). All enrolled patients were compared length of hospital stay, adverse events, mortality (interventional study), and antibiotic costs (both studies), including costs associated with future antibiotic resistance. Results: Among the 1203 patients included in the cohort study (350 with MDI), TREAT was significantly more likely to prescribe appropriate empiric antibiotic treatment than physicians (70% vs. 57%, P<0.001) who used fewer broad-spectrum antibiotics at half the physician's antibiotic costs. The randomized study included 2326 patients, 570 with MDI. The rate of appropriate empiric antibiotic treatment was higher on intervention wards than on control wards [73% versus 64%, odds ratio (OR): 1.48, 95% confidence interval (CI): 0.95–2.29, intention to treat, adjusted for location and cluster formation]. In patients treated in intervention units according to TREAT recommendations, the difference from controls was highly significant (OR: 3.40, 95% CI: 2.25-5.14). Length of hospital stay, costs associated with future resistance, and total antibiotic costs were lower in intervention wards than in control wards. Conclusions: TREAT improved the rate of appropriate empiric antibiotic treatments while reducing antibiotic costs and the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

title: Improving Feedback on Prescribing Errors from Junior Physicians: Mixed Methods Evaluation of a Quality Improvement Project
abstract: Background Prescribing errors occur in up to 15% of in-patient medicine orders in the UK. Residents, however, report insufficient feedback on errors. A barrier preventing feedback is that individual prescribing physicians often cannot be clearly identified in the prescribing documents. Objective To reduce prescribing errors in a UK hospital by improving feedback on prescribing errors. Interventions We developed three interrelated interventions using Plan-Do-Study-Act cycles: (1) Name stamps for trainee physicians who were encouraged to clearly stamp or write their name when prescribing";" (2) Principles of Effective Feedback to assist pharmacists in providing feedback to physicians on individual prescribing errors; and (3) Fortnightly Prescribing Advice emails addressing a common and/or major error. Implementation and evaluation In August 2013, interventions were introduced at one hospital site and a second served as a control. Process metrics included the proportion of inpatient drug prescriptions for which residents gave their names. Outcome measures were the perceptions of trainee physicians and pharmacists on the current provision of feedback (evaluated using quantitative pre- and inquiry forms and qualitative focus groups) and the prevalence of incorrect drug prescriptions written by trainee physicians between August and December 2013. Results The percentage of drug orders where residents gave their names increased from around 10% to 50%. Responses to the questionnaire showed a significant improvement in pharmacists' perceptions, but no significant change for physicians. The results of the focus groups indicated an increased commitment by physicians to safe prescribing. Interrupted time-series analyzes showed no difference in weekly prescribing error rates between baseline and intervention periods compared to the control center. Conclusion The results indicate an improved experience with feedback. However, attempts to achieve a measurable reduction in prescribing errors will likely require a multi-pronged approach, which should include feedback.

title: Improving compliance: a randomized trial evaluating strategies to increase beta-blocker use in heart failure
abstract: Background – The dissemination of guidelines for clinical practice has often not been accompanied by desired improvements in guideline adherence. This study evaluated interventions to implement a new practice guideline advocating the use of beta-blockers in patients with heart failure. METHODS AND RESULTS - This was a randomized controlled trial in heart failure patients (n=169) with an ejection fraction of =45% and no contraindications to beta-blockers. Patients' primary caregivers were randomized to 1 of 3 interventions in a stratified design: (1) control: caregiver education; (2) Provider and Patient Notification: Computerized reminders from the provider and patient letters advocating beta-blockers;' and (3) Nurse Facilitator: Supervised nurse to initiate and titrate beta-blockers. The primary outcome, the proportion of patients who started or up-titrated and maintained beta-blockers, analyzed by intention-to-treat, was achieved in 67% (36 of 54) of patients in the Nurse Facilitator group compared to 16% (10 of 64) in the provider/patient notification and 27% (14 of 51) in the control groups (P<0.001 for the comparisons between the nurse group and the other two groups). The proportion of patients on target beta-blocker doses at study end (median follow-up 12 months) was also highest in the nurse group (43%) compared to the control group (10%) and the provider/patient notification group ( 2%) (P<0.001). There were no differences in adverse events between groups. Conclusions - The use of a nurse practitioner was a successful approach to implementing a beta-blocker guideline in patients with heart failure. The use of provider education, clinical reminders, and patient education was of limited value in this situation.

title: Improving nurses' hand hygiene behavior through action planning: A pilot study in the intensive care unit and surgical ward
abstract: Adherence to hand hygiene guidelines by clinicians and nurses is generally low, and there is a need to apply effective intervention methods from the social sciences to improve compliance. One method is the formation of implementation intentions (or action plans), in which concrete “if-then” plans are formulated in order to link an eco-label with the implementation of an intended behavioral action. This pilot study examined the practicability and impact of action planning on hand hygiene behavior (HHB) of nurses in an intensive care unit and a surgical ward of a university teaching hospital. A pre-post test design was used and 17 nurses were invited to participate. A trained researcher observed HHB of caregivers before and three weeks after the intervention, in which action plans were formulated. Frequencies were calculated and logistic regression analysis was performed to assess changes in HHB. Of the 17 participants, 10 (seven in the surgical ward, three in the ICU) had complete data and were included in the analyses. A total of 283 potential hand hygiene moments were identified, 142 in the surgical ward and 141 in the intensive care unit. HHB increased from 9.3% at baseline to 25.4% after the intervention (odds ratio: 3.3 in; confidence interval: 1.7-6.5; P<0.001). Although the study was small, the results are promising for the use of action planning to improve nurses' HA in the short term. Action planning has proven successful in bridging the intention-behaviour gap in other areas, and its use to improve HA in healthcare should be further explored.

title: Improved handoff from ICU to ward medical teams with simple paperwork changes
abstract: Medical handover has been highlighted by the General Medical Council[1] as a critical step in patient care, ensuring continuity of care and patient safety, and enabling efficient multidisciplinary functioning. Handoff between critical care team physicians and ward teams at Great Western Hospital upon withdrawal was assessed by reviewing discharge reports and patient notes, and by following up discharged patients. Surrender was noted in only a minority of patients and was not documented in any. Easy changes to discharge papers to prompt and document who the transfer was made to, as well as free up space in the daily review sheets for patients to be completed pending transfer. The first audit results were presented at a local meeting to remind employees of the importance of the handover. These simple modifications brought handover rates up to 100% (n=12). Handover documentation rates also increased from 0% to 100%. This quality improvement project aims to show that carefully targeted, simple changes in practice in identified critical areas can produce dramatic, legally and ethically required results in a very short time.

title: Improving knowledge and behavior change towards guideline-based decisions in diabetes care: a controlled intervention study of a team-based learning approach to the continuous professional development of physicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: Continuing Professional Development (CPD) courses should ideally enhance a physician's knowledge and change their professional behavior in day-to-day practice towards a reference model for best clinical practice and adherence to guidelines. Interactive methods such as team-based learning and case-based learning can impart sustainable knowledge compared to lectures and lead to a high level of satisfaction among the participants. We developed an interactive case-based CPD diabetes care seminar using a team-based learning approach to assess whether it results in improvement in short-term knowledge and behavior change towards guideline-based decision-making and how this learning approach is perceived by participants. METHODS: Questionnaires and an electronic voting system were used to evaluate the motivation, acceptability, and knowledge of the volunteer participants. In addition, in a quasi-experimental design, we analyzed data on index diagnostic tests and referrals of patients with diabetes from participating physicians over a six-month period before and after the course compared to a matched control group. RESULTS: Participants (n=103) rated interactivity and team-based discussions as the main reasons for improved learning. They also expected that the course would change their professional behavior. Participants achieved an average of 43.9% correct answers before the course and 62.6% after the course (p<0.001). Referrals to diabetes specialists increased by 30.8% (p<0.001). Referral for fundoscopy also increased (8.5%, ns), while it decreased in the control group. In addition, participating physicians tested their patients more frequently for microalbuminuria (7.1%, ns). CONCLUSIONS: Our team-based CPD approach was very well received and resulted in an increase in short-term knowledge. It significantly increased referral to diabetes specialists in daily practice, while all other key indicators of professional behavior changed, but not significantly.

title: Improving laboratory monitoring at the start of drug therapy in outpatient care: a randomized study.
abstract: Background The importance of laboratory surveillance of medicinal products is reflected in product labeling and published guidelines, but surveillance recommendations are followed inconsistently. There is an opportunity to improve monitoring with the potential to reduce therapy complications. Methods The aim of this randomized study was to determine whether computerized alerts were effective in increasing the percentage of outpatients with laboratory monitoring at the start of drug therapy. Physicians and pharmacists have teamed up to develop organization-specific guidelines for monitoring selected medicines. Working with physicians, pharmacists were alerted to missing laboratory test results, ordered missing tests, reminded patients to take tests, assessed test completion, reviewed test results, and managed abnormal results. Eligible participants included patients among 400,000 health plan members who started therapy with any of the 15 drugs. Results In the intervention group, 79.1% (n = 4076"; 95% confidence interval [CI], 78.0% - 80.2%) of deliveries were monitored compared to 70.2% (n = 3522;" 95% CI, 68.9% - 71.5%) in the normal care group (p<0.001). For example, 78.6% of amiodarone delivery (95% CI, 73.1% - 83.5%) was monitored in the intervention group versus 51.4% (95% CI, 44.4% - 58.4%) in the group receiving usual care (P<0.001). Conclusions This study demonstrates the effectiveness of a computerized tool and collaboration between healthcare professionals in increasing the percentage of patients who receive laboratory monitoring at baseline. The coupling of data available from information systems with the knowledge and skills of physicians and pharmacists can lead to improved patient monitoring.

title: Improving mammography referral: a nurse-initiated intervention
abstract: We sought to improve our adherence to American Cancer Society (ACS) guidelines for mammography screening recommendations for eligible patients seen by primary care physicians by employing a multi-pronged intervention aimed at identifying To remove knowledge and behavioral barriers on the part of the residents. Copies of the ACS Cancer Screening Guidelines were posted in all exam and conference rooms and made available to all residents. The intervention to address the behavioral barriers consisted of three components: (1) identification by the nursing staff of eligible women who were overdue for a mammogram when presenting for treatment, (2) completion of a checklist by the residents indicating whether a mammography was or was not recommended and why, and (3) a nurse-initiated backup reminder system for patients who escaped the primary checklist system. A review of 200 preintervention and 270 postintervention charts showed statistically and clinically significant increases in recommended or performed mammograms. Similar statistically significant increases were found in a cohort of 111 patient records at both the pre- and post-intervention audits. The results indicate that an intervention to remove identified resident-dependent barriers to compliance with mammography screening guidelines can be effective in increasing recommended mammography rates.

title: Improving medication management in multimorbidity: Development of the Multimorbidity COllaborative Medication Review And Decision Making (MY COMRADE) intervention using the Behavior Change Wheel
abstract: BACKGROUND: Multimorbidity, the presence of two or more chronic conditions, affects over 60% of patients in primary care. Due to the association with polypharmacy, the focus is on the development of interventions to optimize medication management in patients with multimorbidity. The Behavior Change Wheel is a new approach to applying behavioral theory to intervention design. Here we describe how we used findings from a review of previous research, our own original research and the Behavior Change Wheel to develop an intervention to improve medication management in multimorbidity by General Practitioners (GPs) within the overarching UK Medical Research Council Guidance on complex interventions . METHODS: Following the behavior change wheel steps, we searched for behaviors related to medication management in multimorbidity by conducting a systematic review and a qualitative study of primary care physicians. From the identified modifiable behaviors of GPs, we selected one and performed a targeted behavioral analysis to explain why GPs did or did not exhibit this behavior. We used behavior analysis to determine the intervention features, behavior change techniques, and implementation plan most likely to produce behavior change. RESULTS: We identified numerous modifiable behaviors of primary care physicians in the systematic review and the qualitative study, from which active review of medication (rather than passive maintenance of the status quo) was selected as the target behavior. The behavioral analysis showed the abilities, possibilities and motivations of the general practitioners in relation to an active medication assessment. We combined the three intervention functions thought to be most likely to induce behavior change (empowerment, environmental restructuring, and incentives) to form the Multimorbidity Collaborative Medication Review And Decision Making (MY COMRADE) intervention. MY COMRADE is primarily about the technique of social support: two general practitioners jointly review the medications prescribed to a complex multimorbid patient. Four other behavior change techniques are integrated: social environment restructuring, prompts/cues, action planning, and self-incentives. CONCLUSIONS: This study is the first to use the Behavior Change Wheel to design an intervention targeting multimorbidity and validates the applicability and usefulness of the approach in a complex area of clinical care. The systematic development of the MY COMRADE intervention will facilitate a thorough assessment of its effectiveness in the next phase of this work.

title: Improving transitions in child and adolescent mental health care: a protocol for implementing and evaluating a clinical pathway for the emergency department
abstract: Background While the emergency department (ED) is often a first port of call for children and adolescents with mental health problems (MH), there is limited capacity in this setting to respond to MH needs. Children's MH schemes are typically spread across multiple ministries, organizations and providers. Communication between these groups is often poor, leading to gaps, particularly in the transition of care for this vulnerable population. The Evidence-Based Clinical Pathway for Mental Health in the Emergency Department (EDMHCP) was created with two main purposes: (1) to guide the risk assessment and disposition decision for children and adolescents presenting to the ED with concerns about MH, and (2) to a Streamlined transition to follow-up services with community MH agencies (CMHAs) and other providers. The purpose of this paper is to describe our study protocol to implement and evaluate the EDMHCP. Methods/Design This mixed-methods healthcare research project involves the implementation and evaluation of the EDMHCP in four exemplary ED-CMHA dyads. The Theoretical Domains Framework is used to develop a tailored intervention strategy to implement the EDMHCP. A multiple baseline study design and interrupted time series analysis are used to determine whether the EDMHCP improved health care utilization, medical management of MH problems, and health sector coordination. The primary process outcome is the proportion of patients with MH-specific recommendations documented in the medical record. The primary outcome of treatment is the proportion of patients who receive the EDMHCP-recommended follow-up at 24 hours or at 7 days. Data sources include qualitative interviews, audits of medical records, administrative databases, and patient surveys. A concurrent process assessment will be conducted to assess the degree of variability and accuracy in implementation at sites. Discussion This paper presents a novel model for measuring the effects of the EDMHCP. Our development process will identify how the EDMHCP is best implemented by partner organizations to provide evidence-based risk management for children and adolescents with MH concerns. More broadly, it will contribute to the evidence supporting implementation of the clinical pathway in novel partnerships.

title: Improving Opioid Safety Practices in Primary Care: Protocol for the Development and Evaluation of a Multifaceted, Theory-Driven Pilot Intervention for Healthcare Providers
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Drug overdose deaths are reaching unprecedented levels in North America, largely due to increases in prescription opioid-related deaths. Despite the development of several opioid guidelines, prescribing behavior still contributes to poor patient outcomes and societal harm. Factors at the provider and system level may impede or facilitate the use of evidence-based guidelines”; Interventions aimed at addressing such factors are needed. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Based on implementation science and behavior change theory, we planned to develop and evaluate a comprehensive opioid self-assessment package designed to increase compliance among primary care physicians with the Canadian Opioid Guideline. The intervention uses practical educational and self-assessment tools to provide prescribers with feedback on their current knowledge and practices, as well as resources to improve their practice. The assessment approach uses a pretest and posttest design and includes both quantitative and qualitative methods at baseline and at 6 months. We will recruit a targeted sample of approximately 10 Ontario primary care physicians from different practice settings who are currently treating patients on long-term opioid therapy for chronic pain. Quantitative data is analyzed using basic descriptive statistics, and qualitative data is analyzed using the framework method. ETHICS AND DISSEMINATION: The University Health Network Research Ethics Board approved this study. The dissemination plan will include publications, conference presentations and short reports from stakeholders. This evidence-based, theory-guided intervention has implications for the national use of tools to improve opioid quality in primary care. We engage experts and end users in advisory and stakeholder roles throughout our project to increase its national relevance, application and sustainability. The performance indicators could be used as a basis for health system quality improvement indicators to monitor opioid prescription. In addition, the methods and approaches used in this study could be adapted for other opioid guidelines or applied to other areas of healthcare and clinical guideline implementation processes.

title: Improving pediatric asthma outcomes in primary health care: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: AIM: To evaluate the effectiveness of the Practitioner Asthma Communication and Education (PACE) Australia program, an innovative communication and pediatric asthma management program for general practitioners. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: General practices from two regions in the greater Sydney area. PARTICIPANTS: 150 primary care physicians recruited between 2006 and 2008 and 221 children with asthma in their care. INTERVENTION: GPs in the intervention group participated in two 3-hour workshops focused on communication and education strategies to enable quality asthma care. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: Patient outcomes included receipt of a written asthma action plan (WAAP), appropriate medication intake, parents' days off work, and children's days absent from school or childcare. GP outcomes included frequency of providing a WAAP and patient education, communication and teaching behaviors, and adherence to national asthma guidelines regarding medication use. RESULTS: More primary care physician patients in the intervention group reported receiving a WAAP (difference, 15%; 95% CI, 2% to 28%; adjusted P=0.046). In the intervention group, children with infrequent intermittent asthma symptoms had less use of inhaled corticosteroids (difference 24%; 95% CI -43% to -5%; P=0.03) and long-acting bronchodilators (difference 19%; 95% CI -34% to -5%; P=0.02).GPs in the intervention group were more confident in communicating with patients (difference 22%; 95% CI, 3% to 40%; P=0.03). A higher proportion of primary care physicians in the intervention group reported providing a WAAP more than 70% of the time (difference, 23%; 95% CI, 11% to 36%; adjusted P=0.002) and prescribing spacers more than 90% of the time (difference, 29%; 95% CI, 16% to 42%;" adjusted P=0.02). CONCLUSIONS: The PACE Australia program improved primary care physicians' asthma management practices and led to improvements in some important patient outcomes TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry ACTRN12607000067471.

title: Improving patient care through medical image perception research
abstract: Interpreting medical images across medical specialties is critical to patient care. Healthcare is changing as technology evolves, and clinicians are now increasingly viewing medical images in a variety of settings. Although access to such data is useful, even physicians experienced in interpreting images make mistakes. These errors can become more common as the doctor's work days increase and the number of images to be interpreted increases. To avoid errors in interpreting medical images, we need to understand the underlying perceptual and cognitive mechanisms that guide image interpretation. We can then use what we learn to develop better training methods, automated image analysis, and processing tools. We can develop methods to reduce clinical staff fatigue and stress and develop practice guidelines, thereby improving patient care and outcomes.

title: Improving patient discharge and reducing hospital readmissions using intervention mapping
abstract: Background There is a growing impetus to reorganize the hospital discharge process to reduce avoidable readmissions and costs. The aim of this study was to provide insight into hospital discharge problems and underlying causes, and to provide an overview of solutions that guide providers and policy makers in improving hospital discharge. Methods The Intervention Mapping Framework was used. First, a problem analysis was conducted that examined the extent, causes, and consequences of ineffective hospital discharge. The analysis was based on primary data from 26 focus group interviews and 321 individual interviews with patients and families and involved hospital and community care providers. Second, improvements were specified in terms of intervention outcomes, performance goals, and change goals. Third, 220 experts were consulted and a systematic review of effective mitigation measures was conducted to select theory-based methods and practical strategies needed to achieve change and better performance. Results Ineffective discharge is related to factors at the level of the individual provider, the patient, the relationship between providers, and organizational and technical support to providers. Providers can reduce readmission rates and hospital adverse events by focusing on quality discharge information, well-coordinated care, and direct and timely communication with their colleagues. Patients or their caregivers should participate in the discharge process and be aware of their medical condition and treatment. Assessments by hospital providers of whether discharge information is accurate and understood by patients and their peers in the community are important examples of overcoming identified barriers to effective discharge. Discharge templates, medication coordination, a liaison nurse or pharmacist, regular site visits, and teach-back are identified as effective and promising strategies to achieve the desired behavioral and environmental change. Conclusions This study provides a comprehensive framework of guidance for providers and policy makers to improve patient transfer from hospital to primary care.

title: Improving physician compliance with preventive medicine guidelines
abstract: Similar general practice outpatient clinics with randomized patients were used to evaluate the effectiveness of a program designed to increase domestic staff compliance with preventive medicine guidelines. Two clinics were designated as experimental and two served as controls. In the experimental clinics, age-specific checklists of all recommended preventive measures (taken from the Canadian Task Force report on The Periodic Health Examination and American Cancer Society guidelines) were attached to each patient's medical record. In addition, House Officers were introduced to a series of weekly seminars addressing screening issues as well as the specific recommendations contained in the checklist. In all four clinics, the general practitioners were tested for their knowledge and attitude towards the prevention program before and after the intervention. The number of immunizations and mammograms performed and the total populations eligible for these procedures were determined for all four clinics. As predicted, test results, mammography and vaccination rates increased significantly (from 2 to 40 percent) in the intervention centers compared to controls. We conclude that this intervention was clearly effective in the short term. However, follow-up studies are needed to determine whether the desired long-term effect has been achieved.

title: Improving population-based cervical cancer screening in general practice: Effects of a national strategy
abstract: AIM: To assess the impact of a Dutch national prevention program aimed at general practitioners (GPs) on compliance with organizational guidelines for effective early detection of cervical cancer in general practice. Identify the characteristics of general practice that are critical to success. DESIGN: A prospective questionnaire study with pre- and post-measurement (before and 15 months after the introduction of the national program). SETTINGS AND STUDY PARTICIPANTS: A random sample of one third of all 4758 Dutch GP practices. One family doctor per practice was asked to participate. INTERVENTION: A national primary care physician prevention program to improve population-based cervical cancer prevention, combining different methods for quality improvement in primary care and implemented at national, district and practice levels. Outreach visitors were a key strategy to bring about behavior change. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: The proportion of practices that adhere to 10 recommendations (in four guidelines) for organizing effective cervical cancer screening. RESULTS: After 15 months, all Dutch practices showed a significant improvement in adhering to nine out of ten recommendations. Two recommendations, specifically "identify women who should be medically excluded from screening" and "send a reminder to non-compliers," showed the largest absolute increases of 26% and 33%, respectively. In addition to more intensive care for visiting visitors, practice features such as "computerisation" and "delegation of many clinical tasks to the practice assistant" were important in order to improve compliance with the guidelines. CONCLUSION: The national program with a combination of different quality improvement methods proved effective to improve the organization of cervical screening in general practice. The computerization and, to a lesser extent, the delegation of many clinical tasks to the practice assistant and the increased supervision of the practices had a positive impact on the effectiveness of the national programme.

title: Improving prescribing patterns for older people through an online drug use review intervention
abstract: Context: Pharmacotherapy is among the most effective interventions for improving health outcomes in older people. However, because some medications are less appropriate for older patients, systems approaches to improving pharmacy care can be an effective way to reduce inappropriate medication use. Aim: To determine whether a computerized drug use review (DUR) database linked to telepharmaceutical intervention can improve suboptimal drug use in the elderly. Design.—Population-based cohort design, April 1, 1996 to March 31, 1997. Setting.—Outpatient care. Patients.— A total of 23,269 patients 65 years of age and older in the United States who received prescription drug benefits from a major pharmaceutical benefits administrator during a 12-month period. Intervention. â€”Assessment of providers who prescribe via an online computerized DUR database using explicit criteria to identify potentially inappropriate drug use among older people. Computer alarms triggered telephone calls from geriatrically trained pharmacists to physicians, during which principles of geriatric pharmacology and therapeutic substitution options were discussed. main target parameter. – Rate of contact with physicians and rate of change to the proposed drug regimen. Results.— A total of 43007 alerts were triggered. From a total of 43,007 telepharmacy calls generated by the alerts, we were able to reach 19,368 physicians for 24,266 alerts (56%). The rate of switching to a more appropriate therapeutic was 24% (5860), but ranged from 40% for long-term benzodiazepines to 2% to 7% for drugs that were theoretically contraindicated based on patient self-report. With the exception of the rate of change of beta-blockers in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, all rates of change were significantly greater than the expected rate of change of 2% from baseline. Conclusions: Using a system that integrates computers, pharmacists, and physicians, our large-scale intervention improved prescribing patterns and quality of care, thus providing a population-based approach to advancing geriatric clinical pharmacology. Future research should focus on demonstrating improved health outcomes that result from improved prescribing options for older people.

title: Improving quality improvement through achievable physician feedback benchmarks: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Context Performance feedback and benchmarking, common tools for improving healthcare, are rarely explored in randomized trials. Achievable Benchmarks of Care (ABCs) are standards of excellence achieved by high performers in a peer group and are easily and reproducibly calculated from existing performance data. Aim To evaluate the effectiveness of using achievable benchmarks to improve typical physician performance feedback and improve care. Design Group randomized controlled trial conducted in December 1996 with follow-up to 1998. Setting and Participants Seventy physicians in private practice and 2978 Medicare patients with fee-paying diabetes mellitus participating in the Ambulatory Care Quality Improvement Project in Alabama. Intervention Physicians were randomized to receive a multimodal enhancement intervention including a table review and physician-specific feedback (comparative group; n=35) or an identical intervention plus achievable benchmark feedback (experimental group; n=35). Key Outcome Measure Preintervention (1994-1995) to Postintervention (1997-1998) Changes in the proportion of patients who received influenza vaccination; foot exam;" and each of 3 blood tests measuring glucose control, cholesterol levels, and triglyceride levels compared between the 2 groups. Results The proportion of patients who received an influenza vaccine improved from 40% to 58% in the experimental group (p<0.001) versus from 40% to 46% in the comparator group (p=0.02) The odds ratios (ORs) for patients of accessible comparators vs. comparators who received appropriate care after the intervention adjusted for the preinterventional care and the nesting of patients with physicians, were 1.57 (95% confidence interval [CI], 1.26-1.96) for influenza vaccination, 1.33 (95% CI, 1.05-1.69) for foot examination and 1.33 (95% CI, 1.04-1.69) for long-term glucose monitoring For serum cholesterol and triglycerides, the achievable benchmark effect was statistically significant only after additional adjustment for physician characteristics (OR, 1.40 [95% CI, 1.08-1.82] and OR, 1.40 [95% CI, 1.09-1.79]), respectively. Conclusion The use of achievable benchmarks significantly increases the effectiveness of physician performance feedback as part of a multimodal quality improvement intervention.

title: Improving the quality of delirium care in a general practice service with established interdisciplinary care: a controlled study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines have been developed to improve the screening, prevention, and management of delirium. OBJECTIVES: Implement delirium guidelines in general practitioner patients to reduce the frequency and duration of delirium and improve outcomes in patients with delirium. METHODS: The implementation was managed by a multidisciplinary team of clinicians and project staff in a medical ward. The evaluation was conducted as a controlled study in patients 65 years of age or older with/at risk of delirium compared to a medical control unit. Interventions included risk screening, delirium detection, multidisciplinary education, ward modifications including a four-bed delirium ward, behavioral and medication protocols, and the use of nursing assistants and volunteers. The primary endpoints were incidence and duration of delirium";" secondary endpoints were length of stay, mortality, falls, and discharge target in the delirious subgroup. Trial measures included station transfers, use of neuroleptics, Allied health screening, and use of Delirium Bay. RESULTS: Of 206 consenting elderly medical patients, 22% were delirious on admission and 44% were at risk. No cases of delirium were identified. In the delirious subgroup, significantly fewer intervention participants were discharged with persistent delirium (32% vs. 71%, P=0.016), with trends for reduced inpatient mortality (0% vs. 18.5%, P=0.07) and falls ( 11% vs. 22%, P=0.16), at the expense of a longer hospital stay (16 days vs. 8 days, P=0.01). CONCLUSIONS: The low incidence of new delirium may reflect the established interdisciplinary care setting. The improved outcomes in the delirious group are encouraging, although implementation has been costly, including longer length of stay in the acute care unit.

title: Improving resident compliance with community care standards: Findings from the VA Cooperative Study on Computerized Reminders.
abstract: Context Computerized systems for reminding physicians to provide appropriate care have not been extensively evaluated in a large number of patients in multiple clinical settings. Aim To study whether a computerized reminder system operated in several Veterans Affairs (VA) outpatient clinics improves the resident physician's adherence to standards of outpatient care. Design, Setting and Participants A total of 275 resident physicians at 12 VA clinics were randomly assigned to either a memory group (n = 132) or a control group (n = 143) in companies or half-day clinic blocks. During a 17-month study period (January 31, 1995–June 30, 1996), the residents attended 12,989 individual patients for whom at least one of the standards of care (SOC) studied was applicable. Main outcome measure Adherence to 13 SOCs, tracked using hospital databases and resident-completed encounter forms, compared between residents in the memory group and those in the control group. Results When compliance was measured as the proportion of patients who met all applicable SOCs up to their last visit during the study period, the reminder group had statistically significantly higher compliance rates than the control group for all standards combined (58.8% vs. 53, 5%; odds ratio [OR] 1.24; 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.08-1.42; P = 0.002) and for 5 of the 13 standards examined individually, measuring compliance as a proportion of all visits for which at which residents had care indicated With proper care, the reminder group also had statistically significantly higher compliance rates than the control group for all standards combined (17.9% vs. 12.2%; OR, 1.57; 95% CI, 1.45 -1.71; "p < 0.001) and examined individually for 9 of the 13 standards. However, the usefulness of reminders decreased over the course of the study, although the reminders remained active. Conclusions Our data show that reminder systems installed at multiple sites can improve residents' compliance with multiple SOCs. However, the benefits of such systems seem to diminish over time. Future research must explore methods to better sustain the benefits of memories.

title: Improving Smoking Cessation Counseling Using a Point-of-Care Health Intervention (IT) Tool: from the Virginia Practice Support and Research Network (VaPSRN)
abstract: PURPOSE: Primary care physician offices are an ideal place to reduce national smoking rates, as >70% of smokers visit their physicians annually, yet patients receive inconsistent smoking cessation counseling. We designed and built a novel handheld computer software program and hypothesized that it would improve physicians' ability to provide patient-specific smoking cessation counseling at the point-of-care. METHODS: A handheld computer software program was created based on smoking cessation guidelines and an adaptation of widely accepted behavior modification theories. The tool was evaluated using a validated before/after survey to measure physician smoking cessation counseling behavior, knowledge, and well-being/self-efficacy. RESULTS: Participants included 17 physicians (mean age 41 years; 71% male; 5 resident physicians) from a practice-based research network. After 4 months of use in direct patient care, physicians were more likely to advise patients to quit smoking (P=0.049) and reported an increase in the use of "5 As" (P=0.03). Improved self-efficacy in counseling patients about smoking cessation (P=0.006) was observed, as was increased comfort in providing patient follow-up care (P=0.04). CONCLUSIONS: The use of a portable computer software tool improved smoking cessation counseling among physicians and shows promise for translating findings on smoking cessation counseling into practice and educational settings.

title: Improving testing design in primary care: The added value of a small group quality improvement strategy compared to classical feedback
abstract: PURPOSE: We wanted to evaluate the value of small peer group quality improvement meetings versus simple feedback as a strategy to improve test ordering behavior. The number of tests ordered by GPs is increasing, and many of these tests appear to be unnecessary according to established, evidence-based guidelines. Methods: We recruited 194 general practitioners from 27 local general practices in 5 health regions (5 diagnostic centers). The study was a cluster-randomized study with randomization at the local physician group level. We evaluated an innovative, multifaceted strategy that combines written comparative feedback, group instruction on national guidelines, and peer social influence in small-group quality improvement sessions. The strategy targeted 3 specific clinical themes: cardiovascular problems, upper abdominal disorders and lower abdominal disorders. The mean number of tests per physician every 6 months at baseline and the physician's region were used as the independent variables, and the mean number of tests per physician every 6 months was the dependent variable. RESULTS: The new strategy was implemented in 13 primary care groups, while 14 groups received feedback only. For all 3 clinical subjects, the decrease in the mean number of physician-ordered tests in the intervention arm was significantly larger (an average of 51 fewer tests per physician per semester) than the decrease in the mean number of physician-ordered tests in the intervention arm and the feedback arm (P=0.005). Five tests considered inappropriate for the clinical problem of upper abdominal discomfort decreased in the intervention arm, with physicians ordering 13 more tests per 6 months in the feedback arm (p=0.002). The interdoc variation in the test arrangement decreased more in the intervention arm. CONCLUSIONS: Compared to simply disseminating comparative feedback reports to GPs, the new strategy of incorporating peer interaction and social influence improved physicians' test-ordering behavior. To be effective, feedback must be integrated into an interactive, educational environment.

title: Improving the use of a practice guideline for the assessment and treatment of suicidal behavior by training all staff in psychiatric departments via an e-learning-based train-the-trainer program: study protocol for a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: In 2012, a multidisciplinary practice guideline for the assessment and treatment of suicidal behavior was issued in the Netherlands. The publication of guidelines often does not lead to a change in professional behavior due to several barriers. Structured implementation can improve compliance. This article describes the design of a study that measures the impact of an e-learning-based train-the-trainer program aimed at training all departmental staff in the use of the guideline. We anticipate that both professionals and departments will benefit from the program. METHOD: In a multicentre, randomized, controlled cluster study, 43 psychiatric departments spread across 10 regional psychiatric facilities in the Netherlands are clustered in pairs with respect to the most common diagnostic category of patients and the mean length of treatment. Pair members are randomly assigned to either the experimental or control condition. In the experimental state, the entire staff of the specialist departments, i.e. all registered nurses, psychologists, doctors and psychiatrists (n = 532, 21 specialist departments) are trained in the application of the guideline in a one-day, interactive small group -the-trainer-program. The program is supported by a 60-minute e-learning module with video vignettes of suicidal patients and additional instructions. In the control situation (22 departments, 404 professionals), the guideline aims to be disseminated in the traditional way: through manuals, books, conferences, internet, reviews, etc. The effectiveness of the program will be evaluated at both health professional and department level. DISCUSSION: Our goal is to demonstrate the effect of training all department staff with an e-learning-based train-the-trainer program in the application of a new clinical guideline.
