Strengths of the study are the natural setting, the training of all staff, the random assignment to the conditions, the large scope of the study, and the willingness of both staff and management to participate in the study. STUDY REGISTRATION: Dutch Study Register: NTR3092.

title: Improving the adequacy of antimicrobial use in primary care following the introduction of local antimicrobial guidance at both levels of care
abstract: Aim This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of multiple interventions implemented during the implementation of a guide to improve the adequacy of antimicrobial prescribing in primary care. Design This is a before and after cross-sectional study conducted in the Aljarafe healthcare area (Andalusia, Spain) with a population of 368,728 residents served in 37 healthcare centers. Subjects Subjects include patients with antibiotic prescriptions in 2009 (pre-intervention phase) or 2012 (post-intervention phase), selected by simple random sampling (95% confidence level; 5% accuracy), with infections registered in the electronic medical history. Interventions This study includes training in primary care centers and hospital services, integration of the electronic guide to health services websites, and integration of the digital medical history guide as a decision support tool. Main outcome The study revealed a difference in the appropriate prescribing of antibiotics before and after surgery. Other variables also include age, gender, type of pharmacy, antibiotic prescribed, number of treatments per year, site of infection, and major comorbidities. Sources In addition, this study used computerized pharmacy records of reimbursed and dispensed drugs and electronic medical histories. Results The percentage of appropriate antibiotic prescriptions increased from 36% in 2009 to 57% in 2012 (p?<?0.001). Improvement was observed in patients of all ages and genders and was greater in patients of working age and those with comorbidities. The best results were observed in the beta-lactam group and in the treatment of respiratory and skin infections. Conclusion Implementing multifactorial interventions involving professionals from both levels of care could be an effective strategy to improve antimicrobial use in primary care.

title: Improving the care of people with acute low back pain by healthcare professionals (the ALIGN study): A cluster-randomized study protocol
abstract: Background In many areas of healthcare, there are differences between the recommendations of clinical practice guidelines and actual clinical practice. A 2004 systematic review examining the effectiveness of interventions to promote guideline implementation concluded that there was a lack of evidence to support decisions about effective interventions to promote guideline implementation. In addition, the review recommended the use of theory in developing implementation measures. In Australia (2003) a clinical practice guideline for the management of acute back pain was developed. Acute low back pain is a common condition, has a high burden, and there is some evidence of an evidence-practice gap in the related health environment. This provides an opportunity to design and test a theory-based implementation intervention that, if effective, may bring benefits to patients with this condition. Aims This study aims to assess the effectiveness of a theory-based intervention to increase the compliance of alternative practitioners (physiotherapists and chiropractors in Victoria, Australia) with a clinical practice guideline for acute non-specific low back pain (LBP) compared to providing practitioners with a printed copy the guideline. Specifically, our primary goal is to determine whether the intervention is effective in reducing the percentage of acute nonspecific LBP patients who are either referred or X-rayed and in improving the mean degree of disability for patients three months after onset of acute LBP . Methods The study design is a cluster-randomized study. Using limited randomization, 210 practices (clusters) were assigned to an intervention or control group. Practitioners in the control group received a printed copy of the guideline. Practitioners in the intervention group received a theory-based intervention designed to address prospectively identified barriers to practitioner adherence to the guideline. The intervention consisted primarily of an educational symposium. Patients 18 years and older who visit a participating physician for acute non-specific LBP of less than three months duration over a two-week data collection period, three months after the intervention symposia, are eligible for enrollment. Sample size calculations are based on enrolling 15 to 40 patients per practice. Outcome raters are blinded to group assignment.

title: Improving hypertension management in Kazakhstan: Implications for improving clinical practice, patient behavior and health outcomes
abstract: This paper presents results from the evaluation of a strategy aimed at improving case finding and management of hypertensive patients. Study results suggest that aligning providers with clinical guidelines, public information about hypertension risks, encouraging annual blood pressure screening, and universal access to an outpatient medication package improve case finding and management. Additionally, training providers at pilot sites resulted in a substantial and significant difference in patient care and health outcomes. Training and tools for providers, specifically focused on effective patient counseling, made a significant contribution to improved case finding, patient adherence to prescribed medications, less salt and more regular exercise. However, further refinement is needed to achieve the expected patient adherence to medication and lifestyle advice. In the pilot area, we compared two samples of patients before and after the start of the intervention. We found an increase in the proportion of patients with blood pressure or =160/100 mmHg. The strategy included the joint efforts of the Research Institute of Cardiology and Internal Diseases, Drug Information Center of Karaganda, Karaganda Oblast Health Department, Kazakh Association of General Practitioners, Almaty Postgraduate Institute for Physicians and USAID ZdravPlus project in Central Asia.

title: Improving bipolar disorder outcome through non-pharmacological strategies: the role of psychoeducation
abstract: The present work deals with the effectiveness of psychoeducation and related strategies in bipolar disorders. Recently, several randomized clinical trials have demonstrated the effectiveness of psychological interventions as a prophylactic adjunct to medication, namely identification of prodromal signs, cognitive-behavioral therapy, psychoeducation, and family-centered interventions. All of these studies are presented here along with the pioneering studies in this field. There are several themes that any psychoeducational program should contain to ensure its usefulness and they are summarized in twelve points. Broadly speaking, psychoeducation should include general information about bipolar disorder, elements of compliance improvement, instruction in early detection of relapse, and lifestyle regularity issues. Today, several treatment guidelines include psychoeducation as a crucial prophylactic tool. Clinicians should be aware of this and start implementing psychoeducation in their daily clinical practice.

title: Improving the success of postal intervention programs to influence prescribing behavior: a review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Educational interventions have long been used as a means of influencing prescribing behavior. Various techniques, including educational mailings, scientific detailing, feedback from prescribers with or without disclosure of patient identification data, and supplemental patient information, have been used to encourage appropriate prescribing habits, reduce costs, and optimize patient care. While the effects of educational intervention programs are well reported, little information is available on the effectiveness of various intervention techniques by mail. OBJECTIVE: To review the effectiveness of intervention programs by mail and identify factors that may promote successful outcomes. METHODS: A literature search was conducted via PubMed for reports of mailed intervention programs published up to May 2012. Specific search terms included Drug Usage Review, Drug Usage, Medicaid, Prescribing Feedback, Mailed Doctor Intervention, and Mailed Doctor Notices. Identified publications that met the following criteria were selected for inclusion: (a) evaluated printed educational materials distributed by mail, (b) occurred in an outpatient setting, and (c) measured impact of the intervention on patterns of prescribing, utilization of health care or profitability results. Publications that met all three criteria were abstracted by intervention strategy, follow-up period, data source, intervention goal, prescriber acceptance of the intervention, and impact on prescribing patterns, health care utilization, and economic outcomes. RESULTS: A total of 40 published reports on 39 unique interventions met the inclusion criteria. The majority (34/39 [87.2%]) of studies were conducted in state or federally funded programs; only 5 programs involved private insurers. All programs used follow-up periods of </= 12 months after dispatch of the final intervention. A total of 26 of the 39 unique interventions reported a positive effect on at least 1 outcome. Programs that included a second recipient such as a pharmacist (n=4) reported a greater effect compared to interventions mailed only to prescribing physicians. Identification data had a higher success rate than those providing prescribing feedback and/or educational materials (21/25 [84.0%] vs. 5/14 [35.7%]); it should be noted that 2 of the 5 successful programs that provided non-patient identifying materials also used academic detail. Programs that sent educational materials and/or feedback from prescribers on multiple drug classes or disease states had minimal impact on prescribing patterns (n = 4). ic disease or medication supported by appropriate evidence produced a favorable change in a short period of time. In addition, providing recommendations supported by commonly accepted clinical guidelines or literature was also associated with a high success rate. A subset of programs designed to assess health care utilization (n=5) and economic impact (n=9) observed little change in measured outcomes. Analysis of prescriber response sheets conducted by 7 programs found that changes in therapy occurred in approximately 50% of patients with prescribers who intended to accept intervention recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: Although the degree of heterogeneity between articles prevents the provision of unequivocal results, it appears that a well-designed post-intervention program has the potential to evoke significant changes in prescribing patterns. Prescribers appear receptive to mail-in interventions;' however, there is limited data to determine the association between acceptance and actual prescription change. Future research should focus on identifying barriers that may prevent acceptance of recommendations from leading to changes in therapy. Projects should include longer evaluation periods to assess the duration of action after the final intervention has been dispatched and the potential impact on healthcare and patient outcomes determine economic outcomes.

title: Improving the use of early follow-up after emergency room visits. A randomized study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To test the hypothesis that the adequacy of parents' uptake of early follow-up after emergency department (ED) visits can be improved by post-visit support from a nurse. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial, single blinded. SETTING: Urban University Hospital ED connected to the hospital's primary care center. PARTICIPANTS: Parents of 190 children less than 8 years of age treated for acute illness in the emergency department who, at the discretion of the emergency department clinicians, were treated as outpatients with follow-up at the primary care center. INTERVENTION: Parents in the experimental group were called by a caregiver who offered both individualized follow-up guidance and access to a caregiver for further assistance if needed. The control group received “usual” follow-up counseling during ED visits. MEASUREMENTS/MAIN RESULTS: In the week following the ED visits, parents in the experimental group were more compliant with follow-up instructions (79% vs. 61%) and less likely to miss appointments compared to parents in the control group ( 15% vs. 31%), and less likely to 'shop' elsewhere for care (2% vs. 9%). The adequacy of follow-up care was assessed in a 'blind' manner against pre-established guidelines. Inappropriate use of aftercare was significantly reduced in subjects in the experimental group (10% vs. 20%). CONCLUSION: Nurse practitioner intervention improved follow-up utilization by parents in our sample. Overall care for episodic ED users could be improved through similar interventions.

title: In the tepid defense of public health: doctors and antibiotic resistance
abstract: Antimicrobial resistance threatens populations as a serious public health threat and a costly social problem. Recent proposals to tackle antimicrobial resistance have focused heavily on supply-side approaches. Suggestions include playing around with patent rights so drug companies have more incentive to discover new antibiotics and resist overselling of their newer drugs already on the market. Unfortunately, this article argues that a primarily supply-side emphasis distracts attention from the important demand-side influences of physicians. Physicians have an important and indispensable task to ensure optimal social access to antibiotics. Worryingly, doctors' management of antibiotic supplies has been poor and their defense of public health lukewarm at best. Acting as a prudent steward of antibiotic supplies often seems at odds with a physician's commonly understood fiduciary duties, ethical obligations, and professional standards, all of which traditionally emphasize the individual health paradigm as opposed to responsibility for the health of the community. Meanwhile, physicians face limited incentives to retain antibiotics from other sources, such as B. liability for medical malpractice, regulatory standards and reimbursement systems. While multiple efforts are required to effectively combat antimicrobial resistance, physician gatekeeping behavior should become a priority. This article examines how public health laws and policy instruments could positively change the incentives for physicians to conserve antibiotics. A clear lesson from recent managed care reform struggles is that, for interventions to have the best chance of success, they must respect physicians' interest in clinical autonomy and individualized medicine, even if, somewhat paradoxically, public health perspectives are vigorously promoted . In addition, the legal and ethical responsibilities of physicians related to antibiotics need to be redesigned to better support gatekeeping to protect public health. The main recommendation is to increase the use of financial incentives to reward physicians for adhering to recommended antibiotic prescribing guidelines. While not a panacea, greater experimentation with financial incentives may provide a much-needed boost to physician interest in antibiotic preservation and is probably the best way to address physicians' legitimate concerns about clinical autonomy.

title: For treatment-resistant depression, adding cognitive behavioral therapy to usual care was cost-effective at 1 year
abstract: Question Is adding individual cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) to usual care cost-effective for primary care patients with treatment-resistant depression? Methods Design Cost-benefit analysis from a UK National Health Service (NHS) and Personal Social Services (PSS) perspective, based on a one-year follow-up of a randomized controlled trial (CoBalT trial). Setting up primary care practices in Bristol, Exeter and Glasgow, UK. Patients 469 patients aged 18 to 75 years (mean age 50 years, 72% females) who were on antidepressants for 6 weeks but persisted with depressive symptoms, who were diagnosed with depression using the revised clinical interview schedule and had a Beck Depression Inventory (BDI)-II score ¡Ã 14. Intervention Individual CBT, 12 to 18 one-hour sessions, conducted in general practitioner offices or similar settings, plus usual care (n = 234) or usual care alone (n = 235). Usual treatment might include antidepressants. Outcomes Treatment response (¡Ã50% reduction in BDI-II score)"; Quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), based on EQ-5D-3L scores and quality of life assessments from the UK general population; Cost in 2010 pounds sterling Sterling {UK Â¡Ãª1 = US $1.56}*;" and incremental cost-benefit ratio (ICER). Costs included NHS and PSS costs derived from primary care records, CBT therapist records and patient questionnaires. Follow-up was 83% to 84% for clinical outcomes and 78% for health and social costs at one year. Main Findings Adding CBT to usual care reduced symptoms of depression and increased QALYs (table). CBT plus usual care costs more than usual care alone (table), with an ICER of Â¡Ãª14,911 (US$23,261) per QALY gained over 12 months. In sensitivity analyzes using the short-form 6-dimensional algorithm to estimate QALYs, the ICER was 29,626 (US$46,217). Conclusion In primary care patients with treatment-resistant depression in the UK, adding cognitive behavioral therapy to usual care was cost-effective at 1 year.

title: Inclusion and exclusion criteria in randomized controlled trials on psychotherapy in PTSD
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a widespread and often disabling condition. Fortunately, effective psychological treatments for PTSD are available. However, research shows that these treatments may be underused in clinical practice. One reason for this underutilization could be the unjustified exclusion of patients from these treatments by physicians based on their understanding of the exclusion criteria used in clinical trials of psychological treatments for PTSD. There is no comprehensive and up-to-date review of the inclusion and exclusion criteria used in randomized clinical trials (RCTs) of the psychological treatment of PTSD. Therefore, our goal was to better understand how patients were excluded from such RCTs in order to provide clinicians with guidance on which clinical populations are likely to benefit from these treatments. METHODS: We conducted a comprehensive literature search of RCTs on psychological treatments for PTSD from January 1, 1980 to April 1, 2012. We categorized these clinical trials according to the types of psychotherapy discussed in major PTSD treatment guidelines and reviewed all treatments reviewed in at least two RCTs (N=64 published trials with 75 intervention arms, as some trials have two or more interventions compared). We have abstracted and tabulated information on exclusion criteria for each type of psychotherapy for PTSD. RESULTS: We identified multiple RCTs on cognitive behavioral therapy (n=56), eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (n=11), and group psychotherapy (n=8) for PTSD. The most common exclusions were psychosis, substance abuse and addiction, bipolar disorder, and suicidal ideation. Clinical trials varied in how rigorously these criteria were applied. It is important to note that no exclusion criterion was used in any of the studies and that there was at least one study of each type of therapy that included patients from each of the commonly excluded groups. Evidence is limited for treating patients with PTSD and four comorbidities: alcohol and drug abuse or dependence at current use, current psychosis, current mania, and current suicidal ideation. CONCLUSIONS: Psychological treatments for PTSD have been studied in broad and representative clinical populations. It appears that more generous use of these treatments is warranted regardless of comorbidities.

title: INCOG Recommendations for the Management of Cognition after Traumatic Brain Injury, Part III: Executive Function and Self-Awareness
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) results in complex cognitive (and other) consequences. Impairments in executive function and self-esteem are among the most characteristic neurobehavioral sequelae and can have profound implications for resuming previous life roles. An international group of researchers and clinicians (known as INCOG) came together to develop recommendations for interventions to improve impairments in executive function and self-esteem after TBI. METHODS: The team reviewed the available literature and ensured that the recommendations were up to date. To encourage implementation, the team developed decision-making algorithms that incorporate the recommendations based on the inclusion and exclusion criteria of published studies. The team then prioritized the recommendations for implementation and developed test criteria to assess compliance with best practice recommendations. RESULTS: Intervention programs that include metacognitive strategy instructions for planning, problem solving, and other cognitive-executive impairments have a solid evidence base. New findings support the use of strategies for the targeted improvement of logical skills. There is significant support for using direct corrective feedback to improve self-awareness. CONCLUSIONS: A growing number of scientifically well-designed studies are available demonstrating the effectiveness of a variety of interventions in resolving impairments in executive function and self-esteem after TBI.

title: Increasing Compliance with an Antibiotic Prophylactic Policy to Prevent Infection at Pediatric Surgical Sites: Before and After the Study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate an intervention to improve adherence to antibiotic prophylaxis (AP) guidelines to prevent postoperative wound infections in children. BACKGROUND: Although adequate AP reduces surgical site infections and guidelines improve the quality of care, changing practice is difficult. To enable behavior change, several barriers need to be addressed. METHODS: A multidisciplinary task force at a children's hospital developed an evidence-based AP guideline. Subsequently, the guideline was posted in operating rooms and the online form, only recommended antibiotics were available in operating rooms, incoming trainees were given orientation, antibiotic verification was included in time-out, computerized alerts were set up for inappropriate postoperative prophylaxis, and surgeons were given z -Mails when policy has not been followed. AP indication and administration were documented for surgical procedures in July 2008 (preintervention), September 2011 (postintervention) and April-May 2013 (follow-up). Compliance was defined as complete - appropriate antibiotic, dose, timing, re-dosing and duration when prophylaxis was indicated; partially - appropriate drug and timing when prophylaxis was indicated; and appropriate use - complete compliance when prophylaxis indicated, no antibiotics when not indicated Pre- and post-procedure compliance was compared with Chi(2) tests RESULTS: AP was 43.9% (187/426) and 62, 0% (124/200) of surgical procedures indicated before and after surgery There were significant improvements in appropriate antibiotic use (51.6% - 67.0%; P<0.001), more complete (26.2% - 53.2 %; P < 0.001) and partial compliance (73.3% - 88.7%, P = 0.001), correct dosing (77.5% - 90.7%; P = 0.003), timing (83.3% - 95.8%; p=0.001), re-dosing (62.5%-95.8%, p=0.003), and duration (47.1%-65.3%);" P<0.002). CONCLUSIONS: A multifaceted intervention improved compliance with a pediatric AP guideline.

title: Increasing compliance in low tidal volume ventilation in the ICU with two nudge-based interventions: Assessed by intervention time series analyses
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Low tidal volume ventilation (TVe) improves outcomes in ventilated patients and the majority of clinicians report using it. Unfortunately, most patients never get low TVs. “Nudges” influence decision-making with subtle cognitive mechanisms and are effective in many contexts. There are few studies that have examined its impact on clinical decision making. We examined the impact of 2 interventions designed according to behavioral science principles on the use of low-TVe ventilation in the intensive care unit (ICU). SETTING: University Hospitals Bristol, a 20-bed tertiary, mixed medical and surgical intensive care unit that welcomes over 1300 patients per year. PARTICIPANTS: Data were collected from 2144 consecutive patients who received controlled mechanical ventilation for more than 1 hour between October 2010 and September 2014. Patients on controlled mechanical ventilation for more than 20 hours were included in the final analysis. ACTIONS: (1) Default ventilator settings were adjusted to meet low TVe targets from the start of ventilation unless actively changed by a clinician. (2) A large dashboard was provided showing TVs in ml/kg ideal body weight (IBW) format with warnings when TVs were too high. PRIMARY OUTCOME MEASURE: TVe in ml/kg IBW. RESULTS: TVe was significantly lower in the defaults group. With the dashboard intervention, the TVe fell faster and by a greater amount compared to controls after exceeding a TVe of 8 mL/kg IBW. This effect improved in each subsequent year for 3 years. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrated that adjusting default ventilator settings and a dashboard of excessive TVe alerts can significantly impact clinical decision-making. This offers a promising strategy to improve compliance with low TVe ventilation and suggests that leveraging insights from behavioral science has the potential to improve the translation of evidence into practice.

title: Increasing the quantity and quality of the search for current best evidence to answer clinical questions: Protocol and intervention design of the MacPLUS FS Factorial Randomized Controlled Trials
abstract: Background and Aims Finding the current best evidence for clinical decisions remains a challenge. With 3,000 new studies published every day, no single evidence-based source provides all the answers or is sufficiently updated. McMaster Premium Literature Service - Federated Search (MacPLUS FS) addresses this problem by simultaneously searching across multiple high-quality resources and displaying the results in a one-sided pyramid, with the most clinically useful at the top. However, additional logistical and educational barriers need to be addressed to improve the search for evidence at the point-of-care. This study aims to test three innovative interventions among MacPLUS FS enrolled clinicians to increase the quantity and quality of the search for the current best evidence to answer clinical questions. Methods & Design In a user-centered approach, we developed three interventions embedded in MacPLUS FS: (A) a web-based clinical question recorder; (B) an Evidence Retrieval Coach consisting of eight short instructional videos; (C) an audit, feedback and gamification approach to evidence retrieval based on the assignment of "badge" and "reputation scores". We will conduct a randomized factorial controlled trial among all 904 eligible physicians currently enrolled in MacPLUS FS at McMaster University Hospitals, Canada. Postgraduate trainees (n=429) and clinical faculty/staff (n=475) will be randomized to each of the three following interventions in a factorial design (A x B x C). Usage is continuously recorded across clinicians' accounts, which track logins and usage down to the level of single keystrokes. The primary result is the search rate per month per user over the six months of tracking. Secondary outcomes, measured using the Validated Impact Assessment Method Questionnaire, include: usefulness of the responses found (satisfying clinicians' information needs), usage (application in practice), and perceived usefulness to patient outcomes. Discussion Building on effective models for point-of-care teaching, these interventions approach evidence gathering as a clinical skill. If effective, they can provide an opportunity to improve them for large audiences at low cost, while providing greater access to relevant evidence across many top EBM resources.

title: Indications for cholesterol-lowering drugs: comparison of risk assessment methods
abstract: Background Recommendations for prescribing lipid-lowering drugs emphasize the importance of evaluating the absolute risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) based on all risk factors and not just serum cholesterol concentration. However, if the methods recommended for risk assessment are imprecise, a recommended prescription will not be made. We compared multiple guidelines for such treatment in a series of patients referred to a lipid clinic to assess the difference in the level of CHD risk at which lipid-lowering drugs are recommended by each guideline.";" Background Recommendations for prescribing lipid-lowering drugs emphasize the importance of evaluating the absolute risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) based on all risk factors and not just serum cholesterol concentration. However, if the methods recommended for risk assessment are imprecise, a recommended prescription will not be made. We compared multiple guidelines for such treatment in a series of patients referred to a lipid clinic to assess the difference in the level of CHD risk at which lipid-lowering medication is recommended by each guideline.

title: Individualized treatment goals for elderly patients with type 2 diabetes on vildagliptin add-on or monotherapy (INTERVAL): a 24-week, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study
abstract: Background Guidelines suggest setting individualized goals for glycemic control in elderly patients with type 2 diabetes, although there is no evidence to support this. Our aim was to assess the feasibility of setting and achieving individualized goals over 24 weeks along with conventional HbA1c lowering using vildagliptin versus placebo.";" Background Guidelines suggest setting individualized goals for glycemic control in elderly patients with type 2 diabetes, although there is no evidence to support this. Our aim was to assess the feasibility of setting and achieving individualized goals over 24 weeks along with conventional HbA1c lowering using vildagliptin versus placebo.

title: Individuals with back pain: how do they view physical activity?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Recent guidelines for people with acute low back pain have advocated early return to normal activity and increased physical activity. Little is known about the association between low back pain and physical activity, and the implications of this association for promoting increased levels of physical activity in a general practitioner population. OBJECTIVES: Our aim was to investigate associations between factors influencing changes in physical activity and how individuals perceive and behave about their back pain, and the impact of these perceptions and behaviors on physical activity. METHODS: Twenty-seven informants were selected using a targeted sample from a larger group of people who had been referred by their GPs for their back problems to a community-based, single-blind, randomized controlled trial (RCT) conducted by the University of York to evaluate the efficacy and Evaluating the cost-effectiveness of a progressive training program. 54 interviews were conducted with this subset of the RCT";" four informants were interviewed once, 19 twice and four of them three times. The interviews were transcribed and analyzed using manual and computer-assisted approaches. RESULTS: Physical activity was perceived as (i) activities of daily living, (ii) activities that cause shortness of breath and which they did not avoid, and (iii) more competitive activities. Avoidance of physical activity and fear of recurring pain were the two main factors directly associated with informants' back and changes in physical activity. These two factors hampered an increase in physical activity, although the majority of respondents strongly believed that physical activity helped reduce their back pain. CONCLUSIONS: When addressing the issue of returning to or increasing physical activity in individuals with acute low back pain, it is important for clinicians to recognize physical activity avoidance and/or fear of pain at the earliest stages in order to design counseling and reassurance appropriately. When activity avoidance and fear of pain are identified and clinicians want to encourage patients to engage in and maintain more physical activity, they should examine issues of pain anxiety, avoidance of, and confidence in physical activity, among other contributing factors to physical activity.

title: Injustices among the poorest: health care for children in rural southern Tanzania
abstract: Background: Few studies have been conducted to assess socioeconomic inequalities in health in African countries. We looked for evidence of inequities in health care by gender and socioeconomic status for young children living in a poor rural area in southern Tanzania.";" Background: Few studies have been conducted to assess socioeconomic inequalities in health in African countries. We looked for evidence of inequities in health care by gender and socioeconomic status for young children living in a poor rural area in southern Tanzania.

title: Infectious diseases in general practice and prescription of antibiotics. Observational study in Sicily
abstract: Studies on drug consumption have shown large differences between different countries in prescribing behavior in general medicine. For example, in Italy, the choice of antibiotic prescribing seems to indicate a wider use of parental antibiotics. The aim of this study was to describe the prescribing pattern and therapeutic doses of antibiotics used by Sicilian General Practitioners (GPs) and to assess their prescribing attitudes towards the use of parental ones. Each physician had to fill out a questionnaire over a 6-month period for each therapeutic intervention that ended with a prescription of antibiotics. Diagnosis and medication were classified according to the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-10) and Anatomical Therapeutic-Chemical Classification (ATC), respectively. On 9395 prescriptions made by 76 doctors in 25 Sicilian cities, the analysis revealed that acute respiratory problems are the most common indication (31.7%) for a medical consultation and that macrolides [such as azithromycin (8.8%) and clarithromycin (8.3%)] , penicillin [such as amoxicillin (7.1%) and co-amoxiclav (8.4%)], third generation cephalosporins [such as cefixime (5.5%) and ceftriaxone (5.1% )] represent the most commonly used therapeutic groups. The choice of route of administration was influenced by the patient's age and, more importantly, by symptoms and signs of the disease, rather than by bacteria suspected of causing the disease. In summary, our data clearly indicate a lack of knowledge about antibacterial therapy guidelines among general practitioners in Sicily, as well as the need for independent training to improve antibiotic knowledge and reduce healthcare costs.

title: Impact of patient inquiries for direct-to-consumer advertised antidepressants: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Context Direct-to-consumer (DTC) advertising for prescription drugs in the United States is both ubiquitous and controversial. Critics charge that this leads to overprescription, while proponents counter that it helps prevent underuse of effective treatments, particularly for conditions that are poorly recognized or stigmatized. Objective To determine the impact of DTC-related patient inquiries on physicians' initial treatment decisions in patients with depressive symptoms. Design Randomized study with standardized patients (SPs). Six SP roles were created by crossing 2 conditions (major depression or adjustment disorder with depressed mood) with 3 requirement types (brand specific, general, or none). Establishment of primary care practices in Sacramento, California, San Francisco, California, and Rochester, NY between May 2003 and May 2004. Participants One hundred and fifty-two primary care physicians and general internists recruited from individual and group practices and health care organizations;" Cooperation rates ranged from 53% and 61% Interventions SPs were randomly assigned to 298 unannounced visits, with assignments restricted such that physicians saw 1 SP with major depression and 1 SP with adjustment disorder At approximately one-third of the visits, the SPs made a brand-specific drug request, a general drug inquiry or no inquiry (control condition) Key outcome measures Data on prescribing, mental health referral, and follow-up in primary care obtained from written reports of the SP, audio recordings of visits, review of charts, and analysis of written chen prescriptions and drug samples. The effects of request type on prescribing were assessed using contingency tables and confirmed in generalized linear mixed models that accounted for clustering and adjusted for site, physician, and visit characteristics. Results Standardized patient role compliance was excellent, and the suspicion rate that physicians had seen an SP was 13%. For major depression, the antidepressant prescription rate was 53%, 76%, and 31% for SPs making brand-specific, general, and no requests, respectively (P<0.001). For adjustment disorders, antidepressant prescription rates were 55%, 39%, and 10%, respectively (p<0.001). The results were confirmed in multivariate models. Minimally acceptable initial care (any combination of antidepressant medication, mental health referral, or follow-up within 2 weeks) was offered to 98% of SPs in the major depressive role who made a general inquiry, 90% of those who made a brand-specific inquiry, and 56% of those who did not inquire (P<0.001). Conclusions Patient inquiries have a profound impact on physician prescribing for major depression and adjustment disorders. Direct mail can have competing effects on quality, potentially both preventing underuse and encouraging overuse.

title: Influence on lifestyle interventions and five-year coronary risk from a comprehensive lifestyle intervention program in patients with coronary artery disease
abstract: BACKGROUND: Lifestyle interventions to prevent coronary artery disease (CAD) have been overshadowed by the effectiveness of drug treatments. This is particularly true in the context of secondary prevention, where the benefits of lipid-lowering, anticoagulant, and antihypertensive drugs have been emphasized in numerous studies. Lifestyle measures address multiple CHD risk factors simultaneously and are usually free from serious side effects. OBJECTIVES: The aim of the present study was to determine whether a comprehensive lifestyle modification program could beneficially affect diet and exercise habits in addition to smoking cessation over two years. In addition, an attempt was made to evaluate whether this program could favorably affect the 5-year CHD risk in the male population included in the study. DESIGN: A total of 197 patients with established coronary artery disease were enrolled and randomized to a lifestyle intervention program or usual care. The follow-up examination took place after two years. METHODS: The intervention included a low-fat diet, regular exercise, smoking cessation, psychosocial support, and education delivered by caregivers based on pharmacological and lifestyle interventions. The usual care included follow-up in the routine outpatient clinic. Both groups received the same comprehensive medication according to current guidelines. RESULTS: Patients in the lifestyle intervention group reduced saturated fat, sugar, and cholesterol intake (P<0.001), increased exercise level (P<0.01), and quit smoking (P<0.05) in comparison to the group with the usual treatment. A sub-analysis of the impact of five-year risk of CHD in men revealed a relative risk reduction of 22% (95% CI 9-35). Although this result is significant, it must be interpreted with caution due to the low statistical power and reproducibility of the method. CONCLUSIONS: In the presence of modern drug treatments for the prevention of secondary cardiovascular disease, it is still possible to demonstrate an additional reduction in the 5-year risk of CHD in men through favorable diet, exercise, and smoking cessation.

title: Effects of education and negative news about calcium channel blockers on first-line antihypertensive drug prescribing among the elderly in British Columbia
abstract: BackgroundThe way in which the dissemination of evidence is changing medical practice needs to be better understood. The calcium channel blocker (CCB) controversy over the past 3 years has prompted a natural experiment that has allowed for an assessment of the impact of media reports, a national warning letter, a conference call, small group workshops and newsletters on first-line prescribing of antihypertensive drugs.";" BackgroundThe way in which the dissemination of evidence is changing medical practice needs to be better understood. The calcium channel blocker (CCB) controversy over the past 3 years has prompted a natural experiment that allowed for an assessment of the impact of media reports, a national warning letter, conference call, small group workshops and newsletters on first-line prescribing of antihypertensive drugs.

title: Influencing antibiotic prescribing through prescriber feedback and management guidelines: a 5-year follow-up
abstract: BACKGROUND: The extent of antibiotic use in upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) prompted a previous study of an educational intervention based on prescribing physician feedback and treatment guidelines. This study demonstrated a reduction in antibiotic prescribing for URTI and more appropriate antibiotic choice for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis. There are few long-term follow-up studies of educational programs of this type. OBJECTIVES: This follow-up study aimed to investigate whether the reduction in antibiotic prescribing observed in the intervention group of the original study persisted after 5 years and how prescribing behavior changed of GPs involved in the follow-up study differed from a large national survey of prescribing GPs. METHODS: Attempts were made to contact the 157 primary care physicians involved in the original study. Of these, 121 were in a general practice and are currently working there. Ninety-six agreed to participate, and of these, 79 completed a morbidity and treatment survey of 100 patient contacts (response rate 65.3%). RESULTS: The intervention group (n=37) maintained their pattern of antibiotic prescribing for URTI and antibiotic choice for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis, with no significant change between the completion of the original study and the 5-year follow-up. The control group (n=42) showed a downward trend in prescribing antibiotics for URTI, with the effect that no significant differences between groups remained at the 5-year follow-up. At 5-year follow-up, both groups prescribed significantly fewer antibiotics for URTI and demonstrated greater adherence to prescribing guidelines for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis than participants in a large national primary care physician survey (n=984). CONCLUSION: This study demonstrated maintenance of prescribing behavior in the intervention group over the long term. However, the changes in prescription observed in the control group and the power limitations of the study make it uncertain whether this was the result of a sustained effect of the educational intervention. The differences in both groups from the large national general practitioner survey suggest that other influences on prescription (eg participation in vocational training for general practitioners) also had an important influence.

title: Influencing antibiotic prescribing in general practice: an experiment with feedback from prescribers and management guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: The extent of the use of antibiotics to treat upper respiratory tract infections in general practice is of concern due to the increasing problem of bacterial resistance. Effective educational strategies to promote rational prescribing are needed. OBJECTIVES: Our aim was to investigate the effectiveness of prescribing feedback and treatment guidelines in reducing antibiotic prescribing by GP trainees in undifferentiated upper respiratory tract infections and in improving antibiotic choice in tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis. The research tested a step-by-step approach to targeting educational inputs to high-prescribers. METHOD: New South Wales general practice trainees (n = 157) were randomly assigned to a treatment group (n = 78) that received an educational intervention on antibiotic use or a control group (n = 79) that received an intervention unrelated topic. Trainees completed three practice activity surveys, each of 110 consecutive patient encounters, with 6-month intervals between surveys. Between surveys 1 and 2, written prescribing physician feedback and treatment guidelines on antibiotic use for URTI and antibiotic selection for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis were provided Prescribing rate of antibiotics for all indications, for URTI and prescribing of selected antibiotics for tonsillitis/ Streptococcal pharyngitis. RESULTS: Antibiotic prescription by the intervention group decreased three times from 25.0 to 23.3 to 19.7 per 100 URTI problems, while the control group decreased from 22.0 to 25.0 to 31.7 per 100 URTI problems increased (p=0.002). Prescribing in accordance with accepted guidelines for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis increased over time in the intervention group from 55.6 to 69.8 to 73.0 per 100 problems but decreased in the control group from 59.6 to 57, 5 to 58.5 (p=0.05). CONCLUSION: Prescriber feedback and treatment guidelines have been shown to influence antibiotic prescribing for URTI and antibiotic choice for tonsillitis/streptococcal pharyngitis. This study provides a model for targeting educational input to those prescribers who most urgently need to change their behavior.

title: Information technology for patient safety
abstract: Background Research on patient care has identified significant disparities in the quality and safety of healthcare and the significant risks of iatrogenic harm as major issues. These deficiencies contribute to the high rates of potentially preventable morbidity and mortality and increasing healthcare expenditure in many healthcare systems. There have been significant developments in information technology over the past few decades, and there is now real potential to apply these technological developments to improve the delivery of healthcare more generally. The use of eHealth applications is of particular international interest. However, there is a large gap between the theoretical and empirically proven benefits of eHealth applications. While these applications are typically technically capable of assisting healthcare professionals, insufficient attention to the socio-technical dimensions of their use can lead to new avoidable risks for patients. Findings and Discussion Given the current lack of evidence on quality and safety improvements and cost-effectiveness associated with the deployment of eHealth applications, the focus should be on the implementation of more mature technologies";" It is also important that eHealth applications are evaluated against comprehensive and rigorous measures, ideally at all stages of their application life cycle.

title: Informed consent in clinical research at a general hospital in Mexico: investigators' opinions
abstract: In Mexico, informed consent is a legal requirement that ensures patients invited to participate in clinical trials are given all the information they need to decide whether or not to participate in a research protocol. To improve our understanding of the issues faced by physicians in developing countries when obtaining informed consent (IC), we asked their opinion on the importance of IC in clinical research, the quantity and quality of information provided to the participant, and to the conditions in which the IC is obtained. The investigators felt that IC was useful to patients by providing information that helped the patient make a decision about his/her participation. Nevertheless, they felt that in relation to some aspects of the research, such as drug development in general, the use of placebos and the randomization process, many of the patients were not able to fully understand the information provided, reflecting the complexity of the Information and the complexity of information pointed to illiteracy as the main reason. Many investigators were unfamiliar with some of the guidelines set out in Mexico's General Health Law,(1) 36% of them admitted not having completed their IC letters. Most investigators gave the patient only minutes to make a decision and 20% of the ICs were obtained during the patient's hospital stay. With the exception of one examiner, all considered specific training in medical ethics to be useful for day-to-day clinical work.

title: Informed consent for human experiments before the Nuremberg Code
abstract: The issue of ethics relating to medical experimentation in Germany during the 1930s and 1940s was crucial at the Nuremberg trials and related trials of physicians and public health officials. Those involved in horrific crimes tried to excuse themselves by arguing that there were no explicit rules governing medical research involving humans in Germany at the time, and that research practice in Germany was no different from that in the allied countries . In this context, the Nuremberg Code of 1947 is generally considered to be the first document that established ethical rules for human experimentation based on informed consent. However, new research indicates that ethical issues of informed consent in human experimentation guidelines were recognized as early as the 19th century. These guidelines shed light on the still controversial question of when the concepts of autonomy, informed consent, and therapeutic and nontherapeutic research first emerged. This question gains renewed relevance in the context of current attempts to assess liability and responsibility for human abuse in various experiments conducted in the United States, Canada, Russia, and other nations since World War II.

title: Informed Consent: Coronary Artery Bypass Graft Surgery
abstract: Coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) is a well-documented procedure. Despite the increasing prevalence of percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), surgical revascularization in patients with coronary artery disease will continue to play an important role. As demonstrated in previous clinical trials, physicians can provide important information to patients about risk-adjusted outcomes. A number of databases have been used to develop risk models to predict morbidity and mortality in patients undergoing CABG. Patients must choose between CABG and PCI based on the doctor's explanations. Larger studies have shown a clear survival benefit of CABG in patients at high risk of death from the disease itself, as defined by the severity of angina, the number of diseased vessels, and left ventricular function. However, it is not clear that patients always receive the correct information as to whether CABG or PCI is the more appropriate procedure. Initial informed consent should be obtained from an independent consultant in accordance with relevant guidelines.

title: Informed shared decision making supported by decision coaches for women with ductal carcinoma in situ: study protocol for a randomized controlled cluster study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Women with breast cancer want to be involved in treatment decisions. Guidelines have confirmed the right to informed codecision. However, previous research has shown that the implementation of informed decision making is suboptimal due to limited resources of physicians, power imbalances between patients and physicians, and a lack of evidence-based patient information. We have developed an informed shared decision-making program for women with primary ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The program provides decision-making coaching for women through specialist nurses and aims to support participation in decision-making and informed decisions. This study evaluates the shared decision-making program in breast centers. METHODS/DESIGN: A cluster-randomized controlled trial is conducted to compare the informed shared decision-making program to standard of care. The program includes evidence-based patient decision support and training physicians (2 hours) and specialist breast and oncology nurses (4 days) in informed shared decision-making. Sixteen certified breast centers will be enrolled, with 192 women with primary DCIS being recruited. The primary outcome is the degree of patient participation in shared decision-making, as assessed by the MAPPIN odyad (Multifocal “sharing” approach to shared decision-making: observer-instrument dyad). Secondary endpoints include the submetrics of the MAPPIN inventory (MAPPIN-Onurse, MAPPIN-Ophysician, MAPPIN-Opatient, MAPPIN-Qnurse, MAPPIN-Qpatient, and MAPPIN-Qphysician), informed choice, decision conflict, and duration of encounters. It is expected that decision coaching and the provision of evidence-based decision support to patients will increase patient participation in decision-making with informed decisions and reduce decision conflicts and the length of doctor visits. In addition, an accompanying process evaluation is carried out. DISCUSSION: To our knowledge, this is the first study examining the use of decision coaches in German breast centers. STUDY REGISTRATION: Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN46305518, Registration Date: June 5, 2015.

title: Quality Transformation Infrastructure: Measurement and Reporting in Veterans Administration Intensive Care Units
abstract: Background Veterans Health Administration (VA) intensive care units (ICUs) are developing quality improvement infrastructure using information technology and executive recruitment. Method setting The participation of the 183 intensive care units in the quality improvement program is required. The infrastructure includes measurement (electronic data extraction, analysis), quarterly web-based reporting and support for the implementation of evidence-based practices. Managers prioritize actions based on quality improvement goals. The electronic extraction is manually validated against the medical record, selecting hospitals whose data items and measures are at the extremes (10th, 90th percentile). Results are presented in graphical, narrative, and tabular reports, graded by ICU type and complexity. Results The VA admits 103?689±1156 intensive care patients/year. Variances in electronic business practices, data storage location, and the normal range of some laboratory tests affect data quality. A data management website collects data elements that are critical to ICU performance and not available electronically. A dashboard manages the flood of data (the quarterly reports contain 106 to 299 pages). More than 85% of ICU managers and nurses review their reports. Leadership interest is maintained by including ICU goals in executive performance agreements, identifying local improvement opportunities with analytics software, and conducting targeted reviews. Conclusion Lessons relevant to non-VA institutions include: (1) need for ongoing data validation, (2) substantial leadership involvement at multiple levels, (3) supplementation of electronic data when key elements are missing, (4) benefit of a good , but imperfect electronic indicator to move practice while enhancing data items and (5) value of a dashboard.

title: Initiating quality improvement activities in psychiatric services
abstract: In the public sector psychiatric setting, the responsibility for quality was often seen as the responsibility of the individual physician. This poses a particular challenge to adopting an organization-wide culture of quality improvement in this setting. Adopting a systemic view of quality may face resistance from individual clinicians who are unwilling to accept that some level of clinical autonomy should be incorporated into more standardized intervention and assessment patterns must be subsumed. Services must first address the issue of clinicians' willingness to embrace such a culture, which requires strong leadership leadership. The area of recently diagnosed psychosis was chosen as the starting point for initiating the quality improvement culture in a public sector psychiatric service. The ultimate outcome for the organization was a positive commitment to improvement, but the road has been long and hard. This paper describes the beginning of this ultimately rewarding journey.

title: Innovative strategy to implement guidelines for chronic heart failure among general practitioners in various healthcare facilities in Berlin
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to improve drug therapy for patients with chronic heart failure (CHF). METHODS AND RESULTS: This prospective interventional pilot study was conducted with a comparative cross-sectional analysis before and after the intervention. The usual pharmacotherapy was observed over a period of 8 months in two different outpatient care facilities in Berlin [11 general practitioners from general practitioner practices (IGP) and 12 doctors working in a medical care center (MVZ)]. Medical care centers offer a novel structure for outpatient care and were recently introduced in Germany. Subsequent intervention included implementation of heart failure guidelines via a computerized reminder system, followed by re-observation of prescribing behavior for 1 year. Primary care physicians recruited patients, assessed CHF severity according to NYHA class, and referred patients for echocardiography. The study included 190 patients in the baseline phase and 209 in the intervention phase. A longitudinal follow-up was performed in 172 cases. Echocardiography was ordered by 94.6% of MCC physicians and 79.9% of IGPs. Undermedication was observed in both settings. Guideline-compliant beta-blocker therapy was prescribed for 46.3% of patients (44.8% of IGPs and 48.5% of MCC-GPs). Prescribing improved by 12.3% after the procedure. There were clear deficiencies in the prescription of aldosterone antagonists (35%) in severe heart failure, which improved to 44.2% after the procedure. CONCLUSION: The problem of insufficient implementation of evidence-based therapy in CHF was partially overcome by the use of the reminder system, which provided brief guideline recommendations to participating physicians during the intervention phase.

title: Inpatient computerized standing orders versus physician reminders for increasing influenza and pneumococcal vaccination rates: a randomized study.
abstract: Context Computerized reminder systems increase influenza and pneumococcal vaccination rates, but computerized standing order systems have not been previously described or evaluated. Aim To determine the effects of computer-aided standing orders from doctors compared to reminders from doctors on inpatient vaccination rates. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PATIENTS Randomized study of 3,777 general practitioner patients discharged from 1 of 6 study wards during a 14-month period (November 1, 1998 to December 31, 1999) consisting of 2 overlapping influenza seasons at a municipal public teaching hospital . Interventions The hospital's computerized physician order entry system identified inpatients eligible for influenza and pneumococcal vaccination. For patients with standing orders, the system automatically created vaccination orders addressed to the nursing staff at the time the patient was discharged. For patients with memories, the computer system provided reminders to physicians containing vaccine prescriptions during routine prescription entry sessions. Main Outcome Measure Vaccine administration. Results During the approximately 6-month influenza season, 50% of all hospitalized patients were considered eligible for influenza vaccination. Twenty-two percent of patients hospitalized throughout the 14 months of the study were eligible for pneumococcal vaccination. Patients with a standing order received an influenza vaccination significantly more often (42%) than patients with a reminder (30%) (p<0.001). Patients with a standing order received a pneumococcal vaccination significantly more frequently (51%) than patients with a reminder function (31%) (p < 0.001). Conclusions Computerized standing orders were more effective than computerized reminders in increasing both influenza and pneumococcal vaccine delivery. Our results suggest that computerized standing orders should be used more extensively for this purpose.

title: insomnia
Integrated Guide to Treating Familial Hypercholesterolaemia from the International FH Foundation
abstract: Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is a dominantly inherited condition present from birth that markedly increases plasma low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol and causes premature coronary artery disease. There are at least 20 million people with FH worldwide, but the majority go undetected and current treatment is often suboptimal. To close this major gap in coronary prevention, we present consensus-based guidelines for the treatment of FH from an international perspective. The guidelines were generated from seminars and workshops held at an international symposium. The recommendations focus on the detection, diagnosis, assessment and treatment of FH in adults and children and establish guidelines for clinical use. They also refer to best practices for cascade screening and risk notification and testing of families for FH, including the use of genetic testing. Treatment guidelines are based on risk stratification, management of risk factors other than cholesterol, and safe and effective use of LDL-lowering therapies. Recommendations for lipoprotein apheresis are given. The use of new therapies for FH is also suggested. This international guideline recognizes gaps in evidence, but aims to make best use of current practice and technology to achieve the best outcomes for the treatment of FH. It should be used accordingly to support clinical judgment and adapted to country and local health needs and resources.

title: Integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy for people with psychosis and comorbid substance abuse: randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVES To evaluate the effectiveness of integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy in addition to standard care for patients with psychosis and a comorbid substance use problem. DESIGN Two-center, open-label, randomized controlled trial. RECRUITMENT Secondary care in the UK. PARTICIPANTS 327 patients with a clinical diagnosis of schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, or schizoaffective disorder and a diagnosis of dependence or abuse of drugs, alcohol, or both, according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition. INTERVENTION The intervention consisted of integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy plus standard of care compared to standard of care alone. Phase one of therapy - "Motivational Building" - is concerned with engaging the patient and then exploring and resolving the ambivalence to changing substance use. Phase two - "Action" - supports and facilitates change through cognitive behavioral approaches. Up to 26 therapy sessions were conducted over a year. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary endpoint was death from any cause or hospitalization during the 12 months following completion of therapy. Secondary endpoints were frequency and amount of substance use (assessed using the timeline followback method), willingness to change, perceived adverse consequences of use, psychotic symptom ratings, number and duration of relapses, and global ratings of functioning and intentional self-harm at age 12 and 24 months, with additional timeline follow-up assessments at 6 and 18 months. Analysis was by treatment intent and robust estimates of treatment effect were generated. RESULTS 327 participants were randomly assigned to either the intervention (n=164) or usual care (n=163). At 24 months, 326 (99.7%) were evaluated for the primary endpoint and 246 (75.2%) for the key secondary endpoints. Treatment had no beneficial effect on hospitalizations or deaths during follow-up, with 23.3% (38/163) of the therapy group and 20.2% (33/163) of the control group dying or being admitted (adjusted odds ratio 1.16, 95% confidence interval). 0.68 to 1.99"; p = 0.579). Therapy had no effect on frequency of substance use or perceived negative consequences of abuse, but had a statistically significant effect on the amount used per day of substance use ( adjusted ORs for major compound 1.50, 95% CI 1.08 to 2.09, p=0.016 and all compounds 1.48, 95% CI 1.07 to 2.05, p=0.017), 1.26 to 3 .31; p=0.004) which was not maintained at 24 months (0.78, 95% CI 0.48 to 1.28; p=0.320) There was no effect of treatment on clinical outcomes such as relapses, psychotic symptoms , functioning, and self-harm.CONCLUSIONS:Integrated motivational interviewing and cognitive-behavioral therapy for people with psychosis and substance abuse do not improve hospitalization outcome, symptom scores, or functioning.This approach reduces the amount of substance used for at least one year after A end of therapy. STUDY REGISTRATION Current controlled studies: ISRCTN14404480.

title: Integrating Back to Sleep recommendations into practice in the NICU
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: The American Academy of Pediatrics emphasizes that NICUs should support and model risk reduction recommendations for sudden infant death syndrome well in advance of the infant's expected discharge. Medical staff are important role models for parents, and the way they position infants in the hospital greatly influences parenting practices at home. The goals of this project were to increase the percentage of infants who follow safe sleep practices in the NICU prior to discharge and to determine whether improved adherence to these practices would affect parental behavior at home. METHODS: An algorithm detailing when to start safe sleep practices, a back to sleep crèche card, educational programs for nurses and parents, a crèche audit tool, and post-discharge phone reminders were developed as quality improvement intervention strategies . RESULTS: Compliance in the NICU for the supine position increased from 39% to 83% (p<0.001), provision of a firm sleeping surface increased from 5% to 96% (p<0.001), and removal of soft objects from the bed increased from 45% % improved to 75% (p=0.001). A post-discharge telephone survey found that parental compliance with safe sleep practices improved from 23% to 82% (p<0.001). CONCLUSIONS: Multifactorial interventions improved adherence to safe sleep practices in the NICU and at home.

title: Integrating Addiction Treatment into Primary Care with Mobile Health Technology: Protocol for an Implementation Research Study
abstract: Background Health care reform in the United States is encouraging federally qualified health centers and other primary care practices to integrate treatment for addiction and other behavioral health problems into their practices. The potential of mobile health technologies to treat addiction and co-morbidities such as HIV in these settings is significant but largely untested. This paper describes a protocol to evaluate the implementation of an integrated e-health communication technology delivered through mobile phones called Seva in primary care settings. Seva is an evidence-based system for addiction treatment and recovery support for patients and real-time case count monitoring for physicians. Methods/Design Our implementation strategy uses three models of organizational change: the program planning model to foster adoption and sustainability, the NIATx quality improvement model to create a welcoming environment for change, and Rogers' dissemination of innovation research, which facilitates adaptations of innovations to maximize their potential for adoption. We will implement Seva and conduct an intensive mixed-method assessment at three different Federally Qualified Healthcare Centers in the United States. Our non-concurrent, multiple baseline design includes three periods—pretest (ending in four months of pre-implementation), active Seva implementation, and maintenance—with implementation staggered across sites at six-month intervals. The first location will serve as a pilot clinic. We will track the timing of intervention elements and assess study outcomes within each dimension of the outreach, efficacy, adoption, implementation and maintenance framework, including impact on clinicians, patients and practices. Our mixed-methods approach includes quantitative (e.g. interrupted time-series analysis of treatment visits, with clinics as the unit of analysis) and qualitative (e.g. staff interviews regarding adjustments to the implementation protocol) methods as well as assessment of implementation costs. Discussion If implementation is successful, the field will have proven technology to support federally recognized health centers and affiliated organizations in delivering addiction treatment and recovery support, and a proven strategy for implementing the technology. Seva also has the potential to improve core elements of addiction treatment such as referral and treatment processes. Mobile addiction treatment technology and an accompanying implementation model could provide a cost-effective means to improve the lives of patients with drug and alcohol problems.

title: Integrating evidence on patient preferences into health policy decisions: Protocol of the patient VIP study
abstract: Background Despite a strong movement towards active patient participation in health policy decisions, systematic and explicit consideration of the evidence from this research on patient preferences seems limited. In addition, little is known about the opinions of several stakeholders on the inclusion of research on patient preferences in health policy decisions. This paper describes the protocol for an exploratory study to integrate research on patient preferences into health policy decisions. The study asks: to what extent research evidence on patient preferences is taken into account in current processes for health policy decisions; stakeholder views on integrating this type of evidence into health policy decisions; and what a decision-making framework could be for integrating such research evidence into health policy decisions Methods/design The study is divided into three sub-studies, predominantly using qualitative methods: The first sub-study is a scoping review in five European countries to examine whether and how results of research on patient preferences are taken into account in current procedures for coverage decisions and in the development of guidelines for clinical practice Netherlands The third sub-study is the development of a decision framework for research on patient preferences. The framework consists of: a process description regarding the place of evidence of patient preferences in the decision-making process, a taxonomy describing various terminologies and conceptualizations of “preferences”, and an overview of existing methods of investigating preferences. The conceptual framework will be presented to and discussed with experts Discussion This study aims to raise awareness of the existence and potential value of research on patient preferences for health policy decisions, and to provide insight into the methods used to study patient preferences. Barriers and facilitators for the integration of such research into health policy decisions Guidelines for clinical practice, healthcare decision makers and patient advocates.

title: Integrative medicine in specialist training: competence development through online curriculum training
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The Integrative Medicine in Residency (IMR) program, a 200-hour web-based collaborative education initiative, has been implemented in 8 primary care residency programs and has demonstrated potential as a national model for integrating training in integrative/complementary/alternative medicine in medical education. INTERVENTION: The curriculum content was developed based on a needs analysis and a set of graduate medical education competencies developed in accordance with the Accreditation Council's Graduate Medical Education Accreditation Council Outcome Project Guidelines. Content was delivered through distributed online learning and included on-site activities. A modular format allowed flexible implementation in different living environments. ASSESSMENT: TO ASSESS THE FEASIBILITY OF IMPLEMENTING THE CURRICULUM, A MULTIMODAL ASSESSMENT WAS USED, INCLUDING: (1) the residents' assessment of the curriculum; (2) residents' competency assessments through tests of medical knowledge, self-assessment, direct observations, and reflections;" and (3) residents' well-being and well-being through behavioral assessments. RESULTS: The 2011 cohort (n = 61) had a high completion rate in the first and second year (98.7% and 84.2%, respectively), and course assessments for achievement of objectives, clinical utility, and how the technology works were highly rated. courses, there was a statistically significant improvement in medical knowledge test scores for content-matched questions CONCLUSIONS: The IMR program is a step forward in the national effort to provide physicians with broad education in integrative medicine a success in terms of online education The evaluation suggests that this program is feasible to implement and despite the many burdens of h the stay is acceptable for the residents.

title: Intensive investigation in the treatment of Hodgkin's disease
abstract: Ninety-eight patients with clinically localized Hodgkin's disease underwent laparotomy and splenectomy to determine the extent of microscopic spread. 68 patients underwent the procedure for untreated disease that was evidently confined above the diaphragm. Abdominal disease cannot be ruled out with certainty based on noninvasive examination at presentation. Clinical assessment of spleen disease was unreliable unless gross splenomegaly was present. Pedal lymphography was accurate in assessing para-aortic and iliac disease but of no value in assessing other intra-abdominal lymph node involvement, including that of the mesenteric lymph node. Trephine bone marrow biopsy findings were normal in all patients before surgery, and only one patient was found to have diseased bone marrow by Stryker-Saw biopsy at surgery. Liver disease was identified at surgery in nine patients, some of whom were asymptomatic with clinically undetectable spleen and lymph node disease. In one-third of patients who underwent laparotomy, detailed clinical staging failed to detect the disease. These studies demonstrate that if radiotherapy is to remain the treatment of choice for diseases truly localized to lymph nodes, a detailed staging procedure, including laparotomy and splenectomy, remains essential. The value of this potentially curative treatment is significantly diminished in the under-staged patient.

title: Intensive speech and language therapy in patients with chronic aphasia after stroke: a randomized, open-label, controlled, end-blind trial in a healthcare setting
abstract: Background Treatment guidelines for aphasia recommend intensive speech and language therapy for chronic (6 months) aphasia after stroke, but large-scale, randomized, Class 1 controlled trials of treatment efficacy are scarce. Our aim was to investigate whether a 3-week intensive speech therapy under clinical routine conditions improves verbal communication in everyday situations in people with chronic aphasia after stroke.";" Background Treatment guidelines for aphasia recommend intensive speech and language therapy for chronic (6 months) aphasia after stroke, but large-scale, randomized, Class 1 controlled trials of treatment efficacy are scarce. Our aim was to investigate whether a 3-week intensive speech and language therapy under clinical routine conditions improves verbal communication in everyday situations in people with chronic aphasia after stroke.

title: Statin intentions and prescribing: Can the theory of planned behavior explain physician behavior in the following guideline recommendations?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Few studies have examined the usefulness of the theory of planned behavior (TPB) in explaining physician behavior. This study uses the TPB to explain physicians' implementation of guideline prescribing recommendations. METHODS: We developed the questionnaire by conducting qualitative interviews and a pilot study. A random sample of 155 general practitioners (GPs) in England took part in the study. Prescribing and practice data were collected from routine sources. We analyzed the data using regression methods. RESULTS: TPB explained 48% of the discrepancies in reported intentions to follow guideline prescribing recommendations. Attitudes and perceived controls, but not subjective norms, were predictors of intention variation. TPB belief variables significantly explained the variation in effective and efficient prescribing indicators (14% and 12%, respectively). Normative, control, and behavioral beliefs contributed to the models. Only for efficient prescribing did the TPB items retain their meaning in the presence of demographic variables. We found no significant relationship between intent and prescription. CONCLUSIONS: TPB contributed to understanding the prescribing behavior of general practitioners and their intentions to implement a clinical guideline. Beliefs (eg, normative beliefs) were better predictors of behavior than the composite scores for their corresponding higher-level construct (eg, indirect subjective norm). TPB models should be tested alongside randomized trials to test the causality assumption that a change in beliefs ultimately leads to a change in behavior.

title: Interactions between pharmaceutical representatives and physicians in training. A thematic review
abstract: AIM: Medical studies and specialist training are formative years for the establishment of prescription models. Our aim was to review the literature on the extent of pharmaceutical industry contact with trainees, attitudes towards these interactions and implications for trainee prescribing behaviour, with a focus on potential points of intervention and policy making. DESIGN: We searched MEDLINE for English language articles from 1966 to May 2004. All original articles were included if the abstract reported content relevant to medical education and the pharmaceutical industry. Editorials, guidelines and policy recommendations were excluded. MEASUREMENTS AND KEY RESULTS: Contact with pharmaceutical representatives was common among residents. The majority of trainees found the interactions appropriate.
