A minority believed that their own prescribing could be affected by contact or gifts, but more likely believed that others' prescribing could be affected. Prescribing by the resident was associated with visits from pharmaceutical representatives and the availability of samples. A variety of policy and educational interventions appear to influence residents' attitudes towards interactions with industry, although data on the long-term effects of these interventions are limited. Overall, residents reported insufficient training in this area. CONCLUSIONS: The pharmaceutical industry is strongly represented during residency training, has gained general acceptance among trainees, and appears to influence prescribing behavior. Training programs can benefit from policies and curricula that teach residents about the influence of the industry and ways to critically evaluate the information given to them. Recommendations for local and national approaches are discussed.

title: Interactions between physicians and the pharmaceutical industry: what does the literature say?
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the effect of three types of interactions between physicians and the pharmaceutical industry—corporate-funded clinical trials, corporate-funded continuing medical education (CME), and information for physicians provided by pharmaceutical detailers—on the direction and quality of clinical trials, content of CME courses and the prescribing behavior of physicians. DATA SOURCES: MEDLINE and HEALTH search English-language articles published from 1978 to 1993, supplemented with material from the author's personal collection. STUDY SELECTION: A total of 227 articles from the MEDLINE and HEALTH searches and approximately 2000 articles from the author's library were initially reviewed. The following selection criteria were used: studies conducted in Australia, Canada, New Zealand, Great Britain and the United States; studies conducted after 1977; quantitative surveys with details of the survey methods; Studies on the direction and quality of company-funded clinical trials and the content of CME courses, specifying explicit criteria used in the assessment;” and reports on the results of interactions, indicating how the results were assessed. 36 studies met these criteria. DATA EXTRACTION: Information was extracted on five topics: physician attitudes toward drug industry interactions, frequency of physician participation in the interactions, orientation and quality of company-sponsored clinical trials, content of company-sponsored CME courses, and changes in physician prescribing behavior as result of an interaction. DATA SYNTHESIS: Although most physicians participate in company-sponsored clinical trials only occasionally, most turn to detailers and attend company-sponsored CME courses. However, physicians do not have a very high opinion of information from detailers or from corporate-sponsored CME events. Many physicians view pharmaceutical companies as an important source of funding for clinical trials, but also have reservations about accepting funds from this source. Company funding of clinical trials may affect the quality of the trials and the type of research physicians conduct. Company-sponsored CME courses may have a commercial orientation, even if conducted under policies designed to ensure the independence of the event. All three types of interactions influence physicians' prescribing behavior, and in the case of information gathering by detailers, the interaction makes physicians' prescribing practices less appropriate. CONCLUSIONS: Physicians are affected by their interactions with the pharmaceutical industry. In most cases, more research is needed to determine whether such interactions result in more or less appropriate prescribing practices. The CMA's guidelines on this topic should be evaluated for their effectiveness in controlling physician-industry interactions. Further action may be necessary if the guidelines do not prevent adverse effects on prescribing practice.

title: Interdisciplinary perspectives on management of the restless baby: key strategies for improved outcomes
abstract: The aim of this study was to analyze the perspectives of key informants with clinical expertise in the care of restless infants and their families with respect to changes needed to improve outcomes. The research used a targeted selection strategy and a thematic analysis of interviews with key informants from 24 health professionals from 11 disciplines. The informants were chosen because of their extensive experience in dealing with distressed babies and their families. Participants confirmed existing evidence that postpartum care is fragmented in Australia. All agreed that, first, early intervention in primary care for distressed infants and their families, and second, improved interprofessional communication are essential if the burden of this problem on infants, families and the healthcare system is to be minimized. Third, there was consensus that there are significant gaps in the knowledge base and managerial behavior of health professionals. The development of educational resources, best practice guidelines, common assessment frameworks for primary care physicians, and strategies for improved interprofessional communication are necessary to improve health outcomes and reduce the burden of this common but complex postpartum problem.

title: Internal and external validity of cluster-randomized trials: systematic review of current trials
abstract: OBJECTIVES To evaluate aspects of the internal validity of recently published randomized cluster studies and explore the reporting of information useful for evaluating the external validity of these studies. DESIGN Review of 34 cluster-randomized trials in primary care published in 2004 and 2005 in seven peer-reviewed journals (British Medical Journal, British Journal of General Practice, Family Practice, Preventive Medicine, Annals of Internal Medicine, Journal of General Internal Medicine, pediatrics). DATA SOURCES National Library of Medicine (Medline) via PubMed. DATA EXTRACTION To assess aspects of internal validity, we extracted data on the adequacy of sample size calculations and analysis, methods of identifying and recruiting individual participants, and blinding. To examine the reporting of information useful for assessing external validity, we extracted data on cluster suitability, cluster inclusion and retention, cluster generalizability, and intervention feasibility and acceptability for clustered healthcare providers. RESULTS Twenty-one (62%) of the studies resulted in clustering in the sample size calculations and 30 (88%) in the analysis, "about a quarter were potentially biased due to patient recruitment and identification procedures;" In 19 (56%) of individual participants, assignment status was blinded, and 15 (44%) had outcome raters blinded. Almost half of the reports reported insufficient information on the generalizability of clusters, and two-fifths lacked information on the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention. CONCLUSIONS Cluster-randomized trials are essential for evaluating certain types of interventions. Issues affecting their internal validity, such as B. Appropriate calculations and analysis of sample size, became widespread and are now better addressed by researchers. Blinding of those who identify and recruit patients is recommended but not always done. In studies that do not recruit individual participants, there may be fewer barriers to internal validity. External validity appears to be neglected in many studies, but is arguably just as important as internal validity when assessing quality as a basis for medical intervention.

title: Recommendations of the International Collegium of Rehabilitative Audiology (ICRA) for the structure of multilingual language tests. ICRA Working Group on Multilingual Language Tests
abstract: AIM: To provide guidelines for the development of two types of closed-loop language perception tests that can be applied and interpreted in the same way in all languages. The guidelines cover the digit triple and matrix set tests most commonly used to test speech recognition in noise. They were developed by a working group on multilingual language assessments of the International Collegium of Rehabilitative Audiology (ICRA). DESIGN: The recommendations are based on reviews of existing evaluations of the digit triple and matrix tests and on the research experience of members of the ICRA working group. They represent the result of a consensus process. RESULTS: The resulting recommendations cover: test design and word selection; speaker characteristics; audio recording and stimulus preparation; noise masking; Test Execution;' and Test Validation. CONCLUSIONS: By following these guidelines for developing new tests of this type, clinicians and researchers working in any language can create tests whose results can be compared and combined in cross-language studies.

title: Intervention in infancy: implications for autism spectrum disorders
abstract: There is a paucity of empirically validated treatments for infants and young children under 3 years of age with autism spectrum disorders (ASD), as well as a paucity of empirical research on successful intervention characteristics for this population. However, early screening efforts focus on identifying the risk of autism in children younger than 3 years of age. In order to build ASD interventions for infants and young children on a foundation of evidence-based characteristics, the present paper presents the results of a systematic literature review and effect size analysis of effective interventions for infants and young children with other developmental disabilities: those who were born preterm, have developmental disabilities, or are at high risk for developmental disabilities due to the presence of a biological or familial condition associated with developmental disabilities. A review of 32 controlled, high-quality experimental studies found that the most effective interventions routinely used a combination of four specific intervention procedures, including (1) parental involvement in the intervention, including ongoing parent coaching that focuses on both parental responsiveness and also child-sensitive cues and teaching families to provide the infant interventions, (2) individualization to each infant's developmental profile, (3) focus on a broad rather than a narrow range of learning goals, and (4) temporal characteristics , which start as early as the risk is detected and ensure a greater intensity and duration of the intervention. These four characteristics of effective interventions for infants and young children with other developmental disabilities likely provide a solid foundation upon which researchers and clinicians can build effective interventions for infants and young children at risk of or affected by ASD.

title: Intervention development to integrate conventional tobacco cessation interventions into routine CAM practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Practitioners of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) therapies are an important and growing presence in healthcare systems worldwide. A key question is whether evidence-based behavior change interventions routinely used in conventional health care could also be incorporated into CAM practice to address public health priorities. Critical to successful integration are intervention approaches that are considered acceptable and consistent with the practice patterns and treatment approaches of different types of CAM practitioners—that is, they have context validity. The development of interventions to ensure contextual validity was an integral part of the CAM Reach (CAMR) project, a project investigating the public health potential of tobacco cessation training for chiropractors, acupuncturists, and massage therapists (CAM practitioners). This paper describes formative research conducted to achieve this goal. METHODS: The intervention development, conducted in three CAM disciplines (chiropractic, acupuncture, massage therapy), consisted of six iterative steps: 1) exploratory interviews with key informants; 2) local survey of CAM practitioners; 3) Demonstration of existing tobacco cessation curriculum with CAM practitioner 4) Adaptation/tailoring of existing curriculum 5) External review of adaptations 6) Provision of tailored curriculum to CAM practitioners followed by curriculum evaluation RESULTS: CAM practitioners identified barriers and promoters to tobacco use engage with patients/clients and saw the relevance and acceptability of the intervention content The intervention development process was attentive to their real-world intervention concerns Extensive intervention customization to the context of each CAM discipline was deemed unnecessary Participants and practitioners from all CAM disciplines embraced the training content, as they saw fit, to have broad relevance and application throughout the three CAM disciplines. All findings informed the final intervention. CONCLUSIONS: The participatory and iterative formative research process resulted in an intervention with contextual validity in real-world CAM practices as it: 1) is patient/client centered and emphasizes the practitioner's role in a healing relationship; 2) responds to the different contexts of CAM practitioners' work and patient-client relationships; 3) incorporates relevant best practices from the US Public Health Service's Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Treatment of Tobacco Addiction;" and 4) is appropriate for the breadth of healing philosophies, application areas, and practice patterns found among participating CAM practitioners. The full CAMR study to evaluate the impact of CAMR intervention on the clinical behavior of CAM practitioners is ongoing.

title: Intervention for autistic spectrum disorders
abstract: comprehensive approach to assessing each child with autism must be specific to each individual child and family. This premise applies to medical therapies and special educational services as well as to psychopharmacological interventions. Behavioral, as opposed to pharmacological, treatment is the hallmark of an effective intervention in autism. Physicians who care for children with autism must familiarize themselves with the child-rearing laws and recommendations for intervention. Goals should include improved functional verbal and nonverbal communication and social skills, increased engagement in developmentally appropriate activities, improved fine and gross motor skills, and the development of independent academic and organizational skills, and the replacement of problem behaviors with developmentally appropriate behaviors. Treating children with autism is difficult but often necessary for chronic behavioral disorders. In the absence of clear and up-to-date guidelines, we have attempted to propose an algorithm based on symptom clusters based on evidence and clinical experience. Although children with autism respond to lower doses of medication and are more prone to side effects than other children, medical intervention can significantly improve the quality of life for the child and their family. Careful thought leading to the correct identification of target behaviors can adequately guide better alternatives to drugs. Although these approaches are costly and time-consuming endeavors, spending on such efforts is the only avenue available to improve potential outcomes for individuals with autism and lower the societal cost of living for each individual.

title: Intervention mapping to develop a strategy for implementing insurance medical guidelines for depression
abstract: BACKGROUND: This article describes the development of a strategy to implement the insurance medical guidelines for depression. The application of the guidelines should lead to a more transparent and uniform assessment of applicants with depressive symptoms. METHODS: The implementation strategy was developed using the Intervention Mapping (IM) method to align with insurance medical practice. The behavior explanation model ASE (Attitude, Social Influence and Self-Efficacy) served as the theoretical basis for the development work. A literature study on implementation strategies and interviews with panel doctors were carried out in order to develop instruments for dealing with the guideline. These instruments have been tailored to the needs and working conditions of insurance doctors. Performance indicators to measure the quality of the assessment and adherence to the guidelines were defined with contributions from insurance doctors. RESULTS: This study led to the development of a training course to train insurance physicians in the application of the guidelines for depression using the above tools. The effectiveness of this training course will be evaluated in a randomized controlled trial. Conclusions: The use of IM enabled the development of guideline support tools tailored to insurance medical practice.

title: Interventions by health professionals providing routine child health care to reduce tobacco smoke exposure in children: A review and meta-analysis
abstract: IMPORTANT: Reducing exposure to tobacco smoke in children is a public health priority. Guidelines recommend that health professionals in child health settings should address exposure to tobacco smoke (TSE) in children. OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of interventions performed by healthcare professionals providing routine child health care in reducing TSEs in children. DATA SOURCES: A secondary analysis of 57 studies included in a 2014 Cochrane review followed by an expanded search was performed. Controlled trials (published up to June 2015) of interventions focused on reducing TSEs in children were identified, with no restrictions on who performed the interventions. Secondary data extraction was performed in August 2015. STUDY SELECTION: Controlled studies of routine child health care conducted by health professionals (physicians, nurses, medical assistants, health educators, and nutritionists) that addressed the outcomes of interest (TSE reduction in children and parental smoking behavior) were eligible for inclusion in this review and the meta-analysis to be included. Data extraction and synthesis: Study details and quality characteristics were independently extracted by 2 authors. When outcome measures were sufficiently similar, a meta-analysis was performed using the DerSimonian and Laird random effects model. Otherwise, the results were described narratively. MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES: The primary outcome measure was the reduction of TSEs in children. Secondary endpoints of interest were parental smoking cessation, parental smoking reduction, and maternal postpartum smoking relapse prevention. RESULTS: Sixteen studies met the selection criteria. The narrative analysis of the 6 studies that measured TSE in children did not show any intervention effects compared to comparison groups. Similarly, the meta-analysis of 9 studies that measured parental smoking cessation showed no overall intervention effect (n=6399) (hazard ratio, 1.05 in; 95% CI, 0.74–1.50; p=0.78 ). Meta-analysis of the 3 studies that measured maternal smoking relapse prevention after delivery showed a significant overall intervention effect (n=1293) (hazard ratio, 1.53; 95% CI, 1.10-2.14; P=0.01). A high degree of study heterogeneity likely resulted from variability in outcome measures, length of follow-up, intervention strategies, and unknown intervention adherence. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Interventions delivered by health professionals who provide routine child health care can be effective in preventing maternal smoking relapse. More research is needed to improve the effectiveness of such interventions in reducing TSEs in children and increasing parental smoking cessation. The results of this meta-analysis have implications for policy and practice regarding interventions by routine pediatric health workers aimed at reducing children's exposure to tobacco smoke.

title: Interventions for adolescent depression in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Depression in adolescents is underdiagnosed and undertreated despite its poor long-term outcomes, including suicide risk. Primary care settings can be critical sites for the detection of depression, but little information is available about the usefulness of primary care interventions. OBJECTIVE: We sought to review the evidence for treating depression in primary care, focusing on evidence on psychosocial, educational, and/or supportive intervention strategies. METHODS: Available data on brief psychosocial treatments for adolescent depression in primary settings were reviewed. Given the lack of direct studies, we also consulted relevant literature to summarize the available evidence on whether brief psychosocial support from a member of the primary care team, with or without medication, could improve depression outcomes. RESULTS: We identified 37 relevant studies on the treatment of depression in adolescents in primary care. Only 4 studies directly examined the effects of psychosocial interventions in primary care for adolescent depression, but they suggest that such interventions can be effective. Indirect evidence from other psychosocial/behavioural interventions, including predictive guidance and efforts to improve therapy adherence, and adult depression studies also demonstrates the benefit of interventions in primary care and the impact of provider training to improve psychosocial skills. CONCLUSIONS: There is potential for successful treatment of depression in adolescents in primary care given the evidence that brief psychosocial support, with or without medication, improves a range of outcomes, including adolescent depression itself. Given the major problem of public Health that emerges from depression in adolescents, the likelihood that most depressed adolescents do not receive specialized care, and new guidelines for managing depression in adolescents in primary care, clinicians can usefully consider initiating supportive interventions in their primary care practices .

title: Interventions to implement thromboprophylaxis in hospitalized medical and surgical patients at risk for venous thromboembolism
abstract: BACKGROUND: Venous thromboembolism (VTE) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in hospitalized patients. Numerous randomized controlled trials (RCTs) show that thromboprophylaxis in hospitalized patients at risk of VTE is safe, effective, and inexpensive. Despite this, prophylactic therapies for VTE are underused. System-wide interventions may be more effective in improving the use of VTE prophylaxis than relying on individual provider prescribing behavior. OBJECTIVES: To assess the impact of interventions to increase thromboprophylaxis in adult hospitalized medical and surgical patients at risk for venous thromboembolism (VTE), assessed in terms of: 1. Increasing the proportion of patients receiving prophylaxis and adequate prophylaxis 2. Reducing the risk of symptomatic VTE3. Reducing the risk of asymptomatic VTE4. safety of the intervention. SEARCH METHODS: The Cochrane Peripheral Vascular Diseases Group Trials Search Coordinator (TSC) searched the group's Specialized Register (last search July 2010) and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL, The Cochrane Library) 2010 Issue 3. We searched the Databases PubMed, EMBASE and SCOPUS (April 19, 2010) as well as the reference lists of relevant review articles. SELECTION CRITERIA: We included all studies whose interventions aimed to increase the use of prophylaxis and/or appropriate prophylaxis, reduce the rate of symptomatic VTE, or reduce the rate of asymptomatic VTE in adult hospitalized patients. We excluded studies that merely disseminated published guidelines and studies whose interventions were not clearly described. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: We collected the following endpoints: proportion of patients receiving prophylaxis (RP), proportion of patients receiving adequate prophylaxis (RAP) (primary endpoints), and occurrence of symptomatic VTE, asymptomatic VTE and safety consequences such as bleeding. We categorized interventions into Education, Warnings, and Multifaceted Interventions. We meta-analyzed RCTs and non-randomized studies (NRS) separately by random effects meta-analysis and assessed heterogeneity using the I(2) statistic and subgroup analyses. Before analyzing, we decided that if three or more studies were available for a given intervention, the results would be pooled. We assessed publication bias using funnel plots and a cumulative meta-analysis. MAIN RESULTS: We included a total of 55 studies. One of these reported data in patient days and could not be analyzed quantitatively with the others. The 54 remaining studies (8 RCTs and 46 NRS) eligible for inclusion in our quantitative synthesis included a total of 78,343 participants. There was enough data among the RCTs to pool the results for a primary endpoint (prophylaxis received) for the "Warn" intervention. Alerts, such as computer-based reminders or stickers on patient charts, were associated with a risk difference (RD) of 13%, indicating an increase in the proportion of patients receiving prophylaxis (95% confidence interval (CI) 1% to 25%). There was enough data among the NRS to pool both primary endpoints for each type of intervention. The pooled risk differences for received prophylaxis ranged from 8% to 17% and for received adequate prophylaxis from 11% to 19%. Education and warnings were associated with a statistically significant increase in the prescription of appropriate prophylaxis, and multifaceted interventions were associated with a statistically significant increase in the prescription of any prophylaxis and appropriate prophylaxis. Multifaceted interventions had the largest pooled effects. The results of I(2) showed significant statistical heterogeneity, which was partially explained by patient types and hospital type. A subgroup analysis showed that multifaceted interventions that included an alert may be more effective in improving prophylaxis rates and appropriate prophylaxis than those without an alert. The results for VTE and safety outcomes showed no significant benefit or harm, although most studies were underpowered to assess these outcomes. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: We reviewed a large number of studies that implemented a variety of system-wide strategies aimed at improving thromboprophylaxis rates in many settings and patient populations. We found statistically significant improvements in prescribing warning-related prophylaxis (RCTs) and multifaceted interventions (RCTs and NRS), and improvements in prescribing appropriate prophylaxis in NRS through the use of education, warnings, and multifaceted interventions. Multifaceted interventions with a warning component can be most effective. Proven sources of heterogeneity included patient types and hospital type. The results of our review will help physicians, nurses, pharmacists, hospital administrators and policy makers make practical decisions about the local adoption of specific system-wide interventions to improve the prevention of VTE, an important public health issue. We found no significant benefit in VTE outcomes";" however, previous RCTs assessing the effectiveness of thromboprophylaxis and targeting these endpoints have demonstrated the benefit of prophylactic therapies and a favorable benefit versus increased risk of bleeding events.

title: Interventions to increase patients' trust in physicians and physician groups
abstract: BACKGROUND: Trust is a fundamental component of the patient-physician relationship and is associated with increased satisfaction, adherence to therapy, and continuity of care. It is not clear whether there are measures that are known to be effective in increasing patients' trust in doctors. OBJECTIVES: To assess the impact of interventions aimed at enhancing a patient's trust in the physician or group of physicians. SEARCH STRATEGY: We searched the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (The Cochrane Library Issue 1 2003), MEDLINE (1966 to Week 4 2003), EMBASE (1985 to July 2003), Health Star (1975 to July 2004), PsycINFO (1967) . to July 2004), CINAHL (1982 to June 2003), LILACS (1982 to April 2003), African Trials Register (1948 to April 2003), African Health Anthology (1924 to April 2003), Dissertation Abstracts International (1861 to April 2003) and the bibliographies of the studies evaluated for inclusion. We also searched the bibliographies of studies evaluated for inclusion and contacted researchers working in the field. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), controlled clinical trials, controlled before-and-after studies, and interrupted time-series studies of interventions (informational, educational, behavioral, organizational) targeted at physicians or patients (or caregivers) in whom trust as a primary or secondary result was assessed. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two review authors independently assessed study quality and extracted data. MAIN RESULTS: Three RCTs, all published in English and set in North American primary care and involving 1916 participants, were included. There was significant heterogeneity in terms of objectives, format, and content of the interventions. A study of a training intervention for primary care physicians to improve communication behavior (20 physicians evaluated by 414 patients) showed no effect on trust. The other two interventions were patient-centered. One examined the effects on trust when incentives to physicians in a Health Maintenance Organization (HMO) were disclosed to patients (n=918) and showed no loss of trust. Another examined the effect of induction visits on new HMO members' (n=564) confidence in their HMO physicians. Confidence in physicians increased compared to control group after visit for one type of introductory visit, group visit (confidence out of 10 (standard deviation (SD))) was 8.8 (1.5) and 7.1 (2.2) , difference 1.7 (95% confidence). Interval 1.22 to 2.18)). However, there were many dropouts and the analysis did not correspond to the treatment intention. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: Overall, there remains insufficient evidence to conclude that any intervention can increase or decrease trust in physicians. Further studies are needed to examine the impact of policy changes, guidelines, and specific physician training on patient confidence.

title: Interventions for migraine prophylaxis: protocol of a systematic umbrella review and network meta-analysis
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Several interventions are effective for migraine prophylaxis. However, the comparative effectiveness of these interventions is not yet clear. Therefore, the aim of this study is to summarize the direct and indirect evidence for pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions to prevent migraine attacks. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: We will conduct an overall systematic review to identify appropriate randomized controlled trials (RCTs) for the recommended migraine prophylaxis interventions according to the guidelines. A comprehensive literature search will be conducted in MEDLINE, EMBASE and the Cochrane library for systematic reviews searched for RCTs. We describe the RCTs' general information for participants, interventions, outcome measures, comparisons, and the primary outcomes. In addition, a network meta-analysis will be performed to determine the comparative efficacy of the treatments using a random effects model. The absolute and relative effectiveness of the treatments is reported. Heterogeneity and inconsistency between studies is assessed by the Cochrane statistical test I(2) and Q-test. The risk of bias is assessed and the overall strength of evidence is summarized. DISCUSSION: The outcome of this network meta-analysis will provide direct and indirect evidence for treatments for migraine prevention and potentially provide a ranking of treatments for patients and clinicians to help them select the best option. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: PROSPERO CRD42015015297.

title: Interventions that change clinical behavior: mapping the literature
Interventions to change the behavior of midwifery health professionals to promote weight-related support for obese pregnant women: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: In the last five years, the publication of guidelines on the management of obesity and weight gain during pregnancy has increased significantly. Health professionals have identified several barriers to this area of practice, including the need to improve their communication skills, the belief that pregnant women have negative reactions to discussions about weight, and a lack of knowledge about weight management. This systematic review aimed to identify: the effectiveness of interventions to change the practice of health professionals in relation to maternal obesity or weight management during pregnancy";" and what behavior change techniques and modes of intervention delivery have been used in interventions to date. RESULTS: The search strategy included searching electronic databases, study registers, and citation searches. Inclusion criteria were intervention studies aimed at changing the practice of healthcare professionals related to maternal obesity or weight management. The search identified 3,608 studies. However, no suitable completed studies were identified. One registered Canadian randomized controlled trial was identified. The study includes an educational intervention for primary care physicians to support compliance with guidelines on weight gain in pregnancy. The study had not started yet, so no efficacy data were available. CONCLUSIONS: The current focus of research on maternal obesity and weight control is aimed at changing behavior in pregnant women. These interventions do not address the barriers faced by many health professionals regarding maternal obesity and weight management practice. Further research is needed to identify the most effective approaches to assist healthcare professionals in implementing maternal obesity policies and weight management in practice.

title: Interventions to improve follow-up care for abnormal findings in cancer screening
abstract: The potential reduction in morbidity and mortality from cancer screening cannot be realized without adequate follow-up for abnormalities identified during screening. In this article, the authors critically review the existing literature on correlates of receiving appropriate follow-up for abnormalities detected by screening, as well as the literature on interventions aimed at increasing rates of follow-up. Lessons Learned describe what is known and what is not known about factors associated with or predicting follow-up utilization. Effective interventions to improve aftercare are also described and gaps identified. A conceptual model is developed that divides the healthcare system in the United States into four tiers: policy, practice, provider, and patient. Some patient-level factors influencing the receipt of follow-up care are identified, but the lack of data severely limits understanding of provider-, practice-, and policy-level correlations. The majority of intervention studies to increase follow-up have focused on patient-level factors and have performed targeted follow-up for abnormal Papanicolaou smears. Insufficient information is available on the effectiveness of interventions at the provider, practice, or policy level. There is a lack of standard definitions of what constitutes appropriate aftercare, which severely limits the comparability of study results. The validity of different methods of obtaining outcome data has not been clearly established. More research is needed on interventions that target provider, system, and policy level factors, particularly interventions that focus on the follow-up of colorectal and breast abnormalities. Standardization of definitions and measures is needed to facilitate comparisons between studies. Cancer 2004. Published in 2004 by the American Cancer Society.

title: Interventions to improve hospital patient satisfaction with health care providers and systems: a systematic review
abstract: Background Many hospital systems are attempting to improve patient satisfaction, as determined by the Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (HCAHPS) surveys. A systematic review of the current experimental evidence could support this effort and does not yet exist. Methods We conducted a systematic literature search by searching electronic databases including MEDLINE and EMBASE, the Cochrane Library's six databases, and gray literature databases. We included studies of hospitalized patients with interventions that targeted at least 1 of the 11 HCAHPS domains and that met our quality filter score on the 27-point Downs and Black coding scale. Where applicable, we have calculated the post-hoc performance. Results A total of 59 studies met the inclusion criteria, of which 44 did not meet the 50% quality filter (mean quality score 27.8% ± 10.9%). Of the 15 studies that met the quality filter (mean quality score 67.3% ± 10.7%), 8 targeted the HCAHPS domain “Communication with Physicians”, 6 “Overall Hospital Rating”, 5 “Communication with Nurses”. ’, 5 on ‘pain treatment’ and 5 on ‘communication’ on medication, 5 specific recommendation of the hospital, 3 specific quietness of the hospital environment, 3 specific cleanliness of the hospital environment and 3 specific discharge information. Significant HCAHPS improvements were reported by eight interventions, but their generalizability may be limited by narrowly focused patient populations, heterogeneity of approach, and other methodological concerns. Conclusions Although there are some studies showing some improvement in HCAHPS score by different interventions, we conclude that more rigorous research is needed to identify effective and generalizable interventions to improve patient satisfaction.

title: Interventions to increase the use of electronic health information by healthcare professionals to improve clinical practice and patient outcomes
abstract: BACKGROUND: A large body of health information is available that, when applied to clinical practice, can contribute to effective patient care. Despite a wealth of information, suboptimal care is common. Many factors influence the use of health information by practitioners, and format (electronic or otherwise) can be one such factor. OBJECTIVES: To assess the impact of interventions aimed at improving or increasing the use of electronic health information (EHI) by healthcare professionals on professional practice and patient outcomes. SEARCH METHODS: We searched The Cochrane Library (Wiley), MEDLINE (Ovid), EMBASE (Ovid), CINAHL (EBSCO), and LISA (EBSCO) up to November 2013. We contacted researchers in the field and searched reference lists of relevant articles. SELECTION CRITERIA: We included studies that assessed the impact of interventions to improve or increase the use of EHI by healthcare professionals on professional practice and patient outcomes. We have defined EHI as information accessed on a computer. We have defined "use" as registering with EHI. We considered every doctor involved in patient care. We included randomized, non-randomized, and cluster-randomized controlled trials (RCTs, NRCTs, CRCTs), controlled clinical trials (CCTs), interrupted time series (ITS), and controlled before-and-after studies (CBAs). The comparisons were: electronic versus printed health information”; EHI on various electronic devices (e.g. desktop, laptop or tablet computers, etc.; cellphones/mobile phones); EHI via different user interfaces; EHI with or without an education or training component;' and EHI compared to no other type or source of information. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two review authors independently extracted data and assessed the risk of bias for each study. We used GRADE to assess the quality of included studies. Following our decision to define enrollments in the EHI as a measure of professional conduct, we re-evaluated previously excluded studies. We have given the results in natural units. Where possible, we calculated and reported the mean effect size (odds ratio (OR), interquartile ranges (IQR)). Due to the high heterogeneity of the studies, a meta-analysis was not possible. MAIN RESULTS: We included two RCTs and four CRCTs with 352 physicians, 48 residents, and 135 naturopaths. The overall risk of bias was low, as was the quality of the evidence. One comparison was supported by three studies and three comparisons were supported by individual studies, but the results from the three studies were very heterogeneous. We found no studies supporting EHI versus no alternative. Given these factors, it was not possible to determine the relative effectiveness of the interventions. All studies reported physician use of EHI, two reported adherence to electronic practice guidelines, and none reported patient outcomes. One study (139 participants) measured adherence to an electronic versus a printed guideline, but reported no difference between groups (median OR 0.85, IQR 0.74 to 1.08). A small crossover study (10 participants) reported increased use of clinical guidelines when equipped with a mobile versus stationary desktop computer (mean use per shift: intervention group (IG) 3.6, standard deviation (SD) 1.7 vs. control group (CG) 2.0 (SD 1.9), P value = 0.033). A crossover study (203 participants) reported that the use of a customized versus a generic user interface had little impact on practitioner use of EHI (mean difference in customized study completion rate: 0.77 enrollments/month/user, 95% confidence interval ). (CI) CI 0.43 to 1.11). Three studies included education or training and reported increased use of EHI by practitioners after training. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: This review provided no evidence that EHI use leads to improvement in clinical practice or patient outcomes, although it does suggest that EHI use increases when physicians are provided with EHI and education or training. We have defined usage as the activity of logging into an EHI resource, but based on our findings, usage does not automatically imply application of EHI in practice. While the use of EHI can be an important part of evidence-based medicine, it alone is not sufficient to improve patient care or clinical practice. In order for EHI to be used in patient care, it is necessary to understand why physicians are reluctant to use EHI in treating people and to determine the most effective ways to reduce this reluctance.

title: Interventions to change healthcare provider compliance with asthma guidelines: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE: Adherence to asthma guidelines by healthcare providers is poor. The aim of this study was to assess the effect of interventions to improve healthcare provider compliance with asthma guidelines on the healthcare process and clinical outcomes. METHODS: As of July 2012, data sources included Medline, Embase, Cochrane CENTRAL Register of Controlled Trials, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature, Educational Resources Information Center, PsycINFO, and Research and Development Resource Base in Continuing Medical Education Eligibility Assessments. Investigators abstracted the data one at a time and independently assessed the evidence. RESULTS: Sixty-eight eligible studies were classified by intervention: Decision Support, Organizational Change, Feedback and Audit, Clinical Pharmacy Support, Education Only, Quality Improvement/Payment for Service, Multicomponent, and Information Only. Half were randomized trials (n=35). There was moderate evidence for increased prescribing of controller medications for decision support, feedback and review, and to support clinical pharmacy, and low-level evidence for organizational change and multi-component interventions. Moderate evidence supports the use of decision aids and clinical-pharmaceutical interventions to improve patient delivery of self-education/asthma action plans. Moderate evidence supports the use of decision support tools to reduce ER visits, and low evidence suggests there is no benefit for this outcome with organizational changes, only education and quality improvement/pay for performance. CONCLUSIONS: Decision support tools, feedback and audits, and clinical pharmacy support most likely improved provider compliance with asthma guidelines as measured by outcomes of the healthcare process. There is a need to evaluate provider-focused interventions with standardized outcomes.

title: Interventions to promote evidence-based care for children with ADHD in primary care
abstract: Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a common behavioral disorder in children. Community physicians are often the primary providers of services for children with ADHD. A set of consensus guidelines has been published by the American Academy of Pediatrics that provides best practice diagnostic procedures for primary care physicians. These recommendations emphasize the importance of using the criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition, as a basis for making an ADHD diagnosis and conducting systematic follow-up, including the collection of parent and teacher rating scales to quantitatively assess response to treatment. Although these recommendations are widely used and their adoption is actively encouraged, adherence to guidelines is generally known to be poor. Two types of intervention models, auxiliary service and modification of office systems, have been proposed to encourage the adoption of evidence-based ADHD practice in primary care. This article reviews the effectiveness of these intervention models and discusses the costs and sustainability of each model in relation to the feasibility of intervention dissemination.

title: Intrinsic conflicts of interest in clinical research: disclosure requirements
abstract: Protecting human subjects from investigator conflicts of interest is critical to the integrity of clinical trials. Personal financial conflicts of interest are addressed through university policies, professional association policies, public standards, and government regulations, but “intrinsic conflicts of interest”—conflicts of interest inherent in all clinical research—have received comparatively less attention. Such conflicts arise in all clinical research efforts as a result of the tensions between professionals' responsibilities to their research and their patients and both academic and financial incentives. These conflicts should be disclosed to the research subjects and managed with the same care as financial conflicts of interest.

title: Introduction: Understanding and influencing multi-step factors in the continuum of cancer care
abstract: Health care in the United States is notoriously expensive while often not providing the care recommended by published guidelines. It is therefore necessary to rethink our approach to healthcare. Cancer care is a good example to consider as it encompasses the continuum of health care from primary prevention through long-term survival to end-of-life care. In this monograph, we emphasize that healthcare takes place in a multi-level system that includes organizations, teams, and individuals. In order to achieve healthcare that is consistent with the Institute of Medicine's six quality goals (safety, efficacy, timeliness, efficiency, patient-centricity, and equity), we must affect multiple levels of this multi-level system. The notion that multiple levels of contextual influence influence behavior through interdependent interactions is a well-established ecological view. This view was used to analyze health care and health disparities. However, experience of considering multilevel interventions in health care is much less robust. This monograph contains 13 chapters relevant to expanding the research base for tiered health care interventions. Topics include clinical cases of multilevel thinking in healthcare, state of knowledge on multilevel interventions, study design and measurement considerations, methods for combining interventions, time considerations in assessing impacts, measuring impacts, simulations, application of multilevel thinking to healthcare systems and disparities, as well as implementation of the Affordable Care Act of 2010. Our goal is to outline an agenda to proceed with multilevel intervention research, not because it guarantees an improvement in our current approach to healthcare, but because it ignores the complexities of the multilevel environment, in which care takes place, has not achieved the desired improvements in care quality outlined by the Institute of Medicine around the turn of the millennium.

title: Assessment of breast symptoms in primary care: improving consistency with current best advice
abstract: The purpose of this study was to determine whether a targeted intervention could improve primary care physician compliance with guidelines for treating women with breast symptoms. One hundred and twelve practitioners from randomly selected areas across Australia prospectively reviewed their assessments for each woman with a new breast symptom over two 12-week periods, before and five months after the publication of the national guidelines. Between the two audits, the physicians received feedback on practice compared to peers and attended a seminar in their local areas led by specialists from the Royal Australasian College of Physicians and the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons. Five recommendations had statistically significant improvements at the second audit according to standard guidelines for examining a new breast symptom (INBS). All of this was for examining lumps in the breast. At the first audit there were seven recommendations where practitioners were already treating more than 80% of the women in compliance with the INBS and where there was no statistically significant increase in compliance at the second audit. Another six recommendations showed less agreement with the recommendations before publication of the guidelines and did not improve significantly at the second audit. These generally applied to less frequent presentations and where clinical findings were inconsistent with other test results. We concluded that a targeted intervention improved physician compliance with current best advice for screening women with new breast symptoms in a primary care setting. Further educational programs are needed to improve screening for less common symptoms and to increase physicians' confidence in the results of their clinical assessments.

title: Is it possible to predict improved diabetes outcomes after diabetes self-management training: a longitudinal mixed-methods design
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To predict the diabetes-related outcomes of subjects enrolled in a type 2 diabetes self-management education (DSME) program from their baseline data. DESIGN: A mixed-methods longitudinal experimental study. 6 practicing nurses and 2 clinical academics performed blind assessments of all baseline and process data to predict clinical, behavioral, and psychological outcomes 6 months after the DSME program. SETTING: Basic care. PARTICIPANTS: -31 people with type 2 diabetes who had not previously had a DSME. INTERVENTION: All participants completed the Diabetes Manual 1:1 self-paced 12-week DSME program supported by office nurses trained as Diabetes Manual Facilitators. OUTCOME VARIABLES: Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c), diabetes knowledge, physical activity, waist circumference, self-efficacy, diabetes distress, anxiety, depression, demographics, change talk, and treatment satisfaction. These variables were chosen because they are known to affect self-management behavior or have been empirically affected by a DSME program. RESULTS: Baseline and 6-month follow-up data were available for 27 participants, of whom 13 (48%) were male, 22 (82%) were white British, mean age 59 years, and mean duration of type 2 diabetes 9.1 years. Significant reductions were seen in HbA1c t(26)=2.35, p=0.03 and diabetes distress t(26)=2.30, p=0.03 and a significant gain in knowledge t(26)=-2.06 , p=0.05 observed between baseline and 6 months. No significant changes were seen in waist circumference, physical activity, anxiety, depression, or self-efficacy. The accuracy of the predictions varied little between clinical academics and practicing nurses, but greatly between outcomes (0–100%). The median and mode accuracy of the predicted result was 66.67%. The prediction accuracy for the key result HbA1c was 44.44%. Diabetes distress had the highest predictive accuracy (81.48%). CONCLUSIONS: Clinicians in this small study were unable to identify individuals who were likely to achieve improvement in outcomes from DSME. DSME should be encouraged according to guidelines in all patients with diabetes.

title: Is the provider type associated with cancer screening and prevention: Registered Nurses, Physician Assistants and Physicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physician recommendations for cancer screening and prevention are associated with patient compliance. However, time constraints can limit physicians' ability to provide all recommended preventive services, especially given the increasing demand from the Affordable Care Act in the United States. A team-based practice that includes Registered Nursing and Physician Assistants (APRN/PA) can help meet this need. This study examines the association between an APRN/PA visit and receiving guideline-compliant cancer screening and prevention recommendations. METHODS: Data from the 2010 National Health Interview Survey were analyzed using multivariate logistic regression to assess provider type viewed and receipt of guideline-compliant cancer screening and prevention recommendations (n = 26,716). RESULTS: In adjusted analyses, women who visited a primary care physician (PCP) and an APRN/PA or a PCP without an APRN/PA in the past 12 months were more likely to meet guidelines for cervical and breast cancer screening than women who did did not see PCP or APRN/PA (all p<0.0001 for provider type). Women and men who saw a PCP and an APRN/PA or a PCP without an APRN/PA were also more likely to receive guideline-based colorectal cancer screening and advice to quit smoking and exercise than women and men who did not see a PCP or APRN/PA (all p<0.01 for provider type). CONCLUSIONS: Attending a PCP alone or in conjunction with an APRN/PA is associated with the patient receiving guideline-compliant cancer prevention and screening recommendations. Integrating APRN/PA into primary care can aid in the delivery of cancer prevention and early detection services. Further intervention research efforts are needed to examine how APRN/PA will best be able to improve cancer screening, HPV vaccination and the receipt of behavioral counseling, particularly in this era of healthcare reform.

title: Is there a gap between recommended and "real world" practice in treating depression in young people? A medical record audit of the practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: The literature has shown that the dissemination of guidelines alone is not sufficient to ensure that guideline recommendations are integrated into everyday clinical practice. METHODS: Our aim was to investigate the gaps between guideline recommendations and clinical practice in the management of young people with depression by conducting a medical record review in a community psychiatric service for 15- to 25-year-olds in Melbourne, Australia, in a catchment area performed. RESULTS: The results showed that assessing and recording depression severity to ensure appropriate treatment planning was neither systematic nor consistent";" that the majority of young people (74.5%) were prescribed an antidepressant before an adequate attempt at psychotherapy was made, and that fewer than 50% monitored suicidal behavior for improvement in depression symptoms and for antidepressant treatment (35% and 30% respectively). Encouragingly, 92% of first-line prescriptions for people under 18 who were previously antidepressant-naïve were fluoxetine as recommended. CONCLUSIONS: This research has highlighted the need for targeted strategies to ensure effective implementation. These strategies could include practice system tools that allow for systematic monitoring of depression symptoms and adverse events, particularly suicidal behavior. In addition, adolescent-specific psychotherapy that contains the most effective components for this age group and is delivered in an adolescent-friendly manner would likely support the effective implementation of guideline recommendations for participation in an appropriate psychotherapy study before medication is initiated.

title: Is an untargeted outreach visit to primary care effective? A pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is increasing evidence that clinical guidelines can lead to improvements in clinical care. However, they are not self-implementing. Outreach visits can improve prescribing behavior. METHODS: Within a pragmatic, randomized, controlled before-after study involving all general practices in a health district, routine methods were used to distribute guidelines for the management of Helicobacter pylori eradication. Intervention practices were offered a visit and an audit conducted by a pharmacist trained in outreach techniques. The intervention was assessed using Level 3 Prescribing Analysis and Cost (PACT) data for metronidazole and omeprazole for the two 12-month periods surrounding the introduction of the guidelines. RESULTS: Of the 38 intervention practices, 19 accepted an outreach visit and three accepted the offer of an audit. There was a significant increase in omeprazole use during the study of 0.24 [95 percent confidence interval (CI) +0.19 to +0.29] dose units per year, but no effect by supply [-0.02 (95 percent CI -0.12 to +0.08) dose units] or acceptance of a visit [-0.03 (95 percent CI -0.15 to +0.08) dose units]. Results for metronidazole were similar, with an increase in use of 0.028 (95% CI +0.018 to +0.038) dose units per year. The effect of the intervention was a non-significant change in prescription of -0.005 (95 percent CI -0.025 to +0.015) dose units. Accepting a visit had little effect on prescribing: a change of 0.003 (95 percent CI -0.021 to +0.027) dose units. CONCLUSIONS: The routine use of untargeted outreach visits is probably not a viable strategy.

title: Issues related to the protection of human research participants
abstract: Making ethical decisions related to the protection of human research participants is often complex and fraught with uncertainty and conflict. Knowledge of the basic principles set forth in the Belmont Report and federal regulations and policies can provide a useful framework for making such decisions, although the ultimate responsibility for ensuring ethical research practices rests with the individual researcher. Ongoing dialogue and discussion of these ethical issues will provide a basis for strengthening nursing research and practice while ensuring the maximum protections for the research participants that enable the advancement of nursing science.

title: It's not just about motivating healthcare professionals to practice hand hygiene by focusing on patients.
abstract: Disease often spreads in hospitals because medical staff do not wash their hands. Research suggests that to improve health and safety behavior it is important to highlight the personal consequences for the actor. However, as people (and especially healthcare professionals) tend to be overconfident about personal immunity, perhaps the most effective hand hygiene messages are those that highlight the implications for other people. In two field experiments in a hospital, we compared the effectiveness of hand hygiene messages that emphasized personal safety (“hand hygiene protects against disease”) or patient safety (“hand hygiene protects patients from disease”). We assessed hand hygiene by measuring the amount of soap and hand sanitizer gel used from dispensers (experiment 1) and by making covert, independent observations of hand hygiene behavior by healthcare professionals (experiment 2). The results showed that changing a single word in messages led to meaningful behavioral changes: healthcare professionals' hand hygiene increased significantly when reminded of the effects on patients, but not when reminded of the effects on themselves .

title: Jarvis vs. Levine
abstract: KIE: The Minnesota Court of Appeals has ruled that an involuntarily admitted mental patient has a qualified constitutional right to refuse neuroleptic treatment in a non-emergency situation, subject to the exercise of professional judgment by state clinicians in accordance with mandatory guidelines. It upheld the trial court's decision that patient Jarvis was not eligible for a post-medication review, arguing that the requirements of due process for the administration of neuroleptics were met by compliance with guidelines established by the Minnesota Department of Public Welfare for involuntary medication have been fulfilled.

title: JNC-7 Guidelines: Are They Still Relevant?
abstract: The recommendations of the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC 7), published in 2003, are largely relevant today. Reducing blood pressure (BP) to target in hypertensive patients is of paramount importance in reducing cardiovascular risk. Antihypertensive drugs vary in their effectiveness in lowering blood pressure and may have non-hypertensive effects on cardiovascular events, particularly with regard to the prevention of heart failure and stroke. Thiazide-type diuretics have been recommended as the first line of choice for treating hypertension in most patients, and this is still an appropriate recommendation. Several other classes were recommended as the next priority, but beta-blockers should now play a lesser role in treating uncomplicated hypertension. While a new JNC report would be reassuring to practitioners and should include some changes since JNC 7, I think most of the recommendations are still relevant today.

title: JOURNAL CLUB: Predictors of Provider Response to Clinical Decision Support: Lessons from the Medicare Imaging Demonstration
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The effectiveness of imaging clinical decision support (CDS) varies. Our goal was to identify CDS factors that contribute to cancellation or modification of imaging orders. SUBJECTS AND METHODS: This before and after study was conducted at four institutions participating in the Medicare Imaging Demonstration. The intervention was CDS upon order for selected outpatient imaging procedures. Based on the information entered, EDP warnings indicated to the providers whether orders were not in line with the guidelines, appropriate, of uncertain appropriateness or inappropriate according to the guidelines of the trade association. Order Providers could override or accept CDS. We viewed actionable alerts as those that could prompt an immediate change in the prescribing behavior of the prescribing physician (ie, canceling inappropriate prescriptions or changing prescriptions of uncertain appropriateness for which an alternative was recommended). Chi-square and logistic regression identified predictors of order cancellation or modification after an alert. RESULTS: A total of 98,894 radiology orders were entered (83,114 after intervention). Vendors ignored 98.9% of orders, modified 1.1%, and canceled 0.03% of orders in response to alerts. Actionable alerts had a 10-fold higher change (8.1% vs. 0.7%; p<0.0001) or cancellation (0.2% vs. 0.02%; p<0.0001) orders in comparison on unactionable alerts 7x lower cancellation or change rate than sites with newly implemented CDS (1.4% vs. 0.2%; p<0.0001) In multivariate analysis, actionable alerts were 12x more likely to result in cancellation or changing orders on pre-existing CDS, they were 7.7 times less likely to be canceled or changed (p<0.0001). These results may have implications for the future design of such computerized systems.

title: Health-care worker rule-related behavior assessments: An experimental study
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To explore the assessment of rule-related behavior by healthcare professionals and the general public in the UK as clinical guidelines and protocols proliferate. DESIGN: A questionnaire survey was used in which brief scenarios describing medical practice were presented to a sample of health professionals and members of the general public. METHODS: The healthcare sample consisted of 315 nurses, doctors and midwives from three English National Health Service (NHS) trusts who volunteered to take part in the study. A stratified sample of members of the general public (N=350) was recruited through a market research firm. Three types of behavior (adherence to protocol, violation of protocol, and improvisation where no protocol exists) and three types of patient outcomes (good, bad, bad) were manipulated in nine scenarios. Respondents were asked to provide judgments about (1) the inappropriateness of the behavior, (2) the likelihood that they would take further action, and (3) responsibility for the outcome. RESULTS: The results suggest that the nursing process has a greater impact on the assessment of health professional behavior than the outcome of that behavior. This applied equally to the professional and public rehearsals. CONCLUSIONS: The study has both theoretical and practical implications. First, information about a behavior's relationship to existing rules has a stronger impact than the behavior's consequence on attributions of responsibility. Second, the use of clinical protocols as a risk management tool in the NHS can be counterproductive if full compliance is not achieved.

title: The Judicial Council offers new research guidelines
Prudent use of antibiotics in common pediatric respiratory infections
abstract: BACKGROUND: Antibiotic resistance among common bacteria that cause respiratory infections, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis, has become a major global public health problem. The use of antibiotics, whether or not medically justified for a particular disease, contributes to the development of resistant bacteria. To curb the spread of drug-resistant bacteria, members of the CDC and the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recently published principles for the prudent use of antibiotics for common pediatric respiratory infections, including the common cold, otitis media, sinusitis, and tonsillopharyngitis. This article provides an overview of the CDC/AAP principles for treating these diseases and describes the results of field clinical studies that have attempted to improve the prudent use of antibiotics. CONCLUSIONS: The success of the CDC/AAP principles in containing the growth of antimicrobial resistance depends on their implementation. The results of clinical practice studies indicate that judicious use of antimicrobial therapy in pediatric respiratory infections can be achieved through education and perseverance. Greater education and behavior change efforts are needed to reduce unnecessary antibiotic prescribing and stem the still burgeoning problem of bacterial resistance.

title: Working hours of the juniors
Evidence-Based Just-in-Time Email "Reminders" in Homecare: Implications for Patient Outcomes
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the impact and cost-effectiveness of two provider information-based reminder interventions to improve self-care management and outcomes in heart failure (HF) patients. DATA SOURCES/STUDY SETTINGS: Survey and regulatory data from 628 home care patients with a primary diagnosis of heart failure. STUDY DESIGN: Patients were treated by nurses who were randomly assigned to usual care or to one of two intervention groups. The basic intervention was an email to the patient's caregiver highlighting six HF-specific clinical recommendations. The augmented intervention supplemented the initial care reminder with additional clinician and patient resources. DATA COLLECTION: Patient interviews were conducted 45 days after enrollment to measure self-management behavior, heart failure-specific outcomes (Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire-KCCQ), health-related quality of life (EuroQoL), and use of the service. MAIN RESULTS: Both interventions improved the mean KCCQ summary score (15.3 and 12.9 percent, respectively) compared to usual care (p < or = 0.05). The baseline intervention also resulted in a higher EuroQoL score compared to usual care (p < or = 0.05). In addition, the interventions had a positive effect on medication knowledge, diet and weight control. The baseline intervention was more cost-effective than the extended intervention in improving clinical outcomes. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates the positive impact of evidence-based computer reminders for homecare workers to improve patient self-care behaviors, knowledge, and clinical outcomes. It also advances the discipline's limited understanding of the cost-effectiveness of selected strategies for translating research into practice.

title: Evidence-Based Just-In-Time Email "Reminders" in Homecare: Implications for Patient Outcomes.
abstract: objective. To evaluate the impact and cost-effectiveness of two information-based reminder interventions for providers designed to improve self-care management and outcomes in heart failure (HF) patients. Data Sources/Study Setting. Agency interview and management data of 628 home care patients with a primary diagnosis of heart failure. study design. Patients were treated by nurses who were randomly assigned to usual care or to one of two intervention groups. The basic intervention was an email to the patient's caregiver highlighting six HF-specific clinical recommendations. The augmented intervention supplemented the initial care reminder with additional clinician and patient resources. data collection. Patient interviews were conducted 45 days after enrollment to measure self-management behavior, heart failure-specific outcomes (Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire-KCCQ), health-related quality of life (EuroQoL), and use of the service. main results. Both interventions improved the mean KCCQ summary score (15.3 and 12.9 percent, respectively) compared to usual care (p=0.05). The baseline intervention also resulted in a higher EuroQoL score compared to usual care (p=0.05). In addition, the interventions had a positive effect on medication knowledge, diet and weight control. The baseline intervention was more cost-effective than the extended intervention in improving clinical outcomes. Conclusions. This study demonstrates the positive impact of evidence-based computer reminders for homecare workers to improve patient self-care behaviors, knowledge, and clinical outcomes. It also advances the discipline's limited understanding of the cost-effectiveness of selected strategies for translating research into practice.

title: Evidence-based just-in-time email 'reminders' in homecare: implications for 'nursing practices'.
abstract: objective. To test the effectiveness of two interventions aimed at improving the adoption of evidence-based practices by home caregivers caring for heart failure (HF) patients. Data Sources/Study Setting. Information on nursing practices was extracted from the clinical records of patients admitted to the care of 354 study nurses at a large, municipal, non-profit home care facility between June 2000 and November 2001. study design. The study used a randomized design with nurses assigned to usual care or to one of two intervention groups after identifying an eligible patient. The basic intervention was a one-time email reminder highlighting six HF-specific clinical recommendations. The extended intervention consisted of the initial email reminder supplemented by prompts from the provider, patient education material, and contact with clinical nurses. data collection. At each home health visit that a study nurse performed on an eligible heart failure patient during the 45-day follow-up period, a structured chart abstraction tool was used to collect information about whether the nurse followed the nursing practices highlighted in the email reminder has performed . main results. Both the basic and extended interventions have significantly improved the practice of evidence-based care according to patient records in the areas of patient assessment and instruction in managing heart failure. While not all results were statistically significant at conventional levels, intervention effects were positive in virtually all cases, and effect sizes were often large. Conclusions. The results of this randomized study strongly support the effectiveness of evidence-based just-in-time reminders as a means of changing clinical practice among home health caregivers who are geographically dispersed and spend much of their time in the field.

title: Kids Safe and Smokefree (KiSS): a randomized controlled trial of a multi-step intervention to reduce tobacco smoke exposure in children
abstract: BACKGROUND: Exposure to secondhand smoke (SHSe) harms children's health, yet effective interventions to reduce SHSe in children at home and in the car have proven difficult in pediatric practice. A multi-step intervention that combines counseling from pediatric healthcare providers with behavioral counseling and navigation to pharmacological cessation aids can improve SHSe control in pediatric populations. METHODS/DESIGN: This study used a randomized, two-group design with three measurement periods: pre-intervention, end-of-treatment, and 12-month follow-up. Smoking parents of children <11 years are recruited from children's hospitals. Clinical-level intervention includes the integration of tobacco intervention guideline prompts into electronic medical record screens. Guide providers are encouraged to ask all parents about SHSe harms in children, provide advice on SHSe harms, and refer smokers to smoking cessation resources. After receiving a clinical intervention, eligible parents will be randomized to receive: (a) a 3-month behavioral counseling telephone intervention aimed at reducing SHSe in children, parental smoking cessation, and navigation to access nicotine replacement therapy or cessation medication or (b) a nutritional education intervention for attentional control. Healthcare providers and assessors are blind to the group assignment. Cotinine is used to verify the child's SHSe status (primary outcome) and the parent's withdrawal status. DISCUSSION: This study tests an innovative multi-step approach to reducing childhood SHSe. The approach is sustainable because clinics can easily integrate the prompts for tobacco intervention associated with the “Ask, Counsel, and Refer” guidelines into electronic health records and refer smokers to free, evidence-based behavioral counseling interventions such as government quitlines. TRIAL REGISTRATION: NCT01745393 (clinicaltrials.gov).

title: Kindergarten readiness after prematurity: Integrating health, development, and behavioral functioning to optimize educational outcomes in at-risk children
abstract: In the past 20 years, many advances (eg, maternal steroids and surfactants) have changed the course of neonatal medicine. As a result, extremely preterm infants survive medical complications that were previously fatal. After discharge from the NICU, preterm infants may continue to face a range of medical and developmental challenges, and their families face the potentially daunting task of caring for an at-risk child. Families may be referred to multiple systems of care, including primary care physicians, pediatric subspecialists, and early intervention services. The ultimate goal for preterm infants is to optimize their motor, communicative, social-emotional and adaptive development and to support their learning at home, at school and in the community. As children transition into school, key indicators of their functional status are the amount of developmental, educational, habilitation, and behavioral support they need to participate in learning activities with their peers. Success can be measured by whether preterm babies are ready for learning in large groups with their peers and how much support is needed for this important transition. The purpose of this review is to describe what is known about certain indicators of school readiness in preterm infants, including neurodevelopmental disorders, social-emotional skills, and social factors. We conclude with guidelines for using this transition as an important indicator of developmental trajectories that can help us better understand risk and resilience in this vulnerable population of children.

title: Knowledge, attitude and use of low-dose computed tomography for lung cancer screening in general practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND: The results of the National Lung Screening Trial showed a 20% reduction in lung cancer mortality and a 6.7% reduction in all-cause mortality when high-risk patients were examined with low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) versus chest X-ray (CXR). The US Preventive Services Task Force has issued a Class B recommendation for LDCT screening, and the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services and private insurers now cover the cost of screening under certain conditions. The aim of this study was to assess the knowledge, attitudes and use of LDCT screening for lung cancer among general practitioners. METHODS: A 32-item questionnaire was distributed to members of the South Carolina Academy of Family Physicians in 2015. Descriptive statistics were calculated. RESULTS: There were 101 respondents, and most were misinformed about which organizations recommend screening. Many physicians continued to recommend CXR for lung cancer screening. Most felt that LDCT screening increases the likelihood of detecting disease at earlier stages (98%) and that the benefits outweighed the disadvantages (75%). Concerns included unnecessary procedures (88%), stress/anxiety (52%) and exposure to radiation (50%). Most physicians have discussed the risks/benefits of screening with their patients to some extent (76%), however more than 50% reported having made 1 or no screening recommendations in the past year Referrals low There are gaps in physicians' knowledge of screening guidelines and reimbursement, suggesting a need for further education Developing decision aids can facilitate shared decision-making discussions about screening and Targeted interventions can fill gaps in knowledge. Cancer 2016;"122:2324-2331. (c) 2016 American Cancer Society.

title: Knowledge translation of research results
abstract: Background One of the most enduring lessons from clinical and health care research is the failure to translate research into practice and policy. As a result of these gaps between evidence, practice, and policy, patients do not benefit optimally from advances in healthcare and are exposed to unnecessary risks of iatrogenic harm, and healthcare systems are exposed to unnecessary expenditures that result in significant opportunity costs. Over the past decade, international policy and research attention has increased on how to narrow the gap between evidence and practice and policy. In this paper, we summarize the current concepts and evidence to guide knowledge translation activities, defined as T2 research (the translation of new clinical knowledge into improved health).
