We structure the article around five key questions: what to transfer; to whom should research knowledge be transferred; through whom should research knowledge be transferred; how should research knowledge be transferred;" and with what effect should research knowledge be transferred? Discussion We propose that the basic unit of knowledge translation should normally be recent systematic reviews or other syntheses of research results. Knowledge translators need to identify the key messages for different audiences and translate them into Transform language and knowledge translation products that can be easily assimilated by different audiences. The relative importance of knowledge translation for different audiences depends on the type of research, and appropriate endpoints of knowledge translation may vary by stakeholder. There are a large number of planned knowledge translation models, derived from different disciplinary, contextual (ie setting) and target group points of view, most of which indicate that a planned translation of knowledge Education for healthcare professionals and consumers is more likely to be successful if the choice of knowledge translation strategy is based on an assessment of likely barriers and enablers. Although our evidence for the likely effectiveness of different strategies for overcoming specific barriers is incomplete, there are a number of informative systematic reviews of interventions targeted at healthcare professionals and consumers (i.e., patients, family members, and informal carers) and factors affecting they are important research uses by policy makers. Summary There is an extensive (albeit incomplete) evidence base to guide the choices of knowledge translation activities for healthcare professionals and consumers. The evidence base on the impact of different knowledge translation approaches aimed at policymakers and healthcare leaders is much weaker, but there is a wealth of innovative approaches that warrant further evaluation.

title: Knowledge translation of the American College of Emergency Physicians clinical guideline on syncope using computer-assisted clinical decision support
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To influence practice behaviors of physicians after implementing a computer-assisted clinical decision support system (CDSS) based on the recommendations of the 2007 ACEP Clinical Policy on Syncope. METHODS: This was a pre-post intervention with a prospective cohort and retrospective controls. We conducted a review of the medical histories of consecutive adult patients with syncope. A computerized CDSS has been embedded in the Emergency Department Information System (EDIS) that prompts physicians to explain their imaging and admissions decisions in patients with syncope based on the ACEP Clinical Policy recommendations. The medical records of 410 consecutive adult patients with syncope were reviewed prior to implementation, and 301 records were reviewed post-implementation. Primary endpoints were physician practice behaviors as indicated by admission rate and head computed tomography (CT) imaging rate before and after implementation. RESULTS: There was a significant difference in the admission rate before and after the intervention (68.1% vs. 60.5%, p=0.036). There was no significant difference in the head CT imaging rate before and after the intervention (39.8% vs. 43.2%, p=0.358). There were seven physicians who saw ten or more patients during pre- and post-intervention. The subgroup analysis of the practice behavior of these seven physicians revealed a slight significant difference in the admission rate before and after the intervention (74.3% vs. 63.9%, p = 0.0495) and no significant difference in the head CT scan rate before and post-intervention (42.9% vs. 45.4%, p=0.660). CONCLUSIONS: The introduction of an evidence-based CDSS based on the ACEP Clinical Policy recommendations on syncope correlated with a change in physician practice behavior in an urban academic emergency department. This change suggests that the recommendations of the Emergency Medicine Clinical Practice Guidelines can be integrated into the physician workflow of an EDIS to improve the quality of practice.

title: Knowledge versus practice: The need for education for successful guideline implementation
abstract: This study assessed physicians' familiarity with a practice guideline for bronchiolitis, assessed attitudes towards guidelines, determined preference of educational materials for guideline accessibility, and examined the relationship between guideline familiarity and attitudes towards behavior in clinical practice. Six months after implementation of the guideline, surveys were distributed to eligible physicians. The response rate was 68%. Retrospective analyzes of inhalation therapies across three study cohorts were also performed. Most physicians interviewed in this study were aware of and were using a recently established guideline, despite continued use of unproven inhalation therapies. Despite proven effectiveness of care, ongoing educational intervention is necessary to maintain these gains.

title: Knowledge, attitudes, and practices related to breast cancer screening among educated Appalachian women
abstract: PURPOSE/OBJECTIVES: To determine how and what women learn about breast cancer and screening practices and what factors influence women's breast cancer screening practices. DESIGN: Descriptive analysis of questionnaire data collected at the time of enrollment in a clinical trial. SETTING: Breast care center at a mid-Atlantic academic health sciences center. SAMPLE: 185 women in a mostly rural Appalachian state. METHODS: Participants completed the Modified Toronto Breast Self-Examination Inventory and personal mammography practice questions at the time of enrollment before being randomized into a longitudinal clinical intervention study. KEY RESEARCH VARIABLES: Female demographics, knowledge of breast cancer screening practices, adherence to breast cancer screening guidelines, and motivation, knowledge, and practice skills related to breast cancer screening. RESULTS: These educated women had knowledge deficits about breast cancer, breast cancer risk factors, and screening guidelines, particularly about the timing and behavior of breast self-examination. Women who were tutored in health care and cancer screening by health care providers, including advanced nurses, had greater knowledge about breast cancer and detection practices. Conclusions: Women still have knowledge deficits about breast cancer, breast cancer detection and personal risk factors. In addition, some educated women in this study failed to practice breast cancer screening according to current guidelines. CARE IMPLICATIONS: Physicians must continue to remind and update women of breast disease, and women's cancer screening processes must be strengthened. All levels of providers should improve their rates of performing clinical breast exams with physical exams. Nurses, who have a major impact on women's healthcare, need to stay current in their knowledge of breast disease, screening and treatment.

title: KRAS and colorectal cancer: ethical and pragmatic issues in effecting real-time change in clinical trials and oncology practice
abstract: Systemic therapy has resulted in almost four times longer median survival in patients with advanced colorectal cancer (CRC) than best supportive care, a result achieved through the combination of chemotherapeutic agents and targeted biologics. Although the latter may contain antibodies against the epidermal growth factor receptor like cetuximab and panitumumab, we now have strong evidence that patients whose tumors have mutant KRAS do not benefit from this class of drugs. However, it took several years for acceptance of the reliability and importance of the KRAS data to develop for a variety of reasons. The timeline from the presentation and publication of small, retrospective phase II studies to widespread acceptance of the predictive value of KRAS and behavioral changes, changes in ongoing national studies in advanced/metastatic CRC, changes in national guidelines and practice patterns, and adjustments to those identified Indications for the monoclonal antibody was lengthy. In this commentary, we discuss whether the process of data disclosure regarding KRAS status and management of patients with advanced CRC was effective in enabling timely decisions about ongoing publicly funded clinical trials, and whether such decisions were rational, ethical, or not. The overall objectives are to highlight lessons learned regarding the early disclosure of clinical trial results, the review and acceptance of new scientific data, and to propose changes for dealing with similar situations in the future.

title: The design of laboratory test forms influences test ordering by GPs in the Netherlands
abstract: The effect of a reduced number of laboratory tests on the test request form on the test ordering behavior of a group of 47 Dutch general practitioners was examined. The number of laboratory tests ordered by this experimental group during a 12 month period was recorded. The usual, old standard form was used by a control group of 28 general practitioners in another region. After using the old standard form of 178 tests for 5 months, the experimental group received forms listing only 15 hematological and chemical tests and several urine and fecal tests, and space was allowed for "Others". A comparison of the test and control periods showed that the number of monthly examinations in the test group was reduced by 18. With the reintroduction of the usual standard form, GPs quickly reverted to their old pattern. The results showed that entrenched and often unhealthy routines influence the use of additional diagnostic procedures. In addition, limiting and restructuring the test order forms can break the routine, but does not significantly change the reasoning of the test order behavior.

title: Lack of effectiveness of table reminder in relation to knowledge and attitudes of JNC-VI and NCEP-III guidelines in primary care medicine
abstract: BACKGROUND: The literature shows that resident physicians and practicing physicians exhibit an attitudinal-behavioural discrepancy regarding their positive attitude towards clinical practice guidelines (CPG) and the translation of these guidelines into clinical practice patterns. METHODS: A pilot study was conducted to determine if changing a previously identified CPG compliance factor (accessibility) would result in a significant increase in knowledge and attitudes of primary care physicians towards the guidelines. The primary study intervention involved the publication of a summary of the sixth report of the Joint National Committee on Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC VI) and the National Cholesterol Education Program Expert Panel on Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure High Blood Cholesterol in Adults (NCEP III) CPGs in all patient records (> 18 years) for a three-month period. The JNC VI and NCEP III guidelines were also distributed to each resident of Wayne State Family Medicine, and a copy of each guideline was placed in the Preceptor's area of the participating clinics. Identical pre- and post-intervention questionnaires were administered to all residents regarding CPG knowledge and attitudes. RESULTS: Post-intervention analysis failed to demonstrate a significant difference in CPG knowledge. A statistically significant difference after the intervention was only found for the attitude question. The barriers to CPG compliance were identified as 1) lack of CPG instructions; 2) lack of critical judgment skills; 3) insufficient time; 4) lack of CPG accessibility;' and 5) lack of factorial modelling. CONCLUSION: This study showed no significant changes in CPG knowledge after the intervention and only one question reflecting a change in attitude. Broader resident access to dedicated clinic time, increased faculty modeling, and implementation of an electronic recording/reminder system that uses a team-based approach are compliance factors that should be considered for further investigation. Interpretation of CPG non-compliance will benefit from a causal matrix focused on physician knowledge, attitudes and behavior. Recent findings on resident knowledge-behaviour discordances may direct future investigation of physician non-adherence to guidelines away from general barrier research and toward the development of information that maximizes the individual physician's sense of urgency and reassurance.

title: Old-age depression in primary care. how well are we doing
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine primary care physicians' attitudes towards their ability to identify and treat depression in the elderly. DESIGN: A self-administered questionnaire mailed to 1,000 primary care physicians in the state of Michigan. SETTING: The survey was sent to physicians practicing general internal medicine or family medicine. PARTICIPANTS: The questionnaire was mailed to 500 MD and 500 DO physicians, with general internal medicine and general medicine equally represented. Of all 1,000 physicians, 60% (n=604) responded, 51% (n=309) were MDs, 48% (n=295) were DOs, 41% (n=245) were general internists, and 59% (n=359 ) Primary care physicians MEASUREMENTS AND KEY RESULTS: Despite positive attitudes toward their ability to identify and treat depression in older people, only a quarter of respondents routinely use a screening tool in their practice 41% of all physicians are unaware of the guidelines for depression practice primary care physicians are of their treatment competencies more confident than general practitioners (85% vs 50%;" chi 2 = 11.42, p < or = 0.003). Male physicians were more likely to advocate pharmacological treatment, while female physicians were more likely to use counseling and exercise techniques to treat depressed elderly patients. Half of all Physicians indicated that they were aware of community resources for treating older depressed patients CONCLUSIONS: This survey identified several perceived needs Needs for future targeted interventions: (1) additional Agency for Health Care Policy and Research guidelines for all primary care physicians, (2) targeted counseling competency intervention for male physicians and medication management for female physicians, and (3) additional continuing medical education for practicing general internists. Further research is needed to correlate physician attitudes with resulting behaviors to fully understand the nature of treatment for depression in the elderly in primary care.

title: Learning and Behavior., 5th ed.
abstract: This book examines how humans and animals learn and how their behavior later changes. This text is designed for introductory or intermediate courses in learning, conditioning, or experimental behavior analysis. Chapter 1 discusses the nature of scientific theories and experiments and contrasts the behavioral and cognitive approaches to learning. Chapter 2 describes theories on the learning process. Chapters 3 and 4 discuss innate behavior and habituation and examine the basic principles of classical conditioning. Chapter 5 describes recent theoretical developments and experimental findings in this field. Chapters 6, 7, and 8 involve operant conditioning and examine positive reinforcement"; plans of reinforcement;" and negative reinforcement or punishment. Chapter 9 presents different views on issues such as what constitutes a reinforcer and what conditions are necessary for learning to take place. Chapter 10 takes a closer look at generalization and discrimination and examines research on concept formation. Chapter 11 provides an overview of a wide range of findings in the field of comparative cognition. Chapters 12 and 13 deal with observational and motor learning. Finally, Chapter 14 provides an overview of behavioral research on choices. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Learning Evaluation: Merging quality improvement and implementation research methodologies to study innovation in healthcare
abstract: Background In health care change interventions, local learning about the implementation process is often lost as the primary focus is on improving outcomes. This paper describes Learning Evaluation, a methodological approach that combines quality improvement and implementation research methods to examine innovations in healthcare. Methods Learning Evaluation is an approach to cross-organizational evaluation. Qualitative and quantitative data is collected to conduct a real-time assessment of implementation processes while evaluating changes in context, facilitating quality improvements using history charts and audit and feedback, and generating transferrable lessons. Five principles underpin this approach: (1) collect data to describe changes being made by healthcare organizations and how changes are implemented; (2) collect process and outcome data relevant to healthcare organizations and the research team; (3) assess contextual factors at multiple levels affecting implementation, process, outcome, and transferability, (4) assist healthcare organizations in using data for continuous quality improvement, and (5) operationalize common measurement strategies to achieve transferable outcomes organizations through the following : (1) build a detailed understanding of the baseline implementation plan; (2) identification of target groups and tracking of relevant process measures; (3) Collection and analysis of real-time quantitative and qualitative data on important contextual factors; (4 ) synthesizing data and new insights and ongoing exchange with stakeholders;' and (5) harmonizing and promoting learning from process and outcome data. Application to a multi-site program focused on primary care and behavioral health integration demonstrates the feasibility and usefulness of learner evaluation for generating real-time insights into evolving implementation processes. Conclusions Learning evaluation generates systematic and rigorous cross-organizational insights on the implementation of healthcare innovation while improving organizational capacity and accelerating the translation of insights by enabling continuous learning at individual sites. Researchers evaluating change initiatives and healthcare organizations implementing improvement initiatives can benefit from a Learning Evaluation approach.

title: Learning with computer-aided guidelines in the general practice? A randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background. Evidence-based guidelines are considered an important tool for transferring scientifically generated findings into everyday clinical practice and ensuring high standards in clinical care. Despite widespread use, clinical guidelines have so far only had a limited impact on individual professional learning and on changes in daily medical practice. Goals. Our goals were (i) to investigate potential knowledge gains among German general practitioners after the implementation of web- and evidence-based guidelines and (ii) to identify and analyze potential barriers to individual professional learning with computer-based guidelines. methods. A prospective, randomized, controlled study was conducted with 72 general practitioners (21% female, 79% male). The intervention group (n = 38) had access to clinical guidelines via the Internet or CD-ROM, while the control group did not (n = 34). Both groups received a standardized two-part questionnaire. An increase in knowledge was measured with 25 multiple-choice questions on four different medical topics. In addition, reasons for the use or non-use of computerized guidelines were analyzed after guidelines were open to all participating physicians. Results. There was no significant knowledge gain in the intervention group (p = 0.69). Twenty-two (58%) general practitioners in the intervention group had used the guidelines. Unspecified curiosity (76%) and a specific medical question (38%) were the predominant motives for use by physicians who had applied the guideline. Among the 'non-users', 78% cited 'lack of time' as the main reason for not using guidelines. Conclusion. Efficient knowledge transfer through computerized guidelines was not achieved. Utilization, individual learning and possible implementation depend on appropriate incentives and pragmatic aspects of clinical practice: easy and quick access.

title: left-handedness
Legal liability of physicians in medical research
abstract: The intention of this paper is to provide an overview, in layman's language, of the legal concepts that may be applicable to a research physician. The paper is divided into 2 parts. Part I addresses liability issues and standards of care. It should enable the doctor/researcher to recognize a possible liability situation. Part II examines insurance and related topics such as the role of the Canadian Medical Protective Association (CMPA). The paper begins with an overview of 2 possible categories of liability: criminal and civil tort. Next up are legal issues surrounding the consent process, which make up the majority of negligence claims. The research process is then discussed with a focus on the Medical Research Council of Canada guidelines on human experimentation. Part II addresses research funding and identifies the parties to which insurance coverage may be sought. Information is provided from the various sources that offer insurance and quasi-insurance coverage, with particular attention to the CMPA. Each source states the circumstances necessary for that particular reporting to be triggered. Other issues addressed include those that arise when research is conducted outside of Canada and multiple coverage.

title: Health disparities among lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender people: Summary of a policy position paper from the American College of Physicians
abstract: In this position paper, the American College of Physicians examines the health inequalities faced by the lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) community and makes a number of recommendations to ensure equality for LGBT people in the health care system reach. These recommendations include improving physicians' understanding of how to provide culturally and clinically competent care to LGBT people, addressing environmental and social factors that can affect their mental and physical well-being, and supporting further research to understand their unique ones health needs.

title: Lessons learned from a randomized controlled trial evaluating computer decision support software for improving asthma management
abstract: Primary objective: To study whether computer decision support software used in the management of patients with asthma improves clinical outcomes. Research design: Randomized controlled trial with practices each reporting on 30 patients with asthma over a 6-month period. METHODS AND METHODS: 447 patients were randomly selected from asthma registries maintained by 17 general practices across the UK. Intervention practices used the software during consultations with these patients throughout the study, while control practices did not. Key Outcomes and Outcomes: Physician visits, acute asthma exacerbations, hospital contacts, symptoms at assessment, and medication use. A smaller proportion of patients within the intervention group initiated visits because of their asthma: 34 (22%) vs 111 (34%), odds ratio (OR) = 0.59, 95% confidence interval (CI) (0.37-0 ,95)”; " and experienced acute asthma exacerbations: 12 (8%) vs. 57 (17%), OR=0.43, 95% CI=0.21-0.85 six months after the introduction of the computer decision support software. There were no discernible differences in reported symptoms, maintenance medication prescriptions, or use of hospital services between the two groups.Conclusion: The use of computer decision support software that implements guidelines during patient consultations may improve clinical outcomes for patients with asthma.

title: Lessons learned from the assessment of the UK NHS R&D Implementation Methods Program
abstract: Background Concerns about the effective use of research was a key reason for the establishment of the NHS Research and Development Program in 1991. In 1994 an Advisory Group was established to identify research priorities in conducting research. This resulted in the Implementation Methods Program (IMP), whose client group funded 36 projects. In 2000, responsibility for the program passed to the National Coordinating Center for NHS Service Delivery and Organization R&D, which asked Brunel University's Health Economics Research Group (HERG) to conduct an evaluation in 2002. By this time most of the projects had been completed. This evaluation should cover: the quality of the results, lessons learned from the communication strategy and the commissioning process, and the benefits of the projects. Methods We used a wide range of quantitative and qualitative methods. These included: document analysis, interviews with key stakeholders, questionnaires to the funded lead researchers, questionnaires to potential users and desk analysis. Results The quantitative assessment of the results and dissemination revealed that the IMP funded useful research projects, some of which had a significant impact on the different categories of the HERG payback model, such as: B. Publications, further research, research training, implications for health policy and clinical practice. Qualitative findings from interviews with advisory and commissioning group members indicated that implementation research was a relatively unexplored field when the IMP was established. This was reflected in the roles of the members of the Advisory and Commissioning Groups, the way research priorities were selected and developed and the research projects commissioned. The ideological and methodological debates associated with these decisions continued among those working in the field. Of particular importance was the need for an effective communication strategy for the program as a whole. However, such a strategy was never developed, making it difficult to ascertain the overall impact of the IMP as a programme. Conclusion Our insights into the implications of the funded work and the difficulties faced by those developing the IMP have implications for the development of strategic research programs in general, as well as for the development of more effective research in this area.

title: Letter: Mucosal ulcers in celiac disease
Using insights from behavioral economics to increase the value of health service delivery
abstract: United States healthcare spending continues to grow at an unsustainable rate. A more recent movement to increase price transparency has been proposed to reduce the rate of increase in spending, with legislative efforts at both the state and federal levels. While this may seem like a good idea on the surface, simply providing pricing information to physicians, particularly trainees, may not bring about the kind of big changes in practice patterns that proponents expect. The manner in which price transparency is implemented is likely to play a significant role in its effectiveness as an intervention. In this article, the authors review transparency efforts and default options from other contexts, and use insights from behavioral economics to make recommendations to increase the likelihood that price transparency will lead physicians to weigh the relative value of interventions.

title: LGB Affirmative Cognitive-Behavioural Therapy for Young Adult Gay and Bisexual Men: A Randomized Controlled Trial of a Transdiagnostic Minority Stress Approach
abstract: OBJECTIVES: We tested the preliminary efficacy of a transdiagnostic cognitive-behavioural treatment adapted to improve depression, anxiety, and co-occurring health risks (e.g., alcohol use, sexual compulsion, sex without a condom) in young adult gay and bisexual men. Treatment adjustments have focused on reducing minority stress processes underlying mental health inequalities related to sexual orientation. METHOD: Young gay and bisexual males (n=63; mean age=25.94) were randomized to receive immediate treatment or a 3-month wait-list. At the baseline, 3-month, and 6-month assessments, participants completed self-reports on minority mental health and stress and completed an interview on risky behaviors over the past 90 days. RESULTS: Compared to waiting list, treatment significantly reduced depressive symptoms (b = -2.43, 95% CI: -4.90, 0.35, p<0.001), alcohol use problems (b = -3.79, 95% CI : -5.94, -1.64). , p < 0.001), sexual compulsion (b = -5.09, 95% CI: -8.78, -1.40, p < 0.001), and condomless sex with casual partners in the past 90 days (b = -1, 09, 95% CI: -1.80, -0.37, p<0.001) and improved condom use self-efficacy (b=10.08, 95% CI: 3.86, 16.30, p<0.001). Treatment resulted in anxiety symptoms (b = -2.14, 95% CI: -4.61, 0.34, p = 0.09) and heavy alcohol consumption in the last 90 days (b = -0.32, 95 %) to moderate and marginally significantly greater improvements than on the waitlist. CI: -0.71, 0.07, p=0.09). Effects generally persisted at follow-up. Minority stress processes showed small improvements in the expected direction. CONCLUSION: This study showed preliminary support for the first intervention, which was adapted to address the co-occurring health problems of gay and bisexual men at their source in minority stress. If shown to be effective compared to standard evidence-based treatments, the treatment will have significant potential to help clinicians translate LGB-affirming treatment guidelines into evidence-based practice. (PsycINFO database entry

title: Lifestyle advice through primary health care to prevent cardiovascular disease
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Working Group on Hypertension of the Norwegian College of General Practitioners reports in this paper on the documentation of behavioral advice in the prevention of cardiovascular disease. The focus is on high blood pressure. MATERIAL AND METHODS: The recommendations are mainly based on updated meta-analyses and randomized controlled trials. Hypertension is treated to prevent cardiovascular disease";" That's why we value documentation with meaningful endpoints. The validity of the documentation for general practice is assessed. We also evaluated whether certain behavior change methods or theories might be helpful for the GP. RESULTS: The value of smoking bans, dietary advice (increasing grain, vegetable, fruit, poultry and fish consumption), and exercise advice are well documented and applicable in general practice. Respecting patient autonomy and taking an interest in patients and their health-related habits appear to be important factors in improving the physician's ability to influence patient behavior. INTERPRETATION: The value of lifestyle advice is well documented and should play an important role in clinical strategies to prevent cardiovascular disease in high-risk patients.

title: Life support technologies and the elderly
Lifestyle counseling in primary care: long-term effects on cholesterol levels
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the long-term effectiveness of lifestyle counseling for subjects at low to moderate cardiovascular (CV) risk in primary care. METHODS: DESIGN: Prospective comparison of baseline vs. postintervention and comparison of enrolled patients vs. controls extracted from a large primary care database. SETTING: 94 general practitioner practices in Italy. PARTICIPANTS: All 20-70-year-old hypercholesterolemic subjects, guideline ineligible for statin treatment, followed on 12 specified work days; 713 patients; 94 general practitioners. INTERVENTION: Brief (5-10 min) educational intervention (quality dietary advice, encouragement of walking or other aerobic physical activity); "Delivery of simple dietary advice based on physician judgment. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Total cholesterol levels and global cardiovascular risk calculated using the Framingham equation. RESULTS: Total cholesterol and global cardiovascular risk (10 years) decreased by 0.31 mmol/L (p<0.0001, 95% CI 0.23-0.40) and 1.35% (p<0.01, 95% CI -1.73 to -0.97), at a 54-month follow-up Enrolled patients had greater reductions in total cholesterol than control patients: 2.24% (p<0.05, 95% CI 0 .58-3.91%).CONCLUSIONS: A simple, outpatient, long-term lifestyle counseling program results in small but clinically significant reductions in total cholesterol and global cardiovascular risk.This finding should encourage primary care physicians to improve all of their patients systematically offering simple, unstructured lifestyle advice.

title: Lifestyle interventions in primary health care: professional and organizational challenges
abstract: BACKGROUND: Interventions that support patients' efforts to make lifestyle changes that reduce tobacco use, hazardous alcohol use, unhealthy eating habits, and insufficient physical activity represent important areas of development for health care. Recent research shows that it is difficult to move health care toward Reorient health promotion. The aim of this study was to examine the extent of health professionals' work with lifestyle interventions in Swedish primary health care and to describe professional knowledge, attitudes and perceived organizational support for lifestyle interventions. Methods: The study is based on a web-based cross-sectional survey of general practitioners, other physicians, residents, nurses and registered nurses (n = 315) in primary health care. RESULTS: 59% of participants reported that lifestyle interventions were an essential part of their tasks. A majority (77%) would like to work more with patients' lifestyles. Health professionals generally reported a thorough knowledge of lifestyle intervention methods for disease prevention. Significant differences between the professional groups were revealed with regard to specific knowledge and the extent of work with lifestyle interventions. Alcohol was the least addressed lifestyle habit. Management was supportive, but structures to sustain work with lifestyle interventions were scarce and a need for national guidance was identified. CONCLUSIONS: Health professionals reported thorough knowledge and positive attitudes towards lifestyle interventions. When planning the further implementation of lifestyle interventions in primary health care, differences between the professional groups in terms of knowledge, scope of work with the promotion of healthy lifestyles and lifestyle issues, and the provision of organizational support such as national guidelines should be taken into account.

title: Lifestyle or Life Saving Drugs? A primary opinion poll of healthcare professionals and consumers on over-the-counter statins
abstract: BACKGROUND: Over-the-counter (OTC) simvastatin 10 mg was launched in the UK in July 2004 with the aim of improving primary prevention of ischemic heart disease. AIM: To document the views of key stakeholders (general practitioners [GPs], pharmacists, and consumers) on issues related to the reclassification of simvastatin to OTC availability, highlighting differences between stakeholders, and identifying factors likely to influence consumer behavior. METHODS: Eight months after the launch of OTC simvastatin in the UK, a self-administered questionnaire survey was conducted among GPs, pharmacists and potentially eligible consumers. Participants were asked about their awareness of the drug, their willingness to use such drugs, and their opinions on relevant treatment practices. RESULTS: Awareness of OTC simvastatin was high among primary care physicians but limited among consumers. Although OTC availability was preferred by pharmacists, consumers and GPs generally didn't think it was a good idea. GPs and pharmacists cited increased consumer choice as the most important likely benefit";" Consumers also considered potential savings for the National Health Service to be equally important. Medication abuse and neglect of lifestyle risk factors were unanimously considered the most important likely risks. Unlike the majority of pharmacists, most GPs felt that current dosing guidelines were inappropriate, but there was consensus that long-term non-compliance was likely to diminish any treatment benefit. Most respondents agreed that GPs should be informed when their patients are using OTC statins, but disagreed on how best to communicate this information. CONCLUSIONS: The OTC availability of statins did not appear to be viewed as a popular public health intervention by consumers and primary care physicians, as the drugs were generally viewed as prone to abuse. However, OTC availability was favored by pharmacists who saw it as empowering for both consumers and themselves. Key issues in the delivery, administration, and assessment of the public health impact of this intervention remain.

title: Lifetime prevalence of gender-based violence in women and the relationship to mental disorders and psychosocial functioning
abstract: Context Physical violence by intimate partners, rape, sexual assault and stalking are ubiquitous and co-occurring forms of gender-based violence (GBV). An association between these forms of abuse and lifelong mental disorders and psychosocial disabilities in women needs to be explored. Objectives To assess the association of GBV and mental disorder, its severity and comorbidity, and psychosocial functioning in women. Design, Setting and Participants A cross-sectional study based on the 2007 Australian National Mental Health and Well-being Survey of 4451 women (65% response rate) aged 16 to 85 years. The World Health Organization's World Mental Health Survey Initiative Composite International Diagnostic Interview Version 3.0 was used to assess the lifetime prevalence of mental disorders, anxiety, mood disorders, substance use disorders, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Also included were indices of lifetime trauma exposure, including GBV, sociodemographic characteristics, economic status, family history of mental disorders, social support, general mental and physical functioning, quality of life, and general disability. Results A total of 1218 women (27.4%) reported having experienced at least 1 type of GBV. In women exposed to 3 or 4 types of GBV (n=139), the rate of mental disorders was 77.3% (odds ratio [OR], 10.06", 95% confidence interval [CI], 5.85- 17.30) for anxiety disorders, 52.5% (OR, 3.59; 95% CI, 2.31-5.60) for mood disorder, 47.1% (OR, 5.61; 95% CI, 3rd .46–9.10) for substance use disorder, 56.2% (OR, 15.90; 95% CI, 8.32–30.20) for PTSD, 89.4% (OR, 11.00; 95% CI , 5.46–22.17) for any mental disorder and 34.7% (OR, 14.80; 95% CI, 6.89–31.60) for attempted suicide Violence was associated with a more severe current mental disorder (OR, 4.60; 95% CI, 2.93-7.22), higher rates of 3 or more lifetime disorders (OR, 7.79; 95% CI, 6.10-9.95), physical disability (OR, 4.00, 95% CI, 1.82-8.82), intellectual disability (OR, 7.14; 95% CI, 2.87-17.75), impaired quality of life (OR, 2.96; 95% CI, 1.60-5.47), an increase in sick leave days (OR, 3.14; 95% CI, 2.43-4.05), and general disability (OR, 2.73; 95% CI, 1, 99-3:75.) Sch Conclusion In a nationally representative sample of Australian women, gender-based violence was significantly associated with mental health disorders, dysfunction and disability.

title: "Like Sugar and Honey": The embedded ethics of a larval control project in The Gambia
abstract: This paper describes a malaria research project in The Gambia to stimulate reflection on the social value of transnational research. The Larval Control Project (LCP) investigated the effectiveness of a microbial insecticide in reducing vector density and ultimately clinical malaria in Gambian children. The LCP's protocol described a clinical surveillance program involving village health workers (VHWs) supported by project nurses. Combining insights from ethnographic fieldwork conducted at the Medical Research Council (MRC) laboratories in Farafenni from 2005 to 2009, open-ended interviews with project nurses, and eight focus group discussions held in October 2007 with participating mothers, we consider the social Effects of the The determination method of the LCP against the background of several years of research. We found that while participants associated the LCP with clinical care, they also viewed collaboration between the nurses and VHWs as an added value. Organized around the operational functions of the trial, small collaborations provided the platform from which local capacity could be built. While ethical guidelines emphasize the considerations that need to be added to experimental efforts in Southern countries (e.g., designing informed consent processes, developing strategies for community engagement, or providing therapeutic access to participants after study completion), These results suggest that attention from supplementing ethical protocols to daily research work - embedding ethics through scientific activity - may provide a more solid foundation to strengthen the relationship between scientific rigor and social value.

title: Limited effect of a multicenter intervention to improve the quality and efficiency of pneumonia care
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the impact of a multifactorial intervention to improve the quality, efficiency, and patient understanding of community-acquired pneumonia care. DESIGN: Times Series cohort study. SETTING: Four academic health centers in the New York City metropolitan area. PATIENTS OR PARTICIPANTS: All consecutive adults hospitalized for pneumonia during a 5-month period before (n=1,013) and after (n=1,081) the implementation of a quality improvement (QI) initiative. INTERVENTIONS: A multidisciplinary team of thought leaders developed evidence-based treatment guidelines and critical pathways, conducted educational sessions with physicians, distributed pocket-sized reminder cards, promoted standardized ordering, and developed bilingual patient education materials. MEASUREMENTS AND RESULTS: The mean age was 71.4 years and 44.1% of cases were low risk, 36.8% intermediate risk and 19.2% high risk. The pre- and post-intervention groups were well matched in terms of age, sex, race, nursing home residency, severity of pneumonia, first presentation, and most important comorbidities. The intervention increased the use of guideline-recommended antimicrobial therapy from 78.1% to 83.4% (p=0.003). There was also a borderline decrease in the proportion of patients discharged before becoming clinically stable, from 27.0 to 23.5% (p=0.06). However, there were no improvements in the other outcome measures, including time to first antibiotic dose, proportion of antibiotics received within 8 hours, timely switch to oral antibiotics, timely discharge, length of stay, or patient education outcomes. CONCLUSIONS: This hands-on QI program was able to improve slightly on some quality indicators, but with no impact on resource use or patients' knowledge of their disease. The change in medical and organizational behavior in academic health centers requires the development and implementation of intensive system-oriented strategies.

title: Local clinical guidelines: description and evaluation of a participatory method for their development and implementation
abstract: BACKGROUND: National guidelines are rarely followed by an immediate change in clinical behavior. We present our experiences with an active educational method for local development and implementation of a guideline. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of a participatory method for developing local clinical guidelines. METHODS: A study in one district on the effect of guideline development involving active participation of intended recipients in subsequent relevant prescribing. It was conducted in the Wirral Family Health Services Authority District (Wirral Peninsula), which includes 69 general practices and covers a population of 345,763 residents. Using the method described, an exemplary guideline for “hypertension in old age” was developed. The main drug recommended was bendrofluazide 2.5 mg once daily. The differences in quarterly prescribed daily doses (PDD) of bendrofluazide 2.5 mg tablets per 1000 prescribing units (age-weighted population) between the intervention district and England as a whole were measured. RESULTS: The comparison of the intervention districts with the data from England shows a median difference of 122.49 PDD before and 206.34 PDD after the creation of the guideline, this change is statistically highly significant (Mann-Whitney Two-Tailed P < 0.0001", 95 % CI = 36.51-104.77 Grouped regression analysis shows no significant difference (0.89) in slope gradients before guideline generation (P = 0.35, 95% CI = -3.97-5.76) , but the difference in the slope gradients after (12.95) is highly statistically significant (P < 0.0001; 95% CI = 8.17-17.73).The data suggest that the change in clinical behavior is at least two CONCLUSION: The participation of the intended general practitioners and local specialists in the development of a guideline through an active educational method as described was followed by a positive change in clinical behavior that lasted at least two years.

title: Local Learning Collaborations to Improve Quality in Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD): From Four Regional Practice-Based Research Networks (PBRNs)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Four practice-oriented research networks (PBRNs) participated in a project to increase the dissemination of evidence-based treatment guidelines for chronic kidney disease (CKD). A multi-component organizational intervention involved regionally nearby primary care practitioners in a series of facilitated meetings called Local Learning Collaborations (LLCs). METHODS: The 2-wave strategy began with 8 practices in each PBRN receiving practice facilitations and subsequently joining an LLC. A sequential mixed-methods design addressed the delivery, content, and accuracy of the intervention. Clinicians in 2 PBRNs participated in interviews, and PBRN coordinators reflected on implementation challenges. RESULTS: LLCs were formed in 3 PBRNs, with 121 monthly meetings held in 20 LLCs. Just over half of the participants were clinicians. Qualitative data suggest that clinicians increased the priority for CKD care, improved their knowledge and skills, were satisfied with the project, and attempted to improve care. Implementation challenges were identified and sustainability concerns were raised. CONCLUSION: While PBRNs can successfully use resources to disseminate treatment guidelines and LLCs are well accepted by clinical staff, establishing LLCs was not feasible for 1 PBRN and others struggled to meet regularly and performance data despite logistical support being available to have.

title: Long-term effectiveness in prescribing two multifaceted educational interventions: results from two large-scale randomized cluster studies
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Information about the benefits and risks of drugs is a key element influencing physicians' prescribing decisions. Outreach visits to promote independent information have been shown to be moderately effective in changing prescribing behavior. OBJECTIVES: To test the short- and long-term effectiveness of pharmacist-led small group meetings in GP prescribing. METHODS: Two open-label, randomized, controlled cluster trials (RCTs) were conducted in a large-scale NHS setting. Ad hoc produced evidence-based material was used considering a therapeutic approach – TEA with informational materials on osteoporosis or prostatic hyperplasia – and a single drug oriented approach – SIDRO with informational materials on me-too drugs from 2 different classes: barnidipine or prulifloxacin. In each study, all 115 primary care groups in a northern Italian area (population 2.2 million, 1737 general practitioners) were randomized to small educational group meetings where available evidence was provided along with data on drug use and clinical scenarios. Main results were changes in the six-month prescription of targeted drugs. Long-term results (24 and 48 months) were also evaluated. RESULTS: In the TEA study, one of the four primary endpoints showed a reduction (prescribing of alfuzosin compared to tamsulosin and terazosin in benign prostatic hyperplasia: prescribing ratio -8.5%, p=0.03). Another primary endpoint (prescribing of risedronate) showed a reduction at 24 and 48 months (-7.6%, p=0.02" and -9.8%, p=0.03), but not at six months ( -5.1%, p=0.36). In the SIDRO study, both primary endpoints showed a statistically significant reduction (barnidipine prescribing -9.8%, p=0.02; prulifloxacin prescribing -11.1% , p=0.04) that persisted or increased over time INTERPRETATION: These two cluster RCTs demonstrated the large-scale feasibility of a complex educational program in an NHS setting and its potentially relevant long-term implications for prescribing habits, particularly when the focus on a single drug National health systems should invest in independent drug information programs TRIALS REGISTRATION: Controlled-Trials.com ISRCTN05866587.

title: Long-term effects of an occupational health policy on employee body weight, cardiovascular disease risk factors, and quality of life: results of a randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a draft occupational health and safety guideline aimed at preventing weight gain, on employee body weight, cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors and quality of life. METHODS: Between 2009 and 2011, a cluster-randomized, controlled study with 16 occupational physicians (OT) and 523 employees in the Netherlands compared guideline-based care with usual OP care. The guideline-based mentoring consisted of (i) advising employers on how to assess and intervene in the obese work environment, (ii) conducting five face-to-face behavior change counseling sessions with employees to improve their lifestyle, and (iii) assessing the outcome and retention of Sections i and ii. Data were collected at baseline and at 6, 12, and 18 months of follow-up. Multi-level analyzes were carried out to evaluate the effects of the intervention. RESULTS: There were no significant differences between the intervention and control groups in waist circumference [beta 1.2 cm, 95% confidence interval (95% CI) -0.6-2.9], body weight (beta 0.3 kg, 95 % CI -1.0-1.6) found ), body mass index (beta 0.1 kg/m(2), 95% CI -0.3-0.5), systolic blood pressure (beta 1.7 mmHG , 95% CI -2.4-5.8), diastolic blood pressure (beta 0.3 mmHG, 95% CI -1.0-0.6), cholesterol (beta 0 mmol/L, 95% CI -0, 2-0.2) or quality of life indicators at 18 months of follow-up. Stratified analyzes showed an increase in waist circumference in males (beta 2.5 cm, 95% CI 0.5-4.5) and obese intervention participants (beta 2.7 cm, 95% CI 0.6-4.7) in comparison to control participants. CONCLUSION: The draft occupational health guideline was no more effective than usual care. Therefore, the directive cannot be recommended for implementation in its current form.

title: Long-term effects of asthma education for physicians on patient satisfaction and use of health services
abstract: This randomized clinical study evaluated the long-term effects of an interactive seminar for physicians based on principles of self-regulation on clinical behavior, child asthma health care utilization and parental perceptions of physician performance. 74 general practitioners and 637 of their asthma patients aged 1-12 years were randomized to treatment or control. Children and parents were blind to the participation of physicians. Data were collected at baseline and at follow-up through self-administered surveys (paediatricians), telephone interviews (parents), and medical records. The seminar focused on the development of communication and teaching skills and the application of therapeutic medical therapies for asthma as outlined in the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program guidelines. Approximately 2 years after the intervention, physicians in the treatment group were more likely than control physicians to: use asthma education protocols (odds ratio (OR) 4.9, p=0.2), write the patient how medications are adjusted when symptoms change (OR 5.7, p=0.05) and provide further guidelines for adjusting therapy (OR 3.8, p=0.06). The parents rated the doctors in the treatment group better than the control doctors for five specific positive communication behaviors. Children seen by physicians in the treatment group had fewer hospital admissions (p=0.03), and children with higher emergency department (ED) utilization at baseline had fewer subsequent visits to the emergency department (p=0.03). No differences were found in the number of doctor visits. No significant differences were found between the treatment and control group physicians in terms of the time they spent with patients at doctor visits (26 versus 29 minutes) or in the number of patients treated with anti-inflammatory drugs. It is concluded that interactive asthma workshops for pediatricians had a significant long-term benefit in their asthma care.

title: Long-term reduction in adverse drug events: an evidence-based improvement model
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To develop and test an evidence-based model to reduce medication errors and harms in hospitalized children. METHODS: Prospective discontinuous time-series study evaluating the efficacy of a multifaceted, staged intervention over 4 years in a large urban pediatric referral hospital. Safe pediatric prescribing guidelines were implemented using an evidence-based model. Key components included early clinician engagement and enhanced multidisciplinary communication, consensus development, interactive education, and timely data feedback through iterative Plan-Do-Study-Act cycles. The impact on medication errors and harms (adverse drug events, [ADEs]) were measured using standard definitions and a multi-method approach. Prospective data from voluntary reports from nurses, physicians and pharmacists and an intensive medical record review were combined. All data were reviewed by a multidisciplinary panel, including ADR causality assessments. RESULTS: Over 3 periods, 1011 patients with 6651 drug prescriptions were reviewed. The total number of ADEs decreased by >50% in the first year and this was maintained at 4 years. The greatest improvements were in potential ADEs, which decreased from 12.26 per 100 patients at baseline to 4.60 per 100 patients at 4 years (p<0.05). Overall medication errors decreased from 4.51 per 100 orders at baseline to 2.78 per 100 orders at 4 years (p<0.05). Prescribing errors decreased by 65%, from 4.07 per 100 orders at baseline to 2.05 orders at 4 years (p<0.05). CONCLUSIONS: A multifaceted, evidence-based model for the safe implementation of prescribing guidelines involving multidisciplinary clinicians was effective in reducing medication errors and harms in hospitalized children, resulting in sustained long-term improvement.

title: Look for gallbladder disease in the patient's iris
abstract: In alternative healthcare, iridology is used as a diagnostic tool. The diagnosis of gallbladder disease was used to examine its validity and interperformer consistency. The presence of an inflamed gallbladder with gallstones should be easily recognized by certain signs in the lower lateral part of the iris of the right eye. Stereo color slides were made of the right eye. Color stereo slides were prepared from the right eyes of 39 patients with the disease and 39 age-matched controls. The slides were randomly presented to five leading iridologists without additional information. The prevalence of the disease has been estimated at 56%. The median validity was 51% with 54% sensitivity and 52% specificity. These results were close to chance validity (iota = 0.03). None of the iridologists achieved high validity. The median interperformer consistency was 60%. This was only slightly higher than chance consistency (kappa = 0.18). This study showed that iridology is not a useful diagnostic tool.

title: Low-quality care: a persistent global problem with no quick fix
Magnetic resonance imaging of the head and spine: effective for the doctor or the patient?
abstract: OBJECTIVES To test how results from magnetic resonance imaging affect physicians' diagnoses and treatment plans for patients with cranial and spinal problems, and assess changes in the quality of life of these patients. DESIGN Survey of patients undergoing cranial and spinal magnetic resonance imaging with questionnaires on diagnoses and intended treatment plans before and after imaging, and questionnaires on quality of life at the time of imaging and again four months later. SETTING Regional Magnetic Resonance Imaging and Spectroscopy Unit. PARTICIPANTS 100 consecutive patients referred for cranial imaging in early 1989; 100 similar patients referred for spinal imaging Contribution to patient's future management;" Changes in patients' quality of life. RESULTS Magnetic resonance imaging changed physicians' lead diagnoses in 35 of 169 (21%) cases. In 90 of 167 (54% ) clinicians gained confidence in their lead diagnoses. There was a change in management plan in 113 of 182 (62%) patients. Clinicians considered that magnetic resonance imaging made an important contribution to treatment in 119 of 162 (73%) patients. Overall, patients' quality of life was unchanged at the four-month assessment.CONCLUSIONSMagnetic resonance imaging of patients with cranial and spinal problems influences clinicians' diagnoses and treatment plans, but the quality of life of these patients remains unchanged.

title: Efficacy of Sertraline Maintenance Phase in Chronic Depression A Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: Context.Â¡Âª Chronic major depressive disorder is associated with high prevalence and high rates of disability, but no controlled research has examined the effects of long-term treatment on the course and burden of the disease. Aim: To determine whether maintenance therapy with sertraline hydrochloride is effective in preventing the recurrence of depression in the high-risk group of patients with chronic major depressive disorder or major depressive disorder with a prior history of dysthymic disorder ("double depression"). Design.Â¡Âª A 76-week randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study conducted from September 1993 to November 1996. Setting.Â¡Âª Psychiatric outpatient clinics at 10 academic medical centers and 2 clinical research centers. Intervention.ÂªÂªMaintenance therapy with either sertraline hydrochloride (n=77) in flexible doses up to 200 mg or placebo (n=84). patients. A total of 161 outpatients with chronic major or dual depression who responded to sertraline in a 12-week, double-blind acute-phase treatment study and continued to demonstrate a satisfactory therapeutic response during a subsequent 4-month continuation phase. Main Outcome Measure.Â¡ÂªTime to recurrence of major depression. Results.Â¡Âª Sertraline resulted in significantly greater relapse prevention than placebo (5 [6%] of 77 in the sertraline group vs. 19 [23%] of 84 in the placebo group"; P=0.002 for the log Rank test of time-to-relapse distributions) Clinically significant depressive symptoms recurred in 20 (26%) of 77 patients treated with sertraline compared to 42 (50%) of 84 patients treated with placebo (p=0.001) Cox proportional hazards model, patients receiving placebo were 4.07 times more likely (95% CI, 1.51-10.95; p=0.005) to have a Recurrence of depression, after adjustment for study site, type of depression, and randomization strata.Conclusions.Â¡ÂªMaintenance therapy with sertraline is well tolerated and has significant efficacy in preventing recurrence or recurrence of depression in chronically depressed patients.

title: Making comparative performance information more understandable: An experimental assessment of the impact of formats on consumer understanding
abstract: Study objectives We wanted to investigate how different presentation formats affect consumers' understanding and use of comparative performance information (CPI). Methods An experimental between-subjects and within-subjects design with manipulations of CPI presentation formats. We enrolled both consumers with lower socioeconomic status (SES)/cognitive skills and consumers with higher SES/cognitive skills recruited via an online access panel. Respondents received fictitious CPIs and answered questions about interpretation and information usage. Between the subjects we tested, (1) showed an overall performance score (yes/no)"; (2) showed a small number of quality indicators (5 vs. 9);" and (3) displaying various types of rating symbols (rating stars, colored dots, and word symbols versus numbers and bar graphs). Within subjects, we tested the effect of a reduced number of healthcare providers (5 vs. 20). Data were analyzed using descriptive analysis, analysis of variance, and paired-samples t-test. Results A total of 902 (43%) respondents participated. The display of an overall performance rating and the use of colored dots and word symbols particularly improved consumer understanding. Importantly, respondents marked with colored dots were the most likely to correctly select the top three healthcare providers (84.3%) compared to word symbols (76.6% correct), star ratings (70.6% correct), numbers (62.0 %) and bars (54.2%). when looking at the performance figures of 20 providers. In addition, a smaller number of healthcare providers appeared to be supportive of consumers, for example 69.5% of 20 providers correctly selected the top three compared to 80.2% of five providers. Discussion Certain presentation formats improved consumer understanding of CPI, most notably the use of overall performance scores, word symbols and colored dots, and a reduced number of vendors displayed. Public reports should use these formats to maximize consumer impact.

title: Making electronic patient records useful
Making research a requirement for treatment: why we doctors should sometimes pressure patients to engage in research
abstract: If a patient could be offered one of several established treatments, physicians should only be able to offer a treatment if the patient agrees to participate in research aimed at determining which of the treatments is most effective. The condition of treatment from participating in the research will help researchers complete much-needed studies.

title: Making the invisible visible: a qualitative study of radiologist values, attitudes and norms regarding radiation protection
abstract: Some safety deficiencies were found during inspections of Swedish radiology departments by the Swedish Radiation Protection Agency, which perform 5.4 million radiological examinations and 100,000 nuclear scans annually. To ensure safety in the healthcare system and to build a strong radiation protection environment for patients (and staff), a strong safety culture must be in place. In order to understand an organization's behavior, decisions and actions, it is important to study its cultural values. The aim of this study was to discuss how values, attitudes and norms affect the decisions of radiologists and how they influence the implementation of various radiation protection measures. To investigate this, focus group interviews and in-depth individual interviews were conducted in a sample from a range of radiology departments in hospitals in Sweden. The results show that the core value was derived from the patient's perspective, with a focus on knowing that they came to the healthcare system for a specific reason: to discover a disease or, at best, to be declared healthy. Most of the settings were based on experience related to aspects that the radiologist could not influence. This often relates to the increased pressure on radiological examinations from the clinics in the various operating units. Under the concept of standards, the radiologists in the study called for the development of regulations and guidelines to be linked to justification questions for various radiological issues.

title: Malaria policy versus practices, a reality check from Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of the Congo
abstract: BACKGROUND: Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) after a confirmed parasitological diagnosis is recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Congolese National Malaria Control Program (NMCP). However, the commitment and competence of all stakeholders (patients, healthcare professionals, governments and funders) is required to achieve effective case management and ensure the "therapeutic useful life" of the recommended drugs. The health-oriented behavior of patients and the practices of medical professionals for the treatment of malaria were evaluated. METHODS: This was an observational study embedded in a two-stage randomized cluster survey conducted at a health center (HC) in each of the 12 selected health zones in the city of Kinshasa. All patients with a clinical diagnosis of malaria were eligible. Their health-oriented behavior was recorded in a special questionnaire, as was the practice of alternative practitioners. The latter were unaware that their practices would be judged. RESULTS: Six hundred and twenty-four patients were studied, of whom 136 (21.8%) were younger than five years. Three hundred and thirty-five (55%) had been taking medication (self-medication with any product or visiting another HC) prior to the current consultation, of whom 47 (14%) were taking an antimalarial medication and 56 (9%) were presumptively treated. Of these, 53.6% received monotherapy with either quinine, artesunate, phytopharmaceuticals, sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine or amodiaquine. On the other hand, monotherapy was prescribed in 39.9% of confirmed malaria cases when doctors were informed of the laboratory results. Only 285 patients (45.7%) were treated according to WHO and NMCP guidelines, of whom 120 (19.2%) were prescribed an appropriate comparator therapy after a positive blood smear and 165 (26.4%) after a negative result received no antimalarials. CONCLUSION: This study demonstrates the discrepancy between malaria policy and field reality in Kinshasa in terms of patient health-oriented behavior and health-care worker practices. Consequently, poor adherence to guidelines may contribute to the development and spread of antimalarial drug resistance and also negatively impact disease burden.

title: Competence network for malignant lymphoma
abstract: The Malignant Lymphoma Competence Network is one of 3 oncological networks that have been funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research since 1999. The activities of the network are based on the work of the German lymphoma research groups, which have made significant advances in the diagnosis and therapy of malignant lymphoma in recent years. Building on this infrastructure, the network aims to establish professional quality management for the diagnosis and treatment of malignant lymphomas. The focal points of the activity are: 1. Development of an IT-supported information and communication platform, 2. IT-supported networking of study groups and cooperating centers for pathology and radiotherapy, 3. Epidemiological and health-economic research, 4. Research on improved and new therapeutic approaches, 5 Evidence-based medicine. Further information can be found at http://www.lymphome.de.

title: Management for Physicians: An Annotated Bibliography of the Recent Literature
abstract: With the increasing organization and bureaucratization of the health care system in the United States, physicians are often forced to assume managerial responsibilities. The precise nature of the physician's responsibilities can range from the line management duties of heading an emergency room, specialty department, or clinical department, to more advisory roles on hospital committees for quality assurance, facility design, long-term planning, human resources, or finance. Regardless of the duties and responsibilities assigned to them, physicians rarely have sufficient backgrounds or skills in the various managerial disciplines to be as effective as they would like to be. However, as the cost and quality of healthcare provide difficult choices for hospitals and other healthcare organizations, it is becoming increasingly important for physicians to become better managers and to understand the opportunities and limitations of improved management.

title: Management of acute coronary syndromes at hospital discharge: do targeted educational measures improve practice quality?
abstract: Evidence-based guidelines for the management of patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) exist, but compliance is suboptimal. The Acute Coronary Syndrome Discharge Management project used a quality improvement approach with targeted intervention strategies to optimize: prescribing of guideline-recommended drugs, education about lifestyle changes including cardiac rehabilitation (CR), and communication between hospital staff, patients and general practitioners. Hospitals across Australia participated in a quality improvement cycle of audit, feedback, intervention and re-audit. Interventions included training meetings, academic detailing and point-of-care reminders, and feedback on exit audit results. Outcome measurements included prescription of guidelines -Recommended medication, referral to CR, and documentation and communication of the management plan. At baseline, 49 hospitals recruited 1,545 patients, and after the intervention, 45 hospitals remained active in the project and recruited 1,589 patients. 3,044 hospital staff attended the group education or academic details sessions. After the intervention, there was a significant increase in the prescription of all four guideline-recommended drugs (69% vs. 57%; p<0.0001); short-acting nitrates (68% vs. 56%; p<0.0001); and documented referral to CR (68% vs. 57%; p<0.0001). There were significant increases in documented discharge medication advice, smoking cessation advice, and communication of treatment plans. Targeted educational interventions as part of a quality improvement cycle can improve adherence to evidence-based guidelines for the management of patients with ACS.

title: Management of Alzheimer's Disease
abstract: The treatment of Alzheimer's disease is based on drug and non-drug treatments. Specific drug treatment includes acetylcholinesterase inhibitors and memantine. They show a moderate effectiveness compared to placebo for general condition, cognitive disorders, need for care and behavioral problems, but do not prevent a further decline. These treatments are underused. The effectiveness of psychotropic drugs (antidepressants, neuroleptics, and antipsychotics) in treating behavioral problems is not well documented. Non-drug activities and interventions have not been adequately evaluated scientifically. This includes interventions against the consequences of the disease (loss of autonomy, malnutrition) and support for the patient's family caregivers. Among these activities, the best rated and most interesting are: Nurse Education Programs, Home Occupational Therapy and Home Interventions by Nurses Specially Trained as Case Managers.

title: Management of asthma based on exhaled nitric oxide in addition to guideline-based treatment for inner-city adolescents and young adults: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background: Preliminary evidence on the role of exhaled nitric oxide (NO) in the clinical management of asthma is inconclusive. Our aim was to assess whether measuring exhaled NO as a biomarker of airway inflammation could increase the efficacy of asthma treatment when used as an adjunct to clinical care based on asthma guidelines for inner-city adolescents and young adults.";" Background: Preliminary evidence on the role of exhaled nitric oxide (NO) in the clinical management of asthma is inconclusive. Our aim was to assess whether measuring exhaled NO as a biomarker of airway inflammation could increase the efficacy of asthma treatment when used as an adjunct to clinical care based on asthma guidelines for inner-city adolescents and young adults.

title: Management of heart failure in primary care (IMPROVEMENT of heart failure programme): an international survey
abstract: Background Heart failure is a common disease that is generally treated in primary care. The aim of this study was to assess how primary care physicians feel that heart failure should be treated, how they apply their knowledge and whether there are differences in practice between countries.";" Background Heart failure is a common disease that is generally treated in primary care. The aim of this study was to assess how GPs think heart failure should be treated, how they apply their knowledge and whether there are differences in practice between countries.

title: Treatment of hypertension in clinical practice: discernible qualitative differences in approaches used by clinicians
abstract: The authors recruited a group of physicians from the study physicians participating in the Antihypertensive and Lipid-Lowering Treatment to Prevent Heart Attack Trial (ALLHAT), with a greater (successful) or smaller (less successful) proportion of study patients measuring blood pressure (BP) achieved ) control objectives. The authors used qualitative focus group methods to identify similarities and differences in practice behavior. Successful and less successful physicians had similarities in knowledge and practice related to awareness of treatment guidelines, diagnostic approaches, use of pharmacologic management, and the belief that systolic blood pressure guidelines should take a patient's age into account. However, there were discernible differences between the two groups of physicians in their views on the physician-patient relationship: physicians from the less successful group were more paternalistic with their patients, while physicians from the more successful group used a more patient-centred clinical approach to BP awareness and -Management.

title: Management of obesity in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus in primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Obesity and overweight are the major risk factors responsible for 80-90% of patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). The obesity epidemic is driving the diabetes epidemic to alarming levels and primary care is becoming an important environment for obesity management in T2DM in India. Still, many primary care physicians feel ill-equipped or under-supported to address obesity in patients with diabetes. This article provides an overview of the latest and strongest evidence-based strategies that can help physicians manage obesity in patients with T2DM in primary care. MATERIAL AND METHODS: A systematic literature search was performed in MEDLINE using the search terms obesity, obesity in T2DM, weight loss and primary care. The websites of the American Diabetes Association, the National Institute for Health, the National Institute of Health and Excellence (NICE), the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) and the World Health Organization were also searched. Most studies in this area are observational with few randomized controlled trials (RCTs). Articles and studies with meta-analyses or RCTs were preferred over other types. RESULTS AND CONCLUSION: Effective weight management treatment in T2DM patients can be implemented in primary care. Evidence-based individualized lifestyle and pharmacological interventions, supported by behavioral intervention and counseling with appropriate and informed surgical referrals, have the potential to improve the success of weight management in primary care.

title: Management of Obstructive Sleep Apnea in Adults: A Clinical Practice Guideline from the American College of Physicians
abstract: Description: The American College of Physicians (ACP) developed this guideline to present the evidence and provide clinical recommendations for the management of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in adults. Methods: This guideline is based on published literature from 1966 to September 2010 identified using MEDLINE, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. A supplemental MEDLINE search identified additional articles up to October 2012. The search was limited to English-language publications. Clinical outcomes assessed for this guideline included cardiovascular disease (such as heart failure, hypertension, stroke, and myocardial infarction), type 2 diabetes, death, sleep study measurements (such as the Apnea-CHypopnea Index), measurements of cardiovascular status (such as blood pressure) , measurements of diabetes status (such as hemoglobin A1c levels) and quality of life. This guideline assesses the evidence and recommendations using the ACP clinical practice guidelines assessment system. Recommendation 1: ACP recommends that all overweight and obese patients diagnosed with OSA should be encouraged to lose weight. (Grade: Strong recommendation”; low-quality evidence) Recommendation 2: ACP recommends treatment with continuous positive airway pressure as initial therapy for patients diagnosed with OSA. (Grade: strong recommendation; moderate-quality evidence) Recommendation 3: ACP recommends mandibular advancement devices as an alternative therapy to continuous positive airway pressure treatment for patients diagnosed with OSA who prefer mandibular advancement devices or for patients with adverse reactions associated with continuous positive airway pressure treatment positive airway pressure (grade: weak recommendation; low-quality evidence)

title: Management of occupational therapy services for people with cognitive impairments (explanation). The American Occupational Therapy Association, Inc
abstract: In summary, occupational therapists play a critical role in helping people with cognitive impairments establish or maintain meaningful and productive lives in their social and cultural communities. Occupational therapists effectively treat a wide range of cognitive difficulties in clients across a wide range of ages and diagnoses. The intervention may be directed at the person with cognitive impairment or at those who care for or interact with them (e.g., family members, caregivers, employers, school staff, other healthcare workers). Treatment includes changing the person's skills or behavior, or adjusting the task and/or environment to maintain function, facilitate caregiving, reduce safety risks, and maximize independence.

title: Management of persistent pain in elderly patients: a clinical review
abstract: IMPORTANT: Persistent pain is common, costly, and often disabling later in life. AIM: To describe barriers to the management of persistent pain in older adults, summarize current treatment approaches including pharmacological and non-pharmacological modalities, present rehabilitative approaches, and highlight aspects of the patient-physician relationship that may help improve patient outcomes.
