This review is relevant to physicians seeking an age-appropriate approach to providing pain management to older adults Evidence Collection: Search of MEDLINE and the Cochrane database from January 1990 to May 2014 using the search terms "older adults", "senior", " Age 65 and older”. , elderly and elderly along with non-cancerous pain, chronic pain, persistent pain, pain management, intractable pain and refractory pain to identify English-language peer-reviewed systematic reviews, meta-analyses, Cochrane reviews, consensus statements and guidelines relevant to treatment persistent pain in older adults RESULTS: Of the 92 studies identified, 35 evaluated pharmacological interventions while 57 evaluated non-pharmacological modalities;" the majority (n=50) focused on older adults with osteoarthritis. This evidence base supports a stepwise approach with acetaminophen as first-line therapy If treatment goals are not met, a trial of a topical NSAID, tramadol, or both is recommended Oral NSAIDs are not recommended for long-term use Careful monitoring Attention to monitoring for toxicity and efficacy is crucial as the risk of side effects increases with age. A multimodal approach is strongly recommended - with an emphasis on a combination of pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments, including physical and occupational rehabilitation, as well as cognitive-behavioural and movement-based interventions. An integrated pain management approach is ideally achieved by cultivating a strong therapeutic alliance between the elderly patient and the physician. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Treatment planning for persistent pain later in life requires a clear understanding of treatment goals and expectations, comorbidities, and the patient's cognitive and functional status, as well as coordination of community resources and family support when available. A combination of pharmacological, non-pharmacological, and rehabilitative approaches in addition to a strong therapeutic alliance between patient and physician is essential to set, adjust, and achieve realistic therapy goals.

title: Management of severe hypertension in France in 1999 and 2000: interim results of a health insurance intervention program
abstract: AIM: As part of their long-term public health program to improve clinical management of hypertension (HBP), the French health insurance funds conducted two national surveys of member organizations recently exempted from co-payment for severe hypertension. The objective was to assess the difference between observed clinical management and benchmark care, defined by the 1997 National Agency for Accreditation and Health Evaluation (ANAES) guidelines, at baseline (May 1999) and during the program (November 1999). measure to detect any changes in clinical management between the two study periods, with the time frame corresponding to the intervention period. METHODS: The patient samples used in the two studies were from partners between the ages of 20 and 80 years living in France or one of its overseas territories who were recently exempted from the co-payment (ETM) for severe hypertension (these patients will become 100% reimbursed for all care related to the illness). The evaluation was based on retrospective information from the treating physicians. The indicators isolated to compare the two study periods were blood pressure control, suggested lifestyle changes, and prescribed medications. RESULTS: The first survey took place between May and November 1999 and included 10,665 patients (corresponding to a weighted patient population of 50,383), while the second in November 2000 examined 2,649 patients. The study population in 1999 was on average younger than the study population in November 2000: 63.1 years +/- 0.2 vs. 65.4 years +/- 0.4. Almost two out of three patients had at least one other important cardiovascular risk factor in addition to HBP (cigarette smoking, diabetes mellitus or dyslipidemia): 63.9% in 1999 and 64.4% in 2000. Almost every seventh patient had concomitant coronary artery disease: 14.1% in 1999 and 15.3% in 2000 and more than one in ten had associated cerebrovascular disease: 12.7% in 1999 and 12.2% in 2000. In the 1999 group there were more diabetics than in the 2000 group: 27.5% +/- 1.0 versus 23.9% +/- 1.6. The proportion of patients with poorly controlled blood pressure (systolic > 140 mmHg or > 160 mmHg in those aged 60-80 years with isolated systolic hypertension or diastolic > 90 mmHg) did not change: 46.8% +/- 1.1 Zoll 1999 and 45.7% +/- 1.9 in 2000. Using guideline recommendations for diabetics (BP < 130/85). 85.4% of diabetics were poorly controlled in 1999 and 86.6% in 2000. Similarly, in hypertensive patients with renal failure (guideline recommendations: <125/75 mmHg), 94.5% in 1999 and 96.3% in 2000 were poorly controlled. Recommended lifestyle changes (reduction in salt intake, weight loss, lower alcohol consumption, increased physical activity) were not well tracked in either study: in 1999, fewer than a quarter of patients fully implemented the desired changes (23.7%), although this was only the The case was In 2000 it was 24.5%. In 1999, physicians prescribed specifically indicated therapeutic agents for 68.0% of patients and in 2000 for 67.6% of patients, taking into account concomitant diseases. The prescriptions contained a potentially contraindicated drug in 27.3% of the cases in 1999 and in 28.0% of the cases in 2000. CONCLUSION: A comparison of the results of the two surveys from the years 1999 and 2000 on the treatment of patients with severe hypertension was not significant Detect differences in blood d pressure control or treatment modalities. Without questioning the value of health insurance interventions, these results highlight how difficult it is to change clinical practice in a short period of time, especially in a disorder that involves a number of different elements, including individual patient behavior . In order to significantly improve clinical management, it will probably be necessary to continue the dialogue between medical advisers of the health insurance funds (medecins conseils) and clinicians and to renew campaigns aimed at empowering patients.

title: Management of severe sepsis in patients admitted to Asian intensive care units: prospective cohort study
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess the adherence of Asian ICUs and hospitals to the Surviving Sepsis Campaign's resuscitation and treatment packages. Secondary objectives were to assess the impact of compliance on mortality and the organizational characteristics of hospitals associated with higher levels of compliance. DESIGN Prospective cohort study. RECRUITMENT 150 intensive care units in 16 Asian countries. PARTICIPANTS 1285 adult patients with severe sepsis were admitted to these intensive care units in July 2009. The organizational characteristics of the participating centers, patient baseline characteristics, achievement of goals within the resuscitation and treatment packages, and outcome data were recorded. KEY OUTCOME MEASURE Compliance with Surviving Sepsis Campaign resuscitation (six hours) and management (24 hours) packages. RESULTS The in-hospital mortality rate was 44.5% (572/1285). The compliance rates for the resuscitation and management packages were 7.6% (98/1285) and 3.5% (45/1285), respectively. On logistic regression analysis, compliance with the following bundle goals independently predicted reduced mortality: blood cultures (achieved in 803/1285); 62.5%, 95% CI 59.8% to 65.1%), broad spectrum antibiotics (reached in 821/1285; 63.9%, 61.3% to 66.5%) and central venous pressure (reached in 345/ 870; 39.7%, 36.4% to 42.9%). High-income countries, university hospitals, ICUs with an accredited fellowship program, and surgical ICUs were more likely to fulfill the resuscitation package. CONCLUSIONS While mortality in severe sepsis is high, compliance with resuscitation and treatment packages is generally poor in much of Asia. Because the centers included in this study may not be fully representative, the reported success rates may overestimate the true level of adherence to recommended treatment and should be interpreted with caution. Achieving goals for blood cultures, antibiotics, and central venous pressure was independently associated with improved survival.

title: Management of Stable Ischemic Heart Disease: Summary of a Clinical Practice Guideline from the American College of Physicians/American College of Cardiology Foundation/American Heart Association/American Association for Thoracic Surgery/Preventive Cardiovascular Nurses Association/Society of Thoracic Surgeons
abstract: Description: The American College of Physicians (ACP) shared this guideline with the American College of Cardiology Foundation (ACCF), the American Heart Association (AHA), the American Association for Thoracic Surgery, the Preventive Cardiovascular Nurses Association, and the Society of Thoracic Surgeons is developing to present available evidence for treating stable known or suspected ischemic heart disease. Methods: Literature on this topic published before November 2011 was identified using MEDLINE, Embase, Cochrane CENTRAL, PsychINFO, AMED, and SCOPUS. The search was limited to human studies published in English. This guideline reviews the evidence and recommendations according to a translation of the ACCF/AHA rating system into the rating system of the ACP clinical practice guidelines. Recommendations: The guideline contains 48 specific recommendations on the following topics: patient education, management of established risk factors (dyslipidemia, hypertension, diabetes, physical activity, body weight and smoking), strategies to reduce risk factors with unproven benefit, medical therapy to prevent myocardial infarction and death, and for symptom relief, alternative therapies, revascularization to improve survival and symptoms, and patient follow-up.

title: Dealing with anxiety associated with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder in the emergency setting
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Patient anxiety presents a significant challenge in the Emergency Department (ED), an environment where medical staff work under pressure and deal with a wide variety of medical emergencies. The potential for escalation into aggressive behavior that puts patients, staff and others at risk makes it imperative to address agitated behavior quickly and efficiently. Time constraints and limited access to specialized psychiatric support have historically led to the 'restrain and reassure' strategy which was believed to represent the optimal approach'; However, there is increasing recognition that more patient-centred approaches lead to better outcomes. The goal of this review is to raise awareness of best practices for management of agitation in the emergency department and to consider the role of new pharmacological interventions in this setting. DISCUSSION: The Best Practices in Evaluation and Treatment of Agitation (BETA) guidelines address the full management of agitation, including triage, diagnosis, interpersonal calming skills, and drug selection. Since their publication in 2012, pharmacological approaches to managing agitation have evolved, including both new agents and new dosage forms, expanding the options available to both patients and physicians. Newer modes of administration that may be useful in the rapid management of agitation include inhaled, buccal/sublingual, and intranasal formulations. To date, inhaled loxapine is the only formulation administered via a non-intramuscular route with a specific indication for agitation associated with bipolar or schizophrenia. Although non-invasive formulations require patient collaboration, they have the potential to improve the overall patient experience and thereby improve future collaboration between patients and healthcare providers. CONCLUSION: Management of agitation in the ED should include a patient-centered approach that includes non-pharmacological approaches whenever possible. If pharmacologic intervention is required, a collaborative approach using noninvasive drugs should be used whenever possible.

title: Managing pain in high-risk patients in a patient-centered medical home
abstract: Despite remarkable advances in diagnostics, pharmacotherapy and invasive and non-invasive interventions, chronic pain remains a major health problem. The prevalence of chronic pain in the United States is staggering and increasing, and the personal and societal costs are not inconsiderable. The etiology of pain is complex, and individuals suffering from chronic pain tend to have significant medical and psychiatric comorbidities such as depression, anxiety, and in some cases, substance use disorders. There is great concern about the rising rate of misuse/abuse of prescription opioids for both non-medical use and among pain patients receiving chronic opioid therapy. While there is an ongoing debate about the "true" incidence of opioid abuse in the pain population, patients affected by both pain and substance use disorders clearly pose a particular challenge. The majority of patients with chronic pain, including those with co-occurring substance use disorders, are treated in primary care. GPs have limited time, resources, and training to effectively assess, treat, and monitor these complicated cases. A number of evidence- and consensus-based treatment guidelines for opioid therapy and risk reduction have been developed, but have been underutilized in both specialty and primary care clinics. This article discusses the use of new technologies and delivery systems for risk stratification, intervention, and monitoring of pain patients receiving opioids.

title: Dealing with panic attacks in emergency patients
abstract: Patients suffering from panic attacks often seek help in emergency rooms. However, the symptoms of a panic can be difficult to distinguish from some common medical emergencies. Additionally, many emergency medical professionals may not be able to effectively treat panic attacks and related psychiatric conditions such as panic disorder and agoraphobia. Early misdiagnosis and inadequate treatment of panic attacks can have devastating long-term clinical and financial consequences. The purpose of this document is to provide information designed to improve the convenience and effectiveness of emergency physicians and allied professionals in managing panic attacks. The authors provide guidelines for differential diagnosis, present strategies for managing acute panic and anxiety symptoms, and provide recommendations for brief post-panic clinical interventions.

title: Dealing with perceived conflicts of interest while ensuring the continuous innovation of medical technology
abstract: Without the ongoing collaboration between vascular surgeons and the medical device industry, many of these advanced treatments used daily in vascular interventional surgery would not exist. The flip side of this coin is that these vital relationships create multiple roles for surgeons and must be managed accordingly. The dynamic process of innovation along with factors such as refinement of product delivery technology, education, testing and clinical trials, and product support necessitate continuous and close collaboration between surgeons and the device industry. This unique relationship sometimes leads to perceptions of conflicts of interest for physicians, in part because the competitive pressures of the multiple, overlapping roles of clinician/carer/investigator/innovator/client are significant. To address this issue, the Advanced Medical Technology Association (AdvaMed), the nation's largest medical technology association representing medical device and diagnostics companies, has developed a code of ethics designed to guide medical technology companies in their interactions with healthcare professionals. First introduced in 1993, the AdvaMed Code strongly encourages both industry and physicians to commit to openness and high ethical standards in conducting their business relationships. The AdvaMed Code addresses many types of interactions that may occur between companies and healthcare professionals, including training, consulting contracts, the provision of demonstration and evaluation units, and charitable donations. By complying with the Code, companies are sending a strong signal that treatment decisions must always be made in the best interests of the patient.

title: Dealing with urinary incontinence in stroke rehabilitation - an overview
abstract: BACKGROUND: Post-stroke urinary incontinence is a pervasive problem for patients and their families, affecting well-being and future care. There are many therapeutic interventions, but their effectiveness is not known in detail. The question for rehabilitation practice is how best to treat urinary incontinence (UI) in a way that does not interfere with patients' daily lives. Method: The search for clinical studies was performed in PubMed, CINAHL and Cochrane Library, limited to German and English language publications published between 1989 and April 2005. Medical, nursing, and physiotherapeutic interventions for the treatment of post-stroke UI were described and analyzed. RESULTS: The clinical trials were divided into process-oriented trials and those investigating individual interventions. The process tests could be divided into three different groups with an overall success rate of 82-95%, 50-56% and 23-36%. Behavioral methods (caregiver-induced, patient-active, and other interventions) and medical interventions are available. The studies of the most successful group include staff training and application of interventions based on an assessment process and guideline. No clinical study on individual interventions came to a conclusion like the process-oriented studies. CONCLUSION: Treatment of urinary incontinence requires a multimodal approach: specific training of nurses, application and action in a problem-solving process, such as the rehabilitation cycle, and care based on an assessment process and guidelines. The development of a guideline for the treatment of urinary incontinence after a stroke can be recommended. Further research on the effectiveness of individual interventions is needed.

title: Marketing an investigational drug service
abstract: The customer survey was a useful tool for marketing the IDS. It provided guidelines for making decisions about the best use of limited human and material resources. Analysis of the survey results provided new priorities and directions for the IDS. These results were then used in conjunction with pharmacy financial and operational data to focus on areas that are most important to customers and the pharmacy. Physicians should not hesitate to pursue compassionate use treatments because of the administrative program responsibilities that accompany such programs. Every patient should have the opportunity to benefit from alternative therapies that are being tested. In order for the quality of patient care to be maintained or even improved during the conduct of studies, nurses must be well trained. The marketing survey served its purpose of identifying service gaps and allowing us to improve our services.

title: The Massachusetts General Physicians Organization's Quality Incentive Program is yielding encouraging results
abstract: Doctors are increasingly becoming employees of hospitals or large groups of doctors. However, few published reports have evaluated provider-driven quality incentive programs for employed physicians. In 2006, the Massachusetts General Physicians Organization launched a quality incentive program for their salaried physicians. Eligible physicians received performance targets for three quality measures every six months. The incentive payments could be as high as 2 percent of a doctor's annual income. Over thirteen six-month periods, the program used 130 different quality measures. Although improvements in quality of care and cost reductions have been difficult to calculate, anecdotal evidence points to multiple successes. For example, the program helped physicians meet many federal criteria for the wise use of health information technology and resulted in $15.5 million in award payments. The program also facilitated the introduction of an electronic health record, improved hand hygiene compliance, increased efficiencies in radiology and cancer centers, and reduced emergency room utilization. The program has shown that even small incentives, tied to carefully structured metrics, prioritization and clear communication, can help change the behavior of employed physicians in a way that improves the quality and safety of healthcare and reduces the sense of administrative burden to the doctors is reduced.

title: MASTER PLAN: Study of the role of nurses in a multifactorial intervention to reduce cardiovascular risk in patients with chronic kidney disease
abstract: Moderate to severe chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with an increased cardiovascular risk. Normally, nephrologists are primarily responsible for the care of CKD patients. However, in many cases treatment goals as formulated in guidelines are not achieved. The addition of a nurse could improve the quality of care. The Multifactorial Approach and Superior Treatment Efficacy in Renal Patients with the Aid of Nurse Practitioners (MASTERPLAN) study is a randomized, controlled, multicenter study that aims to investigate whether a multifactorial approach can be used in patients with moderate to severe chronic kidney disease (Stage 3 and 4) treatment enables targets using both a multi-drug strategy and lifestyle treatment, either with or without the addition of a nurse, reduce cardiovascular risk and slow renal function decline. Patients (n=793) were randomly assigned to nursing or medical care. In the nursing arm of the study, nurses use flowcharts to address risk factors that require medication and/or lifestyle changes. They have been trained to coach patients through motivational talks with the aim of improving patient self-management. At baseline, both treatment groups show equal distributions for key study variables. Furthermore, only one patient had all risk factors within the limits defined in various guidelines, underscoring the relevance of our initiative.

title: Maternal dietary habits and physical activity habits during the postpartum period: associations with clinical counseling in a sample of Australian first-time mothers
abstract: BACKGROUND: Numerous health benefits are associated with achieving optimal diet and exercise habits during and after pregnancy. Understanding predictors of these behaviors is an important public health consideration, but little is known about associations between medical advice and diet and physical activity behaviors in women after childbirth. The aims of this study were to compare the frequency of diet and physical activity advice given by physicians during and after pregnancy and to assess whether this advice is related to postpartum diet and exercise behaviors. METHODS: Primiparous mothers (n=448) participating in the Melbourne InFANT Extend study completed the Cancer Council of Australia's Food Frequency Questionnaire at three to four months of age postpartum, which measured usual fruit and vegetable intake ( servings/day). Total physical activity time, time spent walking, and time engaged in both moderate and vigorous activity in the previous week (min/week) were assessed using the Active Australia survey. Counseling received during and after pregnancy was assessed using separate survey items asking whether a health practitioner had discussed healthy eating and physical activity. Linear and logistic regression examined the associations of advice with food intake and physical activity. RESULTS: Overall, 8.6% of women met the guidelines for combining fruit and vegetables. Overall, the mean physical activity time was 350.9 +/- 281.1 min/week. Time spent walking (251.97 +/- 196.78 min/week) was longer than time spent with moderate (36.68 +/- 88.58 min/week) or vigorous activity (61.74 + /- 109.96 min/week) and 63.2% of women were compliant with physical activity recommendations. The majority of women reported receiving advice on healthy eating (87.1%) and physical activity (82.8%) during pregnancy. Fewer women reported receiving advice on healthy eating (47.5%) and physical activity (51.9%) up to three months after giving birth. No significant association was found between the provision of dietary and/or physical activity counseling and maternal food intake or level of physical activity. CONCLUSIONS: Advice on healthy eating and physical activity was received less after pregnancy than during pregnancy, but no association was observed between receiving advice and behavior. More intensive approaches than providing advice may be needed to promote healthy eating and physical activity among new mothers. TRIAL REGISTRATION: Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ACTRN12611000386932 13.04.2011).

title: McMaster PLUS: a cluster-randomized clinical trial of an intervention to accelerate the clinical use of evidence-based information from digital libraries
abstract: Background: Physicians struggle to keep up with new discoveries from medical research. Methods: We developed the McMaster Premium Literature Service (PLUS), a web-based supplement to an existing digital library that provides physicians with quality and relevance-rated medical literature tailored to their clinical disciplines. We evaluated PLUS in a cluster-randomized study with 203 participating physicians in Northern Ontario and compared a full-serve version (which included new article alerts and a cumulative database of alerts) with a self-serve version (which included a passive guide to evidence-based literature). Service use was the primary study endpoint. Results: Average library logins increased by 0.77 logins/month/user (95% CI 0.43, 1.11) in the full-serve group compared to the self-serve group. The proportion of full-serve participants using the service in each month of the study period increased sustainably during the intervention period, with a relative increase of 57% (95% CI 12, 123) compared to the self-serve group. There were no differences in these proportions during the baseline period, and after the transition from the self-serve group to full-serve, the usage of the self-serve group became indistinguishable from that of the full-serve group (relative difference 4 .4 (95%) CI -23.7, 43.0) Even during the intervention and crossover periods, the measures of self-reported utility showed no difference between the two groups. Conclusion: A quality and relevant online literature service increased utilization evidence-based literature information from a digital library of practicing physicians.

title: Measures to assess the change of practice among doctors
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is a growing body of randomized trials and systematic reviews examining the effectiveness of interventions aimed at inducing change in clinical practice. The results of this research will be used to guide strategies to improve the uptake of evidence into clinical practice. Knowledge of the outcomes measured by these studies is crucial not only for the interpretation and application of the work done to date, but also to inform future research in this expanding field and to aid in the compilation of the results in systematic reviews and meta-analyses. METHODS: The aim of this review was to identify methods used to measure changes in clinical practice by healthcare professionals following an intervention aimed at improving the uptake of evidence into practice. All published studies included in a recent comprehensive health technology assessment of clinical practice guideline implementation and clinical practice change interventions (n=228) comprised the sample for this study. Using a standardized data extraction form, one reviewer (SH) extracted the relevant information from the methods and/or results sections of the studies. RESULTS: Measures of change in health practitioner behavior were the most common, with 88.8% of studies using them as outcome measures. Measures that assessed patient-level change, either actual measures of change or surrogate measures of change, were used in 28.8% and 36.7% of the studies, respectively. 22.8% of the studies assessed the knowledge and attitudes of health professionals and 17.6% assessed changes at the organizational level. CONCLUSION: Most studies of interventions aimed at changing clinical practice have measured the effect of the intervention at the physician level, ie has the physician changed what he is doing, or has his knowledge and/or attitude changed changed to this practice? Less than a third of the studies measured resulted in a change in the ultimate endpoint of the patient's health status, whether or not the practice was changed.

title: Measuring and monitoring success in compressing morbidity
Measuring persistence of implementation: QUERI series
abstract: As more quality improvement programs are implemented to drive performance gains, the need to assess their lasting impact becomes more apparent. However, such long-term follow-up assessments are rare in the science of health care delivery, largely relegated to the “further research needs” section of most project descriptions. This article examines the diversity of conceptualizations of implementation sustainability, as well as behavioral and organizational factors that affect the maintenance of profits. It highlights the intricacies of design considerations and draws on our own experiences of measuring sustainability, framed by the rich theoretical and empirical input of others. In addition, recommendations for the design of sustainability analyzes are given. This article is one of a series of articles documenting scientific frameworks and implementation approaches developed by the US Department of Veterans Affairs' Quality Enhancement Research Initiative (QUERI).

title: Measuring the Effectiveness of Quality Improvement Collaboration in Pediatric Asthma Care: Does Implementing the Chronic Care Model Improve Care Processes and Outcomes?
abstract: Objective: To investigate whether collaboration to improve pediatric asthma care positively impacts the processes and outcomes of that care. METHODS: Medical record summaries and patient/parent interviews were used to conduct pre- and post-intervention comparisons of patients at 9 sites who participated in the assessment of a Breakthrough Series (BTS) collaboration on asthma care with patients at 4 matched control sites. Vicinity. â€”Thirteen primary care clinics. patients. - 385 asthmatic children treated in an intervention clinic and 126 treated in a control clinic (response rate = 76%). Intervention. â€“ Three 2-day training sessions for quality improvement teams from participating sites, followed by 3 â€œactionâ€ periods over the course of a year. Results: The overall process of asthma care improved significantly in the intervention group but remained unchanged in the control group (change in process score +13% vs. 0%; p<0.0001). Patients in the intervention group were more likely than patients in the control group to monitor their peak flows (70% vs. 43%; p<0.0001) and to have a written action plan (41% vs. 22%; p=0.001) . better general health-related quality of life (scale score 80 vs. 77; p=0.05) and asthma-specific quality of life related to treatment problems (scale score 89 vs. 85; p<0.05). Conclusions: - The intervention improved some important aspects of nursing processes previously associated with better outcomes. Patients treated in intervention clinics also reported a higher general and asthma-specific quality of life.

title: Measuring the effectiveness of mentoring as a knowledge translation intervention to implement empirical evidence: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Mentoring as a knowledge translation (KT) intervention uses social influence among health professionals to increase the use of evidence in clinical practice. OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of mentoring as a KT intervention aimed at improving the use of evidence by healthcare professionals in clinical practice. METHODS: A systematic review was performed using electronic databases (eg, MEDLINE, CINAHL), gray literature, and manual searches. Eligible studies evaluated mentoring of healthcare professionals responsible for patient care to improve the uptake of evidence into practice. Mentoring is defined as (a) a mentor who has more experience than a mentee; (b) individual support based on the needs of the mentee;" and (c) engage in an interpersonal relationship characterized by mutual benefit, commitment and commitment. Two reviewers independently screened citations for suitability, extracted data, and assessed study quality. The data were analyzed descriptively. RESULTS: Out of 10,669 citations from 1988 to 2012, 10 studies were eligible. Mentoring as a KT intervention has been evaluated in Canada, the US and Australia. Exposure to mentoring compared to no mentoring improved some behavioral outcomes (one study). Compared to controls or other multifaceted interventions, multifaceted interventions with mentoring improved practitioner knowledge (four of five studies), beliefs (four of six studies), and impact on organizational outcomes (three of four studies). There were mixed results regarding changes in professional behavior and impact on physician and patient outcomes: some outcomes improved while others showed no difference. LINKING EVIDENCE TO ACTIONS: Only one study evaluated the effectiveness of mentoring alone as a KT intervention, showing improvement in some behavioral outcomes. The other nine studies that assessed the effectiveness of mentoring as part of a multifaceted intervention showed mixed results, making it difficult to determine the additive effect of mentoring. Further research is needed to identify effective mentoring as a KT intervention.

title: Measuring the impact of reminders of outpatient influenza vaccination at the time of the clinical opportunity
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the impact of computerized influenza vaccination reminders on individual clinician behavior at each clinical occasion. DESIGN: The authors conducted a prospective study of physicians' influenza vaccination behavior over four years. About half of the physicians in an internal medicine clinic used a computerized medical record system (CPR users) that generated computerized reminders. The other clinicians used traditional paper records (PR users). MEASUREMENTS: Any non-acute visit to a patient who was eligible for influenza vaccination was considered an opportunity for intervention. Patients with contraindications to vaccination were excluded. Compliance with the guideline was defined as documentation that a clinician ordered the vaccine, advised the patient about the vaccine, offered the vaccine to a patient who refused it, or confirmed that the patient received the vaccine elsewhere. The authors calculated the proportion of occasions each clinician documented actions in the CPR and PR user groups. RESULTS: The CPR and PR user groups had different baseline compliance rates (40.1 and 27.9 percent, respectively); P<0.05). Both rates remained stable over a two-year baseline period (P=0.34 and P=0.47, respectively). Compliance rates in the CPR user group increased by 78 percent from baseline (P<0.001), while rates for the PR user group did not change significantly (P=0.18). CONCLUSIONS: Clinicians who used CPR with reminders had a higher documentation rate of adherence to influenza vaccination guidelines than those who used a paper record. Measurements of individual clinical behavior at the time of each clinical opportunity can provide an accurate assessment of interventions aimed at improving compliance.

title: Physician's referral order to improve prophylaxis rates for deep vein thrombosis and other outcomes
abstract: Preliminary results were presented as a poster at the American Medical Informatics Association Annual Meeting in Washington, DC in October 2005. After completing the study, CO and KD became executive officers of Open Source Order Sets (OSOS), a company that created an order set cooperative for Canadian hospitals. OSOS was not involved in the current study. This study received no specific funding. JF is supported by a Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) Clinician' Scientist Award. We thank Barbara Stanek for her invaluable assistance in collecting patient record data.

title: Medical care of type 2 diabetes mellitus in the light of international and national recommendations: a retrospective analysis
abstract: SUPPORTED QUESTION: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2Dm) is a chronic disease with a major economic impact. In 2009, the Swiss Society for Endocrinology and Diabetes (SSED) published recommendations for the treatment of T2Dm. In Switzerland, little data is currently available on metabolic control and physician compliance with treatment guidelines. Our aim was to examine clinical care in T2Dm in the year after publication of the SSED recommendations. METHODS: We retrospectively reviewed the medical histories of all patients with T2Dm admitted to our general practice clinic in 2009. Metabolic control was assessed by glycated hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) levels. Antidiabetic therapy was analyzed and the frequency of screening for end-organ damage was examined. A group with newly diagnosed T2Dm was analyzed separately from patients with known T2Dm at admission. RESULTS: In patients with known T2Dm, the mean (+/- standard deviation) HbA1c was 7.66% +/- 1.73%. Only 44% of the patients had an HbA1c value of 8.5%, the proportion of patients treated with insulin increased from 49% at admission to 76% at discharge. Only half of the patients received a lifestyle intervention in the year before admission or during the hospital stay. Screening for diabetic retinopathy and nephropathy was performed in approximately one-third and two-thirds of patients, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: The majority of unselected T2Dm patients admitted to our hospital had suboptimal metabolic control. The implementation of treatment recommendations by general practitioners and hospitals should be improved.

title: Medical communication and technology: A video-based process study on the use of decision-making aids in general practitioner consultations
abstract: BACKGROUND: Much research on healthcare decision making has focused on counseling outcomes. What is less well known is the process by which clinicians and patients arrive at treatment decisions. The aim of this study was to quantitatively describe the behavior of physicians and patients during primary care consultations when three types of decision aids were used to support treatment decisions in a randomized controlled trial. METHODS: A video-based study as part of an efficacy study that compared the use of paper-based guidelines (control) versus two forms of computer-assisted decision support (implicit and explicit versions of DARTS II). The treatment decision was for anticoagulation with warfarin to reduce the risk of stroke in elderly patients with atrial fibrillation. Twenty-nine consultations were videotaped. A 10-minute "snippet" of the consultation was sampled for detailed content analysis using existing interaction analysis protocols for verbal behavior and ethological techniques for non-verbal behavior. RESULTS: Median consultation times (quartiles) differed significantly depending on the technology used. Working through paper-based guidelines took 21 (19-26) minutes compared to 31 (16-41) minutes for the implicit tool and 44 (39-55) minutes for the explicit tool. Primary care physicians dominated in the ten minutes immediately before the decision point the conversation and accounted for 64% (58-66%) of all utterances, and this trend was similar in all three arms of the study. Giving information was the most common activity for both GPs and patients, although GPs compared to Patients twice as likely and more likely to consult with computer-assisted decision support. GPs used highly technical language and only 7% of their conversations had socio-emotional content;" this was half of the socio-emotional content the patients displayed (15%). However, frequent head nods and close mirroring in line of sight indicated that both parties actively participated in these deliberations. But even in consultations aimed at promoting shared decision-making, GPs were verbally dominant and acted mainly as information providers to patients. In addition, computer-aided decision-making aids lengthened the deliberations considerably, especially in the later phases. These data suggest that decision aids may not result in more 'sharing' in the treatment decision and that, in their current form, they may be taking too long to be negotiated for use in routine primary care.

title: Medical diagnosis through semiotics: Giving meaning to the sign
abstract: Physicians are busy incorporating quantitative methods for making clinical decisions into their practice. An occupation with semiotics, the theory of signs, can complement this project. A sign stands for something. We communicate indirectly through signs, and by interpreting what signs mean, we understand our world and diagnose and understand our patients. Thus, through association and inference, we turn flowers into love, Othello into jealousy, and staring eyes into thyrotoxicosis. Characteristically, upon diagnosis, beginning with an unstable conclusion, we test and ask questions that are likely to produce evidence to support (or discredit) ours. Hypothesis. In a literary sense, we join with the author to clarify and rewrite the text"; creative interpretation is key. The diagnosis is completed through the narrative, through the meaning revealed through the telling of the patient's story . Diagnosis will succeed only to the extent that we respect the principles and caveats of sign interpretation. The sign is both the key to the unknown and the master imitator. The sign and its meaning are usually not the same;" meaning must Because interpretations are subjective, they are limited by the experience and bias of the practitioner, and the contexts in which the sign appears shape and can change the meaning of the sign altogether.

title: Medical ethics in the revolutionary age
Medical Research and Alzheimer's Disease: A Study of the Dangers of Conducting Research on the Incompetent Patient
abstract: After reviewing legal questions about the importance of legal capacity and consent in the context of clinical research with possibly incompetent patient groups, the question of how those involved in this area solve the problems is investigated. Responses from 101 local research ethics committees, 13 pharmaceutical companies and 10 researchers involved in working with patients with Alzheimer's disease indicate significant differences in approach to legal and ethical issues, as well as a degree of conflict in evaluating the ability of patients towards consent. The conclusion is that the recent proposals of the Legal Commission in this area need further examination and elaboration in several respects.

title: Medical Research: The Role and Responsibility of Physicians
abstract: The General Medical Council in the UK has decided to join the already very large number of national and international organizations that issue guidelines for conducting research. This may be related to the fact that the UK, through the GMC, takes research misconduct more seriously than most countries, except that the GMC is developing separate policies in this area in collaboration with the Royal College of Physicians. So the purpose of another set of guidelines, which will be professionally binding on physicians, is unclear. The draft guidelines are open for comment until June 21 and are reprinted below.

title: Medical management of benign prostatic hyperplasia: physician and patient preferences and satisfaction
abstract: Practice guidelines recognize the importance of patient preferences in determining the appropriate treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Recent literature suggests that patient and physician perspectives and satisfaction with BPH treatment management may differ";" this may impact clinical outcomes and patient compliance. This review evaluates patients' and physicians' preferred treatment options for treating BPH and patient satisfaction with therapy. A Medline-based systematic review was conducted using the terms 'benign prostatic hyperplasia' + 'patient preference/perception/satisfaction' or 'doctor/urologist preference/perception'. Patients prefer therapies that affect the long-term course of the disease over those that produce a short-term improvement in symptoms, contrary to what their physicians believe. The prescription behavior of urologists and general practitioners can be very different. Studies of patient satisfaction with specific treatments generally show high levels of overall satisfaction, but cross-study comparisons are limited due to study design heterogeneity. Evidence to date suggests that the views and beliefs of patients and their doctor may not always coincide. Improved communication between doctor and patient will help determine the best treatment option for patients with BPH and can ensure better compliance and treatment success.

title: Medication coordination during the transition period as a patient safety strategy
abstract: Medication reconciliation identifies and resolves unintended discrepancies between patients' medication lists during care transitions. The purpose of this review is to summarize the evidence on the effectiveness of in-hospital medication balancing interventions. The search included MEDLINE up to November 2012 and EMBASE and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials up to July 2012. Eligible studies assessed the impact of in-hospital medication matching on unintended discrepancies with non-trivial risks to patients or emergency room visits 30 days after the dismissal and reinstatement. Two reviewers assessed study eligibility, abstracted data, and assessed study quality. Eighteen studies evaluating 20 interventions met the selection criteria. In 17 of the 20 interventions, the pharmacists carried out a medication comparison. Most of the unintended discrepancies found were of no clinical significance. Medication balancing alone is unlikely to reduce hospital utilization after discharge, but may do so when bundled with interventions aimed at improving transitions in care.

title: Medication review and comparison with cooperation between pharmacist and general practitioner and the benefit for the patient: a systematic review
abstract: This article systematically reviews the literature on the impact of collaboration between pharmacists and general practitioners and describes its impact on patient health. A systematic literature search yielded 1041 articles. After the first title and abstract check, 152 articles remained. After viewing the full text, 83 articles were included. All included articles are presented according to the following variables: (i) reference, (ii) study design and setting, (iii) patient inclusion criteria, (iv) description of the intervention, (v) whether a patient interview was conducted to assess the experience of patients with their drug-taking behavior, (vi) outcomes, (vii) whether healthcare professionals have received additional training, and (viii) whether healthcare professionals have received financial reimbursement work together to improve patient health. Only nine studies reported serious outcomes such as (re)hospitalization;' However, these studies had mixed results, not all of which were statistically significant. Randomized controlled trials should be able to describe hard results, but large patient populations are required to conduct such trials. Patient involvement is important for long-term success.

title: Medicine and Human Rights: Reflections on the Fiftieth Anniversary of the Doctors' Trial
abstract: 1996 marks the 50th anniversary of the beginning of the trial of Nazi doctors in Nuremberg, a trial that has been variously referred to as the "doctors' trial" and "medical case." Aside from documenting atrocities committed by doctors and scientists during World War II, the most significant contribution of the process has come to be known as the "Nuremberg Code", a legal codification of 10 requirements for the moral and legal treatment of people in experiments. Anniversaries give us an opportunity to reflect on the past, but they also allow us to renew our efforts to plan for the future. This article briefly describes the historical development of the Nuremberg Code, discusses its current relevance and applicability using a case study example, and proposes future steps to be taken by the international community.

title: Meeting Expectations: The Solihull Approach Parenting Group's Pilot Assessment
abstract: We have developed a new parent group based on the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence guidelines for parent groups in behavioral disorders and the Solihull Approach, a multi-agency approach to improving parent-child relationships and behavior management. Our goal was to create a parent group that is theoretically coherent, proven effective, time efficient, for universal to more complex problems, for parents of children from birth to age 18, accessible to parents with dyslexia, manageable by community practitioners such as health visitors and school nurses and supported by a cost-effective and uncomplicated staff training model. This article describes the development of the Solihull Approach Parenting Group and the results of its first large-scale pilot assessment. The results show an improvement in child behavior and a reduction in parental anxiety.

title: Merging the perspectives of regulators, pharmaceutical industry and US payers to improve approaches to treatment effect heterogeneity in research and practice
abstract: Effective pursuit of the science and management of treatment effect heterogeneity (HTE) relies on mutual understanding of perspectives and collaboration among the diverse healthcare stakeholders. In this article, we compare, contrast, and seek to find areas of agreement between the perspectives of three such stakeholders - regulators, the biopharmaceutical and device industry, and US payers. First, we discuss how evidence for HTE is generated and how it could be improved. In pharmaceuticals, much of the initial research is performed by the pharmaceutical industry, which is guided by basic research but also limited by potential markets, regulatory approval requirements, study size considerations, and payer expectations of proof of value. Once a drug is commercialized, further evidence can be generated by combining study data, performing meta-analysis, and analyzing real-world results through observational research designs.";" We examine how these efforts can benefit from collaboration between these stakeholders. Second, we discuss the equally important use of HTE evidence to enable physicians and patients to access and benefit from the evidence from this research. Research results need to be translated into actionable information and guidelines that can be incorporated into daily practice. This requires interaction and collaboration between all stakeholders, based on facilitated communication and further evaluation research. We present examples of several cross-sectoral initiatives underway in this area. Finally, we examine some economics of HTE research as part of the drug development, marketing and treatment process. Understanding the economic incentives that exist is fundamental to aligning those incentives to improve the availability and use of HTE evidence. A clear understanding between regulators, pharmaceutical companies and payers about high value goals, methods to efficiently generate and communicate information and value propositions can lead to “win-win” scenarios for patients, individual payers, the healthcare system as a whole and the future of drug development in manufacturing new drugs.

title: menopause and sports
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Accumulating data suggest that regular physical activity reduces mortality and increases functional lifespan in both men and women. This review attempts to describe the current state of the medical literature on this topic. METHODS: A narrative review of the current medical literature, including randomized clinical trials and clinical guidelines, addressing the health benefits of physical fitness and regular exercise in midlife and postmenopausal women. RESULTS: Reduction and prevention of obesity and its associated comorbidities (hypertension, glucose intolerance, dyslipidemia, and heart disease) are one of the main benefits of physical activity. However, long-term physical activity is also associated with a reduction in cancer, dementia and cognitive decline, poor mood and anxiety symptoms, and a reduction in osteoporosis, osteopenia, falls and fractures. Beneficial physical activity includes exercises that promote cardiovascular fitness (aerobics), muscular strength (resistance), flexibility (stretching), and balance (many of the foregoing and additional activities such as yoga). CONCLUSIONS: Because it is clearly beneficial, inexpensive, and with minimal risk, maintaining a healthy exercise program should be a goal for each participant to improve lifelong well-being. Physicians should employ a variety of behavioral strategies to support their participants' physical fitness goals.

title: Mental Health Link: the development and formative evaluation of a complex intervention to improve shared care for patients with long-term mental illness
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: This study aims to develop an intervention and related conceptual framework for the development of collaborative care for patients with long-term mental illness and to provide a case study of the development of a complex intervention in primary care. METHODS: A pragmatic iterative design included a literature review and focus groups, followed by a formative evaluation including reflection, questionnaires, and interviews. GP practices and associated mental health teams in the south-east London community were involved. Participants included community psychiatrists, psychiatrists, nurses, GPs, managers and local experts with an interest in primary mental health care. RESULTS: The shared care model includes the core components of improved communication along with the development of a registry and database with systems for review and recall. Local needs assessments, audits, training and guidelines are complementary components. The intervention, Mental Health Link, is a facilitated quality improvement program designed to accelerate service development by bringing teams together to agree on a model of shared care that is responsive to local needs, abilities, and interests conforms, and by supporting the development of practice systems. CONCLUSIONS: A model for shared care must take into account the interdependencies of the components and the relationship to the context. The heterogeneity of primary and outpatient care needs to be reflected in the development of complex interventions aimed at improving shared care. It is possible to develop a generalizable complex intervention that responds to local circumstances.

title: mentally ill families. When are the children unsafe?
abstract: This article examines the impact of parental mental illness on child behavior and development. Early detection and intervention are critical";" too often the child is not considered, especially when the parent is not overtly abusive. Parenting support and help can be crucial for mentally ill parents to prevent relapse and support the child's mental health. GPs play a crucial role in this process.

title: Meta-analysis: The effect of dietary advice on weight loss
abstract: Background: Efforts to change diet and lifestyle are the primary treatments for people who are obese or overweight. The effect of dietary advice on long-term weight change is unclear. Purpose: To conduct a meta-analysis of the effect of dietary counseling versus usual care on body mass index (BMI) over time in adults. Data sources: Early studies (1980 to 1997) from a previously published systematic review; MEDLINE and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials from 1997 to July 2006. Study selection: English-language randomized controlled trials (≥ 16 weeks in duration) in overweight adults reporting the effect of dietary advice on weight. The authors only included trials of weight loss with a nutritional component. Data Extraction: Individual reviewers performed full data extraction;" at least 1 additional reviewer reviewed the data. Data Synthesis: Random effects model meta-analysis of 46 dietary counseling studies yielded a maximum net treatment effect of 1.9 (95% CI, 2nd .3 to 1.5) BMI units (approximately 6%) at 12 months Meta-analysis of weight changes over time (slopes) and meta-regression indicate a change of approximately 0.1 BMI units per Month from 3 to 12 months of active programs and a recovery of approximately 0.02 to 0.03 BMI units per month during subsequent maintenance periods Various analyzes indicate that calorie recommendations, the frequency of support meetings, the inclusion of Exercise and diabetes may be independent predictors of weight change Limitations: The interventions, study samples, and weight changes were heterogeneous.The Stu The studies were generally of moderate to poor methodological quality. They had high rates of missing data and could not explain these losses. The meta-analytic techniques could not fully account for these limitations. Conclusions: Compared to usual care, dietary counseling interventions result in modest weight losses that decrease over time. Future studies should emphasize minimizing loss to follow-up and determining which factors lead to more effective weight loss.

title: Methadone substitution - a scientific review in the context of outpatient therapy in Germany
abstract: The German Narcotics Prescription Ordinance BtmVV, 5th Part 2, July 1st, 2001 commissioned the German Medical Association to create guidelines for methadone maintenance therapy according to the medical-scientific state of the art. A joint commission of the German Medical Association and the National Association of Statutory Health Insurance Physicians developed guidelines for substitution therapy for opiate addiction, which were adopted in March 2002 by the Board of Directors of the German Medical Association and published in Deutsches Ärzteblatt on May 24th. 2002. The present study is a systematic literature search on treatment success in general and on specific aspects of methadone substitution therapy, which are taken into account by the guidelines of the German Medical Association. The literature was updated through January 2004. Older randomized controlled trials and more recent quasi-experimental studies support that methadone maintenance therapy is an effective strategy to reduce illicit drug use, improve the health of drug users, reduce criminal behavior and promote rehabilitation of opiate addicts. The evaluation of international studies clearly shows that criteria for access to substitution therapy that go beyond the diagnosis of opiate dependence, eg the presence of a life-threatening comorbidity, are not a prerequisite for substitution therapy in other countries and are therefore not discussed internationally. Study evidence shows that the guideline of the German Medical Association on substitution therapy for opiate addiction reflects the best available evidence from scientific studies and applies it to the conditions of the German healthcare system.

title: Methodology and reporting of mobile health and smartphone application studies for schizophrenia
abstract: The proliferation of mobile devices among patients of all demographics has the potential to transform the way we diagnose, monitor, treat, and study mental illness. With the advent of new tools and technologies, clinicians and researchers are faced with an increasing variety of options, both for clinical assessment through digital capture of the essential behavioral elements of a condition, and for intervention through formalized treatments, coaching, and other technology-enabled means of patient communication . And yet, as with any new set of tools used to assess or treat a disease, establishing and following reporting guidelines - ie what works and under what conditions - is an essential part of the translational research process. Using the World Health Organization's recently published mHealth evaluation, reporting, and assessment guidelines for evaluating mobile health applications, we review the methodological strengths and weaknesses of existing studies on smartphones and wearables for schizophrenia. While growing evidence supports the feasibility of using mobile tools in severe mental illness, most studies to date have not adequately reported on accessibility, interoperability, cost, scalability, replicability, data security, usability testing, or compliance with national guidelines or legal regulations. Future research efforts addressing these specific gaps in the literature will help advance our understanding and realize the clinical potential of these new tools in psychiatry.

title: Methods for treating cognitive deficits in schizophrenia
abstract: Studies ranging from the molecular to the clinical level suggest that cognitive dysfunction plays a central role in the characterization of schizophrenia. Accordingly, increased efforts have been expended to seek effective treatments for these broad and debilitating cognitive deficits. Three general strategies for treating cognitive dysfunction in schizophrenia have emerged in the literature. Second-generation (atypical) antipsychotics have received much attention, but their procognitive effects are rather modest. Augmentation strategies driven by basic or translational research have often shown promise in small uncontrolled studies";" However, few compounds have performed well in rigorously designed studies. Behavioral interventions have shown beneficial effects that generalize to other symptom domains and persist post-intervention, but tend to be costly and labor-intensive. Although there have been some exciting advances in the treatment of cognitive dysfunction, progress to date has been modest and the search for treatments continues.

title: Microcomputer generated memories. Improving primary care physician compliance with mammography screening guidelines
abstract: Recent studies have documented that doctors' adherence to recommended regular check-ups improves with reminders about doctors. However, these reminders are often expensive to maintain and modify. This study examines the influence of a microcomputer tickler system on the arrangement of mammograms. All women (N = 1262) aged 40 years and older who attended an outpatient clinic during a 6-month period were randomly assigned to one of two groups. For the experimental group, the date of the last mammogram ordered and recorded in the clinical database was printed on the encounter form generated for each patient visit. No prior mammogram information was printed for patients in the control group. Women in the experimental group were more likely to have a mammogram ordered during the study period (19% vs. 12%, P=0.001), and consequently were more likely to comply with mammography guidelines at study completion (27 % versus 21%, P=0.011). Microcomputer-based data storage and retrieval systems can help draw physicians' attention to screening recommendations.

title: Microcomputer generated memories. Improving primary care physician compliance with mammography screening guidelines.
abstract: study was conducted to examine the influence of microcomputer-generated "reminders" in prompting physicians to schedule regular mammography screenings for patients. The main reasons given by physicians for not performing screening tests such as mammography included forgetfulness, lack of time, inconvenience, and patient discomfort or refusal. The doctor's failure to recommend a mammogram is often due to an oversight on the part of the doctor at the time of a patient visit. This study demonstrates that a microcomputer-based reminder system can be used to increase adherence to physician recommendations for preventive healthcare. An experimental system resulted in a 50 percent increase in mammography orders among a group of women over 40 who participated in the study.

title: Minimal risk, administrative solid studies and informed consent
Minimizing omission errors: behavioral reinforcement of heparin to avoid venous embolism: the BEHAVE study
abstract: AIM: Improve patient safety by increasing heparin thrombosis prophylaxis for patients in medical-surgical intensive care units using a multiple method approach for evidence-based guideline development and implementation. DESIGN: Prospective longitudinal observational study. SETTING: Medical-surgical intensive care unit. PARTICIPANTS: Multidisciplinary clinicians caring for critically ill patients in a 15-bed closed medical-surgical intensive care unit. INTERVENTIONS: Phase 1 was a 3-month baseline period during which we documented anticoagulation and mechanical thromboprophylaxis. Phase 2 was a 1-year period during which we implemented a thromboprophylaxis guideline using a) interactive multidisciplinary educational events; b) verbal reminders to the ICU team; c) computerized daily recording of thromboprophylaxis by nursing staff; d) weekly graphic implemented feedback to individual critical care physicians on adherence to guidelines;" and e) publicly displayed graphical feedback on group performance. Phase 3 was a 3-month follow-up phase 10 months later, during which we documented thromboprophylaxis. The computerized daily recording of thrombosis prophylaxis by the nursing staff continued during this period. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: ICU and in-hospital mortality rates were similar in all phases, although patients in phase 2 had higher acute physiology and chronic health assessment II scores than patients in phases 1 and 3. The proportion (median in % [ Interquartile range]) of patient days in the ICU with heparin thromboprophylaxis in phases 1, 2 and 3 was 60.0 (0, 100), 90.9 (50, 100) and 100.0 (60, 100) (p = 0.01). The proportion (median in % [interquartile range]) of days on which heparin thromboprophylaxis was incorrectly omitted in phases 1, 2 and 3 was 20 (0; 53.8), 0 (0; 6.3) and 0 (0,0) (p<0.001). CONCLUSIONS: After the development and implementation of an evidence-based thrombosis prophylaxis guideline, we found significantly more patients who received heparin thrombosis prophylaxis. Guideline compliance was maintained 1 year later. More research is needed on which strategies are most effective for implementing patient safety initiatives in the ICU.

title: Misprescribing Controlled Substances: An Evaluation of a Professional Development Program
abstract: BACKGROUND: Controlled prescription drug (CPD) abuse has reached epidemic proportions in the United States. Most physicians enrolled in a three-day continuing professional development (PDP) continuing education (CME) program lack training in risk identification and how to manage patients who abuse CPDs. To address this issue, the authors conducted an evaluation of a PDP that trains physicians in proper prescribing, substance abuse detection, use of screening, brief intervention and referral for treatment (SBIRT), and implementation of motivational interviews (MI). METHODS: The authors conducted a program evaluation to assess the effectiveness and impact of PDP on physician knowledge and prescribing behavior. RESULTS: Participants (N = 174) were typically middle-aged (mean age 53 years), male (89%), and physicians (82%) and other healthcare professionals (18%). Many physicians practice in solo primary care settings (46%). Course evaluations were conducted by n = 155 (89%) participants who rated the course and instructors highly (mean 4.8/5). The physicians' knowledge values at pre/post-assessments increased significantly: pretest (mean = 58.7, SD = 13.12) and posttest (mean = 78.28, SD = 9.83) (t(173) = 20.06, P</=0.0001, 95% confidence interval, CI: [-21.51, -17.65]). Almost half of the participants, n=83/174 (48%), completed the follow-up survey, and 93% agreed/strongly agreed (A/SA) that they had made changes in professional practice. Of participants practicing with an active Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) registration (n=57), most/strongly agreed that they had made changes to align their practices with current guidelines (89%), CPD used more appropriately (87%) and implemented an office prescribing policy (81%) identified and referred more substance abuse patients for treatment (80%) shared new information/experiences from the course with other 25 healthcare professionals (93%) and felt that the course had a positive impact on their personal and professional behavior (90% and 96%, respectively). CONCLUSIONS: This is the first known study evaluating PDP in this population. Results showed participant satisfaction and an improvement in prescriber knowledge and self-reported prescribing behavior. However, more studies are needed to assess actual changes in clinical practice, direct impact on patient outcomes, and relapse rates.

title: Mitigating prenatal Zika virus infection in America
abstract: Background: Because of the risk of Zika virus infection in America and the links between infection and microcephaly, other serious neurological disorders, and fetal death, health departments across the Region have advised women to delay pregnancy. However, the effectiveness of these policies in reducing prenatal Zika virus infection has yet to be quantified. Aim: To evaluate the effectiveness of pregnancy delay interventions on the incidence and prevalence of prenatal Zika virus infection. Design: Vector-borne Zika virus transmission model fitted to 2015-2016 epidemiological data on Zika virus infection in Colombia. Setting: Colombia, August 2015 to July 2017. Patients: Population of Colombia stratified by sex, age, and pregnancy status. Intervention: Recommendations for delaying pregnancy by 3, 6, 9, 12, or 24 months with different levels of adherence. Measurements: Weekly and cumulative incidences of prenatal infections and cases of microcephaly. Results: At 50% adherence to recommendations to delay pregnancy by 9 to 24 months, the cumulative incidence of prenatal Zika virus infection is likely to decrease by 17% to 44%, while recommendations to delay pregnancy by 6 months or less prenatal are likely to increase Infections by 2% to 7%. This paradoxical exacerbation of prenatal Zika virus exposure is due to an increased risk of pregnancies being delayed towards the peak of the outbreak. Limitation: Sexual transmission was not explicitly accounted for in the model due to limited data, but was implicitly subsumed in the overall transmission rate, which was calibrated to the observed incidence. Conclusion: Pregnancy delays can have a significant impact in reducing microcephaly cases, but carries the risk of exacerbating Zika virus outbreaks if the duration is insufficient. The length of the delay, population adherence, and timing of the start of the intervention must be carefully considered. Primary funding source: National Institutes of Health.

title: Mobile diabetes intervention study: testing a personalized treatment/behavioural communication intervention for glycemic control
abstract: BACKGROUND: National data showing that baseline glycemic control is within target range (A1c or = 7.5%) (n = 260) and enrolled into study groups based on PCP randomization. All study patients will receive blood glucose (BG) meters and a year's supply of test materials. Patients in three treatment groups will choose one of two cell phone models, receive one year of unlimited cell phone data and a service plan, register on the web-based individual patient portal, and receive study treatment phone software based on study assignment. Patients in the control group receive the usual care from their general practitioner. The primary outcome is the mean change in A1c over a 12-month intervention period. CONCLUSION: Traditional methods of disease management have not achieved adequate control of blood glucose and other conditions important to people with diabetes. Tools to improve communication between patients and primary care physicians can improve treatment outcomes and provide satisfaction for both patients and physicians. This RCT is ongoing.

title: Mobile web app for self-management of low back pain: randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Nonspecific low back pain (NLBP) is the diagnosis for individuals with low back pain without an underlying medical cause (eg, tumor, infection, fracture, herniated disc, spinal canal stenosis). The American College of Physicians (ACP) and the American Pain Society (APS) recommend multidisciplinary treatments for NLBP that last longer than 4 weeks. However, this approach is impractical for many physicians, and relatively few providers offer NLBP treatment that meets the common ACP-APS guidelines. AIM: This study evaluated the effectiveness of a mobile web intervention called "FitBack" to help users implement self-tailored strategies to manage and prevent NLBP occurrences. METHODS: A total of 597 adults were recruited, screened, consented, and assessed online at baseline, 2 months (T2), and 4 months (T3). After baseline assessment, participants were randomized into three groups: FitBack intervention, alternative care group, which received 8 emails asking participants to link to six internet resources for NLBP, and control group. The FitBack group also received weekly email reminders and assessment emails for 8 weeks. The control group was only contacted to make assessments. RESULTS: Users of the FitBack program demonstrated greater improvement compared to the control group for each comparison of the critical physical, behavioral, and workplace outcome measures at the 4-month follow-up. In addition, at the 4-month follow-up, users of the FitBack program performed better than the alternative treatment group on current back pain, behavior and workplace outcomes. For example, subjects in the control group were 1.7 times more likely to report current back pain than subjects in the FitBack group; Subjects in the alternative care group were 1.6 times more likely to report current back pain at the 4-month follow-up visit. In addition, users of the FitBack program demonstrated greater improvement in patient activation, planned behavior theory constructs, and attitudes toward pain compared to the control group and the alternative treatment group at the 4-month follow-up A theory-based standalone mobile web intervention , which tailors content to users' preferences and interests, can be a powerful tool for back pain self-treatment. Viewed from the RE-AIM perspective (ie, outreach, efficacy/effectiveness, adoption, implementation fidelity, and maintenance), this study supports the notion that this type of intervention has significant value as a potentially cost-effective tool that can reach a large number of users People. The results are promising considering that the FitBack intervention was not supported by professional caregivers, nor was it integrated into a health promotion campaign that might have offered additional support to the participants. However, more research is needed on how self-directed interventions are used on the mobile web over time and to understand factors associated with sustained user engagement. STUDY REGISTRATION: Clinicaltrials.gov NCT01950091;” http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01950091 (Archived by WebCite at http://www.webcitation.org/6TwZucX77).

title: Modeling of Gaze Patterns in Doctor-Patient Interaction with Sequential Delay Analysis
abstract: AIM: The aim of this study was to investigate whether lag sequence analysis could be used to describe gaze orientation between physicians and patients in the medical encounter. This topic is especially important as new technologies are implemented in multi-user healthcare settings, where trust is critical and non-verbal cues are an integral part of trust building. This analysis method could lead to design guidelines for technologies and more effective assessments of interventions. BACKGROUND: Nonverbal communication patterns are important aspects of doctor-patient interactions and can influence patient outcome. METHOD: The gaze behavior of physicians and patients in 110 videotaped medical encounters was analyzed using the lag-sequential method to identify significant behavioral sequences. The sequential delay analysis included both event-based delay and time-based delay. RESULTS: The results of the event-based lag analysis showed that the patient's gaze followed that of the doctor, while the doctor's gaze did not follow that of the patient. Time-based sequential analysis showed that patient responses typically occurred within 2 seconds of the physician's initial behavior. CONCLUSION: Our data suggest that the physician's gaze significantly affects the medical encounter, but that the converse is not true. APPLICATION: Findings from this research have an impact on the design of clinical work systems and the modeling of interactions. Similar research methods could be used to identify different behavioral patterns in clinical settings (physical arrangement, technology, etc.) to facilitate and evaluate the design of clinical work systems.

title: Moderators of remission with interpersonal counseling or drug treatment in primary care patients with depression: randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although depressive disorders are very common, there is little research to assist primary care physicians in making treatment choices for patients with mild to moderate depression. OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of interpersonal counseling versus selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in primary care physicians with major depression and identify moderators of treatment outcome. METHOD: A nine-centre randomized controlled trial (DEPICS, Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry number: ACTRN12608000479303). The primary outcome was remission of the depressive episode (defined as the Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression Score </=7 at 2 months). Daily functioning was assessed using the Work and Social Adjustment Scale. Logistic regression models were used to identify moderators of treatment outcome. RESULTS: The percentage of patients achieving remission at 2 months was significantly higher in the interpersonal counseling group than in the SSRI group (58.7% vs. 45.1%, P=0.021). Five moderators of treatment outcome were found: depression severity, functional impairment, anxiety comorbidity, previous depressive episodes, and smoking habits. CONCLUSIONS: We identified some patient characteristics that predict a different outcome with pharmacological and psychological interventions. Should our findings be confirmed in future studies, these characteristics will help clinicians define criteria for first-line treatment of depression that are targeted to patient characteristics.

title: Modifying dyspepsia management in primary care: a cluster-randomized controlled trial of education versus passive guideline dissemination
