abstract: BACKGROUND: Quality improvement initiatives in healthcare rely on the effective implementation of clinical practice guidelines. However, even well-constructed guidelines have little impact unless supported by dissemination and implementation strategies. AIM: To test the effectiveness of 'education' as a strategy to facilitate the uptake of dyspepsia management policies in primary care. STUDY DESIGN: A pragmatic, cluster-randomized, controlled guideline adoption study comparing outreach to guideline dissemination by mail. AREA OF APPLICATION: 114 general practices (233 general practitioners) in the Salford and Trafford Health Authority catchment area in North West England. METHOD: All practices received guidelines in the mail in July 1997. The intervention group practices began providing information three months later. This consisted of practice-oriented seminars with hospital experts, in which guideline recommendations were reviewed and implementation plans were formulated. The seminars were followed by “reinforcement visits” after a further 12 weeks. Outcome measures were: (a) the appropriateness of referral for" and (b) findings on open-line upper gastrointestinal endoscopy; (c) cost of family doctor prescriptions for acid-suppressing drugs; and (d) use of laboratory-based serologic testing for Helicobacter pylori Die Data were collected for seven months before and/or after the intervention and analyzed by intention-to-treat. RESULTS: (a) The proportion of appropriate referrals was higher in the intervention group at the six-month-intervention period (practice medians: control = 50.0%, intervention = 63.9%, P<0.05); (b) the proportion of major findings at endoscopy did not change significantly; (c) there was a greater increase in total expenditure on acid-suppressing drugs in the intervention compared to the control group (+8% vs. +2%, P=0.005);" and (d) the mean per-office testing rate for Helicobacter pylori in the post-intervention period was significantly greater in the intervention group (four versus 0, P<0.001). CONCLUSION: This study suggests that education may be more effective in changing clinical behavior than passive dissemination of guidelines. It also shows that unpredictable and unexpected results can occur.

title: Modifying angiotensin receptor blocker prescribing behavior by selectively removing management pre-approval requirements for losartan.
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess whether lifting the pre-approval (PA) for losartan in a healthcare organization (HMO) could reduce prescribing of the more expensive angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs). METHODS HMO physicians were informed that losartan would no longer require PA and changes were made to the electronic prescribing computer program accordingly. The monthly distribution by drug of the number of prescriptions for ARBs issued to new patients before and after the policy change was calculated from data collected from electronic records. The proportion of losartan-treated patients (percentage and 95% confidence interval) who met criteria for treatment with ARBs (hypertension or heart failure in patients who developed angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor-reaction or macroproteinuria-related adverse reactions) in the first Month after treatment met PA requirement was reversed was calculated. RESULTS The total number of PA requests for ARBs decreased by 48.6% from 961 in December 2008, the month before the policy change, to 494 the following January and increased again to 651 in January 2010. Prescribing incidence changed from 121 to 255 treated patients per month (114% increase) for losartan, from 15 to 16 (6.7% increase) for candesartan and from 89 to 71 (20.2% decrease) for valsartan. The duration of action for reducing ARB requests for the more expensive drugs was approximately 1 year. Only 23.3% (95% CI 18.1-28.4) of patients receiving losartan met the criteria for receiving ARBs. CONCLUSIONS Eliminating the PA requirement for this drug alone was an effective, limited-duration strategy to reduce prescription of relatively expensive drugs

title: Modular ICT-based patient empowerment framework for diabetes self-management: design perspectives and validation results
abstract: INTRODUCTION: It is estimated that more than 382 million people worldwide have diabetes, most of them between the ages of 40 and 59. ICT can play a key role in better diabetes management and patient empowerment. Patient empowerment involves patients to a greater extent in their own healthcare process, and disease management becomes an integrated part of their daily lives. Self-management gives patients the opportunity to contribute to their own health care and to have better control over their disease. OBJECTIVES: The aim of our study was to investigate the impact of an ICT-based patient empowerment framework on diabetes self-management. METHODS: A modular patient empowerment framework that promotes diabetes self-management was designed and implemented. The framework incorporates expert knowledge in the form of clinical guidelines and supports patients in defining personalized activities based on medical recommendations and personal goals, as well as collecting daily life observations. The applicability and usefulness of the proposed framework were evaluated in a pilot study involving 60 patients and 12 healthcare professionals. RESULTS: The study demonstrated that a patient empowerment approach based on ICT self-management tools is useful and accepted by both patients and physicians. For those patients who were already disciplined in their disease management, the pilot solution served as a data-logging facility. Moreover, it served as an incentive for better adherence to the principles of disease management. The ICT tools prompted many patients to become more physically active and to adjust their dietary habits. However, this influence proved to be closely correlated with the sociocultural background of the subjects. The study also showed that even with patient-centered self-management interventions, physicians still have a key role to play. However, the acceptability of such interventions by healthcare professionals depends not only on the impact on their patients' disease management, but also on the impact on their workflow. CONCLUSIONS: It is evident that a patient empowerment approach based on ICT self-management tools is useful and accepted by patients and physicians. In addition, there is clear evidence that ICT frameworks like the one presented in this paper support patients in behavior change and better disease management. Finally, it was recognized that self-management solutions should be built around the goal of not only educating and guiding patients in disease self-management, but also to support them in exploring the decision space and providing insight and explanations about the impact of their self-treatment on their own values in decision-making.

title: Molecular sources of residual cardiovascular risk, clinical signals, and innovative solutions: Association with subclinical disease, undertreatment, and poor adherence: Implications of new evidence for optimizing cardiovascular patient outcomes
abstract: The residual risk, the continued significant risk of major cardiovascular events (MCVE) in statin-treated patients who have achieved evidence-based lipid goals, remains a concern for cardiologists. Factors contributing to this ongoing risk are atherogenic non-low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles and atherogenic processes unrelated to LDL cholesterol, including other risk factors, the inherent properties of statin drugs, and patient characteristics ie genetics and behavior. In addition, providers, healthcare systems, the community, public policies and the environment play a role. Large statin studies indicate an average 28% reduction in LDL-C and a 31% reduction in relative risk, leaving a residual risk of about 69%. Incomplete risk mitigation and failure to improve at-risk conditions can result in sustained progression of atherosclerosis with new and recurrent lesions at original and distant sites, remodeling, arrhythmias, rehospitalizations, invasive procedures, and fatal disabilities. As a result, identifying additional agents to reduce residual risk, particularly when co-administered with statin drugs, has been an ongoing quest. The current model of atherosclerosis includes many steps during which the disease can progress independently of elevations in LDL-C as defined by the guidelines. Differences in genetic response to statin therapy, differences in the ability of the endothelium to regenerate and repair, and differences in susceptibility to non-lipid risk factors such as tobacco smoking, hypertension, and molecular changes associated with obesity and diabetes may all pose residual risk. A large number of inflammatory and metabolic processes can also offer possible therapeutic targets to reduce the residual risk. Classically, epidemiological and other evidence suggested that increasing high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol would be cardioprotective. When LDL cholesterol is aggressively lowered to target levels, low HDL cholesterol levels are still inversely related to MCVE. Efflux capacity, or the ability to translocate cholesterol from macrophages, is thought to be an important anti-atherogenic mechanism responsible for the reduction in MCVE, mediated in part by healthy HDL. HDL cholesterol is a complex molecule with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, anticoagulant and vasodilating properties, including protecting LDL from oxidation. HDL-associated paraoxonase-1 has a major impact on endothelial function. In addition, HDL promotes endothelial repair and progenitor cell health, and supports the production of nitric oxide. HDL from patients with cardiovascular disease, diabetes and autoimmune diseases may not be protective or even become pro-inflammatory or pro-oxidant. Mendelian randomization and other clinical studies in which raising HDL-cholesterol was not beneficial suggest that high plasma levels do not necessarily reduce cardiovascular risk. These data, coupled with extensive pre-clinical information on the functional heterogeneity of HDL, challenge the "HDL hypothesis" that raising HDL-cholesterol per se will reduce MCVE. Following the ambiguous AIM-HIGH study (Atherothrombosis Intervention in Metabolic Syndrome With Low HDL/High Triglycerides: Impact on Global Health Outcomes) and the withdrawal of two key cholesteryl ester transfer protein compounds, one for off-target side effects and the other for lack of efficacy Development continues on two additional compounds, anacetrapib and evacetrapib, both of which significantly lower LDL cholesterol. The negative but controversial HPS2-THRIVE study (The Heart Protection Study 2-Treatment of HDL to Reduce the Incidence of Vascular Events) casts further doubt on the HDL cholesterol hypothesis. The growing impression that HDL functionality, rather than abundance, is clinically important is supported by experimental evidence highlighting the conditional pleiotropic effects of HDL. Mirroring the cholesterol in all atherogenic particles containing apolipoprotein B, non-HDL cholesterol has surpassed LDL cholesterol as a lipid marker of cardiovascular risk and future mortality. In addition to including a measure of residual risk, the benefits of using non-HDL cholesterol as the primary lipid target are now compelling. The reinterpretation of data from the Treating to New Targets study suggests that better control of smoking, body weight, high blood pressure and diabetes will help reduce residual risk. Although greatly improved, control of risk factors other than LDL-cholesterol currently remains inadequate due to deficiencies in guideline compliance and poor patient adherence. More efficient and widespread use of proven simple therapies such as aspirin, beta-blockers, angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors, and angiotensin II receptor blockers in combination with statin therapy may improve outcomes better than the use of other complex therapies. Comprehensive, intensive, multimechanistic, global and national programs employing primary, primary and secondary prevention to reduce the overall level of cardiovascular risk are needed.

title: Monitoring and management of metabolic effects of antipsychotic drugs: a cluster-randomized study of an intervention combining evidence-based quality improvement and external moderation
abstract: Background The treatment of psychotic disorders consists mainly of second-generation antipsychotics, which are associated with metabolic side effects such as overweight/obesity, diabetes and dyslipidemia. Evidence-based clinical practice guidelines recommend timely assessment and treatment of these conditions,” however, research studies show deficits and delays in metabolic monitoring and treatment in these patients. This protocol article describes the project "Monitoring and Management for Metabolic Side Effects of Antipsychotics," which is testing an approach to implementing recommendations for these practices.Methods/Design This project uses a cluster-randomized clinical trial design to to test the effectiveness of an evidence-based quality improvement plus supportive intervention. Eligible study sites were VA medical centers with ¡Ã 300 patients starting a new antipsychotic prescription within six months. A total of 12 sites, matched in pairs based on the results of an organizational practice survey, were then randomized within pairs to receive intervention or control conditions. Study participants include VA staff involved in metabolic monitoring and treating patients ed with antipsychotics at participating sites. The intervention includes researchers collaborating with clinical stakeholders to facilitate customization of local implementation strategies to remove barriers to monitoring and management of metabolic side effects. The intervention includes a design phase (initial site visit and subsequent development of a local implementation plan); Implementation phase (guided by an experienced external facilitator);" and a sustainability phase. The assessment will include development-oriented, implementation-oriented, progress-oriented, and interpretative formative assessment components, as well as a summative assessment. Assessment methods will include surveys, qualitative data collection by the vendor participant, and quantitative data analysis of the data from all Patients prescribed a new antipsychotic drug at a study center and pending metabolic adverse event surveillance or treatment periods during the study phases Changes in rates of recommended surveillance and management actions at intervention and control centers will be compared using time series analyses.Discussion Improving surveillance at metabolic side effects of antipsychotics, as well as promoting timely evidence-based management when these effects occur, is becoming a lead to improved patient safety and long-term outcomes. This article discusses the major strengths and challenges of studying.

title: More informative summaries of articles describing guidelines for clinical practice
abstract: Recommendations for creating more informative summaries of articles describing guidelines for clinical practice are suggested. Information on the development and content of guidelines should be summarized using the following structure. Objective: A concise statement of the goal of the guideline, including the targeted health problem, the targeted patients and providers, and the primary reason for developing recommendations about that problem for this population. Options: Key practice options considered in formulating the guideline. Outcomes :Significant health and economic outcomes identified as potential consequences of the practice options.Evidence:Methods used to collect, select, and synthesize evidence, and the date of the most recent evidence obtained. Values: People and methods used to assign values (relative importance) to potential outcomes of alternative practice options. Benefits, harms and costs: nature and extent of the main expected benefits, harms and costs resulting from the implementation of the guideline.Recommendations:a concise and specific list of the main recommendations.Vali dation: the results of external reviews, comparisons with guidelines made by others Groups have been developed, or clinical tests of guideline application. Sponsors: Key individuals or groups that developed, funded, or endorsed the guideline. Abstracts that adhere to these recommendations may improve readers' ability to assess the applicability, importance, and validity of guidelines for specific providers, patients, and settings. More informative abstracts could also promote the use of more explicit methods of guideline development, more consistent reporting of guideline documents, and more appropriate use of guidelines by clinicians.

title: Mother-to-child transmission of HIV-1 infection during exclusive breastfeeding in the first 6 months of life: an intervention cohort study
abstract: Background Exclusive breastfeeding is uncommon, although it is superior to other forms of infant feeding and is associated with improved infant survival. We assessed HIV-1 transmission risks and survival associated with exclusive breastfeeding and other types of infant feeding.";" Background Exclusive breastfeeding is uncommon, although it is superior to other forms of infant feeding and is associated with improved infant survival. We assessed HIV-1 transmission risks and survival associated with exclusive breastfeeding and other types of infant feeding.

title: Motivation is a critical factor in maintaining a healthy lifestyle in people with coronary artery disease after percutaneous coronary intervention
abstract: AIM: To test the Theory of Adherence of People with Chronic Disease with regard to treatment adherence in patients with coronary artery disease after percutaneous coronary intervention. BACKGROUND: Advanced knowledge of the concept of adherence is required for the development of nursing interventions and nursing guidelines for patients with coronary artery disease. DESIGN: A multicenter, cross-sectional study. Methods: This study was conducted from February to December 2013 in 416 patients with coronary artery disease 4 months after percutaneous coronary intervention. A self-report questionnaire was used to assess their adherence to therapy. The data were analyzed using structural equation models. RESULTS: The theory explained 45% of healthy lifestyle adherence and 7% of medication adherence. Structural equation modeling confirmed that nursing motivation and outcomes had the highest association with adherence to a healthy lifestyle. Responsibility was associated with adherence to medication. Support from family members, support from nurses and doctors, and motivation, cooperation, fear of complications, and a sense of normalcy were associated with adherence. CONCLUSION: Patients who are motivated to care for themselves and who value the outcomes of care are more likely to adhere to a healthy lifestyle. Responsible patients were more likely to stick to their medication. It is important to consider these elements as part of secondary prevention strategies in patients with coronary artery disease after percutaneous coronary intervention.

title: Motivational Enhancement Therapy with and without cognitive behavioral therapy for the treatment of type 1 diabetes
abstract: Background: Although psychological problems can interfere with diabetes care, the effectiveness of psychological treatments in improving diabetes outcomes is uncertain. Aim: To determine whether motivational enhancement therapy with or without cognitive behavioral therapy improves glycemic control in type 1 diabetes compared to usual care. Design : Randomised, controlled study. Setting: 8 diabetes centers in London and Manchester, United Kingdom. Patients: 344 adults with type 1 diabetes for more than 2 years, with hemoglobin A1c values from 8.2% to 15% and without complications or severe co-morbidity.Intervention: Nurse-delivered motivational therapy (4 sessions over 2 months), motivational therapy plus cognitive behavioral therapy (12 sessions over 6 months), or usual treatment ), hypoglycemic events, depression, quality of life, anxiety about Hypoglycaemia, self-care activities in diabetes, and body mass index (secondary endpoints). Results: In an analysis that included all randomized patients, the 12-month change in hemoglobin A1c levels compared to usual care was 0.46% (95% CI, 0.81% to 0.11%) in in the Motivational Enhancement Therapy Plus group with cognitive behavioral therapy and 0.19% (CI, 0.53% to 0.16%) in the Motivational Enhancement Therapy alone group. There was no evidence of treatment effects on secondary outcomes. Limitations: Of 1659 patients screened, only 507 were eligible and 344 participated. No primary endpoint data were available for 11.3% of participants. The study design did not allow distinguishing the additive effect of cognitive behavioral therapy plus motivational enhancement therapy from the effect of greater intensity and duration of the combined intervention compared to motivational enhancement therapy alone. Conclusion: Nursing motivational enhancement therapy and cognitive behavioral therapy is feasible for adults with poorly controlled type 1 diabetes. Combination therapy results in a modest 12-month improvement in hemoglobin A1c levels compared to usual care, but motivational enhancement therapy alone does not.

title: Motivational interviewing: Helping people through change., 3rd edition
abstract: This best-selling work for professionals and students is the authoritative presentation of Motivational Interviewing (MI), the powerful approach to facilitating change. More than just an update, the third edition has been completely restructured around the new four-process model of MI (Engagement, Focus, Evocation and Planning). MI originators William R. Miller and Stephen Rollnick demonstrate how the processes work in practice, describe a rich spectrum of applications, and address the growing evidence base. Imbued with respect and compassion for clients, the book begins with a thorough overview of the spirit and method of MI. Sections on each of the four processes provide step-by-step guidance on building a strong working relationship, developing clear focus and direction, evoking and strengthening the client's motivation for change, and formulating a concrete plan of action. The main communication skills used in MI are explained";" Vignettes and interview examples clearly illustrate the "dos and don'ts" of successful implementation in different contexts. Ways to build proficiency in MI, integrate it with other practices, and assess intervention fidelity are discussed. Key points at the end of each chapter increase the book's usefulness for teaching and professional development. The accompanying website (www.guilford.com/p/miller2) provides other helpful resources, including reflection questions, annotated case material, an expanded bibliography, and a glossary. Reflecting major advances in the understanding and teaching of MI, this book is essential reading for mental health and healthcare practitioners, including addiction specialists, clinical psychologists, psychiatrists, social workers, family therapists, counselors, nurses, physicians, and health educators. Doctoral students in these fields will find accessible, uniquely informative course text. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Motivational Interviewing: Is That All Our Clients Need?
abstract: Motivational Interviewing (MI) and its offshoots, such as the Drinker's Check-up and Motivational Enhancement Therapy, have grown in popularity in the academic and addiction treatment communities over the past decade. This article first looks at the reasons for this popularity, suggesting that it is due to suspected cost-effectiveness, relevance to interventions in non-treatment-seeking populations, and the essential nature of addiction as a motivational disorder. The article then proceeds to review evidence for the effectiveness of MI in both non-treatment-seeking and treatment-seeking samples, taking into account published systematic reviews and, in particular, the results of the MATCH project. The relevance of possible results from the UK Alcohol Treatment Trial will also be considered. The article also looks at mechanisms of change that might be responsible for the functioning of MI. It ends with a list of conclusions about the effectiveness of MI, the possible roles in treatment it can fulfill, the client groups for which it may be particularly useful, and what further research is needed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Mouthwash for oral mucositis in allogeneic stem cell transplantation: a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Oral mucositis is a common side effect of allogeneic stem cell transplantation and can lead to increased morbidity, mortality and costs. It also affects the patient's quality of life. In the stem cell transplantation station of a Swiss university hospital, the patients are instructed according to the current guidelines for mouthwashes and the oral status is evaluated daily. RESEARCH QUESTION: How do patients experience oral mucositis and what factors influence their behavior to rinse their mouth regularly? METHOD: In this qualitative part of a concurrent embedded mixed-methods research, 14 patients were interviewed using an interview guide. The data was analyzed using content analysis methods. RESULTS: The results showed that oral mucositis cannot be considered separately from illness, isolation and care. Mucositis was only a serious burden for patients if it was severe. In patients with low-grade onset, other symptoms were more important. The research identified motivating and debilitating factors for regular mouthwashing, which is one of the most important preventive measures. CONCLUSIONS: This study underscores the importance of understanding oral mucositis in the context of transplantation and that knowledge of motivating and disabling factors can assist nurses in patient care. An essential aspect is the improvement of patient self-management.

title: Much Cheaper, Almost as Good: Decrementally Cost-Effective Medical Innovation
abstract: In resource-constrained conditions, cost-saving innovations, even if slightly less effective than available options, can improve overall outcomes by enabling more efficient reallocation of resources. The authors systematically reviewed all MEDLINE-cited cost-benefit analyzes written in English between 2002 and 2007 to identify and describe cost- and quality-reducing medical innovations that might offer favorable "decremental" cost-effective trade-offs - defined as Savings of at least $100,000 per quality-adjusted year of life lost. Of 2128 cost-effectiveness ratios from 887 publications, only 9 comparisons (0.4% of the total) described 8 innovations that were considered decrementally cost-effective. Examples included percutaneous coronary interventions (instead of coronary artery bypass grafts) for multivessel coronary artery disease, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (instead of electroconvulsive therapy) for drug-resistant major depression, vigilant waiting for inguinal hernias, and sterilization and reuse of hemodialyzers. On a patient basis, these innovations resulted in savings of $122 to nearly $12,000 but losses of 0.001 to 0.021 quality-adjusted life years (roughly 8 hours to 1 week). These results demonstrate the rarity of decrementally cost-effective innovations in the medical literature.

title: Multidimensional analyzes to assess the connections between treatment decisions by physicians and patient characteristics using COPD as an example
abstract: BACKGROUND: In some settings, practice guidelines do not provide clear, evidence-based guidance for COPD treatment choices, particularly when large studies have failed to identify subgroups of high or low responders to available medications. METHODS: This observational, cross-sectional study examined the yield of four types of multidimensional analyzes to assess associations between clinical characteristics of COPD patients and pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments prescribed by pulmonary specialists in a real-world context. RESULTS: A total of 2494 patients from 515 respiratory physicians were recruited. Multiple correspondence analysis and hierarchical clustering identified 6 clinical subtypes and 6 treatment subgroups. Strong bidirectional associations between clinical subtypes and treatment subgroups were found in multivariate logistic regression. Although the overall frequency of prescriptions varied from one clinical subtype to another for all types of pharmacologic treatments, clinical subtypes were not associated with specific prescription profiles. When canonical redundancy analysis was used, the proportion of variation in pharmacological treatments explained by clinical features remained modest: 6.23%. This proportion was larger (14.29%) for non-pharmacological treatment components. CONCLUSION: This study shows that although pharmacologic treatments for COPD are quantitatively very well associated with patient clinical characteristics, there is no specific patient profile that could be qualitatively associated with prescriptions. This underscores the uncertainties felt by physicians in differentiating the relative effects of available pharmacological treatments. The methodology used here is useful for identifying areas of uncertainty that require further research and/or guidance clarification.

title: Multidisciplinary treatment of pediatric obesity: nutritional assessment and management
abstract: Assessment and treatment methods for pediatric obesity are evolving rapidly. Obesity is thought to be caused by an imbalance between caloric intake and expenditure and requires a comprehensive assessment of patient, family, environmental, genetic, and cultural characteristics so clinicians can design successful interventions. Quantitative nutritional assessment of caloric intake is difficult and time consuming and should only be used in isolated settings, e.g. B. in research, or if initial approaches to treatment were not successful. Alternatively, providers should identify dietary patterns or behaviors that have been associated with obesity and represent promising targets for change. Clinicians should tailor interventions by considering patient and family motivations and willingness to change. Current guidelines recommend a gradual escalation of treatment plans, and multidisciplinary treatment teams are recommended for patients requiring intensive intervention. Vendors involved at a multidisciplinary level need to integrate their area of expertise with that of the team to develop a comprehensive management plan. This article provides an overview of current recommendations for the assessment and management of pediatric obesity with a focus on nutritional assessment as part of a multidisciplinary team.

title: Multifactorial influences and deviations from the safety and quality of drug administration in the acute medical and surgical context
abstract: BACKGROUND AND AIMS: Although numerous factors influence drug administration, our understanding of the interplay of these factors is limited to medication quality and safety. The aim of this study was to investigate the multifactorial influences on medication quality and safety within the framework of a uniform test guideline for medication administration in acute care. APPROACH: An exploratory/descriptive study with nonparticipant observation and follow-up interview was used to identify factors affecting medication quality and safety in medication administration episodes (n=30). Observations focused on nurses' interactions with patients during drug administration and the characteristics of the environment in which this took place. Confirmation of the observed data occurred after the conclusion of the observation period during short semi-structured interviews with participating nurses. RESULTS: Results indicated that nurses developed therapeutic relationships with patients in terms of assessing patients prior to administering medication and educating patients about medication during medication administration. Caregivers were more likely to be distracted when medications were stored and prepared in a shared medication room per ward design. Nurses deviated from best practice guidelines when administering medication. IMPLICATIONS: Nurses' skills and willingness to develop therapeutic relationships with patients increased the quality and safety of medication, thereby protecting patients from potential adverse events. Deviations from best practice drug administration had the potential to reduce medication safety. System factors such as station design, which determines medication storage areas, can easily be taken into account to minimize potential errors. CONCLUSIONS: Nurses demonstrated behaviors that improved the quality and safety of medication administration";" however, violations of practice standards have been observed. These results will inform future intervention studies to improve drug quality and safety.

title: Multifactorial intervention with nurses does not change cardiovascular outcomes in patients with chronic kidney disease
abstract: Strict implementation of multi-target guidelines reduces vascular risk in diabetics. Whether this also applies to patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is uncertain. To assess this, the MASTERPLAN study randomized 788 patients with CKD (estimated GFR 20-70 mL/min) to receive additional intensive care (the intervention group) or a nephrologist (the control group). The primary endpoint was a composite of myocardial infarction, stroke, or cardiovascular death. During a mean follow-up of 4.62 years, modest but significant decreases in blood pressure, LDL-cholesterol, anemia, proteinuria along with increased use of active vitamin D or analogs, aspirin, and statins were noted in the intervention group compared to controls. No differences were found in rates of smoking cessation, weight loss, sodium excretion, physical activity, or glycemic control. Intensive control did not reduce the rate of the composite endpoint (21.3/1000 person-years in the intervention group compared to 23.8/1000 person-years in the control group (hazard ratio 0.90)). No differences were found in the secondary endpoints of vascular surgery, all-cause mortality, or end-stage renal disease. Thus, the additional intensive caregiver support in patients with CKD improved some risk factor levels but did not significantly reduce the rate of primary or secondary endpoints.

title: Multi-level support for physical activity and healthy eating
abstract: AIM: This paper reports on a study evaluating the relationship between social and community support and physical activity and dietary behaviors in a low-income Latino population with multiple chronic conditions. BACKGROUND: With consistently lower levels of physical activity than whites and documented nutritional deficiencies, Latinos represent a disproportionate proportion of the population with chronic diseases in the United States. This pattern of health inequalities is evident in all countries working to improve the health of low-income, immigrant and indigenous communities. Social-ecological theories of health behaviors emphasize the importance of considering social and community support for health behaviors and provide a useful framework for considering ways to improve physical activity and nutrition for immigrant and aboriginal groups. METHOD: We report here data from a baseline assessment of 200 patients from a health clinic in the United States serving a low-income, primarily Hispanic population. Participants were enrolled in Resources for Health, a randomized controlled trial to promote multilevel support for chronic disease self-management. Measures included self-reported physical activity, dietary behaviors, and multi-level support for chronic disease management, as well as demographic data. The basic data reported here were collected between February 2002 and September 2003. RESULTS: Utilizing multi-level support (e.g., family, individual, and healthcare provider) was statistically significantly associated with meeting physical activity guidelines and better dietary behaviors. Being a woman and having multiple chronic medical conditions has also been linked to better eating habits. These variables explained 20% of the variance in dietary behavior. CONCLUSION: The results support a social-ecological approach to promoting healthy behaviors in this low-income, mainly Hispanic sample with multiple chronic conditions. In interventions to improve physical activity and nutrition, it is important to address multiple levels of support for healthy behaviors, and caregivers may be particularly well placed to address such issues for low-income, Aboriginal and immigrant patients with chronic conditions.

title: Multiple prescription patterns for antipsychotics
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate current prescribing practices related to concomitant antipsychotic drug use and summarize the reasons why clinicians may prescribe >1 planned agent. METHODS: The pharmacy identified patients at William R. Sharpe Jr Hospital who were currently receiving antipsychotic therapy. All patients receiving >/=2 concomitant scheduled antipsychotics were included in the study. Data on demographic characteristics, drug combinations currently used, history of attempted regimens, and prescribing physician rationale were prospectively evaluated for a 60-day period from December 13, 2000 to February 10, 2001. Other tried drug regimens were compared with medical records and published treatment guidelines for schizophrenia compared. RESULTS: Over a 60-day follow-up period, 206 patients were placed on scheduled antipsychotics, with 85 (41%) receiving at least 2 agents. Respondents to a prescriber questionnaire (59%) indicated that augmentation was the most common justification for combination therapy”; the least likely rationale was cross-titration. The survey responses also demonstrated the belief that there was questionable therapeutic benefit in more than half of the patients treated with multiple antipsychotic combinations. In addition, medical records showed that the majority of these patients had not received an adequate trial of monotherapy with other atypical or typical agents or clozapine prior to combination antipsychotic therapy. Fifty-one percent of medical records did not document a justification for adjunctive therapy. CONCLUSIONS: Due to the lack of published data, the use of multiple antipsychotics is considered a gray area that requires increased awareness by the prescriber when assessing efficacy and safety. Documenting the rationale, side effects, and response to the treatment regimen is essential to optimal patient care.

title: Electronic alerts on multiple screens to improve venous thromboembolism prophylaxis
abstract: Venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis in high-risk patients is often underutilized. We previously developed a one-screen computer alert program that identified hospitalized patients at high risk of VTE who were not receiving prophylaxis and advised their physicians to prescribe prophylaxis. While this strategy reduced the 90-day incidence of symptomatic VTE by 41%, the majority of electronic alerts were ignored. We have now developed a serial three screen alert computer program to educate physicians who initially refused to order prophylaxis after a single screen alert. Of a total cohort of 880, physicians in charge received a single electronic alert for 425 patients, while 455 who declined prophylaxis after the first screen received the second and third screens of the novel three-screen alert. Our enhanced serial three-screen alert program generated VTE prophylaxis orders for 58.4% of the 455 patients whose physicians initially declined to order prophylaxis after the one-screen alert. There was no significant difference in the 90-day symptomatic VTE rates between the two cohorts (2.8% for the one-screen vs. 2.2% for the three-screen, p=0.55). We conclude that our three-screen computer alert program can significantly improve prophylaxis for physicians who reject an initial single-screen alert.

title: Does diabetes have to be a deadly disease in Africa? Investigating the cost of treatment
abstract: GOAL Estimate the cost of diagnosing and treating diabetes in Tanzania. DESIGN Costs were estimated using the reported and recorded experiences of patients with new-onset diabetes in 1989-90 and of diabetics first seen in 1981-2. SETTING Muhimbili Medical Centre, Dar es Salaam. PARTICIPANTS 464 patients (315 males and 149 females). 262 patients with diagnosis from September 1, 1989 to August 31, 1990 (Group 1) and 202 patients from June 1, 1981 to August 31, 1982 (Group 2). RESULTS The average annual direct cost of diabetes care in 1989-90 was $287 for an insulin-dependent patient and $103 for a non-insulin-dependent patient. Insulin purchases accounted for 68.2% ($156) of the average annual outpatient cost for insulin-dependent patients. For patients who do not require insulin, the cost of oral antidiabetic drugs and management of chronic complications and infections accounted for 42.5% ($29.3) and 48.8% ($33.7) of costs, respectively. The cost of diabetic outpatient care across Tanzania was estimated at $2.7 million, *75,128 (32.2%) of which for insulin. Doctor and nursing costs accounted for 0.2% of the total costs of outpatient care. Annual direct inpatient care costs have been estimated at $1.25 million. Approximately 0.2% of Tanzania's population aged 15 and over used the equivalent of 8% of total government health spending, equivalent to $47,4088,382. CONCLUSION Diabetes places a heavy strain on the limited resources of developing countries. If African patients with diabetes have to pay for their treatment, most will not be able to and will die.

title: Nationwide survey of alcohol screening and brief intervention practices at US Level I trauma centers
abstract: BACKGROUND: In 2007, the American College of Surgeons (ACS) Committee on Trauma introduced a requirement that Level I trauma centers have a mechanism for identifying patients who are problem drinkers and the ability to provide an intervention for patients provide that have tested positive. Although the landmark alcohol screening and brief intervention (SBI) mandate is expected to have an impact on trauma practice nationwide, a literature review found no studies that have systematically documented SBI practice prior to the ACS requirement. STUDY DESIGN: Trauma programs at all U.S. Tier I trauma centers were contacted and asked to complete a survey on SBI practice prior to ACS requirements at trauma centers. RESULTS: One hundred forty-eight of 204 (73%) Level I trauma centers participated in the survey. More than 70% of responding centers routinely used laboratory tests (eg, blood alcohol concentration) to screen patients for alcohol, and 39% routinely used a screening question or standardized screening tool. About 25% of screen-positive patients received formal alcohol counseling or had an informal alcohol talk with staff. CONCLUSIONS: The study observed significant differences between Level I centers in the percentage of patients screened and in the type and extent of intervention delivery in screen-positive patients. Following the requirements of the ACS Committee on Trauma, future research could systematically implement and evaluate training to deliver evidence-based alcohol interventions and training to develop the organizational capacity of trauma centers for sustainable delivery of SBI.

title: Naturopathic treatment of earache in children
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Otitis media is one of the most common diseases of infancy and childhood and one of the most common reasons for children to consult a doctor. In the last 2 decades, the diagnosis of otitis media has increased significantly worldwide. In the United States, 93% of all children by age 7 have had at least 1 episode of acute otitis media (AOM). Otalgia is the hallmark of AOM. Most affected children either complain of earache or exhibit behavior that the parents interpret as evidence of earache. Treating ear pain early in the course of AOM reduces both parental anxiety and child discomfort, and accelerates the healing process. The aim of this study was to determine the efficacy and tolerability of a naturopathic treatment compared to conventional treatment for otalgia commonly associated with AOM in children. Methods: The study was designed as a double-blind study in an outpatient community clinic. A total of 171 children aged 5 to 18 years with ear pain and clinical findings related to otitis media were examined. Children were randomly assigned to treatment with naturopathic herbal extract ear drops (NHED) or anesthetic ear drops with or without amoxicillin. At enrollment, children were assigned by computer-numbered randomization to receive NHED (contents: Allium sativum, Verbascum thapsus, Calendula flores, Hypericum perfoliatum, lavender, and vitamin E in olive oil) 5 drops 3 times daily alone (Group A) or concomitantly a local anesthetic (amethocaine and phenazone in glycerol) 5 drops 3 times a day (group B) or oral amoxicillin 80 mg/kg/day (maximum 500 mg/dose) divided into 3 doses with either NHED 5 drops 3 times a day ( Group C) or local anesthetic 5 drops 3 times a day (Group D). A double-blind design was used and all ear drops were placed in identical bottles. Treatment was initiated by the nurse in all cases. A single physician (MS) evaluated and treated all patients included in the study and collected all data. The presence or absence of ear pain was assessed over 3 days using a visual analogue scale. Ear pain was assessed from previous reports using a specially designed observational instrument. One side of the instrument consisted of a linearly numbered scale from 1 (no pain) to 10 (worst possible pain) and a corresponding color scale ranging from blue to dark red. The back contained a scale of 5 facial expressions ranging from a big smile (no pain) to a sad and crying face (worst pain) and a corresponding color scale ranging from blue to dark red. RESULTS: There were no significant differences between the groups in terms of patient age or sex, fever grade, main symptoms, associated symptoms, and severity or laterality of the acute otitis media. Each group had a statistically significant improvement in ear pain over the 3 days. Patients given ear drops alone responded better than patients given ear drops along with amoxicillin. The results were better in the NHED group than in the control group. However, the findings showed that the pain was mostly (80%) self-limiting and could be explained simply by the elapsed time. The American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery guidelines recommend topical medications as the first line of treatment for ear pain in the absence of a systemic infection or serious underlying condition. Since no evidence was found that systemic antibiotics alone improve treatment outcome, if antibiotics do not alter the natural history of otitis media, the main goal of treatment should be relief of ear pain, as in the present study. The alternative, naturopathic herbal extract medications may offer many new opportunities in the treatment of earache associated with AOM. GPs should be aware that at least 10% of their patients may have tried one or more forms of alternative/complementary medicine before presenting for a consultation. As has been extensively reported in the medical literature, these herbal extracts have the potential to fulfill all the requirements for suitable drugs that could be routinely used in pediatric patients, namely bacteriostatic and bactericidal activity in vitro against common pathogens, immune stimulating ability, antioxidant activity and anti-inflammatory effects. They are also well absorbed and penetrate well into the tissues surrounding the eardrum. They have been found to enhance local immunological activity. Finally, herbal extracts are well tolerated (due to their long elimination time), easy to administer, and less expensive than the new antibiotics. There are no documented side effects. Based on our findings that the group with the most significant treatment effects (NHED with topical anesthesia) explained only 7.3% of the total pain reduction, we suggest that sometimes the family doctor or pediatrician needs to give the human body a chance to repair itself. However, if the physician believes there is an indication for treatment, particularly if the parents are concerned, then local treatment such as that used in our study may be appropriate. CONCLUSIONS: This study indicates that in cases of pediatric earache caused by AOM that require active treatment in addition to a simple 2 to 3-day waiting period, a herbal extract solution may be beneficial. Simultaneous antibiotic treatment is obviously not beneficial.

title: Needs and opportunities in rehabilitation. AIDS and the environment
Negative pressure wound therapy after partial diabetic foot amputation: a multicenter, randomized, controlled trial
abstract: Background Diabetic foot wounds, particularly those following amputation, are very complex and difficult to treat. We investigated whether negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) improves the rate and rate of wound healing after partial foot amputation in patients with diabetes.";" Background Diabetic foot wounds, particularly those following amputation, are very complex and difficult to treat. We investigated whether negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) improves the rate and rate of wound healing after partial foot amputation in patients with diabetes.

title: Decision-making at the end of life in newborns: Physicians' attitudes and relationship to self-reported practices in 10 European countries
abstract: Context The ethical issues surrounding end-of-life decision-making for infants with poor prognosis are controversial. There is little empirical evidence on the attitudes and values underlying such decisions in different countries and cultures. Aim To investigate the variability in attitudes of neonatal physicians in 10 European countries and the relationship between such attitudes and self-reported practice of end-of-life decisions. Design and Setting Survey conducted in 1996-1997 in 10 European countries (France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom, Estonia, Hungary and Lithuania). Participants A total of 1391 physicians (response rate 89%) regularly employed in 142 neonatal intensive care units (NICUs). Main outcome measures scores on an attitudinal scale that measures opinions about the absolute value of life (score 0) versus the value of quality of life (score 10)";" Self-report of ever setting limits to intensive neonatal interventions with poor neurological prognosis. Results Physicians from Hungary (mean setting values, 5.2 [95% confidence interval {CI}, 4.9-5.5]), Estonia (4.9 [95% CI, 4.3-5.5]), Lithuania (5.5 [95% CI, 4.8-6.1]) and Italy (5.7 [95% CI, 5.3-6.0]), while physicians tend to agree that quality of life is considered came from the United Kingdom (attitude values, 7.4 [95% CI, 7.1-7.7]), the Netherlands (7.3 [95% CI, 7.1-7.5]), and Sweden (6.8 [95% CI, 6.4-7.3]) . Other factors associated with positive attitudes about quality of life were being female, having no children, being Protestant or having no religious background, not considering religion important, and being in a NICU with a high number to work from very low-birth weight newborns. Physicians with scores that more closely reflected quality of life were more likely to report that their practice had limited intensive interventions in the face of poor neurologic prognosis, with an adjusted odds ratio of 1.5 (95% CI, 1.3–1 ,7) per unit adjustment score change. Conclusions In our study, the likelihood that physicians set limits for intensive neonatal interventions when the neurological prognosis is poor depends on their attitude. After adjusting for potential confounders, country remained the most important predictor of physician attitudes and practices.

title: Neurobehavioural morbidity associated with sleep disordered breathing in children: a comprehensive review
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVES: To comprehensively review the research on the association between childhood sleep-disordered breathing (SDB) and neurobehavioral functioning. DESIGN: Qualitative and quantitative literature research. ADJUSTMENT: N/A. PATIENTS OR PARTICIPANTS: N/A. INTERVENTIONS: N/A. MEASUREMENTS AND RESULTS: The results of 61 studies on the relationship between child SDB and neurobehavioural functioning were critically assessed and synthesized. There is strong evidence that SDB in childhood is associated with deficits in behavioral and emotional regulation, academic achievement, sustained attention, selective attention, and wakefulness. There is also evidence that SDB is minimally associated with a child's typical mood, expressive language skills, visual perception, and working memory. The results were insufficient to draw any conclusions about intelligence, memory, and some aspects of executive functioning. Mechanisms by which SDB might lead to neurobehavioral morbidity are under investigation, but clinical symptoms such as chronic snoring remain the best predictors of morbidity. Short-term studies of SDB treatment outcomes are encouraging, but long-term outcomes are unknown. If SDB is not treated, children appear to be at risk for long-term neurobehavioural deficits. CONCLUSIONS: SDB in childhood is associated with neurobehavioral morbidity. Using commonly used guidelines for causal inference, there is strong evidence for associations, consistent results, and specificity of effect, even in the absence of a much-needed randomized clinical trial. There is evidence that this association fits the expected temporal pattern and that SDB is a biologically plausible cause of neurobehavioural deficits. Clinicians should be alert to the coexistence of SDB symptoms and concerns about a child's academic progress, attention, arousal, or behavior or emotion regulation.

title: Neurotropic viruses and cerebral palsy: population-based case-control study
abstract: AIM To investigate the association between cerebral palsy and direct evidence of perinatal exposure to neurotropic viruses. DESIGN Population-based case-control study. SETTING Adelaide Women's and Children's Hospital Research Laboratory. PARTICIPANTS AND MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Newborn screening cards from 443 white patients with cerebral palsy and 883 white controls were tested for enterovirus and herpesvirus viral nucleic acids by polymerase chain reaction. Group A herpesviruses included herpes simplex viruses 1 and 2 (HSV-1 and HSV-2), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), cytomegalovirus (CMV), and human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and group B herpesviruses included varicella-zoster virus (VZV) and human herpesviruses 6 and 7 (HHV-6 and HHV-7). RESULTS The prevalence of viral nucleic acids in the control population was high: 39.8% of controls tested positive and the prevalence was highest in preterm infants. Detection of herpes group B viral nucleic acids increased the risk of developing cerebral palsy (odds ratio 1.68, 95% confidence interval 1.09 to 2.59). CONCLUSIONS Perinatal exposure to neurotropic viruses is associated with preterm birth and cerebral palsy.

title: Never too old? Age should not be a barrier to participation in cancer clinical trials
abstract: Across Europe and the US, over 60% of all cancer incidence occurs in the elderly (> or = 65 years), a patient population that, due to a number of factors, requires special consideration in treatment decisions. Despite this, elderly patients are generally underrepresented in clinical trials, so study data should be interpreted with caution, as results in younger cancer patients cannot always extrapolate to the typical elderly cancer patient. Reports suggest that elderly cancer patients account for approximately 22% of patients enrolled in phase II clinical trials. Barriers to enrolling older patients in clinical trials include the lack of appropriate trials, a high comorbidity burden, study-related limitations, and physician recruitment. There is an assumption that elderly patients may not tolerate various cancer therapies, which may lead to the exclusion of this patient population from prospective studies. However, clinical data show that age alone is not a sufficient reason to discontinue treatment. A lack of data from clinical trials and the associated lack of evidence-based guidelines for older patients means that physicians have little guidance, resulting in patients potentially not receiving the optimal therapy. Because clinical trials are the primary method for evaluating the efficacy and safety of adjuvant and palliative cancer therapies, trials specifically targeting older cancer patients are needed to adequately assess the risks and benefits of treatment in this vulnerable population. The aim of this review is to assess the clinical reality and the discrepancy between age and age of clinical trials in order to assess the implications for older cancer patients and how to address this situation. Possible reasons for the disparity and the resulting clinical consequences are also considered.

title: New challenges in family interventions in schizophrenia
abstract: This review first outlines the rationale and research base supporting the development of family interventions in schizophrenia. It then presents the overarching principles that guide effective family interventions in schizophrenia, along with the key components (engagement, assessment, education, communication skills training, and problem-solving) shared by most family programs in schizophrenia. Meta-analyses showing the effectiveness of family interventions in reducing relapse and rehospitalizations in schizophrenia are then discussed, along with questions about the minimal duration of effective treatment, differential benefits of single and multi-family modalities, and mixed evidence for maintenance of treatment effects after termination. It then describes the benefits of participating in family-organized extra-occupational support and education programs. Finally, three issues are outlined that warrant further investigation.

title: New developments in the psychotherapy of schizophrenic psychoses
abstract: There is already sufficient evidence for the effectiveness of psychotherapeutic interventions, in particular cognitive behavioral therapy, for symptom reduction and relapse prevention. Evidence-based treatment guidelines recommend this approach for routine care. An increasing number of randomized clinical trials and research into active treatment elements characterize this field. This paper presents research and clinical implications. Treatment strategies to reduce positive and negative symptoms, which represent an innovative research area, are presented and discussed in terms of efficacy, treatment principles, and possible future developments.

title: New drugs in anesthesia: can we afford them?
abstract: The key challenge facing physicians today is the dilemma of providing quality care in a fiscally responsible manner. The costs are no longer negligible. Pharmacoeconomics is a fundamental part of medical education. Economic issues should be an integral part of drug development and clinical trials. While anesthesiologists are concerned that using cheaper drugs could affect outcome and patient satisfaction, there is little evidence to support such concerns. This is a fertile area for intensive future research. Pharmacoeconomics is a dynamic. Drug costs are not static, drug use patterns are changing rapidly, and clinical practice is in a state of constant flux. The answer to cost containment is not simply to trim, clip, eliminate or simply hope for the best for the best, but to manage and modify the practice while accommodating changing needs. Educational programs, policies, departmental policies, system changes, and financial incentives can be implemented to ensure consistent and ongoing adherence to the principles of pharmacoeconomics and value-based care. Some suggest that National Societies should establish guidelines for cost-effective practice. Others advocate the physician's autonomy in drug selection. It is difficult to change the doctor's behavior. This change will be gradual and will be the subject of many emotionally charged philosophical debates. There will be great reluctance to refuse patients pharmacologically superior drugs based on cost alone, especially since drugs represent such a small part of the total cost. We must exercise caution to ensure that we do not become too clever and foolish. Drug procurement costs are just one element in a large and complex equation. Focusing on the cost of buying drugs can be dangerous, even naïve when we fall for knowing the cost of everything but the value of nothing.

title: New format for printed BMJ research articles
abstract: It's been almost 10 years since we started abridged original research articles for readers of the printed BMJ. Now we are going one step further and using the advantages of web and print. The fully open access version of this original article by Hollingshurst and colleagues is published online (doi:10.1136/bmj.a2656), along with our first-ever BMJ research video and podcast. Here are two abridged versions: a BMJ Pico, a new evidence abstract prepared by the authors, and a short cuts article written by the BMJ. Which version would you read and use? What would you prefer if you were the author? Please share your views as readers and researchers with us by quickly replying to this article. Sandra Hollinghurst,1 Debbie Sharp,1 Kathleen Ballard,3 Jane Barnett,2 Angela Beattie,1 Maggie Evans,1 George Lewith,2 Karen Middleton,2 Frances Oxford,3 Fran Webley,2 Paul Little2 Study Question What is the difference in cost? Efficacy between long and short courses in Alexander Technique, massage, and general practitioner prescription for exercise in patients with persistent back pain? Answer At values above £20,000 per Quality Adjusted Life Year (QALY), one practice recipe and six Alexander Technique lessons were each more than 85% cost effective, but Alexander â‚¬ Â¦

title: New insights into common variable immunodeficiency
abstract: Common variable immunodeficiency (CVI) is a heterogeneous immunodeficiency syndrome characterized by hypogammaglobulinemia, recurrent bacterial infections, and various immunological abnormalities. In addition to recurrent infections, patients with this syndrome also have an increased incidence of autoimmune diseases and malignancies. Since the spectrum of associated diseases is wide, patients with CVI are examined by different specialists. This review discusses the pathogenesis, clinical manifestation, diagnosis, and treatment of CVI.

title: Newly diagnosed idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura in childhood: an observational study
abstract: Background Diagnosis and treatment of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) has so far been based mainly on expert opinion and practice guidelines and less on evidence. We used a registry to prospectively examine the presentation characteristics and the diagnostic assessment and treatment practices used for children with ITP worldwide.";" Background Diagnosis and treatment of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) has so far been based mainly on expert opinion and practice guidelines and less on evidence. We used a registry to prospectively examine the presentation characteristics and the diagnostic assessment and treatment practices used for children with ITP worldwide.

title: NHMRC Guidelines for Clinical Practice in ASD and PTSD
abstract: Dear Editor, I recently described the case of a diving instructor who was suffering from Acute Stress Disorder (ASD), a type of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), following the death of one of her students. The treatment described was a combination of EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing) and exposure-based cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) exercises. Coincidentally, in August, the Australian Center for Post-Traumatic Mental Health published Australian Clinical Practice Guidelines for ASD and PTSD. These have been endorsed by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). The treatment described in the diver injury case is consistent with these guidelines. NHMRC guidelines suggest that immediately following a traumatic episode (e.g., death or serious injury to a diver), the most helpful response is to provide psychological first aid. This includes providing information about traumatic stress responses, encouraging self-care, and using available social support. It is recommended that the physician monitor the patient, be alert for improvement, plateau, or worsening, and be prepared to offer help or appropriate referral if necessary. The guidelines recommend the use of trauma-focused psychological therapy as a first-line intervention for ASD and PTSD. EMDR, including in vivo exposure, and CBT are considered the most effective treatments. When medication is required, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are considered the best choice. For the benefit and convenience of patients and physicians, the NHMRC guidelines and a comprehensive set of educational guides on ASD and PTSD are available online as PDF file downloads at http://www.acpmh.unimelb.edu.au. An update in the Medical Journal of Australia provides traumatic stress information for medical professionals, including screening questions that can be used to identify patients suffering from ASD and PTSD. This article is available online at: http://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/187_02_160707/for10467_fm.html. Short articles and factsheets specific to divers on traumatic stress responses, death and panic are available at http://psychodiver.com.

title: NHS 1948-88: less ideology, more humanity
NHS profile. The men from the Audit Committee come in. Interview by Richard Smith
NICE Guide to Preventing Sexually Transmitted Diseases and Teenage Pregnancy
abstract: NICE has released new guidelines for public health interventions to stop the rising number of sexually transmitted infections, including HIV, and prevent conception in under-18s. This article outlines the role of nurses in implementation.

title: No impact from active dissemination of the Ottawa Ankle Rules: further evidence of the need for local implementation of practice guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Local implementation strategies are often required to promote consistent adherence to clinical guidelines, but they are time-consuming and expensive. The authors tested an educational intervention aimed at increasing the use of the Ottawa Ankle Rules, a widely used set of clinical guidelines previously shown to reduce the use of radiographs to diagnose acute ankle injuries. Methods: The study consisted of a quasi-experimental, comparative before-and-after analysis. Trained experts provided hour-long training sessions and educational materials on the Ottawa Ankle Rules to healthcare professionals from 63 Ontario hospitals. Participants were asked to rate the intervention. The authors then compared, for periods before and after the training sessions, the use of ankle radiography in adults with acute ankle injury in 10 hospitals who received the training intervention and reported no (n = 5) or some (n = 5) prior use of the rules and in 5 Control hospitals that rejected the educational intervention because they were already implementing the rules. RESULTS: Although participants rated the Ottawa Ankle Rules and the training very positively, there was no reduction in the use of ankle radiography in the 10 hospitals that received the training (73% before and 78% after the intervention, p=0 ,11). In contrast, the use of X-ray decreased significantly from 75% to 65% in the 5 control hospitals (p=0.022). INTERPRETATION: Even if a dissemination strategy is well accepted and includes a widely accepted clinical guideline, the impact on behavior in clinical practice may be small. In addition to wide dissemination, an active local implementation strategy is needed to encourage physician adoption of clinical guidelines.

title: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and fibrosis in adolescents taking psychiatric drugs: literature review, case reports, and management
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has become a worldwide epidemic due to the greater prevalence of obesity. Despite the impact on adolescents with severe mental disorders, little has been published in the psychiatric literature about this increasingly common medical comorbidity. The objectives of this article are: 1) to provide an overview of the epidemiology and pathophysiology of NAFLD, including progression to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)"; 2) to describe two clinical cases illustrating difficulties in management;" and 3) reviewing screening recommendations, differential diagnoses, and surveillance and intervention approaches. METHODS: A literature review was performed, including guidelines and recommendations, with case presentations including case and control liver histology biopsy photos. RESULTS: Childhood NAFLD, a precursor to NASH, progresses to fibrosis in a small percentage of adolescents, putting them at risk for early-onset cirrhosis and the need for transplantation. The cases presented raise concern that adolescents with severe mental health disorders, who are already at higher risk of obesity and its consequences, may be at greater risk of progression to NASH, possibly due to greater weight gain on top of being overweight or obese Changes in liver metabolism caused by psychotropic drugs that promote fat storage. CONCLUSIONS: Patients with rapid weight gain in the overweight or obese categories, or patients who develop elevated hepatic transaminases that persist beyond 3-6 months, should be evaluated by their psychotropic physician for early detection, diagnosis, and co-evaluation, or be referred for screening. Treatment by a pediatric gastroenterologist to reduce the risk of progression to NASH, which is reversible when early and sufficient lifestyle modification results in significant weight loss. There is an urgent need for controlled research into the associations between weight gain, psychiatric drugs, ultrasound and biopsy findings, and rates of progression to NAFLD and NASH in adolescents taking weight-gaining psychiatric drugs.

title: Noninvasive imaging predicts spinal failure loading with simulated osteolytic defects
abstract: BACKGROUND: The clinical management of lytic tumors of the spine is currently based on geometric measurements of the defect. However, the mechanical behavior of a structure depends on both its material and its geometric properties. Quantitative computed tomography and dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry have been studied as non-invasive tools to measure the material and geometric properties of vertebrae with a simulated lytic defect. Yield loads were predicted from these measurements using composite beam theory. METHODS: Thirty-four fresh-frozen cadaveric spines were segmented into functional spinal units of three vertebral bodies with two discs at the thoracic and lumbar spine. Lytic defects of the same size were created in one of three locations: anterior, lateral, or posterior of the vertebra. Each spinal unit was scanned using computed tomography and dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry, and axial and flexural stiffnesses were calculated from the image data. Each specimen was failed under combined compression and forward bending, and the axial load and bending moment in yield were recorded. RESULTS: Although the relative defect size was nearly constant, the measured yield loads showed a large scatter, suggesting that the defect size alone is a poor predictor of failure. However, the image-derived measures of structural stiffness correlated moderately well with the measured yield loads. Furthermore, using composite beam theory with quantitative computed tomography-derived stiffnesses, vortex yield loads were predicted on a one-to-one basis (concordance, r(c) = 0.74). CONCLUSIONS: Although current clinical guidelines for predicting fracture risk are based on geometric measurements of the defect, we have shown that the relative size of the defect alone is not responsible for the variation in vertebral yield stress. However, analysis of composite beam theory with quantitative measures of stiffness derived from computed tomography can be used to prospectively predict the yield loads of vertebrae with lytic defects. CLINICAL RELEVANCE: Image-predicted vertebral loads and analysis models that approximate spinal loads during activities of daily living can be used to calculate a fracture risk factor that can be used by physicians to plan an appropriate treatment or intervention.

title: Nonsurgical management of a blunt splenic injury
Nonpharmacological therapies for acute and chronic low back pain: A review of the evidence for an American Pain Society/American College of Physicians clinical practice guideline
abstract: BACKGROUND: Many non-pharmacological therapies are available for the treatment of low back pain. PURPOSE: To evaluate the benefits and harms of acupuncture, back schools, psychological therapies, exercise therapy, functional restoration, interdisciplinary therapy, massage, physical therapies (interference therapy, low-level therapy). laser therapy, lumbar supports, shortwave diathermy, superficial heat, traction, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, and ultrasound), spinal manipulation, and yoga for acute or chronic low back pain (with or without leg pain).DATA SOURCES: English-language studies were identified by searching MEDLINE (up to November 2006) and the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (2006, Issue 4). These electronic searches were supplemented with manual searches of reference lists and additional citations suggested by experts. STUDY SELECTION: Systematic reviews and randomized trials of one or more of the preceding therapies for acute or chronic low back pain (with or without leg pain) that reported pain outcomes, back function, general health status, disability, or patient satisfaction. DATA EXTRACTION: We have information on study design, population characteristics , interventions, outcomes and adverse events are abstracted. To assess methodological quality, we used the Oxman criteria for systematic reviews and the Cochrane Back Review Group criteria for single studies Chronic or subacute (>4 weeks) low back pain. Benefits over placebo, sham, or no treatment averaged 10 to 20 points on a 100-point visual analog pain scale, 2 to 4 points on the Roland-Morris Disability Questionnaire, or a standardized mean difference of 0.5 to 0.8. We found strong evidence that acupuncture, massage, yoga (viniyoga), and functional restoration are also effective for chronic low back pain. For acute low back pain (duration < 4 weeks), the only non-pharmacological therapies with proven efficacy are superficial heat (good evidence of moderate benefit) and spinal manipulation (good evidence of minor to moderate benefit). Although serious damage appeared to be rare, little data on damage was reported. No studies have addressed the optimal sequence of therapies, and methods for tailoring therapy to individual patients are still in the early stages of development. There is insufficient evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of sciatica therapies. LIMITATIONS: Our primary data source was systematic reviews. We included non-English-language studies only if they were included in English-language systematic reviews. CONCLUSIONS: Therapies with good evidence of moderate efficacy for chronic or subacute low back pain include cognitive behavioral therapy, exercise, spinal manipulation, and interdisciplinary rehabilitation. For acute low back pain, the only therapy with good evidence of efficacy is superficial heat.

title: Non-pharmacological management of hypertension: results from interviews with 100 general practitioners
abstract: AIM: To describe the type and extent of non-pharmacological treatment that general practitioners offer for essential hypertension. DESIGN: An open-label, interviewer-administered survey using a standard case of a 60-year-old male with essential hypertension. 70 interviews were conducted in person and 30 by telephone. SETTING: General practices in Auckland. SUBJECTS: A random sample of 100 general practitioners in Auckland. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: Aspects of patient history, physical examination, laboratory testing, and treatment relevant to nonpharmacological management. RESULTS: There was a response rate of 84%. Most general practitioners reported offering non-pharmacological treatment at the first consultation prior to prescribing medication. Few, however, offered detailed programs. Dietary therapy, alcohol restriction, and exercise were suggested by most general practitioners. Less popular non-pharmacological interventions were sodium restriction and behavioral therapy. The median number of patient visits to a primary care physician before prescription medication was five, in line with guidelines. The median number of days from the first visit to the prescription of drug therapy was 42 (range 2-341). Clinical advice provided by the majority of participants was consistent with current guidelines for treating hypertension, but the range of advice given was wide. CONCLUSIONS: The results suggest that primary care physicians are aware of non-pharmacological interventions to treat hypertension. They report the routine use of non-pharmacological therapies for blood pressure reduction and other health benefits early in the clinical process before pharmacological therapy is considered. These non-pharmacological therapies do not come with well-defined and detailed programs.

title: Unresponsive celiac disease
Nordic Myeloma Study Group, the first 15 years: scientific collaboration and improving patient care
abstract: The achievements of the Nordic Myeloma Study Group (NMSG) during its first 15 years are briefly reviewed along with a discussion of the principles guiding the group's clinical trials and the issues that need to be addressed in the years to come. The group has so far conducted 12 clinical trials involving more than 2500 patients, ranging from small phase II to large randomized phase III trials. At the time of writing, two randomized trials (comparing two doses of IV pamidronate and melphalan-prednisone (MP) vs. MP-thalidomide in elderly patients) are ongoing. The group aimed for a simple organization with much responsibility delegated to regional coordinators (Denmark 3, Norway 5, Sweden 5). Regarding the study design, the group considered it important that studies are based on sound scientific questions, are easy to handle for the participants, are population-based, are investigator-initiated, include assessments of quality of life and health resources as endpoints and can be used as a basis for various scientific spin-off projects are used. Like other clinical trial groups, NMSG faces a number of challenges in the coming years.
