The financial situation for independent investigator-initiated studies is far from satisfactory, especially with regard to the resource-intensive implementation of stricter rules of good clinical practice and the demands of ethics committees. NMSG has also encountered increasing difficulties in recruiting patients for the most recent trials, in part due to issues related to participating physicians (lack of support, cumbersome paperwork, insufficient credit to participate). Solutions to these problems must be found if non-industry clinical trial groups are to survive.

title: Norepinephrine plus dobutamine versus epinephrine alone for the treatment of septic shock: a randomized trial
abstract: Background International guidelines for the treatment of septic shock recommend dopamine or norepinephrine over epinephrine. However, no large comparative study has yet been conducted. Our aim was to compare the efficacy and safety of norepinephrine plus dobutamine (when needed) versus epinephrine alone in septic shock.";" Background International guidelines for the treatment of septic shock recommend dopamine or norepinephrine over epinephrine. However, no large comparative study has yet been conducted. Our aim was to compare the efficacy and safety of norepinephrine plus dobutamine (as needed) versus epinephrine alone in septic shock.

title: Normal ranges of heart rate and respiratory rate in children from birth to age 18: a systematic review of observational studies
abstract: BackgroundAlthough heart rate and respiratory rate are routinely measured in children in acute settings, current reference ranges are not based on evidence. Our aim was to derive new percentile plots for these vital signs and to compare these percentiles with existing international ranges.";" BackgroundAlthough heart rate and respiratory rate are routinely measured in children in acute settings, current reference ranges are not based on evidence. Our aim was to derive new percentile charts for these vital signs and to compare these percentiles with existing international ranges.

title: Nudging guideline-compliant antibiotic prescribing: a randomized clinical trial
abstract: IMPORTANT: Nudges, which influence decision-making through subtle cognitive mechanisms, have proven to be highly effective in a variety of applications, but there have been few experiments to improve clinical practice. AIM: To investigate the use of a behavioral “nudge” based on the principle of public obligation to promote prudent use of antibiotics in acute respiratory infections (ARIs). DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: Randomized clinical trial in 5 primary care outpatient clinics. A total of 954 adults had ARI visits during the study period: 449 patients were treated by physicians randomized to the posted letter of commitment (335 in baseline period, 114 in intervention period)";" 505 patients were treated by physicians randomized to standard practice control (384 at baseline, 121 intervention). INTERVENTIONS: The intervention consisted of posting poster-sized letters of commitment in examination rooms for 12 weeks. These letters, which include doctors' photos and signatures, reaffirm their commitment to avoiding the inappropriate prescribing of antibiotics for ARIs. MAIN RESULTS AND MEASURES: Antibiotic prescription rates for antimicrobial ineligible ARI diagnoses at baseline and intervention periods, adjusted for patient age, gender, and insurance status. RESULTS: The baseline rates were 43.5% and 42.8% for the control and the poster, respectively. During the intervention period, inappropriate prescription rates increased to 52.7% for controls but decreased to 33.7% in the published commitment condition. Controlling for baseline prescribing rates, we found that the posted letter of commitment resulted in an absolute 19.7 percent reduction in inappropriate antibiotic prescribing rates compared to the control group (P=0.02). There was no evidence of a shift in diagnostic coding, and rates of prescription of appropriate antibiotics did not decrease over time. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Posting poster-sized commitment statements in exam rooms reduced inappropriate antibiotic prescribing for ARIs. The effect of this simple, inexpensive intervention is comparable to more costly, intensive quality improvement efforts. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01767064.

title: Nudging physician prescribing decisions by order set partitioning: results of a vignette-based study
abstract: Background Healthcare professionals are rapidly adopting Electronic Medical Records (EHRs). Within EHRs, seemingly innocuous menu design configurations can sway vendor decisions for better or worse. Aim The aim of this study was to investigate whether the grouping of menu items systematically influences the prescribing practices of general practitioners. Participants We surveyed 166 primary care physicians in a research network of practices in the greater Chicago area, of whom 84 responded (51% response rate). Respondents and non-respondents were similar on all observable dimensions, except that respondents tended to work in an academic setting. Design The questionnaire consisted of seven clinical vignettes. Each vignette described typical signs and symptoms of acute respiratory infections, and providers selected treatments from a menu of options. For each vignette, providers were randomly assigned to one of two menu areas. For antibiotic-inappropriate vignettes, the treatment menu either listed over-the-counter (OTC) drugs individually while prescriptions were grouped together, or displayed the reverse split. For antibiotic-eligible vignettes, the treatment menu either listed narrow-spectrum antibiotics individually while broad-spectrum antibiotics were grouped, or displayed the reverse split. Key Metrics The key outcome was provider choice of treatment. For antibiotic-inappropriate vignettes, we categorized reactions as prescription drug or OTC-only options. For antibiotic-appropriate vignettes, we categorized the responses as broad-spectrum or narrow-spectrum antibiotics. Key Findings Across all vignettes, there was an 11.5 percentage point reduction in the selection of aggressive treatment options (eg, broad spectrum antibiotics) when aggressive options were grouped compared to listing the same options individually (95% CI: 2.9 up to 20.1%); " p?=?.008). Conclusions Provider treatment choice appears to be influenced by the grouping of menu options, suggesting that the layout of EHR prescription sets is not an arbitrary exercise. The careful creation of EHR prescription sets can be an important opportunity to improve patient care without compromising physicians' ability to prescribe what they believe is best for their patients.

title: Push to caution? The effect of reminders on antibiotic prescriptions.
abstract: Antimicrobial resistance is a major and growing global health threat with significant consequences. The judicious use of antibiotics is crucial to delay the spread of resistance. In this study, I use a randomized controlled trial to test the effect of reminders from primary care patients on antibiotic use. The intervention was carried out in 31 clinics during the flu season in Stockholm. Two-tiered randomization was used, with randomization at the clinic level as well as at the individual patient level. With reminders, antibiotic use fell by 12.6 percent compared to the control clinics. The effect occurs at a clinical level, suggesting that physician or physician–patient interactions, not individual patients, are affected. Results from a follow-up experiment also suggest that an impact on doctor-patient interactions is the main reason for the main findings. Behavioral interventions that target these interactions have the potential to reduce antibiotic use. More research is needed, however, as monitoring and compliance may also play a role.

title: Nurse-led, home-based self-care treatment for primary care patients with chronic fatigue syndrome: randomized controlled trial
abstract: AIM To evaluate the effectiveness of home-delivered pragmatic rehabilitation—a program of gradually increasing activity developed jointly by the patient and therapist—and supportive listening—an approach based on nondirective counseling—for patients in primary care with chronic fatigue syndrome /Myalgia encephalomyelitis or encephalitis (CFS/ME). DESIGN Single-blind, randomized, controlled study. MISSION 186 general practices in North West England between February 2005 and May 2007. PARTICIPANTS 296 patients aged 18+ with CFS/ME (mean disease duration seven years) diagnosed according to the Oxford criteria. INTERVENTIONS Participants were randomly assigned, as usual, to pragmatic rehabilitation, supportive listening, or general practitioner care. Both therapies were delivered at home in 10 sessions over 18 weeks by one of three specialist adult general nurses who had received four months of training, including supervised practice, in each of the interventions. General practitioner treatment as usual was unrestricted, except that patients were not to be referred for systematic psychological therapies during the treatment period. Main outcome measures The primary clinical endpoints were fatigue and physical functioning at the end of treatment (20 weeks) and 70 weeks after enrollment compared to usual family care. Lower fatigue scores and higher physical functioning scores indicate better outcomes. RESULTS A total of 257 (87%) of the 296 patients enrolled in the study were evaluated at 70 weeks, the primary endpoint. Analysis was based on treatment intent, with robust treatment effects estimated using probability weights after adjusting for missing data. Immediately after treatment (after 20 weeks), patients assigned to pragmatic rehabilitation (n=95) showed significantly improved fatigue (estimate of effect -1.18, 95% confidence interval -2.18 to -0.18"; p= 0.021) but no physical functioning (-0.18, 95% CI -5.88 to +5.52; p=0.950) compared to patients assigned to treatment as usual (n=100) at one year after the end of treatment (70 weeks), there were no statistically significant differences in terms of fatigue or physical discomfort functioning between patients assigned to pragmatic rehabilitation and those treated as usual (-1.00, 95% CI -2.10 to +0.11, p=0.076 and +2.57, 95% CI 3.90 to +9.03, p=0.435) Patients assigned to supportive listening (n=101) , had poorer physical functioning than those allocated to treatment as usual (-7.54, 95% CI -12.76 to -2.33; P=0.005) and no difference in fatigue. At 70 weeks, patients assigned to supportive listening did not differ significantly from those assigned to treatment as usual on either of the primary endpoints. CONCLUSIONS In patients with CFS/ME in primary care, pragmatic rehabilitation performed by trained nursing therapists improves fatigue in the short term compared to unrestricted family care as usual, but the effect is small and not statistically significant at one year of follow-up. Supportive listening by trained nursing therapists is not an effective treatment for CFS/ME. Trial Registration International Standard Randomized Controlled Trial Number IRCTN74156610.

title: Nurses improve quality of care in chronic kidney disease: two-year results of a randomized study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with an increased cardiovascular risk. Here we evaluate whether rigorous implementation of multi-objective guidelines with the help of nurses practitioners (NP) improves management in patients with CKD. METHODS: MASTER PLAN is a randomized controlled clinical trial conducted in nine Dutch hospitals. Patients with CKD (estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) 20–70 mL/min) were randomized to receive NP support (intervention group (IG)) or medical care (control group (CG)). Patients were followed for a median of five years. The data presented are an interim analysis of risk factor control after two years of follow-up. RESULTS: We enrolled 788 patients (532 M, 256 F), (393 KG, 395 IG), mean (+/-SD ) age 59 (+/-13) years, eGFR 38 (+/-15) ml/min a/1.73 m(2), blood pressure (BP) 138 (+/-21)/80 (+/-11) mmHg. After two years, 698 patients (352 IG, 346 KG) could be analyzed. IG had lower systolic (133 vs. 135 mmHg; p=0.04) and diastolic blood pressure (77 vs. 80 mmHg; p=0.007), LDL-cholesterol (2.30 vs. 2.45 mmol) compared to CG (-l);" p= 0.03) , and increased use of ACE inhibitors, statins, aspirin, and vitamin D. The intervention had no effect on smoking cessation, body weight, physical activity, or sodium excretion. CONCLUSION: In risk factor management improved in both groups. However, changes in blood pressure control, lipid management, and medication use were more pronounced in IG than in CG. Lifestyle interventions were not effective. Coaching by NPs thus benefits the day-to-day care of CKD patients. Whether these changes translate into an improvement in clinical endpoints remains to be seen.

title: Nurse-led motivational interviews for lifestyle changes in patients with type 2 diabetes (MILD project): protocol for a cluster-randomized, controlled trial of implementing lifestyle recommendations
abstract: BACKGROUND: The diabetes of many patients is treated in general medicine";" Healthcare providers aim to promote healthy behaviors such as healthy eating, adequate physical activity and smoking cessation. These measures can reduce insulin resistance, improve glycemic control, lipid abnormalities and high blood pressure. They can also prevent cardiovascular disease and complications of diabetes. However, professionals do not optimally adhere to guidelines for lifestyle advice. Lifestyle change motivational sessions for patients with type 2 diabetes are designed to improve diabetes care according to national lifestyle counseling guidelines. Primary care nurses are trained in motivational interviewing embedded in structured care in general practice. The aim of this paper is to describe the design and methods of a study evaluating the impact of nurse education on patient outcomes. METHODS/DESIGN: A grouped, randomized, controlled study of 70 primary care practices (35 practices in the intervention arm and 35 in the control arm) that began in March 2007. A total of 700 patients with type 2 diabetes will be recruited. Patients in the intervention arm are cared for by the primary care nurse, who is trained in an implementation strategy using motivational interviewing as a core component. Other components of this strategy will include localization of the diabetes protocol, introduction of a social card to support lifestyle, and educational and supportive tools to maintain motivational interviewing. The control arm is encouraged to maintain usual care. The nursing process, metabolic parameters (glycosylated hemoglobin, blood pressure and lipids), lifestyle (nutrition, physical activity, smoking and alcohol), health-related quality of life and the patient's willingness to change behavior are used as measures of effectiveness. The measurements take place at the start of the study and after 14 months. DISCUSSION: The use of motivational interviewing in patients with diabetes in primary care has been studied, but to our knowledge no other study has evaluated the implementation and sustainability of patient motivation and involvement in daily diabetes care in general practice. If this intervention proves effective and cost-effective, large-scale implementation of this care-oriented intervention will be considered and expected. STUDY REGISTRATION: Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN68707773.

title: Nurse-led, over-the-phone advice to improve lipid levels in people with diabetes
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is a need for randomized, prospective studies of case management interventions with resource use analyses. OBJECTIVES: To determine whether algorithm-driven nurse telephone care improves lipid control in patients with diabetes. DESIGN: Prospective, randomized, controlled study. PARTICIPANTS: Adults with diabetes at a government-funded community health center were randomly assigned to intervention groups (n = 381) or usual care groups (n = 381). INTERVENTIONS: Nurses independently initiated and titrated lipid therapy and promoted behavior change through motivational interviewing and self-management techniques. Other parameters of diabetes care were addressed due to time constraints. MAIN MEASURES: The primary endpoint was the proportion of patients with low-density lipoprotein (LDL) less than 100 mg/dL. Secondary endpoints included the number of hospital admissions, total hospital costs per patient, and the proportion of patients meeting other lipid, glucose, and blood pressure guidelines. MAIN RESULTS: The percentage of patients with an LDL < 100 mg/dL increased from 52.0% to 58.5% in the intervention group and decreased from 55.6% to 46.7% in the control group (p<0.01 ). The average cost per patient to the healthcare system was lower for the intervention group ($6,600 vs. $9,033, P=0.03). Intervention patients tended to have fewer hospital admissions (p=0.06). The intervention had no effect on blood glucose and blood pressure results. CONCLUSIONS: Nurses can improve lipid control in patients with diabetes in a mainly poor population by telephone care using moderately complex algorithms, but a more targeted approach is warranted. Telephone contact may reduce resource use, but further studies are needed.

title: Nurses' assessments of CPOT use 12 months after implementation in the ICU
abstract: BACKGROUND: Conducting routine pain assessments in all patients in the intensive care unit (ICU) is strongly recommended in clinical practice guidelines. Because many ICU patients are unable to self-report, the Critical-Care Pain Observation Tool (CPOT) is one of the two behavioral pain scales recommended for clinical use. Nonetheless, no study has described the assessments of its use in daily practice in the ICU. OBJECTIVE: To describe nurses' assessments of feasibility, clinical relevance, and satisfaction with CPOT use 12 months after its implementation in the ICU. Method: A descriptive design was used. It was performed in the medical-surgical intensive care unit of a university-affiliated facility in Greenfield Park (Quebec, Canada). A four-section self-administered assessment questionnaire (ie, feasibility, clinical relevance, satisfaction, and sociodemographic information) was completed by critical care nurses, all trained in the use of the CPOT. The questionnaires were filled out anonymously. RESULTS: A total of 38 critical care nurses returned their completed questionnaire (63% response rate). In terms of its feasibility, the majority rated the CPOT as quick to use, easy to understand and easy to fill out (92-100%). In terms of clinical relevance, nearly 70% of ICU nurses reported that CPOT had impacted their practice, but lower scores (<50%) were found for effective communication of pain assessment results with physicians and other healthcare professionals . More than 80% of ICU nurses were satisfied with daily use. CONCLUSION: The use of CPOT was considered feasible and relevant in daily practice according to the nurses' assessments, but did not allow for effective communication with other members of the nursing team in the ICU. RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: Training should be offered to all members of the ICU care team, and other implementation strategies should also be explored to ensure optimal adoption of a pain assessment approach that impacts their pain management decision-making process.

title: Salary of nurses
Nurses' representations of caring for mentally challenged patients and perceived needs to ensure quality care
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: To examine nurses' representations of caring for people with intellectual disabilities, intervention strategies they currently use, and identify the needs to ensure quality care. BACKGROUND: Nurses work in many settings and with different clientele. Certain clientele have needs that require specific approaches, such as people with an intellectual disability. The care of these patients can be influenced by the substitutions of the nurses who care for them. DESIGN: Qualitative descriptive study. METHODS: Semi-structured interviews with thematic analysis were conducted with 18 nurses working in hospitals and communities. RESULTS: Nurses are concerned about their ability to recognize the specific nature and complex needs associated with intellectual disability in patients, to promote quality care by addressing the behavioral and communication challenges, and with the perceived lack of time and organization within the work environment. Current strategies include attempts to promote continuity of care. Participants also identified their learning needs, which are relational and informational in nature. CONCLUSIONS: Nurses generally seem to be aware that they want to provide quality care to patients with intellectual disabilities, while acknowledging that there are many contextual and practical elements that need to be improved to ensure the safety of these patients . RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: Nurses need to be trained to adapt to evidence emerging from current research showing that people with intellectual disabilities want to be part of their local communities and to encourage those individuals to do so. This can be facilitated by adopting specific policies, protocols, and care programs. Further research is needed to better understand the expectations of these patients and their caregivers, with a focus on self-advocacy and health promotion techniques, with the goal of improving personalized standards of practice and reducing inequalities in health education for these patients.

title: Strategies used by nurses to address self-care issues related to medication adherence and symptom recognition in patients with heart failure: an in-depth look
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Despite an increasing body of knowledge about self-care in heart failure patients, the need for effective interventions remains. Our goal was to increase understanding of the interventions heart failure nurses use in clinical practice to improve patient adherence and symptom monitoring. METHODS: A qualitative study with a targeted content analysis was conducted using data from a selected sample of Dutch-speaking heart failure nurses who had completed two-vignette brochures addressing medication adherence and symptom recognition. RESULTS: Nurses regularly reassess and reassess patients before deciding on an intervention. They evaluate basic/factual information and barriers in a patient's behavior and try to find room for improvement in a patient's behavior. Interventions that heart failure nurses use to improve adherence to therapy and monitor symptoms were categorized as enhancing knowledge, increasing motivation, and providing practical tools for patients. Nurses also described the use of technology-based tools, increased social support, alternative communication, partnership approaches, and care coordination to improve medication adherence and symptom monitoring. CONCLUSION: Despite a strong focus on educational strategies, nurses also reported other strategies to increase patient adherence. Nurses employ various strategies to improve patient adherence that are not included in guidelines. These interventions need to be evaluated for further applications to improve heart failure management.

title: Nursing Research in the United States: The Protection of Human Subjects
abstract: In the United States, protection of the rights of human subjects in experiments has evolved at three levels: professional, public, and private. At the professional level, codes, guidelines, and patients' rights address issues of protecting the dignity, privacy, and autonomy of individuals serving as research subjects. At the public level, regulations issued by the Food and Drug Administration and the Department of Health and Human Services have become the standard for protecting human subjects. At the private level, United States common law regulates the behavior of individual researchers by requiring them to act in accordance with generally accepted standards of care. As professionals, nurses must be actively involved in shaping public policy regarding the conduct of research and strive to formulate a research agenda that ensures that the ethics of research in nursing are unquestioned.

title: Standard of care of practice protocol: depression in elderly patients. NICHE faculty
abstract: Depression is a common but underappreciated and undertreated mental health problem among community-based, medically ill, and institutionalized older adults. Untreated depression is associated with serious negative consequences for the elderly patient. Nurses in different practice settings can reduce the negative impact of depression through early detection, intervention, and referral of patients with depression. This article provides an overview of depression in later life with a focus on age-related assessment considerations, clinical decision-making, and nursing intervention strategies for older people with depression. A standard practice protocol for use by caregivers in a variety of practice settings is also presented.

title: Nursing student beliefs about smoking, their own smoking behavior, and the use of professional tobacco treatment interventions
abstract: As the largest group of healthcare professionals, nurses are in a unique position to influence their smoking patients. They also have more patient contact than any other provider. The purpose of this survey study was to describe nursing student beliefs about cigarette smoking, their smoking behavior and use of evidence-based tobacco treatment interventions. Of 200 nursing students surveyed, only 6% were smokers. The most inaccurate perception about tobacco treatment was that less than 3 minutes of counseling had no effect on improving smoking cessation rate. Eight percent of smokers surveyed said they had offered tobacco treatment to all smoking patients, compared to 26 percent of non-smokers. Smoking-related morbidity and mortality justify the consistent application of clinical practice guidelines by nursing students and professional nurses.

title: Diet is more important than nature in childhood obesity, study finds
abstract: A study comparing the weight of birth and adopted children to that of their parents found that lifestyle, not genes, is the primary cause of children's obesity.1 Researchers from the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics and Political Science, concluded that interventions aimed at influencing the lifestyle of parents could help combat childhood obesity. For the study, the researchers brought together data from 13 years

title: diet and politics

Assessing and treating obesity: Expert Committee recommendations. The Maternal and Child Health Department, the Administration for Health Resources and Services, and the Department of Health and Human Services
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To develop recommendations for physicians, nurses and nutritionists to guide the assessment and treatment of overweight children and adolescents. METHODS: The Maternal and Child Health Bureau, Health Resources and Services Administration, Department of Health and Human Services convened a panel of pediatric obesity experts to develop the recommendations. RESULTS: The committee recommended that children with a body mass index (BMI) greater than or equal to the 85th percentile with complications of obesity, or with a BMI greater than or equal to the 95th percentile, with or without complications, be evaluated and possible undergo treatment. Physicians should be aware of the signs of the rare exogenous causes of obesity, including genetic syndromes, endocrine disorders, and mental disorders. They should screen for complications of obesity, including hypertension, dyslipidemia, orthopedic disorders, sleep disorders, gallbladder disease, and insulin resistance. Medical conditions that warrant consultation with a pediatric obesity specialist include pseudotumor cerebri, obesity-related sleep disorders, orthopedic problems, massive obesity, and obesity in children under 2 years of age. Recommendations for treatment assessment included an assessment of the patient's and family's willingness to engage in a weight management program and a targeted assessment of diet and exercise habits. The primary goal of obesity therapy should be a healthy diet and activity. The use of weight maintenance versus weight loss to achieve weight goals depends on the patient's age, baseline BMI percentile, and the presence of medical complications. The committee recommended treatment that starts early, involves the family, and introduces gradual lasting changes. Parenting skills are the basis for a successful intervention that allows for gradual, targeted increases in activity and targeted reductions in high-fat, high-calorie foods. Ongoing family support after the initial weight management program will help families maintain their new behaviors. CONCLUSIONS: These recommendations provide practical guidelines for pediatricians evaluating and treating overweight children.

title: Observational study of telephone consultations by stroke professionals to support the delivery of plasminogen activators into community tissues
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Barriers to the intravenous (iv) use of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) in ischemic stroke are the limited treatment experience of general practitioners. Acute stroke care models have been developed to address these limitations by providing community support. This includes support by phone or televideo, with or without subsequent transport to tertiary care centers. The authors describe the incidence, characteristics, and impact of community telephone consultations at a 24/7 stroke "hotline" staffed by stroke physicians at an academic stroke center using such a model. METHODS: Twelve interventional hospitals participating in the Increasing Stroke Treatment through Interventional Behavior Change Tactics (INSTINCT) study were provided with a single-access number ("hotline") for expert advice on tPA use. The experts consisted of stroke-trained physicians from an academic medical center. The use of a hotline was not required by the study protocol, nor was patient transfer required. The consultants had to record all treatment questions in a web-based log. All patients referred via the hotline and/or treated with tPA at an INSTINCT hospital underwent a multi-level medical record review by trained care coordinators. Cases were linked to logged hotline calls based on time of treatment and first treating hospital. Physician assessors assessed the adequacy of tPA treatment, the presence of deviation from standard guidelines, and treatment complications (intracranial hemorrhage [ICH], systemic hemorrhage, or death). RESULTS: Over a 27-month period, there were a total of 204 hotline calls to 116 patients. Ninety-one percent of the calls were between 8 a.m. and midnight, and 77% of the questions addressed questions of eligibility for IV tPA, particularly for mild stroke or improving stroke (26%). A total of 243 patients were treated with iv tPA in the 12 intervention hospitals, 54 of whom used a hotline consultation. 76% of hotline patients for whom tPA was recommended actually received tPA, while 2% of those for whom tPA was not recommended received the drug. There were no differences in protocol deviations (27.8% hotline group vs. 23.8% non-hotline group), incidence of symptomatic ICH (5.6% vs. 7.3%), or in-hospital mortality (5.6% vs .13.2%). No medico-legal issues were reported in any case in the study. CONCLUSIONS: Providing tPA decision support via telephone consultation to office-based physicians is feasible and safe. Counselors may play a more important role in determining tPA non-eligibility than acceptability. Future work should include a real-time survey of physicians to identify such potential qualitative benefits of a stroke hotline.

title: Oncology Perspectives on Treatment of Rare Cancers: A Nationwide Survey
abstract: PURPOSE: In response to the challenges and difficulties of rare cancers, multi-stakeholder initiatives to improve the treatment of rare cancers were launched and several recommendations from professional societies were made. However, these primarily reflect the views of proponents and supporters and may not represent the views of the "average" clinician or researcher. In this study, we attempted to examine perceived difficulties related to treating rare cancers and possible solutions supported by oncologists. MATERIALS AND METHODS: A representative sample of 420 oncologists recruited from 13 cancer centers participated in a nationwide survey. RESULTS: Oncologists faced various difficulties when treating patients with rare cancers, including lack of clinical practice guidelines (65.7%) and personal experience (65.2%), lack of approved treatment options (39 .8%) and reimbursement issues (44.5%). . They generally supported recent recommendations from multi-stakeholder initiatives and professional societies to develop clear clinical practice guidelines (66.0%), flexible reimbursement policies (52.9%) and a national registry for rare cancers (47.4%) ). However, there was only moderate support for referrals to high-volume centers (35.5%) and promotion of off-label treatments (21.0%). CONCLUSION: Insights into the general attitudes of oncologists gained through our nationwide survey of representative samples would be helpful in developing clinical practices and public health policies in the treatment and research of rare cancers.

title: Implementation of the 5A model of brief smoking cessation intervention by oncology healthcare providers: patient perceptions
abstract: AIM: Health care providers (HCPs) can play an important role in promoting smoking cessation and preventing relapse. Public Health Service guidelines recommend the "5A" model of brief intervention. The aim of the current study was to examine perceptions of cancer patients regarding the implementation of the 5A model by their oncological HCPs. METHODS: This study enrolled 81 breast and 87 head and neck cancer patients at a large NCI-designated comprehensive cancer center. Patients completed questionnaires assessing their oncology HCPs' perception of their implementation of the 5A model of brief intervention. RESULTS: The results indicate partial implementation of the 5A model. The majority of patients reported that their caregivers asked about smoking and advised them to quit";" only half reported that their interest in quitting had been assessed, and few reported support for quitting or follow-up. Provision of the 5A was greater in patients who sought cessation advice from their HCPs. CONCLUSION: The current results suggest that adherence to 5A in oncology needs to be improved. PRACTICAL IMPLICATIONS: Efforts to improve the delivery of smoking cessation treatments by HCPs may improve smoking cessation rates in cancer patients and ultimately translate into better long-term cancer treatment outcomes.

title: One size fits all? Mixed methods evaluation of the impact of 100% single room accommodation on staff and patient experience, safety and costs
abstract: Background and objectives There is little clear evidence on the impact of single room placement on the quality and safety of healthcare. We examine the impact of all single rooms on staff and patient experience, safety outcomes and costs. Methods Mixed methods before/after “relocation” comparison within four nested case study wards in a single acute care hospital with 100% single rooms; Quasi-experimental before-and-after study with two control hospitals;" Analysis of capital and operational costs associated with single rooms. Results Two-thirds of patients expressed a preference for single rooms, in which comfort and control outweighed the disadvantages felt by some (feeling of isolation) Outweighed. Patients valued privacy, confidentiality, and flexibility for visitors who provide single rooms. Staff perceived improvements (patient comfort and confidentiality), but single rooms were inferior in terms of visibility, monitoring, teamwork, monitoring, and patient protection. The walkways of the Staff increased significantly after moving. A temporary increase in falls and medication errors on a ward was likely related to the need to adjust work patterns rather than to single rooms per se. We found no evidence that single rooms reduced infection rates. Building a one-room hospital can cost 5% more with higher housekeeping and cleaning costs, but the difference over time is marginal. Conclusions Employees had to make significant adjustments to their work practices and did not feel prepared for new ways of working that could have a significant impact on the way teams work in the longer term. Staff preference remained at a mix of single rooms and bays. Patients preferred single rooms.

title: One-year outcomes of surgical versus nonsurgical treatments for discogenic low back pain: a community-based prospective cohort study
abstract: BACKGROUND: The clinical entity discogenic low back pain remains controversial at a fundamental level, including its pathophysiology, diagnostic criteria, and optimal treatment. This is despite the availability of four randomized trials comparing the effectiveness of surgical and nonsurgical treatments. One study showed benefit for lumbar fusion compared to unstructured nonsurgical care, and three others showed roughly similar outcomes for lumbar surgery and structured rehabilitation. PURPOSE: To compare outcomes of community-based surgical and nonsurgical treatments for patients with chronic low back pain due to degeneration at one or two levels of the lumbar spine. DESIGN: Prospective observational cohort study. PATIENT SAMPLE: Patients presenting with axial back pain to orthopedic surgeons and neurosurgeons in academic and private practices in a large metropolitan area. OUTCOME MEASURES: Roland-Morris score for back disability (primary outcome), current assessment of total pain severity on a numeric scale, back and leg pain burden measures, the Short Form Questionnaire 36 version 2 physical function scale, use of medication for pain, work status, emergency room visits, hospitalization and other operations. METHODS: Patients who underwent spinal surgery within 6 months of admission were designated as the "surgical treatment" group and the remainder as the "nonsurgical treatment" group. Results were assessed at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months after enrollment. RESULTS: We recruited 495 patients with discogenic low back pain who presented for the initial surgical consultation in the offices of 16 surgeons. 86 patients (17%) underwent surgery within 6 months of study entry. Surgery consisted of instrumented fusion (79%), disc replacement (12%), laminectomy or discectomy (9%). Surgical patients reported greater pain and physical disability at baseline and were more likely to have had prior surgery. Adjusting for baseline differences between groups, surgery showed a limited benefit over nonsurgical treatment of 5.4 points on the modified (23 points) Roland disability questionnaire (primary outcome) 1 year after study enrollment . Using a composite definition of success that includes 30% improvement in Roland score, 30% improvement in pain, no use of opioid painkillers, and work (if relevant), the 1-year success rate was 33% for surgical procedures and 15% for for non-surgical treatment. The reoperation rate was 11% in the surgical group";" The post-treatment surgery rate in the non-surgical group was 6% at 12 months post-enrollment. CONCLUSIONS: The surgical group showed greater improvement compared to the non-surgical group at 1 year, although the combined success rate for both treatment groups was only fair. Results should be interpreted with caution as results are short-term and treatment was not randomly assigned. Only 5% of nonsurgical patients received cognitive behavioral therapy. The non-surgical treatment patients received varied and, for the most part, did not conform to key guidelines.

title: The continuous provision of individual clinical performance data improves practice behaviour
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines summarize findings from the scientific community and attempt to translate these findings into clinical practice. The ubiquitous and consistent adoption of these guidelines into the day-to-day practice of vendors has proven slow. METHODS: Using postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) prophylaxis guideline compliance as our metric, we compared the effects of continuing medical education (CME) alone (I), CME with a single snapshot of provider compliance (II) and the ongoing reporting of the provider's compliance data without further CME (III). We retrospectively analyzed the compliance of 23,279 anesthetic drugs at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center. Compliance was defined as a patient with 1 risk factor for PONV who received at least 1 antiemetic, 2 risk factors who received at least 2 antiemetics, and 3 risk factors who received at least 3 antiemetics. Drugs of the same class were counted as a single dose of antiemetics. Propofol-based anesthetic techniques were counted as 1 antiemetic. Patients with 0 risk factors for PONV were not included. We estimated compliance rates for each of the 4 study periods, adjusting for multiple observations at the same clinician. Individual performance feedback was given once 6 months after Intervention I concurrently with a refresher presentation on PONV (beginning of Intervention II) and on an ongoing quarterly basis during Intervention III. RESULTS: Compliance rates were not significantly affected with CME (Intervention I) compared to baseline (54.5% vs. 54.4%, P=0.9140). A significant improvement occurred during the period when CME was combined with performance data (Intervention II) compared to Intervention I (59.2% vs. 54.4%, P=0.0002). Another significant improvement occurred when data alone was presented (Intervention III) compared to Intervention II (65.1% vs. 59.2%, P<0.0001). In patients with 3 risk factors, we saw a significant improvement in compliance rates during Intervention III (P = 0.0002). In the post hoc analysis of overtreatment, the percentage differences between baseline and period III decreased as the number of risk factors increased. CONCLUSIONS: We observed the greatest improvement in compliance with continuous personal performance feedback. Provider feedback can be a powerful tool to change clinical practice, but it can have unforeseen consequences.

title: Online interventions for social marketing campaigns to change health behaviors: a meta-analysis of psychological architectures and adherence factors
abstract: BACKGROUND: Researchers and practitioners have developed numerous online interventions that encourage people to reduce their alcohol consumption, exercise more, and better control their weight. Motivations to develop eHealth interventions can be driven by the reach, interactivity, cost-effectiveness, and studies showing that online interventions work, of the Internet. However, when designing online interventions suitable for public campaigns, evidence-based guidelines are scarce, taxonomies are difficult to apply, many studies lack impact data, and previous meta-analyses are not applicable to large-scale public campaigns aimed at voluntary behavior change . OBJECTIVES: This meta-analysis evaluated design features of online interventions to inform the development of online campaigns, as employed by social marketers, that aim to encourage voluntary health behavior change. Another goal was to improve understanding of the relationships between intervention adherence, study adherence, and behavioral outcomes. Methods: Based on systematic review methods, a combination of 84 search terms in 5 bibliographic databases with additional gray literature searches was used. This resulted in 1271 abstracts and articles; 31 met the inclusion criteria. A total of 29 articles describing 30 interventions were included in the primary meta-analysis, with the 2 additional studies qualifying for the adherence analysis. The first analysis estimated the overall effect size, including groupings by control conditions and time factors. The second analysis assessed the impact of psychological design features, coded with taxonomies from evidence-based behavioral medicine, persuasive technology, and other areas of behavioral influence. These separate systems were integrated into a coding framework model called the communication-based influencer component model. Finally, the third analysis assessed the relationships between intervention compliance and behavioral outcomes. RESULTS: The overall effect of online interventions across all studies was small but statistically significant (standardized mean difference effect size d=0.19, 95% confidence interval [CI]=0.11-0.28, P<.001, number of interventions k=30). The greatest effect with moderate efficacy was achieved by online interventions compared to waitlists and placebo (d=0.28, 95% CI=0.17-0.39, P<0.001, k=18), followed by comparison with Low-tech online interventions (d=0.16, 95% CI=0.00-0.32, P=0.04, k=8);" no significant difference was found compared to sophisticated print interventions (d = -0.11, 95% CI = -0.34 to 0.12, P = 0.35, k = 4), although online interventions proved to offer a small effect with the advantage of lower cost and more time emerged as a critical factor, with shorter interventions generally having greater impact and higher adherence design, most interventions were transtheoretical and goal-oriented, employed multiple influencing components aimed at showing users the consequences of their behavior in helping them achieve their goals to support and exert normative pressure d effectiveness of the intervention. Despite a conflicting correlation, the evidence suggests that study adherence, intervention adherence, and behavioral outcomes are correlated. CONCLUSIONS: These results demonstrate that online interventions have the ability to influence voluntary behaviors such as those routinely targeted by social marketing campaigns. The high reach and low cost of online technologies can set the stage for increased public health campaigns that combine online people-to-people systems with mass media reach. Such a combination of approaches could help individuals achieve personal goals that help citizens improve their quality of life at the individual level and contribute to a healthier society at the state level.

title: Operational research as an implementation science: definitions, challenges and research priorities
abstract: Background Operational Research (OR) is the discipline of using models, either quantitative or qualitative, to support decision making on complex implementation problems. The methods of OR have been used in healthcare since the 1950s in various areas such as emergency medicine and the interface between acute and ambulatory care, hospital performance, planning and management of patient home visits, patient appointment planning, and many other complex implementation problems of an operational or logistical nature. Discussion So far, there has been limited debate about the role that operational research should play within implementation science. I describe three such roles for OR, all based on forward-thinking systems thinking: structuring implementation problems, prospectively evaluating improvement actions, and strategic reconfiguration. Case studies from mental health, emergency medicine, and stroke care are used to illustrate each role. I then describe the challenges for applied OR within implementation science at organizational, interventional, and disciplinary levels. Two key challenges are the difficulty in reaching a position of mutual understanding between implementation scientists and research users and a marked lack of evaluation of OR interventions. To address these challenges, I propose a research agenda to assess applied OR through the lens of implementation science, liberating OR from the specialized research and consulting environment, and co-creating models with service users. Summary Operational research is a mature discipline that has developed a significant body of methods to improve health services. OR offers implementation scientists the opportunity to think more upfront about the system before tying up resources or taking risks. OR has three roles within implementation science: structuring an implementation problem, prospective assessment of implementation problems, and a tool for strategic reconfiguration of healthcare services. Challenges facing OR as an implementation science include limited evidence and impact assessments, limited involvement of service users, lack of managerial awareness, effective communication between research users and OR modelers, and availability of health data. Advancing the science requires a focus on three key areas: evaluating OR interventions, embedding knowledge of OR in healthcare services, and educating OR modelers on the goals and benefits of engaging service users.

title: Opinion poll among physicians on ethical issues in medical research
abstract: total of 3622 physicians registered in the Association of Physicians of India were contacted via email and asked to answer a semi-structured questionnaire related to various aspects of medical ethics, with a particular focus on informed consent. 629 physicians (17.4%) answered the questionnaire: "86% of respondents indicated that they had no formal training in medical ethics;" 49% of subjects who conducted research received only verbal consent. The majority of respondents pointed to the relevance of ethics in various medical settings, although ethical issues were considered less important in specific areas such as public health and research involving animals. Patients' inability to attend regular follow-up and illiteracy were considered the main barriers to obtaining consent. Opinions about the amount of information to be imported to research participants as part of informed consent were at odds with standard guidelines. Physicians who reported taking an orientation course in medical ethics and those with prior research experience were more aware of ethical issues. The majority of professionals wanted ethics to be included in the medical curriculum.

title: Opportunistic Electronic Memories. Improving the performance of preventive care in general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Prevention plays an important role for general practitioners, yet prevention opportunities are often missed. METHOD: We provided an automated electronic record-reminder system for 12 preventive measures to a 10-physician practice. All participating patients were randomized according to the last digit of their case number. RESULTS: Control uptake of opportunistic prevention was low";" between 1.5% (tetanus vaccination) and 27% (influenza vaccination). In four of 12 activities (vaccinations against tetanus and pneumococci and recording allergies and weight), these increased significantly but slightly as a result of the reminders, in four (immunization against mumps, measles and rubella, recording smoking and taking cervical swabs) negligible and blood pressure) and negligibly reduced influenza immunization and screening for diabetes and hyperlipidemia. DISCUSSION: Opportunistic electronic reminders have the potential to improve prevention in general medicine.

title: Optimal adjustments to patient preferences for information, decision-making, and interpersonal behavior: Evidence, models, and interventions
abstract: AIM: A comprehensive review of theoretical and empirical work addressing preference match strategy in doctor-patient communication was conducted. METHODS: Up to 2004, searches were conducted in Medline, PsychINFO, InFoTrac One File Plus, Sociological Abstracts, and Dissertation Abstracts. The following keywords were used: patient-preferred and received information, patient-preferred and updated treatment decisions, patient-physician beliefs in shared decision-making; patient-physician match, fit or concordance; mutual relationship or reciprocity; Physician-patient affiliation, control, relationship;" agreement/fit between patient and physician in affiliation, control, or relationship. RESULTS: Results indicated varying degrees of support for the positive effects of adjusting patients' preferred levels of information, decision control, and des consultative interpersonal behavior CONCLUSIONS: The findings warrant not only continued but expanded research efforts in this area that would include recommended changes in research design and conduct PRACTICE AND RESEARCH IMPLICATIONS: Assessment strategies and matched interventions are discussed that, if the evidence remains supportive that physician-patient encounters could be routinely optimized toward more positive outcomes Methodological guidelines are suggested that could improve future preference-match studies of patient-physician interaction n. Practitioners need to consider the adoption of patient-match assessment and intervention strategies in addition to the recent exclusive focus on patient-centered and shared decision-making approaches.

title: Optimal treatment pattern in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
abstract: In healthy adults, there is an intimate relationship between the physiological processes of respiration and swallowing at all levels of neuromotor control and peripheral function. Little is known about the possible changes in these patterns in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), yet the impact of dysphagia and aspiration on the health outcomes of patients with COPD can be significant. COPD is a common comorbidity in patients with head and neck cancer and neurological disorders seen by swallowing physicians and requires consideration during swallowing management. This article summarizes reports of changes in nutritional status, airway defenses, and swallowing efficiency that may contribute to or exacerbate chronic and debilitating lung disease. To optimize the state of health of patients with COPD, care guidelines are given for modifying eating and swallowing behavior. The need for controlled clinical trials to validate the impact of these treatment guidelines on clinical outcomes is discussed.

title: Optimizing antiretroviral therapy (ART) for maternal and child health (MCH): Rationale and design of the MCH-ART study
abstract: BACKGROUND: The prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV faces major challenges worldwide, particularly in the context of universal, lifelong antiretroviral therapy (ART) for all HIV-infected pregnant women. METHODS: We describe the rationale and methods of the Maternal and Child Health-Antiretroviral Therapy (MCH-ART) study, a scientific implementation project investigating strategies for delivering HIV care and treatment to HIV-infected women receiving ART during Pregnancy and its HIV-exposed infants. RESULTS: MCH-ART consists of 3 related study designs over the prenatal and postnatal period. Phase 1 is a cross-sectional assessment of consecutive HIV-infected pregnant women seeking antenatal care; Phase 2 is an observational cohort of all women from Phase 1 who are eligible to start ART according to local guidelines, and Phase 3 is a randomized study of strategies to provide ART to lactating women from Phase 2 onwards during the postpartum period. During each phase, a series of study measurement visits will be conducted separately from antenatal care and ART services. From the beginning of the prenatal care until 12 months after the birth, there are a maximum of 9 visits. At the same time, questions of ART adherence and retention are qualitatively examined in in-depth interviews, and the costs and economic efficiency of care models are examined. Separate sub-studies examine health outcomes in non-HIV infected women and their non-HIV infected infants, and the role of the adherence club model in long-term adherence and retention. DISCUSSION: The MCH-ART study combines observational and experimental components and presents a novel approach to understanding and optimizing ART administration for MCH.

title: Optimizing hypertension management in clinical practice
abstract: There is a clear relationship between elevated blood pressure (BP) and various manifestations of cardiovascular disease. Despite the availability of numerous treatment guidelines, hypertension remains poorly controlled, with only a small proportion of patients achieving blood pressure goals. Many factors, both patient and physician related, contribute to this poor level of hypertension control. Key determinants include implementation of inappropriate treatment regimens that do not allow patients to achieve goal and poor patient compliance. For example, it is generally accepted that most patients require two or more antihypertensive drugs to reach their blood pressure goal";" However, physicians may be reluctant to use such treatment strategies. The aim of this review is to examine factors that contribute to poor hypertensive control rate and how these can be overcome, including reasons for selecting combination therapy, with particular reference to angiotensin II receptor blocker combinations.

title: Optimizing the treatment of hypertension with combination therapy: considerations for the caregiver
abstract: Hypertension is an important factor in the risk of cardiovascular disease and death, yet success in achieving blood pressure (BP) control has been limited. Most patients require 2 or more medications to control their blood pressure. Nurses play an important role in treating patients with hypertension and can help overcome obstacles to reaching blood pressure goals. Measures to improve adherence to therapy include educating the patient and simplifying the medication regimen. Use of single-pill combination therapy that reduces pill burden may contribute to improved medication persistence and compliance. Rational combination therapy combines drugs with complementary mechanisms of action, such as a calcium channel blocker (CCB) and a renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) inhibitor";" it is often more effective than monotherapy and allows the use of lower doses of each component, usually resulting in better tolerability. Current guidelines support the first-line use of combination therapy in many patients. Initiating therapy with a combination of RAAS inhibitors may reduce blood pressure and cardiovascular risk and may be more effective in some patients than traditional combinations such as B. a beta-blocker with a diuretic. Adverse events associated with a drug can compromise its therapeutic usefulness. Peripheral edema is a common and dose-dependent adverse reaction observed with dihydropyridine CCBs, which can cause significant patient distress, reduce adherence to therapy, and lead to dose reduction or even discontinuation of therapy. In most cases, CCB-induced peripheral edema can be successfully treated and CCB therapy does not have to be discontinued. Treatment strategies include non-pharmacological and pharmacological measures. Several clinical studies have shown a lower incidence of peripheral edema in patients receiving combination therapy with a CCB and a RAAS blocker compared to CCB monotherapy.

title: Oral contraceptives and smoking, current considerations: recommendations from a consensus panel
abstract: In a closed session, the members of the consensus panel evaluated the presentations of the scientific panel and developed a set of recommendations. They outlined clinical imperatives related to identifying and educating smoking patients, the physician's role in smoking cessation, and prescribing oral contraceptives to smoking patients. They also outlined research goals for the future. The main suggestions are: All patients should be asked about their smoking status at each visit, and all smokers should be encouraged and supported to quit. The decision to prescribe an oral contraceptive requires a detailed personal and family history of thrombotic disease. In smokers over 35 years of age who use or require oral contraceptives, measurement of lipid profiles should be considered in addition to exercise and dietary intervention. Patients > 35 years of age who smoke heavily (> 15 cigarettes/day) should be refused oral contraceptives. Preliminary data suggest that an oral contraceptive containing the very low dose of ethinyl estradiol 20 micrograms may be safer for oral contraceptive users who smoke, even for those over 35 years of age who smoke occasionally, but these laboratory results require clinical confirmation Confirmation."; " PIP: This article summarizes the activities of a conference in Montreal, Canada entitled "Oral Contraceptives and Smoking: Current Considerations". The members of the consensus panel evaluated the presentations of the scientific panel and developed a set of recommendations. The clinical imperatives in Regarding the identification and education of smoking patients, the role of physicians in smoking cessation and the prescribing of OCs for smokers were elaborated.The following recommendations were made: 1) encourage patients who smoke to quit smoking 2) patients advising on the benefits of OC; further advising patients on the risks of both smoking and taking OC at the same time;" and 3) prescribe 20 mcg of ethinyl estradiol for women who smoke. Given the remaining open questions, the panel outlined several research goals for the future .

title: Oral quinolones in hospitalized patients: an evaluation of a computer-assisted decision support intervention.
abstract: objective. To determine if a computerized decision support system could increase the proportion of oral quinolone antibiotics ordered by hospitalized patients. Design. Prospective discontinuous time series analysis. Setting. University Hospital in the Southeastern United States. Subjects. Quinolone orders placed for inpatients from February 1, 2001 to January 31, 2003. Intervention. A web-based intervention was deployed on February 5, 2002 as part of an existing order entry system at a university hospital. Based on an automated query of medication and diet orders, a suggestion was made to some users who ordered intravenous quinolones to consider choosing an oral formulation. main outcome measure. The proportion of inpatient quinolone orders for oral formulations before and after the use of the intervention. Results. There were a total of 15,194 quinolone orders during the study period, of which 8,962 (59%) were for oral dosage forms. Orders for oral quinolones increased from 4202 (56%) before the intervention to 4760 (62%) after, with no change in overall orders. In the time-series analysis, there was an overall increase in weekly oral quinolone prescriptions due to the intervention of 5.6% (95% CI 2.8-8.4%; P<0.001), with the greatest impact on non-ICU medical units . Conclusions. A web-based intervention increased oral quinolone prescriptions in hospitalized patients. This is one of the first studies to show a significant effect of computer-assisted intervention on the dosing route within an antibiotic class. This model could be applied to other antibiotics or other drug classes with good oral bioavailability.

title: Oral triptans (serotonin 5-HT1B/1D agonists) in acute migraine treatment: a meta-analysis of 53 studies
abstract: Background The triptans, selective serotonin 5-HT1B/1D agonists, are very effective drugs for acute migraine with a well developed scientific rationale. Seven different triptans will soon be clinically available, necessitating evidence-based selection guidelines. Triptan studies have a similar design, facilitating meta-analysis; this will provide a basis for the use of triptans in clinical practice. Seven different triptans will soon be clinically available, necessitating evidence-based selection guidelines. Triptan studies have a similar design, facilitating meta-analysis." This will provide a basis for the use of triptans in clinical practice.

title: Orbital/periorbital plexiform neurofibromas in children with neurofibromatosis type 1: multidisciplinary treatment recommendations
abstract: TOPIC: Children and adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a common autosomal dominant disease, present with a variety of ophthalmic disorders. Plexiform neurofibromas (PNs) affecting the eyelid, orbit, periorbital, and facial structures (orbital-periorbital plexiform neurofibroma [OPPN]) can cause significant vision loss in children. Equally important, OPPNs can cause a significant change in physical appearance due to proptosis, ptosis, and facial disfigurement, leading to social embarrassment and reduced self-esteem. CLINICAL RELEVANCE: Although NF1 is a relatively common condition that requires routine ophthalmological evaluation, there are no formal recommendations for the clinical management of children with OPPNs. Although medical and surgical interventions have been reported, there are no agreed criteria for when OPPNs require therapy and which treatment produces the best outcome. METHODS: Because a multidisciplinary team of specialists (oculofacial plastics, pediatric ophthalmology, neuroophthalmology, medical genetics, and neuro-oncology) guides managerial decisions, the lack of a consistent outcome measure representing visual or aesthetic outcomes complicates evidence design. based studies and feasible clinical studies. RESULTS: In September 2013, a multidisciplinary task force composed of pediatricians from tertiary care centers experienced in caring for children with OPPN was convened to address the lack of clinical management guidelines for children with OPPN. CONCLUSIONS: This consensus statement provides recommendations for ophthalmic surveillance, outlines treatment indications and upcoming biologic therapies, and discusses challenges in conducting clinical trials in this complicated disease.

title: Organization of surveillance in GI practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Several reports have documented inefficient use of available resources and suboptimal compliance with monitoring recommendations. Although evidence suggests that organizational issues can affect the quality of care provided, surveillance protocols are usually based on disorganized approaches. METHODS: We performed a literature search (publication date: 01/2000-06/2016) on PubMed and Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects and Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials for guidelines or consensus statements, such as surveys of practice , patient reporting, or provider attitudes and behaviors for intervention studies to improve compliance. Related articles were also scrutinized. Based on the clinical relevance and burden of endoscopy services, this review focused on surveillance for Barrett's esophagus, IBD, and surveillance for colonic adenomas after polypectomy. RESULTS: Existing guidelines generally recognize structural and process requirements that influence the implementation of surveillance interventions, while less attention has been paid to transitions and interfaces in the care process. Available evidence from real-world surveys suggests the need to develop organizational strategies aimed at enabling patients to participate and providers to provide timely and appropriate care. However, well-designed studies evaluating the effectiveness of specific interventions in this setting are lacking. Indirect evidence from screening settings suggests that implementing automated standardized recall systems, utilizing clinical registries, removing financial barriers could improve appropriateness of use and adherence to recommendations. CONCLUSIONS: The lack of solid evidence on the utility and methodology of surveillance may help explain the observed variability in provider and patient attitudes and adherence to recommended surveillance.

title: Organizational theory for dissemination and implementation research
abstract: Background Even under optimal internal organizational conditions, implementation can be undermined by changes in organizations' external environment, such as: B. fluctuations in funding, adjustments in contract practices, new technologies, new laws, changes in guidelines and recommendations for clinical practice, or other changes in the environment. Internal organizational conditions are increasingly reflected in implementation frameworks, but implementation research lacks differentiated explanations of how the external environment of organizations influences implementation success. Organizational theories offer implementation researchers a variety of existing, highly relevant, and hitherto largely unexplored explanations for the complex interactions between organizations and their environment. In this paper, we demonstrate the usefulness of organizational theories for implementation research. Discussion We applied four well-known organizational theories (institutional theory, transaction cost economics, contingency theories, and resource dependency theory) to published descriptions of efforts to implement SafeCare, an evidence-based practice to prevent child abuse and neglect. Transaction cost economics theory explained how frequent, uncertain contracting processes for SafeCare may have led to inefficiencies and thus hampered implementation by private child protection organizations. Institutional theory explained how child care systems may have been motivated to implement SafeCare because it aligned with the expectations of key stakeholders in child care system professional communities. Contingency theories explained how efforts such as inter-agency collaborative teams promoted SafeCare implementation by facilitating adaptation to the internal and external contexts of child protection agencies. Resource Dependency Theory (RDT) explained how interagency relationships, supported by contracts, memorandums of understanding, and negotiations, facilitated SafeCare implementation by balancing autonomy and dependence on funding agencies and SafeCare developers. Summary In addition to the retrospective application of organizational theories outlined above, we advocate the proactive use of organizational theories to design implementation research. For example, implementation strategies should be selected to minimize transaction costs, promote and maintain congruence between organizations' dynamic internal and external contexts over time, while attending to organizations' financial needs while preserving their autonomy. We describe implications of applying organizational theory in implementation research to implementation strategies, evaluation of implementation efforts, measurement, research design, theory and practice. We also provide implementation researchers with guidance on how to apply organizational theory.

title: Educating about osteoporosis prevention: behavioral theories and calcium intake
abstract: Osteoporosis is a global health problem. Preventing osteoporosis and subsequent fractures has become a goal of many medical professionals, particularly nutritionists. However, few prevention models have proven effective. The aim of this project was to determine whether an educational, theory-based osteoporosis prevention program would significantly affect calcium intake. This project used a sample of 42 women who participated in an 8-week educational activity similar to a community class. The program included hands-on self-efficacy activities and was based on the Health Belief Model and Theory of Reasoned Action (TRA). The main endpoints were calcium intake and constructs from the Health Belief Model and TRA. Significant changes in the Health Belief Model and TRA constructs after the intervention included an increased perceived susceptibility to osteoporosis (P<0.001), perceived benefits of increased calcium intake (P<0.001), and increased self-efficacy related to calcium intake (P < 0.001). /=.003). Statistically significant regression equations were found for all preintervention intentions related to calcium. Post-intervention calcium intake increased significantly to 821 +/- 372 mg/day (p<0.0001). The results of this project can be used as guidelines for nutrition professionals to develop osteoporosis prevention programs for their clients.

title: Outcomes and costs of primary care surveillance and intervention in overweight or obese children: the LEAP 2 randomized controlled trial
abstract: AIM To determine whether detection of childhood obesity through surveillance followed by structured secondary prevention in primary care improves outcomes in overweight or mildly obese children. DESIGN Randomized controlled trial embedded in a baseline cross-sectional body mass index (BMI) survey. Randomization and outcome measurement, but not participants, were blinded to group assignment. RECRUITMENT 45 general practitioner practices (66 general practitioners) in Melbourne, Australia. PARTICIPANTS 3,958 children who visited their general practitioner between May 2005 and July 2006 were asked about their BMI. Of these, 258 children aged 5 years 0 months to 10 years who were overweight or obese according to International Obesity Taskforce criteria were randomized to an intervention (n=139) or control (n=119) group. Children who were very obese (UK BMI z-score > or = 3.0) were excluded. INTERVENTION Four standard consultations over 12 weeks aimed at modification of diet, physical activity and sedentary lifestyle supported by specially designed family materials. Main Outcome Parameters The primary parameter was BMI 6 and 12 months after randomization. Secondary measures were the mean activity number/min after 7-day accelerometry, the nutrition score from a 4-day abbreviated food diary, and the child's health-related quality of life. Differences were adjusted for socioeconomic status, age, gender, and baseline BMI. RESULTS Of 781 eligible children, 258 (33%) participated in the study; the fluctuation was 3.1% after 6 months and 6.2% after 12 months. The adjusted mean differences (intervention - control) at 6 and 12 months for BMI were -0.12 (95% CI -0.40 to 0.15, P=0.4) and -0.11 (-0, 45 to 0.22, P=0.5); for physical activity in counts/min, 24 (-4 to 52, P=0.09) and 11 (-26 to 49, P=0.6);" and for nutritional score, 0.2 (-0.03 to 0.4, P=0.1) and 0.1 (-0.1 to 0.4, P=0.2).There was no evidence of harm to the child.The costs to the health care system were significant in the intervention arm CONCLUSIONS Primary care screening followed by brief counseling did not improve BMI, physical activity, or diet in overweight or slightly obese 5- to 10-year-olds, and it would be very costly if mainstreamed Results conflict with national policy in countries such as the US, UK and Australia TEST REGISTRATION ISRCTN 52511065 (www.isrctn.org).

title: Results of population-based language promotion for slow-speaking toddlers aged 2 and 3 years: Let's Learn Language Cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the benefits of a low-intensity language support program for parents and infants offered to infants identified as slow-speakers through universal service screening. DESIGN Cluster-randomized study embedded in a population-based survey. SETTINGS Three local governments in Melbourne, Australia. PARTICIPANTS Parents who participated in 12-month child health checks over a six-month period completed an initial questionnaire. At 18 months of age, children at or below the 20th percentile on an expressive vocabulary checklist participated in the study. INTERVENTION Maternal and child health centers (clusters) were randomly assigned to intervention (modified You Make a Difference program over six weekly sessions) or control (usual care) arms. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was Expressive Language (Preschool Language Scale-4) at 2 and 3 years; the secondary outcomes were receptive language at 2 and 3 years, vocabulary checklist raw score at 2 and 3 years, expression vocabulary test at 3 years, and Child Behavior Checklist/1.5-5 raw score at 2 and 3 years RESULTS 1217 parents concluded completed the baseline survey, 1138 (93.5%) completed the 18-month checklist, while 301 (26.4%) children achieved vocabulary from 1.5 to the 20th percentile and were randomized (158 interventions, 143 controls ) 115 (73%) intervention parents attended at least one session (mean 4.5 sessions) and most reported high satisfaction with the program Intermediate outcomes at age 2 were similar to those at age 3 the adjusted mean differences (intervention-control) -2.4 (95% confidence interval -6.2 to 1.4; p=0.21) for expressive language and -0.3 (-4.2 to 3.7; p=0.90). ) for receptive language; 4.1 (-2.3 to 10.6; P=0.21) for vocabulary checklist; -0.5 (-4.4 to 3.4; P=0.80) for Expressive Vocabulary Test; -0.1 (-1.6 to 1.4; P=0.86) for externalizing behavior problems; and -0.1 (-1.3 to 1.2; P=0.92) for internalized behavior problems. CONCLUSION This community-based program targeting speech-deficient young children was feasible and acceptable, but little evidence was found that it improved language or behavior either immediately or immediately by age 3. STUDY REGISTRATION Recent controlled trials ISRCTN20953675.

title: Overdiagnosis and overtreatment as a quality problem: insights from research to improve health care
Overweight and obesity in pregnancy: the evidence-practice gap in relation to staff knowledge, attitudes and practices
abstract: BACKGROUND: Statewide (Queensland) clinical guidelines reflecting current best practice have recently become available for the treatment of gestational obesity. However, the dissemination of guidelines alone does not change practice. OBJECTIVE: To systematically assess the evidence-practice gap in multidisciplinary management of overweight and obesity (ow/ob) in pregnancy to inform an intervention that facilitates the translation of obesity guidelines into practice in a tertiary maternity service. MATERIALS AND METHODS: An online survey, available over a three week period (May-June 2011), was distributed to obstetricians, midwives and allied health workers. Outcomes of interest included a 15-point guideline adherence score, knowledge of guideline content, advice given, knowledge of obesity-related pregnancy complications, prior training, and referral patterns. RESULTS: 84 employees completed the surveys (57% response rate). Widespread discrepancy with guideline was noted. The majority (88.1%) identified overweight/obesity (ow/ob) as an important/very important common obstetric problem, with most correctly identifying associated complications. However, only 32.1% of the existing guidelines were known, with only half correctly identifying the BMI categories for ow/ob. Adherence to referral recommendations varied";" 20% of employees considered the transfer to be “not their job”. CONCLUSIONS: Staff are aware of the negative consequences associated with maternal pregnancy, although few fully comply with referral guidelines or provide advice as recommended. These outcomes are categorized using scientific methodological frameworks, and effective behavior change interventions are constructed to facilitate the translation of this important guideline into practice.

title: Oxygen therapy in hospitalized patients: the impact of local policies
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To study the influence of local policies on the behavior of nursing and medical staff to optimize oxygen consumption in hospitalized patients.
