METHODS: The study was conducted in a district teaching hospital. Guidelines included suggested indications, monitoring, use of arterial blood gases (ABGs), and advice on when to stop oxygen therapy. The guidelines were implemented both verbally and in writing to all nursing and medical staff before and after an audit examining the oxygen consumption of patients on medical and surgical wards. RESULTS: Ninety patients were included in the pre-intervention audit and 59 in the post-intervention study. Oxygen prescription did not change with guidelines 30% (27/90) vs 32% (19/59). Nurses administered oxygen better 95% (18/19) vs 70% (19/27) (p=0.043) and monitored it more frequently with oximetry 91% (54/59) vs 69% (62/90) (p= 0.043). 0.001) according to the guidelines. In patients with respiratory disease, blood glucose levels were controlled more frequently 87% (14/16) vs 65% (15/23) on admission and after initiation of oxygen inhalation 68% (11/16) vs 34% (8/23) . CONCLUSION: The oral and written guidelines had no impact on oxygen prescribing but did improve the practice of closely monitoring patients with respiratory disease. The nurses improved their performance both in administering oxygen according to the prescribed dose and in monitoring with oximetry.

title: The postoperative pain management practices of pediatric nurses in hospitalized non-ICU settings: a narrative review
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To examine the postoperative pain management practices of pediatric nurses with the goal of identifying the factors associated with inadequately managed postoperative pain in children. DESIGN: Systematic search and review. DATA SOURCES: PsychInfo, CINAHL, PubMed, EMBASE and hand search. REVIEW METHODS: English peer-reviewed research articles on quantitative, qualitative, or blended methods published between 1990 and 2012 that examined the postoperative pain management practices of pediatric nurses were included. Articles that primarily focused on the pain management practices of nurses in the NICU or pediatric intensive care unit, the recovery room, and/or children with cognitive impairment were excluded. The search terms used were: "postoperative pain", nurses*; pediatrics; pediatrics; children; pain assessment; non-pharmaceutical*; analgesics*. Titles and abstracts were used for the initial screening. Two investigators each performed data extraction and rigor assessment RESULTS: Of the initial 248 citations, 27 studies were included. Most studies were descriptive, examining the relationships between personal factors and nurses' pain management practices. Observational data from four papers added insights beyond those provided in self-report studies. Two articles used experimental designs with vignettes. The data were categorized into four themes: pain assessment; pharmacological practices; non-pharmacological practices;" and factors influencing the practices. Despite improvements in analgesic administration over the past 20 years, practices remain suboptimal. Children's behavior appears to influence nurses' assessment of pain more than validated interventions. In a significant proportion of the children, no pain scores were recorded in the first 24 hours after the operation. Children receive more painkillers when ordered around the clock than when they need them. However, around-the-clock prescription of analgesics did not guarantee administration. Nurses reported routinely using several non-pharmacological strategies, but some are not evidence-based. CONCLUSIONS: The results of this review indicate that nurses' assessment and management of pain in children is inconsistent with published guidelines. The results of studies examining nursing and child-related factors are inconclusive. Research needs to examine the impact of organizational factors on nurses' pain management practices. Intervention studies are needed to identify the most effective strategies to support and improve caregivers' pain management of children.

title: Pain descriptors for critically ill patients unable to self-report
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To examine descriptors used by nurses in two Canadian ICUs to document the presence of pain in critically ill patients who are unable to self-report. BACKGROUND: Systematic documentation of pain assessment is essential for communication and continuity of pain management, allowing for better pain control, maximizing recovery, and reducing physical and psychological sequelae. METHOD: A retrospective, mixed-method observational design in two Level III ICUs of a quaternary academic center in Toronto, Canada. In 2008-2009, data were abstracted by chart review guided by a reference compendium of potential behavior descriptors assembled from existing behavioral pain assessment tools. RESULTS: A total of 679 narrative descriptions were extracted. Behavioral descriptors (232.34%), physiological descriptors (93.14%), and descriptors indicating that the patient was pain-free (117.17%) were used to describe the presence or absence of pain. Reports also described administration of analgesics without descriptors of pain assessment (117.17%) and assessment and administration of analgesics prior to a known painful procedure (30.4%). Emerging themes included life-threatening treatment disorders, decision uncertainty, and a wakefulness continuum. CONCLUSION: Inconsistent or ambiguous documentation was problematic in this sample. This can reflect confusing behaviors and associated security priorities. The development of a lexicon of pain assessment descriptors from critically ill patients unable to self-report for use, combined with valid and reliable measures, can improve documentation and facilitate appropriate pain medication management. Unit protocols or policies that prioritize an attempt at analgesia over the administration of sedatives may reduce decision uncertainty when patients exhibit ambiguous behaviors such as agitation or agitation.

title: pain in the ankle
Parallel ways to improve heart failure outcomes: Evidence matters
abstract: Gaps and inequalities in education about heart failure by caregivers and in the performance of patients with advanced heart failure in implementing self-care behaviors may be factors in clinical decompensation and unplanned health care utilization. Is nurse-led training conducted effectively prior to hospital discharge? Nurse leaders need to understand the strength of the nurses' knowledge base related to self-care principles and key barriers to best practice. Nurses may not feel comfortable teaching patients about dry weight, meal planning, heart failure medication, or progressive activity and movement steps. Additionally, clinical nurses may not have time to thoroughly educate patients prior to discharge. Equally important is research to identify factors that promote adherence to heart failure behaviors in patients, as adherence to the recommendations of national, evidence-based heart failure guidelines improves clinical outcomes. Therefore, caregivers and patients are on parallel paths to lay the foundation for improved adherence to self-care in advanced heart failure. Through research, we found that nurses were underprepared to be heart failure educators and that patients did not believe they were capable of controlling heart failure. In 2 educational intervention studies designed to teach patients that they could control their fluid management and maintain a strict daily fluid limit, patients showed improved clinical outcomes. Therefore, misconceptions about heart failure can be overcome with interventions that go beyond communicating “which” self-care behaviors are recommended. Research Shows Evidence Matters! Systems and processes are required to support the knowledge, convenience and frequency of caregivers in providing pre-discharge self-care training, increase the accuracy of patients' heart failure control beliefs, and increase patient desire to Adhere to guideline-recommended heart failure self-care behaviors. This article describes the development of the parallel paths of nursing and patient research programs and examines the translation of findings into practice and the development of clinical translational research.

title: Parental presence during invasive procedures and resuscitation: evaluating a change in clinical practice
abstract: Rationale: The presence of parents during invasive procedures and/or resuscitation is a relatively underdeveloped and controversial practice. Much of the concern stems from the concern of the medical community. OBJECTIVES: To assess whether the implementation of formal practice guidelines and appropriate interprofessional training would improve clinicians' sense of preparedness and comfort in providing parents with options during their children's procedures. METHODS: Multi-phase pre-post survey on (1) clinician perceptions and (2) practice from the perspectives of clinicians and parents experiencing the same procedure. Data were collected over a 4-year period from a cardiovascular and critical care program at a US children's hospital. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: More than 70% of the clinicians participated in the perception surveys (n = 782), and 538 clinicians and 274 parents participated in the practice surveys. After the procedure, physicians reported that parents were present for more invasive procedures and reported a greater level of comfort in the practice of offering parents options during CPR events. Comfort was higher for physicians who had practiced skills in a simulated learning environment. In both phases, few physicians reported that parental presence affected their technical performance (4%), therapeutic decision-making (5%), or ability to teach (9%). During the follow-up phase, clinicians reported more active parental behavior during the procedures. Parents who reported receiving information to help them prepare for their children's procedures reported higher levels of procedural understanding and emotional support. CONCLUSIONS: Implementation of practice guidelines and interprofessional education had a positive impact on clinician perceptions and practice in offering parents options and support during invasive procedures and/or resuscitation of their children.

title: Educational intervention in Sure Start services for children at risk of conduct disorder: pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effectiveness of an educational program as a preventive intervention in parents of preschool children who are considered at risk of developing a behavioral disorder. DESIGN Pragmatic randomized controlled trial using a block design with area allocation. SETTING Eleven Sure Start areas in North and Mid Wales. PARTICIPANTS 153 parents from disadvantaged areas with children aged 36 to 59 months at risk of having a conduct disorder as defined by a score above the clinical cut-off of the Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory. Participants were randomized on a 2:1 basis, 104 to intervention and 49 to remain on the waitlist (control). Twenty (13%) were not followed up six months later, 18 from the intervention group. INTERVENTION The Webster-Stratton Fundamental Educational Program Incredible Years, a 12-week group-based intervention. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Problem behavior in children and parenting skills as assessed by parental self-reports and by direct observation at home. Self-reported parenting skills, stress, and depression. Standardized and well-validated instruments were used throughout. RESULTS At follow-up, most measures of parenting and problem behavior in children showed significant improvement in the intervention group. Intention-to-treat analysis for the primary outcome measure, the Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory, showed a mean difference between groups of 4.4 points (95% confidence interval 2.0 to 6.9, P<0.001) on the problem scale with an effect size of 0.63, and a mean difference of 25.1 (14.9 to 35.2, P<0.001) on the intensity scale with an effect size of 0.89. CONCLUSION This community-based study demonstrated the effectiveness of an evidence-based parenting intervention reliably delivered by regular Sure Start staff. It has influenced policy in Wales and offers lessons for England where Sure Start programs have not been effective. TRIAL REGISTRATION ISRCTN46984318.

title: Parenting program for parents of children at risk of conduct disorder: cost-effectiveness analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To study the cost-effectiveness of an educational program. DESIGN An incremental cost-effectiveness analysis alongside a pragmatic, randomized, controlled trial of the effectiveness of a group parenting program implemented by Sure Start in the community. SETTING Sure Start areas in North and Mid Wales. PARTICIPANTS Parents of 116 children aged 36-59 months (87% of the clinical sample) at risk of developing behavioral disorders as defined by a score above the clinical cut-off of the Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory). Children were identified by health visitors and recruited by the research team. INTERVENTION The Webster-Stratton Incredible Years basic parenting program or a six month wait list check. KEY OUTCOME MEASURE Incremental cost per unit of improvement on the Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory Intensity Score. RESULTS The bootstrap point estimate for the incremental cost-effectiveness ratio was £73 (€109, $142) per point improvement in intensity score (95% confidence interval £42 to £140). It would cost 5,486 (8,190 euros, US$10,666) to bring the child with the highest intensity score below the clinical cutoff and 1,344 (2006 euros, US$2,618) to bring the average child in the intervention group within the nonclinical Bringing limits on the intensity value (below 127). With a cap of £100 ($194) per point increase in the intensity score, there is an 83.9% chance that the intervention will be cost-effective. The average cost per child attending the parent group was £1,934 (EUR 2,887, $3,760) for eight children and £1,289 (EUR 1,924, $2,506) for 12 children, including initial costs and materials for training group leaders. When we divided the sample into relatively mild, moderate, and severe behavior groups based on baseline intensity scores, the intervention appeared more cost-effective for those at highest risk of developing a behavioral disorder. CONCLUSION This parenting program improved the child's behavior, as measured by the intensity score of the Eyberg Child Behavior Inventory, at a relatively low cost and was cost-effective compared to wait-list control. This parenting program has a modest cost and shows strong clinical impact, suggesting it represents good value for public spending.

title: Parkinson's disease
Participant- and study-related characteristics predicting treatment completion and study duration in a study of adolescent smoking cessation.
abstract: Purpose: To determine what factors predict completion and maintenance of smoking cessation treatment in adolescents. Methods: In a multi-site, randomized, controlled study, the effectiveness of motivational interviewing with brief structured counseling for smoking cessation and reduction in adolescents (n = 355) aged 14-18 years (55% female, 45% black, 12% Hispanic) . Treatment lasted 12 weeks, with follow-up visits at 24 weeks. Treatment completion was defined as the completion of all five counseling sessions. Study retention was defined as the completion of the 24-week assessment. Participant and study variables served as predictors of treatment completion and retention. Results: Overall, 79% of participants completed all five counseling sessions and the same percentage completed the 24-week assessment. Black race, pre-consideration period for reduction, and shorter time between baseline assessment and first counseling session were significantly associated with completion of treatment. For every 7.5 day delay in starting treatment after the baseline visit, the likelihood of completing all five treatment sessions decreased by 50%. Retention at 24 weeks was predicted by black race, younger age, better maternal education, college degree expectations, and structured brief counseling intervention. Conclusions: High treatment completion and study retention rates can be achieved in a multi-session behavioral smoking cessation intervention in adolescents. The results suggest that treatment should begin soon after the intake session to maximize treatment completion. Increased efforts to retain older adolescents and youth with lower academic aspirations and lower family incomes will be important in future studies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Participation in biomedical research: The consent process from the perspective of children, adolescents, young adults and physicians
abstract: We examined the ability of children, adolescents, and young adults to consent and consent to participate in biomedical research, and what physicians and investigators believe is important for patients in these age groups to know about such participation. The sample included 44 male and female subjects aged 7 to 20 who were hospitalized for treatment for childhood cancer or obesity. Participants completed a structured interview that assessed knowledge of research participation using the elements outlined in the federal guidelines for informed consent. Study participants were best informed about those elements of consent that assessed specific information (e.g., freedom to ask questions, time elements involved, and benefits of participation). They were less well informed about the elements of informed consent that assessed abstract information (e.g., scientific vs. therapeutic purpose of the study and alternative treatments). Chronological age was not associated with knowledge of the elements of informed consent. The strategies study participants used to think about participating in the research seemed to parallel their thinking about other physical phenomena.

title: Children's participation in clinical trials: UK, European and international legal perspectives on consent
abstract: The Declaration of Helsinki was until recently the leading international code for the conduct of human clinical trials. The Council of Europe Convention on Human Rights and Biomedicine (1997) and the ICH Guidelines for Good Clinical Practice (1996) represent a significant step towards greater harmonization of standards in the conduct of medical experiments involving humans. But despite emerging areas of consensus, important ones remain Areas of ambiguity and divergence. Physicians involved in pediatric research in the UK are concerned about the lack of legal certainty, particularly in relation to the application of consent rules for emergency research. This paper examines UK, European and international norms on child participation in medical research and compares the circumstances in which consent rules can be waived under each normative regime.

title: Participatory action research in antimicrobial stewardship: a novel approach to improving antibiotic prescribing in hospitals and long-term care facilities
abstract: Changing the way physicians prescribe antimicrobials is a challenge. Although antimicrobial prescribing is determined by contextual (e.g., lack of guidelines), cultural (e.g., peer practice), and behavioral (e.g., perceived decision-making autonomy) factors, most antimicrobial stewardship programs do not consider these factors in their approach. This can lead to suboptimal effectiveness of the intervention. We present a new approach in antimicrobial stewardship program development that addresses relevant determinants of antimicrobial prescription: participatory action research (PAR). PAR is a collaborative process that aims to transform social situations by producing practical knowledge useful in local practice. It requires significant involvement of relevant stakeholders to address the determinants of the behavior being studied and to facilitate empowerment. PAR is well suited to complex problems in multidisciplinary settings as it adapts to local needs and provides a tailored approach to improve local practice. We describe how PAR can be applied to antimicrobial stewardship and describe the PAR design of two ongoing multicenter antimicrobial stewardship projects in acute care and long-term care, respectively.

title: Secondhand smoke exposure and risk of COPD among adults in China: the Guangzhou Biobank Cohort Study
abstract: Background Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a leading cause of death in China, where the population is also exposed to high levels of secondhand smoke, but little information is available on the impact of such exposure on COPD. We examined the association between secondhand smoke and COPD and respiratory symptoms in an adult Chinese population.";" Background Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a leading cause of death in China, where the population is also exposed to high levels of secondhand smoke, but little information is available on the impact of such exposure on COPD. We examined the association between secondhand smoke and COPD and respiratory symptoms in an adult Chinese population.

title: Pathology of Poverty: The need for quality improvement efforts to address social determinants of health
Patient compliance with primary care physician recommendations for breast cancer screening: a historical cohort study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Breast cancer is the most common malignancy among women in Israel, and routine screening is recommended for early detection. In 1997, a primary care center of a health management organization in rural Israel established a year-long program encouraging family doctors to remind their patients to get breast cancer screening. This study evaluates the impact of medical intervention on patient compliance. METHODS: Primary care physicians from two practices were asked to discuss the importance of early breast cancer detection with all eligible patients attending the clinic for any reason and to assist in scheduling an appointment for screening. The files of the patients who received the referral were stamped accordingly. Upon completion of the program, physician records were reviewed and potential breast cancer screening candidates were divided into two groups: those who had received the intervention (n=251) and those who had not received the intervention (n=187)”; The results were also compared to those of a third group of patients who had self-administered (ie, did not require intervention) prior to the study (n=100). A random sample of half the patients also completed an Ad -hoc questionnaire covering sociodemographic variables and the impact of medical intervention on their behavior.RESULTS: Patients in the intervention group showed significantly greater behavioral change related to breast cancer screening than controls (32% versus 13%, P=0.001). This change was particularly evident in the group of women aged 50-74 years who received the recommendation to have mammography (according to guidelines).CONCLUSION: Although this is a two-office study, the results suggest this that general practitioners significantly change the behavior of their patients with regard to regular breast examinations can change. The use of a specific reminder can also help the individual physician ensure that each patient has been properly instructed.

title: Patient representation and proactive care planning in the acute care hospital
abstract: AIM: The aim of this study was to explain the role of patient advocacy in the advance care planning (ACP-ing) process. Nurses rank the prolongation of the dying process through inappropriate interventions as their top ethical concern and are concerned about the protection of patients' rights (Johnston et al. 2002). Paradoxically, codes of ethics assume that nurses have autonomy to uphold patients' healthcare choices. Advance directives (AD) to improve end-of-life care are rarely adopted, and acute care hospitals are generally not geared to the few patients they receive. The Respecting Patient Choices Program (RPCP) improves AD usage by providing a supportive framework for ACP-ing and primarily equipping caregivers as RPC advisors. Assisting patients in this process requires qualities consistent with patient advocacy and stem from the most fundamental principle of nursing, caring for others. DESIGN: Likert-scale survey conducted before and six months after the intervention on pilot and control groups, with matched focus groups. SETTING: Selected wards at a public acute care hospital in South Australia. TOPICS: Nurses at the pilot palliative care, respiratory, renal and colorectal and haem-oncology, coronary, cardiology and neurology/geriatric control wards. INTERVENTION: The RPCP during the 2004-2005 South Australian Pilot Project (RPCP). KEY FINDINGS: The organizational support of ACP-ing gave nurses autonomy to be patient advocates regarding end-of-life care, align clinical practice with their code of ethics, and alleviate the stress of inappropriately prolonging the dying process. RESULTS: Statistically significant survey results in the post-intervention group indicated that caregivers are experienced in: "Encouragement to ensure patients can make informed decisions about their end-of-life care (84%)"; ability to maintain these desires in practice ( 73%); and job satisfaction from providing appropriate end-of-life care (67%)," compared to approximately half (42-55%) of respondents in the pre-intervention and control groups. Focus group participants reported that that patients used to be difficult to advocate for, but now they can act legally and feel ethically comfortable about subsequent end-of-life care CONCLUSION: The results suggest that patient advocacy, facilitated by the supportive RPC environment, effects the ACP-ing process It is recommended that the RPCP be used as an integral part of the funding of high-quality security at the end of life and the associated job satisfaction is recognized and developed.

title: Patient and physician reminders to promote colorectal cancer screening: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Screening reduces colorectal cancer mortality, but effective screening tests are still underutilized. Systematic patient and physician reminders could increase screening rates Methods We conducted a randomized controlled trial of patient and physician reminders in 11 ambulatory health centers. Participants included 21,860 patients aged 50 to 80 who were overdue for colorectal cancer screening and 110 general practitioners. Patients were randomly assigned to receive mailings that included an educational brochure, fecal occult blood testing kit, and instructions for direct scheduling of flexible sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy. Physicians were randomly assigned to receive electronic reminders during physician visits with patients whose screening was overdue. The primary outcome was receipt of a fecal occult blood test, flexible sigmoidoscopy, or colonoscopy for 15 months, and the secondary outcome was detection of colorectal adenomas. Results Screening rates were higher in patients who received mailings than in those who did not (44.0% vs. 38.1%; p<0.001). aged 60-69 and +10.1% aged 70-80 (p=0.01 for trend). 47). However, electronic reminders tended to increase screening rates in patients with 3 or more primary care visits (59.5% vs. 52.7%; P=0.07). P=0.10) and physician recall (6.0% vs. 4.9%; P=0.09). Conclusions E-mail reminders to patients are a powerful tool to promote colorectal cancer screening, and electronic reminders to physicians can increase screening among adults who attend primary care more frequently.

title: Patient education on the subject of coughing: Effects on the counseling behavior of family doctor patients
abstract: The aim of this general practitioner study was to investigate how the counseling behavior of patients with cough is affected when the tasks and responsibilities of patients, nurses and general practitioners are reorganized. The effects of a rational cough practice and a systematic cough education on the counseling behavior of the patients were compared with the patient behavior in four matched control practices in four “average” single-handed general practices. Behavioral changes were measured in 548 patients who consulted for cough at least twice in two consecutive autumn-winter periods. Significantly more patients in the experimental practice changed their behavior to follow practice guidelines than patients in the control practices (56% versus 30%, P<0.001). The proportion of patients who continued to consult in the approved manner was greater among patients who received an intervention (66% vs. 29%, P<0.001). This was equally true for patients who had fewer than four or more than four coughing attacks. The more often the patients received the information, the more effective it was. All patients who consulted the family doctor about cough in the first autumn-winter period filled out a cough diary in the second period. This showed that the intervention did not cause patients to delay consultation if they had a cough that lasted more than three weeks or a cough with "severe" symptoms. It appears that rational practice policies and the provision of patient education can encourage patients to change their counseling behavior. This could reduce healthcare costs.

title: Patient education for colorectal cancer screening: a randomized trial of a video sent prior to a physical exam
abstract: BACKGROUND: Colorectal cancer screening is underutilized and primary care physicians face challenges in providing patient education within the confines of busy practices. OBJECTIVE: To test the effect of an educational video sent to patients' homes prior to a physical exam on the performance of colorectal cancer screening, particularly sigmoidoscopy. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: 5 primary care practices in central Massachusetts. PARTICIPANTS: 938 patients aged 50 to 74 years scheduled for an upcoming physical examination, had no personal history of colorectal cancer and were eligible for lower endoscopy screening under current guidelines. INTERVENTION: Participants were randomly assigned to receive usual care (n=488) or a video about colorectal cancer, the importance of early detection, and screening options (n=450). MEASUREMENTS: Telephone baseline and 6-month follow-up evaluations were conducted. A dependent variable classified as screening since baseline was 1) sigmoidoscopy with or without other tests, 2) another test or combination of tests, or 3) no tests. RESULTS: The overall screening rates were the same in the intervention and control groups (55%). In regression modeling, intervention participants were not significantly more likely to perform sigmoidoscopy alone or in combination with another test (odds ratio, 1.22 [95% CI, 0.88 to 1.70]). The intervention dose (watching at least half of the video) was significantly associated with performing a sigmoidoscopy with or without further testing (odds ratio 2.81 [CI 1.85 to 4.26]). Recruitment records showed that at least 23% of those who presented for regular health assessments were currently being evaluated by a lower endoscopy procedure and were therefore ineligible. LIMITATIONS: The primary care sample studied consisted primarily of white, middle-class individuals who had high screening rates at baseline. The results may not generalize to other populations. The study was conducted at a time of increasing health insurance for lower endoscopy procedures and increasing media attention to colorectal cancer screening. CONCLUSIONS: Video sent by mail did not affect the overall rate of colorectal cancer screening and only slightly improved sigmoidoscopy screening rates in patients in primary care offices.

title: Patient engagement programs for the detection and initial treatment of depression in primary care
abstract: Significance Encouraging patients in primary care to address symptoms of depression and engage with physicians could improve outcomes, but may also result in unnecessary treatment. Aim To determine whether a depression engagement video (DEV) or customized interactive multimedia computer program (IMCP) improves initial depression treatment compared to a control group without increasing unnecessary antidepressant prescriptions. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Randomized clinical trial comparing DEV, IMCP, and control among 925 adult patients treated by 135 general practitioners (603 patients with depression and 322 patients without depression, as defined by Patient Health Questionnaire C9 [PHQ-9] score) ) conducted from June 2010 to March 2012 at 7 primary care clinical sites in California. Gender- and income-targeted interventions DEV, an IMCP tailored to individual patient characteristics, and a sleep hygiene video (control). Key outcomes and measurements Among depressed patients, assessment of the superiority of the composite measure of patient-reported antidepressant recommendation, mental health referral, or both (primary outcome)"; depression at 12 weeks of follow-up, as measured by the PHQ-8 (secondary Outcome). Among non-depressed patients, non-inferiority assessment of clinician- and patient-reported antidepressant recommendations (primary endpoints) with a non-inferiority margin of 3.5%. Analyzes were cluster-adjusted. Results Of the 925 eligible patients, 867 were included in the primary endpoint Analysis (depressed: 559; non-depressed: 308) to 8.9], p=0.79 IMCP vs. control 9.9 [95% CI, 1.6 to 18.2], p=0.02 ) There were no effects on the PHQ-8 measured depression score at 12 weeks of follow-up: DEV vs. control: 0.2 (95% CI, 1.2 to 0.8), IMCP vs. control: 0, 9 (95% KI, Δ0.1 to 1.9). In nondepressed patients, physician-reported antidepressant prescription in the DEV and IMCP groups was non-inferior to the control group (mean percentage point difference [PPD]: DEV vs. 0.0499 for non-inferiority, IMCP vs. control, 3rd .3 [90% CI, 9.1 to 2.4], P=0.02 for non-inferiority); Patient-reported antidepressant recommendation did not reach non-inferiority (mean PPD: DEV vs. control, ≥ 0.9 [90% CI, ≥ 4.9 to 6.7], P ≥ 0.23 for non-inferiority; IMCP vs. control, ≥ 0.3 [90% CI , ?5.1 to 5.7], P?=?.16 for non-inferiority) Conclusions and Relevance Tailored IMCP increased clinical recommendations for antidepressants, mental health referral, or both in depressed patients but had no effect on mental health at 12 weeks follow-up The possibility that IMCP and DEV increased patient-reported clinical recommendations for an antidepressant in non-depressed patients could not be ruled out.

title: Patient perceptions of risky drinking: knowledge of daily and weekly guidelines for low risks and standard drink sizes
abstract: BACKGROUND: An effective intervention for risky drinking requires clinicians and patients to be aware of the daily and weekly low-risk guidelines and what constitutes a “standard drink”. The authors hypothesized that most patients lack this knowledge and that education is needed. METHODS: After primary care visits, patients completed anonymous baseline questionnaires containing the 3 alcohol use detection test-use questions (AUDIT-C): "How many drinks (containing alcohol) can you safely drink in a day?" and questions to the size of a standard beverage of wine, beer and spirits in ounces. Descriptive analyzes were performed in Stata. RESULTS: Of 1,331 respondents (60% female, mean age: 49.6, SD = 17.5), 21% screened positive for risky drinking in the AUDIT-C. Only 10% of these low risk estimated daily limits accurate, 9% accurate to weekly limits and half of the low risk estimated limits at or below guidelines. Less than half who ticked 'yes' to 'Do you know what a 'standard drink' is? provided accurate answers for beer, wine or spirits. Patients who screened positive were twice as likely to say they knew what a standard drink is, but only a third gave accurate guesses. When asked about plans to change their drinking habits over the next month, 23% with a positive AUDIT-C said they were at least considering making a change. CONCLUSIONS: Most patients in primary care are unaware of the specifics of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA) guidelines for low-risk alcohol use. Examining patient perceptions of low-risk guidelines and current drinking behavior can reveal discrepancies worth discussing. For high-risk drinkers, most of whom are unfamiliar with daily and weekly low-risk guidelines or standard drink sizes, education can be critical when intervening. The results suggest the need for detailed and explicit social marketing and communication about what exactly safe drinking entails.

title: Patient safety research: a review of the global evidence
abstract: Background Unsafe medical care can result in significant morbidity and mortality worldwide, despite inaccurate estimates of the extent of the problem. To better understand the magnitude and nature of the problem of unsafe care, the WHO World Alliance for Patient Safety commissioned a review of the worldwide literature on patient safety research. Methods Important patient safety issues were identified through a consultative and investigative process and categorized within the framework of structure, process and outcomes of unsafe care. Leading experts examined current evidence and identified major knowledge gaps related to issues in developing, transition and developed countries. The report was reviewed by internal and external experts and improved based on the feedback. Results Twenty-three important patient safety issues were examined. Much of the evidence on the consequences of unsafe care comes from developed countries, where prevalence studies show that between 3% and 16% of hospitalized patients are harmed by medical care. Data from transition and developing countries also indicate considerable damage from medical care. However, significant knowledge gaps about the structural and procedural factors underlying insecure care worldwide make finding solutions difficult, especially in resource-poor settings. Interpretation Damage caused by medical care seems to impose a significant burden on the world's population. However, much of the evidence base comes from developed countries. Understanding the scope and solutions for unsafe care for the rest of the world is a critical component to delivering safe and effective care to all citizens of the world.

title: Patient Safety: The Physician's Perspective
abstract: Medical error can be defined as the failure of a planned action to complete as intended, or the use of an incorrect plan to achieve a goal. Aside from their economic and human cost, errors result in a loss of patient confidence in the healthcare system and reduced satisfaction for both patients and healthcare professionals. There are many evidence-based, safety-focused behaviors and interventions that are easy to implement, such as: In vascular access, the development of patient safety research has raised a variety of issues that need to be addressed in order to provide an optimal patient safety approach. Patients are key contributors to their own safety, and therefore physicians should develop a new approach to include them in the decision-making cycle at every step of their treatment. Along this path, there are many opportunities for the patient to engage in safety behaviors and for the access team to ensure such behaviors through the use of simple strategies. The advent of the access center based on multidisciplinary teamwork has increased the potential for improving patient safety by preventing errors in the planning and execution of access surgeries, avoiding delays in treating access disorders, and improving communication between team members. However, significant research efforts are still needed to implement an intervention through evidence-based data with a focus on patient safety.

title: Patient-carried card prompts versus computer-generated prompts to remind general practitioners to perform health maintenance procedures.
abstract: Background: We compared the effectiveness of a computer-generated notice placed on the front of the patient record versus a patient-carried notice card to remind physicians to perform selected health maintenance interventions. METHODS: A randomized, prospective, single-blind study was conducted in private practice in rural eastern North Carolina, involving 28 general practitioners and nine general internists. Twenty-two physicians were randomly assigned to the computer-prompted group and 22 to the card-prompted group. Four physicians in the computer group did not complete the study because of computer software problems, and three physicians did not complete the study because their limited staff was unable to enter patient data into the computer. Prior to the procedure, 20 patient records (10 males and 10 females) were reviewed by each physician for influenza vaccination history, stool occult blood count, pap smear, physician-performed breast exams, and mammograms. One year after the start of the intervention, the record reviews for the above five items were again performed on 20 different patient records for each physician. Results: There was a 7% increase in influenza vaccination performance in the card group (17% vs. 24%) compared to a 6% increase in the computer group (20% vs. 26%). There was a 5% decrease in occult blood stool performance in the card group (28% vs. 23%) compared to a 1% increase in the computer group (30% vs. 31%). Pap smear performance decreased by 11% in the card group (26% vs. 15%) compared to a 3% increase in the computer group (23% vs. 26%). Physician breast exam performance decreased by 2% in the card group (35% vs. 33%) compared to a 3% increase in the computer group (30% vs. 33%). Finally, there was a 3% increase in mammography performance in the card group (22% vs. 25%) compared to an 11% increase in the computer group (15% vs. 26%). Conclusions: Our data show a greater increase in the performance of health maintenance tasks in the computer-assisted group. The performance of stool for occult blood, Pap smear, medical breast exams, and mammograms was increased more in the computer-assisted group than in the card group. However, there was no statistically significant difference after the intervention for any of the tested health maintenance items, neither for the computer group nor for the map group. Overall, health-preserving measures were only carried out in a minority of suitable patients. (Arch Intern Med. 1994";"154:1957-1960)

title: Patients with gout adhere to curative treatment when adequately informed: proof-of-concept observational study
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Many physicians believe that patients with gout are unwilling to receive uric acid-lowering therapy (ULT) and blame it for poor adherence. AIM: To test the effectiveness of a complex intervention for gout that incorporates key elements of the current guidelines, including full patient information, delivered in an optimal setting (specialist clinic). METHOD: Observational study of patients reporting persistent gout attacks recruited from primary care lists. 106 participants (94 males, 12 females; mean age 61 years) were enrolled in the study. Patients received a predominantly nurse-led intervention that included education, individualized lifestyle counseling, and appropriate ULT. The predefined goal was to achieve serum uric acid (SUA) levels</=360 mumol/L at 1 year in at least 70% of participants. RESULTS: Of the 106 participants at baseline, 16% had tophi, the mean (SD) SUA level at baseline was 456 (98) micromol/L. All participants agreed to a shared aspiration to confirm gout and all wished to receive ULT. At 12 months, 92% of the 106 participants had achieved the therapeutic goal (SUA </=360 micromol);" 85% had SUA < 300 micromol/L. Allopurinol was the most commonly used ULT and required a mean dose of 400 mg daily, to achieve goal Improvements in Short Form-36 were observed at 1 year (significant for pain) CONCLUSION: A predominantly nurse-led intervention, including education, lifestyle counseling, and ULT, may be the recommended treatment goal in more than 9 out of 10 patients Elaborate explanations and discussions about the nature of gout and its treatment options, as well as the individualization of management, are likely responsible for this success.

title: Pearls, dangers, and pitfalls in the assessment and treatment of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder in adolescents
abstract: PURPOSE OF THE REVIEW: To provide clinicians with an updated overview of important considerations related to the clinical evaluation and management of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in adolescents. RECENT FINDINGS: The American Psychiatric Association's recently revised Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5 included significant changes in the diagnostic criteria for ADHD in adolescents. The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) also recently revised their Clinical Practice Guidelines for ADHD”; While previous guidelines focused on children aged 6-12, the new guidelines extend to 17 years of age. An understanding of these revised diagnostic criteria and clinical guidelines is essential for pediatricians and others caring for adolescents. In addition to an updated overview of the clinical approach to the assessment and treatment of ADHD in adolescents, current knowledge regarding common comorbidities, psychosocial risks and long-term outcomes are briefly described. SUMMARY: Diagnosing and treating adolescents with ADHD presents unique challenges and obstacles. Clinicians must use caution and judgment in evaluating a teenager with recent symptoms suggestive of ADHD, consider other conditions that might mimic ADHD, and common ones investigate comorbid diseases. Regarding the treatment of adolescents, the AAP recommends medication as the first-line intervention, noting that stimulants have a much broader evidence base and greater effect than non-stimulants. Although physicians today have a variety of drug formulations to choose from, they also need to be aware of the possibility of stimulant abuse and diversion.

title: Pediatric nurse managing child anxiety at a rural primary care clinic using the evidence-based COPE program
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Anxiety is the most common mental disorder in children. Many communities have a shortage of mental health providers, and the majority of children with anxiety are not receiving the evidence-based treatment they need. The purpose of this pilot study was to evaluate the feasibility and impact of a short, seven-session cognitive-behavioral-building intervention, Creating Opportunities for Personal Empowerment (COPE), delivered to anxious children by a pediatric nurse practitioner in a primary care setting . METHODS: A pre-experimental, one-group, pre-test, and post-test design was used. RESULTS: Children who participated had a significant decrease in anxiety symptoms (13.88 points, SD = 17.96, 95% confidence interval [CI] = -1.13-28.89) as well as an increase in cognitive-behavioural knowledge coping skills (M=11.38, CI=5.99-8.26, P=0.00) and improved functioning (at school and at home). Reviews from parents and children were positive. DISCUSSION: COPE is a promising, evidence-based intervention for children with anxiety of feasible delivery by pediatric nurses in primary care.

title: Peer support for patients with type 2 diabetes: cluster randomized controlled trial
abstract: AIM To test the effectiveness of peer support for patients with type 2 diabetes. DESIGN cluster randomized controlled. RECRUITMENT 20 GP practices in the east of the Republic of Ireland. PARTICIPANTS 395 patients (192 in the intervention group, 203 in the control group) and 29 peer supporters with type 2 diabetes. INTERVENTION All practices have introduced a standardized diabetes care system. The peer support intervention ran over a two-year period and included four elements: peer supporter recruitment and training, nine group meetings led by peer supporters in the participant's own primary care practice, and a peer retention plan -Supporters. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES HbA(1c)", cholesterol concentration, systolic blood pressure;" and feel-good factor. RESULTS There was no difference between intervention and control patients at baseline. All practices and 85% (337) of the patients were followed up. At the two-year follow-up, there were no significant differences in HbA(1c) (mean difference -0.08%, 95% confidence interval -0.35% to 0.18%), systolic blood pressure (-3.9 mm Hg , -8.9 to 1.1 mm). Hg), total cholesterol concentration (-0.03 mmol/L, -0.28 to 0.22 mmol/L) or well-being (-0.7, -2.3 to 0.8). While at follow-up there was a trend towards decreases in the proportion of patients with poorly controlled risk factors, particularly for systolic blood pressure (52% (87/166) > 130 mmHg at intervention vs. 61% (103/169) > 130 mm Hg in the control), these changes were not significant. The process evaluation showed that the intervention was generally delivered as intended, although 18% (35) of the patients in the intervention group never attended group meetings. CONCLUSIONS A group-based peer support intervention is feasible in general practice, but the intervention was not effective when targeted to all patients with type 2 diabetes. While there has been a trend towards improving clinical outcomes, the results do not support the widespread adoption of peer support. Study registration Current controlled studies ISRCTN42541690.

title: Perception and performance of function and physical activity in assisted living communities
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this study was to describe residents' self-efficacy and outcome expectations in relation to function and physical activity (PA), measure functional performance and time in PA, assess the fit between the resident and the environment ; and to assess the knowledge, beliefs, and nursing behaviors of nursing assistants (NAs) in 4 different assisted living (AL) communities DESIGN: This was a descriptive study using baseline data from an ongoing intervention study, Testing the Impact of a Function Focused Care Intervention, Res-Care-AL SETTING: Four assisted living communities in Maryland PARTICIPANTS: A total of 171 residents and 96 NAs consented, passed eligibility, and were enrolled in this study MEASUREMENTS: Descriptive data were obtained from NAs and residents. Resident data also included self-efficacy and outcome expectations related to functional tasks and exercise, social support for exercise, and subjective and objective information about functioning and physical activity. The NA data included self-efficacy and outcome expectations, knowledge, and performance of functional nursing. RESULTS: Residents were predominantly female, white, and widowed; needed support in activities of daily living; and dealt with very little PA based on subjective and objective reports. NAs were predominantly female and black, had more than a decade of nursing experience, had strong self-confidence but limited knowledge of function-based nursing, and performed that nursing in 76% of the observed nursing interactions. There were no site-specific differences between NAs in beliefs, knowledge, or implementation of function-based care. Location-specific differences in the residents were shown with regard to self-efficacy for functioning; functional performance; social support for movement from experts;" and from family, person-environment fit, and PA, based on subjective surveys. No differences were found, based on actigraphy Locations could benefit from ongoing education on how to increase PA among residents and help them comply with current PA guidelines to optimize overall health.

title: Performance of the TREAT decision support system in an environment with low prevalence of resistant pathogens.
abstract: Objectives To evaluate a decision support system (TREAT) to guide empiric antimicrobial therapy in an environment with low prevalence of resistant pathogens. Methods A retrospective study of TREAT was conducted at the University of Copenhagen, Hvidovre Hospital. The patient cohort included adults with systemic inflammation and suspected community-acquired bacterial infection. The empiric antimicrobial treatment recommended by TREAT was compared to the empiric antimicrobial treatment prescribed by the first attending clinical physician. Results Of 171 recruited patients, 161 (65 with microbiologically documented infections) met the TREAT inclusion criteria. The coverage achieved by TREAT was significantly higher than that achieved by clinical practice (86% versus 66%, P=0.007). There was no significant difference in the cost of future resistance between the treatments chosen by TREAT and those chosen by the physicians. Direct expenditure on antimicrobials was higher in TREAT when patients without antimicrobial treatment were included, while there was no significant difference otherwise. The side effect costs were significantly lower with TREAT. Conclusions The results of the study suggest that TREAT can improve the adequacy of antimicrobial therapy and reduce adverse event costs in regions with low prevalence of resistant pathogens, albeit at the expense of increased antibiotic use.

title: Perioperative care map improves adherence to best practices for morbidly obese people
abstract: BACKGROUND: Morbid obesity can complicate perioperative management. Best practice guidelines have been published but are typically only followed in bariatric patients. Little is known about the awareness of and adherence to these clinical recommendations by non-bariatric surgeons. Our study examined whether an educational effort could improve physician acceptance and adherence to established best practices for all surgically treated patients with morbid obesity. METHODS: In 2013, a best practice care card for morbidly obese patients was distributed to all surgeons and anesthesiologists in 4 teaching hospitals. In 2012 and 2015, pre- and post-intervention surveys were sent to participants to assess changes in clinical practice. A post-intervention chart audit determined physician adherence to distributed guidelines. RESULTS: In the study, 567 physicians completed the survey in 2012 and 375 physicians completed the survey in 2015. After the intervention, statistically significant improvements were seen in the percentage of surgeons and anesthesiologists combined who reported changing their management of morbidly obese patients undergoing surgery Adherence to best practices preoperatively (89% vs. 59%), intraoperatively (71% vs 54%), postoperatively (80% vs. 57%) and overall (88% vs. 72%). Results were similar when surgeons and anesthesiologists were analyzed separately. A chart review of 170 cases from the 4 hospitals revealed that 167 (98%) cases met best practices. CONCLUSION: After distribution of the treatment cards, the percentage of physicians reporting that they had changed their management to conform to best practices improved significantly. These results underscore the positive impact that this educational activity can have on physician behavior. Further research is needed to assess the impact of this intervention on clinical outcomes.

title: Perioperative β-blockers in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery: a meta-analysis
abstract: Background The American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) guidelines for perioperative assessment recommend perioperative ? Blockers for non-cardiac surgery, although the results of some clinical trials do not appear to support this recommendation. Our aim was to critically review the evidence to support the use of perioperative ? Blockers in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery.";" Background The American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) guidelines for perioperative assessment recommend perioperative ? Blockers for non-cardiac surgery, although the results of some clinical trials do not appear to support this recommendation. Our aim was to critically review the evidence to support the use of perioperative ? Blockers in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery.

title: Person-centered primary care strategies for assessment and intervention for aggressive behavior in dementia
abstract: With the increasing number of people affected by dementia, it is imperative for healthcare providers to be familiar with the most effective methods of treating neuropsychiatric symptoms such as aggression. Aggression can be particularly difficult to manage because it poses a risk of harm to formal and informal caregivers, and the options for medical intervention are complex and situational. Although several guidelines for anger management in dementia are available in the literature, their scope is widespread and proposed treatments often vary, making decision-making difficult for busy clinicians. Using a composite case as a model, the current article provides guidelines that guide outpatient providers through the steps needed to provide effective treatment for aggression in people with dementia. Shifting the current focus of care for patients with aggressive dementia towards a more person-centred approach will have a positive impact on patient care. [Journal of Gerontological Nursing, 43(2), 9-17.].

title: Pharmaceutical care in chronic kidney disease: experience at the University Hospital Grenoble from 2006 to 2010
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical pharmacists (CPs) specifically manage follow-up of laboratory tests, adjust drug dosing according to guidelines, and assess cardiovascular risk factors and deterioration in renal function. The aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of clinical-pharmaceutical services in outpatient renal clinics. METHOD: Medical history and current treatment were recorded for each patient. Each intervention has been classified according to the Act-IP document of the French Society of Clinical Pharmacy. This tool provides identifications and guidelines for preventing and resolving drug-related problems (DRPs). RESULTS: From January 2008 to April 2009, 42 patients who saw the CP on at least 2 visits were enrolled in the study. We observed 350 pharmaceutical consultations and 263 interventions. Affected pharmaceutical interventions: untreated indication (30%), underdosing (25.9%) and overdosing (18.3%). The CP interventions consisted of: adjusting doses (42.2%) and adding treatments (31.9%). The major drugs involved were related to the cardiovascular (33.1%), digestive-metabolic (28.6%), and hematopoietic (21.6%) systems. CONCLUSION: The inclusion of a CP in the management of patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is necessary for the identification and prevention of DRPs. In addition to the medical improvement of CKD patients, the CP is involved in the development of prescription recommendations and therapeutic education programs for patients. In addition, redefining the roles and practices of clinical team members has proven their effectiveness in optimizing the care of CKD patients. In addition, patients' entry into dialysis is being postponed, leading to a reduction in health insurance costs.

title: Pharmacoeconomic implications of measuring and modifying hospital drug use
abstract: Patterns of drug use impact hospital-based health care in a variety of ways. Adverse drug reactions (ADRs) account for about 5% of admissions and compromise care for about 20% of hospitalized patients, while inadequate drug therapy compromises outcomes and prolongs hospital stays. Conversely, the appropriate use of medication can promote recovery and increase the quality of care. Well-documented examples include the prevention of deep vein thrombosis and postoperative wound infections. Accordingly, the optimization of drug consumption represents an important quality assurance issue alongside determining the cost-effectiveness of healthcare. Drug Utilization Review (DUR) requires all elements of the quality assurance process. In practice, therapeutically meaningful and cost-effective exercises can only be carried out if the relationship between drug use patterns and clinical outcomes is known. These measurement methods are currently speed-determining in quality assurance. There are several ways in which hospital drug use can be measured. These range from readily available and relatively cheap quantitative methods to methods that require the availability of skilled personnel. There is a succession of processes that involve increasing costs and increasing resource requirements, resulting in more and more detailed information being obtained. This sequence begins with pharmacy purchases, followed by pharmacy issues related to specific clinical areas, prescription or treatment sheet review, clinical record review, and finally the reports of trained investigators working in the clinical area. The simpler methods can provide useful information and an efficient basis for selecting and planning definitive studies. Once a category of drug use is appropriately earmarked for intervention, drug use can be modified through planned intervention with improvement in clinical outcomes and reduced economic costs in many cases. The intervention strategies for modifying drug use can be classified as re-education, persuasion, facilitation, and power strategies. Other models for implementing behavior change were considered, including the impact of trained investigators and the use of online computer prescribing with interactive software with appropriate guidelines. The challenge is to achieve sustainable change when interventions are implemented. Cost-effective quality assurance of drug use is possible with modest resources if impact-oriented measures are prioritized.

title: Pharmacological treatment of insomnia: An evidence review for a clinical practice guideline from the American College of Physicians
abstract: Background: Pharmacological interventions are often prescribed for sleep disorders. Purpose: To evaluate the benefits, harms, and comparative efficacy of pharmacological treatments for adults with insomnia. Data sources: Multiple electronic databases (2004–September 2015), reference lists and US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) documents. Study selection: 35 randomized controlled trials of at least 4 weeks duration evaluating pharmacotherapies available in the United States and reporting effects on population or sleep; 11 long-term observational studies reporting harm information; FDA review data for non-benzodiazepine hypnotics and orexin receptor antagonists and product labels for all drugs Data Extraction: Data extraction by a single investigator, endorsed by a second reviewer, assessment of risk of bias by two investigators, consensus determination of weight of evidence Data synthesis: eszopiclone, zolpidem and Suvorexant improved short-term overall and sleep outcomes compared to placebo, although absolute effect sizes were small (low-to-moderate-strength evidence) Evidence for benzodiazepine hypnotics, melatonin agonists, and antidepressants, and for most pharmacologic interventions in older adults was insufficient or low strength. Evidence was also insufficient to compare efficacy within or between pH armacotherapy classes or versus behavioral therapy. The evidence of adverse effects reported in the studies was assessed as insufficient or low.” Observational studies suggested that use of hypnotics for insomnia was associated with an increased risk of dementia, fractures, and serious injury. The FDA documents reported that most pharmacotherapies presented risks for cognitive and behavioral changes, including impaired driving and other side effects, and recommended dose reductions in women and older adults. Limitations: Most studies were small and short-lived, and accepted People who met strict criteria participated. Minimum significant differences in outcomes were often not found or reported. Few data were available for many treatments. Conclusion: Eszopiclone, zolpidem, and suvorexant may improve short-term overall and sleep outcomes in adults with insomnia, but comparative efficacy and long-term efficacy of pharmacotherapies for insomnia are unknown Related are d with rare but serious damage. Primary source of funding: Health Research and Quality Agency. (PROSPERO: CRD42014009908)

title: Pharmacologic treatment of low bone density or osteoporosis to prevent fractures: A clinical practice guideline from the American College of Physicians
abstract: Description: The American College of Physicians (ACP) developed this guideline to present the available evidence on various pharmacologic treatments to prevent fractures in men and women with low bone density or osteoporosis. METHODS: Published literature on this topic was reviewed using MEDLINE (1966 to December 2006), the ACP Journal Club database, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (without date limitation), the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (without date limitation), websites of the United Kingdom National Institute of Health and Clinical Excellence (without date limitation) and the United Kingdom Health Technology Assessment Program (January 1998 to December 2006). The search was limited to English-language publications and human studies. Search keywords included terms for osteoporosis, osteopenia, low bone mineral density, and the drugs listed in the key questions. This guideline assesses the evidence and recommendations according to the ACP clinical practice guidelines assessment system. Recommendation 1: ACP recommends that physicians offer pharmacologic treatment to men and women with known osteoporosis and those who have sustained fragility fractures (Grade: Strong Recommendation”; high-quality evidence). Recommendation 2: ACP recommends that physicians consider pharmacologic treatment Men and women at risk for developing osteoporosis (Grade: weak recommendation; moderate-quality evidence) Recommendation 3: ACP recommends that clinicians Benefit assessment of choosing between pharmacological treatment options for osteoporosis in men and women in individual patients (grade: strong recommendation; moderate-quality evidence). Recommendation 4: ACP recommends further research to evaluate the treatment of osteoporosis in both men and women.

title: Pharmacological treatment of neuropsychiatric disorders
abstract: Emotional and cognitive symptoms such as depression, mania, mood and affect lability, psychosis, impaired arousal, anxiety, and irritability and aggression are common in neurological disorders. These neuropsychiatric syndromes significantly impair functioning and rehabilitation efforts. Patients with brain damage are particularly sensitive to the side effects of medication. When appropriate guidelines are followed, psychopharmacological intervention relieves these symptoms, improves rehabilitation, and avoids impairment of arousal and cognition.

title: Pharmacologic treatment of bipolar disorder in children and adolescents
abstract: It is increasingly recognized that bipolar disorder often first appears in adolescence. Preadolescents with volatile behavior and severe mood swings also represent a large group of patients whose difficulties may lie on the bipolar spectrum. However, the majority of scientific effort and clinical trials for this condition are focused on adults. This overview summarizes the complexity of bipolar disorder and the diagnosis of the disease in young people. It then reviews the principles of pharmacotherapy, assesses current treatment options, and highlights areas where evidence-based guidelines are lacking. Recent developments have expanded the range of possible treatments for bipolar disorder. Nevertheless, differences in the phenomenology, course and consequences of bipolar disorder in young people force greater attention to the benefits and risks of therapy for those affected by the early onset of this disease. By summarizing current research and opinions on diagnostic issues and treatment approaches, this review aims to provide an update on a clinically important but controversial topic.

title: Pharmacotherapy of social anxiety disorder at the turn of the millennium
abstract: In the last 21 years, since SP was included in the diagnostic nomenclature, there has been a significant increase in knowledge about effective pharmacological and psychotherapeutic treatments. The SSRIs have emerged as the first-line pharmacological treatments, although good evidence supports the efficacy of benzodiazepines”; MAOIs;” and anticonvulsants, such as gabapentin and pregabalin. There is also evidence for the effectiveness of the novel antidepressant venlafaxine and also optimism about the potential benefit of nefazodone and possibly bupropion. However, there are many areas that require further investigation. The publication of the RUPP anxiety study demonstrating the effectiveness of fluvoxamine in socially phobic adolescents has attracted a lot of attention. Given that SP begins in childhood and adolescence, more data are needed to support the use of pharmacotherapy in this age group, as early intervention can prevent the consequences of chronic SP. More research needs to be done on what is required for socially phobic individuals who achieve a good response to pharmacotherapy to progress to complete remission status. Additional research is needed to assess the comparative efficacy of different drug classes and to develop an improved ability to predict treatment response to a particular type of treatment. In addition, further research on treatment resistance is needed. For most anxiety disorders studied, the combination of CBT with a psychopharmacological treatment has shown little benefit over either treatment alone. These results may be due to methodological problems. Research needs to be done into how treatments can be sequenced to maximize the benefits of combining the two types of effective treatments. Finally, many clinicians are seeing an emerging trend of individuals who have had untreated SP their whole lives and are now presenting for treatment in their "golden years." The currently established treatments need to be further evaluated in this geriatric population.

title: Pharmacy Asthma Care Program (PACP) improves patient outcomes in the community.
abstract: Background: Despite national disease management plans, optimal asthma management in Australia remains a challenge. Community pharmacists are ideally placed to implement new strategies aimed at ensuring asthma care meets current standards of best practice. The impact of the Pharmacy Asthma Care Program (PACP) on asthma control was evaluated using a multisite, randomized intervention study design versus a repeated measures control study. METHODS: Fifty Australian pharmacies were randomized into two groups: intervention pharmacies introduced PACP (an ongoing cycle of assessment, goal setting, monitoring and review) to 191 patients over 6 months, while control pharmacies provided usual care to 205 control patients. Both groups completed questionnaires and performed spirometric tests at baseline and 6 months later. The main endpoint was asthma severity/control status. Results: 186 of 205 control patients (91%) and 165 of 191 intervention patients (86%) completed the study. The intervention resulted in improved asthma control: patients receiving the intervention were 2.7 times more likely to improve from severe to not severe than control patients (OR 2.68, 95% CI 1.64 to 4 .37; p<0.001). The intervention also resulted in improved adherence to therapy (OR 1.89, 95% CI 1.08 to 3.30; p?=?0.03), a reduced mean daily dose of reliever medication (difference -149.11 µg, 95 % CI -283.87 to -14.36; p?=?0.03), a shift in the medication profile from reliever therapy alone to a combination of prevention, reliever therapy with or without a long-acting beta-agonist (OR 3.80, 95 % CI 1.40 to 10.32; p?=?0.01) and improved risk of non-compliance scores (difference -0.44, 95% CI -0.69 to -0.18; p?=?0 .04), quality of life (difference -0.23, 95% CI -0.46 to 0.00; p?=?0.05), knowledge of asthma (difference 1.18, 95% CI 0.73 to 1.63 ; p<0.01) and perceived control over asthma questionnaires (difference -1.39, 95% CI -2.44 to -0.35; p<0.01). There was no significant change in spirometric measurements in either group. Conclusions: A pharmacist-provided asthma care program based on national guidelines improves asthma control. The sustainability and implementation of the program within the healthcare system has yet to be explored.

title: Physical activity on prescription (PAP) from a general practitioner perspective - a qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Prescription physical activity (PAP) is a successful intervention to increase physical activity in patients with sedentary lifestyles. The method appears to be little used by General Practitioners (GPs) and there is limited information on GPs hiring to consult using PAP as a tool. The aim of the study was to explore and understand the importance of prescribing physical activity from the general practitioner's point of view. METHODS: Three focus group interviews were conducted with a targeted sample of 15 Swedish general practitioners in southern Sweden. Participants were invited to share their experiences of using PAP. The interviews were transcribed verbatim and analyzed using qualitative content analysis. RESULTS: The analysis identified four categories: Tradition makes it difficult to change attitudes, Shared responsibility is needed, PAP has low status and is viewed with suspicion, and Lack of procedures and clear policies. Traditionally, GPs talk to patients about the importance of increased physical activity, but do not prescribe physical activity as a treatment. Medical training focuses on the use of medicines. Responsibility for patients' physical activity levels is shared with other healthcare professionals, patients and society. General practitioners express reservations about prescribing physical activity. A heavy workload is a source of frustration. PAP is viewed with suspicion and seen as a task of lower value and status. Using a prescription to highlight an elevated level is considered redundant, and GPs feel it should be administered by someone else in the healthcare system. Skepticism about the result of the method was also expressed. CONCLUSIONS: There is uncertainty regarding the use of PAP as a treatment due to the physicians' lack of training in non-pharmaceutical methods. GPs do not see the written referral as a priority and rather refer to other professionals in the healthcare system to prescribe the PAP. The GPs pointed out the need to establish routines and precautions in order for the method to gain credibility and become common practice among GPs.

title: Physician counseling for adolescents on smoking: who is counseled and who benefits most?
abstract: PURPOSE: The Clinical Practice Guidelines direct physicians to ask their patients about smoking and to discourage tobacco use. Physicians are urged to pay particular attention to ethnic minorities and youth, as these groups are at increased susceptibility to smoking. Research into race and medical advice against smoking have produced conflicting results. The aim of this study is to clarify the relationships between physician communication about tobacco, race and smoking among adolescents. METHODS: This retrospective, cross-sectional study examined (1) racial differences in rates of physician communication and (2) whether the relationship between physician communication and smoking among adolescents was moderated by race. Multiple measures of smoking status were used (e.g., intention to quit, attempts to quit, relapse status). We used a large (N=5,154), predominantly African American (82.9%) sample of 11th grade students. RESULTS: Regular smokers were more likely to be screened for smoking. African Americans were more often discouraged from smoking than Caucasians. Among African Americans, non-smokers were the most likely to be both screened and counseled";" Among Caucasians, normal patients were most likely to be examined and counseled. Overall, medical intervention was associated with greater benefits for young African Americans, including fewer intentions to smoke, a greater likelihood of quitting, and fewer relapses. CONCLUSIONS: Physician communication about smoking may hold particular promise for African-American teenagers because it reduces health disparities due to racial differences in smoking-related mortality and morbidity. Physicians should be encouraged to screen and advise on tobacco in all young people, regardless of race or smoking status.

title: Physician and patient predictors of evidence-based prescribing in heart failure: a multi-stage study
abstract: BACKGROUND: The management of patients with heart failure (HF) must take into account variable and complex individual clinical characteristics. Guidelines recommend the use of renin-angiotensin system inhibitors (RAAS-I) at target dose. But physicians do not seem to follow this recommendation sufficiently, while little is known about physician and patient predictors of adherence to therapy. METHODS: To study the coherence of knowledge and self-perceived competencies of primary care physicians (PC) regarding RAAS-I with their respective prescribing behavior in relation to patient-associated barriers. Cross-sectional follow-up study after a randomized medical-educational intervention study with a seven-month observation period. PC doctors (n = 37) and patients with systolic heart failure (n = 168) from practices in Baden-Württemberg. Knowledge (blueprint-based multiple choice test), self-perceived competencies (questionnaire on global confidence in the therapy and frequency of use of RAAS-I) and patient variables (age, gender, NYHA functional status, blood pressure, potassium level, renal function). The prescription was collected from the documentation of the studies. The outcome variable consisted of >/=50% of the recommended RAAS-I dosage assessed by two-level logistic regression models. RESULTS: Patients (69% male, mean age 68.8 years) had symptomatic and objectified left ventricular (NYHA II vs. III/IV: 51% vs. 49% and mean LVEF 33.3%) and renal (GFR/=50 %). Determinants of improved prescribing of RAAS-I were patient age (OR 0.95, CI 0.92-0.99, p=0.01), overall physician confidence at follow-up (OR 1.09, CI 1, 02-1.05, p=0.01) and NYHA class (II vs. III/IV) (OR 0.63, CI 0.38-1.05, p=0.08) CONCLUSIONS: A change of physician confidence as a predictor of RAAS-I dose increase is a new finding that may reflect an intervention effect of improved physicians' intent and that may encourage new strategies to improve safe evidence-based prescribing. These should include alignment to knowledge, attitudes and skills.

title: Willingness of physicians and patients to pay for electronic cardiovascular disease management
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is an important target for electronic decision support. We investigated the potential sustainability of an electronic CVD management program using a discrete choice experiment (DCE). Our aim was to estimate the willingness to pay (WTP) of physicians and patients for the current and expanded programs. METHODS: Focus groups, expert input, and literature reviews decided the attributes to be evaluated for physician and patient DCEs performed using a web-based program. Estimated preference coefficients from hierarchical Bayesian analysis for each respondent and latent class analysis segmented each sample.
