Simulations were used to estimate the WTP for each of the attributes individually and for an improved vessel management system. RESULTS: 144 participants (70 physicians, 74 patients) completed the DCE. Overall, speed of access to updated records and monthly payments for a care coordinator were the most important determinants of physician choice. Two distinctly different segments of physicians were identified - one highly sensitive to the monthly subscription fee and the speed of updating the tracker with new patient data, and the other highly sensitive to the monthly care coordinator costs and government billing incentives. Patient choice was most significantly influenced by annual subscription cost. The physician's estimated WTP was slightly above the estimated sustainability threshold, while the patient's WTP was below. CONCLUSION: Current willingness-to-pay for electronic cardiovascular disease management should encourage innovation to achieve economies of scale in program development, delivery, and maintenance, and to meet sustainability thresholds.

title: Physicians' attitudes towards the proliferation of optical spectroscopy equipment for cervical cancer screening: an industrial-academic collaborative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Optical spectroscopy has been evaluated for biological plausibility, technical efficacy, clinical efficacy, patient satisfaction, and cost-effectiveness. OBJECTIVE: We sought to identify healthcare provider attitudes or practices that might act as barriers to the spread of this new technology. METHODS: As part of an academic-industrial partnership, we conducted a series of focus groups to examine the barriers physicians face in optical diagnosis. The study was carried out in 2 stages. First, a pilot group of 10 physicians (8 obstetricians, gynecologists, and 2 general practitioners) were randomly selected from 8 regions of the United States and each physician was interviewed individually. Physicians were presented with the results of a large study (N=980) testing the accuracy of a spectroscopic device in detecting cervical neoplasia. They were also shown a prototype of the device and had time to ask questions and get answers about the device. They were also asked to provide feedback on a questionnaire, which was then revised and submitted to three larger focus groups (n=13, 15, and 17 for a total of N=45). The larger focus groups were conducted during national scientific meetings with 20 obstetrical gynecologists and 25 primary care physicians (GPs and internists). RESULTS: When asked about the dissemination potential of the new cervical screening technology, all study groups tended to rely on established clinical guidelines from their respective professional societies with regard to the screening and diagnosis of cervical cancer. In addition, study participants unanimously agreed that real-time spectroscopy would be viewed favorably by their patients. Participants were positive about the potential of the new technology as an adjunct to colposcopy and agreed that the improved accuracy would result in lower healthcare costs (due to fewer biopsies and fewer visits). Although all participants recognized the potential of real-time diagnostics, there were many perceived obstacles. These obstacles included changes in planning and workflow, liability, documentation, ease of use, length of training, equipment costs, and reimbursement from third-party payers. CONCLUSIONS: There are barriers to the spread of optical technologies in medical practice. These need to be addressed before cervical screening and diagnostic programs can use spectroscopy-based tools to fight cancer.

title: Physician behavior in the management of pediatric chronic conditions: association with health outcomes and treatment adherence
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Physician behavior is an important but understudied influence on child and parent adherence to therapy. METHOD: To address this need, research was reviewed in the following thematic areas: children's and adolescents' perceptions of physician behavior in the management of chronic diseases in children; parents' perceptions of physician behavior in the management of chronic diseases; Physician compliance with pediatric guidelines Management of chronic diseases; the sharing of information by physicians about the management of chronic diseases in children; the relationship between physician behavior and adherence to therapy;" and interventions to improve physician management of pediatric chronic diseases. RESULTS: The results underscore discrepancies between parental and adolescent needs and physician behavior, as well as inconsistencies in physician behavior, including adherence to practice guidelines, that may limit children's adherence to medical treatment.However, the results of interventions to improve medical management of pediatric asthma have been promising.CONCLUSIONS:Future research should be guided by a comprehensive model of physician behavior in chronic disease management that includes contextual determinants (e.g., culture and socioeconomic status), identified clinically relevant intervention goals, and documented the impact on health outcomes Chronic disease management approaches that involve physicians in active communication, support, and decision-making with children with chronic diseases and their parents should be developed and evaluated.

title: Physician intervention and patient risk perceptions in smokers with acute respiratory disease in the emergency department
abstract: BACKGROUND: Acute respiratory illnesses account for over 12 million visits to emergency departments in the United States each year. Between a quarter and half of these patients are smokers. We assessed the incidence of physician intervention to quit smoking in patients with acute respiratory disease in the emergency department and examined the impact of physician intervention on patients' perceived risk of smoking and motivation to quit. Methods: This study was conducted in the emergency department of a large inner-city hospital. Adult smokers (n = 63) presenting with symptoms of acute respiratory disease were interviewed in the emergency department through a baseline interview. The frequency and extent of smoking interventions by physicians were studied using the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research guidelines as a model. We also assessed patients' perceptions of risk from smoking, the presence of other smokers in the household, and patients' motivation to quit smoking. RESULTS: Emergency department physicians provided an incomplete and conflicting intervention for smoking. While most patients reported being asked if they smoke, only half of smokers were advised to stop smoking. Only 9% were offered help when quitting. Risk perception was generally low, however, the majority of smokers were willing to seek on-site smoking cessation counseling during their stay in the emergency department. CONCLUSIONS: The small sample size in this study requires that the results be interpreted with caution. However, the results of this study suggest that the emergency department can provide a unique “teachable moment” in which to initiate smoking cessation counseling for this high-risk population.

title: The physician's involvement in the management of obesity as a primary condition
abstract: As the obesity epidemic escalates, more and more patients suffer from serious comorbidities associated with being overweight. Obesity should be recognized and treated as a primary disease that is progressive, chronic and relapsing. Effective treatment of obesity has been shown to reduce cardiovascular risk factors and comorbidities. Physician involvement is required for medical assessment, management, counseling, and coordination of multidisciplinary management of obesity. Obese patients who are consulted by physicians and engaged for weight management are significantly more likely to participate in weight management programs than those who are not. Obesity treatment guidelines and materials are available from various health organizations. A comprehensive weight management program must include dietary changes, increased physical activity, and behavior changes. Dietary changes should take into account the energy content, composition, and suitability of the diet for the individual patient. The physical activity component should be safe and practical, including aerobic activity, strength training, and increased daily lifestyle activities. Various behavioral strategies allow the patient to make lifestyle changes that promote weight loss and management. Adjunctive therapies can be used to support lifestyle changes in severe or resistant cases of obesity. Models for multidisciplinary care differ depending on whether they are designed for a single doctor's office or as part of the healthcare delivery of a larger facility. Lifestyle changes for healthy weight management must be permanently incorporated into a patient's daily lifestyle to reduce obesity and its associated health risks. Such intervention is necessary if the growing obesity epidemic is to be slowed and reversed.

title: Medical treatment of hypercholesterolemia. A randomized study of continuing medical education
abstract: To determine the impact of continuing medical education (CME) on compliance with the National Cholesterol Education Program Expert Panel recommendations on high serum cholesterol in adults, we randomly assigned primary care physicians at 174 practices into 3 groups, 2 who adhered to either a standard or subjected to a standard examination intensive CME and a control group. The Standard CME group was offered a free 3-hour High Serum Cholesterol seminar, while the Intensive CME group was offered additional follow-up seminars and free stationery. After 18 months, we reviewed 13,099 medical records from 140 practices. There were no significant differences (P > 0.15) in screening for high serum cholesterol or in compliance with guidelines between the groups that received continuing medical education (51% screening; 33% compliance) and the control group (57% screening;" 37% agreement). In the pre-specified subgroup of patients with hypercholesterolaemia, there was a trend towards a modest benefit from the further training measures: compliance was 21% in the control group, 23% in the standard CME group and 27% in the intensive care CME group (P=0.07 overall) These results underscore the need for better behavior change opportunities among practicing physicians and the importance of investigating the implementation of health prevention recommendations.

title: Physician remuneration through salary or fee: Effect on the practice behavior of physicians in a randomized prospective study
abstract: We used a local continuity clinic to prospectively compare the effects of salary and fee reimbursement on physician practice behavior. This model allowed physicians to be randomized into salary and fee brackets and to separate the impact of reimbursement from patient behavior. Physicians reimbursed by fees for services scheduled more visits per patient than employed physicians (3.69 visits vs. 2.83 visits, P less than 0.01) and saw their patients more frequently (2.70 visits vs. 2.21 visits, P less than 0.05). the 9-month study. Almost all of the difference was due to fee physicians treating more healthy patients than employed physicians (1.42 visits and 0.99 visits per enrolled patient, respectively, P less than 0.01). Analysis of the visits using the American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines showed that fee-based physicians visited more patients for good child care than employed physicians because they missed fewer recommended visits and missed scheduled visits in excess of those recommendations. Fee physicians also provided better continuity of care than salaried physicians by attending a larger percentage of all their patients' visits (86.6% of visits vs. 78.3% of visits, P less than 0.05) and promoting fewer emergencies visits per admitted patient (0.12 visits vs. 0.22 visits, P less than 0.01). Physicians' interest in private practice, as determined by their career plans, correlated significantly with the total number of patients admitted (r = 0.48, p less than 0.05) and the total number of clinic patients served by each resident during the study were seen (r = 0.40 , P less than 0.05). (ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)

title: Physician's response to computer reminders.
abstract: A computerized medical record system was developed to identify clinical events that may require corrective action and to remind the responsible clinician of them. These reminders greatly increased the physician's rate of response (in terms of test orders and treatment changes) to the events in question. Adding citations from relevant medical literature to the reminders did not significantly alter the clinicians' response rate compared to the reminder alone, nor did it encourage physicians to read any of the cited articles kept in a readily available "library" of reprints became.

title: Doctors' responses to a community-level study promoting prudent use of antibiotics
abstract: PURPOSE: In an environment of numerous campaigns promoting the prudent use of antibiotics in children, it is important to identify effective strategies. We assessed physician responses to community-level intervention in terms of antibiotic prescribing, associated practices, and perceived effectiveness. METHODS: This study was a mixed qualitative and quantitative evaluation of a randomized, controlled, community-wide educational intervention in 16 communities in Massachusetts. Physicians in intervention communities received locally recognized guidelines, group training, and biweekly newsletters. Parents received materials at doctor's offices and in the mail at the same time. After the intervention, we conducted a postal physician survey and individual interviews to assess the effect of the intervention. We compared survey responses from interventional and control physicians and analyzed interview transcripts to provide detailed information on selected topics. RESULTS: Among the survey participants (n=168), 91% of the intervention physicians and 4% of the control physicians reported having received intervention materials. Doctors received information from several other sources. From 2000 to 2003, more intervention physicians than control physicians reported less antibiotic prescribing (75% vs. 58%, P=0.03), but there were no differences between groups in knowledge, attitudes, or behaviors that promote prudent encourage the use of antibiotics. Both groups were concerned about antibiotic resistance and reported ways to reduce their own prescribing. Physicians surveyed suggested frequent repetition of messages, brief written materials on specific topics for themselves and patients, and mass media advertising as the most effective strategies to reduce prescription. CONCLUSIONS: In several communities, an intervention in physician offices to promote prudent antibiotic prescribing reached its intended target audience, but physicians' self-reported attitudes and practices were similar in intervention and control communities. Campaigns that include repeated short, consistent reminders to multiple stakeholders may be most effective in ensuring prudent use of antibiotics.

title: Physician screening for multiple behavioral health risk factors
abstract: BACKGROUND: Screening rates in primary care for individual behavioral health risk factors are well documented. However, such risk factors accumulate among individuals and populations. This article examines the number and types of behavioral risk factors reported by adults in the United States who reported being evaluated at their last routine medical evaluation. METHODS: The sample consisted of 16,818 adults from the 1998 National Health Interview Survey who reported having had a routine physical in the past year. Respondents completed questions about four behavioral risk factors (physical inactivity, obesity, cigarette smoking, hazardous drinking) and provider screening for behaviors related to those risk factors. RESULTS: Half of the sample (52.0%) reported having two or more of the four risk factors, and more than half (59.4%) were assessed for two or more risk behaviors at their most recent routine visit, although 28, 6% said they had been screened for none of them. Respondents who identified at least one risk factor were screened for an average of 57.7% of their own risk factors. Women, adults with lower income and education, and those aged 65 and over said they were screened for fewer of their risk factors. CONCLUSIONS: While guidelines for risk factor screening and intervention typically focus on single behavioral risk factors, most primary care patients have and are screened for more than one. Screening tools and interventions for behavioral risk factors need to be expanded to cover multiple risks. In addition, efforts are needed to reduce the significant missed screening opportunities and to eliminate demographic differences in screening practices and accuracy.

title: Physician, heal thyself: health maintenance behaviors among physicians
abstract: The aim of this article is to assess the need for health maintenance intervention programs aimed at physicians and patients. We compared adherence to health maintenance behavior by physicians (as patients) to a control patient population. An online survey was sent to the clinical and non-clinical basic science faculties of the Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center (TTUHSC) School of Medicine and to the non-TTUHSC clinicians of the local county medical society. The survey included questions about basic demographics and recent participation in regular health maintenance strategies, including annual screening, influenza vaccination, colonoscopy, Pap smear, and mammography. Logistic regressions were performed to determine whether being a doctor had a significant association with the likelihood of participating in the health maintenance behavior outcomes listed above. This article shows that physicians are less likely than the general population to adhere to specific health maintenance guidelines: namely, annual checkups, colonoscopies, and mammograms. Pap smear rates did not differ between physicians and a control population, but physicians showed an increased likelihood of receiving an influenza vaccine.

title: Physician-industry relations. Part 1: Individual Doctors
abstract: This is part 1 of a two part paper on ethics and physician-industry relations. Part 1 offers advice for individual physicians";" Part 2 gives recommendations to medical training providers and medical societies. Physicians and industry have a common interest in the further development of medical knowledge. Nonetheless, the physician's primary ethic is to promote the patient's best interests, while the industry's primary ethic is to promote profitability. While partnerships between physicians and industry can lead to impressive medical advances, they also create opportunities for bias and can lead to unfavorable public perceptions. Many physicians and medical trainees believe that they are not exposed to commercial influences. However, recent studies show that accepting hospitality and industry gifts, even drug samples, can affect judgments about medical information and subsequent decisions about patient care. It is up to the doctor to judge whether a gift is acceptable. A very general guideline is that it is ethical to accept modest gifts that advance medical practice. It is clearly unethical to accept any gift or service that obliges the physician to provide something in return. Conflicts of interest may arise from other financial ties between physicians and industry, whether with outside companies or their own companies. These ties include fees for speaking or writing about a company's product, payments for participating in clinical research, and referrals to medical resources. All of these relationships have the potential to influence a physician's attitudes and practices. This paper examines the ethical issues involved and provides guidelines for ethical business relationships.

title: Physicians and pharmaceutical industry (Update 2001)
Doctors' health habits are linked to lifestyle advice for hypertensive patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: The seventh report of the Joint National Committee on Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC VII) recommended lifestyle interventions, either with or without pharmacologic treatment, for all patients with hypertension. The aim of this study is to determine the association between physicians' personal habits and their attitudes and behaviors in relation to the JNC VII lifestyle modification guidelines. METHODS: One thousand primary care physicians completed DocStyles 2010, a voluntary web-based survey designed to gain insight into physician attitudes and behaviors toward various health issues. RESULTS: The mean age of respondents was 45.3 years and 68% were male. In terms of medical behavior, 4.0% smoked at least once a week, 38.6% ate >/= 5 cups of fruit and/or vegetables >/= 5 days/week and 27.4% smoked >/= 5 days/ week sports. When asked about specific types of advice for their hypertensive patients, physicians said they would advise their patients to eat healthily (92.2%), reduce salt (96.1%), or achieve or maintain a healthy weight ( 94.8%). or limit alcohol consumption (75.4%) or be physically active (94.4%). Overall, 66.5% made all 5 lifestyle change recommendations. Non-smoking physicians were more likely to recommend any lifestyle intervention to their hypertensive patients. Those who exercised at least 1 day per week were more likely to recommend limiting alcohol consumption. CONCLUSIONS: Physicians who did not smoke and exercised at least 1 day per week were more likely to recommend all 5 JNC VII interventions.

title: Doctors' response to victims of domestic violence: towards a model of care
abstract: While current domestic violence guidelines, such as those released by the AMA in 1992, attempt to relieve physicians of the "full burden of intervention," they continue to urge physicians to play a large role in detection, intervention, and follow-up partner abuse. In this paper, we define a limited role for domestic violence physicians that advances the direction recommended by the AMA and complements exemplary programs. We propose simplifying and restricting physicians' responsibilities to "question" patients about abuse," provide affirmative notices, acknowledge beatings are wrong and affirm patient value, document signs, symptoms, disclosures, and sacrifice to specialists for Domestic Violence (AVDR) Using the literature and our own experience, we show how focusing the role of the physician on these four tasks is consistent with exemplary programs and expands healthcare professionals' ideas on addressing domestic violence, barriers to physician interventions casualties reduced; provides a realistic approach to physicians and reduces unrealistic educational requirements;" and complements managed care trends in modern healthcare.

title: Physicians' understanding of the consent requirements for Phase I clinical trials in cognitively impaired or highly vulnerable populations
abstract: We examined physicians' attitudes to enrolling patients who are unable to provide informed consent or who belong to a vulnerable population into clinical trials. A survey tool asked a nationwide sample of practicing physicians whether ten hypothetical patients could be enrolled in a Phase I clinical trial. The impact of demographic variables on the number of scenarios considered fully or reasonably acceptable was analyzed via Student's t-tests or analysis of variance (ANOVA) as appropriate. All significant (p<0.01) variables were entered into a multiple logistic regression model. 84% of respondents indicated that at least one case study was acceptable. A majority of those conducting clinical trials (62%), who had training in clinical research ethics (78%) and who sit on institutional review boards (IRBs) (83%) supported at least one case study. Physicians approved the participation in clinical trials of some patients who cannot give informed consent or who belong to a vulnerable population. Practitioners, residents and medical students should receive more effective education about clinical research guidelines. It should also be ensured that physicians conducting clinical trials or sitting in IRBs have the necessary knowledge of clinical research ethics.

title: Establishing the diagnosis in breast cancer
Point-of-service reminders for cardiovascular medication prescriptions.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To provide evidence-based recommendations for physician care at the point-of-service using an automated system and evaluate its effectiveness in promoting prescriptions for the prevention of cardiovascular events. STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. METHODS: Patients at risk for cardiovascular events who might benefit from angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors or 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A reductase inhibitors (statins) were enrolled in a managed care system using electronic data -Organization identified and randomly divided into 2 groups. An information sheet with the relevant patient data and recommendations for prescribing the indicated medication was faxed to the outpatient physicians in the intervention group. In the control group, the data sheet did not contain the recommendation. Dispensed prescriptions were compared between the groups. RESULTS: More than 4000 visits were observed for each medication type. Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers were dispensed at 7.1% of visits in the intervention group versus 5.7% in the control group (p=0.048) after the initial patient-physician contact. No significant difference was observed for statins (intervention, 8.1% vs. control, 7.7%). Data for all patient-physician encounters and both medications were combined in a logistic regression analysis. The odds ratio was 1.19 for a prescription issued in the intervention group and 1.54 for 2 or more visits versus 1 visit. CONCLUSIONS: An automated system providing relevant data and tailored recommendations for care at the point-of-service slightly increased prescription dispensing rates. Targeting patient-provider encounters to change provider behavior is a challenge";" however, even small effects over time can lead to clinically important results.

title: Electronic prompts at the point of care: a powerful way to increase compliance, demonstrate quality and improve outcome
abstract: BACKGROUND: Incentives based on quality indicators such as the core measures of the Surgical Care Improvement Project (SCIP 1) promote the consistent implementation of evidence-based guidelines in clinical practice. Information systems with point-of-care electronic prompts (POCEPs) can facilitate the implementation of processes and benchmarking services. We evaluated the effectiveness of POCEPs on the rate of antibiotic administration within 60 minutes after surgical incision and the effect on outcome in a prospective observational study. METHODS: SCIP 1 compliance and the corresponding outcome variable (Surgical Site Infection [SSI]) were prospectively assessed over 2 consecutive 6-month periods before (A) and after (B) POCEPs implementation in a regional healthcare system. The secondary analysis extended the observation to two 12-month periods (A' and B'). A 2-year (C and D) sustainability phase followed. RESULTS: The 19,744 interventions included 9,127 and 10,617 interventions before (A) and after (B) POCEPs implementation, respectively. POCEPs increased adherence to SCIP indicators by 31% (95% CI, 30.0%-32.2%) from 62% to 92% (P 95%) in period B, with the mean SSI rates for all Periods were lower than the SSI rates before POCEPs (0.8%, 0.7% and 0.5% vs. 1.1% ";" P 30% and were associated with an absolute risk reduction of 0.4% at the Incidence of SSI associated.

title: Population-based interventions to reduce sexually transmitted infections, including HIV infection
abstract: BACKGROUND: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are common in developing countries. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that in 1999 there were 340 million new cases of syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydia and trichomoniasis. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is also widespread in developing countries. UNAIDS estimates that over 95% of the 40 million people infected with HIV as of December 1999 live in developing countries (UNAIDS 2003). The STI and HIV epidemics are interdependent. Similar behaviors such as B. Frequent unprotected sex with multiple partners puts people at high risk for both infections, and there is strong evidence that traditional STIs increase the likelihood of HIV transmission. Several studies have shown a strong association between both ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs and HIV infection (Cameron 1989, Laga 1993). There is also biological evidence that the presence of an STI increases HIV shedding and that STI treatment decreases HIV shedding (Cohen 1997, Robinson 1997). Therefore, STI control may have the potential to contribute significantly to HIV prevention. OBJECTIVES: To determine the impact of population-based STI interventions on the incidence of HIV infection, the incidence of STIs, and the quality of STI management. SEARCH STRATEGY: The following electronic databases were searched for relevant randomized trials or reviews:1) MEDLINE for the years 1966 to 2003 using the search terms "sexually transmitted diseases" and "human immunodeficiency virus infection"2) The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effectiveness and the Cochrane Clinical Trials Register, in the latest edition of the Cochrane Library3) The subject registry of trials maintained by the Cochrane Infectious Diseases Group.4) EMBASE Relevant conference abstracts were searched and reference lists of all reviews and primary studies were scanned . Finally, the authors of the included studies and other experts in the field were contacted as needed. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials in which the randomized entity is either a community or a treatment facility. Studies in which people were randomized were excluded. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently applied the inclusion criteria to potential studies, with all disagreements resolved through discussion. The studies were examined for completeness of reporting. The methodological quality of each study was assessed by the same two reviewers, with details of randomization method, blinding, use of intention-to-treat analysis, and number of patients lost to follow-up recorded using standard Cochrane Infectious Diseases guidelines became group. MAIN RESULTS: Five studies were included. Frequency of HIV infection: In Rakai, after 3 rounds of treatment for all community members for STIs, the rate ratio of HIV infection was 0.97 (95% CI 0.81 to 1.16), indicating that the intervention had no effect. In Mwanza, the incidence of HIV infection in the intervention groups (increased syndromic management of STIs in primary care hospitals) was 1.2% compared to 1.9% in the control groups (OR = 0.58, 95% CI 0.42– 0.70), corresponding to a 38% reduction (95% CI 15% to 55%) in HIV incidence in the intervention group. In the latest study by Kamali et al. the rate ratio of behavioral intervention and STI management compared to HIV incidence control was 1.00 (0.63-1.58, p=0.98). These are consistent with the Rakai data, which show no effects of the intervention. Incidence of STIs: In both Mwanza and Rakai, there was no significant reduction in gonorrhea, chlamydia, urethritis, or reported STI symptoms in the intervention communities. The prevalence ratio of syphilis between intervention and control groups in Rakai was 0.8 (95% CI 0.71-0.89), of trichmoniasis 0.59 (0.38-0.91), and of bacterial vaginosis 0.87 ( 0.74-1.02). In Mwanza, the prevalence of serologically diagnosed syphilis was 5% in the intervention community compared to 7% in the control community at the end of the study (adjusted re7% in the control community at the end of the study (adjusted relative risk 0.71 (95% CI 0.54 -0.93).In Kamali et al., there was a significant decrease in the incidence of gonorrhea and active syphilis.Rate ratio for gonorrhea was 0.29 (0.12–0.71, p=0.016), active syphilis was 0, 53 (0.33–0.84, p=0.016) trend towards significance with intervention for condom use with the last casual partner"; rate ratio 1.27 (1.02–1.56, p=0.036) Quality of treatment: In Lima after training the Pharmacy assistants in the treatment of STI syndromes identified symptoms as attributable to an STI in 65% of standardized simulated patients (SSPs) who attended interventions and in 60% of SSPs who attended control pharmacies (p = 0.35) medications were in the me without a referral to a doctor most cases (83% intervention and 78% control, p=0.61). Of the SSPs who offered medications, only 1.4% who attended intervention pharmacies and only 0.7% of those who attended control pharmacies (p=0.57) were offered a recommended regimen. Likewise, only 15% and 16% of SSP visits offered any recommended medication. However, SSPs who attended intervention pharmacies were more likely to receive education and counseling (40% vs. 27%, p=0.01). No SSPs received partner cards or condoms. In Hlabisa, after intervention for caregivers in primary care clinics (reinforced STI syndrome management and provision of packs of recommended medications, condoms, partner cards, and patient information booklets), SSP were more likely to receive recommended medications in intervention clinics (83% vs. 12%, p<0.005 ) and more likely to have correct case management [with correct medication, partner cards, and condoms] (88% vs. 50%, p<0.005). There were no significant differences in the proportions who received appropriate advice (68% vs. 46%, p=0.06), experienced good staff attitudes (84% vs. 58%, p=0.07), and received confidential advice (92% vs. 86%, p=0.4). There was no clear evidence of an effect on treatment-seeking behavior, service utilization, or sexual behavior in any of the four studies. REVIEWER'S CONCLUSIONS: There is limited evidence from randomized controlled trials for STI control as an effective HIV prevention strategy. Improved STI treatment services have been shown to reduce HIV incidence in an environment characterized by an emerging HIV epidemic (low and slowly increasing prevalence), where STI treatment services are poor and STIs are common. There is no evidence of any significant benefit from treating all members of the community. The addition of the Kamali trial to the existing evidence supports the data from the Rakai trial to no effect. However, there are other compelling reasons why STI treatment services should be strengthened, and the available evidence suggests that an accepted intervention can significantly improve the quality of services provided. The Kamali study shows an increase in condom use, a marker of improved risk-taking behavior. Further community-based randomized controlled trials testing a range of alternative STI control strategies are needed in a variety of different settings. Such studies should aim to measure a range of factors, including health-oriented behavior and quality of care, as well as HIV, STI and other biological endpoints.

title: Population-based interventions to reduce sexually transmitted infections, including HIV infection
abstract: BACKGROUND: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are common in developing countries. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that in 1995 there were 333 million new cases of syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydia and trichomoniasis. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is also widespread in developing countries. UNAIDS estimates that over 90% of the 33 million people infected with HIV as of December 1999 live in developing countries (UNAIDS 1999). The STI and HIV epidemics are interdependent. Similar behaviors such as B. Frequent unprotected sex with multiple partners puts people at high risk for both infections, and there is strong evidence that traditional STIs increase the likelihood of HIV transmission. Several studies have shown a strong association between both ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs and HIV infection (Cameron 1989, Laga 1993) and there is biological evidence that the presence of an STI increases HIV shedding and that treatment for STIs reduced HIV shedding (Cohen 1997, Robinson 1997). Therefore, STI control may have the potential to contribute significantly to HIV prevention. OBJECTIVES: To determine the impact of population-based STI interventions on the incidence of HIV infection, the incidence of STIs, and the quality of STI management. SEARCH STRATEGY: The following electronic databases were searched for relevant randomized trials or reviews: 1) MEDLINE for years 1966 to present using the search terms sexually transmitted diseases and human immunodeficiency virus infections 2) The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effectiveness and the Cochrane Clinical Trials Register in the latest edition of the Cochrane Library 3) The specialist register of trials maintained by the Cochrane Infectious Diseases Group. 4) EMBASE The abstracts of relevant conferences were searched and reference lists of all review articles and primary studies were searched. Finally, the authors of the included studies and other experts in the field were contacted as needed. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials in which the randomized entity is either a community or a treatment facility. Studies in which people were randomized were excluded. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently applied the inclusion criteria to potential studies, with all disagreements resolved through discussion. The studies were examined for completeness of reporting. The methodological quality of each study was assessed by the same two reviewers, providing details on the method of randomization, blinding, use of intention-to-treat analysis, and the number of patients lost to follow-up using standard Cochrane Infectious Diseases Group guidelines were recorded. MAIN RESULTS: Four studies were included. Frequency of HIV infection: In Rakai, after 3 rounds of treatment for all community members for STIs, the rate ratio of HIV infection was 0.97 (95% CI 0.81 to 1.16), indicating that the intervention had no effect. In Mwanza, the incidence of HIV infection in the intervention groups (increased syndromic management of STIs in primary care hospitals) was 1.2% compared to 1.9% in the control groups (OR = 0.58, 95% CI 0.42– 0.70), corresponding to a 38% reduction (95% CI 15% to 55%) in HIV incidence in the intervention group. Incidence of STIs: In both Mwanza and Rakai, there was no significant reduction in gonorrhea, chlamydia, urethritis, or reported STI symptoms in the intervention communities. The prevalence ratio of syphilis between intervention and control groups in Rakai was 0.8 (95% CI 0.71-0.89), of trichmoniasis 0.59 (0.38-0.91), and of bacterial vaginosis 0.87 ( 0.74-1.02). In Mwanza, the prevalence of serologically diagnosed syphilis was 5% in the intervention community compared to 7% in the control community at the end of the study (adjusted relative risk 0.71 (95% CI 0.54-0.93). Treatment quality: In Lima , following training of pharmacist assistants in the management of STI syndromes, symptoms were recognized as being due to an STI in 65% of standardized simulated patients (SSPs) who visited an intervention and in 60% of SSPs who visited control pharmacies (p=0.35) Referral to a physician in most cases (83% intervention and 78% control, p=0.61) Of the SSPs who offered medication, only 1.4% visited intervention pharmacies , and only 0.7% of those visiting control pharmacies (p=0.57) offered a recommended regimen.Similarly, only 15% and 16% of SSP visits offered a recommended medication, respectively.SSPs, the intervention pharmacies visited , but were more likely to receive education and advice (40% vs. 27%, p=0.01). .No S SPs received partner cards or condoms. In Hlabisa, after intervention for caregivers in primary care clinics (reinforced STI syndrome management and provision of packs of recommended medications, condoms, partner cards, and patient information booklets), SSP were more likely to receive recommended medications in intervention clinics (83% vs. 12%, p<0.005 ) and more likely to have correct case management [with correct medication, partner cards, and condoms] (88% vs. 50%, p<0.005). There was no significant difference in the proportions of those who received appropriate advice (68% vs. 46%, p=0.06), experienced good staff attitudes (84% vs. 58%, p=0.07) and received confidential advice ( 92% vs 86%, p=0.4). There was no clear evidence of an effect on treatment-seeking behavior, service utilization, or sexual behavior in any of the four studies. REVIEWER'S CONCLUSIONS: There is limited evidence from randomized controlled trials for STI control as an effective HIV prevention strategy. Improved STI treatment services have been shown to reduce HIV incidence in an environment characterized by an emerging HIV epidemic (low and slowly increasing prevalence), where STI treatment services are poor and STIs are common. There is no evidence of any significant benefit from treating all members of the community. However, there are other compelling reasons why STI treatment services should be strengthened, and the available evidence suggests that an adopted intervention can significantly improve the quality of services delivered. Further community-based randomized controlled trials testing a range of alternative STI control strategies are needed in a variety of different settings. Such studies should aim to measure a range of factors, including health-oriented behavior and quality of care, as well as HIV, STI and other biological endpoints.

title: Population-level intervention strategies and examples for childhood obesity prevention
abstract: With obesity affecting approximately 12.5 million American youth, population-level interventions are warranted to support healthy behaviors. The purpose of this review is to provide a summary of population-level intervention strategies and specific examples of interventions that illustrate ways to prevent and control childhood obesity through improving diet and physical activity behaviors. Information is aggregated into the environments in which children live, learn and play (early care and education, school, community, health care, home). Intervention strategies are activities or changes aimed at promoting healthy behaviors in children. They were identified from (a) systematic reviews; (b) evidence- and consensus-based recommendations, guidelines, or standards from non-governmental or federal agencies; and finally (c) peer-reviewed synthesis reports. Examples of interventions illustrate how at least one of the strategies was used in a specific setting. To identify examples of interventions, we considered (a) peer-reviewed literature and (b) additional sources with research-tested and practice-based initiatives. Researchers and practitioners can use this review when setting priorities and promoting integration across different settings and to find research- and practice-proven examples of interventions that can be replicated in their communities for childhood obesity prevention.

title: Positron emission tomography in gynecologic cancer
abstract: Most positron emission tomography (PET) imaging studies in gynecologic cancer are performed using (18)F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG). It provides valuable information for primary staging of untreated advanced cervical cancer, post-treatment monitoring for unexplained elevation or suspected recurrence of tumor markers (such as . Its value in resectable early-stage cervical cancer is questionable. In ovarian cancer, FDG-PET offers advantages for those with plateau or increasing abnormal serum CA 125 (> 35 U/mL), computed tomography and/or magnetic resonance imaging (CT-MRI) defined localized recurrence necessary for locally destructive procedures (such as surgery, radiotherapy, or radiofrequency ablation) and in clinically suspected recurrent or persistent cancer in which CT-guided biopsy cannot be performed.The role of FDG-PET in endometrial cancer is relatively less defined due to the lack of data in the literature.In our prospective study, FDG-PET can be used in conjunction with MRI-CT in well selected cases optimal treatment enable development of endometrial cancer. The clinical impact was positive for 29 (48.3%) of the 60 scans, 22.2% for primary staging, 73.1% for post-therapy monitoring, and 57.1% for salvage therapy. Few studies are available on the treatment of vulvar cancer with FDG-PET. More data is needed. The trophoblastic neoplasia of pregnancy is quite unique in its biological behavior and clinical management. Our preliminary results suggest that FDG-PET is potentially useful in selected trophoblastic neoplasms of pregnancy by providing accurate metastatic mapping of tumor extent in advance, monitoring response, and locating viable tumors after chemotherapy. The evaluation of a diagnostic tool like PET is usually done by comparing diagnostic efficacy (sensitivity, specificity, etc.), by using a more sophisticated receiver operating curve method, or by changing the treatment fraction. Evaluation of PET for clinical benefit is specific to the individual tumor and is an attractive new endpoint.

title: Postnatal depression and child development
Postphlebitic syndrome after leg fractures
Potential of trans fat policies to reduce socioeconomic inequalities in mortality from coronary artery disease in England: cost-effectiveness modeling study
abstract: OBJECTIVES To determine the health and equity benefits and cost-effectiveness of taking action to reduce or eliminate trans fats from processed foods compared to consumption, which remains current in England. DESIGN Epidemiological modeling study. ADJUSTMENT Data from National Diet and Nutrition Survey, Low Income Diet and Nutrition Survey, Office of National Statistics, and health economic data from other published studies PARTICIPANTS Adults 25 years of age stratified by fifth socioeconomic circumstances. ACTION Total ban of trans fats in processed foods; improved labeling of trans fats; Ban trans fats in restaurants and takeaways. KEY TARGET ACTIONS Prevent or delay deaths from coronary artery disease; years of life gained; quality-adjusted life years gained. Political costs to government and industry;' political savings from cuts in direct health care, informal care and lost productivity. RESULTS A total ban on trans fats in processed foods could prevent or delay about 7,200 deaths (2.6%) from coronary heart disease between 2015 and 2020 and reduce inequality in mortality from coronary heart disease by about 3,000 deaths (15%). Actions to improve labeling or simply remove trans fats from restaurants/fast food could save between 1800 (0.7%) and 3500 (1.3%) deaths from coronary heart disease and reduce inequality by 600 (3%) to 1500 (7th %) reduce fatalities, making them half as effective at best. A full ban would have the largest net cost savings of around £265m ($361m, $415m) excluding reformulation costs, or £64m if significant reformulation costs occur outside of the normal cycle. CONCLUSIONS A regulatory policy to eliminate trans fats from processed foods in England would be the most effective and equitable policy option. Intermediate policies would also be beneficial. However, simply continuing to rely on industry to voluntarily reformulate products could have negative health and economic consequences.

title: Practical clinical trials in psychopharmacology: a systematic review
abstract: Practical clinical trials (PCTs) are randomized experiments under typical practice conditions with the aim of testing the benefits and risks of therapeutic interventions "in practice". Influential PCTs have been performed in cardiology, oncology, and internal medicine. Psychotropic drugs are used frequently and increasingly in medical practice. This review examines recent advances in the performance of PCTs in psychopharmacology. The MEDLINE, Scopus, and ClinicalTrials.gov databases from January 2000 to October 2014 were searched for peer-reviewed publications of PCTs with at least 100 subjects per treatment arm. Most PCTs in psychiatry assessed mental health services or psychosocial interventions rather than specific pharmacotherapies. Of 157 PCTs in psychiatry, 30 (19%) were in psychopharmacology, with a median of 2 publications per year and no increase over the observation period. The sample size ranged from 200 to 18,154";" only 11 studies randomized 500 patients or more. Psychopharmacology PCTs were equally likely to be funded by industry as public bodies. There were 10 PCTs with antidepressants in a total of 4206 patients (compared to at least 46 PCTs with antihypertensive drugs in a total of 208,014 patients). Some psychopharmacology PCTs used suicidal behavior, treatment discontinuation, or mortality as primary endpoints and provided efficacy and safety data that have influenced both practice guidelines and regulatory decisions. Real-world clinical trials can be an important source of information for clinicians, patients, regulators, and policy makers, but have been relatively underexploited in psychopharmacology. Electronic medical records and integrated practice research networks offer promising platforms for conducting PCTs more efficiently.

title: Practical implementation of the coronary revascularization heart team
Practice changes related to the Department of Veterans Affairs' Family Care Collaborative
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) provides rehabilitation for veterans with moderate to severe war injuries through four regional polytrauma rehabilitation centers (PRCs). To standardize and improve care for family members of these veterans, health care researchers worked with program leaders and rehabilitation specialists to implement a collaboration to improve the quality of family care. OBJECTIVE: To describe practice changes associated with the Family Care Collaborative intervention. DESIGN: Cross-site, mixed-method evaluation. PARTICIPANTS: Members of the interdisciplinary rehabilitation team (n=226) working at the four participating sites. INTERVENTIONS: The collaboration developed and implemented a web-based tool to standardize and promote family-centered care in a 6-month pilot project. RESULTS: Survey of family care providers, satisfaction with family care and perceived competence in working with families; specific changes in practice at each site; perception of collaborative work by providers and moderators; and a validated measure to predict the probability of success of the selected intervention. MAIN RESULTS: Family-centered practices and satisfaction improved at sites with lower baseline scores (P<0.05) and were equivalent at all sites after the pilot. Providers initiated specific family-centered practices, often starting in one location and spreading to the others through collaboration. Sites standardized family building and collaboration. Providers felt that the collaboration brought about a “culture shift” from patient-centered to family-centered care and saw the involvement of program leaders and health service researchers as critical to success. Values for the measure predicting successful implementation of the intervention beyond the pilot project were encouraging. CONCLUSIONS: Collaborations that bring together clinicians, program leaders, and researchers can be useful to facilitate complex change with interdisciplinary teams.

title: Practice Development: Bridging the gap between research and practice by appointing a research leader
abstract: Research suggests that while most clinicians support the importance of evidence-based practice, without the right culture of support and encouragement, such practice can be difficult to achieve. This paper provides an overview of a method for improving evidence-based practice. It reports on the evaluation of a new type of occupational therapy agency, research leadership based on clinical practice, and suggests that the agency has the potential to bridge the gap between research and practice. Based on clinician feedback, research findings and implications for practice, the findings provide insight into the role of the research leader in promoting and improving the use of evidence-based practice. It is hoped that these findings will also benefit other areas considering the strategies and support needed to improve and invest in evidence-based practices.

title: Practice doesn't always make perfect: A qualitative study that explains why trying an educational toolkit hasn't improved quality of care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Diabetes is a chronic disease commonly managed by primary care physicians, with the most common complication being cardiovascular disease (CVD). Clinical practice guidelines were developed to support physicians in the care of diabetics. We conducted a pragmatic cluster randomized controlled trial (RCT) of a printed educational toolkit aimed at improving CVD management in diabetes in primary care and found no effect and indeed the possibility of some harm. We performed a qualitative assessment to examine the strategy used in this study to implement the guidelines and to understand its impact. This paper focuses solely on the qualitative results, as the quantitative results of the RCT have been reported elsewhere. METHODS AND RESULTS: All primary care practices in the province of Ontario were randomized to receive the educational toolkit in the mail in either Summer 2009 (intervention arm) or Spring 2010 (control arm). A subgroup of 80 primary care physicians (approximately 10% of the randomized and contacted practices with datasets on 1,592 randomly selected patients with diabetes at high risk for cardiovascular disease) then participated in a chart audit and reflective feedback exercise related to their own practice compared to the guideline recommendations. They were asked to fill out two forms (a pre-audit and a post-audit) to understand their level of knowledge of the guidelines before the exam, their expectations about their individual performance before the exam, and their thoughts on their exam results. In addition, individual interviews were conducted with thirteen other general practitioners. Textual data from interview transcripts and written comments from the pre- and post-examination forms were subjected to qualitative descriptive analysis to identify common themes and patterns. The analysis revealed four main themes: impressions of the toolkit, awareness was not the problem, 'It's not me, it's my patients', and chart audit as a more effective intervention than the toolkit. Participants did not consider the toolkit content or its dissemination strategy to be effective, indicating that they were aware of the guidelines prior to the process. However, their accounts also indicated that they may struggle to prioritize CVD management amid competing demands for their attention. When they received their chart audit results, many participants expressed surprise that they hadn't done better. They reported that the audit results would be an important motivator for behavioral change. CONCLUSIONS: The qualitative findings outlined in this paper provide important insights into why the intervention was not effective. They also show that physicians have an unperceived need for CVD management and that the chart audit served to identify deficiencies in their practice that they were previously unaware of. The results also indicate that new methods of intervention development and implementation should be explored. This is important given the high prevalence of diabetes worldwide";" Appropriate CVD management is critical to address the morbidity and mortality associated with the disease.

title: Practice Feedback Interventions: 15 Suggestions for Optimizing Effectiveness
abstract: Electronic practice records are increasingly being used to provide feedback to improve practices. However, there is evidence that, despite decades of experience, the effects of such interventions vary widely and do not improve over time. While there are guidelines on how to provide more effective feedback, they are spread across a wide range of disciplines and theoretical perspectives. and experience in providing, assessing, and receiving practice feedback identified 15 suggestions thought to be associated with effective feedback interventions. These suggestions are intended to provide practical guidance for quality improvement professionals, information technology developers, educators, administrators, and practitioners who receive such interventions. Designing interventions with these suggestions in mind should improve their impact, and examining the mechanisms underlying these suggestions will advance a stagnant literature.

title: Practice guidelines developed by professional societies: The need for critical appraisal
abstract: BackgroundThere are increasing concerns about the quality, reliability and independence of practice guidelines. As no information is available on the methodological quality of guidelines developed by professional societies, we conducted a survey of those published in peer-reviewed journals.";" BackgroundThere are increasing concerns about the quality, reliability and independence of practice guidelines. As no information is available on the methodological quality of guidelines developed by professional societies, we conducted a survey of those published in peer-reviewed journals.

title: Practice nurses' intentions to apply clinical guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is evidence that while nurses are increasingly using clinical guidelines to ensure higher quality of care, adherence to them varies widely. The utility of the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) to explain this variability in community care has not previously been explored. OBJECTIVE: This paper reports a study whose primary objective was to examine the usefulness of TPB in explaining variations in practice nurses' intentions to provide smoking cessation counseling in accordance with coronary artery disease guidelines. Methods: A cross-sectional survey was conducted using a postal questionnaire. A 52-item questionnaire was sent to 48 nurses in England. The questionnaire was designed to assess the components of the TPB and included measures of intent to offer smoking cessation advice, self-reported past behavior, attitudes, subjective norms, perceived behavioral controls (PBCs), behavioral beliefs and evaluations, normative beliefs, and motivation Fulfill and control beliefs and evaluations. RESULTS: The TPB explained up to 40% of the discrepancies in the intention to offer smoking cessation advice. Attitudes and PBCs were the top predictors of intent. Among other elements of the TPB, indirect attitudes and indirect PBCs made significant positive contributions to explaining the variance in intent. DISCUSSION: Future studies of interventions to improve nurse adherence to clinical guidelines could attempt to address the elements identified as important factors in this study. Further studies are needed to examine the utility of the TPB in predicting office nurse behavior.

title: Practice parameters for the non-pharmacological treatment of chronic insomnia. A report from the American Academy of Sleep Medicine. Standards of Practice Committee of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine
abstract: Insomnia is the most common sleep complaint reported to doctors. Treatment traditionally involves medication. Behavioral approaches have been available for decades, but lack of physician awareness and training, difficulties in obtaining reimbursement, and questions about effectiveness have limited their use. These practice parameters review the current evidence for a variety of non-pharmacological treatments for insomnia. The available literature was analyzed using an accompanying paper that provides a background overview. The evidence was reviewed using previously reported American Academy of Sleep Medicine criteria with reference to American Psychological Association criteria. Treatments contemplated include: stimulus control, progressive muscle relaxation, paradoxical intention, biofeedback, sleep restriction, multicomponent cognitive-behavioral therapy, sleep hygiene education, imagery training, and cognitive therapy. An improved experimental design has significantly advanced the process of evaluating non-pharmacological treatments for insomnia using guidelines outlined by the American Psychological Association (APA). Recommendations for individual therapies using the respective recommendation levels of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine are: Stimulus Control (Standard)", Progressive Muscle Relaxation, Paradoxical Intention, and Biofeedback (Guidelines); Sleep Restriction, and Multicomponent Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (Options);" Sleep hygiene education, imagery training, and cognitive therapy did not have sufficient evidence to be recommended as individual therapies. Optimal duration of therapy, who should administer the treatments, long-term outcomes and safety concerns, and the effect of treatment on quality of life are questions that warrant future research.

title: Impact of practice-level interventions to improve asthma care in primary care: the research team on patient outcomes in pediatric asthma care.
abstract: objective. To assess the practice-level impact of (1) a peer-leader physician intervention and (2) peer-leader interventions combined with the introduction of asthma nurses to facilitate care. And to compare the results to previously reported patient-level results from study participants. study setting. Data were included on children aged 5 to 17 years with asthma in 40 primary care practices affiliated with managed healthcare plans participating in the Pediatric Asthma Care Patient Outcomes Research Team (PORT) randomized study. study design. GP practices were randomly assigned to one of two care improvement arms or usual care. Automated claims data were analyzed for 12-month periods using a repeated cross-sectional design. The primary endpoint was to demonstrate that patients with persistent asthma were receiving at least one control drug. Secondary endpoints included controller delivery in all identified asthmatics, evidence of chronic controller use, and oral steroid delivery. Health service utilization outcomes included the number of outpatient visits and hospital events. main results. The proportion of children with persistent asthma prescribed controllers increased in all study arms. No effect of the interventions on the proportion of receiving controllers was found (peer leader intervention effect 0.01, 95 percent confidence interval [CI]: -0.07, 0.08"; planned nursing intervention effect -0.03, 95- Percent CI: -0.09, 0.02) A statistical trend towards an increased number of oral corticosteroid bursts delivered in interventional offices was noted Significant adjusted increases in outpatient visits from 0.08 to 0.10 Visits per child per year were observed in the first year of intervention, but only a statistical trend in these outcomes persisted in the second year of follow-up.No differences in in-hospital events were noted.Conclusions.This analysis showed a slight increase in outpatient asthma visits as an outcome of interventions to improve asthma care using automated data The lack of demonstrable effects on medications Practice-level practice-level use differs from the positive intervention effect observed in patient self-reported data from study participants. Analysis of automated data on non-participants adds information on the impact of practice-level strategies to improve care. The benefits of practice-level interventions may disproportionately benefit the subset of people participating in the study. The impact of such interventions may be less obvious at the practice or health plan level.

title: Preclinical Rett Syndrome Research: Laying the Groundwork for Translational Success
abstract: In September 2011, the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS), Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD), International Rett Syndrome Foundation (IRSF) and Rett Syndrome Research Trust (RSRT) nominated launched a workshop attended by a broad cross-section of basic scientists, clinicians, and representatives from the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the pharmaceutical industry, and private foundations to review the state of the art evaluate animal experiments on Rett syndrome (RTT). The aim of the workshop was to identify key knowledge gaps and to propose scientific priorities and best practices for the use of animal models in the preclinical evaluation of potential new RTT therapeutics. This review summarizes the results of the workshop and extensive follow-up discussions among participants and includes: (1) a comprehensive summary of the physiological and behavioral phenotypes of RTT mouse models to date and areas where further phenotypic analysis is needed to improve their usefulness these models for translational studies"; (2) discussing the impact of genetic differences between mouse models and methodological differences between laboratories on the expression and analysis of phenotypic traits, respectively;" and (3) definitions of the standards that the RTT research community can implement for rigorous preclinical study design and transparent reporting to ensure that decisions to initiate costly clinical trials are based on reliable preclinical data.

title: Upfront commitment to choosing low-value services wisely: a graded wedge cluster randomized trial.
abstract: Background Little is known about how to discourage physicians from ordering low-value services. Our goal was to test whether clinicians who commit their future self (ie, pre-commit) to following Choosing Wisely's recommendations with decision aids could reduce potentially low-value orders. Methods We conducted a randomized 12-month step-wedge cluster study involving 45 primary care physicians and experienced practice providers in six adult primary care clinics of a group practice in the US, imaging uncomplicated headache and unnecessary antibiotics in acute sinusitis. Pre-committed clinicians received 1-6 months of pre-commitment point-of-care reminders, as well as patient education handouts and weekly resource emails to support communication about low-value services. The primary outcome was the difference between the percentages of control and intervention period visits with potentially low-value orders. Secondary outcomes were differences between the percentages of control and intervention period visits with possible alternative orders, and differences between the percentages of control and 3-month post-intervention follow-up periods of visits with potentially low-value orders. Results The intervention was not associated with a change in the percentage of visits with potentially low-value orders overall, for headache or acute sinusitis, but was associated with an overall increase of 1.7% in alternative orders (p=0.01). For low back pain, the intervention was associated with a 1.2% decrease (p=0.001) in the percentage of visits with potentially low-value orders and a 1.9% increase (p=0.007) in the percentage of visits with alternative instructions . No changes were maintained in follow-up. Conclusion The physician's upfront commitment to follow Choosing Wisely's recommendations was associated with a small, non-sustained decrease in potentially low-value orders for only one of three target conditions, and may have resulted in an increase in alternative orders.

title: Predicting physician guideline compliance: an assessment of motivators and perceived barriers
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although clinical practice guidelines are widely recognized as best practices, provider compliance remains low. OBJECTIVES: To examine the relationship between providers' behavioral intentions and their adherence to practice guidelines; assessing the impact of perceived barriers that most impede compliance;" and to examine the ability of factors in the Physician Guideline Compliance Model to predict intent to adhere to and comply with guidelines implemented at specific practice locations. METHODS: Survey research methods were used to assess the Effects of past histories (attitudes, subjective norms, past behaviors, and perceived behavioral control) on providers' intentions to comply with clinical practice guidelines and assessing compliance Provider Survey I was conducted at the time of guideline introduction and Survey II at 4 months performed after implementation.RESULTS:Behavior history and behavioral intention scores reflected positive responses to guideline use.Mean self-reported compliance behavior was 65%, while co mpliance was 54% according to chart review. Approximately 68% of the variance in physicians' behavioral intentions was explained by variables included in the Physician Guideline Compliance Model. A significant negative correlation was found between perceived barriers and self-reported behavior, but not between perceived barriers and behavior assessed by chart reviews. CONCLUSIONS: Some variables, particularly perceived barriers to guideline implementation, predicted a provider's practice intentions and self-reported behavior. Future guideline intervention efforts should identify and reduce these barriers to guideline adherence prior to implementation.

title: Predicting the risk of type 2 diabetes in England and Wales: prospective derivation and validation of QDScore
abstract: AIM To develop and validate a new diabetes risk algorithm (the QDScore) to estimate the 10-year risk of being diagnosed with type 2 diabetes over a 10-year period in an ethnically and socioeconomically diverse population. DESIGN Prospective open-label cohort study using routinely collected data from 355 general practices in England and Wales to develop the score and from 176 separate practices to validate the score. PARTICIPANTS 2,540,753 patients aged 25-79 in the derivation cohort who contributed 16,436,135 person-years of follow-up and of whom 78,081 had an incidental diagnosis of type 2 diabetes; 1,232,832 patients (7,643,037 person-years) into the validation cohort with 37,535 onset cases of type 2 diabetes OUTCOME MEASURES A Cox proportional hazards model was used to estimate the impact of risk factors in the derivation cohort and a risk equation for Males and females inferred in the final model were self-assigned race, age, gender, body mass index, smoking status, family history of diabetes, Townsend Deprivation Score, treated hypertension, cardiovascular disease, and current use of Corticosteroids;' the outcome of interest was incident of diabetes recorded in general practice records. Calibration and discrimination measures were calculated in the validation cohort. RESULTS There was a four- to five-fold variation in type 2 diabetes risk between different ethnic groups. Compared to the white reference group, the adjusted hazard ratio was 4.07 (95% confidence interval, 3.24 to 5.11) for Bangladeshi women, 4.53 (3.67 to 5.59) for Bangladeshi men, 2.15 (1.84 to 2.52) for Pakistani women and 2.54 (2.20). to 2.93) for Pakistani men. Pakistani and Bangladeshi men had significantly higher risk rates than Indian men. Black African men and Chinese women were at increased risk compared to the corresponding white reference group. In the validation data set, the model explained 51.53% (95% confidence interval 50.90 to 52.16) of the variation in females and 48.16% (47.52 to 48.80) of the variation in males. The risk score showed good discrimination with a D-statistic of 2.11 (95% confidence interval 2.08 to 2.14) in females and 1.97 (1.95 to 2.00) in males. The model was well calibrated. CONCLUSIONS The QDScore is the first risk prediction algorithm that estimates the 10-year diabetes risk based on a prospective cohort study and takes into account both social disadvantage and ethnicity. The algorithm does not require laboratory testing and can be used in clinical settings and also by the public via a simple web calculator (www.qdscore.org).

title: Predicting hip fractures in older women: a prospective study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the relative importance of osteoporosis of the os calcis, cognition and mobility in the risk of later hip fracture in older women. DESIGN Prospective study of elderly women in residential care over two years. FACILITIES 21 private or 38 community residential homes for the elderly and 4 geriatric hospitals in Doncaster and Hull. PARTICIPANTS 1414 outpatient women aged over 69 in private, community or elderly care. Those who had bilateral hip surgery were excluded. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Broadband Ultrasound Attenuation Index (BUA), Clifton Assessment Procedure for the Elderly (for cognition), and mobility on a six-point scale and hip fracture over the following two years. RESULTS 73 women fractured their hips during the two years. Their mean age was not significantly different from that of the non-fracture women (85.3 (SD 5.6) vs. 83.9 (6.3)"; p=0.07), but their mean BUA index (40, 3 (19.3) vs. 50.9 (22.2) db/MH2) and the score for cognition (median 19 (interquartile range 10.5-27.0) vs. 24 (17-30)) were significantly lower (both p<0.001).These variables had independent associations with hip fractures.Women with fractures had a significantly lower score on the psychomotor component of the cognition test (4.5(1-8) v 7(2-10); p less than 0 .0025 and were significantly more mobile (1(1-3) v 3(1-6); p less than 0.02) Division of women into high, medium, and low scores on the BUA index and the awareness test yielded one group high risk (118 women) with low BUA index and low consciousness score, whose fracture incidence was 12.8%;" in the lowest risk group (136 women) with high BUA index and high consciousness score re ug fracture incidence was only 1.5% (relative risk 8.4 (95% confidence interval -2.0 to 35.5). Further analysis showed that those at highest risk were additionally the most mobile, but that less mobile, well-aware women had a low incidence of fractures regardless of the BUA index (1.2%, high index, v 0.9%, lower Index). CONCLUSIONS Older women who were most at risk of hip fracture were those with a low BUA index, a low cognition test score, and high mobility. Improving bone strength and awareness in older women may reduce the incidence of hip fractures.

title: Predictors of colorectal cancer screening of patients enrolled in a managed care health plan
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite increasing recognition of the importance of colorectal cancer screening in reducing cancer mortality, national screening rates are low, indicating an urgent need to understand the barriers and remedies to underutilization of CRC screening tests. METHODS: Using results from independent cross-sectional telephone surveys of patients aged > or = 50 years who entered before (2000"; n = 498) and after (2003; n = 482) a quality improvement intervention for CRC screening within a large managed care plan, trends and predictors of CRC screening with fecal occult blood testing (FOBT) and/or endoscopy (flexible sigmoidoscopy/colonoscopy) were examined from the patient perspective for each test, 23% for endoscopy and 22% for FOBT. In 2003, screening rates increased to 50% for all tests, 39% for endoscopy, and 24% for FOBT After discussing CRC with a doctor, the likelihood of having CRC screened (FOBT : odds ratio [OR], 2.09 [95% confidence interval (95% CI), 1.47-2.96] Endoscopy: OR, 2.33 [95% CI, 1.67-3.26]; and each test: OR, 2.86 [95% CI, 2.06-3.96]) and reporting Ba Errors for CRC generally reduced the likelihood of being screened (FOBT: OR, 0.76 [95% CI, 0.60-0.95]; Endoscopy: OR, 0.74 [95% CI, 0.60-0.92];” and each test: OR, 0.66 [95% CI, 0.54-0.80]). The 2 strongest determinants for obtaining CRC screening were provider influence and patient barriers associated with CRC screening in general, indicating the need for multi-level interventions targeting both provider and patient.

title: Predictors of fatigue 30 days after completion of adjuvant chemotherapy with anthracycline plus taxane in breast cancer
abstract: PURPOSES/OBJECTIVES: To identify the predictors of fatigue 30 days after completion of adjuvant chemotherapy for breast cancer and whether differences are observed between a behavioral sleep intervention and a healthy diet control group in predicting fatigue. DESIGN: Descriptive, exploratory secondary analysis of a randomized clinical trial. SETTING: Oncology outpatients in a Midwestern city. SAMPLE: 96 women, aged 29-83 years, 72% married, 95% white, diagnosed with stage I-IIIA breast cancer, receiving adjuvant anthracycline and taxane chemotherapy. METHODS: Participants were randomly assigned to a behavioral sleep intervention group or an attentional control group. Participants performed data collection before and during the peak and rebound days of the initial chemotherapy treatment cycle and after the last treatment. MAIN RESEARCH VARIABLES: Fatigue, circadian activity rhythms, objective and subjective sleep-wake and objective and subjective activity-rest rhythms. RESULTS: Predictors of fatigue were shorter total sleep time before treatment, higher pre-treatment and peak fatigue, and less energy after waking on rebound days. In the control group, the predictors of higher fatigue were higher pre-treatment fatigue, higher body mass index, higher number of positive lymph nodes, and fewer daytime dysfunctions. For the intervention group, lower peak activity at the peak of initial treatment was a different predictor of fatigue. CONCLUSIONS: Results suggest that participants in the sleep intervention group whose activity was sleep-balanced at the peak of initial treatment benefited most from the intervention. NURSING IMPLICATIONS: Nurses should screen for fatigue prior to initial chemotherapy and periodically, continue to screen for poor sleep in patients reporting fatigue of 4 or greater (on a 0-10 scale), and use evidence-based guidelines to select use appropriate interventions.

title: Predictors of HPV vaccine provider recommendation in young adult men and women: results of a cross-sectional survey
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although physician recommendation is one of the strongest predictors of human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination, it is unclear for whom physicians recommend the vaccine. To guide intervention efforts, this study examined predictors of participant-reported physician recommendation for HPV vaccination in young US adults. METHODS: Females and males (N=223) aged 18-26 years were recruited online through Craigslist, a popular classified advertising website. Ads ran from September 2013 to March 2014 in the 25 largest US cities. Participants completed a survey that evaluated demographic and sociopolitical characteristics, sexual history, HPV vaccination history, and whether they had ever received a recommendation for HPV vaccination from a doctor or healthcare provider. RESULTS: 53% reported receiving a referral for HPV vaccination and 45% had received >/= 1 dose of HPV vaccination.
