Participants who received a referral were over 35 times more likely to receive >/= 1 dose of HPV vaccine than participants without a referral. Bivariable and multivariable correlates of provider recommendation were identified. The results of the multivariable model indicated that younger (aged 18-21 years), female, white participants with health insurance (i.e., employer or other type, such as . CONCLUSIONS: The results suggest that the recommendations of the Physicians for HPV vaccination vary based on patient characteristics.The results underscore the key role of the healthcare provider in advancing HPV vaccination and have important implications for future HPV vaccine interventions in young adults.

title: Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Protocols (PRISMA-P) 2015: Elaboration and Explanation
abstract: Logs of systematic reviews and meta-analyses enable planning and documentation of review methods, protect against arbitrary decision-making during review conduct, allow readers to assess the existence of selective reporting based on completed reviews, and, when made publicly available, reduce duplication and possibly encourage collaboration. Evidence of selective reporting and excessive duplication of reviews on the same or similar issues is mounting, and calls have been made for support of documentation and public availability of review logs. Several efforts have been made in recent years to address these issues, including the development of an international registry of prospective reviews (PROSPERO) and the launch of the first open-access journal dedicated solely to the publication of systematic review products, including Protocols, dedicated (Systematic Reviews by BioMed Central). . To further this effort and building on the PRISMA guidelines (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses), an international group of experts has created a guideline to improve the transparency, accuracy, completeness and frequency of documented systematic reviews and meta-analyses protocols – PRISMA -P (for protocols) 2015. The PRISMA-P checklist contains 17 items considered essential and minimal components of a systematic review or meta-analysis protocol, full understanding and evidence of the necessity of each item, and a prime example from an existing published protocol. This paper should be read in conjunction with the PRISMA-P 2015 Statement. Authors and reviewers of systematic reviews are strongly encouraged to use PRISMA-P when creating and evaluating review protocols.

title: Prescribing habits of general practitioners when selecting an empiric antibiotic regimen for lower respiratory tract infections in adults in Sicily
abstract: The survey was conducted between September 1995 and May 1996 to describe the prescribing behavior among Sicilian General Practitioners (GPs) when choosing an empiric antibiotic regimen for LRTIs in adult patients and to initiate an educational process involving the same GPs in decisions regarding their prescribing and in enforcing local policies. Each doctor filled out a questionnaire for each therapeutic intervention, which ended with a prescription of antibiotics. The questionnaire also asked about the patient's characteristics, the diseases to be treated and the prescription of medication. Physicians were asked to provide an opinion on the infectious disease severity rating prior to selecting antibiotic treatment, in order to evaluate physicians' prescribing behavior in relation to the patient's symptoms. Of all the Sicilian GPs contacted, 76 doctors from 25 Sicilian cities with a patient population of 96,630 agreed to participate. The GPs used 49 different molecules and six different combinations of two antibiotics. The most commonly used antibiotics were cephalosporins (55.0%). Penicillins (11.7%), fluoroquinolones (11.4%), macrolides (10.1%), and combinations of penicillins with beta-lactamase inhibitors (7.9%) together accounted for 41.1% of the remaining antibiotic prescriptions out of. The choice of route of administration was significantly influenced by the patient's age, symptoms and signs of the disease, and the presence of comorbidities rather than bacteria suspected of causing the disease. The rather marked variation in antibiotic prescribing pattern for LRTIs among Sicilian GPs reflects the lack of availability or knowledge of local or national guidelines for treating these diseases.

title: Prescription data as an aid in the pharmacotherapy audit (I). General Considerations
abstract: This article discusses how prescription data provided by pharmacies can be used as a tool to support the improvement of prescribing behavior. For the optimal use of prescription data in the pharmacotherapeutic audit, the specific objective of the audit meeting must be clear. Next, appropriate measures (quality of drug selection, volume, cost) for presentation and discussion of the prescription must be selected. For some of the objectives of the audit meetings, suggestions for appropriate measures are made. For each stage of behavior change, the article describes why and how prescribing data can make a useful contribution. Finally, recommendations are given on the prerequisites for the optimal use of recipe data. Important factors are that the prescription data should adequately cover the physicians' patient population, information is needed on the extent of repeat prescriptions and the prescription of drugs with multiple indications can cause difficulties in the interpretation of the graphs. With this information in mind, prescribing feedback can be tailored to the needs of the study groups and targeted to the intended intervention.

title: Prescribing of non-occupational HIV prophylaxis after exposure by emergency physicians: An analysis of prescribing accuracy and compliance
abstract: We performed a retrospective analysis of data from a prospective nPEP (non-occupational post-exposure prophylaxis) registry based on patient consultations in an academic emergency department in Brussels, Belgium. Here we review 1,357 consultation cases from January 2011 to December 2013. The aim of the study is to determine whether emergency physicians prescribe nPEP according to national guidelines with the support of IDS (infectious disease specialists). Since this procedure is associated with high costs, we wanted to verify the correct assignment of treatment to high-risk patients. In addition, we wanted to determine whether adherence to nPEP when prescribed by an emergency physician differs from literature reports. Finally, we wanted to describe the population counseling for nPEP in our center. EMS physicians were more likely to prescribe nPEP for high-risk exposures (98.6%) compared to moderate-risk exposures (53.2%)";" appropriate allocation of resources from a public health perspective. The adequacy of the prescription when assessed according to the Belgian nPEP guidelines was 98.8%. Adherence to nPEP prescribed by emergency physicians was 60% in our study. Compliance was highest among MSM (men who have sex with men), while victims of sexual assault showed the lowest compliance. Overall, this study suggests that emergency physicians can safely and appropriately prescribe nPEP when supported by comprehensive guidelines. Recognizing intrinsic differences within heterogeneous populations counseling for nPEP can improve compliance with this costly public health intervention.

title: Prescription omega-3 fatty acids: a review for caregivers
abstract: Nurse practitioners (NPs) often take a multidisciplinary approach to treating and educating patients. Working with a registered dietitian is not uncommon when treating patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia (triglycerides [TGs] >/=500 mg/dL). Patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia should be managed and treated to normalize TG levels (TG levels < 150 mg/dL). Treatment for severe hypertriglyceridemia is often threefold, including lifestyle modifications, diet modification, and pharmacotherapy. Therapeutic lifestyle changes are generally the first step in lowering TG levels. Registered Dietitians promote a heart-healthy diet rich in fruits and vegetables. There is growing evidence supporting the consumption of eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid to lower TGs. When lifestyle and dietary changes do not effectively lower TGs, the NPs recommend pharmacological therapy as the next step. A viable pharmacological option includes prescription omega-3 (P-OM3) fatty acid ethyl esters. Each 4 g/day dose of P-OM3 provides 465 mg eicosapentaenoic acid and 375 mg docosahexaenoic acid. Clinical studies show that P-OM3 can safely and effectively lower TGs by 45% in patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia. Nurses play an important role in managing severe hypertriglyceridemia and educating patients about lifestyle and dietary changes that can have a profound impact on patient health.

title: Treatment of pressure ulcers: clinical guidelines
abstract: Like any intervention, clinical guidelines can and should be systematically evaluated. Evaluation is essential because an intervention that appears to improve care may not, in practice, do so. In addition, guidelines rely on behavior change on the part of practitioners, and failure to achieve this can undermine potential health gains. The key areas considered here are the assessment of the guidelines themselves and the assessment of their impact on care.

title: Prevalence of a healthy lifestyle among individuals with cardiovascular disease in high, middle, and low-income countries The Prospective Urban Rural Epidemiology (PURE) Study
abstract: Relevance Little is known about healthy lifestyle adoption among individuals with a coronary artery disease (CAD) or stroke event in communities in a number of countries worldwide. Aim To investigate the prevalence of avoidance or cessation of smoking, a healthy diet, and regular physical activity in people who have had a history of CAD or stroke. Design, Setting, and Participants Prospective Urban Rural Epidemiology (PURE) was a large, prospective cohort study that conducted an epidemiological survey of 153,996 adults aged 35 to 70 years from 628 urban and rural communities in 3 high-income countries (HIC), 7th Upper-middle-income countries (UMIC), 3 lower-middle-income countries (LMIC) and 4 low-income countries (LIC) included between January 2003 and December 2009. current, past, never), exercise level (low, <600 metabolic equivalent task [MET]-min/week; moderate, 600-3000 MET-min/week; high, >3000 MET-min/week), and diet (classified by the Food Frequency Questionnaire and defined using the Alternative Healthy Eating Index) Results Among 7519 people with self-reported CHD (earlier event: median, 5.0 [interquartile range {IQR}, 2.0-10.0] years ago) or stroke (earlier event: median, 4.0 [IQR, 2.0-8.0] years), 18.5% (95% CI, 17.6%-19.4%) continued to smoke, only 35.1 % (95% CI, 29.6%-41.0%) engaged in a high level of work- or leisure-related physical activity, and 39.0% (95% CI, 30.0%-48.7%) died become healthy; 14.3% (95% CI, 11.7% - 17.3%) have none of the 3 healthy lifestyles and 4.3% (95% CI, 3.1% - 5.8%) had all 3. A total of 52.5% (95% CI, 50.7%-54.3%) have quit smoking (by income country classification: 74.9% [95% CI, 71.1 %-78.6%] in HIC; 56.5% [95% CI, 53.4%-58.6%] at UMIC; 42.6% [95% CI, 39.6%-45.6%] in LMIC and 38.1% [95% CI, 33.1%-43.2%] in LIC). Physical activity levels increased with increasing national income, but this trend was not statistically significant. The lowest prevalence for a healthy diet was in LIC (25.8%; 95% CI, 13.0%-44.8%) compared to LMIC (43.2%; 95% CI, 30.0%-57). .4%), UMIC (45.1%, 95% CI, 30.9%-60.1%) and HIC (43.4%, 95% CI, 21.0%-68.7%) Conclusion and Relevance Among a sample of patients with an event of CHD or stroke from countries with different income levels, the prevalence of healthy lifestyles was low, and even lower in poorer countries.

title: Prevalence of Chlamydia trachomatis infection in women with cervical swab
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases in patients with normal and abnormal cervical swabs. DESIGN A prospective study of asymptomatic women with normal cervical swabs visiting their general practitioner and newly referred patients with abnormal swabs visiting a colposcopy clinic. SETTING A colposcopy clinic and urban general practice (list size 5500) in north west Glasgow. PARTICIPANTS 197 asymptomatic women visited their general practitioner for cervical swab testing and 101 randomly selected patients visited the colposcopy clinic for abnormal swab testing. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Presence of various sexually transmitted infections as determined by culture and serological testing. RESULTS Of the 101 women with cytologic abnormalities, six had current chlamydial infection demonstrated by culture and none had gonococcal infection";" Of the 197 women with normal swabs, 24 (12%) had chlamydial infection and two had gonorrhea. Serological studies of Chlamydia trachomatis-specific antibodies also showed that a large proportion of patients in both groups were exposed to this agent. There was no significant difference between the groups in the prevalence of any sexually transmitted disease examined. CONCLUSION There is a high prevalence of chlamydial infection in women in north-west Glasgow, regardless of their cervical cytologic status.

title: Prevalence of nonpolypoid (flat and depressed) colorectal neoplasms in asymptomatic and symptomatic adults
abstract: Context Colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death in the United States. Prevention has focused on the detection and removal of polypoid neoplasms. Data on the significance of nonpolyposis colorectal neoplasms (NP-CRNs) are limited. Objectives To determine the prevalence of NP-CRNs in a veteran hospital population and to characterize their association with colorectal cancer. Design, Setting, and Patients Cross-sectional study at a California Veterans Hospital of 1819 patients who underwent elective colonoscopy from July 2003 to June 2004. Results The overall prevalence of NP-CRNs was 9.35% (95% confidence interval [95% CI], 8.05%-10.78%; n=170). The prevalence of NP-CRNs in the subpopulations for screening, surveillance, and symptoms was 5.84% (95% CI, 4.13%-8.00%; n=36), 15.44% (95% CI, 12 .76%-18.44%; n=101) and 6.01% (95% CI, 4.17%-8.34%; n=33).The overall prevalence of NP-CRNs with in situ or submucosal invasive carcinoma was 0.82% (95% CI, 0.46%-1.36%; n=15), in the screening population the prevalence was 0.32% (95% CI, 0.04% -1.17%;n=2). Overall, NP-CRNs were more likely to contain carcinomas (odds ratio, 9.78; 95% CI, 3.93-24.4) than polypoid lesions, regardless of size. The positive size-adjusted association of NP-CRNs with in situ or submucosal invasive carcinomas was demonstrated also observed in subpopulations for screening (odds ratio 2.01; 95% CI 0.27-15.3) and surveillance (odds ratio 63.7; 95%). CI, 9.41-431). The depressed type had the highest risk (33%). Nonpolypoid colorectal neoplasms containing carcinoma were smaller in diameter compared to the polypoid ones (mean [SD] diameter, 15.9 [10.2] mm vs. 19.2 [9.6] mm). The procedure times have not changed significantly compared to historical controls. Conclusion In this group of experienced patients, NP-CRNs were relatively common lesions diagnosed during routine colonoscopy and had a greater association with carcinoma compared to polypoid neoplasms, regardless of size.

title: Prevalence of war-related mental illness and association with displacement status in post-war Jaffna District, Sri Lanka
abstract: Context Almost 2.7 million people worldwide are internally displaced (they seek refuge in safe areas of their own countries) each year by armed conflict. Although the psychological effects of war are well documented, less is known about the psychological symptoms of forced displacement among internally displaced people. Objectives To estimate the prevalence of the most common war-related mental illnesses, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms, anxiety and depression and to assess the association between displacement status and these disorders in post-war Jaffna District, Sri Lanka. Design, setting and participants Between July and September 2009, a multi-stage cross-sectional cluster sample survey was conducted among 1517 households in Jaffna district, including two IDP camps. The response rate was 92% (1448 respondents, 1409 eligible respondents). Two percent of participants (n=80) were currently displaced, 29.5% (n=539) were recently relocated, and 68.5% (n=790) were long-term residents. Bivariable analyses, followed by multivariable logistic regression models, were performed to determine the association between displacement status and mental health. Main Outcome Parameters Symptom criteria for PTSD, anxiety and depression as measured by the Harvard Trauma Questionnaire and the Hopkins Symptom Checklist C25. Results The overall prevalence of symptoms of PTSD, anxiety and depression was 7.0% (95% confidence interval [CI], 5.1% - 9.7%), 32.6% (95% CI, 28.5% - 36 .9%) and 22.2% (95% CI, 18.2%–26.5%). Currently displaced participants were more likely to report symptoms of PTSD (odds ratio [OR], 2.71", 95% CI, 1.28-5.73), anxiety (OR, 2.91; 95% CI, 1.89- 4.48) and depression (OR, 4.55; 95% CI, 2.47-8.39) compared to long-term residents. Recently resettled residents were more likely to report symptoms of PTSD (OR, 1.96; 95% KI, 1.11-3.47) compared to long-term residents. However, displacement was no longer associated with mental health symptoms after controlling for trauma exposure. Conclusion Among residents of Jaffna district of Sri Lanka, the prevalence of symptoms of war-related mental illness was significant and significantly associated with displacement status and underlying trauma burden.

title: Preventing and dealing with unprofessionalism in medical schools
abstract: Professionalism is a required competency for medical students, residents, practicing physicians, and academic faculty. Faculty members must adhere to codes of conduct or risk disciplines. The authors describe problems of unprofessionalism, culminating in allegations of scientific misconduct or the filing of complaints in academic medicine, and outline strategies for early intervention and prevention. The authors, vice and associate deans and executive directors of the office of faculty affairs at a major US medical school, have dealt with many allegations of unprofessional conduct over the past decade. They present case studies based on behaviors such as disrespect, inappropriate language and behavior, lack of cooperation with healthcare team members, and sexual harassment/discrimination. They discuss factors that make evaluating these behaviors difficult, including variable definitions of respect, different cultural norms, and false accusations. The authors provide recommendations for prevention and intervention, including early detection, performance management, sexual harassment education and referrals to professional coaches, anger management classes, and teacher support programs.

title: Caries prevention in young children of Bangladeshi immigrant families in New York: Maternal and pediatrician perspectives
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Childhood caries is common in South Asian immigrant families. Few children visit a dentist by the age of 12 months as recommended by current guidelines. The pediatric visit has important potential to connect children to preventative care. The aim of this study was to understand the barriers and promoters of caries prevention for young children of Bangladeshi immigrant families in New York. Qualitative data were collected as a preliminary step in developing an oral health counseling intervention for South Asian children. BASIC DESIGN: Qualitative interviews on child nutrition and oral health prevention were conducted with mothers from Bangladesh. Qualitative interviews were conducted with paediatricians on their experiences with care. The data were analyzed using standard qualitative approaches. SETTING: Pediatric practices for low-income Bangladeshi immigrants in New York City. PARTICIPANTS: 26 mothers of children aged 6-24 months receiving services in five pediatric facilities and 15 pediatricians serving these facilities. RESULTS: Both mothers and their pediatricians described risky feeding practices, communication problems, and lack of compliance. The oral health of young children has been a low priority for some mothers. However, most were concerned about childhood tooth decay but lacked the skills or resources to reduce the risk of tooth decay. CONCLUSIONS: The results support our plan to develop an empowerment-based counseling intervention to address the risk of caries in children. Pediatric dentists should be aware of the barriers to caries prevention in this group.

title: Preventing Child Abuse and Neglect with a Nursing Home Visitation Program: The Disabling Effects of Domestic Violence
abstract: Context Home visits to families with young children have been promoted as an effective means of preventing child abuse, but few studies have examined the conditions under which such programs achieve this goal. Aim To investigate whether the presence of domestic violence limits the impact of nursing home visits on reducing reasonable reports of child abuse and neglect. Design Fifteen-year follow-up of a randomized trial. A semi-rural community in upstate New York. Participants Of 400 socially disadvantaged pregnant women with no previous live births who were consecutively admitted between April 1978 and September 1980, 324 mothers and their children participated in the follow-up study. Interventions Families were randomized to receive routine perinatal care (control group; n = 184 attended follow-up), routine care plus home visits by nurses during pregnancy (n = 100), or routine care plus home visits by nurses during pregnancy assigned and until the child's second birthday (n = 116). Key Outcome Measures Number of substantiated reports over the entire 15-year period involving the study child as a subject regardless of the offender's identity or the mother as an offender regardless of the child's identity extracted from state records and analyzed by treatment group and extent of domestication Domestic violence as measured by the Conflict Tactics Scale. Results Families who received home visits during pregnancy and infancy had significantly fewer reports of child abuse involving the mother as the perpetrator (p=0.01) or the study child as the subject (p=0.04) than families who did not receive home visits. The number of reports of abuse in mothers who received home visits only during pregnancy did not differ from the control group. For mothers who received visits up to the child's second birthday, the treatment effect decreased with increasing levels of domestic violence. Of those women who reported 28 or fewer incidents of domestic violence (79% of the sample), home-visiting mothers had significantly fewer incidents of child abuse over the 15-year period than mothers who did not receive longer-term intervention (p=0.01). However, this intervention did not significantly reduce child abuse among mothers who reported more than 28 incidents of domestic violence (21% of the sample). Conclusions The presence of domestic violence can limit the effectiveness of interventions in reducing incidents of child abuse and neglect.

title: Prevention of coronary heart disease and stroke with aggressive statin therapy in older adults using a team management model
abstract: PURPOSE: The purpose of this review was to highlight recent results from clinical trials on the safety and efficacy of statin therapy in adults aged 65 years and older and to examine how Nurses Practitioners (NPs) and Doctor Assistants (PAs) work with physicians as collaborators team to better address the needs of this fastest-growing subset of the US population, which is at high risk for cardiovascular events, including stroke. DATA SOURCES: This report was compiled by reviewing the scientific literature on the safety and efficacy of statin therapy, including impact on cardiovascular, coronary, and stroke endpoints, with particular reference to clinical trial results in elderly patients. CONCLUSIONS: Recent guidelines emphasize that age alone is not a reason to discontinue statin treatment in older adults. Despite the evidence highlighted in this review showing that older patients can safely benefit from statin therapy, studies have consistently shown an inverse relationship between age and treatment propensity. Older patients often have multiple risk factors and many chronic comorbidities that appear to complicate and hinder treatment in many busy clinical practices. More comprehensive guidelines for statin use in older patients, including recommendations for treatment goals and developing a framework for statin use in stroke prevention, would assist healthcare providers in treating this high-risk population. Finally, NPs and PAs are both well trained and well positioned to treat patients with chronic stable cardiovascular disease (CVD). PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: Implementing a multidisciplinary team approach to identifying those at risk and providing them with education, counseling and effective statin treatment will support efforts to reduce the increased risk of cardiovascular disease-related morbidity and mortality in older adults.

title: Prevention of depression in at-risk youth: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Initial situation Adolescent offspring of depressed parents have a significantly increased risk of developing depressive disorders. Although some smaller targeted prevention studies have found that the risk of depression can be reduced, these findings have yet to be replicated and extended to large at-risk populations in different settings. Aim To determine the impact of a group cognitive-behavioral (CB) prevention program compared to usual care in preventing onset of depression. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS A multicenter, randomized, controlled study conducted in 4 US cities, enrolled 316 adolescent (aged 13-17 years) offspring of parents with current or previous major depressive disorders from August 2003 to February 2006 were recruited. Adolescents had a history of depression, current elevated but sub-diagnostic depressive symptoms, or both. Assessments were conducted at baseline, after the 8-week intervention, and after the 6-month extension period. Intervention Adolescents were randomly assigned to the CB prevention program, which consisted of 8 weekly 90-minute group sessions followed by 6 monthly maintenance sessions, or were assigned to usual care alone. Main outcome measures Rate and hazard ratio (HR) of a probable or definite depressive episode (i.e. depressive symptom score of ≥ 4) for at least 2 weeks, as diagnosed by clinical interviewers. Results During follow-up after the continuation session, the rate and heart rate of depressive episodes were lower in participants in the CB prevention program than in those in usual care (21.4% vs. 32.7%; HR 0.63; 95% confidence interval [ CI ], 0.40–0.98) Adolescents in the CB prevention program also showed significantly greater improvement in self-reported depressive symptoms than those in usual care (coefficient, ?1.1; z = ?2.2; P = 0 ,03). Baseline moderated intervention effects (HR, 5.98; 95% CI, 2.29-15.58; P=0.001) In adolescents whose parents were not depressed at baseline, the CB prevention program was more effective in preventing onset of depression than the usual treatment (11.7% vs. 40.5%; HR: 0.24; 95% CI: 0.11-0.50) during the CB prevention program in adolescents with a currently depressed parent was no more effective than usual treatment in preventing depression (31.2% vs. 24.3%; HR, 1.43; 95% CI, 0.76-2.67). Conclusion The CB prevention program had a significant preventive effect based on both clinical diagnoses and self-reported depressive symptoms during the 9-month follow-up period, but this effect was not evident in adolescents with a currently depressed parent.

title: Fall prevention among older adults in shared accommodation: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement
abstract: DESCRIPTION: Update to the 1996 US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) Recommendation Statement on Advice on the Prevention of Home and Leisure Injuries, Including Falls. METHODS: The USPSTF reviewed emerging evidence on the effectiveness and harms of primary care interventions for fall prevention among older adults living in communities. Interventions were grouped into 5 main categories: multifactorial clinical assessment (with or without direct intervention), clinical management (with or without screening), clinical education or behavioral counseling, home hazard modification, and exercise or physical therapy. RECOMMENDATIONS: The USPSTF recommends exercise or physical therapy and vitamin D supplementation to prevent falls in ambulatory adults aged 65 years and older who are at increased risk of falls. (Grade B Recommendation) The USPSTF does not recommend automatically conducting an in-depth multifactorial risk assessment in conjunction with comprehensive management of identified risks to prevent falls in community-dwelling adults aged 65 years and older because the likelihood of benefit is low. In deciding whether this service is appropriate in an individual case, patients and clinicians should weigh the benefits and harms based on the circumstances of previous falls, comorbid conditions, and the patient's values. (Recommendation grade C).

title: Preventive Care Advised (PCA)/ Operative Care Advised (OCA) - Categorization of caries by management option
abstract: number of systems and classifications are currently used by clinicians, epidemiologists and clinical researchers to classify carious lesions into various grades. These systems are based on the depth of the lesion and/or the presence/absence of macroscopic cavitation. In order to improve the validity and comparability of such systems in the face of increasing knowledge about disease course, lesion behavior and caries management options, the authors propose a new categorization system that distinguishes between lesions that usually require surgical intervention and those that do not require surgical intervention. In the future, it is proposed that diagnostic systems, in addition to the existing conventional criteria, also include the reporting of results in the form of 1) lesions for which appropriate non-invasive preventive treatment is recommended (PCA lesions) and 2) lesions for which surgery is performed should allow caution (OCA lesions). For certain specific applications, locally acceptable subdivisions may need to be developed and agreed. The adoption of this additional nomenclature and approach in the future should support communication between the different groups involved in caries diagnosis and research. It can facilitate the dissemination of research results and help "drive" researchers working on caries diagnostic methods to focus on techniques that help in the accurate assessment of lesion activity and behavior. Such a focus should also improve our understanding of treatment decisions and encourage the development of clinical guidelines. The possibility to keep existing criteria in parallel for local and other purposes would preserve comparability with previously collected data.

title: Preventive Evidence into Practice (PEP) Study: Implementation of Guidelines for the Prevention of Primary Vascular Diseases in the General Practice Protocol for a Cluster-Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: There are significant gaps in the implementation and uptake of evidence-based guideline recommendations for cardiovascular disease (CVD) and diabetes in Australian general practice. This study protocol describes the methodology for a cluster-randomized study to assess the effectiveness of a model designed to improve implementation of these guidelines in Australian general practice, developed by a collaboration between researchers, NGOs and the profession. METHODS: We anticipate that the intervention will change physician and patient behavior, resulting in improved assessment of lifestyle and physiological risk factors (by 20%) and increased adherence to guideline recommendations for: the management of cardiovascular and diabetic Risk factors (by 20%)" and lifestyle and physiological risk factors of at-risk patients (by 5%). Thirty-two primary care practices will be randomized in a 1:1 allocation to either receive the intervention or continue usual care, after stratification by state. The Intervention is delivered through: small group instruction; review of patient records to determine preventive treatment;" and practice facilitation visits adapted to the needs of practices. Outcome data is extracted from electronic medical records and patient questionnaires, and a qualitative assessment from provider and patient interviews is performed. DISCUSSION: We plan to disseminate the study results widely and directly inform implementation strategies of governments, professional associations and non-governmental organisations, including partner organisations.

title: Preventive interventions for postnatal psychosis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Postnatal psychosis is a life-threatening condition worldwide, affecting one to two in 1000 new mothers. It has an abrupt onset within a month of birth. Affected young mothers quickly develop overt psychosis, cognitive impairment, and disorganized behaviors. Factors that increase the risk of postnatal psychosis include being a single mother, elderly women, or women with a psychiatric history and family history of mood disorder, prenatal depression, and autoimmune thyroid dysfunction. The risk of future postnatal recurrence is 25% to 57%. Preventive interventions for postnatal psychosis aim to identify women with risk factors, to detect an impending psychosis early through screening, and to carry out preventive drug therapy. Mood stabilizers, antipsychotics, and hormonal therapy may be helpful in preventing postnatal psychotic episodes in women at risk. OBJECTIVES: To examine the best available evidence for interventions to prevent postnatal psychosis. SEARCH METHODS: We searched the Cochrane Schizophrenia Group Trials Register and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) in October 2012 using the Cochrane Schizophrenia Group search strategy. SELECTION CRITERIA: All randomized controlled trials relevant to the prevention of postnatal psychosis. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two review authors checked all citations to ensure reliable selection. When we included relevant studies, we planned to assess the methodological quality of the identified studies using the criteria recommended in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions. Two review authors independently extracted data. For homogeneous dichotomous data, we planned to calculate the risk ratio (RR), 95% confidence interval (CI), and number required to show benefit/harm of treatment (NNTB/NNTH) on an intention-to-treat basis . MAIN RESULTS: There were no included studies in this review. The electronic search yielded three relevant references, among which we identified two old planned studies that appeared never to have started and one that we excluded as a study because it was a case series report. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: This is not an empty review - it is a review full of unanswered questions. Despite the growing interest in women's mental health, the literature in the field of postnatal psychosis is still very limited. It appears that clinicians have no choice but to continue with their current practice, which is guided solely by differing clinical judgements. Women at risk of postnatal psychosis and their families are entitled to be disappointed in the medical/research community. A post hoc PubMed topic search (not method specific) identified mainly case series. Policy makers have no trial-based evidence to base their policies on. Certainly, preventive interventions for postnatal psychosis are difficult to justify without well-designed, well-conducted, and well-documented randomized trials. Available publications suggest that such studies are possible, and research funders may wish to make this work a priority.

title: Adherence to guidelines for the management of chronic musculoskeletal pain by primary care physicians: results of the study on the effectiveness of a collaborative pain approach
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We assessed the standard of care provided by the primary care physician as documented in patients' medical records, predictors of documented standard of care, and their association with pain-related functioning. The patients were participants in a randomized study of the cooperative treatment of chronic musculoskeletal pain. The intervention included patient and primary care physician education, symptom monitoring, and intervention team feedback to physicians. METHODS: To assess compliance with the evidence-based treatment guidelines on which our intervention was based, we developed an 8-point chart review tool, the Pain Process Checklist (PPC). We then reviewed the electronic medical records of 365 long-term patients treated by 42 general practitioners over a 12-month period. Intervention status, demographic, and clinical variables were tested as predictors of PPC scores using generalized estimating equations (GEE). GEE was also used to test whether PPC scores predicted treatment response (>/=30% decrease in Roland-Morris Disability Questionnaire score). RESULTS: The rates of documented guideline-compliant care varied widely between the PPC items, from 94% of patients with pain to 17% of patients on opioids with addressed adverse events. Intervention status was unrelated to item scores, and PPC-7 total scores were not significantly different between intervention and treat-as-usual patients (61.2%, standard error [SE] = 3.3% vs 55.2%, SE = 2.6%, P = 0.15 ). In a multivariate model, higher PPC-7 scores were associated with opioid prescription (odds ratio [OR] = 1.07, P = 0.007) and lower PPC-7 scores with patient age (10-year difference OR = 0.97, P = 0.004). Finally, intervention patients who received quantitative pain and depression assessments were less likely to respond to treatment (assessed vs. not: 18% vs. 33%, P=0.008 and 13% vs. 28%, P=0.001, respectively). CONCLUSIONS: As measured by medical record review, additional training and clinical feedback did not result in improved delivery of documented, guideline-compliant pain care, and adherence to guidelines by primary care physicians did not improve clinical outcomes for patients with chronic musculoskeletal pain.

title: Experiences of primary care physicians prescribing HIV preexposure prophylaxis at a specialty community health center in Boston: lessons from first-time users
abstract: INTRODUCTION: An estimated 1.2 million Americans have indications for the use of preexposure antiretroviral prophylaxis (PrEP) to prevent HIV infection. For many of these at-risk individuals, the best opportunity to learn about and receive PrEP is during routine visits to their general practitioners. However, few general practitioners have prescribed PrEP, mainly due to practical concerns about the provision of PrEP in primary care. The experiences of specialist primary care physicians who have prescribed PrEP may shed light on the feasibility of general practitioner provision of PrEP. METHODS: From January to February 2015, 35 primary care physicians at a Boston community health center specializing in the care of sexual and gender minorities completed anonymous surveys regarding their experiences and practices with the provision of PrEP. Responses were analyzed using descriptive statistics. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION: Thirty-two physicians (response rate = 91%) completed the surveys. Almost all physicians (97%) had prescribed PrEP (median 20 patients, interquartile range 11-33). Most clinicians reported risk reduction testing and counseling practices that follow US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention guidelines for PrEP. Clinicians noted that drug toxicity was uncommon in patients using PrEP and adherence was generally reported to be high. However, the practices of some clinicians deviated from guideline recommendations, and some clinicians observed patients with increased risk behaviors. Most clinicians (79%) rated PrEP care as easy to achieve, and 97% thought they were likely to prescribe PrEP in the future. CONCLUSIONS: At a primary care hospital with specialized expertise in HIV prevention, clinicians felt that PrEP administration was safe, feasible, and potentially effective for a large number of patients. Efforts to involve general practitioners in PrEP care could facilitate the scale-up of this effective intervention.

title: Primary care guidelines on counseling practices: The effectiveness of computer-based versus paper-based versions. A cluster-randomized controlled trial among newly qualified general practitioners.
abstract: Aim: To compare the impact of computer-based and paper-based versions of guidelines on the office practice of newly qualified physicians. METHODS: Two-arm, randomized, controlled study. Physicians were randomized to receive computerized or textbook-based versions of the same guidelines for a 4-week study period. Physician compliance with guideline recommendations on laboratory, radiological, physical and other examinations, procedures, non-pharmacological and pharmacological treatments, physical therapy, and referrals was measured by reviewing case notes. Results: The study involved 139 recently qualified physicians working in 96 primary health care centers in Finland. Data on 4,633 patient contacts were abstracted, of which 3,484 were suitable for further analysis. Physician compliance with guidelines was high (over 80% using laboratory, radiology, physical exams and referrals). There were no significant differences in the physicians' counseling practices on any of the measured outcomes between the computer and textbook groups. Conclusion: Guidelines are a useful source of information for newly qualified physicians working in primary care. However, how the guidance is presented (electronically or on paper) does not affect the use of the guidance or its impact on decisions. Other factors should be considered when choosing the method of presenting guidelines, such as: B. Time to search for information, ease of use during the consultation, ability to be updated, cost of production and the doctor's own preferences.

title: Response of general practitioners to the dissemination of practice guidelines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Much effort has been expended to produce guidelines for clinical practice, but relatively few studies address dissemination issues. If no guidelines are used, little is gained. This study evaluates the effect of three methods of disseminating asthma guidelines on physician behavior and attitudes towards educational strategies. METHODS: Asthma guidelines were mailed to 60 physicians at three Area Health Education Centers in Arkansas. One-site dissemination efforts included a brief synopsis, phone calls from physicians with "details," and a medical education conference. Computer strategies were used at the second site and a multi-media approach was used at the third site with faxes, posters, videocassettes, audiocassettes and a medical education conference. A fourth location with 22 participants served as a comparison. Data were collected through mailed questionnaires, outpatient medical records, and physician interviews. Changes between baseline and posttest assessments after a 4-month intervention were calculated for medication intake and peak flow monitoring was compared to the control group (general linear model). Regression analyzes were used to identify physician and practice factors associated with specific training techniques. RESULTS: Each site improved with use of medication or peak flow monitoring, but none improved in all areas. The multimedia, continuous-recall approach was well accepted, but there was little support for the computational strategies. CONCLUSIONS: Further efforts to disseminate clinical guidelines should include a variety of formats, with an emphasis on short, concise summaries and frequent reminders. Social influence seems to play a role and will be a fertile area for further research.

title: Use of lumbar spine imaging tests by general practitioners: impact of guidelines and feedback on practice patterns
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To reduce variability in primary care physician use of lumbar spine imaging techniques. DESIGN: Controlled intervention using clinical practice guidelines and feedback on practice patterns. STUDY SAMPLE: Sixty-seven internists and 28 general practitioners in a large group model HMO. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: Physicians in the intervention group received the clinical practice guideline for low back pain, followed by three bimonthly feedback reports on their current usage rates of lumbar spine radiographs and computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging of the lumbar spine. Physicians in the control group received neither the guideline nor the feedback reports. Automated radiology usage data was used to compare changes in usage rates and variability in usage rates among intervention- and control-group physicians over the study period. Neither guideline alone nor guideline plus feedback was associated with a significant decrease in usage rates or variability in usage rates for the lumbar spine imaging modalities studied. CONCLUSIONS: Clinical practice guidelines and practice pattern feedback fail to achieve their goals if characteristics of the practice environment and patient expectations and behaviors are not identified and considered.

title: GP recruitment is associated with smoking cessation counseling and referral
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Most primary care providers (PCPs) support the importance of smoking cessation, but rates of counseling are low. We assessed the consistency of PCP's attitudes towards smoking cessation counseling and corresponding smoking cessation behaviors. DESIGN: This was a post-interventional analysis of a population-based sample from a randomized controlled group study of improving adherence to smoking cessation guidelines. SETTING: A total of 18 VA locations in the Southwest and Western United States participated. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 280 primary care physicians completed a survey 12 months after implementing a quality improvement (QI) program for smoking cessation. Their patients also completed 12 (n=1080) and 18 months (n=924) follow-up surveys. INTERVENTION: The quality improvement intervention included setting local priorities, developing, implementing and monitoring quality improvement plans. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: GPs at intervention sites were more likely to report having counseled patients on smoking cessation (P=0.04), but no referral. PCP attitudes to smoking cessation counseling were strongly associated with reported counseling (P<0.001) and with referral (P=0.01). Other associations with counseling were the perceived barrier "patients are not interested in quitting" (P=0.01) and fewer years in practice (P=0.03)"; other associations with referral were specialist consultation (P<0.0001) and the perceived barrier of “not convenient referral” (P=0.001) (negative association). PCP attitudes were associated with higher rates of counseling, referral, and program participation. CONCLUSIONS: PCPs had attitudes consistent with their reported smoking cessation behaviors regardless of intervention participation, and more positive attitudes were associated with higher rates of patient-reported smoking cessation behaviors. The results suggest that primary care physicians who advocate smoking cessation counseling and referral may provide more treatment recommendations and have higher rates of smoking cessation.

title: Smoking cessation interventions by primary care physicians and smoking cessation among participants in the National Lung Screening Trial
abstract: IMPORTANT: The National Lung Screening Trial (NLST) found a reduction in lung cancer mortality in participants screened with low-dose computed tomography compared to chest radiography. In February 2015, Medicare announced its decision to cover annual lung screening for patients with a significant history of smoking. These guidelines encourage smoking cessation treatment as an adjunct to screening, but the incidence and effectiveness of clinically delivered smoking cessation interventions administered after lung screening is unknown. OBJECTIVE: To determine the association between the reported physician-provided 5As (ask, advise, assess, support [talk about quitting or recommend smoking cessation medication, or recommend counseling] and arrange follow-up) after lung screening and changes in smoking behavior. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: A matched case-control study (cases were quitters and controls were continued smokers) of 3336 NLST participants who were smokers at enrollment examined the rates and patterns of participants' 5A administration after lung screening and reported on smoking cessation behavior. MAIN FINDINGS AND MEASURES: Prevalence of physician-delivered 5As and associated smoking cessation after lung screening. RESULTS: The delivery of the 5As 1 year after screening was as follows: ask, 77.2%; advise, 75.6%; rate, 63.4%; support, 56.4%; and arrange aftercare, 10.4%. and assessment was not significantly associated with quitting in multivariate models adjusted for sociodemographic characteristics, medical history, screening outcomes, nicotine dependence, and motivation to quit. 95% CI, 1.21-1.63), and organizing was associated with a 46% increase in the likelihood of quitting (odds ratio, 1.46; 95% CI, 1.19-1.79). Smoking GPs who participated in the NLST were associated with increased cessation rates; less intensive interventions (questioning, counseling, and rating) were not. However, rates of support and arranged follow-up were relatively low. Our results confirm the need and benefit of physicians to take more active intervention steps to help patients undergoing screening to quit smoking.

title: The responsiveness of general practitioners to unhealthy behavior in adolescent patients
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate physician responsiveness to unhealthy behaviors reported by adolescent patients during a comprehensive visit to clinical screening services. DESIGN: Non-probability sample of adolescent patients scheduled for routine physical examination. SETTING: Seven clinical sites in the Chicago, Illinois area. PARTICIPANTS: Fifteen general practitioners and 95 adolescent patients between 11 and 18 years of age. INTERVENTION: Providers provided comprehensive clinical preventive services to adolescent patients using the model of adolescent preventive services guidelines. This model includes screening, counseling, a physical exam, and immunizations. Prior to the visit, the adolescent patients completed a screening questionnaire that included a 52-item health risk behavior profile. The responses to the screening questionnaire were discussed during the visit. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Each provider's responsiveness to reported unhealthy behaviors was determined by comparing the adolescent patient's responses on the screening questionnaire to those reported during a debriefing session with the adolescent to determine whether specific topics were discussed. Responsiveness to highly sensitive behaviors was determined by comparing the screening questionnaire and medical record. RESULTS: On average, each adolescent patient reported 10 risk behaviors, 7 of which were discussed. The severity of the reported risky behavior, the number of reported biological health concerns, and the gender of the adolescent patient were significant predictors of provider responsiveness. The number of unhealthy behaviors reported, length of visit, physician's job role and gender, whether the adolescent was a new patient, and the age of the adolescent patient were unrelated to responsiveness. CONCLUSIONS: Providers responded to most unhealthy behaviors reported during a single visit, but responsiveness decreased when 3 or more biological health concerns or relatively serious problems were reported. Steps can be taken to increase vendor responsiveness.

title: Basic services, generalism, common good: Déjà vu? Once again!
Primary care-based, multifaceted, interdisciplinary medical education intervention for patients with systolic heart failure: lessons from a cluster-randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Chronic (systolic) heart failure (CHF) is a common and disabling condition. Adherence to evidence-based guidelines in primary care has been shown to improve health outcomes. The aim was to investigate the impact of a multidisciplinary training intervention for general practitioners (GPs) (Train the Trainer = TTT) on patient and performance outcomes. METHODS: This paper presents the key findings from the study and discusses the lessons learned during the conduct of the TTT study. General practitioner practices were randomly assigned to the TTT intervention or the control group. 37 general practitioners (18 TTT, 19 controls) were randomized and 168 patients with diagnosed CHF (91 TTT, 77 controls) were included. GPs in the intervention group participated in four meetings to provide clinical practice guidelines and feedback on pharmacotherapy. The primary endpoint was patient self-reported quality of life at seven months using the SF-36 physical functioning scale. Secondary endpoints included other SF-36 scales, Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire (KCCQ), all-cause mortality, heart failure hospitalizations, prescription, major depressive disorder (PHQ-9), behavior change (European Heart Failure Self-Care Behavior Scale), patient -Perceived quality of care (EUROPEP) and heart failure improvement using NT-proBNP values. As the recruitment goals were not met, an exploratory analysis was performed. RESULTS: For many endpoints, there was high baseline power in both groups. At seven months, there was no significant mean difference between groups for the primary outcome measure (-3.3, 95% CI -9.7 to 3.1, p=0.30). The only difference in secondary outcomes related to primary care physician prescription of aldosterone antagonists in the intervention group, with significant differences between groups at follow-up (42 vs. 24%, adjusted OR = 4.0, 95% CI 1.2- 13";" p=0.02). CONCLUSION: The intervention did not change the primary endpoint or most of the secondary endpoints. Recruitment goals were not met, and under-recruitment of practices and patients, and selection bias among participating general practitioners preclude firm conclusions, but the CI indicates ineffectiveness of the intervention in this sample. We describe lessons learned from conducting the study for future planning and conduct of confirmatory studies in primary care. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN08601529.

title: Smoking interventions in primary care
abstract: Primary care is an important venue for promoting smoking cessation. Randomized clinical trials (RCTs) testing the effects of brief smoking interventions and comprehensive programs in a primary care setting provide excellent evidence that such interventions significantly increase patients' smoking cessation rates and that the effect increases with increasing dose of the intervention. Unfortunately, despite the widespread dissemination of guidelines for prevention services and the positive attitudes of physicians towards such services, the current level of delivery of smoking cessation interventions by physicians in real settings is not high, making this a major research and public health concern . Interventions to increase implementation rate Provider-delivered brief smoking interventions can be broadly classified into the following groups: provider education, clinical systems and procedures (e.g., patient screening and follow-up); and organizational policies (e.g., reimbursement, coverage, performance measurements). Given the significant impact that primary care interventions can have on smoking cessation, it is important to investigate methods to increase their delivery rate and impact. Examples of research questions to motivate intervention are: What are the best incentives or combinations of incentives for physicians? What are the most effective strategies for reminding vendors to intervene? How can these best be implemented in different types of environments and systems? How can a step care and patient treatment matching model be used? Examination of factors such as reimbursement policies and services covered does not lend itself well to tightly controlled randomized trials. Therefore, the use of quasi-experimental designs and the application of qualitative strategies are required. These designs present a different challenge for the research community.

title: Primary coronary intervention (PCI) within the heart attack network system in a German city (Essen)
abstract: In a large German city (Essen, 490,000 inhabitants), a new network system for patients with ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) was set up in 2004. This included a so-called integrated care model (IV model) with the participation of health insurance companies. In a cooperative structure between invasive and non-invasive hospitals, general practitioners and cardiologists as well as emergency services, it was possible to ensure that every patient with STEMI is treated with primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) as quickly as possible in accordance with the current guidelines. The patient characteristics (age, gender, comorbidity, medication) were comparable to other studies and registries. The primary success rate was high (96.4%). Acute in-hospital outcomes showed low mortality (7.6%). The delay times were comparable to other registers. The symptom-to-balloon time was 239 min, the medical contact-to-balloon time 95 min, the door-to-balloon time 60 min and the puncture-to-balloon time 18 min (median values). The STEMI network system in Essen demonstrates the possibility of modern therapy for patients with heart attacks (primary PCI) in a cooperative modality between all participants in the healthcare system.

title: Primary prevention of type 2 diabetes mellitus and cardiovascular disease with a cognitive behavioral program targeting lifestyle modifications in at-risk individuals: design of a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: The number of people with cardiovascular disease (CVD) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is growing rapidly. A large part of this increase is due to lifestyle-related risk factors such as obesity, lack of exercise and an unhealthy diet. Changing these risk factors has the potential to delay or prevent the development of T2DM and CVD. It is hypothesized that a cognitive behavioral program (CBP) specifically focused on motivation and self-management in individuals at high risk for cardiovascular disease and/or T2DM will improve their lifestyle behaviors and, as a result, reduce their risk of developing T2DM and CVD. METHODS: 12,000 residents aged 30 to 50 years living in several communities in the semi-rural region of West Friesland are invited by their general practitioner (n = 13) to measure their own waist circumference with a tape measure. Individuals with abdominal obesity (male waist >/= 102 cm, female waist >or= 88 cm) will be invited to participate in the second step of the screening, which includes blood pressure, a blood sample, and anthropometric measurements. T2DM and CVD risk scores are then calculated according to the ARIC and SCORE formulas, respectively. Individuals with a score indicating high risk of developing T2DM and/or CVD are then randomly assigned to the intervention group (n=300) or the control group (n=300). Participants in the intervention group follow a CBP goal in changing their diet, physical activity, and smoking behavior. Motivational Interviewing (MI) and Problem Solving Treatment (PST) are used as counseling methods, which are aimed in particular at intrinsic motivation for change and self-management of problems on the part of the participants. The CBP is administered by trained nurses in the participant's general practice and consists of a maximum of six individual 30-minute sessions, followed by 3-month refresher sessions via telephone. Control group participants receive booklets with health guidelines on physical activity and diet, and smoking cessation. The primary outcome measures are changes in T2DM and CVD risk scores. Secondary outcome measures are changes in lifestyle behavior and cost-effectiveness and value for money. All relevant direct and indirect costs are measured and followed up for 24 months. DISCUSSION: Behavior change is difficult, requiring time, significant effort, and motivation. The combination of the two counseling methods MI and PST, followed by refresher sessions, can lead to a lasting change in behavior. STUDY REGISTRATION: Current controlled studies ISRCTN59358434.

title: Preparing for hand hygiene compliance in clinical settings
abstract: Introduction: Effective hand hygiene is the single most important measure to prevent nosocomial infections. Traditional information/education-based interventions have shown only modest benefits for compliance. This study aimed to investigate whether priming via olfactory and visual cues affects hand hygiene compliance. Method: Randomized controlled trial in a surgical intensive care unit (SICU) of a teaching hospital in Miami, Florida. The primary outcome data included observations – a mix of healthcare professionals and service users were observed entering the SICU by two trained observers and their hand hygiene compliance was independently verified. Interventions included either an olfactory primer (clean citrus smell) or a visual primer (male or female eyes). The primary endpoint was hand hygiene compliance (HHC) as measured by the visitor using the hand gel dispenser. Results: At the 5% level, there was significant evidence that a clean citrus smell significantly improved HHC (46.9% vs. 15.0%, p=0.0001). A significant improvement in HHC was observed when an image of “male eyes” was superimposed over the hand gel dispenser compared to the control group (33.3% vs. 15.0%, p<0.038). No significant improvement in HHC was observed when an image of female eyes was overlaid on the same hand gel dispenser (10.0% vs. 15.0%, p=0.626). Conclusions: This is one of the first studies to show that priming can affect HHC in a clinical setting. The results suggest that priming interventions could be used to change other behaviors relevant to public health. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Printed educational materials: Implications for professional practice and health care outcomes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Printed educational materials (PEMs) are widely used passive dissemination strategies to improve knowledge, awareness, attitudes, skills, professional practice, and patient outcomes. Traditionally presented in paper formats such as monographs, publications in peer-reviewed journals, and clinical guidelines, they appear to be the most commonly used method of disseminating information. OBJECTIVES: To determine the effectiveness of PEMs in improving process outcomes (including healthcare professional behavior) and patient outcomes. To investigate whether the impact of characteristics of PEMs (e.g., source, content, format, mode of delivery, timing/frequency, complexity of desired behavior change) can affect process outcomes (including healthcare professional behavior and patient outcomes). SEARCH STRATEGY: The following electronic databases were searched up to July 2006: (a) The EPOC Group Specialized Register (including the database of studies to be assessed (see “Specialised Register” under “Group Details”)”; (b) The Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) and the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effectiveness;" (c) MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, and CAB Health. An updated search of MEDLINE was conducted in March 2007. SELECTION CRITERIA: We included randomized controlled trials ( RCTs ) , controlled clinical trials (CCT), controlled before-and-after studies (CBAs), and interrupted time series analyzes (ITS) that assessed the impact of printed educational materials on healthcare professional practice and/or patient outcomes.There was no language restriction.Any objective measure of professional performance (e.g. number of tests ordered, prescriptions for a particular drug) or di e Health outcomes of the patient (e.g. B. blood pressure, number of caesarean sections) are included again. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Four reviewers independently performed data abstraction using a modified version of the EPOC data collection checklist. Any disagreements were resolved through discussions between the assessors and arbitrators. The statistical analysis was based on considering dichotomous process outcomes, continuous process outcomes, dichotomous patient outcome measurements, and continuous patient outcome measurements. We have presented the results for all comparisons using a standard presentation method whenever possible. We reported separately for each study the median effect size for each outcome type and the median of these effect sizes across studies. MAIN RESULTS: Twenty-three studies were included in this review. Evidence from this review indicated that PEMs appear to have little positive impact on professional practice. RCTs comparing PEMs with no intervention observed a median absolute risk difference: +4.3% for categorical process outcomes (eg, x-ray requests, prescription, and smoking cessation activities) (range -8.0% to +9.6% , 6 studies) and a relative risk difference +13.6% for continuous process outcomes (eg, medication change, X-ray requests per practice) (range -5.0% to +26.6%, 4 studies). These results are similar to those reported for the ITS studies, although significantly larger effect sizes were observed (relative risk difference ranges from 0.07% to 31%). In contrast, the median effect size for categorical measures of patient outcome (eg, screening, return to work, smoking cessation) was -4.3% (range -0.4% to -4.6%, 3 studies)). Two studies reported worsening patient outcomes (eg, depression score, smoking cessation attempts) of -10.0% and -20.5%, respectively. A study comparing PEMs to educational workshops found minimal differences. Two studies comparing PEMs and educational work showed no statistically significant differences between the groups. It was not possible to investigate potential effect modifiers across studies. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: The results of this review suggest that PEMs, when used alone, can have a positive effect on process outcomes compared to no intervention, but not on patient outcomes. Despite this wide range of effects reported for PEMs, the clinical significance of the observed effect sizes is unknown. There is insufficient information on how educational materials can be optimized. The effectiveness of educational materials compared to other interventions is uncertain.

title: Printed educational messages fail to increase the use of thiazides as first-line drugs for hypertension in primary care: a randomized controlled cluster study [ISRCTN72772651
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is conflicting evidence on the effectiveness of printed educational messages in helping increase evidence-based clinical practice. Nonetheless, this news is flooding doctors' offices to promote treatments that can reduce costs while improving patient outcomes. This study evaluated the ability of printed educational messages to encourage the choice of thiazides as first-line treatment for people with newly diagnosed hypertension, a practice supported by good evidence and incorporated into guidelines that could reduce costs to the healthcare system. METHODS: The study used a pragmatic, cluster-randomized controlled trial (randomized by physician office group). DISCONTINUATION: The discontinuation affects all general/family doctor practices in Ontario. Bulletins recommending the use of thiazides as first-line treatment for hypertension were sent to each doctor, along with a well-read professional newsletter. Physicians were randomized to receive different versions of printed educational messages: an "insert" (two-page evidence-based article) and/or one of two different versions of an "outsert" (short, instructional message pinned to the outside of the newsletter). ). One outsert was developed with no explicit theory and one with messages that developed targeting factors from planned behavior theory or neither (newsletter only, no mention of thiazides). The percentage of patients over the age of 65 with newly diagnosed hypertension who were prescribed a thiazide as their only primary prescription. The effect of the intervention was estimated using a logistic regression model estimated using generalized estimating equation methods to account for the clustering of patients within physician offices. RESULTS: Four thousand five hundred four physicians (with 23,508 patients) were randomized, providing a power of 97%, to detect an absolute 5% increase in thiazide prescribing. No intervention effect was found. Thiazides were prescribed to 27.6% of patients visiting control physicians, 27.4% of patients with inserts, 26.8% of outsert patients, and 28.3% of patients visiting insert + outsert physicians, p=0 ,54. CONCLUSIONS: The study clearly failed to demonstrate any impact of printed educational messages on the increase in prescribing of thiazide diuretics for the first-line treatment of hypertension. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ISRCTN72772651.

title: Private enterprise and the public good: ethical issues in clinical research funding
abstract: Health centers, universities and the researchers and clinicians working there are encouraged to raise research funds through the development of commercial relationships. There are positive, practical and morally relevant arguments in support of this initiative, but the move also raises ethical questions regarding potential conflicts of interest. These include conflicts between the responsibilities of an institution or a researcher to each other, to research topics and to the public, as well as competing financial interests. This article examines developments in research funding and ethical issues that may arise in the current governance context. It proposes guidelines for institutions to develop to support investigators in their efforts to improve clinical care through critical external funding and research.

title: Pro re nata medication for inpatient psychiatric patients: time for action
abstract: Pro re nata (PRN) Medication is an archetypal support for the management of acute psychiatric inpatient symptoms and behaviors. Psychiatric and psychiatric nursing practices have evaded the development of a unified medical-ethical standard for PRN drug administration. This paper reviews the evidence supporting PRN drug administration and proposes in the context of evidence-based best practices, current mental health guidelines, and professional ethics standard Australian PRN administration protocol. The procedures and circumstances leading to a nurse administering psychiatric drugs are broken down into five simple steps, namely (i) medical prescription; (ii) assessment of the patient's indications for intervention by the nursing staff; (iii) consideration of therapeutic options by nursing staff; (iv) obtaining the patient's consent;" and (v) documenting the results of PRN administration. The literature associated with each step is presented together with national and international professional ethics, guidelines and documents on patients' rights in relation to the care of patients with mental disorders Conditions reviewed. Recommendations for best practice care are discussed at each step. There is a gap in published evidence supporting the use of PRN drugs in inpatient psychiatric inpatients. However, there is published evidence that PRN drugs increased co-morbidity Risks of morbidity and misuse may result in over-recommended dosages or polypharmacy, and complicate the assessment of the efficacy of regularly scheduled medications Alternative non-pharmacological treatment options to PRN medication are effective and associated with fewer side effects There are n.a an explicit national standard, operational criteria, or quality assurance for the use of PRN drugs in inpatient mental health facilities. Current PRN practices are largely unregulated and driven by essentially anecdotal evidence, leaving clinicians and the service vulnerable to claims of poor accountability and misuse (intentional and unintentional) of psychotropic drugs. The development of best practice guidelines for the use of PRN administration is essential.

title: Proactive asthma treatment in childhood: general practice-based randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Objectives To evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a general practice-based, proactive system for the management of asthma in children. Design Randomized controlled trial with cluster sampling by general practitioner. Cessation of general practices in the Northern Region of the Australian Capital Territory. Participants 174 children with moderate to severe asthma who were attended by 24 general practitioners. Structured asthma care intervention system (the 3+ visit plan) in which participating families are reminded to see their family doctor. Key Outcome Measures Process measures: rates of asthma visits to primary care physician, written asthma plans, completion of 3+ visit plan"; clinical measures: rates of emergency room visits for asthma, days absent from school, symptom-free days, symptoms gone in past year, activity limitation in past year and asthma medication use in the past year Spirometric lung function measurements before and after cold air challenge Results Children in the intervention group had significantly more asthma-related consultations (odds ratio for three or more consultations 3.8 (95% confidence interval 1.9 to 7.6; p = 0.0001), written asthma plans (2.2 (1.2 to 4.1); p=0.01), and 3+ visit plans (24.2 (5.7 to 103.2); p=0 The sch Official asthma action plan included 5 (3 to 41) children. Children in the intervention group had lower rates of emergency room visits for asthma (odds ratio 0.4 (0.2 to 1.04); P=0.06) and fewer speech-restrictive wheezes (0.2 (0.1 to 0.4) ; P = 0.0001) than control group children, and they were also more likely to use a spacer (2.8 (1.6 to 4.7); P = 0.0001). There were no differences in the number of days absent from school or the values for symptom-free days in general practice and appears to be beneficial.

title: Problems in policy implementation: a randomized controlled trial of consensus management of dyspepsia
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the feasibility and utility of developing guidelines for the treatment of dyspepsia through consensus among general practitioners (GPs) and specialists, and assess their adoption in GP prescribing, use of surveys, and referrals. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial of the effect of consensus guidelines agreed between GPs and specialists on GP behavior. SETTING: Southampton and South West Hampshire Health District, United Kingdom. PARTICIPANTS: 179 GPs working in 45 practices in the Borough of Southampton out of 254 eligible GPs, 107 in the control group and 78 in the study group. KEY MEASURES: Referral and screening rates and prescription costs for dyspepsia in the six months before and after the guidelines were introduced. RESULTS: Consensus guidelines were created with relative ease. After their introduction, referral rates for upper GI symptoms decreased significantly in both the study and control groups, but no significant changes occurred in either group in terms of the use of endoscopy or radiology, neither in terms of referral rates that patient selection or the test results. No difference in the number of items prescribed was observed between the control and study groups, but prescription costs increased by 25% in the study group (from £2,634 to £3,215 per GP) almost entirely due to an increased prescription rate of ulcer-remedies. CONCLUSION: The development of district guidelines for the management of dyspepsia in consensus between general practitioners and specialists was feasible. However, their acceptance and acceptability have varied, and their measured impact on some aspects of clinical behavior has been relatively weak and not necessarily associated with reduced costs or improved quality of care.

title: Proceedings of the 9th Annual Conference on the Science of Dissemination and Implementation
Proceedings of the 3rd Biennial Conference of the Society for Implementation Research Collaboration (SIRC) 2015: Advancing Efficient Methodologies through Community Partnerships and Team Science
Proceedings of the 8th Annual Conference on the Science of Dissemination and Implementation
Process and outcome in the National Health Service
Process evaluation of an occupational health guideline to avoid weight gain among employees
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the process of an occupational health guideline to prevent weight gain. METHODS: Quantitative data on seven process items were assessed and associated with the impact on employees' waist circumference and body weight at 6 months. RESULTS: Occupational health practitioners (n = 7) partially implemented the guideline at the environmental level, but performed well at the individual level. Behavior change counseling was provided “to a certain extent”. Employees (n=274) demonstrated high reach (86%), satisfaction (7.1), and attendance rates (4.4 out of 5 sessions). Significant effects on waist circumference (-1.5 cm to -2.1 cm) and body weight (-0.9 kg to -1.4 kg) were found in workers with higher attendance and satisfaction rates. CONCLUSIONS: Workplace health promotion through an occupational health guide is feasible, but the environmental component and behavior change advice need to be revised before practical application.

title: Process assessment of complex interventions: Medical Research Council guidance
abstract: Process evaluation is an essential part of designing and testing complex interventions. New MRC guidelines provide a framework for conducting and reporting process assessment studies Attempts to address problems such as smoking and obesity use increasingly complex interventions. These are commonly defined as interventions that involve multiple interacting components, although additional dimensions of complexity include the difficulty of their implementation and the number of organizational levels they target.1 Randomized controlled trials are considered the gold standard for determining the effectiveness of interventions. Randomization is randomization possible. However, effect sizes do not provide policymakers with information about how an intervention might be replicated in its specific context or whether study results are reproduced.
