Previous MRC guidelines evaluating complex interventions focused on randomized trials and made no mention of process evaluation.2 Updated guidelines recognized the value of process evaluation within trials, stating that it can be used to assess the accuracy and quality of implementation, clarifying causal mechanisms and identifying contextual factors associated with variation in outcomes.â‚¬Â 3 However, it did not provide guidance on how to conduct the process evaluation. #### Summary In 2010, a workshop funded by the MRC Population Health Science Research Network discussed the need for guidance on process assessment.4 There was consensus that researchers, funders and...

title: Procrastination, Deadlines und Performance: Self-Control by Precommitment
abstract: Procrastination is all too familiar to most people. People are delaying writing their research (that's what we're hearing!), repeatedly declaring that they'll start their diets tomorrow, or putting it off until next week to do odd jobs around the house. However, sometimes people try to control their procrastination by setting themselves deadlines. In this article, we ask three questions: (a) Are people willing to set themselves meaningful (ie, costly) deadlines to overcome procrastination? (b) Are self-imposed deadlines effective in improving task performance? (c) When people set deadlines for themselves, are they setting them optimally for maximum performance improvement? A number of studies have examined these questions experimentally and shown that the answer to the first two questions is yes and the third is no. People have self-control problems, they recognize them and try to control them by setting themselves costly deadlines. These deadlines help people control procrastination, but they're not as effective as some externally imposed deadlines in improving task performance.

title: Professional and lay social support for hysterectomy patients
abstract: This article describes a study of social support for women undergoing hysterectomy and shows how initial research plans had to be altered when early interviews revealed the women's need for, and desire to receive, basic information from the researcher . The modified design allowed for comparisons between a group of women who received information as part of the research interview and a second group who received no such help. Hysterectomy follow-up at 3 months showed significant differences between the two groups, with the 'information group' being less hostile but more critical of their hospital treatment. The study also confirms previous findings by the same author of generally high levels of satisfaction, health, and return to activity after hysterectomy. Regarding social support, it is pointed out that full-time housewives are particularly dependent on support from carers due to their relative isolation from other sources of support and information. However, all respondents would have liked more information and support from medical professionals. Despite the acknowledged limitations of the study, some guidelines are offered for caregivers seeking to increase the level of lay and professional support for their patients.

title: Professional interventions for general practitioners to treat musculoskeletal disorders
abstract: BACKGROUND: Musculoskeletal disorders require special management skills. Identifying interventions that equip general practitioners (GPs) with such necessary skills could lead to improved health outcomes for patients and reduced health care and societal costs. OBJECTIVES: To determine the effectiveness of professional interventions for general practitioners aimed at improving the management of musculoskeletal disorders in primary care. SEARCH METHODS: We searched the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), 2010, Issue 2"; MEDLINE, Ovid (1950 - October 2013); EMBASE, Ovid (1980 - October 2013); CINAHL, EbscoHost (1980 - November 2013) .) and the EPOC Specialized Register. We performed cited reference searches using ISI Web of Knowledge and Google Scholar, and hand-searched selected editions of Arthritis and Rheumatism and Primary Care-Clinics in Office Practice. The last search was conducted in November 2013. SELECTION CRITERIA : We included randomized controlled trials (RCTs), non-randomized controlled trials (NRCTs), controlled before-and-after studies (CBAs), and interrupted time-series studies (ITS) of professional interventions for primary care physicians delivered in an outpatient setting aiming to improve the management (including diagnosis and treatment) of MSDs and to provide all objective measures of behavior in H Physician, patient, or economic outcomes report length, duration, intensity, and complexity compared to active or inactive controls. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two review authors independently abstracted all data. We calculated the risk difference (RD) and risk ratio (RR) of adhering to the desired practice for dichotomous outcomes, and the mean difference (MD) and standardized mean difference (SMD) for continuous outcomes. We examined whether the direction of the intended behavior change influences the effectiveness of interventions. MAIN RESULTS: Thirty studies met our inclusion criteria. Of 11 studies on osteoporosis, a meta-analysis of five studies (high-certainty evidence) showed that a combination of a GP alert system for a patient's increased risk of osteoporosis and a patient-directed intervention (including patient education and a reminder to see their GP ) improves the general practitioner's behavior regarding diagnostic tests of bone mineral density (BMD) and prescribing of osteoporosis drugs (RR 4.44; (95% confidence interval (CI) 3.54 to 5.55; 3 studies; 3386). participants)) for BMD and RR 1.71 (95% CI 1.50 to 1.94; 5 studies; 4,223 participants) for osteoporosis medications. The meta-analysis of two studies showed that alerting the general practitioner alone probably also increased the osteoporosis guideline-compliant behavior of the general practitioner (RR 4.75 (95% CI 3.62 to 6.24; 3,047 participants)) for BMD and RR 1.52 (95% CI 1.26 to 1.84; 3.047 participants) for osteoporosis medications) and that adding the patient-directed component is unlikely to result in a larger effect (RR 0.94 (95% CI 0.81 to 1.09 ; 2,995 participants)) for BMD and RR 0.93 (95% CI 0.79 to 1.10). ;“ 2,995 participants) for osteoporosis medication. Of the 10 studies on back pain, seven showed that the dissemination of guidelines and the provision of information for GPs can lead to little or no improvement in terms of guideline-compliant behavior by GPs. Two studies showed that the combination of guidelines and GP feedback on the total number of tests requested can affect GP behavior and lead to a slight reduction in the number of tests, while one of these studies showed that the combination of guidelines and GP r Radiology report reminders can result in a small but sustained reduction in the number of exam requests. Of the four studies on osteoarthritis, one study showed that the use of physicians with an educational influence can lead to an improvement in guideline-compliant behavior by general practitioners. Another study showed slight improvements in patient outcomes (pain control) after primary care physicians were trained in pain management. Of three shoulder pain studies, one reported that patient outcomes (functioning) may have improved little or not at all after general practitioner training in shoulder pain and injection training. Of two studies on other musculoskeletal disorders, one study on pain management showed that patient outcomes (pain control) may be worse after hands-on training in using validated rating scales. The 12 remaining studies on all musculoskeletal disorders showed little or no improvement in primary care physician behavior and patient outcomes. The direction of the desired behavior (ie, increasing or decreasing a behavior) does not appear to affect the effectiveness of an intervention. The majority of the studies did not examine the potential side effects of the interventions, and only three included a cost-benefit analysis. Overall, there were important methodological limitations in the evidence, with only a third of the studies reporting adequate attribution concealment and blinded outcome assessments. While our confidence in the pooled estimate of effects of interventions to improve diagnostic testing and prescription of medications in osteoporosis is high, our confidence in the reported estimates of effects in the remaining studies is low. AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: There is good-quality evidence that a GP alert system with or without patient-centred osteoporosis education improves guideline-compliant GP behavior, leading to better diagnosis and treatment rates. Interventions such as GP reminder messages and GP performance feedback combined with guideline dissemination may result in modest improvements in guideline-compliant behavior by GPs regarding back pain, while educating GPs on OA pain and employing pedagogically influential physicians lead to a slight improvement in patient outcomes or guideline-compliant behavior. However, more studies are needed to determine the effectiveness of such interventions in improving GP behavior and patient outcomes.

title: Prognostic Research Strategy (PROGRESS) 1: a framework for research into clinical outcomes
abstract: Understanding and improving the prognosis of a disease or health condition is a priority in clinical research and practice. In this article, the authors present a framework of four interrelated themes in prognostic research, describe the importance of the first of these themes (understanding future outcomes in relation to current diagnostic and treatment practices), and present recommendations for the field of prognostic research in the clinical In medicine, the term prognosis refers to the risk of future health outcomes in people with a specific disease or health condition. Prognostic research is thus the study of relationships between future outcomes (endpoints) in people with a given baseline health status (starting point) to improve health (see supplemental figure at bmj.com). The study of prognosis has never been more important, as more people worldwide are living with one or more diseases or conditions that affect their health than ever before.1 As a result, governments around the world are becoming increasingly interested in health care outcomes for people with disease. 2 Similarly, research funders and researchers are increasingly focused on transferring new interventions and technologies from the laboratory to clinical practice and then into health policy to establish and implement new standards of quality care and improve patient outcomes to enhance. The results of prognostic research should therefore be an integral part of clinical decision-making, health policy and the discovery and evaluation of new approaches to patient management. However, there is a worrying gap between the potential and actual health implications of prognostic research. Prognostic research studies all too often fall far short of the high standards required in other areas such as therapeutic studies and genetic epidemiology. In the PROGnosis RESearch Strategy (PROGRESS) series (www.progress-partnership.org) we propose a framework of four distinct but interrelated forecasting research themes:

title: Promising developments in neuropsychological approaches to detecting preclinical Alzheimer's disease: a selective review
abstract: Recently published guidelines suggest that the best time to treat people with Alzheimer's disease is in the preclinical phase of the disease. This is a phase when individuals are defined as clinically normal but show signs of amyloidosis, neurodegeneration, and subtle cognitive/behavioural decline. While our standard cognitive tests are useful for detecting cognitive decline in the mild cognitive impairment stage, they were not designed to detect the subtle cognitive changes associated with this biomarker stage of preclinical Alzheimer's disease. However, neuropsychologists are attempting to address this challenge by designing newer cognitive measures and questionnaires derived from translational efforts in neuroimaging, cognitive neuroscience, and clinical/experimental neuropsychology. This review is a selective summary of several new, potentially promising approaches being explored for detecting early cognitive signs of preclinical Alzheimer's disease in presymptomatic individuals.

title: Promotion of evidence-based psychosocial care for cancer patients
abstract: With numerous studies showing that mental health care reduces stress and improves quality of life, physicians have an obligation to treat cancer patients in a manner consistent with this evidence. Although the rationale is simple, there are major challenges in achieving the goal of translating research into clinical practice. One challenge has been the nature of the evidence, with many studies of psychosocial interventions characterized by poor methodological quality, a lack of eligibility criteria specifying increased burden, and minimal consideration of dissemination potential. A second challenge was to bring relevant evidence to the attention of practitioners. Targeted dissemination efforts, such as issuing clinical practice guidelines and evidence-based recommendations and distributing intervention materials over the Internet, appear to be more effective than passive efforts to provide physicians with useful information. Perhaps the most difficult aspect was persuading practitioners to change their practice. An approach currently under development would allow practitioners and healthcare organizations to conduct self-assessments of the quality of their mental health care based on medical record reviews. Feedback showing that the quality of care is not optimal is likely to inspire change, especially if the quality indicators assessed are considered important and reliable and point to concrete actions that can be taken. Using evidence to drive change in clinical practice is one of the key ways in which the field of psycho-oncology can realize its full potential to positively impact the lives of people living with cancer.

title: Promote hand hygiene compliance
abstract: BACKGROUND: The German “Clean Hands Campaign” (an adaptation of the WHO Clean Care is Safer Care program) to promote hand hygiene among hospital staff at Hannover Medical School (MHH), known as Clean Hands Campaign (ASH ), had first Successes. However, by 2013, hygienic hand sanitiser compliance rates at the hospital's ten intensive care units (ICUs) and two hematopoietic stem cell transplant units (HSCTUs) had returned to baseline values (doctors: 48%; nurses: 56%). . The PSYGIENE cluster-randomized controlled trial was conducted to investigate whether tailored interventions suggested by behavioral psychology research could produce more sustained improvements than ASH. Methods: The compliance model "Health Action Process Approach" (HAPA) specifies important psychological determinants of compliance. These determinants were collected from the nursing staff in the intensive care units and HSCTUs of the MHH by questionnaire (response rates: doctors: 71%; nurses: 63%) and by interviews with the responsible ward doctors and head nurses (100%). In 2013, 29 tailor-made techniques for behavior change in Training sessions and feedback sessions implemented in the six wards constituting the intervention arm of the study, while ASH training sessions were offered in the control arm (Results of the study) were determined by nonparticipant observation of World Health Organization gold standard hygienic hand disinfection. RESULTS: The two groups differed in 2013 not in their baseline compliance rates (intervention: 54%, control: 55%, p=0.581). Control arm rose to 68% in 2014 (p<0.001) but fell back to 64% in 2015 (p=0.007). The increases in compliance from 2013-2015 and the compliance rate in 2015 were higher in the intervention arm (p<0.005). This was mainly due to the behavior of the nurses, since the corresponding parameters for physicians in the stratified analysis did not differ significantly between the two study arms. CONCLUSION: Tailored interventions based on behavioral principles resulted in a more sustained increase in hand hygiene compliance than ASH training. This applied to nurses and thus to hospital staff as a whole (ie nurses and doctors together). Further studies are needed to identify more targeted interventions that may improve physician compliance.

title: Promoting recovery in schizophrenic patients: gap between routine practice and evidence. The SIEP-DIRECT project
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The objective of this work is to show the main discrepancies between the evidence-based NICE guidelines for schizophrenia and the usual practices of the Italian psychiatric services, demonstrated by the SIEP-DIRECT'S project, to promote the recovery of patients with schizophrenia . METHODS: 41 indicators were developed based on the main NICE recommendations for promoting recovery. These were tested in 19 participating Italian psychiatric departments (MHD) or psychiatric services through self-evaluation of the activities carried out to promote patient recovery, with the aim of assessing the degree of compliance with the recommendations. The data required for most of the indicators were obtained from the psychiatric information system or from the management of the MHD. In addition, specific research was carried out on medical records and representative patient samples. In addition, for 14 indicators, an assessment was requested from 'multidisciplinary' or 'technical' focus groups, which then assigned a score according to a defined 'ad hoc' scale. RESULTS: According to the data received, while psychiatric services seem to care about the physical condition of their patients, they do not routinely assess key parameters such as blood pressure, blood glucose, etc., and collaboration with GPs is often complex or practiced inconsistently. Most psychiatrists and psychologists have the basic communication skills but lack sufficient competence in cognitive-behavioural therapy";" Such treatments, and any other form of structured individual psychotherapy, are rarely undertaken and seem to have become marginal activities within the services. Family psychoeducational interventions are also underused. The services are very active in caring for multi-problem schizophrenia patients, who make up a large percentage (almost a quarter on average) of the patients in their care. These patients are offered specific and integrated treatment plans involving other health services and social organizations operating in the area. The strategies used by the services for pharmacological treatment in relapse prevention and for patients with frequent crises or with treatment-resistant schizophrenia are all in line with the NICE recommendations. Finally, the services encourage vocational training and supported employment activities, the results of which, however, are often unsatisfactory. CONCLUSIONS: The results of the study paint a picture of Italian mental health services with bright but also dark areas in relation to recovery promotion activities. Services seem to guarantee appropriate pharmacologically evidence-based treatments, integrated care and good management of multi-problem patients. However, they face difficulties in monitoring patients' physical health, psychotherapeutic activities, including for families, and promoting supported employment. In addition, they still show problems in structuring and formalizing care processes. To improve this situation, they should make more use of professional guidelines, protocols and written procedures.

title: Promotion of screening mammography in inner-city settings: a randomized controlled trial using computer-assisted reminders as part of a mammography facilitation program
abstract: In a one-year randomized controlled trial, we evaluated the effectiveness of a computerized mammography reminder system as part of a program to increase the use of mammography screening at three health care facilities serving inner-city women in Detroit, Michigan (two locations of a health department, an HMO location and two locations of a private hospital). 4,401 women over the age of 40 who had attended a study center in the previous year were randomly assigned to one of two treatment groups. Limited intervention (LI) included training physicians and staff on breast cancer control, simplified mammography scheduling procedures, and eliminating patient costs for mammography (at three of five sites). The full intervention (FI) included all of the components of the limited intervention plus an additional set of cues-to-action. These included a mammography reminder form to be placed in the medical records of women scheduled for mammography to increase physician referrals for mammography appointments, and patient reminders to be used to encourage mammography for referred women raise. During the one-year intervention period, 2,725 randomized women attended one study center. 6-month mammography visits in FI women vary from 38% to 65%, and the FI rate exceeds the LI rate at each site with differences ranging from 13% (95% CI, 6 to 20) to 29% (21 to 38). . The annual completed mammography rate in FI women ranges from 43% to 64% and exceeds the LI rate at each site by 12% (5 to 19) to 25% (16 to 34). After age adjustment, the effect sizes of the mammography intervention were not significantly different between the five sites. The average increase in FI compared to LI was 18%. The computerized reminder system is effective in increasing the use of mammography at each of the study sites, and the primary effect is physician referral for mammography.

title: Promoting self-management through adherence in heart failure patients discharged from rural hospitals: a study protocol
abstract: UNLABELING: Background Heart failure is one of the most prevalent chronic diseases in adults, resulting in prolonged morbidity, recurrent hospitalizations and an enormous economic burden on the healthcare system. Heart failure patients discharged from rural hospitals or primarily critical access hospitals have higher 30-day readmission and mortality rates compared to patients discharged from urban hospitals. Self-management improves heart failure patient outcomes and reduces rehospitalizations, but adherence to self-management guidelines is low. We propose a home post-acute care service led by experienced nurses to improve patient activation and lead to improved self-management compliance in heart failure patients discharged from rural hospitals. Aim This article describes the study design and research methods used to conduct and evaluate the intervention. Method Our intervention is a 12-week Patient Activated Care at Home [PATCH] to improve self-management compliance. Patients were randomized into two parallel groups (12-week PATCH intervention + usual treatment vs. usual treatment only) to assess the effectiveness of this intervention. Outcomes were measured at baseline, 3 months and 6 months. Discussion This study aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a rural theory-based, nurse-led, activation-enhancing intervention on self-management compliance in heart failure patients living in rural areas. Our expectation is to facilitate heart failure patients' adherence to self-management behavior after discharge from rural hospitals, and reduce complications and hospital readmissions, resulting in a reduction in economic burden. CLINICAL TRIAL REGISTRATION INFORMATION: ClinicalTrials.gov";" https://register.clinicaltrials.gov/NCT01964053.

title: Promote the use of colorectal cancer screening tests
abstract: BACKGROUND: Colorectal cancer screening is underutilized, despite evidence that screening reduces mortality. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effect of an intervention targeted at physicians and their patients on CRC screening rates. DESIGN: A randomized clinical trial involving general practitioners and their patients. PARTICIPANTS: Ninety-four community primary care physicians were randomly assigned to an intervention consisting of academic detailing and direct mailings to patients or a control group. Patients aged 50 to 79 years in the doctors in the intervention group received a letter from their doctor, a booklet on CRC screening, and a packet of fecal occult blood (FOBT) testing cards. MEASUREMENTS: At 1 year, we measured receipt of: (1) FOBT in the past 2 years, (2) flexible sigmoidoscopy (SIG) or colonoscopy (COL) in the past 5 years, and (3) any CRC screening. We report the percent change from baseline in both groups. RESULTS: 9,652 patients were enrolled for 2 years and 3,732 patients for 5 years. There was no increase in CRC screening that occurred in the intervention group for patients enrolled for 2 years (12.7 increase versus 12.5%, P=0.51). Similar results were observed for each CRC screening in patients enrolled for 5 years (9.7% increase vs. 8.6%, P=0.45). The only outcome affected by the intervention was the patients' screening SIG rate (increase of 7.4% vs. 4.4%, P<0.01). CONCLUSION: With the exception of an increase in SIG rates in the intervention group, the intervention had no effect on CRC screening rates. Future interventions should evaluate innovative approaches to increase rates of CRC screening.

title: Promotion and prescription of hormone therapy according to the Women's Health Initiative harm report
abstract: Context Little is known about how the pharmaceutical industry responds to evidence of harm related to their products, such as: Dose Prempro dealt significant damage and lacked net benefit. Objective To study the pharmaceutical industry's response to the GHI E+P results by analyzing hormone therapy advertising spending before and after July 2002. Design and Setting Nationally representative and prospectively collected longitudinal data (January 2001 to December 2003) on the prescription and promotion of hormone therapy were collected sourced from IMS Health and Consumer Media Reports. Key Outcome Measures Trends in quarterly hormone therapy prescriptions and spending for 5 forms of drug advertising: sample, practice-based detailing, hospital-related advertising, magazine advertising, and direct mail. Results Prior to the WHI E+P report, prescription rates and advertising spend for hormone therapy were stable. In the quarter preceding the GHI E+P report (April-June 2002), 22.4 million hormone therapy prescriptions were filled and US$71 million was spent on advertising (annualized US$350 per year per US physician). Within 9 months of the report's publication (Q1 2003), there was a 32% decline in hormone therapy prescriptions and a nadir in advertising spending (37% decline compared to pre-GHI E+P). levels). Spending on all advertising and most hormone therapies went down. Overall, the largest decreases were in samples (36% decrease from Q1 2003) and direct mail (100% decrease). The largest decreases in production occurred for standard-dose Prempro (61% decrease from Q1 2003), the compound mentioned in the GHI E+P report. More recently, there has been an increase in promotional activity, particularly for lower-dose Prempro, a resurgence that has been associated with slightly increased prescriptions for this newer compound. Conclusions Consistent with its widespread use, hormone therapy was one of the most heavily advertised drugs prior to the WHI E+P report. Following the reporting of the evidence of harm from this study, there has been a significant decrease in advertising spending for hormone therapy, particularly for the compounds most directly involved in the study. Coupled with the impact of the study results themselves and subsequent media coverage, reduced advertising may have contributed to a significant decrease in hormone therapy prescriptions.

title: Proper antibiotic therapy. From penicillin to pharmacogenomics
abstract: Antibiotics have always been considered one of the miracle discoveries of the 20th century. Flaming's use of penicillin ushered in the golden era of antibiotics and is now an integral part of antibiotic-free medical practice. Life-threatening infections such as meningitis, endocarditis, bacteremic pneumonia, sepsis would in turn prove fatal. Aggressive chemotherapy and transplant procedures would also prove impossible. Another real miracle was the rise in antibiotic resistance shortly after the clinical use of penicillin in hospitals and communities. Several studies have shown overprescribing of antibiotics for community and inpatients, and in some hospitals up to 50% of antibiotic use is inappropriate: the benefits of antibiotic treatment come with the risk of developing antibiotic resistance. In hospitals, infections caused by antibiotic-resistant bacteria are associated with higher mortality, morbidity, and longer hospital stays compared to infections caused by antibiotic-sensitive bacteria. A variety of strategies have been proposed to reduce costs and improve the quality of drug use. Education, guidelines and evidence-based recommendations are considered essential elements of any prescribing influencing program and can provide a knowledge base that improves and increases the acceptance of stewardship strategies. Evidence-based recommendations, a clinical practice approach that helps make decisions based on clinical expertise and a thorough knowledge of the individual patient's situation, beliefs, and priorities, improve antimicrobial management, including appropriate selection, dosage, type, and Duration of antibiotic therapy can maximize clinical cure or infection prevention while limiting unintended consequences such as emergence of resistance, adverse drug reactions and costs. These evidence-based guidelines are not a substitute for clinical judgment and clinical discretion is always required in their use. Genomic studies have identified hundreds of genetic polymorphisms that are important determinants of therapy efficacy, and several studies have demonstrated the successful use of pharmacogenomic testing to reduce the incidence of hypersensitivity reactions in patients. If a patient's phenotype is known prior to therapy, drugs can be prescribed at the optimal dose and type to achieve better patient care.

title: Infection prophylaxis after appendectomy: a review of current surgical practice
abstract: Two hundred and eighty questionnaires were sent to junior surgical staff across England asking about their use of systemic antibiotic prophylaxis, topical antibacterial agents and surgical drainage in appendectomy. One hundred seventy-five (63%) responses were received from 81 of the 87 hospitals included in the survey. Prophylactic systemic antibiotics were used by 78 surgeons (46%) when operating on a normal appendix, but by 168 (99%) when the organ was perforated. Most surgeons started antibiotics before surgery, but proportionately fewer did so when the appendix was gangrenous or perforated. Patients with severe contamination tended to receive longer courses of antibiotics, although the duration of administration varied significantly. Metronidazole was included in over 95% of all prophylactic therapies and was often combined with other drugs when the appendix was gangrenous and perforated. Topical antibacterials were routinely applied to the wound by only 45 surgeons (26%), although 106 (61%) sometimes used them. Povidone iodine was the most commonly used agent. Only 98 surgeons (56%) ever drained appendectomy wounds, while 135 (77%) sometimes drained the peritoneal cavity. There is evidence that current methods of systemic antibiotic prophylaxis should be continued, but that topical agents and surgical drains may be unnecessary if surgeons are confident of the effectiveness of the systemic treatment being used.

title: Prophylaxis of surgical wound sepsis
Proposed guidelines for the participation of people with dementia as research subjects
Proposed revision of the Helsinki Declaration
Prospective comparative study of computer programs used for the management of warfarin.
abstract: OBJECTIVES - To compare the efficacy of three computerized systems currently used to aid in warfarin control in outpatients versus the standard dosing method used by experienced healthcare professionals. METHODS - A randomized pilot study using three systems with an independent randomized follow-up study using two of these systems was conducted in 186 patients who were on long-term treatment or who had recently started and been discharged from warfarin treatment. RESULTS - All three computerized systems appeared to provide satisfactory control compared to the traditional dosing method. In patients receiving more intensive treatment with an assigned target range of 3.0-4.5, computerized dosing programs achieved significantly better control";" medical staff undertreated such patients in almost 50% of cases. CONCLUSION – Computerized programs can support outpatient anticoagulant control with warfarin during both early and long-term treatment. In most patients, the control achieved is as good as that achieved by the usual method of dosing by experienced clinical physicians, although the latter tend to be overly conservative when treating patients within the intensive target range of 3.0 to 4.5 Dose International Normalized Ratio (INR). . In this higher range, the computers were significantly more successful.

title: Prospective study of quality of life before and after coronary artery bypass graft surgery
abstract: OBJECTIVES To measure changes in patients' perceptions of how different health conditions affect their lives and to determine the ability of preoperative variables to predict outcome after coronary artery bypass graft surgery. DESIGN Prospective study with completion of questionnaires before coronary artery bypass graft and three months, one year and five years after. ADJUSTMENT Regional Cardiothoracic Center. PATIENTS 100 male patients, all under 60 years of age at the time of surgery, who were patients of two cardiothoracic surgeons. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Patient assessment of their health status in relation to functional capacity and aspects of burden according to the Nottingham Health Profile and outcome of surgery in relation to changes in symptoms, work life and daily activities determined by self-completed study questionnaires prior to surgery as well as three and six months after. RESULTS One year interim results are reported. The differences between the Nottingham Health Profile scores before surgery and three months after surgery were significantly different (p<0.01), indicating a noticeable improvement in general health, and compared favorably with those of a normal male population at one year. The analysis of the answers to the study questionnaire showed that 65 of 89 patients (73%) were employed one year after the operation, another seven (8%) stated that they were able to work but could not find a job. The proportion of patients complaining of chest pain decreased from 90% (88/98) before transplantation to 19% (17/89) one year after coronary artery bypass graft surgery, with 91% (81/89) of patients maintained their condition as either completely better or definitely improved. The significant positive factors influencing return to work and home activities were work prior to surgery, short wait times for surgery, absence of dyspnoea, and a low score for physical mobility in the Nottingham health profile (all p less than 0.001). CONCLUSIONS Improvements in general health, symptoms and activity were seen three months and one year after coronary artery bypass graft surgery. Interventions likely to influence outcomes included reducing wait times for surgery, rehabilitation initiatives, and paying more attention to the quality of information given to patients, their families, and the community.

title: Prospective study of real-time electronic monitoring to accelerate early treatment of severe sepsis.
abstract: Study Aim An automated, electronic, real-time medical record query and caregiver notification system was developed and evaluated for its utility in improving sepsis care. We anticipate that the algorithm will increase the rate and timeliness of blood lactate and blood culture sampling, chest x-rays and antibiotic delivery. Methods A prospective before-and-after study with consecutive recruitment evaluated an algorithm that automatically identified adult patients who had 2 or more Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) criteria and 2 or more blood pressure measurements less than or equal to 90 mm Hg during their accumulated Emergency Department (ED) stay. In phase 1, the system collected information but did not alert caregivers. In phase 2, the nursing staff were informed about the patient's possible illness via alphanumeric paging and a text entry in the electronic patient file and provided with specific recommendations. Results Patients (33,460) were screened over a 6 month period; 398 patients activated the system, including 184 (46%) who were appropriately identified as severely septic. The algorithm had a positive predictive value of 54% and a negative predictive value of 99% in detecting severe infections with acute organ dysfunction. The median time for patients to accumulate SIRS and blood pressure criteria was 152 minutes (interquartile range [IQR] 71 to 284 minutes), underscoring the dynamic nature of emergency critical illness diagnosis and the need for detection algorithms Repeatedly assess patients during their evaluation After performance, 2 procedures were performed more frequently, pre-admission chest X-ray (odds ratio 3.2; 95% confidence interval 1.1 to 9.5) and blood culture collection (odds ratio 2.9; 95% confidence interval 1.1 to 7.7) Only blood culture tests were performed significantly faster when a decision aid was present (median time to culture before inter-invention 86 minutes, IQR 31, 296 minutes; mean time to culture after intervention 81 minutes, IQR 37, 245 mi groove P=0.032 after Cox proportional hazards modelling). Sepsis increased the frequency and timeliness of some ED interventions in severe sepsis. Future efforts need to identify patient characteristics that are present earlier in the ED assessment than SIRS and hypotension.

title: Protection of the rights of human subjects
abstract: A significant problem exists with the amount of human research being conducted by investigators who do not follow the Belmont Report's guidelines for human protection. There are numerous reasons for non-compliance, which can lead to dilemmas in resolving this issue. However, it is important that healthcare organizations - regardless of size - take a proactive stance to address this issue. This article has briefly described the nature, scope, and underlying dilemmas of this problem, and proposed a strategy to address the problem at an organizational level. As patient advocates by virtue of their professional licenses, nurses in every role can and must take a leadership role in protecting people's rights.

title: Protection of children involved in research studies
Protection of Human Subjects"; Informed Consent;" proposed rule
Protocol for a pragmatic randomized controlled cluster study to reduce irrational antibiotic prescribing in children with upper respiratory tract infections in rural China
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Irrational use of antibiotics is a serious problem in China and internationally. In 2012, the Chinese Ministry of Health issued a regulation on antibiotic prescriptions, limiting it to <20% of all outpatient prescriptions, but no operational details on the implementation of the guidelines were released. This study aims to test the effectiveness of a multidimensional intervention aimed at reducing antibiotic use in children (aged 2 to 14 years) with acute upper respiratory tract infections in rural primary care settings in China by reducing prescribing behavior of the doctors are changed and the parents/carers are educated. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: This is a pragmatic, parallel-group, controlled, cluster-randomized superiority study with blinded interpretation of outcomes and data analysis and open-label treatment. From two counties in Guangxi province, 12 township hospitals will be randomized to the intervention arm and 13 to the control arm. In the control group, treatment of antibiotic prescriptions continues through usual treatment through clinical consultations. In the intervention arm, a provider- and patient/carer-centered intervention will be embedded in routine primary care practice. Provider intervention includes operational guidelines, systematic training, peer review of antibiotic prescribing, and provision of health education to patient caregivers. We will also provide patient caregivers with printed training materials and training videos. The primary outcome is the proportion of all provider prescriptions for upper respiratory tract infections in children ages 2 to 14 that contain at least one antibiotic. ETHICS AND DISSEMINATION: The study was ethically approved by the Ethics Committee of Guangxi Provincial Center for Disease Control and Prevention, China. Results are disseminated through workshops, policy briefs, peer-reviewed publications, local and international conferences. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: ISRCTN14340536";" preliminary results.

title: Protocol for a systematic review of assessment research for adults who participated in the SMART recovery mutual support program
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Self-Management and Recovery Training (SMART Recovery) offers an alternative to the prevailing 12-step approaches to mutual aid (e.g., anonymizing alcoholics). Although the principles (e.g. self-efficacy) and therapeutic approaches (e.g. motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy) of SMART Recovery are evidence-based, further clarity is needed regarding direct evidence of its effectiveness as a mutual support package. Compared to methodologically rigorous reviews supporting the effectiveness of 12-step approaches, SMART Recovery's reviews to date have been descriptive. Our aim is to fill this gap by providing a comprehensive overview of the evidence for SMART recovery in adults with problematic alcohol, substance and/or behavioral dependence, including a commentary on the outcomes assessed, potential mediators, feasibility (including economic results) and a critical assessment of the methods used. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: The methods follow the Cochrane guidelines for systematic reviews and the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis Statement. 6 electronic peer-reviewed and 4 gray literature databases were identified. Preliminary searches of SMART recovery literature were performed (liberal inclusion criteria, not limited to randomized controlled trials (RCTs), exclusively qualitative designs excluded). Appropriate review items are evaluated using standardized criteria and reviewed by an independent reviewer. The searches will be rerun shortly before the final analyzes and further studies are retrieved for inclusion. A narrative summary of outcomes is reported, structured by intervention type and content, population characteristics, and outcomes. Whenever possible, “Summary of Results” tables are prepared for each comparison. When data are available, we calculate a risk ratio and its 95% CI (dichotomous endpoints) and/or effect size according to Cohen's formula (continuous endpoints) for the primary endpoint of each study. ETHICS AND DISSEMINATION: No ethical issues are foreseen. Results are shared with clinicians and researchers through journal publications and conference presentations. PROSPERO REGISTRATION NUMBER: CRD42015025574.

title: Protocol for a systematic review of telephone-delivered psychosocial interventions for relapse prevention, psychotropic drug adherence, and health-risk behaviors in adults with a psychotic disorder
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The mental and physical health of individuals with a psychotic illness is typically poor. If followed, medication can reduce relapse. However, despite compliance, relapse remains common and functional outcomes often remain compromised. Compliance is also usually low. Cardiovascular-related morbidity and mortality are also increased, along with several important modifiable health risk behaviors. Access to psychosocial interventions is therefore important but currently limited. Telephone interventions represent a promising solution, although further clarity is needed. Accordingly, we aim to provide an overview and critical analysis of the current evidence for telephone-delivered psychosocial interventions that target important health priorities in adults with a psychotic disorder, including (1) relapse, (2) psychotropic drug adherence, and/or (3) modifiable risk behavior for cardiovascular health. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Our methods are based on published guidelines. The review is registered and all log changes are tracked. Ten peer-reviewed electronic databases and four gray literature databases were identified. A preliminary literature review was conducted on psychosocial telephone interventions targeting relapse, drug use, and/or unhealthy behavior in adults with a psychotic disorder. Articles classified as "Evaluation" are assessed using standardized criteria and checked by an independent reviewer. The searches will be rerun shortly before the final analyzes and further studies are retrieved for inclusion. A narrative synthesis structured around intervention type and content, population characteristics, and outcomes is reported. Whenever possible, “Summary of Results” tables are prepared for each comparison. For the primary endpoint of each study, where data are available, we calculate a risk ratio and its 95% CI (dichotomous endpoints) and/or the effect size according to Cohen's formula (continuous endpoints). ETHICS AND DISSEMINATION: No ethical issues are foreseen. Results are shared with clinicians and researchers through journal publications and conference presentations. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: PROSPERO CRD42015025402.

title: Protocol processing system (ProtoVIEW) to support emergency department residents.
abstract: This paper describes the design, implementation and evaluation of a prototype protocol processing system (ProtoVIEW). ProtoVIEW provides protocol information for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. The developed system described here is used as a research tool to study the impact of automated protocols on medical decision-making by physicians. A first evaluation shows that the residents enjoy using the system and that the use of the system leads to a more uniform working strategy.

title: Attitudes of providers to oral preexposure prophylaxis for HIV prevention among high-risk men who have sex with men in Lima, Peru
abstract: Oral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) was the first biomedical intervention to demonstrate its effectiveness in preventing HIV infection in men who have sex with men (MSM). Attitudes towards PrEP by healthcare providers will be critical to translating this insight into effective public health adoption programs. In a sample of 186 healthcare providers in Peru, we assessed knowledge, barriers, and attitudes about prescribing and monitoring HIV PrEP for high-risk MSM and transgender women, the populations with the highest incidence of HIV in this setting. A total of 57.5% reported awareness of PrEP, and awareness was independently associated with caring for more than 50 MSM (OR: 3.67, p<0.002). The lack of local guidelines, concerns about increased risk behaviors, antiretroviral drug resistance, and the limited availability of antiretroviral drugs for HIV-infected individuals were the most common barriers to prescribing PrEP. Of all physicians, 44.6% said they are now likely to prescribe oral PrEP";" the likelihood of prescribing was higher when PrEP was supported by local guidelines (70.3%, p<0.001), when more studies demonstrated its effectiveness (68.5%, p<0.001), and when intermittent use was shown to be effective ( 62.2%, p<0.001). =0.019). Physicians are now more likely to prescribe PrEP when caring for more than 50 MSM (OR: 6.62, p=0.010). Infectious disease specialists were less likely to prescribe PrEP (OR: 0.10, p=0.003) than laypersons. Successful large-scale implementation of PrEP in Peru requires targeted educational campaigns to raise awareness and address concerns among healthcare providers.

title: Vendor Details: An Intervention to Reduce Prescription Opioid Deaths in Utah
abstract: BACKGROUND: Utah has embarked on a multifaceted effort to reverse an epidemic of deaths among patients taking prescription opioids. This article describes the part of the effort that details the provider. METHODS: Presentations highlighting six recommended prescribing practices were developed and presented to healthcare workers. Participants were encouraged to use the state prescribing database and complete a series of surveys that assessed changes in confidence and behavior at 0, 1, and 6 months after presentation. Credits for continuing medical education encouraged participation. RESULTS: Utah's drug-related overdose deaths decreased 14.0% in 2008 compared to 2007 after program implementation. A total of 581 doctors and numerous non-medical health professionals were reached in 46 presentations. Follow-up surveys on the level of acceptance of practice changes were completed by 366 participants at 0 months, 82 participants at 1 month, and 29 participants at 6 months. Combined results for all three assessments showed that 60-80% of responding physicians reported that they no longer prescribe long-acting opioids for acute pain or with sedatives”; 50% reported using the Utah Controlled Substances Database during patient care and using lower starting doses and slower escalations;" and 30-50% reported receiving ECGs and sleep studies in eligible patients, using patient education tools, and prescribing guidelines of Utah. CONCLUSIONS: Provider disclosure was associated with a decrease in the mortality rate from prescription opioids in Utah and improvements in the provider's self-reported prescribing behavior. Other concomitant interventions may have contributed to the decrease in mortality rates. The effect of this intervention was enhanced by short-term funding limited.

title: Provider training to promote the implementation of clinical practice guidelines
abstract: STUDY OBJECTIVES: Although interest in and dissemination of clinical practice guidelines has increased significantly over the past two decades, concerns remain about their actual implementation. This article focuses on one strategy to promote guideline implementation at the clinical level: clinician education. The aims of the article are to review educational strategies, to place them in the context of complementary strategies carried out at the organizational and clinical levels, and to outline challenges and recommendations for continuing education of clinicians. METHODS: Experience and data from relevant randomized clinical trials within an educational setting are reviewed. COMMENTS: The implementation of clinical practice guidelines requires a variety of skills including assessment, adequately describing a treatment and monitoring plan, patient tracking, and patient counseling and education. Learning strategies need to reflect the content and teaching methods that best fit the learning objectives. The pressures of today's practice limit the resources, particularly the clinician's time, that are available for continuing education. Organizational resources must be allocated to build the complementary support systems needed for improved clinical practice. In addition to physicians, training must target non-physician clinical staff, office staff, and administrators who are also responsible for implementing the guidelines. CONCLUSIONS: To meet the challenges of developing clinician motivation, balancing competing demands, and treating patients with complex diseases, clinical leaders must design educational activities that are supported by leadership, reflect compelling evidence, and employ multiple strategies and teaching techniques, and engage learners in skill building and problem solving.

title: Providing feedback on social norms for high antibiotic prescribers in general practice: a pragmatic national randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Unnecessary antibiotic prescribing contributes to antibiotic resistance. In this study we aimed to reduce unnecessary prescriptions of antibiotics by General Practitioners (GPs) in England. Methods In this randomized, 2 × 2 factorial study, publicly available databases were used to identify GP practices whose antibiotic prescribing rate was in the top 20% for their local National Health Service (NHS) team. Eligible practices were randomly (1:1) divided into two groups by a computer generated matching sequence layered by the NHS Local Area Team. Participants, but not investigators, were blinded to group assignment. On September 29, 2014, each GP in the feedback intervention group received a letter from the UK Chief Medical Officer and a leaflet on antibiotics for use in patients. The letter states that the practice prescribes antibiotics more than 80% of the practices in its local NHS team. Primary care physicians in the control group received no communication. The sample was again randomized into two groups and in December 2014 GP practices either received patient-centred information encouraging reduced antibiotic use or received no notification. The primary outcome measure was the rate of antibiotics dispensed per 1000 weighted population, accounting for past prescriptions. The analysis was intended to treat. This study is registered and completed with the ISRCTN registry under number ISRCTN32349954. Results Between September 8 and 26, 2014, we recruited 1581 primary care practices and assigned them to feedback intervention (n=791) or control (n=790) groups. Letters were sent to 3227 general practitioners in the intervention group. Between October 2014 and March 2015, the rate of antibiotics dispensed per 1000 population was 126·98 (95% CI 125·68–128·27) in the feedback intervention group and 131·25 (130·33). "132 x 16) in the control group, a difference of 4 x 27 (3 x 3%", incidence rate ratio [IRR] 0 x 967 [95% CI 0 x 957-0 x 977]; p<0 x 0001), which represents an estimated 73–406 fewer antibiotics dispensed.As of December 2014, primary care practices were assigned to the patient-centered intervention groups (n=777) or the control group (n=804) between December 2014 and March 2015 had no significant impact on the primary outcome measure (antibiotics dispensed per 1000 inhabitants: 135 00 [95% CI 133 77–136 22] in the patient-oriented intervention group and 133 98 [133 06–134 90] in the control group, IRR for difference between the groups 1 01, 95% CI 1 00 – 1 02, p = 0 105) Interpretation of social norm feedback from a high-profile messenger can significantly reduce antibiotic p prescribing at low cost and at the national level;" This finding makes it a useful adjunct to antimicrobial stewardship programs.

title: Providing mothers of babies in the ICU with recorded conversations with neonatologists: randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether providing mothers of babies in the NICU with tapes of their conversations with a neonatologist improves information recall and psychological well-being. DESIGN Randomized, single-blinded study. SETTING Neonatal Intensive Care Unit, North Queensland, Australia. PARTICIPANTS 200 mothers of babies in a neonatal intensive care unit. INTERVENTIONS Mothers gave (n=102) or not (n=98) tapes of their conversations with a neonatologist. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Recall of information, attitudes towards the tape and its use, satisfaction with interviews, postnatal depression, anxiety, general health status, and stress related to parenting at 10 days and four and 12 months. RESULTS 91% (n=93) of the mothers in the cassette group listened to the cassette (once at day 10, twice at four months, and three times at 12 months; range 1-10). At 10 days and four months, mothers in the tape group remembered significantly more information about diagnosis, treatment, and outcome than mothers in the control group. At four months, mothers in the tape group were 75% more likely to remember all information about treatment as mothers in the control group (59% vs. 34%; risk ratio 1.75, 95% confidence interval 1.27 to 2.4). Six mothers, all in the control group, could not remember their conversations. No statistically significant differences were found between groups in interview satisfaction (10 days), postnatal depression and anxiety scores (10 days, four, and 12 months), and parenting stress (12 months). CONCLUSION Providing mothers of babies in the NICU with tapes of conversations with a neonatologist improved their recall of information (up to four months). The recorded conversations did not affect the mothers' well-being or satisfaction with the neonatologist. STUDY REGISTRATION Australian Clinical Trials Registry 12606000478516.

title: Psychiatric experiments: the lessons of history
Psychoeducation: Improving Outcomes in Bipolar Disorder
abstract: BACKGROUND: A relevant paradigm shift in the treatment of bipolar disorder began several years ago";" Critical evidence on the usefulness of psychological interventions clearly supports the shift from an exclusively pharmacological approach to therapy to a combined but hierarchical model in which pharmacotherapy plays a central role, but psychological interventions can help bridge the gap that exists between theoretical efficacy and effectiveness in the "real world". We hereby examine the effectiveness of several concomitant psychotherapies in the maintenance therapy of bipolar patients. METHODS: A systematic literature search on this topic was conducted using the MEDLINE and CURRENT CONTENTS databases. The keywords entered were “bipolar”, “psychotherapy”, “psychoeducation”, “cognitive-behavioural” and “relapse prevention”. RESULTS: Psychological treatments specifically designed for relapse prevention in bipolar disorder are useful tools in conjunction with mood stabilizers. Most recently published psychotherapy studies report positive results for maintenance as an add-on treatment and effectiveness in treating depressive episodes. Interestingly, several groups from around the world reported similar positive results and came to very similar conclusions";" Almost every intervention tested contains important psychoeducational elements, including both improving compliance, early detection of prodromal signs—emphasizing the importance of a regular lifestyle—and exploring patients' health beliefs and disease awareness. CONCLUSIONS: The usefulness of psychotherapy in improving adherence and clinical outcome in bipolar patients is now undisputed, and future treatment guidelines should encourage its regular use among clinicians. As clinicians, our primary mission is to provide our patients with the best available treatment, and this includes both evidence-based psychoeducational programs and newer pharmacological agents.

title: Psychological and behavioral interventions for the treatment of insomnia disorders: An evidence review for a clinical practice guideline from the American College of Physicians
abstract: BACKGROUND: Psychological and behavioral interventions are commonly used for sleep disorders. PURPOSE: To assess the benefits and harms of psychological and behavioral interventions for sleep disorders in adults. DATA SOURCES: Ovid MEDLINE, Embase, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials and PsycINFO through September 2015, supplemented by manual search. STUDY SELECTION: Randomized controlled trials of psychological or behavioral interventions published in English and included adults with insomnia that lasted 4 or more weeks. DATA EXTRACTION: Data extraction by a single reviewer, confirmed by a second reviewer"; Risk of bias assessment by two reviewers;" Consensus determination of the strength of evidence. DATA SYNTHESIS: Sixty studies with low to moderate risk of bias compared psychological and behavioral interventions with inactive controls or other psychological and behavioral interventions. Cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) improved global and most post-treatment sleep outcomes, often compared to informational or wait-list controls (moderate-strength evidence). CBT-I use improved several sleep outcomes in older adults (low-to-moderate-strength evidence). Multicomponent behavioral therapy improved several sleep outcomes in older adults (low-to-moderate-strength evidence). Stimulus control improved 1 or 2 sleep outcomes (low-strength evidence). There was insufficient evidence for other comparisons and for harm to draw any conclusions. LIMITATIONS: A large number of comparisons limited the ability to summarize data. Studies did not always report global outcomes and rarely performed remitter or responder analyses. Comparisons were often to informational or wait-list groups, and publication bias was possible. CONCLUSIONS: The use of CBT-I improves most outcomes compared to inactive controls. Multicomponent behavioral therapy and stimulus control may improve some sleep outcomes. Evidence on other outcomes, comparisons, and long-term efficacy was limited.

title: Psychological treatments for post-traumatic stress disorder: recommendations for the clinician based on a literature review
abstract: This article provides an overview of available research data supporting the use of psychotherapy in the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The authors highlight how this evidence could inform clinical decisions in the management of PTSD and show how assumptions based on gaps in the available literature can be misleading. The authors first discuss results on a range of interventions commonly used in the treatment of trauma victims or patients with PTSD: stress debriefing of critical incidents, psychoeducation, exposure therapy, eye movement desensitization, reprocessing, stress vaccination therapy, trauma management therapy, cognitive therapy, psychodynamic psychotherapy, and hypnotherapy. They also discuss a number of treatment strategies that have recently been explored in PTSD, including imagery exercises, memory structure interventions, interpersonal psychotherapy, and dialectical behavior therapy. PTSD is associated with significant symptomatic morbidity, although the desired outcomes in clinical practice are more typically related to reducing social, interpersonal, and occupational impairments. The most methodologically sound studies, which have typically examined cognitive or behavioral treatments, show that psychotherapy helps reduce the severity of symptoms”; However, there is no consistent information on whether these interventions are helpful in improving other areas of impairment and associated disability, although these issues are often the greatest concern for patients. Also, the available evidence does not indicate when and to whom different psychotherapeutic interventions should be provided, or whether different treatment modalities can and should be combined or offered sequentially, as is often the case in specialized treatment programs. Clinicians should keep these issues in mind when reviewing the literature for current (and future) clinical research. Unfortunately, the current evidence base on psychotherapy for PTSD provides only limited guidance for clinical decisions in the management of PTSD. The authors therefore provide some literature-based clinical guidelines for clinicians treating patients with PTSD.

title: Psychometric analysis of the R18V2 three-factor diet questionnaire in adolescent and young adult-aged central nervous system tumor survivors
abstract: PURPOSE: Adolescent and young adult (AYA) central nervous system (CNS) tumor survivors are an understudied population at risk of developing adverse health outcomes such as obesity. Long-term follow-up guidelines recommend monitoring of those at risk for obesity, which justifies the need for an eating behavior questionnaire. An abbreviated online version of the Three-Factor Eating Questionnaire (TFEQ-R18v2) has been developed, but its applicability to this population is not yet known. This study examined the factor structure and reliability of the instrument in this population. METHODS: CNS tumor survivors of AYA age (n = 114) aged 15 to 39 years completed the TFEQ-R18V2 questionnaire online. The fit of the three-factor structure (uncontrollable eating, cognitive restraint and emotional eating [EE]) and reliability (internal consistency of the TFEQ-R18v2) were examined using confirmatory factor analysis. Associations between the three factors and body mass index (BMI) were assessed by linear regression. RESULTS: The theorized three-factor structure was supported in our population (RMSEA = 0.056 and CFI = 0.98) and showed good reliability (alpha of 0.81-0.93). EE (beta = 0.07, 95% CI 0.02-0.13) was positively associated with BMI, while the other two subscale scores were not. CONCLUSION: The TFEQ-R18v2 instrument shows promise for research and clinical use in AYA-aged CNS tumor survivors. The instrument can be a useful tool for researchers to develop tailored weight management strategies. It can also be a valuable tool for clinicians to monitor and facilitate referral of survivors at risk for obesity. Our results also suggest that EE should be further explored in this population as a potential target for intervention.

title: Psychopharmacology in pregnancy
abstract: Physicians are faced with challenging situations when working with women who are pregnant and at the same time suffer from a mental illness. A risk-benefit assessment is helpful to identify possible care interventions. Psychopharmaceutical intervention is a consideration when nonpharmacological interventions are ineffective or inappropriate. Informed consent should be obtained based on known and unknown risks to the mother and fetus. Literature and case reports are conflicting and inconclusive about the risks of drugs used in psychiatric disorders. This article reviews the literature and provides clinical guidelines for antipsychotics, antidepressants, mood-stabilizing drugs, and anti-anxiety drugs.

title: Psychosocial aspects in cardiac rehabilitation: from theory to practice. A position paper from the Cardiac Rehabilitation Section of the European Association of Cardiovascular Prevention and Rehabilitation of the European Society of Cardiology
abstract: Numerous empirical studies show that psychosocial risk factors (PSRFs) such as low socioeconomic status, social isolation, stress, type D personality, depression and anxiety increase the risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) and also contribute to poorer health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and Prognosis in patients with existing CHD. PSRFs can also act as barriers to lifestyle changes and therapy adherence, and mitigate the impact of cardiac rehabilitation (CR). In addition, there appears to be a bidirectional interaction between PSRFs and the cardiovascular system. Stress, anxiety and depression affect the cardiovascular system through immune, neuroendocrine and behavioral pathways. In turn, CHD and associated treatments can cause conditions in patients, including anxiety and depression. In clinical practice, PSRFs can be assessed using single-item screening questions, standardized questionnaires, or structured clinical interviews. Psychotherapy and medication can be considered to alleviate any PSRF-related symptoms and improve HRQoL, but the evidence for a clear beneficial effect on cardiac endpoints is inconclusive. Comprehensive CR should include a multimodal behavioral intervention that integrates counseling for PSRFs and disease management. Patients with clinically significant symptoms of distress should be referred for psychological counseling or psychologically focused interventions and/or psychopharmacological treatment. In summary, the success of CR can critically depend on the interdependence of mind and body, and this interdependence needs to be addressed through the assessment and management of PSRFs consistent with sound scientific evidence by trained personnel integrated into the CR core team is to be reflected.

title: Pulmonary edema induced by nifedipine
Putting evidence into practice: Evidence-based interventions in sleep-wake disorders
abstract: Symptom management is an essential aspect of oncology nursing practice. The Oncology Nursing Society has identified outcomes that are responsive to nursing interventions, known as care-sensitive patient outcomes. This article provides information on sleep-wake disorders seen in cancer patients and provides recommendations for evidence-based interventions to improve patients' sleep. Sleep-wake disorders occur in 30-75% of cancer patients and negatively impact other symptoms and quality of life. Despite the frequency and severity of sleep-wake disorders, limited research has tested interventions to improve sleep-wake outcomes. Although no intervention currently receives the highest recommendations for implementation in practice, several non-pharmacological interventions are showing early positive results in promoting quality sleep and daytime functioning. Oncology nurses can examine sleep-wake disorders and suggest tailored interventions. Four categories of promising interventions are cognitive behavioral therapy, complementary therapies, psychoeducation and information, and exercise. Clinicians can use the Putting Evidence Into Practice (PEP) card and PEP resources at www.ons.org/outcomes to improve sleep-wake outcomes.

title: Put prevention into practice
abstract: In primary care institutions, disease prevention services are provided at lower prices than recommended. Additionally, practitioners tend to overestimate the speed at which they perform them. There are two main steps in delivering evidence-based prevention services: (1) knowing the evidence for performing various detection and intervention maneuvers, and (2) integrating prevention services into daily practice. The first is a scientific process and is conducted in Canada by the Canadian Task Force on the Periodic Health Examination. However, after a decade of experience with evidence-based guidelines, we know that guidelines are not enough. Integrating clinical prevention into busy practices is a political and logistical process. This truth is best captured by the joke, "An ounce of prevention takes a pound of office system change." A number of studies have shown that continuing education courses and workshops for physicians are not sufficient to anchor clinical prevention in practice. According to Lomas, the traditional CME educational approaches need to be complemented by strategies from such paradigms as the social impact model, the diffusion of innovation model and the adult education model. In “From Science to Practice”, Battista points out the complexity of the communication process required for the dissemination of innovation in practice. Walsh's systems model of clinical prevention best captures the interacting factors that mediate between physicians' intentions and their actions when it comes to the delivery of clinical preventive services. This paper reports on a practical example of supporting GPs in developing a "supporting practice system in prevention" that minimizes barriers, focuses energy and integrates clinical prevention into everyday practice. The key components are (i) a practice coordinator for prevention, (ii) clear clinical prevention-related job descriptions for everyone involved with patients, (iii) an information management system that reinforces prevention, and (iv) a practice feedback and problem-solving strategy.

title: Qualitative data collection and analysis methods: the INSTINCT study
abstract: Patient care practices often lag behind current scientific knowledge and professional guidelines. The failure of such knowledge translation (knowledge translation, KT) efforts may reflect inadequate assessment and addressing of specific barriers faced by both physicians and patients at the treatment level. Effective KT in this setting can benefit from using qualitative methods to identify and overcome these barriers. The qualitative methodology allows for an in-depth study of the barriers associated with adopting practice changes and has rarely been used in emergency medicine research. The authors describe the methodology for the qualitative analysis as part of the INCreasing Stroke Treatment through INteractive Behavioral Change Tactics (INSTINCT) study. This includes processes for valid data collection and reliable analysis of the text data from focus group and interview protocols. INSTINCT is a 24-hospital, randomized, controlled trial designed to evaluate a systems-based barrier assessment and an interactive educational intervention to increase the appropriate use of tissue plasminogen activators (tPA) in ischemic stroke. Intervention hospitals undergo a basic barrier assessment using both qualitative and quantitative (survey) techniques. Investigators will receive data on local barriers to tPA use, as well as information on local attitudes, knowledge, and beliefs regarding acute stroke management. Target audiences at each site include emergency physicians, emergency room nurses, neurologists, radiologists, and hospital administrators. Transcript analysis using NVivo7 with a predefined barrier taxonomy is described. This will provide both qualitative insight into thrombolytic use and the importance of specific barrier types for each site. The qualitative findings then steer the form of professional further education efforts and system interventions at treatment centers.

title: Qualitative research within trials: development of a standard operating procedure for a clinical trials department
abstract: BACKGROUND: Qualitative research methods are increasingly used in clinical trials to answer broader research questions than can be addressed with quantitative methods alone. These methods enable healthcare professionals, service users, and other stakeholders to contribute their views and experiences to the evaluation of healthcare treatments, interventions, or policies, and to influence study design. Qualitative data often provides information that is better suited to reforming policy or influencing design. METHODS: Healthcare researchers, including study participants, clinicians, and qualitative researchers, collaborated to develop a comprehensive portfolio of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for the West Wales Organization for Rigorous Trials in Health (WWORTH), a clinical trials unit (CTU). from Swansea University, which recently received registration with the UK Clinical Research Collaboration (UKCRC). Although the UKCRC requires a total of 25 SOPs from registered CTUs, WWORTH chose to add an additional SOP for qualitative methods (QM-SOP). RESULTS: The SOP for qualitative methods (QM-SOP) defines best practices in the design and implementation of qualitative components of studies while allowing flexibility in approach and method. Its basic principles are: Qualitative researchers should contribute with qualitative potential from the beginning of studies; the qualitative component should have clear objectives;' and the main study publication should report on the qualitative component. CONCLUSIONS: We recommend CTUs to consider developing a QM-SOP to improve the execution of quantitative studies by adding qualitative data and analysis. We believe this will enhance the value of quantitative studies and contribute to the future development of multi-method studies.

title: Quality assessment in surgical supply departments: proposal for a scoring system in terms of structure and process
abstract: Objective To create a score that can reflect and rank surgical departments according to a definition of “quality” in terms of structure and process. Methods Collaborative design of a quality score within the French clinical research project NosoQual. Feasibility and observational study in 46 surgical departments visited between November 2002 and March 2003 according to standardized procedures. A bibliographic review followed by expert consultations, a field test, an analysis and a final review leading to the definition of a consensual score. Results 138 variables comprised the score. They were divided into seven dimensions, each representing a different aspect of the quality of care in surgery. According to the threshold and weight assigned to each variable, scores were calculated for each division. The average degree of fulfillment of the scores varied between 42% and 71% of the theoretical maximum values. The variability of the scores related to the seven dimensions was greater and more significant than that expressed by the total score (coefficient of variation = 0.1). Conclusion This analytical work contributed to the design of a surgical quality score. However, the progress of the score should still take into account all observed obstacles and meet the high demands of the actual topic of patient safety.

title: Quality improvement and changes in patient outcomes for diabetics in a registered nurse's primary care practice
abstract: PURPOSE: To study a range of systemic interventions in the management of patients with diabetes and the outcomes of their management. DATA SOURCES: Data collected from electronic medical records before and after the intervention. CONCLUSIONS: The sample size was smaller than expected, contributing to a lack of statistical significance from preintervention to postintervention in patient outcome measures. System-level variables that were under the direct control of clinicians (e.g., pneumococcal vaccine administered) showed a large improvement. Before the intervention, the percentage of “yes” responses to the system-level variables ranged from 8 to 24 and jumped to 16 to 95 after the intervention. IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: This project has clearly demonstrated that system-level changes result in improved patient care";" However, these had minimal impact on patient outcome variables. It is difficult to encourage change in patient behavior, which may have contributed to the lack of significance in this domain, while variables could be more easily changed under the direct control of clinicians.

title: Improving the quality of medical records in a teaching hospital
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The aim of this study was to evaluate the quality of MR imaging in some operative units of the "Azienda Ospedaliera Universitaria--II Universita di Napoli" (AOU-SUN)-Italy, before and after a quality improvement intervention, highlighting possible differences in the behavior of different specialists (doctors vs. surgeons). METHODS: Two random samples of 660 MRs were reviewed. A four-step program was developed: (1) Initial assessment of the MR"; (2) Implementation of the MR quality, sending a letter with the purpose of the investigation, the results obtained in the first step from this station, the guidelines for correctly filling out the MR ; (3) next step four months later;" (4) Comparison of the data before and after the distribution of the guidelines using indicators of the completeness of all sections of the MR, the clarity of the handwriting and the presence and clarity of the signature.
