Results: The main concerns related to the signature of the doctor on duty (present in 2.0% and legible in only 15.4%), the presence of the discharge letter (18.0%) and the clarity of the hospital days (32.0%) . After the procedure, the improvement in compilation quality was modest and affected medical rather than surgical wards. DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS: The improvement was not satisfactory as the indicators should reach 100% clarity and completeness from a medical and legal point of view. Another study will be carried out to improve the involvement of healthcare professionals so that such requirements are perceived as a common goal and not as mere bureaucratic initiatives.

title: Quality of hospital care for children in Kazakhstan, Moldova and Russia: systematic observational assessment
abstract: Background In developing countries, major concerns have been raised about the quality of primary hospital care for children, but no formal assessment to international standards has been conducted in the Commonwealth of Independent States.";" Background In developing countries, major concerns have been raised about the quality of primary hospital care for children, but no formal assessment to international standards has been conducted in the Commonwealth of Independent States.

title: Quality of pharmaceutical advertisements in medical journals: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Magazine advertising is one of the primary sources of drug information for physicians. Despite the availability of regulations and controls on drug advertising worldwide, information about drugs provided in journal advertisements has been criticized in several studies as substandard. However, no attempt has been made to systematically summarize these research results. We designed this systematic review to assess all studies that examined the quality of drug advertising for prescription products in medical and pharmaceutical journals. METHODS AND RESULTS: Studies were identified by searching electronic databases, web libraries, search engines, and citation checks (1950 - February 2006). Only articles published in English that examined the quality of information contained in pharmaceutical advertisements for prescription products in medical or pharmaceutical journals were included. For each eligible article, a researcher independently extracted data on study methodology and outcomes. The data were then reviewed by a second researcher. Any disagreements were resolved amicably. The data were analyzed descriptively. The final analysis included 24 articles. The studies examined advertisements from 26 countries. The number of journals examined in each study ranged from four to 24 journals. Several outcome measures were examined, including notices and claims in advertisements, availability of product information, compliance with codes or policies, and presentation of risk outcomes. The majority of the studies used a convenience sampling method. Brand name, generic name and particulars were usually given. Journal articles have often been cited to support pharmaceutical claims. Less than 67% of claims were supported by a systematic review, meta-analysis, or randomized controlled trial. Studies evaluating misleading claims had at least one ad with a misleading claim. Two studies found that less than 28% of the claims were clear clinical claims. Most displays with quantitative information provided risk results as relative risk mitigation. Studies have only been conducted in 26 countries and then the generalizability of the results is limited. CONCLUSIONS: Evidence from this review suggests that low quality magazine advertising is a global problem. Because information in magazine ads can change physician prescribing behavior, continued efforts to improve drug advertising education are critical. The results of our review point to the need for a global proactive and effective regulatory regime to ensure that the information provided in medical journal advertising supports the quality use of medicines.

title: Quantitative comparison of cognitive-behavioral therapy and music therapy research: a best-practice methodological analysis to guide future investigations for adult psychiatric patients
abstract: While the music therapy profession is relatively young and small, it can treat a wide variety of clinical populations and has built a diverse research base. However, although the profession has its origins in working with individuals diagnosed with mental illnesses, there is a significant lack of quantitative research on the impact of music therapy on this demographic. Music therapy clinicians and researchers have reported this lack of evidence and the difficulty in conducting psychosocial research on their interventions (Choi, 1997";" Silverman, 2003a). Although published studies have provided suggestions for future research, no study has made detailed suggestions for the methodology and design of thorough, high-quality, randomized, controlled, psychiatric music therapy research. How do other psychotherapies fill out their databases and could music therapy borrow from their rigorous "methodological best practices" to strengthen their own literature base? Therefore, as stated by the National Institutes of Mental Health, the treatment of choice for evidence-based psychotherapy is cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), aspects of the literature base of this psychotherapy were analyzed. The purpose of this literature review was to (a) analyze and identify components of high quality quantitative CBT research for adult psychiatric users, (b) to analyze and identify the variables and other elements of existing quantitative psychiatric music therapy research for adult users, and (c ) compare the two datasets to identify the best methodological designs and variables for future quantitative music therapy research with the mental health population. A table analyzing randomized and rigorously controlled trials involving the use of CBT in individuals with severe mental illness is included to identify the key components of a quality experimental research design and implementation of quantitative clinical research. The table also shows the same analyzed components for existing quantitative psychiatric music therapy research involving adult consumers, highlighting potential areas and elements for future investigation. A second table shows a range of potential dependent measures and their sources to be evaluated in future music therapy studies. A third table with suggestions for future research is derived from a summary of the tables and is intended to guide researchers and encourage further development and expansion of the current literature base. The main part of the work is a discussion of the results of the literature analysis derived from the tables, meta-analyses and literature reviews. It is hoped that this report will result in the literature base of psychiatric music therapy being supplemented with future high-quality quantitative research, thus making evidence-based services available to as many people with mental illness as possible.

title: Striving for quality care and patient safety: the case of Singapore
abstract: The quality of care in Singapore has seen a paradigm shift from a traditional focus on structural approaches to a broader multidimensional approach that includes monitoring of clinical indicators and medical errors. Strong political commitment and institutional capacity were important factors in the transition. What is still missing, however, is a culture of rigorous program evaluation, public participation, and patient empowerment. Despite these imperfections, Singapore has made significant strides, and its experience can be a lesson to other small developing countries as they seek quality care and patient safety together.

title: Quetiapine augmentation in depression: dosing patterns in routine practice
abstract: This study evaluated the dosing patterns of quetiapine augmentation (QA) in major depressive disorder (MDD) in routine practice. Between January 1, 2009 and May 31, 2013, patients diagnosed with MDD and receiving QA in conjunction with an ongoing antidepressant were enrolled in this study. A total of 977 patients' electronic medical records and clinical data were reviewed for up to one year. Almost half of the patients continued QA treatment for more than 3 months. The mean duration of QA was approximately 6 months, and the mean starting and maintenance doses were 23.6 and 40.7 mg/day, respectively (range = 12.5-400 mg/day). The most frequently observed side effects were somnolence, followed by dry mouth and lethargy. Our results indicate that actual QA doses for MDD in routine practice should be lower than doses used in placebo-controlled clinical trials and those recommended by any regulatory agency. Sufficiently rigorous and well-controlled prospective studies are needed to better understand the precise role of low doses of QA in the management of MDD, particularly in routine practice.

title: Randomized controlled trial of a complex intervention by primary care nurses to increase walking ability in patients aged 60-74 years: protocol of the PACE-Lift study (Pedometer Accelerometer Consultation Evaluation - Lift).
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity is essential for the physical and mental health of older people and for maintaining independence. The guidelines recommend at least 150 minutes per week of physical activity of at least moderate intensity, with activity most days. The most common physical activity of older people is walking, light intensity walking, moderate intensity at a more brisk pace. Less than 20% of UK 65-74 year olds say they have achieved the guidelines, although most are able to do so. Effective behavior change techniques include strategies such as goal setting, self-monitoring, building self-efficacy, and relapse prevention. The exercise advice in the basic care allows an individual adjustment of the advice. Pedometers measure the number of steps taken and accelerometers measure the intensity of physical activity. This protocol describes an innovative intervention to improve gait in the elderly that incorporates feedback from pedometers and accelerometers into a primary care nurse's physical activity consultation and uses behavior modification techniques. METHODS/DESIGN: DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial with intervention and control arms (usual care) plus process and qualitative assessments. PARTICIPANTS: 300 people aged 60-74 registered in 3 general practices within the Oxfordshire and Berkshire West Primary Care Trusts were able to go outside and increase their physical activity without restrictions. INTERVENTION: 3-month intervention based on pedometers and accelerometers, supported by physical activity consultations in the in-office nurse. Four consultations based on behavior modification techniques, physical activity diary, average daily pedometer steps, and accelerometer feedback on physical activity intensity. Individual exercise plans are created based on increased walking and other existing physical activities. RESULTS: Change in mean daily steps (primary outcome) and mean weekly time spent in physical activity of at least moderate intensity (secondary outcome) at 3 months and 12 months, assessed by accelerometry. Other outcomes are quality of life, mood, self-efficacy, injuries. Qualitative analyzes will examine reasons for non-participation in the study, patient and caregiver acceptability of the intervention, and factors that promote or act as barriers to older people increasing their physical activity. DISCUSSION: The PACE-Lift study will determine the feasibility and effectiveness of an intervention to increase physical activity in older primary care patients. Measures to minimize bias and the expected challenges are discussed. Word Count 341. TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: ISRCTN42122561.

title: Randomized controlled trial of Alexander Technique Instruction, Exercise and Massage (ATEAM) for chronic and recurrent low back pain
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the effectiveness of lessons in the Alexander Technique, massage therapy, and advice from a physician to exercise (exercise prescription) along with behavioral counseling from nurses for patients with chronic or recurrent low back pain. DESIGN Factorial randomized study. RECRUITMENT 64 GP practices in England. PARTICIPANTS 579 patients with chronic or recurrent low back pain; 144 were randomized to regular care, 147 to massage, 144 to six Alexander Technique sessions, and 144 to 24 Alexander Technique sessions; Half of each of these groups was randomly selected for exercise prescription. INTERVENTIONS Normal care (control), six massage sessions, six or 24 Alexander Technique lessons and exercise prescription by a physician with behavioral counseling by a nurse. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Roland Morris Disability Score (number of activities affected by pain) and number of days with pain. RESULTS Alexander Technique exercise and lessons, but no massage, remained effective at one year (compared to control Roland disability score 8.1: massage -0.58, 95% confidence interval -1.94 to 0.77, six lessons -1.40, -2.77 to -0.03 , 24 Lessons -3.4, -4.76 to -2.03 and Exercise -1.29, -2.25 to -0.34). The exercise after six lessons produced 72% of the effect of 24 lessons alone (Roland disability score -2.98 and -4.14, respectively). The number of days with back pain in the last four weeks was lower after classes (compared to control median 21 days: 24 hours -18, six hours -10, massage -7) and quality of life improved significantly. No significant damage was reported. CONCLUSIONS One-to-one instruction in the Alexander Technique by registered teachers has long-term benefits for patients with chronic low back pain. Six lessons followed by a practice prescription were almost as effective as 24 lessons. TEST REGISTRATION National Research Register N0028108728.

title: Randomized controlled trial of Alexander Technique instruction, exercise and massage (ATEAM) for chronic and recurrent low back pain: economic assessment
abstract: OBJECTIVE To provide an economic evaluation of therapeutic massage, exercise and instruction in the Alexander Technique for the treatment of persistent low back pain. DESIGN Cost-impact study and cost-effectiveness analysis at 12 months follow-up of a factorial randomized controlled trial. PARTICIPANTS 579 patients with chronic or recurrent low back pain were recruited from primary care. INTERVENTIONS Normal care (control), massage and six or 24 lessons in the Alexander Technique. Half of each group was randomly assigned a prescription for exercise from a doctor plus behavioral counseling from a nurse. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Cost to the NHS and participants. Comparison of costs using Roland-Morris Disability Score (number of activities impaired by pain), pain days and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs). Comparison of NHS cost to QALY gain using incremental cost-effectiveness ratios and cost-effectiveness acceptance curves. RESULTS Intervention costs ranged from £30 for an exercise prescription to £596 for 24 Alexander Technique lessons plus exercise. Health services costs ranged from £50 for 24 lessons in Alexander Technique to £124 for exercises. Incremental cost-effectiveness analyzes of individual therapies showed that exercise offered the best value (61 pounds per point on disability score, 9 pounds per additional pain-free day, 2847 pounds per QALY gain). For two-step therapy, six Alexander Technique lessons combined with exercise was the best value (an additional 64 pounds per point on the disability score, 43 pounds per additional pain-free day, 5332 pounds per QALY gain). CONCLUSIONS At values above £20,000 per QALY, the probability that one practice prescription and six Alexander Technique lessons alone was more than 85% cost effective was higher, but the Alexander Technique outperformed practice on all outcomes. A combination of six Alexander Technique lessons followed by exercises was the most effective and cost-effective option.

title: Randomized controlled trial of integrated care to reduce disability from chronic low back pain in work and home life
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the effectiveness of an integrated care program that combines a patient-centered and a workplace-based intervention for patients with chronic low back pain. DESIGN Population-based randomized controlled trial. RECRUITMENT Primary care (10 physical therapy practices, one occupational health service, one occupational therapy practice) and secondary care (five hospitals). PARTICIPANTS 134 adults aged 18 to 65 who had been on sick leave for at least 12 weeks due to back pain. INTERVENTION Patients were randomly assigned to usual care (n=68) or integrated care (n=66). The integrated care consisted of a participatory ergonomics-based workplace intervention involving a supervisor and a graded activity program based on cognitive behavioral principles. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was the length of time from incapacity (incapacity) to work due to back pain to full sustained return to work. Secondary endpoints were pain intensity and functional status. RESULTS The median time to sustainable return to work was 88 days in the integrated care group compared to 208 days in the usual care group (P=0.003). Integrated care was effective in returning to work (hazard ratio 1.9, 95% confidence interval 1.2 to 2.8, P=0.004). At 12 months, patients in the integrated care group improved significantly more in functional status compared to patients in the usual care group (P=0.01). Pain relief between groups did not differ significantly. CONCLUSION The integrated care program has significantly reduced the disability caused by chronic back pain in private and professional life. Study registration Current controlled studies ISRCTN28478651.

title: Randomized controlled trial on tailored strategies to implement guidelines for the management of patients with depression in general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Various methods are available to implement changes in the clinical behavior of general practitioners (GPs). Although passive dissemination of information is generally ineffective, other methods can have varying degrees of effectiveness. Few studies have examined the effects of tailored methods. OBJECTIVE: To determine whether methods tailored to overcoming barriers to change using psychological theories are more effective in implementing guidelines for depression in primary care physicians than dissemination alone. STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: Sixty general practices in England”; 30 general practitioners in the control group, 34 in the intervention group. METHOD: Physicians identified patients with depression before and after implementation of the guidelines (control group n=192 in the first data collection, n=181 in the second; intervention group n=210 in the first data collection and n=197 in the second). Proportion of patients with a Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) score less than 11 at 16 weeks after diagnosis. RESULTS: Compared to the control group, the proportion of patients screened for suicidal risk was increased in the group of general practitioners who received tailored implementation. In the intervention group, the proportion of patients with BDI values less than 11 increased after 16 weeks. CONCLUSION: Implementation barriers can be identified and strategies developed to address them. The results indicate a new approach for research to understand and develop methods of implementation.

title: Randomized controlled trial of change in hospital management for unstable angina
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To investigate the usefulness of a guideline-based educational program to improve the management of unstable angina pectoris (UAP) in hospitalized patients. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: 37 public hospitals across New South Wales. PATIENTS: 1,872 patients admitted between February 1 and June 30, 1996 (baseline) with a UAP diagnosis and 1,368 patients with the same diagnosis admitted between July 1 and December 31, 1998 ( follow-up survey). INTERVENTION: Awareness sessions led by local thought leaders presenting National Health and Medical Research Council guidelines on management of UAP and feedback on local practice using data from the baseline survey. The meetings were held between March and June 1998. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Use of evidence-based practices identified through review of medical records. RESULTS: Beta-blocker use increased in intervention and control hospitals, although the increase was only significant in the former. The use of calcium channel blockers decreased significantly in both intervention and control hospitals. However, the change in drug use between baseline and follow-up did not differ significantly between intervention and control hospitals. CONCLUSIONS: Despite some reasonable changes in drug use for UAP management between 1996 and 1998, there was no evidence that a guideline-based training program was of benefit in management change. This again confirms the difficulty of changing physician behavior through practice guidelines. Alternative methods of promoting evidence-based practice should be considered.

title: Randomized trial of an integrated education strategy to reduce screening rates in young women with dysfunctional uterine bleeding
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the effectiveness of an integrated educational strategy to change clinical behavior and reduce the number of hysteroscopies and/or dilatations and curettage in women younger than 40 years with dysfunctional uterine bleeding (DUB). DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial with six-month follow-up. SETTING: Gynecological departments of the public teaching hospital with 12,000-13,000 relevant procedures per year. PARTICIPANTS: Six public gynecology units consisting of 62 gynecologists or trainees randomly assigned to an intervention group—three or control—opinion leaders and a laminated algorithm and guidelines. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: The number of hysteroscopies and/or dilations and curettage performed for DUB in women under 40 years of age, change in clinical behavior, and perceived booking rates of the procedure. RESULTS: At six months, there was no significant effect on the number of hysteroscopies and/or dilatations and curettage performed, but there was an increase in evidence-based behavior. CONCLUSIONS: While the evidence-based educational strategy for the appropriate screening of young women with DUB resulted in a change in clinical behavior when applied to theoretical cases, it did not result in a reduction in hysteroscopy/D&C rates at six months.

title: Randomized Clinical Trial of a Custom Electronic Alert Requiring a Positive Response Versus a Control Group Receiving a Commercial Passive CPOE Alert: NSAID - Warfarin Co-Prescribing Test Case.
abstract: Background studies looking at the effectiveness of computerized decision support systems in preventing drug-drug interactions have reported modest results due to poor vendor response to the automated alerts. Objective To evaluate the incremental effectiveness of an alert requiring a provider response within an inpatient Computerized Doctor Order Entry (CPOE) system intended as a stronger intervention to prevent concomitant warfarin and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) orders. 1963 Design Randomized clinical trial with clinicians assigned to either an intervention group that received a custom electronic alarm requiring a positive response or a control group that received a commercially available passive alarm as part of the CPOE. The study period was from August 2, 2006 to December 15, 2007. Measurements Alert adherence was compared between study groups. Results The proportion of desired ordering reactions (ie no reordering of the alarm-triggering medication after dispensing) was lower in the intervention group (114/464 (25%) issued individual alarms) than in the control group (154/560 (28%) passive alarm triggering). The adjusted OR of inappropriate order was 1.22 (95% CI 0.69 to 2.16). Conclusion A custom CPOE alert that required a physician response had no effect in reducing co-prescribing of NSAIDs and warfarin beyond that of the commercially available passive alert received by the control group. New CPOE warnings to improve prescribing cannot be assumed to be effective and need to be evaluated.

title: Randomized controlled clinical efficacy trial of cognitive behavioral therapy versus usual care for persistent insomnia in cancer patients
abstract: PURPOSE: Persistent insomnia is a common complaint in cancer survivors but is rarely treated satisfactorily. Matching a validated, cost-effective intervention to cancer treatment may be a viable solution. The aim of this study was to investigate the clinical efficacy of protocol-guided cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for insomnia performed by oncology nurses. PATIENTS AND METHODS: Randomized, controlled, pragmatic, two-center study of CBT versus treatment as usual (TAU) in 150 patients (103 females; mean age 61 years) who were on active therapy for breast, prostate, colon, or gynecologic cancer. The study was in accordance with CONSORT guidelines. Primary endpoints were sleep diary measurements at baseline, post-treatment, and 6-month follow-up. Actigraphic sleep, health-related quality of life (QOL), psychopathology, and fatigue were secondary measures. CBT consisted of five small group sessions over consecutive weeks following a manual protocol. TAU represented normal clinical practice;" the appropriate control for a clinical efficacy study. RESULTS: CBT was associated with an average reduction in wakefulness of 55 minutes per night compared with no change in TAU. These results persisted 6 months after treatment. The standardized relative effect sizes were large for complaints of difficulty falling asleep, waking up from sleep during the night, and sleep efficiency (percentage of time spent asleep in bed.) CBT was associated with moderate to large effect sizes on five out of seven QOL outcomes, including one significant reduction in daytime sleepiness. There was no significant interaction effect between these endpoints and demographic, clinical, or baseline sleep characteristics. CONCLUSION: CBT for insomnia may be both clinically effective and practically feasible.

title: Randomized controlled study of a computer strategy to improve general practitioner screening
abstract: BACKGROUND: Previous interventions targeted at primary care physicians and aimed at improving preventive care have shown limited effectiveness. The primary objective of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a computer-assisted medical education program to increase rates of three screening behaviors (cholesterol, blood pressure, and cervical cancer screening) and to identify three risk behaviors (smoking, alcohol use, benzodiazepine use). . in general practice. METHODS: Nineteen general practitioners were randomly assigned to intervention or control conditions. Those who received the intervention received a computerized feedback system. The procedure was performed via a touch screen computer located in the surgery waiting area. The preventive behaviors of interest were smoking, alcohol use, benzodiazepine use, and blood pressure, cholesterol, and cervical screening using the Papanicolou test. Differences in performance by group in each of the outcomes were measured at baseline and 3-month follow-up. Logistic regression analyzes with generalized estimation equations were carried out as the main analyses. RESULTS: At 3 months follow-up, statistically significant differences were evident in the following outcome measures: accurate classification of benzodiazepine users (z=2.8540, P<0.05)", accurate classification of non-benzodiazepine users ( z=2.7339, P<0.05); accurate classification of dangerous or harmful alcohol drinkers (z=2.3079, P<0.02); blood pressure screening (z=3.4136, P<0.001);" and cholesterol screening (z=6.6313, P<0.001). CONCLUSION: A computerized system of performance-specific feedback was effective in improving some preventive care services in general practice.

title: Randomized controlled trial of a computer-adapted multiple health behaviors intervention in general practice: 12-month follow-up results
abstract: BACKGROUND: Effective strategies to address noncommunicable disease risk factors are needed to contain rising healthcare costs. This study tested the effectiveness of a minimal intervention targeting multiple health behaviors (diet, physical activity, alcohol, and smoking) in a general practice by providing personalized computer-tailored feedback over a one-year period. METHODS: Patients who had attended a GP practice in the previous 6 months were recruited from 21 GPs in Brisbane, Australia. Baseline data was collected from self-reported adherence to ten health behaviors and summarized into a 0 to 10 health score. This randomized controlled trial used a 2x2 factorial design, with one arm randomly assigning subjects to the intervention or control group. The other arm was either feedback at baseline (single contact) or an additional assessment with feedback at 3 months (dual contact). As such, 4 study groups were formed into which the participants were blindly randomized: A. Intervention with one-on-one contact; B. Dual contact intervention; C. Single Contact Control; and D. Dual Contact Control. All participants were reassessed. RESULTS: Of the 4676 randomized participants, 3065 completed the questionnaires at 12 months. Both single and dual contact groups improved their 10 item health scores (+0.31 and +0.49, respectively) compared to the results of the control group (+0.02; p<). 0.01). Improvement in adherence to guidelines for fish consumption, milk consumed, vegetable and fruit consumption, and alcohol consumption was observed in single and double contact intervention groups (p<0.01). Both intervention groups showed greater improvement than controls for the individual Health behaviors other than red meat consumption, smoking behavior, physical activity, and body weight. Interestingly, there was an improvement in reported smoking rates in both the intervention and control l groups (3% single exposure; 4.5% dual exposure). CONCLUSIONS: Small but meaningful long-term changes in health behavior can be achieved with a low-intensity intervention that, if implemented widely, can reduce healthcare costs. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanism by which maintenance of behavior change can be achieved. STUDY REGISTRATION: Australia-New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry: ACTRN12611001213932.

title: Randomized controlled trial to provide education and feedback on implementation of acute low back pain guidelines
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The effect of clinical guidelines on resource use in complex conditions with significant barriers to clinical behavior change has not been well studied. We report the impact of a multifaceted guideline implementation intervention on primary care physician utilization of radiological and specialized services for the management of acute low back pain. DESIGN: Physician groups were randomized to receive guideline training and individual feedback, supportive patient training materials, both or neither. Impact on compliance and resource utilization were assessed during the 12-month period before and after implementation. PARTICIPANTS: Fourteen physician groups with 120 primary care physicians and associated practitioners from 2 group model HMO practices. INTERVENTIONS: A training/audit/feedback model with local opinion leaders was used in the implementation of the guideline. The patient education component included written and videotaped material on the management of back pain. MAIN RESULTS: Clinical intervention was associated with an absolute increase in guideline compliance of 5.4% in the intervention group compared to a decrease of 2.7% in the control group (p=0.04). The patient education intervention did not bring about a significant change in guideline-compliant behavior, but was only insufficiently accepted. Patient characteristics, including duration of pain, history of low back pain, and number of visits during the illness episode, were strong predictors of service utilization and guideline-compliant behavior. CONCLUSIONS: The implementation of a training- and feedback-supported guideline for the treatment of acute low back pain for general practitioners was associated with an increase in guideline-compliant behavior. Patient education materials did not improve the effectiveness of the guideline. Implementation barriers could limit the usefulness of this approach in common care settings.

title: Randomized controlled trial of cardiovascular risk management by practice nurses supported by self-monitoring in primary care
abstract: UNTITLED: BACKGROUND: Treatment goals for cardiovascular risk management are generally not met. Specialized practice nurses are increasingly making the work of general practitioners easier, and self-monitoring devices have been developed to provide advice. The aim of this study was to compare standard of care supported by self-monitoring versus standard of care without self-monitoring, both performed by practice nurses, in terms of cardiovascular risk and individual risk factors. METHODS: Men aged 50-75 years and women aged 55-75 years with no history of cardiovascular disease or diabetes but with a SCORE 10-year risk of cardiovascular mortality >/= 5% and at least one treatable Risk factor (smoking, high blood pressure, lack of exercise or obesity) were randomized into two groups. The control group received standard treatment in line with the guidelines, the intervention group also received proactive advice and self-monitoring (pedometer, scales and/or blood pressure monitor). After one year, the treatment effect was analyzed in 179 participants. RESULTS: The SCORE risk score decreased by 1.6% (95% CI 1.0-2.2) for the control group and by 1.8% (1.2-2.4) for the intervention group, the difference between groups was 0.2% (-0.6–1.1). Most risk factors tended to improve in both groups. In the intervention group, the number of visits was higher and the visits took longer (4.9 (SD2.2) vs. 2.6 (SD1.5) visits p < 0.001 and 27 (P25 - P75:20-33 ) vs. 23 (P25-P75:19-30) minutes/visit p= 0.048). CONCLUSIONS: In both groups, cardiovascular risk decreased significantly after one year of treatment by practicing nurses. Despite the additional time investment, no additional effect was found when proactive counseling was based on self-monitoring. TEST REGISTRATION: trialregister.nl NTR2188.

title: Randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of a primary health care liaison worker in promoting shared care for opiate users
abstract: BACKGROUND: Recent national guidance emphasizes the requirement for all general practitioners to treat drug users within a shared care system and suggests that a primary health care liaison officer (PHCLW) can facilitate these arrangements. We conducted a group randomized controlled trial to determine the effectiveness of a PHCLW in promoting shared care. METHODS: Primary health care teams from Stockport Health Authority, North West England, were randomly assigned to either an intervention arm, which was offered the services of a PHCLW, or a control arm, which was offered standard support from the local drug team (CDT). The proportion of CDT clients with a history of regular opiate abuse who were in co-care 12 months after randomization was compared across study arms. RESULTS: Eighteen (24.0 percent) of the 75 CDT clients in the intervention arm, but none of the 80 CDT clients in the control arm were in co-care at 12 months (chi2 = 9.37, df = 1, p<0.01 ";" 95 percent confidence interval 8.6-39.4 percent). CONCLUSION: A PHCLW can significantly increase the number of CDT clients in shared care arrangements.

title: Randomized controlled trial: Effect of nutritional counseling in the general practice
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To investigate the effectiveness of a non-structured 15-minute educational intervention by general practitioners (GPs) to adjust daily diet in healthy adults. DESIGN: Two-arm randomized study with a duration of 12 months. SETTING: Italian general practitioner departments. Subjects A total of 3,186 men and women aged 18-65 years were admitted to the medical unit by their general practitioners. INTERVENTIONS: An educational intervention and brochure on the basics of healthy eating based on the Italian guidelines for proper nutrition, 1998. The main objective of the study was to achieve an intake of fruits and vegetables of >5 servings per day. Follow-up check every 6 months. The main outcome measures weight, blood pressure and a 40-item food frequency questionnaire. RESULTS: The intervention group showed a slightly reduced net intake of meat and a slightly increased net intake of fruit and vegetables, fish products, and olive oil. Body mass index (BMI) changed only in the treatment arm [-0.41 95% confidence interval (95% CI) -0.11 to -0.53]. The net change at 1 year in the intervention arm was +1.31 (CI 0.90-4.39) for fruits and vegetables and -0.22 (-0.11 to -0.69) for meat (servings per week). We also calculated a "Healthy Eating Score" that reflects adherence to recommended eating habits. In the intervention group, the mean at recruitment was significantly lower than the mean at the end of follow-up (change in raw score = 0.29"; CI 0.19-0.48). No differences were observed in the control group (change in raw score = -0.04; "CI -0.22-0.02). The difference in score from baseline to last visit comparing the intervention to the control group was statistically significant (P<0.001) (MANOVA adjusted for gender, BMI, education and time). CONCLUSIONS: Brief educational intervention by primary care physicians can induce several dietary changes that can lower BMI and potentially reduce the risk of chronic disease in generally healthy adults.

title: Randomized study of online vaccination reminders in adult primary care
abstract: Online vaccination reminders were implemented in an adult medicine environment where all vaccination history, vaccine ordering and record-keeping were required online. Physicians were randomized to one of two arms in a cross-over design. Each arm was presented with online vaccine recommendations provided by nationally accepted guidelines during either the first or second part of the study period. The main purpose of the study was to assess the impact of reminders on correct vaccine prescribing decisions. Online reminders had the following effects on physician behavior: 1) Physicians used the application almost three times more when reminders were presented to them. 2) Physicians in the memory group were 27% less likely to order a vaccine in the memory group (P-value 0.0005). 3) Adherence to the guidelines was significantly improved for tetanus and for hepatitis B in several analyses. No such effects have been observed with pneumococcal, measles or influenza vaccines.

title: Randomized Trial of a Clinical Decision Support System: Implications for the Treatment of Children with Unidentified Source Fever.
abstract: Aim: To evaluate adherence to a clinical decision support system (CDSS) for the diagnostic management of children with fever without an identifiable source and to investigate the impact of using the CDSS on the time spent in the emergency department (ED) and the number of laboratory tests. Design: The CDSS was used by ED nurses to register children presenting with a fever. The CDSS identified children who met the inclusion criteria (1-36 months and fever without apparent source (FWS)) and provided patient-specific diagnostic treatment recommendations. Children at high risk of serious bacterial infections were randomly assigned to the "intervention" (n _x0001_ 74) or the "control" (n _x0001_ 90) group. In the intervention group, the CDSS advised that laboratory tests be ordered immediately, and in the control group, the ED doctor first examined the children and then decided to order laboratory tests. RESULTS: Adherence to registration of febrile children was 50% (683/1,399). Adherence to the recommendation to order laboratory tests was 82% (61/74). Children in the intervention group had a median (25th-75th percentile) length of stay in the emergency department of 138 (104-181) minutes. The median length of stay in the emergency room in the control group was 123 (83-179) minutes. Laboratory tests were ordered significantly more frequently in the intervention group (82%) than in the control group (44%, p 0.001, _x0001_2 test). Conclusion: The implementation of a CDSS for the diagnostic management of infants with fever without an identifiable source was successful in terms of adherence and adherence to CDSS recommendations, but had unexpected implications for patient outcome in terms of length of ED stay and count of laboratory tests. The use of the current CDSS has been discontinued.

title: Randomized study of model predictive control for improved anemia management
abstract: Background and Objectives: A variable hemoglobin (Hb) response to erythropoiesis-stimulating agents can lead to undesirable outcomes. The utility of model predictive control for drug dosing has been previously demonstrated. DESIGN, SETTING, PARTICIPANTS, AND MEASUREMENTS: This was a double-blind, randomized, controlled study testing model predictive control for dosing of erythropoietin in ESRD patients. The study included 60 hemodialysis patients who were randomized to a treatment arm (30 subjects) that received erythropoietin doses based on the computer recommendations or a control arm (30 subjects) that received erythropoietin doses based on recommendations from a standard anemia Management received log (control). The subjects were followed for 8 months and the proportions of measured Hb within the target range of 11 to 12 g/dl and outside of 9 to 13 g/dl were measured. Hb variability was measured using the absolute difference between the achieved Hb and the target Hb of 11.5 g/dl and the area under the Hb curve. Results: The model predictive control revealed 15 observations >13 or <9 g/dl (outliers), a mean absolute difference between the achieved Hb and 11.5 g/dl of 0.98 ± 0.08 g/dl and an area under the Hb curve of 2.86 ± 1.46. The control group algorithm resulted in 30 Hb outliers (P=0.051), produced a mean absolute difference between achieved Hb and 11.5 g/dL of 1.18 ± 0.18 g/dL (P<0.001 difference in variance) and an area under the Hb curve of 3.38 ± 2.69 (P = 0.025 difference in variance). Conclusions: Model predictive control of erythropoietin administration improves anemia management.

title: Randomized study of problem-based vs. didactic seminars to disseminate evidence-based asthma management guidelines to general practitioners
abstract: INTRODUCTION: This randomized controlled trial (RCT) evaluated the effectiveness and satisfaction with small group problem-based learning (PBL) versus a didactic lecture approach to guideline dissemination in asthma management that controls for confounders common in comparative educational interventions. METHODS: Sites were selected as either lecture or PBL with simple randomization. All participants were exposed to similar educational resources to ensure equivalence of treatment. The tools included standardized programme/speaker rating forms and a validated case-based questionnaire with a visual analogue scale measuring the confidence level of the responses. The latter was presented immediately before and after the intervention and 3 months later. The statistician was blinded to intervention groups. RESULTS: A total of 52 general practitioners agreed to participate, 23 to the PBL sessions (mean 4.6 per group) and 29 to the didactic lecture sessions (mean 7.25). There was no significant difference between the groups in knowledge gain for each test administration. Participants rated the instructor or facilitator as equally good for creating a positive learning environment. PBL participants rated the perceived educational value of the program higher than lecture participants (4.36 vs. 3.93; p=0.04). Both groups experienced a significant increase in asthma-related knowledge after the intervention. Turnover rates for the 3-month posttest were 14% for PBL participants versus 32% for lecture-based participants. DISCUSSION: PBL was as effective at acquiring and retaining knowledge as lecture-based continuing education (CME) programs. Further studies are warranted to examine whether the assessment of higher educational value or an increase in delayed test response rate is reproducible in other RCTs addressing common confounders and whether these factors influence future CME participation, changes in clinical behavior of physicians or patient health outcomes.

title: Randomized study to improve prescription safety in outpatient elderly patients.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To determine whether a computerized tool that alerted pharmacists when patients 65 years of age and older were being re-prescribed potentially inappropriate medications was effective in reducing the proportion of patients dispensing those medications. DESIGN: Prospective, randomized study. SETTING: US health care organization. PARTICIPANTS: All 59,680 health plan members aged 65 years and older were randomized to receive intervention (n=29,840) or usual care (n=29,840). Pharmacists received notifications for all patients randomized to the intervention who were newly prescribed a targeted drug. INTERVENTION: Prescribing and age information was linked to alert pharmacists when a patient age 65 years or older was prescribed any of 11 medications that may be inappropriate for the elderly. MEASUREMENTS: Physicians and pharmacists collaborated to develop the targeted medication list, indications for medication use for which intervention should be made, intervention guidelines and scripts, and implementation of the intervention. RESULTS: During the 1-year study, 543 (1.8%) patients aged 65 years and older in the intervention group received new prescriptions for targeted medications, compared with 644 (2.2%) patients in the usual care group (P = 0.002). For medication indications that warrant intervention, the deliveries of amitriptyline (P<0.001) and diazepam (P=0.02) were reduced. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrated the effectiveness of a computerized pharmacy alert system and collaboration between healthcare professionals in reducing potentially inappropriate medication spending in elderly patients. The coupling of data available from information systems with the knowledge and skills of physicians and pharmacists can improve prescription safety for patients aged 65 and over.

title: Randomized controlled trial of the effectiveness of simulation teaching: A 24-month follow-up study in a clinical setting
abstract: BACKGROUND: The knowledge and skills of critical care nurses to follow evidence-based guidelines to prevent complications associated with intubation and mechanical ventilation are currently limited. We hypothesized that a single simulation training session would result in sustained higher levels of proficiency in critical care nurses. MATERIALS AND METHODS: A randomized controlled trial was conducted from February 2012 to March 2014 in a 22-bed adult mixed medical-surgical intensive care unit in Finland. Thirty of 40 originally randomized critical care nurses participated in a 24-month follow-up study. Behavior and cognitive development were assessed using a validated ventilation bundle observation plan and questionnaire at baseline and repeated 3 times during simulation and in real clinical conditions. RESULTS: After the simulation training, the mean competence score increased from 46.8% to 58.8% of the total score in the final postintervention measurement (P-time < 0.001, P-time x group = 0.040, and P-group = 0.11). The mean knowledge values within the groups did not change significantly. The mean difference between groups in competency scores was significant only when measured at 6 months (P=0.006). CONCLUSIONS: Critical care nurses' skills in adhering to evidence-based guidelines improved over time in both groups, but improvements between study groups were significantly different only at 6 months and were no longer evident at 2 years after a single simulation training session.

title: Rapid Change in Prescribing Behavior in Hospitals Participating in the Guidelines - Stroke after Approving Management of Atherothrombosis with Clopidogrel in High-Risk Patients (MATCH) Clinical Trial Results
abstract: BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE: Physician prescribing patterns are changing slowly, despite published randomized trials and consensus guidelines. We measure the effect of the Management of Atherothrombosis With Clopidogrel in High-Risk Patients (MATCH) study on the prescribing patterns of stroke and transient ischemic attack patients in the Get With The Guidelines (GWTG)-Stroke Program. METHODS: We analyzed the discharge prescription patterns of antithrombotic drugs for patients admitted to hospitals participating in GWTG-Stroke between October 2002 and January 2006 with ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack. Clinical information by quarter was analyzed in relation to the publication of the MATCH study. The frequency of discharge prescription of aspirin + clopidogrel after MATCH publication was compared to the pre-MATCH period after patient and hospital characteristics were adjusted and clustered by hospital. RESULTS: A total of 107,872 patients at 632 sites were eligible for antithrombotic therapy at discharge. Use of aspirin + clopidogrel therapy decreased from 22.4% to 15.4% of patients after publication of MATCH (adjusted OR 0.62, 95% CI 0.56 to 0.70, p<0.0001 ). Quarterly analysis revealed a rapid and sustained decline in aspirin + clopidogrel therapy use for the remainder of the study period. CONCLUSIONS: After publication of the MATCH study without MATCH-specific GWTG stroke initiatives and prior to an update of the American Heart Association guidelines, a rapid and sustained reduction in the frequency of aspirin + clopidogrel use in ischemic stroke and transient ischemic attack was observed .

title: Rational prescribing in primary care (RaPP): Economic evaluation of an intervention to improve professional practice.
abstract: Background Interventions aimed at bridging the gap between research findings and clinical practice can be effective but also costly. Whether such interventions are worthwhile can be assessed on the basis of economic evaluations. We assessed the economic impact of a tailored intervention to support the implementation of guidelines for the use of antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering drugs. The tailored intervention was evaluated in a randomized trial and was shown to significantly increase thiazide use in patients who started antihypertensive medication, but had little or no effect on other outcomes. It was not to be expected that the increased use of thiazides would have an impact on the health consequences. Methods and Results We performed cost minimization and cost-effectiveness analyzes on data from a randomized study of 146 general practices from two geographic areas in Norway. Each practice was randomly assigned to either the tailored intervention (70 practices; 257 physicians) or the control group (69 practices; 244 physicians). Only patients who were started on antihypertensive medication were included in the analyses. A multi-faceted intervention was tailored to address identified barriers to change. Key components were an educational visit with audit and feedback, and computerized reminders. Pharmacists conducted the visits. A cost minimization framework was put in place, comparing the cost of the intervention with the reduced cost of treatment (mainly due to the increased use of thiazides instead of more expensive drugs). The cost-effectiveness of the intervention was estimated as the cost per additional patient started on thiazides. The annual net cost (cost minimization) in our study population was $53,395, equivalent to $763 per practice. The cost per additional patient who started thiazides (cost-effectiveness) was US$454. Annual net savings in a national program were modeled at $761,998, or $540 per practice at 2 years. In this scenario, savings exceeded costs in all but two of the sensitivity analyzes we performed, and cost-effectiveness was estimated at $183. Conclusions We found a significant shift in antihypertensive drug prescribing towards the use of thiazides in our study. A key reason for promoting the use of thiazides is their lower price compared to other drugs. The cost of the intervention more than doubled the savings within the time frame of our study. However, we project modest savings over a 2-year period.

title: Rationale and design of the study to evaluate the effect of cardiovascular drugs provided as a low-cost, evidence-based generic samples (SAMPLES) study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Highly effective generic cardiovascular drugs are often underused, leading to higher overall drug costs and cost-related nonadherence. OBJECTIVE: We wanted to evaluate an intervention to promote the appropriate use of generic cardiovascular drugs without creating administrative or financial barriers that might impede the use of essential drugs. STUDY DESIGN: The SAMPLES study (Study Assessing the Effect of Cardiovascular Medications Provided as Low-cost, Evidence-based Generic Samples) is a clustered, randomized, controlled study of the effect of providing free generic samples of hydrochlorothiazide to patients with hypertension and simvastatin to patients with hyperlipidemia. We will randomize 660 primary care physicians in Pennsylvania, grouped by physician practice, to receive free samples for both conditions or not to receive samples. We will use data on prescriptions issued from a government-sponsored prescription drug support program to conduct an intention-to-treat assessment of the impact of the intervention on physician prescribing behavior (proportion of generic prescriptions) and patient adherence. Secondary outcomes include physician adherence to established guidelines and overall prescription drug costs. CONCLUSION: This study will define the potential role of an innovative approach in promoting clinically appropriate, cost-effective prescribing. We will determine whether free generic drug trials can reduce overall drug costs and patient costs without compromising efficacy, and whether this approach leads to improved adherence to essential cardiovascular drugs. This intervention can also improve adherence to practice guidelines and improve the quality of care received. If successful, this strategy could be used extensively by private insurers or government payers to promote cheaper, better quality care.

title: Reasons and consequences of poor adherence to standard precautions by the care team
abstract: Standard Precautions (SP) are recommendations to prevent infection and protect healthcare workers during care, however, there is still low adherence to these recommendations. Objective To analyze the reasons and consequences of low compliance by nursing staff with Standard Accommodations. Method Integrative literature search, search in seven databases, from 2005 to 2014. Results 30 articles were selected for analysis. The proven reasons for low compliance relate to poor lifelong learning practices, risky behavior by workers, insufficient provision of equipment and protective equipment, and poor working conditions. The consequences are accidents and occupational diseases. There are few intervention studies that merely provide guidance to professionals. Conclusions Low compliance with standard accommodations is related to individual aspects of workers, employers and educational institutions. The intervention strategies implemented have proven to be ineffective if they only focus on the worker.

title: Oral health recall intervals in primary care patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: The frequency with which patients should come for dental check-ups and the potential impact on oral health of changing the reminder intervals between check-ups has been the subject of ongoing international debate for almost 3 decades. Although recommendations for optimal obituary intervals vary by country and dental health care system, in many developed countries, general dentists have traditionally advocated every 6-month dental check-up. OBJECTIVES: To determine the beneficial and detrimental effects of different fixed repeat intervals (e.g., 6 months versus 12 months) for the following different types of dental examination: a) "clinical examination" only; b) clinical examination plus scale and polish; c) clinical Examination plus preventive consultation d) Clinical examination plus preventive consultation plus scale and polish To determine the relative beneficial and harmful effects between these different types of dental check-ups at the same fixed repeat interval. To compare the beneficial effects and harmful effects of recall intervals based on the judgment of the clinical staff on the disease risk of patients with fixed recall intervals Comparison of the beneficial and harmful effects of no recall interval/patient-directed attendance (which may be symptomatic) with fixed recall intervals We searched en the Cochrane Oral Health Group Trials Register, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE and EMBASE reference lists of relevant articles were scanned and the authors of some articles were contacted to identify additional studies and obtain additional information. Date of Last Search: March 5, 2007. SELECTION CRITERIA: Studies were selected if they met the following criteria: Design - random assignment of participants; Participants - all children and adults receiving primary care dental check-ups, regardless of their risk level for oral disease; Procedures - reminder intervals for the following different types of dental check-ups: a) clinical examination only; b) clinical examination plus weighing and polishing; c) clinical examination plus preventive advice; d) clinical examination plus scale and polish plus preventive consultation; e) no recall interval/patient controlled attendance (which may be symptomatic); f) risk-based physician recall intervals; Results - clinical status results for dental caries (including but not limited to mean dmft/DMFT, dmfs/DMFS scores, caries increment, filled teeth (including replacement restorations), early carious lesions stopped or reversed); periodontal disease (including but not limited to plaque, calculus, gingivitis, periodontitis, change in probing depth, attachment height);" oral mucosa (presence or absence of mucosal lesions, potentially malignant lesions, cancerous lesions, size and stage of cancerous lesions at diagnosis) In addition, the following outcomes were considered where reported: patient-centric outcomes, economic cost outcomes, other outcomes such as improvements in oral health knowledge and attitudes, harms, changes in dietary habits, and other behaviors related to oral health DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Information on methods , participants, interventions, outcome measures, and outcomes were independently extracted in duplicate by two review authors. Data Clarification A quality assessment of the included study was performed t Statistics of the Cochrane Collaboration guidelines were met. MAIN RESULTS: Only one study (with 188 participants) was included in this review and was assessed as having a high risk of bias. This study provided limited data on dental caries outcomes (dmfs/DMFS increment) and economic cost outcomes (reported time spent on assessment and treatment). AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: There is insufficient evidence from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to draw conclusions regarding the potential beneficial and harmful effects of changing the reminder interval between dental check-ups. There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the practice of encouraging patients to have dental check-ups every 6 months. It is important that high-quality RCTs are conducted for the endpoints presented in this review in order to achieve the objectives of this review.

title: Oral health recall intervals in primary care patients
abstract: BACKGROUND: The frequency with which patients should come for dental check-ups and the potential impact on oral health of changing the reminder intervals between check-ups has been the subject of ongoing international debate for almost 3 decades. Although recommendations for optimal obituary intervals vary by country and dental health care system, in many developed countries, general dentists have traditionally advocated every 6-month dental check-up. OBJECTIVES: To determine the beneficial and detrimental effects of different fixed repeat intervals (e.g., 6 months versus 12 months) for the following different types of dental examination: a) "clinical examination" only; b) clinical examination plus scale and polish; c) clinical Examination plus preventive consultation d) Clinical examination plus preventive consultation plus scale and polish To determine the relative beneficial and harmful effects between these different types of dental check-ups at the same fixed repeat interval. To compare the beneficial effects and harmful effects of recall intervals based on the judgment of the clinical staff on the disease risk of patients with fixed recall intervals Comparison of the beneficial and harmful effects of no recall interval/patient-directed attendance (which may be symptomatic) with fixed recall intervals We searched en the Cochrane Oral Health Group Trials Register, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE and EMBASE reference lists of relevant articles were scanned and the authors of some articles were contacted to identify additional studies and obtain additional information. Date of Last Search: April 9, 2003. SELECTION CRITERIA: Studies were selected if they met the following criteria: design - random assignment of participants; Participants - all children and adults receiving primary care dental check-ups, regardless of their risk level for oral disease; Procedures - reminder intervals for the following different types of dental check-ups: a) clinical examination only; b) clinical examination plus weighing and polishing; c) clinical examination plus preventive advice; d) clinical examination plus scale and polish plus preventive consultation; e) no recall interval/patient controlled attendance (which may be symptomatic); f) risk-based physician recall intervals; Results - clinical status results for dental caries (including but not limited to mean dmft/DMFT, dmfs/DMFS scores, caries increment, filled teeth (including replacement restorations), early carious lesions stopped or reversed); periodontal disease (including but not limited to plaque, calculus, gingivitis, periodontitis, change in probing depth, attachment height);" oral mucosa (presence or absence of mucosal lesions, potentially malignant lesions, cancerous lesions, size and stage of cancerous lesions at diagnosis) In addition, the following outcomes were considered where reported: patient-centric outcomes, economic cost outcomes, other outcomes such as improvements in oral health knowledge and attitudes, harms, changes in dietary habits, and other behaviors related to oral health DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Information on methods , participants, interventions, outcome measures, and outcomes were independently extracted in duplicate by two authors. Authors were contacted when deemed necessary and possible to provide further information to obtain further details on the study design and data. Clarification: A quality assessment of the included study was carried out. The statistical Gu. the Cochrane Oral Health Group ideals were met. MAIN RESULTS: Only one study (with 188 participants) was included in this review and was assessed as having a high risk of bias. This study provided limited data on dental caries outcomes (dmfs/DMFS increment) and economic cost outcomes (reported time spent on assessment and treatment). AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS: There is insufficient evidence from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to draw conclusions regarding the potential beneficial and harmful effects of changing the reminder interval between dental check-ups. There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the practice of encouraging patients to have dental check-ups every 6 months. It is important that high-quality RCTs are conducted for the endpoints presented in this review in order to achieve the objectives of this review.

title: Recent trends in violent behavior among high school students in the United States
abstract: Context Violent behaviors such as fighting and carrying weapons have serious physical and psychosocial consequences for young people. Objective To measure trends in nonfatal violent behavior among youth in the United States between 1991 and 1997. Design, Setting, and Participants Nationally representative data from the 1991, 1993, 1995, and 1997 Youth Risk Behavior Surveys were analyzed to determine the percentage of students describe in grades 9 through 12 who exhibited violent behaviors. The overall response rates for each of these years were 68%, 70%, 60%, and 69%, respectively. To assess the statistical significance of time trends for these variables, logistic regression analyzes controlling for sex, class, and race or ethnicity while assessing linear and higher-order effects were performed. Main Outcome Measures Self-reported carrying of weapons, physical combat, combat-related injuries, feeling unsafe, and damaged or stolen property. Results Between 1991 and 1997, the percentage of students engaged in physical combat decreased by 14%, from 42.5% (95% confidence interval [CI], 40.1% - 44.9%) to 36.6% (95% CI , 34.6% - 38.6%). "; the percentage of students who were injured in a physical fight decreased by 20%, from 4.4% (95% CI, 3.6% - 5.2%) to 3.5% (95% CI, 2.9% - 4.1%)); and the percentage of students who carried a gun decreased by 30%, from 26.1% (95% CI: 23.8% - 28.4 %) to 18.3% (95% CI: 16.5% - 20.1%), 25%, from 7.9% (95% CI, 6.6% - 9.2%) to 5 .9% (95% CI, 5.1%-6.7%); the percentage of students engaging in physical fights on school premises decreased by 9% (95% CI, 15, 0% - 17.4%) to 14.8% (95% CI, 13.5% - 16.1%));" and the percentage of students carrying a gun on school property decreased by 28%, from 11.8% (95% CI, 10.4%-13.2%) to 8.5% (95% CI, 7th .0% - 10.0%). All of these changes represent significant linear decreases. Conclusions The declines in hostilities and gunplay among US youth between 1991 and 1997 are encouraging and consistent with the declines in homicide, nonfatal victimization, and school crime. Further research should examine why behaviors related to interpersonal violence are declining and what types of interventions are most effective.

title: Recommendations for treating depression in community-based older adults
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To present recommendations for community-based treatment of depression in the elderly to public health and aging networks. METHODS: In April 2006, an expert panel of mental health and public health researchers and community-based practitioners on aging was convened to formulate consensus-based recommendations. In making recommendations, panelists considered the feasibility and appropriateness of community-based delivery, as well as the strength of evidence on the program's effectiveness from a systematic literature review of articles published up to 2005 at home or in the primary care setting. The panel recommended individualized cognitive behavioral therapy. Interventions not recommended as primary treatments for depression in old age included education and skills training, comprehensive geriatric health assessment programs, exercise, and physical rehabilitation/occupational therapy. There was insufficient evidence to make recommendations for several categories of interventions, including group psychotherapy and psychotherapies other than cognitive behavioral therapy. CONCLUSIONS: This interdisciplinary expert panel decided that the recommended interventions should be disseminated in the public health and aging networks, recognizing the challenges and barriers involved. Interventions that were not recommended or had insufficient evidence often did not treat depression primarily and/or did not include a clinically depressed sample while attempting to establish efficacy. These interventions may provide other benefits but should not be assumed to be effective in treating depression on their own. Panelists also identified primary prevention of depression as a much understudied area. These findings should help both individual physicians and public health decision-makers in the delivery of population-based mental health services in diverse community settings.

title: Referral service for chronic disease patients in the home setting with multimodel sensors
abstract: With advanced technologies in hand, there are potential applications and services around monitoring the Activities of Daily Living (ADL) of elderly people in care homes. Most of the elderly in these institutions suffer from various chronic diseases such as dementia. Existing technologies mainly focus on non-drug interventions and monitoring of ADL to address loss of autonomy or well-being. Monitoring and management of ADL-related cognitive behaviors for non-drug interventions are very effective in improving the condition of dementia patients. However, patients' cognitive functions can be improved if appropriate drug recommendations are made at a given time. Previously, we developed the Secured Wireless Sensor Network Integrated Cloud Computing for Ubiquitous-Life Care (SC(3)). The SC(3) services were limited to monitoring the ADL of older people with Alzheimer's disease and providing non-drug recommendations to the patient. In this article, we propose a system called Smart Clinical Decision Support System (CDSS) as an integral part of the SC(3) platform. The Smart CDSS gives patients access to medication recommendations from medical specialists. Physicians are provided with an interface to create clinical knowledge for medication recommendations and to monitor the patient's condition. The clinical knowledge created by physicians as the knowledge base of the Smart CDSS gives nursing staff recommendations for medications based on each patient's symptoms.

title: Recruiting hospital patients for research: how do participants differ from eligible non-participants?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Randomized controlled trials provide strong evidence for guidelines and interventions. Nevertheless, a large part of the population in question refuses to be examined. OBJECTIVE: To identify differences between participants and eligible non-participants in (1) perceived stress, (2) self-efficacy, (3) expectations of recovery, (4) discussion of advance directives, and (5) understanding of a standard prescription label (health literacy). DESIGN: Quasi-experimental prospective cohort study in 5 acute care hospitals. METHODS: We approached 295 inpatient hospital patients when they were recruited for a behavioral intervention and asked them to answer 5 screening questions. We matched respondents' responses to their acceptance of the behavioral intervention and to Medicare entitlements and enrollment data. We used multivariate logistic regression to compare agreement rates based on responses to screening questions. SETTING/PATIENTS: Hospitalized Medicare patients with fee. RESULTS: Patients were less likely to agree to the behavioral intervention when they reported feeling unable to control important things in their lives (odds ratio [OR]: 0.35, 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0 .14-0.92) and had low expectations of recovery (OR: 0.17, 95% CI: 0.06-0.45) or were confused by some question (OR: 0.11, 95% CI: 0.05 -0.24). Conversely, people who answered the medication question incorrectly were more likely to agree with the behavioral intervention (OR: 3.82, 95% CI: 1.12-13.03). There were no significant differences in compliance among patients who felt overwhelmed or reported having discussed proactive treatment planning with family members or physicians. CONCLUSIONS: Eligible non-participants in the hospital differ in terms of perceived stress, expectancy of recovery, and health literacy. Recognizing such features can inform strategies for improving in-hospital intervention recruitment and representation in clinical trials.

title: Recruitment and retention of older patients in clinical trials: problems and strategies
abstract: Clinicians and researchers alike are shifting their focus to older patients to find the most effective treatments for a variety of psychiatric disorders. Clinical trials in elderly patients are needed because they take most prescription drugs. There are special challenges and considerations when designing and conducting clinical trials. The authors detail the various phases of such research, including recruiting suitable patients and retaining those who enroll, and make suggestions, using examples from research studies already completed, that illustrate the methods that have proven to be the most successful.

title: Recurrence after surgical treatment of hidradenitis suppurativa
abstract: From six to 89 months after surgery, 82 patients treated by radical surgery (118 excisions) for intractable hidradenitis suppurativa were examined. Local recurrence rates varied widely with disease site and were low after axillary (3%) and perianal (0%) surgery and high after inguinoperineal (37%) and submammary (50%) excision. Recurrences result from inadequate excision or an abnormally wide distribution of apocrine glands, but physical factors such as obesity, local pressure, and skin maceration played a role in some patients. Recurrences due to inadequate surgery tended to be the most problematic. At follow-up, 75 (91%) patients were satisfied with the results of their surgery. A quarter of the patients developed disease at a new anatomical site after surgery. Radical surgery provides good symptomatic control of severe suppurative hidradenitis of the axillary, groin, and perianal regions, but is less satisfactory in submammary disease.

title: Redesigning the “choice architecture” of hospital prescribing tables: a mixed-methods study that includes in situ simulation testing.
abstract: Objectives To incorporate behavioral insights into the user-centered design of an Imperial Drug Chart Evaluation and Adoption Study (IDEAS table) and determine whether changes in the content and design of prescribing tables could affect prescribing behavior and reduce prescribing errors. Design A “mixed methods” approach was followed in the development phase of the project; In situ simulations were used to evaluate the effectiveness of the newly developed IDEAS prescribing table. Setting A teaching hospital in London. Interventions/Methods A multimodal approach that includes: (1) an exploratory phase consisting of chart reviews, focus groups, and gathering user insights, (2) the iterative design of the IDEAS prescription chart, and finally (3) testing of the final chart with prescribing physicians using an in situ simulation Results Significant differences were found between existing inpatient prescription charts used in 15 different UK hospitals. Review of 40 completed prescribing charts from a hospital revealed a number of common prescribing errors, including illegibility and difficulties in identifying the prescribing physicians. Insights from focus groups and direct observations were incorporated into the design of the IDEAS table. Situ simulation tests showed significant improvements in prescribing t Comparison of the IDEAS table with the prescribing table currently used at the study hospital. Medication orders on the IDEAS table were significantly more likely to include correct dose entries (164/164 vs. 166/174; p=0.0046) as well as the printed name of the prescribing physician (163/164 vs. 0/174; p<0.0001) and contact number (137/164 versus 55/174; p<0.0001). Anti-infective indication (28/28 vs. 17/29; p<0.0001) and duration (26/28 vs. 15/29; p<0.0001) were more likely to be populated using the IDEAS table. Conclusions In a simulated context, the IDEAS Prescribing Table significantly reduced a number of common prescribing errors, including dosing errors and illegibility. Positive behavioral changes were observed without prior education or support, suggesting that some common prescribing errors may simply be caused by changes in the content and design of Prescription tables can be fixed is an open access article distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution Non Commercial (CC BY-NC 4.0) license which allows others to distribute, remix, adapt, onto this work non-commercially and license their derivative works under different terms, provided the original work is properly cited and the use is non-commercial. See: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/

title: Reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease in patients with diabetes: a message from the National Diabetes Education Program
abstract: PURPOSE: To provide nursing practitioners (NPs) with an overview of current practice guidelines that help clinicians reduce morbidity and mortality associated with diabetes and its major macrovascular complications. DATA SOURCES: This paper presents data from large evidence-based trials and clinical trials that define the scope of the problem, rationale for risk reduction, and a patient-centered action plan for NPs to effectively manage cardiovascular risk factors in people with diabetes. CONCLUSIONS: NPs are active partners of the National Diabetes Education Program and play a key role in efforts to effectively manage cardiovascular risk factors in people with diabetes and to increase their awareness of the association between diabetes and heart disease and stroke. PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: The action plan to reduce cardiovascular risk in people with diabetes will help NPs implement the most effective management strategies for medical nutrition therapy, physical activity, and pharmacological therapy required for patient-centered proactive management of hyperglycemia, hypertension, and lipid abnormalities.

title: Reducing the amount of blood transfused: a systematic review of behavioral interventions to change physician transfusion practices
abstract: BACKGROUND: Transfusion services have used various techniques to reduce the use of blood products. Given the potential adverse effects of transfusions and the resources expended in implementing transfusion reduction strategies, there is a need to understand their effectiveness. Therefore, we conducted a systematic literature review to examine the effectiveness of behavioral interventions in reducing blood product use. METHODS: We identified all relevant articles using electronic searches in MEDLINE and EMBASE, as well as hand searches of review articles and personnel files. The electronic searches included articles published between January 1966 and May 2003. Searches included blood transfusion, plasma exchange, policy, education, practice patterns, and professional practice. Outcomes of interest were the number of units transfused and the proportion of patients who received transfusions.
