RESULTS: Nineteen studies examining the effectiveness of single (guidelines, prospective audits, retrospective audits, and reminders) or multifaceted interventions to reduce RBC, platelet, plasma, cryoprecipitate, and albumin transfusions met inclusion criteria. Eighteen studies showed a relative reduction in the number of units administered (range 9% to 77%) or the proportion of patients receiving transfusions (range 17% to 79%). The reported reductions were qualitatively similar for the different blood products tested. No particular intervention or combination of interventions appeared to be more effective in reducing enrollment. CONCLUSIONS: Behavioral interventions, including simple interventions, appear to be effective in changing physician transfusion practices and reducing blood consumption. Appropriately designed clinical trials are still needed to determine the relative effectiveness of different practice change interventions.

title: Reducing the risk of alcohol use disorders in women
abstract: Nurses and other clinicians help women review their lifestyle and consider changes to promote optimal health. When it comes to drinking alcohol, what is appropriate to recommend? While moderate intake can be beneficial for cardiovascular and bone health, drinking more than the recommended amount increases the risk of adverse effects. This column examines guidelines for moderate drinking for women, provides an overview of the assessment process, and provides an example of a brief intervention. A program of screening, brief intervention, and referral for treatment (referred to as SBIRT by the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration) should be part of the standard assessment for every woman. Ongoing assessment of alcohol use can help better identify behaviors for early intervention.

title: Reducing overuse of therapeutic injections through interaction group discussions between patients and prescribing physicians in Kinondoni District, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania
abstract: Inappropriate prescribing of injections has been reported in both developing and industrialized countries. Previous studies in Tanzania showed that over 70% of patients visiting outpatient clinics in private pharmacies received at least one injection per consultation, a figure above the WHO recommended target of 10%. This is of concern given the likelihood of adverse effects from the potential use of unsafe syringes to transmit HIV, hepatitis B and C, poliomyelitis, and additional economic implications for the patient and healthcare system. This study aimed to investigate the impact of behavioral change interaction group discussions on injectable prescribing practice in ten selected community pharmacies in Kinondoni District, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. Patient injection prescription records were obtained from 5 randomly selected control and 5 randomly selected intervention facilities for the three month period prior to the study. Maternal and prescribing physician IGDs were performed at each health facility for one month, followed by a survey 3 months after IGD to determine the impact of IGDs. Statistical chi-square calculations were performed to compare the data on the percentage of prescriptions with one prescribed injection and those conforming to national standard of care (STG) between baseline and 3-month follow-up. The results showed no significant difference between the percentage of prescriptions with an injection prescribed at baseline and the 3-month follow-up in community pharmacies (P>0.05, X2 test). Prescribed injections that matched STG were low at baseline and did not improve significantly at 3 months thereafter (P>0.05, X2 test). Comprehensive studies and raising awareness among prescribing physicians of STG compliance are recommended.

title: Reducing rates of ventilator-associated pneumonia through a staff education program
abstract: Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is the most common nosocomial infection in patients on mechanical ventilation, leading to increased mortality, longer hospital stays, and costs. Preventive measures for VAP are well documented and evidence-based, but are still poorly implemented in most ICUs. We conducted a pre- and post-intervention observational study to assess whether an educational program focused on preventive practices for VAP could reduce incidence. 677 adult patients who were mechanically ventilated > 48 h were included in the study population. An evidence-based guideline for preventive bedside interventions was developed and distributed to ICU staff. VAP incidence rates before and after the implementation of the educational program were compared. VAP infection rates reduced by 51%, from a mean of 13.2 +/- 1.2 in the pre-intervention period to 6.5 +/- 1.5/1000 device-days in the post-intervention period (mean difference 6 .7"; 95% CI: 2.9–10.4, P=0.02). A multidisciplinary training program targeted at ICU staff can successfully reduce incidence rates of VAP. More studies are needed to Assess the impact on broader outcome measures such as cost or mortality.

title: Reduction of clinical lower extremity abnormalities in patients with non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus. A randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effect of a patient, a healthcare provider, and a systems intervention on the prevalence of risk factors for lower extremity amputation in patients with non-insulin-dependent diabetes. DESIGN: Blinded, randomized, controlled study. SETTING: Academic general practitioner practice. PARTICIPANTS: Of the 395 patients with non-insulin dependent diabetes who underwent the initial patient assessment, 352 completed the study. INTERVENTION: The 12-month intervention was diverse. Patients received foot care training and entered into a behavioral contract for desired foot self-care, which was reinforced by telephone and postcard reminders. Healthcare providers received practice guidelines and informative flowcharts on foot-related risk factors for diabetic amputation. In addition, the folders for intervention patients had special markings that prompted healthcare providers to: 1) ask patients to remove their shoes, 2) perform foot exams, and 3) provide foot care training. RESULTS: Patients who received the intervention were less likely than control patients to have severe foot lesions (baseline prevalence: 2.9%; odds ratio: 0.41 [95% CI: 0.16 to 1.00]; P = 0.05) and other dermatological abnormalities. They were more likely to report appropriate self-care behaviors, to be evaluated at doctor visits (68% vs. 28%; P<0.001), and to receive foot care training from healthcare providers (42% vs. 0.001). 18%; P<0.001). Physicians assigned to intervention patients were more likely than physicians assigned to control patients to examine patients' feet for ulcers, pulse, and abnormal dermatological conditions and referred patients to the foot clinic (10.6% vs. 5.0%; " P = 0.04). CONCLUSIONS: An intervention aimed at reducing risk factors for lower extremity amputations had a positive impact on patients' self-care behaviors and foot care by healthcare providers, and reduced the prevalence of clinical lower extremity disorders in patients with diabetes.

title: Referral to fertility preservation counseling in cancer patients
abstract: STUDY QUESTION: What changes can be seen over time in fertility preservation (FPC) counseling and what are the determinants associated with the referral of newly diagnosed cancer patients aged 0-39 years to a reproductive medicine specialist for FPC? SUMMARY ANSWER: Although the absolute number of patients receiving FPC increased over time, only 9.8% of all potential patients (aged 0-39 years) were referred in 2011 and differences in referral have been identified factors related to patient age, cancer diagnosis, and healthcare provider. WHAT IS KNOWN ALREADY: Referral rates for FPC prior to initiating gonadotoxic cancer treatment are low. Determinants related to low referral and referral differences have been identified in previous studies, although there is little data on referral practices and determinants of FPC referrals in FP(C)-reimbursing facilities. STUDY DESIGN, SCOPE, DURATION: We conducted a retrospective observational and questionnaire study in a Dutch university hospital. Data were collected on all female cancer patients counseled at this center for FP (2001-2013) and all newly diagnosed female cancer patients aged 0-39 years in the region (2009-2011). PARTICIPANTS/MATERIALS, FACILITIES, METHODS: Data were retrieved from medical records (FPC patients), cancer incidences reported by the Dutch Cancer Registry (to calculate referral percentages), and referring professionals (to identify reasons for current referral behavior). MAIN RESULTS AND THE ROLE OF CHANCE: In 2011, a total of 9.8% of patients were referred to FPC. Patients aged 20-29 years or diagnosed with breast cancer or lymphoma were referred more often than patients under 20 years old or patients diagnosed with other malignancies. The absolute number of patients receiving FPC increased over time. Healthcare provider-related determinants of low referral did not initiate discussion about fertility issues, did not know where to refer a patient for FPC, and did not collaborate with patient associations. LIMITATIONS, REASONS FOR CAUTION: Actual referral rates may vary slightly from our estimate as there may have been patients who did not wish to receive FPC. Sporadically, patients may have been directly referred to other regions or received ovarian transposition without FPC. By excluding skin cancer patients, we underestimated the group of women eligible for FPC since this group also includes melanoma patients who may have received gonadotoxic therapy. WIDER IMPACT OF RESULTS: The low referral rates and referral disparity reported in the current study indicate that there are opportunities to improve referral practices. Future research should focus on the implementation and evaluation of interventions to improve referral practice, such as B. Educational materials for patients in oncology departments, discussion ideas or methods to raise awareness of FP techniques and guidelines among physicians and patients. STUDY FUNDING/COMPETITIVE INTERESTS: This work was supported by the Radboud University Medical Center and the Radboud Institute for Health Sciences. The authors have declared no conflicts of interest related to this work. ATTEMPTS REGISTRATION NUMBER: Not applicable.

title: Regeneration of peripheral nerves after injury
Regulate and enact security: a plea for openness
Regulatory models for human embryo cloning: the free market, professional guidelines, and government restrictions
abstract: Both the experimental and the therapeutic use of the new reproductive technologies were not determined by the medical ideology of the well-being of patients and their children, but by the market ideology of profit maximization under the cloak of "reproductive freedom". Government in our constitutional, democratic society has the authority and obligation to enact and enforce appropriate regulations to manage the new reproductive market in order to protect the interests of the public, of the parents-to-be and their children-to-be. The "clone" debate provides a useful opportunity to compare and contrast the competing models of free market regulation, professional guidelines, and government restrictions.

title: Rehabilitation of Antisocial Personalities: Treatment through Self-Management Strategies
abstract: Perpetrators with Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD) are generally assumed to resent psychotherapeutic intervention. Some commentators therefore argue that those with the disorder are better treated in the criminal justice system where, after the introduction of indefinite sentences, the obligation to receive psychological treatment is mandatory with the achievement of parole. In comparison, the National Institute of Clinical Excellence's guidelines on the treatment and management of ASPD recommend that those seeking treatment should be considered for admission to specialized psychiatric hospitals. This is because prison interventions are underfunded and ASPD treatment is given too little priority. The rationale is that offenders with ASPD can be rehabilitated if they are motivated. A problem, however, is that little is known about why offenders with ASPD seek treatment or the impact subsequent treatment has on their self-image. The aim of this paper is to address these unresolved issues. It draws on the findings of a qualitative study funded by the Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC) that examined the experiences of convicted male offenders admitted to a specialized personality disorders unit within the medium-security estate and of physicians who treat them. The data are analyzed with reference to Michel Foucault's work on governmentality and strategy in power relations. Two arguments are advanced: First, legal coercion motivates offenders with ASPD to use a variety of Foucaultian strategies to create the false impression of treatment progress. Second, and related, the treatment does not lead to changes in the self-image of the resistant patient with ASPD. This assumes that, at least for this group, Foucault was wrong in claiming that resistive behavior merely obscures the effectiveness of treatment norms over time. Nevertheless, the paper concludes that specialist treatment in hospital can bring about changes in the resistance offender's self-image, but not if the completion of treatment leads to his return to prison, as is usual.

title: Rehabilitation of children and young people
abstract: In recent years, a significant increase in most chronic mental and physical illnesses in children and adolescents has been reported. Therefore, the medical rehabilitation of children and young people plays a major role. Therefore, early diagnosis and multimodal intervention in childhood and adolescence are necessary to prevent a chronic progression of the disease. Patient education programs have proven effective in managing chronic conditions. These programs are primarily aimed at improving compliant behavior and disease management. Consequently, the state of health and the quality of life should be improved. The implementation of guidelines and evaluation studies has improved the quality of rehabilitation programs over the past 15 years. However, future research should in particular develop flexible rehabilitation programs (duration of rehabilitation, rehabilitation near or far from home, rehabilitation chain with inpatient, semi-outpatient and outpatient programs), the effectiveness of which must be proven.

title: Relapse of Successfully Treated Anxiety and Anxiety: Theoretical Questions and Recommendations for Clinical Practice
abstract: Despite the existence of effective interventions for anxiety disorders, long-term relapse – or return of anxiety – poses a significant problem for patients and clinicians. This paper draws on the experimental and clinical behavioral literature and examines the mechanisms by which return of anxiety occurs can. The goal of the paper was to create a list of treatment recommendations for clinicians aimed at reducing relapse in successfully treated anxiety disorders. Clinical and experimental literature on the mechanisms of renewal, recovery, spontaneous recovery, and reacquisition are reviewed. These will be linked to the clinical and experimental literature on fear return in successfully treated anxiety. A list of recommendations for reducing the likelihood of recurrence in successfully treated anxiety is presented. This list includes methods for application in the behavioral (exposure) treatment of anxiety disorders aimed at improving clinical outcomes. Despite the significant problem of recurrence in successfully treated anxiety, methods are available to reduce the likelihood of recurrence through renewed anxiety. Clinicians involved in the treatment of anxiety disorders should consider these methods to ensure optimal treatment outcome.

title: Ratio of completeness of health research reporting to journal endorsement of reporting guidelines: systematic review
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess whether the completeness of health research reporting is related to journal endorsement of reporting guidelines. DESIGN Systematic review. DATA SOURCES Reporting guidelines from a published systematic review and the EQUATOR Network (October 2011). Studies assessing the completeness of reporting against an included reporting guideline (referred to as “reviews”) (1990 to October 2011; follow-up searches January 2012) from searches of Medline, Embase and the Cochrane Methodology Register or Scopus, depending on the reporting guideline name STUDY SELECTIONS Reporting guidelines in English, which provided explicit guidelines for reporting, described the guideline development process, and indicated the use of a consensus development process, were included. The CONSORT statement was excluded because assessments of CONSORT compliance had been previously reviewed. English or French language reviews of the included reporting guidelines were eligible if they assessed the completeness of the reporting of studies as the primary intent and the included studies allowed for interesting comparisons (d journals) Abstract and then reviewed as full-text reports. If the eligibility for funding was unclear, the authors of evaluations were contacted; Where necessary, journal websites were consulted for endorsement information. Completeness of reporting of reporting guidelines was analyzed in terms of endorsement per item and, where consistent with the authors' analysis, a mean cumulative score. RESULTS 101 reporting guidelines were included. From 15,249 records found when searching for evaluations, 26 evaluations were identified that assessed completeness of reporting in terms of agreement with nine reporting guidelines. Of these, 13 evaluations could be evaluated, which evaluated seven reporting guidelines (BMJ Economic Checklist, CONSORT for harms, PRISMA, QUOROM, STARD, STRICTA and STROBE). Items of the reporting guideline were assessed by a small number of evaluations. CONCLUSIONS The completeness of reporting of only nine out of 101 health research reporting guidelines (excluding CONSORT) was assessed in terms of journal recognition. Items from seven reporting guidelines were analyzed quantitatively, each through a few evaluations. There is insufficient evidence to determine the relationship between journal endorsement of reporting guidelines and the completeness of coverage of published health research reports. Journal editors and researchers should consider collaborative, prospectively designed, controlled trials to provide more robust evidence. REGISTRATION FOR SYSTEMATIC REVIEWS Unregistered; no known registry currently accepts protocols for methodological systematic reviews.

title: memory therapy in dementia
abstract: BACKGROUND: Reminiscence therapy (RT) has been defined as the vocal or silent reminiscence of events in a person's life, either alone or with another person or group of people. Typically these are group meetings at least once a week, where participants are encouraged to talk about past events, often aided by tools such as photos, music, objects and videos of the past. There is often little consistent use of psychological therapies in dementia services. A number of these 'therapies' have been enthusiastically received by health practitioners in unstimulating care settings. They were expected to work miracles and their "failure" to do so has led to their widespread disuse. A systematic review of the available evidence is important to identify the effectiveness of different therapies. Subsequently, guidelines for their use can be drawn up on a well-founded evidence basis. OBJECTIVES: RT involves groups of older people speaking about past events, supported by tools such as videos, images and archives to communicate and reflect on their life experiences. The aim of the review is to assess the effects of RT in dementia. SEARCH STRATEGY: We searched the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register, MEDLINE, PSYCHLIT, EMBASE, OMNI, BIDS, Dissertation Abstracts International, SIGLE and reference lists of relevant articles up to 1998 and contacted specialists in the field. We also searched relevant websites and searched Aging and Mental Health, The Gerontologist, Journal of Gerontology, Current Opinion in Psychiatry, Current Research in Britain: Social Sciences, British Psychological Society Conference Proceedings and Reminiscence database. SELECTION CRITERIA: Randomized controlled trials and quasi-randomized trials of RT for dementia in the elderly. DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two reviewers independently extracted data and assessed study quality. MAIN RESULTS: Two studies were included in the review, but only one study with 15 participants had extractable data. The results were not statistically significant for either cognition or behavior. REVIEWER'S CONCLUSIONS: No firm conclusions could be drawn regarding the effectiveness of RT in dementia. The review stressed the urgent need for more systematic research in this area.

title: Remission, residual symptoms, and non-response to standard treatment for major depressive disorder in controlled clinical practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although published guidelines recommend continuing treatment for depression until complete remission of symptoms and recovery of functioning, little is known about how often remission is achieved in usual practice and the reasons for treatment discontinuation when treatment outcome is suboptimal was. METHOD: A naturalistic study design evaluated 1859 patients who received treatment for DSM-III-R major depression in the national provider network of a Managed Behavioral Health Organization (MBHO) between 1995 and 1997. Clinician symptom and impairment ratings were used to classify patients into complete response, partial response, and no response. Performance data were used to characterize treatment and identify comorbid conditions. RESULTS: According to physician assessment, approximately 27% to 39% of patients achieved a complete remission. Comorbidity related to medication and drug use and hospitalizations were more common in patients with partial treatment responses. Only half of the non-responders received a drug test during their treatment. Patient choice was the most common reason for stopping treatment, although almost 40% of clinicians agreed with patients' choices even when symptoms had not improved. CONCLUSION: Although complete response rates were comparable to those seen in antidepressant clinical trials, the results suggest that clinicians may not recommend continuation and maintenance treatment according to best practice guidelines, and that unsuccessful treatment often does not include antidepressants.

title: replantation of the foot
Report of the PHLS Surveillance Center for Communicable Diseases
abstract: An outbreak of Legionnaires' disease was reported between August and September among holidaymakers returning from Yugoslavia; there have been further outbreaks of gastrointestinal diseases related to shellfish; and two tropical diseases were in the news, leishmaniasis and cercarial dermatitis.

title: Report of the NIH Panel on the Definition of Principles of Treatment in HIV Infection*
abstract: Recent research advances have led to a significantly improved understanding of the biology of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and the pathogenesis of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). With the advent of sensitive tools to monitor HIV replication in infected individuals, the risk of disease progression and death can be accurately assessed and the effectiveness of anti-HIV therapies directly determined. In addition, combinations of newly available, effective antiviral therapies, when used appropriately, can provide sustained suppression of detectable HIV replication rates and circumvent HIV's inherent tendency to generate drug-resistant virus variants. However, as antiretroviral therapy for HIV infection has become more effective, it has also become more complex. Familiarity with the latest research advances is required to ensure that newly available therapies are deployed in the most effective ways to improve the health and prolong life of people living with HIV. To help practitioners and those living with HIV quickly make the most of new information about the pathogenesis and treatment of HIV disease, the Office of AIDS Research of the National Institutes of Health sponsored the NIH Panel on the Definition of Therapeutic Principles for HIV Infection. This panel was asked to define key scientific principles that should be used to guide the most effective use of antiretroviral therapy and viral load testing in clinical practice. Based on a detailed review of the most recent data, the panel has identified eleven principles that address issues fundamental to the management of HIV infection. These principles provide the scientific basis for the specific treatment recommendations made by the Panel on Clinical Practices for the Treatment of HIV Infection, sponsored by the Department of Health and Human Services and the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation. The reports of these two bodies are included in this publication. Together they summarize new data and provide both the scientific basis and concrete guidelines for the treatment of people living with HIV. This information is of interest to healthcare providers, people living with HIV, HIV/AIDS advocates, public health educators, public health agencies and any organization that sponsors health care for people living with HIV.

title: Reproductive rights and the medical care system: a plea for a rational health policy
abstract: Recently, there have been many challenges to women's reproductive rights and freedoms: court-ordered cesareans, criminal cases against women for prenatal child abuse, and attempts to restrict the practice of midwifery, home births, and alternative birth centers. In these cases, medicine has been complicit or proactive in attempts to control pregnant women's behavior or health care options. We discuss the role of medicine as a means of social control, the medical reconstruction of problems of a social nature, and the need for a more coherent policy framework to guide medical practices." PIP: Reproductive issues are very contentious. Women's legal abortion rights continue to be Questioned, women's rights are being pitted against the rights of the fetus, and there are concerns about teenage pregnancy, the appropriate use of reproductive technology, and drug and alcohol use during pregnancy, but little attention has been given to the role of medicine as an actor social control and arbiter of reproductive behavior, medical reconstruction and intervention in problems that are essentially social in nature, or equity and social justice in reproductive health care.The authors discuss these latter issues in the Light historical and recent attempts to control the behavior of pregnant women. In the absence of current reproductive health policy, the medical profession makes arbitrary decisions on individual cases that may or may not reflect patient or community desires. A more coherent policy framework and regulatory mechanisms to guide medical practice are needed. The authors discuss the problem in context, key issues, social discrimination in reproductive health care, choice of services to be delivered, coercion and choice, and reproductive health policies as a solution.

title: Requiring physicians to respond to computerized reminders improves their adherence to screening protocols.
abstract: Objective: Improve compliance with computer-generated reminders for performing fecal occult blood (FOBT) testing, mammography, and cervical Papanicolaou (Pap) testing. DESIGN: Six-month prospective, randomized, controlled study. Setting: Academic general practice for general internal medicine. Subjects: Thirty-one general internal medicine faculties, 145 resident physicians, and 5,407 patients with scheduled visits who were eligible for any of the three cancer screening protocols. Intervention: Primary care teams of internists and teachers received either routine computer reminders (control) or the same reminders that required them to circle one of four responses: 1) "Done/ordered today," 2) ""Doesn't apply to this patient," 3) "patient refused" or 4) "next visit". p=0.002) and separately with reminders for FOBT (61% vs. 49%, p=0.0007) and mammography (54% vs. 47%, p=0.036), but without cervical Pap (21% vs. 18%, p=0.2) . Intervention residents responded significantly more frequently than control residents to all reminders together and separately to reminders for FOBT and mammography, but not for Pap tests. There was no significant difference between the intervention and control faculty, but the compliance rate for the control faculty was significantly higher than the rate for the control residents for all reminders together and separately for FOBT but not mammography or Pap tests. The effect of the intervention was greatest in patients 70 years of age, with significant results for all tests, collectively and individually, for residents but not for faculty. Intervention physicians found that the reminders were inapplicable 21% of the time (due to insufficient data in electronic medical records) and reported that their patients refused 10% of the time. Conclusions: Requiring physicians to respond to computer-generated reminders improved their compliance with screening protocols, particularly in elderly patients, in whom compliance of control physicians was lowest. However, 100% adherence to cancer screening reminders will not be achievable due to incomplete data and patient refusal.

title: Research based on archived information and samples. Recommendations of the Royal College of Physicians Committee on Ethical Issues in Medicine
abstract: In 1996, the College published Guidance on the Practice of Ethics Committees in Medical Research Involving Humans (3rd Edition), which includes a section on unobtrusive research. The recommendations published here are intended to clarify the questions surrounding this research category in connection with consent to the use of archived information and samples.

title: research in the field of psychiatry
Research into Practice: Collaboration for Leadership in Applied Health Research and Care (CLAHRC) for Nottinghamshire, Derbyshire, Lincolnshire (NDL)
abstract: Background To address the problem of transferring research-based evidence into routine health practice, the Collaboration for Leadership in Applied Health Research and Care for Nottinghamshire, Derbyshire, and Lincolnshire (CLAHRC-NDL) was funded by the National Institute for Health Research as a unit of nine CLAHRCs all over England. This paper outlines the underlying theory and its application adopted by CLAHRC-NDL as a case study that could be generalized to practice outside of the CLAHRC, compared to alternative implementation models. Discussion Traditional approaches to health research often generate evidence in isolation from the setting in which it is intended to be used. The premise of the CLAHRC-NDL model is that implementation barriers can be overcome when knowledge is co-produced by academic and clinical staff, taking into account the organizational context in which it is intended to be applied. This approach is based on organizational learning theory and recognizes that change is a social and political phenomenon. Evidence is created in real-time, taking full account of the environment in which it is to be implemented. To support this process, senior healthcare professionals are seconded to the CLAHRC as ¡Â®Diffusion FellowsÂ¡Â¯ (DFs) to actively bridge the gap between research and practice by being a full member of both the research team and theirs clinical field are train. To facilitate innovation and embed change in the local health community, existing communities of practice will be enhanced and new ones encouraged on specific topics. Our approach has been adopted by 16 clinical research studies in the areas of mental health, children and adolescents, primary care and stroke rehabilitation. Summary The CLAHRC-NDL implementation model applies organizational learning theory by addressing the social and situational barriers and enablers to implementation and adopting a philosophy of co-production. Two key mechanisms for translating innovation were leveraged: DFs to actively bridge the gap between research and practice, and communities of practice to underpin and sustain improvements in healthcare. The model shows promising results in translating research into practice, which may be transferrable to other health contexts.

title: Research opportunities in early childhood: birth to 5 years
abstract: The American Occupational Therapy Association's (AOTA) Evidence-Based Practice Project has developed a table summarizing early childhood research opportunities. The table provides an overview of the currently available evidence on interventions in the context of occupational therapy practice and is based on the systematic reviews of the AOTA Evidence-Based Practice Guidelines Series. Researchers, students and clinicians can use this information to develop innovative research to answer important questions in the field of occupational therapy.

title: Research priorities for public health
abstract: The Association of Community Health Nursing Educators (ACHNE) Research Committee initiated a revision of the ACHNE Research Priorities for Public Health Practice in 2006, following those developed in 1992 and 2000 by 7 selected nursing journals to review progress in addressing the priorities from 2000"; (b) identified research methods used, health problems addressed and health behaviors and demographics of the study populations in the abstracts;" and (c) reviewed research priorities from major federal funding agencies and journal publishers. Overall, progress towards meeting previous priorities has been modest, with a limited range of methods, topics and examples described. The 2009 ACHNE research priorities for public health include: (1) Population-Based Outcomes and (2) Public Health Workers. Addressing these priorities will require multi-site studies, clinical trials, community-based participatory research, the development and/or analysis of existing large datasets, and the development of valid and reliable methods. Collaboration between educators, researchers, and practitioners is critical to developing the scientific evidence base for population-based nursing practice.

title: Exploring Effective Approaches to Cleaning in Hospitals: Protocol of the REACH Study, a Randomized Multisite Wedge Trial
abstract: Background The REACH study (Research Effective Approaches to Cleaning in Hospitals) will provide evidence of the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a novel cleaning initiative aimed at improving the environmental cleanliness of hospitals. The initiative is an environmental cleaning package with five interdependent, evidence-based components (training, technical, product, audit and communication) to be implemented with environmental service workers to improve hospital cleaning practices. Methods/Design The REACH study will use a randomized controlled step wedge design to test the study intervention, an environmental cleaning package, in 11 Australian hospitals. All study hospitals will receive the intervention and act as their own controls, with the analysis of change in each hospital being performed based on the data collected in the control and intervention periods. Each site will be randomly assigned to one of 11 intervention time points with staggered start dates in 2016 and an intervention period ranging from 20 to 50 weeks. All sites will complete the study simultaneously in 2017. The inclusion criteria allow for a targeted sampling of both public and private hospitals with patient populations at higher risk for healthcare associated infections (HAIs). The primary outcome (goal one) is the monthly number of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremias (SABs), Clostridium difficile infections (CDIs), and vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) infections per 10,000 bed-days. Secondary outcomes for goal one include thoroughness of hospital cleaning assessed using fluorescent marker technology, bioburden from frequent touching of surfaces after cleaning, and changes in staff knowledge and attitudes about environmental cleaning. A cost-benefit analysis determines the second key outcome (goal two): the incremental cost-benefit ratio of implementing the cleaning package. The study uses the integrated Promoting Action on Research Implementation in Health Services (iPARIHS) framework to support the bespoke implementation of the environmental cleaning package in each hospital. Discussion Findings from the REACH study will contribute to future policy and practice guidance on cleaning the hospital environment. It is used by healthcare leaders and clinicians to support decision making and implementation of best practice infection prevention strategies to reduce HAIs in hospitals.

title: Respond flexibly but not gullibly to drug addiction
Responding to patient-initiated humor: guidelines for practice
abstract: In recent decades, increasing evidence has shown the positive effects of humor. The use of nurse-initiated humor as a healthcare intervention has both physiological and emotional benefits. Little has been written, however, about another very important aspect of humor, patient-initiated humor. When patients use humor to relieve their feelings of stress, uncertainty, or embarrassment, they are attempting to communicate with their caregiver. This use of humor by patients is not intended to 'take lightly' the situation, but rather to reduce their feelings of dehumanization. Humor is an interactive process of sharing and an important aspect of communication. Patients watch the caregiver for a reaction. An open, accepting answer signals understanding";" however, a negative or no response may serve to isolate the patient. The guidelines for recognizing, interpreting, and responding to patient-initiated humor discussed in this article will help home care and hospice caregivers encourage more open communication between patients and caregivers and create a supportive humanistic atmosphere for patient care.

title: Responding to the health risks of young people in primary care: A cluster randomized study training clinicians in screening and motivational interviewing
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of a complex intervention to implement best-practice guidelines recommending physicians to screen and counsel young people regarding multiple psychosocial risk factors, health risk identification by physicians, and patient risk behaviors in comparison to a didactic seminar on young people's health. DESIGN: Pragmatic cluster-randomized study in which voluntary primary care practices were stratified by zip code advantage or disadvantage and billing type (private, free national healthcare, community health center) and then randomized to either intervention or comparator arms using a computer-generated random sequence. Three months after the intervention, patients from all practices were recruited after the consultation for a computer-assisted telephone interview and followed up three and twelve months later. Researchers who recruited, consented and interviewed patients and patients themselves were masked with referral status; clinicians don't. SETTING: General practices in metropolitan and rural Victoria, Australia their 14-24 year old patients INTERVENTION: This complex intervention was developed using evidence-based practice learning and changing clinical behavior and general practice systems and incorporated best practice approaches motivating risk behavior change in adolescents (nine hours) Health risk screening, use of a screening tool and motivational interviewing; Trained all practice staff (receptionists and clinicians) on youth engagement; providing feedback to clinicians on patient risk data; and two office visits to support new screening and reference resources Comparator clinicians received a didactic educational seminar (three hours) on dedicated youth and health risk screening. OUTCOME MEASURES: Primary outcomes were the patient's report of (1) clinical evidence of at least one of six unhealthy behaviors (tobacco, alcohol, and illicit drug use, risks of sexually transmitted infections, STIs, unplanned pregnancy, and traffic risks); and (2) change in one or more of the six unhealthy behaviors at three months or at 12 months. Secondary endpoints were likelihood of future visits, trust in physician after exit interview, physician's recognition of emotional distress and anxiety and abuse in relationships, and emotional distress at three and 12 months. Patient acceptance of the screening tool was also described for the intervention arm. Where appropriate, the analyzes were adjusted to the practice location and billing method, gender, age, patient recruitment method, and past health risks. An intention-to-treat analysis approach was used that included a multi-level multiple imputation for missing outcome data. RESULTS: 42 practices were randomly assigned to intervention or comparison arms. Two intervention practices withdrew after pre-training allocation, leaving 19 intervention practices (53 clinicians, 377 patients) and 21 comparator practices (79 clinicians, 524 patients). 69% of patients in both the intervention (260) and comparator (360) arms completed the 12-month follow-up. Intervention physicians discussed more health risks per patient (59.7%) than comparators (52.7%) and were therefore more likely to detect a higher proportion of young people exhibiting at least one of the six unhealthy behaviors (38.4% vs. 26.7%, risk difference [RD] 11.6%, confidence interval [CI] 2.93% to 20.3%, adjusted odds ratio [OR] 1.7, CI 1.1 to 2.5). Patients reported less illicit drug use (RD -6.0, CI -11 to -1.2; OR 0.52, CI 0.28 to 0.96) and a lower risk of STIs (RD -5.4, CI -11 to 0.2, OR 0.66, CI 0.46 to 0.96). ) after three months in the intervention relative to the comparator arm and for an unplanned pregnancy after 12 months (RD -4.4; CI -8.7 to -0.1; "OR 0.40, CI 0.20 to 0.80 No differences were found between the arms of the other health risks. There were no differences in the secondary endpoints, apart from greater detection of abuse (OR 13.8, CI 1.71 to 111.) There were no reports of adverse events and adolescents in the intervention arm had high acceptance of the screening tool CONCLUSIONS: A complex intervention compared to a simple practices training seminar Better detection of unhealthy behaviors in young people Impact on health outcomes was inconclusive Technology that provides a more efficient, systematic health risk Screening allows providers to target counseling to those at higher risk. Further trials required rn more power to confirm health benefits. TEST REGISTRATION: ISRCTN.com ISRCTN16059206.

title: Responding to Intervention: Principles and Strategies for Effective Practice.
abstract: This is the first comprehensive guide to implementing a school-wide response-to-intervention (RTI) program that addresses a core need. The book is designed to help practitioners understand and respond to No Child Left Behind and the new Special Education Eligibility Guidelines outlined in IDEIA 2004 with students with learning disabilities. Special features include reproducible planning and implementation worksheets and more than two dozen overhead slide masters for use in RTI training sessions with lay-flat binding for ease of photocopying. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: responsibility of the educator
Results of a collaboration between a physician and a respiratory therapist to improve long-term metered dose inhalation technique in a pediatric asthma clinic
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite advances in therapy, asthma remains the chronic condition most frequently responsible for absenteeism from school and pediatric hospitalizations. This is especially true for inner-city children. We operate a downtown Pediatric Asthma Compliance and Technique (PACT) clinic where physicians and respiratory therapists work together to improve technique and outcomes of metered dose inhalers (MDI) in asthmatic children. OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of our strategy in improving MDI technique and asthma outcomes. METHODS: Children referred to the PACT Clinic underwent a standardized assessment based on the guidelines of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI) expert panel. Physicians demonstrated and confirmed correct MDI technique at each visit. Using a standardized format, we prospectively collected data at the patient's first visit (T1) and last visit (T2) on demographics, MDI technique scores (MDI steps performed correctly"; "scale of 0-8), lung function, and severity of asthma (NHLBI classification scale: 1 = mildly intermittent to 4 = severely persistent). Statistical analyzes were performed using parametric and non-parametric tests. RESULTS: Of the 60 patients who attended the PACT Clinic between 1999 and 2002, 15 were excluded from the study because of incomplete data collection. The mean duration from T1 to T2 was 11.8 +/- 9.5 months. At T1 and T2, mean MDI technique scores were 53% and 81%, respectively, mean total asthma severity scores were 2.6 and 2.3, and total pulmonary function severity scores were 2.4 and 2 ,1. MDI technique scores improved significantly between TI and T2 (p<0.001). The black patients showed the greatest improvement with the MDI technique (p<0.001), but their pulmonary function test scores, global asthma severity score, and pulmonary function severity score did not improve significantly. The white patients significantly improved both their MDI technique (p=0.004) and their overall asthma severity scores (p=0.005). CONCLUSION: At our PACT clinic, asthmatic children showed sustained improvement with the MDI technique, and some of the patients improved in lung function and total asthma severity score.

title: Results that matter: structured vs. unstructured blood glucose self-monitoring in type 2 diabetes
abstract: Self-monitoring of blood glucose (SMBG) is a part of diabetes management. SMBG presents information about current glycemic status and provides the ability to get instant feedback on the impact of behavioral and pharmacological interventions on glucose levels. However, SMBG is only useful if the glucose information is properly understood, the data is accurately interpreted, and the results lead to appropriate therapeutic measures. The International Diabetes Federation (IDF) recently published guidelines for the use of SMBG in non-insulin-treated people with diabetes and recommends that SMBG should only be used when patients and/or their physicians have the ability and willingness to use SMBG -Include monitoring and therapy adjustment in their diabetes care plan. If SMBG is used, the IDF also recommends that structured SMBG be performed using defined schemes to meet individual needs. Structured SMBG can be performed as daily glucose profiles that are representative of daily glucose variances. Measuring preprandial/postprandial blood glucose (BG) levels on consecutive or alternating days (“pairwise testing”) also provides meaningful glucose information for daily diabetes management. This article reviews recent studies that have appropriately used structured SMBG as an integral part of overall diabetes management and discusses how their results support the IDF recommendations. Our goal is to support physicians in making more informed decisions about the value and usefulness of SMBG in diabetes management.

title: Rethinking Pragmatic Randomized Controlled Trials: Introducing the Cohort-Multiple Randomized Controlled Trial Design.
abstract: Pragmatic studies are important for routine clinical practice, but current study designs have shortcomings. Clare Relton and colleagues outline the new design of a multi-cohort randomized controlled trial that may help address the issues associated with existing approaches. Randomized controlled trials are generally considered the best Å“gold standard” for determining how well an intervention is working. However, studies that aim to determine the effectiveness of a treatment through a double-blind, placebo-controlled design (i.e., explanatory studies) are sometimes criticized. For example, although the design of explanatory studies leads to strong internal validity, we can rely on the results of a particular study. Such studies may have limited external validity: we cannot be confident that we can apply the results to routine clinical practice. Pragmatic studies1 2 , aiming to inform practice-based healthcare decision-making, have been offered as a solution as they maintain the rigor of randomization (and thus remove selection bias) but retain the characteristics of normal clinical practice. Conducting and interpreting both pragmatic and explanatory randomized controlled trials presents significant problems. This article describes a study design that helps address these issues—the “cohort-multiple randomized controlled trial” approach. Existing clinical trial designs can fail in four areas: recruitment, ethics, patient preferences, and treatment comparisons. ### Recruitment Most randomized controlled trials have difficulties in recruiting a sufficient number of patients. For example, one review found that less than a third of 114 multicentre, publicly funded studies in the UK recruited their original target number of patients within the originally specified time.3 Failure to target recruitment can impact the validity and generalizability of study results to have. In addition, many clinical studies exclude hard-to-reach groups and ethnic minorities4, leading to differences between the “need” (reference) population and the study population.5 6 “ ¦

title: Review of legal instruments and codes on medical experimentation involving children
abstract: Medical research involving children is the subject of ongoing debate. The reason for the controversy is clear. As with research involving adults, a balance must be found between two goals – promoting the health of children through advances in scientific knowledge and protecting child subjects from exploitation and harm. However, due to their age and relative immaturity, children cannot protect their own interests as well as adult subjects. But as they approach adulthood, more and more care must be taken to involve children in decisions that affect them, even to the extent that they can make decisions that can have serious and long-term consequences.

title: Revision of the Helsinki Declaration: a fresh start
Revision of the History of Cold War Research Ethics
abstract: Part of President Clinton's assignment to the Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experimentation was to identify ethical and legal standards for evaluating government-sponsored radiation experiments conducted during the Cold War. In this paper, we review the traditional account of the history of American research ethics, and then highlight the importance of a number of the Committee's historical findings that relate to that account. These results include both the debates of the national defense with legal and insurance-technical questions regarding human experiments as well as the perspective of the medical profession on human experiments in the years after the Nuremberg medical trials. We conclude that the Committee's work both enriches the traditional view of the history of research ethics and opens up important new areas of research.

title: RHEUMATISM AND ARTHRITIS: REVIEW OF AMERICAN AND ENGLISH LITERATURE OF RECENT YEARS: (ELEVENTH REVIEW OF RHEUMATISM): Part II
Rheumatism and Arthritis: Review of the American and English Literature of Recent Years: (Sixteenth Rheumatism Review)
abstract: SINCE 1935, under the auspices of the American Rheumatism Association, fifteen editions of Rheumatism Reviews have been regularly published in the ANNALS OF INTERNAL MEDICINE. This sixteenth edition contains an analysis of selected articles from the American and English literature dealing with the basic and clinical aspects of connective tissue diseases for the years 1961 and 1962. The American Rheumatism Association (ARA), with support from the editors of the ANNALS OF INTERNAL MEDICINE, will continue to publish, at approximately bi-annual intervals, an analysis of the significant contributions to this field, with a focus on topics of interest to clinicians. The American Rheumatism Association, in collaboration with the National Library of Medicine, is preparing a recurring bibliography of rheumatic diseases on computer tape. Using this method of literature research, the "Current Bibliographic Listings in Arthritis and Rheumatism" are compiled and made available to all those interested in connective tissue diseases. Future Rheumatism Reviews are prepared by a committee of the American Rheumatism Association to provide a single comprehensive analysis of both the fundamental and clinical aspects of the field of rheumatology. These are published in the journal Arthritis and Rheumatism.

title: RHEUMATISM AND ARTHRITIS:: REVIEW OF RECENT YEARS OF AMERICAN AND ENGLISH LITERATURE: (THIRTEENTH RHEUMATISM REVIEW)
abstract: CONTENTS PART I General incidence of rheumatic diseases 2 Classification of diseases of the joints and related structures 5 Diseases mainly related to trauma 5 Arthritis due to specific infectious agents 8 Rheumatic fever 19 Sydenham's chorea 29 Rheumatoid arthritis 30 Rheumatoid (ankylosing) spondylitis 81 Osteoarthritis (degenerative Joint Disease) 88 PART II Back Pain and Sciatica 95 Gout and Gouty Arthritis 119 The Uric Acid Problem 144 "Collagen Diseases" 149 Psoriatic Arthritis 162 Reiter's Syndrome 163 Neurotrophic Arthropathy: Charcot Joints 165 Rheumatic Purpura (Schönlein-Henoch Syndrome) 166 Hemophilic Arthritis 167 Allergic Arthritis 168 Pharmacological arthritis and arthralgia 168 Alkaptonuria, ochronosis and ochronic arthritis

title: Richard Cabot: Medical reformer during the progressive era (1890-1920)
abstract: Richard Cabot's (1868-1939) decision in 1920 to leave full-time medical practice to teach social ethics illustrates some of the tensions inherent in the 20th-century transformation of medicine from clinical practice to a biomedical science. Cabot, then one of America's best-known physicians, was practicing medicine at a time when science was redefining medical practice and thinking. Although Cabot was a champion of medical science, his main concerns were clinical and humanistic. He emphasized the importance of outpatient medicine, advocated group practice, founded hospital social work, conducted clinical-epidemiological research, advocated preventive medicine, founded the Clinical-Pathological Conference, and wrote extensively on medical ethics. In 1912, despite Cabot's great talent, a top professorship at Harvard Medical School was instead given to David Edsall, a clinician with a broader background in science. However, Cabot's efforts to define the role of the physician as well as the health care system in human well-being anticipated contemporary attempts in medicine to emphasize the social context of the patient.

title: Rid the world of hydroxyquinolines
On the Knowledge Translation Carousel: Lessons from the Canadian Institutes of Health Research Summer Institute in Knowledge Translation
abstract: Background Funding the education and training of the next generation of health researchers is a key mandate of the Canadian Institutes of Health Research's (CIHR) Knowledge Translation (KT) portfolio. The field of KT is growing daily";" Therefore, the training and development of a new generation of KT researchers is crucial. Methods Using curriculum documents, participant assessments and self-reflection, this paper describes a unique summer institute hosted by CIHR in Cornwall, Ontario, Canada. We outline the key aspects of a successful training initiative that could inform organizations and agencies worldwide that are interested in or have a mandate for KT. Outcomes This work provides prospective funders, faculty and students with insight into the purpose, process and outcomes of such training initiatives. Conclusion National and international KT organisations, research institutes and funding agencies are encouraged to consider replicating the training model used here, as investment in KT staff will support further development of the field within and beyond local borders. “For those who devote their lives to science, nothing can bring greater joy than seeing the results immediately put to practical use. There are not two sciences. There is science and there is the application of science, and these two are connected as fruit is to tree.' Â¨C Louis Pasteur, 1871 (from a presentation by Ian Graham, 2008 CIHR Knowledge Translation Summer Institute)

title: Risk communication in clinical trials: a cognitive experiment and survey
abstract: BACKGROUND: A working group of the Royal Statistical Society recently recommended that in initial human clinical trials "greater use should be made of numerical rather than verbal risk descriptions". This reflected the view of many clinicians and psychologists on risk communication. As the clinical trials industry is expanding rapidly worldwide, it is important to understand risk communication in Asian countries. METHODS: We conducted a cognitive experiment on participation in a hypothetical clinical trial of an analgesic and survey among cancer and arthritis patients in Singapore. In part 1 of the experiment, patients received information about the risk of side effects in one of three formats (frequency, percentage and verbal descriptor) and in one of two sequences (least to greatest and highest to least). and asked about their willingness to participate. In part 2, the patients were informed about the risk in all three formats in the same order and asked again about their willingness to participate. This was immediately followed by a survey on preference for risk presentation methods and use of verbal descriptors. Results: The willingness to participate and the probability of changing one's own decision were not influenced by the methods of risk representation. Most patients reported a preference for the frequency format, but those with primary or no formal education were indifferent. While patients used the verbal descriptors 'very often', 'frequently' and 'very rarely' similar to the European Commission guidelines, their use of the descriptors 'uncommon' and 'rarely' differed significantly from the EU. CONCLUSION: In this sample of Asian cancer and arthritis patients, the format of risk presentation did not influence willingness to participate in a clinical trial. However, there is a clear preference for the frequency format. The lay use of verbal descriptors differed significantly from that in the EU.

title: Risk factors for methotrexate-induced lung injury in patients with rheumatoid arthritis: a multicenter case-control study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Toxicity limits the use of methotrexate. AIM: To identify risk factors for methotrexate-induced lung injury in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. DESIGN: Case-control study. SETTING: One private and five academic rheumatology practices. PARTICIPANTS: Methotrexate recipients with rheumatoid arthritis with and without lung injury. MEASUREMENTS: Potential risk factors evaluated were sociodemographic and lifestyle characteristics, medical history, clinical and ancillary characteristics, and treatment of rheumatoid arthritis prior to methotrexate therapy, and characteristics of methotrexate therapy. Cases of lung injury were defined using the modified Searles and McKendry criteria. RESULTS: 94% of study participants were white and 67% were women. Case patients (n=29) were older than controls (n=82) (61.5 versus 54.5 years). The strongest predictors of lung injury, after adjusting for other variables, were older age (odds ratio [OR], 5.1 [95% CI, 1.2 to 21.1]), diabetes (OR, 35.6 [CI, 1st .3 to infinity]), rheumatoid pleuropulmonary involvement (OR, 7.1 [CI, 1.1 to 45.4]), prior use of disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (OR, 5.6 [CI, 1.2 to 27.0 ]) and hypoalbuminemia (OR, 19.5 [CI, 3.5 to 109.7]) . Previous use of disease-modifying anti-inflammatory drugs and hypoalbuminemia had very large attributable risks. CONCLUSION: Knowledge of the risk factors that predispose patients with rheumatoid arthritis to the toxic effects of methotrexate on the lungs may provide a rationale for monitoring and facilitating management of high-risk patients.

title: Risk of inpatient heart failure in new users of saxagliptin, sitagliptin and other antihyperglycaemic drugs
abstract: Background: Recent post-marketing studies have provided conflicting results on the risk of in-hospital heart failure (hHF) associated with dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors, creating uncertainty about the safety of these antihyperglycemic agents. Aim: To study the associations of hHF with saxagliptin and sitagliptin. Design: Population-based retrospective cohort study for new users. Framework: 18 health insurance and health systems data partners in the US Food and Drug Administration's Mini-Sentinel program. Patients: Patients 18 years and older with type 2 diabetes who started therapy with saxagliptin, sitagliptin, pioglitazone, second-generation sulfonylureas, or long-acting insulin products between 2006 and 2013. Ninth Revision, Clinical Modification Codes 402.x1, 404.x1, 404.x3 and 428.xx recorded as the main discharge diagnosis. RESULTS: 78,553 saxagliptin users and 298,124 sitagliptin users contributed a mean of 7 to 9 months of follow-up data to one or more pairwise comparisons. The risk of hHF was no greater with DPP-4 inhibitors than with the other study drugs. The hazard ratios from the stratified analyzes of disease risk scores (DRS) were 0.83 (95% CI, 0.70 to 0.99) for saxagliptin versus sitagliptin, 0.63 (CI, 0.47 to 0.85 ) for saxagliptin versus pioglitazone, 0.69 (CI, 0.54 to 0.87) for saxagliptin versus sulfonylureas, and 0.61 (CI, 0.50 to 0.73) for saxagliptin versus insulin. The hazard ratios stratified by DRS were 0.74 (CI 0.64 to 0.85) for sitagliptin versus pioglitazone, 0.86 (CI 0.77 to 0.95) for sitagliptin versus sulfonylureas, and 0.71 (CI 0, 64 to 0.78) for sitagliptin versus insulin. The results of the 1:1 propensity score matched analyzes were similar. Results were also similar in subgroups of patients with and without prior cardiovascular disease and in a subgroup defined by the 2 highest DRS deciles. Limitation: Remaining confounding and short follow-up. Conclusion: In this large cohort study, no increased risk of hHF was observed in users of saxagliptin or sitagliptin compared to other selected antihyperglycemic agents. Primary Funding Source: US Food and Drug Administration.

title: Risk prevalence and cancer screening by general practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND: This study presents the cancer risk prevalence and screening rates of patients who visit primary care physicians. Conditions treated include smoking, skin cancer, Pap smears, clinical breast exams and mammography. METHODS: A cross-sectional study of 7,160 patients aged 18-75 years presenting to 230 general practitioners in a metropolitan and rural region of Queensland, Australia was used. Risk prevalence was determined from patients' self-reports of risk behavior and pre-consultation screening. Information on preventive care during the consultation was based on the doctors' self-declaration at the end of the consultation. RESULTS: 27% of men and 23% of women smoked, with rates being highest in the younger age groups. According to national guidelines, prior screening for men and women had not been performed as recommended, as follows: skin cancer screening - 66% of men, 70% of women; cervical cancer screening – 27%; clinical breast examination – 45%; Mammography – 75%. These patients were therefore classified as “at risk” and the screening rates for these patients in the consultation were as follows: smokers – 34%; skin cancer – 5%; cervical cancer – 16%; mammography – 4% ;" clinical breast examination – 8%. CONCLUSIONS: A significant number of patients presenting to primary care physicians were at risk of developing cancer according to national guidelines. Of these, only small proportions of all groups had preventive intervention by their GP at the consultation identified in this study. While primary care physicians generally recognize their role in prevention as important, these results raise questions for future cancer prevention strategies and primary care physician education.

title: Role and interactions of the cardiologist in a regional institutional project of primary prevention
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is evidence to support policy support for a population-wide approach to "shifting the distribution of risk factors", but it is difficult to set up permanent primary prevention projects and to bring together the right experts. METHODS: 1999 The Piedmont Region Administration set up a multi-year intervention with aims to reduce risk factors and increase protective factors for oncological and cardiovascular diseases in the general population, especially in disadvantaged groups.The cardiologists played a major role by supporting the project of evidence guidelines, production of bibliographic reviews and dissemination of coronary risk maps In A core group of trainers has been set up in each local health service to promote a system of lifestyle advice centered on GP work - media campaign with health promotion in newspapers, television, open public transport and notice boards on the following topics: nutrition, high blood pressure, tobacco, physical activity, stress;" Warehouses, food markets, trains and squares were involved. In addition, since January 2000, a Newsletter Review has been published to provide basic models, the most effective interventions and recommendations for their implementation. RESULTS: GPs were shown a new level of care for primary prevention and counseling arguments, and the need for continuous education to promote preventive measures. A system was developed to identify the best channels, ways of communication and the most effective messages for a healthy lifestyle. A model for monitoring changes in risk factors and protective behavior in the population that describes social differences was developed to better plan and evaluate effective interventions. CONCLUSIONS: After more than half a century of productive public health scholarship, there is an urgent need for government administrations to align health policies with health determinants and create the best conditions to engage citizens in improving their lifestyles.

title: Role of "external facilitation" in implementing research results: A qualitative assessment of facilitation experiences in the Veterans Health Administration
abstract: Background Facilitation has been identified in the literature as a potential key component for successful implementation. However, it is neither well defined nor well studied. Significant questions remain about the operational definition of facilitation and the relationship of facilitation to other interventions, particularly other change agent roles when used in multi-layered implementation projects. Researchers who are part of the Quality Enhancement Research Initiative (QUERI) are actively investigating various approaches and processes, including facilitation, to enable implementation of best practices in the Veterans Health Administration's healthcare system, the largest integrated healthcare system in the United States. This paper describes a systematic, retrospective evaluation of implementation-related facilitation experiences within the framework of QUERI, a quality improvement program developed by the US Department of Veterans Affairs. Methods A post-hoc evaluation was conducted through a series of semi-structured interviews to explore the concept of facilitation in several multi-site QUERI implementation studies. The interview process is based on a technique developed in the educational field that systematically enhances experiential learning by stimulating the recall and reflection of past complex activities. For data analysis, an iterative content analysis approach was used in relation to a set of conceptually sound interview questions. Results The results suggest that facilitation in the context of an implementation study initiated by a central change agency is a conscious and valued process of interactive problem solving and support that takes place in the context of a recognized need for improvement and a supportive interpersonal relationship. Moderation has been primarily described as a distinct role with a range of potentially critical behaviors and activities. The data further suggest that outside facilitators are likely to use or integrate other implementation interventions while performing this problem-solving and supportive role. Preliminary conclusions This review provides evidence that facilitation could be viewed as an implementation intervention in its own right, in the same way that audit and feedback, education or similar methods are viewed as interventions in their own right. Therefore, moderation should be clearly defined and explicitly evaluated for its perceived benefits within multi-intervention implementation projects. In addition, researchers should better define moderation's specific contribution to the success of implementation in different types of projects, different types of sites, and with evidence and innovations of varying strength and complexity.

title: The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Schizophrenia and Related Disorders
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists coordinates the development of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) in psychiatry funded under the National Mental Health Strategy (Australia) and the New Zealand Health Funding Authority. This paper presents guidelines for schizophrenia and related disorders. In the last decade, schizophrenia has become more treatable than ever. A new generation of drug therapies, a renaissance in psychological and psychosocial interventions, and a first generation of reforms within the specialized mental health system have all combined to create an evidence-based climate of realistic optimism. Ongoing neuroscientific advances offer the strong possibility of more definitive biological treatments in the near future. However, this improved potential for better outcomes and quality of life for people with schizophrenia has not materialized in Australia. The gap between efficacy and effectiveness is wider in schizophrenia than in any other serious medical disorder. Therapeutic nihilism, under-resourced services and a stalled service reform process, poor morale within specialized mental health services, a lack of broad-based recovery and life support programs, and a climate of persistent stigma and resulting lack of concern for people with schizophrenia are the contributory causes for this failure of effective treatment. Therefore, these guidelines address only one element in the quest to reduce the impact of schizophrenia. They distill the current evidence base and make recommendations based on the best available knowledge. METHOD: A comprehensive literature search (1990-2003) was performed, including all Cochrane schizophrenia reviews and all relevant meta-analyses, and a number of recent international clinical practice guidelines were consulted. A number of drafts were refined by the panel of experts and further developed through a bi-national consultation process. TREATMENT RECOMMENDATIONS: These guidelines provide evidence-based recommendations for the management of schizophrenia by treatment type and disease stage. The key features of the guidelines are: (i) Early detection and comprehensive treatment of first episode cases is a priority, since the psychosocial and possibly biological impact of a disease can be minimized and outcome improved. An optimistic attitude on the part of healthcare workers is an essential part from the start and throughout all phases of the disease. (ii) A comprehensive and sustained intervention should be ensured during the first 3-5 years after diagnosis, since the course of the disease is strongly influenced by the events in this "critical phase". Patients should not be required to “prove chronicity” before being granted permanent access to specialized mental health services and employment. (iii) Antipsychotic medication is the cornerstone of treatment. These drugs have improved in terms of quality and tolerability, but should be used more carefully and in a more targeted manner than before. The treatment of choice for most patients is now the novel antipsychotic drugs because of their better tolerability and particularly the reduced risk of tardive dyskinesia. This applies in particular to patients in the first episode, for whom new drugs are the first, second and third choice due to better tolerability. However, these novel agents are themselves associated with potentially serious medium- to long-term side effects for which patients must be carefully monitored. Conventional antipsychotic medications at low doses may still play a role in a small proportion of patients who have achieved complete remission and are well tolerated";" however, the indications are increasingly decreasing. These principles are now accepted in most developed countries. (vi) Clozapine should be used early in the course once treatment resistance to at least two antipsychotics has been demonstrated. This usually means an incomplete response to positive symptoms, but clozapine may also be considered when there are pervasive negative symptoms or there is a significant or persistent risk of suicide. (v) Comprehensive psychosocial interventions should be routinely available to all patients and their families and delivered by appropriately trained mental health professionals who can commit to the task. These include family interventions, cognitive-behavioral therapy, occupational rehabilitation, and other forms of therapy, particularly for comorbidities such as substance abuse, depression, and anxiety. (vi) The social and cultural environment of people with schizophrenia is a key area of intervention. Adequate housing, financial security, access to meaningful social roles, and the availability of social support are essential components of recovery and quality of life. (vii) Interventions should be carefully tailored to the phase and stage of the disease, as well as gender and cultural background. (viii) Genuine involvement of consumers and families in the development and delivery of services should be standard. (ix) The maintenance of good physical health and the prevention and early treatment of serious medical conditions have been seriously neglected in the management of schizophrenia, leading to premature death and widespread morbidity. The quality of medical care for people with schizophrenia should be in line with general community standards. (x) General practitioners (GPs) should always be closely involved in the care of people with schizophrenia. However, this should be truly shared care, and care provided solely by a GP with minimal or no involvement of specialists, while very common, is not considered an acceptable standard of care. Optimal management of schizophrenia requires a multidisciplinary team approach in which a consultant psychiatrist is central.

title: The Royal College calls for a central research ethics committee
Evidence-based guidelines from the Intercollegiate Stroke Working Party of the Royal College of Physicians for secondary prevention of stroke through diet or dietary modification
abstract: BACKGROUND: Every year 15 million people worldwide and 110,000 people in England suffer a stroke. Having a stroke increases your risk of having another. There are a number of additional known risk factors that can be modified through diet. The present study aimed to systematically review key nutrients and diets and their role in secondary prevention, and to provide evidence-based guidelines for use in clinical practice. The work was carried out as part of the process to develop the 4th edition of the Royal College of Physicians (RCP) National Clinical Guideline (NCG) for stroke. METHODS: Questions were generated by the research team in consultation with the Virtual Stroke Group, an online professional advocacy group, and the RCP Intercollegiate Stroke Working Party Guideline Development Group. Nine questions on multiple individual nutrient and diet combinations were defined and searched in five electronic databases (Embase, Medline, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library and Web of Science) up to October 31, 2011. All included studies were assessed for quality and risk of bias using the Van Tulder criteria for randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and the Quality of Reporting of Meta-analyses (QUORUM) criteria for systematic reviews. RESULTS: From 4287 abstracts were identified, 79 articles reviewed, and 29 systematic reviews and RCTs included to provide evidence for the secondary prevention components of the guidelines. Evidence statements, recommendations and practical considerations were developed for each question. CONCLUSIONS: This systematic review process has led to the development of evidence-based guidelines for use in clinical practice and identified areas for further research.

title: Saccadic eye movement metrics reflect surgical resident fatigue
abstract: AIM: Little is known about the impact of OR resident fatigue on patient safety. We monitored residents' fatigue status during their visiting day using (1) eye movement metrics, (2) objective measurements of laparoscopic surgical performance, and (3) subjective reports based on standardized questionnaires. BACKGROUND: Previous attempts to study the effects of fatigue on surgical performance suffered from methodological limitations, including inconsistent definitions and lack of objective measures of fatigue and non-standardized measures of surgical performance. Recent research has shown that fatigue can affect the properties of saccadic (rapid ballistic) eye movements in non-surgical scenarios. Here we asked whether duty time (~24 hours)-induced fatigue might affect saccade metrics in surgical residents. Because saccade velocity is not under voluntary control, a saccade velocity-based fatigue index has the potential to provide an accurate and unbiased measure of the occupant's fatigue level. METHODS: We measured the eye movements of members of the resident general surgery team at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center (Phoenix, AZ) (6 males and 6 females) with a head-mounted video eye tracker (similar configuration to a surgical headlight). ), while performing 3 tasks: 2 simulated laparoscopic surgical tasks (peg transfer and precision cutting) and a guided saccade task, before and after their day of deployment. Residents rated their perceived fatigue every 3 hours during their 24-hour shift using a standardized scale.
