RESULTS: Length of service decreased saccade velocity and increased subjective fatigue, but had no effect on laparoscopic performance. These results support the hypothesis that saccadic indices reflect graded changes in fatigue. They also point out that fatigue due to longer hours of service does not necessarily lead to medical errors, highlighting the complicated relationship between continuity of care, patient safety and fatigued providers. CONCLUSIONS: Our data show for the first time that saccade velocity is a reliable indicator of the subjective fatigue of healthcare professionals during extended shifts. These results have potential implications for the development of neuroergonomic tools to detect fatigue in healthcare professionals and for the specifications of future policies related to residents' working hours.

title: Security risks associated with the lack of integration and connectivity of hospital health information technologies: a qualitative study of hospital e-prescribing systems in England
abstract: Background Significant sums of money are being invested in health information technology worldwide. However, realizing benefits and mitigating security risks depends heavily on the effective integration of information into systems and/or interfaces to enable cross-system information sharing. As part of an English research program, we examined the social and technical challenges related to the integration and connection of hospitals that have already had initial experiences with stand-alone and hospital-wide multi-modular integrated electronic prescribing systems (ePrescribing). Methods We collected qualitative longitudinal data from six hospitals, which we designed as case studies. We conducted 173 interviews with users, implementers, and software vendors (up to three different times), 24 system usage observations and strategy meetings, 17 implementation plan documents, and 2 full-day expert discussions. The data were first analyzed within and then across cases thematically, using perspectives around information infrastructures. Results We found that integration and interface issues impeded effective information transfer in both standalone and multi-modular systems, leading to a patient safety threat arising from the unavailability of timely information and duplicate data entry. On some standalone systems, where users had to deal with multiple logins, interface problems arose immediately that did not alleviate over time. At first glance, multi-modular systems seemed to avoid such problems. However, with these systems there was a perceived lack of data coherence between the modules, leading to challenges in presenting a comprehensive view of the patient record, possibly due to the piecemeal implementation of modules with different functionalities. Although it was possible to access data from some primary care systems, we found that poor bi-directional transmission of data between hospitals and primary care required bypasses, which in turn led to the possibility of new errors associated with duplicate and manual information transmission . Extending eRescribing to modules containing other clinically important information needed to support care was still an aspiration at most sites, although some advanced multi-module systems had begun to implement this functionality. However, multi-modular systems were considered difficult to interface with external systems. Conclusions The decision to pursue a strategy of buying standalone systems and then connecting them, or to pursue a strategy of buying hospital-wide multi-modular systems is crucial for hospitals to realize the vision of a fully integrated digital record, and on that should be based a clear appreciation of the relative trade-offs between these choices. While multi-modular systems offered slightly better usability, standalone systems offered greater flexibility and opportunities for innovation, especially in terms of interoperability with external systems and in terms of adaptability to the needs of different user groups.

title: Salivary cortisol response after a medical interview: the impact of physician communication behavior, depressive affect, and alexithymia
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To study whether—and possibly how—a medical interview can affect adrenal cortical activity in pain patients with and without alexithymia. METHODS: Female patients (N=54) recruited from a fibromyalgia patient organization completed the Toronto Alexithymia Scale (TAS-20) and subgroups with low and high scores were selected for participation. Seven physicians conducted consultations in which they tried to vary their communication according to the given guidelines. All consultations were videotaped and analyzed by the Roter Interaction Analysis System (RIAS) to assess the actual content of the consultations. RESULTS: An increase in depressive affects from before to after the interview was associated with relatively high cortisol levels 24 h after the interview, but only in patients with alexithymia. Immediately after the interview, psychosocial questions from the doctor were associated with an increased depressive mood, but at no time with cortisol reactions. CONCLUSION: In patients with impaired affect regulation, an increase in depressive affect after a medical consultation may be associated with delayed effects of adrenal cortical activity, possibly mediated by rumination. PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: Providers should be sensitive to potential affect regulation deficits in their patients.

title: Salt, hypertension and cardiovascular risk
abstract: Salt and blood pressure have been linked for more than a century. Prospective randomized clinical trials and meta-analyses have provided evidence that a 100 mmol reduction in daily salt intake reduces systolic blood pressure by 3-5 mm Hg, while diastolic blood pressure can be reduced by 1 mm Hg. The effect of salt restriction is highly dependent on individual salt sensitivity. Whether reducing salt intake ultimately leads to a reduction in cardiovascular morbidity and mortality needs to be determined in future studies.

title: Scan for gratification or dig for dismay? Comparison of the results of a postal survey with those of a focus group study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Despite growing support for mixed-methods approaches, we still have little systematic knowledge about the implications of combining surveys and focus groups. While the methodological aspects of questionnaire surveys have been extensively researched, the characteristics of focus group methodology have been under-researched. We propose and discuss whether focus group setting, compared to questionnaire surveys, encourages participants to exaggerate views in a negative direction. DISCUSSION: Based on an example from our own research in which we conducted a survey as a follow-up to a focus group study, and referring to theoretical approaches and empirical evidence from the literature on survey participant behavior and small group dynamics, we discuss the possibility that a discrepancy in the results between the focus groups and the questionnaire reflect characteristics of the two different research methods. In contrast to the survey, the focus group study showed that physicians were generally hostile to clinical guidelines. We were not convinced that this difference in results was due to methodological flaws in any of the studies, and instead discuss how this difference might have been the result of a general methodological phenomenon. SUMMARY: Based on studies of how poll questionnaires affect responses, it seems reasonable to suggest that polls are more likely to find overly positive opinions. Conversely, there is some evidence in the literature that focus groups can lead to complaints and overly negative attitudes, but this is still an open question. We point out that problematic issues tend to be under-communicated in questionnaire surveys, but may be over-emphasised in focus groups. We argue that it is important to improve our understanding of focus group methodology, e.g. In addition, more experimental research on focus groups should be conducted to advance the methodology and test our hypothesis.

title: School-based mental health intervention for children affected by political violence in Indonesia
abstract: Context Little is known about the effectiveness of mental health interventions for children exposed to armed conflict in low- and middle-income settings. Mental health problems in children are difficult to manage in situations of persistent poverty and political instability. Aim To evaluate the effectiveness of a school-based intervention for conflict-exposed children delivered in a low-income setting. Design, Setting, and Participants A cluster-randomized study of 495 children (81.4% inclusion rate) with a mean age (SD) of 9.9 (1.3) years attended randomly selected schools in political violence-affected communities in Poso, Indonesia and were compared to a control group on the waiting list for exposure (=1 event), post-traumatic stress disorder and anxiety symptoms. Between March and December 2006, an unblinded assessment took place before, 1 week after and 6 months after treatment. Intervention Fifteen sessions over 5 weeks of a manual, school-based group intervention, including trauma processing activities, cooperative play and creativity - expressive elements implemented by locally trained paraprofessionals. Main Outcome Measures We assessed psychiatric symptoms using the Child Posttraumatic Stress Scale, Depression Self-Rating Scale, Self-Report for Anxiety Related Disorders 5-item version, and Children's Hope Scale, and assessed functional impairment as treatment outcomes using standardized symptom checklists and locally developed rating scales. Results Adjusted for grouping of participants within schools, we found significantly greater improvement in PTSD symptoms (mean difference in change, 2.78 inches; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.02 to 4.53) and sustained hope (mean difference in change, -2.21; 95% CI, -3.52 to -0.91) in treatment group versus waitlist, changes in traumatic expression (stress-related physical symptoms) (mean difference in change, 0.50; 95% CI, -0.12 to 1.11), depressive symptoms (mean difference in change, 0.70; 95% CI, -0.08 to 1.49), anxiety (mean difference in change, 0.12; 95% CI , -0.31 to 0.56) and functioning (mean difference in change, 0.52; 95% CI). , -0.43 to 1.46) did not differ between the treatment and waiting list groups. Conclusions In this study of children in violence-affected communities, a school-based intervention reduced post-traumatic stress symptoms and helped maintain hope, but did not reduce traumatic stress symptoms, depressive symptoms, anxiety symptoms, or functional impairment.

title: Screening and brief intervention for obesity in primary care: a parallel, two-arm, randomized study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Obesity is a common cause of noncommunicable diseases. Guidelines recommend that physicians conduct screening through referral to behavioral weight loss programs and provide brief advice to motivate weight loss. However, doctors rarely intervene and no studies have been conducted on the subject. We conducted this study to determine whether brief physician intervention is acceptable and effective for reducing body weight in obese patients. METHODS: In this parallel, two-arm, randomized study, patients consulting 137 GPs in England were evaluated for obesity. Individuals who were at least 18 years old, had a body mass index of at least 30 kg/m2 (or at least 25 kg/m2 for Asians) and an increased body fat percentage could be included. At the end of the consultation, the physician randomly (1:1) assigned participants to one of two 30-second interventions. Randomization was performed via prepared randomization cards, marked with a code representing assignment, placed in opaque, sealed envelopes and given to physicians to open at the time of treatment assignment. In the active intervention, the physician offered a referral to a weight management group (12 sessions of 1 hour each, once a week), and if the referral was accepted, the physician arranged for the patient to schedule an appointment and offered follow-up care . At the control intervention, the doctor advised the patient that their health would benefit from weight loss. The primary endpoint was weight change at 12 months in the intention-to-treat population blinded to treatment allocation. We also assessed how patients feel when they talk about their weight when they have visited their GP for other reasons. Given the nature of the intervention, we did not expect any adverse events in the usual sense, so safety results were not assessed. This study is registered with the ISRCTN registry under number ISRCTN26563137. RESULTS: Between June 4, 2013 and December 23, 2014, we studied 8403 patients, of whom 2728 (32%) were obese. Of these obese patients, 2256 (83%) consented to participate and 1882 were eligible, enrolled and included in the intention-to-treat analysis, with 940 individuals in the support group and 942 individuals in the counseling group. 722 (77%) subjects assigned to the supportive intervention agreed to participate in the weight management group, and 379 (40%) of these subjects participated, compared with 82 (9%) subjects assigned to the counseling intervention. In the overall study population, the mean weight change at 12 months was 2.43 kg for the supportive intervention and 1.04 kg for the advisory intervention, an adjusted difference of 1.43 kg (95% CI 0.89-1.97) results. The patients' reactions to the brief interventions of the general practitioners did not differ significantly between the study groups with regard to appropriateness (adjusted odds ratio 0.89, 95% CI 0.75-1.07, p=0.21) or helpfulness (1.05, 0.89–1.26, p=0.54)";" Overall, four (<1%) patients considered their intervention inappropriate and unhelpful, and 1530 (81%) patients considered it appropriate and helpful. INTERPRETATION: A behavioral, very brief, opportunistic intervention administered by the physician is acceptable to patients and an effective means of reducing the mean weight of the population. FUNDING: The UK National Prevention Research Initiative.

title: Screening and intervention for comorbid substance use disorders, PTSD, depression, and suicide: A trauma center survey
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Few studies have examined screening and intervention procedures for comorbid substance use and mental disorders in trauma centers in the United States, although these disorders are endemic among survivors of traumatic injuries. In 2006, the American College of Surgeons (ACS) mandated that Level I and Level II trauma centers be screened for alcohol use problems and that Level I centers provide brief interventions for those who tested positive. The ACS is expected to recommend best practice guidelines for screening for substance use problems and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). This study examined screening and intervention procedures for the full spectrum of comorbid mental and substance use disorders in US trauma centers. METHODS: Respondents from all Level I and II trauma centers in the United States (N=518) were asked to participate in a survey describing screening and intervention procedures for alcohol and drug use problems, suicidality, depression, and PTSD. RESULTS: There were 391 (75%) respondents. Over 80% of trauma centers are routinely screened for alcohol and drug use problems. Routine assessments and interventions for suicidality, depression, and PTSD were significantly less frequent";" in fact, only 7% of centers reported routine screening for PTSD. Consistent with ACS policy, Level I centers were significantly more likely than Level II centers to offer alcohol interventions. CONCLUSIONS: Alcohol screening and interventions were common in US trauma centers and appeared to be responsive to ACS mandates. In the future, efforts to orchestrate clinical investigations and guidelines could improve screening and intervention procedures for common comorbid mental disorders.

title: Screening and interventions for obesity in children and adolescents: statement of recommendations
abstract: The US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) is an independent panel of nongovernmental prevention and primary care experts that systematically reviews evidence of efficacy and develops recommendations for clinical preventive services. This recommendation addresses the evidence for the accuracy of screening children and adolescents for BMI, the effectiveness of behavioral and pharmacologic interventions in improving health outcomes in these children, and the potential harms of routine screening and interventions. Using USPSTF methodology, an analytical framework with key questions was developed to guide the systematic review that serves as the basis for this recommendation. The number of overweight children and young people has more than doubled in the last 25 years. Obesity in childhood and adolescence is associated with increased health risks. The USPSTF found insufficient evidence for the effectiveness of behavioral counseling or other preventive interventions in overweight children and adolescents that can be delivered in primary care settings. Currently available studies are limited by factors such as small sample sizes, poor generalizability, and variable follow-up. Based on this critical gap in efficacy evidence, the USPSTF concludes that there is insufficient evidence to recommend for or against routine obesity screening in children and adolescents as a means of preventing adverse health outcomes (“I "-Recommendation). There are several gaps in research on screening and interventions for overweight children and adolescents in primary care. Research is needed to provide well-defined and effective approaches to medical and psychological assessment in children, as well as effective clinical approaches to the prevention and treatment of childhood obesity that can be implemented by primary care physicians.

title: Screening for and treatment of suicidal risk relevant to primary care: A systematic review for the US Preventive Services Task Force
abstract: Background: In 2009, 36,897 deaths in the United States were caused by suicide. Purpose: To review the accuracy of screening tools and the effectiveness and safety of screening and treatment for suicide risk in populations and settings relevant to primary care. Data sources: Citations from MEDLINE, PsycINFO, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and CINAHL (2002 to July 17, 2012); gray literature; and a surveillance search of MEDLINE for additional screening studies (July to December 2012). Study selection: English-speaking Studies of reasonable or good quality that assessed the accuracy of screening tools in primary care or similar populations and studies of suicide prevention interventions in primary care or mental health care Data extraction: one researcher extracted data, a second checked the abstraction, two researchers assessed the Study quality. Data synthesis: The evidence was insufficient to determine the benefits of screening in primary care;" Very limited evidence did not identify any serious harm. Minimal evidence suggests that screening tools can identify some adults at increased risk of suicide in primary care, but accuracy has been lower in studies of older adults. Minimal evidence, limited to high-risk populations, suggested poor performance of screening tools in adolescents. Study results showed that psychotherapy reduced suicide attempts in high-risk adults but not in adolescents. Most studies were not sufficiently powered to detect effects on deaths. Limitation: Evidence of treatment was derived from high-risk rather than screening-detected populations. Evidence relevant to adolescents, older adults, and racial or ethnic minorities was limited. Conclusion: Primary care Feasible screening tools could help identify some adults at increased risk of suicide, but have limited ability to detect suicide risk in adolescents. Psychotherapy can reduce suicide attempts in some high-risk adults, but effective interventions for high-risk adolescents have not yet been established. Primary source of funding: Health Research and Quality Agency.

title: Screening for colorectal cancer by one-time sigmoidoscopy: a feasibility study in Turin
abstract: Objectives – To evaluate the impact on compliance of three methods of invitation and the acceptability and effectiveness of two bowel preparation regimens for endoscopic screening in the general population. Methods - 1170 subjects (males and females aged 55-59 years from the lists of a sample of General Practitioners (GPs) in Turin) were randomly assigned to one of three invitation groups (A: personal letter signed by general practitioner with pre-established Appointment"; B: as for A + letter in support of the study from a well-known investigator; C: letter signed by the study coordinator, NS) and two preparation regimens (i: one enema self-administered at home two hours before the test; ii: two Enemas administered the night before and two hours before the test A reminder by post was sent to non-participants A sample of non-participants was contacted by a registered nurse for a telephone interview All subjects who underwent the test were Written informed consent was obtained.RESULTS—A total of 278 subjects participated in the sigmoidoscope screen ng part. An invitation from the GP alone led to the highest response rate (compliance: A = 29.3%; B = 24.9%; C = 26.8%). A single enema was as effective as two enemas in providing satisfactory preparation for to achieve the test: The proportion of subjects invited to repeat the test was 8.1% in the group receiving a single enema and 9.6% in the group receiving two enema Conclusions – Compliance with this Screening procedure tends to be minimal A self-administered enema two hours before sigmoidoscopy can ensure satisfactory bowel preparation.

title: Colorectal cancer screening at the forefront
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study was to assess primary care physician knowledge, beliefs, and practices related to colorectal cancer screening. METHODS: We surveyed 77 primary care physicians at six central Massachusetts clinics to assess several factors associated with colorectal cancer screening. RESULTS: Most agreed with the guidelines for fecal occult blood testing (97%) and sigmoidoscopy (87%), which were generally reported as standard practice. Although the majority (86%) recommended colonoscopy as a screening test for colorectal cancer, it was rarely reported as standard practice. Additionally, 36% considered barium enema an option for colorectal cancer screening, and it was rarely reported as a common practice. Despite a lack of evidence of efficacy, digital rectal exams and fecal occult blood testing have been reported as common practice. However, these were mostly reported in combination with a guideline-compliant test option. Although only 10% reported that stool/home occult blood testing was frequently denied, 60% reported that sigmoidoscopy was performed. Commonly cited barriers for patients to sigmoidoscopy compliance included fears that the procedure might hurt and that patients assume symptoms will occur when there is a problem. Perceptions of healthcare system barriers to sigmoidoscopy were less strong. CONCLUSIONS: Most providers recommended guideline-compliant colorectal cancer screening. However, patients often refused sigmoidoscopy. Results indicate that multiple levels of intervention, including patient and provider education and system strategies, may help increase prevalence.

title: Screening for dementia in primary care: A summary of the evidence for the US Preventive Services Task Force
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dementia is a major and growing problem, but it is often not diagnosed in its early stages. Screening and earlier treatment could reduce the burden of this syndrome. PURPOSE: To review the evidence on the benefits and harms of screening for and early treatment of dementia. DATA SOURCES: MEDLINE, PsycINFO, EMBASE, Cochrane Library, Experts and Bibliographies of Reviews. STUDY SELECTION: The authors developed eight key questions that represent a logical chain between screening and improved health outcomes, along with eligibility criteria for admissible evidence for each question. Permissible evidence was obtained by searching the data sources. DATA EXTRACTION: Two reviewers abstracted relevant information using standardized abstraction forms and graded item quality according to US Preventive Services Task Force criteria. DATA SYNTHESIS: No randomized controlled trial of screening for dementia has been completed. Brief screening tools can detect some individuals with early dementia (positive predictive value < or = 50%). Six to 12 months of treatment with cholinesterase inhibitors modestly slows the decline in cognitive and global clinical change scores in some patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. Function is minimally affected, and fewer than 20% of patients stop taking cholinesterase inhibitors because of side effects. Only limited evidence suggests that any other pharmacological or non-pharmacological intervention slows regression in individuals with early dementia. Although intensive caregiving interventions with multiple components can delay the placement of patients in nursing homes with caregivers, the relevance of this finding for those who do not already have caregivers is uncertain. Other potential benefits and harms of screening have not been studied. CONCLUSIONS: Screening tests can detect undiagnosed dementia. In people with mild to moderate clinically proven Alzheimer's disease, cholinesterase inhibitors are somewhat effective in slowing cognitive decline. The effect of cholinesterase inhibitors or other treatments on people with dementia identified through screening is uncertain.

title: Screening for depression in adult patients in primary care: A systematic review of the evidence
abstract: Background: In primary care, major depressive disorder prevalence estimates range from 5% to 13% for all adults, with lower estimates for those aged 55 and over (6% to 9%). In 2002, the US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommended screening adults for depression in clinical practices that have systems in place to ensure accurate diagnosis, effective treatment, and follow-up. Purpose: To conduct a focused, updated systematic review for the US Preventive Services Task Force on the benefits and harms of screening adult patients for primary care depression, the benefits of treating depression in older adults, and the harms of treating depression with antidepressants. Data sources: MEDLINE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects, PsycINFO (1998 to 2007), expert suggestions and bibliographies of recent systematic reviews. Study selection: Randomized clinical studies of adequate to good quality or controlled clinical studies"; systematic reviews; meta-analyses;" and large observational studies of serious adverse events and premature discontinuation due to adverse events. All studies were published in English. Data Extraction: Two investigators abstracted, critically appraised, and synthesized 33 articles that met the inclusion criteria. Data Synthesis: Nine studies of reasonable or good quality indicate that depression screening in primary care and care management programs with staff support, such as case management or involvement of mental health specialists, can improve depression response and remission. Benefit was not evident in screening programs without support from depression care staff. Seven regulatory reviews or meta-analyses and 3 large cohort studies indicate no increased risk of completed suicide with antidepressant treatment. The risk of suicidal behavior was increased in young adults (aged 18 to 29 years) who were taking antidepressants, particularly those taking paroxetine, but was reduced in older adults. Limitation: The examination of harms was limited to serious adverse events and mainly existing systematic reviews were used. Additional studies published from 2007 to 2008 expand this overview. Conclusion: Depression screening programs without substantial support from staff-assisted depression treatments are unlikely to improve depression outcomes. Close monitoring of all adult patients starting antidepressant treatment, particularly those younger than 30 years of age, is important both for safety and to ensure optimal treatment.

title: Screening for high blood pressure
abstract: Purpose: To review the evidence on four questions on screening asymptomatic adults for arterial hypertension: Is hypertension a significant health problem? Can it be detected at an early, pre-symptomatic stage? Is a treatment available and effective? Do the benefits of screening outweigh the costs and risks? DATA IDENTIFICATION AND SELECTION: We performed a computerized search of the MEDLARS database to identify community-based trials of drug therapy for mild hypertension";" other relevant citations are included where appropriate. Data Synthesis: We approached the preliminary questions in our analysis through narrative review and reasoning. Estimates of therapeutic efficacy are based on previously published meta-analyses. The cost-effectiveness of screening was assessed through formal mathematical modeling of the effect of screening on different US populations. Results of the Analysis: Hypertension is clearly a significant health problem. It can be detected early and effective treatment is available. Screening asymptomatic adults for hypertension has advantages that compare favorably to the risks and costs involved. We estimate that screening is most cost-effective for older adults compared to younger adults and for men compared to women, and is very sensitive to the cost of therapy for mild hypertension. Conclusions: We recommend screening for hypertension in all adults. We also discuss the frequency and scope of screening activities. When low-cost therapy is used, the cost-effectiveness of screening for hypertension compares favorably with other cardiovascular interventions.

title: Screening for postnatal depression in primary care: cost-effectiveness analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the cost-effectiveness of routine screening for postnatal depression in primary care. DESIGN Cost-effectiveness analysis using a decision model of alternative methods for screening for depression, including standardized postnatal depression and generic depression instruments. The performance of screening instruments was derived from a systematic review and a bivariate meta-analysis on a set of instrument cut-offs";" Estimates of other relevant parameters were derived from literature sources and relevant databases. A decision tree considered the entire treatment pathway from the possible onset of postnatal depression through identification, treatment and possible relapse. SETTING Basic care. PARTICIPANTS A hypothetical population of women screened for postnatal depression either through routine treatment alone or supplemented by the use of formal identification methods six weeks after delivery, as recommended by the latest guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Costs expressed in 2006-7 prices and impact on health outcomes expressed in quality-adjusted life-years (QALYs). The time horizon of the analysis was one year. RESULTS Routine use of postnatal or general depression questionnaires did not appear to be cost-effective compared to routine care alone. The Edinburgh Scale for Postnatal Depression (at an intercept of 16) had an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) of £41,103 per QALY compared to routine care alone. The ICER for all other strategies ranged from £49,928 to £272,463 per QALY compared to routine care alone, while the probability that no formal identification strategy was cost-effective was 88% (59%) at a cost-effectiveness threshold of £20,000 (£30,000). per QALY. While the sensitivity analysis indicated that the cost of treating misidentified depression (false positive result) was an important driver of the model, formal identification approaches did not appear to be cost-effective given any feasible estimate of these costs. CONCLUSIONS Formal methods of identifying postnatal depression do not appear to offer good value for money for the NHS. The main driver of cost effectiveness appears to be the potential additional cost of treating women who have been misdiagnosed as depressed. Formal identification methods for postnatal depression currently do not meet the National Screening Committee's criteria for adoption of a screening strategy as part of national health policy.

title: Screening for Speech and Language Delay in Preschool Children: Systematic Review of the Evidence for the US Preventive Services Task Force
abstract: BACKGROUND: PEDIATRICS (ISSN numbers: Print, 0031-4005";" Online, 1098-4275). Released into the public domain by the American Academy of Pediatrics. Speech and language development is a useful indicator of a child's overall development and cognitive abilities and is related to academic success. Identifying children at risk for developmental delays or related problems can lead to intervention services and family support from an early age when the chances of improvement are best. However, optimal methods for screening for speech and language delay have not been identified, and screening is inconsistently practiced in primary care. PURPOSE: We sought to assess the strengths and limitations of the evidence about the effectiveness of screening and interventions for speech and language delay in preschool children, to determine the balance between benefits and side effects of routine screening in primary care for guideline development US Task Force on Preventive Services. The target population includes all children up to the age of 5 years with no prior history of speech and language delays, such as B. Hearing and neurological impairments. METHODS: Studies were identified from the Medline, PsycINFO, and CINAHL databases (1966 to November 19, 2004), systematic reviews, reference lists, and experts. The evidence review included only English-language published articles available through libraries. Only randomized controlled trials were considered to examine the effectiveness of interventions. Outcome measures were included if collected at any time point or at any age after screening and/or the intervention, as long as the initial assessment was made while the child was or =2 screening techniques in 1 population and comparisons of a single screening technique absent across different populations. Fourteen randomized controlled intervention trials of good and fair quality reported significantly improved speech and language outcomes compared to control groups. Improvements were demonstrated in multiple areas, including articulation, phonology, expressive language, receptive language, lexical acquisition, and syntax in children across all age groups studied and in multiple therapeutic settings. Improvements in other functional outcomes such as socialization skills, self-esteem, and improved play themes were demonstrated in some, but not all, of the 4 studies that measured them. In general, intervention studies have been small and heterogeneous, may be subject to plateau effects, and have reported short-term outcomes based on different tools and measures. As a result, long-term outcomes are unknown, interventions could not be compared directly, and generalizability is questionable. CONCLUSIONS: The use of risk factors to guide selective screening is not supported by studies. Several aspects of screening have been insufficiently studied to determine optimal methods, including which instrument to use, the age at which to screen, and what interval is most useful. Intervention trials show improvement in some outcome measures, but conclusions and generalizability are limited. No data are available addressing other important issues, including the effectiveness of screening in primary care, the role of increased surveillance by primary care physicians prior to referral for diagnostic evaluation, non-speech and language, and the long-term benefit of interventions and side effects of screening and interventions.

title: Screening Surgeons for HIV Infection: A Cost-Benefit Analysis
abstract: OBJECTIVE. To determine the cost-effectiveness of a strategy to screen surgeons for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection to prevent transmission of HIV to patients undergoing invasive procedures. DESIGN: Cost-Benefit Analysis. RESULTS: A one-time national screening program would identify approximately 137 surgeons with HIV infection (range 28 to 423 surgeons) and prevent approximately 4.3 infections (range 1.9 to 21.3 infections) in patients treated by infected surgeons treated, and 0.9 infections (range , 0 to 12.9 infections) in sexual partners of infected surgeons with direct costs of US$8.1 million and induced costs of approximately US$44 million. It would result in expenditure of US$458,000 per life year saved (range US$147,000 to US$687,000 per life year saved), while an annual screening program would result in expenditure of approximately US$1.1 million per life year saved (range $338,000 to $1,886,000). year of life saved). If the prevalence of HIV infection among surgeons is estimated to be three times our base case estimate (an increase from 0.1% to 0.3%), annual screening would result in expenditure of approximately $741,000 per life year saved. If the probability of seroconversion after a patient is exposed to a contaminated instrument is increased from our base case estimate of 0.29% to 5.0%, an annual screening program would still cost more than $228,000 per life year saved costs. CONCLUSION: Screening surgeons for HIV to prevent transmission of HIV to patients undergoing invasive procedures requires expenditure per life year saved that is significantly higher than most accepted health interventions. Surveillance studies in patients treated by HIV-infected surgeons should be continued to confirm that transmission of HIV to patients undergoing invasive procedures is rare.

title: Screening, Isolation, and Decolonization Strategies in the Control of Meticillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus in Intensive Care Units: Evaluation of Cost-Effectiveness
abstract: OBJECTIVE To evaluate the cost-effectiveness of screening, isolation, and decolonization strategies in the control of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) in intensive care units. DESIGN Economic evaluation based on a dynamic transmission model. SETTING England and Wales. Population Theoretical patient population in an intensive care unit. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Infections, deaths, costs, quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), incremental cost-effectiveness ratios for alternative strategies, and net financial benefit. RESULTS All decolonization strategies improved health outcomes and reduced costs. Although universal decolonization (regardless of MRSA status) was the most cost-effective in the short term, strategies that use screening to target MRSA carriers may be preferred due to the lower risk of resistance selection. Among these targeted strategies, universal intake and weekly polymerase chain reaction screening coupled with decolonization with nasal mupirocin was the most cost-effective. This result was robust to the size of the ICU, the prevalence of MRSA on admission, the proportion of patients classified as high-risk, and the exact value of willingness to pay for healthcare. All strategies that used isolation but not decolonization improved health outcomes, but increased costs. If the prevalence of MRSA on ICU admission was 5% and the willingness to pay per QALY gained was between £20,000 ($23,000; $32,000) and £30,000, the best such strategy was to isolate only those patients who had a are at high risk of carrying MRSA (either pre-emptively or after identification by admission and weekly screening for MRSA using chromogenic agar). Universal enrollment and weekly screening using polymerase chain reaction-based detection of MRSA in conjunction with isolation were unlikely to be cost effective unless the prevalence was high (10% of patients at enrollment were with MRSA colonized). CONCLUSIONS MRSA control strategies using decolonization are likely to be cost-effective in an ICU provided resistance is absent, and the combination of universal polymerase chain reaction screening with decolonization is likely to represent good value for money when untargeted decolonization is considered unacceptable. In intensive care units that do not undergo decolonization, there is insufficient evidence to support universal screening for MRSA outside of high-prevalence settings.

title: Secondary prevention after mild strokes and TIA - standard care and development of an accompanying program
abstract: BACKGROUND: Effective methods of secondary prevention after stroke or TIA are available, but adherence to recommended evidence-based treatments is often poor. The aim of the study was to determine the quality of secondary prevention in standard care and to develop a step-by-step modeled support program. METHODS: Two consecutive cohorts of acute mild stroke or TIA patients undergoing usual outpatient care were compared to a secondary prevention program. Risk factor control and medication adherence were assessed in 6-month follow-ups (6M-FU). The usual care consisted of detailed information on targets for vascular risk factors at discharge and regular outpatient care by general practitioners. The step-by-step modeled care program also included up to four outpatient appointments. A combination of educational and behavioral strategies was used. RESULTS: 168 patients in the observation cohort who reported willingness to participate in a prevention program (mean age 64.7 years, admission blood pressure (BP): 155/84 mmHg) and 173 patients participating in the support program (mean age 67.6 years, blood pressure : 161/84 mmHg) were assessed after 6 months. The proportions of patients with BP according to guidelines were 50% in usual care and 77% in the support program (p<0.01). LDL < 100 mg/dl was measured in 62 versus 71% (p = 0.12). The proportion of patients who quit smoking was 50 versus 79% (p<0.01). 72 versus 89% of patients with atrial fibrillation received oral anticoagulation (p = 0.09). CONCLUSIONS: Risk factor control remains unsatisfactory in current treatment. Secondary prevention goals were more frequently achieved within the supervised cohort. The effects on the (cerebro)vascular recurrence rates are examined in a multicenter randomized study.

title: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and routine specialist care with and without cognitive behavioral therapy in adolescents with major depression: randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine whether a combination of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) plus clinical treatment is more effective in the short term than SSRI and clinical treatment alone in adolescents with moderate to severe major depression. DESIGN Pragmatic, randomized, controlled superiority study. SETTING 6 ambulances in Manchester and Cambridge. PARTICIPANTS 208 adolescents aged 11-17 years with moderate to severe severe or probably severe depression who had failed a brief initial intervention. Adolescents with suicidal tendencies, depressive psychosis or behavioral disorders were included. INTERVENTIONS 103 adolescents received an SSRI and routine treatment";" 105 received an SSRI, routine care, and CBT. The study lasted 12 weeks, followed by a 16-week maintenance phase. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Change from baseline in the Health of the Nation Child and Adolescent Outcome Scale (primary outcome) score with 12 weeks as the primary and 28 weeks as the follow-up endpoint. Secondary measures were the change in scores on the Mood and Emotion Questionnaire, the Revised Child Depression Rating Scale, the Child Global Rating Scale, and the Clinical Global Impression Improvement Scale. RESULTS At 12 weeks, the treatment effect for the primary endpoint was -0.64 (95% confidence interval -2.54 to 1.26, P=0.50). In a longitudinal analysis, there was no difference in treatment efficacy for the primary (mean treatment effect 0.001, -1.52 to 1.52, P=0.99) or secondary endpoints. Thoughts of suicide and self-harm decreased on average. There was no evidence of a protective effect of cognitive behavioral therapy on suicidal thinking or acting. After 28 weeks, 57% had improved greatly or very much, and 20% remained unchanged. CONCLUSIONS For adolescents with moderate to severe major depression, there is no evidence that the combination of CBT plus an SSRI in the presence of routine clinical care contributes to an improved outcome at 28 weeks compared to the provision of routine clinical care plus an SSRI alone . STUDY REGISTRATION Current Controlled Trials ISRCNT 83809224.

title: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors in childhood depression: systematic review of published versus unpublished data
abstract: BackgroundQuestions about the safety of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in the treatment of depression in children prompted us to compare and contrast published and unpublished data on the risks and benefits of these drugs.";" BackgroundQuestions about the safety of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) in the treatment of depression in children prompted us to compare and contrast published and unpublished data on the risks and benefits of these drugs.

title: Self-formulated condition plans for changing the health behavior of health consumers and health professionals.
abstract: This is a protocol for a Cochrane Review (Intervention). The objectives are as follows: Our main objective is to assess the impact of self-formulated conditional plans to change health-related behaviors of health consumers and health professionals. Our secondary aim is to examine whether the effects of self-formulated conditional plans are modified by: (i) the form of the plan (z does the individual participate in its development as planned?); and (iii) complexity of the desired behavior (e.g. number of actions required); "Regularity of Conduct".

title: Self-Help Books for Depression: How Can Practitioners and Patients Make the Right Choices?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Depression is a common and important public health problem, most often treated by primary care physicians. A self-help approach is popular with patients, but little is known about its effectiveness. OBJECTIVE: Our main objective was to review and update the evidence for the clinical efficacy of bibliotherapy in the treatment of depression. Our secondary goal was to identify which of these self-help materials are commonly available and to examine the evidence specific to these publications. METHOD: Medline, CINAHL, EMBASE, PsycINFO, CCTR, PsiTri, and the National Research Register were searched for randomized trials evaluating self-help books for depression that included participants over 16 years of age with a diagnosis or symptoms of depression. Clinical symptoms, quality of life, cost or user acceptability were the required outcome measures. Papers were independently obtained and data extracted by two researchers. A meta-analysis using a random effects model was performed using the mean and standard deviation of the Hamilton rating scale for depression at the study endpoint. RESULTS: Eleven randomized controlled trials were identified. None met CONSORT guidelines and all were small, with the largest study having 40 patients per group. Nine of these evaluated two recent publications, Managing Anxiety and Depression (UK) and Feeling Good (US). A meta-analysis of 6 studies evaluating Feeling Good found a large treatment effect compared to delayed treatment (standardized mean difference = -1.36"; 95% confidence interval [CI] = -1.76 to -0.96). Five Self-help books were identified as available and were widely purchased by members of the public, in addition to the two books evaluated in trials.CONCLUSION: There are a number of self-help books on treating depression that are readily available.For the majority, there are hardly any direct evidence of its effectiveness. There is weak evidence that bibliotherapy based on a cognitive behavioral therapy approach is useful for some people when given additional guidance. More work is needed in primary care to assess the cost-effectiveness of self-help and the am examine the most appropriate format and presentation of materials.

title: Self-management programs for COPD: Making progress
abstract: Self-management is becoming increasingly important in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). However, there is confusion about which processes are involved, how the value of self-management should be determined, and research priorities. To gain more insight into and consensus on the content of programs, outcomes and future directions of COPD self-management, a group of interested researchers and physicians, all of whom had previously published on the topic and previously worked on other projects, convened a workshop. This article summarizes their initial findings. Self-management programs aim for structural behavior change to maintain treatment effects after the programs are completed. Programs should include behavior modification techniques, be individually tailored, take into account the patient's perspective, and may vary depending on the patient's disease course and comorbidities. The assessment should include process variables. This report is a step towards more self-government compliance. To improve clarity about effectiveness, future studies should clearly describe their intervention, be properly designed and substantiated, and contain results that focus more on the acquisition and practice of new skills. In this way, more evidence and a better understanding of self-management programs will be gained and a more specific formulation of self-management guidelines will be possible.

title: Self-reported use of personal protective equipment among Chinese critical care physicians during the 2009 H1N1 flu pandemic
abstract: BACKGROUND: Critically ill patients with 2009 H1N1 influenza are often treated in intensive care units (ICUs), posing a significant risk of nosocomial transmission to critical care physicians and other patients. Despite a large body of literature and guidelines recommending infection control practices, numerous barriers leading to poor compliance with the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) have been identified in intensive care units. The use of PPE by critical care physicians has not been extensively evaluated, especially during the influenza pandemic. This study examined the knowledge, attitudes, and self-reported behaviors and barriers to compliance for PPE use among healthcare workers in intensive care units during the influenza pandemic. METHODOLOGY/MAIN RESULTS: A 36-question survey tool was developed and distributed to all medical professionals in 21 intensive care units in 17 provinces in China. A total of 733 doctors, nurses and other professionals were interviewed, of whom 650 (88.7%) were included in the analysis. Fifty-six percent of respondents reported having completed a pandemic influenza education program prior to caring for H1N1 patients, while 77% reported having adequate knowledge of self-protection and patient protection. Only 18% of respondents were able to correctly identify all components of the PPE and 55% reported high compliance (>80%) in using PPE during patient care. In the multivariate analysis, vaccination against the 2009 H1N1 influenza, positive attitudes towards PPE use, organizational factors such as availability of PPE in the ICU and patient information about influenza precautions, and reprimands for non-compliance by supervisors were associated with high compliance, while they were negative Attitudes to PSA use and violation of PSA use were independent predictors of low compliance. CONCLUSION/SIGNIFICANCE: Knowledge and self-reported adherence to the recommended use of PPE among Chinese critical care physicians is suboptimal. The perceived barriers should be addressed to close the significant gap between perception and knowledge or behavior.

title: Self-reported versus actual test ordering behavior among general practitioners
abstract: To determine the accuracy of clinical self-reports, 38 clinicians in a university health organization (HMO) practice were interviewed about their thyroid function test (TFT) patterns one year after the distribution of an educational intervention (the intervention). The mean of the absolute difference between self-reported and actual test order rates was 12%";" the difference was greater than 20% for only 3 of 33 physicians who ordered TFT in at least five patients during the study period. A strong association was found between self-reported change and actual mean change in TFT ordering rates post-intervention (p<0.0001). The results suggest that, at least in certain settings, clinicians can accurately assess their usage patterns and the impact of practice guidelines.

title: Self-reported violations during medication administration in two children's hospitals
abstract: Content Violations of security protocols are pathways to adverse outcomes that have been inadequately addressed by existing security efforts. This study reports on nurse self-reported violations in the medication administration process. Objective To capture the extent of violations in the medication administration process among nurses. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS The participants were 199 nurses from two municipal, academic, independent pediatric tertiary care hospitals in the United States who were based in a pediatric intensive care unit (PICU), a hematology-oncology-transplant unit (HOT), or a medical surgical (Med /Surg) unit. In a cross-sectional survey, nurses were asked about violations in routine or emergency situations at three steps of medication administration. Main Outcome Measures Self-reported violations of three medication administration protocols were assessed using a seven-point scale from 0 to 6 from “not at all” to “very severely”. Results Analysis of variance revealed that reports of violations were highest in emergency situations rather than routine surgeries, highest in HOT ward nurses, followed by ICU nurses and then the med/surgical unit, and highest in verifying patient identification, followed by associating a medication with a medication administration record and then documenting an administration. There was also a significant three-way interaction between injury situation, step in process, and unit. Conclusions Protocol violations occur throughout the medication process and their prevalence varies by hospital unit, step in the process, and injury situation. Further research is needed to determine whether these violations improve or worsen security, and for those that do, how the management system can be redesigned to reduce the need to violate protocol to complete work tasks.

title: Self-study using web-based and printed guides. A randomized controlled trial among general practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND: Online physician education is increasing, but its effectiveness compared to existing self-study methods is unknown. OBJECTIVE: To compare knowledge, learning effectiveness, and learner satisfaction produced by self-study of World Wide Web-based and printed guidelines for acute myocardial infarction care. DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. SETTING: 12 residency programs in family medicine and internal medicine at four universities. PARTICIPANTS: 162 residents. INTERVENTIONS: In proctored sessions, participants were randomly assigned to study printed materials or SAGE (Self-Study Acceleration with Graphic Evidence), a web-based tutorial system. Both methods used identical self-assessment questions and answers and guideline text, but SAGE included hyperlinks to specific guideline passages and graphical evidence animations. MEASUREMENTS: Scores on multiple-choice knowledge tests, score gains per unit of study time, and ratings on a learner satisfaction scale. RESULTS: Immediately post-test scores on a 20-point scale were similar in the SAGE and control groups (median 15.0 vs. 14.5 inches; P > 0.2), but SAGE users spent less time spent learning (median 27.0 versus 38.5 minutes; P<0.001) and therefore had higher learning efficiency (median gain 8.6 versus 6.7 points per hour; P=0.04). On a scale of 5 to 20, SAGE users were more satisfied with their learning (median 17.0 compared to 15.0; P<0.001). After 4 to 6 months, knowledge had decreased to the same extent in the SAGE and control groups ( Median, 12.0 compared to 11.0; "P = 0.12). CONCLUSIONS: Online tutorials can lead to greater learning efficiency and satisfaction than printed materials, but self-study may be insufficient for long-term knowledge retention. Further research is needed to identify instructional characteristics that motivate better outcome learning and retention.

title: Sertraline as monotherapy for the treatment of psychotic and non-psychotic depression
abstract: BACKGROUND: Previous studies suggest that selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are effective when used alone in the treatment of unipolar depression with psychotic features. The purpose of the present study was to assess the response to sertraline in patients with and without psychotic features using standard criteria such as recovery and remission. METHOD: An 8-week, open-label study of sertraline in depressed hospitalized patients was conducted. Twenty-five subjects had DSM-IV major depressive disorder with psychotic features and 25 had DSM-IV major depressive disorder without psychotic features. After a week of open washout, all subjects were assessed at baseline using the Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D) and the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS). The HAM-D was administered weekly and the BPRS was not re-administered until the end of the 8-week study. The drug dose was started at 50 mg/day, increased to 100 mg/day after 1 week, and then increased to 200 mg/day if the subjects were not in remission. RESULTS: Depressed patients without psychosis responded significantly better than depressed patients with psychosis using the criteria remission (HAM-D score - 7 inches; p=0.001), response (HAM-D score - 50% of baseline; p = 0.001) used 0.011), referral to electroconvulsive therapy (HAM-D score >/= 15; p = 0.011), or change in HAM-D scores (p = 0.016). The baseline HAM-D score and psychosis independently predicted response, while the baseline BPRS scores did not, regardless of whether psychotic status was included in the analyses. CONCLUSIONS: Psychotic depression is less responsive to sertraline alone than depression without psychosis. Psychosis was a predictor of response, independent of the level of depression and general psychopathology. Limitations due to an open-label design are discussed, as are differences between this study and others using SSRIs for psychotic depression.

title: Services for children with developmental coordination disorder: an assessment using best practice principles
abstract: PURPOSE: The National Health Service in Scotland has published a best practice framework to support Occupational Therapists and Physiotherapists in providing effective services to children with Developmental Coordination Disorder (DCD). However, compliance is variable. To highlight areas of development, this study compared the care pathway within a pediatric DCD service to the NHS Scotland framework. METHODS: A UK-based partnership of researchers and clinicians conducted a qualitative study with 37 participants (N=13 interviewees, N=24 workshop participants). In-depth interviews and/or workshops were used to align DCD service with the NHS framework. Identified gaps were matched against four key phases of the care pathway. Qualitative analysis software was used to analyze the data. RESULTS: For each phase of the path, core principles were identified that should guide future development. These core principles related to the NHS framework and focused on issues such as family involvement, defining clear pathways and encouraging children's participation. Participants identified potential strategies for improving services, such as developing community-based interventions and providing information. CONCLUSION: Challenges in providing services to children with DCD include confusing treatment pathways and poor collaborative partnerships. Therefore, it is important that physicians employ collaborative working strategies that encourage children's participation. IMPLICATIONS FOR REHABILITATION: There are numerous challenges associated with implementing best practice principles in the delivery of therapy services for children with developmental coordination disorder (DCD). It is important that AHPs look for ways to involve parents and educators at all stages of the care journey to ensure optimal service delivery for the child. Addressing participation is an important aspect and community-based strategies can be particularly useful, both as a preventive activity and as an intervention approach.

title: Sex in the doctor's office
abstract: KIE: A case study explores the dilemma of a physician faced with a colleague's serious violation of professional norms. dr Jones, a psychiatrist, learns from a patient that she is volunteering with her internist, who has threatened to harm her if she goes against him. Though desperate and suicidal, the woman insists on protecting the internist, and Jones must decide for himself how to proceed. In her commentary, Shapiro, a psychiatrist, points out that Jones's actions depend on those of his patient, with whom he has a duty of confidentiality. He also has moral and fraternal obligations to his colleague, which may include contacting an impaired physician committee. Morrow, a sociologist, argues that Jones has a moral and legal obligation to intervene to protect patients and the integrity of the medical profession. This intervention should probably take the form of a notification from an agency investigating problem doctors.

title: Sex, Stroke, and Inflammation: The Potential for Estrogen-Mediated Immune Protection in Stroke.
abstract: Stroke is the third leading cause of death and the leading cause of disability in developed countries. Experimental and clinical data indicate that stroke is a sexually dimorphic disorder in which males show increased intrinsic susceptibility to ischemic damage throughout most of their lives. The neuroprotective role of estrogen in the female brain is well known, but estrogen exposure can also be harmful, particularly in older women. The mechanisms for this are still unclear. Our current understanding is based on studies examining estrogen in relation to neuronal injury, but cerebral ischemia also induces a robust sterile inflammatory response involving local and systemic immune cells. Despite estrogen's potent anti-inflammatory effects, few studies have examined estrogen's contribution to sex differences in the inflammatory response to stroke. This review examines the potential role of estrogen-mediated immune protection in ischemic injury. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Sexual activity and counseling in the first month after acute myocardial infarction in younger adults in the United States and Spain: a prospective observational study
abstract: BACKGROUND: United States and European Cardiovascular Society guidelines recommend physicians counseling patients about resuming sexual activity after acute myocardial infarction (AMI), but little is known about patients' experiences of counseling about sexual activity after AMI famous. METHODS AND RESULTS: The prospective longitudinal study, Variation in Recovery: Role of Gender on Outcomes of Young AMI Patients (VIRGO), conducted in 127 hospitals in the United States and Spain, was designed in part to address gender differences in sexual baseline to assess activity, function, and patient experience with physician counseling about sexual activity after an AMI. This study used baseline and 1-month data collected from the 2:1 sample of women (N=2349) and men (N=1152) aged 18 to 55 years with AMI. The average age was 48 years. Among those who reported having discussed sexual activity with a doctor in the month after AMI (12% of women, 19% of men), 68% had restrictions imposed: limit sex (35%), adopt a more passive role (26th %), and/or keep heart rate low (23%). In risk-adjusted analyses, factors associated with not discussing sexual activity with a physician included female gender (relative risk 1.07 in; 95% confidence interval 1.03-1.11) and age (relative risk 1.05 per 10 years; 95% confidence interval). , 1.02-1.08) and sexual inactivity at baseline (risk ratio, 1.11; 95% confidence interval, 1.08-1.15). Among patients who received counseling, women in Spain received significant more likely to have limitations than US women (relative risk ;" 1.36, 95% confidence interval, 1.11-1.66). CONCLUSIONS: Very few patients reported seeking sexual activity counseling after AMI. Those who did so often had limitations imposed that were not supported by evidence or guidelines CLINICAL TRIAL REGISTRATION URL: http://www.clinicaltrials.gov Unique Identifier: NCT00597922.

title: Sexual health curricula in US medical schools: current educational goals
abstract: GOAL: The authors identify the explicit and implicit goals that shape decisions about what medical schools teach regarding human sexuality. METHODS: The authors reviewed relevant articles in journals, medical examinations, and professional association publications to identify learning goals for human sexuality in medical curricula. RESULTS: There is consensus about many of the recruitment goals and some of the skills that sexual health medical students should acquire. There is less consensus about what sexuality-related information medical students need to master. The few common information objectives narrowly focus on the diagnosis of sexual dysfunction and disease. CONCLUSION: The model sexual health curricula, licensing exams, and professional association guidelines focus primarily on the pathological aspects of sexuality. Medical students should master basic information about healthy sexual function and become familiar with the role of practitioners in various therapeutic disciplines in treating sexual concerns and improving sexual function and patient well-being. Classes should also identify ways to incorporate this important topic into time-limited interactions with patients.

title: Sexually Transmitted Diseases in Users of Erectile Dysfunction Drugs: Analysis of Claims Data
abstract: Background Pharmacological treatments for erectile dysfunction (ED) have gained wide popularity among middle-aged and elderly men in recent years. Increased sexual activity among users of these treatments raises concerns about sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). Objective To study the association between sexually transmitted diseases and ED drugs (see Design Longitudinal Analysis of ED Drug Users and Non-Users of 1,410,806 Male Employees 40+ with Private Insurance from 44 Large Companies <0.005). Adjusted for these baseline rates, ED drug users had higher rates of STDs in the year after first ED drug use compared to non-users over the same period (OR 2.06, p<0.05). In ED drug users, STD rates were higher in the year after first ED drug use than in the year before (327 vs. 289 annually per 100,000 people, p<0.05). Limitations Selection bias precludes firm conclusions about whether use of ED treatments directly results Conclusions Compared to non-users, ED drug users have higher rates of STDs both before starting treatment and one year after. At the very least, this relationship suggests that men taking ED medication may benefit from early discussions about safe sex practices and closer surveillance for STDs. It's also possible that the availability of ED medications may increase STD rates.

title: Shared decision-making does not bias physicians against the guidelines of clinical practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: While shared decision-making (SDM) and adherence to clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) are important, some believe they are incompatible. This study examined the trade-off between physicians' intent to engage in SDM and their intent to follow guidelines. METHODS: Embedded in a clustered randomized trial evaluating the impact of training physicians in SDM on the use of antibiotics to treat acute respiratory infections, this study assessed physicians' intentions to both engage with SDM and follow guidelines. A self-administered questionnaire based on the theory of planned behavior assessed both behavioral intentions and their respective determinants (attitude, subjective norm, and perceived behavioral control) at study entry and exit. We used path analysis to examine the relationships between intents. We performed statistical analyzes using the maximum likelihood method and the variance-covariance matrix. Goodness-of-fit indices included the chi-square statistic, the comparative fit index, and the root mean square error of approximation. RESULTS: We analyzed 244 responses at entry and 236 at exit. In the control group, we observed initially that physicians' intention to engage in SDM (r = 0, t = 0.03) did not affect their intention to follow guidelines; however, their intention to follow guidelines (r = -0.31, t = -2.82) negatively impacted their intention to engage in SDM. Upon exit, no behavioral intent influenced the other. In the experimental group, no behavioral intention influenced the other upon entry;" Upon exit, intention to engage in SDM still did not influence intention to use CPGs, although intention to adhere to CPGs (r = −0.15 t = -2.02) slightly negatively influenced intent to engage in SDM, but this was not clinically significant.CONCLUSION: Physicians' intent to engage in SDM does not affect their intent to use guidelines even after SDM training Physician intent to adopt guidelines had no clinically significant impact on intent to engage in SDM STUDY REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT01116076.

title: short course of cognitive behavioral therapy can reduce health anxiety, researchers say
abstract: A short course of cognitive-behavioral therapy, administered by nurses with minimal training, would be an effective and relatively inexpensive way to reduce health anxiety in general practice clinics, researchers claim. Health anxiety or hypochondria places a significant burden on health services as it leads to multiple consultations and investigations. Cognitive behavioral therapy is known to be an effective treatment for other anxiety disorders, but there is a shortage of specialized therapists and long waiting lists for treatment. The Cognitive Behavior Therapy for Health Anxiety in Medical Patients (CHAMP) study randomized 445 people with abnormal health anxiety who attended gastroenterology, neurology, and respiratory clinics in Ethiopia

title: Should future interventional neuroradiologists be screened for mutations affecting radiation-induced DNA repair?
abstract: In our current medical practice, more and more medical specialists now have access to radiological technical platforms to perform imaging procedures. Although knowledge of current guidelines and radiation protection equipment is a prerequisite for the use of radiation, the preventive measures are often more or less strictly followed, resulting in chronic daily exposure to significant radiation doses and large cumulative lifetime exposures. In particular, aortic procedures, electrophysiology, and neuroprocedures can result in high doses for operators. Interventionalists might try to justify their denial of exposure risks with various excuses: they don't know where they left their badges (though they would guiltily admit that it's good practice to always wear them), the estimated short duration of the intervention , significant muscle strain and cramps caused by the weight of lead aprons, decreased dexterity with lead gloves, or discomfort when wearing lead goggles. But their dismissive attitude is most likely due to an inherent inability to feel threatened by something they cannot see or feel, a commitment to the patient at all costs, and a culture of bravery that reinforces their behavior.

title: Should recommendations for starting inhaled corticosteroids in mild asthma be based on symptom frequency: a post-hoc efficacy analysis of the START study
abstract: Background: Low-dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are highly effective in reducing asthma exacerbations and mortality. Conventionally, ICS treatment is recommended for patients with symptoms more than 2 days per week, but this criterion is poorly documented. Our aim was to assess the validity of the previous symptom-based cutoff for the onset of ICS by determining whether there was a differential response to budesonide versus placebo in severe asthma exacerbations, pulmonary function, and asthma symptom control in the subgroups ;" Background: Low-dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are highly effective in reducing asthma exacerbations and mortality. Traditionally, ICS treatment is recommended for patients with symptoms for more than 2 weeks days per week is recommended, but this criterion is poorly documented.Our aim was to assess the validity of the previous symptom-based cutoff for the start of ICS by determining whether there was a differential response to budesonide versus placebo in severe asthma exacerbations, of lung function and control of asthma symptoms tome in the subgroups identified by the frequency of asthma symptoms at baseline.

title: Should women participate in breast cancer clinical trials? problems and some solutions
abstract: PURPOSE: The purpose of this review is to review the issues for women associated with participation in clinical trials evaluating breast cancer management and provide some recommendations for future initiatives to address the identified problem areas. METHODS: The National Breast Cancer Center of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) hosted an international workshop on "Clinical Trials in Breast Cancer: Should Women Participate?" We also reviewed the literature on informed participation in clinical trials identified in a broad search covering Medline, PsycLIT and HealthPlan from 1986 to 1996. RESULTS AND CONCLUSION: When women are asked to participate in a clinical trial, they are faced with many questions and dilemmas. These include issues related to the conduct and ethical considerations of the study, the implications of participation or non-participation on treatment, the physician's role as a clinician and as a researcher, the informed consent process, the timing of the request for participation, and the Benefits and Costs of Participation It identifies a number of steps that could help women in deciding whether to participate in clinical trials, including providing community information about clinical trials, establishing independent brokers and clinical trial registries, reviewing information by consumers and protocols and participation in trials reviewing the role of ethics committees collecting data on the proportion of women currently being recruited into clinical trials, their reasons for participation or refusal, and their views on the recruitment and participation process; models for best practice in recruiting women for clinical trials and encouraging ongoing participation in trials; evidence-based communication skills training for clinicians to provide skills to appropriately inform women about clinical trial participation;" and sponsorship and sponsorship of trials by an independent agency.

title: Significance of chronic fatigue syndrome in rehabilitation medicine - status and prospects
abstract: From a clinical perspective, chronic fatigue or fatigue appears to be an important factor in rehabilitation. However, this is first a phenomenon that, according to the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (JCF), can be described as a function caused by chronic disease or chronic overwork. As part of a workshop at the 12th Rehabilitation Science Colloquium in 2003, the clinical and socio-medical significance of chronic fatigue or exhaustion with regard to rehabilitation was discussed from the perspective of psychiatric rehabilitation, methodology, sociology and practical rehabilitation, and conclusions for future research were drawn . The definition of chronic exhaustion is based primarily on the feeling of chronic fatigue, but also on phenomena such as concentration disorders, physical complaints, headaches and "drive" and mood disorders. A psychiatric diagnosis associated with symptoms of chronic fatigue is neurasthenia, which is made according to well-defined criteria. Depressive disorder is one of the most important differential diagnoses in this area. Research by primary care physicians revealed that about 90% of patients diagnosed with a psychovegetative disorder fully agreed with the diagnosis of neurasthenia. Neurasthenia led to phases of inability to work more frequently than somatization disorders and other psychosomatic diagnoses. Based on the "IRES" scale "vital exhaustion", depending on the individual range of indications, isolated or even serious changes are found in about 50% to 90% of those undergoing rehabilitation. As expected, the majority of the pathological findings affect patients in psychosomatic rehabilitation, since there are overlaps with symptoms of psychosomatic illnesses. However, it is remarkable that even in somatically oriented orthopedic rehabilitation up to 50% of the patients show signs of fatigue. Preliminary studies have shown that these symptoms can definitely be improved as part of rehabilitation, even if there are still plenty of pathological signs to be seen in follow-up examinations. Pronounced manifestations of "vital exhaustion" and "professional exhaustion" can also be observed in rheumatism patients undergoing somatic rehabilitation. This agrees with the details of the medical history given by many female and male patients. Therefore, it seems necessary to adapt the rehabilitative intervention to both the psychovegetative and the behavioral aspects of this symptom. The scientific classification of the entire field of chronic fatigue with regard to rehabilitation requires a classification of the relevant functions within the framework of the ICF. On the one hand, patient surveys would have to be carried out as part of cross-sectional studies and, on the other hand, a systematic consensus process among experts would have to be used to assign the corresponding functions. This is the basis for the development of suitable assessment instruments for use in prospective studies to systematically evaluate the impact on functions and in particular their impact on activities and participation.

title: Simplifying care: When is the burden of care too great for patients living in poverty?
Simulation instruction as an individual intervention does not improve hand hygiene practices: A randomized controlled follow-up study
