abstract: BACKGROUND: To assess how nurses' critical knowledge and adherence to current nursing hand hygiene (HH) guidelines differ between randomly assigned intervention and control groups before and after simulation training, both in a simulation setting and in clinical practice during a 2nd -year follow-up differ period. It was hypothesized that the intervention group's knowledge and adherence to current HH guidelines might increase after simulation training compared to a control group. METHODS: A prospective, parallel, randomized, controlled, repeated measures study was conducted in a 22-bed adult mixed medical-surgical intensive care unit in Oulu, Finland. Thirty of 40 originally randomized critical care nurses participated in the baseline measurements";" 17 of them completed all study procedures. Participants' HH adherence was observed only in high-risk contact situations before and after endotracheal suction events using a direct nonparticipant observation method. Participants' HH knowledge was assessed at the end of each observation session. RESULTS: Overall HH adherence increased from a baseline of 40.8% to 50.8% at the final postintervention measurement at 24 months (p=0.002). However, the linear mixed model did not identify any significant group (P=0.77) or time group interactions (P=0.17) between the study groups after 2 years of simulation training. Furthermore, the simulation training had no impact on the HH knowledge of the participants. CONCLUSIONS: After a single simulation training session, critical care workers' knowledge of and adherence to current HH guidelines remained below targeted behavioral rates.

title: Sleep disorders in adults with cancer: a systematic review of evidence for best practice in assessment and treatment for clinical practice
abstract: Sleep disorders are common in cancer and have adverse health effects. Sleep problems are rarely recognized or treated in cancer practice. The purpose of this review was to identify the evidence base for the assessment and management of cancer-related sleep disorders (insomnia and insomnia syndrome) for oncology practice. The health literature search included gray literature data sources and empirical databases from June 2004 to June 2012. The evidence was reviewed by a Canadian sleep expert panel composed of nurses, psychologists, primary care physicians, oncologists, sleep disorder physicians, researchers and guideline methodologists to develop clinical Practice recommendations for Pan-Canadian application reported in a separate article. Three clinical practice guidelines and 12 randomized controlled trials were identified as the main sources of evidence. Additional guidelines and systematic reviews were also reviewed for evidence-based recommendations for evaluating and treating insomnia, not necessarily cancer. A need for routine screening for sleep disorders has been established, and evidence from randomized controlled trials (RCT) suggests benefits of cognitive behavioral therapy for improving sleep quality in cancer. Sleep disturbances are a common problem in cancer that needs more attention in clinical practice and future research.

title: Smoking in emergency chest pain patients: motivation to quit, risk perception, and medical intervention
abstract: The feasibility of the emergency department (ED) as a setting for smoking interventions was evaluated in 159 adult patients with chest pain (38% were smokers). The subjects had been admitted to a 24-hour observation unit (OU) to rule out myocardial infarction. We examined the frequency and magnitude of smoking interventions by physicians using the AHCPR guidelines as a model. We also assessed patients' perceptions of risk from smoking and motivation to quit smoking. The results show that ED physicians performed an incomplete and inconsistent intervention. While most patients were asked if they smoked, only half were advised to quit and few were offered help to quit. The perceived risk from smoking was low for almost half of all smokers. However, more than three quarters were willing to seek smoking cessation counseling in the emergency room. The emergency department may be an appropriate setting to initiate smoking cessation counseling for certain high-risk populations.

title: Smoking cessation activities by general practitioners and practice nurses
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To assess GPs' and nurses' self-reported behaviour, attitudes and knowledge of smoking cessation. DESIGN AND SETTING: Two postal surveys with randomized national samples of 303 GPs (Survey 1) and 459 nurses (Survey 2) from England and Wales; the effective response rates were 75% and 96%, respectively. RESULTS: Survey 1 found that 96% of primary care physicians accepted that smoking intervention was part of their role and almost all (99%) reported that they recorded smoking status when registering patients; 57% reported that they routinely updated their smoking status records, 50% reported advising smokers to quit during most or all consultations, and 76% reported advising smokers to cut down if they were unable to quit . felt that NRTs were effective, with only a minority believing that they were worth the cost (47%) or should be available on a National Health Service (NHS) prescription (32%). , m ore positive attitudes or greater knowledge. Survey 2 found that almost all in-office nurses (99%) agreed that intervening to stop smoking was part of their role and 95% said they advised patients to quit at least occasionally; A majority (74%) said they recommended NRT to their patients. As with GPs, most in-office nurses thought nicotine replacement therapy was effective (79%) but fewer (42%) thought the cost was justified and only around half (53%) thought it could be available on NHS prescription should. Carers who reported being trained in smoking cessation were more engaged in smoking cessation, had more positive attitudes and were more knowledgeable that smoking was an important part of their role, and a large majority reported that they were at least some smokers have intervened, providing a promising base from which to proceed in terms of implementation of the new smoke. However, there is hope that improvements will be made in terms of frequency of updating records and interventions, and acceptance of the cost-effectiveness of NRT can be achieved as a life-sustaining intervention.

title: Beliefs and behaviors of outpatient oncologists about smoking cessation counseling
abstract: PURPOSE: Many cancer patients continue to smoke after diagnosis, increasing their risk of treatment complications, reduced treatment efficacy, secondary cancers, and reduced survival. Outpatient oncology providers may not use the “teachable moment” of cancer diagnosis to provide smoking cessation support. PROVIDERS AND METHODS: Physicians and middle-care providers (n=74) offering outpatient oncology services completed an online survey on behaviors, beliefs, and perceived barriers to smoking cessation counseling. Ambulatory medical records of 120 patients with breast, lung, head and neck, colon, prostate, and acute leukemia cancer were reviewed to assess current practices for assessing smoking cessation and documenting interventions. RESULTS: Providers reported that they frequently assessed smoking in new patients (82.4% frequently or always), but rates decreased at subsequent visits for both current smokers and recent smokers. Rates of patients quitting smoking were also high (86.5% often or always), but <30% of providers reported often or always offering interventions (e.g., nicotine replacement therapy or other medications, self-help materials) to smoking patients and/or recommendations). Only 30% of providers reported that they frequently or always followed up patients to assess progress towards quitting. Few providers (18.1%) reported a high level of confidence in their ability to counsel smoking patients. The lack of patient motivation was identified as the most important obstacle to smoking cessation. CONCLUSIONS: Although views on the provision of smoking cessation services to smoking patients were generally positive, few providers reported that they often offer interventions beyond cessation counseling. Additional education and clinically based interventions can improve adherence to tobacco cessation guidelines in outpatient oncology.

title: Smoking cessation counseling for pregnant and postpartum women: a survey of community health center providers
abstract: OBJECTIVES: This study evaluated the performance of smoking cessation counseling providers for low-income pregnant and postpartum women attending community health centers. METHODS: WIC (Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children) program staff, obstetricians, and pediatric clinicians at 6 community health centers were asked to complete surveys. Smoking intervention practices (performance), knowledge and attitudes, and organizational facilitators were measured. Factors associated with performance were examined using analysis of variance and regression analysis. RESULTS: Performance scores differed significantly by clinic and provider type. Providers in obstetric clinics had the highest scores and those in pediatric clinics had the lowest scores. Nurses and nutritionists scored higher than other providers. Hospital type, greater knowledge about smoking, older age, and perception of smoking cessation as a priority were independently associated with better counseling performance. CONCLUSIONS: Mean performance scores showed room for improvement in all groups. Low scores for taking steps beyond assessment and advice indicate that the focus needs to be on the support and follow-up steps of national guidance. Providers' own commitment to helping mothers quit smoking was important.

title: Smoking cessation from the office to the bedside. An evidence-based, practical approach
abstract: Cigarette smoking remains a national health crisis and is responsible for unacceptable levels of suffering, disease and death. The barriers to effective intervention such as training, time and reimbursement are formidable, although the situation is improving as the right behavioral approaches and medications are clearly defined. Applying these practical points is an acquired skill that takes time. Incorporating these suggestions into daily practice ensures that your smoking patients have the best opportunity to quit and receive the highest level of care.

title: Smoking cessation in family medicine: implications of a training program at a regional health education center
abstract: BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES: Many clinicians have not received adequate smoking cessation training. We examined the effects of a tobacco education program on physician behavior, attitudes, knowledge, and comfort related to smoking cessation. METHODS: In a prospective cohort study, primary care physicians and general practice schools completed a pre-test followed by an educational intervention that included presentations on smoking cessation resources, motivational interviewing, and the neurobiology of addiction and pharmacotherapy. After 3 months, participants completed a postintervention survey. The results were analyzed using chi-square tests to examine the effects of training. RESULTS: Thirty-three residents and teachers completed the pre-training survey and 25 completed the post-training survey. After the training, participants were more familiar and familiar with the guidelines for public health clinical practice (P<0.0001). No significant differences were found in the performance of the 5 As (Ask, Counsel, Evaluate, Support, and Agree) or other behaviors including providing support with counseling, cessation plans, resources, or pharmacotherapy. There were no improvements in knowledge of specific intervention plans or attitudes related to smoker identification and counseling. CONCLUSION: A multidisciplinary tobacco education program increases clinician familiarity and comfort with practice guidelines and may help improve nursing activities that promote a healthy lifestyle. Future research should examine other interventions that have the potential to change practice patterns on a larger scale. Future studies should also evaluate the effect of exercise programs on patient-centred outcomes.

title: Smoking cessation - a central role for physicians
abstract: Doctors are in the unique position of advising smokers to quit because they can consider the various aspects of nicotine addiction. This review provides an overview of interventions for smokers presenting in a primary care setting. The strategies used for smoking cessation counseling differed depending on the patient's willingness to quit. For smokers who do not intend to quit smoking, physicians should educate and educate patients about tobacco use and cessation, particularly by personalizing the benefits of smoking cessation and challenging smokers' beliefs. For dissonant smokers, clinicians should use motivational strategies such as B. Discussing barriers to quitting and their solutions. For smokers who are willing to quit, the doctor should show strong support, help set a date for quitting, prescribe pharmaceutical therapies for nicotine dependence, such as replacement therapy and/or bupropion, with directions for use, and suggest behavioral strategies to prevent relapse.

title: Smoking: can we really make a difference?
abstract: The tremendous health benefits of quitting smoking are now well established. Physicians play a crucial role in motivating smokers and initiating attempts to quit. The mainstay of the National Health Service's smoking cessation strategy should be the routine delivery of brief, opportunistic interventions in primary care, supported by referral to a specialized smoking cessation service. There is an urgent need to significantly increase the number of smokers referred to specialized smoking cessation services by GPs, other members of the primary care team and acute hospital staff, and to improve communication channels between the different agencies. The use of pharmacotherapy (nicotine replacement therapy or bupropion) in combination with behavioral support yields higher cessation rates than either component alone and is the most effective way to help smokers quit. Smokers who quit smoking often relapse and therefore need repeated help.

title: Social status and mortality
Societal preferences for returning incidental findings from clinical genome sequencing: a discrete choice experiment
abstract: BACKGROUND: A major challenge in applying next-generation sequencing technology is the ability to uncover incidental genomic findings. A lack of evidence for the personal benefit of incidental findings has hampered clinical guidelines. Our aim was to estimate the personal utility of complex information derived from random genomic findings. METHODS: We used a discrete choice experiment to assess participants' personal utility for the following attributes: disease penetration, disease treatability, disease severity, carrier status, and cost. Study participants were drawn from the Canadian public. We analyzed the data using a mixed logit model. RESULTS: A total of 1200 participants completed our questionnaire (available in English and French). Participants appreciated receiving information about high-penetrance disorders, but did not express a benefit from receiving information about low-penetrance disorders. The mean willingness to pay was $445 (95% confidence interval [CI] $322-$567) for incidental findings in a scenario where physicians returned information about medically treatable conditions with high penetrance, but only 66% of participants (95% CI 63%-71%) indicated that they would choose to receive information in this scenario. On average, participants placed a high priority ($725, 95% CI $600 to $850) on having a choice about what type of findings they would receive, including receiving information about high penetrance, treatable disorders, or receiving Information on high penetrance disorders with or without available treatment. The predicted acceptance of this scenario was 76% (95% CI 72%-79%). INTERPRETATION: Most participants appreciated receiving random results, but personal benefit depended on the type of finding, and not all participants wanted to receive random results, regardless of the potential health implications. These results indicate that to maximize utility, participant-level preferences should influence the decision on whether to return incidental findings.

title: Position paper of the Society for Youth Medicine on reproductive health care for young people
abstract: PIP: This article is a revision of a 1983 Society for Adolescent Medicine position paper to incorporate the latest medical advances in the study of "adolescent sexuality", i.e., contraceptive compliance, promotion of behavior change, racial and pregnancy relationships, and male reproductive health Health The issues for the 1990s will be morbidity and mortality from sexually transmitted diseases. The issues identified are sexual activity and pregnancy in adolescents, caring for pregnant teenagers, sexually transmitted diseases, HIV infection, the male adolescent, adolescent sexual abuse, gay men and lesbian youth, interventions, reproductive health care for adolescents with disabilities and chronic illnesses, and education of family physicians The HIV/AIDS epidemic has focused attention on reproduction behavior directed by men. Sexual activity varies by race/ethnic group Delay in sexual initiation needs investigation, although condom use has increased among 17-19 year olds from 21% to 58% in metropolitan areas. However, condom use is lowest in the group of men most at risk of STDs: those who have ever used drugs, those who have ever had sex with a prostitute, and those who have 5 or more partners/year had. Male beliefs about contraception have rarely been studied. There are misconceptions about heterosexual transmission of HIV. Better screening is needed for STD detection. Fathers are more involved in prenatal care and postnatal intervention programs. 7% of children between the ages of 18 and 21 have had involuntary sexual intercourse. ;”, ie 12.7% of white women, 9% of black women, 1.9% of white men and 6.1% of black men. alcohol, smoking and drug use of parents. Sexual assault was linked to hitchhiking and alcohol and drug use in one cited study. Doctors need to be sensitive to this issue and seek information. The sexual needs of people who are unsure of their orientation or who are homosexual or lesbian are beginning to be recognized. Among 12th graders, 1% of men and 1% of women consider themselves predominantly or wholly gay or lesbian, and 10% are unsure. Psychological and medical problems arise. Required interventions include reproductive and STD information, multiple approaches in a variety of settings, youth clinics, and outreach.

title: Socioeconomic Factors, Health Behavior, and Mortality: Results from a Nationally Representative Prospective Study of US Adults
abstract: Context.Â¡Âª A prominent hypothesis regarding social inequalities in mortality is that the increased risk among the socioeconomically disadvantaged is largely due to the higher prevalence of unhealthy behaviors among those with lower education and income levels. Aim.Â¡Âª To investigate the extent to which 4 behavioral risk factors (cigarette smoking, alcohol consumption, physical inactivity, and relative body weight) explain the observed association between socioeconomic characteristics and all-cause mortality. Design.Â¡Âª Longitudinal study to examine the impact of education, income, and health behavior on the risk of death over the next 7.5 years. Participant. A nationally representative sample of 3617 adult women and men who participated in the Americans' Changing Lives survey. Main Outcome Measure.Â¡Âª All-cause mortality verified by the National Death Index and death certificate reviews. Results.Â¡Âª Educational differences in mortality were fully explained by the strong association between education and income. Adjusting for age, sex, race, urbanity, and education, the mortality hazard ratio was 3.22 (95% confidence interval [CI], 2.01–5.16) for the lowest income group and 2.34 (95 % CI, 1.49 -3.67) for middle-income people. When hazardous behaviors were accounted for, the risk of death for the lowest-income group (hazard ratio, 2.77 inches; 95% CI, 1.74-4.42) and the middle-income group (hazard ratio, 2.14 ;" 95% CI, 1.38-3.25). Conclusion.Â¡Âª Although reducing the prevalence of unhealthy behaviors in low-income populations is an important public health goal, socioeconomic differences in mortality are at a broader range of factors and would therefore remain disadvantaged even with improved health behavior among people.

title: Sources of variation and bias in diagnostic accuracy studies
abstract: Background: Studies evaluating diagnostic accuracy are subject to different sources of bias and variation than studies evaluating the effectiveness of an intervention. Little is known about the effects of these sources of distortion and variation. Purpose: To summarize the evidence on factors that may bias or discrepant the results of diagnostic accuracy studies. Data sources: MEDLINE, EMBASE and BIOSIS, as well as the methodological databases of the Center for Reviews and Dissemination and the Cochrane Collaboration. Method experts for diagnostic tests were contacted. Study selection: Studies examining the effects of bias and variation on measures of test performance were eligible for inclusion, which were reviewed by one reviewer and reviewed by a second reviewer. Discrepancies were clarified in the discussion. Data Extraction: Data extraction was performed by one reviewer and verified by a second reviewer. Data Synthesis: The best documented effects of bias and variation were found for demographic characteristics, disease prevalence and severity, partial verification bias, clinical review bias, and observer and instrument variation. For other sources such as B. biased selection of participants, missing or inappropriate reference standard, different verification bias and review bias, the amount of evidence was limited. Evidence was lacking for other features, including incorporation bias, treatment paradox, arbitrary choice of threshold, and dropouts. Conclusions: Many issues in the design and conduct of diagnostic accuracy studies can introduce bias or discrepancies";" However, empirical evidence on the magnitude and impact of these problems is limited.

title: Identifying malignant melanoma
Stability of attitudes to the ethical issues raised by the return of random genomic research results in children: A follow-up study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: We examine the stability of parental attitudes towards the ethical issues raised by the return of genomic research results. METHODS: A 19-item questionnaire was mailed to participants in a large genomic research consortium 18 months after a baseline survey. We describe the stability of parental attitudes towards (a) sharing genome research results, (b) supporting children in genome research, (c) responsibility of researchers, and (d) responsibility to extended family. We also examine their experience of getting results. RESULTS: Of 170 original participants, 154 (91%) responded. Most participants declared their positive right to receive random genomic research results (85%), even when ameliorating therapy was unknown (85%). Only 3% found it acceptable to delegate the decision to return results to an independent committee. Researchers, accompanied by either a parent (42%) or a doctor (17%), felt a responsibility to communicate research results to children as they grew up. Most participants (74%) indicated that the results should be shared with potentially affected extended families. These results are very similar to those of the baseline survey. All participants who received genomic results would do so again and report actions similar to their expressed attitudes. CONCLUSIONS: Parental opinions on genome research remain stable over time. Results return policies should incorporate these insights.

title: Staged diabetes management: computerization of a disease state management program
abstract: Recently, the Diabetes Control and Complication Trial (DCCT) and other similar studies have shown that bringing blood sugar close to normal in diabetes reduces complications by up to 75%, but translating these findings into practice has been difficult. In an attempt to provide the best possible control of patients with diabetes, we have undertaken an attempt to contribute to the best possible control of patients with diabetes, we have developed a new disease state management system for diabetes called Staded Diabetes Management . (SDM), implemented it in over 100 locations worldwide and developed a computer program to simplify its use. SDM, designed to transform the way we treat patients with diabetes, is based on five principles: (1) community participation in setting treatment guidelines; (2) negotiating goals with patients; (3) reasonable timeframes for therapeutic success; (4) use of flow charts for medical decisions;' and (5) evaluation of the program. SDM is designed to be modified by a community to meet their needs and resources. It encourages GPs to provide better diabetes care with a team approach and to refer patients with diabetes to specialists where appropriate. It has a complete set of materials for communities, individual healthcare providers and patients. SDM has been tested for changes in structure, process and results. A meta-analysis of seven clinical trials involving over 500 patients has shown a time-weighted average drop in hemoglobin A1c of 1.7 points (equivalent to a drop in mean blood glucose of approximately 3.5 mM or 60 mg/dL). Preliminary pharmacoeconomic analysis shows lifetime cost savings of over $27,000 per patient. A computer program was developed for the Microsoft Windows environment that includes a DiabCare-based client-server database for the data file structure.

title: The standard operating procedure changed the behavior of anesthesiologists in prehospital intensive care: a quality control study
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The ability of standard operating procedures to improve prehospital critical care by changing physician prehospital behavior is uncertain. We report data from a prospective quality control study on the behavioral implications of anesthesiologists in prehospital critical care when implementing a standard operating procedure for prehospital controlled ventilation. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Anesthesiologists from eight prehospital intensive care teams in the central Denmark region prospectively registered prehospital data on advanced airway management according to the Utstein template. We collected pre-procedure data from February 1, 2011 to January 31, 2012, implemented the standard surgical procedure on February 1, 2012, and collected post-procedure data from February 1, 2012 to October 31, 2012. We included transported patients of all ages requiring controlled ventilation and treated with out-of-hospital endotracheal intubation or placement of a supraglottic airway device. The aim was to evaluate whether the development and implementation of a standard operating procedure for controlled ventilation during transport could change the behavior of anesthesiologists in prehospital intensive care and thereby increase the use of automated ventilators in these patients. RESULTS: Implementation of a standard surgical procedure increased the overall prevalence of automated ventilator use in transported patients requiring controlled ventilation from 0.40 (0.34-0.47) to 0.74 (0.69-0. 80) with a prevalence ratio of 1.85 (1.57–2.19). (p=0.00). The prevalence of automated ventilator use in transported traumatic brain injury patients requiring controlled ventilation increased from 0.44 (0.26-0.62) to 0.85 (0.62-0.97) with a prevalence ratio of 1.94 (1.26–3.0) (p=0.0039). The prevalence of automated ventilator use in patients transported after recovery of spontaneous circulation from prehospital cardiac arrest increased from 0.39 (0.26-0.48) to 0.69 (0.58-0.78) with a prevalence ratio of 1.79 (1.36–2.35) (p=0.00). ). CONCLUSION: We have shown that implementing a standard workflow for prehospital controlled ventilation can significantly change the behavior of anesthesiologists in prehospital critical care.

title: Statement on Standards for Reporting Implementation Studies (StaRI).
abstract: Implementation studies are often poorly reported and indexed, reducing their potential to inform initiatives to improve health services. The Standards for Reporting Implementation Studies (StaRI) initiative aimed to develop guidelines for transparent and accurate reporting of implementation studies. Based on the results of a systematic review and a consensus-building e-Delphi exercise, an international working group of implementation science experts discussed and agreed on the 27-point StaRI checklist. It asks researchers to describe both the implementation strategy (techniques to encourage implementation of an underused evidence-based intervention) and the effectiveness of the intervention delivered. An accompanying explanation and elaboration document (published in BMJ Open, doi:10.1136/bmjopen-2016-013318) describes each of the points, explains the rationale and provides examples of best reporting practices. The adoption of StaRI will improve reporting of implementation studies, potentially facilitate the translation of research into practice, and improve the health of individuals and populations.

title: State of the art: beta-blockers and reduction of perioperative cardiac events
abstract: This article reviews the current literature on the use of perioperative beta-blockade to reduce cardiac events in the hope that it may provide clinicians with direction or identify gaps in medical knowledge and thus uncover areas that are amenable to future study. The current standard of practice for the use of perioperative beta-blockade in preoperative patients is outlined in the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines. Results regarding risk and benefit of perioperative use of beta-blockers to reduce cardiac events are mixed. More research is needed to support the ACC/AHA recommendations. It is important that the decision to use beta-blockade is made on a case-by-case basis with appropriate risk stratification as part of the criteria.

title: Adhering to minimum standards: Implementing antibiotic stewardship in intensive care medicine
abstract: BACKGROUND: In Australia, antimicrobial stewardship programs are a mandatory part of hospital accreditation. Good documentation surrounding antimicrobial prescribing supports communication and can improve prescribing practices in multi-stakeholder environments. OBJECTIVE: This study aims to develop and implement an intervention to improve antibiotic prescribing practice in a 24-bed intensive care unit in a tertiary adult referral hospital. Methods: We conducted a four-phase (observation, reflection, implementation, evaluation) prospective collaborative before-and-after study on quality improvement. Baseline audits and antimicrobial prescribing surveys identified barriers and enablers to good prescribing practice. A tailored intervention was then implemented over a 6-week period that included a yellow medication card sticker, quarterly educational sessions, and ICU-specific empirical guidelines for antimicrobial prescribing. After implementation, the impact was monitored for 1 year through serial antimicrobial prescribing audits. The primary outcomes were clear documentation of start date, planned stop date or review date, and indication for an antibiotic. These were all considered “minimum standards” for prescribing antimicrobials in the medication record. RESULTS: Improved documentation of the minimum standards specifically addressed by the label (start date (72% to 90%, P<0.001), stop date (16% to 63%, P<0.001), antimicrobial indication documented on medication card (58% to 83%, P<0.01)). Overall, compliance with all three minimum standards (start date, end date, and indication) improved from 41/306 (13%) to 306/492 (63%) (p<0.001). A year after implementation, the yellow badge was firmly established in everyday practice. CONCLUSION: A systematic approach to quality improvement combined with the implementation of a tailored, multifaceted intervention can improve antimicrobial prescribing practice.

title: Stimulant Drugs
abstract: Stimulants are a key element in the treatment of ADHD. Carefully designed studies of stimulants have found substantial improvements in core ADHD behaviors in 65-75% of individuals with ADHD. Most standard stimulants are quickly absorbed, with their behavioral effects appearing within 30 minutes, peaking within one to three hours, and disappearing within five hours. Cans in school are often necessary, despite the risk of ridicule from their peers and additional demands for adult supervision. The mechanism by which stimulants work to reduce hyperactivity is not fully understood, but they improve impulsivity and activity levels. Several controlled evaluations conducted over periods of more than one year show a clear persistence of drug effects over time. A carefully designed treatment program with methylphenidate is more effective in reducing hyperactivity symptoms than an intensive program of behavioral and cognitive interventions. The combination of stimulants with psychosocial interventions in ADHD offers few advantages over medication alone. It is difficult to propose unchallengeable guidelines for practice that would be appropriate anywhere. It is imperative that doctors prescribing stimulants properly monitor the use of the drug and make sure it is not being abused by the child's family, peers, or those dispensing drugs at school. Polypharmacy should only be started by a specialized service, and the combination of methylphenidate and clonidine should be used with caution. Aside from ADHD, stimulants are useful for narcolepsy, resistant depression, and partial syndromes of attention and hyperactivity. Large gaps in knowledge remain";" Pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and pharmacogenetics of stimulant effects need further study. Details of stimulant administration regimens appear to have a major impact on the response achieved. Further research needs, if possible in realistic settings, comparison of different forms of combination with psychological interventions, investigation of the effects in groups of children outside the core of school children with typical ADHD: preschool children, adults, those with partial syndromes (e.g. inattention) and those with comorbid diseases.

title: Strangle the future
Strategies for rehabilitation professionals to put evidence-based knowledge into practice: a systematic review
abstract: Rationale: Rehabilitation clinicians need to stay current on best practices, especially as adhering to clinical guidelines can significantly improve patient outcomes. However, little is known about the benefits of knowledge translation interventions for these professionals. OBJECTIVES: To investigate the effectiveness of single- and multi-component knowledge translation interventions in improving knowledge, attitudes, and practice behaviors of rehabilitation clinicians. METHODS: Systematic review of 7 databases conducted to identify studies evaluating knowledge translation interventions specific to occupational therapists and physical therapists. RESULTS: 12 studies met the selection criteria. For physical therapists, participation in an active multi-component knowledge translation intervention resulted in improved evidence-based knowledge and practice behaviors compared to passive dissemination strategies. These gains did not result in a change in clinician attitudes toward best practices. For occupational therapists, no studies have evaluated the use of multicomponent interventions";" Studies on individual interventions indicate limited evidence of efficacy for all outcomes measured. CONCLUSION: While this review suggests the use of active, multicomponent knowledge translation interventions to improve physical therapist knowledge and practice, further research is needed to understand the impact of these strategies on occupational therapists. Serious research gaps remain regarding which knowledge translation strategies positively impact patient outcomes.

title: strengthen general medicine
Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (STROBE): Explanation and Elaboration
abstract: Much of medical research is observational. Reporting on observational studies is often of poor quality. Poor reporting hinders the assessment of a study's strengths and weaknesses and the generalizability of its results. Taking empirical evidence and theoretical considerations into account, a group of methodologists, researchers and editors developed the Recommendations for Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (STROBE) to improve the quality of reporting of observational studies. The STROBE statement consists of a checklist of 22 items related to title, abstract, introduction, methods, results and discussion sections of articles. Eighteen items are common to cohort studies, case-control studies, and cross-sectional studies, and four are specific to each of the three study designs. The STROBE Statement provides authors with guidance on improving the reporting of observational studies and facilitates the critical appraisal and interpretation of studies by reviewers, journal editors, and readers. This explanatory and elaborating document aims to improve the use, understanding and dissemination of the STROBE statement. The meaning and rationale for each checklist item are presented. One or more published examples and, if possible, references to relevant empirical studies and methodological literature are given for each item. Examples of useful flowcharts are also included. The STROBE Statement, this document, and the associated website (http://www.strobe-statement.org/) should be helpful resources to improve the reporting of observational research.

title: Stress as a cardiovascular risk factor
abstract: Stress is an organism's reaction to a stressor with various negative health consequences, including the development of arteriosclerosis. Stress can cause myocardial ischemia, arrhythmias, platelet stimulation, increased blood viscosity from hemoconcentration, and endothelial dysfunction and coronary vasoconstriction in the presence of coronary artery atherosclerosis. Psychosocial risk factors can also lead to the development and clinical consequences of arteriosclerosis. The five most important psychosocial risk factors are: depression, anxiety, personality factors, social isolation and chronic life stress. Various components are responsible for the fact that life events or certain psychosocial factors can lead to a stress reaction. Psychosocial risk factors have direct pathophysiological implications but also influence lifestyle and behavior. Various stress management intervention programs have been shown to be effective. Psychosocial interventions in conjunction with cardiac rehabilitation programs have been shown to reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.

title: Stress echocardiography in heart failure
abstract: Echocardiography has the ability to noninvasively examine hemodynamic variables during pharmacologic or exercise stress testing in patients with heart failure. In this review, we describe some important potential applications of stress echocardiography in heart failure patients. In patients with coronary artery disease and chronic LV dysfunction, dobutamine stress echocardiography can discriminate between viable and fibrotic tissue to make appropriate clinical decisions. Exercise testing combined with echocardiographic monitoring is a method to obtain accurate information to assess functional capacity and prognosis. Functional mitral regurgitation is a common finding in patients with dilated and ischemic cardiomyopathy, and stress echocardiography in the form of exercise or pharmacologic protocols may be useful to assess mitral regurgitation behavior. It is clinically useful to seek the presence of contractile reserve in non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, for example to screen or monitor the presence of latent myocardial dysfunction in patients exposed to cardiotoxic agents. Furthermore, in patients with suspected diastolic heart failure and normal systolic function, stress echocardiography may be able to detect the presence of such dysfunction and determine that it is sufficient to limit exercise tolerance. Finally, in aortic stenosis, dobutamine echocardiography can distinguish severe from non-severe stenoses in patients with low transvalvular gradients and impaired left ventricular function.

title: Structured follow-up by general practitioners after intentional self-poisoning: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: General practitioners (GPs) play an important role in the follow-up of patients after intentional self-poisoning (DSP). The aim was to investigate whether structured follow-up care by general practitioners increases content, adherence to therapy, and satisfaction with treatment after discharge from the emergency department. METHODS: This was a multicenter, randomized, blinded assignment study. Five emergency rooms and general practitioners' practices in the catchment area were involved. 202 patients discharged from emergency departments after DSP were assigned. The intervention was a structured follow-up by the GP over a period of 6 months with a minimum of five consultations, accompanied by written guidelines for the GP with suggestions on patient motivation for treatment, assessment of personal problems and suicidal ideation, and availability in the event of a suicide crisis . Outcome measures were data retrieved from the Healthcare Providers Reimbursement Control and Payment Registry (KUHR) and through questionnaires sent to patients and general practitioners. After 3 and 6 months, the frequency and content of family doctor contacts as well as compliance with family doctor consultations and treatments in general were recorded. Satisfaction with the general treatment and with the general practitioner was measured using the EUROPEP scale. RESULTS: Patients in the intervention group received significantly more consultations than the control group (mean 6.7 vs. 4.5 (p = 0.004)). The intervention group was significantly more satisfied with the time their GP took to listen to their personal problems (93.1% vs. 59.4% (p=0.002)) and with the fact that the GP involved them in medical decisions included (87.5% vs. 54.8% (p=0.009)). Overall, the intervention group was significantly more satisfied with the treatment than the control group (79% vs. 51% (p = 0.026)). Conclusions: Guidelines and structured, improved follow-up by the general practitioner after discharge of the DSP patient increased the number of consultations and satisfaction with follow-up in the general practitioner's office. Consistent with previous research, there is still a need for intervention studies. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01342809. Registered April 18, 2011.

title: Structured smoking cessation training for healthcare professionals on cardiology wards: a prospective study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Smoking is an important cardiovascular risk factor and smoking cessation is essential for patients hospitalized with a cardiovascular event. This study aimed to evaluate a systems-based approach to help in-hospital smokers quit and to identify implementation barriers. DESIGN: Prospective intervention study followed by qualitative analysis of employee interviews. METHODS: The prospective intervention study evaluated the impact of implementing standard operating procedures (SOPs) for the provision of counseling and pharmacotherapy to smokers admitted to cardiac units on counseling frequency. In addition, a qualitative analysis of staff interviews was conducted to examine the determinants of physician and nurse behavior";" This attempted to understand barriers related to motivation, ability, and/or opportunity. RESULTS: A total of 150 smoking patients were included in the study (75 before and 75 after SOP implementation). Before the introduction of SOPs, the proportion of patients who reported receiving cessation counseling from physicians and nurses was 6.7% and 1.3%, respectively. After SOP implementation, these proportions increased to 38.7% (p<0.001) and 2.7% (p=0.56), respectively. The qualitative analysis revealed that lack of motivation, eg role incongruity, seemed to be a major obstacle. CONCLUSIONS: The implementation of a standard set of smoking cessation procedures was effective for physicians but not for nurses. Analysis of barriers to implementation highlighted lack of motivation, rather than skills or opportunity, as a key factor that needed to be addressed.

title: Study confirms value of STD treatment in curbing HIV transmission
abstract: PIP: An intervention was conducted in the Mwanza region of Tanzania to determine whether improved treatment of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) other than HIV/AIDS in rural health centers and pharmacies could reduce the incidence of new HIV infection. Medical assistants and nurses at six rural health centers have been trained in syndromic treatment for STDs, and health center staff have been encouraged to counsel their patients, offer them condoms and ask for referrals from sexual partners for treatment. The centers received the least expensive effective drugs to treat the major STD syndromes. Health professionals trained as supervisors visited each center every 8 weeks to review medication inventories and patient records, provide refresher training, and ensure adherence to syndrome management guidelines. In addition, a cohort of 1000 adults in the communities served by the six health centers were interviewed and tested for HIV at baseline and 2 years after the intervention was implemented. The number of new cases of HIV infection occurring in the cohort was then compared to that occurring in another cohort selected from communities served by health centers that had not provided improved STD treatment . 11,632 cases of STD were treated at the centers during the 2-year study period. The intervention was found to reduce the number of new HIV infections that occurred during the study period by 42%. This decrease affected both sexes and all age groups, but was particularly evident in women aged 15 to 24 years. Survey results show that the reduction in HIV incidence was the result of improved STD treatment rather than changes in sexual behavior. Preliminary calculations put the cost at around US$300 per HIV infection averted.

title: Study of a new curriculum for electronic communication in specialist practices for general medicine
abstract: Electronic communication between doctors and patients is widespread, but it can pose risks for users – both patients and doctors. Little is known about electronic communication between doctor and patient and even less about electronic communication during residency training. We examined knowledge and practices before and after a controlled test of a novel curriculum teaching email communication with patients using residents and faculty in 16 family medicine residences in the United States. Both faculty and residents demonstrated a lack of knowledge about confidentiality and encryption, little familiarity with published guidelines for doctor-patient email, and failure to comply with documentation requirements prior to curriculum presentation. Post-tests showed a greater improvement in knowledge and appropriate behavior regarding patient-physician emails in the intervention group compared to control centers (mean increase in intervention is 13 points [t = -4.065, P < 0.01], mean Increase in control is 5 points [t=-2.015, P<.05]). Increased uncertainty about the convenience of patient emails among intervention residents is an interesting finding that may reflect increased problem awareness but limited time to take up the issue. Suggestions for the implementation of the curriculum are made.

title: Study protocol for a randomized controlled trial: feasibility and impact of cardiovascular absolute risk assessment in Australian general practice
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although cardiovascular absolute risk assessment (CVAR) has been recommended for use in Australian general practice for a number of years, there remains uncertainty about its implementation and implications. Our work to date has developed a multi-faceted implementation model. This study aims to explore both the feasibility of using this model and the impact of CVAR assessment and management on clinical processes and patient care in general practice. STUDY DESIGN: This cluster-randomized controlled trial will be conducted in general practices in Sydney and will include general practitioners (GPs), other practice staff and patients aged 45 to 69 years without existing cardiovascular disease. Methods: A total of 32 practices (40 general practitioners) and 1,320 patients are recruited. Randomization is performed at the practice level. The intervention group of GPs will be trained to use a CVAR implementation model, while the control group of GPs will continue with usual care. Study outcomes include clinical processes, patient risks, use of lifestyle interventions, and prescription of antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications. Data is collected and analyzed using mixed methods. The study results before and after the intervention are compared, and the two groups are also compared after adjusting for the baseline difference and clustering factors. DISCUSSION: This study will be the first study in Australian general practice and one of the few international studies to assess the impact of implementing CVAR assessment and management. The results of this study will help improve primary prevention of cardiovascular disease and inform guidelines for clinical practice and implementation of other health initiatives.

title: Investigating healthcare deimplementation: an analysis of funded research grants
abstract: Background The study of de-implementation, defined here as the reduction or cessation of use of a healthcare service or practice offered to patients by physicians and healthcare systems, has gained prominence in recent years. De-implementing ineffective, unproven, harmful, overused, inappropriate, and/or substandard healthcare services and practices is important to mitigate patient harm, improve care processes, and reduce healthcare costs. A better understanding of the state of the art is required to guide future goals and funding initiatives. To this end, we characterized United States (US) National Institutes of Health (NIH) and Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) funded research grants for de-implementation. Methods We used systematic methods to search, identify, and describe de-implementation research grants funded by all 27 NIH institutes and centers (ICs) and AHRQ from fiscal year 2000 to 2017. Eleven keywords and three announcements of funding opportunities were used to search for research grants in the NIH Query, View and Report (QVR) system. Two coders identified eligible grants based on inclusion/exclusion criteria. A code book was developed, pilot tested and revised prior to coding the full final sample grant applications. Results A total of 1277 grants were identified through the QVR system";" 542 remained after removing duplicates. After the multi-stage suitability assessment and the review process, 20 funding applications were coded. Many grants were funded by NIH (n?=?15), fewer by AHRQ, and the majority were funded between FY2015 and 2016 (n?=?11). The grant proposals focused on the de-implementation of a range of health services and practices (e.g. drugs, therapies, screening tests) in different health domains (e.g. cancer, cardiovascular diseases) and care settings (e.g. hospitals, nursing homes, schools). The grants suggested using a variety of study designs and research methods (eg, experimental, observational, mixed methods) to achieve study goals. Conclusions Based on the systematic portfolio analysis of NIH and AHRQ-funded research grants over the past 17 years, relatively few have focused on examining the de-implementation of ineffective, unproven, harmful, overused, inappropriate, and/or low-quality health services and practices, offered to patients by healthcare practitioners and systems. Strategies for profiling and expanding the research field de-implementation will be discussed.

title: Success after treatment of a periprosthetic joint infection: a Delphi-based international multidisciplinary consensus
abstract: BACKGROUND: The lack of agreement on what constitutes successful treatment of periprosthetic joint infections (PJI) makes it difficult to compare the different treatment strategies used in clinical practice and research studies. QUESTIONS/PURPOSE: The purpose of this study was to establish a consensus definition of post-PJI treatment success and to provide a universal, multidimensional framework for reporting of PJI treatment trials. METHODS: A basic two-round Delphi method was used to reach a consensus definition. We invited 159 international experts (orthopaedists, infectious disease specialists and clinical researchers) from 17 countries to participate.” 59 participated in the first round and 42 in the second round. The final definition consisted of all statements that achieved strong agreement (80% or more of participants considered a criterion relevant to the definition of success.) RESULTS: The consensus definition of successfully treated PJI is: (1) infection clearance, characterized by one cured wound without fistulas, drainage or pain and no infection Recurrence caused by same strain; (2) no subsequent surgical intervention for infection after reimplantation surgery;" and (3) no incidence of PJI-related mortality (from causes such as sepsis, necrotizing fasciitis). The Delphi Panel agreed to define intermediate-term outcomes as those reported 5 or more years after definitive PJI surgery, and long-term outcomes as those reported 10 or more years after surgery Although no consensus was reached on the definition of short-term outcomes, 71% of participants agreed that 2 years after definitive PJI surgery is acceptable to define it.CONCLUSIONS: This multidimensional definition of success after PJI treatment can be used to report and compare outcomes of treatment of this catastrophic complication.Level of Evidence: Level V, Therapeutic Study See Author's Guidelines for a full description level of evidence.

title: Successful implementation of a guideline through peer comparisons, education and positive medical feedback
abstract: The aim of this study was to determine whether peer comparisons, an educational intervention, and positive physician feedback would reduce the ordering of knee radiographs. We prospectively evaluated the scheduling of knee radiography for patients with knee injuries before and after an educational program to promote the use of the Ottawa decision rule for knee radiography. Physicians could privately compare their individual baseline X-ray usage data to that of their colleagues. Although acceptance of the rule was voluntary, both oral and written feedback encouraged consideration of the rule in clinical decision-making. The percentage of knee injury patients who received X-rays and the percentage of abnormal results (PAR, defined as the percentage of X-rays showing a fracture or effusion) were calculated before and after the training event. The results of the study showed that the percentage of patients with knee injuries who received X-rays decreased by 23%. In addition, the PAR increased by 58.4% between the two study periods. In summary, the physician's behavior can be positively changed through reinforcement. Peer comparisons, education, and positive feedback from physicians reduced physician ordering of tests, even without mandating the use of a protocol. PAR is a useful outcome measure for tracking physician utilization.

title: Successful implementation of a neonatal pain and sedation protocol on 2 NICUs
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the implementation of a neonatal pain and sedation protocol in 2 intensive care units. METHODS: The intervention began with an assessment of local practice, problems, and staff satisfaction. We then developed and implemented the Vienna Protocol for Neonatal Pain and Sedation. The protocol included well-defined strategies for both non-pharmacological and pharmacological interventions, based on periodic assessment of a translated version of the Neonatal Pain Agitation and Sedation Scale and titration of analgesic and sedative therapy according to target values. Healthcare workers were trained in assessment using video-based tutorial and bedside instruction. In addition, we carried out reassessments, retraining and random quality checks. Frequency and quality of assessments, pharmacologic therapy, duration of mechanical ventilation, and outcome were compared between baseline (12 months before implementation) and 12 months after implementation. RESULTS: Cumulative median (interquartile range) opiate dose (baseline dose of 1.4 [0.5-5.9] mg/kg versus intervention group dose of 2.7 [0.4-57] mg/kg morphine equivalents”; p=0.002), pharmacological interventions per episode of continuous sedation/analgesia (4 [2-10] vs. 6 [2-13]; p=0.005) and overall staff satisfaction (doctors: 31% vs. 89%; p<0.001; nurses: 17% vs 55%;" P < 0.001) increased after implementation. Duration of mechanical ventilation, length of stay in ICU, and side effects were similar before and after implementation. CONCLUSIONS: The implementation of a neonatal pain and sedation protocol in 2 ICUs resulted in increases in opiate prescription, pharmacologic interventions, and staff satisfaction without compromising time on mechanical ventilation, length of ICU stay, and adverse outcomes.

title: Successful reduction of catheter-related UTIs: Focus on nurse-led catheter removal.
abstract: Background Despite sterile catheter insertion, closed drainage systems and structured day care, catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI) occur regularly in acute care hospitals. We believe that a significant reduction in CAUTI rates can only be achieved by reducing urinary catheter use. METHODS: We used an interventional study of a hospital-wide, multidisciplinary program to reduce the use of urinary catheters and CAUTIs across all patient care units in a 300-bed community teaching hospital in Connecticut. Our primary focus was to implement a caregiver-led urinary catheter removal protocol. This protocol was linked to the physician's order for catheter insertion. Three additional elements included physician documentation of catheter insertion criteria, a device-specific charting module added to the physician's electronic progress notes, and bi-weekly unit-specific feedback on catheter utilization rates and CAUTI rates in a multidisciplinary forum. Results We achieved a 50% reduction in catheter usage and a 70% reduction in hospital-wide CAUTIs over a 36-month period, although there was wide ward-to-ward variation in catheter reduction efforts, ranging from 4% (maternity) up to 74% ranged (telemetry). Conclusion Urinary catheter use, and ultimately CAUTI rates, can be effectively reduced through the careful application of relatively less evidence-based interventions. Aggressive implementation of the nurse-led catheter removal protocol was associated with lower catheter usage rates and reduced infection rates.

title: Suicidality: what to do in an emergency
abstract: Emergency physicians (EP), paramedics, and emergency room personnel play an increasingly important role in the medical and psychological emergency care of patients after suicide attempts, as well as in the crisis intervention of persons with acute suicidal tendencies. This article aims to provide an overview of prevalence rates, methods of suicide or attempted suicide, and the problems faced by EPs in treating these patients. In addition, concepts are presented that enable an adequate risk assessment of suicidal tendencies and the possibilities of a primary crisis intervention. Paramedics and intensive care physicians are increasingly confronted with this complex process with social, personal and medical aspects. In order to treat people in suicidal crises and/or after a suicide attempt and to provide this often heterogeneous patient group with safe and optimal care, clear guidelines are a prerequisite. The initial assessment of the acute risk of suicide is of particular importance due to the resulting consequences and a clear procedure for dealing with people at risk of suicide is shown. In addition, the legal basis is presented.

title: Diagnostics of suicide and violence in psychiatry
abstract: Psychiatrists are increasingly expected to predict and prevent their clients' suicidal and violent/homicidal impulses. This article provides an overview of the current literature and research in these areas. While debate continues as to whether the clinician can successfully predict either violence or suicidal behavior in their patients, the vast majority of studies suggest that predicting suicide and violence in the individual may not be possible given current knowledge. To compensate for prognostic limitations, conservative clinicians deliberately overpredict suicide or violence to ensure the safety of their patients and the larger communities in which they live. In addition, clinicians must conduct thorough assessments and make logical clinical decisions consistent with perceived risks. Preventive measures for violence remain complex, but clinicians can maximize treatment effects by following specific intervention guidelines. At a minimum, documentation of violence must focus on the reasons why treatment interventions were or were not implemented. The diagram does not require lengthy notations, but should include an appropriate risk assessment and description of a prudent course of action.

title: Summary of practice parameters for the assessment and treatment of children and adolescents with suicidal behavior
abstract: These guidelines review what is known about the epidemiology, causes, management and prevention of suicide and suicide attempts in young people. Detailed guidelines are provided for the assessment and emergency management of children and adolescents with suicidal behavior. The guidelines also include suggestions on how the clinician can interact with the community. Crisis hotlines, method limitations, educational programs, and screening/case finding strategies for suicide prevention are explored, and media counseling is provided to the clinician. Community intervention after a suicide, minimizing contagion or suicide mimicry, and training primary care physicians and other gatekeepers to identify and refer children and adolescents who are potentially suicidal are discussed.

title: Supporting clinical practice at the bedside with wireless technology.
abstract: Objectives: Despite studies showing improvements in both standards of care and outcomes with prudent application of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs), their clinical application remains low. This randomized controlled trial evaluated physicians' use of a wirelessly networked mobile computer (MC) at the bedside with access to an emergency room information system, decision support tools (DSTs), and other software options. METHODS: Using a matched-pair design, each of ten emergency physician volunteers was randomized to work five shifts in standard mode (desktop computer [DC] access) and five shifts with a wirelessly networked MC. Work pattern issues and electronic CPG/DST usage were compared using end-of-shift satisfaction questionnaires and review of a CPG/DST database. Repeated measures analysis of variance was used to examine differences between the shifts. Results: A total of 100 8-hour shifts were evaluated; 99% compliance with post-shift questionnaires was achieved. Using a 7-point Likert scale (MC scores first), MCs were rated as equally fast (5.04 vs. 4.54; S=0.13) and practical (5.08 vs. 4.14; p=0.07) than DCs Overall, physicians rated MCs as less efficient (3.18 vs. 4.30; p=0.02) but encouraged more frequent use of DSTs (4.10 vs. 3.47 ; p=0.03) with no impact on doctor-patient communication (2.78 vs. 2.96; p=0.51) During the study period, use of an intranet web application (eCPG) by physicians during shifts assigned to the MC more frequently than DC during the study period (eCPG use/shift, 3.6 vs. 2.0;" p=0.033). Conclusions: MC technology enabled physicians to access information at the bedside and increased use of CPG/DST tools According to physicians, patients seemed to accept their use of information technology to support decision-making The development of improved computer technology can address the main limitation of MC portability.

title: Supporting insulin initiation in type 2 diabetes in primary care: results from the Stepping Up pragmatic cluster randomized controlled clinical trial
abstract: Aim: To compare the efficacy of a novel treatment model ("Stepping Up") to usual primary care in normalizing insulin initiation in type 2 diabetes, resulting in improved glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels. Establishment of primary care practices in Victoria, Australia, with a practicing nurse and at least one consenting eligible patient (HbA1c 7.5% at maximum oral treatment). Participants: 266 patients with type 2 diabetes and 74 practices (mean cluster size 4 (range 1-8) patients), followed up for 12 months. Intervention The Stepping Up model of nursing intervention involved theory-based practice systems change and reorientation of the roles of health professionals in the primary care diabetes team. The core components were an enhanced role for the office nurse in directing insulin initiation and the provision of care by a registered nurse with diabetes education qualifications. Key Outcome Measures The primary endpoint was change in HbA1c. Secondary endpoints included the proportion of participants who switched to insulin, the proportion who achieved target HbA1c and a change in depressive symptoms (Patient Health Questionnaire, PHQ-9), diabetes-specific burden (problem areas in diabetes scale, PAID) and overall health status (Assessment of Quality of Life Instrument, AQoL-8D). Results: HbA1c improved in both arms, with a clinically significant difference between arms (mean difference -0.6%, 95% confidence interval -0.9% to -0.3%), favoring the procedure. At 12 months, 105/151 (70%) of participants in intervention practices had started insulin compared to 25/115 (22%) in control practices (odds ratio 8.3, 95% confidence interval 4.5 to 15.4, P< 0.001) . Target HbA1c (Ä7% (53 mmol/mol)) was achieved by 54 (36%) intervention participants and 22 (19%) control participants (odds ratio 2.2, 1.2 to 4.3, P=0.02 ) . Depressive symptoms did not worsen at 12 months (PHQ-9: -1.1 (3.5) vs. -0.1 (2.9), P=0.05). A statistically significant difference in the mean change in mental health was found between the arms (summary mental AQoL component: 0.04 (SD 0.16) vs -0.002 (0.13), mean difference 0.04 (95 % confidence interval 0.002 to 0.08), p=0.04) favoring intervention but no significant difference in physical health (summary physical AQoL component: 0.03 (0.15) vs 0.02 ( 0.13)) or diabetes-specific burden (5.6 (15.5) vs. No major hypoglycemic events were reported. Conclusions The stepping-up care model was consistent with increased insulin initiation rates in primary care and improvements in glycated hemoglobin without worsening the related to emotional well-being.

title: Supporting middle management health workers in Malawi: Lessons learned from the implementation of the PALM PLUS package
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Government of Malawi is committed to the widespread uptake of antiretroviral treatment in Malawi in the public health sector”; However, one of the biggest challenges was the lack of trained health workers. The Practical Approach to Lung Health Plus HIV/AIDS in Malawi (PALM PLUS) package is an innovative guideline and training intervention designed to support mid-level primary care health workers to deliver integrated frontline primary care. The purpose of this document is to describe the lessons learned from the implementation of the PALM PLUS package. METHODS: A clinical tool based on algorithm- and symptom-based guidelines was adapted to the Malawian context. A companion training program based on outreach education principles was developed and a cascaded training approach was used for the implementation of the PALM PLUS package in 30 health centers, targeting clinical staff, medical assistants and nurses. Lessons learned were identified during program implementation through collaboration with collaborators and program participants and reviewing the results of the program evaluation. RESULTS: Key learnings for successful program implementation of the PALM PLUS package include the importance of building networks for peer-based support, ensuring adequate training capacity, linking it with accreditation for continuous professional development, and providing modest budgets for in-service training courses The main limiting factors for implementation were staff turnover and the desire for financial training allowances. CONCLUSIONS: The PALM PLUS approach is a potential model to support mid-level health professionals in delivering integrated primary care at the front line in low- and middle-income countries and may be useful for future task shifting initiatives.

title: Surgical decision making and behavior. Social psychological explanations and research perspectives
abstract: Social psychology is the discipline that studies thought processes, emotions, and behaviors in an interpersonal context. There are three broad themes: understanding yourself and others, interpersonal relationships, and group influence. The most important method is the experiment. The importance of the socio-psychological perspective becomes clear based on the following surgical research questions: How do surgeons come to their decisions? How do surgeons confirm their decisions? Why do decision-making aids (computer support, guidelines) find so little acceptance? How should patients be informed? Which group processes play a role in the OR? What are the determinants of patient outcomes? Social psychology can enhance surgical research in three ways: better understanding of everyday phenomena in the clinical and surgical field, methodologically refined and more patient-oriented study designs, and new perspectives for improved patient outcomes.

title: Surgical treatments for men with benign prostate enlargement: cost-effectiveness study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine which surgical treatment of lower urinary tract symptoms indicative of benign prostate enlargement is cost effective. DESIGN Treatment pathways that describe credible treatment strategies were established by consensus. The cost-benefit analysis used Markov modeling and Monte Carlo simulation. DATA SOURCES Clinical efficacy data are derived from a systematic review and an individual level data set. Values in use come from previous economic evaluations. Costs were calculated from the National Health Service (NHS) and commercial sources. METHODS The Markov model included parameters with associated uncertainty measures that describe health states that individuals might move between at three-month intervals over 10 years. Consecutive annual cohorts of 25,000 men were entered into the model and the likelihood that treatment strategies were cost-effective was assessed using a 10,000 iteration Monte Carlo simulation. RESULTS A treatment strategy of initial diathermy vaporization of the prostate, followed by endoscopic holmium laser enucleation of the prostate in the absence of benefit or subsequent relapse, was cost-effective with an 85% probability at a willingness-to-pay of £20,000 ( 21,595, $28,686)/quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) gained. Other strategies using diathermy vaporization as first line treatment have generally been cheaper and more effective than the current standard of transurethral resection, repeated once if necessary. The use of potassium titanyl phosphate laser vaporization was more expensive and less effective than transurethral resection, and strategies that included initial minimally invasive treatment with microwave thermotherapy were not cost effective. The results were not changed by extensive sensitivity analyses. CONCLUSION The outcome of this economic model should be interpreted with caution due to the limitations of the data used. The finding that initial vaporization followed by holmium laser enucleation at failure or relapse could be beneficial for both men with lower urinary tract symptoms and healthcare providers requires confirmation in a high-quality prospective clinical study before any change of current practice. Laser vaporization of potassium titanyl phosphate was unlikely to be cost effective in our model, which argues against its full use until further evidence of efficacy and cost reduction is available.

title: Surrogate decisions for severely cognitively impaired research topics: the ongoing debate
abstract: As research into Alzheimer's disease and other dementia conditions becomes more complex, risky, invasive, and mundane, the need for a discussion about the ethics of including people with dementia in research, particularly research with more than minimal risk and no anticipated direct involvement, intensifies use the topic. (It is beyond the scope of this paper to discuss the ethical issues related to the research participation of children with cognitive impairments or children or adults with intermittent and/or reversible cognitive or psychiatric impairments. For such discussions see the references in Notes 1– 6.) Reviewing such studies pushes our traditional analytical tools to their limits. Simply weighing and prioritizing the basic ethical principles of respect for the person, benevolence, and justice, which serve us well in reviewing the vast majority of studies, is insufficient when research is being conducted on such ethical complexities as studies with significant risks and reviewed without expectation of direct benefit to the subjects will not be able to consent or withdraw. Going down to the level of theory and placing these principles within the commonly applied framework of consequentialism, deontology, or virtue ethics, we come to learn about reducing the tensions that such research creates between upholding individual autonomy and advancing societal needs , how to treat and cure, these devastating diseases arise, no step closer. What is needed is the introduction of more contemporary moral analysis. In particular, we need to be more inclusive of the diverse value perspectives of our citizenry. In more theoretical terms, we should elevate a communitarian perspective and feminist ethics, with emphasis on relationships and context, to a more central role as we rush to ethically keep up with this fast-growing area of medical research.

title: Survivor care plans and adherence to lifestyle recommendations in breast cancer survivors
abstract: PURPOSE: The effectiveness of survivor care plans has not been extensively tested. We evaluated whether a one-time brief lifestyle counseling as part of a broader treatment plan for survivors was effective in changing diet and lifestyle patterns. METHODS: A diverse sample of women with stage 0-III breast cancer were randomized to a control or intervention group within 6 weeks of completion of adjuvant treatment. Both groups received the National Cancer Institute publication, Facing Forward: Life after Cancer Treatment. The intervention group also met with a nurse (1 h) and a dietician (1 h) to receive personalized lifestyle recommendations based on national guidelines. Diet, lifestyle, and perceived health were assessed at baseline, 3, and 6 months. Linear regression analyzes assessed the effects of the intervention adjusted for covariates. RESULTS: A total of 126 women completed the study (60 control/66 intervention, 61 Hispanic/65 non-Hispanic women). After 3 months, the intervention group reported greater knowledge of healthy eating (P=0.047), the importance of physical activity (P=0.03), and appropriate use of dietary supplements (P=0.006), and lower frequency of alcohol consumption ( P=0.03) as controls. After 6 months, only more knowledge about a healthy diet persisted (P = 0.01). The intervention was more effective in improving attitudes towards healthy eating (P=0.03) and frequency of physical activity (P=0.006) in non-Hispanics than in Hispanics. CONCLUSIONS: The intervention changed lifestyle behavior and knowledge in the short term, but the benefits were not permanent. IMPLICATIONS FOR CANCER SURVIVORS: Culturally competent long-term behavioral interventions should be tested beyond the survival plan to facilitate long-term behavior change in breast cancer survivors.

title: Kwashiorkor-like syndrome after partial gastrectomy
Systematic Review: An Evaluation of the Major Commercial Weight Loss Programs in the United States
abstract: Background: Each year, millions of Americans enroll in commercial and self-help weight loss programs. Health care providers and their obese patients know little about these programs due to the lack of systematic reviews. Purpose: To describe the components, costs, and effectiveness of the major commercial and organized self-help weight loss programs in the United States that offer structured in-person or online counseling. Data Sources: Company website reviews, phone calls to company representatives, and MEDLINE database search. Study selection: Randomized studies of at least 12 weeks duration, enrolling only adults, that assessed interventions as typically made available to the public or case series that met these criteria, reported the number of enrollments, and a follow-up assessment included that lasted 1 year or more. Data Extraction: Data on study design, attrition, weight loss, duration of follow-up, and maintenance of weight loss were extracted. Data Synthesis: We found studies from eDiets.com, Health Management Resources, Take Off Pounds Sensibly, OPTIFAST, and Weight Watchers. Of 3 Weight Watchers randomized controlled trials, the largest reported a 3.2% loss of baseline weight at 2 years. A randomized study and multiple case series of medically supervised very low-calorie diet programs found that patients who completed treatment lost approximately 15% to 25% of their baseline weight. These programs were associated with high costs, high failure rates, and a high probability of regaining 50% or more of the weight lost in 1 to 2 years. Commercial interventions available over the internet and organized self-help programs resulted in minimal weight loss. Limitations: Because many studies did not account for high turnover rates, the reported results are likely to represent a best-case scenario. Conclusions: With the exception of 1 study from Weight Watchers, the evidence supporting the use of major commercial and self-help weight loss programs is suboptimal.
