Controlled trials are needed to assess the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of these interventions.

title: Systematic review: Elected induction of labor versus expectant management of pregnancy
abstract: BACKGROUND: Rates of labor induction and elective labor induction are increasing. Whether elective labor induction improves outcomes or simply leads to greater complications and healthcare costs is a widely debated topic in the literature (2009), Web of Science, CINAHL, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (up to March 2009), bibliographies of included studies, and previous systematic ones reviews. STUDY SELECTION: Experimental and observational studies on elective labor induction reported in English. DATA EXTRACTION: Two authors abstracted the study design, patient characteristics, quality criteria and outcomes, including cesarean delivery and maternal and neonatal morbidity.DATA SYNTHESIS: Of 6117 potentially relevant articles, 36 met the inclusion criteria: 11 randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and 25 observational studies. A total of one was wait and see Pregnancy management associated with a higher odds ratio (OR) of cesarean than elective induction (OR, 1.22 [95% CI, 1.07 to 1.39]; absolute risk difference, 1.9 percentage points [CI, 0.2 to 3 .7 percentage points]) in 9 RCTs. Women ≥ 41 completed weeks' gestation who were treated expectantly had a higher risk of having a cesarean section (OR, 1.21 [CI, 1.01 to 1.46]), but this difference was statistical in women less than 41 completed weeks gestation not significant (OR, 1.73 [CI, 0.67 to 4.5]). Women who received watchful waiting were more likely to have meconium-stained amniotic fluid than women who were electively initiated (OR, 2.04 [CI, 1.34 to 3.09]). LIMITATIONS: There were no recent RCTs on elective labor induction at less than 41 weeks gestation. The 2 studies conducted at less than 41 weeks gestation were of poor quality and not transferrable to current practice. CONCLUSION: RCTs suggest that elective labor induction at 41 weeks gestation and beyond is associated with a reduced risk of cesarean section and meconium-stained amniotic fluid. There are concerns about translating these findings into actual practice.” Therefore, future studies should examine elective labor induction in settings where most obstetric care is provided.

title: Systematic Review: The Long-Term Effects of False-Positive Mammograms
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although abnormal screening mammograms deleteriously affect women's psychological well-being during the immediate testing environment, their long-term effects are poorly understood. PURPOSE: To characterize the long-term effects of false-positive screening mammograms on the behavior and well-being of women aged 40 and older. DATA SOURCES: English-language studies from MEDLINE, Web of Science, EMBASE, CINAHL, PsycINFO, and ERIC databases up to August 2006. STUDY SELECTION: Studies that examined the effects of false-positive routine screening mammography results on behavior, well-being, or beliefs were identified of women.DATA EXTRACTION: Two investigators independently coded study characteristics, quality, and effect sizes.DATA SYNTHESIS: 23 eligible studies (n=313,967) were identified. A random effects meta-analysis showed that US women who received false-positive screening mammography results were more likely to return to routine screening than those who received normal results (hazard ratio 1.07 [95% CI , 1.02 to 1.12]). The effect was not statistically significant in European women (hazard ratio 0.97 [CI 0.93 to 1.01]), and Canadian women were less likely to return to routine screening because of false positive results (hazard ratio 0.63 [CI 0.50 to 0.80]). Women who received false-positive results were more likely to perform breast self-exams and had higher, but not obviously pathologically elevated, levels of stress and anxiety and more thought of breast cancer than women with normal results, a number of studies suggesting a lack of clinical validation for many measures and possible heterogeneity. CONCLUSIONS: Some women with false-positive mammogram results may differ in their return to mammography, occurrence of breast self-examination, and level of anxiety compared to women with normal results. Future research should examine how false positive results in mammography affect other results, such as B. Trust and utilization of health care.

title: Systematic Review: The Value of Periodic Health Assessment
abstract: Background: Periodic health assessment (PHE) has been a fundamental part of medical practice for decades, although there is no consensus as to its value. Purpose: Synthesis of evidence on the benefits and harms of PHE. Data Sources: Electronic searches of such databases B. MEDLINE and Cochrane Library, review of reference lists, and manual search of peer-reviewed journals up to September 2006. Study Selection: Studies (English only) evaluating the provision of prevention services, clinical outcomes and costs in patients who who receive PHE versus those receiving usual care. Data Extraction: Study design and settings, descriptions of PHE, and clinical outcomes associated with PHE. DATA SYNTHESIS: The best available evidence assessing the benefits or harms of PHE consisted of 21 studies published from 1973 to 2004. The PHE had a consistently favorable association with patients undergoing pelvic exams and Papanicolaou smears, cholesterol screening, and fecal occult blood testing. The PHE also had a positive effect on patient "worry" in a randomized controlled trial, but had mixed effects on other clinical outcomes and costs. Limitations: The descriptions of the PHE and the outcomes were heterogeneous. Some studies were conducted before the US Preventive Services Task Force guidelines were promulgated, limiting their applicability to modern practice. Although additional research is needed to clarify the long-term benefits, harms, and costs of maintaining PHE, the demonstration of benefit in this study warrants the implementation of PHE in clinical practice."

title: Systematic reviews examining the translation of research into practice and the impact on population health are needed
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To investigate the focus of the research translation phase (T1-T4) of systematic reviews published in the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (CDSR) and the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE). In short, T1 includes reviews of basic science experiments; T2 includes reviews of human studies that led to the development of guidelines; T3 includes reviews examining how guidelines can be translated into policy and practice;' and T4 includes reviews describing the impact of changing health practices on population outcomes. STUDY DESIGN AND SETTING: A cross-sectional review of randomly selected reviews of CDSR (n=500) and DARE (n=500) was performed. The research translation phase of reviews overall and by communicable disease, noncommunicable disease, and injury subgroups was coded by two investigators. RESULTS: A total of 898 reviews examined a communicable, noncommunicable, or injury-related disease. Of these, 98% of reviews within CDSR focused on T2 and the remaining 2% on T3. For DARE, 88% focused on T2, 8.7% on T1, 2.5% on T3, and 1.3% on T4. Almost all reviews examining communicable (CDSR 100%, DARE 93%), non-communicable (CDSR 98%, DARE 87%), and injuries (CDSR 95%, DARE 88%) were also T2-focused. CONCLUSION: There are few reviews to help practitioners and policy makers implement evidence-based treatments or programs.

title: Competence network for systemic inflammatory rheumatic diseases
abstract: With the founding of the Rheumatology Competence Network, which has been funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF) since 1999, it has been possible to create a research structure that is unique in Germany: Doctors and scientists from six university rheumatology centers (Berlin, Düsseldorf, Erlangen, Freiburg, Hanover and Lübeck/Bad Bramstedt) work closely with basic research scientists from the German Rheumatism Research Center (DRFZ), with rheumatology clinics, rehabilitation clinics and rheumatologists. Together they look for the causes of systemic inflammatory rheumatic diseases and try to improve therapies - nationwide and interdisciplinary. The primary goal of this cooperation is the faster transfer of new scientific findings to improve diagnostic and treatment methods for patients.

title: Systems of care for ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction: a report from the American Heart Association Mission: Lifeline
abstract: BACKGROUND: National guidelines require participation in systems for the rapid diagnosis and treatment of ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). To characterize currently implemented STEMI reperfusion systems and to identify practices common to system organization, the American Heart Association surveyed existing systems in the United States. METHODS AND RESULTS: A STEMI system was defined as an integrated group of separate entities focused on reperfusion therapy for STEMI within a geographic region that included at least 1 hospital performing percutaneous coronary interventions and at least 1 emergency medical department. Systems that fit this definition were invited to participate in a 42-question survey based on a panel of experts' opinion and knowledge of existing systems. Data was collected through the American Heart Association's Mission: Lifeline website. Between April 2008 and January 2010, 381 individual systems representing 899 percutaneous coronary intervention hospitals in 47 states responded to the survey, of which 255 systems (67%) were in metropolitan areas. The predominant sources of funding for STEMI systems were percutaneous coronary intervention clinics (n=320, 84%) and/or cardiac practices (n=88, 23%). Predominant system characteristics identified in the survey included: STEMI patient acceptance in the hospital for percutaneous coronary intervention regardless of bed availability (N=346, 97%)", activation of the catheterization laboratory by a single call (N=335, 92%), physician of the Emergency room activation of the laboratory without cardiac consultation (N = 318, 87%); participation in the data register (N = 311, 84%);" and prehospital activation of the lab by emergency room without cardiology notification (N=297, 78%). The most common barriers to system implementation were hospital (n=139, 37%) and cardiology group competition (n=81, 21%), and ambulance transport and finances (n=99, 26%). CONCLUSIONS: This survey broadly describes the organizational characteristics of how hospitals and emergency medical services work together to provide timely reperfusion in the United States. These results serve as a benchmark for existing systems and should help healthcare teams organize the care of patients with STEMI.

title: Tailored Information Increases Discussion Between Patients and Physicians About Colon Cancer Risk and Testing: The Cancer Risk Intake System Study
abstract: Assess whether receiving customized printouts created by the Cancer Risk Intake System (CRIS) — a touchscreen computer program that collects data from patients and creates printouts for patients and doctors — has led to more reported discussions between patients and providers about colorectal cancer (CRC) leads. Risk and screening as receiving non-tailored information. Cluster-randomized study, randomized by the physician, with data collected via pre-visit CRIS and a 2-week follow-up telephone survey in 623 patients. Patients 25 to 75 years of age with upcoming primary care visits who are eligible for but currently not adhering to CRC screening guidelines. Patient-reported discussions with providers about CRC risk and testing. Tailored recipients were more likely to report patient-physician discussions about personal and family risks, stool testing, and colonoscopy (all p<0.05). Tailored recipients were more likely to report discussions about: cancer risk (+10%), family history (+15%), stool testing (+9%), and colonoscopy (+8%) (all p<0.05). CRIS is a promising strategy to facilitate discussions about testing in primary care.

title: Tailored competency training for practitioners to improve assessment of prognostic factors for persistent and disabling low back pain: four single-point quasi-experimental studies
abstract: The well-known gap between guidelines and behavior in clinical practice requires effective behavior change interventions. An example showing this gap is the underestimation of psychosocial prognostic factors in back pain by physical therapists (ie yellow flags). The present study aimed to evaluate an educational model by conducting a tailored skill training intervention for nurses and examining the changes over time in physiotherapists' assessment of prognostic factors in telephone consultations. A single-subject, quasi-experimental design was used over 36 weeks, with repeated measurements during the baseline, intervention, and postintervention periods. Four primary care physiotherapists recorded a total of 63 consultations with patients. The tailored intervention included individual goal setting, skills training, and performance feedback. The primary outcome was the number of prognostic factors evaluated (0-10). Changes were noted in all four participants. The number of prognostic factors assessed increased from 0 to 2 at baseline to 6 to 10 after the intervention. The time spent assessing psychosocial factors increased and the time spent discussing biomedical pain symptoms decreased. Knowledge and biopsychosocial attitudes towards back pain conformed to the guidelines upon admission and did not change significantly during the intervention. Self-efficacy in assessing cognitive and emotional prognostic factors increased during the study phases. The results suggest that a tailored skill training intervention using behavior modification techniques such as B. individual goal setting, skill training and feedback on performance, is effective in inducing change in specific clinical behaviors in physiotherapists.

title: Targeted Intervention Programs: Creating a Tailored Practice Model to Improve the Treatment of Allergic Rhinitis in a Managed Care Population
abstract: AIM: To develop an intervention program to improve health outcomes in patients with allergic rhinitis in a managed care setting. STUDY DESIGN: The Lovelace Health Systems Episodes of Care (EOC) team selected allergic rhinitis for an intervention program because it was identified as one of the top 10 reasons for visits to primary care clinics. The intervention program was based on a multidisciplinary team process aimed at creating a tailored educational program for providers and patients to address inconsistencies or deficiencies in the management of allergic rhinitis. PATIENTS AND METHODS: The EOC team reviewed literature and current practices, then identified inconsistencies in diagnostic and treatment patterns. Based on this research, the team developed guidelines and a training program for providers. Intervention strategies were structured around decision points in a treatment protocol. More than 500 patients were monitored throughout allergy season using written and telephone surveys, symptom diaries, and encounter data. Measurable outcomes for provider and patient behavior were identified. Patient outcomes were derived from a preventive behavioral index and administrative data reporting use of 5 classes of drugs. RESULTS: Approximately 50% of providers changed their practice patterns as a result of the intervention program. Patient outcomes showed a decrease in the use of rescue medication, particularly antibiotics, and an increase in preventive measures in the treatment group compared to the control group. CONCLUSION: The EOC model led to positive changes in provider and patient behavior. The multidisciplinary approach resulted in broad vendor participation.

title: Targeting cognitive deficits in schizophrenia: an overview of the development of a new class of drugs from the perspective of mental health researchers in the community
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Schizophrenia is a chronic disease associated with positive and negative symptoms and widespread deficits in neurocognitive function. Neurocognitive deficits are considered to be the central pathophysiological symptoms of the disease. Neurocognitive deficits are also closely related to functional outcome. Currently, cognitive deficits remain one of the most important unmet therapeutic needs in schizophrenia. AREAS COVERED: Neuroscientific discoveries over the past few decades have enriched our understanding of the neurobiological mechanisms underlying cognitive deficits in schizophrenia. This research has identified new molecular mechanisms and processes as promising pharmacological targets. However, despite extensive efforts to develop a new class of cognitive-enhancing drugs to treat schizophrenia over the past 5 years, no novel pharmacological agent has received regulatory approval as required by the Food and Drug Administration. Efficacy and safety results from selected phase II clinical trials are reviewed. EXPERT OPINION: The evolving concept of neurocognition and current guidelines for the design and methodology of clinical trials of cognition-enhancing drugs for the treatment of individuals with schizophrenia are critically reviewed. Future directions in the development of cognitive-enhancing drugs for the treatment of schizophrenia from the perspective of clinicians and researchers from community mental health organizations are discussed.

title: Task Force VI: Self-monitoring of blood pressure
abstract: BACKGROUND: Self-monitoring of blood pressure by patients at home or in other non-hospital settings has become increasingly common in recent years. This phenomenon has been fueled in part by the increasing availability of automatic blood pressure monitors, which are now both affordable and easy for patients to use. BENEFITS OF SELF-MONITORING: Self-monitoring of blood pressure can be an important adjunct to the management of hypertension. Technology enables patients to be more involved in their care. Self-measured blood pressure values are more representative of average daily blood pressure than a clinical measurement and may be better associated with hypertensive target organ involvement and cardiovascular morbidity than clinical blood pressure. Finally, self-monitoring of blood pressure has the potential to reduce the cost of treating hypertension. LIMITATIONS OF SELF-MONITORING: There are several issues that prevent the more widespread use of self-monitoring of blood pressure in clinical practice. First, devices marketed for patient use have technically advanced in the 1990s, but many have not undergone rigorous clinical validation for precision and reliability (e.g., in relation to the Association for the Advancement of Medical Instrumentation guidelines and the British Hypertension Society). It is recommended that blood pressure measurement devices used by patients at home undergo the same validation processes as those used for ambulatory recording. Second, although the upper limits of the normal value for the self-monitored blood pressure of a general population can be statistically defined (it is approximately 135/85 mmHg), it is not yet possible to determine the normal self-monitored blood pressure, since these values are required with classical clinical cardiovascular Endpoints or outcomes are linked. Third, the relationships between self-monitored, clinical, and ambulatory blood pressure readings are well defined for some populations, but their behavior with respect to age, gender, race, and treatment status requires further investigation. Fourth, several different schedules for patient self-monitoring of blood pressure have been used in clinical research and practice. It is necessary to determine the optimal schedule and number of recordings required when patients conduct self-monitoring of blood pressure. Fifth, self-monitoring of blood pressure is certainly feasible in clinical trials of antihypertensive therapies, but has typically not been included in their design by researchers or pharmaceutical sponsors. Sixth, there is data to suggest that self-monitoring of blood pressure reduces the overall costs associated with treating hypertension annually. However, since most of the work on the economic impact of self-monitoring of blood pressure in managed care settings has been conducted in the US, it is not known whether this healthcare cost reduction would be applicable to other types of practice settings on a global basis. CONCLUSIONS: Self-monitoring of blood pressure is currently useful as an adjunctive measurement in the management of hypertensive patients and could be useful in clinical trials of antihypertensive therapy. However, the available data on self-monitoring of blood pressure are insufficient to provide physicians with a basis for primary diagnostic or therapeutic decisions and should not override blood pressure determined by clinical measurement or ambulatory monitoring.

title: Teaching appropriate interactions with pharmaceutical company representatives: the impact of an innovative workshop on student attitudes
abstract: BACKGROUND: Pharmaceutical company representatives (PCRs) influence the prescribing habits and professional behavior of physicians. However, the skills to interact with PCRs are not taught in the traditional medical school curriculum. We examined whether an innovative mandatory workshop for third-year medical students had an immediate impact on knowledge and attitudes about interactions with PCRs. METHODS: Surveys conducted before and after the workshop intervention solicited opinions (five-point Likert scales) from third-year students (n = 75) about the degree of bias in PCR information, the impact of PCRs on prescribing habits, the acceptance of certain gifts, and the educational value of PCR information for both practicing physicians and students. Two faculty members and one PCR led the workshop, which highlighted typical physician-PCR interactions, the use of specimens and gifts, the validity and legal limitations of PCR information, and related ethical issues. Role playing with the PCR demonstrated appropriate and inappropriate strategies for interacting with PCRs. RESULTS: The majority of third-year students (56%, 42/75) had experienced more than three face-to-face interviews involving a PCR about a drug product since entering medical school. Five percent (4/75) said they had no personal experience with PCRs. Most students (57.3%, 43/75) were unaware of the available guidelines on PCR interactions. Twenty-eight percent of students (21/75) felt that none of the named activities/gifts (lunch, free stethoscope, textbooks, educational CD-ROMs, sporting events) should be restricted, while 24.0% (8/75) were of the opinion that students should only be excluded from sporting events. The perceived educational value of PCR information for both practitioners and students increased from 17.7% to 43.2% (chi-square, p=0.0001) and 22.1%, respectively, after the workshop intervention 40.5% (p=0.0007). Student perceptions of the degree of bias in PCR information decreased from 84.1% to 72.9% (p=0.065), but the perceived degree of influence on prescription increased (44.2% to 62.1% (p= 0.02)). CONCLUSIONS: Students are exposed to PCRs early in their medical education. A single workshop intervention can influence student attitudes towards interactions with PCRs. Students were more likely to recognize the educational value of the PCR interactions and their impact on prescribing after the workshop intervention.

title: Teaching hospital medical staff how to wash hands
abstract: Objective Increase the frequency of hand washing by medical staff. Design A prospective study of handwashing before and after patient contact. Setting A pediatric intensive care unit in a tertiary level hospital. Participants 61 ICU medical staff and visiting medical staff. Interventions A five-phase behavior change program: (i) unobtrusive observation for four weeks to obtain a baseline of handwashing; (ii) open observation for five weeks (prior written consultation); (iii) open-ended observation continued for four weeks with performance feedback; (iv) suspended all observations and feedback for seven weeks;" and (v) unremarkable observation for five weeks to obtain a residual rate. Results 939 patient contacts were observed. The baseline handwashing rates before and after patient contact were 12.4% and 10.6% During the open observation, the respective rates increased and stabilized at 32.7% and 33.3%, but continued to increase during the performance feedback period (to 68.3% and 64.8%). Residual handwashing rates, observed unobtrusively seven weeks after the completion of performance feedback, were 54.6% before and 54.9% after patient contact.ConclusionsPerformance feedback is moderately effective in training hospital medical staff to wash hands.

title: Unraveling "the tangled web" of the impact of policy dialogues: Lessons from a case study of dialogues on health care reform options for Canada
abstract: Background The knowledge-sharing literature suggests that policy dialogues should serve to improve the short-, medium- and long-term abilities of individuals, organizations and health systems to use evidence for decision-making. Key characteristics of effective dialogues have been suggested, but the links between these characteristics and the realization of improved capacities for evidence-based policymaking among dialogue participants and the subsequent impact on policymaking are not well understood. Methods We conducted a qualitative case study of a series of four policy dialogues convened in Canada in 2011 between national, provincial and regional stakeholders on issues related to health care funding and funding. Data sources included videos of participant perspectives recorded during or immediately after each dialogue event and follow-up interviews with key informants among dialogue participants that took place 4 years later in 2015. Factors shaping the implementation of evidence guided the thematic analysis. We then synthesized the results across the three frameworks. Results The results indicate that the potential benefits of the policy dialogues described in the literature were developed among the participants of these dialogues. The informants explained how the characteristics of the dialogue influenced their ability to use evidence, the ideas, interests and institutions during the agenda setting and policy formulation phases of policy making, and how implementation is influenced by characteristics of policy options, individuals, organizations and the external environment was and processes. Conclusions We present a conceptual framework that advances our understanding of the potential influence of policy dialogues on the content and mechanisms of policy development, and illustrates pathways of influence at different stages of the policy cycle, from agenda setting to formulation and implementation. The framework highlights important factors to consider when designing and evaluating policy dialogues and supporting post-dialogue knowledge-sharing efforts.

title: Education via teleconference: Diabetes education for general practitioners
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Formal continuing education courses (CME) are relatively ineffective in changing physician behavior. Diabetes mellitus is an increasingly prevalent condition, and interventions are needed to improve adherence to clinical practice guidelines (CPGs). METHODS: A stratified, cluster-randomized, controlled study design was used to assess the effects of Teleconferenced Educational Detailing (TED-CME) on glycemic control (hemoglobin [Hb] A1c) and primary care physician compliance with national diabetes guidelines. TED used sequential, case-based, small-group training using guidelines provided by a diabetes specialist. Medical record review data from baseline to the end of a 12-month post-intervention period were compared for the control and intervention groups. Satisfaction with the intervention was assessed. RESULTS: 61 physicians provided 660 medical records. The intervention had no effect on mean HbA1c levels but significantly (p=0.04) changed the distribution of patients by category of glycemic control, with fewer patients in the intervention group having inadequate control (15.8% vs. 23, 9%). More patients were taking insulin (alone or with oral agents) in the intervention group (21.2% versus 12.0%, p=0.03) and more patients were taking oral agents alone in the control group (89.0% versus 82, 9%, p=0.005) . More patients in the intervention group had documentation of body mass index (7.8% versus 1.9%, p<0.02), eye examination (12.1% versus 5.1%, p=0.02 ) and treatment plan (43.5% versus 23.6%, p=0.01) and used a flowchart (14.6% versus 7.7%, p<0.03). Although generally satisfied with the conference call format, specialist educators found the format more challenging than GPs. DISCUSSION: CME, conducted via conference call, was feasible, well attended, well received by participants, and improved some key diabetes management practices and outcomes.

title: Telemedicine for patients at high risk for cardiovascular disease: pragmatic randomized controlled trial
abstract: GOAL Ã‚Â Assess whether non-clinical staff can effectively treat people at high risk of cardiovascular disease using digital health technologies. DESIGN – Pragmatic, multicenter, randomized, controlled study. RECRUITMENT 42 GP practices in three areas of England. PARTICIPANTS Ã‚Â Between December 3, 2012 and July 23, 2013, we recruited 641 adults aged 40 to 74 years with a 10-year cardiovascular disease risk of 20% or greater, no prior cardiovascular event, at least one modifiable risk factor (systolic blood pressure Ã 140 mm Hg, body mass index 30, current smoker) and access to telephone, internet and e-mail. Participants were individually assigned to intervention (n=325) or control (n=316) groups using automated randomization, stratified by location, minimized by practice, and baseline risk score. INTERVENTIONS Intervention was the Healthlines service (alongside usual care) which included regular telephone calls from trained lay health workers following scripts generated by interactive software. Counselors facilitated self-management by helping participants use online resources to reduce risk factors and sought to optimize drug use, improve adherence to therapy, and promote healthier lifestyles. The control group included only usual care. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary outcome was the proportion of participants who responded to treatment, defined as maintaining or reducing their cardiovascular risk at 12 months. The results were collected six and twelve months after randomization and analyzed in a masked manner. The participants were not masked. RESULTS 50% (148/295) of participants in the intervention group responded to treatment compared to 43% (124/291) in the control group (adjusted odds ratio 1.3, 95% confidence interval 1.0 to 1.9" , number required to treat = 13); a difference possibly due to chance (p = 0.08) mean diastolic -2.8 (-4.0 to -1.6 mmHg); weight -1, 0 kg (-1.8 to -0.3 kg) and body mass index -0.4 (-0.6 to -0.1) but not cholesterol -0.1 (-0.2 to 0 .0), smoking status (adjusted odds ratio 0.4, 0.2 to 1.0), or total cardiovascular risk as a continuous measure (-0.4, -1.2 to 0.3)).The intervention was associated with improvements in diet, physical activity, medication adherence, and satisfaction with access to care, treatment received, and care coordination A serious adverse event occurred when a participant was admitted to the hospital with low blood pressure became. CONCLUSIONS This evidence-based telemedicine approach was associated with small clinical benefits for a minority of people at high cardiovascular risk, and there was no overall mean risk improvement. However, the Healthlines service has been associated with improvements in some risk behaviors and perceptions of support and access to medical care.

title: Telephone care management to improve cancer screening among low-income women
abstract: BackgroundMinority and low-income women receive fewer cancer screenings than other women.ObjectiveTo evaluate the effect of a telephone support intervention in increasing screening for breast, cervical, and colorectal cancer in minority and low-income women.DesignRandomized controlled study conducted between November was 2001 and April 2004. Established 11 community and migrant health centers in New York City. 1413 patients overdue for cancer screening Control group received usual care. Follow-up data were available for 99% of women, and 91% of the intervention group received at least 1 call Women who had mammography increased from 0.58 to 0.68 with the intervention and decreased from 0.60 to 0, 58 with usual treatment; the proportion having Papanicolaou tests increased from 0.71 to 0.78 with the intervention and remained unchanged with usual care;' and the proportion having colorectal screening increased with the intervention from 0.39 to 0.63 and with of the usual care from 0.39 to 0.50. The difference in change in screening rates between groups was 0.12 for mammography (95% CI, 0.06 to 0.19), 0.07 for the Papanicolaou test (CI, 0.01 to 0 .12) and 0.13 for colorectal screening (CI, 0.07 to 0.19). The proportion of women who were up to date for 3 tests increased from 0.21 to 0.43 with the intervention. Limitations Participants were from a city and had access to a regular source of care. Medical records may not have recorded all cancer screenings. Conclusions Telephone support can improve cancer screening rates among women attending community and migrant health centers. The intervention appears well-suited to health plans, large medical groups, and other organizations trying to increase cancer screening rates and address inequalities in care.

title: Telephone screening, outreach, and care management for depressed workers and impact on clinical and work productivity outcomes: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Context Although guideline-compliant treatment for depression is clearly effective, treatment often falls short of evidence-based recommendations. Organized depression treatment programs significantly improve the quality of care, but employer buyers have been slow to adopt these programs because they believe there is no evidence of cost-effectiveness. Objective To assess the impact of an outreach treatment program for depression on workplace outcomes, a concern of employers. Design, Setting, and Participants In a randomized controlled trial of 604 employees covered by a managed behavioral health plan, a two-stage screening process was used to determine that they had significant depression. Patient treatment assignment was concealed and assessments of depression severity and work performance at months 6 and 12 were blinded. Employees with lifelong bipolar disorder, substance use disorder, recent specialty psychiatric treatment, or suicidal tendencies were excluded. Intervention A telephone counseling and care management program encouraged staff to engage in outpatient treatment (psychotherapy and/or antidepressants), monitored continuity of care quality, and attempted to improve care by providing referrals to providers. Participants who resisted treatment were offered structured cognitive-behavioural psychotherapy over the phone. Main outcome measures depression severity (Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology, QIDS) and job performance (World Health Organization Health and Productivity Questionnaire [HPQ], a validated self-report instrument that assesses job retention, absenteeism from work, job performance, and critical job incidents). Results Combining data from 6- and 12-month assessments, the intervention group had significantly lower QIDS self-report scores (relative odds of cure, 1.4 inches; 95% confidence interval, 1.1-2.0; P=0.009). higher job retention (relative probability 1.7; 95% confidence interval 1.1-3.3; P = 0.02) and significantly more work hours during the intervention (ß = 2.0; P = 0.02; "corresponding to a annualized effect of 2 weeks of work) than the usual caregiving groups that were employed.Conclusions A systematic program to detect depression and promote effective treatment not only improves clinical outcomes but also workplace outcomes significantly.The financial value of the latter for employers in covering hiring, training and salary costs suggests that many employers are seeing a positive return on investment from outreach e and improved treatment of depressed workers.

title: Telephone assisted cooperative care for the treatment of depression after CABG
abstract: Context Depressive symptoms often follow coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) and are associated with less favorable clinical outcomes. Aim To test the effectiveness of cooperative care provided by telephone for post-CABG depression compared to usual medical care. Design, Setting, and Participants Single-blinded efficacy study at 7 college and community hospitals in or near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Participants were 302 post-CABG patients with depression (150, intervention"; 152, usual care) and a comparison group of 151 randomly selected post-CABG patients without depression, recruited between March 2004 and September 2007 and until June 2008 as outpatients were observed. Intervention Eight months of collaborative telephone care provided by nurses working with patients' primary care physicians and monitored by a psychiatrist and primary care physician from this study Main outcome measures Mental health-related quality of life (HRQL) as measured by the short form -36 Mental Component Summary (SF-36 MCS) at 8-month follow-up; secondary outcome measures included assessment of mood symptoms (Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression [HRS-D]), physical HRQL (SF-36 PCS), and functional status (Duke Activity Status Index [DASI]), and hospital readmissions. Outcomes The intervention patients reported greater improvements mental HRQL (all P=0.02) (SF-36 MCS: ?, 3.2 points; 95% confidence e-interval [CI], 0.5-6.0), physical functioning (DASI: ?, 4.6 points; 95% CI, 1.9-7.3) and mood symptoms (HRS-D: ?, 3.1 points; 95% CI, 1.3-4.9); and were more likely to report a decrease in HRS-D score of 50% or more from baseline (50.0% vs. 29.6%; number to treat: 4.9 [95% CI, 3.2-10 .4]) than patients with normal care (P < .001). Men with depression were particularly likely to benefit from the intervention (SF-36 MCS: ?, 5.7 points; 95% CI, 2.2-9.2; P=0.001). However, the mean HRQL and physical functioning of the intervention patients did not reach those of the non-depressed comparison group. Conclusion Compared with usual care, telephone cooperative care for the treatment of depression after CABG resulted in improvements in HRQL, physical functioning, and mood symptoms at follow-up 8 months.

title: Telepraxis in the assessment and treatment of individuals with autism spectrum disorders: A systematic review
abstract: AIM: Studies involving the use of telepractice in the delivery of services to persons with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) were reviewed with the intention of informing practice and identifying areas for future research. METHODS: Systematic searches of electronic databases, reference lists, and journals identified eight studies that met predetermined inclusion criteria. These studies were analyzed and summarized in terms of: (a) characteristics of the participants, (b) technology used, (c) services provided via telepractice, (d) research methodology, and (e) results of the study. RESULTS: Telepractice was used by academic researchers, behavior analysts, psychiatrists, and psychologists to assist caregivers and educators in delivering services to 46 participants with ASD. Services provided included behavioral and diagnostic assessments, educational advice, guidance and monitoring of behavioral interventions, and coaching/training in implementing a comprehensive early intervention program. CONCLUSIONS: The results suggest that telepractice is a promising approach to service delivery in the management of individuals with ASD that requires additional research. Guidelines for practitioners and possible directions for future research are discussed.

title: Trial ordering policies may alter ordering patterns in an academic ER
abstract: To determine the effects of an educational program to change test-ordering behavior in an academic emergency department (ED), an observational before-and-after study was conducted at a university-level tertiary referral center and an emergency medicine (EM) residential site. Test order standards were developed by EM faculty, RNs, and NPs based on group consensus and published data. The standards were distributed to all ED staff beginning February 1996 and were included in the Evidence-Based Medicine Orientation and Training Program for all residents and medical students prior to the start of their rotation. No restrictions were imposed on the actual test order. The number of laboratory tests ordered per 100 patients (total and individual) decreased significantly after the start of the educational program for: total tests, CBC and liver function test (LFT). In addition, the decreases during individual months for these tests were statistically significant. Prothrombin time and blood culture tests did not show a significant decrease in test order frequency. The frequency of ordering chemical tests showed statistically significant increases. Overall, about $50,000 was saved by reducing the number of test orders. Test ordering behavior can be modified and maintained through an educational program and can have a significant economic impact.

title: Testimony of LeRoy Walters

Testing the effectiveness of an innovative information pack on physician-reported behaviors and beliefs: UK Chiropractors, Osteopaths and Musculoskeletal Physiotherapists Low Back Pain Management (COMPLeMENT) Trial [ISRCTN77245761
abstract: BACKGROUND: Low back pain (LBP) is a common and costly problem. Initiatives designed to help physicians and patients make decisions about appropriate healthcare for LBP include printed evidence-based clinical guidelines. The three UK professions of chiropractic, osteopathy and musculoskeletal physiotherapy share a common ground in their approaches to treating LBP and are among those targeted by LBP guidelines. Despite this, many seem unaware that such guidelines exist. In addition, the behavior of at least some of these practitioners deviates from what is recommended in these guidelines. Few randomized controlled trials evaluating printed information as a physician behavior change intervention have used a no-intervention control group. All of these studies have used a cluster design and most have methodological flaws. None focuses specifically on physician behavior toward LBP patients. Studies examining other strategies to change physician behavior in LBP patients have yielded conflicting results. Although numerous LBP guidelines have been developed around the world, there is little data on whether their dissemination is actually changing physician behavior. Sending printed information to a large number of practitioners is an attractive dissemination and implementation strategy, mainly because of the low unit costs. The effect size of such a strategy at the individual practitioner level is likely to be small. However, if a large number of practitioners are reached, this strategy could bring about significant changes at the population level. METHODS: The main objective of this prospective, pragmatic, randomized, controlled study is to test the short-term efficacy (six months after the intervention) of a directly published information package about the reported clinical behavior (primary outcome), attitudes and beliefs of UK chiropractors, osteopaths and musculoskeletal physiotherapists. We attempted to randomly assign a combined sample of 1,800 consenting practitioners to receive either the information package (intervention arm) or no information beyond that gleaned during normal practice (control arm). We collected questionnaire data at baseline and six months after the intervention. Analysis of the primary outcome will assess between-arm differences in the proportions of responses to activity, work, and bed rest recommendation questions that fall into categories previously defined by an expert consensus exercise as either "guideline-compliant" or "guideline." -inconsistent'.

title: Review of the implementation of clinical guidelines
Texas Children's Medication Algorithm Project: Update from the Texas Consensus Conference Panel on Medication Treatment of Childhood Major Depressive Disorder
abstract: AIM: To revise and update the consensus guidelines for drug treatment algorithms for childhood major depressive disorders based on new scientific evidence and the clinical consensus of experts when evidence is lacking. METHOD: A consensus conference was held on January 13-14, 2005, and was attended by academic clinicians and researchers, practicing clinicians, administrators, consumers and families. The focus was on reviewing, updating and incorporating the most up-to-date data to inform and recommend specific pharmacological approaches and clinical guidelines for the management of major depressive disorders in children and adolescents. RESULTS: Consensual medication algorithms for major depression (with and without psychosis) and comorbid attention-deficit disorders were updated. These revised algorithms also included approaches to treat suicidality, aggression, and irritability. Levels 1, 2 and 3 of the algorithm consist of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and norepinephrine serotonin reuptake inhibitors, the use of which is supported by controlled acute clinical trials and clinical experience. Recent studies support that selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are still recommended as first-line drugs in addition to fluoxetine. The need for additional evaluation, precautions and monitoring, as well as continuation and maintenance treatment is emphasized. CONCLUSIONS: Evidence and clinical expert consensus support the use of selected antidepressants in the treatment of depression in adolescents. Use of the recommended antidepressants requires appropriate monitoring for suicidal tendencies and potential side effects, as well as consideration of other evidence-based treatment alternatives such as cognitive behavioral therapies.

title: The 2013 ACC/AHA guideline on treating blood cholesterol to reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in adults: the good, the bad, and the uncertain aspects: a comparison with the 2011 ESC/EAS guidelines for the management of dyslipidemia
abstract: Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is the most important public health problem of our time in both Europe and the rest of the world, accounting for the largest expenditure in most health budgets. Achieving consistent clinical care, incorporating new knowledge and synthesizing it into practical recommendations for clinicians is the task of various guideline bodies around the world. Any change to a set of policies can therefore have far-reaching consequences, especially if they appear to conflict with existing policies. This article reviews the most recent 2013 American College of Cardiology (ACC)/American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines on controlling blood cholesterol levels to reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in adults. Compared to the 2011 ESC/EAS guidelines on lipid modification, the 2013 ACC/AHA guidelines differ significantly. In particular, (i) the scope is limited to randomized trials, which excludes a significant amount of data and essentially only promotes a statin-centric approach”; (ii) the elimination of low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (LDL-C) targets advocated by specific statin therapies that produce a 30-50% reduction in LDL-cholesterol levels will, we believe, confuse many physicians and the Missing opportunity to adhere to medication and involve patients in self-care; (iii) the lack of target LDL-cholesterol levels in very high-risk patients with high absolute or residual risk factors will discourage clinicians from considering additional lipid modification treatments and individualizing patient care; (iv) lowering the threshold for treatment in primary prevention will result in a larger number of patients being treated on prescribed statin therapy, which is potentially good in young patients at high lifetime risk, but will result in a very large number of older ones patients are offered therapy;" and (v) the mixed-pool risk calculator used to assess cardiovascular risk in the primary prevention guidelines has not been fully evaluated. This article discusses the potential impact of adopting the ACC/AHA guidelines on patient care in Europe and beyond and concludes with the opinion that the ESC/EAS guidelines of 2011 appear to be the most comprehensive, pragmatic and appropriate choice for European countries.

title: The aggressive kid
abstract: The acute assessment and treatment of the aggressive or violent child or adolescent is a challenge for clinicians. Early recognition of signs of impending violence and a clear understanding of the progression of violent behavior are essential to ensure the safety of patients and staff. Managing violent and aggressive patients with behavioral interventions tailored to the stage of violence or aggression is critical to reducing the likelihood that the child or young person will attack staff or harm themselves or others. The indications and risks of chemical and physical fixations and hospital standards and policies governing the use of behavioral and experiential values related to the prevalence, presentation, and differential diagnosis of psychotic disorders in adolescents. The clinician must quickly disentangle which elements of the clinical presentation are indicative of genuine psychotic thought processes and which elements represent misunderstood developmentally appropriate phenomena, symptoms of nonpsychotic illness, or harbingers of an underlying primary medical condition. A thorough examination is required before appropriate treatment can begin.

title: The AHCPR heart failure guidelines: comparison of a general practice and a medical practice with the guidelines and an educational behavior change intervention
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The objectives of this study were to apply the Agency for Health Policy and Research (AHCPR) guideline for heart failure to measuring quality of care in the outpatient setting, to compare the outcomes of two large practices, and to design a training intervention for the two practices studied . METHODS: A retrospective file review was performed on a random sample of 50 heart failure patients, each selected from two outpatient practices: general internal medicine practice and family practice at a large academic medical center. Five medical assessment criteria were developed from the AHCPR heart failure guideline to compare the two practices to each other and to the guidelines. An educational intervention was developed to change physician behavior related to adherence to guidelines. RESULTS: Left ventricular function was assessed in 79% of all cases. 68% of eligible patients were treated with angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE-Is). Of the patients treated with enalapril and captopril, 30% and 12%, respectively, received the target dose defined in the AHCPR guidelines. Of the patients unsuitable for treatment with ACE-Is, none were treated with hydralazine and nitrates. When ejection fraction was less than or equal to 40%, 81% of eligible patients were treated with ACE-Is, while 59% were treated with ACE-Is when ejection fraction was greater than 40%. Calcium channel blockers were used in the treatment of 42% of patients. A statistical difference (p=0.05) was noted between the two practices for documenting left ventricular function, the use of ACE-Is in patients with an ejection fraction less than or equal to 40%, and the use of calcium channel blockers and beta blockers. CONCLUSIONS: In the practices studied, documentation of left ventricular function, ACE-Is in eligible patients, target doses of ACE-Is, and use of hydralazine and nitrates in non-eligible patients is underutilized. A higher proportion of patients receive ACE-I therapy when the ejection fraction is less than or equal to 40%. Some patients may experience inappropriate use of calcium channel blockers. There are unexplained clinical differences between the two procedures studied.

title: The altruistic medical researcher: gone and forgotten?
abstract: With increasing economic, political, and bureaucratic involvement in research, little attention is paid to the idealistic and benevolent intentions of the medical researcher. Benevolence is a pillar of human ethical research, and altruism is a form of benevolence that is difficult to quantify. It is an interest in the welfare of others without personal benefit. This article examines the extent of altruism in medical research from philosophical, psychological, and practical perspectives. With the advent of experimental human studies in the first half of the century, the fame and recognition of physicians largely precluded altruistic motivation. Philosophically, altruism is at best an optional moral principle. It is not apparent in ethical guidelines. In the scientific process, altruism can only exist in ethical and properly designed research. Selfishness, scientific misconduct and conflicts of interest undermine them";" but altruism is also a possible solution to these problems. Research is not globally oriented and distributed unfairly. In an evolutionary model, altruism cannot thrive due to its lack of rewards and feedback, especially in the economic climate of science today. Anonymity decreases, selfishness increases. Research has become an industry and virtuous ideals are a romantic notion. If we use altruism as an indicator, then its rarity and fragility indicate the unhealthy state of research.

title: Die American Society of Clinical Psychopharmacology Survey of Psychopharmacologists' Practice Patterns for the Treatment of Mood Disorders
abstract: BACKGROUND: Optimal sequential treatment decisions are not well established after initial drug failure in major depressive disorder or bipolar disorder. While practice guidelines provide consensus-based treatment recommendations from experts, little is known about the pharmacological decision-making of practicing psychopharmacologists in the "real world." MATERIALS AND METHODS: We conducted an Internet survey of the national membership of the American Society of Clinical Psychopharmacology (ASCP) to examine preferred pharmacotherapeutic strategies and factors influencing drug choice for patients with mood disorders. RESULTS: Surveys were returned by 154/752 ASCP members (21%). After failure to respond to a serotonin reuptake inhibitor for major depressive disorder, participants equally preferred switching within or between antidepressant classes. After a partial response, adjunctive bupropion was the preferred intervention, followed by antidepressant class switching. Atypical antipsychotic augmentation was only a fourth-line consideration, although in most cases moderate or significant efficacy was perceived with olanzapine, aripiprazole, and quetiapine. Respondents preferred antidepressant avoidance in bipolar I patients with mixed/cyclic features or prior antidepressant-associated mania/hypomania. For rapid cyclers, they advocated stopping antidepressants and favored the use of atypical antipsychotics and lamotrigine. CONCLUSIONS: Participating psychopharmacologists treating adults with mood disorders report prescribing drugs that broadly reflect the evidence base, with only a few notable exceptions, accounting for the characteristics of definable clinical subpopulations.

title: The expected clinical and economic impact of 90-90-90 in South Africa
abstract: Background The UNAIDS global treatment goal “90-90-90” aims to achieve 73% virologic suppression in HIV-infected people worldwide by 2020. This ambitious goal is to be achieved in South Africa. Design We model: the Current Pace strategy, simulating existing scale-up efforts and gradual increases in overall virological suppression from 24% to 36% in 5 years";" and the UNAIDS Target Strategy, which simulates 73% suppression in 5 years. Data Sources Published estimates and South African survey data provide HIV transmission rates (0.16–9.03/100 years), HIV-specific age-stratified fertility rates (1.0–9.1/100 years), and costs (ART: $11–11 ). 31/month, routine care: $20-157/month). Target population HIV-infected population of South Africa, including emerging infections over the next ten years Perspective Modified societal perspective without time and productivity costs Time horizon Five and ten year interventions Aggressive HIV case detection, efficient linkage to care, rapid extension of treatment and adherence /Retention Interventions to UNAIDS Target Strategy Outcome Measures HIV transmissions, deaths, years of life saved (YLS), maternal orphans, costs (2014 USD) and cost effectiveness In 10 years, the UNAIDS Target Strategy would (873,000) 2,051,000 HIV transmissions, (1,174 .000) prevent 2,478,000 deaths and (726,000) 1,689,000 maternal orphans while saving (3,002,000) 13,340,000 years of life. The additional budget that would be required for the UNAIDS Target Strategy would be ($7.965)$15.979 billion, giving an incremental cost benefit ratio (ICER) of ($2,720/YLS)$1,260/YLS, (< 50%) < 20% of South Africa's per capita GDP. Sensitivity Analysis Results The results generally differed from the base case results by less than 20% when we varied the key input parameters within plausible ranges. Limitations Multiple signaling pathways can lead to an overall suppression of 73% examined in the sensitivity analysis. Conclusions Achieving the 90-90-90 HIV suppression target would be costly, but both highly effective and cost-effective in South Africa. Global health policymakers should mobilize political and economic support to make the 90-90-90 goal a reality.

title: Application of an occupational health guideline reduces sedentary behavior and increases fruit consumption at work: results of an RCT
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of a draft occupational health practice guideline aimed at preventing weight gain on staff physical activity, sedentary and dietary behaviors and body weight outcomes. METHODS: A randomized controlled trial was conducted between 2009 and 2011 comparing guideline-based care to usual care in 16 occupational physicians and 523 employees in the Netherlands and intervene in the obese work environment and conducted five face-to-face behavior change counseling sessions with employees, to improve their lifestyle. Staff data were collected through questionnaires and physical measurements at baseline and 6-month follow-up. Linear and logistic regression analyzes were carried out to determine the effects. RESULTS: The intervention showed significant effects on sedentary behavior at work (beta -28 min/day, 95% CI -2 to -54) and on fruit consumption (beta 2.1 items/week; 95% CI 0.6 to 3.6). No significant intervention effects were found for physical activity, sedentary behavior during leisure time or on weekend days, snack intake, and body weight-related endpoints. CONCLUSION: Guideline-based nursing resulted in more favorable sedentary behavior at work and increased fruit consumption, but did not improve physical activity, snack intake, or staff body weight outcomes. Study registration number ISRCTN/73545254 and NTR/1190.

title: The assessment of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder in rural primary care: The transferability of the American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines to the “real world”.
abstract: objective. To study the implementation of a protocol for assessment of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in rural pediatric offices. The protocol was developed to provide pediatricians with an efficient means of learning and applying the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) ADHD guidelines. methods. Primary care staff (doctors, nurses, etc.) from 2 rural pediatric practices were trained in the use of the ADHD assessment protocol. The medical records of 101 patients were reviewed 1 to 2 years prior to the implementation of the protocol and of 86 patients in the following 2 to 3 years to assess compliance with the AAP guidelines. In addition, 34% of scales scored by staff were rescored to verify scoring accuracy. Results. Prior to the availability of the AAP guidelines and the implementation of the assessment protocol, none of the primary care sites consistently collected the comprehensive information that is now recommended for an ADHD assessment. Rating scales for parents and/or teachers were collected for only 0% to 21% of ratings at all sites. When supplemented with brief training and support materials, medical records reflected a significant improvement in identifying clinically necessary ADHD information, with parent and teacher rating scales present 88% to 100% of the time. The staff demonstrated the ability to rate rating scales with a high degree of accuracy. The integrity of log collection and management was maintained 2 to 3 years after training. Conclusions. An efficient system for conducting ADHD assessments per AAP guidelines in rural children's hospitals can be initiated and maintained with integrity. Further research is needed to determine if this system improves diagnostic decision making and patient outcomes. Pediatrics 2005";115:e120–e126. URL: www.pediatrics.org/cgi/doi/10.1542/peds.2004-1521;" Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder Assessment Guidelines Pediatrics

title: The behavioral economics of health care and health care
abstract: People often make healthcare decisions that aren't in their best interests, from not enrolling in health insurance to which they are entitled to engaging in extremely harmful behaviors. Traditional economic theory offers limited tools for improving behavior because it assumes that people make decisions rationally, have the mental capacity to deal with vast amounts of information and choice, and have distinct tastes that cannot be manipulated . Behavioral economics combines economics with psychology and recognizes that people often do not act rationally in an economic sense. It therefore offers a potentially richer set of tools than traditional economic theory for understanding and influencing behavior. However, only recently in the healthcare sector. This article provides an overview of behavioral economics, reviews some of its contributions, and shows how it can be used in healthcare to improve people's decisions and health.

title: The behavior change wheel: A new method for characterizing and designing behavior change interventions
abstract: Background Improving the design and implementation of evidence-based practices depends on successful behavior change interventions. This requires an appropriate method to characterize interventions and link them to an analysis of the intended behavior. There is a plethora of frameworks for behavior change interventions, but it is not clear how well they serve this purpose. This paper evaluates these frameworks and develops and evaluates a new framework that aims to overcome their limitations. Methods A systematic search of electronic databases and consultations with behavior change professionals were used to identify frameworks for behavior change interventions. These were evaluated according to three criteria: completeness, coherence and clear reference to a higher-level behavioral model. A new framework was developed to meet these criteria. The reliability with which it could be applied has been studied in two areas of behavior change: tobacco control and obesity. Results Nineteen frameworks were identified, covering nine intervention functions and seven policy categories that might enable those interventions. None of the frameworks reviewed covered the full range of intervention functions or measures, and only a minority met the criteria of coherence or linkage to a behavioral model. At the heart of a proposed new framework is a 'behavioural system' that encompasses three essential conditions: ability, opportunity and motivation (what we call the 'COM-B system'). This forms the center of a 'Behaviour Change Wheel' (BCW) around which are arranged the nine intervention features aimed at addressing deficits in one or more of these disorders'; Arranged around these are seven categories of policies that could enable these interventions. The BCW has been reliably used to characterize interventions under the UK Department of Health's Tobacco Control Strategy 2010 and the National Institutes of Health and Clinical Excellence guidelines for reducing obesity. Conclusions Behavior change interventions and measures can usefully be characterized in terms of a BCW, which includes: a 'behavioural system' at the top, surrounded by intervention functions, and then categories of measures. Research is needed to determine to what extent BCW can lead to more efficient design of effective interventions.

title: The Black report on socioeconomic inequalities in health 10 years later
The Bold Promise Project: a system change in primary care to support cardiovascular risk screening
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To develop a set of systemic changes in primary care to facilitate cardiovascular risk screening of all eligible patients identified under the current New Zealand Cardiovascular Guidelines (NZGG) and to provide the opportunity to increase clinical management of high-risk patients to measure and track. METHODS: Within the GP practice management software, several system modifications were designed to identify the patient cohort eligible for cardiovascular risk screening, calculate cardiovascular disease risk (CVR), and collect the data for reporting of screening results and clinical management indicators at high risk extract patients. After a baseline audit, the system changes were tested over a 12-month period in three general practices with a total of 30,963 enrolled patients. RESULTS: A total of 6570 NZGG-eligible patients were identified";" 20.1% of these were Maori and 19.7% were Pacific people (mainly of Samoan, Tongan, Niuean or Cook Islands origin). Over 12 months, cardiovascular risk assessment screening rates increased from 4.7% to 53.5% for the cohort. Of the 3516 patients screened, 482 (13.7%) had established cardiovascular disease. An additional 230 (6.5%) had diabetes without CVD and 646 (18.4%) had a 5-year CVD risk > or = 15% Management data were available for 232 (48.1%) of the patients with CVD , 74%, 65%, and 79% were taking aspirin, statins, and antihypertensive drugs, respectively. Fifty-five percent exceeded the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) target of 2.5 mmol/L, 62% had a systolic blood pressure (BP) above the target of 130 mmHg, 18% were still smoking, and only 9% met all clinical targets recommended in the guideline. Of 646 with a 5-year CVD risk > or = up to 15%, management data were available for 347 (53.7%). Only 34% received aspirin, 40% statins and 57% antihypertensive drugs. 40% of this group had a systolic BP > 140 mmHg, 36% an LDL > 3.5 mmol/L, with only 7% of the patients achieving all clinical target values of the guideline. CONCLUSIONS: The system changes encompassing this intervention have dramatically increased cardiovascular risk assessment rates in a primary care setting and will facilitate appropriate targeting of intensive cardiovascular preventive interventions to close the observed treatment gap.

title: The challenge for preventive cardiology

The challenge of transferring an implementation strategy from science to practice: a process evaluation of local quality improvement collaborations in Dutch primary care using normalization process theory
abstract: Rationale, Objectives, and Objectives: A quality improvement strategy consisting of comparative feedback and peer review embedded in available local quality improvement collaborations proved effective in changing primary care physician test ordering behavior. However, the implementation of this strategy was problematic. Our goal was the large-scale implementation of a customized strategy covering both trial ordering and prescription performance. Since we were not able to implement it on a large scale, the aim of this study was to describe and analyze the challenges of the transfer process. Methods: In a qualitative study, 19 provincial health officers, pharmacists, laboratory specialists and general practitioners were interviewed within 6 months after the transfer. The interviews were tape-recorded, transcribed and coded independently by two of the authors. The codes have been adapted to the dimensions of the normalization process theory. RESULTS: The basic idea of the strategy was widely accepted, however, the generation of the feedback was more complex than expected and the need for external support after the transfer of the strategy remained high, as the participants did not take on the work involved and the allocation of resources with it. CONCLUSION: Evidence of effectiveness, a national infrastructure for these collaborations and a generally positive attitude were not sufficient for normalization. When planning complex quality improvement strategies, the management of large databases, the responsibility for tasks and the allocation of resources should be considered as early as possible. It is not enough to just examine the barriers and facilitators experienced in a previous process. Although multifaceted implementation strategies for changing professional behavior are attractive, their inherent complexity is also a pitfall for large-scale implementation.

title: The clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of low-intensity psychological interventions for secondary prevention of relapse after depression: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Depression is the most common mental disorder in social settings and a leading cause of disability worldwide. The goal of treatment is to achieve remission or at least adequate control of depressive symptoms, but even after successful treatment, the risk of post-remission relapse is significant. Although the effectiveness of low-intensity interventions for treating primary symptoms of psychological difficulties has been extensively evaluated, there has been significantly less research examining the use of these interventions as a relapse prevention strategy OBJECTIVE: To systematically review the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of using psychological or psychosocial interventions low-intensity to prevent relapse or recurrence in patients with depression Because the broader definition of “low-intensity” psychological intervention is somewhat controversial, the review was conducted in two parts: A, a systematic review of all assessments of “low-intensity” interventions ' conducted by para-professionals, peer supporters or psychological well-being practitioners in terms of improving access to the psychological therapy program; and B, a scoping review of relevant evaluations of interventions involving qualified mental health professionals (e.g., psychiatrists, clinical psychologists, cognitive-behavioural therapists) that involved < 6 hours of contact per patient. DATA SOURCES: Extensive literature reviews were developed; electronic databases were searched from inception through September 2010 (including MEDLINE, MEDLINE In-Process & Other Non-Indexed Citations, PsycINFO, EMBASE, The Cochrane Library), Internet resources were used to identify depression treatment guidelines and the bibliographies of relevant reviews, guidelines and included studies were questioned. REVIEW METHODS: Two reviewers independently reviewed titles and abstracts; Data were independently extracted by one reviewer using a standardized data extraction form and verified by another. Discrepancies were resolved by consensus, involving a third reviewer where necessary. Inclusion criteria were population - adults or adolescents who had received treatment for depression; Intervention – Part A, low-intensity interventions, specifically any unsupported psychological/psychosocial interventions or any supported interventions that did not involve highly qualified mental health professionals, and Part B, interventions delivered by qualified mental health professionals and less than 6 hours of contact per patient; comparator - any, including no treatment, placebo, psychological or pharmacological interventions; Outcomes - relapse or recurrence, other outcomes (e.g., social functioning, quality of life) were recorded if reported; and study design - randomized, quasi-randomized and non-randomized studies with concurrent control patients for clinical efficacy. For cost-effectiveness, full economic assessments comparing two or more treatment options, considering both costs and consequences. No study met the inclusion criteria for Part A. RESULTS: For the review of clinical efficacy, 17 studies (14 completed, three ongoing) reported in 27 publications met the inclusion criteria of Part B. These studies were clinically and methodologically diverse and reported about different degrees of effectiveness for the evaluated interventions. A randomized controlled trial (RCT) evaluating a collaborative care program was potentially relevant to Part A; This study reported no difference between patients receiving the intervention and those receiving usual care in terms of depression recurrence over a 12-month period. For the cost-benefit review, two studies met the criteria for Part B. One was an economic assessment of the RCT above that was potentially relevant for Part A. This assessment concluded that the intervention can be a cost-effective application of resources compared to usual care; However, it was unclear how valid these estimates were for the NHS. LIMITATIONS: Although any definition of "short" is likely to be somewhat arbitrary, an inclusion threshold of 6 hours of contact per patient was used to select short high-intensity intervention studies. Most excluded studies clearly evaluated resource-intensive interventions, although occasionally studies were excluded based on just a little over 6 hours of contact per patient. CONCLUSIONS: There is insufficient evidence to determine the clinical efficacy or cost-effectiveness of low-intensity interventions in preventing depression recurrence or recurrence. A scoping review of short, high-intensity therapies shows that some approaches have shown promise in some studies, but the results have not been consistent. Many uncertainties remain and more primary research is required. The scope of such research should be carefully considered; It is important to evaluate the broader patient pathway that takes into account the heterogeneous patient populations of interest. Future RCTs conducted in a UK primary care setting should include adult participants in remission or recovery from depression and, where appropriate, assess the quality of the intervention and consistency of delivery by all practitioners. The incidence of recurrence or recurrence should be measured using established methods, and functional outcomes and symptoms should be measured.” Quality of life data using a generic instrument such as FUNDING: The Health Technology Assessment Program of the National Institutes for Health Research.

title: The clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of screening for anal intraepithelial squamous lesions in homosexual and bisexual HIV-positive men
abstract: Context Gay and bisexual men infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) are at increased risk of human papillomavirus-associated anal neoplasia and anal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Aim To assess the clinical utility and cost-effectiveness of screening HIV-positive gay and bisexual men for anal squamous intraepithelial lesions (ASIL) and anal SCC. Design Cost-effectiveness analysis from a societal perspective using reference case recommendations from the Panel on Cost-Effectiveness in Health and Medicine. A state-transition Markov model was developed to calculate lifetime costs, life expectancy, and quality-adjusted life expectancy without screening versus multiple screening strategies for ASIL and anal SCC using anal Papanicolaou (Pap) tests at different intervals . Scores for incidence, progression, and regression of anal neoplasia", effectiveness of screening and treatment, natural history of HIV, health-related quality of life;" and costs were taken from the literature. Setting and Participants Hypothetical cohort of homosexual and bisexual HIV-positive men living in the United States. Main outcome measures Life expectancy, quality-adjusted life expectancy, quality-adjusted life years saved, lifetime cost and incremental cost-benefit ratio. Results Screening for ASIL increased quality-adjusted life expectancy at all stages of HIV disease. Screening with anal Pap tests every 2 years starting with early HIV disease (CD4 count > 0.50 × 109/L) resulted in a 2.7-month improvement in quality-adjusted life expectancy with an additional cost-benefit Ratio of $13,000 per quality-adjusted life year saved. Annual screening with anal Pap tests offered additional benefits at an additional cost of $16,600 per quality-adjusted life-year saved. If screening was initiated later in the course of HIV disease (CD4 cell count < 0.50 × 109/L), then annual Pap test screening was preferred due to the greater number of prevalent anal disorders (cost-effectiveness of less than $25,000 saved per quality-adjusted life-year compared to no screening). Screening every 6 months provided little additional benefit over annual screening. The results were most sensitive to the rate of progression from ASIL to anal SCC and the effectiveness of treatment of precancerous lesions. Conclusions Screening HIV-positive gay and bisexual men for ASIL and anal SCC with anal Pap testing offers quality-adjusted life expectancy benefits at a cost comparable to other accepted clinical preventive interventions.

title: The clinician-examiner: unavoidable but controllable tension
abstract: The "difference position" states that clinical research and therapeutic medical practice are sufficiently different activities to require different ethical rules and principles. The "similarity position" instead states that clinical investigators should be bound by the same fundamental principles that govern therapeutic medicine - specifically, a duty to provide each patient or subject with the optimal therapeutic benefit. Some defenders of the similarity position defend it because of the overlap between the treating physician's role and the investigator's role in a research trial. This overlap is at a maximum when the same physician fills both roles in relation to a particular patient subject. We address the ethical tensions inherent in this role conflict, arguing that the tensions are real but manageable. The difference position provides a solid ethical framework within which to manage these tensions, while the similarity position is unsatisfactory because it attempts to deny the existence of the tensions.

title: The CLUES study: a cluster-randomized clinical study to evaluate the implementation of cardiovascular guidelines in primary care
