abstract: BACKGROUND: Appropriate care for people with cardiovascular risk factors can reduce morbidity and mortality. One strategy to improve care for these patients is to implement evidence-based guidelines. To date, little research has been published on the impact of such implementation strategies in our environment. Goals. To evaluate the effectiveness of a multifaceted tailored intervention in the implementation of three cardiovascular risk-related guidelines (hypertension, type 2 diabetes and dyslipidemia) in primary care in the Basque health service compared to usual implementation. METHODS/DESIGN: A two-year cluster-randomized clinical trial in primary care in two districts of the Basque Health Service. All primary care units are randomized. Data from all patients with diabetes, hypertension and patients susceptible to screening for coronary risk will be analyzed.Interventions. The control group receives a standard implementation. The experimental group will receive a multi-faceted tailor-made implementation strategy, including a dedicated website and workshops for GPs and nurses. endpoints. Primary endpoints: annual requirement for glycated hemoglobin, basic laboratory tests for hypertension, cardiovascular risk screening (females 45-74 and males 40-74 years old). Secondary endpoints: other process and clinical guideline indicators. ANALYSIS: Data is extracted from centralized computerized medical records. The ANALYSIS is performed at the primary care unit level, weighted by cluster size. DISCUSSION: The main contribution of our study is that it attempts to identify an effective strategy for the implementation of cardiovascular guidelines in primary care in our setting. STUDY REGISTRATION: Current Controlled Trials, ISRCTN88876909.

title: The Colorado Asthma Toolkit Program: a practice coaching intervention from the High Plains Research Network
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Asthma is often underdiagnosed and undertreated in primary care. The Colorado Asthma Toolkit program was initiated to establish a method for improving asthma care by providing primary care practices with coaching, training, and support for (1) evidence-based asthma diagnosis and treatment, and (2) educating and enabling patients to use effective treatment are offered self-management of their illness. METHODS: A collaborative program was initiated involving two academic medical institutions and the High Plains Research Network, a practice-based primary care research network in eastern Colorado. Focus groups were conducted with rural Colorado patients and health care physicians to assess needs and determine the most effective intervention strategies. Two intertwined training programs or 'toolkits' were then developed, one each for physicians and patients. Clinicians received 3 coaching sessions delivered by 2 practice nurses, including training in guideline-based methods for assessing and managing asthma, coaching to support practices in implementing these methods, and training in communication techniques to promote asthma self-management . The practices also received a spirometer and were trained in its use and interpretation. Patient self-management toolkits were provided to clinicians, who were trained to use the materials to educate patients and increase adherence to therapy. The evaluations were based on practical interviews 1 to 3 months after the coaching. RESULTS: Coaching occurred in 57 of the 58 primary care practices in eastern rural and semirural Colorado. The offices reported changes in their asthma management behavior: (1) 40.4% of offices increased their use of inhaled corticosteroids, with the median percentage of patients using inhaled corticosteroids increasing from 25% to 50%; (2) 53.2% of practices increased their use of inhaled corticosteroids Use of asthma action plans, with the median percentage of patients with action plans increasing from 0% to 20%; and (3) 78.7% of practices started use of spirometry or increased their use, resulting in an increase in mean use from 0% to 30%. CONCLUSION: The Colorado Asthma Toolkit program has successfully disseminated asthma care education to most rural health care practices. The acceptance in the practices was attributed to the flexible coaching in the practice and the provision of spirometry. Significant changes seen in asthma management practices are likely to reduce hospitalizations and emergency room visits.

title: The Community Physicians' Network (CPN): a science-community partnership to close health inequalities
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Health care inequalities are perpetuated by three main factors: 1) patient factors, which include multiple risk factors and comorbidities; 2) physician factors, which include inconsistent application of practice guidelines due to a limited database of clinical trials of effective therapies in African Americans and other underrepresented minorities, and 3) barriers in the health care system resulting in poor access to care. The Morehouse School of Medicine Community Physicians' Network (CPN) was formed to address inequalities in healthcare by focusing on provider-specific strategies. OBJECTIVES: To: 1) use disease-specific registries to identify treatment gaps and facilitate quality improvement processes between CPN practices; 2) develop practice-specific and guideline-based educational messages to promote quality care; 3) Engage and train CPN physicians to participate in approved NIH, other government, and industry-supported clinical protocols; and 4) Developing a data archive of all CPN-sponsored clinical trials that include significant numbers of African Americans and other underrepresented minorities. METHODS: The disease-specific outpatient registries will have the following features: 1) data structures and data elements will use standard database codes and a data dictionary; 2) HIPPA compliant data abstraction and data transfer tool; 3) Review of baseline plots to establish practice patterns and provide practice-specific feedback; 4) annual update of the register; 5) Data registration and storage maintained on Morehouse School of Medicine's secure servers; 6) Register publications contain only aggregated data, without identification of contributing practices; 7) An Electronic Health Records platform will be promoted as the ultimate data management tool for CPN practices. In addition, up to three Continuing Medical Education (CME) programs are conducted each year with national speakers and evidence-based practice guidelines are promoted. RESULTS: 85 primary care and subspecialty practices are actively enrolled in CPN with a total of 385,000 outpatient visits per year. The composition of insurance status is: HMO/PPO (45%); Medicare only (19%); Medicare HMO (11%); Medicare plus (8%); Medicaid (6%); “Not insured” (11%). CONCLUSIONS: The Community Physicians' Network will fill specific gaps in healthcare for African American and other minority patients by promoting quality care among its members and facilitating participation in approved clinical trials. The unique partnership with the academic community is consistent with the goal of the NIH roadmap to eliminate inequalities in health care.

title: Compensation for patients injured in clinical trials
abstract: The issue of no-fault compensation for patients who experience adverse events as a result of their participation in clinical trials is discussed in light of the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry (ABPI) guidelines and our recent experience in reviewing protocols at the local Sub-Committee on Ethics of submitted to surgical research. We have identified a multitude of disparagements by pharmaceutical companies that are not in the best interests of the guidelines, let alone the interests of patients, and propose a way to assure patients of fair treatment in the event of a 'no mistake' .

title: The context of antibiotic overuse
The cost-effectiveness and population outcomes of expanded HIV screening and antiretroviral treatment in the United States
abstract: Background Although recent guidelines call for expanded routine screening for HIV, resources for antiretroviral treatment (ART) are limited and all eligible individuals are currently not being treated. Objective To assess the impact of expanded ART, HIV screening, or interventions on the US HIV epidemic to reduce risk behavior.DesignDynamic mathematical model of HIV transmission and disease progression, and cost-benefit analysis.Data sourcesPublished literature.Target populationHigh-risk individuals ( injectors, men who have sex with men) and low-risk individuals aged 15 to 64 in the US 20-year time horizon and lifetime (costs and QALYs).PerspectiveSociety.InterventionsExpanded HIV screening and counseling, treatment with ART or both.Outcome measuresNew HIV infections, reduced costs and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), and incremental cost-effectiveness ratios.Outcomes Base-case analysisOne-time HIV screening of low-risk individuals coupled with annual screening of high-risk individuals could 6,7 % of p predicted to prevent 1.23 million new infections and cost $22,382/QALY assuming a 20% reduction in sexual activity after screening. Extending ART use to 75% of eligible individuals prevents 10.3% of infections and costs $20,300/QALY gained. A combination strategy prevents 17.3% of infections and costs $21,580/QALY achieved. Results Sensitivity Analysis Without restricting sexual activity, extended screening prevented 3.7% of infections. Earlier ART initiation, when CD4>350 cells/mL, prevents 20–28% of infections. Additional efforts to halve high-risk behaviors could reduce infections by 65%.LimitationsSimplified model of disease progression and treatment";" Exclusion of acute HIV screening. Conclusions Expanding HIV screening and treatment at the same time offers the greatest health benefits and is cost-effective. However, even significant expansion of HIV screening and treatment programs will not be enough to significantly reduce the HIV epidemic in the US without significantly reducing risk behavior ) and the US Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: The cost, clinical utility, and cost-effectiveness of screening for cervical cancer in HIV-infected women
abstract: Background: HIV-infected women are at higher risk of cervical squamous intraepithelial lesions than non-HIV-infected women, and the optimal regimen for screening for cervical cancer in these women is uncertain. Aim: To evaluate the net health consequences, costs, and cost-effectiveness of different screening strategies for cervical neoplasia and cancer in HIV-infected women. Design: A cost-benefit analysis from a societal perspective conducted using a state-transition Markov model. Incidence, progression, and regression scores of cervical neoplasia"; effectiveness of screening and treatment; progression of HIV disease; mortality from HIV infection and cancer; quality of life;" and costs were taken from the literature. Setting: Simulated clinical practice in the United States. Patients: HIV-infected females representative of the US population. Intervention: Six main screening strategies, no screening, annual Papanicolaou smears, annual Papanicolaou smears after two negative smears 6 months apart (recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention), biannual Papanicolaou smears, annual colposcopy, and six-monthly colposcopy were taken into account. Effectiveness. Results: Annual Papanicolaou swab screening resulted in a 2.1-month improvement in quality-adjusted life expectancy at an additional cost of $12,800 per QALY saved. Annual Papanicolaou swab screening after two negative swabs 6 months apart yielded an additional 0.04 QALYs at a cost of $14,800 per QALY saved. The biannual Papanicolaou swab screening provided an additional 0.17 QALYs at a cost of $27,600 per QALY saved. Annual colposcopy cost more but provided no additional benefit compared to biannual Papanicolaou swab screening, and biannual colposcopy exceeded $375,000 per QALY saved. The results were most sensitive to the rate of progression from neoplasia to invasive cancer. Conclusions: In HIV-infected women, cervical cancer screening with annual Papanicolaou smears after two negative smears 6 months apart provides quality-adjusted life expectancy benefits at a cost comparable to other clinical preventive interventions.

title: The current situation of health research and ethics in Sudan
abstract: At the beginning of the 20th century, health research in Sudan developed primarily as a function of the British colonial administration. Ethical issues in the medical profession in Sudan are regulated by the Sudan Medical Council. To address these issues, the Sudan Medical Council issued medico-legal and ethical guidelines in 1967. This important document mainly focuses on ethical issues that arise in clinical medicine. In the history of health research in Sudan, it is very difficult to relate to research ethics. Nevertheless, there have been some attempts to articulate ethics in health research. In 1979, Sudan witnessed the establishment of the first Ethics Committee, formed at the initiative of a group of doctors and scientists from the National Health Research Laboratory. This committee found neither political nor institutional recognition. Therefore, it was not developed and ended shortly after its introduction. However, in 2000 FMOH established an Ethical Review Committee (ERC). The role of this committee was to review, independently of the funders, ethical research proposals for health research to be conducted in the country. Unfortunately, the committee dedicated all tasks to reviewing only externally funded health research and research conducted by foreign researchers or international organizations.

title: Demonstrating a theory-based approach to designing localized patient safety interventions.
abstract: Background There is evidence of insecure care in healthcare systems worldwide. Interventions to implement recommended practice often have modest and variable impacts. Ideally, selecting and tailoring interventions to local contexts should enhance impact. However, the means by which this can be done are rarely systematic, theory-based, or made transparent. This work aimed to demonstrate the applicability, feasibility and acceptability of a Theory Domains Framework Implementation (TDFI) approach for the collaborative design of patient safety interventions. Methods We worked with three hospitals to support the implementation of evidence-based guidelines to reduce the risk of feeding from misplaced gastric tubes. Our staged process, based on the TDF and key principles from the implementation literature, included: stakeholder engagement, identifying target behaviors, identifying local factors (barriers and levers) influencing behavior change, using a TDF-based questionnaire, collaborating with Stakeholders to provide specific local strategies to overcome key barriers and support stakeholders in implementing strategies Exit interviews and audit data collection were conducted to assess the feasibility and acceptability of this approach Results After review and discussion, the implementation teams for each trust identified the Pre-feed feeding tube verification process as a key target behavior Questionnaire results revealed differences in key barriers between organizations. Focus groups developed innovative, generalized Buildable and customizable strategies to overcome obstacles, such as z rces. Exit interviews identified issues related to the benefits, challenges and sustainability of this approach. Time-trend audit data were collected for 301 patients over an 18-month period for one trust, suggesting clinically significant improved application of pH and documentation of practice post-intervention. Conclusions The TDF is a practical and acceptable framework to guide the implementation of patient safety interventions. The tiered TDFI approach engages health professionals and facilitates contextualization in identifying target behaviors, identifying local barriers, and selecting strategies to overcome those barriers. This approach may be of use to implementation teams and policy makers, although our promising results confirm the need for more rigorous assessment; a balanced block evaluation is currently underway.

title: Design and evaluation of a graphical representation for laboratory data
abstract: Objective Advances in healthcare information technology have created ways to represent data in new, more effective ways. In this study, we designed a laboratory display containing small, high-density graphics called sparklines, which have recently been promoted as effective representations of medical data but have not been well studied. The impact of this novel display on how physicians interpret data was studied. Design Twelve physicians chatted loudly as they reviewed laboratory data from four patients in a pediatric intensive care unit using the chart display and a traditional spreadsheet display. Measurements verbalizations were coded based on the abnormal values and trends identified for each laboratory variable. The consistency of interpretations of variables in each display was evaluated, and patterns were examined between participants. The evaluation time was also analyzed. Results Physicians completed assessments significantly faster using the graphical display (3.6 min vs. 4.4 min, p=0.042). When comparing between displays, 37% of interpretations disagreed. Charts were more useful when the visual cues in tables did not provide trend information, while slightly abnormal values were easier to identify with tables. Conclusions Data presentation format can affect how physicians interpret laboratory data. Graphic displays have several advantages over numeric displays, but are not always optimal. User, task and data characteristics should be considered when designing information displays.

title: The development of an intervention to promote adherence to national guidelines for suspected viral encephalitis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Central nervous system infections can have devastating clinical consequences if not timely diagnosed and treated. There is a documented gap between recommended and actual practice and limited understanding of its causes. We have identified and investigated the reasons for this gap, focusing on points in the patient's care pathway most amenable to change and developing a tailored intervention strategy to improve diagnosis and treatment. METHODS: Using theory-based, semi-structured interviews, we investigated barriers and options for the diagnosis and treatment of patients with suspected encephalitis, specifically performing lumbar puncture and initiating antiviral therapy within 6 hours. We deliberately sampled hospitals and hospital staff in the UK. We recorded and transcribed all interviews prior to scoping analysis. We have mapped identified barriers and enablers for the patient journey. We matched behavior change techniques targeting clinicians with key barriers and enablers and embedded them in an intervention package. RESULTS: We surveyed 43 staff in six hospitals. Clinical staff expressed uncertainty about when and how spinal taps should be performed and pointed out practical difficulties in performing them in a busy clinical setting. Once the need for treatment was triggered, clinicians generally felt able to take appropriate therapeutic action, albeit within organizational and resource constraints. Adapted behavior modification techniques have largely targeted the history of treatment. This included decision support for quick detection, showing the consequences of missed diagnoses for clinicians and patients, and practical support for spinal taps. We then developed an evidence-based package that includes “core” interventions and, to allow for local flexibility, “optional” interventions. CONCLUSIONS: We identified several points in the patient pathway where practice could be improved, with the most critical point being clinical suspicion and initial assessment. Interventions that target professional beliefs and behaviors while optimizing their clinical setting have been among the most promising approaches to improving care for suspected encephalitis. STUDY REGISTRATION: Randomized study registered with Controlled Trials ISRCTN06886935.

title: The development of an intervention to promote adherence to national guidelines for suspected viral encephalitis.
abstract: Background Infections of the central nervous system can have devastating clinical consequences if not diagnosed and treated in a timely manner. There is a documented gap between recommended and actual practice and limited understanding of its causes. We have identified and investigated the reasons for this gap, focusing on points in the patient's care pathway most amenable to change and developing a tailored intervention strategy to improve diagnosis and treatment. Methods Using theoretically informed semi-structured interviews, we investigated barriers and options for the diagnosis and treatment of patients with suspected encephalitis, specifically performing lumbar puncture and initiating antiviral therapy within 6 hours. We deliberately sampled hospitals and hospital staff in the UK. We recorded and transcribed all interviews prior to scoping analysis. We have mapped identified barriers and enablers for the patient journey. We matched behavior change techniques targeting clinicians with key barriers and enablers and embedded them in an intervention package. Results We interviewed 43 employees in six hospitals. Clinical staff expressed uncertainty about when and how spinal taps should be performed and pointed out practical difficulties in performing them in a busy clinical setting. Once the need for treatment was triggered, clinicians generally felt able to take appropriate therapeutic action, albeit within organizational and resource constraints. Adapted behavior modification techniques have largely targeted the history of treatment. This included decision support for quick detection, showing the consequences of missed diagnoses for clinicians and patients, and practical support for spinal taps. We then developed an evidence-based package that includes “core” interventions and, to allow for local flexibility, “optional” interventions. Conclusions We have identified several points in the patient pathway where practice could be improved, with the most critical point being clinical suspicion and initial assessment. Interventions that target professional beliefs and behaviors while optimizing their clinical setting have been among the most promising approaches to improving care for suspected encephalitis.

title: The development of evidence-based psychotherapy for use in alcoholism. a review
abstract: In the last few decades, tremendous progress has been made in the development and validation of evidence-based approaches to the psychotherapy of alcoholism. While psychoanalytic and early behavioral techniques were the original foundation of psychotherapy in this area, evidence-based approaches today build on the principles of motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy. Various techniques have been developed to modify antecedent and ongoing conditions that favor problem behaviors, e.g. B. Training in coping/social skills and the community empowerment approach. According to the results of the MATCH project, one of the largest treatment studies, the "cognitive behavioral intervention" combines motivational enhancement therapy, the 12-step approach and cognitive behavioral therapy with the aim of providing a new and even more effective psychotherapy for alcohol-dependent patients. However, these promising developments are fraught with major problems in that only a few of the new evidence-based treatment approaches are accepted as standard treatment in Germany and, moreover, only a fraction of all alcohol dependents in this country make it into the care system, for various reasons. Early diagnosis and facilitating access to the different treatment options available could be a future task for general practitioners and also for occupational health systems.

title: The dirty dozen: 12 sources of bias in forensic neuropsychology with ways to mitigate.
abstract: The ever-growing role of a forensic neuropsychologist in civil litigation has rightly led to higher expectations of this expert in areas such as clinical and forensic knowledge, objectivity, and the usefulness of the work product. It is the responsibility of the forensic neuropsychologist to ensure that these expectations are met. Given that biases are inherent in clinical and forensic work, it is imperative that in high-stakes situations such as forensic neuropsychological assessment, the assessor proactively and conscientiously recognize and minimize the impact of these biases. This article highlights 12 of many common biases that the prudent forensic neuropsychologist should always consider when evaluating, as well as making statements or process statements. Role, cognitive and practice bias are defined and illustrated with examples. Concrete suggestions for recognizing and reducing these prejudices are taken from both empirical literature and forensic experience. The information contained in this article is intended to provide sound and practical strategies that may be useful to forensic neuropsychology practitioners. Lawyers will also find the content useful when working with such experts, including during deposition and preparation for cross-examination. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

title: The economy-wide impact of pandemic influenza in the UK: a computable general equilibrium modeling experiment
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess the potential economic impact of an influenza pandemic, associated behavioral responses, school closures and vaccination in the UK. DESIGN A computable general equilibrium model of the UK economy was specified for various combinations of mortality and morbidity from pandemic influenza, vaccine effectiveness, school closures and prophylactic absenteeism using published data. SETTING The UK Economy 2004 (the most recent data available with appropriate economic data). KEY OUTCOME MEASURES The economic impact of different scenarios with different severity of the pandemic, vaccination, school closures and prophylactic absenteeism, given in terms of gross domestic product, the performance of different economic sectors and corresponding fluctuations. RESULTS The cost of disease alone ranged from 0.5% to 1.0% of gross domestic product (£8.4bn to £16.8bn) for low death scenarios, 3.3% and 4.3% (55, £5bn to £72.3bn) for high-fat scenarios, and even larger for an extreme pandemic. School closures increase the economic impact, especially during mild pandemics. If widespread behavior change occurs and large-scale prophylactic absence from work occurs, the economic impact would be significantly increased with small health benefits. Vaccination with a prepandemic vaccine could save 0.13% to 2.3% of gross domestic product ($2.2bn to $38.6bn);" and two doses of a matched vaccine could reduce the overall economic impact to about 1% for all disease scenarios % of gross domestic product CONCLUSION Balancing school closures with business as usual and obtaining adequate supplies of effective vaccines are more important factors in determining the economic impact of an influenza pandemic than the disease itself increase significantly.

title: The EDUCATE study: an exemplary further education example for the implementation of guidelines in clinical practice
abstract: Cancer care is evolving from a solitary practitioner delivery system based on tradition and anecdotal experience to a multidisciplinary, collaborative, science-based paradigm. Evidence-based practice enables optimal quality of care for cancer patients and is achieved for medical and nursing practitioners through the implementation of clinical practice guidelines. Clinical education based on the principles of adult education is a method of implementing clinical practice guidelines in clinical practice. However, research shows that traditional static parenting methods do little to change behavior";" Instead, effective education involves interactive formats, provides feedback, and incorporates reminder and reinforcement strategies. The EDUCATE study (Educating Clinicians to Achieve Treatment Guideline Effectiveness) offers a model for the implementation of guidelines in clinical practice with pedagogical methods. A faculty of nursing educators, along with practice champions, delivered an intensive educational intervention consisting of multiple teaching/learning activities over a 12-month period in community oncology practices across the United States. In addition to an overview of clinical practice guidelines and pedagogical methods that can be used for the implementation of clinical practice guidelines, the obstacles and experiences from the EDUCATE study and recommendations for implementation in practice are presented.

title: The effect of a computerized reminder system on the prevention of postoperative venous thromboembolism
abstract: Study objective To measure the effect of a modified treatment process guided by a computerized reminder system on the rates of symptomatic postoperative venous thromboembolism. Design comparisons of preinterventional and postinterventional measurements. Setting A university-affiliated community hospital in Utah. Patients Two thousand seventy-seven consecutive patients who underwent major surgery between January 1, 1997 and October 31, 1997 (prior to the intervention) in four surgical departments and 2,093 consecutive patients who underwent between January 1, 1998 and October 31, 1998 had undergone the same interventions ,1998 (after intervention). Intervention A venous thromboembolism prevention program developed using guidelines from the American College of Chest Physicians and a modified workflow driven by a computerized reminder system. Measurements Rates of symptomatic, objectively confirmed deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and death from venous thromboembolism occurring within 90 days of the date of surgery. Results The preintervention and postintervention cohorts did not differ in terms of age, disease severity, number of risk factors for venous thromboembolism, or individual risk factors for venous thromboembolism. The overall prophylaxis rate increased from 89.9% before introduction of the computerized reminder system to 95.0% after introduction (p < 0.0001). The 90-day combined rate of symptomatic DVT, PE, and death due to PE remained the same (pre-intervention 1.0%; post-intervention 1.2%; odds ratio 1.21; 95% CI: 0.67 to 2.20). Forty of 46 venous thromboembolic complications (87%) occurred despite American College of Chest Physicians-recommended venous thromboembolic prevention measures. Conclusions Computerized reminder systems combined with modified care regimens increase the rate of prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism without reducing the rate of symptomatic venous thromboembolism when the baseline rate of prophylaxis is high. There is a population of surgical patients who are resistant to prophylactic measures for venous thromboembolism recommended by the American College of Chest Physicians. New strategies are needed to address prophylaxis-resistant venous thromboembolism.

title: The effect of a mobile clinical decision support system on the diagnosis of obesity and overweight in acute and primary care settings.
abstract: The purpose of the study was to compare the proportion of obesity-related diagnoses in clinical encounters (N=1874) documented by nurses using a personal digital assistant-based protocol with and without obesity decision support features. The experimental group encounters in the randomized controlled trial had significantly more (P=0.000) obesity-related diagnoses (11.3%) than the control group encounters (1%) and a significantly lower false-negative rate (24.5% versus 66.5%, P=0.000). The study results demonstrate that the integration of a decision support function that automatically calculates an obesity-related diagnosis increases diagnoses and decreases missed diagnoses, and suggest that such systems have the potential to improve the quality of obesity-related care. Obesity and overweight pose a public health challenge and are the target of public health prevention goals in the United States.1 Obesity and overweight have been underestimated as diseases, resulting in many obese patients not receiving appropriate interventions.2 ,3 Prevention and treatment of obesity and overweight involves a complex and dynamic set of processes,4 and the integration of relevant evidence into practice is required to improve obesity management.5,6 Clinical practice guidelines can be used as a tool for providing an evidence-based serve practice”; However, few studies have been conducted involving nurses, and methodological problems limit the generalizability of their results.7 Although advanced nurses have the potential to play a central role in the prevention and treatment of obesity and overweight, there is little empirical evidence for their adherence to guidelines, and therefore research is needed to explore effective strategies to support policy implementation.8 The purpose of this study was to compare the proportion of obesity-related diagnoses (obesity and overweight) in clinical encounters that were associated with an on A personal digital assistant-based clinical decision support system compared to a personal digital assistant-based clinical protocol without obesity decision support capabilities.

title: The effect of a patient-centered treatment bundle intervention on pressure ulcer incidence (INTACT): A cluster-randomized study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hospital-acquired pressure ulcers are a serious patient safety issue associated with poor patient outcomes and high healthcare costs. They are also used as an indicator of the quality of care. AIM: To evaluate the effectiveness of a pressure ulcer prevention package in preventing hospital-acquired pressure ulcers in at-risk patients. DESIGN: Pragmatic cluster-randomized study. SETTING: Eight tertiary referral hospitals, each with >200 beds, in three Australian states. PARTICIPANTS: 1600 patients (200/hospital) were recruited. Patients were eligible if they were: >/=18 years old; were at risk of pressure ulcers due to reduced mobility; expected to stay >/=48 hours in the hospital and be able to read English. METHODS: Hospitals (clusters) were stratified into two strata groups according to recent pressure ulcer rates and randomized within strata to receive either a pressure ulcer prevention treatment package or standard care. The treatment package was theoretically and empirically based on patient involvement and clinical practice guidelines. It consisted of several components and contained three messages for patients. Participating in Pressure Ulcer Prevention: Keep Moving, Take Care of Your Skin and Eat Healthy Patient training tools included a DVD, brochure and poster Nurses in intervention hospitals were trained to work with patients on their pressure ulcer prevention. The statisticians, recruiters, and outcome evaluators were blinded to group assignment, and the interventionists were good to the study hypotheses tested at both the cluster and patient levels. The primary outcome, the incidence of hospital-acquired pressure ulcers, which was true at both the cluster and individual participant levels, was measured by daily skin inspection. RESULTS: Four clusters were randomized to each group, and 799 patients per group were analyzed. The intraclass correlation coefficient was 0.035. After adjusting for clustering and pre-determined covariates (age, pressure ulcer present at baseline, body mass index, reason for admission, place of residence, and number of comorbidities at admission), the hazard ratio developed for new pressure ulcers (pressure ulcer prevention care package relative to standard of care) was 0, 58 (95% CI: 0.25, 1.33; p=0.198). No adverse events or harm were reported. There was a high degree of uncertainty around this estimate and the difference was not statistically significant. Possible explanations for this non-significant result are that the care package was effective in preventing pressure ulcers, but the sample size was too small to tell.

title: The impact of adding pap smear information to a mammography reminder system in an HMO: results of a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background While reminders can enhance cancer prevention in primary care, little is known about the possible interaction between multiple reminders. Methods We conducted a randomized controlled trial to compare the effect of combined Pap smear plus mammography reminders and mammography reminders in 2471 women aged 40 years or older enrolled in a healthcare organization that had a predominantly Medicaid eligible population. The reminders included both a mailed letter for the woman and a request for medical records. Results Intervention assignment was not associated with differences in the frequency of visits to primary care physicians or internal medicine specialists or completion of a mammogram during the academic year. Compared to women assigned to mammography reminder treatment alone, those assigned to the combined Pap smear plus mammography reminder intervention were more likely to visit a gynecologist (34% vs. 29%, adjusted odds ratio = 1, 33, 95% confidence interval 1.08). "1.63) and to perform a Pap smear (30% vs. 23%, adjusted odds ratio = 1.39, 95% confidence interval 1.07-1.89). Conclusions Within the study, the addition of a Pap smear to mammography reminders has a procedure-specific effect that increases OB visits and Pap smear use, while neither increasing nor decreasing other primary care visits or mammography. We find no evidence of reinforcement or competition between these memories.

title: The effect of computer reminders on general practitioner prescribing behavior: a cluster-randomized study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Despite the development and dissemination of guidelines, it is difficult to control the prescribing behavior of drugs in general practitioners' practices. The purpose of this study was to assess the effect on drug prescribing behavior through the implementation of prescribing guidelines using a computer reactive reminder system (CRS). DESIGN: Cluster randomized controlled trial with incomplete block design in the south of the Netherlands: 25 GPs (7 GP practices) received antibiotic and asthma/COPD prescription reminders, 28 GP (7 GP practices) received cholesterol prescription reminders. Prescription guidelines were integrated into the computer-assisted general practitioner information system. MEASUREMENTS: Both performance indicators and prescription volume were calculated as key outcome measures. In addition to the individual volume measurement, total values for the volume measurements per drug group (antibiotics, asthma/COPD and cholesterol) were formed. RESULTS: The variation between primary care physicians turned out to be larger and more biased than expected. No differences were found between the groups for indicators and volumes related to recommendations for endorsement of specific drugs. Although clinically relevant results tended to be recorded with supposedly decreasing prescription quantities, the difference in the total score between the groups was not significant. For antibiotic prescriptions that should decrease, the total score for the intervention group was 28.2 (95% CI: 20.8–44.5) prescriptions per 1000 patients per general practitioner, for the control it was 39.7 (95% CI : 29.7-64.1). group (p0.2). For asthma/COPD prescriptions that should decrease, the total score for the intervention group was 1.1 (95% CI: 0.6–2.6) prescriptions per 1000 patients per general practitioner, for the prescriptions it was 2.2 ( 95% CI: 1.4-4.3). the control group (p 0.1). Significant differences were found for three specific recommendations (on quinolones for cystitis, corticosteroids for CPOD, and antibiotics for acute sore throat). CONCLUSIONS: This study proved to be underpowered due to the large differences in prescribing behavior between physicians. Nevertheless, computer-assisted reminders sometimes have a favorable effect on the restriction of certain medications that are not or no longer indicated in the general practitioner's practice.

title: The effect of educational intervention on the acquisition of medical diagnoses in residents
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Studies indicate that the use of interventions, including education, can improve medical record documentation and reduce incomplete records. Because physicians play a critical role in documenting medical records, the researchers intend to examine the effect of educational interventions on physician performance and knowledge of the principles of recording medical diagnoses among residents of the Hormozgan University of Medical Sciences (HUMS). METHODS: This quasi-experimental study was conducted in 2010 on 40 medical specialists (internal medicine, obstetrics and gynaecology, paediatrics, anesthesiology and surgery) at the Hormozgan University of Medical Sciences. During a workshop, guidelines for collecting diagnostic information related to the respective specialty were given. Before and after the intervention, five medical records were selected from each resident to assess the physician's record keeping performance. The knowledge of the physicians before and after the intervention was surveyed by means of a questionnaire. The data were analyzed by a one-way ANOVA test. RESULTS: The change in physician knowledge before and after training was not statistically significant (p = 0.15). The behavior of the residents did not change statistically significantly in three phases of the study. CONCLUSION: The diversity of related factors contributing to the quality of documentation compels a portfolio of strategies to improve medical records. Employing a combination of best practice efforts, including training physicians from the start of the internship and applying a targeted strategy that focuses on problem areas and existing gaps, can improve physician record keeping behaviors.

title: The effect of external feedback on the management of Medicare inpatients with congestive heart failure
abstract: The purpose of this study was to compare the effect of 2 feedback strategies on adherence to congestive heart failure (CHF) guidelines. Thirty-two hospitals in 4 states were randomized to receive either a written feedback intervention (low-intensity intervention [LII]) or an intervention with feedback, physician contact, and quality improvement tools (high-intensity intervention [HII]). The CHF quality indicators were assessed and quality managers were interviewed at start-up and re-measurement. No significant changes in quality indicators were found as a result of either intervention. 78% of the quality managers stated that the implementation of hospital projects only started shortly before the re-evaluation. HII quality managers found the CHF project to be significantly more successful compared to LII quality managers (63% versus 13%, P<0.01). Evaluating the impact of external feedback on practice behavior requires sufficient time for organizational and individual clinical changes. Liaison doctors can play a role in facilitating this change.

title: The effect of mobile phone SMS reminders on adherence to malaria treatment guidelines by Kenyan health workers: a randomized cluster study
abstract: Background Health care workers' malaria case management practices often deviate from national guidelines. We assessed whether SMS reminders sent to healthcare workers' mobile phones could improve and maintain their adherence to treatment guidelines for outpatient pediatric malaria in Kenya. Methods From March 6, 2009 to May 31, 2010, we conducted a cluster-randomized controlled trial in 107 rural health facilities in 11 districts in coastal and western Kenya. Using a computer-generated sequence, health facilities were randomly assigned to either the intervention group, in which all health workers received malaria case management text messages on their personal mobile phones for 6 months, or the control group, in which health workers received no text messages. Healthcare workers were not masked at the intervention, although patients did not know whether they were in an intervention or control facility. The primary outcome was correct treatment with artemether-lumefantrine, defined as a dichotomous composite indicator of treatment, delivery and counseling tasks in accordance with Kenyan national guidelines. The primary analysis was by treatment intent. The study is registered with Current Controlled Trials, ISRCTN72328636. Results 119 health workers received the intervention. Case management practices were evaluated for 2269 children requiring treatment (1157 in the intervention group and 1112 in the control group). The intention-to-treat analysis showed that correct artemether-lumefantrine management improved by 23 7 percentage points (95% CI 7 6-40 0", p=0 004) immediately after the intervention and by 24 5 percent improved scores (8 1-41 0;" p=0 003) 6 months later. Interpretation In resource-constrained settings, malaria control programs should consider the use of text messaging to improve health care workers' case management practices.

title: The effect of orthodontic referral guidelines: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: AIM: To develop and evaluate the effectiveness of referral guidelines for referring orthodontic patients to specialist and orthodontic specialists. DESIGN: Single center randomized controlled trial with random assignment of orthodontic treatment referral guidelines to general dentists. SETTING: Orthodontic departments in hospitals and specialist orthodontic practices in Manchester and Stockport. TOPICS: General dentists and the patients they refer for orthodontic treatment. MAIN OUTCOME MEASUREMENT: Adequacy of referral, defined as if the patient was accepted for orthodontic treatment. RESULTS: The referral policies did not reduce the number of inappropriate referrals. CONCLUSIONS: Referral guidelines for orthodontic referrals had no impact on general dentist behavior. Further research is needed on the optimal methods for disseminating and implementing referral guidelines for use in general dental care.

title: The effect of register-based performance feedback via short text messages and traditional postal letters on general practitioner prescribing of parenteral steroids--a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background It is believed that providing feedback on physician prescribing behavior improves the quality of drug prescribing. However, the effectiveness of providing feedback and the manner in which feedback is conveyed is not well understood. The aim of this study was to evaluate and compare the effect of traditional paper letter (TPL) and short text message (STM) feedback on general practitioner prescribing behavior for parenteral steroids (PS). Methods In a single-blind, randomized, controlled study, 906 general practitioners (GPs) with at least 10 monthly prescriptions were randomized into two intervention and one control arm with 1:1 assignment, stratified by percentage of prescriptions. The intervention consisted of providing 3 feedback messages with prescription indices in TPL and STM (in the first two arms) compared to the control arm (CG) with an interval of 3 months between these messages. We calculated the defined PS daily dose (DDD) for each GP each month and compared between the 3 arms before and after the interventions. The expected primary outcome was a reduction in the participants' prescription of parenteral steroids. The study was conducted at the Kerman Social Security Organization in Iran. Results A total of 906 general practitioners were selected for the study, but only 721 of them (TPL = 191, STM = 228, CG = 302) were recruited for the 1st feedback. The mean age of the general practitioners was 44 years and 59% of them were male. Prescribed parenteral steroid DDDs at baseline were similar (TPL = 121.62, STM = 127.49, CG = 115.68, P > 0.5). At the end of the study, the DDDs in the TPL and STM arms were similar (TPL = 104.38, STM = 101.90, P > 0.9), but the DDDs in each intervention arm were statistically significantly lower than in CG ( CG = 156.17, P<0.0001). ). Being in the TPL and STM arms resulted in a reduction in DDD of 36.1 and 41.7 units, respectively, compared to the control arm at the one-year study period (P<0.02 and P<0.005). Conclusion Feedback from TPLs and STMs on prescribing performance effectively reduced the prescribing of PSs by GPs. STM is a cheap and fast tool and potentially powerful and efficient for streamlining drug prescribing.

title: The effect of the Vermont Diabetes Information System on inpatient and emergency department use: results of a randomized study.
abstract: Objective To describe the effect of the Vermont Diabetes Information System (VDIS) on use in hospitals and emergency departments. Data source Nationwide relief database. Study design Randomized controlled trial of a decision support system for 7412 adults with diabetes and their 64 general practitioners. Data Collection/Data Extraction Charges and data for hospital admissions and emergency room care in Vermont during a mean follow-up of 32 months. Data from New York hospitals were not available. Results Patients randomized to VDIS had fewer hospital admissions than controls (0.17 admissions vs. 0.20 in; p=0.01) and incurred lower hospital charges ($3,113 vs. $3,480; p=0.019) . VDIS patients also had fewer emergency department occupancy rates (0.27 visits versus 0.36; P<0.0001) and charges ($304 versus $414; P<0.0001). The intervention was particularly effective in males and older subjects. Conclusions Despite data limitations that tended to reduce the apparent effect of the system, this randomized controlled trial showed that VDIS reduces hospital admissions and emergency department utilization and costs.

title: The efficacy and cost-effectiveness of dark chocolate consumption as a preventive therapy in people at high risk for cardiovascular disease: best-case scenario analysis using a Markov model
abstract: OBJECTIVE To model the long-term efficacy and cost-effectiveness of daily dark chocolate consumption in a population with metabolic syndrome and high risk of cardiovascular disease. DESIGN Best case scenario analysis using a Markov model. SETTING Australian Study of Diabetes, Obesity and Lifestyle. PARTICIPANTS 2013 People with hypertension who met criteria for metabolic syndrome, with no history of cardiovascular disease and not on antihypertensive therapy. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Treatment effects related to dark chocolate consumption, derived from published meta-analyses, were used to determine the absolute number of cardiovascular events with and without treatment. The costs associated with cardiovascular events and treatments were used to determine the potential amount of funding needed for dark chocolate therapy to be considered cost-effective. RESULTS Daily consumption of dark chocolate (polyphenol content equivalent to 100 g dark chocolate) can reduce cardiovascular events by 85 (95% confidence interval 60 to 105) per 10,000 treated population over 10 years. $40 (£25; $31; $42) per person per year could be inexpensively spent on dark chocolate prevention strategies. These results assume 100% compliance and represent a best-case scenario. CONCLUSIONS The blood pressure and cholesterol-lowering effects of dark chocolate consumption are beneficial in preventing cardiovascular events in a population with metabolic syndrome. Daily consumption of dark chocolate could be an effective cardiovascular prevention strategy in this population.

title: The Efficacy and Cost-Effectiveness of Psychological Treatments by Lay Counselors for Harmful and Dependent Drinking and Moderate-to-Severe Depression in Primary Care in India: PREMIUM Study Protocol for Randomized Controlled Trials
abstract: BACKGROUND: The most common psychological causes of the global burden of disease are depression in women and alcohol use disorders in men. A major obstacle to the implementation of evidence-based psychological treatments in primary care in developing countries is the unavailability of qualified human resources. The aim of these studies is to evaluate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of two psychological treatments developed for the treatment of depression and alcohol use disorder in primary care in India. METHODS/DESIGN: This study protocol is for randomized parallel group controlled trials (Healthy Activity Program for Moderate to Severe Depression, Alcohol Counseling for Harmful and Addictive Drinking) at eight primary health centers in Goa, India. Adult participants in primary care are assessed for depression using the Patient Health Questionnaire and, for males only, for alcohol problems using the Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test. Participants who test positive will be invited to participate.” Men who test positive for both disorders will be invited to participate in the Alcohol Counseling study. Those who consent will be allocated in a 1:1 ratio to either of the two appropriate psychological treatments plus reinforced usual care or reinforced usual care only using a computer-generated matching sequence stratified by primary health center and, for depression, by gender. Improved usual care includes the provision of contextualized World Health Organization guidelines and screening results to primary health center physicians. Treatments are delivered by lay counselors over a maximum period of three months. Primary endpoints are disorder severity and remission rates three months post-treatment Admission and for the Alcohol Counseling study, drinking and the impact of drinking on daily life. Secondary endpoints include disorder severity and remission rates at 12 months, and disability scores, suicidal behavior and economic impact, and cost-effectiveness at 3 and 12 months . 500 participants with depression and 400 participants with harmful alcohol use will be recruited. Primary analyzes will be intention-to-treat. DISCUSSION: These studies may offer a new approach to treating moderate depression and alcohol problems in primary care that is potentially scalable because it relies on delivery from a single pool of lay counselors. STUDY REGISTRATION: Both studies are registered with the International Society for the Registration of Clinical Trials (registration number ISRCTN95149997 for the Healthy Activities Program; registration number ISRCTN76465238 for Counseling for Alcohol Problems).

title: The effectiveness of a published information pack on the beliefs and behaviors of musculoskeletal practitioners: the UK Chiropractors, Osteopaths, and Musculoskeletal Physiotherapists Low Back Pain Management (COMPLeMENT) randomized study.
abstract: STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial. AIM: To investigate the effect of a printed information pack on the beliefs and reported behavior of musculoskeletal practitioners (chiropractors, osteopaths and musculoskeletal physiotherapists) related to low back pain (LBP) in the UK. SUMMARY OF BACKGROUND DATA: A significant proportion of UK musculoskeletal practitioners do not follow current LBP guideline recommendations. Methods: A total of 1758 practitioners were randomly assigned to one of the two study arms. A printed information packet with guideline recommendations for LBP management was sent to one arm (n=876) and the other received no intervention (n=882). The primary outcome measure consisted of 3 "quality indicators" (activity, work, and bed rest) in relation to a vignette of a patient with LBP in which the responses were dichotomized as either "guideline-inconsistent" or "guideline-inconsistent". The secondary outcome was practitioners' LBP-related beliefs as measured by the Health Care Providers Pain and Impairment Relationship Scale. Outcomes were measured at baseline and after 6 months. RESULTS: Follow-up at 6 months was 89%. The changes in reported behavior on the quality indicators were as follows: activity, odds ratio (OR), 1.29 (95% confidence interval, 1.03-1.61), and number of patients to be treated (NNT), 19 (15-28 )”; Work , OR 1.35 (1.07–1.70) and NNT 19 (14–29) and bed rest, OR 1.31 (0.97–1.76) and NNT 47 (33–103) The composite NNT for a change from guideline-inconsistent to guideline-consistent behavior on at least one of the 3 quality indicators was 10 (9-14) LBP-related beliefs were significantly improved (P=0.002) in those who were sent the information pack, but only to a small extent (mean difference, 0.884 scale points; 95% confidence interval, 0.319-1.448). CONCLUSION: Printed educational materials can shift LBP-related beliefs and reported behaviors from musculoskeletal practitioners towards practice more in line with guideline recommendations.

title: The effectiveness of an intervention in improving the delivery of preventive care by community physicians: a study protocol of a multi-baseline, non-randomized study
abstract: BACKGROUND: The primary behavioral risks for the most common causes of mortality and morbidity in developed countries are tobacco smoking, poor diet, hazardous alcohol use, and physical inactivity. Evidence, guidelines and guidelines support routine clinical care to avoid these risks in primary care. Despite the potential that community health services offer for the delivery of such care, the limited evidence available suggests that it is delivered at suboptimal levels. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a multi-strategic practice change intervention in improving the routine delivery of preventive care by clinicians in a network of community health services. METHODS/DESIGN: A multiple baseline study will be conducted involving all 56 community health facilities in a single health district in New South Wales, Australia. Facilities are assigned to one of three administratively defined groups. A 12-month practice change intervention will be implemented at all facilities in each group to facilitate clinical risk assessment of eligible clients and the provision of brief physician consultation and referral to those identified as “at risk”. The intervention will be delivered in a non-random order across the three facility groups. For all three facility groups, a repeated cross-sectional measurement of clinical preventive care for four individual risks (smoking, improper diet, risky alcohol consumption and lack of exercise) is carried out continuously over a period of 54 months via telephone interviews. The interviews are conducted with randomly selected clients who have visited a community health facility in the past two weeks. Data collection begins 12 months prior to the implementation of the intervention in the first group and continues for six months after the completion of the intervention in the last group. As a secondary source of data, pre- and post-intervention telephone interviews will be conducted with randomly selected physicians from each facility group to assess reported provision of preventive care and acceptability of the intervention and implementation of the practice change. DISCUSSION: The study will provide novel evidence of the ability to improve the routine delivery of preventive care by clinicians in a network of community health facilities. STUDY REGISTRATION: Australian Clinical Trials Registry ACTRN12611001284954 UNIVERSAL TRIAL NUMBER (UTN): U1111-1126-3465.

title: The effectiveness of computer reminders to improve quality assessment for point-of-care testing in general practice - a randomized controlled trial
abstract: Background Computer reminders are increasingly being used to improve quality and patient safety. However, more research is needed to determine the effectiveness of different types of memories in different environments. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of computer reminders in improving adherence to a quality assessment scheme for point-of-care testing in general practice. Method The study was conducted as a randomised, controlled, crossover study between general practices in the Danish capital region. The intervention consisted of sending computer reminders (ComRem) to practices that did not follow the guideline recommendations of the split test for hemoglobin and glucose. The practices were randomly divided into two groups. During the first follow-up period, one of the groups received the ComRem intervention together with the general implementation activities (GIA), while the other group received only the GIA. For the second follow-up period, the intervention was switched between the two groups. Results were measured as compliance with the split test procedure. Results A total of 142 practices were randomly assigned to the early intervention group and 144 practices to the late intervention group (the control group in the first follow-up period). In the first intervention phase, the average number of split tests performed in the group receiving ComRem increased from 1.22 to 3.76 (out of eight possible tests), while the average number of split tests in the group receiving the targeting only GIA increased from 1.11 to 2.35 (p=0.0059). A similar memory effect was observed after the crossover. In addition, the temporal developments of the outcome measures showed a strong effect of computer memories beyond the intervention periods. Conclusion There was a significant effect of computer recall on adherence to the quality rating scheme for point-of-care testing. Therefore, computer reminders seem to be useful to support the implementation of relatively simple quality and safety procedures.

title: The effectiveness of computer-aided clinical guidelines in the nursing process: a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Clinical practice guidelines have been developed that aim to improve the quality of care. The implementation of the computerized clinical guidelines (CCG) was supported by the development of computerized clinical decision support systems. This systematic review evaluates the impact of CCG on the treatment process in comparison to non-computerized clinical guidelines. METHODS: Specific features of CCG were investigated through an extensive search of the scientific literature querying electronic databases: Pubmed/Medline, Embase, and the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register. Multivariable logistic regression was performed to assess the association of CCG traits with positive effects on the nursing process. RESULTS: 45 items were selected. The logistic model showed that the automatic provision of the electronic version of the recommendation as part of the clinical workflow (odds ratio [OR] = 17.5"; 95% confidence interval [CI]: 1.6-193.7) and publication year (OR = 6.7;" 95% CI: 1.3-34.3) were statistically significant predictors. CONCLUSIONS: From the conducted research we can conclude that after the implementation of CCG there are significant improvements in the nursing process. Our results also suggest to clinicians, managers, and other healthcare decision-makers what features of CCG could improve the structure of the computerized system.

title: The effectiveness of interventions to improve laboratory request patterns in primary care physicians: a systematic review
abstract: Background Laboratory testing is an integral part of day-to-day family practice, with approximately 30% of patient interactions resulting in an inquiry. However, research suggests that a large proportion of requests for patient care do not benefit and are avoidable. The aim of this systematic review was to comprehensively search the literature for studies evaluating the effectiveness of interventions to improve the use of laboratory tests by primary care physicians. Methods A search of PubMed, Cochrane Library, Embase and Scopus (from beginning to 09/02/14) was performed. The following study designs were considered: systematic reviews, randomized controlled trials (RCTs), controlled clinical trials (CCTs), controlled before-and-after studies (CBAs), and interrupted time series analyzes (ITSs). The quality of the studies was assessed using a modified version of the Effective Practice and Organization of Care (EPOC) checklist. The population of interest were general practitioners. Interventions were considered when they aimed to improve laboratory testing in primary care. The interesting result was a series of laboratory tests. Results A total of 6,166 titles and abstracts were screened, followed by 87 full texts. Of these, 11 articles could be included in the systematic review. These included four RCTs, six CBAs and one ITS study. The types of interventions studied included education, feedback, guidelines, education with feedback, feedback with guidelines, and alternating assignment forms. The quality of the included studies varied, with seven studies classified as having a low risk of bias, three with an unclear risk of bias, and one with a high risk of bias. All but one study found a significant reduction in testing volume after the intervention, with effect sizes ranging from 1.2 to 60%. No meta-analysis was performed due to the heterogeneity. Conclusions Interventions such as educational strategies, feedback and modified test order forms can improve the efficient use of laboratory tests in primary care”; However, the level of evidence is quite low and the quality is poor. The reproducibility of findings from different laboratories is also difficult to determine from the literature. Some standardization of both interventions and outcome measures is required to allow for a formal meta-analysis.

title: The effectiveness of SPARX, a computer-assisted self-help intervention for adolescents seeking help for depression: randomized controlled non-inferiority study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess whether a new computer-assisted cognitive-behavioral therapy intervention (SPARX, Smart, Positive, Active, Realistic, X-Factor Thoughts) could reduce depressive symptoms in help-seeking adolescents as much or more than usual treatment. DESIGN Multicenter, randomized, controlled, noninferiority study. SETTING 24 Primary health care facilities in New Zealand (youth clinics, general practices and school-based counseling services). PARTICIPANTS 187 adolescents aged 12 to 19 years who sought help for depressive symptoms, were not at greater risk of self-harm and were identified by their GPs as requiring treatment: 94 were allocated to SPARX and 93 to usual care. INTERVENTIONS Computational Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (SPARX) consisting of seven modules delivered over a period of four to seven weeks compared to usual treatment, which mainly includes face-to-face counseling by trained counselors and clinical psychologists. RESULTS The primary outcome was change in score on the Revised Child Depression Rating Scale. Secondary outcomes included response and remission on the revised childhood depression rating scale, change scores on the second edition of the Reynolds adolescent depression scale, the mood and emotion questionnaire, the children's Kazdin hopelessness scale, the children's Spence anxiety scale and the pediatric quality of life enjoyment and satisfaction questionnaires and overall satisfaction with treatment ratings. RESULTS 94 participants were allocated to SPARX (mean age 15.6 years, 62.8% female) and 93 to treatment as usual (mean age 15.6 years, 68.8% female). 170 adolescents (91%, SPARX n=85, treat-as-usual n=85) were evaluated after the intervention and 168 (90%, SPARX n=83, treat-as-usual n=85) at the time of the three-month follow-up. Per-protocol analyzes (n=143) showed that SPARX was non-inferior to usual care. After the intervention, there was a mean reduction of 10.32 in SPARX and 7.59 in treatment-as-usual in raw scores on the revised childhood depression rating scale (difference between groups 2.73, 95% confidence interval -0.31 to 5.77"; p=0.079). Remission rates were significantly higher in the SPARX arm (n=31, 43.7%) than in the treatment arm (n=19, 26.4%) (difference 17.3%, 95 -% confidence interval 1.6% to 31.8%; P=0.030) and response rates were not significantly different between the SPARX arm (66.2%, n=47) and the treatment arm (58.3%, n = 42) (difference 7.9%, -7.9% to 24%; P = 0.332). All secondary measures supported non-inferiority. Intention-to-treat analyzes confirmed these results. Improvements were maintained at follow-up. The Frequency of adverse events classified as “possibly” or “probably” related to the intervention den, did not differ between the groups (SPARX n = 11; "Treatment as usual n = 11"). CONCLUSIONS SPARX is a potential alternative to usual treatment for adolescents with depressive symptoms in primary care and could be used to fill some unmet treatment needs. STUDY REGISTRATION Australian-New Zealand Clinical Trials ACTRN12609000249257.

title: The effectiveness of workplace interventions to increase physical activity and reduce sedentary behavior in adults: protocol for a systematic review
abstract: BACKGROUND: A physically active lifestyle plays a preventive role in the development of various chronic diseases and mental illnesses. Unfortunately, few adults achieve the minimum level of physical activity and spend an inordinate amount of time sedentary. The development of targeted interventions to promote active living among adults is an important public health endeavor. A plausible context to reach adults is in the workplace. This systematic review aims to verify the effectiveness of workplace interventions to increase physical activity and reduce sedentary behavior in the workplace. METHODS: An advisory group of practitioners will work in collaboration with the research team to inform the systematic review and knowledge mobilization. Fifteen electronic databases are searched to identify studies examining the effectiveness of workplace interventions on physical activity and physical inactivity. All experimental designs and observational studies (non-experimental intervention studies) that meet the study criteria are included. Studies with generally healthy, employed adult participants are included in the review. Interventions focus on increasing physical activity and/or reducing sedentary behavior from the individual to the policy level. The primary outcome variables are reported or observed physical activity and/or sedentary behavior at work. Secondary outcomes include variables ranging from return on investment to quality of life. Study quality is assessed for risk of bias using the protocol identified in the Cochrane Manual for Systematic Reviews of Interventions and supplemented by the guidelines developed by the Cochrane Effective Practice and Organization of Care group using RevMan. The quality of the evidence is assessed using the Grading of Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation approach. When appropriate, meta-analyses, forest and crop plots will be used to assess the direction, magnitude, and consistency of the intervention effect in the studies with similar intervention strategies. Further knowledge mobilization activities and products will be developed to support the application of this knowledge in practice. DISCUSSION: This protocol paper describes a systematic review evaluating the effectiveness of different types of workplace interventions to increase physical activity and reduce sedentary behavior at work. Working with an advisory group of potential knowledge users throughout the process posits greater use and reach of the information gained from this systematic knowledge user review. SYSTEMATIC REVIEW REGISTRATION: PROSPERO CRD42015019398.

title: The impact of a postgraduate course on primary care physician opioid prescribing patterns
abstract: BACKGROUND: The aim of this study was to evaluate whether a single palliative care workshop that included information about drug prescribing had an impact on primary care physicians' opioid prescribing patterns in daily practice. Method: The opioid prescription numbers of 68 primary care physicians who took part in the workshop were aggregated from the state health insurance fund's computer system. Prescription numbers one year before and one year after the workshop were compared and a control group of non-participants was included. Results: This study showed a limited effectiveness of a palliative care cancer workshop on GP morphine prescription rates in daily practice. This limited effect was not consistent with the results of a pre- and post-workshop questionnaire assessing the attitudes of the same practitioners. CONCLUSION: A single workshop cannot bring about significant changes in prescribing behavior. Possibilities for further reinforcements are discussed.

title: The effects of a theory-based training program on the self-efficacy and behavior of smoking cessation counseling caregivers
abstract: BACKGROUND: Cigarette smoking continues to put Americans at risk of serious health consequences and early death. Nurses play an important role in disseminating smoking cessation interventions to hospitalized patients. However, caregivers are not prepared for smoking cessation counseling. METHOD: A quasi-experimental design was used. Fifteen nurses participated in the Clinical Practice Guideline “5 A's” Brief Intervention Training Program and completed a three-period survey. RESULTS: There were several statistically significant changes in the dependent variables for self-efficacy and behavior for smoking cessation counseling. CONCLUSION: The results of this study support further research and theory-based education of nurses.

title: The effects of lowering LDL-C with statin therapy in people at low risk for vascular disease: meta-analysis of anecdotal data from 27 randomized trials
abstract: BackgroundStatins lower LDL-C and prevent vascular events, but their net effect in people at low risk of vascular events remains uncertain.";" Background Statins lower LDL-cholesterol and prevent vascular events, but their net effects in people at low risk of vascular events remain uncertain.

title: The Effects of Maternal Depression, Anxiety, and Perceived Stress During Pregnancy on Preterm Birth: A Systematic Review
abstract: BACKGROUND: Experiencing psychological distress such as depression, anxiety, and/or perceived stress during pregnancy may increase the risk of adverse birth outcomes, including preterm birth. Clarifying the relationship between exposure and outcome may improve understanding of risk factors for preterm birth and guide future clinical and research practices. AIM: The aim of the present review was to outline the evidence on the risk of preterm birth associated with prenatal depression, anxiety and stress. METHODS: Four electronic database searches were performed to identify quantitative population-based, multicenter cohort studies and randomized controlled trials focused on the association between prenatal depression, anxiety and stress and preterm birth published in English between 1980 and 2013. RESULTS: Out of 1469 From electronically retrieved articles, 39 peer-reviewed studies met the final selection criteria and were included in this review according to the PRISMA and MOOSE review guidelines. Information on study characteristics was extracted";" Depression, anxiety, and perceived stress were studied as separate and combined exposures. There is strong evidence that prenatal stress during pregnancy increases the likelihood of preterm birth. CONCLUSION: Complex pathways of significant interactions between depression, anxiety and stress, risk factors and prematurity have been revealed in both direct and indirect ways. The effects of pregnancy stress have been associated with spontaneous but not medically indicated preterm births. Health care practitioners involved in women's perinatal care, such as obstetricians, midwives, nurses, and mental health specialists, need to provide appropriate support to women with mental distress to improve maternal and infant outcomes.

title: The impact of pay-for-performance programs on health, health care utilization and care processes
abstract: Background: The benefits of pay-for-performance (P4P) programs are uncertain. Purpose: To update and expand on a previous review that examined the impact of P4P programs at the physician, group, managerial, or institutional level on the care process and patient outcomes in the outpatient and inpatient setting. Data sources: PubMed from June 2007 to October 2016"; MEDLINE, PsycINFO, CINAHL, Business Economics and Theory, Business Source Elite, Scopus, Faculty of 1000 and Gartner Research from June 2007 to February 2016. Study selection: Studies and observational studies in outpatient and inpatient settings Facilities reporting outcomes of care process, health, or use.Data Extraction:Two investigators extracted data, assessed study quality, and assessed the strength of evidence.Data Synthesis:Of the 69 studies, 58 were in outpatient settings, 52 reported treatment outcomes, and 38 about Patient outcomes.Low-strength evidence suggested that P4P programs in outpatient settings improve pro outcomes of dependency over a short period (2 to 3 years), while data on longer-term effects were limited.Many of the positive studies were conducted in the UK , where the incentives were greater than in the United States. The greatest improvements were seen in areas where output was poor. There was no consistent effect of P4P on mean health outcomes (low-strength evidence) and insufficient evidence to characterize an effect on patient health outcomes. In the hospital setting, there was weak evidence that P4P had little or no impact on patient health outcomes and a positive effect on reducing hospital readmissions. Limitation: Few methodologically rigorous studies; heterogeneous population and program characteristics and incentive goals. Conclusion: Pay-for-performance programs can be associated with improved nursing processes in outpatient settings, but no consistently positive associations with improved health outcomes have been demonstrated in any setting.

title: The impact of pricing information on physician test ordering behavior: Diagnostic test ordering.
abstract: This study evaluated the impact of providing physicians with information about diagnostic test prices on their subsequent test ordering behavior. The study population consisted of 36 second- and third-year residents and 23 clinical educators at three primary care practice centers affiliated with the Department of Family Medicine at Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, Michigan. Study participants were asked to review four case studies, each describing a patient with ambiguous symptoms, and to indicate on an attached test order form the tests they would order for each patient. Subjects were randomly assigned to either a group that received test order forms with the prices of diagnostic tests printed on them (pricing information group) or to a group that received test order forms without price information (control group). The study results show that in each of the four cases, the average number of diagnostic tests ordered was significantly lower in the price information group than in the control group. Our results also show an average 31.1 percent reduction in the cumulative cost of ordered tests per patient associated with the provision of pricing information.
