The feasibility of providing physicians with pricing information on a regular basis is discussed and reviewed in light of other approaches that have been developed to change physician behavior when ordering diagnostic tests.

title: The effectiveness of an automated feedback system for general practitioners
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To develop an automated feedback system that generates comments about non-compliance by General Practitioners (GPs) with accepted practice guidelines for ordering diagnostic tests. Before implementing the automated feedback system into daily practice, we assessed the potential impact of the system on GP test ordering behavior. DESIGN: We used a randomized controlled trial with a balanced block design. SETTING: Five times six participant groups of general practitioners in a computer laboratory setting. INTERVENTION: The GPs reviewed a random sample of 30 claim forms they had filled out earlier in the year. If necessary, they could make changes to the requested tests. Next, the system displayed critical comments about their non-compliance with the guidelines, as reflected in the (updated) application forms. SUBJECTS: Twenty-four randomly selected general practitioners participated. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: The number of diagnostic tests requested (17% with 95% confidence interval [CI]: 12-22%) and the proportion of tests ordered that did not meet practice guidelines (39% with 95% CI: 28-51%) dropped due to comments from the automated feedback system. The general practitioners accepted 362 (50%) of the 729 reminders. CONSEQUENCES: Although our experiment cannot predict the magnitude of the actual effect of the automated feedback system in daily practice, the observed effect can be considered as the maximum attainable.

title: The effectiveness of computer reminders for external quality assessment for point-of-care testing in Danish general practice: rationale and methodology for two randomized trials
abstract: BACKGROUND: Point-of-care testing (POCT) is increasingly used in general medicine to assist general practitioners (GPs) in managing patients with disease. However, low compliance with quality guidelines regarding split testing procedures among general practitioners was observed in parts of the Capital Region in Denmark. Computer reminders embedded in primary care physicians' electronic medical records (ComRem) may facilitate improved quality control behavior, but more research is needed to determine which types of reminders work and when. The overall objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of ComRem to improve adherence to quality guidelines by general practitioners. This article describes the rationale and methods of study that make up this research project. METHODS/DESIGN: The study will be conducted in two randomized controlled trials (RCTs) among general practices in two districts of the Capital Region of Denmark. These districts include a total of 739 general practitioners in 567 practices with a total of 1.1 million patients who are assigned to the practice lists. In the first RCT (RCT A), ComRem is compared with postal dunning letters. In the second RCT (RCT B), ComRem is compared to usual activities (no memories) using a crossover approach. In both studies, results are measured by the number of split tests the lab receives. CONCLUSIONS: This study will add to the knowledge of the effectiveness of ComRem in primary care. Since the study does not examine the perceptions and experiences of general practitioners with regard to ComRem, we will subsequently conduct a qualitative survey on these aspects. STUDY REGISTRATIONS: Study A: ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT01152151Study B: ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT01152177.

title: The effectiveness of visual cues to improve hand hygiene compliance
abstract: BACKGROUND: Guidelines for healthcare worker (HCW) hand hygiene behavior are well established. Despite well-known dangers of healthcare-associated infection for healthcare workers and patients, hand hygiene compliance (HHC) rates remain alarmingly low. To evaluate a potential solution to this ongoing challenge, we used a simulated patient encounter in a real hospital room to test the effectiveness of individual HH triggers. METHODS: One hundred and fifty HCW (75 physicians and 75 nurses) participated in this study and were randomly assigned to one of five equal-sized groups. Each participant performed a focused physical exam on a standardized patient and was expected to maintain HH before and after the exam. Using two rooms in a medical-surgical department in a tertiary care teaching hospital, various cues were used and the effects on HHC before and after the examination were recorded. In the control group, the hand sanitizer dispenser was in its usual location (baseline). In one group, the donor was placed in line-of-sight upon entering the room; in another, flashing lights were attached to the dispenser (baseline & flicker) in its usual position (baseline & flicker); and in a third group, the dispenser was moved to line-of-sight and line-of-sight & flicker lights were installed. In the last group, a large warning sign was placed on the door informing the doctor that the room was under electronic control surveillance and failure to perform HHC would trigger an alarm. Data were analyzed using a generalized linear model to perform repeated measures logistic regression. P<0.05 was considered statistically significant. RESULTS: In the control group (baseline), the pre- and post-examination HHC rates were 36.7% and 33.3%, respectively. All interventions improved HHC preintervention compared to baseline (line of sight = 53.3%, baseline and flicker = 60%, line of sight and flicker = 66%, red flag = 93.3%), but only the sight & flicker and red flag led to a statistically significant increase in HHC before the examination (p = 0.022 and p < 0.001, respectively). Only the warning sign resulted in a statistically significant increase in HHC follow-up (P < 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: Visual cues can improve HHC, but their effectiveness varies. A warning sign indicating a monitoring system with subsequent reporting of non-compliance led to the most significant improvement in the HHC. Using a standardized patient in an actual hospital room was a useful tool to assess the impact of different interventions to improve HHC and patient safety.

title: The employment of opinion leaders on the ward for further training in the hospital.
abstract: Opinion Leaders (OLs) are members of a social group with significant social influence over others. A guideline on urinary catheter care was established in three groups (A, B, and C) from two randomly assigned wards. Two OLs per ward were identified by the nurses in groups A and B using a sociological method. Training used in-service lectures for 30% of nurses and OLs tutorials for all nurses in group A; OLs tutorials in B, lectures in C and ward nurses were in turn responsible for the training of new entrants of nursing students. Before and after the training, the frequency of practice of the guideline was determined by interviewing 30% of the randomly selected nurses and by direct observation for incorrect practices. A student quiz on the guideline was also carried out. For all three measurement methods, the best results were in group A, followed by B and C;" and the differences for the three groups were significant (p<0.05). This indicates that in-hospital training through hiring wards -OLs can be done effectively.

title: The escalating pandemics of obesity and physical inactivity. A call to action for clinicians
abstract: Obesity and sedentary lifestyles are leading to an escalation of national and global epidemics that require increased attention from physicians and other health professionals. These intricately interconnected conditions are responsible for a tremendous burden of chronic disease, impairment of physical function and quality of life, at least 300,000 premature deaths, and at least $90 billion in direct health care costs each year in the United States alone. Clinicians are on the front lines of the fight, yet minimal attention is paid to these conditions during a typical office visit. Clinicians often feel overwhelmed by these challenges, citing a lack of clear guidelines and practice tools, minimal training in behavior change strategies, and lack of time as reasons for not addressing them. This report offers a "call to action" with step-by-step guidelines specifically designed to address the central role of physicians and other healthcare professionals in containing these dangerous epidemics. This action plan, which requires only minutes of a clinician's time to implement, will facilitate more effective intervention related to obesity and inactivity and should have beneficial public health implications.

title: The Esperance Primary Suicide Prevention Project
abstract: BACKGROUND: Suicide has been a major community problem in Esperance, a geographically isolated port city on the south coast of Western Australia. OBJECTIVES: To assess the impact of three evidence-based primary suicide prevention initiatives: (i) provide suicide education sessions for health, education and social care workers; (ii) limit the sale of over-the-counter analgesics (aspirin and paracetamol) to packets containing less than the minimum lethal dose;' and (iii) implement Commonwealth Media Guidelines on media coverage of suicides. METHODS: Changes in knowledge, awareness, attitudes, comfort, and use before and after each intervention were assessed using standardized instruments and pro forma devices derived from previous work such as the Youth Suicide Prevention Training Manual and the Suicide Intervention Beliefs Scale. Percentage changes in the number of retail outlets selling over-the-counter analgesics in less than potentially lethal amounts (less than 8g of acetaminophen or aspirin) were also measured. Media representatives were surveyed to get their perceptions of the Commonwealth guidelines for reporting suicide and encouraged to consult the project team before reporting problems with suicide. RESULTS: The baseline survey showed that mental health staff and general practitioners were more aware than staff of other services of the issue of suicide, risk factors for suicide, and awareness of professional and ethical responses, and were more willing to discuss the issue with a person at risk . Thirty-three subjects participated in suicide training, of which 21 (66%) returned questionnaires. There was a significant increase in awareness of suicide-related issues and risk factors, as well as a reported level of knowledge about professional and ethical responses, and comfort, competence, and confidence in supporting a person at risk. Only three media representatives were aware of the Commonwealth Department of Health's guidelines for reporting suicide, and only one believed the guidelines influenced their reporting. The local newspapers then contacted the researchers to verify that their reporting was within guidelines. Regarding access to analgesics, one in seven retailers said they would implement the strategy (subject to approval from other retailers), another claimed to have increased awareness of the danger of analgesics, and three said they would try monitor excessive quantities sold to an individual. CONCLUSIONS: Local initiatives can improve the awareness and knowledge of suicide risk assessment staff and local media. These need to be complemented by initiatives at the state or commonwealth level to bring about changes in national media or the sale of over-the-counter analgesics.

title: The ethical evaluation of innovative therapies: liver transplantation with living donors
abstract: Liver transplantation is the treatment of choice for many forms of liver disease. Unfortunately, the scarcity of donor cadaveric livers limits the availability of this technique. To improve the availability of liver transplants, surgeons have developed the ability to remove part of the liver from a living donor and transplant it into a recipient. A few liver transplants from living donors have been performed worldwide. Our aim was to analyze the ethics of living donor liver transplantation and to propose guidelines for the procedure before it was introduced in the United States. We used a “research ethics consultation” process that involves collaboration between clinical researchers and clinical ethicists. We concluded that it is ethically appropriate to perform living donor liver transplantation in a small patient series on an experimental basis and published our ethical guidelines in a medical journal before the procedure was introduced. We recommend this prospective, public approach for the introduction of further innovative therapies in medicine and surgery.

title: The ethics of medicine: an annotated bibliography of recent literature
The European Psychiatric Association (EPA) guidelines on suicide treatment and prevention
abstract: WITHOUT LABELING: Suicide is a major public health problem in the WHO European Region, causing over 150,000 deaths annually. Suicidal Crisis: Acute intervention should begin immediately to keep the patient alive. DIAGNOSIS: Up to 90% of people who have committed suicide have an underlying psychiatric disorder. Comorbidity with depression, anxiety, substance abuse, and personality disorders is high. In order to achieve successful suicidality prevention, adequate diagnostic procedures and appropriate treatment of the underlying disease are essential. TREATMENT: Existing evidence supports the effectiveness of pharmacological treatment and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) in preventing suicidal behavior. Some other psychological treatments show promise, but supporting evidence is currently insufficient. Studies show that treatment with antidepressants reduces the risk of suicide in depressed patients. However, depressed patients treated with antidepressants are at risk of suicidal behavior during the first 10-14 days of treatment, which requires careful monitoring. Short-term concomitant medication with anxiolytics and hypnotics for anxiety and sleep disorders is recommended. TREATMENT with antidepressants in children and adolescents should only take place under the supervision of a specialist doctor. Long-term lithium treatment has been shown to be effective in preventing suicide and suicide attempts in patients with unipolar and bipolar depression. TREATMENT with clozapine is effective in reducing suicidal behavior in patients with schizophrenia. Other atypical antipsychotics show promise, but more evidence is needed. TREATMENT TEAM: Multidisciplinary treatment teams made up of psychiatrists and other professionals such as psychologists, social workers and occupational therapists are always preferable, as the integration of pharmacological, psychological and social rehabilitation is recommended, especially for patients with chronic suicidal tendencies. Family: Regardless of age, the suicidal person should always be motivated to involve the family in treatment. Social support: Psychosocial treatment and support is recommended as the majority of suicidal patients have problems with relationships, work, school and lack of functioning social networks. SAFETY: A safe home, public, and hospital environment without access to means of suicide is a necessary strategy in suicide prevention. Each treatment option, prescription of medication and discharge of the patient from the hospital should be carefully weighed against the risks involved. Training of staff: Training of general practitioners (GPs) is effective in suicide prevention. It improves treatment for depression and anxiety, the quality of care provided, and attitudes towards suicide. Psychiatrists and other mental health professionals need continuous education, including discussions on ethical and legal issues.

title: The evaluation of a tailored intervention to improve the management of suspected viral encephalitis: protocol for a randomized controlled cluster study
abstract: Background Viral encephalitis is a devastating disease in which delayed treatment is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. Clinical audits indicate significant scope for improved detection and treatment. Improvement strategies should ideally be tailored to identified needs and barriers to change. The aim of the study is to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a tailored intervention to improve secondary care for suspected encephalitis. Methods/Design The study is a two-armed, cluster-randomized, controlled study awarded by the Postgraduate Dean's Office. Participants were identified from 24 hospitals nested within 12 postgraduate deaneries in the United Kingdom (UK). We have developed a multi-faceted intervention package that includes core and flexible components with embedded behavior change techniques selected based on identified needs and barriers to change. The primary outcome will be composed of the proportion of patients with suspected encephalitis who receive a timely and appropriate diagnostic spinal tap within 12 hours of hospital admission and aciclovir treatment within 6 hours. We collect pre-procedure and up to 12 months post-procedure outcome data from patient records. Cluster-level statistical analysis is blind to attribution. An economic evaluation will assess the cost-effectiveness of the intervention from a health care perspective.

title: The Evolution of Current Medical and Popular Attitudes to Exposure to Ultraviolet Light: Part 3
abstract: In the 1930's, attitudes toward ultraviolet (UV) light began to change significantly within the medical profession. UV radiation has been promoted as beneficial to health since the beginning of the century, particularly after the discovery of its role in vitamin D metabolism. However, increasing attention would be paid to the risks of UV light exposure from sunlamps and sunbathing. During this time, the American Medical Association established guidelines for the approval of UV lamps and the associated therapeutic uses of phototherapy. Findlay and other researchers' pioneering experiments inducing malignant skin tumors in rodents after exposure to UV lamps or sunlight would lead to widespread recognition of the carcinogenicity of UV radiation. The role of sunlight in the etiology of skin cancer was increasingly mentioned in articles in popular journals in the 1940s and 1950s. The sunscreen industry also experienced rapid growth, although product efficacy remained very variable. In the 1950s, interest developed in the use of 8-methoxypsoralen ("the suntan pill") and dihydroxyacetone ("tan in a bottle"). Despite the well-known risks of UV exposure and attempts by doctors and other health professionals to educate the public and change behavior, tanning has remained stubbornly popular. Today, excessive exposure to UV light is recognized as the leading cause of the approximately 1.3 million cases of skin cancer in the United States each year.

title: The Evolution of Informed Consent in American Medicine
The set of expert consensus guidelines. Optimization of the pharmacological treatment of psychotic disorders. Introduction: Methods, Commentary and Summary
abstract: OBJECTIVES: A growing number of atypical antipsychotics are available to clinicians of choice in the treatment of psychotic disorders. However, a number of important issues related to drug selection, dosing and dose equivalents, and how to manage poor response, compliance issues, and relapse have not been adequately addressed in clinical trials. To support clinical decision making, a consensus survey of expert opinions on pharmacological treatment of psychotic disorders was conducted to answer questions that have not been definitively answered in the research literature. METHOD: Based on a literature review, a written survey with 60 questions and 994 options was developed. Approximately half of the options were assessed using a modified version of the 9-point RAND scale for assessing the appropriateness of medical decisions. For the other options, the experts were asked to fill in answers (e.g. average doses) or tick a box to indicate their preferred answer. The survey was sent to 50 national experts in the pharmacological treatment of psychotic disorders, of whom 47 (94%) completed it. In analyzing responses to items rated on the 9-point scale, consensus on each option was defined as a non-random distribution of scores by the chi-square "test of goodness". We assigned each option a categorical rank (first line/preferred choice, second line/alternative choice, third line/usually inappropriate) based on the 95% confidence interval around the mean rating. Then, guideline tables were developed that indicate preferred treatment strategies for important clinical situations. RESULTS: The expert panel reached consensus on 88% of the options that were rated on the 9-point scale. The experts overwhelmingly endorsed the use of atypical antipsychotics for the treatment of psychotic disorders. Risperidone was the first choice for patients with first and multiple episodes, with the other newer atypical drugs classified as first or high second line depending on the clinical situation. Clozapine and a long-acting injectable atypical drug (when available) were other highly effective second-line options for patients with multiple episodes. The expert's dosing recommendations closely matched the drug package inserts, and their estimates of dose equivalence among the antipsychotics followed a linear pattern. The experts considered 3-6 weeks an adequate antipsychotic study, but would wait slightly longer (4-10 weeks) before making a major change in treatment regimen if there is a partial response. The experts recommended trying to improve response by increasing the dose of atypical antipsychotics and depot antipsychotics before switching to another agent”; There was less consensus about increasing the dose of conventional antipsychotics before switching, likely due to concerns about side effects at higher doses. If a decision is made to switch to the drug due to an inadequate response, risperidone was the expert's first choice, regardless of which drug was initially tried. Although there were some differences in the expert's recommendations on how many drugs to try before switching to clozapine, the expert's responses suggest that a switch to clozapine should be done. Clozapine was also the antipsychotic of choice for patients with suicidal behavior. When switching from oral antipsychotics, experts considered cross-titration to be the preferred strategy. When switching to an injectable antipsychotic, the experts emphasized the importance of continuing the oral antipsychotic until therapeutic levels of the injectable are reached. The experts considered psychosocial interventions as the first-line strategy for patients with partial compliance, and pharmacological interventions as the first-line strategy for patients with clear evidence of non-compliance. However, because it can be difficult to distinguish partially compliant from noncompliant patients, the editors recommended combining psychosocial and pharmacological interventions whenever possible to improve compliance. If patients relapse due to compliance issues or there are doubts about compliance, the experts recommended using a long-acting injectable antipsychotic and would select an injectable atypical drug once that option becomes available. The experts would also consider the use of an injectable atypical antipsychotic (when available) in many clinical settings that do not involve compliance issues. The experts stressed the importance of monitoring patients being treated with antipsychotics for health problems - particularly obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular problems, HIV risk behaviors, medical complications of substance abuse, heavy smoking and its effects, hypertension and amenorrhea. Although many patients are prescribed add-on treatments, multiple antipsychotics, and combinations of different classes of drugs (eg, antipsychotics plus mood stabilizers or antidepressants) to improve response, experts did not support any of these strategies except for antidepressants for patients with dysphoria/depression, antidepressants, or ECT for patients with suicidal behavior and mood stabilizers for patients with aggression/violence. When asked about indicators of remission and recovery, the experts considered acute improvement in psychotic symptoms as the most important indicator of remission, while assessing more sustained improvement in several outcome areas (e.g., recovery). CONCLUSIONS: The experts scored on many of the key treatment questions in high consensus from the survey.Within the limits of expert judgment, and with the expectation that future research data will prevail, these guidelines provide guidance for addressing common clinical dilemmas encountered in the pharmacological treatment of psychotic disorders.They can be used to To inform clinicians and educate patients about the relative merits of a variety of interventions Clinicians should remember that no guideline can address the complexity of each patient's care and that in applying these recommendations sound clinical judgment based on clinical experience should be used.

title: The set of expert consensus guidelines. Treatment of behavioral emergencies 2005
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Because of the inherent dangers and barriers to research in emergency settings, little data is available to guide clinicians on how best to manage behavioral emergencies. Key constructs such as agitation are poorly defined. This lack of empirical data prompted us to conduct an expert review, the results of which were published in the 2001 Expert Consensus Guidelines for the Treatment of Behavior Disorders. Several second-generation (atypical) antipsychotics (SGAs) are now available in new formulations for the treatment of behavioral emergencies (e.g., intramuscular [IM] olanzapine and ziprasidone";" fast-dissolving tablets of olanzapine and risperidone). The field faces critical questions. The SGAs differ significantly from the FGAs and from each other and have not been studied like the FGAs in unselected patients. Can the SGAs be considered as a class, do all antipsychotics have similar antiagitation effects under different conditions, and what limitations might their safety profiles impose if they are equally effective? Should antipsychotics be used more specifically to treat psychotic disorders while benzodiazepines (BNZ) alone are used non-specifically? Few data are available on combinations of SGAs and BNZs, and evidence on the traditional combination of haloperidol plus a BNZ may not be relevant to combinations with SGAs. The culture is also evolving, placing more emphasis on patient involvement in treatment decisions. An international consensus has developed that reassurance rather than sedation is the appropriate endpoint of behavioral emergency interventions. We conducted a new expert survey to update the recommendations from the previous survey. METHOD: A written survey with 61 questions (1,020 options) was sent to 50 experts in the field, of whom 48 (96%) completed it. The survey aimed to determine the level of arousal at which emergency interventions are appropriate, the scope of the assessment depending on the urgency and the patients' ability to cooperate, guiding principles for the selection of the interventions, and appropriate physical and drug strategies at different levels of diagnostic reliability for a variety of preliminary diagnoses to be defined and aggravating conditions. A modified version of the RAND Corporation's 9-point Medical Decision Appropriateness Scale was used to rate most options. Consensus was defined as the non-random distribution of results by a chi-square "fitness test". We assigned each option a categorical rank (first line/preferred, second line/alternative, third line/usually inappropriate) based on the 95% confidence interval about the mean. Ratings were used to develop guidelines for preferred strategies in key clinical situations. This study received financial support from multiple sponsors, with the panel remaining blind to sponsors to reduce potential bias. Medication ratings were based only on responses from respondents with direct experience with each medication. When reporting on practice patterns, the panel was asked to respond based on actual data rather than estimates. RESULTS: The expert panel reached consensus on 78% of the options rated on the 9-point scale. The responses suggest that physicians can make preliminary diagnoses with some confidence and that pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions are selected differently based on the diagnosis and other salient demographic and medical characteristics. BNZs are recommended when data are unavailable, when there is no specific treatment (eg, personality disorder), or when they may have a specific benefit (eg, intoxication). No single SGA emerges as a non-specific replacement for haloperidol; instead, different SGAs are preferred in different circumstances, consistent with current evidence. To the extent that haloperidol is recommended, it is almost always in combination with a BNZ; Haloperidol alone is only preferred in those who are medically impaired. In contrast, the SGAs are more often recommended for use alone, and the Panel would avoid combining BNZs with some SGAs. Oral risperidone alone or in combination with a BNZ has strong support in a variety of settings. Oral olanzapine was rated very good, similar to risperidone, with slightly higher ratings than risperidone in settings where it has been studied (eg, schizophrenia, mania), and slightly lower ratings when it has not been studied or the security could be a concern; there was less support for combining oral olanzapine with a BNZ Olanzapine alone, risperidone alone or in combination with a BNZ, and halo peridol plus a BNZ are the first choices, with strong support as well, for the oral treatment of agitation associated with schizophrenia or mania for the combination of divalproex with the antipsychotic in suspected mania. Oral ziprasidone and quetiapine received generally similar second-line ratings in most settings. When a parenteral agent is needed, im-olanzapine alone received slightly more support than im-ziprasidone alone; however, there was more support for im-ziprasidone alone or in combination with a BNZ than for im-olanzapine plus BNZ, likely reflecting safety concerns. For example, for a tentative diagnosis of schizophrenia, first-line parenteral options are olanzapine or ziprasidone alone, or haloperidol or ziprasidone in combination with a BNZ no data are available or the diagnosis involves a medical comorbidity or intoxication. If the initial intervention with When risperidone, ziprasidone, or haloperidol was unsuccessful, the panel recommended adding a BZD to the antipsychotic Dose is recommended Perphenazine was consistently given second-line and droperidol and chlorpromazine received third-line ratings consistently. CONCLUSIONS: Within the limits of expert judgment and with the expectation that future research data will prevail, these guidelines suggest that SGAs are now preferred for agitation in primary psychiatric disorders, but that BNZs are preferred in other settings.

title: The Fit Family Challenge: A Pilot Intervention in Childhood Obesity in Primary Care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Childhood obesity has increased dramatically over several decades, and the American Academy of Pediatrics has recommended family physician offices as ideal sites for identifying, educating, and implementing therapeutic interventions. The aim of this study was to describe the implementation and outcomes of the Fit Family Challenge (FFC), a primary care-based intervention for childhood obesity. METHODS: A single-intervention pilot project that educates primary care practices related to childhood obesity policies and the implementation of a family-centered behavior change curriculum. A total of 29 general practitioner and pediatric group practices in Colorado participated. The participants included 290 patients aged 6 to 12 years with a body mass index (BMI) above the 85th percentile. The main outcomes included the feasibility of implementing a program to treat childhood obesity in primary care; secondary outcomes were changes in BMI percentile, BMI z-scores, blood pressure, and changes in lifestyle factors associated with childhood obesity. RESULTS: When implementation of FFC is feasible, statistically significant changes in decreases in BMI percentile and BMI z-scores were observed for participants who completed 9 to 15 months of follow-up;" Lifestyle Factors Associated with Childhood Obesity in Evidence Spanish-speaking families and food insecurity were associated with a shorter follow-up time (p < 0.01) CONCLUSIONS: Primary care-based intervention for childhood obesity can result in significant clinical and lifestyle changes.

title: The Future of British Psychiatric Hospitals
The Gestational Diabetes Management System (GooDMomS): Development, feasibility, and lessons learned from a patient-informed, web-based pregnancy and postpartum lifestyle intervention
abstract: BACKGROUND: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) contributes to the epidemic of diabetes and obesity in mothers and their offspring. The main objective of this pilot study was: 1) to refine the GDM Management System (GooDMomS), a web-based pregnancy and postpartum behavioral intervention, and 2) to assess the feasibility of the intervention. METHODS: In Phase 1, ten semi-structured interviews were conducted with women suffering from current or recent onset GDM mellitus GDM to collect pilot data on the web-based intervention interface and content, and to solicit recommendations from women on refinements to improve the GoodDMomS intervention site. The interviews were audio-taped, transcribed, and independently reviewed to identify key themes using Atlas.ti v7.0. In Phase 2, a single-arm proof of concept study was conducted and 23 participants were enrolled in the GooDMomS program. Participants received web lessons, weight and glucose self-tracking, automated feedback, and access to a message board for peer support. The primary outcome was feasibility, including recruitment and retention, and acceptance. Secondary outcomes included the proportion of women whose weight gain during pregnancy (WLG) was within Institute of Medicine (IOM) guidelines and who were able to return to their pre-pregnancy weight after delivery. RESULTS: Comments from semi-structured interviews focused on: 1) usability of the online diary and tracking system for self-monitoring, 2) access to a safe, reliable social network for peer support, and 3) ability of prenatal clinicians to access the online Diary for clinical management. A total of 21 (91%) completed the pregnancy phase. 15/21 (71%) of the participants complied with the Institute of Medicine (IOM) GWG guidelines. Sixteen (70%) completed the postpartum period. 7/16 (43%) and 9/16 (56%) of the participants returned to their pre-pregnancy weight at 6 and 30 weeks postpartum, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: This study documents the feasibility of the GooDMomS program. Findings may have implications for weaving technology in perinatal care and inform the current care paradigm for women with GDM. The results support further research with recruiting a larger sample of participants and comparing the results with the intervention and standard of care. STUDY REGISTRATION: The study was submitted to ClinicalTrials.gov on May 15, 2012 under protocol no. NCT01600534 .

title: The effects of a body weight and physical activity intervention (BeWEL) initiated by a national colorectal cancer screening program: randomized controlled trial
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the impact of a diet and physical activity intervention (BeWEL) on weight change in people with body mass index >25 weight (kg)/height (m)(2) at increased risk of colorectal cancer and other comorbidities associated with obesity . DESIGN Multicenter, randomized, controlled, parallel-group study. SETTING Four health boards of the Scottish National Health Service. PARTICIPANTS 329 overweight or obese adults (aged 50 to 74 years) who underwent colonoscopy after testing positive for fecal occult blood, as part of the national bowel screening program, and who had a histopathological diagnosis of adenoma has been confirmed. 163 were randomized to the intervention and 166 to the control. INTERVENTION Participants were randomized to a control group (weight-loss brochure only) or a 12-month intervention group (three in-person visits with a lifestyle consultant plus monthly 15-minute phone calls). The goal was a 7% reduction in body weight, and participants received a personalized energy prescription (2508 kJ (600 kcal) less than needed for weight maintenance) and a body weight scale. Motivational interviewing techniques examined self-assessed confidence, ambivalence, and personal values related to weight. Behavioral strategies included goal setting, identifying implementation intentions, self-monitoring of body weight, and providing counselor feedback on reported diet, physical activity, and weight change. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary endpoint was weight change over 12 months. Secondary endpoints included changes in waist circumference, blood pressure, fasting cardiovascular biomarkers, and variables of glucose metabolism, physical activity, diet, and alcohol consumption. RESULTS At 12 months, primary endpoint data were available for 148 (91%) participants in the intervention group and 157 (95%) in the control group. The mean weight loss was 3.50 kg (SD 4.91) (95% confidence interval 2.70 to 4.30) in the intervention group compared to 0.78 kg (SD 3.77) (0.19 to 1.38 ) in the control group. The group difference was 2.69 kg (95% confidence interval 1.70 to 3.67). Between-group differences were significant for waist circumference, body mass index, blood pressure, blood glucose levels, diet, and physical activity. No reported adverse events were assumed to be related to study participation. CONCLUSIONS Significant weight loss can be achieved through a diet and exercise intervention initiated as part of a national colorectal cancer screening program, which offers significant potential for reducing disease risk in older adults. STUDY REGISTRATION Current Controlled Trials ISRCTN53033856.

title: The effects of a nurse-led care program on events and physical and psychosocial parameters in heart failure patients with preserved ejection fraction: a randomized clinical trial in primary care in Russia
abstract: BACKGROUND: Disease management programs (DMPs) improve the quality of care for patients with heart failure (HF). However, only a limited number of studies have evaluated the effectiveness of such programs for patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFPEF). OBJECTIVE: To estimate the impact of a structured, nurse-led patient education program and general practice care plan on outcome measures and events in patients with HFPEF. METHODS: Single-blind, randomized clinical trial with a six-month intervention and an additional 12-month follow-up. In the control group, patients (n = 41) were treated according to Russian national guidelines. Patients in the intervention group (n=44) received education on individual lifestyle modifications and changes in risk factors for cardiovascular disease (CVD), home exercise training, and weekly nurse consultations, in addition to usual care. RESULTS: Six months after enrollment, patients in the intervention group significantly improved body mass index, waist circumference, six-minute walk test distance, total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein, left ventricular end-diastolic volume index, quality of life, and level of fear. At 18 months, there were 11 deaths (25%) or hospitalizations in the intervention group and 12 (29%) in the control group (p=0.134). Cardiovascular mortality and readmission rates were not significantly reduced at six months of follow-up: the hazard ratio was 0.47 (95% CI: 0.17-1.28"; P=0.197). At 18 months, this was 0.85 ( 0.42-1.73;" P = 0.658). CONCLUSION: This primary care-based DMP for patients with HFPEF improved patients' emotional status and quality of life, positively influenced body weight, functional capacity, and lipid profile, and dampened cardiac remodeling.

title: The impact of cost notifications on primary care physician ordering of laboratory tests.
abstract: BACKGROUND Physicians are under increased pressure to help control rising healthcare costs despite a lack of information regarding the cost implications of patient care decisions. OBJECTIVE To evaluate the impact of real-time display of laboratory costs on primary care physician prescribing for standard outpatient laboratory testing. DESIGN Interrupted time series analysis with parallel control group. PARTICIPANTS Two hundred and fifteen primary care physicians (153 intervention and 62 control physicians) using a shared electronic medical record between April 2010 and November 2011. The setting was an alliance of five multidisciplinary group practices in Massachusetts. INTERVENTION The average Medicare reimbursement rate for 27 laboratory tests was displayed in an electronic health record at the time of ordering, including 21 less expensive tests (<$40.00) and six more expensive tests (>$40.00). MAIN INTERVENTIONS We compared the change in the slope of the monthly laboratory order rate between intervention and control physicians for 12 months before the intervention and 6 months after the intervention. We surveyed all intervention and control physicians 6 months after the intervention to capture attitudes towards costs and cost presentations. MAIN FINDINGS Among 27 laboratory tests, interventional physicians demonstrated a significant decrease in ordering rates compared to control physicians for five (19%) tests. These included a significant relative decrease in order rates for four out of 21 (19%) lower-cost lab tests and one out of six (17%) more expensive lab tests. A majority (81%) of physicians reported that the intervention improved their knowledge of the relative costs of laboratory testing. CONCLUSIONS The real-time display of cost information in an electronic medical record can result in a modest reduction in laboratory test orders and is well received. Our study shows that electronic health records can serve as a tool to promote cost transparency and reduce the use of laboratory tests.

title: The impact of evidence-based dissemination of guidelines for the assessment and treatment of major depression in a behavioral health care organization
abstract: This study tests whether a managed behavioral therapy organization can influence adherence to practice guidelines for the management of major depressive disorder in a randomized guideline dissemination trial. Guidelines were distributed to psychotherapists (N=443) under one of three conditions: (1) a general mailing of guidelines to clinicians, (2) a mailing in which guidelines were addressed to a patient beginning treatment with the clinician, and (3) no mailing of policies. Results showed no impact of guideline dissemination, despite sentinel effects, as measured by patient and physician self-reports and by episode characteristics derived from claims data. The results also revealed high rates of clinically reported compliance that were not detected in the harm data, indicating significant undertreatment of depression. Findings suggest that mental health systems need to look for other dissemination strategies to improve adherence to standards of care and increase the performance of independently practicing clinicians.

title: The influence of guidelines, standards and economic restrictions on clinical decision-making processes
abstract: Guidelines aim to improve clinical decision-making. In contrast to textbooks and journals, which aim to improve medical knowledge, guidelines attempt to influence medical behavior. Scientific models of clinical decision-making such as action theory and empirical data on the effectiveness of guidelines suggest that guidelines do not always achieve their goals and can even lead to a deterioration in the quality of medical care. Therefore, there is a need for controlled clinical trials to investigate whether guideline-exposed physicians achieve better patient outcomes than guideline-naïve physicians. Guidelines can only be regarded as evidence-based if their positive effect is empirically proven.

title: The impact of infectious diseases. Specialist-led, computerized, physician-directed, antimicrobial stewardship program for input linezolid
The impact of medication adherence on lung health outcomes in cystic fibrosis
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: As new drugs continue to be introduced to improve the health of individuals with cystic fibrosis (CF), addressing patient adherence becomes increasingly important. Currently, adherence to pulmonary medications in people with CF is about 50%. Recent research has shown that poor adherence to therapy is associated with poorer health outcomes. This review summarizes recent research on the impact of adherence on lung health and highlights future areas of research and clinical practice to address this growing need. RECENT FINDINGS: Recent research has shown that nonadherence is associated with more hospital admissions and pulmonary exacerbations, lower lung function, and longer length of stay. However, most research has been conducted using pharmacy refill records as an objective measure of compliance. Electronic drug monitoring provides more detailed information about usage patterns that can feed directly into clinical care. In addition, few clinical studies have been published examining behavioral interventions to promote adherence. SUMMARY: Given recent research linking adherence to lung health outcomes, there is a growing need to measure and assess adherence in clinical care. As new drugs are approved for CF, methods for monitoring adherence to therapy must also be developed and approved. Clinicians must continue to assess barriers to adherence in order to tailor interventions to a patient's needs.

title: The effects of assisted telemetry monitoring in people with type 2 diabetes: study protocol for a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: The prevalence of diabetes is increasing and current treatments are unsustainable. Effective approaches to support self-management are needed. The aim of this randomized controlled trial is to determine whether assisted telemetric monitoring of glycemic control and blood pressure leads to a reduction in glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c; the primary outcome of a measurement of long-term glycemic control) and secondary outcomes of blood pressure and weight in humans with poorly controlled diabetes compared to a control group receiving usual care. METHODS/DESIGN: Design: Multicenter, randomized controlled study with embedded qualitative study. Setting: Primary care in the Lothian, Kent, Glasgow and Borders regions of the UK. Participants: People with type 2 diabetes and confirmed HbA1c>7.5% (58 mmol/mol). Intervention/Comparison: Randomization into intervention or control groups will be performed by the Edinburgh Clinical Trials Unit. Intervention group participants are shown how to use blood glucose and blood pressure monitors and scales that use Bluetooth wireless technology to modem readings to a remote server. These participants will be asked to measure morning and evening blood sugar at least twice a week, and weight and blood pressure weekly. Measurements are reviewed at least weekly by in-office nurses who liaise with patients to adjust therapy according to guidelines and reinforce lifestyle advice. The participants in the control group receive the usual care. All participants receive individual training. Follow-up: Measurements will be taken at practices 9 months after randomization by research nurses blinded to assignment. The primary outcome measure is HbA1c and the secondary outcome measure is daily systolic and diastolic blood pressure, weight, and cost per quality-adjusted life year. Analysis: Intention-to-treat analyzes are carried out. The sample size of 320 participants allows for a 20% drop-out and has a power of 80% at 5% significance to detect an absolute drop in HbA1c of 0.5% (6 mmol/mol) in the intervention group. The qualitative study will examine the experiences of patients and professionals using the intervention. STUDY REGISTRATION: Study Registration Number ISRCTN71674628.

title: The importance of cardiovascular risk management in the management of hypertension: the role of ACE inhibitors and ARBs
The importance of doctor-patient communication in the care of somatizing patients
abstract: The term "somatization" refers to the manifestation of multiple somatic ailments that are not explained by organic changes. According to the literature, 15-25 percent of all doctor visits are related to somatization. Because medical education places too little emphasis on evaluating the possible psychological background of certain somatic symptoms, physicians can feel powerless and make unwarranted diagnostic and therapeutic efforts. Patients may also feel helpless and frustrated, and their anxiety and distress may increase. Because stress is an important factor in the somatization process, reducing stress and improving coping are key elements of chronic disease treatment guidelines. Evidence-based interventions range from brief counseling and medication to cognitive and behavioral psychotherapy. Reattribution, a short (10-30 minutes) structured intervention that can be delivered in primary or secondary care, can result in significant reductions in somatic symptoms and anxiety in certain cases.

title: The Study to Improve Care in Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease: CAROL-Improvement of Care Processes and Quality of Life of COPD Patients in Primary Care: Study Protocol for a Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Swiss Ministry of Health launched a national quality program "QualiCCare" in 2011 to improve healthcare for patients with COPD. The purpose of this study is to determine whether participation in the COPD Quality Initiative (“QualiCCare”) improves adherence to recommended clinical trials processes and shows the impact on COPD care for patients and on the impact of COPD on an individual's life . METHODS: CAROL is a cluster-randomized controlled trial with randomization at the general practitioner level. Thirty primary care physicians are randomly assigned to an intervention or control group of equal size. Each general practitioner consults patients aged 45 years or older with a smoking history of >/= ten pack years (PY) sequentially and regardless of the reason for the current consultation. Patients with confirmed (by spirometric evaluation) COPD will be included in the study. General practitioners in the intervention group receive “QualiCCare” training, which addresses knowledge, decision-making and behavioral aspects and the delivery of care according to COPD quality indicators and evidence-based key elements. In the control group, no educational intervention is used and COPD patients are treated as usual. The duration of study is one year. The primary outcome measure is an aggregate score of relevant clinical processes that define elements in the care of patients with COPD: smoking cessation counseling, influenza vaccination, motivation for physical activity, appropriate pharmacotherapy, patient education, and collaborative care. With a power of 90% and an alpha significance level of 5%, 15 general practitioners with eight patients each are required in both study arms. Assuming a dropout rate of 20%, 288 patients must be included. DISCUSSION: It is important to design and implement interventions that add value to COPD care while considering quality and efficiency. Care pathways that transform physician knowledge and behavior have the potential to improve care by transferring knowledge into clinical practice. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT01921556.

title: The impact of a physician and patient intervention program on food intake
abstract: BACKGROUND: Efficient dietary interventions for hypertensive patients in clinical settings are required. AIM: To evaluate the separate and combined impact of a physician intervention (MD-I) and a patient intervention (PT-I) on food intake in hypertensive patients. DESIGN: A nested 2x2 design, randomized controlled trial conducted over 18 months. PARTICIPANTS: A total of 32 physicians and 574 outpatients with hypertension. INTERVENTION: MD-I included training modules addressing the Seventh Report of the Joint National Committee on the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation and Treatment of Hypertension, Guidelines for the Management of Hypertension and Lifestyle Modifications. PT-I included lifestyle coaching on adopting the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) eating pattern, reducing sodium intake, weight management, increasing physical activity, and moderate alcohol consumption. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Food intake was measured using the Block Food Frequency Questionnaire. Conformity with the DASH dietary pattern was estimated by a DASH score. STATISTICAL ANALYZES: The main effects of MD-I and PT-I and their interaction were assessed using analysis of covariance. RESULTS: After 6 months of intervention, MD-I participants significantly increased intakes of potassium, fruits, juices, and carbohydrates; decreased fat intake; and improved overall diet quality as measured by the Healthy Eating Index. The PT-I intervention resulted in increased intakes of carbohydrate, protein, fiber, calcium, potassium, fruit and fruit juices, vegetables, dairy, and the Healthy Eating Index, and decreased intakes of fat, saturated fat, cholesterol, sodium, Sweets and additives fats/oils/sweets. In addition, PT-I improved the overall DASH concordance score. The change in DASH score was significantly associated with changes in blood pressure and weight at 6 months. After 18 months, most changes returned to baseline, including the DASH score. CONCLUSIONS: Both MD-I and PT-I improved eating behavior at 6 months with some lasting effects at 18 months. Although all observed dietary changes were consistent with DASH nutrient goals or food group guidelines, only the PT-I intervention was effective in improving overall DASH concordance score. This finding confirms the role of medical nutritional therapy in intensive long-term interventions for hypertensive risk reduction and weight control, and underscores the need to develop maintenance strategies. Additionally, this study emphasizes the importance of collaboration between physicians, licensed dietitians and other nutritionists, and lay health professionals while supporting patients to make healthy behavior changes.

title: The influence of patient characteristics on the adequacy of surgical treatment in breast cancer patients. Progetto Oncologia Femminile
abstract: BACKGROUND: As part of a multi-year educational effort sponsored by the Ministry of Health and regional health authorities, patterns of care for breast cancer patients in Italian general hospitals were monitored to identify areas of practice whose quality needed improvement. DESIGN: Information on the diagnostic and therapeutic procedures performed on 1724 consecutive breast cancer patients in 63 general hospitals in eight Italian regions was collected retrospectively from medical records. The quality of care was assessed by a diagnostic and therapeutic score based on the observed level of adherence to pre-established procedures. RESULTS: The median of the total diagnostic score and the staging score was 60%. About a third of surgical procedures (38%) were inappropriate: a quarter (24%) of stage I-II patients had unnecessarily radical surgery (i.e., Halsted mastectomy) and limited surgery in patients with small tumors (i.e., , < or = 2 cm) was underused. Chronological age influenced physician behavior: older patients were more likely to have less intensive diagnostic work-up and less appropriate surgical treatment (with more frequent use of unnecessary radical surgery and less frequent resort to limited surgery), regardless of their overall health status. The presence of one or more concomitant diseases was associated with a lack of axillary clearance and a lower use of conservative surgery regardless of age. CONCLUSION: In agreement with others, this study confirms the existence of a clinically meaningful influence of patient age on diagnostic and therapeutic behavior and the use of unnecessarily radical surgical procedures. The paper discusses the implications of these findings for the next phase of the educational project, in which practice guidelines will be developed and implemented to improve the quality of care for breast cancer patients.

title: The Intellectual Structure and Substance of the Knowledge Use Field: A Longitudinal Cocitation Analysis by Authors, 1945 to 2004
abstract: Background It has been argued that science and society are in the midst of a far-reaching renegotiation of the social contract between science and society, with society becoming a far more active partner in the creation of knowledge. On the one hand, new forms of knowledge production are emerging, on the other hand, science and society are experiencing a rapid acceleration of new forms of knowledge use. At the same time, since World War II, the science underpinning the field of knowledge exploitation has experienced exponential growth. There is little in-depth research in this area and no comprehensive analyzes using bibliometric methods have been carried out. Methods Using bibliometric analyses, particularly first-author co-citation analyses, our group performed a domain analysis of the knowledge use field and traced its historical development between 1945 and 2004. Our aim was to map the historical development of knowledge use as a field and to identify the changing intellectual structure of its scientific domains. We have more than 5,000 articles based on citation data from the Web of Science? analyzed. Search terms were combinations of knowledge, research, evidence, policy, ideas, science, innovation, technology, information theory and use, utilization and uptake. Findings We provide an overview of the intellectual structure and how it has changed over six decades. The field does not become large enough to represent with a cocitation map until the mid-1960s. Our results show strong growth from the mid-1960s to 2004, as well as the emergence of specialized domains that reflect distinct collectives of intellectual activity and thought. By the mid-1980s, the main domains were focused on innovation diffusion, technology transfer, and knowledge exploitation. Beginning slowly in the mid-1980s and then growing rapidly, a fourth scientific field emerged, evidence-based medicine. The field is dominated every decade by one individual, Everett Rogers, and by one paradigm, diffusion of innovation. Conclusion We conclude that the common view that social science disciplines are in a state where no accepted principles or theories guide research (that is, that they are preparadigmatic) cannot be supported for this area. Second, we document the emergence of a new domain in the field of knowledge use, evidence-based medicine. Third, we conclude that Everett Rogers was the dominant figure in this field and that his presentation of the general model of diffusion was the dominant paradigm in this field until the advent of evidence-based medicine.

title: The Irritable Bowel Syndrome Outcome Study (IBSOS): rationale and design of a randomized, placebo-controlled study with 12-month follow-up of self-administered versus clinically administered CBT in moderate-to-severe irritable bowel syndrome
abstract: Irritable bowel syndrome is a common, often disabling, gastrointestinal disorder whose full spectrum of symptoms lacks satisfactory medical or dietary management. One of the few empirically validated treatments involves a specific psychological therapy called cognitive behavioral therapy, which, when available, is typically administered over several months by trained physicians in tertiary care settings. There is an urgent need to develop more effective versions of CBT that require minimal professional assistance but retain the efficacy profile of clinically based CBT. The Irritable Bowel Syndrome Outcome Study (IBSOS) is a multicenter, placebo-controlled, randomized study to evaluate whether a self-administered version of CBT is at least as effective as standard CBT and more effective than an attentional control in reducing core GI symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome and its burden (e.g. psychological strain, impairment of quality of life, etc.) in moderately to severely affected irritable bowel patients. Additional objectives are to assess the durability of the response to treatment over a 12-month period at quarterly intervals; identifying clinically useful patient characteristics associated with the outcome to gain an understanding of subgroups of participants for whom CBT is most beneficial; identify theory-based mechanisms of change (agents) that explain how and why CBT works;" and assess the economic costs and benefits of CBT. Between August 2010, when IBSOS began recruiting subjects, and February 2012, the IBSOS randomized 171 of 480 patients The results have the potential to improve the health of IBS patients, reduce their social and economic costs, conserve scarce health care resources and inform evidence-based practice guidelines.

title: The Italian Diabetes and Physical Activity Study 2 (IDES-2): a long-term behavioral intervention for adopting and maintaining a physically active lifestyle
abstract: BACKGROUND: Physical activity (PA)/exercise has become an integral part of the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). However, due to a number of obstacles, most notably the lack of acceptable, feasible, and validated behavioral intervention strategies, current guidelines are difficult to implement in this population. The present manuscript reports the rationale, study design, and methods, and design considerations of the Italian Diabetes and Exercise Study (IDES)-2, a randomized controlled trial that evaluated the effectiveness of a behavior modification strategy in increasing total daily PA and reducing sedentary time tests (SED time) in patients with T2DM. METHODS/DESIGN: On January 7, 2014, IDES_2 began enrolling 300 patients with known T2DM of at least 1 year's duration in three tertiary-referral diabetes outpatient clinics in Rome. Additional requirements are age 40 to 80 years, body mass index 27 to 40 kg/m(2), sedentary lifestyle and physical inactivity for at least 6 months, ability to walk 1 mile unaided, and fitness based on cardiovascular assessment . Patients will be randomized by center and within each center, by age, and type of diabetes treatment to either the intervention or control groups. Patients in the intervention group (INT) (n = 150) receive theoretical and practical training counseling consisting of aggregated behavior modification techniques once a year (one individual theoretical counseling session plus eight twice-weekly individual theoretical and practical training counseling sessions). 3 years. Patients in the control group (CON) (n = 150) receive standard care, including general practitioner recommendations for daily PA. The primary outcomes are total daily PA and SED time, measured objectively through the use of an accelerometer. Secondary outcomes are physical fitness, modifiable cardiovascular risk factors, musculoskeletal disorders, well-being/depression and health-related quality of life. DISCUSSION: The behavioral intervention strategy tested in IDES_2 is based on solid theoretical foundations and uses multiple behavior change techniques, two factors that have been shown to improve the effectiveness of behavioral interventions. In addition, physicians and exercise specialists have been specifically trained to advise/prescribe and/or monitor PA/exercise in patients with metabolic disorders. Finally, the large sample size, the long study duration, and the objective measurement of PA allow statistically significant and scientifically robust conclusions on the feasibility and effectiveness of this intervention in T2DM patients. TRIAL REGISTRATION: ClinicalTrials.gov"; NCT01600937 ;" October 10, 2012.

title: The disease of knowledge
The lack, need and opportunities for decision-making and information tools to educate primary care physicians and women about breast cancer chemoprevention
abstract: This perspective on Vogel et al. (starting on page 696 in this issue of the journal) examines the prescribing patterns of tamoxifen and raloxifene and why these agents are underused for breast cancer prevention, despite their effectiveness in definitive studies, approval by the Food and Drug Administration, and the American Society of Clinical Oncology Guidelines Committee confirmation for this purpose. The complexity of weighing the positives and negatives of drugs and estimating net benefits are discussed, as is the need for informational resources such as interactive web-based tools to enable better individual decisions about chemoprevention options.

title: The legal status of local research ethics committees

The LIFESTYLE Study: Costs and Effects of a Structured Lifestyle Program in Overweight and Obese Subfertile Women to Reduce the Need for Fertility Treatment and Improve Reproductive Outcome. A randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: In the Netherlands, 30% of subfertile women are overweight or obese and there is currently no agreement on fertility treatment for them. Data from observational and small intervention studies suggest that weight reduction increases the likelihood of conception, reduces pregnancy complications, and improves perinatal outcome, but this has not been confirmed in randomized controlled trials. This study will evaluate the costs and effects of a six-month structured lifestyle program aimed at weight loss followed by conventional fertility treatment (intervention group) versus conventional fertility treatment (control group) in overweight and obese subfertile women. We hypothesize that the intervention will reduce the need for fertility treatment, reduce obesity-related pregnancy complications, and improve perinatal outcome. METHODS/DESIGN: Multicenter, randomized, controlled study in subfertile women (age 18-39 years) with a body mass index between 29 and 40 kg/m2. Exclusion criteria are azoospermia, use of donor sperm, severe endometriosis, premature ovarian failure, endocrinopathies, or pre-existing hypertensive disorders. In the intervention group, a weight loss of at least 5% to 10% over a period of six months is aimed for through a combination of diet, increased physical activity and behavior change. If conception has not been achieved after six months, these patients start fertility treatment according to the Dutch fertility guidelines. In the control group, treatment is started according to the Dutch fertility guidelines, regardless of the patient's weight. OUTCOME MEASURES AND ANALYSIS: The primary outcome measure is a healthy singleton born at least 37 weeks gestation after vaginal delivery. Secondary outcome measures including pregnancy outcome and complications, percentage of women requiring fertility treatment, clinical and sustained pregnancy rates, body weight, quality of life, and cost were performed to compare costs and health effects in the intervention and control groups. DISCUSSION: The study will provide evidence of the costs and effects of a lifestyle intervention aimed at weight reduction in overweight and obese subfertile women and will provide clinician guidance for the management of these patients. STUDY REGISTRATION: Dutch Study Register NTR1530.

title: The treatment of "psychogenic" orofacial pain
The management of patients with nicotine dependence - the role of the general practitioner
abstract: The porter needs disease management for his smoking patients. Questionnaires help define the patient's diagnosis and degree of nicotine addiction, as well as the fingerprint of their smoking history. The ICD-10 code and the Fagerstrom nicotine addiction test are used. Without optimal patient motivation, no therapy is indicated. Prochaska and DiClemente's transtheoretical model of dividing the motivational stage into anticipation, contemplation, preparation and action is widespread. Many other factors such as previous experiences, disaster scenarios, self-efficacy, and choice of therapeutic modality are important for the best outcome. 90% of a gatekeeper's job is minimal intervention. This means individually tailored reasoning to guide the patient's motivation to quit smoking. The concept is defined in the rules of the five R's with Relevance, Risks, Rewards, Obstacles and Repetition. According to these criteria, the gatekeeper achieves up to a 60% positive motivational shift with only minimal intervention. Smoking cessation guidelines around the world are very similar, showing a Level A synergy of behavioral therapy and medication with either nicotine replacement, bupropion, or varenicline. Choosing a different regimen is either less efficient or, anecdotally, results in a further loss in the smoker's life expectancy. The gatekeeper has the infrastructure, know-how and trust of his patients to act as disease manager. Successful therapy is possible over a period of six months with around seven consultations, and the success rate should even be higher than the values in the medication studies. Smokers should be informed by health organizations to avoid self-medication and to seek professional help. The gatekeeper is an ideal candidate.

title: The MAURO Study: Baseline Characteristics and Guideline Compliance
abstract: BACKGROUND: The Multiple Intervention and Audit in Renal Diseases to Optimize Care (MAURO) study was a cluster-randomized controlled trial in 22 renal clinics that aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a multimodal quality improvement intervention to improve adherence to guideline recommendations for prevention chronic kidney disease improve disease progression (CKD) and cardiovascular (CV) complications. The aim of the study was to test whether this multimodal intervention improves adherence to recommended targets for a number of surrogate indicators relevant to blood pressure (BP) control, sodium intake, proteinuria, dyslipidemia, anemia, and calcium phosphate changes. The study also tested whether the same procedure slowed the progression of CKD and prevented cardiovascular complications in CKD patients. METHOD: Twenty-two renal clinics were randomized into 2 arms: an intervention arm applying a multi-method quality improvement intervention and a control arm providing standard of care. Surrogate indicators were measured to assess blood pressure (BP) control, sodium intake, proteinuria, dyslipidemia, anemia, and calcium phosphate changes. RESULTS: Despite the fact that the vast majority of patients enrolled in this study (95%) were treated with antihypertensive drugs, baseline blood pressure goals (specific for proteinuria and diabetes) were met in only 45% of non-proteinuric patients, and only just 45% reaches 14% and 18% of proteinuria and diabetics, respectively. Use of diuretics in hypertensive patients was less than required, and approximately 80% of patients had salt excretion > 100 mmol/24 hours. Total cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol were outside the target range in over 40% of patients, but only about 60% of them were on statins. A large majority of CKD patients were obese or overweight. The proportion of smokers was relatively low (13%) and 37% of patients had quit smoking, indicating patient awareness of the health risks of smoking. CONCLUSIONS: In our cohort, the management of modifiable risk factors for chronic kidney disease progression and cardiovascular disease was significantly improved.

title: The McMaster curriculum: a critique
The 21st Century Medical Practice (MOXXI): Effectiveness of computer-assisted decision support in reducing inappropriate prescriptions in primary care.
abstract: Background: Adverse drug-related events are common in the elderly, and inappropriate prescribing is a preventable risk factor. Our aim was to determine whether inappropriate prescriptions could be reduced if GPs had computerized access to information on all prescriptions issued and automatic alerts to potential prescription problems. METHODS: We randomly assigned 107 general practitioners with at least 100 patients aged 66 years and older (total 12,560) to receive computerized decision making support (CDS) or a control group. Physicians in the CDS group had access to current and past prescription information through a special computer link to the province's senior drug insurance program. When any of the 159 clinically relevant prescribing issues were identified by the CDS software, the physician received a notification detailing the nature of the issue, potential consequences, and alternative therapies. The rate of initiation and discontinuation of potentially inappropriate prescriptions was assessed over a 13-month period. Results: In the 2 months prior to the study, 31.8% of patients in the CDS group and 33.3% of patients in the control group had at least 1 potentially inappropriate prescription. During the study, the number of new potentially inappropriate prescriptions per 1000 visits was significantly lower (18%) in the CDS group than in the control group (relative rate [RR] 0.82, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.69-0, 98) , but between-group differences in the discontinuation rate of potentially inappropriate prescriptions were only for therapeutic duplication by study physician and another physician (RR 1.66, 95% CI 0.99-2.79) and drug-drug interactions induced by Investigator-issued prescriptions were significantly investigator (RR 2.15, 95% CI 0.98-4.70). Interpretation: Computerized access to full drug profiles and alerts to potential prescribing problems reduces the rate of initiation of potentially inappropriate prescriptions, but has a more selective impact on the discontinuation of such prescriptions.

title: The moderating effect of client adherence-promoting interventions on evidence-based practices for children and adolescents with mental health problems
abstract: The lack of adherence of children and adolescents to evidence-based psychosocial interventions remains a fundamental barrier to treatment effectiveness. To maintain patient adherence, researchers and clinicians have employed a range of strategies to promote adherence, from phone calls and letters to the provision of transportation and childcare to motivation-enhancing therapies. However, the impact of adherence promoters on intervention outcomes has not been reported. This study examined the moderating effect of adherence-promoting strategies in a survey and meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials of cognitive-behavioral therapy, interpersonal therapy, and psychoeducation for children and adolescents with mental health problems (k = 33). The results showed the nature and intensity of the moderated study effect sizes of the adherence promoters according to the patient characteristics (age, gender, diagnosis). Preliminary results suggest that men had higher effect sizes when more intensive efforts were made to promote adherence. Efforts to promote adherence were associated with smaller effect sizes in adolescents diagnosed with externalizing disorders. The results of this study suggest directions for future research to clarify clinical guidelines to maximize retention in evidence-based psychotherapy.

title: The myADHDportal.com Improvement Program: An innovative quality improvement effort to improve the quality of ADHD care provided by community-based pediatricians
abstract: Although the American Academy of Pediatrics has developed and disseminated clear evidence-based guidelines for ADHD care, outpatient pediatricians often have difficulty implementing these guidelines. New strategies are needed to improve the quality of care for children with ADHD and improve pediatrician application of the AAP consensus guidelines. An evidence-based quality improvement intervention was developed that effectively improves the quality of ADHD care provided by outpatient pediatricians. To enable this intervention model to be widely disseminated, the entire intervention was modified for online delivery. The intervention is called the myADHDportal.com Improvement Program. The full functionality of this online intervention is described, including the collection of online ADHD rating scales from parents and teachers, and online communication between parents, teachers, and physicians. In addition, the web portal integrates several innovative quality improvement features, including an online wizard to map ADHD patient flow, an online report card to monitor quality of care, and an online wizard to guide practices through the Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) cycle process. The combination of clinical utility and quality improvement tools facilitates the delivery of quality ADHD care and reduces several of the barriers to implementing AAP-recommended behaviors. First results with this intervention model are reviewed and goals for dissemination are described.

title: The Nazi Doctors' Trial and the International Ban on Medical Involvement in Torture
The need for research designed to support decisions in mental health service delivery
abstract: MEP Seligman (1995) argued that traditional approaches to researching mental health services do not provide consumers and practitioners with useful information, particularly in a setting increasingly dominated by managed care. The authors recommend 4 guidelines for designing a research program so that the results can support the decisions of key stakeholders (client families, practitioners, service managers, and policy makers): (a) Research must be targeted, programmatic, and include a strategy of complementary efficacy , Efficacy and cost-effectiveness studies”; (b) study design and intervention selection must be sensitive to describing who and in what context which intervention best serves; (c) the design must inform stakeholders about the nature and amount of effort required to achieve a behavioral criterion;" and (d) the strategy should inform researchers how information should be formatted to inform key stakeholders' decisions best to support.

title: The NIH report on its review of the Baby Fae case
The Nuremberg Code and Medical Research
abstract: Addresses the tensions between religious discourse and bioethics. Issues of Accessibility and Meaning";" Address different moral language and concepts.

title: The Nuremberg Code and the Nuremberg Trial. A re-evaluation
abstract: The Nuremberg Code contains 10 principles to guide physicians and researchers when experimenting with humans. These principles, particularly the first principle of “voluntary consent,” were primarily based on legal concepts, since the codes of medical ethics in existence at the time of the Nazi atrocities did not address consent and other safeguards for human subjects.
