The US judges leading the case did not want the code to apply only to the case before them, be a response to the atrocities committed by Nazi doctors, or not apply to research typically conducted in medical institutions is carried out . Instead, a careful reading of the judgment suggests that they wrote the code for the practice of human experiments whenever they are conducted.

title: The potential of asthma compliance management to improve asthma policy
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Expert panel report 3 guidelines recommend physicians to use "adherence management strategies", however the evidence for these interventions is weak. Clinicians need effective, proven adherence interventions because approximately 50% of patients with asthma fail to follow physician medication recommendations, resulting in unnecessary morbidity This review examines components of an organized adherence management program that has been successful in uncontrolled trials to promote adherence and morbidity and reduce costs DATA SOURCES: A literature review was conducted in the following areas of asthma management: guidelines, costs, morbidity, adherence, monitoring, and communication skills STUDY SELECTION: Studies examining outcomes of psychoeducational, behavioral, monitoring, and communication interventions RESULTS: Studies, using single interventions alone were moderately effective in promoting adherence Two uncontrolled studies in children with severe asthma ma treated in both inpatient and outpatient rehabilitation settings used 4 intervention strategies to achieve significant reductions in morbidity and costs. These strategies included: (1) objective monitoring of compliance; (2) identification of the cause(s) of nonadherence; (3) providing specific strategies for each cause;' and (4) using communication skills for motivational interviews to enhance strategy implementation. CONCLUSION: Nonadherence remains a significant problem Reducing morbidity and costs A controlled evaluation of effective methods is warranted to increase the evidence for adherence management for future asthma guidelines.

title: The power of clinical trials and guidelines and the challenge of conflicts of interest
The practice of ethics committees
abstract: KIE: A brief news item welcomes the publication of a useful report by the Royal College of Physicians of London in September 1984, Guidelines on the Practice of Ethics Committees in Medical Research. An important recommendation in the guidelines is that committees should be informed of adverse or unforeseen circumstances arising from a study and that abstracts or reprints of publications should be sent to them. If it turns out that clinical trials were conducted without reference to ethical concerns, the committee should forward the facts to the institution for which it has jurisdiction.

title: The problem with the "5 whys".
abstract: The Problem with... series covers controversial issues related to efforts to improve the quality of healthcare, including commonly recommended but deceptively difficult strategies for improvement, and pervasive problems that seem intractable.

title: The problem of survey research.
abstract: The problem with survey research argues against survey research as the primary source of reliable information. George Beam argues that all survey research tools, all types of questions - including surveys, face-to-face interviews and focus groups - produce unreliable and potentially inaccurate results. Because those who rely on survey research only see answers to questions, they and others cannot evaluate the results. They have no way of knowing whether the responses reflect respondents' actual behavior (objective phenomena) or their true beliefs and opinions (subjective phenomena). Reliable information can only be obtained through observation, experimentation, multiple data sources, formal model building and testing, document analysis and comparison. In fifteen chapters divided into six parts – Ubiquity of Survey Research, The Problem, Questioning Tools, Question Settings, Questioners and Appropriate Methods and Research Designs – The Problem with Survey Research shows how questioning tools, settings in which questions and answers take place, and survey researchers themselves falsify the results and thereby make the answers unreliable. The final two chapters and appendices examine observation, other methods of data collection, and research designs that can provide accurate or correct information, and show how reliance on survey research can and must be overcome. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: The Prussian Ordinance of 1900: Early Ethical Standards for Human Experimentation in Germany
The QICKD study protocol: a cluster-randomized study comparing quality improvement interventions with lower systolic blood pressure in chronic kidney disease (CKD) in primary care
abstract: Background Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a relatively newly recognized but common long-term disease affecting 5 to 10% of the population. Effective CKD management, with an emphasis on strict blood pressure control, reduces cardiovascular risk and slows CKD progression. Currently, there is an unprecedented increase in referrals to specialized kidney services, which are often based in tertiary centers, are inconvenient for patients and waste resources. National and international CKD guidelines contain quality goals for primary care. However, no rigorous evaluations of strategies implementing these guidelines have been conducted. The purpose of this study is to test whether quality improvement interventions improve primary care for elevated blood pressure in chronic kidney disease, reduce cardiovascular risk, and slow kidney disease progression with usual exercise. The two interventions include: providing clinical practice guidelines with prompts and audit-based education. The study population will be all people with CKD from general practices in eight locations across England. Randomization takes place at the level of general practitioners. The intended sample (three arms from 25 practices) allows the study to detect a difference of 3 mmHg in systolic blood pressure between the different quality improvement interventions. An additional 10 practices per arm will receive a questionnaire to measure changes in confidence in managing CKD. Follow-up is over two years. Outcomes are measured using anonymized, routinely collected data extracted from office computer systems. Our primary outcome measure will be the reduction in systolic blood pressure in people with chronic kidney disease and hypertension at two years. Secondary outcomes include biomedical outcomes and quality markers, including physician confidence in managing CKD. A small group of practices (n = 4) participate in an in-depth process evaluation. We will use time series data to examine the natural history of CKD in the community. Finally, we carry out an economic assessment based on a comparison of the cost-effectiveness of each intervention.

title: The Quality of Diabetes Care for Gullah Families in South Carolina
abstract: Empirical evidence from the Diabetes Control and Complication Trial (DCCT) suggests that maintaining normal glycemic control can prevent both microvascular and macrovascular disease in individuals diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) (DCCT, 1993 ). Adults with T2DM are also more likely to have hypertension (73% [HTN]) and patients with both are 2 to 4 times more likely to develop diabetic complications compared to the general population (CDC, 2005). The purpose of this descriptive study was to 1) describe the quality of diabetes care received by Gullah families who participated in the Project SuGar research study";" and 2) compare Gullah's quality of care to the national sample in the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Diabetes Reporting Card using two indicators of blood pressure and HbA1c. This was a secondary analysis from an overarching study that compared selected data to the CDC Diabetes Report Card, the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES III), and the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS). Sociodemographic and clinical data were collected from 1,057 research participants (N=1,057). Overall, compared to the national sample in the CDC reporting map, HbA1c was greater than 9.5% mg/dL in the gullahs (30.2% vs. 18%) and blood pressure was greater than 140/90 mmHg lower (29% vs. 34%) among participants. Almost half of the gullahs (45.9%) self-reported neurovascular complications such as foot pain, claudication, and kidney complications from kidney infection and dialysis (7.3%). The Gullah study participants are at risk for diabetes-related complications. The results suggest a quality gap in diabetes care and also suggest health differences in outcome measures. Optimal care that conforms to clinical guidelines could have a significant impact in reducing complications and health inequalities.

title: The rational patient and beyond: implications for treatment adherence in people with psychiatric disabilities.
abstract: Aim: Many people with mental disabilities do not benefit from evidence-based practices because they often do not seek or fully adhere to them. One way psychologists have made sense of this rehabilitation and health decision-making process, and subsequent behaviors (of which adherence might be considered one) is by proposing a “rational patient”; that is, decisions are made consciously by weighing perceived costs and benefits Intervention options However, social psychological research suggests limitations of a rational patient theory that affect models of health decision design: the research literature has been based on studies of rational patient models and alternative theories with empirical Support reviewed, with a particular focus on models related to decisions about rehabilitation strategies for psychiatric disabilities. Results: Notions of the rational patient evolved from several psychological models, including the health belief model, protective motivation theory, and planned behavior theory. A variety of practice strategies have evolved to encourage rational decision-making. However, research also suggests limitations to rational considerations of health. (1) Rather than being carefully and consciously considered, many health decisions are implicit and may be made outside of awareness. (2) decisions are not always planned; often it is the immediate needs of a context, rather than prior trade-offs, that have the greatest impact. (3) cool cognitions often do not dictate the process; emotional factors play an important role in health decisions. Each of these limitations suggest additional exercise strategies that will ease a person's health decisions. Conclusion: Old models of rational decision making need to be replaced by multiprocess models that explain supradeliberative factors in health decisions and behaviors (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Regulating gene therapy research in competent adult patients today and tomorrow: Implications of EU Directive 2001/20/EC
The results of large clinical trials: critical appraisal, dissemination of information and media coverage
abstract: The roundtable chose to focus its discussion on studies that, in terms of their importance, are likely to transform medical practices and behaviors. Such studies can be pre- or post-marketing studies. For the results of a study to change practice, they must be credible and meet basic methodological criteria. Nonetheless, it is appropriate to complete this binary assessment through the use of an assessment checklist appropriate for each category of user, ie the regulator, prescribing physicians and patients, sometimes informed directly by the media. The Round Table members proposed the "Giens 2003 Checklist". It consists of an interpretive semi-quantitative assessment checklist based on simple, actionable messages. A critical evaluation is a necessary prelude to the dissemination of the results to the different parties involved (healthcare professionals, patients, patient associations, the media and the general public) and the process of informing these parties in easy to understand but precise terms. The practical implementation of the results with a change in behavior and/or the issuing of guidelines are follow-up steps for which a certain delay time is unavoidable. The evaluation of implementation programs, together with a detailed analysis of the obstacles to changing medical practice in the future, is intended to improve and accelerate the implementation of important results in order to optimize patient management.

title: The right thing for early intervention in psychosis: time, setting, location, intensity, treatment, and cost
abstract: This article provides information on an exciting new approach to psychiatry. For the past 12 years the authors have worked with young people experiencing their first episode of psychosis. It is clear that intervention in the earliest stages of a psychotic illness allows physicians to make significant changes in the lives of young people and their families. This article summarizes current intervention strategies considered best practice guidelines for early treatment.

title: The rise of private hospital care
The role of the clinical pharmacist in lipid control in patients with dyslipidemia in Northern Jordan
abstract: AIM: The purpose of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of introducing clinical pharmacy services to achieve the target lipid profile in dyslipidemia patients in North Jordan. The study setting was conducted in a primary care facility in northern Jordan. METHODS: One hundred and fifty-two dyslipidemic patients were randomized into intervention and control groups and followed up for a period of 6 months. Patients in the intervention group were closely monitored by a clinical pharmacist who worked closely with physicians to monitor lipid profiles according to the third edition of the National Cholesterol Education Program Adult Treatment Panel recommendations. The patients in the control group received standard medical care. The main outcome measures the percentage of patients in the intervention group who met their low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol goal compared to the percentage of patients in the control group who met their low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol goal at the end of the study achieved. RESULTS: One hundred twenty-five patients completed the study period. At 6 months, 94.5% of patients in the intervention group and 71.2% of patients in the control group achieved their target low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol levels (P value < 0.001, Pearson's chi-square test), compared to 24.7 and 28.8% at baseline. The majority of pharmacist recommendations (90.4%) were followed by physicians, and overall lipid-lowering drug use increased to 91.8% in intervention-group patients and 86.5% in control-group patients, compared with 69.9 and 78.8% at baseline. CONCLUSION: The implementation of clinical pharmacy services in Jordan has improved the lipid profiles of patients with dyslipidemia.

title: The role of primary care physicians in increasing compliance to colorectal cancer screening: a randomized controlled trial (Italy)
abstract: Objectives To assess the effect of provider (GP versus hospital) on compliance with return of the stool occult blood test. Analysis of the GP characteristics associated with high compliance among its beneficiaries. Methods A questionnaire on screening behavior was sent to 1192 general practitioners from 13 districts of the Lazio region. We asked GPs to participate in a randomized study, we drew samples from 130 GPs, and approximately 1/10 of GP beneficiaries aged 50-75 (n = 3657) were invited for a screening in the GP office, and 1 /10 (3675) at the nearest gastroenterology center. Results 58.5% of the general practitioners completed the questionnaire and 22.7% agreed to take part in the study. Compliance in the general practitioner arm was 50%, in the hospital arm 16% (RR 3.4”; 95% CI: 3.13–3.70). There was great variability in the compliance achieved by primary care physicians. GPs with more than 25 patients visited/day and those wrongly recommended for early detection of colorectal cancer achieved lower compliance (OR 0.74, 95% CI: 0.57-0.95 and OR 0.76, respectively, 95% CI: 0.59-0.97). . Conclusions Involving primary care physicians in colorectal cancer screening can be very effective in improving compliance, but effectiveness depends on their willingness to participate.

title: The role of nurses/social workers in using a multidimensional guideline to diagnose anxiety and challenging behavior in people with intellectual disabilities
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND OBJECTIVES: This study attempts to (1) examine the impact of implementing the "Diagnostic Guideline for Anxiety and Challenging Behavior in Clients with Intellectual Disability" on the knowledge and self-efficacy of nurses/social workers"; and (2) assess the role of nurses/social workers in the diagnostic process when using the guideline. BACKGROUND: Nurses/social workers have extensive contact with clients with intellectual disabilities. Despite this key position, the contribution of nurses/social workers to diagnosing mental health problems and challenging behaviors is rather limited. The authors developed the multidimensional "Diagnostic Guide for Anxiety and Challenging Behavior". This article evaluates the implementation of this guideline with regard to the knowledge and self-efficacy of nurses/social workers and the role of nurses/social workers in the diagnostic process. DESIGN: This study used a comparative design with multiple case studies. METHODS: Qualitative and quantitative research methods. RESULTS: Working with the Diagnostic Guide to Anxiety and Challenging Behavior resulted in a statistically significant increase in knowledge and self-efficacy among the nurses/social workers in the experimental condition compared to the nurses/social workers in the control condition. Nurses/social workers and psychologists appreciated the nurses/social workers' more active contribution to the diagnostic process. CONCLUSIONS: Working with the guideline increased the knowledge and self-efficacy of nurses/social workers and led to more active involvement of nurses/social workers in the diagnostic process. RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: After completing a training program, nurses/social workers can effectively contribute to the process of diagnosing clients with anxiety and associated challenging behaviors.

title: The role of relational, developmental, neonatal critical care in strengthening preterm infant outcomes
abstract: This article describes the conceptual framework, clinical application, and efficacy of a relationship-based, developmental supportive approach to neonatal critical care called NIDCAP (Newborn Individualized Developmental Care and Assessment Program). The results of the approach are reported in terms of infant health and development, reduction in hospital costs, and family adaptation. The approach is guided by a neurodevelopmental framework for understanding preterm infants and depends on the ability of professionals to work with each other and families to support the medical, developmental and emotional well-being of infants. The primary vehicle for clinical implementation is a detailed behavioral observation, followed by recommendations for individualized care based on the infant's current functioning and apparent developmental goals. A number of key components of developmental care are described, including strategies for coordinated discharge planning and linkage with community services. The voices of individual clinicians underscore the process of shifting from protocol-based to relationship-based care.

title: The role of stimulants in the management of preschool children with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder
abstract: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) symptoms can start early, beginning before age 6. Despite the significant number of preschool children who can be diagnosed with ADHD, there is limited controlled data on the pharmacologic interventions that are increasingly being used in this population. A 1990 review showed that 34% of pediatricians and 15% of general practitioners had prescribed psychostimulants for preschool children with ADHD, and pharmacoepidemiological studies indicate an increase in stimulant use among preschool children in the 1990s. Unfortunately, only six controlled trials totaling fewer than 200 children have been conducted with these drugs in preschool children. Although these small studies provide some evidence of the benefit of using methylphenidate in preschoolers with ADHD, more data is urgently needed. Practice parameters developed by the American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry and the American Academy of Pediatrics provide some guidance for diagnosing and treating young children with ADHD, but are based primarily on research in elementary-school children. The ongoing Preschool ADHD Treatment Study (PATS), funded by the National Institutes of Mental Health, will provide important clinical guidance for diagnostic considerations and intervention strategies for children with ADHD ages 3 to 5 years. Until data from the PATS study is published, clinicians must rely on developmental assessment skills, available standardized assessment tools, reports of the child from multiple informants, and knowledge of the risks and benefits of available pharmacological and behavioral treatments to treat preschool children effective with ADHD.

title: The role of surveillance in the management of small renal tumors
abstract: Incidentally, the detected small renal tumors (SRMs) have increased significantly in recent years due to the widespread use of enhanced cross-sectional imaging. A significant number of incidental SRMs are diagnosed in elderly patients who are more likely to undergo imaging for other medical problems. The natural history of SRM is historically not well understood, as most masses are surgically removed shortly after diagnosis. Several reports on the surveillance of SRM have been published in recent years. When followed conservatively with serial imaging, SRMs have variable growth rates averaging 0.28 cm/year according to a recent meta-analysis. Larger series with longer follow-up are needed, but a significant number of small tumors appear to be indolent in behavior with a slow growth rate and a limited tendency to progress. The standard of care for improving SRMs is surgery. Up to a third of surgically removed tumors < 4 cm are histologically benign. The results of current surgical treatment of histologically confirmed renal cell carcinoma < 4 cm are excellent, but this has not resulted in a reduction in mortality. Based on these considerations and the available data on the natural history of SRMs, it seems reasonable to assume that we may be overtreating these lesions. This is especially true for elderly or unfit patients who have a reduced life expectancy. In these selected patients and in patients who refuse active treatment, it seems reasonable to propose an initial phase of active surveillance for incidental SRM, with delayed intervention for those tumors that show rapid growth during follow-up. Percutaneous needle biopsies of renal tumors can be safely performed using modern techniques and have the potential to characterize SRMs in histological diagnosis, allowing for better selection of the conservative or active treatment that is most appropriate for each individual patient.

title: The role of theory in research to develop and evaluate the implementation of patient safety practices
abstract: Theories provide a way to understand and predict the impact of patient safety practices (PSPs), interventions to prevent or mitigate healthcare harm, or risks of such harm. However, most published evaluations make little or no explicit reference to the theory, hampering efforts to generalize findings from one context to another. Theories from a wide range of disciplines are potentially relevant to research into PSPs. Theory can be used in research to explain clinical and organizational behavior, guide the development and selection of PSPs, and assess their implementation and mechanisms of action. A key recommendation from an expert consensus process is that researchers should describe the theoretical basis for selected intervention components or provide an explicit logic model for "why this PSP should work". a cumulative understanding of the nature of change.

title: The Roles of Social Workers and Nurses in Case Management: Applying the Three Rs
abstract: There are different skills that nurses and social workers need to achieve a good patient outcome. The problem is that there is a gap in the relationship between social workers and caregivers, and that gap rests on factors that can and must be addressed. This gap can be minimized through conscious effort, addressing the problem, and a willingness to maximize the energy expended in professional relationships to improve patient outcomes. Equally important is the professional experience of each practitioner. The intervention is based on three Rs: reciprocity, responsibility and respect.

title: The SPHERE study. Secondary prevention of heart disease in general practice: Protocol to a randomized controlled trial of tailored practice and patient care plans with parallel qualitative, economic, and policy analyses. [ISRCTN24081411
abstract: BACKGROUND: The goal of the SPHERE study is to design, implement, and evaluate tailored practice and personal care plans to improve the care process and objective clinical outcomes for patients with established coronary artery disease (CAD) in general practice in two different healthcare systems improve the island of Ireland. CHD is a leading cause of death and a major cause of morbidity in Ireland. Secondary prevention was recommended as a key strategy to reduce CHD mortality, and general practice was highlighted as the ideal setting for secondary prevention initiatives. Current evidence suggests that there is significant room for improvement in the provision of secondary prevention for patients with established heart disease in the island of Ireland. The review literature recommends structured programs with ongoing patient support and follow-up; the provision of training tailored to the needs of practitioners to access evidence of the effectiveness of secondary prevention; structured recall programs that also address individual practice needs;" and patient-centered consultations, accompanied by adherence to disease management guidelines. METHODS: SPHERE is a cluster-randomized controlled trial with practice-level randomization to intervention and control groups that 960 Patients were recruited from 48 practices in three study centers (Belfast, Dublin and Galway. Primary endpoints are blood pressure, total cholesterol, physical and mental health status (SF-12) and hospital admissions. The intervention will take place over two years and data will be collected at baseline, one year and two years of follow-up.Data were collected from medical records, practitioner consultations, and postal patient questionnaires.The SPHERE intervention involves the implementation of a structured systematic care program for patients with CAD presenting to a general practitioner is a multifaceted intervention designed to respond to barriers and solutions to optimal secondary prevention identified in preliminary qualitative research involving practitioners and patients. GPs and office nurses participate in training to facilitate behavior change and guidelines on prescribing medication for secondary prevention of CHD. Patients are invited to regular four-month consultations over a two-year period to set and review targets and goals for secondary prevention. The analysis is reinforced by economic, political and qualitative components.

title: The standard of care: A case report and ethical analysis
abstract: Physicians are increasingly allowing their perceived legal responsibilities to override their clinical judgment. Misunderstandings surrounding the term "standard of care" have fueled fears of liability and led to defensive medicine. Physicians may view the standard of care as a technical or legal obligation, but an optimal standard would be one based on detailed knowledge of a patient's medical history and personal condition. It would involve the physician's clinical judgment integrating specific technical and legal information with clinical experience in caring for patients. Occasionally, such a judgment may conflict with the judgments of a court that considers technical and legal information without the benefit of clinical judgment. Physicians must be willing to be advocates for their patients, especially when legal proceedings are flawed or harmful. Systematic investigative and analytical techniques, such as those used by ethics advisers, can help clarify questions about the standard of care.

title: The state of office-based interventions for adolescent tobacco use
abstract: Tobacco use is a serious pediatric health problem because addiction begins in childhood or adolescence for most tobacco users. Primary care facilities offer tremendous opportunities for the delivery of tobacco treatment to young tobacco users. Although evidence-based practice guidelines for treating adolescent nicotine addiction are not yet available, professional associations and the current clinical practice guideline for adults provide recommendations based on expert opinion. This article reports on the current tobacco treatment practices of pediatric and primary care clinicians, discusses similarities and differences between adolescent and adult tobacco use, summarizes research efforts to date and current cutting-edge research that can ultimately help inform and guide clinicians, and presents existing recommendations for the treatment of tobacco use in adolescents. Finally, recommendations are made for the general practitioner, professional associations and healthcare systems and policies. Pediatricians and other clinicians can and should play an important role in treating adolescent tobacco addiction.

title: The Study Team for Early Life Asthma Research (STELAR) consortium "Asthma e-lab": Scientific team bringing together data, methods and researchers
abstract: We have created Asthma e-Lab, a secure web-based research environment to support the consistent recording, description and sharing of data, computational/statistical methods and new knowledge across the five UK birth cohorts. The e-Lab serves as a data repository for our unified data set and provides the computing resources and scientific social network to support collaborative research. All activities are transparent and new findings are shared via the e-Lab, linked to explanations of analysis methods, enabling knowledge transfer. eLab facilitates iterative interdisciplinary dialogue between clinicians, statisticians, computer scientists, mathematicians, geneticists and basic scientists, capturing the collective thinking behind the interpretation of results.

title: The systematic impact of gain- and loss-related messages on interest in and use of different types of health behaviors
abstract: The systematic formulation of health messages in terms of wins or losses affects people's behavior. Rothman and Salovey suggested that the relative impact of win and loss messages depends on perceptions of the risk or uncertainty associated with adopting the recommended behavior. Specifically, loss-related messages are more effective in promoting disease-aware (screening) behaviors, but gain-related messages are more effective in promoting health-affirming (prevention) behaviors. Two experiments provide a direct test of this conceptual framework. In Experiment 1, participants' willingness to act after reading about a new disease depended on how the information was presented and what type of behavior was encouraged. Experiment 2 repeated and expanded these results to include a real health issue - gum disease. Profit-framed brochures increased interest in a plaque-fighting mouthrinse, while loss-framed brochures increased interest in a plaque-detecting disclosure rinse. Message framework research provides a theoretically sound guide to developing effective health messages.

title: The time is now: education and organization of services
The tools of an evidence-based culture: implementation of clinical practice guidelines in an Israeli HMO
abstract: PURPOSE: Although clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) are introduced with the assumption that they will improve the quality, efficiency, and consistency of healthcare delivery, they generally have limited impact on changing physician behavior. The purpose of this study was to design and implement an effective policy formulation, dissemination and implementation program to promote the development of an evidence-based culture in an Israeli HMO. METHOD: The authors implemented a four-step program of incremental collaborations with academic institutions consisting of developing quantitative tools to assess prescribing patterns, updating CPGs, collecting input from MDs via focus groups and quantitative surveys, and conducting a randomized controlled trial of two people consists of -stage, multi-pronged intervention. The test case for this study was the development, dissemination, and implementation of CPG for the treatment of acute uncomplicated cystitis in adult women. Interventions in the form of a lecture at a conference and a letter with personalized feedback were both used individually and combined to improve physicians' rates of prescribing the first-line drug, nitrofurantoin, and, when nitrofurantoin is not present, therapy to comply with the recommended treatment duration of three days with ofloxacin. RESULTS: The tools and data-generating capabilities designed and constructed in phase I of the project were integral parts of all subsequent phases of the program. Personalized feedback alone was enough to improve adherence to guidelines by 19.4% (95% CI = 16.7, 22.1). CONCLUSIONS: This study provides a template for introducing the experimentation component that is essential to cultivating an evidence-based culture. This process, which consists of collaborative efforts between academic institutions and a managed care organization, can be beneficial to other healthcare systems.

title: The United States Educational Institute for Public Health Dissemination and Implementation Research
abstract: Background The science of dissemination and implementation (D&I) is expanding the knowledge base on how evidence-based interventions can best be integrated into clinical and community settings, and how the way or conducting the research itself can be redesigned to make it more relevant and actionable there the settings. As the field grows, training programs for D&I research are few; this is an important way to build the capacity of the field. To improve the United States' capacity for D&I research, the National Institutes of Health and Veterans Health Administration have collaborated to develop a five-day training institute for postdoctoral-level applicants who wish to advance this science, Dissemination and Implementation of Research in Health (TIDIRH ) Outcomes The TIDIRH used a five-day immersion in a dormitory to maximize the interaction opportunities for trainees and faculty. The train-the-trainer-like approach was intended to provide participants with materials they could easily use to bring back to their home institutions to facilitate the To increase interest and further invest in D&I, take lessons and interactive sessions in small groups. 35 out of 266 applicants for the first annual training institute were accepted from a variety of disciplines including psychology (12 trainees); Medicine (6 trainees); Epidemiology (5 trainees); Health behavior/health education (4 trainees); and 1 intern each from the fields of Education and Human Development, Health Policy and Management, Health Services Research, Public Health Studies, Public Policy and Social Work, with a maximum of two people from one institution. The institute was rated as very helpful by the participants and six months after the institute a follow-up survey (response rate of 97%) revealed that 72% had initiated a new grant application in D&I research; 28% had received funding, and 77% had used TIDIRH's capabilities to influence their peers across disciplines about D&I research by building local research networks, organizing formal presentations and symposiums, teaching, and interdisciplinary teams to conduct D&I research Research have conducted trainee assessment at the end of the week-long training and six-month follow-up, and there are plans to continue and possibly expand the TIDIRH in the coming years. Strengths are seen in the living format, the quality of the faculty and their flexibility in adapting the content to the needs of the trainees and highlighting concrete D&I examples by the local host institution, which rotates lessons learned and plans for future TIDIR H trainings.

title: The UPBEAT program for depression and coronary artery disease: using the UK Medical Research Council framework to develop a nurse-led complex intervention for use in primary care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Depression is a common feature of coronary artery disease (CAD) and increases the incidence of coronary artery symptoms and death in CAD patients. Interventions that are feasible for use in primary care are needed to improve both mood and cardiac outcomes. The UPBEAT-UK research program was funded by the NHS National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) to investigate the relationship between CHD and depression and to develop a new intervention for use in primary care. METHODS: Using Medical Research Council (MRC) guidelines for designing and evaluating complex interventions, we conducted a systematic review and qualitative research to evaluate a primary care-based, nurse-led intervention to improve mood and cardiac outcomes in patients with CHD and to develop depression. An iterative literature review was used to synthesize our empirical work and identify evidence and theories to inform the intervention. RESULTS: We developed a primary care-based, nurse-led, personalized care intervention that leverages elements of case management to promote self-management. After a biopsychosocial assessment, a personalized treatment plan is created. Nurses trained in behavior change techniques help clients address issues that are important to them. The identification and use of existing resources is promoted. Care time is saved by telephone follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: Applying the MRC framework to complex interventions has allowed us to develop an evidence-based intervention based on patient and clinician preferences and established theory. The feasibility and acceptance of this intervention is now being further tested in an exploratory study.

title: The use of computerized reminders of birthday greetings in the management of diabetes.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Although reminder emails have been used for prevention in the general population, few studies have evaluated their effectiveness in chronically ill populations. OBJECTIVE: We evaluated the effectiveness of postal reminders in improving diabetes management. The reminder included a letter from the person's primary care physician (PCP), a self-care manual, a preventive checklist, and specific recommendations for receiving routine monitoring and screening. METHODS: Of 195 primary care physicians practicing in a large group practice, 111 agreed to have their adult diabetic patients randomized to receive reminder (n = 1,641) or usual (n = 1,668) care. Using data from automated databases, we fit generalized estimating equations to estimate the effect of reminder receipt on fasting lipid profile and glycated hemoglobin tests, receipt of the dilated retinal exam, and visit frequency during the 6 and 12 months post-randomization, and glycated hemoglobin and assess cholesterol levels in the year after randomization. RESULTS: Reminder and normal care recipients did not differ in sociodemographic, clinical, or prior test characteristics. In the 6 months after randomization, reminder recipients were more likely to receive a retinal exam (odds ratio [OR], 1.29", 95% confidence interval [95% CI], 1.12 to 1.49) and a visit for diabetes (OR , 1.28; 95. % CI, 1.12 to 1.47) In the 12 months after randomization, reminder recipients were more likely to receive a glycated hemoglobin test (OR 1.21; 95% CI 1.03 to 1 .43) and a retinal exam (OR, 1.23; 95% CI. , 1.07 to 1.41) and diabetes visit (OR, 1.25; 95% CI, 1.09 to 1.29). reminder recipients also tended to have a glycated hemoglobin test that did not reflect a poor control (<9.5%) CONCLUSIONS: We found small but significant improvements in the management of patients with diabetes who received a computerized reminder in the mail.

title: The use of laboratory interventions to stem the flow of fresh frozen plasma
abstract: Four methods of laboratory intervention were tested by the hospital's blood bank to modify the use of fresh frozen plasma (FFP). Serially initiated over a period of one year was a usage review with feedback to physicians, a recurring training program for domestic staff outlining guidelines for the use of FFP, a form requiring justification for FFP orders, and a policy established requiring pathologist approval of FFP in patients with normal or no coagulation studies. Comparing the period after all forms of intervention (February 1986–October 1986) and the baseline period before each form of intervention (July 1984–March 1985), FFP use decreased by 52% overall while increasing by 17% for red blood cell use. It was concluded that blood banks could dramatically change the use of this product with established methods of changing physician ordering behavior.

title: Using Simulations to Train Teamwork in Healthcare: How Deep Can You Go?
abstract: High-fidelity simulation has become a popular technique for training team skills in high-risk industries such as aerospace, healthcare, and nuclear power generation. Simulation is a powerful training tool because it allows the trainer to systematically control the schedule of exercises, the presentation of feedback, and the introduction (or suppression) of environmental distractions within a safe, controlled learning environment. Unfortunately, many in the training community have started using the terms simulation and high-fidelity simulation almost interchangeably. This is unfortunate as it puts too much emphasis on instructional technology at the expense of more substantive aspects such as the objectives, content and design of the training. It also perpetuates several myths: simulation fidelity is one-dimensional, or higher simulation fidelity leads to increased training effectiveness. The authors propose a simulation fidelity typology and provide examples of how the different simulation classes have been successfully used to train teamwork in high-risk industries. Guidelines are also provided to maximize the use of simulation for healthcare team skill training.

title: The use of the nicotine inhaler in smoking cessation
abstract: PURPOSE: To raise awareness of the nicotine inhaler among Nursing Practitioners (NPs) by providing clinical and practical information on the use of the nicotine inhaler as a treatment option for smoking cessation. DATA SOURCES: This included data-based and review articles in the medical literature, the Clinical Practice Guidelines on Tobacco Use and Addiction, and the Medline and Cinahl search engines. Criteria for the search terms were “nicotine inhaler” and “nicotine replacement therapy”. The first search was conducted in December 2004. CONCLUSIONS: The nicotine inhaler was tested to be safe and effective in the treatment of tobacco cessation. Clinical studies show that the nicotine inhaler is useful alone or as an adjunct to other pharmacological therapies. Current national guidelines recommend the use of nicotine inhalers in smoking cessation therapy. PRACTICAL IMPLICATIONS: The nicotine inhaler is suitable for a wide variety of smokers, including certain types of cardiac patients. NPs may include the nicotine inhaler in a group of nicotine replacement therapies to ensure smokers are successful in quitting tobacco.

title: The use of appropriate osteoporosis medication improves after a multifaceted educational effort: the Canadian Quality Circle Project (CQC)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Osteoporosis is a serious but treatable disease. However, adequate therapeutic use of the disease remains suboptimal. Therefore, the aim of the study was to change physicians' therapy delivery behavior in accordance with the Osteoporosis Canada 2002 guidelines. METHODS: The project was a two-year cohort study consisting of five Quality Circle (QC) phases that included: 1) Training and baseline data collection, 2) Initial pedagogical intervention and initial follow-up data collection, 3) Initial strategy implementation session, 4) Final pedagogical intervention and final follow-up data collection; and 5) Final strategy implementation session. A total of 340 general practitioners formed 34 QCs and participated in the study. Physicians analyzed a total of 8376, 7354, and 3673 randomly selected patient records at baseline, follow-up #1, and last follow-up, respectively. The patients were divided into three groups";" the high-risk, low-risk, and low-risk non-fracture groups. The generalized estimating equation technique was used to model the change in physicians' outcomes over time: the probability of appropriate therapy was 1.29 (95% CI: 1.13, 1.46) and 1.41 (95% CI: 1, 20, 1.66) in patients in the high-risk group, 1.15 (95% CI: 0.97, 1.36) and 1.16 (95% CI: 0.93, 1.44) in the low-risk group, and 1.20 (95% CI: 1.01, 1.43) and 1.23 (95% CI: 0.97). , 1.55) in the low-risk group with no fractures at follow-up #1 or the last follow-up. CONCLUSION: The QCs methodology was successful in increasing the appropriate use of osteoporosis medication by physicians in accordance with Osteoporosis Canada guidelines.

title: The value of a "gentle reminder" of safe medical behavior
abstract: Background Based on findings and methods from cognitive psychology and behavioral economics, we have introduced "gentle memory". This process requires a public plan of safety standards and an agreement by all team members to help each other comply with this plan. Methods Team members agree to gently remind their employees whenever they deviate from the safety norm. For the study, we observed the use of gloves during intravenous insertion and blood collection. Results and Discussion During the 2-year follow-up, safe behavior increased when safe behavior was 55% prior to the implementation of 'soft reminder' on a ward; it rose to over 80% after 2 months; 2 months later, it was 83% and 90%;" and finally it stabilized at 90%. A similar pattern was documented in all wards. This is a recommended way to overcome unsafe behavior.

title: Theory and practice in the treatment of depressive disorders
abstract: Scientific, professional and governmental bodies have in recent years intensified their efforts to formulate guidelines for the treatment of depression with the aim that medical practice conforms to these standards and thus improves patient care. "Evidence-based medicine" requires that medical practice explicitly refers to the best available scientific knowledge. Empirical data on nursing epidemiology suggest that there are major differences between guidelines and routine practice. The inability to recognize mental disorders is between 45 and 90%. Only 1 in 10 depressed patients receive adequate treatment. Treatment is inadequate, with prescribed dosages routinely being too low, up to 50% of treatments being terminated prematurely, and patient non-compliance compromising the proper use of treatment. Psychological treatment occurs in only 60% of cases of need and is mostly non-specific, ie listening or advisory. In addition, there are large regional differences in prescribing patterns, showing that treatment is influenced by many non-medical factors. Empirical studies show that educating doctors or even measures to improve detection alone are not enough to change treatment behavior. Only if measures are taken to directly improve treatment interventions could a better course of the disease be shown, at least for more severe cases. To understand therapist non-adherence to treatment guidelines, one must first understand the medical decision-making process. Action theory offers a model that brings together theoretical and experimental knowledge, goal setting, medical and emotional evaluation, and operational procedures. Based on this theory, future guidelines should specify the setting for which they claim validity, they should be tested empirically for their feasibility and implications for patient outcome, and they should give due attention to non-medical factors that have a major impact on the medical practice.

title: Therapeutic Enhancement: Nursing intervention category for patients diagnosed as being ready for therapeutic regimen management
abstract: OBJECTIVES: To introduce a new nursing intervention category called therapeutic enhancement. BACKGROUND: Fewer than half of North Americans follow their doctor's recommendations for diet and exercise, even when they are critical to their health or recovery. It is imperative that caregivers consider new ways to promote healthy behaviors. Therapeutic reinforcement aims to offer such a fresh approach. Traditional intervention techniques that focus on education, contracting, social support, and more frequent interaction with physicians do not appear to be effective on their own. Successful strategies were multidisciplinary";" and have included interventions by professional nurses to help patients understand their disease and the disease process, and to help them develop disease management and self-management skills. Therapeutic improvement includes The Stages of Change Theory, Commitment to Health Theory, motivational interviewing techniques, and tools specifically designed for the process evaluation of health-promoting interventions. METHOD: This is a critical review of approaches not previously synthesized in a single published article. CONCLUSIONS: Based on the commonly used model of stages of change, therapeutic enhancement is useful for patients who are in the action phase of change. Using therapeutic enhancement and therapeutic strategies identified in Stages of Change theory, such as Using techniques such as emergency management, relationship support, counterconditioning, stimulus control, and motivational interviewing techniques, nurses can significantly increase patients' chances of moving from the action phase to the maintenance phase of change for a given health behavior. RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: Using the Nursing Intervention category, therapeutic enhancement can increase the success of nurses in assisting patients to maintain healthy behaviors.

title: Therapy and supportive care for alcoholics: guidelines for practitioners
abstract: BACKGROUND/OBJECTIVES: Alcoholism is a widespread disorder in our societies. However, only a small percentage of alcoholics enter specialized psychotherapeutic treatment programs. The vast majority are consulted by general practitioners or experts in other medical specialties, where they receive intensive treatment for their alcohol-related comorbidities. But the cause of these comorbidities, alcoholism itself, is rarely addressed. This article provides specialists and laypersons with guidelines on how these patients can be treated correctly in non-specific therapy programs and how motivation for abstinence can be increased. In addition, the concept can be quickly and easily integrated into the everyday life of every therapeutic team. Methods: The literature on the therapeutic methods of brief interventions, motivational interviewing and pharmacological relapse prevention was reviewed in PubMed for the years 1991-2005. RESULTS/CONCLUSION: The disease burden of alcoholism and alcohol abuse as primary disorders is very obvious, but is often underestimated even by therapists of different medical specialties. Systematic studies of the brief intervention method, motivational interviewing, and also pharmacological treatment with acamprosate have shown that they are potent methods that can easily be used to increase the duration of abstinence and the motivation of patients to participate in further specific treatments .

title: Thoughtful electronic health record design leads to overuse, but purposeful design can lead to improved patient care
Three- and 4-dimensional ultrasound in obstetric practice: does it help?
abstract: AIM: The purpose of this article was to review the published literature on 3-dimensional ultrasound (3DUS) and 4-dimensional ultrasound (4DUS) in obstetrics and to determine whether 3DUS adds diagnostic information to what is currently provided by 2-dimensional ultrasound ( 2DUS ) and if so, in which areas. METHODS: A PubMed search was conducted for articles reporting the use of 3DUS or 4DUS in obstetrics. Seven hundred and six articles were identified, of which 525 actually related to the subject of this review. Articles describing technical developments, clinical studies, reviews, editorials, and studies on fetal behavior or maternal-fetal bonding were reviewed. RESULTS: Three-dimensional ultrasound provides additional diagnostic information for the diagnosis of facial abnormalities, especially facial clefts. There is also evidence that 3DUS provides additional diagnostic information in neural tube defects and skeletal malformations. Large studies comparing 2DUS and 3DUS for diagnosis of congenital anomalies have not provided conclusive results. Preliminary evidence suggests that sonographic tomography can reduce obstetric ultrasound examination time with minimal impact on visualization rates of anatomical structures. CONCLUSIONS: Three-dimensional ultrasound provides additional diagnostic information for the diagnosis of facial anomalies, the assessment of neural tube defects, and skeletal malformations. Further research is needed to determine the clinical role of 3DUS and 4DUS in the diagnosis of congenital heart disease and central nervous system abnormalities. Future studies should clarify whether the information contained in the volume dataset alone is sufficient to evaluate fetal biometric measurements and diagnose congenital anomalies.

title: Through the carpal tunnel
Thyroid disease in pregnancy
Tics in the pediatric population: Pragmatic management
abstract: BACKGROUND: Primary tic disorders, particularly Tourette syndrome, are very common movement disorders in childhood. However, the treatment of such patients still poses major therapeutic challenges for physicians. METHODS: Based on a synthesis of the available guidelines published in Europe, Canada and the United States coupled with recent therapeutic developments, the authors provide a pragmatic guide to help clinicians decide when and how to treat patients with primary Tic disorders to be treated . RESULTS: After a systematic survey of tics and common neuropsychiatric comorbidities (primarily attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder [ADHD] and obsessive-compulsive disorder [OCD]), the first treatment step is comprehensive psychoeducation of patients and families that addresses the protean phenomenology of tics and associated behaviors , coping mechanisms, prognosis, and treatment options. When a more active intervention beyond vigilant surveillance is indicated, a hierarchical assessment of treatment goals (i.e., tics vs. comorbid behavioral symptoms) is critical. Behavioral treatments for tics are limited to older children and are not available in all centers, mainly due to the lack of well-trained therapists. Pharmacologic treatments, such as antipsychotics for tics, stimulants and atomoxetine for ADHD, and alpha2A agonists for children with tics plus ADHD, are widely available and effective treatment options, but safety needs to be monitored. Combined polypharmacological and behavioral/pharmacological approaches as well as neuromodulation strategies are underexplored in this patient population. Conclusions: The treatment of children with tics and Tourette's syndrome is diverse. Multidisciplinary teams with expertise in neurology, psychiatry, psychology and pediatrics can be helpful in addressing the complex needs of these children.

title: Tobacco Brief Intervention Training for Chiropractors, Acupuncture and Massage Practitioners: Protocol for the CAM-Reach Study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Tobacco use remains the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the US. Effective tobacco cessation tools are widely available but underused. Brief tobacco cessation interventions (BIs) increase smoking cessation rates. However, BI training has focused on conventional medical providers and overlooked other healthcare practitioners with regular exposure to tobacco users. The 2007 National Health Interview Survey found that approximately 20% of those using provider-based complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) are tobacco users. Therefore, CAM practitioners potentially represent a major untapped community resource to promote tobacco cessation and the use of effective cessation aids. Existing BI training is not well suited to the background and practice patterns of CAM practitioners, as they assume a conventional biomedical knowledge base and philosophical approaches to health, healing, and the patient-physician relationship. There is an urgent need to develop and test the effectiveness of BI training that is both based on Public Health Service (PHS) guidelines for tobacco addiction treatment and relevant and appropriate for CAM practitioners. METHODS/DESIGN: The CAM Reach (CAMR) Intervention is a BI smoking cessation training and office system intervention specifically tailored for chiropractors, acupuncturists, and massage therapists. The CAMR study uses a single-group, one-way crossover design to examine the impact of CAMR intervention on tobacco-related practice behaviors of CAM practitioners. Primary endpoints included CAM practitioner self-reported screening for tobacco use and BIs. Secondary endpoints included tobacco users' willingness to quit, attempts to quit smoking, use of guideline-based treatments and smoking cessation rates, and non-smoking patients' actions to help someone else quit. DISCUSSION: CAM practitioners serve a significant number of tobacco users. Their practice patterns and philosophical approaches to health and healing lend themselves well to delivering BIs. The CAMR study examines the impact of the CAMR intervention on practitioners' tobacco-related practice behaviors, the behaviors of CAM patients, and documents factors important for conducting practice-based research in real-world CAM practices.

title: Tobacco cessation in primary care: maximizing intervention strategies
abstract: The most effective preventive intervention a clinician can offer to tobacco-using patients for heart disease, cancer, cerebrovascular disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is an empathetic, personalized smoking cessation intervention program with enhanced support and follow-up. The goal of the intervention must be complete smoking cessation. The reduction offers no direct health benefits to the individual smoker. Interventions are readily available but underutilized, in part due to a lack of clinical training and organizational support. This article summarizes the current guidelines for smoking cessation interventions as a framework to work from. The guidelines include the transtheoretical model of patient behavior change and the "Five A's": Ask, Advise, Assess, Assist and Arrange. Pharmacotherapeutic agents, including nicotine replacement therapies (nicotine gum, patches, nasal sprays, inhalers, and new therapies) and nicotine-free therapies (bupropion, clonidine, nortriptyline, and other antidepressants and anxiolytics) are considered. Compliance validation methods, new approaches to tobacco and addiction treatment that appear in the recent research literature are reviewed. Beyond this framework, specific categories of tobacco users (including smokeless tobacco users), cultural and ethnic minorities, youth who use snuff and bidis, women, Medicaid recipients, and users of multiple forms of tobacco deserve special attention. With this framework and the modifications that may be required for specific patient categories, practicing clinicians can incorporate a successful tobacco cessation intervention program with smoking cessation rates of nearly 20% into their daily practice.

title: Tobacco cessation in the dental practice
abstract: Evidence-based smoking cessation guidelines, when used by physicians, are effective in reducing tobacco use and enabling patients to successfully quit smoking. Dentists were encouraged to provide in-office tobacco cessation instruction and interventions. The dental provider is in a unique position to match oral reports to the patient and provide tobacco users with cessation advice. In addition, dentists are able to assess patients' selfishness and degree of willingness to quit tobacco use. With this information, dentists can help patients quit smoking by providing appropriate pharmacotherapeutic guidance, thereby improving their oral and overall health.

title: Tobacco cessation training for complementary and alternative medicine practitioners: results from a practice-based study
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Brief behavioral intervention (BI) is a proven method for smoking cessation that is well established among conventional health practitioners. Complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) practitioners treat a significant number of tobacco users, but receive no systematic BI training. The CAM-Reach study developed and evaluated a BI tobacco cessation training program/exercise system that was specifically adapted for CAM practitioners and evaluated in real CAM practices. STUDY DESIGN: One-arm intervention. Data was collected in 2010-2014 and analyzed in 2015. SETTING/PARTICIPANTS: Private practices of 30 chiropractors, 27 acupuncturists, 42 massage therapists (N=99) in metropolitan Tucson, Arizona. INTERVENTION: 8-hour BI continuing education workshop on smoking cessation, practice/assessment of BI skills in practice and systems intervention. Training tailored to the CAM practice setting addressed tobacco cessation best practices from US Public Health Service guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Seventeen items (assessment of practitioner's behavior, motivation, and self-efficacy in smoking cessation) encompassing three factors, tobacco cessation activity, tobacco cessation motivation, and non-CAM tobacco cessation comfort, were assessed at baseline and 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after the training through the self-report of the practitioner. Research staff visited practices at roughly even intervals to directly observe changes in clinical practice systems. RESULTS: At 3 months, there was a significant increase in practitioners' tobacco cessation activities, motivation and confidence in helping patients quit tobacco, and comfort in providing information and recommendations for guideline-based tobacco cessation aids (p<0.0001 ). Practitioners resulted in significantly higher rates of discussing smoking cessation medication with patients (AOR = 3.76, 95% CI = 1.84, 7.68) and routinely asking about tobacco use in clinical practice (AOR = 2.62, 95 %CI = 1.11, 6.20). Increases occurred in all three types of practitioners and persisted after 12 months - despite the heterogeneity in professional training, practice patterns / organization and practice business models. CONCLUSIONS: The results suggest that CAM practitioners are willing and able to provide BIs and that they are an important but overlooked channel for promoting tobacco cessation and the use of evidence-based cessation aids.

title: Tobacco Addiction Treatment Guidelines
abstract: Tobacco addiction causes every sixth death in the Czech Republic and is associated with diseases of the whole body. Treatment of tobacco dependence should be an integral part of clinical care within the time available, from brief intervention at each clinical contact with patients to intensive care. It includes psychosocial behavioral support and pharmacotherapy. It should apply to all clinical medicine professions – as recommended by WHO, mainly doctors, nurses, pharmacists and dentists – and be covered within healthcare systems. Economically, it is one of the most cost-effective interventions in medicine. In our population over 15 years of age, about 30% smoke (about 2.2 million people), the diagnosis of F17 affects about 1.75 million people (about 80% of smokers).

title: Tobacco Intervention Practices by Licensed Psychologists
abstract: Tobacco addiction is a serious public health problem. The US Department of Health and Human Services has issued a best practice guideline to encourage all healthcare providers to intervene with tobacco dependent individuals they encounter. Psychologists may be ideally suited to deliver brief tobacco interventions because of their expertise in behavior change strategies and interpersonal counseling skills. The aim of this study was to examine current tobacco assessment and intervention practices and perceptions of accountability for tobacco intervention among a regional sample of licensed, practicing psychologists. The results suggest that a majority of psychologists fall far short of the ideal best practices recommended in the practice guideline, and many are unaware that the guidelines are available. Additionally, the psychologists in this study viewed tobacco intervention as a greater responsibility of physicians and other health care providers than psychologists and other mental health professionals.

title: Tobacco smoking in individuals with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder: epidemiology and pharmacological approaches to cessation
abstract: The co-occurrence of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and nicotine addiction is common. Individuals with ADHD are more likely to start smoking and become dependent on nicotine than their non-ADHD counterparts, and recent evidence suggests they may have more difficulty quitting. Little is known about how best to manage these comorbidities to optimize clinical outcome. Clinicians treating individuals with ADHD or nicotine dependence should be aware of their common coexistence and the need to consider both in treatment. This review of ADHD and nicotine dependence provides an overview of relevant epidemiology, bidirectional interactions, and implications for pharmacological and concomitant psychosocial treatment. Incorporating the current evidence base and their clinical experience, the authors propose a stepwise approach to treating patients with comorbid ADHD and nicotine dependence. Given the potential of ADHD symptoms to interfere with smoking cessation success, the first priority is to stabilize ADHD. The first-line pharmacologic approach should be a long-acting psychostimulant. After ADHD stabilization, motivational techniques should be used to encourage willingness to try smoking cessation. In the context of behavioral smoking cessation interventions that address the patient's needs and developmental stage, a pharmacologic intervention aimed at smoking cessation can be initiated. The authors recommend varenicline as the drug of first choice due to its superior potency among available drug treatments. Symptoms of ADHD and nicotine withdrawal and craving symptoms should be closely monitored during the cessation attempt, and therapy adjustments should be considered if warranted. The authors conclude that while current treatments may be effective for comorbid ADHD and nicotine dependence, further research is needed to analyze the complex relationships between these disorders and to prospectively investigate combined treatments.

title: Tobacco-nicotine education and training for health care students and practitioners: a systematic review
abstract: INTRODUCTION: The aim of this systematic review was to examine what characteristics of education and training prepare and support healthcare professionals (HCPs) to provide competent and effective care to patients who use tobacco nicotine. METHODS: A search of eight bibliographic databases for English-language peer-reviewed publications from January 2006 to March 2015. Studies were included if they met a priori inclusion criteria, which consisted of: 1) quantitative study design, and 2) focus on tobacco -Nicotine education or training for HCP students and practitioners. All studies were independently reviewed for inclusion by two reviewers. Data from included studies were extracted for study characteristics and key outcomes and then critically assessed for methodological quality. Results: 59 studies were included for narrative synthesis. Two categories emerged: 1) curriculum features (n=10) and 2) education and training interventions (n=49). The included curriculum studies identified the following themes: content, intensity, competency assessment, and barriers. Study outcomes on education and training interventions were grouped by educational level (pre-licensing, post-licensing, and faculty training), instructional modality, health discipline, and associated HCP and client outcomes. Conclusion: This comprehensive review suggests a lack of consistency in the characteristics of tobacco-nicotine education and training for HCPs. This paper provides a valuable categorization of the most commonly used components of the academic curriculum and discusses the interventions in relation to HCP and client outcomes. Gaps in the literature are identified and the need for standardization of tobacco-nicotine training competencies and assessments is discussed. Future research examining the most effective training approaches is needed. Study Registration: PROSPERO - Protocol Number: CRD42015019219 Available at http://www.crd.york.ac.uk/PROSPERO/display_record.asp?ID=CRD42015019219. IMPLICATIONS: This systematic review summarizes existing tobacco-related curriculum components (content, intensity, skill assessment, barriers) and training interventions for health professionals worldwide and shows that they are associated with positive health professional outcomes (knowledge, attitudes, behaviors, skills) and client outcomes (quitting attempts). and smoking abstinence).

title: Tools for implementing an evidence-based approach in public health practice
abstract: Rising disease rates, limited funding, and the ever-growing scientific basis for interventions require the use of proven strategies to improve population health. Public health practitioners must be willing to implement an evidence-based approach in their work to achieve health goals and allocate the necessary resources. We explored easily accessible and time-efficient tools to implement an evidence-based public health approach (EBPH) to improve population health. Several tools have been developed to meet the needs of the EBPH, including free online resources in the following subject areas: Training and Planning Tools, US Health Surveillance, Policy Tracking and Monitoring, Systematic Reviews and Evidence-Based Guidelines, Economic Assessment and Gray Literature . Key elements of EBPH are "Community involvement in assessment and decision-making", systematic use of data and information systems, making decisions based on the best available peer-reviewed evidence (both quantitative and qualitative), application of programming frameworks (often based on in health behavior theory); Conducting an informed assessment;" and dissemination of what has been learned.

title: Topical intranasal corticosteroids in 4-11 year old children with persistent bilateral otitis media with effusion in primary care: double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study
abstract: OBJECTIVE To determine the clinical efficacy of topical intranasal corticosteroids in children with bilateral otitis media with effusion. DESIGN Double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study. SETTING 76 Medical Research Council General Practice Research Framework practices in the UK between 2004 and 2007. PARTICIPANTS 217 children aged 4 to 11 who had at least one in-office episode of otitis media or associated ear problem in the past 12 months , and with bilateral otitis media with effusion confirmed by a research nurse by otoscopy plus microtympanometry (B/B or B/C2, modified Jerger types). INTERVENTION Mometasone furoate 50 micrograms or placebo spray once daily in each nostril for three months. KEY OUTCOME MEASUREMENTS Proportion of children cured of bilateral otitis media with effusion assessed by tympanometry (C1 or A type) at one month (primary endpoint), three months and nine months; Unwanted events; three-month diary symptoms. Results 41% (39/96) of the topical steroid group and 45% (44/98) of the placebo group were healed in one or both ears at one month (difference in favor of placebo 4.3% (95% CI -9.3 % to 18.1%) Poisson regression was performed with adjustment for four predefined covariates (clinical severity, P=0.003; atopy, P=0.67; age, P=0.92; season, P=0.71 The adjusted relative risk at one month was 0.97 (95% confidence interval 0.74 to 1.26) At three months, 58% of the topical steroid group and 52% of the placebo group were cured (relative risk 1.23, 0 .84 to 1.80) Diary symptoms did not differ between the two groups and no significant harms were reported.CONCLUSIONS Topical steroids are probably not an effective treatment for otitis media with effusion in general practice High natural resolution rates occurred at 1-3 months. STUDY REGISTRATION G Current controlled studies ISRCTN38988331; National Research Registry No. 575123823; MREC 11.03.073.

title: Stubborn magazine editor faces accusations of clemency
Towards criteria for pragmatic measurement in implementation research and practice: a stakeholder-driven approach using concept mapping
abstract: Background The advancement of implementation research and practice requires valid and reliable measurements of implementation determinants, mechanisms, processes, strategies and outcomes. However, researchers and implementers are unlikely to apply measures unless they are also pragmatic. The aim of this study was to establish a stakeholder-driven conceptualization of the domains that comprise the pragmatic measurement construct. It built on a systematic literature review and semi-structured stakeholder interviews that generated 47 pragmatic action criteria and aimed to further refine this set of criteria by identifying conceptually distinct categories of the pragmatic action construct and providing quantitative assessments of the criteria. ¯s clarity and meaning. Methods Twenty-four stakeholders with experience in implementation practice conducted a concept mapping activity in which they grouped the initial list of 47 criteria into conceptually distinct categories and rated their clarity and importance. Multidimensional scaling, hierarchical cluster analysis and descriptive statistics were used to analyze the data. Results The 47 criteria were meaningfully grouped into four distinct categories: (1) acceptable, (2) compatible, (3) simple, and (4) useful. Average ratings of clarity and importance at the category and each criterion level are presented. Conclusions This study advances the field of implementation science and practice by providing clear and conceptually distinct domains of the pragmatic measurement construct. Next steps will include a Delphi process to build consensus on key criteria and to develop quantifiable pragmatic evaluation criteria that can be used to evaluate interventions.

title: Towards evidence-based medical statistics. 1: The P-value fallacy
abstract: There is an important problem with the interpretation of modern medical research data: Biological understanding and previous research hardly play a formal role in the interpretation of quantitative results. This phenomenon manifests itself in the discussion sections of research articles and can ultimately affect the reliability of conclusions. The standard statistical approach created this situation by promoting the illusion that conclusions with certain "error rates" can be generated without considering information from outside the experiment. This statistical approach, the key components of which are p-values and hypothesis testing, is widely regarded as a mathematically coherent approach to inference. There is little recognition in the medical community that the methodology is an amalgam of incompatible elements, the usefulness of which for scientific conclusions has been the subject of intense debate among statisticians for nearly 70 years. This article presents some of the key elements of this debate and traces the appeal and detrimental effects of this method to the P-value fallacy, the misconception that a single number can capture both the long-term results of an experiment and the conclusive meaning of a single result. This argument is made as a prelude to the suggestion that a different standard of proof should be used - the Bayesian factor, which properly separates questions of long-term behavior from evidentiary weight and allows for the integration of background knowledge with statistical insights.

title: Towards common terminology: a simplified intervention framework for promoting and integrating evidence into health practices, systems and policies
abstract: Background A wide range of different and conflicting terminology exists in the field of knowledge translation. This limits the performance of evidence synthesis, hinders communication and collaboration, and undermines the knowledge translation of research results in different settings. Improving the consistency of terminology could help address these challenges. In 2012, we convened an international working group to explore the idea of developing a common terminology and overarching framework for knowledge translation interventions. Results Methods included identifying and summarizing existing frameworks, mapping a subset of these frameworks, and convening a multidisciplinary group to begin consensus work. The group considered four possible approaches to creating a simplified framework: merging existing taxonomies, creating a framework of intervention mechanisms instead of intervention strategies, using a consensus process to extend one of the existing models/frames used by the group, or developing a new consensus framework . Conclusions The working group decided to draft a new, simplified consensus framework for action to promote and integrate evidence into health practices, systems and policies. The framework will include four key components: strategies and techniques (agents), how they work (causal mechanisms), how they are delivered (mode of delivery), and what they aim to change (intended goals). The draft framework needs to be further developed through feedback and consultation with the research community and tested for its usefulness through application and evaluation.

title: Toxic hepatitis during treatment with ketoconazole
tracheostomy and weaning
