abstract: No hypothesis regarding respiratory care in the ICU has been more difficult to objectively test than the commonly held assumption that tracheostomy accelerates weaning from ventilator support. Tracheostomy may facilitate weaning by reducing dead space and reducing airway resistance, improving secretion clearance, reducing the need for sedation, and reducing the risk of aspiration. Available evidence suggests that dead space and airway resistance are indeed reduced, although whether the magnitude of these reductions explains the clinical observation of faster weaning after tracheostomy is less certain. Most of the data on this topic comes from laboratory experiments and short-term physiological studies in clinically stable patients, and the available evidence from clinical trials with weaning as the primary endpoint is sparse. A large multicenter study showed no benefit from early tracheostomy but demonstrated the difficulty of getting clinicians to treat their patients with therapies that contradict their firm beliefs. The most recent clinical study found that percutaneous dilated tracheotomy performed in the first 2 days in patients expected to require >14 days of ventilator support greatly reduced ventilator days and ICU days, and both the incidence of pneumonia and the All-cause mortality compared to decreased tracheostomy after day 14. Conducting such studies is difficult due to investigator and clinician bias, the inability to predict which patients will actually require prolonged mechanical ventilation, and several other factors discussed in this article. The tracheotomy likely helps relieve some patients from ventilator support, but this may be due to both its effect on clinical behavior and physiological implications.

title: Tracing the foundations of a conceptual framework for a patient safety ontology
abstract: Background Working for the World Alliance for Patient Safety on research methodologies and policies, as well as defining key concepts for an International Classification of Patient Safety (ICPS), it became clear that there was a need to try to understand what patient safety means and what lies behind the concepts relate to the existing safety and quality frameworks commonly used in healthcare. Objectives To demonstrate the concept of patient safety and its relationship to safety and quality frameworks commonly used in healthcare, and to follow the development of the ICPS framework as a basis for electronic recording of the component elements of patient safety. Conclusion The ICPS Patient Safety Framework has its origins in existing frameworks and an international consultation process. Although its 10 classes and their semantic relationships can be used as a reference model for various disciplines, it must remain dynamic in the ever-changing world of healthcare. By expanding the ICPS by examining data from all available sources and ensuring strict adherence to the latest principles in informatics, a deeper interdisciplinary approach is gradually being developed to tackle the complex, intractable problem of reducing harm to health.

title: Education for general practitioners in opioid prescribing for chronic pain based on practice guidelines: a randomized pilot and proof-of-concept study
abstract: UNRATINGED: This study is a pilot and feasibility study comparing two training experiences to improve appropriate opioid prescribing for chronic pain. Both training conditions included education on opioid guidelines. After training, one condition included training to improve mental flexibility and the other included training in practical knowledge and skills related to pain management. The study involved 81 general practitioners (GPs), each randomly assigned to 1 of the training conditions. It proved easy to recruit GPs for the training. Overall, primary care physicians showed increased knowledge of prescribing opioids for chronic pain and fewer concerns about prescribing after training. However, no changes were observed in reported prescribing practices or in secondary measures of well-being. There were also no significant differences between the training conditions, apart from a greater increase in intent to use the prescription guidelines in the psychological flexibility condition. Feasibility and acceptance of the training methods were generally rated highly. The psychological flexibility condition was rated higher in terms of interest and satisfaction than the comparison condition. Finally, pre- and post-training processes of psychological flexibility correlated significantly with measures of GP well-being, partially supporting the relevance of these processes as a focus in GP education. PERSPECTIVE: A general practitioner education intervention, including education on opioid guidelines for chronic pain and psychological flexibility training, increased prescribing knowledge and reduced concern, but did not alter prescribing behavior or well-being. The training was very acceptable for general practitioners but may have been too short to produce other effects.

title: Training in internal fixation of fractures
Training of doctors for high-quality and cost-conscious care
abstract: Significance Increasing health expenditure burdens the sustainability of the health system. Physicians should be prepared to provide quality and cost-conscious care. Objective To understand the circumstances in which the provision of quality, cost-conscious care is learned with the aim of informing the development of effective educational interventions. Data Sources PubMed, EMBASE, ERIC and Cochrane databases were searched from inception to 5 September 2015 to identify learner- and cost-related issues. Study Selection Studies were included on the basis of topic relevance, intervention delivery, intervention assessment, educational components of the intervention, and appropriate target population. There were no limitations regarding the study design. Data extraction and synthesis Data extraction was guided by a merged and modified version of a Best Evidence in Medical Education abstraction form and a Cochrane data coding sheet. The articles were analyzed using the realist review method, a narrative review technique that focuses on understanding the mechanisms underlying interventions. Thematic analyzes identified recurring patterns in the data. Resulting issues were discussed within the research team until consensus was reached. Key Findings and Actions The key findings were factors that promote education in the delivery of quality, cost-conscious care. Results The initial search identified 2650 articles; 79 met the inclusion criteria, 14 of which were randomized clinical trials. The majority of studies were conducted in North America (78.5%) with a pre-post-interventional design (58.2%; at least 1619 participants); they concentrated on practicing physicians (36.7%; at least 3448 participants), resident physicians (6.3%; n?=?516), and medical students (15.2%; n?=?275). clinical studies, 12 addressed knowledge transfer, 7 reflective practice and 1 supportive environment; 10 (71%) concluded that the intervention was effective. Data analysis suggested that 3 factors support successful learning: (1) effective knowledge delivery, related knowledge, e.g. on general health economics and prices of health services, scientific evidence on guidelines and the benefits and harms of health care, and patient preferences and personal values ( 67 items); (2) facilitating reflective practice, such as providing feedback or asking reflective questions about decisions related to laboratory orders or prescriptions, to provide trainees with insight into their past and current behavior (56 items);" and (3) creation of a supportive environment in which the organization of the healthcare system, the existence of role models for the provision of quality, cost-conscious care, and a culture of quality, cost-conscious care reinforce the desirable , cost-conscious care suggest that the combination of specific knowledge delivery, reflective practice and a supportive environment enhances the learning of practicing physicians, physicians in private practice and medical students n educational interventions are taken into account.

title: Educating Physicians to Provide Quality, Cost-Conscious Care: A Systematic Review
abstract: IMPORTANT: Increasing healthcare expenditure is a burden on the sustainability of the healthcare system. Physicians should be prepared to provide quality and cost-conscious care. OBJECTIVE: To understand the circumstances in which the provision of quality, cost-conscious care is learned, with the aim of informing the development of effective educational interventions. DATA SOURCES: PubMed, EMBASE, ERIC and Cochrane databases were searched from inception through September 5, 2015 to identify learner and cost-related issues. STUDY SELECTION: Studies were included on the basis of topic relevance, implementation of the intervention, evaluation of the intervention, educational components of the intervention, and appropriate target group. There were no limitations regarding the study design. DATA EXTRACTION AND SYNTHESIS: Data extraction was guided by a merged and modified version of a Best Evidence in Medical Education abstraction form and a Cochrane data coding sheet. The articles were analyzed using the realist review method, a narrative review technique that focuses on understanding the mechanisms underlying interventions. Thematic analyzes identified recurring patterns in the data. Resulting issues were discussed within the research team until consensus was reached. KEY FINDINGS AND ACTIONS: The key findings were factors promoting education in the delivery of quality, cost-conscious care. RESULTS: The initial search identified 2650 articles; 79 met the inclusion criteria, of which 14 randomized clinical trials were at least 1619 participants); they focused on practicing physicians (36.7%; at least 3448 participants), resident physicians (6.3%; n=516), and medical students (15.2%; n=275). 12 addressed knowledge transfer, 7 reflective practice and 1 supportive environment. 10 (71%) concluded that the intervention was effective. Data analysis indicated that 3 factors support successful learning: (1) effective knowledge delivery, e.g. on general health economics and prices of health services, on scientific evidence on guidelines and on the benefits and harms of health care, and on patient preferences and personal values (67 articles), (2) enabling reflective practice, such as giving feedback or reflective questions on related decisions with laboratory orders or prescriptions to provide trainees with insight into their past and current behavior (56 items);" and (3) creating a supportive environment in which the organization of the healthcare system, the existence of role models for the provision of quality, Cost-Conscious Care and a Culture of Quality, Cost-Conscious Care Desirables Reinforce Training Goals (27 articles) CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE: Research on training physicians for quality, cost-conscious care suggests that learning from practicing end physicians, resident physicians and medical students is promoted through the combination of specific knowledge transfer, reflective practice and a supportive environment. These factors should be considered when designing educational interventions.

title: Training practitioners to provide opportunistic advice on multiple behavior change in primary care: a randomized cluster study
abstract: OBJECTIVES To assess the effect of training primary care professionals in behavior change counseling on the proportion of patients self-reporting a change in four risk behaviors (smoking, alcohol use, exercise, and healthy eating). DESIGN Cluster-randomized study with primary care practices as the randomization unit. SETTING General practices in Wales. PARTICIPANTS 53 general practitioners and practice nurses from 27 general practices (one each in all practices but one) recruited 1827 patients who tested positive for at least one risky behavior. INTERVENTION Behavior change counseling was developed from motivational conversations to enable physicians to increase patients' motivation to change health-related behaviors. Clinicians were trained using a blended learning program called Talking Lifestyles. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Percentage of patients reporting beneficial changes in at least one of the four risky behaviors after three months. RESULTS 1308 patients from 13 intervention and 1496 from 14 control practices were contacted: 76% and 72% agreed to participate, respectively, with 831 (84%) and 996 (92%) being candidates for an intervention, respectively. There was no effect on the primary endpoint (beneficial behavior change) at three months (362 (44%) vs. 404 (41%), odds ratio 1.12 (95% CI 0.90 to 1.39)) or biochemical or biometric measurements after 12 months. More patients who consulted trained physicians recalled a health behavior counseling session (724/795 (91%) versus 531/966 (55%), odds ratio 12.44 (5.85 to 26.46) ) and intended to change it (599/831 (72%) vs. 491/996 (49%), odds ratio 2.88 (2.05 to 4.05)). More intervention practice patients reported an attempt at change (328 (39%) vs. 317 (32%), odds ratio 1.40 (1.15 to 1.70)), sustained behavior change at three months (288 (35%) vs. 280 (28%), odds ratio 1.36 (1.11 to 1.65)) and reported slightly larger improvements in healthy eating at 3 and 12 months, and improved activity at 12 months. Training cost £1597 per exercise. DISCUSSION Training primary care physicians in behavior change counseling using a brief blended learning program did not increase patients reporting beneficial behavior changes at three months or improve biometric and biochemical measurements at 12 months, but it did increase patients' recall, Discuss behavioral changes with physicians, intentions to change, attempts to change, and perceptions of having made a lasting change after three months. Lasting behavior change and improvements in biometric measurements are unlikely after a single routine consultation with a physician trained in behavior change counseling without additional intervention. TEST REGISTRATION ISRCTN 22495456.

title: Transforming an assertive community treatment into an integrated system of care: the role of partnerships between nursing and primary care
abstract: Despite the high rate of co-occurring illness among individuals receiving assertive community treatment (ACT), this comprehensive service model continues to be viewed primarily as a mental health intervention. Without compromising fidelity to the model, ACT can serve as an ideal platform from which to deliver both primary and behavioral health care to people with complex service needs. Using a case study, this article considers the transformation of the ACT model of mental health care into an integrated health care system through the development of partnerships between nursing and primary care. Specifically, by expanding and explicitly redefining the role of the ACT caregiver, well-developed models of care such as guided care can provide additional guidance and training for ACT caregivers who are specifically trained and aligned to act as leaders and coordinators of health integration efforts.

title: transfusion medicine
abstract: The development of transfusion medicine into a clinically oriented discipline with a focus on patient care has been accompanied by challenges that need to be addressed in the future. Emerging issues affecting blood safety and blood supply, such as: New challenges, such as pathogen inactivation and stricter donor screening questions, are putting new pressure on the availability of an affordable blood supply. Imminent alternatives for treating anemia, such as oxygen carriers, show promise but require close monitoring if available. With current estimates of viral transmission of HIV or hepatitis C (HCV) approaching one in 2,000,000 units transfused, minimizing bacterial contamination of platelet products (one in 2000) and transfusion errors, with an estimated of 800 ˆ000 death rate, assume great urgency. Finally, serious challenges in blood safety and availability in poor developing countries require innovative strategies and commitments of resources.

title: Translating clinical research into clinical practice: implications of using prediction rules for decision making
abstract: Clinical prediction rules, sometimes called clinical decision rules, have proliferated in recent years. However, very few have undergone formal impact analysis, the standard of evidence for assessing their impact on patient care. Without impact analysis, clinicians have no way of knowing whether using a prediction rule is beneficial or detrimental. This paper provides an overview of "evidence standards for the development and evaluation of prediction rules", important differences between prediction rules and decision rules, how the potential clinical impact of a prediction rule can be evaluated before it is translated into a decision rule, methodological aspects necessary for a successful impact analysis are critical, including defining outcome measures and estimating sample size; the importance of close collaboration between clinical researchers and practicing clinicians before, during and after impact analysis;" and the need to measure both effectiveness and effectiveness when analyzing the clinical implications of a decision rule. These considerations should inform the future development, evaluation, and use of any clinical prediction or decision rule.

title: Translating Evidence-Based Fall Prevention into Clinical Practice in Nursing Facilities: Outcomes and Lessons from a Quality Improvement Collaboration
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Description of the changes in the care process before and after an evidence-based quality improvement in fall reduction in care facilities. DESIGN: Natural experiment with nonparticipating institutions serving as controls. SETTING: Community nursing homes. PARTICIPANTS: Thirty-six participating and 353 nonparticipating care facilities in North Carolina. INTERVENTION: Two in-person learning sessions, monthly conference calls, and email discussion list over 9 months. The package of amendments emphasized screening, labeling and reducing risk factors. MEASUREMENTS: Adherence was measured using facility self-report and chart abstraction (n=832) before and after the intervention. As an exploratory result, the fall rates measured with the Minimum Data Set (MDS) were compared with those of non-participating institutions. RESULTS: Self-reported compliance with screening, labeling, and risk factor reduction approached 100%. Graph abstraction revealed only modest improvements in screening (51% to 68%, p<0.05), reduction in risk factors (4% to 7%, p=0.30), and medication assessment (2% to 6%, p = 0.05). .34). There was a significant increase in vitamin D prescriptions (40% to 48%, p=0.03) and a decrease in sedative hypnotics (19% to 12%, p=0.04), but no change in Use of benzodiazepines, neuroleptics, or calcium. There were no significant changes in proportions of falls or fall rates according to chart abstraction (28.6% to 37.5%, P=0.17), MDS (18.2% to 15.4%, P=0.56) or self-report (6.1–) observed. 5.6 falls/1,000 bed days, P=0.31). CONCLUSION: Tasks aimed at reducing multiple risk factors are rarely implemented, while screening tasks appear more easily modifiable in a real setting. Significant discrepancies between self-reporting and medical record documentation require the use of additional data sources to assess care transition processes resulting from quality improvement programs. Interventions to improve interdisciplinary collaboration need to be developed.

title: Putting guidelines into practice: Outcomes of a multidisciplinary preventive cardiology program in the west of Ireland
abstract: OBJECTIVES: The objective of this observational, descriptive study is to evaluate the impact of an intensive, evidence-based preventive cardiology program on medical and lifestyle risk factors in patients at high risk for developing cardiovascular disease (CVD). METHODS: Patients at increased risk of CVD and their family members/partners were invited to participate in a 16-week program consisting of professional multidisciplinary lifestyle intervention with appropriate risk factor and therapeutic management in a community setting. Smoking, dietary habits, physical activity, waist circumference and body mass index, and medical risk factors were measured at the initial assessment, at the end of the program, and at one-year follow-up. RESULTS: Adherence to the program was high, with 375 (87.2%) participants and 181 (84.6%) partners completing the program, with 1-year data from 235 (93.6%) patients and 107 (90.7%) partners were surveyed. There were statistically significant improvements in both lifestyle (body mass index, waist circumference, physical activity, Mediterranean diet score, fish, fruit and vegetable consumption, smoking cessation rates), psychosocial (anxiety and depression scales and quality of life indices) and medical risk factors (blood pressure). , lipid and glycemic targets) between baseline and the end of the program, with these improvements being maintained at 1 year of follow-up. CONCLUSIONS: These results demonstrate how a holistic model of CVD prevention can improve cardiovascular risk factors by achieving healthier lifestyles and optimal medical management.

title: Translation of alcohol screening and brief intervention guidelines for pediatric trauma centers
abstract: BACKGROUND: As part of the American College of Surgeons' verification as a Level 1 trauma center, centers must be able to identify trauma patients with risky alcohol use and provide an intervention. Despite supporting scientific evidence and national policy statements promoting alcohol screening, brief intervention and referral for treatment (SBIRT), barriers still exist that prevent the integration of SBIRT into clinical care. The study objectives of this multi-site, translational research study were to identify best practices for integrating SBIRT services into the routine care of pediatric trauma patients, measure changes in practice in adopting and implementing a SBIRT policy, and identify barriers and opportunities for the Adoption and implementation to define SBIRT services in pediatric trauma centers. METHODS: This translational research study was conducted over a 3-year period at seven US pediatric trauma centers. Changes in SBIRT practice were measured through self-reports and medical record review at three distinct study phases, namely adoption, implementation, and maintenance phases. RESULTS: Based on medical record review, 11% of eligible patients at all sites were screened at baseline and received brief intervention (if needed). Upon completion of the SBIRT technical support activities, all seven participating trauma centers had effectively developed, adopted and implemented SBIRT guidelines for injured adolescent hospitalized patients. Additionally, 73% of eligible patients across all locations received SBIRT services after both the implementation and maintenance phases. Opportunities and barriers to successful integration were identified. CONCLUSION: This model can serve as a method for putting SBIRT services into practice in pediatric trauma centers.

title: Translating the adequacy criteria into practice guidelines: applying decision table techniques to the RAND criteria for coronary artery bypass grafts.
abstract: The process of creating clinical practice guidelines from collected evidence is not well defined. We have developed a technique for translating a comprehensive set of appropriateness criteria into a usable set of practice guidelines. The criteria are derived from a formal RAND consensus process and relate to the indications for coronary artery bypass graft surgery for acute myocardial infarction. The clinical indications defined by the panel of experts are entered as conditions in a decision table. For each combination of relevant clinical findings, the recommended action is defined from the median ranking of the fringe panel. The fully constructed table is next condensed and sorted by conventional decision table techniques to facilitate analyzing the knowledge. Ultimately, 8 narrative statements are derived from 51 rules. Advanced decision tables allow detailed data to be viewed in the summary table and accessed as needed.

title: Translation of obesity practice guidelines: interprofessional perspectives on the impact of system-level interventions by public health caregivers
abstract: AIM: The purpose of the study was to examine administrators' and clinicians' perceptions of a public health-supported collaboration that supports the implementation of the Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) guideline on adult obesity into practice . DESIGN AND SAMPLE: This qualitative study was conducted with 10 health organizations participating in a voluntary, interprofessional obesity management collaboration. A targeted sample of 39 participants included two to three clinicians and one administrator from each organization. The interview analysis focused on how the intervention affected the participants and their practices. RESULTS: Four themes described participants' experiences with translation of the obesity guideline: (1) a shift from powerlessness to positive motivation, (2) heightened awareness coupled with improved responsiveness, (3) personal responsibility and use of creativity, and (4 ) a Sense of the importance of increased interprofessional collaboration. CONCLUSIONS: The examination of interprofessional perspectives sheds light on the feelings and perceptions of the clinical and administrative participants regarding the translation of the obesity practice guideline. These themes suggest that positive motivation, enhanced capacity, personal creative ownership, and interprofessional collaboration can be conducive to successful implementation of the evidence-based obesity guideline. Further research is needed to evaluate these results in relation to the translation of the ICSI obesity guideline and other guidelines into practice in different clinical settings.

title: Translation of obesity practice guidelines: measurement and assessment
abstract: OBJECTIVE(S): A public health nurse (PHN) in the Midwestern United States (USA) led a collaborative systems-level intervention to translate the Institute of Clinical Systems Improvement (ICSI) guideline on adult obesity into interprofessional practice . This study (1) assessed the extent of guideline translation between organizations and (2) evaluated the Omaha system as a method for translating system-level interventions and measuring outcomes. DESIGN AND SAMPLE: This mixed-methods retrospective study was conducted with a targeted sample of one administrator (n=10) and two to three clinicians (n=29) from each organization (n=10). ACTIONS: Omaha System Problem Rating Scale for Outcomes Knowledge, Behaviour, and Status (KBS). KBS scores collected from semi-structured interviews and Omaha System documentation were analyzed using standard descriptive and inferential statistics and triangulated results with participant citations. RESULTS: KBS ratings and participant citations demonstrated the effectiveness of the intervention in creating sustainable system-level change. Self-reported and observed KBS assessments showed improvements in all organizations. There was moderate to high agreement on benchmark achievement across organizations. On average, self-reported improvement exceeded observer improvement. CONCLUSIONS: System-level interventions by PHN practitioners successfully translated clinical obesity guidelines into interprofessional use in healthcare settings. The Omaha System Problem Rating Scale for Outcomes has reliably measured system-level outcomes.

title: Trap of trends to statistical significance: Probability that a near-significant P-value becomes more significant with additional data
abstract: Given a P-value that has not reached a certain threshold (generally P < 0.05), authors of scientific articles may imply a "trend toward statistical significance" or otherwise suggest that it is not statistical Reaching significance was due to insufficient data. This paper presents a quantitative analysis to show that such descriptions are misleading and undermine the principle of accurate reporting. P-values that do not reach the conventional significance level of PâÂ¤0.05 are regularly reported as moving in that direction. Expressions such as "near/approaching statistical significance" or, most tellingly, a "trend toward statistical significance" continue to find their way into publications in journals with high impact factors.1 In this article, we examine and evaluate the mathematical basis for this assumption the extent to which a near-significant P-value can predict movement toward a future significant P-value by adding additional data. We also examine the likelihood that additional data would actually yield a significant result, and finally the confidence one might have that a repeat experiment would independently yield statistically significant results. The clearest context in which to consider the correct interpretation of a P-value is within a randomized trial. Fisher described how the "simple precaution of randomization is sufficient to ensure the validity of the significance test." Explain result between groups. The AP value tells us the extent to which chance alone can explain the observed difference, and serves as a "snapshot" measure of the strength of evidence at the end of the study. As evidence accumulates, the conclusions become more robust. The AP value could easily be imagined as follows: â‚¬Â¦

title: Treating Alcohol Problems: Making ends meet
Treating depression within the HIV "medical home": a guided algorithm for antidepressant treatment by HIV clinicians
abstract: People living with HIV/AIDS (PLWHA) suffer from an increased prevalence of depression compared to the general population, negatively impacting antiretroviral (ART) compliance and HIV-related outcomes and leading to morbidity and mortality. Nevertheless, depression in this population group often goes unrecognized and untreated. The current project aimed to design an evidence-based approach to integrate treatment for depression into HIV clinics. The model chosen, measurement-based care (MBC), is based on existing guidelines and the largest randomized study in the treatment of depression. MBC was adapted to the clinical realities of HIV treatment for use in a randomized controlled depression management efficacy study at three academic HIV clinics. The adjustment accounts for drug interactions, which are critical to the continued effectiveness of ART, and can be performed by a multidisciplinary team of non-psychiatric providers. A treatment algorithm was developed that allows clinically supervised, nonphysician depression care managers (DCMs) to track and monitor antidepressant tolerability and treatment response, while assisting nonpsychiatric prescribers in antidepressant drug selection and dosing. The quality of care is ensured through weekly supervision of DCMs by psychiatrists. Key areas of flexibility important to implementation included flexibility in the timing of assessments, accommodating discrepancies between algorithm recommendations and vendor decisions, and accommodating delays in the implementation of treatment plans. This adaptation of the MBC model to HIV care has addressed critical antidepressant-antiretroviral interactions and facilitated the delivery of quality antidepressant management in the HIV medical facility.

title: Treating obesity with a novel handheld device, computer software program and internet technology in primary care: the SMART motivational study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the short-term motivational effect of a technology-based weight loss program for overweight adults. METHODS: One hundred and eleven obese (37.0 +/- 5.8 kg/m(2)) middle-aged (45.5 +/- 10.8 years) adults (62% female) were randomized to a usual care or experimental (SMART: self-monitoring technology and resting metabolic rate). The normal care group received a standard nutritional program according to national guidelines. All participants received a comprehensive weight management program consisting of Motivational Interviewing (MI) sessions and automated behavioral email newsletters. Body weight, arterial blood pressure, and psychobehavioural constructs were assessed over 12 weeks. RESULTS: Completer analysis (n=80) showed significant improvement in body weight (-3.9%), arterial systolic pressure (-4 mmHg) and all motivational constructs after the 12-week study (p<or=0.05 ). However, there were no significant differences between the groups at any time point. CONCLUSIONS: Based on these data, a comprehensive 12-week weight reduction program consisting of MI and automated behavioral email newsletters with or without SMART is effective in treating overweight adults. PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: Although both treatment regimens were equally effective, physicians should consider a treatment regimen that meets the needs of the patient. This study was registered with ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00750022.

title: Treatment and prophylaxis of recurrent urinary tract infections
abstract: Recurring urinary tract infections are typical diseases of sexually active young women. Only older women have significant rates of underlying, mostly urological diseases. In addition to behavioral changes, long-term antimicrobial therapy is still the mainstay of both prophylaxis and therapy. This report provides information on the etiology of recurrent urinary tract infections. Strategies for prevention are shown. The actual importance of bio-medicines or antibiotics is discussed";" Ineffective therapies are identified. In addition, an outlook is given on promising novel therapeutics, ie vaccines that are already being tested in clinical trials.

title: Treatment of anxiety disorders in the primary care setting: a randomized controlled trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Anxiety disorders are prevalent in primary care settings. Psychological treatment is effective but time-consuming, and there are waiting lists for secondary care. Therefore, interest has grown in developing treatment guidelines that would be feasible in primary care. OBJECTIVE: To compare the effectiveness and feasibility of guided self-help, the Dutch College of General Practitioners' anxiety disorder guidelines, and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). STUDY DESIGN: Randomized controlled trial of 12 weeks with 3 and 9 months follow-up for primary care patients with panic disorder and/or generalized anxiety disorder. SETTING: The first two treatment regimens were administered by 46 general practitioners who were randomly assigned to one regimen or another. CBT was performed by cognitive behavioral therapists in a psychiatric outpatient clinic. METHOD: Participants (n = 154) were randomly assigned to one of three treatment modalities. The state subscale of the Spielberger anxiety inventory was used as the main outcome measure. RESULTS: All three treatment modalities resulted in a significant improvement between pre- and post-test, and this improvement remained stable between post-test and follow-up visits. The results obtained with the three forms of treatment did not differ significantly over time. The feasibility of the anxiety disorder guide was low compared to guided self-help. CONCLUSION: Our results indicate that primary care patients with prevalent anxiety disorders for whom the primary care physician does not consider referral to be necessary can be treated appropriately by the primary care physician. Referral to a psychiatric outpatient clinic does not bring better results. Guided self-help is easier for the general practitioner to carry out than less structured treatment, as specified in the anxiety disorder guidelines.

title: Treatment of childhood memories: theory and practice
abstract: With the growing interest of cognitive behavioral therapy in early developing psychopathologies such as personality disorders, there is an increased need for therapeutic methods to more directly treat pathogenic schemas. Exploring and reinterpreting memories of early childhood experiences that are believed to have contributed to pathogenesis are increasingly viewed as a promising way to modify nuclear schemas. Experimental methods seem to be the most effective. This article discusses two main forms of these methods: (i) imagination with rescripting and (ii) role play, both of childhood interactions with key figures. Protocols are provided for both as guidelines for clinicians and to stimulate standardization to open this new field for experimental research. Theoretical views are discussed as to why these methods might be so effective in treating chronic problems that originate in childhood.

title: Treatment of common "life event" trauma
abstract: BACKGROUND: GPs are confronted daily with patients who have experienced stressful "life events". Guiding patients through this process can be challenging. AIM: This article points out the reactive symptomatology that may be overt or hidden in a stressful event and its sequelae, sets the goal of restoring a person's functioning and self-resources, and provides guidance on what counseling can do for a patient. DISCUSSION: People who are trying to cope with a stressful "life event" or the consequences of a trauma can be effectively helped by early short-term counseling. While this task may not be attractive to the busy primary care physician, many accessible interventions can restore a person's coping capacity and avoid the prospect of persistent and deepening pathology. Many symptoms do not fit into the diagnostic categories normally associated with stress disorders. Some may show impaired social engagement and social phobia";" others may describe low self-esteem, malaise, dissatisfaction in relationships, and mismatches in key areas of behavior. The task is to help the person gain a different perspective on the stressful event, their own abilities, and the supportive influences around them.

title: Management of Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome: A Systematic Review for a National Institutes of Health Pathways to Prevention Workshop
abstract: Background: Myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME)/chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) is a debilitating multisystem disease affecting more than 1 million adults in the United States. Purpose: To determine the benefits and harms of treatments for adults with ME/CFS and to identify future research needs. Data Sources: MEDLINE, PsycINFO and Cochrane Databases (January 1988 to September 2014), Clinical Trials Registers, Reference Lists and Manufacturer Information. Study selection: English-language randomized studies on the effectiveness and side effects of ME/CFS treatments. Data Extraction: Data on participants, study design, analysis, follow-up, and outcomes were extracted and validated. Study quality was assessed twice using predefined criteria. Discrepancies were resolved by consensus. Data Synthesis: Among 35 Treatment Studies That Mainly Enrolled Participants In accordance with the 1994 Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and Oxford CFS case definitions, the immunomodulator rintatolimod improved some measures of exercise performance compared to placebo in 2 studies (low weight): Studies with galantamine, hydrocortisone, IgG, valganciclovir, isoprinosine, fluoxetine and various complementary drugs have been inconclusive (insufficient evidence). ies and graded exercise therapy improved fatigue, function, general improvement, and work impairment compared to no treatment, relaxation, or support in some studies." Counseling therapies also improved quality of life (low-to-moderate strength of evidence). Harms have rarely been reported across studies (insufficient evidence). Limitation: The studies were heterogeneous and limited by size, number, duration, applicability, and methodological quality. Conclusion: Studies of rintatolimod, counseling therapies, and graded exercise therapy suggest benefit for some patients who meet case definitions for CFS, while evidence for other treatments and harms is insufficient. More definitive studies are needed to fill research gaps, comparing participants meeting different case definitions, including ME, and providing a subgroup analysis.

title: Treatment of seasonal depression
abstract: Winter-type seasonal affective disorder (SAD) is characterized by the regular annual occurrence of major depressive episodes in the fall or winter, followed by spontaneous remission and sometimes hypomanic or manic episodes in spring and summer. SAD is of clinical importance, affecting approximately 2-5% of the general population in temperate climates. Since the syndrome was first described, researchers have tried to elucidate the pathophysiological background of SAD. Bright light therapy has been proposed as the treatment of choice for this disorder. However, numerous studies have also investigated appropriate psychopharmacological treatments for SAD. This report aims to provide an overview of the clinical management and current treatment options for SAD.

title: Treatment services for children with ADHD: a national perspective
abstract: AIM: To summarize knowledge about treatment services for children and adolescents with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), trends in services from 1989 to 1996, types of services provided, service mix, and barriers to service. METHOD: A literature review and analyzes from 2 national surveys of medical practices are presented. RESULTS: Major changes have occurred in stimulant prescriptions since 1989, with prescriptions now accounting for three quarters of all physician visits by children with ADHD. Between 1989 and 1996, related services such as health counseling for children with ADHD increased 10-fold and diagnostic services increased 3-fold. However, the provision of psychotherapy declined from 40% of pediatric visits to just 25% over the same period. Follow-up visits also dropped from more than 90% of visits to just 75%. Primary care physicians were more likely than pediatricians or psychiatrists to prescribe stimulants and were less likely to use diagnostic services, offer psychological counseling, or recommend follow-up care. Approximately 50% of children with identified ADHD seen in the office are receiving treatment that meets American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry guidelines. Physicians reported significant barriers to providing services to these children, including shortages of pediatricians, barriers to insurance, and long waiting lists. CONCLUSIONS: The trends in treatment services and physician variations in service delivery indicate large gaps between the research base and clinical practice. Clinical variability may reflect educational differences, disparities in specialist availability and duty locations, and changes in health care incentives.

title: Trends in the social control of medical and psychiatric research
Triggering GP anti-smoking counseling: Mechanism of action of an intervention stimulating GP smoking cessation counseling
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the mode of action of an intervention (Family Doctor Desktop Resource, DDR) that increased the frequency of family doctor (GP) advice on smoking cessation. Methods: Analyzes were carried out in order to distinguish between three hypotheses on the functioning of the GDR. That the GDR acts: (1) by changing the attitudes of GPs, (2) causing GPs to intervene in smokers regardless of attitudes, or (3) by changing the relationship between attitudes and behavior. RESULTS: GDR was an independent predictor of the number of patients recommended to quit smoking (beta = .345, p < .001). Concern about the doctor-patient relationship was the only attitudinal variable that independently predicted giving advice, in this case negatively (beta = -.465, p < .001). Possession of DDR did not change GPs' views on whether intervention in smokers harms the doctor-patient relationship, but weakened the relationship between this attitudinal element and the number of patients recommended to quit smoking (beta = 0.595, p<0.001 for interaction). CONCLUSION: This study is the first to show that concern about the doctor-patient relationship was an independent predictor of counseling, while in other studies it was only mentioned as something about which primary care physicians express concern. A simple device designed to trigger action by GPs appeared to work by mitigating the negative effects of an attitudinal barrier to action. It would be interesting to examine this phenomenon more generally in relation to health promotion activities by health professionals. PRACTICE IMPLICATIONS: Recommendations that GPs engage in health promotion activities with their patients need to take into account that GP concerns about damaging the doctor-patient relationship may discourage such interventions. DDR appears to be effective in getting GPs to advise their smoking patients to quit smoking, and its widespread dissemination to GPs should be considered.

title: Tumor boards: optimizing the structure and improving the efficiency of the multidisciplinary management of cancer patients worldwide
abstract: Multidisciplinary management tumor boards for the treatment of cancer patients are now being conducted worldwide. Studies evaluating their impact on decision making and patient outcome are limited";" However, single-center studies have reported significant changes in diagnostic and treatment plans. A survey from Arab countries showed that tumor boards are widespread and rely on tumor boards for decision-making. A recent multi-agency survey of Veterans Affairs (VA) hospitals in the United States found a limited association between the presence of tumor boards and care and outcomes. The Cancer Care Outcomes Research and Surveillance Consortium examined the relationship between tumor board functions and quality of care measures. Overall survival results among patients from these tumor board participating physicians are ongoing, but preliminary results are outlined in this article along with a recent ASCO survey of international members on the presence, use, and impact of tumor boards. Tumor boards enable the implementation of clinical practice guidelines and can help collect cases for clinical trials. Efforts to improve the preparation, structure, and conduct of tumor boards, research methods to monitor their performance, teamwork, and outcomes are also outlined in this article. The concept of mini tumor boards and more efficient methods for MDM in countries with limited resources will also be discussed. In sub-optimal settings such as small community hospitals, rural areas and areas with limited resources, tumor boards, particularly through the use of video conferencing facilities, can overcome or at least improve diagnostic and management limitations. Studies from the UK showed that specialized training of multidisciplinary teams (MDT) resulted in better team dynamics and communication, improved patient satisfaction and improved clinical outcome. This article also examines the weighting of benefits versus time and effort to improve efficiency, patient care, and better time management in the United States and in the international oncology community.

title: Putting knowledge into action at the point of care: The collective experience of caregivers facilitates the implementation of evidence-based practices
abstract: BACKGROUND: Facilitation is viewed as a way of enabling clinicians to put evidence into practice by solving problems and providing support. Practice development is a well-established movement in the UK that involves the use of facilitators, but in Canada the role is more obtuse. Few studies have observed the process of facilitation as described by those experienced in implementing guidelines in North America. OBJECTIVE: To describe the tacit knowledge about facilitation embedded in the experiences of nurses putting evidence into practice. METHODS: Twenty nurses from across Canada were specifically selected to participate in an interactive knowledge translation symposium to examine what has and has not worked in translating evidence into practice. This study is an additional in-depth analysis of the data collected at the symposium, focusing on moderation as an intervention to improve evidence uptake. Critical Incident Technique was used to collect examples to examine nurses' experiences of facilitation. The participants exchanged their experiences and carried out initial data analysis and coding together. The data were further thematically analyzed using the qualitative inductive approach of constant comparison. RESULTS: A number of factors emerged at various levels that are related to the successes and failures of participants' efforts to facilitate evidence-based practice. Successful implementation in terms of: (a) focus on a priority issue, (b) relevant evidence, (c) development of strategic partnerships, (d) use of multiple strategies to effect change, and (e) facilitator characteristics and approach. Negative factors affecting the process were: (a) poor engagement or ownership, (b) resource deficiencies, (c) conflict, (d) context issues, and (e) lack of evaluation and sustainability. CONCLUSIONS: Factors at the individual, environmental, organizational, and cultural levels affect the facilitation of evidence-based practice in real-life situations at the point-of-care. With a better understanding of the factors that contribute to successful or unsuccessful facilitation, future research should focus on analyzing facilitation interventions that are tailored to remove barriers and improve evidence-gathering facilitators.

title: Two highs or three for treatment guidelines? Pushing prescribers in the right direction
Type 2 diabetes mellitus in youth
abstract: In the United States, the incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) in children and adolescents has been increasing at an alarming rate. Early detection and intervention can delay the onset of type 2 DM and prevent the long-term complications. School nurses play an integral role in implementing the American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommended screening guidelines to identify youth at high risk for type 2 DM and in implementing health programs for students that will benefit the importance of physical Focus on activity and healthy eating habits. The purpose of this article is to provide an overview of the epidemiology, pathophysiology, complications, diagnosis and treatment, and recommended screening guidelines for type 2 DM in the pediatric age group. The information provided will raise awareness, encourage screening and empower the school nurse to more effectively promote healthy living education.

title: Basic medical training: current status and future requirements
Understanding and preventing criminal recidivism in adults with psychotic disorders
abstract: The high prevalence of adults with psychotic disorders in the criminal justice system has received much attention recently, but our understanding of this issue is shaped by differing opinions. Mental health professionals point to deinstitutionalization and our fragmented mental health system as key causes. Criminologists downplay the role of mental illness, claiming that people with and without mental illness are arrested for the same reasons. Meanwhile, practice guidelines offer clinicians little guidance on how to address the problem. Drawing on current crime prevention principles and knowledge of psychotic disorders and their treatment, this article provides a conceptual framework for understanding and preventing relapse. The framework highlights the importance of individual and service-related risk variables and emphasizes the central role of treatment non-compliance as a mediator between modifiable risk variables and relapse. Based on the conceptual framework described in this article, three necessary intervention elements for relapse prevention in adults with psychotic disorders are presented: competent care, access to services, and legal influence. Research is needed to further define and test these intervention elements as a basis for future service delivery efforts.

title: Understanding and promoting smoking cessation: overview and guidelines for medical intervention
abstract: This chapter outlines the prerequisites for successful smoking cessation and effective treatments. It presents practical guidelines for physicians and allied healthcare providers with specific recommendations on how to motivate and support patients to quit “on their own” and how to select more intensive concomitant treatment if needed. Useful guides, references and resources are suggested, with recommendations on how best to use nicotine gum.

title: Understanding the diagnosis and management of dementia and guideline implementation in general practice: a qualitative study using the theoretical domain framework
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dementia is a growing problem that places a significant burden on patients, their families and society. General practitioners (GPs) play an important role in the diagnosis and treatment of dementia, but there are gaps between recommended and current practice. The aim of this study was to examine the reported practice of GPs in the diagnosis and treatment of dementia and to theoretically describe terms that proposed explanations for the practice that were consistent with evidence-based guidelines and not. METHODS: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with GPs in Victoria , Australia, conducted The Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF) guided data collection and analysis on factors hindering and enabling the achievement of 13 recommended behaviors. The data were analyzed based on content and thematic analyses. This paper provides an in-depth description of the factors influencing two behaviors, assessing comorbid depression using a validated instrument, and conducting a formal cognitive assessment. RESULTS: A total of 30 primary care physicians were surveyed, most primary care physicians reported not doing the assessment comorbid depression using a validated tool according to recommended guidelines. Obstacles included the belief that depression can be adequately assessed using general clinical indicators and that validated instruments provide little additional information (beliefs about outcome theory); discomfort in using validated tools ('emotion'), possibly due to limited training and confidence ('skills'; 'beliefs about skills'); limited awareness of the need for a depression assessment (“knowledge”; “memory, attention, and decision-making processes”) and forgetting to do it. Most reported practicing in a manner consistent with the recommendation that formal cognitive assessment be conducted using a validated scale. Key factors that made this possible were awareness of the need to undertake cognitive assessment ("knowledge"); Possession of the necessary skills and confidence (“skills”; “beliefs about skills”);” and sufficient time and resources (“environmental context and resources”). CONCLUSIONS: This is, to our knowledge, the first study to use a theoretical approach to examine the barriers and prerequisites to guideline-recommended diagnosis and management of dementia in general practice. Key factors were identified that likely explain the acceptance of the guidelines by general practitioners. Findings have influenced the design of an intervention aimed at supporting practice switching in line with dementia guidelines, which is currently being evaluated in a cluster-randomized study.

title: Understanding How Physician Assessment Works: A Realistic Review Protocol
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Physicians in the UK must now participate in revalidation to retain their license to practice medicine. The assessment is a fundamental part of revalidation. However, there is limited objective evidence that assessment changes physician behavior and directly translates to improved patient care. In particular, it is not clear how the assessment process is intended to change physician behavior and improve clinical performance. The aim of this research is to understand how and why the assessment of physicians should have an effect. METHODS AND ANALYSIS: Realist Review is a theory-driven interpretative approach to evidence synthesis. It applies realistic investigative logic to produce an explanatory analysis of an intervention, ie what works, for whom, under what circumstances and in what respects. Using a realistic review approach, an initial program theory of assessment is developed by consulting key stakeholders in assessing physicians on expert panels (ethical approval is not required) and by searching the literature to identify relevant existing theories. The search strategy consists of a number of phases including a combination of: (1) searches of electronic databases, e.g. (4) contacting authors; and (5) searching gray literature. The evidence search will be iteratively expanded and refocused as the review progresses. Studies are included based on their ability to provide data that allow verification of the program theory. For example, data extraction is performed through notes and annotations at various stages of review, as per the realistic approach. The evidence is synthesized using realistic logic to challenge the final program theory of the impact of assessment on physician performance. Synthesis results will be written according to RAMESES guidelines and disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and presentations. TEST REGISTRATION NUMBER: The protocol is registered at PROSPERO 2014:CRD42014007092.

title: Understanding the implementation processes of clinical pathways and clinical practice guidelines in pediatric contexts: a study protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Canada is among the wealthiest nations in the world, yet the health and well-being of Canadian children is surprisingly poor. There is some evidence that these poor health outcomes are partly due to differences in clinical practice, which may result from a failure to apply the best available research in clinical practice, also known as knowledge translation (KT). Surprisingly, deviations are ubiquitous in clinical practice, even with common acute pediatric conditions. Deviations in clinical practice result in unnecessary medical treatments, increased suffering, and increased healthcare costs. This study focuses on improving health outcomes for common acute health problems in children by evaluating strategies that improve KT and reduce variation in clinical practice. DESIGN/METHODS: Using a multiple case study design, qualitative and quantitative data are collected from four emergency departments in western Canada. Data sources include: pre- and post-implementation focus group data from multidisciplinary healthcare professionals; individual interviews with the local champions, KT intervention providers and department/site heads/managers; Alberta Context Tool (ACT) survey data” and aggregated patient outcome data. Qualitative and quantitative data are systematically triangulated and matrices are created for cross-case comparisons. Based on the cross-case comparisons, statements about the success or failure of the clinical practice guidelines (CPG) and the inclusion of clinical pathways (CPs) are produced. SIGNIFICANCE: This study will generate new insights into the potential causal mechanisms and factors shaping implementation. Future studies will track the impact of implementing the CPG/CPs on children's health and healthcare costs.

title: Understanding colorectal cancer screening non-compliance: a case-control study embedded in a randomized trial
abstract: Background The greatest limit to the effectiveness of colorectal cancer screening is often low compliance. We examined the reasons for non-compliance and determinants of compliance with fecal occult blood testing in Lazio, Italy. Methods This is a case-control study embedded in a study that tested the effect of test type and provider on colorectal cancer screening adherence. Non-compliant subjects were classified as cases and compliant subjects were classified as controls. We studied 600 cases and 600 controls who were matched by their GP, half invited to the hospital for screening and the other half directly to their GP's office. Cases and controls answered questions about: distance from the test provider, logistical issues, perception of colorectal cancer risk, confidence in the effectiveness of screening, fear of results, family history of colorectal cancer, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Results Approximately 31% of the cases never received the letter offering free screening, and 17% of the sample population had already been screened. The first reported reason for non-compliance was “lack of time” (30%)”;” The most important determinant of compliance was distance from the testing provider: odds ratio > 30 minutes vs. < 15 minutes 0.3 (95% CI = 0, 2-0.7). The odds ratio for lack of time was 0.16 (95% IC 0.1-0.26). The effect was stronger when the hospital (0.03 95% CI = 0.01-0.1) and not the general practitioner (0.3 95% CI = 0.2-0.6) was the provider. Twenty-two percent of the controls were accompanied by someone to the test. Conclusion To increase compliance, screening programs must involve testing providers who are geographically close to the target population.

title: Understanding physician acceptance of mobile technology: Insights from two telephone interviews in Finland
abstract: This paper examines physicians' perception and usage of a new mobile medical information system piloted in the Finnish healthcare sector. Two sets of data were collected through telephone interviews in June and October 2003. The doctors surveyed perceived the mobile system positively and began to use it frequently in their work. They reported few negative experiences using a Nokia Communicator. They favored the use of mobile technology as a way to better disseminate medical knowledge. The main contents of the system, the Evidence-Based Medical Guidelines and the Pharmaca Fennica (the Pharmacopoeia), were crucial for the use of the system. Some differences in physician behavior over time were also noted. Implications for system improvements are discussed.

title: Understanding practice: the factors influencing management of mild traumatic brain injury in the emergency department - a qualitative study using the Theoretical Domains Framework
abstract: BACKGROUND: Mild traumatic brain injury is a common reason for presentation to the emergency department. Despite the availability of clinical practice guidelines in this area, there are differences in practice. One of the goals of the Neurotrauma Evidence Translation program is to develop and evaluate a targeted, theory- and evidence-based intervention to improve the management of mild traumatic brain injury in Australian emergency departments. This study is the first step in the intervention development process and uses the Theoretical Domains Framework to examine the factors perceived to influence the adoption of four key evidence-based recommended practices for treating mild traumatic brain injury. METHODS: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with rescue workers in the Australian state of Victoria. The interview guide was developed using the Theoretical Domains Framework to examine current practice and identify the factors affecting practice. Two researchers coded the interview transcripts using a thematic content analysis. RESULTS: A total of 42 participants (9 directors, 20 physicians, and 13 nurses) were interviewed over a seven-month period. The results suggest that (i) the prospective assessment of post-traumatic amnesia was influenced by: knowledge, beliefs about consequences, environmental context and resources, skills, social/professional role and identity, and beliefs about skills; (ii) the use of Criteria or decision-making rules developed in guidelines for informing about the appropriate use of a CT scan was influenced by: knowledge; beliefs about consequences; environmental context and resources; memory, attention, and decision-making processes; beliefs about abilities; social influences; skills and behavioral regulation; (iii) the Provision of oral and written patient information at discharge was influenced by: beliefs about outcomes; environmental context and resources; memory, attention, and decision-making processes; social/professional role and identity; and knowledge; (iv) the practice of informing became routine Discharge follow-up influenced by: environmental context and resources, social/professional role and identity, knowledge edge; beliefs about consequences;" and motivation and goals. CONCLUSIONS: Using the Theoretical Domains Framework, factors thought to influence the treatment of mild traumatic brain injury in the emergency department were identified. These factors provide theoretically sound targets for future intervention represent.

title: Understanding the neurobiology, assessment and treatment of substances of abuse and dependence: a guide for the critical care worker
abstract: What do I do as an intensive care nurse? Because of their training in health promotion, and also because they interact with patients, families and communities, nurses have first-hand opportunities to play an active role in the practice of primary prevention. To prevent the first occurrence of substance abuse, assess community needs, facility needs, and identify potential risks. Identify the extent of the problem. Intervene early in young people and risk groups. Refer patients and their families to mental health specialists. Educate patients, families and communities. To reduce the incidence of substance abuse, practicing secondary prevention requires immediate action at the earliest moments of recognition of a problem and directing patients to early intervention and rehabilitation. Screening your patients, providing brief education, and prompt referral constitute early intervention. To delay disease progression, practice tertiary prevention by providing the affected individual with education, counseling, and support in achieving and maintaining sobriety through medication and offer rehabilitative group and counseling work. The goal of intervention in the lives of drug addicts is to stop drug use, prevent relapse, and aid in recovery. After years of research, NIDA has identified 13 core principles for effective drug abuse treatment. 1. Addiction is a complex but treatable disease that affects brain function and behavior. 2. No single treatment is right for everyone. 3. The treatment must be readily available. 4. Effective treatment addresses the diverse needs of the individual, not just his or her substance abuse needs. 5. Remaining in treatment for an appropriate length of time is essential. 6. Counseling - individual and/or group counseling - and other behavioral therapies are the most commonly used forms of substance abuse treatment. 7. Medication is an important element of treatment for many patients, particularly when combined with counseling and other behavioral therapies. 8. An individual's treatment and benefit plan must be continually evaluated and adjusted as necessary to ensure that it meets their changing needs. 9. Many drug addicts also have other mental disorders that require treatment. 10. Medically assisted detoxification in the first stage of addiction treatment alone does little to change long-term substance abuse. 11. Treatment does not have to be voluntary to be effective. 12. Drug use during treatment needs to be monitored continuously, as there are interruptions during treatment. 13. Treatment programs should screen patients for the presence of HIV/AIDS, hepatitis B and C, tuberculosis, and other infectious diseases, and provide targeted risk reduction counseling to help patients change or modify behaviors that put them at risk of infection or spread of infectious diseases. To really impact this disease, there is a need to improve risk factor identification and early detection and intervention in children and adolescents. The future of neuroscience lies in objective brain scans and genetic testing. From these approaches, more objective measures of addiction and dependency can emerge using brain scans and genetic testing. These actions would potentially enable the development of vaccines against certain drugs of abuse and addiction, as well as increasingly selective and effective pharmacological treatment approaches, and a new consensus on standard treatments for substance addiction.

title: Understanding the performance of community health care volunteers involved in the delivery of health programs in underserved areas: a realistic synthesis
abstract: Background Recruitment of Community Health Volunteers (CHVs) to support the delivery of health programs is a well-established approach in underserved areas and particularly where health inequalities exist due to a lack of trained staff. However, there is a lack of evidence on what works to improve the performance of CHVs. This review aimed to summarize the existing literature to explain why, how, and under what circumstances intervention approaches to improve CHV performance are more likely to be successful. Methods We performed a realistic synthesis. We identified possible theories related to our review questions, which then guided the selection, assessment, and analysis of primary studies. Interesting publications from the years 2008 to 2012 were identified by a systematic search in the PubMed and IDEAS databases. We considered all study designs that examined the different aspects of CHV performance in the context of formal organizational settings as appropriate and excluded the studies that did not provide explanations for CHV performance either in the results or in the discussion section. The data were organized according to their relation to context, interventions, outcomes and mechanisms to identify the interaction between them. The synthesis of the data allowed us to determine explanatory patterns within or between studies. Findings We identified broad approaches to intervention within the 23 papers included in the review: positioning the CHV within the community, establishing clear roles, providing competency-based and continuous training, incentives, supervision, and logistical support for task distribution and implementation. The results shed light on which mechanisms (self-esteem, sense of duty, self-efficacy, feeling of being treated fairly) should be targeted when implementing such approaches, and which contextual factors (stable and supportive cultural, political and social context and closely connected intervention). with local health services) create the most favorable conditions for the occurrence of these mechanisms and ultimately contribute to better performance of CHVs. Four main explanatory patterns around these mechanisms have emerged as fundamental to better performance. Conclusions The patterns identified, combined with the designers' and other stakeholders' assumptions about how such interventions are intended to work, can be tested through empirical studies to provide useful information that can be used by program implementers, policymakers, donors, and the community.

title: Unemployment and Mortality in Denmark, 1970-80
abstract: Relative mortality in the period 1970-80 was examined among Danish men and women who were unemployed and employed on the 1970 census day. The study population consisted of the entire labor force aged 20 to 64 on November 9, 1970, ie approximately 2 million employed and 22,000 unemployed. Relative mortality was analyzed using a multiplicative hazards regression model (as a natural extension of the standardized mortality rate) and a multiplicative regression model with extra Poisson variation. A significantly increased mortality rate (40-50%) was found among the unemployed after adjusting for occupation, housing category, geographic region and marital status. Analysis of the five main causes of death showed increased mortality from all causes, but particularly from suicide or accidents. In areas where the local unemployment rate was comparatively high, the relative mortality among the unemployed was lower. The increased mortality among the unemployed was interpreted as a consequence of health-related selection and as an increased susceptibility to psychosocial stress caused by unemployment.

title: Unequal protection of patients' rights: the gap between university and health ethics committees
abstract: Despite the Cartwright Report's recommendations, ethical scrutiny by health ethics committees in New Zealand has continued without health practitioners ever having to acknowledge their dual role as health practitioners researching their own patients. On the other hand, universities explicitly identify doctor-researcher-patient relationships as potential role conflicts. This stems from the recognition within the higher education sector itself that faculty-researcher-student relationships are fraught with such conflicts. Although similar unequal relationships exist between health researchers and their patients, patients/subjects are not afforded the level of protection afforded to students/subjects. In this paper, we argue that the difference between universities and health research is the result of the Operational Standard Code for Ethics Committees' failure to explicitly recognize patient vulnerability and conflicts of interest in the dual role of health practitioner/researcher. We conclude the paper recommending that the Department of Health consider rewriting the Ethics Committee Code of Operations, specifically rewriting Section 26 of the Ethics Committee Code of Operations. We also identify the value of a comparative ethical review and propose the New Zealand Health Research Council's trilateral relationship with Australia's NHMRC (National Health and Medical Research Council) and Canada's CIHR (Canadian Institute of Health Research) as a useful starting point for such a process .

title: Unhealthy drinking habits and receipt of preventive medical services by older adults
abstract: BACKGROUND: The use of preventive services among older adults is suboptimal. Unhealthy drinking can be a risk factor for not making use of these services. OBJECTIVES: To determine the association between unhealthy drinking and utilization of recommended preventive services in older Medicare beneficiaries, using the framework of current alcohol use guidelines. DESIGN/METHODS: The data source is the nationally representative 2003 Medicare Current Beneficiary Survey. The sample included 65 years and older (N = 10,523). Based on self-reported alcohol consumption, respondents were categorized as non-drinkers, within-guidelines drinkers, monthly but not daily limit drinkers, or heavy episodic drinkers. The influenza vaccination, the pneumonia vaccination, the glaucoma screening and the mammography entry were determined on the basis of survey and damage data. Bivariate and logistic regression analyzes were performed. RESULTS: Overall, 70.3% of women received influenza vaccination and 49% glaucoma screening, 66.8% pneumonia vaccination, and 56.2% of women received mammography over 2 years over the year. In logistic regression, heavy episodic drinking was associated with a lower likelihood of receiving services compared to drinking within guidelines: influenza shot (OR 0.75, CI 0.59-0.96), glaucoma screening (OR 0, 74, CI 0.58-0.95) and vaccination against pneumonia (OR 0.75, CI 0.59-0.96). Non-drinkers were less likely to receive a mammogram (OR 0.83, CI 0.69-1.00) compared to those who reported drinking within guidelines. CONCLUSIONS: Heavy episodic drinking is associated with a lower likelihood of utilizing multiple preventive services. Practitioners should be encouraged to screen all elders for alcohol use and, in addition to appropriate intervention, consider that elders who report heavy episodic alcohol use are at greater risk of not receiving preventive services.

title: Unintended effects of a computerized physician order entry near-continuous alert to prevent drug-drug interaction: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background The effectiveness of computerized medical order entry (CPOE) systems has been modest, primarily because clinicians frequently override electronic alarms. Methods To evaluate the effectiveness of a near-hard-stop CPOE prescription alert aimed at reducing concomitant prescriptions of warfarin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, a randomized clinical trial was conducted at two academic medical centers in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. A total of 1981 clinicians were assigned to either an intervention group, which received a near-hard stop alert, or a control group, which received standard practice. The study period was from August 9, 2006 to February 13, 2007. Results The proportion of desired responses (i.e. no reordering of the alarm-triggering drug within 10 minutes of initiation) was 57.2% (111 of 194 hard-stop alarms) in the intervention group and 13.5% (20 of 148) in the control group (adjusted odds ratio 0.12; 95% confidence interval 0.045-0.33). However, the study was terminated early due to 4 unintended consequences identified in patients in the intervention group: a delay in treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole in 2 patients and a delay in treatment with warfarin in an additional 2 patients. Conclusions An electronic emergency stop alarm as part of an inpatient CPOE system appeared to be extremely effective in changing prescriptions. The intervention resulted in clinically meaningful treatment delays in 4 patients requiring immediate medical therapy. These results illustrate the importance of formal assessment and monitoring for unintended consequences of the Programmatic interventions to improve prescribing habits.

title: Update on interventions that focus on symptom clusters: what has been tried and what have we learned?
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: Although clinicians and researchers recognize clusters of symptoms, the focus was on alleviating a single symptom. This review summarizes the current literature on interventions focused on alleviating symptom clusters in cancer patients. RECENT RESULTS: Twelve intervention studies that met the inclusion criteria were published in 2011-2012. The time frame was extended to 2009-2012 and 24 studies met the criteria: 18 in early-stage and 6 in advanced-stage cancer patients. Several cognitive behavioral therapies, complementary therapies, and exercise interventions have shown positive results in alleviating a variety of symptom clusters in multiple cancers. Most psychoeducational interventions, using traditional formats or those combined with automated clinical alerts, showed efficacy in reducing a wide variety of clusters. Clusters that included fatigue and anxiety or depression were reduced by exercise in early-stage patients and by methylphenidate in advanced-stage patients. Recent studies funded by the NIH R01 confirmed the trends in the types of interventions tested. SUMMARY: Few interventions have been tested and found effective to alleviate specific symptom clusters in early- and advanced-stage cancer patients. Future research must expand our understanding of the mechanisms that trigger co-occurring symptoms.
