Mechanism-directed interventions need to be identified and tested in homogeneous samples with specific symptom clusters. Interventions must be repeated before policies can be established.

title: Update on pediatric hyperlipidemia
abstract: PURPOSE OF REVIEW: The purpose of this study is to review the National Heart Lung and Blood Institute (NHBLI) guidelines for the screening and management of hyperlipidemia in children and to discuss critics' concerns about universal screening. RECENT RESULTS: Data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey showed favorable trends in serum lipid levels in children and adolescents aged 6-19 years between 1988-1994 and 2007-2010. Mean total cholesterol (TC) decreased from 165 to 160 mg/dL and the prevalence of elevated TC decreased from 11.3 to 8.1%. However, between 2007 and 2010, about 20% of children ages 9 to 11 had either low high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) or high non-HDL-C. This warrants an additional assessment under NHBLI guidelines. SUMMARY: The NHBLI guidelines provide physicians with a balanced perspective for the screening and management of hyperlipidemia in children. These guidelines provide a schematic approach to help GPs make treatment decisions. The hope is that this will lead to reduced healthcare system spending and overall improved health through early detection and intervention.

title: Medical researchers in the United States, the Nuremberg Doctors' Trial and the Nuremberg Code. A review of the results of the Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experiments
abstract: The Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experimentation (ACHRE), established to review allegations of abuse of human subjects in government-sponsored radiation research, was tasked with identifying appropriate standards for assessing the ethics of Cold War radiation experimentation. A key question for ACHRE was to determine the role of the Nuremberg Code in the norms and practices of US medical research. Based on evidence from ACHRE's Ethics Oral History Project and extensive archival research, we conclude that at the time of its promulgation, the Code had had little impact on established medical researchers studying humans. Although some clinical researchers raised questions about conducting research on humans, it was not until the 1960s that the medical profession began to pursue the issue.

title: Use and impact of health information sharing: a systematic review
abstract: Background: Health information exchange (HIE) is increasing in the United States and is encouraged by government policies. Purpose: To systematically review and evaluate evidence for the use and effect of HIE on clinical care. Data Sources: Selected databases from January 1, 2003 to May 31, 2014. Study Selection: English-language hypothesis testing or quantitative studies of various types of data exchange between independent organizations for use in clinical care that addressed health outcomes, efficiency, utilization, cost, satisfaction, HIE usage, sustainability, and attitudes or barriers. Data extraction: Data extraction was performed twice. DATA SYNTHESIS: Low-quality evidence from 12 hypothesis-testing studies supports an effect of HIE use on reduced use or costs in the ED. Direct evidence of HIEs being used by providers was reported in 21 studies involving 13 different HIE organizations, 6 of which were based in New York, and generally showed use in less than 10% of patient encounters. Findings from 17 sustainability studies indicate that about a quarter of existing HIE organizations rate themselves as financially stable. Findings from 38 studies on attitudes and barriers showed that providers, patients, and other stakeholders see HIE as valuable, but barriers include technical issues and workflows, costs, and privacy concerns. Limitation: publication bias, possible selective reporting of results, and a lack of reporting of context and implementation processes. Conclusion: Leveraging health information sharing is likely to reduce emergency room utilization and costs in some cases. Effects on other endpoints are not known. All stakeholders claim to value HIE, but there are many barriers to adoption and sustainability. A small subset of operational HIEs has been evaluated and further research is needed to identify and understand success factors.

title: Using and Avoiding Isolation and Restraint: Consensus Statement of the American Association for Emergency Psychiatry Project Beta Seclusion and Restrain Workgroup
abstract: Issues related to reducing and/or eliminating episodes of isolation and restraint in patients with behavioral problems in crisis clinics, emergency departments, inpatient psychiatric departments, and specialized psychiatric emergency services continue to be an area of concern and discussion among mental health clinicians. An important guiding principle of the BETA (Best Practices in Evaluation and Treatment of Agitation) project is non-forced de-escalation as the intervention of choice in dealing with acute agitation and threatening behavior. In this article, the authors discuss various aspects of seclusion and restraint, including a review of Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services policies governing its use in medical behavioral settings, adverse consequences of this intervention for patients and staff, and a review of quality improvement and risk management strategies, that have been effective in reducing their use in various treatment settings. An algorithm designed to help the clinician determine when solitude or restraint is most appropriate is introduced. The authors conclude that because of their primary treatment of acute patients, the specialized psychiatric emergency services and emergency departments may not be able to completely eliminate the use of isolation and restraint events, but these programs can employ strategies to reduce their utilization interventions.

title: Use and Care of Animals in Research and Education: MMA Policy Statement
Using a Clinical Decision Support Tool to Improve Guideline Adherence for the Treatment of Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus: Skin and Soft Tissue Infections.
abstract: Skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs) with abscesses are commonly seen in the emergency room (ED). With the increasing prevalence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)-related abscesses, appropriate evidence-based decisions are essential for successful treatment. Provider adherence to clinical guidelines for the management of SSTIs with suspected MRSA remains inconsistent in terms of prescription practice related to antibiotic selection, wound culturing, and patient discharge recommendations related to the use of infection control techniques. There is evidence that the use of clinical decision support tools (CDS) is valuable to improve provider awareness and adherence to clinical guidelines. This study was conducted to investigate whether developing a CDS tool to guide order entry for the treatment of MRSA-related SSTIs and embedding it in the electronic medical record program would improve compliance with the North Carolina Consensus Guideline for Management of Suspected Community-Acquired MRSA -Skin and soft tissue.

title: Using a computer to recognize and respond to clinical events: its impact on clinical behavior.
abstract: computer was used to prospectively identify and suggest responses to simple, medication-related events as reflected in a computerized recording in a prospective, randomized study of a primary care-responsible diabetes clinic. There were two categories of events/suggestions: If the last observation of a test required for medication control was too old, the computer suggested a repeat”; and when an abnormality with therapeutic implications was detected, the computer suggested a specific change in therapeutics. Clinicians responded to 36% of events in the first category with computer recall and 11% without (P<0.0001); they responded to 28% of events in the second category with computer assistance and 13% without (P<0.026). For the most clinically significant of these second category events, the difference was even greater: 47% with and 4% without computer assistance (p<0.0004). I believe that computer recognition and response (in the form of memories) to simple clinical events will change the behavior of physicians.

title: Use of a computerized guideline for glucose regulation in the ICU improved both guideline adherence and glucose regulation.
abstract: Objective: To measure the effects of a computerized glucose regulation policy in an intensive care unit. DESIGN: A randomized controlled trial with an off-on-off design. Methods: In the first phase of the study, we implemented a paper-based glucose regulation guideline in an intensive care unit. During the second period, the guideline was applied randomly in either paper or computerized form. In the third period, the guideline was only available in paper form. Measurements and results: We analyzed data from 484 patients. During the intervention period, the control group comprised 54 patients and the computer-assisted intervention group comprised 66 patients. The two guideline-related outcome measures consisted of compliance with: (a) the timing recommendations for glucose testing and (b) the insulin dose recommendation. We measured clinical effect as the percentage of time glucose levels fell within the target range. In the first (paper-based) phase of the study, 29.0% of the samples were optimally timed; during the second phase this rose to 35.5% for paper-based and 40.2% for computer-based protocols. Punctuality scores in the third study period returned. Late (suboptimal) sampling occurred in 66% of glucose measurements in the first study period, 42% of the paper-based and 28% of the computer-based protocol samples in the second period, and 50.0% samples in the third study period. In the first study period, adherence to insulin dosing guidelines was 56.3%; in the second period it was 64.2% for paper-based and 77.3% for computer-based protocols, and in the third period it fell to 42.4% For the second study period, the time it took for a patient's glucose levels to fall within the target range improved for both the control group (52.9%) and the computer-assisted group (54.2%) compared to the first study period (44 .3%) and the third study period (42.3%) Conclusion: Implementation of a computer-based version of a guideline significantly improved the timeliness of measurements and glucose regulation in critically ill patients compared to implementation of a paper-based version of the guideline.

title: Using a decision aid with overdetection information to support an informed breast cancer screening decision: a randomized controlled trial.
abstract: Background Mammography screening may reduce breast cancer mortality. However, most women are unaware that trivial diseases can also be detected through screening, leading to overdiagnosis and overtreatment. Our aim was to investigate whether including information about overdetection of breast cancer in a decision aid would help women around the age of 50 make an informed decision about breast screening. Methods We conducted a community-based, randomized, parallel-group, controlled study in New South Wales, Australia, with a randomized cohort of women aged 48-50 years. The study was recruited by telephone”; Women were eligible if they had not had a mammogram in the past 2 years and had no personal or strong family history of breast cancer. Using a computer program, we randomly assigned 879 participants to either the intervention decision aid (consisting of evidence-based explanatory and quantitative information on overdetection, breast cancer mortality reduction, and false positives) or a control decision aid (including information on breast cancer mortality reduction and false alarms) Participants and interviewers were masked to the group. The primary endpoint was informed choice (defined as adequate knowledge and consistency between attitudes and screening intentions), which we assessed via telephone interview approximately 3 weeks after random assignment. The primary endpoint was assessed in all Women analyzed who had completed the relevant follow-up Interview questions in full This study is registered with the Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry, number ACTRN12613001035718. Results Between January 2014 and July 2014, 440 women were assigned to the intervention group and 439 to the control group. 21 women in the intervention group and 20 controls were lost to follow-up; another 10 women assigned to the intervention and 11 controls did not answer all questions about attitudes. Therefore, 409 women in the intervention group and 408 controls were analyzed for the primary endpoint. 99 (24%) of 409 women in the intervention group made an informed choice compared to 63 (15%) of 408 in the control group (difference 9%, 95% CI 3-14; p=0·0017). Compared to the controls, more women in the intervention group reached the threshold for adequate overall knowledge (122/419 [29%] vs. 71/419 [17%]; difference 12%, 95% CI 6-18; p<0 0001 ), fewer women expressed a positive attitude towards screening (282/409 [69%] vs. 340/408 [83%]; 14%, 9–20; p<0 0001), and fewer women intended to be screened ( 308/419 [74%] vs. 363/419 [87%]; 13%, 8-19; p<0·0001). When only conceptual knowledge was considered, 203 (50%) of 409 women in the intervention group made an informed decision compared to 79 (19%) of 408 in the control group (p < 0 0001) Interpreting information to overdetect breast cancer in a decision aid increased the number of women who consciously chose to have breast screening Being better informed could make women less likely to choose screening.

title: Application of a fall prevention practice guideline for at-risk older people in community accommodation: a feasibility study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Falls are common in older people and are a common cause of physical and psychological morbidity and health service utilization. The problem can be traced back to a complex interaction between health, behavioral and environmental factors. In order to ensure a uniform and evidence-based approach, a practical guide to fall prevention for elderly people at risk of falling at home was developed. AIM: To test the feasibility of integrating a practice guideline on falls prevention into the daily practice of 4 primary health care disciplines, ie general practitioners, nurses, occupational therapists and physical therapists. METHODS: This was a descriptive study conducted by 10 local health networks across Flanders. The subjects involved in the study were 99 domestic workers and 1,142 elderly patients (65 years or older) who could get up from a chair and move around independently. For 6 months, primary care workers implemented our fall prevention guideline, which consisted of 3 parts (case finding, multifactorial in-depth assessment, and interventions). After the 6-month trial period, the participating primary care physicians were asked to complete a semi-structured questionnaire to assess the guideline's applicability in daily practice. RESULTS: The average time required to complete the guideline was 32.0 +/- 14.0 min. Health care workers of all 4 disciplines considered case finding their task. The situation was different when assessing risk factors and interventions. Although 87.5% considered fall prevention to be an important issue, health professionals across disciplines disagreed on how to integrate the prevention guideline into daily practice. A lack of time (57.3%), low motivation of the target population (53.3%) and insufficient cooperation between healthcare workers (37.3%) were perceived as barriers to the implementation of the guideline. CONCLUSION: The integration of prevention strategies into daily practice can be initiated with the help of a guide. Case finding can be carried out for all disciplines. Multifactorial assessment and interventions require specific task allocation, multidisciplinary collaboration, and clear communication.

title: Using action planning to improve the delivery of smoking cessation treatment by general practitioners: role of specificity and implementation of the plan
abstract: Background Strategies are needed to help general practitioners (GPs) promote smoking cessation, as recommended in the guidelines. This study examines whether the quality of primary care physicians' action planning improves their delivery of smoking cessation treatment. Methods The effectiveness of a 1-hour exercise program was evaluated in a cluster-randomized controlled trial involving 49 general practitioners. General practitioners who participated in the training (intervention group";" n?=?25) formulated action plans in relation to i) questions about smoking, ii) advice on smoking cessation and iii) organization of follow-up care for smokers motivated to quit. GPs also formulated a coping plan for encountering smokers who were not motivated to quit. The quality of these plans (plan specificity) was assessed and GPs reported on the execution of these plans (plan implementation) 6 weeks after the training. The effects of plan specificity and plan implementation on the patient-reported smoking cessation activities of primary care physicians in the intervention group (n?=?1,632 patients) compared to the control group (n?=?1,769 patients) were examined using multilevel regression analyses. . Results Compared to the control group, primary care physicians who formulated a very specific action plan during the training asked their patients about smoking more often after the training than before the training (OR 2.11, 95% CI 1.51-2.95). GPs were the most likely to ask patients about smoking after the training compared to before the training, when they had adopted a very specifically formulated action plan (OR 3.08, 95% CI 2.04-4.64). The impact of the specificity of the GP plan and the implementation of the plan on patients' questioning about smoking was most evident among GPs who intended to provide smoking cessation treatment at baseline. Conclusions A highly specific action plan formulated by a GP on when, how and by whom patients will be interviewed about smoking had a positive effect on GP surveys about smoking, particularly when these professionals reported implementing the plan. This effect was most evident in primary care physicians who intended to provide smoking cessation treatment prior to the intervention. Training on how to create personalized coping plans is recommended to further improve the way GPs offer smoking cessation services and organize smoking cessation follow-up care.

title: Using an internet portal to improve community-based pediatric ADHD care: a randomized cluster study
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the effectiveness of a quality improvement program to improve pediatrician adherence to existing, evidence-based guidelines for treating attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). METHODS: Forty-nine pediatricians in 8 practices participated in a cluster-randomized study. The practices were grouped according to the number of pediatricians and the proportion of patients receiving Medicaid. Medical histories for a random sample of patients with ADHD for each of the participating pediatricians were examined at baseline and at 6 months. All practices participated in 4 training sessions including didactic lectures and workshops on changing office flow. The practices were then given access to an ADHD web portal that allowed parents, teachers, and pediatricians to enter information (e.g., rating scales) about patients, after which the information was assessed, interpreted, and formatted in a reporting style helpful for the assessment was and treatment of patients with ADHD. Physicians evaluated their practice behavior quarterly and addressed underperforming areas. RESULTS: Pediatricians in the intervention group demonstrated significantly higher rates of many ADHD care practices recommended by the American Academy of Pediatrics, including surveys of parents (Cohen's d = 0.69) and teachers (i.e = 0.68) Rating Scales for Assessing Children with ADHD, Using the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition, Criteria (d = 0.85), and Using Teacher Rating Scales to Monitor Treatment Success (d = 1.01) . CONCLUSION: A quality improvement intervention that can be widely disseminated through the use of Internet-based information technology has significantly improved the quality of ADHD care in community-based pediatric settings.

title: use of antibiotics. sepsis
Use of evidence in WHO recommendations
abstract: Background WHO regulations from 1951 emphasize the role of expert judgment in developing recommendations. However, the organization's guidelines, approved in 2003, emphasize the use of systematic reviews to demonstrate impacts, processes that allow for the explicit inclusion of other types of information (including values), and evidence-based dissemination and implementation strategies. We have examined the use of evidence, particularly evidence of effects, in recommendations developed by WHO departments.”;” Background WHO regulations from 1951 emphasize the role of expert judgment in the development of recommendations. However, the organization's guidelines, approved in 2003, emphasize the use of systematic reviews to demonstrate impacts, processes that allow for the explicit inclusion of other types of information (including values), and evidence-based dissemination and implementation strategies. We examined the use of evidence, particularly evidence of effects, in recommendations developed by WHO departments.

title: Use of warfarin at discharge in acute ischemic stroke patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation in China
abstract: BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE: Guidelines recommend oral anticoagulation for patients with ischemic stroke and atrial fibrillation, and previous studies have shown that anticoagulation is underused in these patients in China. We have attempted to examine the underlying reasons and factors currently affecting warfarin use in China. Methods: From June 2012 to January 2013, 19,604 patients with acute ischemic stroke were enrolled in 219 city hospitals who voluntarily participated in the China National Stroke Registry II. Multivariable logistic regression models using the generalized estimating equation method were used to identify patient/hospital factors independently associated with warfarin use at discharge. RESULTS: Of the 952 acute ischemic stroke patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation, 19.4% were discharged on warfarin. The risk of bleeding (52.8%) and patient refusal (31.9%) were the main reasons for not prescribing anticoagulation. Larger/teaching hospitals were more likely to prescribe warfarin. Older patients, heavy drinkers, and patients with a higher National Institutes of Health stroke score at admission were less likely to receive warfarin, while patients with a history of heart failure and an internationally normalized ratio of between 2.0 and 3.0 during hospitalization were significantly associated with warfarin use at discharge. CONCLUSIONS: The use of warfarin in patients with ischemic stroke and known non-valvular atrial fibrillation in China remains low. Hospital size and academic status along with patient age, heart failure, heavy alcohol consumption, internationally normalized hospital ratio, and stroke severity at admission were each independently associated with warfarin use at discharge. There is much room for improvement in secondary stroke prevention in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation in China.

title: User satisfaction and frustration with a portable, pen-based system for implementing asthma guidelines
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate physician satisfaction and frustration with the use of a handheld computer system implementing a policy for the management of childhood asthma exacerbations. SETTING: Nine pediatric primary care practices. DESIGN: Survey component of a randomized, prospective before-after study. INTERVENTION: Newton MessagePad equipped with custom software (called “AsthMonitor”) that helps document clinical findings and provides guideline-based recommendations. RESULTS: Overall, 3 users gave strongly positive global ratings while 6 users were neutral. At the same time, the majority used the documentation functions with care. With the exception of the recommendations for administering oxygen (which were not supported by evidence), users found the recommendations appropriate and valued the memories. Seven out of nine participants felt that documentation took more time with AsthMonitor. CONCLUSIONS: Handheld computers are acceptable to some practitioners in practice for providing guideline-based advice in the context of the clinical encounter.

title: Using "nudge" principles for order set design: a before-and-after evaluation of an e-prescribing template in critical care
abstract: Aim Computerized prescription sets have the potential to reduce clinical variability and improve patient safety, but the impact varies. We sought to assess the impact of prescription set design changes on the delivery of chlorhexidine mouthwash and hydroxyethyl starch (HES) to ICU patients. Methods The study was conducted at University Hospitals Bristol NHS Foundation Trust, UK. Our intensive care unit uses a clinical information system (CIS). All medications and fluids are prescribed using the CIS, and medication and fluid charts are stored in a database. Chlorhexidine mouthwash was added to the prescription template as a default prescription in January 2010. HES was removed from the prescription template in April 2009. Both interventions could be manually prescribed throughout the study period. We performed a database review of all patients eligible for each intervention before and after changes to the choice configuration within the prescribing system. Results 2231 ventilated patients were identified as eligible for treatment with chlorhexidine, 591 before the intervention and 1640 afterwards. 55.3% were prescribed chlorhexidine before the switch and 90.4% afterwards (p<0.001). 6199 patients were included in the HES intervention, 2177 before the intervention and 4022 after. The mean HES volume infused per patient decreased after the change from 630 mL to 20 mL (p<0.001) and the percentage of patients receiving HES decreased from 54.1% to 3.1% (p<0.001). These results have been well maintained over time. Conclusions The presentation of choices within an e-prescribing system influenced the delivery of evidence-based interventions in a predictable manner, and the effect was sustained. This approach has the potential to improve the effectiveness of computerized job sets.

title: Using a taxonomy of behavior modification techniques to identify agents in studies implementing interventions for diabetes care
abstract: BACKGROUND: Methodological guidelines for reporting on interventions emphasize the detailed description of intervention content. Despite this, systematic reviews of quality improvement (QI) interventions remain limited by a lack of clarity and detail regarding the intervention content to be assessed. Our aim was to apply the recently developed Behavior Change Techniques Taxonomy Version 1 (BCTTv1) to studies of implementation interventions for diabetes management to assess the capacity and usefulness of this taxonomy to characterize agents. METHODS: Three psychologists independently coded a random sample of 23 studies on health system, provider, and/or patient-centric implementation interventions from a systematic review that included 142 such studies. The intervention content was encoded using BCTTv1, which describes 93 behavior change techniques (BCTs) grouped into 16 categories. We have supplemented the generic coding instructions within the BCTTv1 with decision rules and examples from this literature. RESULTS: Less than a quarter of the possible BCTs within the BCTTv1 were identified. For implementation interventions aimed at providers, the most commonly identified BCTs included: adding objects to the environment, prompts/cues, instructions on how to perform the behavior, credible source, goal setting (outcome), feedback on behavior outcome, and social support ( practical). For implementation interventions that also target patients, the most commonly identified BCTs were: Prompts/cues, Instructions to perform the behavior, Information about health outcomes, Restructuring of the social environment, Adding objects to the environment, Social support (practical) , and goal setting (behaviour). BCTTv1 mapped well to implementation measures aimed directly at physicians and patients, and could also be used to study the impact of system-level interventions on physician and patient behavior. CONCLUSIONS: The BCTTv1 can be used to characterize the agents in intervention delivery studies and provides substantive specificity beyond what is indicated by broader intervention labels. Identifying BCTs may provide a more helpful means of gathering knowledge about the content used in attempts at implementation interventions, which may help better inform replication efforts. In addition, prospectively using a taxonomy of behavior change techniques to develop and report on intervention content would further help build a cumulative science of effective implementation interventions.

title: Using a planned behavioral framework theory to examine beliefs about hand hygiene in the '5 critical moments' among Australian hospital nurses
abstract: BACKGROUND: Improving hand hygiene among healthcare workers (HCWs) is the single most effective intervention in reducing HAIs. Understanding the cognitive determinants of hand hygiene decisions for healthcare workers with the greatest patient contact (nurses) is critical to improving compliance. The aim of this study was to examine the beliefs of nurses in hospitals related to the implementation of hand hygiene according to the World Health Organization (WHO) 5 critical moments. Using the belief-based framework of Theory of Planned Behavior, we examined attitudinal, normative, and controlling beliefs that underpin caregiver decisions to perform hand hygiene according to recently introduced national guidelines. METHODS: Thematic content analysis of qualitative data from focus group discussions with nurses from 5 wards in 3 hospitals in Queensland, Australia. RESULTS: Key advantages (patient and self-protection), disadvantages (time, hand damage), facilitators (supportive: patients, colleagues"; unsupportive: some physicians), barriers (overload, emergency situations), and facilitators (sink/product accessibility, training). , memories) were identified. There was some ambiguity regarding the relative importance of hand washing after exposure to the patient environment. CONCLUSIONS: The belief base of the theory of planned behavior provided a useful framework to systematically assess the beliefs underlying nurses' hand hygiene decisions according to the 5 critical Moments to examine and allow for comparisons to previous persuasion studies A commitment to improving caregivers' hand hygiene practices in the 5 Moments should focus on individual strategies to combat distraction from other tasks, peer-based initiatives to promote a A sense of shared responsibility and management-driven solutions to address staffing and resource issues. Hand hygiene after touching a patient's environment continues to be reported as the most neglected opportunity for compliance.

title: Promoting evidence-based practice in nursing with Appreciative Inquiry: The glass is more than half full
abstract: It is now clear that successful implementation of evidence-based practice (EBP) requires a focus on the context of the care setting. While many reports focus on the limitations and barriers, this paper proposes a new approach to “make EBP a reality”. Appreciative inquiry (AI), both a social research method and an organizational development or change intervention, is a novel means of evoking enthusiasm and support for EBP in nursing. Readers are introduced to the theoretical foundations and assumptions as well as the "4-D model" of AI. It is suggested that the Advanced Practice Nurse (APN) has a key role in introducing and supporting this intervention in healthcare organizations to promote the successful implementation of EBP.

title: Use of computer-assisted clinical decision support for screening for latent tuberculosis infection.
abstract: Background The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has published guidelines recommending that high-risk groups be screened for latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). The aim of this study was to determine the impact of computer-assisted clinical decision support and guided web-based documentation on screening rates for LTBI. Design Non-randomized, prospective intervention study. Setting and participants Participants were 8463 patients treated in two primary care ambulatory public health centers in late 2002 and early 2003. Intervention The CDC's LTBI guidelines were coded into a computer-assisted clinical decision support system that provided an alert message with recommendations for further assessment of LTBI risk when certain guideline criteria were met (birth in a high-risk TB country and age <40). A guided web-based documentation tool was provided to facilitate appropriate adherence to the LTBI screening guideline and to encourage accurate documentation and assessment. Baseline data was collected for 15 weeks and study phase data was collected for 12 weeks. Key Outcome Measures Adequate LTBI screening per CDC guidelines based on a table review. Results Of 4135 patients enrolled during the post-intervention period, 73% had at least one CDC-defined risk factor, and 610 met alert criteria (birth in a high-risk TB country and age <40 years) for potential screening for LTBI. Adherence to the LTBI screening guideline improved significantly from 8.9% at baseline to 25.2% during the study period (183% increase, p<0.001). Conclusions This study demonstrated that computer-assisted clinical decision support with alerts and guided web-based documentation improved the screening of high-risk patients for LTBI. This type of technology could lead to an improvement in LTBI screening in the United States and also promises improved care for other preventive and chronic diseases.

title: Use implementation intentions to teach practitioners: Change practice behavior through continuing education
abstract: AIM: This study evaluated the effectiveness of implementation intentions to increase the use of an exercise behavior among psychiatrists who attended a one-day continuing education course. METHODS: Seventy-eight physicians were randomly assigned to one of two psychiatric advance directive classes. One class integrated instructions into implementation intentions (N=40) and the other class did not (N=38). The intent-to-execute training required participants to describe the best time and place to use a practitioner-led process to help consumers complete a psychiatric living will. Use of the practitioner-guided procedure was the dependent variable in this study. The use of the method in practice was evaluated three months after the lesson by means of an electronic self-assessment survey. RESULTS: There were no statistically significant differences between the two classroom conditions in terms of participant characteristics or pre- and post-teaching knowledge of and intentions to use the procedure. 54 participants (69%) responded to the three-month follow-up survey and indicated that they had used the practitioner-led process. The results of the follow-up survey showed that the participants in the class with the intention to implement it used the practice-led approach significantly more often than those in the other class (80% versus 58%). The effect of implementation intentions on the use of the practitioner-led approach was evident among practitioners whose postclass intentions were high but below the median of the overall sample (chi(2)=7.1, df=1, p<.01). The implementation rates among the practitioners with the highest intentions after the class were equivalent in the two class states. CONCLUSIONS: Incorporating implementation intentions into continuing education courses can increase the utilization of the practices taught in these courses among well-motivated practitioners.

title: Use implementation intentions to teach practitioners: Change practice behavior through continuing education.
abstract: Aim: This study evaluated the effectiveness of implementation intentions to increase the use of an exercise behavior among psychiatrists who attended a one-day continuing education course. METHODS: Seventy-eight practitioners were randomly assigned to one of two psychiatric advance directive classes. One class integrated instructions into implementation intentions (N=40) and the other class did not (N=38). The intent-to-execute training required participants to describe the best time and place to use a practitioner-led process to help consumers complete a psychiatric living will. Use of the practitioner-guided procedure was the dependent variable in this study. The use of the method in practice was evaluated three months after the lesson by means of an electronic self-assessment survey. Results: There were no statistically significant differences between the two classroom conditions in terms of participant characteristics or pre- and post-teaching knowledge of and intentions to use the procedure. 54 participants (69%) responded to the three-month follow-up survey and indicated that they had used the practitioner-led process. The results of the follow-up survey showed that the participants in the class with the intention to implement it used the practice-led approach significantly more often than those in the other class (80% versus 58%). The effect of implementation intentions on the use of the practitioner-led process was evident among practitioners whose post-teaching intentions were high but below the median of the overall sample (?2=7.1, df=1, p<.01). The implementation rates among the practitioners with the highest intentions after the class were equivalent in the two class states. Conclusions: Incorporating implementation intentions into professional development courses can increase the utilization of the practices taught in these courses among well-motivated practitioners. (Psychiatric Services 59:747-752, 2008)

title: Use of paper chart-based clinical reminders to improve adherence to lipid management guidelines
abstract: Rationale, Aims, and Objectives: The aim of this study was to apply paper-based clinical reminder to improve adherence to lipid guidelines. METHODS: Coronary artery disease (CHD) patients not on lipid-lowering therapy (LLT) were recruited and medical records were reviewed. Eligible subjects were randomized";" In the study group but not in the control group, a clinical reminder was stamped on the paper record with current standards and local insurance policy. The primary endpoint was a new LLT subscription at the 6-month follow-up period and the secondary endpoint was the composite result of the LLT or lipid profile review. RESULTS: Ninety-two patients were assigned to the study group and 102 to the control group. The primary endpoint showed no difference at the end of 6 months (OR: 1.70, P=0.248, 95% CI: 0.69-4.19). The secondary endpoint was significantly higher in the memory group (OR: 2.81, P=0.001, 95% CI: 1.57-5.04). CONCLUSION: A paper chart-based clinical reminder with updated clinical recommendations could change physician behavior and improve awareness of lipid levels. However, its effect cannot be translated into an increase in LLT or a decrease in low-density lipoprotein levels due to local political restrictions.

title: Using Pathology-Specific Laboratory Profiles in Clinical Pathology to Reduce Inappropriate Testing Requests: Two Completed Audit Cycles
abstract: BACKGROUND: Systematic reviews have shown that the Consensus Guidelines, although well prepared, have not changed clinical practice. In the health district of Castelnovo ne Monti (Reggio Emilia, Italy) it became necessary for general practitioners and clinical pathologists to work together to jointly define laboratory profiles. METHODS: Observational study of two cycles of retrospective review of test request forms in a primary care setting. The objectives of the study were to develop pathology-specific laboratory profiles and to increase the number of tentative diagnoses on laboratory test request forms. A multi-professional, multi-disciplinary, multi-hospital work team developed pathology-specific laboratory profiles for a more effective testing requirement. After 8 training sessions using a combined strategy with multiple interventions, the 23 General Practitioners (GPs) in the test district (Castelnovo ne Monti) tested the profiles”; the 21 GPs in the Puianello district were the control group; all GPs in both districts participated in the study All laboratory tests for both health districts are performed in the laboratory located in the study district Baseline examination and 1-year audit were performed in both districts using GP inquiry forms RESULTS: Seven pathology-specific laboratory profiles for outpatients were developed. In the year after the first audit cycle: 1) the number of tests requested in the study district was significantly lower than in the previous year, with a decrease of approximately 5% (p<0.001); 2) the preliminary diagnosis on the claim forms was 52.8% in the experimental district and 42% in the control district (p<0.001) 3) the decrease in the number of tests on each claim form was much more pronounced in the district (8.73 vs. 10, 77; p<0.001). CONCLUSIONS: The first cycle of audits showed a significant decrease in the number of tests ordered in the trial area only. The combined strategy used in this study improved prescription compliance for most primary care physicians involved. The presence of the clinical pathologist is seen as an added value.

title: Use of second-generation antidepressants for the treatment of depressive disorders: A clinical practice guideline from the American College of Physicians
abstract: Description: The American College of Physicians developed this guideline to review the available evidence for the pharmacological treatment of the acute, continuation, and maintenance phases of major depressive disorder, dysthymia, subsyndromic depression, and associated symptoms such as anxiety, insomnia, or neurovegetative symptoms, using Second-generation antidepressants Methods: Published literature on this topic was identified using MEDLINE, EMBASE, PsychLit, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts from 1980 to April 2007-language studies in adults over 19 years of age. Keywords for the search included terms for depressive disorders and 12 specific second generation antidepressants bupropion, citalopram, duloxetine, escitalopram, fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, mirtazapine, nefazodone, paroxetine, sertraline, trazodone and venlafaxine and their specific trade names This policy classifies t The Evidence and recommendations are generated using the American College of Physicians Guidelines for Clinical Practice rating system. Recommendation 1: The American College of Physicians recommends that when considering pharmacological therapy to treat patients with acute major depressive disorder, physicians select second-generation antidepressants based on side effect profiles, cost, and patient preference (Grade: Strong Recommendation; moderate- proof of quality). Recommendation 2: The American College of Physicians recommends that clinicians regularly assess patient status, therapeutic response, and side effects of antidepressant therapy, beginning within 1 to 2 weeks of starting therapy (Grade: strong recommendation; evidence of moderate Quality). Recommendation 3: The American College of Physicians recommends that physicians adjust treatment if the patient does not show an adequate response to pharmacotherapy within 6 to 8 weeks of starting treatment for major depressive disorder (Grade: strong recommendation; moderate-quality evidence). Recommendation 4: The American College of Physicians recommends that physicians continue treatment for 4 to 9 months after a satisfactory response in patients with a first major depressive episode. For patients who have had 2 or more depressive episodes, an even longer duration of therapy may be beneficial (grade: strong recommendation; moderate-quality evidence).

title: Using shared goal setting to improve access and equity: a mixed methods study of Good Goals intervention in child occupational therapy
abstract: Background Access and equity in children's therapy services can be improved by directing the use of resources by clinicians toward specific goals that are important to patients. To achieve this, a practice change intervention (titled ¡Â®Good GoalsÂ¡Â¯) was developed. This study examined uptake, acceptance, and potential impact of this intervention in occupational therapy for children. Methods Mixed methods case studies (n?=?3 services including 46 therapists and 558 children) were conducted. The intervention was delivered over 25 weeks through personal training, team workbooks and 'tools for change'. Data were collected before, during, and after the intervention on a range of factors using interviews, a focus group, case note analysis, routine data, document analysis, and investigator observations. Outcomes Factors related to reception and adoption were: type of intervention delivery, competing demands for therapist time, and service provider leadership. Service providers and therapists reported that the intervention: Helped therapists find common rationale for clinical decisions Increased clarity in service delivery Improved interactions with families and schools Ratio 2.4 (95% CI 1, 5 to 3.8); Goal agreement, 3.5 (2.4 to 5.1);" Assessment of progress, 2.0 (1.1 to 3.5). Children's LoT decreased by two months [95% CI ?8 to +4 ?months] across services.Costs per trained therapist ranged from Â¡Âª1,003 to Â£1,277, depending on service size and therapist salary range.Conclusions Good goals are a promising quality improvement measure that can be implemented and adopted in practice and Further research is needed to assess: (i) impact on patient outcomes, efficacy, cost-effectiveness, and (ii) transferability to other clinical contexts.

title: Using standardized patients to measure physician professional performance
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To determine the types of inaccuracies likely to arise when standardized patients (SPs) are used to measure physician behavior and to assess the potential impact of these inaccuracies on estimates of physician performance. DESIGN: Secondary analysis from a randomized controlled trial. SETTING: General practitioner offices. STUDY PARTICIPANTS: Eighteen subjects, each presenting one of two patient scenarios, made a total of 179 visits to 92 general practitioners participating in a separate randomized controlled trial to assess the impact of an educational workshop on implementation of prevention guidelines. MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Accuracy of the SPs' presentation of the assigned scenarios and accuracy of their coding of physician performance, determined based on audiotapes of the visits and correlated with indicators of the physicians' preventive practices. RESULTS: The accuracy of patient scenario presentation was 84.8% for the male SPs and 93.5% for the female SPs. Inaccuracies in the presentation had no influence on the doctors' performance values. The accuracy of coding the medical service was 90.5% for the female SPs (kappa = 0.66) and 90.1% for the male SPs (kappa = 0.68). Coding errors occurred most frequently in the assessment of alcohol consumption and smoking recommendation. CONCLUSION: SPs can provide valid information about physicians' professional performance. However, standardization of their activities should not be taken for granted. It may be more difficult to obtain standardized coding for counseling activities, an aspect of physician visits for which SPs are particularly well suited.

title: Using the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF) to understand adherence to multiple evidence-based indicators in primary care: a qualitative study
abstract: Background There are recognized gaps between evidence and practice in general practice, an environment that poses particular implementation challenges. We previously reviewed clinical guideline recommendations to derive a set of high-impact indicators based on criteria including potential for significant patient benefit, scope for improved practice, and measurability using routinely collected data. Here we examine the perceived determinants of adherence to these indicators, as perceived by health professionals, and examine the extent to which the determinants were indicator-specific or potentially generalisable across indicators. Methods We surveyed 60 general practitioners, practice nurses and practice managers in West Yorkshire, UK, on their compliance with four indicators: avoidance of risky prescriptions; Treatment goals in type 2 diabetes; Blood Pressure Goals in Treated Hypertension;' and Anticoagulation in Atrial Fibrillation. The interview questions were based on the Theoretical Domains Framework (TDF). The data were analyzed by frame analysis. Findings Professional role and identity as well as environmental context and resources featured prominently in all indicators, while the importance of other areas, e.g. B. beliefs about consequences, social influences and knowledge, varied for all indicators. We have identified five meta-themes that represent broader organizational and contextual factors common to all indicators. Conclusions The TDF has helped identify a variety of reported determinants of adherence to high-impact indicators in primary care. It was more difficult to determine which determinants, when targeted by an implementation strategy, would maximize change. Overall, the meta-themes underscore the need to align the design of interventions targeting general practices with higher-level support and broader contextual considerations. However, our results suggest that it is possible to design interventions to encourage uptake of different evidence-based indicators that share common characteristics while incorporating content-specific adjustments.

title: Leveraging the Turning Research Into Practice (TRIP) Database: How Are Clinicians Really Searching?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Clinicians and patients are increasingly accessing information through Internet searches. This study aimed to examine the current search behavior of clinicians when using the Turning Research Into Practice (TRIP) database to examine search engine usage and opportunities for improvement. METHODS: A weblog analysis of the TRIP database, a meta-search engine covering 150 healthcare resources including MEDLINE, The Cochrane Library, and a variety of guidelines, was performed. The connectors for search terms were examined and the search behavior of 9 users when working with the TRIP database was observed. RESULTS: Of 620,735 searches, most used a single term and 12% (n=75,947) used a Boolean operator: 11% (n=69,006) used "AND" and 0.8% (n=4,941) used "OR". Of the elements of a well-structured clinical question (population, intervention, comparator, and outcome), the population was used most frequently, while fewer searches included the intervention. Comparator and result were rarely used. Participants in the observational study were interested in how to formulate better searches. CONCLUSIONS: Web log analysis showed that most searches used a single term and no Boolean operators. Observational study found that users were interested in conducting efficient searches but didn't always know how. Therefore, either better training or better search interfaces are needed to support users and enable more effective searches.

title: Using theory to improve back pain management in primary care for Australian Aboriginal people: a single-cohort, mixed-methods pilot study
abstract: BACKGROUND: The management of low back pain (LBP) is often at odds with research. This pilot study evaluated changes in LBP care following a systematic, theory-based intervention in a rural Australian Aboriginal health service. Our goal was to improve three aspects of care: reduce inappropriate referrals for radiological imaging of LBP, improve psychosocially oriented patient assessment, and improve the provision of information on self-management of LBP to patients Systematic Implementation Approach: A Mixed-Methods Pre -/Post-cohort design assessed the changes in the three behaviors using a clinical audit of LBP care over a six-month period before the intervention and then after implementation. In-depth interviews elicited the perspectives of the primary care physicians involved. RESULTS: The proportion of patients receiving guideline-inconsistent imaging referral (GICI) improved from 4.1 GICI per 10 patients to 0.4 (95% CI for rate decrease: 1.6 to 5.6). ) among the general practitioners involved in the intervention ), the GICI rate increased from 1.5 to 4.4 GICI per 10 patients (95% CI for rate increase: 0.5 to 5.3). There was a slight increase in the number of patients receiving LBP self-management information from participating GPs and no significant changes in participants' psychosocially oriented patient assessments, however, GPs qualitatively reported that their behavior had changed Consequence knowledge and beliefs were important behavioral domains related to changes in environmental and resource factors, including on-site staff protocols and clinical tools embedded in patient management software, were identified as future strategies. CONCLUSIONS: A systematic intervention model resulted in partial improvements in LBP care, better knowledge of clinical guidelines, education from someone considered a trusted source of information, and awareness of the negative consequences of inappropriate practices, particularly the radiologist ic imaging, on patient outcomes problem that has emerged and will pose a significant future challenge. The systematic approach used is applicable to other services interested in improving LBP care.

title: Use of wearable devices and smartphones to track physical activity: initial activation, sustained use, and step counts across sociodemographic characteristics in a national sample
abstract: Background: Interest in using wearable devices and smartphones to monitor daily health behaviors, such as B. physical activity, is increasing (1, 2). Many large employers use these technologies in workplace wellness programs (3). The Precision Medicine Initiative has described how the data collected by these technologies can be used for more targeted interventions. However, the characteristics of people using these devices are poorly understood. Objective: To describe the rates of initial activity tracker use, sustained use at 6 months, and step count by various sociodemographic characteristics from a wellness program offered in the United States. METHODS AND RESULTS: Data on activity tracker use, average daily step count, and sociodemographic characteristics between 2014 and 2015 was collected by Humana from policyholders with access to HumanaVitality (now Go365), a wellness program offered in the United States. Median household income from US Census data was associated with the zip code. The data was received de-identified and deemed exempt from review by the University of Pennsylvania Institutional Review Board.

title: Validation of the SF-36 health survey questionnaire: new outcome measurement for primary care
abstract: OBJECTIVES To test the acceptability, validity and reliability of the Short Form 36 Health Questionnaire (SF-36) and compare it to the Nottingham Health Profile. DESIGN Postal survey using a booklet of questionnaires together with a doctor's letter. Non-responders received two reminders two weeks apart. The SF-36 questionnaire was retested on a subsample of respondents two weeks after it was first sent. RECRUITMENT Two GP surgeries in Sheffield. PATIENTS 1980 patients aged 16-74 years randomly selected from the two practice lists. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES Scores for each health dimension on the SF-36 questionnaire and the Nottingham Health Profile. Answers to questions about recent use of health services and socio-demographic characteristics. RESULTS The response rate for the SF-36 questionnaire was high (83%) and the completion rate for each dimension was over 95%. Considerable evidence was found for the reliability of the SF-36 (Cronbach's alpha greater than 0.85, reliability coefficient greater than 0.75 for all dimensions except social functioning) and for construct validity in discriminating between groups with expected health differences. The SF-36 was able to detect poor health in patients who scored a score of 0 (good health) on the Nottingham health profile. CONCLUSIONS The SF-36 is a promising new tool to measure the perception of health in the general population. It is easy to use, accepted by patients and meets strict criteria for reliability and validity. Their use in other contexts and in different disease groups requires further research.

title: Variations in primary care physicians' decisions to screen suspected lung cancer: a factorial experiment using multimedia vignettes
abstract: Introduction Lung cancer survival rates in the UK are low and comparatively poor. Patients with symptoms suggestive of lung cancer often consult the general practitioner's office, but it's unclear how general practitioners (GPs) distinguish which patients need further evaluation. This study examined how patients' clinical and sociodemographic characteristics influence primary care physicians' decisions to initiate lung cancer screening. Methods A factorial experiment was conducted among a national sample of 227 English GPs using vignettes presented as simulated consultations. A multimedia interactive website simulated key features of consultations with actors ("patients"). GP participants made online treatment decisions for six "patients" whose sociodemographic characteristics varied systematically across three cancer risk levels. For low-risk vignettes, an investigation (ie, ordered chest x-ray, computed tomography, or referral from a respiratory specialist) was not indicated; for medium risk vignettes an investigation might be appropriate; in the case of vignettes with a high risk, an investigation was definitely indicated. Each "patient" had two lung cancer-related symptoms: one voluntarily and another when GPs asked for it. Variations in the probability of examination were examined using multi-level logistic regression. Results The general practitioners decided lung cancer in 74% (1000/1348) from vignettes. The probability of examination did not increase with the risk of cancer. Investigations were more likely when primary care physicians requested information about symptoms that "patients" had but did not agree to (adjusted OR (AOR) = 3.18; 95% CI 2.27 to 4.70 In 42% (570/ However, GPs failed to collect this information in 1348) of the cases.GPs were less likely to study older than younger "patients" (AOR = 0.52; 95% CI 0.39 to 0.7) and black "patients." ' than white (AOR=0.6 ± 8; 95% CI 0.48 to 0.95). Conclusions GPs were no more likely to screen 'patients' with high-risk than low-risk cancer symptoms, nor did they screen everyone the same symptoms alike Inadequate data collection could account for missed opportunities in diagnosis.

title: Risk of venous thromboembolism and prophylaxis in acute hospital care (ENDORSE study): a multinational cross-sectional study
abstract: Background Information on differences in venous thromboembolism (VTE) risk and prophylactic practices across the world is scarce. The ENDORSE study (Epidemiological International Day for the Evaluation of Patients at Risk for Venous Thromboembolism in the Acute Hospital Care Setting) is a multinational cross-sectional survey designed to assess the prevalence of VTE risk in the acute hospital care setting and to determine the proportion of patients at risk who have a receive effective prophylaxis.";" Background Information on differences in venous thromboembolism (VTE) risk and prophylactic practices across the world is scarce. The ENDORSE study (Epidemiological International Day for the Evaluation of Patients at Risk for Venous Thromboembolism in the Acute Hospital Care Setting) is a multinational cross-sectional survey designed to assess the prevalence of VTE risk in the acute hospital care setting and to determine the proportion of patients at risk who have a receive effective prophylaxis.

title: Violence and Aggression: Short-Term Management in Mental Health, Healthcare, and Community Settings: Updated Edition.
abstract: Â This guideline was developed to provide advice on short-term management of violence and aggression in mental health, healthcare and community settings for adults, children (up to age 12), and adolescents (ages 13 to 17). This guideline updates Violence: the Short-term Management of Disturbed/Violent Behavior in In-Patient Psychiatric Settings and Emergency Departments (NICE Clinical Guideline 25), developed by the National Collaborating Center for Nursing and Supportive Care and published in 2005 since publication Since the 2005 guideline, there have been some important advances in our knowledge of how to cope with violence and aggression, including service users' views on the use of physical intervention and seclusion, and the effectiveness, acceptability, and safety of medications and their doses for rapid calming. The previous guideline was limited to persons 16 years and older in adult psychiatric facilities and emergency departments";" This update adds some of the previously excluded populations and settings. All areas of the NICE clinical guideline 25 have been updated and this guideline will replace them entirely. The guideline recommendations were developed by a multidisciplinary team of healthcare professionals, people with mental health problems who have had personal experience of dealing with violent or aggressive behavior, their carers, and guideline methodologists after careful review of the best available evidence. The guideline is intended to be useful to clinicians and service providers in providing and planning quality care for dealing with violence and aggression, while emphasizing the importance of the experience of caring for these service users and the experience of their carers (see Appendix 1 for more details on the scope of the directive). Although the evidence base is growing rapidly, there are a number of major gaps. The guideline includes a number of research recommendations specifically designed to fill gaps in the evidence base. In the meantime, it is hoped that the guideline will help clinicians, service users and caregivers by identifying the merits of particular treatment approaches when evidence from research and clinical experience is available.

title: Violence in the GP Practice: A Survey of GP Views
abstract: OBJECTIVE To assess the extent of abuse and violence against GPs in the course of their work and to categorize the characteristics of such aggression. DESIGN Retrospective survey of the views of a large sample of general practitioners using a piloted postal questionnaire. RECRUITMENT All medical practices in the West Midlands. PARTICIPANTS A total of 1093 general practitioners (40.6% of the total sample) who answered the questionnaire. KEY OUTCOME MEASUREMENT Number of incidents of aggression experienced by primary care physicians over a 12-month period and the presence of various precipitating factors. RESULTS Although the response was low at 40.6%, this study is the largest published database on GP aggression. Overall, 687 (62.9%) of respondents had experienced abuse or violence in the previous 12 months, and 191 (17.5%) had experienced some type of abuse at least once a month, and 11 (1%) had verbal abuse every month Abuse experienced day. Even assuming that all non-responders have not experienced violence, 25.5% of GPs in the West Midlands are affected by patient aggression. Among the physicians who had experienced patient aggression, the annual incidence of one event per primary care physician was 2.42. Overall, 96 (14%) of these GPs felt that aggression was increasing. A total of 1520 (91.3%) of all incidents involved verbal abuse or threats without direct physical action. Surgery was the most common site of aggression, with 942 (56.6%) incidents";" However, 90 (62.5%) of the incidents involving physical harm or assault occurred during home calls, and 22 (66%) of the injuries occurred during late-night calls. Relatives were the aggressors in 668 (37.6%) cases, fear was a trigger in 435 (25.7%) cases, and long waiting in 183 (10.8%) cases. CONCLUSIONS Violence against GPs is widespread and may be increasing. Some of the triggers of aggression may be preventable, and practices should make vigorous attempts to identify and address such factors. Staff training in interpersonal skills and recognizing anxious or intoxicated patients is essential and should be complemented by consideration of surgical layout and repair. Physicians should avoid delays for patients by changing booking policies or surgery times and durations. Victims of aggression must be followed up. A prospective study or a centralized record of incidents should be funded.

title: 'We can only do what we have available from the perspective of 'GPs' for the primary care of older people with complex health problems
abstract: BACKGROUND: Due to demographic change, general practitioners (family doctors) are increasingly required to care for older people with complex health problems. Little is known about the subjective assessments of general practitioners regarding the required changes. Our goal is to examine how primary care physicians view their professional responsibilities and capacities to provide comprehensive care to older people with complex health problems. Does geriatric education or experience influence perspectives? Are there barriers to implementing changes in primary care for older people with complex health problems? Methods: This qualitative study preceded a controlled intervention study on case management of elderly patients in general practice (OMAHA II) and included 10 general practitioners with different geriatric qualifications. Semi-structured interviews were conducted and tape-recorded. Full interview transcripts were analyzed starting with case-based open coding and case descriptions. The resulting thematic structure was enriched with comparative dimensions through repeated case comparisons and developed into a multidimensional view typology. RESULTS: Based on the issues arising from the data and their presentation by the general practitioners surveyed, we were able to identify three different perspectives on the primary care of older people with complex health problems: "maneuvering at the limits of competence", "Herculean task" and "cooperation and networking". The perspectives differ in terms of role perception, perception of one's own professional domain and patterns of action in relation to cooperation. One guy shows a strong correspondence with a geriatrician. Across all groups there is a shared interest in the availability of sufficient resources to meet the challenges of primary care for older people with complex health conditions. CONCLUSIONS: Limited financial resources, lack of collaborative networks and attitudes appear to be barriers to ensuring better primary care for older people with complex health problems. To overcome these barriers, geriatric education should have a positive impact, but needs to be complemented by reimbursement regulations. Most importantly, GP care for older people with complex health problems needs a conceptual framework that provides guidance on their specific role and contribution, as well as supportive networks. For example, it is important that general treatment guidelines become more explicit about how to deal with older people with complex health problems.

title: Web-based computer tailoring for practice nurses to improve adherence to smoking cessation guidelines: A study protocol for a randomized controlled efficacy trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Dutch practice nurses have suboptimal adherence to evidence-based smoking cessation guidelines. Web-based computer tailoring could be effective in improving their compliance. Therefore, this paper aims to describe the development of a web-based computer-tailored program and the design of a randomized controlled trial testing its (cost-)effectiveness. METHODS: Theoretically grounded in the I-Change model and self-determination theory, and based on the results of a qualitative needs assessment among practicing nurses, a web-based, computer-based program was developed, comprising three modules of tailored counseling and an online forum, modules of up-to-date information on smoking cessation, Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) and project information as well as a counseling checklist. The impact of the program is assessed by comparing an intervention group (access to all modules) with a control group (access only to FAQs, project information and counseling checklist). Adherence to smoking cessation guidelines and behavioral predictors (ie, intention, knowledge, attitude, self-efficacy, social influence, action and coping planning) will be measured at baseline and at 6 and 12 months follow-up. In addition, the indirect effects of the program on smoking cessation rates and the number of smoking cessation attempts are assessed at 6 and 12 months. DISCUSSION: This paper describes the development of a web-based, computer-based adherence support program for practicing nurses and the study design of a randomized controlled trial testing its (cost) effectiveness. This program may contribute to improving the quality of smoking cessation treatment in Dutch general practices. If proven effective, the program could be adapted for use by other health professionals, thereby increasing public health benefits through improved cessation counseling for smokers.

title: Web-based interventions for ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease: systematic review and future directions
abstract: Behavioral Intervention Technologies (BITs), the application of psychological and behavioral interventions through the use of technology, offer physicians the opportunity to deliver care in a way that overcomes a number of treatment barriers. Web-based interventions are a subset of BITs that are emerging as promising alternatives for in-person treatment and monitoring of patients with ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease (CD). A systematic literature review led to five empirical studies on web-based interventions for UC and MC. In addition, an informal search of a popular search engine revealed limited currently available web-based interventions for patients with UC and CD. Although they represent an ideal population for the development and dissemination of online interventions, patients with UC and CD have far fewer treatment options compared to other behavioral health problems. With the growing body of research into web-based interventions for other conditions, researchers and clinicians involved in the management and treatment of ulcerative colitis and CD have the advantage of being able to leverage the BIT model, an existing conceptual framework for development web-based interventions for both diseases. The BIT model is presented and applied to the treatment of UC and CD, as well as a technology development program, Purple, and usability guidelines to guide clinical researchers in the future development, evaluation, and dissemination of BITs for patients with UC and CD.

title: Weekly email reminders influence emergency physician behavior: a case study using pneumonia guidelines from the Joint Commission and the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Improving physician compliance with evidence-based guidelines is a challenge. The authors wanted to determine whether weekly email reminders to emergency department (ED) staff increase compliance with the Joint Commission and Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) quality standards for community-acquired pneumonia. METHODS: A nurse reviewed weekly the records of all adult patients admitted to the hospital from the emergency department with a working diagnosis of pneumonia. An email was then sent to all emergency department staff detailing the percentage of patients whose antibiotic timing was less than 4 hours after arrival. The names of people who administered antibiotics in less than 1 hour were highlighted. This study compared time to antibiotics for 11 months before and 11 months after the start of this intervention. RESULTS: There were 281 patients in the control cohort and 37 met the exclusion criteria, leaving 244 for analysis. There were 342 patients in the intervention cohort and 40 met the exclusion criteria, leaving 302 for analysis. The median time from arrival to ordering the chest X-ray decreased significantly from 61 to 47 minutes (p<0.001). The median time interval from the request for a chest X-ray to the administration of antibiotics did not change significantly (92 to 88 minutes, p = 0.294). The median total time from arrival to antibiotic administration decreased significantly from 162 to 146 minutes (p=0.018). The proportion of patients receiving antibiotics within 4 hours increased from 77.5% to 86.1% (p = 0.009). CONCLUSIONS: Weekly email reminders detailing performance on antibiotic administration recommendations are associated with increased adherence to a clinical guideline.

title: Weight Care Project: Attitudes and Ability of Health Professionals to Assess Body Weight Status - Study Protocol
abstract: BACKGROUND: Health professionals working in primary care and public health have the opportunity to address issues with their patients' body weight status through face-to-face contact. The objectives of this all-Ireland project are: 1. to assess the attitudes, current practices/behaviours and knowledge of key health professionals on body weight status; 2. Assess the ability of health professionals to identify body weight status in both adults and children. The occupational groups of the health professions are: (a) Community Public Health Nurse, (b) School Public Health Nurse, (c) General Practitioner and Nurse in Practice (Primary Care);” and (d) Company Nurse (Workplace) both from Northern Ireland as well as from the Republic of Ireland. METHODS/DESIGN: This all-Ireland, multidisciplinary project follows a mixed methods approach using both quantitative and qualitative methods and consists of four components:1. Literature review – to examine the role of health professionals in treating obesity through spontaneous intervention in a variety of health promotion settings.2. Telephone interviews and focus groups – to gain an in-depth insight into the views of healthcare professionals when assessing body weight status.3. Survey (mainly online, but also paper-based) - to identify the attitudes, current practices/behaviors and knowledge of healthcare professionals in assessing body weight status.4. Online Evaluation Study - An online interactive program is being developed to assess the ability of healthcare professionals to assess adult and child body weight status. DISCUSSION: This project will assess and report the attitudes, current practices/behaviors and knowledge of key health professionals in Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland on body weight status and their ability to assess body weight status in both adults and children. The results of this project will produce recommendations for clinical practice in the management of obesity that can serve as a basis for policy guidance.

title: Weight maintenance: challenges, tools, and strategies for primary care physicians
abstract: Obesity is recognized as a chronic disease and one of the greatest public health challenges we face today. Weight loss can be achieved through lifestyle, pharmacological and surgical interventions, but weight maintenance remains a lifelong challenge for people with obesity. Obesity management guidelines have emphasized the role of primary care providers (PCPs). This review examines the long-term results of clinical trials to identify effective weight maintenance strategies that PCPs can utilize. Due to the breadth of the topic, a structured PubMed search was conducted to identify relevant research articles, peer reviews, guidelines, and articles published by regulators. Studies have shown the benefit of sustained weight loss in treating obesity and its comorbidities. Weight loss of 5-10% for >/= 1 year is known to alleviate many comorbidities. Maintaining weight with lifestyle changes—although difficult—is possible, but requires long-term support to increase diet, physical activity, and behavior changes. Complementing lifestyle intervention with pharmacotherapy promotes greater and more sustained weight loss. Clinical evidence and recently approved pharmacotherapies have given primary care physicians improved strategies to help their patients maintain weight loss. Further studies are needed to assess the translation of these strategies into clinical practice.

title: Weighty matters - an approach to obesity in children in general medicine
abstract: BACKGROUND: In Australia, childhood obesity now rivals asthma as the most common chronic health problem in children. The last 2 decades have shown a rapidly increasing prevalence of overweight and obesity in children with no signs of a plateau. Primary care is increasingly recognized as a forum in which to address this growing public health problem. AIM: This article discusses the epidemiology of childhood overweight and obesity in Australia and the associated physical and psychosocial morbidities. It discusses the current evidence base and resources for defining, investigating, and treating childhood obesity and outlines an approach in primary care. It also reports on a recently developed general practitioner who has implemented an intervention to reduce obesity in elementary school children - the Live, Eat and Play (LEAP) project. DISCUSSION: There are now clear clinical guidelines for the assessment and management of childhood overweight and obesity in primary care. The feasibility of these policies and the availability of the resources needed to implement them are not yet clear. The LEAP project proposes an effective intervention, carried out by general practitioners, to address this important and complex issue.

title: Well Balanced: 8 Steps to Wellness for Adults with Mental Illness and Diabetes
abstract: Serious mental illness places an enormous burden on patients, their families, and behavioral and healthcare providers. The coexistence of diabetes and mental illness can further impair day-to-day functioning. Psychiatric nurses can make a significant contribution to improving the health and medical outcomes of this patient population. A partnership was developed between the University of Rochester School of Nursing and the Western New York Care Coordination Program to evaluate a novel model of care for adults with severe mental illness and diabetes mellitus.
