The Well Balanced program included health promotion, disease management, care management and evidence-based practice guidelines in 8 Steps to Wellness for a Community-Based Mental Health Population. During a 16-visit intervention phase, psychiatric nurses interacted with 74 clients. As a result of the program, clients experienced improvements in health risk status and their hemoglobin A1C score, and reported high levels of satisfaction with the Well Balanced program.

title: WellDoc's Mobile Diabetes Management Randomized Controlled Trial: Changing Clinical and Behavioral Outcomes, and Patient and Physician Satisfaction
abstract: BACKGROUND: Less than 63% of people with diabetes meet professional guideline goals of hemoglobin A1c <7.0%, and only 7% meet combined blood glucose, lipid, and blood pressure goals. The primary objective of the study was to evaluate the impact on A1c of a mobile phone-based diabetes management software system used with web-based data analysis and therapy optimization tools. Secondary objectives assessed compliance by healthcare providers (HCP) with prescribing guidelines and assessed HCP acceptance of the technology. METHODS: Thirty patients with type 2 diabetes were recruited from three physicians' offices for a 3-month study and randomized evenly. The intervention group received cell phone-based software developed by endocrinologists and CDEs (WellDoc Communications, Inc., Baltimore, MD). The software provided real-time feedback on patients' blood glucose levels, displayed patients' medication schedules, built-in algorithms to manage hypo- and hyperglycemia, and requested additional data needed to assess diabetes management. The patient data collected and transmitted to secure servers were analyzed by proprietary statistical algorithms. The system sent computer-generated logbooks (with suggested treatment plans) to the HCPs of the intervention patients. RESULTS: The mean decrease in A1c in intervention patients was 2.03% compared to 0.68% (p<0.02, one-sided) in control patients. Eighty-four percent of intervention patients had medication titrated or changed by their HCP compared to controls (23%, P=0.002). HCPs of intervention patients reported that the system facilitated treatment decisions, provided organized data, and reduced logbook review time. CONCLUSIONS: Adults with type 2 diabetes achieved statistically significant improvements in A1c using WellDoc's software. HCP and patient satisfaction with the system were clinically and statistically significant.

title: How do mental health professionals feel about guideline recommendations for treating depression in young people?
abstract: OBJECTIVES: We sought to investigate potential barriers to the use of evidence-based guidelines for adolescent depression in a tertiary mental health specialty service as part of an initiative to implement evidence-based practices within the service. METHODS: This was a qualitative study that took a social constructivist perspective using focus groups. The focus groups conducted with all clinicians (physicians and health professionals) were audiotaped, transcribed and thematically analyzed. Clinicians were asked about the barriers to implementing four key recommendations of the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) guidelines. RESULTS: Barriers existed at (i) the "individual clinician" level; (ii) the clinical level related to young people's presentation;" and (iii) the level of service. The main barrier at the individual clinician level was the stated belief that the guidelines were not relevant to the young people presenting to the service and that there was little evidence of practice. The main obstacle related to clinical presentation was the severity and complexity of this presentation, which often made interventions such as cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) difficult to deliver. At the service level, sequencing of interventions according to guideline recommendations has been difficult due to a lack of integration with primary and secondary care. CONCLUSIONS: There is a clear need to develop the evidence base to ensure that effective treatments for young people aged up to 25 years with severe and complex disorders that include co-morbid conditions, suicidal risk and psychosocial difficulties are studied and disseminated. In addition, this work has highlighted the need for greater investment in models of care that ensure integration between existing primary and secondary care and improved specialized psychiatric early intervention services for young people.

title: What do GPs think and do about prostate cancer screening in Australia?
abstract: BACKGROUND: Men seek advice from their general practitioner (GP) on the benefits of screening for prostate cancer. The aim of this study was to examine how general practitioners' knowledge and clinical experience influenced their position on prostate cancer screening. Methods: A total of 13 focus groups with 77 general practitioners were set up. The focus group discussions were tape-recorded and transcribed verbatim. Transcripts were analyzed by thematic analysis by two investigators. RESULTS: Primary care physicians were evenly split between those who proactively screen men for prostate cancer and those who do so only at the patient's request. Primary care physicians had limited knowledge of recently published evidence from prostate cancer screening studies. DISCUSSION: In order to promote evidence-based decision-making by primary care physicians and their patients, effective methods to increase primary care physicians' knowledge of evidence-based recommendations and potential changes in clinical behavior are needed.

title: What do patients and relatives know about problems and failures in care?
abstract: Objective Understand what patients and families know about problems and failures in healthcare. Design Qualitative, semi-structured, open-ended interviews were conducted with 39 patients and 80 family members about their experiences of tertiary care incidents. Nineteen interviews involved more than one respondent, making a total of 100 interviews. Participants were recruited through advertisements in the national broadsheet and tabloid print media (43%), through the health services where the incidents occurred (28%), through invitations from two internet marketing companies (27%) and through Consumer recruiting organizations (2%). Setting interviews were conducted at respondents' homes or by telephone. One participant emailed her responses to the questionnaire. Findings Analysis of the interview data revealed: (1) significant patient and family knowledge of health care risks, issues, and incidents; (2) respondents' insight into opportunities to improve care;' and (3) challenges patients and families face when attempting to negotiate their knowledge and insights with healthcare professionals. Conclusion Patients (and family members) need access to structured processes that ensure dialogue with healthcare professionals about perceived risks, problems and incidents. Such a dialogue would reveal patients' and family members' questions and knowledge about improvement opportunities and minimize the risk that their questions and knowledge are ignored.

title: What do people with mental illness need to quit smoking? Consumer and provider perspectives on mental health
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Forty-one percent (41%) of people in the US who reported having a recent history of mental illness also smoke cigarettes. Tobacco use in this population is associated with up to 25 fewer years of life and excessive medical comorbidity compared to the general population. While research shows that tobacco interventions can be effective for people with mental illness, they are not commonly used in clinical practice. The current study examined how evidence-based tobacco cessation interventions can be adapted to address the unique physiological, psychological, and social challenges faced by people with mental illness. METHODS: Ten focus groups were conducted using a semi-structured discussion";" 5 for adult mental health users (n=62); and 5 with psychiatrists and administrators (n=22). Content analysis was used to organize topics into categories. RESULTS: Five thematic categories were identified: (1) treatment barriers, (2) resources and infrastructure, (3) negative influences on smoking behavior, (4) knowledge deficits, and (5) treatment needs. CONCLUSIONS: These results are instructive for the development of appropriate tobacco cessation services for this population. Specifically, these data were incorporated into a toolkit for mental health providers on smoking cessation and fed into the development of a tobacco cessation intervention study.

title: What I would say to the Royal Commission. Our neglected wastelands
Which implementation measures increase cancer screening rates? a systematic review
abstract: Background Adequate screening can reduce mortality and morbidity from colorectal, breast and cervical cancer. However, effective implementation strategies are warranted if the full benefits of screening are to be realized. As part of a larger agenda to create implementation guideline, we conducted a systematic review to evaluate interventions aimed at increasing screening rates for breast, cervical, and colorectal cancer (CRC). The interventions considered were: customer reminders, customer incentives, mass media, small media, group instruction, one-to-one instruction, breaking down structural barriers, reducing own costs, provider evaluation and feedback interventions, and provider incentives. Our primary outcome, completion of screening, was calculated as the overall median absolute percentage point change (PP) post-intervention in completed screening tests. Methods Our first step was to conduct an iterative scoping review in the research area. This resulted in three relevant systematic reviews of high quality. As our evidentiary basis, we have performed a formal update. Randomized controlled trials and cluster randomized controlled trials published between 2004 and 2010 were searched in MEDLINE, EMBASE and PSYCHinfo. Results The update identified 66 new eligible studies with 74 comparisons. The quality of the new studies varied greatly. Customer reminders, small media, and provider audits and feedback appear to be effective interventions to increase screening uptake for three cancer types. Individual training and breaking down structural barriers also appear to be effective, but their role in CRC and cervical screening, respectively, is less established. Further studies are needed to evaluate customer incentives, mass media, grouping, captive cost reduction, and provider incentive interventions. Conclusion The new evidence is generally consistent with the evidence and conclusions from the original systematic reviews. This review served as the evidentiary basis for an implementation guideline. Poor reporting, lack of precision and consistency in defining farm elements, and insufficient consideration of context and differences between population groups are areas for additional research.

title: What role does the general practitioner play in relation to the caring relatives of a relative living with dementia? A systematic literature search
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To identify the attitudes and perspectives of primary care physicians towards carers of family members with dementia and to describe carer satisfaction. DESIGN: Systematic review. TOPICS: The population studied consisted of families with dementia and their general practitioners. KEY OUTCOME MEASURES: Outcome measures were the primary care physician's overall role and ability to improve home care from the perspective of family caregivers. Caregivers were rated on their satisfaction with the care they received from their primary care physician. RESULTS: The primary care physician is aware of his or her capabilities and limitations in all aspects of dementia care and their role towards family caregivers. They also recognized the importance of an appropriate diagnostic procedure, but felt uncomfortable disclosing the diagnosis to both the patient and the caregiver. They reported having more confidence in treatment issues than in diagnostic phases. The reports of the carers about the attitude of their general practitioner in the diagnostic process were rated from helpful to not very empathetic. GPs found that they were highly involved in dementia home care, but nurses rated their involvement as insufficient. The GPs' lack of adequate communication skills was not appreciated by the nurses either. Lack of time and remuneration were seen by the general practitioner as a major obstacle in dementia care. CONCLUSION: The key role of GPs as service providers and care planners is reinforced by the caregivers' confidence in their abilities. Clear guidelines from early diagnosis to appropriate referrals should enhance the primary care physician's ability to support these time and energy consuming home care situations. Intervention studies addressing the gaps in primary care physicians' skills in managing dementia in the home could be helpful in supporting family caregivers.

title: What is the value of routinely using patient-reported outcome measures to improve patient outcomes, nursing processes, and healthcare outcomes in cancer care? A systematic review of controlled trials
abstract: PURPOSE: The systematic use of patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) has been advocated as an effective method for standardizing cancer practice. Nevertheless, the question of whether PROMs can actually lead to an improvement in the quality of patient care remains controversial. This review examined whether the incorporation of PROM into routine clinical practice is associated with improvements in patient outcomes, care processes, and public health outcomes during active cancer treatment. METHODS: A systematic review of five electronic databases (Medline, EMBASE, CINAHL [Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature], PsycINFO, and Psychology and Behavioral Sciences Collection [PBSC]) was conducted from database inception to May 2012 to randomize and non-randomized controlled trials in patients receiving active anti-cancer treatment or supportive care, regardless of cancer type. RESULTS: Based on predefined eligibility criteria, we included 26 articles reporting 24 unique controlled trials. A great deal of variability was evident in the design and use of the interventions delivered, the outcomes assessed, and the cancer and modality-specific context. Health services were rarely included as endpoints. Overall, the number of statistically significant findings was limited and the intervention effect sizes of the PROMs were mostly small to moderate. CONCLUSION: The routine use of PROMs increases the frequency of discussion of patient outcomes during consultations. In some studies, PROMs are associated with improved symptom control, increased supportive care, and patient satisfaction. Additional efforts are needed to ensure patient compliance, as well as additional support for physicians responding to patients' concerns and issues, with clear system policies in place to guide their responses. Further research is needed to support the cost-effectiveness of PROM in terms of patient safety, clinical burden, and health care utilization.

title: What should we teach students?
abstract: The opinions of 600 randomly selected physicians on what students should be taught in clinical years were analyzed. General medicine, paediatrics, general surgery, accident surgery and gynecology were given high priority by those surveyed, but forensic medicine, plastic surgery, radiation therapy, anaesthesia, radiology and rehabilitation medicine were given low priority. Doctors thought these should be taught to postgraduates. The two large groups of doctors - general practitioners and specialists - gave essentially the same priorities. Undergraduate curricula cannot cover all major disciplines, so the results of this analysis can provide a useful basis for selecting the most appropriate subjects. Criteria for the inclusion of further disciplines can be the skills and enthusiasm of the teachers as well as well thought-out and academically sound teaching programmes.

title: What's in an environment?: Impact of organizational culture on provider compliance with clinical guidelines for tobacco use management
abstract: BACKGROUND: Organizational culture is an important but understudied characteristic of the work environment that can influence provider behavior, including adherence to clinical practice guidelines. There is strong evidence that medical support for smokers can lead to significant reductions in tobacco use. However, this evidence has not translated well into practice, as only a small proportion of smokers receive recommended treatment during doctor visits. PURPOSE: This study examines organizational culture as a contextual feature of primary care clinics and its impact on adherence to evidence-based tobacco treatment policies. METHODOLOGY: Cross-sectional survey data were collected from 500 primary care physicians at 60 community hospitals in New York City. The relationships between provider compliance with clinical guidelines “5A” as recommended by the US Public Health Service and both provider and organizational covariates have been described. We used hierarchical linear modeling to examine the associations between clinic culture and provider treatment patterns. RESULTS: Providers in clinics with stronger 'group/clan', 'hierarchical' and 'rational' culture types compared to a 'developmental' culture reported greater adherence to 5A guidelines (p<0.05). System-level structures and nursing processes were positively associated (p<0.01), while the number of ongoing quality initiatives was negatively associated with 5A delivery (p<0.05). Provider familiarity with the guidelines (p<0.01), trust in smoking cessation counseling (p<0.05), and perceived effectiveness in smoking cessation were associated with more frequent 5A interventions (p<0.01). IMPACT ON PRACTICE: The results suggest that organizational culture can influence provider adherence to treatment guidelines, even when controlling for other factors known to influence practice patterns. In particular, cultures that emphasize human resources and performance standards are conducive to incorporating 5A policies into routine practice. Understanding the role of organizational culture enables healthcare managers and practitioners to be strategic in implementing and also maintaining the use of evidence-based guidelines.

title: What's on YOUR Facebook profile? Evaluation of an educational effort to promote the appropriate use of privacy settings by medical students on social networking sites
abstract: BACKGROUND: The rise of social media has led to growing concern about the potential impact of "unprofessional" postings by physicians and medical students on individuals, institutions, and the medical community. Relevant and effective policies have been difficult to develop and enforce, and there is a need for students and physicians to think about how their online activities can be viewed in the context of their professional role. The purpose of this project was to study the internet presence of a Canadian medical school class by scanning students' public profiles on the social media site Facebook, integrating this information into an educational activity dealing with professionalism and social media, and to assess the impact of this activity on student behavior. METHODS: A systematic search of the public Facebook profiles of each member of the class was conducted and data was collected on the types of publicly viewable material. These were presented as part of an educational event on social media and professionalism. A month later, the Facebook search was repeated. RESULTS: Of 152 students in the class, profiles were found for 121 (79.8%). The majority of students used reasonably restrictive privacy settings";" However, a significant minority had publicly viewable information, including comments, photos, location, and medical student status. The educational innovation was well received, with more than 90% of students agreeing that the topic was important and well covered. A subsequent search revealed that many students had changed their privacy settings to make less information publicly available. CONCLUSIONS: A small but significant proportion of students share potentially unprofessional content on social media. An interactive pedagogical intervention that involved specific disclosure of how participants came across to others on social media resulted in a significant change in student behavior.

title: When is it cost-effective to change healthcare professional behavior?
abstract: Because of the way healthcare systems work, new, important and inexpensive treatments sometimes do not become routine care, while well-marketed products of ambiguous value find widespread acceptance. Should policy makers seek to influence clinical behavior and correct these inefficiencies? Implementation methods achieve some level of behavior change but cost money to implement. These factors can be combined with the cost-effectiveness of treatments to estimate the cost-effectiveness of the overall policy. In general, the cost-effectiveness of the policy is always less attractive than the cost-effectiveness of the treatment. As a result, trying to improve uptake of underused inexpensive care or reduce overuse of new and expensive treatments may not always make economic sense. In this article we present a method for calculating the cost-effectiveness of the policy and illustrate it with examples from a recent study carried out in 1997 and 1998 of community pharmacist awareness campaigns about medical prescription in England to influence.

title: When pharmacotherapeutic recommendations may result in an adverse effect on physician decision-making
abstract: The medical literature has long demonstrated that patients do not always receive adequate care, including pharmacotherapeutic treatment. To achieve improved patient care, a number of physician-focused interventions are being conducted internationally to implement evidence-based medicine into the daily routine practice of physicians. The pharmacist profession has taken an active role in providing intervention strategies aimed at promoting evidence-based prescribing and improved quality and safety of drug use. However, the medical literature also supports the notion that valid clinical treatment recommendations do not always have the desired effect on physician behavior. We argue that the well-established theory of psychological reactance may at least partially explain cases in which physicians do not follow such recommendations. Reactance theory suggests that when prompted to take a specific action, a motivational state compels us to respond in ways that affirm our agency. Often we choose to do the opposite of what the recommendation suggests, or we simply remain where we are. The basic concepts of psychological reactance are universal and likely applicable to providing recommendations to physicians. Making recommendations about clinical care, including pharmacotherapy, can carry implicit threats as it can be perceived as an attempt to limit one's freedom of choice, potentially leading to reactions and efforts to avoid them. By identifying and addressing factors likely to promote reactance, physician-focused interventions could become more effective.

title: When the branch breaks: rethinking treatment strategies for perinatal depression
abstract: Awareness of depression among ob-gyns has increased, leading to more than 13% of pregnant women in the United States being prescribed antidepressants. But the safety and effectiveness of these compounds have been exaggerated, the effectiveness of psychotherapy has been overlooked and distorted, and various medical guidelines for treating perinatal depression have been downplayed or ignored. This article addresses the common fears and misconceptions surrounding the treatment of depression during pregnancy and after childbirth. The effectiveness of strategic cognitive behavioral therapy, enhanced by hypnosis, offers excellent results without the risks associated with these drugs. Goals for targeted interventions are identified and discussed.

title: When to start dialysis: impact of proposed US guidelines on survival
abstract: Background Current guidelines from the US National Kidney Foundation's Dialysis Outcomes Quality Initiative recommend starting dialysis treatment earlier than was previously the case. Their implementation would have a significant impact on patients' daily lives and would increase costs. The guidelines are largely opinion-based, as evidence is still lacking.";" Background Current guidelines from the US National Kidney Foundation's Dialysis Outcomes Quality Initiative recommend starting dialysis treatment earlier than was previously the case. Their implementation would have a significant impact on patients' daily lives and would increase costs. The guidelines are largely opinion-based, as evidence is still lacking.

title: Where should John go? Newfoundland
Who wrote the Declaration of Helsinki?
Why aren't clinicians accepting the results from pivotal clinical trials in severe sepsis? A Bayesian analysis
abstract: BACKGROUND: Five pivotal clinical trials (intensive insulin therapy; recombinant human activated protein C [rhAPC]; low tidal volume; low dose steroid; early targeted therapy [EGDT]) have demonstrated a reduction in mortality in patients with severe sepsis and expert guidelines have them for the recommended in clinical practice, but acceptance of these therapies among clinicians remains low. Question 2: What is the current probability of increasing the relative risk of death (RRR) of my patient with severe sepsis around meaningful clinical thresholds (RRR > 15%; > 20% ; > 25%)? METHODS: Bayesian methods were applied to this study. Odds ratio (OR) was considered for question 1 and RRR was used for question 2. Effective sample sizes from other relevant clinical trials (unfavorable evidence). Posterior distributions were calculated by combining the previous distributions and the data from pivotal studies (favorable evidence). KEY FINDINGS: Answer 1 - The analysis, based on slightly skeptical antecedents, shows favorable results with the intensive insulin, rhAPC, and low tidal volume studies, but not with the low-dose steroid and EGDT studies. All study results are rendered unacceptable by the analyzes with moderate or severe skeptics. Answer 2 – If we aim for an RRR > 15%, the slightly skeptical analysis shows that the current probability of reducing death around this clinical threshold is 88% for the intensive insulin and 62-65% for the low-tidal volume, rhAPC , is , EGDT studies and 17% for the low-dose steroid study. The moderate and severe skeptical analyzes show no clinically meaningful reduction in risk of death for all studies. If we aim for an RRR > 20% or > 25%, all probabilities of benefit become smaller, regardless of the level of skepticism. CONCLUSIONS: Our clinical threshold analysis provides a new bedside tool that can be directly applied to the care of patients with severe sepsis. Our results indicate that the strength of evidence (statistical and clinical) is weak for all studies, particularly the low-dose steroid and EGDT studies. It is imperative to replicate the results of each of these five clinical trials in confirmatory studies if we are to offer patient care based on scientifically sound evidence.

title: Why do doctors treat their loved ones? Exploring the influence of social psychology
abstract: Doctors often receive requests for treatment, medical advice, or other interventions from loved ones. Most doctors do this. Reasons for compliance can be categorized according to the physician's attitude toward the family member, colleague, self, ethical guidelines, and the problem. Compliance can also be influenced by elements of social psychology. Social exchange theory, persuasion techniques, attribution, conformity, the desire for recognition, and the affinity principle can prompt interventions. Future research should examine physicians' attitudes towards family members, the medium through which inquiries are made, treatment outcomes, changes in the relationship after treatment, cultural or family norms, and changes in physicians' beliefs or behaviors that occur when they are with be confronted with conflicting requests and guidelines. Knowing these influences can help physicians make objective decisions about an intervention.

title: Why even good doctors don't wash their hands
Why no behavior change policies?
abstract: This paper provides an overview of behavioral program guidelines published by the National Association of Retarded Children. The review discusses a number of reasons why behavior modification guidelines should not be formulated, e.g. behavior modification procedures do not appear to be more or less prone to abuse and no more or less in need of ethical regulation than derived intervention procedures using a different set of principles and different terminology. The review recommends alternative methods of protecting the rights of clients participating in behavioral programs. In particular, behavioral therapists, like other therapists, should be subject to the codes of ethics of their profession";" In addition, the ethics of all intervention programs should be assessed against a number of critical points.

title: Why providers are transfusing blood products outside of recommended guidelines despite built-in electronic best practice warnings
abstract: BACKGROUND: Best practice alerts (BPAs) provide clinical decision support (CDS) at the point-of-care to reduce unnecessary transfusions of blood products despite continuing significant transfusions outside of recommended guidelines. AIM: Understand why providers order blood transfusions outside of recommended guidelines despite disruptive warnings. DESIGN: Retrospective review. SETTING: Tertiary care hospital. PARTICIPANTS: Providers of inpatient health services. INTERVENTION: Provider-BPA interaction data was collected from January 2011 to August 2012 from the hospital electronic medical record. MEASUREMENTS: Vendor (free text) responses to BPA prompts for blood transfusion were independently reviewed and categorized by 2 licensed physicians, with agreement assessed by chi(2) analysis and kappa scoring. RESULTS: Reasons for overriding blood transfusion BPA varied widely, with acute bleeding being the most common (>34%), followed by recorded behaviors at specialty services (up to 26%) through to "symptomatic" anemia (11%- 12%). . Many providers transfuse in anticipation of surgery or a procedure (10% to 15%) or impending hospital discharge (2% to 5%). Physicians in private practice represented the majority (55%) of providers who interacted with BPA. CONCLUSION: Vendors interacting with BPAs (primarily resident and mid-market vendors) often do not have the bargaining power to change ordering behavior. Recorded behaviors that are unlikely to be influenced by BPA are among the most commonly cited reasons for transfusions outside of guidelines. Symptomatic anemia is a common, albeit subjective, indication for blood transfusions. Given the multitude of individually unusual reasons for transfusion behavior, the secondary use of electronic medical record databases and integrated CDS tools is important to efficiently analyze common practice behavior.

title: Why we still do arthroscopy for knee osteoarthritis: a multi-method study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Knee arthroscopy has historically been a common treatment for knee osteoarthritis. However, several randomized controlled trials along with a Cochrane review have led to NICE recommending not using arthroscopy in the vast majority of patients with knee osteoarthritis. These recommendations have been replicated internationally. The use of arthroscopy for knee osteoarthritis has decreased";" however, it is still widely used. This study examines the factors thought to influence decision making using a theoretical framework developed for behavior change research (Theoretical Domains Framework). This study will allow future work to design and evaluate an intervention specifically targeting the identified barriers. METHODS: A multimodal approach was used, including questionnaire research and semi-structured interviews with physicians of all grades providing knee arthroscopy service at a Level 1 trauma center in the West Midlands, UK. Focus groups were also conducted with patients. A mixed methods analysis was used, with descriptive statistics for quantitative data and thematic content analysis for qualitative data. RESULTS: A total of 26 surgeons completed questionnaires, with 6 semi-structured interviews taking place. All surgical grades were represented. Two focus groups of six patients were conducted. The results identified 13 beliefs in 12 domains (some beliefs were represented in all domains). The beliefs that there was pressure from patients to do something, that there were limited other options, that surgeons wanted to meet patient expectations, and that there was time pressure in the clinic seemed to be the predominant obstacles. CONCLUSIONS: Using the Theoretical Domains Framework, this paper has described the relevant barriers and requirements for implementing the NICE guidelines regarding the use of arthroscopy in patients with knee osteoarthritis. The next step in this process is the development of a targeted intervention, and we discuss the barriers that are most likely to change practice when a targeted intervention is implemented and what such an intervention might look like. Such an intervention would require evaluation within the clinical setting.

title: Why don't women ask for preconception health information? A qualitative study
abstract: BACKGROUND: Preconceptional care includes health promotion to reduce risk factors that may affect women and couples of childbearing age. Risk factors for adverse reproductive outcomes include recognized family or individual genetic disorders, prior congenital disorders, miscarriage, premature birth, fetal growth restriction, infertility, maternal chronic disease, lifestyle, and occupational or environmental factors. Effective preconception care includes a range of preventive, therapeutic, and behavioral interventions. Although Italy has national preconceived treatment recommendations for the general population, these are usually recommended informally and only for individual risk factors. Currently, there is increasing interest in offering a global intervention in this area. The aim of this study was to examine the attitudes and behaviors of Italian women of childbearing age and healthcare professionals regarding preconception health. Methods: We conducted a qualitative study among women of childbearing potential and healthcare professionals between February 2014 and February 2015. Five focus groups were held: 2 with non-pregnant women aged 22 to 44 and 3 with healthcare professionals. Topics for discussion included women's questions about preconception health, concerns and barriers to preconception care, attitudes and behaviors of women and healthcare professionals regarding preconception health, and sources of information for women. In the analysis of the focus groups, priority was given to the women's comments, supplemented by information from the focus groups of health professionals. RESULTS: Fourteen women of reproductive age (8 null and 6 multiparous) and 12 healthcare professionals (3 nurses, 4 midwives, 5 physicians) participated in the focus groups. The results indicate the presence of many barriers and a lack of awareness of preconceived notions about health in relation to women, health professionals and policies. Women's knowledge of and attitudes to primary preconception care information are described. The main source of information in this area for Italian women seems to be their obstetrician-gynaecologist. CONCLUSIONS: The study indicates that several barriers influence preconception care in Italy. There is also evidence of a lack of awareness of preconceived notions about health and care among Italian women of childbearing age and among healthcare professionals. Findings could contribute to strategies for implementing guidelines for preconception care.

title: WIC providers' perspectives on the delivery of smoking cessation interventions
abstract: PURPOSE: To study the perspectives of WIC clinic providers to provide smoking cessation interventions for pregnant women. STUDY DESIGN AND METHODS: Four focus groups consisting of WIC nurses, nutritionists, and social workers (N = 25) were conducted in WIC clinics in eastern Iowa. Researchers developed discussion guides to determine how WIC providers are currently targeting pregnant women who smoke cigarettes and what they believe are barriers to the delivery of effective smoking cessation interventions. Code mapping was used to analyze focus group discussions. RESULTS: Factors that influenced the ability of WIC staff to provide smoking cessation interventions to pregnant women included time available, clinic priorities, staff interaction with clients, and staff training. In addition, providers raised concerns about customer educational materials and other customer issues that prevent them from quitting smoking. The lack of mechanisms to track clinical outcomes related to smoking cessation was also noted. CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS: WIC providers have time constraints that may require minimal or low-intensity smoking cessation interventions, but have been unaware that such approaches are actually effective. WIC providers need more education on the whole issue of smoking cessation to become more proactive in their attempts to help pregnant women quit. Training that improves self-efficacy and understanding of the effects of smoking on mothers, infants and children should be initiated to motivate staff to intervene. Another strategy to motivate WIC staff in this regard could be to track clinical outcomes to help women quit smoking or prevent relapse.

title: Will mothers of sick children help their husbands quit smoking after receiving brief intervention from nurses? Secondary Analysis of a Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: BACKGROUND: Passive smoking is a serious health risk for children. Clinical guidelines suggest that caregivers advise smoking parents to quit when accompanying their sick children to pediatric facilities, but the guidelines make no mention of what caregivers can do when the parents are not with the children. This study examines the effectiveness of a nurse-led, low-intensity health education initiative for non-smoking mothers to motivate them to take action to help their husbands quit smoking. METHODS: This was a randomized controlled trial and 1,483 non-smoking women living with smoking husbands were recruited as they accompanied their ill children to hospital admissions to general pediatric/outpatient departments of four Hong Kong hospitals. The women were randomized into intervention and control groups. The former received a brief health education consultation from nurses, a specially designed health education pamphlet, a "no smoking" sticker, and a week later a telephone reminder ";" the control group received usual care. The primary outcome was the women's action to help their smoking husbands quit smoking at the 3, 6, and 12 month follow-up visits. RESULTS: A higher proportion of women in the intervention group than in the control group had taken action to help their husbands stop smoking at 3 months (76% vs. 65%, P<0.001), 6 months (66% vs. 49%, P<0.001) and 12 months (52% vs. 40%, P<0.001) follow-ups. Women who received the intervention had better knowledge about the health hazards of smoking, a higher willingness to take action, and a willingness to take action true of their husbands to quit/cut down smoking had previously advised their husbands to give quit smoking were aware of their husbands' smoking history and knew that their husbands had made a previous attempt to quit smoking and intended to help them with their follow-up visits, quitting smoking can be effective in motivating the mothers of sick children to take action to help their husbands cope to quit smoking recommend adding the following to the clinical practice guidelines for treating tobacco use and addiction: “Caregivers should give any non-smoking mother of a sick child a brief piece of advice to encourage their husbands to quit smoking”. STUDY REGISTRATION: Current controlled studies ISRCTN72290421.

title: Words matter: improve the implementation of clinical guidelines.
abstract: Objectives: To determine whether writing clinical guideline recommendations in behavioral “plain English” language increases the likelihood of their implementation by service users (patients). Design: Randomized controlled trial in which participants received either the original text of the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (NICE) public guidelines for the management of schizophrenia or a behavioral text with the same content. Setting: User networks for mental health services and voluntary sector organizations in two central London boroughs. Participants: 84 mental health service users recruited by mail or face-to-face at user meetings. Intervention: The section of the NICE public guidelines for schizophrenia regarding psychological and pharmacological treatments was rewritten to improve style and behavioral specificity by applying evidence-based and psychologically sound principles of good written communication. Outcome Measures: Cognitive behavioral predictors, as specified by the evidence-based theory of planned behavior, provided the primary outcome as it was not possible to measure actual behavior of guideline implementation. The predictors were behavioral intentions to implement the guidelines, attitudes towards implementation, and perceived behavioral control over implementation. Satisfaction with the guidelines and perceived understanding were also measured. Results: Behavioral guidelines in “plain English” resulted in stronger intentions to implement the guidelines, more positive attitudes toward them, and greater perceived behavioral control over their application. There was no difference in satisfaction or perceived understanding. Conclusions: Writing policies with high behavioral specificity combined with using “plain English” can be a simple and effective way to improve their implementation. An assessment with a behavior score is now required.

title: Working to improve hospital management of hyperglycemia through statewide collaboration: the Georgia Hospital Association Diabetes Special Interest Group
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To review the efforts of the Georgia Hospital Association Diabetes Special Interest Group (DSIG) to develop and disseminate model clinical guidelines for the management of inpatient hyperglycemia. METHODS: Beginning in February 2003, a consortium of physicians and related health professionals from across the state of Georgia began meeting regularly to formulate a plan to improve the care of hospitalized patients with hyperglycemia. The immediate goals of the DSIG were to identify and organize interested stakeholders, develop common clinical guidelines, and disseminate information. RESULTS: Since its inception, the DSIG has accomplished the following: developed 7 consensus clinical guideline templates, built a website that publishes these clinical guidelines and other useful information and educational materials, and sponsored workshops throughout the state of Georgia. CONCLUSION: As the importance of glucose control in the hospital setting is increasingly recognized, institutions must find ways to apply clinical trial results to “real” hospital settings. The DSIG is an example of a successful collaboration that could serve as a model for other government hospital organizations looking to develop programs to improve inpatient care for patients with hyperglycemia.

title: The World Medical Association adopts declarations etc. on various matters
Declaration of the World Medical Association of Helsinki. Recommendations for physicians involved in biomedical research involving humans
Xenografts: Proceed with caution
Yoga for chronic low back pain: a randomized study
abstract: Background: Previous studies suggest that yoga can be an effective treatment for chronic or recurrent low back pain. Aim: To compare the effectiveness of yoga and usual treatment for chronic or recurrent low back pain. Design: Parallel-group, randomized, controlled study with computer-generated randomization conducted from April 2007 to March 2010. Results were assessed via postal questionnaire. (International Standard Randomized Controlled Trial Number Register: ISRCTN 81079604) Setting: 13 UK Non-National Health Service establishments. Patients: 313 adults with chronic or recurrent low back pain. Intervention: Yoga (n=156) or usual care (n=157). All participants received an educational brochure about back pain. The intervention group was offered a 12-hour progressive yoga program conducted by 12 teachers over 3 months. Measurements: Results of the RolandÂ¨CMorris Disability Questionnaire (RMDQ) at 3 (primary outcome), 6, and 12 (secondary outcome) months"; pain, pain self-efficacy, and general health measurements at 3, 6, and 12 months (secondary outcomes) Results: 93 ( 60%) Patients offered yoga attended at least 3 of the first 6 sessions and at least 3 additional sessions The yoga group had better back function than usual care at 3, 6, and 12 months Adjusted mean RMDQ score was higher in the yoga group Group 2.17 points (95% CI, 1.03 to 3.31 points) lower at 3 months, 1.48 points (CI, 0.33 to 2.62 points) and 1.57 lower at 6 months Scores (CI, 0.42 to 2.71 points) lower at 12 months The yoga and general care groups had similar scores for back pain and general health at 3, 6, and 12 months, and the yoga group had at 3 and 6 months higher pain self-efficacy scores do not at 12 months Two of the 157 usual care participants and 12 of the 156 yoga participants reported adverse events, mainly increased pain Note: Data were missing for the primary endpoint (yoga group, n=21; "normal care group", n = 18) and differential missing data (more in the yoga group) for secondary endpoints. Conclusion: Providing adults with chronic or recurrent low back pain with a 12-week yoga program resulted in greater improvement in back function than usual treatment.

title: Adolescents undergoing orthodontic treatment are not immune to poor diet and obesity: a call for dentists to get involved in prevention efforts
abstract: OBJECTIVES: While obesity is widespread in the US, differences exist. Orthodontic trials are believed to be more affluent than the general population and do not require assistance in developing or maintaining a healthy lifestyle. This paper assesses the need for intervention in the orthodontic population by examining the diet and weight status of an orthodontic patient specimen and describes a role for dentists in obesity prevention efforts. METHODS: 552 patients, aged 8-14 years, 54% female, 51% non-Hispanic White, 26% Hispanic, were recruited from orthodontic practices in Southern California to participate in a randomized controlled trial of physician health promotion. Height, weight, demographics and diet were recorded. Chi-square analyzes were used to test for differences at baseline by sex, age, race, and income. RESULTS: 13% of the sample was overweight and 9% obese. Men had a higher rate of obesity than women. Low-income youth had a higher rate than higher-income youth. Hispanic youth had a higher rate than non-Hispanic white youth. Non-compliance with national dietary guidelines was widespread and varied significantly across demographic groups. CONCLUSIONS: Within a sample not normally considered needy, nearly 25% were overweight or obese and the majority were not following dietary recommendations. While most patients could benefit from an intervention, male, Hispanic, and low-income groups needed the most support. Dentists, who see young people frequently and who are already discussing nutrition in the context of oral health, have the opportunity to make a contribution to the prevention of obesity.

title: systematic scoping review of the choice architecture movement: To understand when and why nudges work
abstract: In this article, we provide a general scoping review of the nudge movement realm by reviewing 422 choice architecture interventions in 156 empirical studies. We report the distribution of studies across countries, years, domains, subdomains of applicability, intervention types, and the moderators associated with each intervention category to review the current state of the nudge movement. In addition, we highlight certain features of the studies, as well as experimental and reporting practices, that may impede the accumulation of evidence in this area. Specifically, we found that 74% of the studies were primarily motivated to assess the effectiveness of the interventions in a given setting, while only 24% of the studies focused on exploring facilitators or underlying processes. We also found that only 7% of studies used power analysis, 2% used guidelines to improve reporting quality, no study was pre-registered in our database, and the intervention nomenclature used was incomplete and often overlapped categories. Building on our current observations and proposed solutions from other areas, we provide directly applicable recommendations for future research to support the collection of evidence about why and when nudges work.
